headline: Lithium Battery Ban? Check Again
text: If you have been reading reports of the Federal Aviation Adminstration ban on lithium batteries on airliners, don’t get too excited.

headline: New Year’s Day Bowl Matchups
text: This is simply the best day of the year for the college football fan. Intriguing matchups from 11 in the morning until 8 at night. Of course, you can’t sleep on the Fiesta Bowl. Will Hawaii be able to recreate what Boise State did last season? How will the Big Ten fare against tough non-conference opponents? Does Illinois have a shot against U.S.C. in the Rose Bowl? Can Missouri get over being slighted for a B.C.S. game and beat Arkansas in the Cotton Bowl? What kind of game will the Heisman Trophy winner Tim Tebow have against Michigan in the Capital One Bowl? What’s going on with Darren McFadden? The only way to get to the bottom of any of this is by sitting on your couch and watching a lot of football. What’s so hard about that? The rest of the games are prime-time affairs so this is the last full day of college football until next fall. Enjoy.Outback Bowl11 a.m., No. 18 Wisconsin (9-3) vs. No. 16 Tennessee (9-4), Tampa, Fla., ESPN

headline: Eight Years, And Back To The Start
text: If you fled Wall Street eight years ago — remember Y2K? — and came back today, you might conclude that nothing much happened while you were gone.

headline: Tackling Clutter to Improve Your Health
text: Being disorganized is frustrating. But it can also stand in the way of better health.

headline: World Juniors: U.S. and Sweden Run the Table in the First Round
text: Do you believe in omens?

headline: Mitt Romney's Recent Movement
text: For over a month, Mitt Romney has been well behind Mike Huckabee in Iowa. But that's changed in the last few days.

headline: A Change of Plans
text: MUSCATINE, Iowa – No one likes to cancel a big campaign rally in Iowa just three days before the state’s presidential caucuses, but Hillary Rodham Clinton scratched a rally in Waterloo this evening because of bad weather and headed back to Des Moines instead.

headline: Colt Brennan’s Sugar Bowl Q&A
text: NEW ORLEANS — Faithful readers of The Quad know that along with rewriting the N.C.A.A. record book during his three years at Hawaii, Colt Brennan has evolved into one of the more open and honest interviews in college sports. (Brennan has even found time to moonlight as a blogger.) His disarming honesty had the news media wide-eyed here this week. Brennan even told a group of reporters he wasn’t a role model by saying, “I’m a convicted felon.”

headline: Obama Pulls Ahead in Register Poll
text: DES MOINES — The highly anticipated final poll from The Des Moines Register is out and it has some surprising news: Senator Barack Obama appears to have widened his lead over his Democratic rivals, with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton coming in second and former Senator John Edwards a close third.

headline: New Year’s Eve in Ames With Obama
text: Updated AMES, Iowa – Senator Barack Obama was running late and the meatballs were running out – neither of which seemed to matter when word spread through the crowd at his New Year’s Eve party here that he was leading by 7 points in the final Des Moines Register poll before Thursday’s caucuses.

headline: Clinton Raises $100 Million in 2007
text: DES MOINES – Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign raised more than $100 million in total for 2007, her advisers said Monday night, in addition to $10 million that she transferred from her old Senate campaign account.

headline: Iowa Is Suddenly News Central
text: Talk about a media event.

headline: Winnowing the Debate Field
text: The debate stage, it seems, will be getting a little roomier. Invitations to participate are getting harder to come by in 2008.

headline: Despite One Failure, Growth Is Seen in Coachless Flights
text: Maxjet Airways, a pioneer as a discount all-business-class airline, failed Dec. 24. Is the concept that it helped invent two years ago fated to die as well?

headline: Short-Handed Florida St. Can’t Get Past Kentucky
text: NASHVILLE  Florida State Coach Bobby Bowden watched his team, down by two touchdowns, claw at Kentucky in the fourth quarter and he wondered where that spirit his players were showing had been hiding.

headline: No Gimmicks: Eat Less and Exercise More
text: A desire to turn over a new, more healthful leaf typically accompanies the start of a new year. My mail, for example, has been inundated with diet books, most of which offer yet another gimmick aimed ultimately at getting the gullible reader to eat less and exercise more.

headline: U.S. Clears Sale of a Stake in Nasdaq
text: Nasdaq Stock Market obtained clearance on Monday from the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States to sell a stake to Borse Dubai, paving the way for Nasdaq’s eventual acquisition of the OMX exchange in Stockholm.

headline: China: Baidu Shares Fall on Executive’s Death
text: Shares of Baidu.com, owner of China’s most popular Internet search site, fell after the death of its chief financial officer, Shawn Wang. Mr. Wang died in an accident on Thursday, the company said in a statement on Saturday. A group of senior managers will take on his duties until a successor is named. Under Mr. Wang, Baidu’s shares soared past $400 in the United States last month, a 15-fold gain from their initial price of $27. The company has expanded its market share in China, taking 61 percent of Web queries to Google’s 24 percent, according to Analysys International in Beijing. Baidu fell $9.07, to $389.80 in New York. Baidu is the only Chinese company in the Nasdaq 100 index, which consists of the 100 biggest nonfinancial companies by market value listed on the Nasdaq.

headline: Outdoor Game a Reminder of Roots, but Also a Peek at the Sport’s Future
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  In an odd tableau for hockey, or for a fashion show, the Buffalo Sabres emerged from the end-zone tunnel at Ralph Wilson Stadium on Monday walking in their skates on a rubber runway, wearing turtlenecks, eye black and every conceivable kind of winter headgear.

headline: Road to Nowhere
text: The most impressive thing about Mitt Romney is his clarity of mind. When he set out to pursue his party’s nomination, he studied the contours of the Republican coalition and molded himself to its forms.

headline: Stocks Slip, Ending Year of Turmoil
text: Stocks fell on Monday, ending a tumultuous year that battered financial firms but left other pockets of the market and the world with stunning gains.

headline: Canada: Buyout Challenged Over Racial Bias
text: The Royal Bank of Canada’s proposed $1.6 billion acquisition of Alabama National BanCorp was challenged by a group that claimed the Canadian bank engages in discriminatory lending. A financial advocacy group for poor consumers, Fair Finance Watch, said it asked the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., in a letter for hearings and all documents relating to the proposed buyout. The Royal Bank agreed on Sept. 6 to buy Alabama National for cash and stock. Fair Finance Watch claimed that in 2006 Royal Bank’s RBC Centura unit denied mortgage refinance applications in Charlotte, N.C., to blacks 4.4 times more frequently than whites. The group said in the Atlanta area, RBC Centura denied home improvement mortgage applications of blacks 4.2 times more frequently than whites. A bank spokeswoman, Judi Levita, said “the lending practices of RBC Centura satisfactorily comply with all applicable requirements.”

headline: Bloomberg in ’08? If So, Paper Chase Starts Soon
text: In Colorado, all you need is $500 and you’re in. In Texas, you must gather 74,000 signatures from registered voters within 75 days  and none of them can have voted in the last party primaries.

headline: Boy’s Brother, 16, Believes Bullet Was Meant for Him
text: The teenage brother of an 11-year-old Queens boy who was shot in the chest on Sunday night after he answered the front door of their home said he believed that the bullet had been intended for him.

headline: Michigan Will Miss Carr When He’s Gone
text: Happy New Year, Michigan football! Old school is only 60 game minutes from being out, one Lloyd Carr Retirement Classic away.

headline: Corzine to Tour State for Plan to Cut Debt With Toll Roads
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine is hitting the road to build public support for his much-anticipated plan to reduce New Jersey’s debt by refinancing the state’s toll roads.

headline: No Picky Eaters Among Successful Argentine Ants
text: The Argentine ant is a very successful invasive species, having conquered territories far from its native South America. Once introduced, inadvertently, by people, it marches across the landscape, displacing local ant species and making an agricultural pest of itself.

headline: The New Year’s Cocktail: Regret With a Dash of Bitters
text: The ideal New Year’s Eve party would come with a psychological voucher, redeemable the next day for a post-mortem session with friends. A chance to relish the night’s humiliations, take bets on who went home with whom, and nominate the guest most in need of therapy, present company included.

headline: Fund Frozen, Florida Towns Feel the Pinch
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On Nov. 28, Marcia L. Dedert, finance director of this rapidly growing city, called the administrators of Florida’s state-run investment pool to ask whether it was still safe to park her city’s money there. She was hearing talk of urgent withdrawals by others worried about the pool’s investments in debt related to subprime mortgages.

headline: Chasing a Shadowy Imp, García Lorca’s Muse
text: GRANADA, Spain  Federico García Lorca called it “el duende”  in Spanish, the elf  a dark, irrational muse that leads artists to tragic depths. This dangerous goblin, who delights in the “tiny weeds of death,” as the early-20th-century Spanish poet and dramatist said in a lecture in Havana, haunted the streets of García Lorca’s “Poet in New York” and the moonlit night of “Blood Wedding.” It refused to take pity on the barren wombs, the weeping guitars or the silver-eyed Gypsy women of other García Lorca works.

headline: Congressman Named to Fill Lott’s Senate Seat
text: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi appointed a seven-term congressman, Roger Wicker, to fill the seat of departing Senator Trent Lott on Monday, opting for a conservative Republican who was a major figure in the party’s 1994 takeover of the House of Representatives.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about Nintendo’s video game consoles misstated the capabilities of one of the devices. A statement about movie-playing should have referred to the PlayStation Portable or PSP, made by Sony, not to the hand-held Nintendo DS. (The DS does not play movies.) The article also misspelled the surname of the president and chief operating officer of Nintendo of America. He is Reggie Fils-Amie, not Fils-Aimee.

headline: In Reversal, Pakistan Welcomes Outside Help With  Inquiry on Bhutto
text: WASHINGTON  Pakistan’s ambassador to the United States said Monday that his government would welcome outside experts to help investigate the assassination of Benazir Bhutto, reversing Pakistan’s earlier rejection of international help.

headline: Designing Clinical Tests (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Could It Get Worse for the Knicks? Amazingly, Yes
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  New Year’s Eve is a natural time to reflect on the past and look forward to what lies ahead. So on the day the calendar turned to another year, it was time for the Knicks to ponder the mess they had created and perhaps wonder whether things might get even worse.

headline: What Should We Tax?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting Intensifies After Election in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenya sank deeper into trouble on Monday, with a curfew imposed in Kisumu, the country’s third-largest city, ethnic fighting intensifying and more than 100 people killed in election-related violence.

headline: The Claim: Drinking Makes You Warmer in Winter
text: THE FACTS

headline: Huckabee Shows Negative Spot After Pulling It From Television
text: DES MOINES  In a bizarre bit of political theater, Mike Huckabee told news outlets on Monday that he was not going to broadcast a negative commercial against Mitt Romney, his chief rival in the Republican presidential caucuses in Iowa. Then he showed that advertisement to the news media, which in reporting the announcement went on to give his anti-Romney message free publicity while he claimed the moral high ground.

headline: Gunshot Wounds Girl, 3
text: A 3-year-old girl was grazed by a bullet as she rode in the back of a car driven by her father in the Bronx last night, the police said. The girl, whose name was not released, was in stable condition at Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center with a shoulder wound, said Detective John Sweeney, a police spokesman.

headline: A Once-Easy Campaign Becomes a Test for Romney
text: DES MOINES  Just before Thanksgiving, Mitt Romney woke up to a disquieting new reality. After spending millions of dollars to ensure what was shaping up as a relatively easy victory in Iowa, his own polls found that Mike Huckabee had slipped ahead of him here, threatening his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination with a devastating defeat.

headline: On a Remote Path to Cures
text: NINACACA, Peru  High in the Peruvian Andes, a shaman rubs a fluffy white rabbit all over Chris Kilham’s body, murmuring in Quechua, the language of these barren plains. Then she slits the animal’s throat and lets the blood run into a tiny grave.

headline: When Societies Fail (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Merry Mayhem Movies?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still Reeling After All These Years
text: It promised to be a very good year. But then anything would be better than 1967, with its angry kids burning the flag, and the war raging, and American cities going up in flames one after another.

headline: Lawyer for Clemens Explains Strategy
text: In a lengthy conversation Friday with Rusty Hardin, Roger Clemens’s lawyer, I was particularly interested in his answers to two questions. To Hardin’s credit, he answered both candidly with no attempt to obfuscate the answers with typical lawyerly prattle.

headline: When It’s Time to Call the Cavalry
text: Business travelers looking to smooth their itineraries might take some advice from those highly influential executives who always seem to know whom to call when they lose their passport or want a discount on a private jet.

headline: Rebounds
text: Stephon Marbury again practiced with the team, but did not talk with reporters. The Knicks said he would not speak publicly until after he plays his next game. He has had three stints of bereavement leave. ... Jamal Crawford practiced but was limited to shooting and drills as he wore a protective glove. He is questionable for Wednesday.

headline: Israel: Olmert Curbs Settlements
text: Prime Minister Ehud Olmert has sent a letter to defense, housing and agriculture ministers, saying that his and the defense minister’s authorization would be required for any new building, planning or land expropriation for Jewish settlements in the West Bank. The instruction is intended to prevent surprises that could derail peace talks with the Palestinians. It does not apply to East Jerusalem, which Israel has annexed, or to West Bank projects already approved, a spokesman said.

headline: China to Shift $20 Billion as Capital for Policy Bank
text: The China Investment Corporation, the country’s $200 billion wealth fund, will inject $20 billion into China Development Bank, as the government nears the end of a decade-long reorganization of the banking industry.

headline: Can They Stay Out of Harm’s Way?
text: The morning was just starting to heat up when a biologist, Ricardo Costa, set out to look for jaguars on Fazenda San Francisco, a 30,000-acre cattle ranch, rice farm and wildlife reserve in the region of southwest Brazil known as the Pantanal.

headline: A Writer, a Muse, Their Laundry
text: Years ago the Central European writer Ludwig Bemelmans wrote a story about a poor man who went shopping for his own funeral, only to conclude, as the salesman ran down the catalog from grand to plain, that he couldn’t manage any of them. At the end, now dead, he walks to the cemetery, carrying a single candle, his coffin tucked under one arm.

headline: Hawaii Hoping to Be This Year’s Boise State
text: NEW ORLEANS  Boise State’s upset of Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl last season resonates as one of the most exciting and important games in college football history.

headline: Writers’ Return Gives CBS a Head Start
text: In the first competitive move in what may become an A-list booking-war blitz, David Letterman has landed the comedian and film star Robin Williams as the first guest when “The Late Show” returns to CBS television Wednesday night.

headline: Campaigns Feeling Effects of Iowa Poll
text: DES MOINES   Dennis Kucinich today urged his supporters in Iowa to back Senator Barack Obama as their second choice at the caucuses Thursday if his support is not strong enough to be viable in the 1,781 precincts across the state.

headline: Colorado Highway Closing Strands 2,000 Travelers
text: DENVER  Thousands of travelers were stranded in Colorado on Monday after gusting winds, blowing snow and the threat of avalanches forced the closing of a 70-mile stretch of mountain highway just west of Denver.

headline: A Punishing Sun, a Mystery Treatment, and Happy Faces
text: PEOPLE assume I live a pampered life, jet setting from spa to spa where beauty experts coddle me with the best new treatments. The irony is that I am in the business of pampering but rarely have the opportunity to indulge myself.

headline: For U.S.C. and Illinois, Upsets Aren’t Foreign
text: PASADENA, Calif.  What better way to ring out college football’s Year of the Upset than with the Rose Bowl pairing of Southern California and Illinois, teams whose involvement in 2007’s most stunning reversals helped give the year its identity?

headline: Oil in North Dakota Brings Job Boom and Burdens
text: STANLEY, N.D.  At dawn, people from faraway states huddle outside the Mountrail County courthouse here, the coldest ones leaving briefcases and books to secure their spots for the moment it opens.

headline: In a Car, a Lesson in Russian-European Trade
text: BERLIN  The Skoda, a Czech-made car that was long the butt of jokes across Eastern Europe, has become popular in Moscow, a sign that trade between Eastern Europe and its giant neighbor is at last beginning to pick up, economists say.

headline: Pests and Pestilence
text: Q. Are common cockroaches carriers of disease?

headline: On Field or on Bench, Beckham Delivered
text: For better or worse, soccer in 2007, at least in the United States, was the Year of Beckham. David Beckham joined the Los Angeles Galaxy of Major League Soccer in a deal valued at $250 million over five years. He played sparingly because of injuries, but was marketed brilliantly and ceaselessly.

headline: Recognizing Stripes, Not Faces, Software Tracks Whale Sharks
text: Facial recognition software holds great promise, but the jury is still out on how effective it is now. The software, which compares patterns from an electronic image of a face to a database of images, hasn’t proved particularly good at picking criminals out of a crowd, for instance.

headline: Edward Brennan, Who Led Sears at Its Peak, Dies at 73
text: Edward A. Brennan, who became chairman and chief executive of Sears, Roebuck & Company in the 1980s, when it was a financial and retail conglomerate, and then presided over its downsizing, died Thursday at his home in Burr Ridge, Ill. He was 73.

headline: Putting a Plague in Perspective
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Tax the Chewing Gum
text: To the Editor:

headline: Collision on Ohio Highway Kills 5 Members of a Family
text: CINCINNATI  A woman and four children traveling home to Maryland from Michigan were killed on an Ohio highway when their minivan was struck by a pickup truck being driven the wrong way by a man whose blood-alcohol level registered three times the legal limit, the authorities said Monday.

headline: In 2008, a 100 Percent Chance of Alarm
text: I’d like to wish you a happy New Year, but I’m afraid I have a different sort of prediction.

headline: Wielding a Cost-Cutting Ax, and Often, at NASA
text: WASHINGTON  In Washington, it almost seems radical  completing government projects at their original budgeted cost.

headline: Rediscovering a Heroine of Chicago Architecture
text: If women are underrepresented in the architecture profession in 2008, a century ago they were hardly represented at all.

headline: Gay Muslims Pack a Dance Floor of Their Own
text: BERLIN  Six men whirled faster and faster in the center of the nightclub, arms slung over one another’s shoulders, performing a traditional circle dance popular in Turkey and the Middle East. Nothing unusual given the German capital’s large Muslim population.

headline: Batteries Included in New Travel Restrictions
text: BATTERY RESTRICTIONS Beginning Tuesday, airline passengers cannot pack any loose lithium batteries in checked bags, though the batteries are permitted if contained within laptops, cellphones or other electronic devices, according to a new rule by the Transportation Department. The department said that loose lithium batteries can short-circuit and create a fire hazard in cargo holds. The new rule also limits to two the number of large-size spare lithium batteries that may be brought on in carry-on bags, but a department spokeswoman says that restriction applies mostly to professional and industrial-use batteries and does not affect most lithium batteries used in consumer electronics like laptops and cellphones.

headline: The Year That Was
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: The Death Penalty Is Simply Un-American
text: To the Editor:

headline: Darker 2008 for Detroit’s Automakers
text: DETROIT  The way that auto executives here have been talking, 2008 will be a bad year to sell cars and trucks in the United States. Every time one company predicts how the industry will fare, another seems to come up with an even more dismal number.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article on Sunday, about the bicentennial of the banning of slave importations into the United States, misstated the span of time since the end of World War II. The year 2005 was the 60th anniversary of that war’s end, not the 50th.

headline: Connecticut Is Criticized on Spending on Smoking
text: STAMFORD, Conn.  The refrain is a familiar one: Each year, the country’s biggest tobacco companies have provided a bonanza to the states under a $246 billion legal settlement struck nine years ago, and each year a chorus of health care experts, nonprofit groups and policy makers, and even a major tobacco company, question where all the money went.

headline: Fewer Killings in 2007, but Still Felt in City’s Streets
text: A man was shot in the face in front of his wife and children on a street near his home. A teenager in the Bronx died from stab wounds. And in a Brooklyn apartment, two men were found dead seated at a card table, still clutching their playing cards. Each had been shot in the head.

headline: Iraqi Revelers Embrace the New Year
text: BAGHDAD  Firecrackers and machine-gun fire echoed over the capital hours before midnight on Monday as partygoers put aside fears of suicide bombers and gunmen to bring in the new year.

headline: One of Ford’s Would-Be Assassins Is Paroled
text: LOS ANGELES  Sara Jane Moore, a 1970s radical who tried to assassinate President Gerald R. Ford more than 30 years ago, was released Monday on parole from a federal prison in Northern California.

headline: The Lure of Addictions and the Mysterious Transmigration of Red
text: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is rich with fine performers these days, both established and rising stars. On Sunday night at City Center, new casting in two of the season’s revivals suggested just how richly nuanced performances by these dancers can be.

headline: Ettore Sottsass, Designer, Is Dead at 90
text: Ettore Sottsass, an éminence grise of postmodern design who helped found the influential Memphis Group and was responsible for the familiar bright red plastic Olivetti typewriter, died Monday at his home in Milan. He was 90.

headline: Vonage and Nortel End Skirmish Over Patents
text: The Vonage Holdings Corporation, the Internet phone-service provider, said Monday that it had resolved a patent dispute with the Nortel Networks Corporation that had threatened to shut down some Vonage calling features.

headline: Big Cats in Captivity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Carrying On Mother’s Legacy by Caring for a Child
text: The end was near, and Elizabeth Jones seemed to know it. Ms. Jones had just been released from what had become her grim second home  the hospital  and she decided it was time for a barbecue.

headline: Nets Hire Vandeweghe as Special Assistant
text: The Nets announced Monday that they had hired Kiki Vandeweghe to become a special assistant to Rod Thorn, the team’s president, and Thorn sounded as if he would eventually like to see Vandeweghe become the Nets’ next general manager.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Disparities: Obesity and the Odds of a Kidney Transplant
text: Researchers may have found one more way in which fat people suffer discrimination. The higher the body mass index, they report, the less likely a person is to receive a kidney transplant.

headline: Elder Issues
text: To the Editor:

headline: Texas High School Coaches Keep Date With Clemens
text: Roger Clemens has received the benefit of the doubt from at least one group.

headline: NASA Offers Airline Safety Data
text: WASHINGTON  NASA on Monday released an intentionally scrambled, partly deleted version of the safety data it gathered from 24,000 interviews with airline pilots, making good on a promise to Congress to make public information that it said earlier this year would shake public confidence in the airlines and threaten their commercial interest.

headline: Arts, Briefly
text: Robert Frost Home Vandalized

headline: With the Jets’ Season Over, Pennington’s Status Is the Biggest Puzzle
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  By the time Chad Pennington entered the Jets’ locker room, teammates had already packed their belongings into trash bags. Only the news media remained. Reporters stood four deep around his locker.

headline: Children: Study Ties Too Little Sleep With Too Much Weight
text: A study of 7-year-olds has found that sleeping less than nine hours a night was associated with being overweight or obese, even after accounting for amounts of television watching and physical exercise.

headline: Transmeridian to Be Acquired
text: Transmeridian Exploration Inc., the Houston oil company with production in Kazakhstan, agreed on Monday to be acquired and taken private by a company formed by its chief executive, Lorrie T. Olivier.

headline: Outside Groups Spend Heavily and Visibly to Sway ’08 Races
text: DES MOINES  Spurred by a recent Supreme Court decision, independent political groups are using their financial muscle and organizational clout as never before to influence the presidential race, pumping money and troops into early nominating states on behalf of their favored candidates.

headline: A Crackdown on Recycling Spurs Some Vigilance
text: With a cold wind whipping across the back of his neck and against his uncovered, balding head, Jorge Soto stood outside of the apartment building where he works, carefully tearing through dozens of dark, sagging trash bags in search of soda cans, glass bottles, plastic containers and cardboard.

headline: The One Environmental Issue
text: The overriding environmental issue of these times is the warming of the planet. The Democratic hopefuls in the 2008 campaign are fully engaged, calling for large  if still unquantified  national sacrifices and for a transformation in the way the country produces and uses energy. The Republicans do not go much further than conceding that climate change could be a problem and, with the notable exception of John McCain, offer no comprehensive solutions.

headline: Exercise: Better Than the Couch, but Not Equal to the Court
text: The active video games played on the Nintendo Wii console may provide more exercise than its Microsoft rival the Xbox 360, a small British study has found, but they are not a substitute for the real thing.

headline: Year’s Notables
text: PLAYER The Italian Fabio Capello, 61, was only the second non-British coach to take over England’s national team. England has not won a major tournament since playing host to the World Cup ... in 1966. Capello has won league titles with A.C. Milan, Real Madrid, Roma and Juventus (and played for Italy in the 1974 World Cup). He faces the unenviable task of dealing with the ravenous English tabloids.

headline: Migration, Interrupted: Nature’s Rhythms at Risk
text: The world is etched with invisible paths, the routes taken each year by uncountable swarms of geese, elk and salmon, of dragonflies, zebras and leatherback turtles.

headline: Stock Exchanges Are in Talks to Buy Stake in Taiwan Board
text: The chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corporation, Wu Rong-I, said that the exchange, Asia’s seventh-biggest equities market, planned to sell a stake of as much as 25 percent of itself to overseas bourses.

headline: Nights of O’Neill
text: “The O’Neill Festival at Ten,” 10 nights of free readings, screenings and musical events featuring Zoe Caldwell, Charles Durning, Brian Murray, Natasha Richardson, Marian Seldes and KT Sullivan, will take place at the Provincetown Playhouse on Macdougal Street in Greenwich Village from Friday through Jan. 13. Presented by the Playwrights Theater and sponsored by the O’Neill at Yale project of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, the festival will include the films “Long Day’s Journey Into Night” with Katharine Hepburn and Jason Robards; “Ah, Wilderness!”; “The Hairy Ape”; and “Anna Christie,” with Greta Garbo. Live performances will begin on Jan. 11 with a program titled “O’Neill: Playwright and His Mother,” featuring excerpts from plays read by Ms. Caldwell and Ms. Seldes and a post-reading discussion conducted by the O’Neill scholar Barbara Gelb. The 10th anniversary presentation of the festival, begun with the intention of staging all 50 of O’Neill’s plays in order, will conclude with performances of the 18th and 19th: “In the Zone” and “Ile.” Information and reservations: eugeneoneill.net.

headline: The Super Lottery Is No Prize
text: The chance to bet your hard-earned money at unfavorable odds was once mostly limited to casinos in Nevada and Atlantic City. Today there are slot machines on Native American reservations from California to Connecticut and poker on casino boats on the Mississippi.

headline: After Way Too Many Toasts to 2008
text: To the Editor:

headline: Travelers to Pay $6 Million, Ending Inquiry on Brokers’ Fees
text: Travelers Companies, the commercial insurer, reached an agreement with attorneys general from several states to pay $6 million to resolve an investigation into fees it paid to brokers.

headline: Before Carr’s Finale, Career Is Remembered
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  After Michigan plays Florida in the Capital One Bowl on Tuesday, Lloyd Carr will retire after 13 years as head coach of the Wolverines and 40 seasons in his profession. To those who have known him, he has clearly left a mark.

headline: In 2007, Some Giants Went Smaller
text: Bigger is better, right?

headline: Singapore: Growth Is Slowing, but Is Still Strong
text: Singapore’s economy expanded 7.5 percent in 2007, at the lower end of the government’s forecast range, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. Growth eased from 7.9 percent in 2006 and is expected to slow further to as little as 4.5 percent next year. Mr. Lee, left, warned that the United States economy may enter a recession next year amid financial market turmoil. “A U.S. downturn would affect Asia too, but the impact on us would be offset somewhat by the strong momentum in the dynamic Asian economies,” Mr. Lee said. The full-year growth figure suggests that the $132 billion Southeast Asian economy may have contracted in the fourth quarter on an annualized basis, analysts said.

headline: Democrats Fill Day Campaigning Before Ringing In ’08
text: DES MOINES  The Democratic presidential candidates used the last day of 2007 to drive home their final messages to Iowa voters, while calibrating expectations on how they will perform in the caucuses three days later.

headline: Ultimate Report on Manning Is to Come
text: It has been nearly a year since the Giants put a double-team squeeze on quarterback Eli Manning. When the franchise decided to retain Tom Coughlin as coach last January, the team’s president and co-owner, John Mara, said a “major part of our discussions” centered on finding a way to get Manning to “play more consistently.”

headline: Still Playing and Winning at 35
text: Fabrice Santoro, the oldest singles player competing regularly on the ATP Tour, began what may be his last season Monday at the Qatar Open. Santoro, a 35-year-old Frenchman, beat Andreas Seppi of Italy, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2. Assuming that Santoro remains healthy before the Australian Open, which begins Jan. 14, he will break Andre Agassi’s record of playing in 61 Grand Slam events.

headline: Buffett May Not Testify in General Re Case
text: The billionaire Warren E. Buffett, who is on the prosecution witness list in the criminal trial of Ronald E. Ferguson, former chief executive of General Reinsurance Corporation, may not be called to testify, the government said in court filings Monday.

headline: Killing Dogs in Training of Doctors Is to End
text: By next month, all American medical schools will have abandoned a time-honored method of teaching cardiology: operating on dogs to examine their beating hearts, and disposing of them after the lesson.

headline: Chief Justice Again Calls for Pay Raise for Judges
text: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on Monday renewed his call for a pay increase for federal judges. A measure now moving through Congress with bipartisan support is “vital” and long overdue, the chief justice said in his annual report on the state of the federal judiciary.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about John McCain’s relationship with his children misstated, in some editions, the site of a graduation ceremony for Mr. McCain’s son Jimmy, which was attended by several siblings. Jimmy McCain graduated from Marine boot camp; there is no Marine Academy.

headline: Bush Signs Bill Allowing Sudan Divestment
text: CRAWFORD, Tex.  President Bush signed legislation on Monday allowing state and local governments to cut investment ties with companies doing business in Sudan, even as he expressed concerns that the bill could interfere with his right to set foreign policy.

headline: Gaza: 5 Dead in Hamas-Fatah Clashes
text: Five Palestinians were killed and about 30 were wounded in armed clashes between Fatah supporters and Hamas policemen, according to news agency reports. The clashes broke out in Khan Yunis and spread to other parts of Gaza as Fatah commemorated the 43rd anniversary of its founding. Hamas had banned any anniversary rallies. Medical officials said the dead included a 12-year-old boy and a Hamas policeman.

headline: A Slippery Slope Is the Secret Weapon of Some Pitcher Plants
text: A pitcher plant is a devilish organism, digesting ants and other insects that are attracted to the lip of its pitcher  a bowl-shaped leaf with liquid in the bottom  only to slip and fall into it.

headline: Tebow Faces Tough Defense, and Doubters
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Quarterback Tim Tebow of Florida won the Heisman Trophy this season, the only sophomore ever to do so. Shawn Crable, a senior Michigan linebacker, does not seem terribly impressed.

headline: Reaching Drug Users
text: To the Editor:

headline: Uncertain Prospects for Radiohead CD
text: LOS ANGELES  “In Rainbows,” the latest album from the British rock band Radiohead, has been readily available to music fans for almost three months, first as a digital download in an unconventional tip-jar offering in which fans decided for themselves what to pay for it, and then, like most pop music today, as digital files circulating on free, unlicensed file-swapping networks. One matter remains: Will anyone buy the CD?

headline: News Summary
text: INTERNATIONALA3-8

headline: Breast Cancer and Choices (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: 2 More Marine Trials in Killings of 17 Iraqis
text: A Marine infantryman accused of killing 17 Iraqi civilians during a combat maneuver in Haditha in late 2005 will be tried by court-martial on charges of voluntary manslaughter but will avoid more serious murder charges originally pressed against him, the Marine Corps announced Monday.

headline: The Korean Card Trick: Picking One
text: SEOUL, South Korea  Whenever Park Kyung Jin goes shopping, she methodically reviews which of her many credit cards to pull out. Not that Ms. Park, a 28-year-old office worker, is a shopaholic; rather, like millions of other South Koreans, she knows this is a way to trim costs.

headline: Aging: For Uninsured, Medicare Makes a Healthy Impact
text: Uninsured people 55 and older, particularly those with diabetes and cardiovascular disease, significantly reduce their risk of declining health after they enroll in Medicare at 65.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Quotation of the Day on Monday, taken from a front-page article about the selection of Benazir Bhutto’s son to head Pakistan’s largest political party, carried an incorrect attribution in some editions. It was Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of Ms. Bhutto, who was killed on Thursday, who said: “It’s not an easy chair to sit on. A, she leaves me. B, she ties me in this. To say the least, it’s overbearing.” The comment was not by Ms. Bhutto’s son, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari. (Go to Article)

headline: A Family Album Is One for the History Books
text: The old photo albums were such a familiar part of the Woods family’s Adirondack camp that no one paid them much notice. But when the 21-year-old James T. Stever took a closer look at the nearly 1,000 rare photographs that his great-great-grandfather Harry Fowler Woods had taken a century ago, he saw them with fresh eyes.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Monday about Marvin Wachman, the former president of Lincoln and Temple Universities, misstated the date of his death and misspelled the given name of his wife and the middle name of his daughter. Dr. Wachman died on Dec. 23, not Dec. 22. His wife is Adeline Wachman, not Adelina, and his daughter is Lynn Alison Wachman, not Lynn Allison. The obituary also omitted the cause of death. Dr. Wachman died of congestive heart failure, his wife said.

headline: This King, This Courtier, These Kevin Klines
text: The year just past was a notable one in the career  and surely also the life  of Kevin Kline. Notably busy, and at times disappointing. But ultimately, and happily, triumphant.

headline: A Tale of Political Dirty Tricks Makes the Case for Election Reform
text: In New Hampshire’s hotly contested 2002 Senate race, Democratic get-out-the-vote phone banks were jammed with incoming calls on Election Day. The Republican John Sununu, won re-election by under 20,000 votes, and Allen Raymond, a Republican Party operative, went to jail for his role in the jamming.

headline: A Complex Family History, Unfolding in Public
text: NAUDERO, Pakistan  On Sunday evening, as a three-day mourning period drew to a close, Asif Ali Zardari sat with his back to the tiled wall, under a sparkling pink chandelier, in a mansion filled with mementos of his wife’s legendary father, and described discovering how meticulously she had prepared for the aftermath of her death.

headline: Religious and Liberal
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Clutter Too Deep for Mere Bins and Shelves
text: After the holidays, many shoppers load up their carts with storage bins, shelving systems and color-coded containers, all in a resolute quest to get organized for the new year.

headline: Open Season on Coaches: Ravens Are First to Fire
text: The day after the N.F.L. regular season ends is when playoff teams turn their attention to their next opponents and everybody else starts trying to make next season’s playoffs. The Baltimore Ravens decided they would have a better chance of success without Brian Billick, who was fired Monday after the Ravens finished 5-11.

headline: Jury’s Deliberations May Be a Focal Point of Appeal
text: At the beginning of deliberations, the panel weighing the fate of a black man from Long Island charged with manslaughter turned to its lone black juror for guidance.

headline: Bhutto Spouse, Divisive Figure, Asserts Himself
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  It took only a few minutes before the real balance of power between Benazir Bhutto’s son and husband made itself clear at a news conference held Sunday. As the new chairman of the party, her son was asked the first question. Right afterward, his father cut him off.

headline: New Yorkers Crossing East River Lose Water Taxi for the Winter
text: The new year ushers out two of New York City’s ferry services and welcomes a new one.

headline: Explain a Medical Error? Sure. Apologize Too?
text: One morning not long ago, I got a call from the emergency room at my hospital. A young man  an intern, in fact, who had been on rounds that morning  had been admitted with chest pains. Could I come to evaluate him?

headline: Opponent Calls for Musharraf to Quit at Once
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  The most experienced opposition politician in Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, upped the ante in the coming confrontation with the governing party on Monday, calling for President Pervez Musharraf’s immediate resignation and the formation of a government of national consensus.

headline: What if Iowa Settles Nothing for Democrats?
text: DES MOINES  Iowa is packed with presidential candidates and hundreds of campaign aides, advisers and contributors. Twenty-five hundred representatives of news organizations have been granted credentials to cover the caucuses Thursday night, twice as many as in 2004. Rarely has a political event been so intensely anticipated as a decisive moment, at least on the Democratic side.

headline: Giving Disorganized Boys the Tools for Success
text: LOS ALTOS, Calif.  “Can we take a look at your backpack?”

headline: A Family That Beat Anthrax Picks Up the Pieces
text: DANBURY, Conn.  When Ase-AmenRa Kariamu and his wife, Althea, returned to their house here after nearly four months, it neither felt nor looked like home. The odor of chlorine was so powerful that they had to wear masks. A baby portrait of their eldest daughter in an upstairs hallway was a pale bronze, as if a relic from generations past.

headline: When Hospitals Kept Children From Parents
text: Early one morning, I visited my daughter’s 5-year-old friend Eddie, who was laid up in the hospital the night after an emergency appendectomy. Understandably, Eddie looked miserable. Just as understandably, so did his parents, who were still in their pajamas in a fold-out cot next to his bed.

headline: The Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Charges Fly Over Failure to Release 3 in Colombia
text: RIO de JANEIRO  A Venezuelan-led mission to release three hostages held by a Colombian rebel group seemed to be breaking down late Monday, with the Colombian government and the rebels accusing each other of sabotaging the operation.

headline: 3 Different Candidates, 3 Distinct Faces of the G.O.P.
text: DES MOINES  As Mitt Romney, Fred S. Thompson and Mike Huckabee hit points all over Iowa in a closing flurry before Thursday’s caucuses, it can seem as if they are campaigning in three entirely different worlds.

headline: New DVDs
text: HARRY LANGDON

headline: Sarkozy Visits Washington
text: International Herald Tribune reporter Katrin Bennhold on President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, who made his first official visit to Washington.

headline: New Year’s Day Links: The Other Shoes Begin to Drop
text: Day 1 of the N.F.L. postseason is usually one of cleaning house. But in that respect, Monday was a relatively slow day. Brian Billick was fired by the Baltimore Ravens after a 5-11 season that included a nine-game losing streak. Rick Maese of The Baltimore Sun said the move was bold but necessary. Len Pasquarelli of ESPN writes that Billick lost his offensive touch. Adam Schefter of the NFL Network suggests Rex Ryan, Baltimore’s defensive coordinator; Kirk Ferentz, University of Iowa head coach; and Mike Singletary, the 49ers’ assistant head coach, as possible replacements.

headline: Voices From 5th Avenue
text: A weak dollar draws shoppers across the Atlantic.

headline: Bowl Pick ‘Em (The Final Edition)
text: It has finally arrived. The stretch run of this unbelievable college football season is upon us as we enter the new year. New Year’s Day always brings a glut of college football games, and the B.C.S. games that follow over the next few days should be a good way to wrap up a crazy season. It also provides us with one last opportunity to prove how much, or how little, we know. So, as always, feel free to disagree and provide your own picks. As this season has taught us over and over again, you never know what’s going to happen.

headline: The Best Cleavers
text: Sharpen your chopping skills with a cleaver.

headline: Interview with John Edwards
text: The following is a transcript of an interview by Michael Gordon of The New York Times with John Edwards, conducted Sunday on the Edwards campaign bus as it drove between campaign stops in western Iowa. Some of the questions have been edited for brevity and clarity.

text: Images from "The Magic of America" and "Marion Mahony Griffin: Drawing the Form of Nature."

headline: Looking East
text: Images from "William Howard Taft and the 1905 Mission to Asia" at the Nippon Club.

headline: The Early Word: ’08 Really Starts in 2 More Days
text: Corks popped at midnight in Des Moines last night, “Auld Lang Syne” was sung, and those involved with Barack Obama’s campaign celebrated the results of the last major poll before the caucus that showed he had increased his lead in the state.

text: In a recent post I pointed out that up through the third quarter of 2007 rising exports had roughly offset the impact of the housing bust. Here’s the chart again. (By the way, all of the data come from the Bureau of Economic Analysis, which has fairly easy-to-use interactive data tables.)

text: Countdown: 7 days until the primary.

headline: New Year, Classic Campaign Routine
text: As the election year officially began, the presidential candidates were delivering their closing arguments in Iowa and New Hampshire, where losses could signal the end for some campaigns.

headline: Iowa Forecast: The Two-Day Icy Express
text: Caucus Countdown: Two days to go. For good luck, get yourself some black-eyed peas and collard greens today.

headline: World Junior Championship, LIVE on This Blog
text: Stuck at work in the United States and unable to watch the World Junior tournament? Didn’t feel like paying the extra money to follow the knockout-round games on an obscure premium cable channel? Eager to see what a live minute-by-minute description of a hockey game would look like?

headline: Are There Any Good Weather Omens?
text: On New Year’s Day, let us contemplate signs of future weather.

headline: For the Moment | Loden Dager
text: This week’s guest bloggers are Loden Dager, a men’s wear collective based in New York City that launched in the Fall of 2006. Its members, pictured, are: Melissa Vail, Matthew Sandager, Oliver Helden, Paul Marlow, and Alex Galan. (For more on Galan you can check out The Insider profile published earlier on this blog.) This week Loden Dager writes from the road as they journey to Atlanta in search of inspiration.

headline: Court TV, 1991-2007, In Photos

headline: New Year’s Day Kickoff: A Beefy Rose Bowl
text: Happy New Year! We hope that you enjoy the long day of college football, which features several interesting matchups that could produce some great games.

headline: Paul Raises $19.5 Million
text: Updated For most of the candidates, the fourth quarter was more about stumping than fund-raising. Not so for Representative Ron Paul of Texas, who has achieved that Howard Dean-esque feat of turning fervent netroots support into cold, hard cash. The libertarian-leaning Republican raked in $19.5 million over the last three months, which is likely to be more than any other G.O.P. candidate’s haul. (As the campaign points out in its release this morning, the figure is over $9 million more than any Republican raised in the third quarter.)

headline: A Network for ‘Actuality’ Shows
text: Court TV has always served up gritty stuff, like courtroom dramas and crime and justice shows. The cable channel’s new name, truTV, is designed to reflect that, according to Marc Juris, the network’s executive vice president and general manager.

headline: On the Road: Of Eggs and Frogs
text: ALLISON, Iowa – Sometimes it seems Iowa voters have been reduced to mere table ornaments in a massive media chow-down.

headline: McCain on Experience
text: Updated CONCORD, N.H. — Senator John McCain, who has long touted his own experience on matters of national security and foreign policy as top credentials, is now taking the fight directly to Mitt Romney on the topic.

headline: Taking Inventory | Holiday Gifts
text: In the days leading up to Christmas, The Moment published  holiday wish lists of several T Magazine staffers. Now that the big day has come and gone, we’re curious to know what loot they actually received. Here’s an update from the senior designer Elizabeth Spiridakis, who was hoping for a vintage Ray Gun magazine, a Miu Miu dress and wooden dice by Geoff McFetridge. She writes:

headline: Wooo PIG Sooie!
text: Standing in a trailer of wood shavings at the Cotton Bowl, Arkansas mascot Tusk II was in hog heaven this morning as fans took photos of him eating white grapes.

headline: Off Balance Sheet Woes
text: Zion’s Bancorpororation is taking more losses from an off balance sheet investment vehicle. This is the second time in two weeks that Zions has done that.

headline: On the Road: A View From the Bus
text: IOWA FALLS, Iowa – Any reporter who spends time on a press bus rolling down the byways of Iowa will tell a willing listener why the experience, in a word, stinks: long hours on narrow bus seats, cold dinners eaten out of clamshells over a laptop with a dying battery, a different and unremarkable motel every night. (We found seven different room keys in the bottom of our purse this morning.)

headline: But Seriously Folks
text: CLIVE, Iowa—Mitt Romney has added a new favorite word, freighted with meaning in the context of his back and forth with rival Mike Huckabee, to his political lexicon today: serious.

headline: Kucinich Tells Supporters to Caucus for Obama
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa – Representative Dennis Kucinich urged his Iowa followers today to select Senator Barack Obama as their second choice at the caucuses on Thursday if his support is not strong enough to be viable in the 1,781 precincts across the state.

headline: Karachi After Bhutto
text: Pakistanis made fitful attempts to return to normal life in Karachi, the hometown of Benazir Bhutto, after her assassination last week touched off an outbreak of violence.

headline: Make ’Em Laugh
text: AMES, Iowa – Call it post-New Year’s fun or pre-caucus jitters, but Hillary Rodham Clinton’s sense of humor – which her friends often recommend when trying to “humanize” her – was clearly on display today.

headline: World Club Top 10: Salavat Stumble
text: Salavat Yulaev Ufa, the top team in Russia and, until this week, the World Club Top 10, did not exactly cover itself in glory over the holiday break. The Bashkir club lost twice to a team of European-based Canadians at the Spengler Cup tournament in Davos, Switzerland, including a defeat in the championship game. Even though both losses were by a single goal, Salavat’s performance can only be counted as an embarrassment to what had been considered the strongest side on the continent.

headline: The Snow Bowl
text: The Winter Classic just ended with a Sidney Crosby shootout goal. The game’s more thrilling moments involved stops in play when the ice doctors patted and sprayed problematic patches of ice. Would it hold out? As the snow fell more densely, stick handling involved more flakes than puck.

headline: Blogtalk: Debates and Elections
text: Ron Paul supporters, already infamous for their avid online presence, are absolutely enraged that their candidate is being left out of the Fox News G.O.P. candidate debate on Sunday, and there’s a chance Mr. Paul could be left out of Saturday’s ABC forum, too.

headline: Huckabee and the Intelligence Report on Iran
text: Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas Governor, is again making misleading statements about how long he was unaware of a National Intelligence Estimate finding that Iran was not pursuing nuclear weapons.

headline: Crisis in Kenya
text: The crisis over the disputed elections in Kenya worsened.

headline: More on the Register Poll
text: DES MOINES — The Des Moines Register poll, which showed Senator Barack Obama pulling away from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former Senator John Edwards, had some interesting numbers below the top line. (To refresh your memory: Mr. Obama had 32 percent, Mrs. Clinton 25 percent and Mr. Edwards 24 percent.)

headline: Spawning Something Fishy
text: In June 2006, at the invitation of The Times, I spent a month writing a daily online column on matters evolutionary. I called it The Wild Side.

headline: Greetings From the Superdome
text: NEW ORLEANS — After a day of watching bowl games, it’s nice to get settled in the press box here at the Superdome. Players are milling around on the field during pregame warm ups. The Georgia fans just roared in approval as some of their players ran onto the field.

headline: Working on the High Line
text: A defunct railway on the far West Side of Manhattan is destined to become a park in the sky.

headline: Huckabee Thanks Bloggers
text: DES MOINES _ Mike Huckabee held a little event here on Tuesday to thank the roughly 700 bloggers who, he said, were responsible for keeping his campaign alive. Because he had no money and initially got very little media attention, he said, he could not have kept going without their dedication.

headline: Topic: Marbella, Spain
text: An “orgy of exaggeration” is misrepresenting the market in Marbella and the Costa del Sol, estate agent Christopher Clover argues.

headline: Murder Charges Against Tankleff Are Dropped
text: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y.  The Suffolk County District Attorney announced on Wednesday that he was dropping the charges against Martin H. Tankleff for the 1988 murders of his parents and will ask Governor Eliot Spitzer to appoint a special prosecutor to re-investigate the case.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Dec. 26 about Turkish airstrikes on Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq misidentified the area on the Iraqi border where the bombing took place. The area is known as Jamju; it is not Hawler, which is the name of a town and a province whose governor spoke about the numbers of refugees and civilian deaths. (Hawler is the Kurdish word for Erbil.) (Go to Article)

headline: Arsenal Stays In First Place
text: Eduardo da Silva scored his fifth goal in three games to help Arsenal to a 2-0 victory over West Ham that kept the Gunners atop the Premier League. With second-place Manchester United beating Birmingham, 1-0, Eduardo and Emmanuel Adebayor scored to keep Arsenal 2 points ahead. Chelsea stayed in third place with a 2-1 victory at Fulham, while Everton, Portsmouth and Aston Villa also won.

headline: In Illinois, a Ban Sends Smokers Into the Cold
text: CHICAGO  A strict ban on smoking went into effect in Illinois on Tuesday, sending clusters of bundled smokers here out into frigid temperatures and the thick pile of snow that also arrived with the new year.

headline: Mob Sets Kenya Church on Fire, Killing Dozens
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Dozens of people seeking refuge in a church in Kenya were burned to death by a mob on Tuesday in an explosion of ethnic violence that is threatening to engulf this country, which until last week was one of the most stable in Africa.

headline: Nearly Blind, and Coping With Shame
text: How do children learn that their parents are ashamed of them?

headline: The Perfect Snowstorm: The Winter Classic Scores
text: The National Hockey League needed a game like Tuesday’s outdoor Winter Classic. In its fight for the attention of sports fans, it requires events that set it apart. It needed a tight game  this one was won in a shootout by the Penguins star Sidney Crosby  and an entertaining broadcast by NBC’s group of exhilarated announcers. It needed to build a regulation-size rink inside Ralph Wilson Stadium in Orchard Park, N.Y., for a game that started in daylight and ended at dusk.

headline: Caucuses Empower Only Some Iowans
text: DES MOINES  Jason Huffman has lived in Iowa his whole life. Lately he has been watching presidential debates on the Internet, discussing what he sees with friends and relatives. But when fellow Iowans choose among presidential candidates on Thursday night, he will not be able to vote, because he is serving with the National Guard in western Afghanistan.

headline: In Iowa, Edwards Faces His Past and His Future
text: AMES, Iowa  Ever since his surprise second-place finish in the Iowa caucuses in 2004, John Edwards has staked his future in presidential politics on this state. Since 2005, he has spent more than 100 days in Iowa. He has fiercely courted rural voters in particular, visiting all 99 counties  twice.

headline: U.S. Isn’t Ready to Accept Pakistan’s Initial Findings
text: WASHINGTON  United States intelligence analysts are not convinced by the evidence offered so far by Pakistani authorities that a militant linked to Al Qaeda was responsible for Benazir Bhutto’s assassination, American officials said Tuesday.

headline: Oil Hits $100 a Barrel for the First Time
text: HOUSTON  Oil prices briefly reached $100 a barrel on Wednesday, a long-awaited milestone in an era of rapidly escalating energy demand and tightening supplies.

headline: A Wild Card for the Playoffs: Heinz Field
text: PITTSBURGH  The good news for Jacksonville Jaguars running back Fred Taylor: The forecast for Saturday night’s wild-card game against the Steelers calls for a low of 38 degrees and only a 20 percent chance of rain or snow.

headline: The Economy and the New Year
text: As 2008 begins, house prices are still skidding, bank losses are still mounting, oil is again flirting with $100 a barrel and consumers are buying less as prices rise. To many, the wheels appear to be coming off the economy. To others, including President Bush and his aides, the economy is fundamentally sound and resilient.

headline: Customers, Not Brokers, Profited in an Odd 2007
text: The brokers’ customers did reasonably well. The brokers did not.
