headline: Justice Dept. Sets Criminal Inquiry Into C.I.A. Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey said Wednesday that the Justice Department had elevated its inquiry into the destruction of Central Intelligence Agency interrogation videotapes into a formal criminal investigation to be headed by an outside prosecutor.

headline: For Celebrity Magazine, Pregnancy Is a Bonus
text: OK!, the celebrity magazine, could not possibly have purchased all the attention it enjoyed in late December after it got the scoop that Jamie Lynn Spears, the younger and until then less sensational sister of the troubled pop queen Britney Spears, was three months pregnant.

headline: Louis Wolfson, Central to the Fall of a Justice, Is Dead at 95
text: Louis E. Wolfson, a self-made industrialist and financier whose legal troubles were central to the resignation of a Supreme Court justice and who later achieved a cliffhanging sweep of the 1978 Triple Crown as a thoroughbred owner, died Sunday at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 95.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: New Coordinator for Louisville
text: Ron English accepted an offer from Louisville Coach Steve Kragthorpe to be his defensive coordinator. It is the same job English had at Michigan, where the incoming coach, Rich Rodriguez, fired all of Lloyd Carr’s assistants. English agreed to a two-year contract with Louisville, which fired the defensive coordinator Mike Cassity after a disappointing 6-6 season. The Cardinals finished 84th in the country in total defense and 93rd in scoring defense.

headline: Candidates Unleash Final Efforts in Iowa
text: DES MOINES  The presidential candidates began fanning out across Iowa early Wednesday morning  with one, John Edwards, still in the midst of a nonstop 36-hour bus tour  on the final day before the presidential caucuses, courting undecided voters and connecting with supporters to make sure they turn out to caucus Thursday evening.

headline: 2007 Was Unpredictable, but Let’s Brave 2008 Anyway
text: Like baseball or the weather, the economy can be a difficult thing to predict.

headline: Huckabee and Consultant Form an Uneasy Alliance
text: About three weeks ago, Mike Huckabee received an unexpected e-mail message from the veteran political consultant and television commentator Ed Rollins offering help with his unexpectedly surging dark-horse Republican primary campaign. Fifteen minutes later, Mr. Huckabee had signed him up, Mr. Rollins recently recalled.

headline: New Rule May Factor Into Bowl Ineligibility
text: The rites of college football’s bowl games are familiar, with debates about national title contenders, a carousel of game sponsors and a smattering of upsets. But another hallmark of the season  incomplete rosters  has drawn considerable attention in recent weeks.

headline: Chicago Murder Tied to Caste and Marriage
text: A Chicago-area man set a fire that killed his pregnant daughter, grandson and son-in-law, because he was unhappy with his daughter’s marriage, prosecutors said.

headline: Still Skinny, but Now They Can Cook
text: GRAPEFRUIT, cabbage soup and maple syrup have had their moments. Now a new weight-loss ingredient is all the rage: Rage.

headline: Let’s Just Say, It Was Crowded
text: How many people rang in the new year at Times Square on Monday night? The simple answer is: One heck of a lot. The complicated answer is: Perhaps only the Police Department knows for sure, and it won’t tell you.

headline: Doubts Raised on Technology Sales to China
text: WASHINGTON  Six months ago, the Bush administration quietly eased some restrictions on the export of sensitive technologies to China. The new approach was intended to help American companies increase sales of high-tech equipment to China despite tight curbs on sharing technology that might have military applications.

headline: Mall Owner in Australia Seeks Buyers for Company
text: The Centro Properties Group, facing a Feb. 15 deadline to refinance 3.9 billion Australian dollars ($3.4 billion) of debt, said Wednesday it is seeking buyers for the company.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,891 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: St. Paul Stops a Waterfront Developer From Crossing the Mississippi
text: ST. PAUL  As manufacturing declined across the country, cities from Baltimore to San Francisco have reclaimed waterfronts for recreation and development. But here along the Mississippi River, an unusual situation has emerged.

headline: Pakistan’s Days of Rage Leave Cloud of Uncertainty
text: KARACHI, Pakistan  The highway that leads from Benazir Bhutto’s ancestral village to this, her hometown, is one long road of ruin. Here and there along a stretch of 200 miles lie twisted hulks of tractor-trailers, their contents spilling out on the highway, casualties of the riots that broke out after Ms. Bhutto’s assassination last Thursday.

headline: New H.I.V. Cases Drop but Rise in Young Gay Men
text: For years he had numbed his pain and fear with drugs, alcohol and anonymous sex. But in a flash of clarity one day, when the crystal meth was wearing off, Javier Arriola dragged himself to a clinic to get an H.I.V. test, years after he stopped using condoms.

headline: Excerpts From the Edwards Interview
text: Following are excerpts from an interview by Michael R. Gordon of The New York Times with John Edwards, conducted Sunday on the Edwards campaign bus as it drove between campaign stops in western Iowa. Some of the questions have been edited for brevity and clarity. The full transcript can be found at nytimes.com/politics.

headline: Can We Help Fend Off Alzheimer’s?
text: To the Editor:

headline: The A Train
text: Wednesday, Jan. 2, 8.15 a.m.

headline: Of Two Minds on Polar Bears
text: Two agencies in the Department of the Interior are nearing significant yet contradictory decisions that will affect the fate of one of America’s iconic animal species, the polar bear.

headline: Chávez’s Promised Hostage Release Fizzles, His Second Major Setback in Weeks
text: RIO de JANEIRO  Last week, Venezuela’s president, Hugo Chávez, seemed on the verge of one of his biggest triumphs to date. Now, amid renewed acrimony with the Colombian leader, Álvaro Uribe, he is staring at his second major political defeat in just over a month.

headline: Gang Blamed as 10 Are Killed in Attacks at Nigerian Oil Port
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Coordinated assaults on two police stations, a hotel and a restaurant early Tuesday killed at least 10 people, the authorities said, shattering a brief New Year’s Day calm in the violent and oil-rich Niger Delta region of Nigeria.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Dec. 26 about Turkish airstrikes on Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq misidentified the area on the Iraqi border where the bombing took place. The area is known as Jamju; it is not Hawler, which is the name of a town and a province whose governor spoke about the numbers of refugees and civilian deaths. (Hawler is the Kurdish word for Erbil.)

headline: Hungry for a Market, but Where?
text: THE day was wet and so cold that the savoy cabbages nearly froze and the fat on Mario Batali’s porchetta quickly congealed into a solid mass. But the few thousand intrepid souls who made their way to the southern tip of Manhattan on that dark Sunday afternoon in December did not seem to mind.

headline: A McCain Commercial Turns Romney’s Words Against Him
text: Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign introduced a new Web video on Tuesday that portrays his Republican rival Mitt Romney as dismissive of the need for foreign policy experience in a dangerous world, where war and terrorism continue to pose threats to American security.

headline: Gaza Is Tense as It Tallies Casualties
text: GAZA  Gaza remained tense on Tuesday after a night of clashes between Hamas and Fatah gunmen.

headline: Old MacDonald Had a Quail
text: SHORT of hayrides from the curb to the coat check, there’s not a whole lot in the way of farmhouse allusions that the new restaurant Irving Mill doesn’t try.

headline: In His Own Words
text: Mike Huckabee, a former Republican governor of Arkansas, speaking Tuesday at an Elks Lodge in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.

headline: Guitar x Four = Flexible Sound to Fill a Hall
text: Andrés Segovia once described the guitar as an orchestra seen through a reversed telescope, a metaphor suggesting that his instrument’s comparatively small voice and subtle range of timbres offset the chordal and contrapuntal freedom it offers. In a New Year’s Eve concert at the 92nd Street Y, the Los Angeles Guitar Quartet took Segovia’s observation to heart and tested a proposition of its own: that an ensemble of four guitars magnifies both sides of the equation, yielding far greater independence of movement and a louder sound as well.

headline: Let the Oven Do All the Work
text: IF you buy a big pork shoulder and take your time, as you should, the classic Puerto Rican pork roast called pernil can take you nearly all day. The last time I roasted a large one it was in the oven for seven hours.

headline: Calendar
text: Of Guiltless Pleasures

headline: Designer’s Rainbow Brightens Iranian Women’s Look
text: TEHRAN  For many of the chic and well-to-do here in the capital of Iran, a country where women are required by law to conceal the shapes of their bodies, Simin Ghodstinat’s designs provide a sort of middle way. Her clothes are elegant, luxurious and expensive  all while staying well within the religious authorities’ strictly enforced boundaries of propriety.

headline: Taking the Temperature of Dinner
text: THE most important step in mastering heat is to get into the habit of using a thermometer to keep track of temperature  that of the food itself, and of the surface or space in which it is cooked or stored.

headline: 30 Dead in Baghdad’s Worst Attack in Months
text: BAGHDAD  Thirty people were killed Tuesday when a suicide bomber strode into a gathering of mourners at a home in eastern Baghdad and detonated an explosives-packed vest, the Interior Ministry said. It was the most brazen and deadly attack in the capital in months.

headline: Police Kill Maryland Inmate After He Escapes
text: A 45-year-old prisoner who escaped from a hospital in Maryland, where he overpowered a guard, stole a pair of guns and carjacked a motorist, was fatally shot by the police on Wednesday afternoon. The inmate, identified as Kelvin Poke, 45, was killed by police officers when they caught up with him in a cemetery on Suitland Road, outside of Washington. Henry Tippett, a spokesman for the Prince George’s County police, said Mr. Poke was pronounced dead at Prince George’s Hospital Center after an exchange of gunfire with police that took place around 3 p.m. He said that officers who were pursuing the escaped prisoner spotted a white Ford Explorer with two flat tires and followed the vehicle into the cemetery.

headline: Passing Is Fancy; Palmer Is Unhappy
text: The rise of the passing game has been an N.F.L. trend for years, but it reached new heights this season with seven quarterbacks topping 4,000 yards. That is as many as the previous two seasons combined.

headline: Losing an Edge, Japanese Envy India’s Schools
text: MITAKA, Japan  Japan is suffering a crisis of confidence these days about its ability to compete with its emerging Asian rivals, China and India. But even in this fad-obsessed nation, one result was never expected: a growing craze for Indian education.

headline: Hotel’s Prime Audience: Sitting in a Meeting, Dreaming of the Greens
text: THE Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts chain, which caters squarely to business travelers, has signed up a celebrity spokesman whose specialty is near and dear to the guests’ hearts: golf.

headline: Guided by Beckett From the Grave
text: The director Deborah Warner had seen her share of boring productions of Samuel Beckett’s “Happy Days,” and during bleak winter days at the end of 2006, she became worried that she was making one herself. Like Winnie, the chattering protagonist of this 1961 drama, who is gradually being buried alive, Ms. Warner, along with her longtime collaborator, the actress Fiona Shaw, felt stuck.

headline: In Winds of Winter, Midair Park Takes Shape
text: The sleek, computer-driven architectural previews of New York’s first midair park, the High Line, depict pedestrians navigating a public promenade that is on track to be celebrated next fall. Like space-age schematics, they offer a futuristic refuge: a pristine ribbon of green providing exquisite views of Manhattan.

headline: Fire Marshal’s Shooting Death on Staten Island Leaves Family Torn and Puzzled
text: Christmas lights lined Tarring Street on Staten Island, but one spot on the block stayed dark as a hole. It was as if the same pistol that killed its owner, Douglas Mercereau, took the life of his house, too, its time of death suggested by the “Happy Thanksgiving” sign in the front window.

headline: Burglary Suspect Dies
text: A burglary suspect in the Bronx died on Tuesday before officers were able to bring him to a precinct station and file charges, the police said.

headline: Giants’ Reese Deserves Credit, Too
text: During his 13-year run with the Giants, Jerry Reese has watched and listened.

headline: Knicks’ Starting Lineup Remains in Limbo
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Knicks fans may see their splintered team in full Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden. Then again, maybe they won’t. From game to game, the makeup of the team has become anybody’s guess.

headline: F.B.I. Brings a Fresh Set of Eyes to a ’71 Plane Hijacking Mystery
text: CHICAGO  It is considered one of the great unsolved mysteries of American crime: how a seemingly quiet man in his mid-40s hijacked an airliner somewhere between Seattle and Reno in November 1971, then parachuted in his loafers and trench coat, making off with $200,000 in cash.

headline: A Little Help in the Big City
text: New York can be a very difficult place to live on a fixed income. In recent years, 80-year-old Jack Silberman watched helplessly as his everyday expenses inched up above what he could afford.

headline: Rock Is Back. Give Him a Cookie.
text: “That’s right, New Year’s Eve,” Chris Rock said. “I’m a little nervous. I haven’t done this in a while.” These were just about the first words he spoke all night, and this was definitely the last time he sounded hesitant.

headline: A Film Year Full of Escapism, Flat in Attendance
text: LOS ANGELES  Despite a modest increase in 2007 box office receipts, moviedom is trudging into January with a droop in its shoulders.

headline: U.S. Diplomat and Driver Are Shot Dead in Sudan
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  An American diplomat in Sudan and his driver were shot to death early Tuesday as they were coming home from a New Year’s Eve party in Khartoum, the capital.

headline: Missouri Wins With Ease, but Says It Deserved Better
text: DALLAS  When Missouri tailback Tony Temple scored his last touchdown, which set Cotton Bowl records for rushing yards and rushing touchdowns, two teammates carried him off the field.

headline: What’s Your Consumption Factor?
text: Los Angeles

headline: A Second Girl Is Hit by Stray Gunfire
text: For the second time in less than 12 hours, a young girl in New York City was shot by stray gunfire. And like the girl in the first case, the second victim escaped with a nonfatal wound and was expected to make a full recovery, a hospital administrator said.

headline: India’s Exports Surge Before an Expected Slowdown
text: India’s exports of manufactured goods, including gems and fuel products, rose in November as companies completed orders and hedged to cope with the rupee’s appreciation.

headline: Saying Race Is No Barrier, Obama Still Courts Blacks
text: WATERLOO, Iowa  At a recent focus group of black voters in South Carolina, strategists for Senator Barack Obama presented a videotape of a speech he delivered at the Jefferson Jackson Dinner in Iowa, featuring images of an overwhelmingly white audience applauding earnestly.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $4,158,143

headline: Pakistan Vote Delayed to February
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  Parliamentary elections scheduled for Jan. 8 have been postponed by the government until February, the secretary of the Election Commission said Tuesday.

headline: A More Modest Crowd in Albany, With Plenty of Advice for Spitzer
text: ALBANY  Last year, they came by the thousands, most of them Democrats eager to shake the hand of their bold, triumphant, newly elected leader. This year, they came in the hundreds, and like caring relatives seemed intent on offering Eliot Spitzer their advice as well as their adulation.

headline: In the Land of Many Ifs
text: For months, the American economy has been assailed by a wave of troubling news, from plunging housing prices to the soaring cost of oil, provoking gloomy talk of a possible recession. Yet so far the economy has found a way to shrug it all off and keep growing.

headline: Bickering and Negative Ads in Countdown to Caucuses
text: DES MOINES  On a bitterly cold New Year’s Day two days before the Iowa caucuses, the leading Democratic presidential candidates drew some of their largest crowds of this Iowa campaign season, while the top Republican contenders continued to ratchet up their attacks on one other.

headline: U.S.C. Cuts the Profile of a Title Contender
text: PASADENA, Calif.  When it was over at the Rose Bowl, when John David Booty had finished orchestrating a 49-17 victory for Southern California as thorough as it was majestic, he climbed a ladder in the end zone, grabbed the sword from the university’s mascot and conducted the Trojans’ band in a rousing version of “Conquest,” the throbbing U.S.C. victory march.

headline: Customers, Not Brokers, Profited in an Odd 2007
text: The brokers’ customers did reasonably well. The brokers did not.

headline: In London, a Compact but Elegant Flat
text: LONDON

headline: The Invisible Ingredient in Every Kitchen
text: OF all the ingredients in the kitchen, the most common is also the most mysterious.

headline: Stocks Drop on Manufacturing Report
text: Wall Street’s hopes for a bullish start to the year faded on Wednesday after oil prices surged to the symbolic $100 mark and manufacturing activity unexpectedly shrank in December, reviving fears of an impending recession.

headline: The Wolverines Ride Emotion, and Henne’s Arm, to Victory
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Before Michigan played Florida in the Capital One Bowl in the final game of Coach Lloyd Carr’s career Tuesday, he addressed his team with tears in his eyes and emotion in his voice, his players said.

headline: For Start-Up, It’s a Tweak Here, an Experiment There
text: This is the third in a series of three articles about start-ups and their founders’ hopes for the year ahead. The first appeared Dec. 13 and the second on Dec. 19. This column will return to all three after six months, and again after one year, to compare their achievements with their original goals.

headline: Georgia Runs Over Hawaii in Sugar Bowl, 41-10
text: NEW ORLEANS  On Georgia’s first possession of the Sugar Bowl, Bulldogs tailback Knowshon Moreno danced 17 yards, untouched, into the end zone. He celebrated by blowing a kiss to Georgia fans.

headline: North Korea Calls for End to ‘Hostile’ U.S. Policies
text: SEOUL, South Korea  An editorial in North Korea’s three major state-run newspapers urged the United States on Tuesday to abandon its “hostile” policies and proposed closer economic ties with South Korea, which will soon inaugurate a new president.

headline: Candidates Play to Audiences on the Road in Iowa
text: DES MOINES  As Mitt Romney, Fred D. Thompson and Mike Huckabee hit points all over Iowa in a closing flurry before Thursday’s caucuses, it can seem as if they are campaigning in three entirely different worlds.

headline: Eased Rules on Tech Sales to China Questioned
text: WASHINGTON  Six months ago, the Bush administration quietly eased some restrictions on the export of politically delicate technologies to China. The new approach was intended to help American companies increase sales of high-tech equipment to China despite tight curbs on sharing technology that might have military applications.

headline: Big Makeovers for Office Buildings Outside of Midtown
text: Extreme makeovers provide many of the plotlines for reality television, from “Queer Eye for the Straight Guy” to “The Biggest Loser.” The same could also be said for some recent Manhattan real estate deals, where developers have bought office buildings with the intention of pouring millions of dollars into fixing them up.

headline: Man Fatally Shot by Police in Brooklyn
text: Police officers shot and killed an armed man in Brooklyn on Tuesday night during a narcotics investigation, the police said.

headline: Iowa Is Uncertain as Out-of-State Students Return
text: DES MOINES  One of the $64,000-questions about Thursday’s Iowa caucuses is how much students from out of state will influence the outcome.

headline: Got a Night Job? Then No Caucus for You
text: DES MOINES  Jason Huffman has lived in Iowa his whole life. Lately he has been watching presidential debates on the Internet, discussing what he sees with friends and relatives. But when fellow Iowans choose among presidential candidates on Thursday night, he will not be able to vote, because he is serving with the National Guard in western Afghanistan.

headline: Stonewalled by the C.I.A.
text: Washington

headline: Bridging Cultures, and Taking Arabic to Iowa
text: KALONA, Iowa

headline: Edwards Calls for Quick End to Iraq Training
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  John Edwards says that if elected president he would withdraw the American troops who are training the Iraqi army and police as part of a broader plan to remove virtually all American forces within 10 months.

headline: Drowning in Special-Interest Money
text: Special-interest money in politics is said to be like water  blocking its flow in one direction only channels it to another. In this year’s presidential election, the flow is turning into a flood.

headline: Edwards on the Economy
text: John Edwards is running a notably more populist campaign than either Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama. In several ways, Mr. Edwards is more open to using the government to try to help the middle class - and less trusting of the free market.

headline: A Divide as Wolves Rebound in a Changing West
text: CHEYENNE, Wyo.  Sheltered for many years by federal species protection law, the gray wolves of the West are about to step out onto the high wire of life in the real world, when their status as endangered animals formally comes to an end early this year.

headline: An Intellectual Insider, Forever on the Outside
text: “I like this guy because he is excited,” Jack Kerouac wrote in his diary after an encounter with Alfred Kazin on the streets of New York in the late 1940s. “He stumbles about, chatting away, almost getting run over by trucks, eager, stuttering, proud, a little piqued at this world, which makes him cast furtive looks out of the corner of his eye.”

headline: Democrats: More Than Health Care
text: Perhaps you have heard that Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama have come up with different health care plans. Hers would require every American to own health insurance. His would not.

headline: Winter Wonderland for Crosby and N.H.L.
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  With more than 71,000 fans filling a football stadium that at times resembled a snow globe, the N.H.L. had a storybook setting for its outdoor game Tuesday between the Buffalo Sabres and the Pittsburgh Penguins. And with the winning goal coming off the stick of the Penguins star Sidney Crosby in a shootout, the league could not have scripted a more satisfying ending.

headline: Saudis Confirm Detention of Blogger
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  An outspoken Saudi blogger is being held for “purposes of interrogation,” the Saudi Interior Ministry confirmed Tuesday.

headline: Out of the Barn and Into the Snifter
text: Roquefort, France

headline: Swiss Army, Here’s Your Knife
text: AT a cooking lesson with Su-Mei Yu, a Thai chef and cookbook author, I was handed a large lightweight Chinese cleaver and told I was to do all my slicing, dicing and shredding with it.

headline: Making the Scallops Happy
text: A PAN roast at the Oyster Bar, like cheesecake at Junior’s and frozen hot chocolate at Serendipity 3, is one of those dishes New Yorkers love to champion, even if we haven’t tasted it in decades.

headline: Deal to Buy Mortgage Company Collapses
text: In another sign that troubles within the mortgage industry will continue into 2008, one of the largest originators of residential home loans announced Tuesday that it is scrapping a planned $1.8 billion sale, because banks had failed to agree to finance the transaction.

headline: John Lennon’s Death Revisited Through the Words of His Killer
text: “I was nobody until I killed the biggest somebody on earth.”

headline: In Their Own Words
text: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, speaking Tuesday at the Raccoon River Brewing Company in Des Moines, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.

headline: Leonard B. Meyer, Scholar of Music’s Meaning, Is Dead at 89
text: Leonard B. Meyer, a pioneering musicologist whose 1956 book, “Emotion and Meaning in Music,” remains one of the most significant scholarly works in the field of music cognition, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: Viewers of All Sizes Decide Who Walks the Catwalk
text: It doesn’t count as a global crisis, but the ranks of the world’s supermodels are depleted. Kate Moss is aging, and Gisele Bündchen draws more attention for whom she’s dating than whom she’s wearing. Today’s Twiggy-in-the-making, Agyness Deyn, is a quirky platinum pixie, more adorable than memorable. Luckily, models are a renewable resource, and Bravo’s new show, “Make Me a Supermodel,” is asking novices to fill the void.

headline: If Elected: The Candidates on Foreign Policy
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton foresees a “remaining military as well as political mission” in Iraq, and says that if elected president, she would keep a reduced military force there to fight Al Qaeda, deter Iranian aggression, protect the Kurds and possibly support the Iraqi military.

headline: Council Plans Session on Deutsche Bank Fire
text: The City Council plans an extensive hearing next week on the blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building near ground zero that led to the deaths of two firefighters.

headline: Tonight’s Menu: Chestnuts and Guilty Pleasures
text: No one, except the musicians, had to work hard at Avery Fisher Hall on New Year’s Eve. Profundity, nobility and cosmic suffering had the evening off. Joshua Bell played his violin; Lorin Maazel conducted his New York Philharmonic. A big crowd dotted with the dressed-up and the overdressed sat back and sang along inside their heads with old favorites.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Weekly Wrap: Palmer’s Numbers Are Up, but His Mood Is Down
text: Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic contributed to this notebook.

headline: The Fans Are Robbed
text: New Orleans — Obviously, this Sugar Bowl has turned into a gigantic dud.

headline: Undercover
text: Contemporary artist Jorge Macchi was born in Buenos Aires in 1963. His work has been featured in solo exhibitions at the University of Essex in England, Recoleta Cultural Center in Buenos Aires and the Museum of Contemporary Art of Antwerp. His latest exhibition, The Anatomy of Melancholy, is on view at the Blanton Museum of Art at The University of Texas at Austin through March 16, 2008.

headline: Devotion, Thy Name Is Noone
text: The Patriots honored their fan of the year before Christmas, and while these awards are by their nature subjective, it would be hard to argue with this year’s choice.

headline: Feds Share Coupons to Help TV Transition
text: “Millions of $40 government coupons become available Tuesday to help low-tech television owners buy special converter boxes for older TVs that might not work after the Feb. 18, 2009 switch to digital broadcasting,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Gawker Media Gets Strung Out on Sci-Fi
text: Online blogomerate Gawker Media is best known for outsider snark-fests like New York’s Gawker and Washington D.C.’s Wonkette . But the company minors in geekier fare like gadget site Gizmodo, game blog Kotaku and Lifehacker, a productivity site. To that part of its portfolio, Nick Denton’s blog empire is now adding IO9, a site whose motto proclaims that it is “strung out on science fiction.”

headline: A Ramble in Olmsted Parks
text: Images from the coming exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Teacher Burnout? Blame the Parents
text: The stress of teaching is often blamed on rowdy students and unrealistic expectations from school officials. But new research suggests that parents may be the real culprit in teacher burnout.

headline: $450,000 Homes
text: Properties on the market in Vermont, Montana and California.

headline: Food Stuff
text: A Block of Hot Chocolate? Dunk, Melt, Stir, Sip

headline: He’s Back!
text: It takes only five seconds, but this clip, which Laugh Lines used for Halloween, helped a humble but scary-looking creature reach critical critter mass in 2007. It made numerous top “viral video” lists, including here, here and here:

headline: Take My Wife …
text: One of Chris Rock’s best lines at his New Year’s Eve show at Madison Square Garden came while discussing Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign. He mocked the notion that marriage confers professional expertise. “I’ve been with my wife for 10 years now,” he said. “If she got onstage right now, y’all wouldn’t laugh at all.” Read more …

headline: Australian Mall Owner Seeks Buyers
text: The Centro Properties Group, facing a mid-February deadline to refinance 3.9 billion Australian dollars ($3.4 billion) of debt, said Wednesday it is seeking buyers for the company.

headline: Legg Mason Puts Up $1.1 Billion to Bail Out Funds
text: Legg Mason said Friday that it would put up $1.1 billion in cash and guarantees to bail out two of its money market funds that were coming under pressure from their asset-backed commercial paper investments, in the latest of such bailouts triggered by the credit crisis.

headline: Drake Suspends Withdrawals From $3 Billion Fund
text: Drake Management suspended most redemptions from its largest hedge fund after losing 23.7 percent through November, Bloomberg News reported, citing a letter sent to investors of the New York-based firm.

headline: Kerkorian Takes Stake in Delta Petroleum
text: A month after he was spurned by Tesoro, billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian has found another energy company more friendly to his acquisitive advances.

headline: Vietnamese Brewer to Tap Public Markets
text: The Saigon Beer Alcohol Beverage Corporation, Vietnam’s largest brewer, plans to raise at least $557 million by selling 20 percent of its shares in an initial public offering late this month.

headline: MF Global Fined Over Hedge Fund Losses
text: The Commodities Futures Trading Commission formally fined MF Global, a New York-listed futures broker spun off this year by the Man Group, for allegedly helping to conceal losses at a client’s hedge fund, bringing the company’s total legal bill for the case to $77 million.

headline: MC Hammer to Launch Online Video Site
text: MC Hammer hasn’t topped the music charts since the early 1990s, but the former rap star says he has another hit in him — only this time around he’ll produce it as a Silicon Valley entrepreneur.

headline: SpiralFrog Downloads $2 Million
text: A digital music start-up, SpiralFrog, said Friday that it had raised $2 million from private investors, bringing the total investment to date to $13 million as it expands its offerings of free, downloadable tracks.

headline: Former H&R Block Chief Gets $2.5 Million Severance
text: H&R Block disclosed that its former chairman and chief executive, Mark A. Ernst, will receive a $2.55 million cash severance payment. Block, which provides tax, accounting and other financial services, said in a filing Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission that Mr. Ernst, who stepped down last month, also resigned from the company’s board Friday.

headline: OMX Board Backs Bid from Borse Dubai
text: OMX, the Nordic and Baltic exchange owner, said Wednesday that its board had unanimously recommended a takeover bid by Borse Dubai, which had teamed up with Nasdaq to purchase the company.

headline: Fortissimo Snaps Up Magic Software Unit
text: Magic Software Enterprises, a maker of tools for business software development and integration, said it sold its Advanced Answers on Demand subsidiary to a private equity firm, Fortissimo Capital, for $17 million. The agreement calls for payment in two installments with the last coming by the end of January.

headline: India’s Reliance Energy Prepares $3 Billion Offering
text: Reliance Power of India is set to launch an initial public offering to raise up to $2.97 billion in the country’s biggest I.P.O., Reuters reported. The company will issue 260 million shares at an indicated price band of 405 to 450 rupees ($10.30 to $11.40) each, the report said.

headline: Santander Said to Have Held Talks for British Lender
text: Grupo Santander, the owner of Abbey National, was recently in talks to buy another mortgage lender in Britain but negotiations stumbled on price and came to nothing, according to The Financial Times.

headline: 3i to Buy a British Laser Treatment Firm
text: 3i, a publicly traded private equity firm in Britain, has agreed to buy Ultralase, a British laser eye treatment firm, for 174.5 million pounds ($347.8 million) from Corporacion Dermoestetica of Spain.

headline: AT&T Said to Consider Stake in Telekom Malaysia
text: AT&T wants to buy an unspecified stake in the mobile arm of state-controlled phone firm Telekom Malaysia , a Malaysian newspaper reported on Wednesday.

headline: Ghosts of Subprime Past May Continue to Haunt
text: The expression “out with the old and in with the new” may not mean much to investment banks in this new year, as many industry observers are predicting that Wall Street’s subprime-related pain will extend well into 2008.

headline: Warren Buffett Opens His Wallet
text: Warren E. Buffett is apparently in no mood to quit.

headline: Hedge Fund Raises Stake in Northern Rock
text: RAB Capital, the second largest shareholder of Northern Rock, the troubled British lender, has bought shares in the company for the second time in two days, raising its stake to 7.5 percent ahead of a January shareholder meeting, according to a filing Friday.

headline: Customers, Not Brokers, Profited in an Odd 2007
text: The brokers’ customers did reasonably well. The brokers did not.

headline: Buffett May Not Testify in General Re Case
text: The billionaire Warren E. Buffett, who is on the prosecution witness list in the criminal trial of Ronald E. Ferguson, former chief executive of General Reinsurance Corporation, may not be called to testify, the government said in court filings Monday.

headline: Deal for Mortgage Lender PHH Collapses
text: In another sign that troubles within the mortgage industry will continue into 2008, one of the largest originators of residential home loans announced Tuesday that it is scrapping a planned $1.8 billion sale, because banks had failed to agree to finance the transaction.

headline: Hedge Funds Said to Beat Market in Tough Year
text: The hedge fund industry remains on course to beat stock market returns in 2007, The Financial Times said, citing data from Chicago-based Hedge Fund Research.

headline: Buyout Shops’ Exit From Freedom Is Delayed
text: The sale of minority stakes held by the Blackstone Group and Providence Equity Partners in Freedom Communications, a newspaper group, has been halted because banks have balked at financing the deal because of the credit crisis and a poor outlook for print media.

headline: Merrill Said to Be in Fresh Talks for Funding
text: Merrill Lynch, which a little more than a week ago announced that it would sell a $6.2 billion stake to the Singapore government and a mutual fund manager, is reportedly in fresh talks with Chinese and Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds to slice off another piece of itself in return for much-needed cash.

headline: Citi and Merrill Top Underwriting League Tables
text: Ousting their chief executives and multi-billion dollar write-offs weren’t the only thing that Citigroup and Merrill Lynch had in common in 2007. The two banks were the world’s top underwriters of stocks and bonds, measured by volume and reported fees, despite being at the epicenter of the global credit crisis.

headline: ‘Nyah Nyah Nyah Nyah Nyah Nyah’
text: The late-night talk shows are back starting tonight, but your jokes aren’t going away (keep sending them via the comment link below). Fresh reader comedy:

headline: The Early Word: The Independent Turnout Factor
text: As we cross the 24-hour countdown to the Iowa caucuses later today, one of the biggest unknowns is just how significant voter turnout will be among independents and first-time caucus-goers.

headline: Why H.I.V. Cases Are Rising Among Young Gay Men
text: Sarah Kershaw, who covers public health in New York City, examines the reasons by this phenomenon: The number of new H.I.V. infections in men under 30 who have sex with men has increased sharply in the city in the last five years, particularly among blacks and Hispanics, even as AIDS deaths and overall H.I.V. infection rates in the city have steadily declined.

headline: Winners and Losers in a Year of Deal-Making
text: For Wall Street’s deal-makers, 2007 was like two years in one: First it boomed, then the bottom fell out. In our annual “closing dinner” column, DealBook toasted — and roasted — some of the year’s biggest names, including Rupert Murdoch, Lloyd Blankfein, Nelson Peltz and more.

headline: An Unlikely Celebrity Sex Tape: Malaysian Minister
text: If Malaysia’s Minister of Health, Chua Soi Lek, were a lucky man, he might have fended off recent accusations of infidelity the way many others have: by working the he-said/she-said (or he-said/he-said) angle for everything it is worth and hoping that the next news cycle forgets you.

headline: FINAL at the WJC: Canada 4-2 Finland
text: Review the play by play of the World Junior Championship quarterfinal match, described as it happened at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic. Jeff Z. Klein described the action.

headline: Iowa Forecast: Caucus Eve
text: Caucus Countdown: One day. One More Day.

headline: Promises, Promises
text: Promises, especially those made by presidential candidates, are made to be broken: “In U.S. history, I can think of just two presidents (there may be others) who were remarkably good at” fulfilling their campaign pledges, writes Joseph Ellis, the Mount Holyoke historian, on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times.

headline: N.H. Forecast: Are We There Yet?
text: Countdown: 6 days until the primary.

headline: Clinton’s 2-Minute Appeal
text: In her final pitch to Iowans, Hillary Rodham Clinton — rarely breaking eye contact — implores voters to “put on your coats and call up a friend and help me change America.”

headline: U.S. Loses Ground in Law-Firm League Tables
text: Coming off of its fourth year atop the merger advisory league tables, you might think Sullivan & Cromwell would be in a celebratory mood. But as 2007 came to a close, H. Rodgin Cohen, the law firm’s chairman, acknowledged the honor with a decidedly cautious tone.

headline: Jozy Altidore: New Challenges in a New Year
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog each week. In his latest post, Altidore discusses his goals in 2008, his call-up to the United States national team training camp and more.

headline: Racing Along With the Edwards ‘Marathon’
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS – It was not yet midnight on John Edwards’s all-night “Marathon for the Middle Class” tour when the unthinkable metaphor happened: the bus broke down.

headline: Who’s The Man? In Istanbul, it’s Tarkan
text: Tarkan’s new CD cover look. Visitors to Istanbul are likely to hear his songs in clubs and cafes.

headline: Letterman and Leno Return Tonight
text: Update: 1:14 p.m.: When Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien of NBC return to their late-night television homes tonight, their guests and audience members will face picket lines of striking writers.

headline: Paying the Cost of Climate Control
text: Peter Barnes, a founder of Working Assets, the fund making “socially responsible” investments, has long studied various bills and proposals for cutting emissions of carbon dioxide to limit global warming. He sees fatal flaws in every one. So he has come up with a new formula that he says uniquely addresses the most inconvenient truth about climate policy: It will be expensive.

headline: African Cup Creates Holes for Teams in Europe
text: There is one topic dominating international soccer headlines during the first few days of the new year: player personnel. The international transfer window is open until Jan. 31 and teams may buy and sell players — permanently or on loan — to compensate for injuries, fortify rosters for Champions League campaigns and make up for the loss of key players during the African Cup of Nations.

headline: Wednesday Kickoff: A Fitting End for Carr
text: New Year’s Day was a special day for Lloyd Carr. Aside from it being his final game as Michigan’s coach and the Wolverines playing their hearts out in a thrilling victory against Florida, Carr received almost universal plaudits from around the college football world. It must have been a strange feeling for a man who has been routinely second-guessed throughout his career. Bob Wojnowski of the Detroit News brings us inside the Michigan lockerroom after the game and tells us how Carr addressed his team. Not to be outdone, Larry Lage of The Associated Press gives us an inside look at Carr’s final days with the team, from meetings to meals. ESPN’s Eric Adelson writes that Michigan fans were reminded of the type of offense they are giving up now that Carr is being replaced by Rich Rodriguez.

headline: How to Boil a Frog
text: In talking about oil and geopolitics, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has been slipping in this homespun-sounding analogy as of late.

headline: Elections Delayed in Pakistan
text: Pakistan's main opposition parties denounced the decision to postpone parliamentary elections but said they would abide by the ruling.

headline: Two-Buck Huck
text: The rap against Mike Huckabee, the Baptist preacher and ex-Arkansas governor now doing for the Republican Party establishment what three-alarm chili does for an afternoon nap, is that he’s too inexperienced to be president, too naïve — a rube straight out of Dogpatch.

headline: Analyst Dampens Time Warner Deal Speculation
text: Wednesday was not just the first trading day of the year. It was also the first working day for Jeffrey Bewkes in his role as the new chief executive of media octopus Time Warner.

headline: Betti O
text: At a recent appearance, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton had an opening act.

headline: Survival of the Chicest | the Shoehorn
text: I always travel with a shoehorn.

headline: Huckabee Will Cross Picket Line to Appear on Leno
text: Former Governor Mike Huckabee of Arkansas today professed his support for the striking television writers union just a few hours before he was expected to board a plane for a taping of the Jay Leno show where he will face a vocal picket line of striking writers.

headline: Manhattan Gets a New District Attorney, but Only on TV
text: The 18th season of NBC’s “Law & Order” opens tonight with the actor Sam Waterston in a new role, that of Manhattan district attorney. Mr. Waterston’s character will be the fourth Manhattan district attorney in the history of the series, which started in 1990 (not counting a pilot episode shot in 1988). But during that time, there has been only one real Manhattan district attorney: Robert M. Morgenthau, elected in 1974.

headline: Venture Investors Leap Through I.P.O. Window
text: Giving money to start-ups is easy. Getting it back, with profits: That’s the tough part of being a venture capitalist.

headline: CNN Unplugged (Or at Least, Unfiltered)
text: On New Year’s Day, CNN selected some unusual programming: unedited speeches by the presidential candidates.

headline: Promising Debut for ‘Biggest Loser’
text: NBC’s latest edition of “The Biggest Loser” — this time, featuring dieting couples who will be judged by their combined weight loss — got off to a solid start in the ratings on Tuesday, as 10.4 million viewers tuned in from 8 p.m. to 10 p.m. for the show’s debut, according to Nielsen’s overnight estimates. Among adults 18 to 49, the episode fared better than any of the four previous premieres of the series, boosting NBC to a second-place finish for the night.

headline: New Questions for a New Year
text: While I was on vacation, three of my Silicon Valley colleagues posted about the questions they meant to ask in 2007 and didn’t. Now that I’m back, I figured I’d add my list of what I am most curious about for 2008.

headline: The Other Horse Race
text: The Bagger just came back from vacation and heard there was some other contest besides the Oscars going on. Always in search of that elusive Oscar angle, he discovered that Michael Moore, whose “Sicko” is likely to be nominated for best doc, is switching horses. Anne Thompson of Variety details a pitch from the reflexively liberal director on behalf of the one Democrat he feels can make a difference — whose name is not Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Clinton’s Run-Up to the Caucus
text: ABOARD THE CLINTON PRESS BUS – The politico who runs Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign in Iowa, Teresa Vilmain, gave reporters a rundown Wednesday morning of her team’s run-up to the presidential caucuses Thursday night.

headline: Matchup for the Fiesta Bowl
text: Fiesta Bowl8 P.M., No. 9 West Virginia (10-2) vs. No. 4 Oklahoma (11-2), Glendale, Ariz., FOX

headline: Leno, O’Brien Will Face Pickets
text: When Jay Leno and Conan O’Brien of NBC return to their late-night television homes tonight, their guests and audience members will face picket lines of striking writers.

headline: Debatable Democracy
text: On my flight back to Des Moines today, I read an interesting piece by my colleagues Michael Falcone and Sarah Wheaton about the upcoming debates in New Hampshire. It seems that both Fox and ABC have taken it upon themselves to winnow the field of candidates by excluding those who don’t seem viable at this point. Fox, for instance, is shutting out Ron Paul, despite his having reached fourth place in some recent New Hampshire polls and his having spent a truckload of money on ads in the state. (I swear, you can’t drive three miles in New Hampshire without hearing Ron Paul on the radio; he’s more overplayed than Fergie, albeit easier to listen to.) ABC has decided that if you don’t finish in the top four in Iowa, and you don’t reach five percent in New Hampshire or national polls, then you’re just cluttering up the stage and should watch at home like everyone else.

headline: Think You Know Your Body? Here’s a Test
text: Talking to my sister the other day about an ache in her side, I dragged out an anatomy book to try to figure out exactly what body parts were in the vicinity of her pain. We never figured it out and the pain went away, but it did make me realize I needed a better anatomy book.

headline: A Slowing Economy?
text: Today’s economic statistics indicate that the fourth quarter GDP figure is likely to be respectable, as were the last two quarters. Those figures have made the economic naysayers — myself included — look a little foolish, and that trend seems set to continue.

headline: Video: The Divine Ms. O
text: IOWA CITY, Iowa — Life on the campaign trail invariably involves a lot of waiting. Waiting for the candidate to arrive and waiting for the event to begin. Usually with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, a very familiar soundtrack of KT Tunstall and Celine Dion fills the time.

headline: Clinton on the Bus
text: ABOARD THE CLINTON PRESS BUS – Hillary Rodham Clinton just hopped on board the bus carrying the reporters who cover her campaign, and dispensed hot coffee, bagels, and good wishes to those who had been following her since she entered the presidential race in mid-January 2007.

headline: FINAL at the WJC: Russia 4, Czech 1
text: Review the play by play of the World Junior Championship quarterfinal match, described as it happened at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic. Lew Serviss, watching the tube at the Slap Shot bureau in Tucson, Ariz., described the action.

headline: Is Washington Hung Up on 3Com Deal?
text: Government-run funds from Asia and the Mideast have been scooping up billion-dollar stakes in Wall Street firms — with hardly a peep from politicians. But it is a relatively small, private investment in 3Com, the telecommunications equipment company, that seems to be striking a nerve in Washington.

headline: For the Moment | Loden Dager Shoots Models, Scores Award
text: This week’s guest bloggers are Loden Dager, a men’s wear collective based in New York City that launched in the Fall of 2006. Its members, pictured, are: Melissa Vail, Matthew Sandager, Oliver Helden, Paul Marlow, and Alex Galan. This week Loden Dager writes from the road as they journey South in search of inspiration. Today the group reveals something to celebrate: it has won the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award for new talent. (Read yesterday’s blog entry written by Loden Dager and a profile of Alex Galan here.)

headline: Giuliani Calls for Troop Surge in Afghanistan
text: WOLFEBORO, N.H. – Rudolph W. Giuliani did something highly unusual here Wednesday: he unveiled a new policy proposal in a speech, something he has not done in months of recent campaigning.

headline: The Grim Facts About Lethal Injection
text: Supreme Court arguments used to be secretive things. The Internet has changed that. Important cases now often have their own Websites. They offer a wealth of information, much of it for lawyers, but a lot for non-lawyers as well.

headline: The Final Stretch in Iowa
text: The presidential candidates fanned out across the state on the final day before the presidential caucuses.

headline: The Great Plane Robbery and Other Sordid Tales
text: When flight attendants get together for drinks, inevitably the conversation turns skyward. We share details about the deranged man who sprinted up the aisle of an Airbus, slapping passengers’ heads along the way (true story). We gossip about the shameless couple that had sex in a main-cabin seat (I saw them with my own eyes), the freaked-out-flier who tried to open the emergency exit at 15,000 feet (I grabbed him with my own hands), the hapless pilot who stepped into a dark unlocked lavatory and got his foot caught in a screaming woman’s panties. (The captain looked me straight in the eye and recounted his embarrassing experience.)

headline: Pakistan: A View From the D.J. Booth
text: Munizeh Sanai, host of "The Rush Hour" in Karachi, Pakistan, discusses the country's unrest.

headline: Tell Us About Your Commute
text: Every day during January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, with additional details and reader comments here on City Room. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Taking Race Out of the Race
text: As I noted earlier this week, some of Barack Obama’s comments have been inciting fury among labor leaders and Democrats online, especially now that’s he’s increasingly taking aim at John Edwards, whose class-warrior message resonates with the party’s hyper-partisans. The latest sniping on the blogs centered Mr. Obama’s suggestion that Democrats needed to nominate someone whom half the country wouldn’t immediately reject, which, according to Mr. Obama, is what they did in 2000 and again in 2004. This comment wasn’t significantly different from the electability argument that most of the Democrats have made at one time or another, but Mr. Obama’s specific reference to Al Gore and John Kerry was enough to renew dubious allegations that Mr. Obama was, once again, sounding more like a Republican than a Democrat.

headline: Local Gyms Outpace the National Chains
text: If your New Year’s resolution includes going back to the gym, you may be happier at a local club than a national chain, according to a new survey by Consumer Reports.

headline: A Roundhouse Kick for Huckabee
text: Mitt Romney’s latest Web ad, probably too goofy for TV, uses Chuck Norris’s endorsement of Mike Huckabee against the former Arkansas governor.

headline: Cabs’ Flower Power Heads to the Big Easy From the Big Apple
text: As of this week, the city’s flower taxi art project is officially over. The colorful decals were supposed to be removed from yellow cabs by the new year, though word is that there are some die-hard holdouts.

headline: 5 O’Clock News Back On WNBC
text: WNBC has decided there is a reason to be live at five, after all.

headline: French Kiss | Welcome, Marion Cotillard
text: A few minutes ago we hung some new wallpaper on the home page of T Online. You may recognize the actress Marion Cotillard from her appearance on the cover of T’s Fashion & Beauty Winter 2007. She also appears in the film “La Vie en Rose” playing Edith Piaf, the French singer. We’re hoping you’ll be tempted to read Lynn Hirschberg’s profile of Cotillard, or, if you’re more of a pictures person, click the “images only” tab and you’ll get a slide show of the Raymond Meier photo shoot of Cotillard. (We won’t tell Lynn if that’s what you choose.) And don’t miss the chance to take a few seconds to watch our exclusive “Screen Test” video interview with the Oscar-worthy actress.

headline: Former S.C. Governor Endorses Obama
text: CORALVILLE, Iowa – Jim Hodges, a former governor of South Carolina who supported Wesley Clark in the 2004 primaries, announced this afternoon that he will endorse Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Vilsack Says Clinton Has ‘Succeeded’ in Iowa
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa – After Hillary Rodham Clinton’s speech here just now, I caught up with her best-known supporter in Iowa, former Gov. Tom Vilsack, a co-chairman of her national campaign.

headline: Learning Architecture
text: Students at Cooper Union in the East Village are getting a chance to study construction firsthand.

headline: Teenage Smoking Rate Drops to 8.5 Percent
text: The prevalence of smoking among New York City teenagers has continued to fall, continuing a trend that began more than a decade ago, according to figures released by the city government today.

text: What we’re reading elsewhere…

text: New questions on the killing of Benazir Bhutto seem to arise every day, and today is no exception. If the sunroof-latch theory advanced and later retracted by the Pakistani interior ministry didn’t drop your jaw, this bit of news should:

text: “I don’t like it when people say, ‘l really dug your message, man.’ Or: ‘l really dug your play, man. I cried.’ You know? I like it when people come up to me the next day, or a week later, and they say: ‘I saw your play. What happened?’” Jeff Slater (Bill Murray), “Tootsie”

text: Were you out in the lobby getting Raisinettes? Here is “I Am Clemens,” a holiday movie preview from Super Deluxe you probably missed:

headline: Inside, Fans Line Up For ‘Late Night;’ Outside, Writers (Quietly) Picket
text: The Writers Guild of America mounted a small line of picketers outside an entrance to Rockefeller Center Wednesday afternoon as audience members of “Late Night with Conan O’Brien” waited inside.

headline: Bloomberg, Undeclared, Comments About the Declared
text: As he gears up to attend a conference at the University of Oklahoma next week that has been widely seen as a potential launching pad for a third-party presidential campaign, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took several minutes out of a news conference about a sharp decline in teenage smoking rates to sound as if he is already running.He offered one of his auto-pilot denials of interest (“I am not a candidate”), then tossed off one of his broadest critiques yet of the declared field just as the voting is finally about to get under way in Iowa, saying that none of the candidates had sufficiently explained how he or she would solve pressing domestic and international issues.

headline: $138 Oil – Good or Bad? (updated from $100…)
text: [UPDATE, 6/6, 3:30 p.m.:] Here we go again, again. Remember the good (or bad) old days when oil was just $100 a barrel? Now Jad Mouawad charts the latest oil price spike, triggered in part by a rumor related to Iran. Already it’s clear gasoline prices have, in fact, started to change consumer behavior, blunting sales even of hybrid SUV’s and causing a remarkable drop in vehicle miles driven in March (the latest month with statistics). So the question below remains: Are high oil prices good or bad for the environment?[UPDATED 2/26, 6:30 p.m: Here we go again. My friend Jad Mouawad tonight explores the implications of oil topping $100 a barrel  in an ailing economy and gasoline projected to head toward $4 a gallon. There’s some movement toward more efficient cars, if you can call GM’s announcement of an SUV that gets 21 miles per gallon movement. Please read below if you haven’t before. And weigh in if you see high oil prices as good, bad, or indifferent.]

headline: Looking To Next Fight, Romney Hits McCain
text: BETTENDORF, Iowa—Wait, is it the New Hampshire primary tomorrow, not the Iowa Caucus?

Bloomberg took several minutes out of a news conference about a sharp decline in teenage smoking rates to sound as if he is already running.

headline: Whither Huckabee?
text: Hucka Hucka Boom Boom: Terry Eastland, the publisher of The Weekly Standard, boards the “Huckabus” in Iowa to assess the state of the “Huckaboom” and to ascertain whether it precedes a looming “Huckabust.” Mike Huckabee’s economic and cultural populism, Eastland concludes, is at least as important to his appeal as his Christian conservatism.

headline: Our Dream Appliances
text: Last night, I did what I do every New Year’s Day: watch HGTV’s debut of its annual Dream House. This year’s was of particular interest to me because it was built on an island in Florida (Islamorada in the Florida Keys) just like mine.

headline: The McCain-Lieberman Duet
text: DERRY, N.H. — Once we unearthed our car from the snow earlier, we made our way to Mary Ann’s Diner, where Senator John McCain, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and Mr. McCain’s wife, Cindy, sat down to lunch with a few diners.

headline: A City of Contrasts
text: Travel writer Seth Kugel scours New York City for opposites.

headline: Republicans Out-Raised Democrats for National Commitees
text: When it comes to fund-raising, Democrats have outpaced Republicans almost across the board. The lone exception is the Republican National Committee, which reported yesterday that it had raised $83 million for the year, easily topping the Democratic National Committee, which had raised $50.5 million in the first 11 months of 2007.

headline: Bad Start, Recession Near?
text: The maven of S.&P. numbers, Howard Silverblatt, points out that today ranks No. 6 among the worst first days of a year for the S.&P. 500. The index fell by 1.4 percent.

headline: The Snow Bowl Game, as Seen by The Buffalo News
text: We’ve been calling the Sabres-Penguins New Year’s Day game at Ralph Wilson Stadium the Snow Bowl, but in Buffalo they called it the Ice Bowl. No matter — here’s how it looked in The Buffalo News.

Jack Balkin of Yale Law School, left, and Eric Posner of the University of Chicago Law School debate whether government surveillance today is worse than during the Cold War.
