text: An excerpt from the second live HD transmission of this season, a matinee performance of the Met's new production of Humperdinck's "Hansel and Gretel."

headline: Blogtalk: Iowa Aflutter
text: The Caucus can only be in so many places at once, especially on a day like this, and we’re not able to capture every handshake or gem of a quote spoken out on the trail. Fortunately, wonky Iowans run some pretty good blogs. Here are a few brief gems from today’s coverage of caucus eve:

headline: Golden Globe Backers In Talks With Writers
text: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association, the sponsor of the Golden Globe Awards, “said on Wednesday it began discussions with the Writers Guild of America on December 29 to get an ‘interim agreement’ similar to the one David Letterman’s company, Worldwide Pants, reached with the WGA to put ‘The Late Show with David Letterman’ back on the air,” Reuters reports.

headline: Striking Writers Deliver Top Ten List
text: “David Letterman officially made his return to late-night television just after 4:30 on Wednesday afternoon, when he opened the taping of Wednesday night’s show by passing through a chorus line of long-legged showgirls clad in white tie and bearing placards that read, ‘Writers Guild of America on Strike,'” Jacques Steinberg and Bill Carter report.

headline: Prankster Playing Bhutto’s Son on Facebook Fools News Outlets
text: UPDATED

headline: Clinton Appears on Letterman
text: Jacques Steinberg and Bill Cater report that David Letterman’s return to late-night television tonight features a greeting from Hillary Rodham Clinton. After the taping of the show was concluded, the show’s producers inserted a one-line joke to precede the host’s entrance — delivered not by Mr. Letterman but by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, via satellite from Iowa, on the eve of the state’s presidential caucuses.

headline: Obama’s 2-Minute Spot: ‘Leader’
text: In Barack Obama’s last appeal to Iowans for their support, the candidate asks voters to consider, “who can take us in a fundamentally new direction?”

headline: Huckabee Goes Positive in New Ads
text: Now that he canned his own negative ads against Mitt Romney, Mike Huckabee is out with new positive spots, which he is running in both Iowa and New Hampshire. One focuses on his anti-abortion stance, and with his mention of the word “values” (or some variation thereof) four times in the 30-second ad, it’s clear exactly what type of voter he is trying to get to come out for him tomorrow.

headline: Giuliani’s Warning on Readiness
text: Updated Rudolph W. Giuliani has released a graphic new ad, which will begin running on Fox News Channel and in Florida and New Hampshire on Thursday. The spot has footage riots, bombings and general unrest in the Muslim world, as a voiceover narrates:

headline: An Endorsement the Edwards Camp Isn’t Bragging About
text: DES MOINES — About that Ralph Nader endorsement of John Edwards…. It came out in an interview with Mr. Nader in Politico about 8 p.m. on New Year’s Eve. But here’s the interesting thing. The Edwards campaign never put out a release about it.

headline: Edwards Closes With Supporter’s Voice
text: Updated John Edwards, known for his closing arguments both as a trial lawyer and as a candidate in Iowa in 2004, is letting a supporter do it for him this time around.

headline: Garden
text: Where to go for a dose of spring in midwinter.

headline: Marquee Mismatches: Blame the System
text: After a magical season that will resonate as one of the grandest in college football history, the postseason is ending with a thud.

headline: Huckanomics
text: Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee’s Republican primary campaign has stood out from the Republican pack for its appeals to the economic anxieties of hard-pressed Iowans. At every stop he remind voters of his own humble roots— son of a firefighter who worked a second job, one generation from dirt floors and outhouses on his mother’s side— and tells that that he is the candidate who will look out for “the guy who can barely make the payments on his used pick-up truck.”

headline: Mitt Romney's Closing Pitch
text: Mitt Romney speaks to voters on Jan. 1. (NBC Video)

headline: Economists Warm Up to Edwards
text: Two weeks ago, in an article  about John Edwards, Mitt Romney and their attitude toward economic inequality, I wrote the following about Mr. Edwards:

headline: The Title Game: 10 Stories Worth Following
text: With Ohio State and Louisiana State having arrived in New Orleans, now is the time to look at 10 story lines worth following heading into the Bowl Championship Series title game Monday.1. The Hat vs. the Vest — L.S.U. Coach Les Miles is nicknamed the Hat because of the stiff brim he wears during games. Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel is known as the Vest because of his typical game-day sweater vest. Miles has become the known as the consummate sideline gambler, and Tressel is usually as conservative as his attire. But few will gives Miles the strategic edge here because Tressel has won too many big games by close margins.2. The Speed Factor — After Florida, like L.S.U. a team in the Southeastern Conference, routed Ohio State in last season’s title game, team speed was cited as a strong factor. That came into play especially with the Gators’ defensive front seven. Expect the speed factor as an advantage for L.S.U. to be discussed excessively leading up to the game.3. The Imperfect Quarterback — Plenty of observers are going to say that this Ohio State team is better than last season’s. Well, it’s not. The disparity at quarterback is enough of a reason, as the Buckeyes traded the Heisman Trophy winner, Troy Smith, for the immobile and not-so-accurate Todd Boeckman. L.S.U. has the solid-but-unspectacular Matt Flynn, which means that whichever quarterback makes the least mistakes will probably win.

headline: Tom Hanks Battles Contractor
text: In some ways it’s reassuring to know that even celebrities squabble with contractors.

headline: O’Brien Improvises, Saying ‘Sadly, We Do Not Have Our Writers With Us’
text: Conan O’Brien, sporting a red-hued beard on the first new “Late Night” in two months, spent time “finding ways to improvise on camera,” Jacques Steinberg and Bill Carter report. “He had someone clock how long he could spin his wedding ring on his desk (36 seconds) and made a running gag of sipping water from a mug. ‘That’s good water,’ he told the audience, adding, ‘Killed some time.'”

headline: Leno Presents Ten Minute Monologue
text: On his first night back on “The Tonight Show,” Jay Leno “offered a monologue that included jokes he said he had crafted beforehand. Whether that violated rules of the striking Writers Guild of America — to which Leno belongs — was not immediately clear,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Clinton’s Late-Night Rally on Caucus Eve
text: DES MOINES – After hundreds of rallies and speeches in Iowa since her first on Jan. 27, 2007, Hillary Rodham Clinton held her last big campaign event at the Historical Society building here, urging voters to “pick a president” when they gather for the first-in-the-nation Iowa caucuses Thursday evening.

headline: Betting on His Troops
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa

headline: Talk Shows Return as Strike Continues
text: The writers’ strike has upset the natural order of television, and that topsy-turviness was not set right with the return of late-night talk shows on Wednesday.

headline: Netflix Partners With LG to Bring Movies Straight to TV
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Netflix, the DVD-by-mail company with more than seven million customers, has a new strategy that may one day make those red envelopes obsolete.

headline: Ruth Wallis,  Singer-Writer of Risqué Songs, Dies at 87
text: Ruth Wallis, a cabaret singer of the 1940s, ’50s and ’60s who was known as the Queen of the Party Song for the genteelly risqué numbers she performed for happy, and very occasionally horrified, listeners worldwide, died on Dec. 22 at her home in South Killingly, Conn. She was 87.

headline: Grandma, Cousin Billy, Christian Dior
text: LITTLE more than a decade ago, Stanley Marcus, the merchandising wizard who turned Neiman Marcus into the country’s leading luxury retailer, pulled up in a Cadillac at the Dallas residence of one of his 10 grandchildren and deposited nearly 35 years’ worth of personal photographs on the porch. He was moving from the home he had lived in for some 50 years and was clearing out the closets.

headline: Fund Manager Faces Legal Siege Over Investments
text: The State Street Corporation, which manages $2 trillion for pension funds and other institutions, ousted a senior executive on Thursday and said it would set aside $618 million to cover legal claims stemming from investments tied to mortgage securities.

headline: Home-Office Life and Its Discontents
text: BEFORE they were married in September, Nicci Young and Richard Wiese first had to split up. The problem was not romantic, but spatial: Ms. Young Wiese, who organizes community development safaris to Africa, and Mr. Wiese, a writer and explorer, found that their Upper East Side one-bedroom was not big enough for the two of them after both decided to work from home.

headline: Tom Wolfe Leaves Longtime Publisher, Taking His New Book
text: Tom Wolfe, the author of sprawling social novels like “The Bonfire of the Vanities” and “A Man in Full,” has severed his 42-year relationship with Farrar, Straus & Giroux and agreed to sell the rights to publish his next novel, to be set in Miami, to Little, Brown & Company. People involved in the negotiations said on Wednesday that Mr. Wolfe’s advance for the new book was close to $7 million.

headline: Correction: Is This a Toothbrush or a Drill Sergeant?
text: The Skin Deep column on Dec. 20, about dental care, referred incorrectly to the Ultreo, a sonic brush that signals how long to brush each tooth. It should be moved around on the tooth during these intervals; it should not be stationary.

headline: Fresh-Faced Buccaneers Take Nothing for Granted
text: TAMPA, Fla.  In the reception area of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers’ enormous new practice facility stand nine life-size statues depicting the waning moments of the team’s Super Bowl victory after the 2002 season.

headline: Harry Potter Tops British Box Office
text: Harry Potter worked his magic last year when “Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix,” the fifth in the adventures of the boy wizard, took in $97.95 million to become the top-grossing film at box offices in Britain and Ireland, the BBC reported. Runners-up were “Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End” ($93.73 million); “Shrek the Third” ($76.56 million); and “The Simpsons Movie” ($76.4 million).

headline: But First, Doctor, What Was Your Marathon Time?
text: YOU are an athlete, or, at least, very active. Should you seek doctors who are athletes, too? After all, some obese people pass around lists of “fat friendly” doctors who treat them with respect. Women often want female doctors.

headline: A Young Ballerina Learns to Use Her Height to Artistic Advantage
text: Teresa Reichlen is a rarity at New York City Ballet, though for more than her angelic face, long legs and soaring jump, which manages to spring up and float in the air like silk. What’s unusual about Ms. Reichlen is that in the arduous quest to become a ballerina at a competitive and grueling company like City Ballet, her delicacy hasn’t turned into brittleness.

headline: A Courtroom Voice
text: ATLANTIC, Iowa

headline: With Builder in Bankruptcy, Buyers Are Left Out
text: MURRELLS INLET, S.C.  Ettore and Larisa Costanzo are showing off their new house, which they love madly.

headline: What Libraries Stand For
text: To the Editor:

headline: Clemens’s Interview Could Lead to Lawsuit
text: Roger Clemens will face a lawsuit if he says in a “60 Minutes” interview that his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, was not truthful when he said he injected Clemens with performance-enhancing drugs, a lawyer hired by McNamee said Wednesday.

headline: 4 Cameras Middling Only in Price
text: Little silver pocket cameras are small and cheap, they take movies, and they don’t turn you into a tourist cliché by dangling from your neck.

headline: World Business Briefing: Middle East: Israel: I.B.M. Acquires Data Storage Company
text: I.B.M. bought an Israeli data-storage provider, XIV, to meet growing demand for digital archiving. Financial terms were not disclosed. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., has bought about two dozen data-management companies since 2001 to bolster sales of software for storing, gaining access to and analyzing data. XIV, which is privately held, was founded in 2002 by five graduates of Talpiot, an Israeli military technology training program. The company, based in Tel Aviv, has about 50 employees.

headline: Chain Said to Seek Bids for Weather Channel
text: The Weather Channel, one of the last privately owned cable channels, is being put up for sale and could fetch more than $5 billion, according to people briefed on the auction. The channel and its rapidly growing Web site, weather.com, are already attracting interest from some of the biggest names in media, including NBC, a unit of General Electric; the News Corporation; and Comcast, these people said.

headline: No Homecoming for Preserved Head
text: A French court has barred the proposed repatriation of the mummified and tattooed head of a Maori warrior, Agence France-Presse reported. Last year a museum in Rouen, Normandy, where the head had been held since it was donated by a French collector in 1875, decided to return it to New Zealand as an “ethical gesture of respect” for the Maori people. But the French culture ministry intervened, arguing that the relic was part of France’s cultural heritage. On Dec. 27 an administrative court, in effect, blocked the transfer when it ruled that authorities in Rouen had failed to consult a scientific committee before withdrawing the head from the museum’s collection. Before their trade was outlawed, preserved heads of warriors with facial tattoos were popular with 19th-century European collectors.

headline: Justice Dept. Sets Criminal Inquiry on C.I.A. Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey said Wednesday that the Justice Department had elevated its inquiry into the destruction of Central Intelligence Agency interrogation videotapes to a formal criminal investigation headed by a career federal prosecutor.

headline: Man Fatally Shot by Officers Was Armed Fugitive, Police Say
text: The man who was fatally shot by two New York City police officers on Tuesday night when he aimed a silver revolver at them was a fugitive suspected of shooting an officer in Georgia in 2005, police officials said Wednesday.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $4,236,469

headline: The Title Game: 10 Stories Worth Following
text: With Ohio State and Louisiana State having arrived in New Orleans, now is the time to look at 10 story lines worth following heading into the Bowl Championship Series title game Monday.

headline: Unwilling New Frontier for Migrants: 3 Greek Isles
text: SAMOS, Greece  Six men and a woman crouch in the dark against the wall of the coast guard headquarters. An officer wearing camouflage fatigues barks: “Name? Papa? Age?”

headline: Obsessed With Nutrition? That’s an Eating Disorder
text: Not all scientific study of Mars is about extraterrestrial exploration. Some of it is about chocolate. Scientists at Mars Corporation have found evidence that the flavanols in cocoa have beneficial effects on the heart, thus allowing Mars to market products like its health-minded Rich Chocolate Indulgence Beverage.

headline: Nets Rally From a 15-Point Deficit to Edge Magic
text: ORLANDO, Fla. (AP)  Jason Kidd just missed having a triple-double and made a key defensive stop as the Nets overcame a 15-point deficit to defeat the Orlando Magic on Wednesday night, 96-95.

headline: Egypt Permits Pilgrims to Cross Back Into Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  Egypt allowed about 2,000 Palestinian pilgrims to cross back into the Gaza Strip on Wednesday after they had been stranded for days in the Egyptian Sinai on their way back from Mecca in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Library Admits Damage to 18th-Century Diary
text: The British Library has admitted that a historic diary was damaged while in its care, but refused to confirm reports that the manuscript, which recorded preparations for the Jacobite rebellion of 1715, had been left in the trunk of a car, the BBC reported. A library spokeswoman, who refused to confirm that allegation, reported in The Times of London, said that an internal investigation had been conducted, though details remained confidential. But she said that a staff member had since left. The diary had been entrusted to the library in 1994 by its owner, Peter J. Tyldesley, who said he believed it would be safer there than in his home. It was written by his ancestor Thomas Tyldesley, prominent among the Jacobites, who supported the claims to the throne of the exiled Stuart king James II and his descendants. Peter Tyldesley, a lawyer, said he “wanted to weep” when he discovered oily stains on the pages last spring.

headline: Ambition and Horror in Kenya
text: The murderous tribal violence that has spread through Kenya in recent days would be horrifying anywhere. It is particularly tragic to see this happening in a country that seemed finally to be on the path to a democratic and economically sound future. There may still be a chance to retrieve some of these hopes. That will likely require stepping back from the suspicious and hastily declared election results that sparked this ugly upheaval.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Tree Recycling

headline: What Happened to Our America?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Circuits: A Versatile Portable Player Can Carry a Tune From a Satellite, the Internet or a Hard Drive
text: There are essentially four ways to put music onto a portable player: rip it from a CD or other storage media, download it from the Internet, get it streamed from the Internet or receive it by satellite.

headline: Hartford: Contractor Sentenced in Bankruptcy Fraud
text: A Simsbury electrical contractor who told investigators that he gave former Gov. John G. Rowland expensive cigars and Champagne in exchange for access to state business was sentenced on Wednesday to five years in prison for hiding personal assets from a bankruptcy court. The contractor, Kurt Claywell, was convicted in July of conspiracy to commit bankruptcy fraud for attempting to conceal more than $200,000 in assets during a 2005 bankruptcy filing.

headline: States Hesitate to Lead Change on Executions
text: When a state panel recommended last April that Tennessee abandon the three chemicals used in executions across the nation in favor of the single drug usually used in animal euthanasia, the state’s corrections commissioner said no.

headline: Heart Procedure for Paul McCartney
text: Paul McCartney underwent coronary angioplasty last year, Agence France-Presse reported, citing British news media reports on Wednesday. The procedure opens arteries to increase blood flow. A spokesman for Mr. McCartney, right, confirmed that the angioplasty took place. The Sun of London quoted an unidentified source as saying: “Paul had been complaining about not feeling well and saw a Harley Street specialist at the London Clinic. Tests were carried out, and the decision was taken to operate. Paul had the angioplasty in a private hospital. It was all very routine, but any work on your heart is a big deal.” The Sun quoted a friend as saying: “Luckily Paul is in very good shape. He does regular exercise and is fit. He eats well and does not carry any excess weight. He has always been in exceptional health, which is remarkable when you think of the rock and roll lifestyle he once had.” Although no specific date for the angioplasty was given, Mr. McCartney, 65, was well enough to perform with Kylie Minogue on a BBC New Year special.

headline: Iowans Hear Barrage of Final Pleas for First ’08 Votes
text: DES MOINES  A yearlong prelude to the presidential election drew to a frenzied close on Wednesday here as Iowans absorbed a final torrent of campaign arguments before the state’s caucuses formally open the race for the White House.

headline: Volatility of the Markets Carries On in 2008
text: HOUSTON  Oil prices began the year with a volatile surge on Wednesday, briefly reaching $100 a barrel, a long-awaited milestone in an era of rapidly escalating energy demand and tightening supplies.

headline: No Need to Fly South to See Blossoms in Winter
text: JANUARY is a time for gardeners in the North to take time out: to stand in a tropical world, looking at palm trees soaring toward glass domes, or, as I did the other day, step down into a warm, steamy sunken Victorian fernery, where hundreds of ferns of every imaginable shape and size thrive among rocks and waterfalls.

headline: On Gadget Overload and Feeling Powerless
text: IN the end, all it took was a single “wafer-thin mint” to explode Mr. Creosote, the obese Monty Python character who couldn’t stop eating.

headline: How to Keep Momentum Going for Customers and Employees
text: It’s the first week of the new year and, small retailers may ask, now what? Don’t fall prey to the January lull, says Joel R. Evans, a marketing professor at the Zarb School of Business at Hofstra University and co-author of two books on marketing. He has identified the following ways to jump-start sales and avoid a post-holiday letdown:

headline: Closing With a Rout, Georgia Hopes to Open Next Season as No. 1
text: NEW ORLEANS  Georgia Coach Mark Richt acknowledged that he could not believe how long his team’s blowout victory of Hawaii in the Sugar Bowl went on.

headline: Social Net Site Is Said to Be for Sale
text: Plaxo, an early social networking site that helps people keep their address books updated, is up for auction, people briefed on the offering said Wednesday night. The company, which has not made a profit, is seeking as much as $100 million, these people said.

headline: ‘Miraculous’ Recovery for Man Who Fell From Sky
text: Alcides Moreno plunged 47 stories that morning last month, clinging to his 3-foot-wide window washer’s platform as it shot down the dark glass face of an Upper East Side apartment building. His brother Edgar, who had been working with him, was killed when the platform landed.

headline: Brazilian Lessons for 2008
text: RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: Travel Book Publishers Try to Reclaim the Web
text: LONDON  About a dozen years ago, the Rough Guides and Lonely Planet series of travel books, rival bibles for the footloose and fancy free, crossed a new frontier onto the Internet. But they found their road maps to the digital future hard to read.

headline: Putting Your Best Cyberface Forward
text: DO you bite your nails? Have you pierced your tongue? Is your tote bag emblazoned with the words “I’m not a plastic bag”?

headline: Curry Gets Message, Even if Team Does Not
text: The Madison Square Garden fans booed Eddy Curry as he was announced as a starter Wednesday night against Sacramento. But whether they agreed with the decision to reinsert him into the lineup, one inspired effort off the bench from Curry was all Coach Isiah Thomas needed to see.

headline: Politics, Spreadsheets and More Are All Grist for the (Free) Game Mill
text: Two months ago, I was drowning in video games. In the pre-Christmas onslaught, games pour into every video game critic’s office as though blasted out of a fire hose; you need waders to slosh around in them. Then at the end of November the fire hose is shut off, a couple of final games drip out and there is a deafening silence until next autumn.

headline: Britain: Patients Flee Fire at Top Hospital
text: A fire blazed across the top floors of the Royal Marsden Hospital in London, one of Europe’s leading cancer centers, forcing the evacuation of all the patients and staff members. No one was badly hurt in the blaze, which apparently began on the fourth floor and spread quickly, destroying the roof, sending black smoke billowing into the sky and seriously damaging five operating rooms and two wards. About 125 firefighters were called to the scene. In-patients  two who were undergoing surgery when the fire began  were admitted to other hospitals. Hospital officials said that part of the hospital might be able to open again on Thursday.

headline: Marie-Jeanne, a Balanchine Ballerina, Dies at 87
text: Marie-Jeanne, an American ballerina long associated with George Balanchine and a member of the New York City Ballet during its first season, died on Friday in Austin, Tex. She was 87 and lived in a retirement home there.

headline: The Slice of the Sliver Speaks
text: DES MOINES

headline: On the Naming of Kristol as a Times Columnist
text: To the Editor:

headline: ... And Iowa Now
text: Iowa City

headline: Health Care at Age 65
text: To the Editor:

headline: California Sues E.P.A. Over Denial of Waiver
text: SAN FRANCISCO  California sued the federal Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday, challenging its recent decision to block California rules curbing greenhouse-gas emissions from new cars and trucks.

headline: Giuliani Keeps Campaign Focus on Terrorism
text: HOOKSET, N.H.  With the political world focused on Iowa, Rudolph W. Giuliani released a graphic new television advertisement here Wednesday in which scenes of Osama bin Laden firing a rifle segue to the smoking wreckage of the World Trade Center.

headline: The Right Move on the C.I.A. Tapes
text: The Justice Department’s announcement that it has ordered a formal criminal investigation into the destruction of Central Intelligence Agency interrogation videotapes is a heartening, and unaccustomed, sign that the attorney general is doing his duty to get to the bottom of a roiling scandal.

headline: Theater Team Makes an Ally of Random Circumstance
text: Just about all of the publicity materials and even some of the reviews of the Nature Theater of Oklahoma’s production of “No Dice”  a theater work consisting of seven actors performing bizarre dances and reciting telephone conversations about mundane topics  mention that the show is a whittled-down 4-hour version of an 11-hour monster epic.

headline: A Yippie Role for Sacha Baron Cohen?
text: Having bade farewell to his creation Borat, Sacha Baron Cohen, below, is turning to Vietnam War politics to portray Abbie Hoffman, a co-founder of the quintessential 1960s protest group the Yippies, in a Steven Spielberg film “The Trial of the Chicago Seven,” The Sunday Times of London reported. The trial grew out of protests at the 1968 Democratic nominating convention in Chicago, where violence led to the trial of seven demonstrators, including Mr. Hoffman, who were accused of inciting a riot. Variety reported that a representative of Mr. Spielberg would neither confirm nor deny the Sunday Times’s report. Mr. Hoffman committed suicide in 1989.

headline: Under Pressure, Prosecutor in Texas Won’t Run Again
text: HOUSTON  Eager to distance themselves from a political sex scandal, leaders of the Harris County Republican Party on Wednesday quashed the re-election plans of Texas’ most powerful prosecutor, District Attorney Charles A. Rosenthal Jr.

headline: 2 African-American Women File Suit Against the Garden
text: Two African-American women who were security supervisors at Madison Square Garden accused arena management in a lawsuit filed Wednesday in Brooklyn Supreme Court of discriminating against them by giving them less-desirable assignments and favoring white employees despite their lesser qualifications.

headline: Circuits: Out of the Camera Bag, but Still Protected, Encased in Shock-Absorbing Rubber Skin
text: While a padded bag can protect an expensive digital single-lens-reflex camera when it is not in use, there are also the potential bumps and dings after it leaves the bag. To help protect a camera while it is out and about, Made Products has come up with Camera Armor, a custom-fitted ergonomic suit for various S.L.R. models from Canon, Nikon, Sony, Olympus, Pentax and Fuji.

headline: Obama Triumphs in Iowa Contest as Clinton Falters; Huckabee Rolls
text: DES MOINES  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, a one-term Democratic senator trying to become the nation’s first African-American president, rolled to victory in the Iowa caucuses on Thursday night, lifted by what appeared to be a record turnout of voters who rejected the criticism that he did not have enough experience.

headline: The Office, Housebroken
text: IT was not so long ago, Neal Zimmerman recalls, that the term home office meant something very different from what it does today. In the early ’90s, when Mr. Zimmerman, a prominent workplace architect with offices in West Hartford, Conn., started designing residential work spaces, most people thought “home office” meant the headquarters of a company. Back then, the very idea of working at home had a certain stigma, except in a few vocations like freelance writing. In the popular imagination, he said, “people who worked from home were usually laid off or couldn’t hold down a job, or were peripheral to the work force.”

headline: Marquee Mismatches: Blame the System
text: After a magical season that will resonate as one of the grandest in college football history, the postseason is ending with a thud.

headline: Toyota Ousts Ford From No. 2 Spot in U.S. Sales
text: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company’s United States sales fell 12 percent in 2007, allowing Toyota Motor of Japan to replace it as the country’s second largest seller of vehicles.

headline: No Insurance, Poor Health
text: The case for providing health coverage for all Americans got even more compelling in the past week when two new studies presented the most comprehensive evidence yet that the lack of health insurance is seriously harmful to a patient’s health. The studies found that uninsured people suffer significantly worse outcomes from cardiovascular disease, diabetes and cancer than those who have coverage.

headline: Pakistani Opposition Parties Decry Election Delay
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The main opposition parties denounced the government’s decision on Wednesday to postpone parliamentary elections for six weeks after the assassination of the opposition leader Benazir Bhutto, but they said they would abide by the ruling.

headline: Leno and Guild in Dispute Over His Monologue
text: Jay Leno made a triumphant return to late-night television Wednesday night, easily dominating the ratings competition over his chief rival, David Letterman, and delivering one of his traditional full-length monologues  even though he was performing without his team of 19 writers.

headline: Fatigue Factor Gives Equal Time to Candidates
text: DES MOINES  It’s the groggy, nerve-sizzling season on the trail, and forget the attack ads and last-minute scrapping. Any candidate will attest that the epic fight now is against sleep deprivation, the gaffe-inducing monster that looms over every campaign in its final hours.

headline: Guard Mocked by Escaped Prisoners Is Found Dead
text: ELIZABETH, N.J.  The emotional blows had been landing with increasing frequency for Rudolph Zurick. In recent months, he mourned the death of his mother, a neighbor said. Then, in mid-December, Mr. Zurick, a corrections officer at the Union County Jail here, made the troubling discovery that two inmates had burrowed through a concrete wall in a daring escape.

headline: After Talk of Titles, Knicks Tank Again
text: Isiah Thomas walked a red carpet. He shook hands with a well-wisher, who nodded toward the throng of people on Thomas’s heels. “My posse,” Thomas said, chuckling.

headline: Short, Stout, Has a Handle on Colds
text: GABY HAKMAN worked as a chef in professional kitchens in Miami for nearly 20 years, standing in the vacuum of powerful venting fans, inhaling smoke. But she had even bigger nasal challenges ahead. “I work as a personal chef now, which is a lot less toxic, but I also moved to New York City, and because of the city’s pollutants and dry heat I developed painfully dry sinuses,” Ms. Hakman said.

headline: Brooklyn: Girls Left Alone Are Rescued From Blaze
text: Firefighters rescued two young girls from a burning apartment in Flatbush on Wednesday, and the man who left them unattended was charged with endangerment, the police said. The girls, who are sisters believed to be 1 and 3 years old, were taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where they were in stable condition after being treated for smoke inhalation. Their mother had left them in the care of her live-in companion, Steven Vassort, 23, but he went out, the police said. He was charged with two counts of child endangerment. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

headline: Political Field Is Panned by Bloomberg
text: With unusually dismissive language, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg offered tart assessments of his potential presidential rivals at a news conference on Wednesday, suggesting they are offering meaningless bromides rather than serious answers to the problems confronting the country.

headline: Inmate Escapes From Hospital
text: A 45-year-old prisoner being treated at a hospital in Maryland overpowered a guard, stole a gun, and carjacked a motorist as he escaped and fled early Wednesday morning, the authorities said.

headline: New Jersey School Plan Hinges on Odd Alliances
text: TRENTON  Ever since Gov. Jon S. Corzine unveiled his plan three weeks ago to overhaul the way New Jersey finances its schools, he has witnessed the formation of unexpected alliances that either favor the new way he wants the state to dispense billions of dollars or strenuously oppose it.

headline: Regional Bank in Ohio to Trim 900 Jobs
text: CLEVELAND (AP)  The regional bank National City Corporation said on Wednesday that it was cutting its dividend by nearly half and shutting its wholesale mortgage division, eliminating 900 jobs, because of weakened housing and credit markets.

headline: Apartment Prices in Manhattan Defy National Real Estate Slide
text: As the housing market across the country continued to stagnate in the fourth quarter of last year, the market in Manhattan set a record, according to reports to be released on Thursday by four of the city’s major real estate brokerage firms.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q.  What kind of lighting should I install in my home theater?

headline: George MacDonald Fraser, Author of Flashman Novels, Dies at 82
text: George MacDonald Fraser, a British writer whose popular novels about the arch-rogue Harry Flashman followed their hero as he galloped, swashbuckled, drank and womanized his way through many of the signal events of the 19th century, died yesterday on the Isle of Man. He was 82 and had made his home there in recent years.

headline: A Laugh About the Lord
text: SERGEANT BLUFF, Iowa

headline: Redefining ‘Fit to Practice’
text: THE problem with advising very active people to find doctors who are like them is that there may be no way to know whether a doctor is an athlete without calling and asking. But there are at least two professional organizations that try to help.

headline: Domestic Issues Now Outweigh Iraq
text: DES MOINES  The Democratic and Republican presidential candidates are navigating a far different set of issues as they approach the Iowa caucuses on Thursday than when they first started campaigning here a year ago, and that is likely to change even more as the campaigns move to New Hampshire and across the country.

headline: When It’s Time to Get to Work
text: IT can be a pleasure to work at home in an office that is well set up. But not every home has an extra room that can be used as a work space, so outfitting an office often means being smart and efficient about carving out and furnishing a corner of a bedroom or a living room with office essentials.

headline: Tankleff Says He Relishes Freedom
text: In his first few days after winning his freedom from prison, Martin H. Tankleff  who was sent to prison 17 years ago for two murders he insists he never committed  relished the things that were little more than routine to him a half a lifetime ago.

headline: Practicing the Subtle Sell of Placing Products on Webisodes
text: AMERICAN EAGLE OUTFITTERS, the retailer that sells jeans, T-shirts and hoodies for the 15- to-25-year-old set, has been at the forefront of the trend toward advertainment, in which companies make videos to engross viewers while glamorizing a particular brand.

headline: Staying on Message
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa

headline: Well-Rested Buccaneers to Face Surging Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As opposing quarterbacks in a wild-card playoff game Sunday, Eli Manning and Jeff Garcia will have a big impact on the result. But the late-season preparation of Manning’s Giants and Garcia’s Buccaneers could not have been more different.

headline: January’s the Time to Get Shoppers Back in the Stores
text: FRESH off 80-hour workweeks in a sprint for holiday sales, it is little wonder that some entrepreneurs are escaping for a precious few days of sun and relaxation.

headline: Stressing Experience
text: DERRY, N.H.

headline: Three Generations of Help on the Way to a Team Title
text: The winners of the Swiss Teams at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan on Sunday were Jill Levin, Shane Blanchard, Peter Bonfanti, Robert Levin and Glenn Milgrim of New York and Stephen Shane of White Plains.

headline: City Cuts Bronx Center’s Aid, Citing Misuse of Funds
text: A South Bronx day care center being investigated by the city for financial improprieties will lose its city financing next week and have to close, the fourth day care facility to be shuttered in the neighborhood in four years, officials said Wednesday.

headline: You Go to the Movie Theater, and an Opera Breaks Out
text: Television broadcasts of opera have been around for a long time and have done much to demystify the art form. Still, it’s mostly recorded opera broadcasts that are seen on television these days.

headline: White Plains: Ex-official at Nonprofit Group Admits Lying
text: A former chief financial officer of the nonprofit group the Institute for Cancer Prevention admitted in Federal District Court on Wednesday that he lied to federal agents who were checking on the use of grants awarded to the organization, prosecutors said. The former official, Roy Victor, pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said in a statement. Prosecutors said Mr. Victor admitted that he lied repeatedly to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He faces up to 10 years in prison.

headline: Pakistan Turns to Britain for Help in Bhutto Inquiry
text: LONDON  Pakistan’s request for Scotland Yard’s help in investigating the assassination of Benazir Bhutto follows years of close and often successful cooperation between Pakistan and Britain on terrorist cases, especially since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in the United States. But British terrorism experts cautioned Wednesday against expectations of any early breakthroughs in the Bhutto killing.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day on Monday reported on Kijiji, a free classified ads online service owned by eBay that seeks to compete with Craigslist, the San Francisco-based company that manages classified ad sites in hundreds of cities. The column should have noted that eBay, based in San Jose, Calif., and Craigslist have a financial relationship. EBay bought a 25 percent stake in Craigslist in 2004.

headline: Long Island Man Won’t Be Tried Again in Murders
text: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y.  The Suffolk County district attorney said on Wednesday that he would not retry Martin H. Tankleff for the 1988 murders of his parents and that he would ask Gov. Eliot Spitzer to appoint a special prosecutor to reinvestigate the case.

headline: Defendant’s Disarray Points to Instability, Lawyer Says
text: It was like one of those bad dreams in which one goes to school or rides the subway half-dressed.

headline: Even France, Haven of Smokers, Is Clearing the Air
text: PARIS  Overnight, conviviality has taken on an entirely new meaning in France.

headline: Egypt: 4 Women Die of Bird Flu
text: Bird flu has killed four Egyptian women in the past week, according to Egyptian health officials and the World Health Organization. The women, ages 25 to 50, were from different provinces, and the cases were not related, officials said. At least one was a chicken seller, and the others were said to have kept poultry at home. The H5N1 strain of avian flu appears endemic in Egyptian poultry; previously the last human case was in June. A total of 43 Egyptians have been infected with H5N1 since it arrived in early 2006; 19 died.

headline: Circuits: Hi-Fi Earbuds for Hearing Less Noise and Higher Quality When Listening to Music on the iPhone
text: As Steven P. Jobs said when he introduced the iPhone, it’s not just a phone  it’s also a music player. It stands to reason, then, that music fans will want a pair of headphones that can reproduce the highs, lows and midranges they expect from their other music devices.

headline: Law Amended to Shield Tax-Exempt Groups
text: Pension funds, university endowments and other organizations that are exempt from paying taxes will no longer be ensnared by a law intended to combat two notorious corporate tax shelters.

headline: Letterman’s Back, With a Greeting From Clinton
text: David Letterman officially made his return to late-night television just after 4:30 on Wednesday afternoon, when he opened the taping of Wednesday night’s show by passing through a chorus line of long-legged showgirls clad in white tie and bearing placards that read, “Writers Guild of America on Strike.”

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe: Finland: Nokia Siemens Makes Acquisition
text: Nokia Siemens Networks, a maker of wireless networks, agreed to buy Apertio for about 140 million euros ($206 million) to expand its subscriber data management services. Apertio has 237 employees and had sales of about 28 million euros in 2007, Nokia Siemens said. Nokia Siemens, which is a joint venture of Nokia and Siemens and is based in Espoo, Finland, expects the acquisition to close in the first quarter of this year. Apertio’s products are used by wireless and fixed phone operators. Apertio, based in Bristol, England, has operations in Continental Europe, Asia and the United States.

headline: Anger and Blame After Deadly Flood in Northwest
text: CURTIS, Wash.  The big rain fell with fatal efficiency those first few days of December. It washed mud from mountainsides and lifted logs into the Chehalis River, which rose to a historic high as it roared downhill. Bridges broke. Cows drowned. Helicopters plucked people from rooftops.

headline: Tip of the Week: How Stale Is That Web Page?
text: If you have a sneaking suspicion that the Web page you’re looking at is old and stale, you can take a peek to see when it was last updated. In Internet Explorer or Firefox, just go to the address bar while the page is displayed in your browser and type in “javascript:alert(document.lastModified)” without the quotation marks. Hit the Enter key to see a box that tells you when the page you’re viewing was updated.

headline: Recording Calls Over the Net
text: Q. Is there a way to record Internet voice chats on the computer?

headline: Corrections
text: Editors' Note

headline: Discussion of a Fed Cut Only Stirs Up Concerns About a Weak Economy
text: Wall Street stumbled out of the blocks for the new year after oil prices surged briefly to $100 a barrel and a report pointing to a fall in manufacturing activity in December revived fears that the economy would falter in 2008.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: Eggplants in Love

headline: Rangers Cooled by the Red-Hot Iginla
text: CALGARY, Alberta (AP)  Jarome Iginla scored two goals to lead the Calgary Flames to a 4-3 victory over the Rangers on Wednesday night.

headline: Footnotes
text: Eddie Murphy, whose acting credits include “Beverly Hills Cop,” “The Nutty Professor” and “Dr. Dolittle,” married the film producer Tracey Edmonds on New Year’s Day on a private island off Bora Bora in French Polynesia, The Associated Press reported. ... As many as 1.1 million people watched the live broadcast of the traditional New Year’s concert of the Vienna Philharmonic, Agence France-Presse reported. The performance, led by Georges Prêtre, was broadcast around the world on 54 television channels and 35 radio stations. ... More than 30 dramas, documentaries and shorts will be shown when the Jewish Museum and the Film Society of Lincoln Center present the 17th annual New York Jewish Film Festival, from Jan. 9- 24. Films will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater and at the museum in Manhattan.

headline: For Iowa’s Democrats, Too Many Good Picks
text: AMES, Iowa  If conversations with undecided Democrats here were turned into a play, it would consist of the same dialogue repeated over and over again, with slight variations:

headline: Stealing From a Biker Gang
text: ROCK ’N’ ROLL, the art world, Hollywood and fashion have swiped inspiration from biker style so often that it’s a wonder there is anything left to purloin. This has been the case in every two-wheeled decade, and rarely more so than now, when the hip artist du jour Richard Prince seems to have motorcycle culture firmly in the pincers of his ironic quotations, and style avatars like Kate Moss have taken to kitting themselves up like Hells Angels mamas.

headline: Devils Start Fast to Stay Hot at Home
text: NEWARK (AP)  The Devils finally found the net in an opening period.

headline: The Bratty and the Beautiful
text: WALKING into Hickey, a new store of handsome and impetuous men’s clothes in SoHo, you may notice on the far wall a large black-and-white photo print of a beautiful male model. His symmetrical slitty eyes, long, perfect nose and pouty flower-petal lips are framed by a corona of blond hair styled in a beachy sea-salt scraggle.

headline: Bronx: Man Is Fatally Shot
text: A 20-year-old man was shot to death about 8:30 p.m. on Wednesday in an apartment building in Mott Haven, the police said. Officers responding to a 911 call found the man lying in a hallway on the 18th floor of the building, at 360 East 137th Street. The man, whom the police did not identify, suffered multiple gunshot wounds and was pronounced dead at the scene. There were no arrests and no known motive, the police said.

headline: Not Exactly the Jetsons, but Getting Closer
text: Robots are still far from being the chatty companions seen in science-fiction movies. But some toy robots are becoming more than just conversation pieces.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Father Says He Set Fire That Killed Three
text: CHICAGO  A man set a fire last weekend that killed his pregnant daughter, his son-in-law and his 3-year-old grandson, prosecutors say, because he disapproved of his daughter’s marriage.

headline: Investor Adds to Zale Stake
text: WASHINGTON (Reuters)  Richard C. Breeden, the former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman who is now an activist investor, has raised his stake in the Zale Corporation, the jeweler, to 13.3 percent from 7.7 percent, according to a regulatory filing made Wednesday.

headline: $30 Million Fine for Mileage Violations
text: DaimlerChrysler paid a $30 million fine in 2007, the most ever by an automaker, for failing to meet federal fuel-efficiency standards, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Teenagers in the City Smoke Less, Report Finds
text: Health officials reported on Wednesday that smoking among New York City’s teenagers had continued to drop in 2007 at a rate faster than among adults in the city, and is now far lower than among teenagers nationwide. The drop was due mainly to high cigarette taxes and curbs on public smoking, they said.

headline: Hospital Cardiac Arrest Response Often Too Slow
text: When patients in the hospital suddenly go into cardiac arrest, the staff often takes too long to respond, increasing the risk of brain damage and death, a new study finds.

headline: Garcia’s a Nemesis That Really Gets Around
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It may only be a coincidence that the Giants are again facing a team in the playoffs led by quarterback Jeff Garcia. Or it may be much deeper than that, another chance to come full circle.

headline: Lockheed Settles Discrimination Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters)  The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the military contractor, has agreed to pay a former employee $2.5 million, more than any person has received in the settlement of a racial discrimination case filed by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, lawyers for the agency said on Wednesday.

headline: Huckabee Stresses His Humble Roots and Anti-Abortion Stance
text: Former Governor Mike Huckabee of Arkansas sharpened his pitch to Iowa voters that his humble roots gave him a better understanding of the problems of working people than his rival, Mitt Romney, a former private equity fund manager.

headline: Anarchy Rules: The Dishes Stay Dirty
text: THERE are certain things you can count on in a punk house. A killer name: Anarchtica, Scribble Squat, Collective A Go-Go, Firebreathing Kangaroo. Lots of bikes and skateboards. Homemade tattoos. A tattered photocopy of “Soy, Not ‘Oi!’,” the vegan anarchist’s “Joy of Cooking.” Guests are always welcome in a punk house, if they follow the rules: “Don’t be a jerk!” reads a guest policy sign in one.

headline: Trenton: Medicaid Payments Increase for Child Treatments
text: Doctors who care for poor children in New Jersey are receiving an increase in Medicaid reimbursements for the first time in two decades, with payments more than tripling. Under the new rate, which started on Tuesday, physicians are being paid $73.70 from Medicaid for each child’s visit, up from $23.03; dentists will see payments jump to $64 for each exam from $18.02. “It’s a big step toward providing more access for our clients,” said Jennifer Velez, commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Human Services. The new rates will also help the department attract new providers, she said.

headline: The Coaching Carousel May Lead to Reunions
text: Rob Ryan’s expected departure as the defensive coordinator of the Oakland Raiders could set off an episode of “All in the Family” in the N.F.L.

headline: Urban Success Story, With Hint of Unease for Poorer Residents
text: WHITE PLAINS

headline: A High-Definition Projector for Those Who Think Big-Screen Televisions Are Not Quite Big Enough
text: Even as the prices of L.C.D. and plasma TVs slide, high-definition projectors remain expensive  but at least they are getting considerably better. The Sony Bravia VPL-VW40 front projector, for example, costs $3,000 but displays images at a vertical resolution of 1,080 lines and 60 frames a second, the highest on the market.

headline: Time Away a Good Choice for Marbury
text: Stephon Marbury was doing his job again Wednesday night, a full month after the death of his father, Don, on Dec. 2.

headline: With Nods to the Strike, Late-Night Hosts Return
text: Eight weeks after their writers went on strike and plunged their shows into reruns, Jay Leno, David Letterman and Conan O’Brien returned to late-night television Wednesday with original shows in which both the Iowa caucuses and the new facial hair on two of the hosts loomed large.

headline: Iowa Then...
text: Cupertino, Calif.

headline: Compositions That Come Naturally
text: Frederick Law Olmsted, with his Victorian whiskers, grandiloquent diction and vaguely utopian transcendentalism, might have been alarmed to learn that many decades after his death in 1903 he would become a hero of postmodern art.

headline: Bill Bonanno, 75, Mob Family Member, Dies
text: Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno, whose appointment by his father to the second most powerful position in the Bonanno crime family in the mid-1960s touched off what became known as the “Banana Wars” and led to the exile of the Bonannos to Arizona, died on Tuesday at his home in Tucson. He was 75.

headline: NBC’s 'Loser' a Winner
text: NBC’s couples edition of “The Biggest Loser” got off to a solid start in the ratings on Tuesday as 10.4 million viewers tuned in from 8 to 10 p.m. for the show’s debut, according to Nielsen’s overnight estimates. Among adults 18 to 49, the episode fared better than any of the four previous premieres of the series, boosting NBC to a second-place finish on the night. Fox led the night over all with its Sugar Bowl coverage, although exact audience figures for the football game were unavailable on Wednesday. CBS and ABC ranked third and fourth for the night. CBS finished third in total viewers thanks to repeats of “NCIS” at 8 (11.7 million) and “The Unit” at 9 (7.4 million), followed by “48 Hours Mystery” at 10 (6 million). ABC edged past CBS for third in the 18-to-49 set, benefiting from an overrun of its Rose Bowl coverage in the 8 p.m. hour, but struggling at 9 with two episodes of “According to Jim,” which drew under 5 million viewers each. NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (12.3 million) dominated the 10 p.m. hour among nonsports programming.

headline: Yonkers: House Fire Kills Elderly Couple
text: The police blamed space heaters for a house fire that killed a married couple in their 80s on Wednesday. Fire officials said the fast-moving fire was fueled by clothing, papers and other clutter piled five feet high throughout the house. The couple, Caroline and Leo Gorynski, were found inside. Deputy Fire Chief John Flynn said that the fire started when space heaters ignited some of the clutter, and that there was clothing on top of the heaters. The Fire Department said the couple had nailed their front door shut, but Chief Flynn said that that did not delay the search for the victims. Ms. Gorynski, 88, was pronounced dead at the scene, and Mr. Gorynski, 87, died a short time later at a hospital.

headline: Ending a Long Journey
text: MASON CITY, Iowa

headline: Hospitals Slow in Heart Cases, Research Finds
text: In nearly a third of cases of sudden cardiac arrest in the hospital, the staff takes too long to respond, increasing the risk of brain damage and death, a new study finds.

headline: Congressional Crackdown on Lobbying Is Already Showing Cracks
text: WASHINGTON  The party sponsored by the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States to celebrate the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, at the New York Yacht Club was one of the more over-the-top events of the Republican National Convention in 2004, featuring 10 bars and more than a half-dozen special vintage Scotches. The group held a similar soiree that year for Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader, at the Democratic Convention in Boston.

headline: Casting ‘The Seagull’
text: Alan Cumming will join Dianne Wiest in the Classic Stage Company’s production of Chekhov’s “Seagull,” which is to run from Feb. 20 to March 30. Viacheslav Dolgachev, the artistic director of the Moscow New Drama Theater, is directing.

headline: Jones Wants to Stay, but It’s Hawaii’s Call
text: Leigh Steinberg, the agent for Hawaii Coach June Jones, said he expected a decision on Jones’s future to be made in a “fairly rapid time frame.”

headline: Cancer Diagnosis Upends Family’s Finances and Relationships
text: On a recent evening in Washington Heights, Gertrudy Cuevas was longingly remembering her old factory job, where six years ago she started out sewing seat covers but in time proved that, despite her small frame, she was strong enough to build heavy furniture.

headline: Kenya, Known for Its Stability, Topples Into Post-Election Chaos
text: KIAMBAA, Kenya  Daniel Kibigo said he was there, hiding in the burned cornfields nearby, as the mob gleefully stuffed mattresses in front of the church’s doors and set them on fire.

headline: Comic Books in the Classroom
text: Generations of children grew up reading comic books on the sly, hiding out from parents and teachers who saw them as a waste of time and a hazard to young minds. Comics are now gaining a new respectability at school. That is thanks to an increasingly popular and creative program, often aimed at struggling readers, that encourages children to plot, write and draw comic books, in many cases using themes from their own lives.

headline: Italy: Milan Introduces Traffic Fee
text: Milan joined London, Stockholm and Singapore among cities imposing congestion charges on drivers in an effort to improve the air quality in one of Europe’s most polluted urban centers. Vehicles entering the city’s center on weekdays will be charged up to $14 a day, depending on the amount of pollution their models produce. Electric, hybrid and some low-polluting cars are exempt, as are most scooters. About 90,000 cars cross the charge area daily, according to the city’s Web site. The city intends to curb particle matter circulation by 30 percent. Particle matter pollution originates mainly from traffic, heating and industry.

headline: Attacker Bombs Pro-U.S. Sunnis in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber in turbulent Diyala Province detonated an explosive vest on Wednesday at a checkpoint operated by armed Sunni Arab tribesmen who have turned against Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia and pledged support to the United States military.

headline: Wipe Your PC for Safety’s Sake
text: Q. I’m about to give my six-year-old Windows XP computer to a friend. Short of reformatting the hard drive, is there any way to expunge my identity  my name, for instance, automatically supplied to certain forms  from the nooks and crannies of the machine? Is there software to restore a system to “pre-ownership” state?

headline: X68 Express Bus From Midtown to Floral Park, Queens
text: The 5.34 p.m. Bus (which departed at 5:49 p.m.)

headline: Stinky Cheese! Ambassador for Children’s Literature
text: Jon Scieszka, the author of witty and subversive children’s favorites like “The True Story of the Three Little Pigs” and “The Stinky Cheese Man and Other Fairly Stupid Tales,” is to be named the country’s first national ambassador for young people’s literature on Thursday, a kind of children’s book version of the Library of Congress’s poet laureate program.

headline: Circuits: A Tablet PC That Is Receptive to a Soft Touch, but Offers a Full Keyboard for Serious Tapping
text: Long before the computer mouse, the human finger was the original pointing device. Now Dell, with its new Latitude XT Tablet PC, has created a lightweight portable computer with “capacitive touch” capabilities that can accept on-screen input from finger taps as well as a plastic stylus.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: The Slice of the Sliver Speaks
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Jan. 3 column.

headline: Pakistan: A View from the D.J. Booth
text: Munizeh Sanai, host of "The Rush Hour," in Karachi, Pakistan discusses the current unrest in the country.

headline: What’s Been Missing? Late Night!
text: No one’s sure how we’ve survived these last few months without the political put-downs and humor of late-night television. It’s been so long. …

headline: Pushing the Wrong Buttons
text: So, Britney Spears has taken up with a paparazzo. But for celebrity photographers, crossing the line can have its drawbacks:

headline: Late Night Is Back! Hope You Like Strike Jokes.
text: Eight weeks after their writers went on strike, Jay Leno, David Letterman and Conan O’Brien returned to late-night TV last night — the latter two sporting beards (gray and red respectively). Highlights:

headline: A Love Letter to Giants Fans
text: Reader comments tend to run toward criticism and cynicism. Nature of the beast. Satisfied fans have no reason to write. Unhappy fans need a venue to vent. (We’ve all been there. Click here for a rundown of acts of rage committed after Giants losses.)

headline: Praise the Lord; Pass the Quips
text: Mike Huckebee continually taps the genre of humor you might call the Jesus joke:

headline: Vinci Buys Stake in French Airports Operator
text: Shares in the government-controlled Aéroports de Paris, operator of Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports, soared Wednesday after a French construction company said that it had acquired a 3.3 percent stake.

headline: Clean Energy Investments Top $100 Billion
text: Despite the global credit crunch in 2007, new investment in clean energy industries like wind and solar power rose sharply to break through the $100 billion barrier for the first time, a research group, New Energy Finance, said Wednesday.

headline: Ritchie Capital Returns Investor Fire Over Fund
text: A week after some investors tried forcing it into bankruptcy, Ritchie Capital defended management of its multi-strategy hedge fund and warned other investors that the group’s legal action could “cause further damage to the value of your investment.”

headline: Singapore’s China Easter Bid Hits Turbulence
text: A Singapore Airlines bid to buy a 24 percent stake in China Eastern Airlines appeared to be in trouble Wednesday after a major shareholder criticized the deal as unfair.

headline: I.B.M. Acquires Israeli Data Storage Company
text: I.B.M. bought an Israeli data-storage provider, XIV, to meet growing demand for digital archiving. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: EchoStar Spinoff Begins Trading
text: Shares of EchoStar Communications‘s technology unit began trading on Wednesday as part of its founder’s plan to raise the valuations of the company’s operations.

headline: Private-Equity Backed Retailers Look Vulnerable
text: For dozens of retailers that went through leveraged buyouts in the last three years, a lot may be riding on a successful holiday season. Amid a housing slump, high energy prices and growing concern of a possible recession, some highly leveraged companies could face difficulties if consumer confidence ebbs, The Deal.com notes.

headline: Peltz’s Interest in Marsh & McLennan Refuels Deal Chatter
text: News that the activist investor Nelson Peltz and his companies have been cleared by the Federal Trade Commission to buy shares of Marsh & McLennan, the insurance broker, added fuel to speculation that the company might go on the block.

headline: Citadel Said to Eye Centro Stake
text: Centro Properties Group, Australia’s second high-profile victim of a global credit crunch, is attracting interest from the Citadel Investment Group, according to press reports.

headline: Europe Sees More Canceled Offerings Than U.S.
text: The number of postponed and canceled flotations in Europe last year was almost five times higher than in the United States, despite the origins of last summer’s credit crisis and equity market volatility lying in the United States mortgage market.

headline: Weather Channel Said to Seek $5 Billion in Auction
text: The Weather Channel, one of the last privately owned cable channels, is being put up for sale and could fetch more than $5 billion, The New York Times reported.

headline: Digital Single-Lens Reflex Cameras: A Comparison Chart
Commerzbank Replaces 2 U.S. Executives
text: The co-chief of Commerzbank‘s United States business and its New York-based head of credit have exited the bank in the wake of loss-making investments in subprime mortgages.

headline: Wrong-Way Wall Street Predictions
text: For many Wall Street chief executives, the penalty for getting it wrong these days is a cushy exit package. By that logic, David Weidner, the MarketWatch columnist, argues that he should be getting a big windfall for his not-so-prescient predictions for 2007. (One of them was that Wells Fargo and Wachovia would merge.)

headline: Executive Leaves State Street Amid Write-Down
text: State Street, the world’s largest money manager for institutions, said it would post a $279 million charge in the fourth quarter and that the chief executive of its asset-management unit stepped down.

headline: Nokia Siemens Buys Britain’s Apertio for $205 Million
text: Nokia Siemens Networks agreed on Wednesday to pay $205 million to acquire Apertio, a British maker of databases that consolidate mobile and wireline subscriber data on common servers.

headline: S.E.C. May Lift Restrictions on Foreign Trading
text: Stock exchanges outside the United States, including the London Stock Exchange, could provide direct trading access to United States investors through brokers based in the United States for the first time under proposals being prepared by the Securities and Exchange Commission, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Buyout Firms’ True Struggle: Finding the Exit?
text: The collapse of the $1.8 billion buyout of PHH, a mortgage and vehicle leasing company, by the Blackstone Group and General Electric, had industry observers Wednesday lamenting the failed deal as an ominous start to the new year and yet another example of the drastic changes that have torn through the debt markets since the summer of 2007.

headline: Should Merrill Tap BlackRock Stake for Cash?
text: Over the weekend, a report claimed that Merrill Lynch was in fresh talks with Middle East and Asian funds about a new investment on top of the $6.2 billion injection it got from an investor group late last year. That prompted a few financial blogs to offer a different potential solution to Merrill’s financial woes: Sell off a piece of its 49.8 percent stake in BlackRock, the big money management firm.

headline: Court Approves $12.6 Million to Portus Investors
text: Investors in a defunct Canadian hedge fund firm, Portus Alternative Asset Management, are due to get another 12.5 million Canadian dollars ($12.6 million).

headline: A New Twist on Mobile Search: Human Guides
text: The Internet search service ChaCha always seemed like a bit of a throwback. In a Web populated by search services powered by sophisticated algorithms that provide instant answers, ChaCha relied on paid human “guides” to help you find things.

headline: Sun Capital Said to Mull Hostile Bid for Kellwood
text: The private equity firm Sun Capital Partners may be readying a new weapon in its battle to acquire the beleaguered apparel maker Kellwood.

headline: Breeden Raises Stake in Zale
text: Richard Breeden, the former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman-turned-shareholder activist, nearly doubled his stake in Zale, but the struggling middle-market jeweler’s shares are still sinking.

headline: A Lucky Strike for Netflix?
text: Among the many unintended but perfectly predictable consequences of the Hollywood writers’ strike is that without new television episodes to watch, people are beginning to watch more DVDs.

headline: 'In Defense of Food'
text: FOOD SCIENCE'S GOLDEN AGE

headline: Tech Bankers Still Bullish on 2008, Survey Says
text: Technology bankers have enjoyed four consecutive record years of mergers and acquisitions in the tech sector. Even so, most of them say they plan to be even busier in 2008, according to a new survey by The 451 Group, which polled more than 110 bankers from about 70 different firms.

headline: Fees for High-Yield Loans Said to Rise
text: High-yield lenders may have had to write down the value of some of their loans, causing some pain. But Bloomberg News said Thursday they appear to be making some of their money back.

headline: Imperium Renewables Withdraws I.P.O. Plans
text: Imperium Renewables, a biodiesel producer, filed to withdraw its plan for an initial public offering, citing unfavorable market conditions.

headline: Ford Says Tata Leads in Jaguar Bidding
text: Ford Motor said on Thursday that s Tata Motors of India was the front-runner to buy its European brands Jaguar and Land Rover.

headline: Day Dreaming Again
text: In our ongoing quest to help you avoid your responsibilities, we here at the Diner’s Journal offer another set of responses from notable eaters who answered this question for us: If you jump on a plane right now, all expenses paid, where would you go eat? We hope that those of you truly dedicated to blowing off even more of your work day will add your own food travel fantasies.

headline: A Crown of Digital Glory
text: Nikki Finke, who has been called many things, can now add “Media Mensch of the Year,” courtesy of The New York Observer. In part, she was chosen because she has used the Web’s Wild West dynamics so effectively, especially during the writer’s strike.

headline: Plaxo, a Social Network, Said to Be for Sale
text: Plaxo, an early social networking site that helps people keep their address books updated, is up for auction, according to The New York Times. The company, which has not made a profit, is seeking as much as $100 million.

headline: John McCain’s Caucus Speech
text: The following is a transcript of Senator John McCain's address to supporters after the Iowa Caucuses, as provided by Congressional Quarterly via The Associated Press.

headline: As the Globes Turn
text: Party planners hanging by their thumbs! Actors, caught between principles and their own petty egos! Foreign journalists watching their one day in the sun die before their very eyes! Man, this story has it all, including more hairpin turns than a steep canyon switchback.

headline: Atonement = Hillary Clinton?
text: Awards Daily says that “Atonement” may be this year’s movie version of Hillary Clinton: A presumptive favorite that some are having trouble warming up to.

headline: The Neediest Cases | Helping Survivors
text: After reading about the hardships of Holocaust and World War II survivors in Brooklyn, Dr. Robert Ivker was moved to do more than just donate. He got others to join him.

headline: Manhattan Real Estate Isn’t Slowing Down Just Yet
text: Even as the rest of the housing market stagnates, Manhattan’s seems to reach ever-new heights. The average price for an apartment shot up to $1.4 million in the last quarter of 2007, up 17.6 percent from the fourth quarter of 2006, Christine Haughney reports — but average prices were being pushed to record levels mainly because of the increasing number of apartments selling above $10 million.

headline: Fox Hits the Gas
text: On Christmas Day, the Bagger and his extended family took a vote on what movie to watch. The Bagger threw a flag on “P.S. I Love You” because it sounded like the kind of thing that he would have to wear estrogen goggles to get through. Others in the group showed little interest in “Charlie Wilson’s War” even though the Bagger, who has yet to see it, lobbied hard. In the end, “Juno” was the consensus choice, though Mrs. Bagger wondered how Shorty Bagger, age 11, and G.G. Donna, her 83-year-old grandma, would fare. The Bagger assured her that all would be well.

headline: Fusion Ticket, or Late Night Joke?
text: Former Governor Mike Huckabee of Arkansas has had some harsh words for his Republican rival Mitt Romney, but in a night-before-the-caucus appearance on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno Wednesday night, he singled out Senator Barack Obama, a Democrat, for praise.

headline: We Need a Browser for TVs
text: LG’s deal with Netflix to put streaming movies on some LG televisions shows that we are entering the AOL era of Internet television. We are going to see a lot of similar announcements from the Consumer Electronics Show next week as TV makers build walled gardens of hand-picked Internet- delivered video content for their high-end sets that resemble the early online services like AOL, Prodigy and CompuServe. We’ll also see more set-top boxes with their own walled gardens, like Vudu.

headline: Iowa in Perspective
text: Don’t expect their advice to actually be taken, but over the past few weeks several bigwigs of opinionland have urged their colleagues to discount the results of tonight’s Iowa caucuses. In a Dec. 18 Op-Ed in The Times, three prominent Iowans – a former editor of the editorial page of The Des Moines Register, a former director of the Iowa Poll and a former executive secretary of Iowa’s Freedom of Information Council who is now a professor emeritus of journalism at Drake University in Des Moines – urged journalists to demand the Iowa Democratic Party to release the actual vote count among caucus-goers, which is currently “never disclosed to the press or made available for inspection.”

headline: Cellphone Users Slow Traffic
text: Talking on the cellphone while driving isn’t just a safety risk. It also slows down traffic.

headline: Young Man Killed by Tiger Was Quiet One, Witness Says
text: Did a group of young men taunt a Siberian tiger before it escaped from its enclosure at the San Francisco Zoo on Christmas Day and attacked them?

headline: Romney’s Team Assess the G.O.P. Vote
text: DES MOINES — If Republican turnout today is 80,000 or above, Mitt Romney’s campaign could be in trouble, according to Doug Gross, Mr. Romney’s Iowa campaign chairman.

headline: Initial Reaction
text: “Is it just my long-time Giants loyalty speaking, or is anyone else wondering how the moniker ‘L.T.’ was so easily transferred to LaDainian Tomlinson?” Bill Brink writes in this week’s Play newsletter. “Is it as simple as a decree from ‘SportsCenter’ or should the standard be higher — say, like transforming the very way the game is played? That’s what the original L.T., Lawrence Taylor, did when he was terrorizing quarterbacks in the 1980’s. Tomlinson’s superb talent is unquestioned, and he seems sure to eventually join Taylor in the Hall of Fame. But he doesn’t have two Super Bowl rings, hasn’t willed his team to greatness, and most importantly hasn’t fundamentally altered strategy on the other side of the line of scrimmage. Let’s reserve that nickname for their rightful owner!”

headline: Thursday Kickoff: One for Stew
text: How impressive was West Virginia’s dismantling of Oklahoma in the Fiesta Bowl? Well, it apparently got Bill Stewart a job. Dave Hickman of the Charleston Gazette reports that West Virginia will announce today that Stewart is Rich Rodriguez’s successor. ESPN.com’s Pat Forde talked to a source that said if Stewart met certain incentive clauses in his contract, he “could almost make Rod money.” Forde also talked to several players who threw their support behind Stewart being hired as the new head coach. Hickman’s colleague Mitch Vingle takes time to reflect on the Mountaineers’ accomplishment, especially in light of the distractions that surrounded Rodriguez’s departure.

headline: Paying People for the Costs of Climate Control (Part 2)
text: I started off the year writing about a new plan for making deep, sustained cuts in greenhouse-gas emissions while compensating the public for the hit to pocketbooks from higher energy costs. The plan, called “Cap and Dividend,” was conceived by Peter Barnes, an inventor of socially responsible investment funds and author of “Who Owns the Sky?” He says “cap and trade” schemes like the one in the Kyoto Protocol and various climate bills under consideration in Congress do little, if anything, to help the poor and middle class. He also cites problems with a straight tax on carbon content of fuels. (Grist recently explored an earlier iteration of Mr. Barnes’s idea.)

headline: For the Moment | On the Road Again
text: This week’s guest bloggers are Loden Dager, a men’s wear collective based in New York City that launched in the Fall of 2006 and this week won the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award for new talent. Its members, pictured, are: Melissa Vail, Matthew Sandager, Oliver Helden, Paul Marlow, and Alex Galan. This week Loden Dager writes from the road as they journey South in search of inspiration. Today they continue to devour the local influences and junk food. (Read previous blog entries written by Loden Dager and a profile of Alex Galan here.)

headline: A Chilly Candidate for Deal Deathwatch
text: Not that long ago, Wall Street’s favorite parlor game was speculating about the next leveraged buyout target. These days, the guessing has turned to which buyout deal will be the next to die.

headline: Gone So Long We Forgot to Miss You
text: If it weren’t so ridiculous, you’d almost have to admire the quixotic, archaic, almost misanthropic way that college football organizes its postseason, which, after all, is theoretically the most exciting portion of its schedule,” Will Leitch writes in this week’s Play newsletter. “Essentially, college football builds up an avalanche of momentum, then pauses and says, ‘Hey, everybody, let’s take a month off!’ ”

headline: ‘You Can Still Dump the Body in New Jersey’
text: Here’s the bulk of Jay Leno’s monologue Wednesday night, on his return to the air without the help of striking writers: Folks, let’s get right to it. A Jew, a Christian, and a Muslim, walk into a bar. The Jew says to the Muslim … See, I have no idea what they say because there’s a writers’ strike. We don’t know what they say.

headline: Scent Notes | Chloé by Chloé
text: Perfumers are hired to create perfumes by fashion houses, whose “creative teams,” usually a group of marketers, direct the perfumers in making the juices: “a little sweeter, please,” “no, less floral,” “can you boost the wood in the dry-down?” They also make the final call — “It’s this one” — and there’s the perfume. Perfume-making thus functions very much according to the weakest link theory: the scent is only as good as any given team member’s worst decision.

The case has dragged on unsolved since she vanished Oct. 28.

headline: Help Is on the Way for New Jersey Train Problems

But officials hope to have the problems fixed in time for the evening rush; PATH service was restored around noon.

headline: When Movies Don’t Live Up to the Trailer

headline: Goldman Sachs, the Unstoppable Deal Machine
text: The landscape for mergers and buyouts shifted drastically last summer, but one theme remained constant in 2007: If there was a big deal, Goldman Sachs was probably involved. As in previous years, the firm was the top adviser on mergers as measured by dollar volume, both globally and for deals with targets in the United States. It also ranked near the top of the heap as a participant, through its private equity arm, in leveraged buyouts.

headline: Silver Won’t Quit His Second Job
