headline: Is Obama a Plan B for Richardson Voters?
text: Barack Obama’s drive to win tonight’s Iowa caucuses is getting a boost from two of his putative rivals. After earlier winning the support of Dennis Kucinich, Obama’s campaign has reached an agreement with Bill Richardson for the second-choice votes of Richardson supporters in caucuses where the New Mexico governor can’t clear the threshold for competition, according to a senior Obama campaign adviser. The adviser estimated that the deal puts Mr. Obama in position to claim support from roughly half of the 15 percent of Democratic caucus-goers expected to support second-tier candidates.

headline: Hillary and the Frog: An Update
text: DES MOINES — Earlier this week, we reported on Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s fondness for an analogy comparing the dependence of the United States on foreign oil to “boiling a frog.” Her point is that when oil prices are lowered, U.S. consumers and politicians become blasé about becoming more energy self-sufficient ­ just as a frog might be complacent and not realize it is being boiled to death if the water temperature is raised slowly.

headline: Bank of America: We’ve Still Got Soap
text: It’s no secret that Bank of America has been cutting back on its expenses in the wake of its subprime-related losses. But judging from some reports in the week after Christmas, the firm seemed to have become unusually Grinch-like in its efforts.

headline: Who Is Threatening the Pastors?

Mr. Huckabee, a former Southern Baptist minister before he became governor of Arkansas, is banking on heavy turnout from conservative Christians as he battles his rival Mitt Romney’s vastly better financed and organized get-out-the-vote operation.

headline: Live From Des Moines, It’s Caucus Night
text: Goodnight Iowa!  As we shut down for the evening, we’re contemplating the magnitude of Mr. Obama’s win here as well as the challenges for the Clinton campaign. Mr. Edwards is somewhere in the middle. He’s got bragging rights over Mrs. Clinton, even though he beat her by only .28 percent and it’s not clear how much he can build on his showing here. Mrs. Clinton has just five days to prove she is electable; if Mr. Obama beats her in New Hampshire, he will almost certainly win South Carolina. And that makes the Feb. 5 states all the more challenging for her.

headline: Tumultuous Mind, Spread Across Canvas
text: By any standard, the Italian painter Antonio Mancini lived through tumultuous times. He was born in 1852 and died in 1930. In the intervening years Europe experienced the unification of Italy and of Germany, World War I and the rise of communism and fascism.

headline: Manhattan: Former Teacher Charged
text: A former high school teacher was arrested Thursday after school investigators said he had made sexual and harassing comments to several 14-year-old students, including asking one girl out on a date and promising another a good grade if she would “hook him up with someone pretty.” The teacher, Richard Dulberg, 32, who resigned in September, was charged with endangering the welfare of a child, according to Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the city schools. Mr. Dulberg was removed from his position at the School for the Physical City, on East 25th Street, last spring after the investigation began. According to the investigators’ report, released Thursday, Mr. Dulberg denied the allegations. Attempts to reach him at home and through his lawyer were unsuccessful.

headline: Clemens Says Injections Were Not Steroids
text: In a “60 Minutes” interview that will be shown on CBS on Sunday night, the former Yankees pitcher Roger Clemens admits that he received injections from his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee. But he says that the injections were of the painkiller lidocaine and vitamin B12  not steroids or human growth hormone, as McNamee alleged in the Mitchell report released last month.

headline: Minnesota: Boy Dead in Snowbank
text: A 2-year-old New Ulm boy died after crawling out of bed next to his sleeping mother and wandering outside on a frigid night, the authorities and the woman said. The woman, Dara Lenz, found the body of her son, Lucas Boldt, in a snowbank about 10 to 20 feet from her home and called the police, who tried to revive him. The temperature was minus 9 degrees. Ms. Lenz, 26, said she and Lucas went to sleep in her bed at 9:30 p.m. Tuesday, but when she woke up in the morning, he was no longer next to her. He was not in his room, and she raced outside and found him in the snow. It was unclear if the doors had been locked. The police do not suspect foul play, Cmdr. Myron Weiland said.

headline: Kansas Surprises Virginia Tech
text: MIAMI  Instead of their usual blue, the Kansas Jayhawks wore red shirts for the Orange Bowl. And that was not their only surprise during a 24-21 victory over Virginia Tech in what was, finally, a tense and interesting game in this season’s Bowl Championship Series.

headline: Charm City’s Cops and Robbers, Schoolboys and Stevedores
text: SEASON 1 We’re introduced to the theme and the character that will thread through the series: drugs, and the smart, disillusioned, drunk Baltimore homicide detective Jimmy McNulty (Dominic West). McNulty’s anger when a member of the Barksdale drug gang is acquitted of murder charges spurs the creation of what will become the Major Crimes Unit and the introduction of other central law-enforcement characters: Lt. Cedric Daniels (Lance Reddick) and the unit members Kima Greggs (Sonja Sohn), Ellis Carver (Seth Gilliam), Prez Pryzbylewski (Jim True-Frost) and the eccentric Lester Freamon (Clarke Peters). These are the good guys, who, along with McNulty’s partner, Bunk Moreland (Wendell Pierce), and the prosecutor Rhonda Pearlman (Deirdre Lovejoy) do daily battle with crime and with their own bosses at police headquarters and City Hall.

headline: Evolution Book Sees No Science-Religion Gap

text: Michael Goldberg, an abstract painter of the New York School whose vibrant works are in major museums and private collections, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Wednesday about the University of Southern California’s 49-17 victory over Illinois in the Rose Bowl reversed, in some editions, the surnames of two U.S.C. players involved in a scoring play. They are Garrett Green and Desmond Reed.

headline: Steroids Spotlight for a Veteran Bulldog
text: Mike Wallace has been the central figure at “60 Minutes” since its inception in 1968, CBS’s embodiment of the unyielding interrogator. Now he’s 89, working on two stories a year, not 10 or 20 as in the past, in his role as correspondent emeritus.

headline: Nature Abhors a Vacuum, and Politics Abhors Clear Statements
text: Could it be that the one person able to get Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to talk absolutely straight about his political plans is Ryan Seacrest? It doesn’t seem likely, but who knows? In a year when the country may elect its first female, black, Mormon, Arkansas preacher or thrice-married Roman Catholic president, anything is possible.

headline: Under Spagnuolo, Giants Give Grudgingly
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  After the Giants beat the Bills in Buffalo 11 days ago, cornerback R. W. McQuarters went looking for Steve Spagnuolo, the Giants’ defensive coordinator. At first, McQuarters could not find him on the field or in the locker room.

headline: Stage Doors and Rail Stops
text: THE Gettysburg train station, which dates from 1859, is next to the Majestic Theater, and there is a worn path between them. Trains, theaters and traveling shows once went hand in hand.

headline: Bucs Lift Non-Floridian Ticket Ban
text: TAMPA, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Ticketmaster acquiesced to the demands of the New York attorney general on Thursday that fans outside Florida be allowed to buy tickets for Sunday’s wild-card game against the Giants.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: More Than a Coach
text: It's not unusual for high school coaches to play big roles in their players' lives. But Jack O'Brien, the basketball coach at Charlestown High School in Boston, takes it to another level. In "The Assist: Hoops, Hope, and the Game of Their Lives" (Public Affairs, $26), Neil Swidey, a staff writer for the Boston Globe Magazine, uses practically unfettered access to detail the ups and downs of O'Brien's powerhouse program and the coach's fierce dedication to the players.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Arapahoe Basin Grows Wider and a Bit Less Wilder
text: TALL, dark and scary isn’t an easy reputation to live down.

headline: Delay in Shuttle Launching
text: The next effort to launch the space shuttle Atlantis could come as early as Jan. 24, but will probably slip into February as engineers test and repair a suspect fuel sensor connector, a NASA official said. The official, John Shannon, deputy space shuttle program manager, said experts at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Alabama were to test the electrical connector, taken from the Atlantis’s external fuel tank, next week to confirm that it was the source of the problem. Meanwhile, Mr. Shannon said in a telephone news conference from the Johnson Space Center in Houston, technicians at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida will start modifying the shuttle’s tank. NASA postponed two efforts in December to fly the Atlantis and its cargo to the International Space Station and had hoped to try again on Jan. 10.

headline: Drugs Offer No Benefit in Curbing Aggression, Study Finds
text: The drugs most widely used to manage aggressive outbursts in intellectually disabled people are no more effective than dummy pills for most patients and may be less so, researchers are reporting.

headline: Bittersweet Work of Wrapping ‘Wire’
text: CLARK JOHNSON, who plays a crusading newspaper editor in the fifth and last season of “The Wire,” beginning Sunday night on HBO, likes telling autobiographical stories.

headline: Delgado Prepares to Hit; Minaya Is Going to Israel
text: Mets first baseman Carlos Delgado said his rehabilitation from a fractured left hand was on schedule and that he expected to be at full strength when he reports to spring training in six weeks. As Delgado prepared to begin the next phase of his recovery, hitting off a tee, General Manager Omar Minaya was getting ready to depart for an eight-day good-will tour of Israel.

headline: Reports Show Signs of Continued Weakness in the Economy
text: Reports on factory orders and the labor market released Thursday portrayed an economy that is skirting recession as attention shifts to government figures on employment to be released Friday.

headline: U.S. Curtailing Bids to Expand Medicaid Rolls
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration is imposing restrictions on the ability of states to expand eligibility for Medicaid, in an effort to prevent them from offering coverage to families of modest incomes who, the administration argues, may have access to private health insurance.

headline: Two Dreams (One Big, One Tiny) Come True
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Once a week before drifting off to sleep, David Garrard, the Jaguars’ even-keeled quarterback, uncorks his giddiness. He’ll turn to his wife, Mary, in bed and whisper: “Can you believe the kind of season we’re having? Can you believe the kind of season I’m having?” This is what it is like to wake up every morning to a cotton-candy dream that feels as if it is being spun fresh every Sunday.

headline: A Firefighter Is Killed in a Brooklyn Blaze
text: A fire lieutenant died Thursday evening fighting a smoky and blinding fire that enveloped a high-rise apartment building in Brooklyn at the site of the former Ebbets Field, city officials said.

headline: Race Upended, Candidates Sprint Toward Tuesday Vote
text: NASHUA, N.H.  A smaller field of presidential candidates arrived in New Hampshire Friday facing a dramatically upended campaign after two one-time insurgents  Senator Barack Obama, an Illinois Democrat, and Mike Huckabee, the Arkansas Republican  won the Iowa caucuses Thursday night.

headline: Idaho: Furor Over Funeral Home
text: Several older residents of Coeur d’Alene are protesting plans for a funeral home across the street from a center for the elderly, saying it would be a little too close for comfort. About 100 people have signed a petition calling on the City Council to deny a special-use permit for Aspen Funeral Home LLC, the center manager, Vickie Harrison, said. They plan to present the petition Feb. 5, she said. The city’s planning commission approved a special-use permit in December, but a neighbor appealed the decision. Ms. Hansen said the building had been chosen because it suited the business’s needs. Doy Seng, 81, had a practical view of the proposed funeral home. “We’re old here; we’re all ready to go,” Ms. Seng said. “I think it will be handy.”

headline: Gerald Astor, 81, Writer on Americans in Combat, Dies
text: Gerald Astor, an author and journalist who drew on the remembrances of combat veterans in his books recounting epic battles of World War II, died Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 81.

headline: What Did Pitcher Know and When Didn’t He Know It?
text: Roger Clemens keeps inching closer to Barry Bonds territory. By acknowledging that he took injections from his highly personal trainer, Clemens has lost some of the control he likes to impose on every aspect of his life and image.

headline: Bloomberg Will Limit Parking Perk
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, taking aim at one of the most treasured perks of city employees, announced Thursday that he would reduce by 20 percent the number of parking permits issued to city employees.

headline: Blige Tops Last Week, but Groban Takes the Year
text: In the final week of 2007, Mary J. Blige’s “Growing Pains” (Geffen) took the top spot on the Billboard chart from Josh Groban’s “Noël” (Reprise), which had five straight weeks at No. 1 and was the best-selling record of the year. “Growing Pains,” in its second week out, sold 205,000 copies, Nielsen SoundScan reported, and Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J) sold 193,000, climbing one spot to No. 2. “Noël” sold 178,000 last week; released in October, it has sold 3.7 million copies. With no major albums released last week, Chris Brown’s “Exclusive” (Jive) jumped five spots to No. 5, and Colbie Caillat rose seven to No. 10 with “Coco.” Keyshia Cole’s “Just Like You” (Geffen) climbed 15 spots to No. 16, and Robert Plant and Alison Krauss’s “Raising Sand” (Rounder), popular on critics’ year-end lists, rose five to No. 18.

headline: Milwaukee Arts in Transition
text: Edo de Waart has been appointed the next music director of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra as the unanimous choice of a 10-member search committee composed of an equal number of musicians and board members. This season and next he will serve as music director designate, and beginning with the 2009-10 season, when he will conduct a minimum of 12 weeks, he will assume responsibility for the artistic thrust of the ensemble. He succeeds Andreas Delfs, who will have the title of conductor laureate in the 2009-10 season. Mr. de Waart is the chief conductor and artistic director of the Hong Kong Philharmonic and chief conductor of the Santa Fe Opera. ... Daniel T. Keegan has been named to succeed David Gordon as director of the Milwaukee Art Museum. Since 2000 Mr. Keegan has been the executive director of the San Jose Museum of Art in California.

headline: Knicks Stuck in a Loop of Defeat and Despair
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  As the television cameras panned the Knicks’ bench in search of vital signs late Wednesday night, one stubbornly optimistic face stood out in a sea of dour expressions. Malik Rose, on the fringe of the rotation but still vital for all of the right reasons, was urging aggression over passivity, belief over doubt, as he addressed his bedraggled teammates.

headline: For Happy Warrior of Political Coverage, Another Joyous Night
text: If Tim Russert of NBC News is the New Hampshire primary of political pundits  crucial, serious and august  then his colleague Chris Matthews, intense, voluble and unavoidable, is the Iowa caucuses. And it takes one to cover one, as Mr. Matthews demonstrated with his coverage Thursday night on MSNBC.

headline: In War and Peace, in Silver and Gold
text: Tibetan Buddhism, represented by the peace-loving Dalai Lama, is not normally seen as a religion that advocates violence. Earlier generations of followers, however, defended the road to enlightenment with armed horsemen.

headline: Brooklyn Infant Is Killed by Family’s Dog
text: An 8-month-old Brooklyn boy was mauled to death by his family’s Doberman pinscher on Thursday as the boy played on the floor of his apartment, the police said.

headline: For Some Kenyan Villagers, the Action Is in Des Moines
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The postelection mayhem consuming Nairobi and other parts of Kenya has not struck Nyangoma-Kogelo, the western village of tin shacks where some residents also kept an eye on the results of another vote, the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Tata Pulls Ford Units Into Its Orbit
text: LONDON  When Ratan Tata visited the home of the designer Ralph Lauren last autumn, the two auto enthusiasts spent much of their time in the garage, admiring Mr. Lauren’s extensive car collection, including the Batmobile-esque 1955 Jaguar XKD.

headline: Bhutto’s Deadly Legacy
text: New Delhi

headline: New Year’s With the Horses
text: To the Editor:

headline: Shiite Praises Anti-Insurgent Militias
text: BAGHDAD  The leader of Iraq’s most influential Shiite party offered surprisingly conciliatory remarks on Thursday about the former insurgents and other Sunnis who have banded together into militias to work with American forces, stating that the groups had helped improve security and should be continued.

headline: Initial Reaction
text: Is it just my long-time Giants loyalty speaking, or is anyone else wondering how the nickname "L.T." was so easily transferred to LaDainian Tomlinson? Is it as simple as a decree from "SportsCenter" or should the standard be higher -- say, like transforming the very way the game is played? That's what the original L.T., Lawrence Taylor, did when he was terrorizing quarterbacks in the 1980s and early 1990s. Tomlinson's superb talent is unquestioned, and he seems sure to eventually join Taylor in the Hall of Fame. But he doesn't have two Super Bowl rings, hasn't willed his team to greatness, and most importantly hasn't fundamentally altered strategy on the other side of the line of scrimmage. Let's reserve that nickname for its rightful owner.

headline: Judge Denies Bail to Men Accused of Plot Against Fort Dix
text: CAMDEN, N.J.  A federal judge on Thursday denied bail to the five men accused of plotting to attack the Fort Dix military base, saying they would have ample access to evidence to prepare their defense while incarcerated.

headline: Let It Start Now
text: The candidates have spent a year and tens of millions of dollars in Iowa, and Thursday night the first actual voters offered their first assessments. Some candidates and their strategists were hoping the caucuses and the New Hampshire primary next week would settle the race, weeding out the contenders for the two major parties’ presidential nominations. Watching the campaign in cold, snowy and mostly empty Iowa, we were hoping for something else  that this year’s Iowa-New Hampshire rush to judgment will be the last.

headline: Iowa Results Lead Dodd and Biden to Quit Race
text: Two Democratic senators from the Northeast  Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware  became the first casualties of the Iowa caucuses on Thursday night. After both failed to get a single percentage point, they issued statements saying they would drop out of the race.

headline: Law Summons Viewers
text: The 18th season of NBC’s “Law & Order” proved the show can still be a ratings force as its two-hour debut attracted Wednesday night’s largest audience, 13.4 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. NBC won the night over all in total viewers, leading the 8 o’clock hour preceding “Law & Order” with its game show “Deal or No Deal” (12.2 million). Among adults 18 to 49, however, NBC ranked third, trailing just behind ABC and more distantly behind Fox, which led over all in that age group with its Fiesta Bowl college football coverage. ABC got a boost from season premieres of “Wife Swap” at 8 (8.5 million) and “Supernanny” at 9 (8.9 million), followed by a second episode of “Supernanny” at 10 (9.1 million). CBS finished fourth over all with repeats after the second-season start for “Power of 10” at 8 (6.7 million).

headline: Cameron Is Fired by Dolphins
text: Bill Parcells cleaned the Miami Dolphins’ house Thursday morning, firing the first-year head coach Cam Cameron and 16 of his assistants, leaving only two members from the coaching staff that led the Dolphins to a 1-15 season.

headline: Boy and Girl Meet Beasts, Armadillo to Zany Zebra
text: The phrase “based on the book by” may have never been stretched so far.

headline: Teaching the Arts in City Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gone So Long We Forgot to Miss You
text: If it weren't so ridiculous, you'd almost have to admire the quixotic, archaic, almost misanthropic way that college football organizes its postseason, which, after all, is theoretically the most exciting portion of its schedule. Essentially, college football builds up an avalanche of momentum, then pauses and says, "Hey, everybody, let's take a month off!"

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,893 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: West Virginia Pulls Another Shocker and Hires Stewart
text: The West Virginia coaching search had every element of a melodrama. There was meddling from the state’s governor, big-money boosters bickering with the administration and volumes of vitriol directed at the departed football coach and his family. And just when it appeared that the search could be starting over, West Virginia added one more twist  a surprise ending.

headline: Lush Movement to Break Winter’s Spell
text: Snowflakes fell in New York on Wednesday, but none onstage at Lincoln Center. New York City Ballet had closed its annual season of George Balanchine’s “Nutcracker” with a particularly bright performance on Sunday. On Wednesday it opened its eight-week winter repertory season with an account of Balanchine’s “Jewels.” “The Nutcracker” is narrative; “Jewels” has its place in history as “the first abstract full-evening ballet” (as it was billed when new in 1967). Both ballets serve as ideal introductions to what dance theater has to offer; and both are classics that repay innumerable rewatchings.

headline: United Arab Emirates: Link to U.S. Dollar Kept
text: The United Arab Emirates will keep a 30-year link between its currency, the dirham, and the United States dollar, after completing a review of its currency regime, said the central bank governor, Sultan bin Nasser al-Suwaidi, left. “In 12 months I can say to you that the U.A.E. will maintain the peg,” Mr. Suwaidi said. “We have come to the conclusion that the inflation problem does not lie with the peg against the U.S. dollar.” The dirham is fixed to the dollar at 3.6725. “We were studying the causes of inflation, and we came to the conclusion that the causes are not in the dirham/U.S. dollar peg, therefore we need not do anything on that front,” Mr. Suwaidi said.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Spain: Inflation Rate Is Highest in 10 Years
text: Led by higher food and energy costs, inflation in Spain accelerated to the fastest rate in more than a decade in December even after economic growth slowed. The inflation rate rose to 4.3 percent, the highest since the European-standard index was introduced in 1997, the Labor Ministry said. Prices jumped even with unemployment rising for a third month, as a softening real estate market led to a 13 percent increase in benefit claims by construction workers, a separate report showed.

headline: Mexico: President’s Cousin Briefly Abducted
text: A cousin of President Felipe Calderón was abducted at gunpoint, beaten and held for four hours on Wednesday in Morelia, in Michoacán State, newspapers reported. It was unclear if the kidnapping of Alfonso Reyes, who owns a foreign-exchange business, was connected to Mr. Calderón’s offensive against organized crime.

headline: In Grace Notes, Linear Riffs on Reality
text: “A Drawing is the correct title for my work,” the artist Stuart Davis wrote in a 1954 notebook. He meant the correct title for all his work, including the high-color, post-Cubist, proto-Pop paintings that have made him a revered presence in the American modernist pantheon.

headline: Buckeyes Look to Correct Past Mistakes
text: NEW ORLEANS  Of all the enduring lessons and endless perceptions that came out of Florida’s blowout victory against Ohio State in the national title game last season, Ohio State offensive tackle Kirk Barton might have summed it up most succinctly.

headline: Theater Listings
text: O’NEILL FESTIVAL AT 10 When Eugene O’Neill was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1936 (he is the only American playwright who has been so honored), his speech, delivered in absentia because of health problems, acknowledged a debt to August Strindberg, whom O’Neill called “that greatest genius of all modern dramatists.” Many playwrights today would say the same about O’Neill, who wrote with grim candor about his own family and, somehow, a bit about everyone else’s at the same time.

headline: How to Assess Trade
text: To the Editor:

headline: 2 Newcomers Jolt Parties’ Status Quo
text: DES MOINES  The Democratic and Republican establishments and their presidential candidates, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former Gov. Mitt Romney, were brought low in Iowa on Thursday night, shaken seriously by two national newcomers who won decisively on messages of insurgency and change.

headline: Embracing the Cold in a Genteel Place
text: DAVID BARRELL and his wife, Brenda, have nothing against palm trees, white sand beaches and balmy days. But when the time came seven years ago to put a down payment on a vacation getaway, they chose Magog, Quebec  a ski resort 135 miles north of their year-round home in Quechee, Vt.

headline: Life, Love and the Pleasures of Literature in Barsetshire
text: The weather has been cold, the snow deep, the long, dark evenings perfect for holing up with a book. In the past few weeks, I’ve read nine of Angela Thirkell’s Barsetshire novels. I expect to keep going right through all 29 of them, and when I’m done I may start over again. This is a confession of sorts. When I first came upon Thirkell, nearly 30 years ago, she seemed like a diverting minor writer. Minor now seems too slight a word to me for the purveyor of such major pleasures.

headline: Dealing With the Dragon
text: On both Wednesday and Thursday, the price of oil briefly hit $100 a barrel. The new record made headlines, as well it should have. But what does it mean, aside from the obvious point that the economy is under extra pressure?

headline: Lacey Township: Environmental Approval for Nuclear Plant
text: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station received approval from New Jersey environmental officials on Thursday for the plant’s continued operation. The approval was the last major hurdle before the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission votes on whether to extend the plant’s license for 20 years. The State Department of Environmental Protection approved the plant’s coastal land use plans for the next 20 years. The owner, the AmerGen Energy Company, agreed to restore some nearby wetlands and oyster beds and to maintain a recreation area near the nuclear plant. The commission could vote on the extension as soon as Jan. 22.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Al Jazeera No Longer Nips at Saudis
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  When a Saudi court sentenced a young woman to 200 lashes in November after she pressed charges against seven men who had raped her, the case provoked outrage and headlines around the world, including in the Middle East.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Dec. 25 about the information storage capacity of individual neurons referred imprecisely to the process by which brain cells communicate with one another. Although a cell does fire a chemical burst across a space called the synapse to stimulate the hairlike spines on the receiving cell, the part of the cell that sends the burst is called an axonal ending, not a spine.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article in some editions on Monday about running back Thomas Jones’s solid performance in the Jets’ 13-10 overtime victory against Kansas City misspelled the surname of the Chiefs player who stopped Jones on a fourth-down play in the third quarter. He is Tamba Hali, not Ali.

headline: New Face and a Call for Change Shake Up the Democratic Field
text: DES MOINES   They rolled the dice.

headline: Bronx: Lehman Principal Leaving
text: The veteran principal of Herbert H. Lehman High School has agreed to step down at the end of the school year, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said on Thursday, after investigators found that two of his assistant football coaches had for years been paid overtime wages for time spent at home. The principal, Robert Leder, said he had agreed to retire after 29 years in his post only after Education Department officials said he would otherwise be removed from the school midyear, pending a further inquiry into the payments. According to a report by the special investigation commissioner for the schools, Mr. Leder said that he had approved the off-campus overtime payments, explaining that the assistant coaches were “always working.” But in a telephone interview, Mr. Leder said the report had mischaracterized his statements. He said he had been unaware of the improper payments until the investigation started. June Pinto, president of Lehman’s Parent Association, said her group would continue to press Mr. Leder’s case with various elected officials. “He’s an excellent principal,” she said. “We’re hoping that somebody will be able to help us keep him.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A Sports of The Times column on Sunday about the writer’s travels in covering sports in 2007 misidentified the team that defeated the Mets on the final day of baseball’s regular season. It was Florida, not Washington.

headline: Tata Pulls Ford Units Into Its Orbit
text: LONDON  When Ratan Tata visited the home of the designer Ralph Lauren last autumn, the two auto enthusiasts spent much of the time in the garage, admiring Mr. Lauren’s car collection, including the Batmobile-esque 1955 Jaguar XKD.

headline:
Kenyan Riot Police Turn 
Back Rallying Protesters
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Nairobi degenerated into violence again on Thursday, as riot police officers used tear gas, batons and water cannons to push back thousands of opposition supporters who poured into the streets to answer a call for a million-person rally that had been banned by the government.

headline: Bert Bolin, 82, Is Dead; Led U.N. Climate Panel
text: Bert Bolin, a pioneering climatologist and the first chairman of the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which shared the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize with former Vice President Al Gore for their warnings about global warming, died Sunday in Stockholm. He was 82.

headline: Newark: Some Progress at Medical School
text: New Jersey’s state medical school has improved its accounting and billing practices in the two years it has been under federal supervision, but still lacks the ability to investigate fraud allegations aggressively, according to a monitor’s final report, released Thursday. The school, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, has been under supervision since 2005, after revelations that school officials had been overbilling Medicare by tens of millions of dollars, giving hundreds of millions of no-bid contracts to politically connected vendors and offering jobs based on patronage. The monitor, Herbert Stern, said in his report that those practices have stopped and that the school “can now conduct its business honestly and legally,” but urged the university to correct problems in its office of compliance and ethics. Anna Farneski, a university spokeswoman, said it was developing more robust internal monitoring procedures.

headline: Jury Sides With Hospital and Doctor in ’02 Suicide
text: STAMFORD, Conn.  Six years after a chronically suicidal woman hanged herself in her hospital room, a Superior Court jury here ruled Thursday that the psychiatric hospital and a doctor who treated her were not responsible for her death.

headline: The Power of Immigration to Divide
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Iowa, Challenges Lie Ahead for Obama
text: DES MOINES  As he accepted his victory in the Iowa caucuses Thursday night, Senator Barack Obama presented his presidential candidacy as a vessel to wipe away partisan divisions, transcend the boundaries of race and “build a coalition for change that stretches through red states and blue states.”

headline: Panel’s Inquiry on Spitzer Aide May Go On
text: ALBANY  The State Commission on Public Integrity can continue, for now, to gather evidence related to Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s former communications director, Darren Dopp, while a separate criminal investigation proceeds, a state judge ruled on Thursday.

headline: Obama Takes Iowa in a Big Turnout as Clinton Falters; Huckabee Victor
text: DES MOINES  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, a first-term Democratic senator trying to become the nation’s first African-American president, rolled to victory in the Iowa caucuses on Thursday night, lifted by a record turnout of voters who embraced his promise of change.

headline: New Faces Make Most of a Moment in the Sun
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii  Most years, the golfers on the leader board at the $5.5 million Mercedes-Benz Championship, the PGA Tour’s annual opening event for winners only, do not require an introduction. This year  with a dozen first-time winners in the field of 31 and the world’s Nos. 1 and 2 players taking a pass  is an exception.

headline: Albany: Birds Killed by Virus
text: A virus killed hundreds of crows across the state in the last week, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation. Officials said concentrations of dead crows were spotted in Orange, Dutchess, Albany, Jefferson, Montgomery and Steuben Counties. Ward Stone, a state wildlife pathologist, said the strain of avian “reovirus” attacks the birds’ intestinal system and is spread through fecal matter. Winter facilitates the spread, with crows gathering in large roosts. The strain is not likely to be contracted by humans, he said.

headline: Letterman Kvetches, Leno Gets By
text: The writers’ strike has upset the natural order of television, and that topsy-turviness was not set right with the return of late-night talk shows this week.

headline: Binghamton: I.B.M. Sued Over Dumping
text: Lawyers representing nearly 1,000 upstate residents filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court here on Thursday charging I.B.M. with dumping industrial solvents that have contaminated hundreds of homes and businesses over several decades in and around the Broome County village of Endicott. I.B.M. manufactured a range of products, including typewriters and computers, in Endicott from 1924 until 2002. The company discharged millions of gallons of trichlorethylene and other solvents that, over time, formed an underground plume of hazardous chemicals. In 1979, it was discovered that vapors from the chemicals were seeping into homes in Endicott and the neighboring town of Union. Michael Maloney, a company spokesman, said I.B.M. began to address the problem in late 2002, and so far has installed vapor remediation systems in more than 440 properties. The lawsuit claims that residents face higher rates of kidney cancer and other diseases while also suffering losses in the value of their properties.

headline: Open Your Door and You’re on the Lift
text: SKI in with an offer; ski out with a bargain?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sean Penn to Lead Cannes Jury
text: Sean Penn, winner of an Academy Award as an actor and recipient of praise as a director, was named on Thursday the president of the jury of the 61st Cannes Film Festival, Reuters reported. The appointment of Mr. Penn, who is also known for blunt criticism of President Bush and the United States-led invasion of Iraq, injects an element of politics into the festival. In 2004 it awarded its top prize, the Palme d’Or, to “Fahrenheit 9/11,” Michael Moore’s critique of Bush administration policies. Mr. Penn won the 2004 best-actor Oscar for his portrayal of an ex-convict tortured by his daughter’s murder in “Mystic River.” He is the director of “Into the Wild,” which led the field with four Screen Actors Guild Award nominations when the guild announced them last month. The Cannes festival will run from May 14 to 25.

headline: Padilla Sues Ex-Government Lawyer
text: Jose Padilla, the American citizen who was held in military detention for more than three years as an enemy combatant, filed a lawsuit Friday against a former Justice Department lawyer who helped provide the legal justifications for what the suit says was Mr. Padilla’s unconstitutional confinement and “gross physical and psychological abuse.”

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Promised Reforms
text: King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia did the right thing when he pardoned the “Qatif girl.” The perfect injustice of the case, in which a young woman was gang raped and then sentenced to 200 lashes for being alone in a car with a man to whom she was not married, left him no choice. Now another ugly face of Saudi justice has been revealed, one that cannot be explained by religion, ancient tradition or culture. The detention last month of an outspoken blogger, Fouad al-Farhan  only confirmed by the Interior Ministry this week  is an act of thoroughly modern despotism and one the king should immediately overrule.

headline: Merck Makes Deal to Develop Schizophrenia Drug
text: Merck & Company agreed on Thursday to pay a Swiss company, Addex Pharmaceuticals, as much as $702 million to help develop a new schizophrenia drug.

headline: Eager South Koreans Tour a Semi-Open City in the North
text: KAESONG, North Korea  Under the gaze of a bronze statue of Kim Il-sung standing atop a hill, a convoy of 11 buses packed with South Koreans wound its way through this quiet city center in North Korea, which was opened up to daily tours early in December and is now suddenly host to hundreds of mostly South Korean tourists seven days a week.

headline: Art in Review
text: ALBERTO BURRI

headline: CBS Takes a Tighter Hold of CSTV
text: CBS Sports took a firmer grip on CSTV, the college sports media company it acquired in late 2005, by announcing Thursday that it was taking over day-to-day control of it from the last of its three founders, Brian Bedol, who will soon leave CBS.

headline: Broadway Actor Pleads Guilty to Backstage Sex Act With Girl, 15, in 2001
text: A Broadway actor admitted on Thursday that in 2001 he seduced a 15-year-old girl who visited him backstage, and agreed as part of a plea bargain to reveal that admission to anybody he works for in film, television or theater for up to the next three years.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill 9 in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces operating in Gaza killed at least nine Palestinians on Thursday and blew up the houses of some known militant commanders, as the Palestinians fired a Katyusha rocket from Gaza that landed in northern Ashkelon, a city of 120,000 people.

headline: PATH Riders May Get Slight Break on Fare Rise
text: Bridge and tunnel commuters will see expected increases in fares, while those taking PATH trains may get a little bit of a break after the Port Authority votes on proposals on Friday, according to an agency official.

headline: Railroad Pays Fines
text: The CSX Corporation, the third-largest American railroad by sales, paid $349,265 in fines for violating federal rail-safety violations, government railroad regulators said. The Federal Railroad Administration investigated safety on CSX’s rail network, which spans the eastern half of the United States, after a series of accidents. CSX is based in Jacksonville, Fla. The Union Pacific Corporation and the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation are the two largest American railroads by sales.

headline: The Tragic Sublime and Concrete Rubble
text: NORTH ADAMS, Mass.  To its proud owners it was a great work of art. To the Historic District Commission of Fairfield, Conn., it was a broken down concrete wall and it had to go. The courts sided with the commission, so the 82-foot-long, 42-ton concrete sculpture by the internationally celebrated German artist Anselm Kiefer no longer occupies the lawn in front of Andrew and Christine Hall’s 19th-century Greek Revival mansion, where it had resided from August 2003 until late this summer. Now on extended loan to the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art here, it is the centerpiece of an exhibition that includes six gigantic Kiefer paintings, also owned by the Halls.

headline: Few Viewers for Infancy of Fox Business
text: How many people are watching the new Fox Business Network?

headline: Even Trucks Hit the Wall in an Erratic 2007
text: DETROIT  They may be built like a rock, be able to haul boulders and hail from deep in the heart of Texas. But pickup tricks cannot stand up to tough economic times.

headline: One Tough Dame Tells Heartfelt Tales
text: Take away the sets, the costumes, the props, the special effects: It all comes down to storytelling. The ground-level reality of show-business magic is the ability to spin a spellbinding yarn anytime, anywhere. Elaine Stritch has it at her fingertips.

headline: At Huckabee Central, Cheers for Evangelical Base
text: DES MOINES  Just as the Republican caucuses began on Thursday at 6:30 p.m., a small group of women and children joined hands in the middle of the ballroom at Mike Huckabee’s headquarters here and began to pray for his election.

headline: Weak Job Growth Numbers Prompt Stock Selloff
text: The unemployment rate surged to 5 percent in December as the nation added only 18,000 jobs, the smallest monthly increase in four years, the Labor Department reported on Friday. Investors responded by sending the stock market down sharply.

headline: The Auction Block Is the Next Stop for a Well-Traveled Lady
text: In 1994 a young antiques dealer living in Gothenburg, Sweden, bought a dusty, life-size carved-wood sculpture of a woman from a local farmer. The farmer told him that it had once been used as a scarecrow but that it had scared people as well as birds, so one of his ancestors had stuck it in a barn, where it had remained, undisturbed, for a century.

headline: Back at the Zoo, With Sadness for All Casualties
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The giraffes were aloof, the penguins were show-offs and the rhinoceros refused to wake up. But among the human visitors on Thursday at the San Francisco Zoo  as it reopened a little over a week after a tiger escaped and mauled three visitors, killing one  a lingering and conflicted sadness seemed to be a common emotion.

headline: Parent of Dating Sites Looks for a Match
text: Wanted: Single dot-com Yenta seeks ambitious Mr. Big with deep pockets for a long-term relationship.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Cases column in Science Times on Tuesday, about a doctor’s decision to apologize to a patient for a medical error, misstated the number of states that have enacted legislation encouraging such apologies. It is 29, not 17.

headline: After Iowans Vote, Others Step in to Comment
text: Mike Huckabee’s win was Mitt Romney’s loss; Barack Obama’s decisive victory was the official end of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s inevitable march, and Fred D. Thompson’s (narrow) third-place finish could save him from the crowded mausoleum of dead campaigns past for which he was supposedly destined.

headline: The Two Earthquakes
text: Ottumwa, Iowa

headline: With Few Options, Colorado Considers All-Mail Vote
text: DENVER  Colorado’s crash course in how to hold an election has begun.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Findings column in Science Times on Tuesday, about the way severe weather is tied to predictions of global warming, gave an outdated academic affiliation for Timur Kuran. He is a professor of economics and political science at Duke University; he is no longer a professor of economics and law at the University of Southern California.

headline: Early Warriors in the Fight for Racial Equality
text: “In the three decades that followed World War I, black Southerners and their allies relentlessly battled Jim Crow,” Glenda Elizabeth Gilmore writes at the outset of this rich but sprawling book. Ms. Gilmore, a professor of history at Yale, wants her “collective biography of activist black and white Southerners” from that era to illuminate how resistance to the South’s elaborate system of racial segregation, often nicknamed Jim Crow after a 19th-century minstrel song, long predated the onset of traditionally celebrated civil-rights initiatives in 1954-55.

headline: School Commendations Come With a Critique
text: It was supposed to be a day to celebrate the city’s best schools. The schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein, trekked to Public School 46 in Bayside, Queens, to announce that the schools that had received the highest marks on the city’s new school report card were to receive a windfall of extra money.

headline: Another Record Year for Orders at Boeing
text: Boeing said late Thursday that it had received orders for 1,413 commercial jets last year, setting a third consecutive annual record driven by demand from Asian and Middle Eastern airlines.

headline: Frightful Weather? Pack Your Tent.
text: “Yes, it is colder, windier. But the air is crisper, the views clearer, the animal tracks easier to see,” Dave Caldwell writes in The Times tomorrow. “So, it is the perfect time to go camping, right?” Read about five ideal spots in the Northeast for the hardy lover of snow and cold.

headline: Free in Parents’ Murders, and Weighing Future in Law
text: In the first few days after winning his freedom, Martin H. Tankleff  who was sent to prison 17 years ago for two murders he insists he never committed  relished the things that were little more than routine to him half a lifetime ago.

headline: Where Others Saw a Big Old Barn, They Saw a Home
text: DEREK AND MICHELLE SANDERS had been hunting for a vacation place for several months when they heard about a property in Roxbury, N.Y., three hours north of Manhattan, and drove out on a wintry day in 2002 to have a look. Rounding a scenic ridge, they caught sight of it  a rambling old Dutch-style barn nestled in the valley below.

headline: Camping Under a Mantle of Snow
text: THE great outdoors beckons, even in the dead of winter.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article in some editions on Monday about running back Thomas Jones’s solid performance in the Jets’ 13-10 overtime victory against Kansas City misspelled the surname of the Chiefs player who stopped Jones on a fourth-down play in the third quarter. He is Tamba Hali, not Ali. (Go to Article)

headline: High School Coach Earns Army Award
text: For 30 years, Roger Barta has been a football coach in tiny Smith Center, Kan.  one good enough to win seven high school championships. On Thursday, his success was recognized far beyond the plains when the U.S. Army All-American Bowl Selection Committee named him the national coach of the year.

headline: Pennsylvania Road Show
text: THE ghost light stood guard over the empty stage of the Fulton Opera House in Lancaster, Pa. The harsh light from its bare bulb spilled out over the red velvet seats of the dimly lighted auditorium and here and there caught ornate details on columns, plaster moldings and the faces of the cherubs on the box seats to either side of the stage.

headline: State Street Corp. Is Sued Over Pension Fund Losses
text: The State Street Corporation, which manages $2 trillion for pension funds and other institutions, ousted a senior executive on Thursday and said it would set aside $618 million to cover legal claims stemming from investments tied to mortgage securities.

headline: Finalists Named for Hugo Boss Prize
text: FINALISTS NAMED

headline: Ex-Goldman Associate Sentenced to More Than 4 Years for Inside Trades
text: A former Goldman Sachs associate who was accused of masterminding one of the broadest insider-trading conspiracies in years was sentenced on Thursday to nearly five years in prison.

headline: Law & Order, London-Style?
text: Britain could soon hear the sound, familiar to “Law & Order” fans, of “dun-dun.” NBC Universal is close to signing a pact with a British production company to create a version of the long-running New York drama that would be set in London. Kudos Film and Television intends to produce the series for the British network ITV. Stephen Garrett, a managing director of Kudos, said he was in advanced talks to license the rights to the series. Variations of “Law & Order” are already produced in Russia and France, but the British show would be the first foreign English-language version of the NBC original. If a deal is signed, Kudos will start production in the summer, Mr. Garrett said.

headline: Musharraf Says Bhutto Took Excessive Risks
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Pervez Musharraf on Thursday rejected any suggestion that he or any members of the Pakistani military or intelligence agencies played a role in the assassination of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, and said it was probably carried out by the same extremists responsible for a number of suicide bombings in recent months.

headline: Change at Westport Playhouse
text: Joanne Woodward and Anne Keefe have returned as co-artistic directors of the Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut. An announcement said they would be interim leaders, succeeding Tazewell Thompson, whose departure after two years was attributed to “artistic and professional differences” by Elisabeth Morten, the president of the Playhouse board. The announcement said that as a result of the change, the 2008 roster of productions would be altered.

headline: Payroll Is at Heart of Santana Debate
text: Perhaps the most significant story in a busy Yankees off-season has been the emergence of Hank Steinbrenner at the top of the team’s hierarchy. Steinbrenner, the senior vice president, has been outspoken on potential player moves, but he cannot and has not acted unilaterally.

headline: China: Restrictions on Web Video and Audio
text: China will allow only state-run Web sites to broadcast video or radio through the Internet, tightening the government’s regulatory grip over the media content offered there. Starting Jan. 31, Internet broadcasting license applicants must be government-run entities, China’s State Administration of Radio, Film and Television said Dec. 29 in a statement posted on its Web site. Operators will be banned from offering content that promotes sex, violence, gambling or religious cults or divulges state secrets, it said. “Internet video and audio providers must be resolute in the service of the socialist ideal and of the people, and regard the interest of overall society as the top priority,” according to a statement from the agency, which will supervise Web video and radio services.

headline: Bomb Blast Kills 5 in Kurdish Area in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL  A bomb exploded near a shopping mall in the largely Kurdish city of Diyarbakir in southeastern Turkey on Thursday, killing five people and wounding more than 60, in the largest attack on a Turkish city in months, the authorities said.

headline: One Filmmaker’s Vivid Tales of Fathers and Other Strangers
Books to Browse or to Savor
text: READING is part of getting away for many people, whether it’s packing a couple of paperbacks for a Caribbean vacation or browsing the bookshelf on a rainy Saturday at a friend’s country house. Indeed, built-in bookshelves and rooms called libraries are common amenities in vacation-home properties.

headline: 15th Dallas County Inmate Since ’01 Is Freed by DNA
text: HOUSTON  After nearly 27 years in prison for a rape he did not commit, Charles Chatman walked free on Thursday, the 15th wrongfully convicted prisoner in Dallas County to be exonerated by DNA testing since 2001.

headline: Manhattan: Man Sentenced for Fatal Crash
text: A man who said he mistook a bike path for the West Side Highway and fatally struck a cyclist while driving drunk in 2006 was sentenced Thursday in State Supreme Court to 3 ½ to 10 ½ years in prison. The man, Eugenio Cidron, 28, of Queens, pleaded guilty in November to second-degree manslaughter, admitting he hit the cyclist, Eric Ng, 22. Officials said Mr. Cidron’s blood alcohol level was twice the legal limit.

headline: Strikers Complain as Leno Dominates Late-Night
text: Jay Leno made a triumphant return to late-night television Wednesday night, easily dominating the ratings competition over his chief rival, David Letterman, and delivering a traditional full-length monologue  even though he was performing without his team of 19 writers.

headline: Manhattan: Nominee for City Clerk
text: City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn on Thursday nominated Hector L. Diaz, the longtime Bronx County clerk and a former assemblyman, to fill the open position of city clerk. The $175,000-a-year post was vacated in July, when Victor Robles stepped down. Mr. Diaz’s appointment requires the approval of the full Council. Mr. Diaz, 63, was the choice of Jose Rivera, chairman of the Bronx Democratic Party, whose support was critical to Ms. Quinn’s winning the speaker’s office in 2006 and will also be important if she makes an expected bid for mayor in 2009. Ms. Quinn’s office would not comment on the political implications of the nomination, but said Mr. Diaz was well qualified. If his appointment is approved, he said, he plans to begin his tenure with financial and performance audits of the office, which in addition to certifying city laws and maintaining records, performs civil marriages and enforces lobbying laws. The clerk serves a five-year term.

headline: Ohio to Offer Paper Ballots in March
text: CINCINNATI  All 57 counties in Ohio that still use the touch-screen voting machines that were found to be unreliable in a statewide study must provide paper ballots to any voters who request them for the presidential primary in March.

headline: Obama’s Kin Glued to the Radio in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The post-election mayhem consuming Nairobi and other parts of Kenya has not struck Nyangoma-Kogelo, the western village of tin shacks where many residents were instead fixated on the results of another vote on Thursday: the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Panels Approve New Jersey School Financing Plan
text: TRENTON  Despite mounting criticism from the mayors of the state’s largest cities, Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s proposal to revamp New Jersey’s formula for financing schools cleared two important legislative hurdles on Thursday.

headline: As Buyouts Falter, New Tactics Aim to Lock in Deals
text: Happy New Year? Not for Wall Street deal makers.

headline: Illinois: Former Officer Is Sentenced
text: Three former Chicago police officers were sentenced to decades in federal prison for using their guns, uniforms and badges to steal cocaine and marijuana from drug dealers and resell it. “You and your merry band essentially raped and plundered entire neighborhoods,” Judge Ronald A. Guzman of Federal District Court said in sentencing one of the former officers, Broderick Jones, the admitted leader of the ring, to 25 years. The stiffest sentence went to another former officer, Eural Black, the only one of the three who did not plead guilty and was convicted at trial. Judge Guzman sentenced Mr. Black to 40 years. A third former officer, Darek Haynes, was sentenced to 19 years.

headline: Long Wait for N.F.L., Short Wait for Success
text: TAMPA, Fla.  It was cold. It was 3 a.m. Hauling 50-pound water jugs into Manhattan office buildings along Fifth Avenue and throughout Times Square, Greg White recalled how sacking quarterbacks was much easier work.

headline: Germany Posts Month 21 of Declining Jobless Rate
text: FRANKFURT  Of all the measures of Germany’s economic revival over the last two years, none may be more telling than this: there are 711,000 fewer people out of work in this country than in 2006, and 1.5 million fewer than in 2005, when unemployment reached a peak of more than 5 million.

headline: As Expected, Ford Falls From 2nd Place in U.S. Sales
text: DETROIT  Ford Motor had been in second place in the American car market since the Great Depression. But it lost its grip last year.

headline: Now You See Those Securities, Now You Don’t
text: What better time of year is there than New Year’s Eve to release some bad news?

headline: In Cookies and Coaxing, the Will of the Democrats Comes to Life
text: NEVADA, Iowa  By midafternoon, Kathy Johnson was nervous. In a few hours, she would be chairwoman of Nevada 2, one of 1,781 Democratic caucuses in Iowa, and one of five in this town of 6,000 people, a 40-minute drive north of Des Moines.

headline: Movies
text: MOVIES

headline: Intel Leaves Group Backing Education PCs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel said Thursday that it had chosen to withdraw from the One Laptop Per Child educational computer organization, which it joined in July after years of public squabbling between Intel’s chairman, Craig R. Barrett, and the group’s founder, Nicholas P. Negroponte.

headline: Drugs Offer No Benefit in Curbing Aggression, Study Finds
text: The drugs most widely used to manage aggressive outbursts in intellectually disabled people are no more effective than placebos for most patients and may be less so, researchers report.

headline: Guild Complains About Leno’s Monologue
text: Jay Leno delivered a traditional full-length monologue without the help of his team of 19 writers on Wednesday night.

headline: Advertisers Thankful For Return Of Late-Night TV
text: As noted by TV Decoder on Thursday, the late-night shows enjoyed an overall viewership bump Wednesday. But the strong ratings belie the sagging advertising market for late-night television. Before the strike began the late-night shows had shed approximately 10 percent of their viewers. Two months of forced repeats exacerbated the declines.

headline: John McCain
text: John McCain responds to the results of the Iowa caucus. (NBC Video)

headline: John Edwards
text: John Edwards comments on the results from the Iowa caucuses.(NBC Video)

headline: Chaos in Kenya
text: Chaos and ethnic fighting has ignited in Kenya, destabilizing the country, just one week after Kenyans went to the polls to elect their president.

headline: After Iowa: Locker Room Chatter
text: Instant analysis of the Iowa caucuses (that’s the political event that was going on while the Kansas Jayhawks won the Orange Bowl) from around the Web:

headline: The Women Vote
text: DES MOINES — We just caught up with some numbers that you’ll want to see. Turns out Barack Obama did better among women than Hillary Rodham Clinton did.

headline: Mitt Romney
text: Mitt Romney comments on the results from the Iowa caucuses. (NBC  Video)

headline: CBS Takes a Tighter Hold of CSTV
text: “CBS Sports took a firmer grip on CSTV, the college sports media company it acquired in late 2005, by announcing Thursday that it was taking over day-to-day control of it from the last of its three founders, Brian Bedol, who will soon leave CBS,” Richard Sandomir reports in Friday’s New York Times.

headline: Moffitt Update: “I Love Him, but He Doesn’t Know How to Spell.”
text: Here’s the next chapter of the Ben and Shauna Moffitt saga. Brett McMurphy of the Tampa Tribune digs deeper into the academic fraud aspect of the story in this article.

headline: Shanghai pedicure, with sharpened blades
text: Samuel So. Courtesy of the Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong.

headline: Caucus: Media Spotlight Shifts To Obama And Huckabee
text: Television anchors and analysts swiftly anointed the Democratic candidate Barack Obama and the Republican candidate Mike Huckabee the frontrunners of their respective parties on Thursday.

headline: Caucus: TV Crews Move To New Hampshire
text: A number of television personalities and producers won’t get much sleep Friday morning. Correspondents are following presidential candidates to New Hampshire overnight, and several of them will be in position for Friday newscasts.

headline: Let’s Face It
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Caucus: Inside CNN’s Control Room, Balancing Projections With Patience
text: CNN’s fifth-floor newsroom was gift-wrapped in shades of red and blue for the Iowa caucus Thursday evening, as the network deployed the latest electronic toys for the first votes of the 2008 presidential elections.

headline: The Iowa Caucuses: Looking Ahead
text: The Times's John Harwood analyzes Thursday night's Iowa caucuses and what lies beyond.

headline: Where Do We Live?
text: Photos and reviews of plays written by Christopher Shinn.

headline: Minimalism
text: Three exhibitions in New York pivot around one of modern art's most enduringly popular styles.

headline: What We Learned in Iowa
text: Sorry not to have posted something here yesterday. We had some technical glitches here in Iowa. I know that some of you probably forgot to eat dinner and missed all the victory speeches because you were obsessively hitting your refresh buttons all night long, and for that I apologize.

headline: Inside a Caucus
text: The inner workings of a single caucus, that of the second precinct in Nevada, Iowa.

text: From a Times Op-Ed parody of in-flight instructions, from the vantage point of a single seat:

headline: Tata Pulls Ford Units Into Its Ever-Expanding Orbit
text: As Tata Motors begins detailed talks with Ford Motor about buying the Jaguar and Land Rover brands, The New York Times takes a look at Ratan Tata, for whom the takeover will cap 16 years of transforming one of the world’s most diverse and unusual conglomerates, the Tata Group.

headline: Why is Shell Warning Europe About Climate Targets?
text: When leading industrialists warn that plans for cutting greenhouse gases may be too ambitious, it’s hard to know whether they are giving an honest assessment or protecting their interests. That seems doubly true when the person making the comments is a leading representative of the fossil fuel industry like Jeroen Van der Veer, the chief executive of oil giant Shell.

headline: N2N to Close After Losing Only Customer, Report Says
text: One year after signing a $30 million first round of venture financing, n2N Commerce is in the process of shuttering its business.

headline: Burkle and Ovitz to Square Off Over Investment Deal
text: In the latest twisted tale of Los Angeles dealmaking, lawyers for billionaire and former grocery store magnate Ronald W. Burkle and onetime Hollywood superstar agent Michael S. Ovitz are set to square off in court in February.

headline: National City Should Put Itself on the Block, Analyst Says
text: National City Corp., Ohio’s largest bank, had a rough start to the New Year.

headline: Buyout Executive Anticpates More Energy Deals
text: With the price of oil expected to hover near $100 a barrel or move higher still this year, investors should expect more deals to be made in the energy sector, a leading private-equity executive specializing in the oil and gas industry said Thursday.

headline: China Invests in 3 Australian Banks, Report Says
text: A subsidiary of the body overseeing China’s massive $1.4 trillion reserve stockpile has purchased stakes in three leading Australian banks, according to a report.

headline: Start-Up Revives San Francisco Wi-Fi Plan
text: A Silicon Valley start-up is said to be promising to blanket San Francisco with free wireless Internet service, reviving a crusade that crumbled last year after two much larger companies, EarthLink and Google, scrapped their plans to build a high-speed network for Web surfing.

headline: Britain’s Chancellor Plans New Rescue Rules for Banks
text: Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer is planning to push through sweeping new powers to intervene if banks fail, in an effort to prevent a future Northern Rock-style crisis.

headline: Buffett’s New Bond Insurer to Plant Flag in Rhode Island
text: Warren E. Buffett’s new bond insurer is looking to expand to Rhode Island after hearing that the state’s treasurer wanted it to apply for a license to operate in the state, according to a spokeswoman for the billionaire investor.

headline: MidOcean Names New Chairman
text: MidOcean Partners said Thursday that Mark A. Angelson, the former chief executive of printing giant R.R. Donnelley, would join the private equity firm as its new chairman. He will also take responsibility for the Executive Board at MidOcean, which was founded by Ted Virtue, a former executive from Deutsche Bank. MidOcean was spun out from Deutsche Bank in 2003.

headline: As State Street Faces Suit Over Losses, Will Others Follow?
text: Have the floodgates on a new wave of securities fraud lawsuits been opened?

headline: American Industrial Coughs Up $100 Million for Brooks
text: American Industrial Partners purchased the Brooks Instrument division of Emerson Electric for about $100 million, Emerson said Thursday.

headline: Is the Weather Channel Asking Too Much?
text: Is the Weather Channel over-shooting with its $5 billion price-tag?

headline: V.C.’s Inject Tempo With $8.1 Million
text: Combination drug developer Tempo Pharmaceuticals raised $8.1 million in a Series B round of venture capital, bringing total funding in a little more than a year to $22 million.

headline: Weather Alarmism as a Noble Strategy
text: Amidst the denunciations of my column and post on weather alarmism, there was a calm question from one critic, Annie Jia:

headline: New Tactics Aim to Lock in Buyouts
text: Happy New Year? Not for Wall Street deal makers.

headline: For Bear Stearns Funds, a Fatal Margin Call?
text: Merrill Lynch‘s margin call on assets loaned to Bear Stearns may have been the catalyst for the decline in the value of collateralized debt obligations, according to a Bloomberg News report.

headline: Bupa Makes First U.S. Healthcare Deal
text: Bupa, the private health insurer based in the United Kingdom, has agreed to pay $640 million for Health Dialog, its first acquisition of a healthcare company in the United States.

headline: Lazard’s ‘Blank Check’ Grows to $800 Million
text: Investment bank Lazard has filed for an $800 million initial public offering for its blank check company Sapphire Industrial, in what would be the second-largest offering of its kind to date.

headline: N.H. Staffs Prep for the Crush
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — In the latest installment of Campus Voices, a few of the students from Harvard’s Institute of Politics braved the single-digit temperatures today while on their break to visit the candidates’ campaign headquarters, where preparations were under way for the big push here — finally! — toward next Tuesday. The students’ academic project has produced both text and video dispatches throughout the fall and winter as they spent a lot of time in New Hampshire following the primary process and the candidates.

headline: Citadel Said to Consider I.P.O. This Year
text: For hedge fund magnate Kenneth C. Griffin, 2007 was the best year ever. His Citadel Investment Group emerged as one of Wall Street’s top opportunists, picking up the pieces of fallen peers on the cheap. With such deft moves, Citadel rang in 30 percent-plus gains last year, compared with with the industry average of 12 percent.

headline: Regulators Said to Examine Mortgage Securities Sales
text: Federal regulators, concerned brokerages may have sold clients money-losing securities tied to subprime mortgages, are seeking information about how the investments were marketed, Bloomberg News reported citing an unnamed source.

headline: Liz Claiborne Said to Be Near a Sale of Ellen Tracy
text: Liz Claiborne, the women’s clothing giant, is in the process of selling some of its brands and may make an announcement as soon as Friday, Fortune’s Suzanne Kapner reported.

headline: But Was It Collusion?
text: An interesting item from MSNBC on whether Titans Coach Jeff Fisher and Colts Coach Tony Dungy had an under-the-table understanding at the end of Sunday night’s game. Here are some excerpts:

headline: Carlyle Hunts for Infrastructure Deals
text: Carlyle Group is looking for ways to spend its new $1.5 billion infrastructure fund, and a Carlyle executive told The Washington Post it would consider backing the controversial Dulles Rail project, which does not take funds from private sources.

headline: Parent of Dating Sites Looks for a Match
text: Wanted: Single dot-com Yenta seeks ambitious Mr. Big with deep pockets for a long-term relationship.

headline: Dakar Rally cancellation
text: Hard to believe, but the A.S.O., the organizers of the Dakar rally, formerly known as the Paris-Dakar, decided to cancel the race after threats of terrorism in Mauritania led them to conclude it just wasn’t worth it.

headline: Prom Night
text: For the moment, Dave Poland at The Hot Button and others are saying that the writers’ strike may shut down a television show called “The Golden Globes.” But even if the show doesn’t go on, the parties will. Why, just last night one gatekeeper for an annual shindig told the Bagger that he couldn’t come unless pledged to cough up coverage.

headline: Spending Quality Time Inside P.T.’s Noggin
text: The Reeler had a spare 699 minutes on his hands and decided to watch every Paul Thomas Anderson-directed movie in existence. And, oh, he live-blogged along the way.

headline: Oh, Canada
text: Both Spoutblog and EW’s Pop Watch are crushing on Michael Cera’s knobby knees.

headline: Turkey Shoot
text: The Vulture, which knows a thing about large, ungainly avians that have trouble taking wing, has done a bit of databasing in search of the worst movie of the year.

headline: Brooklyn Blaze Kills a Fire Lieutenant
text: A fire lieutenant, Lt. John H. Martinson, 40, died on Thursday evening after a full-scale assault on a smoky and blinding fire that enveloped a 25-story apartment building at 1700 Bedford Avenue in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, at the site of the former Ebbets Field. At least four other firefighters and four residents of the apartment building were injured, with the injuries were not considered life-threatening.

headline: For the Moment | Back in the New York Groove
text: This week’s guest bloggers are Loden Dager, a men’s wear collective based in New York City that launched in the Fall of 2006 and this week won the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award for new talent. Its members, pictured, are: Melissa Vail, Matthew Sandager, Oliver Helden, Paul Marlow, and Alex Galan. Today the gang is back at work on their upcoming Paris and New York shows. (Read previous blog entries written by Loden Dager and a profile of Alex Galan here.)

headline: The Index Kings
text: One of the most evocative short essays I’ve read in a while is Enid Stubin’s “My Life in the Indexing Trade,” available at moreintelligentlife.com. It pokes around in a part of book production most readers don’t often think about – the worker bees who often compile the indexes in biographies and other nonfiction books.

headline: FINAL at the WJC: Sweden 2-1 Russia, OT
text: To follow the play-by-play commentary of the World Junior Championship semifinal match, LIVE, as it happens at the CEZ Arena in Pardubice, Czech Republic, click “more” and then refresh like crazy. Jeff Z. Klein describes the action.

headline:
Dining with Gavin and Bella:
Rosa Mexicano
text: Having sampled the mediocre food that’s the price of kid-friendly theatrics at Mars 2112, the Jekyll and Hyde Club and Max Brenner, I’d come to the sad conclusion that fun for children and decent grub for grown-ups wasn’t a combination to be found in Manhattan.

headline: The Early Word: Next Up, New Hampshire
text: OK, that’s enough celebrating. Iowa caucus kings Mike Huckabee and Barack Obama, thanks to this year’s condensed primary schedule, have to translate their momentum quickly into a New Hampshire victory before their primary on Tuesday. And candidates who didn’t get the results they wanted have limited time to convince Granite Staters that they don’t have to follow Iowa’s cue.

headline: A ‘Bottle Bill’ for the Climate
text: The exploration of ways to create a “sellable” approach to the daunting task of establishing a firm ceiling on greenhouse-gas emissions is important enough that I’m adding another post on this for the weekend.

headline: Allah by Any Other Name
text: Here’s a headline to get the little gray cells puzzling: The Malaysian government has “reminded” — that is, ordered — a Catholic newspaper published in the country not to use the word Allah.

headline: Should Microsoft Put Plaxo in Its Address Book?
text: Microsoft made a big splash with its $240 million deal to buy a sliver of Facebook. Now, some industry observers think the software giant should consider another social-networking deal. This time, the focus is on Plaxo, an early entrant into the social-networking field that was overtaken by rivals and is looking to fetch as much as $100 million in a potential sale of the company.

headline: N.H. Forecast: The Granite State Welcomes You!
text: Countdown: 4 days until the primary.

headline: The Carpetbagger
text: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) visits Arnie Sawyer Studios, an advertising firm that specializes in Academy Award print campaigns.

headline: Did Employment Grow In 2007?
text: The December jobs report provides more evidence of a sluggish economy. Employers have not resorted to large-scale layoffs, but they seem to be quite unwilling to hire.

headline: The Odds of Becoming President
text: How much did the Iowa results change the odds in the 2008 campaign?

headline: An Apple TV With a Blu-ray Player?
text: Rumors are flying fast and furious over what Steve Jobs will pull out of his blue-jean pocket a week from Tuesday at his annual speech at the Macworld Expo in San Francisco. These include a movie rental service for iTunes, a super small notebook computer perhaps with a solid-state hard drive, a notebook docking station, and new features for the iPhone. Shaw Wu, an analyst with American Technology Research, suggested that Apple will start shipping some computers with Blu-ray high-definition DVD drives.

headline: Bloomberg Parses the Iowa Results
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continued to stay mum this morning on his own political aspirations, but continued to assert that the leading candidates for president had failed to be specific enough in their proposed solutions for the nation’s problems. Mr. Bloomberg spoke about a University of Oklahoma conference he plans to attend this weekend, at which participants expect to call for the candidates to renounce what the mayor called “partisan bickering.”

headline: The Clintons Arrive and Face ‘Big Challenges’
text: NASHUA, N.H. – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband Bill emerged here on Granite State soil Friday morning for a pep rally, as her campaign – and her ever-popular husband prepared to redouble their efforts after her loss in Iowa.

headline: The Mouse That Roared (on Cable)

headline: Injuries Dash Hopes of Some African Stars
text: Some of Africa’s brightest stars will miss or are likely to miss the African Cup of Nations later this month in Ghana. Egypt midfielder Mohamad Barakat was ruled out today due to a knee injury. The Egyptian sports site Fil Balad said Barakat, who helped Egypt lift a record 5th African Cup two years ago, was considered a replacement for winger Mohsen Hindawi, also injured. Barakat, who plays for Al Ahly in Cairo, will have surgery in Germany.

headline: Video: For Your Consideration
Friday Kickoff: Kansas Gets Its Signature Victory
text: Kansas entered the Orange Bowl against Virginia Tech as the “least-respected 11-1 college football team in recent memory,” writes Joe Posnanski of the Kansas City Star. The Jayhawks left with a signature victory that silenced their many critics.

headline: Romney Pivots, Aims at McCain Again
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. – Just hours after his plane touched down here, Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney congratulated Mike Huckabee on his win in the Iowa caucuses, saying he did a “real nice job.” But he quickly added: “Things are different here in New Hampshire.”

headline: Outside the Box: Hasbro’s Cranium Deal

headline: A Richardson-Obama Deal? Some Caucus-Goers Thought So
text: DES MOINES – There were many factors contributing to Barack Obama’s decisive victory in Iowa Thursday night –- his efforts to reach out to first-time caucus voters, record turnout, and a willingness by voters to take a chance on a candidate who seemed improbable not long ago -– but was an agreement with the Bill Richardson campaign one of them?

headline: A Scene From "The Wire"
