headline: College Admissions: A Little Guidance
text: Families today agonize over a bewildering array of deadlines and policies. How does early decision differ from early action, or single-choice early action? Does an honors course carry the same weight as A.P.? What’s the best tack for an essay?

headline: Hey, Mr. D.J., Spin Me That Vinyl Obsession
text: As someone who has lugged a couple of hundred beat-up vinyl records to and from more apartments than I care to count over the years, throwing out my back out once in the process, I was excited and a little apprehensive about interviewing James Dier for The City section this week.

headline: ‘There Are More Black People in the Beatles Than in Iowa’
text: Aired Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: The Iowa caucus went on today. Whoever wins gets to be president of Iowa, I guess. I don’t know.

headline: It Used to Take a Village, Now It Takes Synergy
text: The Village Voice and the Los Angeles Week, both of which are owned by Village Voice Media, polled film critics — those still with jobs after the company, which has bought many city weeklies, dumped the local film writers in favor of syndicated ones — and found out that serious film types are still basking in the brilliance of “There Will Be Blood.”

headline: Howard Dean, You Are Missed
text: This time around, Iowa doesn’t seem to have produced its Howard Dean moment, so we’ll just have to live with the original …

headline: Alarming Weather and Global Warming
text: Our provocative science columnist John Tierney endured a hailstorm of responses for a column and blog post this week on the tendency of some climate campaigners to focus on extreme weather as a selling point for cutting greenhouse gases. Today he’s posted an explanation and defense of his view, echoing a lot of what I’ve been writing over the past several years.

headline: ‘Caucusing: Isn’t That What Got Bill Clinton Impeached?’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: The Writers Guild strike does continue. Let me simplify this for you. Here’s what the writers want. Tell me if you don’t think this is fair. They want a share of internet revenues and four more years of President Bush.

headline: Come Down Off That Limb, Son
text: Kris Tapley, who you could call an veteran Oscar ninny if he wasn’t so young and ungrizzled, has gone out on a limb and brought his saw with him, picking “Into the Wild” for best picture. As Mr. Tapley and others, including Pete Hammond, have pointed out, it is an hellaciously confusing year, with no movie making a clear break out of the pack.

headline: Fox Experiments With Monday Nights
text: Fox is moving two of its midseason dramas, “New Amsterdam” and “Canterbury’s Law,” to higher profile time slots. But because the writers’ strike has led to a shortage of new episodes, the shows will be shown in sequence — one will start after the other ends — instead of at different times on the same night between February and May.

headline: McCain Swings Back at Romney

headline: Kenya Isn’t Rwanda
Q. & A.: Time To Panic About Unemployment?
text: The headline numbers on the monthly jobs report this morning were pretty scary. The unemployment rate took its biggest jump up in 12 years, to 5 percent, and only 18,000 nonfarm jobs were created in December, in an economy that needs more than 100,000 a month just to keep up with natural population growth. Take government workers out of the picture, and the economy actually lost 13,000 private-sector jobs.

headline: Bloomberg Weighs In
text: Will Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg enter the already tumultuous field of presidential candidates by mounting a third-party bid for the White House? The billionaire mayor — who appeared on David Letterman’s show on Thursday — continued to stay mum this morning on his own political aspirations. But in a morning radio call-in program, Mr. Bloomberg continued to assert that the leading candidates for president had failed to be specific enough in their proposed solutions for the nation’s problems. He also discussed a University of Oklahoma conference he plans to attend this weekend, at which participants expect to call for the candidates to renounce what the mayor called “partisan bickering.”

headline: Ratings: Huckabee, Obama and…Trump?
text: With the Iowa caucus returns on cable and Orange Bowl college football coverage on Fox, NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” still managed to earn Thursday night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49.

headline: If Sony BMG Drops D.R.M. for Music, D.R.M. Is Gone

headline: Challenges Ahead for Obama

headline: Boats for Sale (Catfish Wrestlers Not Included)
text: Among the cast of characters at this year’s New York National Boat Show: two Oklahoma men who wrestle catfish by grabbing them in their mouths (one had the broken fingers to prove it), Miss Geico (a transvestite version of the insurance company gecko wearing a bikini and a fake eyelashes), two men who created a dolphin-shaped submersible boat named “Sweet Virgin Angel” (“We call it ‘Angel’ for short,” one said), and a boating staff that spent hours simulating fishing with the Nintendo Wii.Boaters can fall either into the stodgy or whimsical lots — and both were evident at the boat show, which started last Saturday and runs through Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

headline: When you Can’t Find a London Cab
text: Although London’s iconic black taxis are sometimes in short supply, visitors should steer clear of unlicensed minicabs that cruise the streets looking for business. They are illegal and dangerous. Their drivers are not licensed by Transport for London (TFL) and often drive unsafe, uninsured vehicles. They are unlikely to know their way around the city and probably will overcharge for any journey.

headline: Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island Crumbles
text: The hauntingly abandoned, Gothically forbidding Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island — perhaps New York City’s most romantic ruin — turned far less romantic and even more ruined last month when part of its crumbling gray stone facade fell to the ground.The collapse, which seems to have been a matter of gravity picking up where negligence left off, came as the publicly owned landmark hospital was closer than ever to being stabilized and preserved as part of the new Southpoint Park planned on the island.

headline: Got Tree? Make Mulch
text: On Saturday and Sunday, New Yorkers will be allowed take their old Christmas trees to 85 parks around the five boroughs for the 12th annual MulchFest — at which tree limbs, branches and trunks are ground into wood chips and turned into vegetation-friendly mulch.Last year, about 12,000 trees were recycled through MulchFest, out of more than 160,000 trees recycled citywide. It turns out that mulch is an important argument in the perennial debate on whether “real” Christmas trees or the artificial, synthetic versions are better.

headline: Did Warner Brothers Just Kill HD DVD?
text: In addition to Apple, Warner Brothers is now going to throw its weight behind the Blu-ray format for high-definition disks. Warner has been the only major studio to publish its movies in both Blu-ray and HD DVD formats. Today, the studio announced that from now on, it would only issue movies in Blu-ray.

headline: The Future of College Football
text: NEW ORLEANS — With the generally uninspiring set of bowl games so far, the issue of the future of football’s postseason format has emerged as the hot topic of the off-season. The 11 conference commissioners will convene in Miami in late April for meetings that could well change the course of college football.
The number of people watching Fox Business News.

headline: Look Out Below
text: When I grew up, in the ’60s, leisure air travel was still relatively expensive and exceptional for people — like us back then — of modest means. So I was 13 when I took my first flight. By way of contrast, our now-22-month-old is a frequent flier. She took her first flight at six months, to France no less! Nowadays, flying is so cheap and routine that it’s those who don’t fly frequently who are exceptional.

headline: Red-Carpet Crawl
text: I’ve just returned from the living room with a copy of “Happy Times,” the photo collection of gods and goddesses by Jerome Zerbe and Brendan Gill. I wanted to see, or to imagine, what the Golden Globes will look like without television cameras, scripted gags and, perhaps, the red-carpet parade of dresses. In other words, if the Globes are to go on as a closed event, without a telecast (which could well be the only alternative at this stage), will the atmosphere resemble the days when Hollywood seemed spectacularly intimate, its gods and goddesses even more remote and unearthly?

headline: Will He? Won’t He? Should He?

headline: Vows: Caroline and Karl
text: Karl was a prosecutor chasing terrorists; Caroline was a law school graduate who watched his trials. They found a perfect match online. Case closed.

headline: Probabilities in finance
text: Joe Stiglitz, today at the American Economic Association Meetings, talking about financial crises: “Once-in-a-hundred-years events occur every 10 years.” He’s thinking of the stock market crash of 1987, the Long Term Capital Management crisis of 1998, and the current subprime-plus crisis — all of which involved changes in asset prices that were supposed to be vanishingly unlikely.

headline: Panama Extends Tax Break
text: Good news for buyers in Panama. The government has extended a 20-year exemption on property taxes for new homes. Under the law, even if you buy an existing home built in recent years, the exemption is transferable.

headline: Clinton at N.H. Democratic Party Dinner
text: MILFORD, N.H. – This is the new battleground, where Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama will fight anew. She comes humbled, but emboldened and “ready’’ as her new signs say, for change and to lead. He comes triumphant.

headline: Making a McCain Town Hall Meeting
text: John McCain gets another try at New Hampshire, where he won in 2000 by 18 percentage points.

headline: Oh-ba-ma Fires It Up
text: MILFORD, N.H. — Spontaneous combustion! We’re here at the New Hampshire Democratic Party’s big dinner and out of the masses of 3,000 people, who have been listening politely to Dennis Kucinich, Hillary Clinton and Bill Richardson, comes a huge surge of people toward the stage for the next speaker — Barack Obama.

headline: Leno Faces Writers Guild Action Over Monologues
text: The restrictions that the striking Writers Guild of America has placed on late-night television hosts to keep them from writing material for their shows continued to have no impact on the leading late-night star, Jay Leno, who planned once again to write and perform a comedy monologue for NBC’s “Tonight Show” Friday night.

headline: Taking a Veteran Approach to the Job of a Young Lifetime
text: Brad Stevens walked off the court earlier this season after a victory at Evansville looking as if he had just stepped from the back room at the dry cleaner’s. His suit had hardly a wrinkle, and not a strand of his neatly trimmed brown hair appeared out of place.

headline: Job Cuts at Sun-Times
text: The Chicago Sun-Times, the flagship newspaper of the Sun-Times Media Group, has proposed cutting 35 union newsroom positions, or about 19 percent of the paper’s nonmanagement news jobs. The union has two weeks to make a counterproposal and plans to ask Sun-Times management to offer a buyout package, said Misha Davenport, a features writer and co-chairwoman of the Chicago Newspaper Guild. Sun-Times Media, formerly Hollinger International, is under pressure from shareholders to sell the company after revenue fell 10 percent to $279 million last year through Sept. 30.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the motivations of the C.I.A. in taping some interrogations and then destroying the tapes misidentified the position held by John A. Rizzo at the intelligence agency. He serves as the acting general counsel; he was never confirmed by the Senate as general counsel. (The White House withdrew his nomination because of mounting opposition from Democrats over Mr. Rizzo’s role in the harsh interrogation of C.I.A. detainees.) (Go to Article)

headline: Heads Up, Ms. Bradshaw, New Foursome’s in Town
text: This may not be such a good time for the rich and powerful.

headline: The Smithsonian, Again
text: W. Richard West Jr., the founding director of the Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of the American Indian, spent $48,500 in museum funds to commission a portrait of himself, The Washington Post reported. The painting, by Burton Silverman, a New York artist whose portraits have appeared on the cover of Time and in The New Yorker, hangs in the patrons’ lounge of the museum. Mr. West, 64, whose last day on the Smithsonian payroll was Monday, also spent more than $250,000 over four years on travel and hotels, the Smithsonian has confirmed. Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, and Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California and chairwoman of the Rules Committee, have asked for independent investigations of the expenses. The Smithsonian said it did not comment on former employees. Similar questions about personal spending by the Smithsonian’s secretary, Lawrence M. Small, led to his resignation last March.

headline: Juvenile Detention Trap
text: One way to lessen the chance that troubled young people grow up to be full-fledged criminals is to send them to community-based counseling and probation programs instead of to detention centers where they are often traumatized and inducted into a life of crime. The community-based programs are less expensive than detention and more effective when it comes to cutting recidivism. But states and localities are often hampered by policies that provide perverse financial incentives for sending young people to the lockup.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about the motivations of the C.I.A. in taping some interrogations and then destroying the tapes misidentified the position held by John A. Rizzo at the intelligence agency. He serves as the acting general counsel; he was never confirmed by the Senate as general counsel. (The White House withdrew his nomination because of mounting opposition from Democrats over Mr. Rizzo’s role in the harsh interrogation of C.I.A. detainees.)

headline: Proposal to Better Unite City Leaves Dresden Divided

headline: North Korea Says Earlier Disclosure Was Enough
text: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Friday that it had already explained enough about its nuclear programs to meet a deadline for declaring its nuclear activities, saying the information was in a nuclear declaration it prepared in November and gave to the United States.

text: For Sadou Brown in a Los Angeles suburb, the decisive victory of Senator Barack Obama in Iowa was a moment to show his 14-year-old son what is possible.

headline: Bafta’s Short List of Films
text: The British Academy of Film and Television Arts has announced its nominees for the best foreign film of 2007, the BBC reported. They are: “Lust, Caution,” “La Vie en Rose,” “The Lives of Others,”  “The Kite Runner” and “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” The Bafta ceremony will be held on Feb. 10 at the Royal Opera House in London.

headline: Nets Beat the Bobcats and Get Back to .500
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets are hot, relatively speaking.

headline: Injured Window Washer Has Operation on Spine
text: A window washer who has made a surprising recovery from a 47-story fall underwent another operation on Friday, and the surgeon said that “everything went smoothly.”

headline: This Round, Accusations of Spying and Thievery
text: Yuan Cao spent a weekend in late September 2006 in front of a computer at Institutional Credit Partners, a private investment bank where he had worked for five weeks. That Sunday, he moved computer files onto two flash drives  standard backups, he would later maintain  signed off, and left the office. Two days later, he quit by e-mail message.

headline: To Friends and Family, a Fallen Firefighter Was ‘Johnny Nice Guy’
text: Beneath the freshly hung black- and-purple bunting on Engine Company 249’s firehouse in Brooklyn on Friday morning, the firefighters’ commanding officer summed up the department’s latest loss in six words.

headline: Huckabee Moves to New Hampshire, With Tweaks to His Message
text: HENNIKER, N.H.  Fresh from his victory in the Iowa caucuses, Mike Huckabee has to be considered a serious contender for the Republican presidential nomination. But that has not sobered up his distinctive Bible Belt-meets-Borscht Belt act on the stump.

headline: The Company With the Biggest Little Black Book
text: EVERY phone call, fax and personal computer connection in North America depends on the services of a little-known company called NeuStar, based in Sterling, Va. The company manages a directory of 500 million telephone numbers in the United States and Canada, says Jeffrey E. Ganek, its chairman and chief executive. The company, a spinoff from Lockheed Martin, had an estimated $430 million in sales in 2007.

headline: James Costigan, Writer of Prestige TV, Is Dead
text: James Costigan, an Emmy-winning writer for television who worked with some of the leading actors of the postwar years, among them Katharine Hepburn, Laurence Olivier, Joanne Woodward and Paul Newman, died on Dec. 19 at his home on Bainbridge Island, Wash. He was believed to have been in his late 70s or early 80s.

headline: The (Possible) Perils of Being Thirsty While Being Green
text: I HAVE the usual New Year’s resolutions  exercise more, lose weight, be a nicer person. I also hope to find out if I am inadvertently poisoning my children.

headline: Warner Backs Blu-ray, Tilting DVD Battle
text: LOS ANGELES  The high-definition DVD war is all but over.

headline: China Censors a Film, Then Bans It Entirely
text: China has pulled Li Yu’s “Lost in Beijing,” a movie whose sexually explicit scenes were already censored, from theaters and banned its producer from the film business for two years, The Associated Press reported. The ruling against “Lost in Beijing” accused the filmmakers of publishing unapproved pornographic scenes from the movie on the Internet and on DVDs, the official China News Service Web site reported. The film’s producer, Fang Li, said he believed that Chinese officials faced political pressure to act amid the rapid spread of uncensored versions of “Lost in Beijing” and another sexually explicit film, Ang Lee’s “Lust, Caution,” on the Internet and in pirated DVDs.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Page 8 of Arts & Leisure this weekend about Jock Soto’s transition to teaching dance after a career as principal dancer with the New York City Ballet misstates the given name of his father. He is Jose Soto, not Joseph.

headline: McCain May Benefit From Huckabee’s Jolt to G.O.P.
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mike Huckabee’s defeat of Mitt Romney in the Iowa caucuses jolted a Republican Party establishment already distressed about the state of its presidential field.

headline: Rehabilitating Libya
text: We are all for forgiveness and second acts, but Libya’s sordid human rights record and continuing police state tactics should not be forgotten. Businesses  and their government backers  rushing to procure contracts with the oil-rich state would prefer to ignore what’s happening on the ground in Libya. President Bush and other democratic leaders cannot, and must keep pressing Tripoli for change.

headline: Noontime Web Video Revitalizes Lunch at Desk
text: In cubicles across the country, lunchtime has become the new prime time, as workers click aside their spreadsheets to watch videos on YouTube, news highlights on CNN.com or other Web offerings.

headline: Congress Calls on Clemens and 4 Others to Testify
text: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer Brian McNamee have been asked to testify under oath before a Congressional committee Jan. 16 in what promises to be a compelling showdown.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Friday about the pressure facing Ohio State as it prepares to play for the college football national championship after losing in last year’s title game misstated the team’s 2006 and 2007 regular-season records. They were 12-0 and 11-1  not 11-0 and 10-1.

headline: A Single Mother of 5Wants to ‘Become Somebody’
text: Since the age of 14, and for most of her adulthood, Cynthia Lora has lived in other people’s homes.

headline: The Appetite for Securities Turns Less Hearty
text: TO some on Wall Street, the last half of 2007 may have had the feel of a buyers’ strike. Financial products that had experienced rapidly growing demand suddenly became all but unsalable.

headline: In Race for Gossip, TV Shows Turn to Blogs
text: Are Joel and Nicole splitting up? Will Britney get her babies back? OmiGOD!

headline: It Takes a Family (to Break a Glass Ceiling)
text: Washington

headline: Padilla Sues Former U.S. Lawyer Over Detention
text: Jose Padilla, the American citizen who was held in military detention for more than three years as an enemy combatant, filed a lawsuit Friday against a former Justice Department lawyer who helped provide the legal justifications for what the suit says was Mr. Padilla’s unconstitutional confinement and “gross physical and psychological abuse.”

headline: Flyer Accused of Biting Hand in the Devils’ Shutout Victory
text: NEWARK, Jan. 4  The middle finger on Devils center Travis Zajac’s left hand had been stitched and was wrapped with tape late Friday. Such an injury among hockey players is common, but the cause of this one was highly unusual.

headline: Centennial Celebration for a Conductor
text: Salzburg, Austria, which was the host for Mozart’s 250th-birthday celebrations in 2006, will commemorate the 100th birthday of another famous native son, the conductor Herbert von Karajan, above. The festivities will begin with a concert by the Berlin Philharmonic on Saturday at the Grosses Festspielhaus hall in Salzburg, Agence France-Presse reported. The orchestra, which von Karajan conducted from 1955 until his death in 1989, will also play in Berlin, Paris and Tokyo, and there will be a Karajan Festival in Lucerne, Switzerland, among other festivities in 2008. The birthday itself, on April 5, will be honored with a ceremony in the Mozart House museum in Salzburg. Von Karajan joined the Nazi Party in 1935, a move that greatly helped his career until he fled Germany for Milan in 1944. He was the favorite conductor of Hermann Goering, Hitler’s second in command. After the war the Allies banned him from conducting. The ban was lifted in 1947.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Dec. 10 about the ways New York has changed in the 20 years since the publication of the Tom Wolfe novel “Bonfire of the Vanities,” which depicted a city in decline, referred imprecisely to the Tawana Brawley case, an example of the racial tension of the times. Although a special prosecutor had been appointed to lead the investigation of claims that Ms. Brawley, a black teenager, had been sexually assaulted by white men, the prosecution did not later collapse because there was in fact no prosecution of any suspect. (A grand jury investigation concluded that there was no evidence that Ms. Brawley had been sexually assaulted.)

headline: Paring Down Parking Permits, and Raising a Fuss
text: When the city announced plans to crack down on the abuse of parking permits issued to city employees, Christopher Stephens felt a shiver of furious recognition.

headline: Death Is on the Line; Can You Hear It Now?
text: Early in “One Missed Call” a snooty cat is yanked into a fish pond by a disembodied arm, unexpectedly following her owner to a watery grave. The moment is wickedly humorous and suggests a movie that’s unwilling to take itself too seriously. If only.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Dec. 28 about Benazir Bhutto, the former prime minister of Pakistan, misstated the location of her detention at the time her father, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the former president and prime minister, was hanged by the military authorities in April 1979. It was a deserted police training camp at Sihala, Pakistan, a few miles from the Rawalpindi District Jail where her father was hanged; she was not under house arrest.

headline: Drawing a New Map for Journalism in the Mideast
text: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates

headline: N.F.L. Offenses Undergo a Thaw in Thinking
text: PITTSBURGH  A video of the Jacksonville Jaguars’ December victory here has played on a loop at the Steelers’ headquarters this week, a continuous reminder of the team’s only home loss this season. The result was startling enough. But one look at the snow, the chopped-up field and the 147-yard pounding by Jaguars running back Fred Taylor underscores the world-turned-upside-down subtext to these playoffs: the geographic rules of football do not apply.

headline: In Obama’s Victory, Clues to the Challenges Ahead
text: DES MOINES  As he accepted his victory in the Iowa caucuses Thursday night, Senator Barack Obama presented his presidential candidacy as a vessel to wipe away partisan divisions, transcend the boundaries of race and “build a coalition for change that stretches through red states and blue states.”

headline: Unexceptional Events Set Off Fatal Blaze
text: A series of minor, seemingly unrelated events  a stove left on to warm an apartment, a boy waving a toy wrapper over the flames, and a self-closing door that got stuck on a rug  helped create the blinding maze of black smoke and oven-hot heat that claimed the life of a veteran fire lieutenant in Brooklyn on Thursday night, officials said Friday.

headline: Recruiting Intensifies for Can’t-Miss Prospect
text: SAN ANTONIO  The call log on Terrelle Pryor’s cellphone doubles as a list of coaches from college football’s blue-blood programs.

headline: Fears on Inflation and Jobs Give 2008 a Stumbling Start
text: Fears that a recession is imminent  or perhaps has already begun  rocked the major stock markets this week as anxiety-addled investors staggered through the first days of 2008.

headline: Glenn W. Ferguson, Former Ambassador to Kenya, Dies at 78
text: Glenn W. Ferguson, a former ambassador to Kenya, the president or chancellor of three universities and, for a brief time in the 1980s, the president of Lincoln Center, died at his home in Santa Fe, N.M., on Dec. 20. Mr. Ferguson, who held other influential positions during his career, including head of Radio Free Europe, was 78.

headline: Lawyer Is Suspended as Conduct Is Criticized
text: A Brooklyn lawyer has been suspended from practicing as a state panel investigates her handling of the estate of John L. Phillips Jr.  the so-called kung fu judge and the owner of the Slave Theater in Bedford-Stuyvesant  while she was acting as his legal guardian.

headline: Hedging Their Way to Billions
text: REMEMBER the colossal salaries of hedge fund managers  when they needed to earn at least $240 million just to be included among the 25 wealthiest in 2006? Well, those numbers may now look puny, especially at the top of the range.

headline: Three Guitars and Plenty of Blues
text: Hubert Sumlin, now 76, is used to playing concerts like “Howlin’ for Hubert,” at the Jazz Standard through this weekend. He was the guitarist who played the silvery leads on Howlin’ Wolf’s great Chicago blues records of the 1950s and ’60s. On Thursday every tune was from Howlin’ Wolf’s songbook, and Wolf’s name scarcely needed to be mentioned. It’s a Hubert Sumlin gig now.

headline: Liam O’Gallagher, 90, a Beat Avant-Gardist and Teacher, Dies
text: Liam O’Gallagher, an avant-garde sound artist, painter and teacher whose San Francisco studio became an early gathering place for Beat writers and poets in the 1950s, died Dec. 4 at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif.

headline: New H.I.V. Cases
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Dec. 23 about a newly declassified plan by J. Edgar Hoover, when he was director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to suspend the writ of habeas corpus and imprison Americans suspected of disloyalty misstated the process by which the Internal Security Act of 1950, also known as the McCarran Act, became law. President Truman vetoed the measure as unconstitutional, but Congress voted overwhelmingly to override his veto and the measure then became law; Truman did not sign the bill.

headline: Nudged by Bush, Israel Talks of Removing Illegal Outposts
text: JERUSALEM  Pressed by President Bush to keep promises to destroy illegal settler outposts, Israeli leaders said Friday that they hoped to take action after his visit to the region next week.

headline: City Ballet’s Greatest-Hit Makers Get Help From Some Old Masters
text: Does any other ballet company in the world come even close to New York City Ballet for the sheer quantity of repertory it presents? The first four weeks of its winter season introduce eight full programs, three of them starting this coming week. Balletgoers in most other cities of the world, wildly grateful if their local companies can open more than four programs in a single month, have long been justly envious.

headline: At Full Strength, Dorsey Is Ready for His Next Step
text: NEW ORLEANS  As the final weeks flipped off the college football calendar, Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey slipped out of the spotlight.

headline: Intel Quits Effort to Get Computers to Children
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A frail partnership between Intel and the One Laptop Per Child educational computing group was undone last month in part by an Intel saleswoman: She tried to persuade a Peruvian official to drop the country’s commitment to buy a quarter-million of the organization’s laptops in favor of Intel PCs.

headline: Supporter of Democrats Is Sentenced in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Norman Hsu, the shamed political powerbroker and Democratic donor, was sentenced Friday to a three-year prison term by a California judge in connection with a 1992 plea in a fraud case in which investors lost millions of dollars in an elaborate Ponzi scheme.

headline: Donors Bring Big Telescope a Step Closer
text: A project to build a digital camera of cosmic dimensions on a mountaintop in Chile has received a $30 million boost from a pair of software moguls and philanthropists.

headline: Romney Embraces Theme Used to Beat Him
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Having barely slept after landing at 3 a.m. on Friday, weary advisers for Mitt Romney gathered a few hours later in a conference room in the Courtyard Marriott in Portsmouth to regroup after the resounding defeat Mike Huckabee handed them in Iowa.

headline: How Long Will Profits Slump?
text: THE housing slump and credit squeeze have affected the broader economy and are finally having an impact where it matters most to stock owners: the bottom line. After increasing at double-digit rates for most of the last five years, corporate profits are about to decline for the second straight quarter, if analysts are correct.

headline: Man Charged in Wife’s Death Acknowledged Having Affairs
text: The Chappaqua lawyer accused of murdering his wife on the side of a darkened Westchester road admitted he sent flowers to his longtime mistress on her birthday in November 2006  the day of the shooting  according to the details of an indictment made public on Friday.

headline: Bequeathing, With Strings Attached
text: ONCE only for the superrich, dynasty trusts now provide a way for the rest of us to leave money to loved ones, preserve wealth for future generations and even control how an inheritance is used once donors die.

headline: Bearing Up
text: Juneau, Alaska

headline: Japan Prisons Begin Adapting to Elderly
text: TOKYO  Japan will build wards exclusively for elderly inmates at three prisons to deal with the steep rise in the prison population 60 and older, the Justice Ministry announced Friday.

headline: A Tribute Followed by Precision and Fire
text: Had it gone exactly as planned, the New York Philharmonic’s concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night would have seemed a flashy, almost carefree welcome to the new year. Along with what turned out to be a winning performance of the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto by a promising young violinist, Viviane Hagner, the program included a Mozart concerto played by the orchestra’s principal hornist, Philip Myers, as well as Mendelssohn’s nimble “Midsummer Night’s Dream” Overture and Elgar’s mammoth “Enigma” Variations.

headline: Knicks Stay Close, but Spurs Show How to Win
text: SAN ANTONIO  The difference between the defending N.B.A. champions and the team that qualifies as their polar opposite seemed remarkably small at times Friday night. But the true gap between the San Antonio Spurs and the Knicks showed up in the final seconds of a tight game that ended the way one would expect.

headline: What Would Hillary Rodham Do?
text: Des Moines

headline: First G.O.P. Delegate Goes to Romney
text: CASPER, Wyo.  Mitt Romney won the first delegate elected to the Republican National Convention Saturday when Albany County chose Tammy Johnson as its representative to the convention in Minneapolis-St. Paul next September. She defeated a Fred Thompson supporter and an uncommitted candidate at the county convention in Laramie. Eleven more delegates were to be elected throughout the day in other counties.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Interior Secretary Rejects Catskill Casino Plans
text: The federal government rejected plans for two casinos in the Catskill Mountains on Friday, saying that the reservations of the two tribes that submitted the plans were too far from where the casinos would be built.

headline: In Global Battle on AIDS, Bush Creates Legacy
text: WASHINGTON  Dr. Jean W. Pape did not know what to expect in early January 2003, when he slipped away from his work treating AIDS patients in Haiti and flew to Washington for a secret meeting with President Bush.

headline: Put Buyers First? What a Concept
text: My Christmas story  the one I’ve been telling and retelling these last 10 days  began on Friday, Dec. 21.

headline: Music Business Dealings
text: Radiohead has signed with iTunes to allow its latest album to be downloaded from the online music store, Agence France-Presse reported. The band was one of the few major acts not to have its songs on the service. In October Radiohead left the EMI record company after its contract expired. The band made its new album, “In Rainbows,” above, available on its Web site, radiohead.com, asking fans to pay whatever they thought it was worth. Radiohead has not said how many times the album was downloaded or the average price paid. ... The concert producer Live Nation said it had reached a two-year deal with the Jonas Brothers band, under which that New Jersey group would play more than 140 concerts around the world, starting in Tucson on Jan. 31, Reuters reported. In October Live Nation lured Madonna from Warner Brothers with a multi-album touring and merchandising partnership.

headline: Arrest in Shooting of Queens Boy Who Answered Door
text: The authorities arrested a suspect in the attack on an 11-year-old boy who was shot after he answered the front door of his home in Queens on Sunday, the district attorney’s office said Friday.

headline: Tracking and Adoring Lions in the Desert
text: It’s hard to say which is the more arresting sight in “The Desert Lions”: the lions themselves, sleek and playful and deadly against the astounding backdrop of the Namib Desert, or Flip Stander, the man who’s there to save them. Tip-toeing, storklike, across the rocky desert in his bare feet or bending down to sniff the paws of a tranquilized lioness  “a sweet, musky smell,” he sighs  Dr. Stander, Cambridge educated, fiercely dedicated and a little loony, is the real star of this episode of the PBS series “Nature.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Dec. 27 about the sentencing of six French aid workers who were convicted in Chad of trying to kidnap 103 children in a campaign to aid Sudanese orphans misstated the outcome of negotiations by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France during a trip to Chad in early November. He negotiated the release of three French journalists and four Spanish flight attendants, but did not secure the release of the aid workers.

headline: Redskins Rally (Around Gibbs) to Salvage Season
text: ASHBURN, Va.  Joe Gibbs was wondering how in the world he had ever won three Super Bowl titles and earned a place in the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and he wanted his Washington Redskins to know it. He had just called back-to-back timeouts to ice Buffalo kicker Rian Lindell, not knowing it would warrant a 15-yard penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct.

headline: Time-Traveling Musical
text: Tommy Tune, right, will direct “Turn of the Century,” a new musical comedy written by Rick Elice and Marshall Brickman, the writers of “Jersey Boys,” at the Goodman Theater in Chicago, The Associated Press reported. “The basic premise involves a young songwriter-piano player and his girl singer who find themselves through mysterious, supernatural, ‘Twilight Zone’-ish activities thrown back to the turn of the century, the 20th century,” said Robert Falls, artistic director of the Goodman. The score will consist of standards by Irving Berlin, Rodgers and Hart, George Gershwin, Rodgers and Hammerstein and others, Mr. Tune said. The show is scheduled to open in September or October. The Goodman’s 2008-9 season will also feature Brian Dennehy in a revival of Eugene O’Neill’s “Desire Under the Elms.”

headline: Judge Imposes Stricter Rules on Navy to Protect Marine Life
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge has ordered the Navy to adopt stringent new safeguards intended to improve protection of whales and dolphins during its sonar training exercises off Southern California.

headline: The Political Road Ahead
text: It is dangerous to draw too many conclusions from the Iowa caucuses  a telegenic display of activism by a tiny slice of Americans.

headline: Scoring One for the Defense and Snagging a Teams Title
text: The Flight A Swiss Teams on Dec. 28 at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Midtown Manhattan was won by Carl Berenbaum of Elkins Park, Pa.; Julian Heicklen of Teaneck, N.J.; Brett Kunin of West Orange, N.J.; and Dennis Thompson of Lake Hiawatha, N.J.

headline: Expanding Into Wind Energy
text: Scottish and Southern Energy, a British utility, agreed to buy the Irish wind farm operator Airtricity for 1.83 billion euros ($2.7 billion) in cash to add to its production of renewable energy. In the deal, Scottish and Southern said it would also take over 375 million euros of debt. The European Union has called for 20 percent of all energy, including transport fuels and heating, to come from renewable sources by 2020. Airtricity, Ireland’s largest wind farm operator, has been expanding operations in Britain and last year won approval to install turbines off the coast of England. Scottish and Southern, based in Perth, Scotland, said the deal would probably be completed in the first quarter.

headline: On TV, Celebrities Trump Politics
text: NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” won Thursday night’s ratings among adults 18 to 49. Nielsen estimated that the premiere of the latest edition of the reality show, with celebrities including the boxer Lennox Lewis, below, had 11 million viewers in the 9 o’clock hour, an improvement of almost 2 million over last season’s debut. NBC tied Fox for No. 1 over all, leading at 8 with “Deal or No Deal” (13.3 million) but trailing at 10 with “ER” (9.6 million). CBS ranked third, despite drawing the largest audience of the night with a repeat of “CSI” at 9 (13.5 million). ABC was a distant fourth.

headline: Hasselbeck Quietly Proves He Is One of Elite
text: KIRKLAND, Wash.  At the Seahawks’ holiday party last month, teammates dragged Matt Hasselbeck onto the dance floor. A crowd gathered around.

headline: Sentence for Jones Could Be Longer
text: Despite a plea to the judge for a light sentence, the former Olympic track star Marion Jones may be facing more prison time than she expected for lying about her steroid use and involvement in a check-fraud scheme.

headline: Top Runners Are Caught in Kenya’s Rising Violence
text: Lornah Kiplagat’s afternoon run is out of the question. Even though her training center in Iten, Kenya, is only a mile from her house, the short trip is more daunting than any race.

headline: Embracing His Moment, Obama Preaches Hope in New Hampshire
text: CONCORD, N.H.  Senator Barack Obama hops up to the stage in that hip-mod gray suit of his, clapping along with the audience on Friday, clapping for himself, clapping for this moment. He gazes at 1,200 people in overcoats and woolen hats and snow boots and asks for a show of hands.

headline: Britney Spears in Hospital After Standoff
text: LOS ANGELES  Britney Spears was strapped to a gurney late Thursday night after a three-hour standoff involving her two toddler sons, Kevin Federline, a court-appointed child monitor, police officers, paramedics and a locked bathroom door. She was rolled out of her home in the hills near Mulholland Drive as photographers swarmed and helicopters hovered, and taken to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center “for her own welfare,” as one police spokeswoman put it.

headline: Opposition Seeks New Vote as Violence Ebbs in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  If the price of cabbage is any indicator, things here in Kenya’s capital may be edging back to normal.

headline: Hunting a Tribe of Minimalists on the Streets of the Upper East Side
text: Unlike the sleek white boxes of Chelsea, the town house galleries of the Upper East Side tend to be small, old and charmingly idiosyncratic. Wooden floors creak, antique moldings and multiple doorways eat up wall space, and ghosts of residents past lurk in the shadows.

headline: Justices to Decide if Rape of a Child Merits Death
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether the Constitution allows the death penalty for the rape of a child.

headline: On Postcards and Even in Rice, Portraits of a Beloved Saint
text: If you’re searching for a reason to visit the too often overlooked Hispanic Society of America in Upper Manhattan, a striking installation of the artist Francis Alÿs’s collection of St. Fabiola portraits will do just fine. The exhibition is the work of the Dia Art Foundation and is the first of three exhibitions that it is organizing with the Hispanic Society. Dia has been without a New York City exhibition space since 2004, when it closed its building in Chelsea after the draining effort of creating Dia:Beacon, the vast upstate outpost that it opened in 2003. It is currently searching for a new foothold in the city.

headline: In Chinese Factories, Lost Fingers and Low Pay
text: GUANGZHOU, China  Nearly a decade after some of the most powerful companies in the world  often under considerable criticism and consumer pressure  began an effort to eliminate sweatshop labor conditions in Asia, worker abuse is still commonplace in many of the Chinese factories that supply Western companies, according to labor rights groups.

headline: A Film Comic Who Portrayed Life’s Drama With His Feet
text: This year’s Dance on Camera Festival documents modern dance in Montreal, looks at choreography in pop music videos and uses film to extend the boundaries of human movement  all lively but not that unusual for the festival, now 36. But there is one oddity: “The Choreographic Moves of Jacques Tati,” which focuses on that great French comic actor and director and his first feature, “Jour de Fête.”

headline: Footnotes
text: Dennis O’Hare and Michael Cerveris will star in Red Bull Theater’s Revelation Readings presentation of Brecht’s “Edward II” on Monday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater in Manhattan. Information: (212) 279-4200. ... The soprano Dísella Làrusdóttir will make her New York recital debut on Feb. 20 at Merkin Concert Hall. Information: (212) 501-3330 or kaufman-center.org.

headline: DNA Suggests That Boy in Chávez Rescue Effort Was Long Gone From Jungle Rebels
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  A DNA analysis released on Friday indicated that a 3-year-old boy born in the Colombian jungle to a woman kidnapped by Marxist guerrillas may have been living near his relatives, without their knowledge, in a foster home in Bogotá, Colombia.

headline: For Now, Musharraf Has Muzzled Legal Critics in Pakistan
text: KARACHI, Pakistan  Not so long ago, Muneer A. Malik was often photographed sitting on the roof of a Mitsubishi Pajero, fists raised, showered with rose petals and thronged by supporters as he accompanied the embattled Supreme Court chief justice on protest cavalcades that became the starkest symbol of opposition to President Pervez Musharraf’s rule.

headline: It’s Time for Roger Clemens to Face the Legal Posse
text: The posse appears to be gaining ground on Roger Clemens.

headline: Saturday Vote Tests Georgian Leader
text: TBILISI, Georgia  The pro-Western president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, was leading in the polls ahead of an election on Saturday that he hoped would restore his mandate to govern after he ordered a police crackdown on protesters and declared a state of emergency here in November.

headline: Health Benefits and Retirees
text: A new federal regulation allows employers to reduce or eliminate health benefits for retirees when they turn 65 and become eligible for Medicare. Although that will cause distress for some, it is a welcome step that could help slow the deterioration of employment-based health insurance. It seems likely that the new rule will help far more people than it hurts.

headline: Like Knicks, Randolph Cannot Shake Troubles
text: SAN ANTONIO  Zach Randolph was suspended Friday, an indignity that might not even rank among his top 10 in his short Knicks career.

headline: Unemployment Sounds Warning About Economy
text: The unemployment rate surged to 5 percent in December as the economy added a meager 18,000 jobs, the smallest monthly increase in four years, the Labor Department reported on Friday.

headline: Booker Is Losing 2 Top Officials, 18 Months Into His Newark Administration
text: NEWARK  There are two notable details that distinguish the otherwise unremarkable office occupied by Bo Kemp, the city’s business administrator, who announced his resignation on Friday.

headline: Alabama Bank’s Loan Losses
text: Regions Financial, Alabama’s biggest bank, will quadruple its reserve for loan losses, to $360 million, for the fourth quarter because of slowing real estate markets in Florida and Georgia. Regions moved $900 million of its $7.5 billion in loans to residential builders into a special asset pool because of slumping demand for housing, particularly in Miami and Atlanta. The Birmingham, Ala., bank raised its provision for loan losses from $90 million as of Sept. 30, to $360 million, and said it expected losses to increase throughout 2008.

headline: A Roosevelt Island Ruin Sinks Further Into Decay
text: The hauntingly abandoned, Gothically forbidding Smallpox Hospital on Roosevelt Island  perhaps New York City’s most romantic ruin  turned far less romantic and even more ruined last month when part of its crumbling gray stone facade fell to the ground.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Dec. 19 about the record producer Joel Dorn, using information provided by a spokesman for a record company with which he was affiliated, referred incorrectly to a survivor, Faye Rosen. She was Mr. Dorn’s wife, not his companion. The obituary also misstated the relationship of the recording executive Nesuhi Ertegun, whom Mr. Dorn wrote to as a young man, to Atlantic Records in its early days. Mr. Ertegun joined Atlantic after it was founded by his brother, Ahmet Ertegun, and Herb Abramson. He did not found it with his brother.

headline: Japan: Prisons to Adapt to Older Inmates
text: Japan will build wards exclusively for older inmates at three prisons to deal with the rise in the prison population 60 and older, the Justice Ministry announced. The wards will include the kind of ramps, handrails and other fixtures found in Onomichi Prison, in western Japan, now the country’s only prison with a ward for older inmates. The number of older people convicted of mostly nonviolent crimes, like shoplifting, has risen sharply because of a breakdown in family ties and a weakening of the social safety net. From 2000 to 2006, while the total population of Japanese 60 and older increased by 17 percent, prisoners in that age group swelled by 87 percent.

headline: More Confusion for Frockmakers
text: So it appears that none of the nominees or presenters for the Golden Globes will have to worry about what to wear on Jan. 13. Alan Rosenberg, the president of the Screen Actors Guild, said members would not cross the picket line to attend the awards event, at the Beverly Hilton. There had been some thought, or hope, that the ceremony would go on, without being televised, and we could at least see the peacock display and the nominees could have their moment. But of course that would mean a tremendous loss of revenue. Anyway, it looks like Wanda McDaniel of Armani was on the money when she characterized the appointments she has scheduled with actresses for this weekend as “faux fittings.” Fashion houses and stylists are going through the motions. But what choice do they have? Come tomorrow or Monday, it could be a different story. The SAG statement, on the face of it, was pretty blunt. The next move seems to belong to NBC. Meanwhile, designers are facing deadlines of their own: the Paris couture starts in two weeks, and the N.Y. shows on Feb. 1.

headline: The View of the Giants From Florida
text: Let’s take a look at what they are saying about the Giants down south as the first-round playoff game against the Buccaneers nears. It has been a turnaround season for Tampa Bay, and Chris Harry of The Orlando Sentinel examines what went right and what went wrong, saying that the signing of quarterback Jeff Garcia was only part of a collective excavation project. In a slideshow preview of the game, The Tampa Tribune says the Giants are the Buccaneers’ toughest challenge since playing the Colts in Week 5. The Buccaneers’ defense is facing a “tall task” in stopping Plaxico Burress, according to The Tribune. The St. Petersburg Times says the “tall order” for Tampa is running back Brandon Jacobs. Similarly, the Buccaneers’ Web site puts the focus on the battle in the trenches.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Jan. 6

Mr. Huckabee appears on CNN’s “Late Edition,” ABC’s “This Week,” and “Fox News Sunday.” His relatively high number of television bookings aligns with his overall campaign emphasis on media appearances over extensive campaign travel. (It’s cheaper too.)Tied for second place on the shows at least are Mr. Huckabee’s two top rivals, Mitt Romney and Senator John McCain. Mr. Romney shares Mr. Huckabee’s face time with Chris Wallace on Fox and George Stephanopoulos on ABC. Mr. McCain gets Tim Russert of NBC’s “Meet the Press” and Bob Schieffer of CBS’s “Face the Nation” all to himself.

headline: The Grapes of Wrath
text: It was mid-July, 10 days into a heat wave so unrelenting that it had penetrated the thick stone walls of my parents’ Umbrian farmhouse, and there was no relief to be found, indoors or out. There was also a big fresh Mediterranean fish waiting in the fridge  its name, in Italian, is ombrina. But not one of us felt like eating, let alone going anywhere near a stove. By the time the sun finally set that night, it was nearly 9:30; we jumped into the pool, cooled off and suddenly realized we were famished. Improvising with what was at hand, my mother, a superb cook, braised the ombrina in a quick sauce of tomatoes, garlic and saffron, and then, reaching for the nearest bottle, splashed some grappa into the pan  and so a favorite family recipe was born.

headline: The Siren Call of the River to a Commuter on the Shore
text: ARI HOFFNUNG, a rosy-cheeked 34-year-old bundled in a dark overcoat over his business suit, boarded the 7:50 a.m. ferry from Yonkers as a rising sun bathed the Palisades in golden light. Seagulls squawked overhead, and whitecaps licked the edge of the yellow, high-speed catamaran as it glided smoothly down the Hudson River.

headline: Letters: The Huckabee Factor
text: Zev Chafets (Dec. 16) reports that Mike Huckabee spoke with “bitterness” about my lack of endorsement of his candidacy. For the record, as a matter of policy during my 19-plus years of service at the Southern Baptists’ Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission, I have not endorsed  and will not endorse  candidates for political office. I have defended various candidates when they have been, in my opinion, attacked unfairly. In recent weeks I have defended Huckabee, Mitt Romney and Fred Thompson, among others. Defending against criticism is not endorsement.

headline: Building Suspense Along the Trail of an Invisible Man
text: YOU don’t ride with the devil in “Zodiac,” that rare American movie that doesn’t turn murder into kicks. With cool intelligence, David Fincher’s masterly opus tracks the years-long efforts by several detectives and newspapermen, including Robert Graysmith (who wrote the book on which the movie is based), to find the killer  the self-anointed Zodiac  who committed a string of murders in Northern California starting in the late 1960s and perhaps continuing into the early 1970s. For these men the search is not only about seeking knowledge but also seeking justice. It is consciousness and conscience both.

headline: Storm Covers Wide Swath of West Coast
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Residents across the West Coast struggled Saturday to dig out and dry out after a thumping storm system, even as more snow and rain bore down on towns from the Puget Sound to the California border with Mexico.

headline: Paperback Row
text: FINAL EXAM: A Surgeon’s Reflections on Mortality, by Pauline W. Chen. (Vintage, $13.95.) To doctors, who are in the business of saving lives, death represents failure. “I learned from many of my teachers and colleagues to suspend or suppress any shared human feelings for my dying patients,” Chen, a liver surgeon, writes. “These lessons in denial and depersonalization began as early as my first encounter with death in the gross anatomy dissection lab.” In these thoughtful, moving essays on the relationship between medical practice and the emotional events surrounding death, Chen draws on her 15 years of clinical experience to inform a discussion of the failings of medical education (and possible remedies) and to share stories about dying patients and their families.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE FALL OF 2001: Islam was not much on America’s mind on Sunday, Sept. 9, 2001  two days before 9/11. The No. 1 book on The Times’s nonfiction list that week was Stephen E. Ambrose’s “Wild Blue: The Men and Boys Who Flew the B-24s Over Germany,” followed at No. 2 by David McCullough’s “John Adams.” (The book at the top of the fiction list was “Valhalla Rising,” by Clive Cussler.) Within a few weeks, though, the picture began to shift. Among the books that received special attention and began to appear on the hardcover nonfiction list that fall  all of them written before 9/11  were: “Islam,” by Karen Armstrong, first published in 2000; “Germs,” a book about biological weapons by the New York Times reporters Judith Miller, Stephen Engelberg and William Broad; “Twin Towers: The Life of New York City’s World Trade Center,” by Angus Kress Gillespie; “The Lost Son: A Life in Pursuit of Justice,” a memoir by Bernard Kerik; and “Final Days,” a critical book about the Clinton White House by Barbara Olson, who died aboard a hijacked jetliner on Sept. 11. After these books, the deluge.

headline: Mermaids Past and Present Keep Things Real

headline: Expensive Boo-Boo
text: When my husband developed a leg infection, his physician prescribed the wrong antibiotic. The insurance company, recognizing the mistake, refused to cover the prescription’s $573 cost. But I had already filled it, and my husband had taken a dose. I think our doctor should reimburse us. (The correct treatment for this common infection was immediately prescribed by two other doctors.) My husband demurs. You?  NAME WITHHELD, LOS ANGELES

headline: The Pragmatic Caliphs
text: Many Westerners think the world would be safer if it were less Muslim, more Western. And in the Middle East and beyond, many Muslims are horrified by our arrogance; a tiny minority respond with violence. Yet the so-called clash of civilizations, as Zachary Karabell’s important new book demonstrates, draws strength from a profoundly partial reading of history. “Peace Be Upon You” is a polemic in the service of peace  readable, accessible and, maybe, indispensable.

headline: They Didn’t Stop Thinking About Tomorrow
text: AFTER so many years of fear and loathing, we had almost forgotten what it’s like to feel good about our country. On Thursday night, that long-dormant emotion came rushing back, like an old dream that pops out of the deepest recesses of memory, suddenly as clear as light. “They said this day would never come,” said Barack Obama, and yet here, right before us, was indisputable evidence that it had.

headline: Home-Style Colombian

headline: Beyond the Burka
text: The veiled, oppressed Muslim woman has become overexposed. American book clubs consume her memoirs. Novels about her, as long as they are bleak, appear in the windows of our bookstores. Intellectuals argue over how she should be described and who can save her.

headline: Cosmetic Imperatives
text: Some beauty products simply get the job done, while others become obsessions. Here are some of winter’s top-selling, most coveted items.

headline: A Movie Star for All Eras, Even the Present
text: SUCH a deep streak of nostalgia runs through George Clooney’s career that he seems to be working his way through every decade of the 20th century.

headline: Her Objects of Desire
text: WHEN I was 20 and married and I desired a life in the fast lane of Los Angeles, I used to collect objects. After these phases and others passed me by, I gave away the wedding gifts, the plastic couch in honor of veganism, a mattress, linens, two bar stools, one director’s chair, my sister’s handmade shelves, the hanging things on the walls and the electronic devices of the ’80s. Not that much, and yet all was offered to my secretary, a new arrival to Los Angeles. She brought her tall male friend along to take whatever they wanted. What they didn’t take, Goodwill did.

headline: Man Killed by the Police After a Chase
text: The police shot and killed a Queens man during a struggle early Saturday after he ran from officers seeking to question him and pointed a loaded pistol at one of them, the authorities said.

headline: School Lessons, by Way of Japan and India

headline: Long Pole in the Tent
text: “The most difficult aspect of developing a weapons program,” said President Bush, trying to counter the C.I.A.’s N.I.E.-jerk relaxation response to Iran’s nuclear ambitions, “or as some would say, the long pole in the tent, is enriching uranium.”

headline: Private Cash Sets Agenda for Urban Infrastructure
text: NEW HAVEN  Conceived as a freeway, the Route 34 Connector still promises to whisk motorists across New Haven as they exit Interstate 95. But in less than a mile, the three broad lanes abruptly end, forcing traffic onto side roads that skirt the unbuilt right-of-way  a wasteland of elongated asphalt parking lots and scrub grass.

headline: New and Improved Stations Top List of Rail Projects to Benefit Riders
text: JAMES PETERS has been taking the New Jersey Transit train from Trenton for more than a decade, so long that he remembers when it used to be “just a Roy Rogers with a train station.”

headline: Racing Toward the Sun
text: PUT aside for the moment the matter of wretched excess. Nobody needs 480 horsepower or a top speed just south of 200 miles an hour, unless he plans to overtake a jetliner before liftoff. And nobody has to spend $136,000 for an invigorating sports car experience.

text: Los Angeles

text: COMEDY

text: Film

headline: Who Will You Be This Summer?
text: IT will surprise nobody that the most competitive wave of high school graduates is now the most competitive wave of college students. The generation that made admissions a contact sport bring the same sharp elbows to how they spend their summers. Or, put in a form that parents would understand: “Internship” is to “first job” as “community service” is to “college.”

headline: Frustrated Sellers, Take Note
text: ON Jan. 27, Fereydoun and Dolores Fani’s five-bedroom three-bath Stony Point colonial is scheduled to be sold at auction. This is not because the house is in foreclosure, but because the Fanis have been waiting 18 months for a buyer to come along, have already moved elsewhere and are tired of paying for two homes.

headline: As All-American as the Matzo Ball
text: IN 1654, when the Portuguese seized Recife, Brazil, from the Dutch, many Jews fled; 23 of them ended up in New Amsterdam, now New York City.

headline: Scratch Bloomberg’s Surface, Find a Democrat
text: Hundreds of miles from the hustings of New Hampshire lurks a possible presidential candidate who supports gay marriage, abortion rights and stricter regulation of handguns. Who doesn’t mind taxing the rich on their income or big companies on their carbon emissions. Who says that deporting illegal immigrants would destroy the nation’s economy. And who is not necessarily averse to adding more bureaucrats to the government payroll.

headline: Humor Sliced and Diced
text: TRACY MORGAN wore a New York Yankees ball cap and a BerdMan sweatshirt, but more important was what he was not wearing, made clear when the waitress at Benihana approached for his drink order.

headline: Quiz Answers
Don’t Urbanize the National Park Service
text: To the Editor:

headline: A City Reveling in Contrasts
text: BIG is to small, as day is to night, as rich is to poor, as New York is to ... ? New York, of course.

headline: And Out of the Corner of My Eye...
text: I HAVE preached to my 17-year-old son that a person’s true character is revealed by his actions when he thinks there’s no chance of being rewarded for them or little danger of getting caught. I myself have failed this litmus test.

headline: Against Hoyas, Rutgers Can’t Outscore Its Football Team
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Georgetown does not simply defeat its opponents, it smothers them. The Hoyas win with a stifling defense and just enough offense, which was, once again, a successful formula Saturday against Rutgers as Georgetown picked up an easy victory in its Big East opener.

headline: A Doyenne of All-in-One Living
text: WHEN Barbara Kling tells you that she turned down the opportunity to buy her spacious three-bedroom, two-bath apartment at 100 West 57th Street when the building went co-op in 1977, your first reaction is to feel sorry for her. After all, she missed her chance to buy at a low insider price that would have allowed her to make a killing today. (She said a similar apartment recently sold for $1.5 million.)

headline: Next-Gen Taliban
text: One day last month, I climbed onto a crowded rooftop in Quetta, near Pakistan’s border with Afghanistan, and wedged myself among men wearing thick turbans and rangy beards until I could find a seat. We converged on the rooftop that afternoon to attend the opening ceremony for Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam’s campaign office in this dusty city in the southwestern province of Baluchistan. Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam, better known by its abbreviation, J.U.I., is a hard-line Islamist party, widely considered a political front for numerous jihadi organizations, including the Taliban. In the last parliamentary elections here, in 2002, the J.U.I. formed a national coalition with five other Islamist parties and led a campaign that was pro-Taliban, anti-American and spiked with promises to implement Shariah, or Islamic law. The alliance, known as the Muttahida Majlis-e-Amal, or M.M.A., won more than 10 percent of the popular vote nationwide  the highest share ever for an Islamist bloc in Pakistan. The alliance formed governments in two of the country’s four provinces, including Baluchistan.

headline: Picketing Feet Could Scuff Red Carpets
text: AN Oscar, as anyone who buys a movie ticket can tell you, has strong symbolic value. Beyond its shape  next to a Coke bottle, it is one of the most recognizable artifacts of Western civilization  Oscar’s public profile means that the telecast sometimes serves as a platform for agendas that have nothing to do with movies. But the Oscars have never been held hostage quite like this.

headline: Salad Days
text: Traditionally, Epiphany, or Jan. 6th, is the day that homes are stripped of Christmas greenery. In my house, I drag out the tree and bring in fresh greens  in the form of salads. After the holidays, a pretty head of lettuce can make all those sugar cookies fade like a bad dream.

headline: Letters: The Clinton Referendum
text: As a lifelong liberal baby boomer, I will say that there is little in Clintonism that conforms to my ideology (Matt Bai, Dec. 23). But what I realized in 1992, as I moved from despising Bill Clinton to actively working on his election campaign, was that he was fundamentally asking me to grow up. He was saying that despite whatever my (or his) utopian dreams for America might be, and no matter how eloquently even the most articulate liberals might convey the short- vs. long-term cost-benefit analysis, the vast majority of Americans were unwilling to go there. The added fact that many liberal candidates were inarticulate in selling this message, while refusing to embrace Clintonesque phrases like “People who work hard and play by the rules” or “End welfare as we know it,” is one reason I’ve spent most of my life with a Republican in the White House. While these expressions don’t conform to my personal ideology (talking about welfare reform is outrageous without a discussion of corporate welfare), their use was an attempt by Clinton to bring back into the Democratic Party what had been lost to “Reagan Democrats.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Correction: A ‘City of Churches’ Emerges as a Culinary Hub
text: The Next Stop column on Dec. 23 about Adelaide, South Australia’s capital and a culinary hub, misidentified its coastal location. It is on the Gulf St. Vincent on the Indian Ocean coast; it is not along the Pacific coast.

headline: Cakes and Ale? No, Port
text: Fonseca Bin No. 27 port evokes a Chesterfield wing chair, fireplace and W. Somerset Maugham novel.

headline: Settling In After an 8-Mile Move
text: IN an early review of Mama Tucci, there’s a photo of the restaurant a few months after its opening in 2004: a narrow storefront on Main Street in Madison, with closely spaced tables, hanging plants and a blackboard with a scrawled list of specials.

headline: A Coen Brother Scales Down to the Stage
text: ETHAN COEN tries very hard to ration his conversation. But he has two different laughs.

headline: Church and State
text: To the Editor:

headline: Randolph Returns; Losing Never Left
text: HOUSTON  The question was a little convoluted and complex, but the premise was clear enough: how could the Knicks play so well against the San Antonio Spurs on Friday, add a highly productive Zach Randolph on Saturday and yet be soundly beaten by a lesser Houston Rockets team?

headline: Mission of Mercy, Ocean of Guilt
text: AT 2 p.m. on a Friday afternoon, I am racing through a Toys “R” Us, searching for Winnie the Pooh gift wrap. Not the Disney version, with Pooh in the tacky T-shirt, but the original Shepard illustrations, where Pooh is naked, but so British you don’t notice.

headline: Knicks Seem Small Next to Yao and Rockets
text: HOUSTON  Yao Ming towered over Eddy Curry, lorded over Zach Randolph and generally stood in the way of the Knicks’ latest attempt at progress.

headline: We Agreed to Agree, and Forgot to Notice
text: AS Martin Bunzl was getting on a plane in 1966, something happened that would stick in his head for the next four decades. A man taking his seat looked around and announced, loudly enough for all to hear: “Oh, geez, not a Negro stewardess.”

headline: Can Burt’s Bees Turn Clorox Green?
text: IN the summer of 1984, Burt Shavitz, a beekeeper in Maine, picked up Roxanne Quimby, a 33-year-old single mother down on her luck, as she hitchhiked to the post office in Dexter, Me. More than a dozen years Ms. Quimby’s senior, the guy locals called “the bee-man” sold honey in pickle jars from the back of his pickup truck. To Ms. Quimby, he seemed to be living an idyllic life in the wilderness (including making his home inside a small turkey coop).

headline: In Newark, Remembering the Dead
text: Aljira, a feisty alternative art space in Newark, often shows artwork that has a razor-sharp social and political edge. Its latest exhibition, “Rest in Peace,” by Helen M. Stummer, is probably the most stark and arresting yet.

headline: For Those Who Remember the Neediest, Helping Others Is Its Own Reward
text: Since Nov. 4, The New York Times has been printing daily profiles looking into the lives of New Yorkers who have overcome hardships with help from one of the seven agencies supported by The Neediest Cases Fund.

headline: If You Go . . .
text: WHEN Mary Hardy of Larchmont, N.Y., began visiting prospective colleges last year with her son, she had no idea how many campuses they would cover or how much it would cost. It wasn’t until their fourth campus, and a stay at an expensive Boston hotel, that she realized, “Wow, this is really going to add up.”

headline: Oh, My Poor Arthritic Ski Club
text: Waitsfield, Vt.

headline: Aesthetic Heft, Sized for a Snow Globe
text: FOR uncounted centuries artists have tried to fit reality’s scale into smaller confines: framed canvases, chiseled statues, portraits on ivory. Walter Martin and Paloma Muñoz have climbed into their own distinct niche: known collaboratively as Martin & Muñoz, they sculpture and arrange miniature, three-dimensional scenes of alienation, dread and dark humor and set them inside snow globes.

headline: Minus Housing, U.S. Job Cuts Look Tame
text: When it came to job cuts last year, a kind of economic firewall seemed to protect most industries from the ravages of the housing crisis.

headline: Notre Dame Recruits Shine in All-Star Game
text: SAN ANTONIO  Before the start of this season, Notre Dame fans expected their inexperienced Fighting Irish to play in a bowl game.

headline: Family Van With More
text: WHILE the Stout Scarab suggests the origins of the minivan, the Nissan Forum could be its future. A concept vehicle that will be displayed at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit this month, the Forum represents an effort to escape the dull bread-loaf design of minivans.

headline: Must a Co-op Owner Install New Pipes?
text: Q I’m a shareholder in a co-op. I would like to spruce up the bathroom by retiling it and replacing the old vanity and sink. I have been told by the managing agent, however, that this work will require replacing all pipes under the floor and in the walls to the point where they connect to the plumbing risers. This will be a substantial additional cost.

headline: Arabic Lessons
text: One dark afternoon last winter, after too many hours spent studying Arabic verbs, I found myself staring uncomprehendingly at a video on my computer screen. An Arab man was holding forth tediously, his words half drowned by the rain outside. At first all I could make out was the usual farrago of angry consonants and strangled vowels. No progress there. Then, at last, the letters lighted up at the back of my brain.

headline: Can Foundations Take the Long View Again?
text: AS business leaders like Ted Turner, Bill Gates and George Soros have moved vast swaths of their private wealth into the philanthropic sector, market expertise has migrated there, too. As a result, foundation directors, trustees and advisers from corporate America have taken a stance that the return on charitable dollars should be tangible and measurable, and should drive capital flow in much the same way that earnings figures do in commerce.

headline: In an Unlikely Part of the Country, a Tiny Huckabee Movement Is Born
text: This is how Bill Garcia became what he calls a Huckabeezer.

headline: Chopra Makes Grand Entrances, On and Off Course
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii  When Daniel Chopra strode into the lobby of the Ritz-Carlton Kapalua on Friday night, well-coiffed heads turned and well-heeled patrons watched. Clad in a form-fitting shirt hanging out of snug Euro designer jeans, Chopra glided across the woven rugs and dark hardwood floors of the reception area toward the Alaloa Lounge to greet some friends, all the while smiling at strangers.

headline: 1977 Exam Opened Escape Route Into China’s Elite
text: BEIJING  In the autumn of 1977, as relative calm returned to China after the decade-long chaos of the Cultural Revolution, An Ping was laboring in the countryside where she had been sent, like millions of other young people from the cities, to learn from the peasants.

headline: Record-Setting Rice Leads Rutgers Over Ball State
text: TORONTO  He had been making Ball State tacklers miss all day during a record-setting performance. And in the news conference after Rutgers’s 52-30 victory Saturday over the Cardinals at the International Bowl, Ray Rice, the Scarlet Knights’ sensational running back, was just as elusive concerning his future.

headline: Killing in Nicaragua Makes Spectacle of the Courts
text: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Somebody raped and strangled Doris Jiménez in her tiny clothing boutique 14 months ago. Ever since, Nicaragua’s justice system has found itself on trial.

headline: 911 Has a Long Memory
text: RIVERHEAD

headline: Correction
text: An essay on Dec. 16 about J. M. Coetzee misspelled the given name of the cultural critic who once referred to him as “the Greta Garbo of South African literature.” He is Shaun de Waal, not Sean. The essay also referred incorrectly to the student with whom the protagonist of Coetzee’s novel “Disgrace” was involved in a sexual harassment scandal. The novel doesn’t specify her race; she is never described as “colored.” The religion to which T. S. Eliot, whom Coetzee discussed in a 1991 essay, became a convert was also misstated. It was Anglicanism, not Catholicism.

headline: To Walk a Landscape Is to Know It
text: “COMES over one an absolute necessity to move. And what is more, to move in some particular direction. A double necessity then: to get on the move, and to know whither.” The unforgettable opening of D. H. Lawrence’s “Sea and Sardinia,” a work written in six weeks flat. “Why can’t one sit still?” he asks.

headline: Anyone Can Make Maps
text: AS popular as global positioning satellite devices have become  they were the fastest selling electronic item last Christmas  consumers still largely use them to get from Point A to Point B.

headline: Israeli Army Operation in Nablus Is Suspended
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Army wound up a large-scale, three-day operation in the northern West Bank city of Nablus on Saturday evening, an army spokesman said.

headline: Canada Wins 4th Junior Title in a Row
text: Matt Halischuk gave Canada its fourth consecutive world junior title Saturday night, scoring 3 minutes 36 seconds into overtime for a 3-2 victory over Sweden in Pardubice, Czech Republic. In the third-place game, Russia beat the United States, 4-2.

headline: Lincoln’s Cottage to Open to Public
text: For a quarter of his presidency, Abraham Lincoln did not live in the White House, but rather in a hilltop cottage three miles north in Washington. It was there that he worked on key war and emancipation strategies, and mourned the death of his son Willie. He last visited the cottage  if you can call a 34-room Gothic Revival, above, a cottage  the day before his assassination.

headline: Paris: BlackBlock
text: “Bring me back a present,” the Significant Other says every time I leave for the Paris fashion shows, when what he really means is, “Why aren’t you bringing me?”

headline: Intimate Apparel
text: When my mom took me shopping for my first bra, I was terrified that a classmate might see me. I kept my head low as she guided me through the dense jungle of satin straps and cups, and I nearly died of humiliation when she asked where the training bras were located.

text: Clinton, Conn.

headline: What This Gadget Can Do Is Up to You
text: “HACKERS, welcome! Here are detailed circuit diagrams of our products  modify them as you wish.”

headline: Exit Polling Suggests Election Victory for Georgia’s Pro-Western President
text: TBILISI, Georgia  Georgia’s pro-Western president seemed close on Saturday to winning an early election called after he declared a state of emergency this fall to deal with protesters.

headline: Going for Growth, Even in a Slowdown
text: IN times of economic uncertainty, you would think that investors would flock to traditionally defensive stocks, like shares of stable utility companies or value-oriented dividend-payers.

headline: The Clash
text: It would have been unlike Samuel P. Huntington to say “I told you so” after 9/11. He is too austere and serious a man, with a legendary career as arguably the most influential and original political scientist of the last half century  always swimming against the current of prevailing opinion.
