headline: Comic Relief via Shortwave
text: “THE great joke of our era is that this is called the information age,” said the actor and humorist Harry Shearer. In other words, if information is free, you get what you pay for. Since childhood, Mr. Shearer has tried to get the genuine article, even if that has meant spending a little time and effort to do so.

headline: Online System Will Let Riders Report Lost Items
text: AFTER John Guastella of Dix Hills dashed from a Long Island Rail Road train recently to avoid missing his stop, he could not find the eyeglasses that had been in his lap.

headline: Army Lets a Felon Join Up, but N.Y.P.D. Will Not
text: NAWA, Afghanistan  On the day after he completed a one-year sentence at the Rikers Island jail, Osvaldo Hernandez walked into an Army recruiting office in Elmhurst, Queens. He was a felon with a plan to change his life.

headline: A Swashbuckling Violinist, Fresh From the 1700s
text: Dobbs Ferry

headline: I’ve Been in That Club, Just Not in Real Life
text: IT began as a typical night on the Lower East Side. A few weeks ago a crowd of young urbanites gathered in the bowels of Cake Shop, the pastry cafe cum music club on Ludlow Street, to see a performance by an indie-rock band, the Virgins. A couple of minutes into the show the subterranean space was already packed to capacity and smelling of stale beer, so I left.

headline: Iowa Victories Scramble the Money Game, Too
text: Victories by Senator Barack Obama and Mike Huckabee in Iowa have not only upset political calculations, they have also upset the money game and spurred a growing flood of donations for these candidates while making fund-raising trickier for the rest.

headline: Right Hand Man
text: As a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and former speechwriter for President Bush, you’re surprisingly critical of him in your new book, claiming he has appointed “consistently mediocre people” to important jobs and made “a shambles” of the Iraq war. Do you see the book as a mea culpa? No. Mea culpa is a kind of hand-wringing, breast-beating, woe-is-me attitude that I don’t share. What I am saying is that there is exhaustion, intellectual exhaustion on the part of Republicans and conservatives.

headline: Not Too Famous to Mind Her Mum
text: LONDON

headline: Emily Ryan, Michael Escott
text: Emily Clare Ryan, the daughter of Carol L. Ryan and E. Peter Ryan of West New York, N.J., was married on Saturday to Michael James Escott, a son of the late Mimi Escott and the late Michael Escott, who lived in New York. The Rev. Stephen Katsouros performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

headline: What Is It About Mormonism?
text: Our post-denominational age should be the perfect time for a Mormon to become president, or at least the Republican nominee. Mormons share nearly all the conservative commitments so beloved of the evangelicals who wield disproportionate influence in primary elections. Mormons also embody, in their efficient organizational style, the managerial competence that the party’s pro-business wing considers attractive. For the last half-century, Mormons have been so committed to the Republican Party that the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints once felt the need to clarify that Republican affiliation is not an actual condition of church membership.

headline: Aliza Pressman, Craig Chosiad
text: Aliza Michal Pressman, a daughter of Beverly Pressman and Rabbi Daniel Pressman of San Jose, Calif., is to be married on Sunday to Craig Isaac Chosiad, the son of Barbara and Jonathan Chosiad of Stoughton, Mass. The bride’s father will officiate at the Decathlon Club in Santa Clara, Calif.

headline: Commanding Attention in or Out of Costume
text: IT’S sometimes hard to remember that the British actress Keira Knightley is only 22. Not that she looks or acts old, exactly. She still has the same gangly teenage frame that earned her the label “sexiest tomboy beanpole.” Not in the least shy about undressing, however, she has lately appeared nearly naked on the cover of Interview and, accompanied by a strategically placed bowler, in an ad for Chanel.

headline: A Sense of Duty Takes Shape During Dinnertime Discussions
text: Starting when she was 9, Claire Gaudiani’s father impressed upon her the importance of being informed. At dinner they would discuss current events.

headline: Many Without Power Amid California Storm
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Residents all across the West Coast struggled on Saturday to dig and dry out from a thumping winter storm system, even as more snow and drenching rain bore down on soaked towns from Puget Sound to San Diego.

headline: When the Grooves of a Lifetime Start to Feel Like a Rut
text: IT started out innocently enough for James Dier. He was about 18, and growing up in Long Beach, Calif., he had attended record fairs and gone home with something rare from Madness or the Specials. This was bigger: an ad in the newspaper from a retired judge who was selling his son-in-law’s entire collection  300 old records for $100.

headline: Finding a Home on Long Island
text: To the Editor:

headline: Film | The Week Ahead
text: Film

headline: From Closet to Condo
text: DURING his first two years out of law school, Akinyemi Akiwowo was satisfied rooming with two friends in a Hoboken, N.J., rental.

headline: The Lost Garden
text: The Umayyad dynasty of Spain, which dominated the Iberian Peninsula for almost 300 years, remained, for all its high cultural sophistication and sheer military might, an empire rooted in nostalgia. Like its founder, Abd al-Rahman I, who composed poignant lyrics evoking the palm groves of his youth in the summer palace of Rusafa, in distant Syria, its poets and chroniclers looked yearningly eastward. They lived in Granada or Seville among feuding Berber tribesmen and conquered Visigoths, but when they wrote their pens flew home to the lost gardens of their origins. When Abd al-Rahman I was proclaimed “amir,” or ruler, of the dynasty on May 15, 756, he was not quite 25 years old, but he had already had long training in the backward glance. He, and the dynasty he created, were fortuitous survivors of a long succession of hairbreadth escapes.

headline: A Breed Apart
text: The art world has long been aware of the singular beauty and intensity of outsider art, also known as art brut  work by self-taught artists, or those with mental disabilities. These are artists working outside the mainstream, historically having little or no contact with art galleries and museums.

headline: One Generation Got Old, One Generation Got Soul
text: SIXTEEN students sat around a table in the Manhattan cafeteria of the New School discussing where commas should go. They were rewriting, for the third time, a mission statement for their chapter of Students for a Democratic Society, the activist group that had been dormant for nearly 40 years. They wanted the document to be collectively produced, but after more than three weeks of communal drafting, no one seemed particularly content with the results.

headline: Does the Road to Princeton Run Through Elizabeth?
text: Elizabeth High School anchors an aging industrial city, about 20 miles southwest of midtown Manhattan, that has become the first stop for many immigrant families in search of a better life. With more than 5,000 students, it’s one of the largest public high schools in New Jersey. Only a quarter of them attend four-year colleges, with the rest dispersing to two-year colleges, the military  Elizabeth is popular with recruiters  or the lower ranks of the work force.

headline: Cartoon Villains
text: Is there such a thing as Islamophobia? To show there is, Peter Gottschalk and Gabriel Greenberg cite a talk show host for CNN Headline News telling Keith Ellison, the first Muslim American congressman: “I have been nervous about this interview with you, because what I feel like saying is, ‘Sir, prove to me that you are not working with our enemies.’” Presumably, the host believed that his viewers shared this anxiety  and popular culture seems to bear that out, according to Gottschalk and Greenberg. “Many members of the media,” they write, “characterize Muslims as Muslims to the exclusion of any other aspect of their identity.”

headline: Public to Weigh In on Leaf Blower Ban
text: A PROPOSED ban on using gas-powered leaf blowers in Yonkers in the summer is scheduled for a public debate Tuesday, after which the City Council is likely to make it official  for a second time.

headline: Dance | The Week Ahead
text: Dance

headline: Palms and Sand, but No Boutique Hotels (Yet)
text: AS founder of the stately but weathered South Florida burg of Hollywood, Joseph Wesley Young called his “dream city” a place designed to welcome everyone “from the opulent at the top of the industrial and social ladder to the most humble of working people.”

headline: Scores Fall, but Weir Holds His Ground
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii  The rain stopped, the winds calmed and the golfers in the $5.5 million Mercedes-Benz Championship reacted accordingly. Permitted to lift, clean and place their golf balls for the first time all week, they unleashed a full-on assault on the defenseless Plantation Course at Kapalua on Saturday, lowering the field stroke average by one full shot and raising the bar for anyone who hopes to claim the $1.1 million first-place check Sunday.

headline: Freedom at Gunpoint
text: In early 1798 the Directory, the oligarchy that was ruling revolutionary France, ordered its top general, Napoleon Bonaparte, to plan the invasion of England. Instead, Napoleon organized and carried out the invasion of Egypt, which became the first modern incursion by the West into the Middle East.

headline: Slips, Falls and Potholes
text: Slips, Falls and Potholes

headline: Top 10 Films: Give Us a List, Please
text: To the Editor:

headline: Miles Is Thriving by Making Quick Decisions That Work Out
text: BATON ROUGE, La.  On Dec. 24 every year, Louisiana State Coach Les Miles clears out a few afternoon hours to do all of his Christmas shopping. He even bought his wife’s engagement ring on Dec. 24 years ago.

headline: Borges and the Foreseeable Future
text: THE Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges might seem an unlikely candidate for Man Who Discovered the Internet. A fusty sort who from the 1930s through the 1950s spent much of his time as a chief librarian, Borges (1899-1986) valued printed books as artifacts and not just for the words they contained. He frequently set his stories in a pretechnological past and was easily enthralled by the authority of ancient texts.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: DIARY OF A BAD YEAR, by J. M. Coetzee. (Viking, $24.95.) Coetzee’s new novel follows the late career of one Señor C, who, like Coetzee himself, is a South African writer transplanted to Australia and the author of a novel titled “Waiting for the Barbarians.”

headline: 36 Hours in Melbourne, Australia
text: IT’S hard not to feel some sympathy for Melbourne. Often overlooked by travelers as they sprint their way through Australia’s Big Three tourist attractions — the dazzling metropolis of Sydney, the startlingly beautiful Great Barrier Reef and the historic Aboriginal site of Uluru — this laid-back city is a place that takes some time to appreciate. But Melbourne slowly grows on you as you stroll around the immaculately preserved Victorian-era downtown or along the revitalized Yarra waterfront, or linger over a cup of “flat white” in one of trendy cafes on Chapel Street (where the very mention of the name Starbucks is greeted with horror). And in January, at least, it has something that Sydney and those other places don’t: the Australian Open. This is a country that loves its tennis, and for two weeks, this city feels like a nonstop party, one in which the chances that a local hero may finally take the title are debated each night in the pubs and where even a doubles match played on an outside court and featuring unranked players from the former Eastern Bloc will draw a capacity crowd. Who needs the Opera House?

headline: Jaguars Beat Steelers at Their Own Game
text: PITTSBURGH  A sense of foreboding hung over Pittsburgh last week, with a city and a fan base used to Steelers success confronting their “uh-oh” scenario. The Steelers were division winners, but ticket-holders could not give them away, few fans volunteering to bear witness to what might happen when the Jacksonville Jaguars returned.

headline: As Strike Persists, Late-Night Hosts to Be Guests
text: In an unusual act of unity emerging from the screenwriters’ strike, two of television’s late-night hosts, Jay Leno of NBC and Jimmy Kimmel of ABC, will appear on each other’s shows on Thursday.

headline: The Matzo Show on Rivington Street
text: ALL day long, people ask Leonides Negron if he is Jewish.

headline: The Wheel Keeps on Rolling
text: The N.H.L. is rife with parity this season, but the Detroit Red Wings refuse to play along.

headline: The Dead and the Naked: Conclusion: The Cruel Little Boy With Golden Curls
text: Last week: Professor McPherson explained to Detective Oakwood and Miss Skattergoods that Dick Treekape stole Lee Stones novel after the young mans death.

headline: Six Decades at the Center of Attention, and Counting
text: WHEN the vast baby-boom generation exploded into adolescence in the 1960s, marketers exulted. Advertising consultants, always eager to coin a phrase, began happily explaining to corporations the difference between “teenyboppers” and “counterculture consumers.” Over the next 40 years, as Aquarius aged and the billable hours accumulated, marketers explained that such “market segmentation” techniques were the key to untold riches.

headline: Caught in the Ayatollah’s Web
text: How many men and women have been brutalized in Evin, Tehran’s notorious political prison? Built by the shah, the prison became a ghoulish instrument of the ayatollah after the Iranian revolution in 1979. Although Evin remains the repressive arm of the state, we rarely hear about its victims. (One notable exception is the Iranian-born Canadian photojournalist Zahra Kazemi, who made headlines after she died under interrogation there in 2003.)

headline: Watchful Eyes on Peaceful Streets
text: SHORTLY after 9 on a recent Friday night, Lou Kirchgessner drove his brand-new Acura sedan over a railroad crossing, passing into a desolate industrial area of Glendale, Queens. As the car crawled past the corrugated metal exterior of a Stop and Stor self-storage business, Mr. Kirchgessner noticed what would be the night’s first flutter of excitement.

headline: Words and Art
Fortune’s Sisters
text: THERE is an ancient Chinese myth that people who are destined to meet are connected from birth by invisible red thread. For three Brooklyn mothers who were strangers until a few years ago, the legend has a deeply personal resonance. In early 2004, when they traveled in the same group to adopt year-old girls in China, Martha Laserson, Molly Parker-Myers and Lauren Uram made a discovery that would thread their families together for life.

headline: Many Unhappy Returns
text: Returned Goods

headline: Stirred, Not Shaken
text: Seattle

headline: Blind Faiths
text: Several authors have published books on radical Islam’s threat to the West since that shocking morning in September six years ago. With “The Suicide of Reason,” Lee Harris joins their ranks. But he distinguishes himself by going further than most of his counterparts: he considers the very worst possibility  the destruction of the West by radical Islam. There is a sense of urgency in his writing, a desire to shake awake the leaders of the West, to confront them with their failure to understand that they are engaged in a war with an adversary who fights by the law of the jungle.

headline: To Ski the Lights: Fantastic
text: ON four nights of the year, when the moon is full and if the sky is clear, the ski resort of Zermatt in Switzerland offers the rare opportunity to journey to the 10,180-foot-high top of the Rothorn ski area, enjoy a traditional fondue dinner, and then ski down, with only the glow of the moon and stars to guide the skiers.

headline: 60 Years Removed From War, but Some Hardships Remain
text: Robert Ivker, 43, read an article in December 2006 about Svetlana Ismailov, a caseworker dedicated to helping Holocaust survivors and World War II refugees apply for reparations from Germany.

headline: U.S. Considers New Covert Push Within Pakistan
text: This article is by Steven Lee Myers, David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt.

headline: Stage-Door Johnnies, With an Agenda
text: FOR generations, when a Broadway show has ended, another time-honored drama has begun at the stage door, where crowds collect to get autographs from the stars. “Behind the barricades, please!” guards urge dozens of times a night in an effort to impose a little order on the scene. “We have to keep the sidewalks clear for pedestrian traffic.”

headline: Religious Practice
text: To the Editor:

headline: Letters: Free-Market Sophistry
text: To the Editor: In your Practical Traveler column "Does Low Cost Mean High Risk?" (Dec. 23) the author quotes the safety expert David Learmount as saying low-cost operations have been safer in the United States because “the Federal Aviation Administration heightened its safety oversight ... .”

headline: California Rules
text: California has now sued the Bush administration over its refusal to allow the state to set its own rules controlling greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks. The state’s legal arguments are sound and so is its policy, especially when one considers the White House’s seven-year failure to seriously confront the problem of global warming.

headline: Heirs to a Headache
text: IN New York City real estate, death is the ultimate leveler, evicting the residents of 16-room duplexes as well as those in fifth-floor walk-ups. It doesn’t matter whom you know.

headline: Charlotte Warren, Vincent Spadafora
text: Charlotte Mary Warren and Vincent Gregory Spadafora were married on Saturday at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields in Manhattan. The Rev. Caroline Stacey, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: No Happy Ending in Dickensian Baltimore
text: ANOTHER swath of society  this time the fourth estate  has fallen into the ecosystem of ‘‘The Wire,’’ bringing with it another set of not-so-great expectations.

headline: Web Site Brings Vox Populi to College Football Polling
text: The final college football polls will be released Tuesday. One will be posted at fanspoll.com, a Web site where fans, not sportswriters or coaches, choose their national champion.

headline: Letters: Cookies and Birdseed
text: Judy Maloney’s Lives column (Dec. 23) was touching and funny, but it was a real downer for those of us who are in our 80s. Next Christmas, please try to run something more cheerful. Yes, I hope to be reading The Times then, after carefully checking that I’m out of my robe, dinner is in the oven and the presents are wrapped. Thanks for the to-do list.

headline: Priscilla Fraser, Marcello Cipriano
text: Priscilla MacMillan Lovat Fraser, a daughter of Linda Lovat Fraser and Arthur William Lovat Fraser of New York, was married on Saturday to Marcello Cipriano, the son of Nuala Hallinan of New York and William Cipriano of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Ann Benton Fraser, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. James Church in New York.

headline: That Campaign Button Can Sting You at Work
text: Q. As the presidential elections heat up, many of your co-workers are openly advocating certain candidates. Are these displays of affiliation appropriate in the office?

headline: Job Requirement
text: SCHOOL-supported stints in the workplace have become as familiar a part of the undergraduate world as bleary-eyed cramming for finals. While on most campuses such spells are optional, more than 125 institutions require a dip into the workforce for certain majors, and at least a dozen mandate it for every full-time undergraduate.

headline: Vans and Skechers, Squaring Off in Court
text: It is fairly common for apparel makers to “borrow” ideas from one another, but when it comes to those checkerboard slip-ons, Vans Inc. feels very protective. Vans, a longtime purveyor to surfers and skateboarders, contends that a new offering by Skechers U.S.A. bears far too close a resemblance to its own checked pattern.

headline: A Stylish Cavern, Straddling a Border
text: IMAGINE a narrow, high-ceilinged cavern illuminated by chandeliers, reminiscent of the cave where Anthony Hopkins mentors a young Antonio Banderas in “The Mask of Zorro.” Now imagine it smaller; add a few tables and a dark wood bar, and you’ve got Bistro Basque in Milford.

headline: A New Tower for the Las Vegas Skyline
text: Watch out, Bellagio: Las Vegas’s newest luxury resort, the Palazzo Las Vegas is opening this month.

headline: In Dispute With a Landlord Over a Deposit
text: Q On Nov. 19, my landlord told me that he was raising the rent $100 and that the increase would take effect with the new lease. Our lease was up on Nov. 30, giving us only 11 days to respond. We decided we didn’t want to pay the higher rent, so within 24 hours of being notified of the increase, we let our landlord know that we would not be renewing.

headline: Video Art Thinks Big: That’s Showbiz
text: WE’RE in a house of many tight, messy rooms. In the suburbs? Cyberspace? Hard to say. Anyway, it’s night. A door bangs open. A girl, who is also a boy, dashes in, talking, talking. Other people are already there, in gaudy attire, dire wigs and makeup like paint on de Koonings.

headline: The College Info Fest
text: ABOUT a year ago, a federal commission called on colleges to share more relevant information about themselves, particularly about how well they prepare graduates for the real world. At the same time, the anti-rankings movement, working to undercut the influence of U.S. News & World Report rankings on college selection, has gathered steam.

headline: Street Smarts in Bangkok
text: SURROUNDED by groups of civil servants greedily slurping bowls of soup at Chote Chitr, a tiny, family-run restaurant in the older part of Bangkok, our table soon overflows like a Thai Thanksgiving. The yam makhua, a salad of grilled long eggplants topped with tiny dried shrimps, combines the tang of fresh shallots with expert charring. Prepared by the hand of a skilled griller, the vegetables retain a smoky crunch on the outside, but a first bite pierces the crackling char and reveals a juicy eggplant so sweet it resembles a ripe peach, full of lime juice and fish sauce that has soaked into the flesh.

headline: Red, White, Blue and Green
text: This book is many things. It is, first, a personal chronicle of Imam Hassan Qazwini’s own trajectory from Karbala, Iraq, where he was born in 1964, to exile in Kuwait and Iran, to Dearborn, Mich., where he currently heads the Islamic Center of America. Second, it is an argument for Qazwini’s variety of Shia Islam, rooted in Iraq and Iran and adapted for America. Finally, it is a political statement  in fact, two of them  a plea for Muslim Americans to immerse themselves in the life of the United States while simultaneously deepening their identification as Muslims, and also for a particular outcome in Iraq, where Qazwini’s father, a leading ayatollah, is imam of the mosque of Imam Hussein in Karbala.

headline: Facing New Mileage Rules, Porsche Preps a Hybrid S.U.V.
text: IT is hard to imagine a less likely candidate for the hybrid treatment: the Porsche Cayenne, a 5,000-pound S.U.V. that ranks among the fastest, most powerful trucks ever built.

headline: Keishann Lee and Clyde Haynes Jr.
text: Keishann Celena Lee, a daughter of Vernetta M. Lee and the Rev. Lynroy L. Lee of Jamaica, Queens, was married on Friday to Clyde Burnett Haynes Jr., the son of Gwendolyn Smith-Allen and Mr. Haynes Sr., both of Chicago. Adam Burt, a senior associate pastor with Morning Star New York, an interdenominational ministry based in Manhattan, officiated at All Souls Church in Manhattan.

headline: A Mystery Tour More Menacing Than Magical
text: ONE of the most surreal moments in “Across the Universe,” Julie Taymor’s passionate ’60s fantasia set to the songs of the Beatles, is a three-and-a-half-minute sequence at an Army induction center in New York City. Here is where Max Carrigan (Joe Anderson), a spirited hippie rebel from an upper-middle-class family, reluctantly reports for his physical examination after receiving his draft notice. Because he was told that if he swallowed cotton balls they would show up on an X-ray as spots on his lungs, he quickly ingests one as he enters the building.

headline: Putting the Quantity in Unknown Quantity
text: Mark down these names and check in the next few years to see how many appear in major league box scores:

headline: Arden Myrin and Dan Martin
text: DAN MARTIN realized he was deeply in love when his girlfriend, Arden Myrin, began dancing wildly to piped-in music in the frozen food aisle of a Hollywood supermarket.

headline: Law and Order
text: Seventy-two percent of students see campus safety as “very important” in selecting a college, says a survey being released this month by the Art and Science Group. How safe is any one campus? With so many ways to consider and report crime, statistics are inconclusive. But by federal law, colleges and universities must distribute them annually. Crime rates can be compared at www.ope.ed.gov/security/Search.asp. The graphic, at left, contains recently posted figures from the nation’s largest urban campuses with residence halls.

headline: If You Need a Past, He’s the Guy to Build It
text: THE production designer Jack Fisk has made a specialty of bringing lost worlds to life. In a more literal sense than cinematographers, production designers are responsible for the look of a film  they create its physical reality  and Mr. Fisk’s projects tend to be more physically demanding and more rooted in reality than most.

headline: A Conservatory Stresses the Music and Eliminates the Bills
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Where Once Brooklyn Triumphed, a Tragic Scene
text: It has been 50 years since the Brooklyn Dodgers played their last game at Ebbets Field on Sept. 24, 1957. For residents of the Ebbets Field Apartments  the high-rise housing complex erected at the site of the ballpark in Crown Heights  50 years can seem like ancient history.

headline: Nearby Haven for Ancient Ways
text: ON the sun-drenched mornings in Playón Chico, Panama, the graveyard is the liveliest place in town. Playón Chico’s inhabitants, the Kuna Indians, still hold to their ancient beliefs that each person has a good and a bad spirit, and that after death the good spirit needs help to get to heaven. So every morning, the Kuna women march up the slippery jungle slope to the hilltop graveyard to keep their deceased relatives company and provide a little celestial boost.

headline: Art | The Week Ahead
text: Art

headline: Giants vs. Buccaneers
text: Eli Manning vERSUS Jeff Garcia

headline: In Game of Swings, Last One Tilts to Seahawks
text: SEATTLE  They met near the Seahawks logo at midfield. Tim Ruskell, the general manager and architect of the revamped defense, extended a hand. Matt Hasselbeck, the quarterback and offensive engineer, shook it.

headline: Loose Lips Win Elections
text: Washington

headline: Officials Say Iraqi Soldier Killed 2 U.S. Soldiers
text: BAGHDAD  Two American soldiers killed last month during an operation in the northern city of Mosul appear to have been deliberately shot to death by an Iraqi soldier on patrol with them, senior Iraqi officers said on Saturday.

headline: Television, From Many Sides
text: MOST of the kids in my neighborhood were going to be doctors or lawyers, so I enrolled in pre-med at the State University of New York at Binghamton. But when it was time to take the Medical College Admission Test, I walked into the test center and walked right back out. I really had no interest in being a doctor.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: At Debate, Two Rivals Go After Defiant Clinton
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  It was as if they sensed vulnerability.

headline: Testing Investors’ Faith in State Street
text: FORCED over the last five months to face icky truths about the credit crisis, investors seem to believe we are near the end of a disturbing interlude. How else to explain the 8.2 percent rally last Thursday in shares of the State Street Corporation after it said it would seek fresh capital and add $618 million in reserves to cover lawsuits over subprime mortgage investments it made for some clients?

headline: Caroline Werner and Karl Metzner
text: Caroline Lisa Werner and Karl Metzner were married on Saturday evening at Bridgewaters, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: Kelly Fuhrman, Benjamin Taylor
text: Kelly Colleen Fuhrman and Benjamin Andrew Taylor were married on Saturday evening at Plymouth Congregational Church in Miami. The Rev. Moira McGuinn, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

headline: Huckabee’s Tax Plan Appeals, but Is It Fair?
text: Long before Mike Huckabee, the former Republican governor of Arkansas, began campaigning for president, advocates for replacing the entire federal tax system with a national sales tax were campaigning to convert him to their cause.

headline: Playing the Angles as a Fare Increase Looms
text: FOR four decades, many pennywise subway riders have hatched a common scheme when confronted by a fare increase. Maybe, goes the thinking, it will pay to hoard. The tradition began in 1966, when the subway fare rose to 20 cents from 15, the first increase since the token was introduced in 1953. In the days preceding the rise, frugal riders bought pocketfuls of tokens, delaying the increase for themselves.

headline: Words and Art; ‘Biggest Loser’;  Long-Form Music; Top 10 Films
text: WORDS AND ART

headline: Kinkri Devi Is Dead at 82; Fought Illegal Mining in India
text: Kinkri Devi, an illiterate and impoverished woman who had waged a long and at least partly successful fight against illegal mining and quarrying in the mountainous northern Indian state of Himachal Pradesh, died last Sunday in Chandigarh, India. She was 82.

headline: Democrats in Sync, Mostly
text: DEMOCRATS might be forgiven for wearing shades, so bright are their days just now.

headline: Lights, Camera, Traffic Ticket
text: IS being forewarned really the same as being forearmed? In the case of radar detectors, law enforcement has often argued that such devices encourage drivers to speed; if drivers believe that they won’t be caught, it will embolden them to speed even more frequently. But is the same argument true when it comes to recent technology that warns drivers about the presence of so-called red-light cameras?

headline: Reading the Koran
text: For Muslims the Koran stands as the Text of reference, the source and the essence of the message transmitted to humanity by the creator. It is the last of a lengthy series of revelations addressed to humans down through history. It is the Word of God  but it is not God. The Koran makes known, reveals and guides: it is a light that responds to the quest for meaning. The Koran is remembrance of all previous messages, those of Noah and Abraham, of Moses and Jesus. Like them, it reminds and instructs our consciousness: life has meaning, facts are signs.

headline: Galleries and High-Line Views
text: IF a Manhattan neighborhood ever had a history of being on the far side of the tracks, it would have been the western part of Chelsea at the turn of the last century.

headline: He Came, and He Saw, but Did He Moderate?
text: The first debates after the Iowa caucuses were a crucible for the candidates, but they were also a test of the Gibson Doctrine. ABC’s anchor, Charles Gibson, began the evening with a policy statement: “The less of a moderator, the better.”

headline: Soldiers of Allah
text: Before the Iraq invasion, a young imam offered some chilling advice to Muslims at the University of Toronto: if they could not fight the jihad against America with their souls or their sons, they should fight with their money. The Muslim Students Association told campus authorities that the imam did not represent the true spirit of Islam. With that, the case was closed.

headline: Correction: When an Auld Acquaintance Was Brand-New
text: An article last Sunday about the first ball dropped in Times Square on New Year’s Eve, in 1907, referred incompletely to the origins of the tradition. It was begun by Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The New York Times, as part of an annual promotional celebration outside the Times Building, which had been the newspaper’s home for three years. The first ball was dropped from a structure atop the building.

headline: Art That Walks a Fine Line Between Reality and Illusion
text: In “The Republic,” Plato uses an allegory of prisoners chained in a cave watching shadows on a wall to suggest that the things we believe are real are often only an illusion, a kind of puppet show of real life. To experience true reality we must escape from the cave of ignorance and into the clear light of day.

headline: Celebrating the Bowery’s Proud History, From Weegee to CBGB
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brooklyn Fighter Retains Title
text: Paulie Malignaggi successfully defended his International Boxing Federation junior-welterweight title Saturday night, unanimously outpointing Canada’s Herman Ngoudjo in Atlantic City. Malignaggi (24-1), of Brooklyn, and Ngoudjo (16-2), a native of Cameroon, treated a capacity crowd at Bally’s ballroom to an exciting fight, with the outcome in doubt until Malignaggi took control in the later rounds.

headline: Ghosts That Haunt Pakistan
text: CAMBRIDGE, England

headline: Tribute to an Uncle Strengthens a Family Bond
text: Stanley Rosenfeld was an Army sergeant stationed in the Pacific during World War II. He returned to New York thankful to be in one piece, he said.

headline: A Visionary’s Minivan Arrived Decades Too Soon
text: THE 2008 Chrysler Town & Country minivan offers a removable table and second row seats that turn 180 degrees to face the rear, a feature that Chrysler calls Swivel ’n Go. But in 1936, William Bushnell Stout had already demonstrated such amenities in his eccentric Stout Scarab, an ancestor of the minivan.

headline: A Starring Role in a Family Series
text: BERKELEY, Calif.

headline: Railroad Plans Improvements
text: WITH its ridership expected to go up by 2.4 percent to nearly 82 million people in 2008, and the number of trains projected to increase by 1 percent, or 2,214, to almost 205,000, the Metro-North Railroad has a list of improvements that it plans to start or complete this year.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Page 8 of Arts & Leisure this weekend about Jock Soto’s transition to teaching dance after a career as principal dancer with the New York City Ballet misstates the given name of his father. He is Jose Soto, not Joseph. (Go to Article)

headline: Just in Case
text: The day before the coldest day last week  when the temperature started out at 4 below and rose to 5 above  I knocked the mailbox off its post with the tractor blade. The mail doesn’t come unless the approach to the mailbox is carefully plowed. So after every storm I sculpture a drive-through lane, because I don’t see the point of a day without mail. By then the Internet had been out for a couple of days because the satellite dish on the peak of the roof had filled with wet snow. And I crushed a hen’s egg I had thoughtlessly stuffed in the pocket of my hand-me-down chore coat.

headline: Gabrielle Lansner, Dean Taucher
text: Gabrielle Elizabeth Lansner was married on Friday to Dean Taucher. Elaine Affronti, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated at San Francisco City Hall.

headline: Raines Could Slide Safely Into the Hall on First Try
text: Even if Tim Raines had not been among the greatest base runners in baseball history, he would still be comfortably qualified for the Hall of Fame, which will announce its new members on Tuesday. Raines was regularly among the league leaders in on-base percentage. He also posted excellent slugging percentages for a leadoff man in the low-scoring 1980s and contributed above-average defense. If he had been merely an average base runner, his long and distinguished career would still have been roughly as valuable as those of his contemporaries Dave Winfield and Paul Molitor, who are in the Hall of Fame.

headline: Runaround on Air Safety
text: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has grudgingly released data from a four-year survey of pilots about the safety of American aviation. The information was released the day before New Year’s, with no interpretation of the findings and in a format that is very difficult for outsiders to analyze. If the agency intended to show contempt for the flying public, it succeeded.

headline: The Most Social Guy Who Ever Wanted to Ditch Society
text: SLAB CITY is a paradoxical  and maybe quintessentially American  place. Situated in the scrubby desert hinterlands of Southern California, this sprawling encampment is a community of mavericks, a makeshift society of misfits, anarchists and stubborn individualists. For Chris McCandless, Slab City is a way station on a long, meandering journey he hopes will ultimately take him to Alaska. But when Chris shows up there at a trailer belonging to Rainey and Jan, a pair of wanderers who had picked him up hitchhiking a few months before, his arrival is also a homecoming.

headline: Nell Shanahan, Adam Schwartz
text: Helena Thorsen Shanahan, a daughter of Kristi V. Shanahan and Edward J. Shanahan, both of Wallingford, Conn., was married on Monday evening to Adam Harris Schwartz, the son of Sally Schwartz of Manhattan and the late Joseph W. Schwartz. Rabbi Jon R. Haddon officiated at the Seymour St. John Chapel of Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, with the Rev. John P. Duffell, a Roman Catholic priest, participating.

headline: The Early Days
text: Few events in history have had so swift, profound and far-reaching an impact as the arrival of Islam. Within a mere 15 years of the Prophet Muhammad’s death, in A.D. 632, his desert followers had conquered all the centers of ancient Near Eastern civilization. They had erased a great and enduring regional power, Persia; reduced its brilliant rival, Byzantium, to a rump state; and carved from their territories an empire as vast as that of Rome at its height. Within 100 years, Muslim armies were harrying the frontiers of Tang dynasty China in the east, while 5,000 miles to the west, they had charged across Spain to clash with the Merovingian princes of what is now France.

headline: Crucial Year for Corzine
text: TRENTON

headline: Economic Policy for Tough Times
text: As one economic pillar after another began to buckle in 2007  lending, home sales and house prices, factory orders, holiday shopping  economists kept saying that recession was avoidable as long as employment held up. A job means a paycheck, a paycheck means spending, and spending means hope for the economy.

headline: Caren Raine, Joel Camche
text: Caren Joy Raine and Joel Truex Camche were married on Saturday at the Harvard Club in Manhattan. Bentley Kassal, a retired justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, officiated.

headline: To the Highest Bidder
text: Used to be, the way to land an internship at a hoity-toity magazine was through tenacity, talent or family connections. Now, in the name of giving, you can bid your offspring into a spot at a national publication.

headline: Morozevich, on a Roll Again, Dominates at Russian Superfinal
text: Alexander Morozevich of Russia is almost certainly the most dangerous player in the world.

headline: How to Approach an Estate Sale
text: EVEN when heirs and executors move in harmony, estate sales can lumber along at an achingly slow pace.

headline: V.I.P.
text: THE guidance department of Mamaroneck High School, a public school of 1,454 in affluent Westchester County, gets an airy suite on the top floor of what looks like a glass-and-steel Adirondack lodge. The walls are covered with glossy posters of colleges and universities, from the Gothic grandeur of Harvard and Duke to the leafy campuses of Indiana Bloomington, St. Lawrence and Wheaton. A popular tradition is for seniors to autograph the posters of the places they plan to attend. Some of the posters bear half a dozen signatures, scribbled in thick black marker.

headline: 3 Kings Transform a Church
text: Plainfield

headline: Up Front
text: Islam, one of mankind’s great religions, numbers 1.3 billion adherents around the world, with major communities not only in Cairo, Baghdad, Istanbul, Jakarta and Tehran, but also in London, Paris, Berlin, New York and Washington. Yet most Americans know very little about Muslims, which often means they know very little about their own neighbors. Even public officials with responsibility for our national security  powerful congressmen, top F.B.I. agents  betray an ignorance of the most basic facts about Islam, like the difference between Sunnis and Shiites.

headline: More Than a Bachelor, Less Than a Master
text: WITH a B.A. in studio art from the University of New Hampshire, Erik Evensen worked as a graphic designer for a few years before deciding to pursue painting as a career. He applied to the master’s program at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, in Boston. He was rejected.

headline: Presbyterian Scares North Carolina State
text: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP)  Presbyterian College, the first-year N.C.A.A. Division I team playing 25 of its 30 games on the road, gave a scare to North Carolina State on Saturday.

headline: Candidates Mount Frenzied Final Push in N.H.
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  A day after back-to-back debates before the voters of New Hampshire, the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates set off Sunday on breakneck campaigning to make their final arguments in person, with the leading contenders seeking to carry their momentum into the primary on Tuesday.

headline: Eat Your Heart Out, Homer
text: In the summer of 2002, as Pentagon strategists were planning the invasion of Iraq, a short distance away, on the National Mall in Washington, the Smithsonian’s Arthur M. Sackler Gallery was showing one of the most interesting exhibitions of Islamic art seen in the United States for years. The show illustrated a story largely set in the Iraqi cities that would shortly become the targets of the Pentagon’s munitions.

headline: Victory for Venus Williams
text: Venus Williams beat Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-3, to win the JB Group Classic exhibition Saturday in Hong Kong, a warm-up event for the Australian Open. Serving at 4-5 in the first set, Sharapova sent a backhand into the net after a long rally, then missed another backhand to allow Williams to take a one-set lead. Sharapova was erratic in the second set. She trailed, 3-2, then double-faulted and missed a forehand to give Williams a crucial break.

headline: Tales of New Life, Aging Life, Hard Life
text: JUNO

headline: Datebook
text: Events in Houston, Reykjavik and San Blas, Mexico, worth getting on a plane for.

headline: Letters: Galápagos Restrictions
text: To the Editor: Your article "Sailing Toward Paradise" (Dec. 23) does sailors and the Galápagos a disservice. While mentioning that private boats are restricted to two anchorages, it fails to point out that they are forbidden from sailing or motoring around the islands without a permit, held only by local operators who also carry a licensed guide. And that would prohibit their stated activities of “cavort[ing] with baby sea lions” and “snorkel[ing] with hammerhead sharks and sea turtles” from their sailboat.

headline: Seeds of Hate
text: One day in Damascus not long ago, I visited the understocked gift shop of the Sheraton Hotel, looking for something to read. There wasn’t much: pre-owned Grishams, a hagiography of Hafez al-Assad, an early Bill O’Reilly (go figure) and a paperback copy of “The International Jew,” published in 2000 in Beirut. “The International Jew” is a collection of columns exposing the putative role of Jews in such fields as international finance, world governance and bootlegging. “Wherever the seat of power may be, thither they swarm obsequiously,” the book states. These columns, which are based on the “Protocols of the Elders of Zion”  they are a plagiary of a forgery, in other words  were first published in Henry Ford’s Dearborn Independent more than 80 years ago.

headline: Independence Daze
text: At some point early in this new year, President Bush and major European Union leaders are likely to recognize the independence of Kosovo over the furious objections of Serbia and its traditional protector, Russia. Such a decision may have unintended consequences. If Kosovo successfully achieves statehood, Republika Srpska, the Serb entity in Bosnia, will be tempted to follow suit in reprisal, slicing Bosnia almost in half. Meanwhile, Belgium has been gripped by talk about repeating Czechoslovakia’s 1993 “velvet divorce,” with Flemings and Walloons possibly splitting and forming their own little states. What about the claims for the independence of Kurdistan from Iraq or Chechnya from Russia or Transdniestria from Moldova? Referring to two regions of Georgia, President Vladimir Putin of Russia remarked, “If someone believes that Kosovo should be granted full independence as a state, then why should we deny it to the Abkhaz and the South Ossetians?” It’s not a bad question  and it’s sure to bedevil Bush’s successor in the White House.

Still, numbers don’t lie: for those in uniform, 2007 was the deadliest year since the invasion.

headline: Exploiting Sound, Exploring Silence
text: FOR all the raves and awards that have so far greeted Joel and Ethan Coen’s “No Country for Old Men,” there is one term of praise that does not apply: It is not a popcorn movie. Which is to say, it is especially ill-suited to the crunching of snacks or the crinkling of wrappers or any of the usual forms of movie-theater noise pollution. There is virtually no music on the soundtrack of this tense, methodical thriller. Long passages are entirely wordless. In some of the most gripping sequences what you hear mostly is a suffocating silence.

The certificate programs have proliferated as med schools have become more open to older applicants and more focused on increasing the number of admissions from underrepresented minorities.

headline: ‘The Adventures of Amir Hamza’
text: The florid news writers, the sweet-lipped historians, revivers of old tales and renewers of past legends, relate that there ruled at Ctesiphon in Persia (image of Heaven!) Emperor Qubad Kamran, who cherished his subjects and was a succor to the impecunious in their distress. He was unsurpassed in dispensing justice, and so rigorous in this exercise that the best justice appeared an injustice compared to his decree. Prosperity and affluence thrived in his dominions while wrong and inequity slumbered in death, and, rara avis-like, mendicants and the destitute were extinct in his lands. The wealthy were at a loss to find an object for their charity. The weak and the powerful were equals, and the hawk and the sparrow roosted in the same nest. The young and the old sought one another's pleasure, neither ever deeming himself the sole benefactor. The portals of houses remained open day and night like the eyes of the vigil, for if someone stole even the color of henna from the palm, he was ground in the mill of justice. The thief therefore did not even dream of thieving, and if perchance a wayfarer should come upon someone's property on the road, he took it upon himself to restore it to its owner. Compared with Qubad Kamran's fearlessness, might, and valor, Rustam was the same as a hag most decrepit and cowardly.

The pirates, fortunately, appear to have abandoned ship, and are nowhere to be found. In their place is a bunch of people taking turns climbing aboard and taking photos.

text: With her dark ponytail and slightly nasal voice, Jessica Durdock looks and sounds like a softer version of the comedian Sarah Silverman. And the bland “All Aboard the Marriage Hearse,” with Ms. Durdock and Nicholas J. Coleman as a couple squabbling about whether to marry, resembles the hokey kind of sitcom parodied so sharply on Comedy Central’s “Sarah Silverman Program.”

headline: Ex-Harvard President Meets a Former Student, and Intellectual Sparks Fly
text: In June 2006, Peter Hopkins, a civic-minded and idealistic 2004 Harvard graduate, trekked up to his alma mater from New York for a meeting with Lawrence H. Summers, the economist and former Treasury secretary. Mr. Hopkins, who finagled the appointment through his friendship with Mr. Summers’s assistant, had a business idea: a Web site that could do for intellectuals what YouTube, the popular video-sharing site, did for bulldogs on skateboards.

headline: The Case of a Sign Painter and Theft: On Page 1, a Paper Leads to a Suspect
text: Subscribers to The Lewiston Tribune, the daily that serves a town of 31,000 in Idaho, did not need to be the brightest bulbs on the Christmas tree to notice something odd on the front page Dec. 13.

headline: People
text: People

headline: Secondary Answers All the Questions
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Corey Webster was surrounded by reporters. During a three-year career in which his role with the Giants has expanded and shrunk again and again, a crowd at his locker has not always been a positive thing.

headline: The Well-Wired Use Libraries More
text: Library use is far more prevalent among people who have a broadband Internet connection at home or at work, according to a new study. The finding counters a decade-old assumption that libraries serve as a “bridge” for people who want to use the Internet, but have only dial-up connections, or no access at all.

headline: Alberto Alonso, Founder of Cuban Troupe, Dies at 90
text: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Alberto Alonso, a Cuban-born dancer, ballet master and choreographer, died last Monday at his home here. He was 90.

headline: Quick to Forget Troubles, Snedeker Stays on Course
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii  Brandt Snedeker does things fast. Talk? Machine-gun bursts of words. Play golf? Not in the Mark Calcavecchia or John Daly category, but it is best not to glance away when it is his turn to hit. Achieve? The 2007 PGA Tour rookie of the year, he shot 61 in his opening round as a PGA Tour player, and his first career win came last year at 26 in the Wyndham Championship in Greensboro, N.C.

headline: Times and CNBC to Share Material on Web Sites
text: CNBC and The New York Times have agreed to share material on their Web sites, uniting the main competitive targets of the News Corporation’s new ventures, the Fox Business Network and The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Starbucks Founder Returns as Chief
text: With the stock plummeting and rivals on the attack, Starbucks is bringing back its top barista to turn the company around.

headline: For Émigré Fans, Soothing Words and Spirited Rhythms From Home
text: Women squealed as the headliner took the stage at S.O.B.’s late on Friday night, elegant in a dark suit with a yellow necktie. He started an anthemic ballad, and within moments, the audience was joyfully singing along and waving its arms overhead. The pop star onstage was Gossaye Tesfaye, a 32-year-old songwriter from Ethiopia, and he was singing love songs in the Amharic language. The crowd that filled the dance floor at 1 a.m. must have made up a considerable fraction of the 2,500 Ethiopians that the last census counted as living in New York City.

headline: Investors Said to Seek a Takeover of CNet
text: CNet Networks, one of the original online media companies, would typically write about all the gossip and speculation at the Consumer Electronics Show this week in Las Vegas. Now, however, the company is likely to be the one talked about.

headline: In Response to M.T.A.’s ‘Say Something’ Ads, a Glimpse of Modern Fears
text: After 9/11, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority coined the slogan, “If you see something, say something,” and put it on posters encouraging subway and bus riders to call a police counterterrorism hot line if they encountered anything suspicious. Then, last July, the authority trumpeted results on new posters and in television ads: “Last year, 1,944 New Yorkers saw something and said something.”

headline: Mickey Mouse Paintings Are Recovered
text: Two valuable Walt Disney Company watercolors depicting Mickey Mouse as the sorcerer’s apprentice in the 1940 film “Fantasia” have been recovered 17 years after they vanished from a collection on loan to what was then the International Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye, N.Y., The Associated Press reported. The paintings were brought to the attention of the police on Oct. 30 by an antiques dealer in New Smyrna Beach, Fla., who bought them from someone who had acquired them in a sale of unwanted items from a storage facility in Florida. The police said the dealer researched the watercolors’ history and realized they were stolen. Rye Brook Police Chief Gregory Austin said they were valued at $60,000 to $80,000 at the time of the theft. It was not immediately clear what would become of them. The museum moved to Boca Raton, Fla., in 1996 and eventually closed.

headline: After New Hampshire, a Rapidly Changing Race
text: The people paying closest attention to the 2008 presidential race have no idea what will happen next. So far, the contest keeps defying precedents.

headline: France Is Trying Free Museum Admission
text: France is proceeding with an experiment in free admission at 18 national museums in an effort to entice more French to visit them, Reuters reported. Until June 30, some of the museums, including the Louvre in Paris, will offer free admission to their permanent collections while others will offer it to visitors under 26 one night a week. Normally the entrance fees range from $9 to $12. “French museums are ready for more visitors, and we hope to draw in a new public, especially young people, said Christine André, a spokeswoman for the Culture Ministry’s museum arm. “It’s a question of money for some people.” Foreign tourists, who make up three-quarters of the visitors between the ages of 18 and 25, will also benefit from the experiment. Ms. André said, “If the French start seeing long lines in front of the museums, they’ll start to tell themselves: ‘Hey, foreigners are taking advantage of this. We’d be morons not to.’ ” Museum attendance in Britain has risen 50 percent since free admission was introduced there in 2001.

headline: After Slow First Half, Chargers Show They Can Win in Postseason
text: SAN DIEGO  For a dozen seasons, the fans of the San Diego Chargers waited patiently for their drought to end. The reigns came for others. In Boston, the Red Sox won the World Series; so did the Chicago White Sox.

headline: Filling Big Hiking Boots at an Early Age
text: A year and a half ago, Bindi Irwin was an 8-year-old growing up in the Australian outback, home-schooled so she could travel with her father, Steve Irwin, to film popular nature shows like “The Crocodile Hunter.” She sometimes appeared on camera, happily petting the occasional wallaby.

headline: Justices Hear Arguments in Lethal Injection Case
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday heard starkly different descriptions of Kentucky’s method of putting people to death, with a lawyer for a condemned prisoner asserting there is an unacceptable risk of agony and a lawyer for the state saying nothing could be further from the truth.

headline: When Illnesses Vie for Our Dollars
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yahoo Makes a New Play for Ads on Mobile Phones
text: SAN FRANCISCO  There may not be a Yahoo phone in the works, but the struggling Internet company is betting that a new mobile-phone strategy will help it better compete with the likes of Google, Microsoft and others for a share of the growing cellphone advertising business.

headline: Spitzer Wants to Endow State’s Public Colleges
text: In his annual address to the Legislature on Wednesday, Gov. Eliot Spitzer will propose establishing an endowment for the state’s higher education system and adding 2,000 faculty members, according to a person with knowledge of the speech.

headline: Congo Opens Talks on Ending Fighting in Eastern Region
text: GOMA, Congo (Agence France-Presse)  Talks to secure peace in conflict-torn eastern Congo opened Sunday amid warnings by the Roman Catholic Church against a “Balkanization” of the vast African country.

headline: Jamaican Music Is Missing
text: An extensive collection of vinyl records and discs of 1970s music, including original recordings by the reggae greats Bob Marley and Peter Tosh, has vanished from the archive of the former Jamaica Broadcasting Corporation, The Associated Press reported. Olivia Grange, Jamaica’s information minister, said the possible theft of the music was a blow to the history of the island.

headline: Interrogation Methods: The View From the C.I.A.
text: To the Editor:

headline: 1 Game, 2 Teams and 3 Opinions
text: How three coaches familiar with Louisiana State and Ohio State feel the game will play out.

headline: For Pentagon and News Media, Relations Improve With a Shift in War Coverage
text: WASHINGTON  The anguished relationship between the military and the news media appears to be on the mend as battlefield successes from the troop increase in Iraq are reflected in more upbeat news coverage.

headline: Issue May Really Be How Far Players Will Go to Gain an Advantage
text: When Roger Clemens explained on “60 Minutes” on Sunday night that he received injections of a painkiller and a vitamin, he illustrated how pervasive various pharmaceuticals, supplements and protein potions have become in professional baseball, in which competition is its own narcotic.

headline: A Tax Scare at the Garden, Among Other Worries
text: These are not halcyon days for Madison Square Garden. The Knicks are rapidly affirming their place as the most uninspired team in basketball. Their coach, Isiah Thomas, is greeted nightly by a chorus of boos.

headline: Seahawk Hopes Words Won’t Haunt Him Again
text: SEATTLE  Quarterback Matt Hasselbeck wore designer jeans, a sweater and a smirk as he stood on a podium and started his postgame news conference.

headline: Lacking a Permanent Home, He Must Lean on ‘Nice People’
text: Despite a right knee stiffened with arthritis, James Zeman’s actor’s bearing makes him appear taller than his six feet three inches. His taste in poetry runs to the classics: Emily Dickinson and William Blake.

headline: Clinton Talks About Strains of Campaign
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  In perhaps her most public display of emotion of the presidential campaign, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s eyes welled with tears, and her voice cracked dramatically on Monday, as she talked about holding up under the rigors of the race and her belief that she is the best candidate for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Record Victory for Finnish Ski Jumper
text: Janne Ahonen of Finland became the first ski jumper to win the prestigious Four Hills tournament for a fifth time.Ahonen, 30, won the final stop in rainy conditions in Bischofshofen, Austria, with jumps of 126 and 136 meters, earning him 251.6 points in the World Cup event.His main competitor, Thomas Morgenstern of Austria, finished third with 242.7 points. Ahonen also won the Four Hills tournament in 1999, 2003 and 2005. In 2006, he shared the victory with Jakub Janda of the Czech Republic.

headline: Sri Lankans Kill 36 Rebels as Monitors Begin Pullout
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, (Agence France-Presse)  Heavy fighting raged Sunday in northern Sri Lanka, where Tamil Tiger rebels said they lost one of their leaders, as Norwegian-led monitors began pulling out before the formal end of a tattered truce.

headline: Poughkeepsie: Assemblyman Hospitalized
text: State Assemblyman Thomas Kirwan, right, was scheduled to have a pacemaker installed Monday following an emergency visit last week to the hospital for a heart ailment. Mr. Kirwan, 74, a Republican from Newburgh, is scheduled for surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. “We were told, absolutely, not to be concerned,” his wife, Verna, said, The Poughkeepsie Journal reported Sunday. “They decided to get this done so he can get his life back on track.”

headline: That Gilbert and Sullivan Maiden With Mission and Erudition
text: For more than 30 years the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players have won loyal audiences by providing musically ingratiating, broadly comic and very tame productions of this timeless repertory. You will not see high-concept stagings here  no “Pirates of Penzance” set in Guantánamo Bay. And that’s the way patrons of this tradition-bound company like things.

headline: Bhutto Book Release Advanced
text: HarperCollins will publish “Reconciliation: Islam, Democracy and the West,” by Benazir Bhutto on Feb. 12, six days before Pakistan’s postponed parliamentary elections are to take place. HarperCollins advanced publication from April 8 after Ms. Bhutto, the two-time former prime minister of Pakistan, was assassinated at a rally on Dec. 27. In the book, completed just days before she was killed, Ms. Bhutto, who collaborated with her friend Mark Siegel, a Washington lobbyist, argues that Islam should be reconciled with democratic principles. The book opens with a chronicle of her return to Pakistan in October after eight years of exile and the assassination attempt upon her return. Her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, now co-chairman of the Pakistan Peoples Party, has written an afterword with her three children. “No one could have know that these would be Benazir Bhutto’s final words, and somehow that makes them carry even more weight, especially at a time like this,” said Tim Duggan, who edited the book. “This book is her legacy.” HarperCollins has also bought paperback rights to “Daughter of the East,” Ms. Bhutto’s autobiography, originally published in Britain in 1988. It will be reissued in the United States in the spring under the title “Daughter of Destiny.”

headline: A Murder Trial, 16 Tenacious Years Later
text: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y.  On an average Sunday in October 1991, the last average day they would have, David and Ann Scoville called their daughter, Patty, to see how she was settling into her new life in Stowe, Vt.

headline: Manhattan: Fire Response Times Improve
text: The Fire Department’s average response time decreased in 2007 for the second consecutive year, even as the number of calls increased slightly, the fire commissioner announced Sunday. The citywide average response time for all incidents was 4 minutes 49 seconds in 2007, a decrease from 4 minutes 54 seconds in 2006, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said. In 2005, the average response time was 5 minutes and 9 seconds, he said. The city’s firefighters responded to 490,767 calls in 2007, a slight increase from 484,954 in 2006, Mr. Scoppetta said. For nonmedical emergencies, firefighters responded to 209,943 calls, the most in the department’s history, he said.

headline: Chopra Wins Mercedes in a Four-Hole Playoff
text: KAPALUA, Hawaii  With night closing in on the Plantation Course at Kapalua on Sunday, the man with hair white enough to pierce the darkness put an end to sudden death. Daniel Chopra, dressed in white from head to toe, won the Mercedes-Benz Championship on the fourth hole of a playoff with Steve Stricker.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,897 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

headline: New CDs
text: SIA “Some People Have Real Problems” (Monkey Puzzle/Hear Music)

headline: Orwellian on Smoking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Unconvincing Portrait of an Angry Victim
text: Roger Clemens did not muster up a gift cocker spaniel named Checkers, the way Richard M. Nixon did in 1952, and he did not wag his finger at the nation the way President Bill Clinton did in 1998. All he could do was muscle up a fading fastball of what appeared to be false outrage Sunday night for “60 Minutes.”

headline: Iowa Caucus Results Put Pressure on Black Leaders for Endorsements
text: Before the Iowa caucus returns were in on Thursday, the phones started ringing in the home of Fletcher N. Smith Jr., a black state legislator from Greenville, S.C. Like other black leaders, Mr. Smith finds himself being courted so assiduously by the campaigns of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama that he said he had thought, “Gosh, maybe I should run for president.”

headline: Poland Signals Doubts About Planned U.S. Missile-Defense Bases on Its Territory
text: BERLIN  Signaling a tougher position in negotiations with the United States on a European antiballistic-missile shield system, Poland’s foreign minister says his country’s new government is not prepared to accept American plans to deploy missile-defense bases in Poland until all costs and risks are considered.

headline: Ligety and Miller Fail in Slalom
text: Mario Matt of Austria won the men’s World Cup slalom Sunday, and Ted Ligety and Bode Miller of the United States failed to finish.Matt, a slalom specialist, finished with a total time of 1 minute 48.45 seconds at the Kuonisbaergli course in Adelboden, Switzerland, a tenth of a second ahead of his teammate Benjamin Raich.Ligety had tied for third in the first run in soft snow conditions. He straddled a gate and went out in the second run. Miller made an error at one of the first gates, then lost his footing a second time and failed to finish the first run.Jimmy Cochran was the only American to finish. He came in eighth, 1.27 seconds behind the leader.

headline: Manhattan: Unlimited-Ride Cards for Path
text: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey plans to introduce unlimited-ride cards of varying time periods on PATH trains later this winter. The cards are similar to ones now sold by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for use on buses and subways. One-day cards will cost $6, 7-day cards will cost $18 and 30-day cards will cost $54. The introduction of the unlimited-ride cards was part of the Port Authority’s decision last Friday to raise the one-way fare to $1.75, from $1.50. The price for 10-, 20- and 40-ride fare cards will increase to $1.30 per PATH ride, from $1.20. The new unlimited-ride cards will be introduced in early March, the same time the higher fares will take effect. PATH, for Port Authority Trans-Hudson, is a railroad that connects New York and New Jersey under the Hudson River.

headline: Publishing That’s All About Me
text: Last Wednesday, I boarded an airplane, one of the last gated communities for major media. Up there  for the most part  there is no e-mail, no YouTube, no cellphone. Just me, my 11-year-old daughter in the bulkhead seat next to me and a stack of newspapers and magazines.

headline: Saying ‘Will You’ for Prizes, on the Web
text: “ENGAGING the consumer” is a popular phrase in marketing, particularly as the public shifts its attention from television to interactive media like the Internet. This Valentine’s Day, engaging consumers  or getting consumers engaged  is precisely what the online floral retailer 1-800-Flowers.com aims to do.

headline: Keeping Guns Out of the Parks
text: Forty-seven United States senators recently wrote to the secretary of the interior, Dirk Kempthorne, asking him to lift the ban on carrying ready-to-fire weapons in national parks and wildlife refuges. Under current law, guns carried into or through a national park or refuge must be unloaded, taken apart, or cased in a way “that will prevent their ready use.” According to the senators’ letter, this rule infringes on gun owners’ rights and is “confusing, burdensome and unnecessary.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: CBS ‘Early Show’ Tries a Revised Format, Again
text: Morning viewers have seen this show before.

headline: Economists Say Movie Violence Might Temper the Real Thing
text: NEW ORLEANS  Are movies like “Hannibal” and the remake of “Halloween,” which serve up murder and mutilation as routine fare, actually making the nation safer?

headline: Bloomberg and Others Begin Talks on a Nonpartisan Path
text: NORMAN, Okla.  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and a dozen current and former elected officials from both parties arrived in this college town Sunday evening with little fanfare but grand ambitions.

headline: Bomber Kills 4 on Iraqi Army Day
text: BAGHDAD  As jubilant Iraqi soldiers celebrated Army Day by dancing and chanting anti-insurgent slogans inside a downtown office building here on Sunday, a suicide bomber attempted to shove his way through the gate.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Bacardi & Company, Miami, chose the Santa Monica, Calif., office of 180, part of the Omnicom Group, to handle the creative duties for its Bombay Sapphire gin, which had been handled by Sugartown Creative, New York. Spending was estimated at $10 million.

headline: Voter ID Laws Are Set to Face a Crucial Test
text: INDIANAPOLIS  In April 2006, a federal judge upheld Indiana’s law on voter identification, the strictest in the nation, saying there was no evidence that it would prevent any voter from having his ballot counted.

headline: Queens: Man Fatally Shot
text: An 18-year-old man was found with a fatal gunshot wound to his head in Bayswater late Saturday night, the police said. The man was identified as Neville Ward of Hassock Street. Police officers responding to a report of a shooting found Mr. Ward behind a building near his home shortly before 11:30 p.m., the police said. He was pronounced dead 30 minutes later at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. There were no arrests Sunday. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Israel Says It Will Toughen Response to Longer-Range Fire
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli security officials said Sunday that a rocket with a longer range than usual fired by Palestinian militants from Gaza into the coastal city of Ashkelon on Thursday had been made in Iran. It was the first such rocket to land in Israel, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said Israel would intensify its response to the firing of such longer-range rockets.

headline: As Primary Day Looms, Republican Rivals Go After One Another
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  After being pounded by his rivals at the Republican debate on Saturday, Mitt Romney struck back with a vengeance on Sunday by aggressively going after his main rivals, Senator John McCain of Arizona and Mike Huckabee, accusing them of breaking with Republican orthodoxy on taxes.

headline: Retracing His Steps, McCain Is Feeling Rejuvenated
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign wheeled out a confetti gun on Saturday in Peterborough to boom a festive end to his 100th town-hall-style meeting. It was the same place he began his New Hampshire primary campaign of 2000.

headline: Grief for a Fallen Fire Officer and ‘Class Act’
text: At the entrance to the Staten Island funeral home, the mourners lined up four rows deep, among them many who had known Lt. John H. Martinson all his life, and at least one man who had never laid eyes on him.

headline: A Careful Game Plan, and a Bold Step
text: Tampa, Fla.

headline: Bush Acknowledges Mixed Signals on Economy
text: CHICAGO  Dampening the administration’s customary upbeat tone on the economy, President Bush acknowledged Monday that the economic signs were “increasingly mixed,” but he also suggested he would oppose Democratic initiatives to increase spending to head off a recession.

headline: Decades-Long High School Streak Ends
text: The Brandon (Fla.) High School wrestling team’s national record of 459 consecutive dual victories dating to 1973 has ended. South Dade High School topped Brandon, 32-28, on Saturday night in the finals of the Jim Graves Beat the Streak Tournament at Brandon High. Brandon’s streak began after Jim Graves, for whom the tournament is named, took over as the Eagles’ wrestling coach. Graves coached the team for nine years. The streak included 66 individual state champions and 18 team titles.

headline: Going Beyond Crafty Defense Into the World of Underruffs
text: The winners of the Board-a-Match teams that ended Dec. 30 at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Midtown Manhattan were David Gurvich and Michael Lipkin of New York; Alex Perlin of Metuchen, N.J.; and Michael Prahin of Irvington, N.Y. They finished less than one point ahead of Melody Bi of Woodbury, Minn.; Steven Beck and Fred Chang of New York; and Michael Camp of Fort Lee, N.J.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Short Passes Lead to Long Day for Bucs’ Defense
text: TAMPA, Fla.  The Tampa Bay Buccaneers claimed to know the answers even before Eli Manning and the Giants’ offense provided the test Sunday in their National Football Conference wild-card playoff game.

headline: Readers’ Comments
text: I appreciate Alina Tugend’s article on plastic bottles even though it was inconclusive about the dangers of drinking from them. There are other dangers she didn’t mention and they include to the environment. The attached Sierra Club report indicates that most single use bottles end up in landfills, in parkways, etc. to the tune of 10 billion a year!

headline: Bronx: Fatal Stabbing After Party
text: Two men were stabbed, one fatally, after attending a house party in Crotona Park East early Sunday, the police said. The stabbings occurred shortly after 2:10 a.m. at an address on Southern Boulevard, the police said. Officers responding to a call of an assault found Frank Banks, 26, of East Harlem, with a stab wound to his chest and a second victim, whose name was not released, less seriously injured, according to the police. They were taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where Mr. Banks died. No arrests were announced Sunday.

headline: After Iowa, Campaigns Cast Even Wider Net Online
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. -- While we have been racing to the candidates’ speeches in New Hampshire and counting the crowds on the ground, there’s been a surge in online interest in both Senator Barack Obama and Mike Huckabee, the winners of the Iowa caucuses. Tech President has quantified it here.

headline: Foiling U.S. Plan, Prison Expands in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  As the Bush administration struggles for a way to close the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a similar effort to scale down a larger and more secretive American detention center in Afghanistan has been beset by political, legal and security problems, officials say.

headline: A Paper Trail for Voting Machines
text: Los Angeles

headline: Xerox Hopes Its New Logo Doesn’t Say ‘Copier’
text: Still think copier when you hear the name Xerox?

headline: Letters From Contributors to The Neediest Cases Fund
text: “My brothers, sister and I were born in New York City, as were my mother (in the Bronx) and father (in Brooklyn). None of us currently live in New York City, but I proudly consider myself a New Yorker. My grandfather passed through Ellis Island, as did many of my relatives of his generation. New York City treated them well. In their memory I would like to help others who live in New York City and are in need.”

headline: Whose Century Is It Anyway?
text: The general election for president is still a ways off, but the New Hampshire primary campaign is providing a preview of the ultimate contest. So far, it’s not looking so good for the Republicans.

headline: On Ground, Jaguars Can Keep Game Up in the Air
text: The Jacksonville Jaguars had lost an 18-point lead, ceding control and emotion to the Pittsburgh Steelers, and watching their chance for a franchise-altering victory evaporate.

headline: As Electronics Show Grows, Some Scale Back
text: LAS VEGAS  People attending the Consumer Electronics Show, starting here on Monday, will encounter a crowded and noisy stage where technology companies from around the world unveil their latest wares.

headline: Stadium Goes Up, but Bronx Still Seeks Benefits
text: Several years ago, as the Yankees negotiated to build a new stadium in the South Bronx, the neighborhood faced the realities of a massive construction project in its midst: parks would be closed and moved, traffic would be horrendous, life would be, for a while, a hassle.

headline: In New Hampshire, Bill Clinton Finds Less Spark
text: DURHAM, N.H.  Is this what it would have been like had Elvis been reduced to playing Reno?

headline: Yale to Increase Endowment Spending
text: Yale University, facing pressure from Congress and even some of its own donors to use more of its robust investment gains, announced on Monday that it would increase by nearly 40 percent the amount of money the university spends next year from its endowment.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
A Reliever From the Old School Awaits His Hall of Fame Day
text: The Yankees’ new relief pitcher lost three of his first four games, and people, including catcher Thurman Munson, were wondering what was going on. That pitcher, Rich Gossage, thereafter to be known primarily as Goose, gave up game-losing hits to Richie Zisk (home run) and Don Money (double), then made errors on successive sacrifice bunts.

headline: In Trenton, Farewells Are Effusive, if Not All Fond
text: TRENTON  Call it the long goodbye.

headline: Police Suspect Drag Racing Played Role in 3 Deaths
text: NORTH BERGEN, N.J.  Three people were killed and a fourth was seriously injured in a two-vehicle collision on Sunday afternoon on a New Jersey road with a reputation as a place for drag racing, the police said.

headline: Clemens Calls Drug Accusations ‘Totally False’
text: Roger Clemens said his former personal trainer’s accusation that he had used steroids and human growth hormone was “totally false,” in a “60 Minutes” broadcast Sunday. The interview set up a showdown next week before a Congressional committee that has summoned them to testify under oath.

headline: 8 Die as Bus Tumbles Off Utah Road
text: Eight people were killed and 20 others were injured on Sunday when a chartered bus ran off a rain-slick road in far southeastern Utah on a weekend when fierce winter weather caused troubles across a wide swath of the West.

headline: A Big Blue Breakthrough for Manning
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Most of the red-clad fans had turned their backs and gone, but a pocket of blue boiled in the northwest corner of the stadium, near the abandoned fake pirate ship on the concourse. The scoreboard overhead showed that the Giants had beaten the Buccaneers, 24-14.

headline: Georgia’s President Narrowly Wins Vote
text: TBILISI, Georgia  Georgia’s pro-Western president narrowly won re-election over the weekend, according to official results released Sunday, but the main opposition candidate contested the outcome.

headline: From Hype to Fear
text: The unemployment report on Friday was brutally bad. Unemployment rose in December, while job creation was minimal  and it’s highly likely, for technical reasons, that the job number will be revised down, showing an actual decline in employment.

headline: Google’s Lunchtime Betting Game
