text: IT probably doesn’t come as a huge surprise to learn that while employees in many companies sit in the cafeteria gossiping about work, or the boss, or the competition, at Google they are doing something else.

headline: Long Island Rail Road from Long Beach to Penn Station
text: Monday, Jan. 7  7.39 a.m. Train

headline: Mobile Backups at Quarterback Find Themselves in a Pivotal Role
text: NEW ORLEANS  The two starting quarterbacks in the Bowl Championship Series title game Monday night are more caretakers than playmakers.

headline: If Your Hard Drive Could Testify ...
text: A couple of years ago, Michael T. Arnold landed at the Los Angeles International Airport after a 20-hour flight from the Philippines. He had his laptop with him, and a customs officer took a look at what was on his hard drive. Clicking on folders called “Kodak pictures” and “Kodak memories,” the officer found child pornography.

headline: Queens: Two Killed in Collision
text: Two men were killed early Sunday when their Ford Thunderbird slid into the path of a public bus on Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, the police said. The accident occurred approximately 4:15 a.m., when the car, traveling east, slid sideways into the bus’ path at 168th Place, the police said. The car’s driver, Christopher Boyd, 23, and his passenger, Eric Richmond, 25, both of Queens Village, were pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The bus was carrying seven passengers from Hempstead to Queens, said Aaron Donovan, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The bus driver and one passenger were treated for minor injuries at Mary Immaculate Hospital and released, he said. The bus driver was not charged or issued a citation, the police said.

headline: Energy Costs a Top Concern for New Hampshire Voters
text: HILLSBOROUGH, N.H.  People here treasure their rugged surroundings and relative isolation in the hills of southwestern New Hampshire. They welcome winter, and consider their distance from urban sprawl a clear advantage.

headline: ‘Treasure’ Still Jingling at the Box Office
text: The Disney film “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” maintained its grip on the No. 1 spot at North American box offices for a third consecutive weekend, while the small film “Juno” powered past the $50 million mark. “National Treasure” hauled in an estimated $20.2 million to bring its three-week total to $171 million, according to the box-office tracking company Media by Numbers. The creepy “One Missed Call” (Warner Brothers), starring Shannyn Sossamon, took in $13.5 million in its debut for fifth place. Between these finishers were the holdovers “I Am Legend” (Warner Brothers), rising to second from third last week with $16.3 million; “Juno” (Fox Searchlight), moving to third from fifth with $16.2 million (and a total take of $52 million in its fifth week in release); and “Alvin and the Chipmunks” (Fox), dropping to fourth from second on a gross of $16 million. The cumulative total for “I Am Legend” reached $228 million, and for “Alvin” $176.7 million. In terms of income per screen, the leader was “There Will Be Blood” (Paramount Vantage), with an average of $26,215 from 51 screens, compared to $8,429 for “Juno” from 1,925 screens and $5,376 from 3,762 screens for “National Treasure.”

headline: Wiki Citizens Taking on a New Area: Searching
text: SAN FRANCISCO  When Jimmy Wales co-founded Wikipedia in 2001 and called the site, which carried only a few articles then, a free encyclopedia, not many people took him seriously.

headline: Deadly Bombing Mars Iraqi Celebration
text: BAGHDAD  As jubilant Iraqi soldiers celebrated Army Day by dancing and chanting anti-insurgent slogans inside a downtown office building here on Sunday, a suicide bomber tried to shove his way through the gate.

headline: Accuracy Takes a Hit in Debates
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Mitt Romney denied describing Senator John McCain’s immigration proposal as “amnesty” in an advertisement. John Edwards claimed he had “never taken a dime from a Washington lobbyist in my entire time in public life.” Rudolph W. Giuliani said the Islamic terrorist threat “has nothing to do with our foreign policy.”

headline: Maazel’s Back in Met’s Pit, and It Took Just 45 Years
text: Right conductor, wrong podium? Not at all.

headline: A Literal Page Turner of a Mystery
text: “For the librarians,” says the dedication page of Geraldine Brooks’s new novel, “People of the Book.” That’s an understatement. What librarian could resist a novel that has the word book in its title, is centered on an intrepid book conservator, exults in book-preservation exotica (“I know the flesh and fabrics of pages, the bright earths and lethal toxins of ancient pigments”) and has a plot about a rare book with a long, fraught and serpentine history?

headline: Songs From an Unrecorded Minstrel
text: “This is a new song,” Natalie Merchant announced onstage at the Hiro Ballroom on Friday night, at her first full New York City concert in four years. “Try to absorb it here, now, ’cause I don’t know when I’ll make a record.”

headline: New Glosses on Ill-Fated Young Lovers
text: “Golden lads and girls all must/ As chimney sweepers, come to dust.” These lines from “Cymbeline” came to mind with the final tableau of Peter Martins’s ballet of “Romeo and Juliet” for New York City Ballet. In this version, which returned to the repertory on Saturday afternoon after its premiere season in May, the star-crossed lovers end their lives in thoroughly nonballet style. Juliet’s head is across Romeo’s chest, but her knees are bent; he is lying at an unpicturesque and probably uncomfortable angle.

headline: Romney Decides Second Beats Last
text: NASHUA, N.H.  With T-minus 36 hours and counting until the New Hampshire primary, Mitt Romney has had a marvelous revelation: He finished second in Iowa, which really means he almost won, which really means he is almost a front-runner here.

headline: Rush of Water Leaves a Nevada Town in Anguish
text: FERNLEY, Nev.  With each squishy step she took Sunday morning on her saturated living room carpet, Becki Morales spotted more trouble. The floodwaters that rushed in after a levee broke on an irrigation canal early Saturday had largely receded in her one-story rental, but they left a sty of stained furniture, soaked power strips and damaged computer parts.

headline: Film Critics Honor ‘There Will Be Blood’
text: The National Society of Film Critics named “There Will Be Blood,” directed by Paul Thomas Anderson and starring Daniel Day-Lewis, right, as a greedy oil speculator, as the best picture of 2007. Mr. Anderson was chosen as best director and Mr. Day-Lewis best actor. The Romanian director Cristian Mungiu’s “4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days,” the Cannes prizewinner about two student friends who are ruthlessly exploited when one seeks an illegal abortion, was designated best foreign-language film. Honors for best actress went to Julie Christie for her portrayal of a woman afflicted with Alzheimer’s disease in “Away From Her.” Casey Affleck was named best supporting actor for his performance as the gunslinger Robert Ford in “The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford” and Cate Blanchett was named best supporting actress for her portrayal of Bob Dylan in “I’m Not There.” “No End in Sight,” Charles Ferguson’s examination of the quagmire in Iraq, was designated best nonfiction film. The votes were cast on Saturday by 41 of the 61 members of the National Society of Film Critics at a meeting at Sardi’s Restaurant.

headline: Observe Early and Often
text: Washington

headline: Cruel and Far Too Usual Punishment
text: The Supreme Court hears arguments on Monday in a case about whether Kentucky’s use of a “cocktail” of injected poisons to carry out the death penalty is unconstitutional. We believe that the death penalty, no matter how it is administered, is unconstitutional and wrong. If a state does execute anyone, it must do so in a way that is humane and does not impose needless suffering. Kentucky’s method does not meet that standard.

headline: Straddling Cultures, Irreverently, in Life and Art
text: BEIT SAFAFA, Israel  Being an Arab Israeli has always been a complex affair, at times almost a contradiction in terms. For Sayed Kashua, 32, an Israeli-born Arab journalist and author, it just got more complicated.

headline: Not So Fast, Clinton Says About Obama Momentum
text: DERRY, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday sought to slow the momentum of Senator Barack Obama heading into the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday by pointedly challenging his voting record and the assertion that he is the only candidate who would bring about change.

headline: Ill-Met by Moonlight With Pain to Spare
text: In “Between Blood & Bone,” an excerpt from Diane Arvanites-Noya and Tommy Neblett’s “Apokalypsis” performed by its choreographers, the two alternately grapple with and curl around each other. Are they seeking advantage or escape? Something quietly terrible is unfolding between these worn-down individuals who seem to have known each other, in a particular way, long enough to have fought to a standstill.

headline: In Musharraf’s Shadow, a New Hope for Pakistan Rises
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Over the last several months, a little-known, enigmatic Pakistani general has quietly raised hopes among American officials that he could emerge as a new force for stability in Pakistan, according to current and former government officials. But it remains too early to determine whether he can play a decisive role in the country.

headline: Some Brand-Name Bloggers Say Stress of Posting Is a Hazard to Their Health
text: Om Malik’s blog, GigaOm, regularly breaks news about the technology industry. Last week, the journalist turned blogger broke a big story about himself. Mr. Malik, 41, blogged that he had suffered a heart attack on Dec. 28.

headline: Jones Torn as Hawaii Makes Third Offer
text: The agent for Hawaii Coach June Jones said late Sunday night that his client was torn between taking the head-coaching job at Southern Methodist and a third offer from the University of Hawaii.

headline: Brutishness Begets Brutishness on the Road
text: It may seem an odd thing to say about a film in which a baseball bat as an instrument of assault and rape is a recurring theme, but what makes “A Bloody Aria” a darkly delightful surprise is its restraint.

headline: Paper Bags Get Pretty Chatty Nowadays
text: Dance may be in for a dire time, judging by the “Fresh Tracks” program on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop. Precious vacuity ruled in this latest installment of an august showcase devoted to choreography by emerging artists, suggesting that these Gen Y artists may not have the tools to make their ideas come to life.

headline: Kenya Kikuyus, Long Dominant, Are Now Routed
text: NAKURU, Kenya  Kenya’s privileged tribe is on the run.

headline: Dig We Must for a Better St. Louis
text: In recent weeks, viewers of TV networks like TCM were treated to numerous showings of a favorite holiday film, “Meet Me in St. Louis.” Now comes a campaign that acknowledges it is going to be awfully hard for a long time to meet anyone in St. Louis.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline on the cover of the Business Day section on Saturday referred incorrectly to the status of the nonprofit organization One Laptop Per Child. The organization, which seeks to put low-cost computers into the hands of the world’s poorest children, continues to operate; there has been no “demise of One Laptop Per Child.” (An article inside that the headline referred to reported that the chip maker Intel had withdrawn its support from the organization.) (Go to Article)

headline: Britney Spears Leaves Hospital
text: The troubled pop star Britney Spears was released on Saturday from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. She had been taken there by paramedics on Thursday night, when the police were summoned to her home after a dispute with her ex-husband, Kevin Federline, about their sons, Sean Preston, 2 and Jayden, 1. On Friday a court commissioner suspended the right of Ms. Spears, 26, to visit the children and awarded sole physical and legal custody to Mr. Federline before scheduling another hearing for Jan. 14. Previously Mr. Federline had temporary custody, and Ms. Spears had court-monitored visitation rights. After seeing Ms. Spears in the hospital, Phil McGraw, the television psychologist, said, “My meeting with Britney and some family members this morning in her room at Cedars leaves me convinced more than ever that she is in dire need of both medical and psychological intervention.”

headline: President Mike Huckabee?
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR Diary:

headline: Pro-Western President Re-elected in Georgia
text: TBILISI, Georgia  Georgia’s pro-Western president narrowly won re-election over the weekend, according to official results released Sunday, but the main opposition candidate contested the outcome.

headline: A Tired Nadal Is Overwhelmed in India
text: Rafael Nadal, fatigued from a nearly four-hour match the previous day, was routed by fourth-seeded Mikhail Youzhny, 6-0, 6-1, Sunday in the final of the Chennai Open in India.The 19th-ranked Youzhny clinched the fourth title of his career. The second-ranked Nadal held his service only once.The 57-minute match turned out to be a letdown for Nadal, who needed 3 hours 54 minutes to overcome his fellow Spaniard Carlos Moyá in what was the longest three-set match on the ATP Tour in 15 years.“Rafa was not Rafa,” Youzhny said. “I did not win today, it was Rafa who lost. I did not expect it to be so easy.”

headline: Discovering Irishness, Recovering Niceness
text: David Morse, the only American in the otherwise all-Irish cast of “The Seafarer,” Conor McPherson’s dark and glinting boozefest of a play now on Broadway after an acclaimed run in London, had a choice of roles. When his agent sent him the script, Mr. Morse said, two parts were open: Sharky, an endearing loser who, as his brother says, has “made a pig’s mickey out of everything,” and the sleek and mysterious Mr. Lockhart (now played by Ciaran Hinds, most familiar to many Americans as Caesar in the HBO mini-series “Rome”).

headline: G.M. to Show a Vehicle That Drives by Itself
text: LAS VEGAS  Within a decade, General Motors thinks it will have the ultimate solution to the growing problem of distracted drivers: a car that can do the driving itself.

headline: Conspiracy and Democracy in Pakistan
text: President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan has bowed, somewhat, to domestic pressure and called in Scotland Yard to help figure out who killed Benazir Bhutto. A credible investigation is urgently needed and Mr. Musharraf  who has no credibility of his own  needs all the help he can get.

headline: In Blog, a Military Man Writes About His Own Death
text: Andrew Olmsted, a United States Army major who wrote an online blog for The Rocky Mountain News, prepared for the possibility of his death by writing a 3,000-word piece.

headline: The Week’s Economic Reports
text: ECONOMIC INDICATORS It is a light week for economic data, headlined by the trade deficit figures for November (Friday). Other reports will include consumer credit for November (Tuesday) and wholesale trade inventories for November (Thursday).

headline: In Strike, Separate Deals Draw Ire of Big Producers
text: LOS ANGELES  A deal between United Artists and the Writers Guild of America West to let the production company sidestep the screenwriters’ strike may have opened the door to a full-blown brawl, as other producers demanded to know why writers have granted some companies a special agreement but not others.

headline: The Times, Are They A-Changing?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Trend-Spotting in N.F.L. Playoffs, Day 2
text: A look at some of the storylines to come out of wild-card weekend:1. Rivers vs. Manning.  Philip Rivers will be matched against Peyton Manning in the next round, but on Sunday, as he has been most of his career, he was on a parallel course with Eli Manning. The Titans stopped LaDainian Tomlinson and forced Rivers to beat them, and he did, earning his first playoff victory.

headline: ‘Need a Will? Leave It to Me!’
text: More of your “late-night” comedy (send yours via the comment link below):

headline: Wiki Citizens Taking on a New Area: Searching
text: Jimmy Wales, the co-founder of Wikipedia, expects his new Internet search engine, Wikia Search, to follow a trajectory similar to that of his free encyclopedia, which since its launch in 2001 has grown into an important, if not always reliable, digital reference for millions of Internet users.

headline: Air China Raises Bid in Battle for China Eastern
text: Air China’s parent vowed on Sunday to pay at least 32 percent more for a coveted slice of China Eastern than a rival suitor, Singapore Airlines agreed to, raising the ante in their contest for China Eastern, China’s No. 3 carrier.

headline: Former TXU Lawyer Gets $5 Million to Stay On
text: Energy Future Holdings‘s private equity buyers, led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and TPG, are coughing up bout $5 million to keep the company’s general counsel, David Poole, on board for the time being.

headline: ‘Rock Band’ — One Man’s Journey
text: A video game nut learns the post-holiday blues, but not how to play them:

headline: Deeya Energy Fires Up $15 Million Round
text: Deeya Energy, which makes large flow batteries to provide backup power to industrial plants, raised $15 million in a second round of financing, according to Venture Wire.

headline: Lone Star Chairman to Testify in South Korean Suit
text: The chairman of Lone Star Funds plans to testify next week at the trial of the buyout group’s South Korean chief for alleged stock price manipulation, a spokesman told The Associated Press.

headline: Toronto-Dominion and Commerce Settle Takeover Lawsuits
text: The Toronto-Dominion Bank and Commerce Bancorp, which is being bought by its Canadian rival, have entered into a settlement agreement to put to rest a number of lawsuits that had been filed on behalf of Commerce’s shareholders.

headline: Hedge Funds With Northern Rock Stakes Fight Takeover
text: Hedge funds SRM Global and RAB Capital on Monday detailed their case for blocking takeover offers for Northern Rock, the troubled British bank that precipitated Britain’s worst banking crisis in more than a century.

headline: Time is Crucial for China’s Wealth Fund
text: The China Investment Corporation may still be operating out of makeshift offices, but with its $5 billion investment in Morgan Stanley the contours of the infant sovereign wealth fund’s strategy are becoming clearer.

headline: When Melanie Met Cristina
text: It takes two to tango but you to amuse. Tell us what’s going on down Argentine way in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Bashing Cerberus’s Chrysler Deal
text: It was only five months ago that Cerberus Capital Management bought 80 percent of Chrysler from Germany’s Daimler but already the vultures are circling, Fortune notes.

headline: Harry Macklowe’s $6.4 Billion Bill
text: In August 2003, Harry B. Macklowe raced from lender to lender to round up a record-breaking $1.4 billion to buy the General Motors Building, the 50-story commercial skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan that is one of New York’s trophy properties.

headline: Finish Line Said to Explore Options to Genesco Deal
text: If Finish Line is forced to complete its ill-fated takeover of rival shoe seller Genesco, the combined company may have to shed assets or sell out to a private-equity shop, The New York Post reported.

headline: Foreign Buyers Ramp Up U.S. Deal Making
text: Foreign investors ramped up purchases of United States companies in the fourth quarter to the fastest pace in at least a decade, a reflection of the falling value of the dollar, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: For the Moment |  Business as Usual
text: Last week’s guest bloggers were Loden Dager, a men’s wear collective based in New York City that launched in the Fall of 2006 and recently won the Ecco Domani Fashion Foundation award for new talent. Its members, pictured, are: Melissa Vail, Matthew Sandager, Oliver Helden, Paul Marlow, and Alex Galan. Judging from their final dispatch, which could not be posted on Saturday because of technical difficulties, it’s as if they never left. (Read previous blog entries written by Loden Dager and a profile of Alex Galan here.)

headline: Pension Funds Balk at Buyout Fund Increases
text: Is a confrontation between buyout shops and pension funds, their largest and most loyal investor base, in the offing?

headline: Coal for Some Goldman Employees?
text: With all the hype recently about Goldman Sachs being the only major investment bank to avoid being stung in last year’s subprime mortgage fiasco and the record profits it rung up last year, bonus time was expected to be a time of good cheer for Goldman employees.

headline: Hedging Their Way to Billions
text: Remember the colossal salaries of hedge fund managers – when they needed to earn at least $240 million just to be included among the 25 wealthiest in 2006? Well, those numbers may now look puny, especially at the top of the range.

headline: The Appetite for Securities Turns Less Hearty
text: To some on Wall Street, the last half of 2007 may have had the feel of a buyers’ strike. Financial products that had experienced rapidly growing demand suddenly became all but unsalable.

headline: FairPoint and Verizon Edge Closer to Clinching Deal
text: FairPoint Communications‘s amended $2.7 billion merger with Verizon Communications‘s local phone operations in the New England states won general approval from Maine regulators, the company said Friday.

headline: Resource Pacific Rejects $840 Million Xstrata Bid
text: An Australian coal mining company, Resource Pacific Holdings, on Friday rejected its second offer in a month, saying a 960 million Australian dollar ($840 million) bid from Switzerland’s Xstrata  was too low and failed to reflect potential synergies.

headline: Monster to Acquire Affinity Labs for $61 Million
text: After roughly nine months on the job, Sal Iannuzzi, the chief executive of Monster Worldwide, the online employment company, is continuing his efforts to revive the company.

headline: Heritage-Crystal Details I.P.O. Terms
text: Heritage-Crystal Clean, which provides parts cleaning and container waste services, expects to sell 1.7 million shares priced between $10.50 and $12.50 each in its initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Friday.

headline: A Silver Lining Behind Imperium’s Aborted I.P.O.?
text: The announcement last week by Imperium Renewables, a biodiesel producer, that it had withdrawn its plan to go public, amounted to an admission that Imperium was overly ambitious in gauging investor demand for alternative energy stocks, The Deal.com’s Tech Confidential blog argued.

headline: Schwarzman Said to Offer Olive Branch to Banks
text: Stephen Schwarzman has been forced to eat a rare slice of humble pie on Wall Street. Schwarzman, chief executive of the Blackstone Group, went hat in hand to JPMorgan Chase and Lehman Brothers in an effort to mend fences after the banks pulled the plug on his $1.8 billion deal to acquire PHH, The New York Post reported.

headline: An Intellectual Bent for New Start-Up
text: Peter Hopkins, a civic-minded and idealistic 2004 Harvard graduate, is hoping that his new Web site, Big Think, will do for intellectuals what YouTube, the popular video-sharing site, did for bulldogs on skateboards.

headline: Carrefour Abandons Bidding for Turkey’s Migros
text: Carrefour, the French supermarket group, said on Monday it had pulled out of the auction of Migros Turk, the biggest supermarket group in Turkey, leaving the field clear for four private equity groups and Agrokor of Croatia, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Credit Suisse Shares Fall Amid Write-Down Fears
text: Shares in Credit Suisse fell by around 3 percent on Monday after a Swiss newspaper reported the bank faced writedowns in its commercial mortgage and leveraged-finance business, Reuters said.

headline: JPMorgan Plans Asia Hiring Spree
text: JPMorgan Chase plans to add at least 700 staff to its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Hong Kong over the next three years and lease up to 11 floors in a new office block to accommodate the growth, Reuters reported.

headline: Clinton's New Hampshire Strategy
text: A look at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's strategy shift  in her first three days in New Hampshire after finishing third in Iowa.

headline: Has Measuring Risk Changed ‘Forever?’
text: For years, three big agencies assigned risk ratings to thousands of securities, helping investors figure out which were likely to be safe investments and which were more speculative.

headline: Investors Seek a Takeover of CNet
text: CNet Networks, one of the original online media companies, would typically write about all the gossip and speculation at the Consumer Electronics Show this week in Las Vegas. Now, however, the company is likely to be the one talked about.

headline: Colony Capital Hires Ex-Amgen C.F.O. as Principal
text: Colony Capital, a private equity firm focused on real estate, said on Monday that it had hired Richard D. Nanula as a principal with a senior role in the firm.

headline: A Different Kind of Support
text: The Bagger saw Amy Ryan, the presumptive favorite in the best supporting category, pick up another laurel from the New York Film Critics Circle for her role in Ben Affleck’s “Gone Baby Gone.” The betting is that she is a near lock for a Golden Guy, with Cate Blanchett providing the only competition for her eerie inhabitation of Dylan in “I’m Not there.” But at the Film Experience blog, the word is, not so fast. What about Marisa Tomei in “Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead”?

headline: The Smart Money On New Hampshire
text: They haven’t voted yet in New Hampshire, but my unnamed sources tell me there’s not much question who will win: Barack Obama and John McCain.

headline: LCD or Plasma? Words From the Master
text: Paik Woo is generally regarded as one of the fathers of digital TV. Along with several colleagues, in the early 1990s, Dr. Paik figured out how to compress a digital signal, making it sufficiently small to be able to be transmitted over the air.

headline: Eyeing the Future at C.E.S., Part 1
text: As Matt Richtel and I report in Monday’s paper, attendees of this year’s Consumer Electronics Show, which has just kicked off in Las Vegas, should not expect to see the Big Consumer Hit of 2008. The show has become too crowded, loud and obsessed with technical features and standards to produce the simple devices that consumers love, like the iPod, Wii or the Flip Video camcorder.

headline: But You Know, Apple Is Really Just One of Us
text: Quantity-wise, C.E.S. has nothing to apologize for. At last count, it has something just shy of a gazillion gadgets and companies.

headline: Letting the Air Out of the Globes, Slowly
text: So, the Globes are on/off/live/private/televised and shuttered. The Bagger is getting on a plane no matter what at the end of the week, but he has no idea what he will be doing after he lands. There had been word that NBC would stand down and that the awards would go off untelevised, but we won’t know with any certainty until later today, according to Variety.

headline: High School With Money
text: What happens when a pregnant teen turns into a monster? Watch and learn, write the folks at rottentomatoes.com:

headline: Clinton's New Hampshire Strategy
text: A look at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's strategy shift  in her first three days in New Hampshire after finishing third in Iowa.

headline: How Riders Responded to M.T.A.’s ‘Say Something’ Ads
text: In July, to trumpet the results of a campaign to urge people to call a police counterterrorism hot line to report suspicious activity, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority proclaimed on posters and in television ads, “Last year, 1,944 New Yorkers saw something and said something.” William Neuman, who covers transit for The Times, asks what, exactly, did those 1,944 New Yorkers see, and what did they say?

headline: Way Too Early for Shaking Hands
text: NASHUA, N.H.—It must have seemed like a good idea at the time to Mitt Romney’s New Hampshire staff: get the Gov out early to greet employees coming in to work at BAE Systems here.

headline: The Early Word: Who’s the Real ‘Change’ Candidate?
text: The weary, hoarse-voiced presidential candidates have just Monday and part of Tuesday to stop the surges of John McCain, who is leading the polls among Republicans, and his Democratic counterpart Barack Obama, in New Hampshire. Or if they happen to be Mr. McCain or Mr. Obama, there are two days left to fend off their rivals and not make a momentum-killing gaffe.

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

headline: New York Hugs Its Own
text: The Bagger made a rare trip in through the tunnel on a Sunday for an evening of awards and vittles at the New York Film Critic’s Circle. The event itself is always a peach, in part because New York shows up to honor its own and some temporary adopted citizens, like Sarah Polley and Daniel Day-Lewis.

headline: What’s Happened to Ronaldinho?
text: He was one of the most dazzling soccer players to samba across the field in a generation. His step-overs, deft flicks, stunning free kicks and uncanny knack for making the ball bend to his will inspired thousands — nay, more than 100,000 — YouTube montage tributes.

headline: The Tussle Over CNet
text: The Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin appears on CNBC to discuss takeover talk about CNET, an online media company.

headline: Hall of Fame & Shame: TV’s Car Ads, 2007
text: Spoilsports at the Insurance Fraud Bureau of Massachusetts and the Washington-based Coalition Against Insurance Fraud wagged accusatory fingers at Toyota last week for one of the funnier television advertising campaigns of 2007. The ads, pumping the manufacturer’s end-of-year clearance sale, depicted car owners so desperate to buy new Toyotas that they were resorting to nefarious activities to get rid of their existing cars –- including rolling boulders onto them, leaving them on railroad tracks and chopping down trees that fell on them.

headline: YouTube Video Draws Australian Condemnation
text: There are YouTube videos that may be described as “un-tasteworthy in the extreme,” and then there are those that draw the attention of world leaders for precisely that reason. Today, Foreign Minister Stephen Smith of Australia issued an (audio statement) condemning a video that accuses his country of racism, according to Agence France-Presse:

headline: N.H. Forecast: Primary Eve
text: Countdown: 1 day until the primary!

headline: Sallie Mae Appoints New Chairman, C.F.O.
text: Sallie Mae on Monday appointed a longtime banking executive as its new chairman, replacing Albert L. Lord at that position as the beleaguered student lending giant continues to struggle with tighter credit markets and the wreckage from its failed buyout. Mr. Lord will remain chief executive.

headline: Obama Cautions Voters About His Lead Position
text: CLAREMONT, N.H. – It wasn’t so long ago when Senator Barack Obama was reminding his audiences not to believe the polls. Today, he isn’t disagreeing with the trends polls are showing in the New Hampshire primary – his lead is widening, they say – but he is urging his supporters not to grow comfortable.

headline: Kristol’s Persuasion
text: In general, The Opinionator isn’t much inclined toward navel gazing, but sometimes the press (or in this case, the pundit) is the story. William Kristol made his debut on the Op-Ed Page of The Times this morning with musings on the Huckabee phenomenon:

headline: Contributor: Mark J. Penn
text: Mark J. Penn was the chief adviser to Bill Clinton in the 1996 presidential election and to Hillary Rodham Clinton in her Senate and presidential races. He is the author of “Microtrends: The Small Forces Behind Tomorrow’s Big Changes.”

headline: Another jobs picture — Europe vs. US (updated)
text: While I’m on the employment thing, I thought it might be worth looking at an international comparison.

headline: Who Gets Free Drug Samples?
text: For years, the drug industry has claimed that poor people benefit from the billions of dollars worth of free drugs that are distributed to doctors every year.

headline: Romney’s 2-Minute Closing Message on the Air
text: Mitt Romney has purchased two minutes of television time tonight on networks in Manchester and Boston for his closing message to New Hampshire voters that centers around his retooled campaign theme focused on change.

headline: Championship Week Around the World
text: It’s the start of a very special week in the NHL and around the hockey world. Thanks to a series of lucky schedule quirks, the top two clubs will square off in the NHL and in two of the top European leagues. In addition, six of last year’s best will meet in the four-day-long European Champions Cup in St. Petersburg to decide top dog on the continent.

headline: Does the MetroCard Need a Makeover?
text: More so than any credit card, library card or health insurance card, the MetroCard is the one piece of plastic that most unites New Yorkers. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority distributes 180 million of them — that’s not a typo — every year. The MetroCard is a fixture of anyone’s pocket, wallet or purse, a mainstay for any commuter, and — ever since the last tokens were phased out in 2003 — the only one way to (legally) ride a subway in New York City. And yet, few people spend much time looking at or thinking about the humble, homely MetroCard.

headline: PHH and Blackstone, Together Again?
text: PHH filed a settlement agreement on Monday that it had signed on Friday with Blackstone in connection with Blackstone’s payment of a $50 million dollar reverse termination fee and the termination of their merger agreement.

headline: Huckabee Attacks Romney’s Record
text: Mason, N.H. — A day before the New Hampshire primary, former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas embarked on his first full day of campaign appearances here since his victory in the Iowa caucus, stepping up his attacks on an unnamed opponent who sounds very much like former Gov. Mitt Romney.

headline: Contributor: Stuart M. Butler
text: Stuart M. Butler is the vice president for domestic policy at the Heritage Foundation, a research foundation, and an adjunct professor in public policy at Georgetown University. In addition to testifying before Congress on health care issues, he writes frequently about health affairs.

headline: Contributor: Ezekiel Emanuel
text: Ezekiel Emanuel, an oncologist, is the chairman of the department of bioethics at the Clinical Center of the National Institutes of Health. The co-director of Stanford University’s FRESH-Thinking Project, which is exploring ways to improve health care, he is also the author of “Health Care, Guaranteed: A Simple, Secure Solution for America.” In 2004, Mr. Emanuel contributed money to Barack Obama’s campaign for the United States Senate, and his brother Rahm Emanuel is President-elect Obama’s chief of staff.

headline: Maher Returns to HBO Without Writers
text: “HBO’s ‘Real Time With Bill Maher’ will return with new episodes Friday without both writers and two of its most popular features, Maher’s opening monologue and the closing segment ‘New Rules,'” according to The Hollywood Reporter (via Reuters).

headline: Contributor: Lawrence C. Levy
text: Lawrence C. Levy, a former political columnist and senior editorial writer for Newsday, is the executive director of the National Center for Suburban Studies at Hofstra University in New York.

headline: U.S. Military Reports Skirmish With Iran
text: Updated with official confirmation and reactions from Iran and several bloggers.

headline: Taking Stock of SPACs
text: No doubt about it: The number and size of special-purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, is surging. But SPAC stocks? That’s a different story.

headline: Eyeing the Future at C.E.S., Part 2
text: Following up on my last post: what if you didn’t have to strap on a pair of geeky goggles to watch video on your iPod, cell phone or video game console, but could project the device’s image on a nearby wall or surface? That’s the premise of Microvision, a company from Redmond, Wash., and its pocket-sized, laser-powered Pico Projector.

headline: For the Moment |  Adam Kimmel
text: This week’s guest blogger is the New York-based men’s wear designer Adam Kimmel. Known for his heady brand of cerebral machismo — Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock are recurring inspirations — Kimmel, 28, will be filing from Florence, Italy, where he is the featured designer at the men’s-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo.

headline: A New You: Gina Kolata on Fitness
text: How much exercise do you really need? What does science tell us about what it takes to lose weight and to keep the pounds off? Reporter Gina Kolata covers health and medicine for The Times and writes Personal Best, a biweekly column on fitness. This week, as readers begin the hard business of keeping New Year’s resolutions, Ms. Kolata is answering questions and hosting a discussion on fitness and weight loss. You may post your comments and questions below. Please remember that she cannot answer all questions, and she cannot respond to solicitations for medical advice. [Eds. note: We are no longer accepting questions and comments.]

headline: After the Hunt
text: My friend Neil shot a deer. This was not surprising, considering that Neil is one surfboard-riding, juji gatame– slapping-on, muzzleloader-wielding kind of guy. So when he brought home the venison yours truly and a small but hungry crew were rested, ready and salivating.

headline: The Best Player in the NHL Today?
text: Sidney Crosby is the face of the NHL, the man in all the league’s ads, the player picked to draw interest to showcase events like the Ice Bowl last week and quite probably the Victoria Cup in September. He’s a great player — but is he really the best in hockey?

headline: The Problem With CNet: No One Wants to Buy It
text: Andrew Ross Sorkin reports in this morning’s New York Times that an investor group has amassed a stake in CNet Networks and wants to put pressure on its management by electing new board members.

headline: A Chilling Idea at C.E.S.
text: Let’s put our skepticism away for a moment. There are in fact some big ideas at the 2008 C.E.S. – speaking literally, at the very least.

headline: L.S.U. Cruises to B.C.S.Title
Contributor: Scott M. Delman
text: Scott M. Delman is the managing partner of a private equity firm and has served on the board of various academic and public policy organizations. He has contributed to and raised money for John McCain’s 2000 and 2008 presidential bids.

headline: Contributor: Eric Wasserstrom
text: Eric Wasserstrom is a managing director at a New York-based hedge fund and previously was an equity analyst for a global investment bank focusing on consumer lending. Prior to working on Wall Street, he did bank regulation for the Federal Reserve. He is also a security fellow at the Truman National Security Project, a national security leadership institute.

headline: Monday on the Trail
text: The weary, hoarse-voiced presidential candidates raced around New Hampshire on the last full day of campaigning before Tuesday’s primary.

headline: A Fan in the French Quarter
text: NEW ORLEANS — I landed here at 10 a.m. Saturday. I sat in front of a nun on the airplane. Maybe that is a sign to behave in the French Quarter.

headline: Sallie Mae's Management
text: CNBC's David Faber discusses Sallie Mae's  appointment of a new chairman.

headline: The Torch of Women’s Lib
text: For centuries women have been told not to smoke. Today, it’s with good reason — smoking is killing women in record numbers.

headline: Contributor: Joanna R. Shelton
text: Joanna R. Shelton is a senior fellow at the Montana World Affairs Council and a research professor in economics at the University of Montana. Previously, she was the deputy secretary general of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. She has also been the deputy assistant secretary of State for trade policy and programs, a professional staff member on the House Ways and Means subcommittee on trade and an economist at the Treasury Department and at the Trade Representative’s Office. She has contributed money to Barack Obama’s presidential campaign.

headline: Big Wheel Keep On Turnin’
text: The Red Wings did it again Sunday, beating their Original Six nemesis, the Blackhawks, in Chicago, 4-1. That makes win No. 32.

headline: C.E.S.: Bill Gates Keynote
text: Bill Gates headlines the C.E.S. festivities last night, reports CNBC's Jim Goldman.

headline: Motorola Still Not Getting the Icahn Lift
text: Carl Icahn has said that his corporate agitations have created $50 billion in shareholder value over the last few years. But so far, Motorola isn’t feeling the Icahn Effect.

headline: Contributor: Sandra Tsing Loh
text: Sandra Tsing Loh, a writer and a performer, is the author most recently of “Mother on Fire,” a comic memoir of her struggle to find a school in Los Angeles for her child to attend. She has been a regular commentator on NPR’s “Morning Edition” and Ira Glass’ “This American Life.” American Public Media’s “Marketplace” broadcasts her monthly segment, “The Loh Down.” She is also a contributing editor for The Atlantic.

headline: A Candidate Spurned
text: For the last year or so, no one professed to love Iowa and the nominating process more than Hillary Rodham Clinton. She told Iowans how much she appreciated their state. She admired the serious way in which they examined all the candidates. She thought they were just the kind of people to help choose the Democratic nominee. So it was noticeable that, by the time the Clinton campaign touched down here in New Hampshire last week, she and her spurned aides had begun dissing Iowa and its role in the process.

headline: Monday Kickoff: Championship Monday Arrives
text: Well, the day has finally come. After all of the unbelievable upsets, the triple-overtime games, the 15-lateral, last-second plays, the final day of the college football season has arrived. Be sure to check out The Quad tonight for live game-tracking of the B.C.S. title game. Until then, here are some articles for your reading pleasure.

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Veya
text: T Magazine’s Senior Editor Sandra Ballentine opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.

headline: Larkin, Atop the High Heap
text: Who is the greatest British writer since 1945?

headline: ‘Dexter’ Will Air on CBS
text: The Showtime series “Dexter” will be shown on a different network, CBS, starting on Sunday, Feb. 17 at 10 p.m., CBS announced today.

headline: CIBC Ousts Two Executives Amid Write-Downs
text: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, the country’s worst-performing bank stock last year, ousted its top investment banker and chief risk officer after announcing debt writedowns of as much as $3 billion, more than any other Canadian lender, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Picketers Will Greet Colbert and Stewart
text: Comedy Central’s pair of news satires will resume production today after a two-month strike-induced hiatus. Small picket lines of Writers Guild of America members will be stationed outside the studios of both “The Daily Show” and “The Colbert Report” as Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert return to their respective broadcasts.

headline: Lewis Hamilton’s birthday present
text: Lewis Hamilton turned 23 years old today, and as a way for him to forget that he is entering 2008 not only no longer as a rookie but far from being a young man in F1 terms (these days – ask Sebastian Vettel), the McLaren Mercedes team gave him a birthday present in the form of the 2008 car.

headline: Romney Finds Stability in ‘Change’ Message
text: STRATHAM, N.H. — Mitt Romney has seemed distinctly more comfortable in New Hampshire after rolling out a revamped stump speech focused on bringing change to Washington.

headline: High-Definition Movies, Without the Format War
text: As the major studios continue to battle over Blu-ray and HD DVD, the competing standards for high-definition DVDs, it’s always worth considering whether both camps are ultimately doomed – leapfrogged by straight-to-the-home digital downloads of high definition movies.

headline: Open Caucus: N.H. Debate Reviews
text: The Times’s virtual round table of voters talked about the recent debates in New Hampshire.

headline: CBS Poll Reflects Iowa Influence
text: Few Democratic primary voters in New Hampshire say last week’s results were important in determining their choices, but polls show the shape of the contest has changed since the Iowa caucuses.

headline: There’s Still Time to Register to Vote in New York
text: Would-be new voters in New York who are head-over-heels for Huckabee or committed to Clinton had better hurry. The deadline is looming for new registrants who want to vote in New York’s Feb. 5 presidential primaries. The state Board of Elections says that all new registrations must be mailed to county boards with a postmark of Friday or earlier. People who choose to register in person also must do so by Friday.

headline: Where Have You Gone, John McCain?
text: Has John McCain’s window closed as quickly as it opened? Joe Klein at Swampland thinks so:

headline: Internet to the TV? Me Too!
text: For all the product announcements and new technologies at the Consumer Electronics Show, there is a monster level of me-tooism. Every exhibitor is trying to out do the other on the topic du jour. This year, as in year’s past, the topic is: piping Internet content onto your TV.

headline: The White House and the Wall Street Factor
text: Are the early results in the presidential races showing an anti-Wall Street tinge?

headline: Clinton Tears Up; Talks About Campaign Strains
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. – In perhaps her most public display of emotion in the presidential campaign, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s eyes welled with tears, and her voice cracked dramatically, as she talked about holding up under the rigors of the race and her belief that she is the best candidate for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Contributor: Michael A. Cohen
text: Michael A. Cohen is a senior research fellow at the New America Foundation and the author of “Live From the Campaign Trail: The Greatest Presidential Campaign Speeches of the 20th Century and How They Shaped Modern America.” He has served as a speechwriter for Senator Chris Dodd and former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Bill Richardson, and has volunteered for a number of Democratic presidential campaigns.

headline: A Word of the Year for Our Times
text: Until the various word authorities agree to hold a decisive event like the Oscars, someone’s going to have to keep track of all of these words-of-the-year. Thus, today we bring the latest champion, and possibly the most convincing: subprime.

headline: Terrelle Pryor Picks Ohio State to Win
text: Terrelle Pryor has yet to make his college choice, but he’s picking Ohio State tonight.

headline: The Times and CNBC.com Team Up
text: Larry Ingrassia, business editor of The Times, and Allen Wastler, managing editor of CNBC.com, discuss the partnership between the two news organizations.

headline: Microsoft's New Hardware
text: A look at Microsoft's presence at the Consumer Electronics Show, with Robbie Bach, president of Microsoft's entertainment devices division, and CNBC's Jim Goldman.

headline: Tax Clash on the Trail
text: CONCORD, N.H. — Emotions ran high on the last day before the primary. At a campaign stop here, Mike Huckabee was mobbed by supporters of the libertarian candidate Ron Paul, who shouted “Tax Hike Mike!” “Tax Hike Mike.”

headline: No More New Things From Microsoft
text: In an era when the vanguard of technology is creating smart devices for entertainment and communications, Bill Gates, the outgoing chairman of Microsoft, had little that was interesting or innovative to show off in his last annual keynote at CES in Las Vegas on Sunday.

headline: Contributor: Andrew Kohut
text: Andrew Kohut is the president of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press. He is a former president of the Gallup Organization and a founder of Princeton Survey Research Associates. The co-author of four books, he is a frequent commentator on polls for National Public Radio, PBS and other news media outlets.

headline: Contributor: Matthew Continetti
text: Matthew Continetti is the associate editor of The Weekly Standard and author of “The K Street Gang: The Rise and Fall of the Republican Machine.” He edits The Standard’s campaign blog and appears regularly as a political analyst on National Public Radio and MSNBC. His articles and reviews have appeared in, among other publications, The Times, The Financial Times and The Washington Post.

headline: Contributor: Ron Klain
text: Ron Klain was a member of Bill Clinton’s 1992 campaign policy and debate preparation staff; was the chief of staff for Vice President Al Gore during the 1996 election; ran Mr. Gore’s “war room” in 2000; and led debate preparation for Senator John Kerry’s 2004 presidential bid.

headline: The Heir to the ‘Crocodile Hunter’
text: In the late 1990s, as Steve Irwin’s star rose, so did the popularity of his United States television partner, Discovery Communications’ Animal Planet channel. More than one year after Mr. Irwin died, his daughter Bindi could conceivably advance Discovery Kids Channel in a similar way.

headline: Contributor: Dan Schnur
text: Dan Schnur is the director of the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California. The national communications director for John McCain’s presidential bid in 2000, Mr. Schnur has worked on four presidential and three gubernatorial campaigns.

headline: A Little Late
text: I got the Wiley Business Spring Catalog in the mail today and found a pitch for a new book to be published in March: “Subprime Mortgage Credit Derivatives.” It is “written by an expert author team of UBS practitioners” and needs to be read because of “the recent growth in subprime lendng.”

headline: Contributor: The Topical Satire Initiative
text: The Topical Satire Initiative is Rachel Axler, Kevin Bleyer, Rich Blomquist, Steve Bodow, Tim Carvell, Scott Jacobson, Rob Kutner, Josh Lieb and Sam Means, who, when gainfully employed, write funny stuff for “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart.”

headline: Contributor: The McLaughin’ Group
text: The McLaughin’ Group is Michael Brumm, Rob Dubbin, Glenn Eichler, Peter Grosz, Peter Gwinn, Barry Julien, Jay Katsir and Frank Lesser, who, when gainfully employed, write funny stuff for “The Colbert Report.”

headline: Wyoming Winter Weighs Down Moondance Diner
text: The cherished Moondance Diner, transplanted to its new home in La Barge, Wyo., went through a trying experience last week that would have been impossible so far this year in New York City. Yes, while in New York, it dodged a wrecking a ball. Yes, a serendipitous online dating moment put it in the loving care of a Wyoming couple. And yes, it survived a perilous 2,100-mile trek cross-country behind a semi to a town with a population of 600 people. But on Thursday, the 75-year-old, yet-to-be-renovated diner simply crumpled under the accumulated weight of snow on its roof.“It’s pretty much in a heap,” said Candy Kjar, the La Barge town clerk, who saw the building as she was driving in and out of town.

headline: Shadowing New York’s Commuters, Week 2
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, with additional details and reader comments here on City Room [Read Week 1]. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: TV Technology Showcased At C.E.S.
text: Recapping some of the TV technology announcements at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas:

headline: Contributor: Francis Wilkinson
text: Francis Wilkinson is executive editor of The Week and theweekmagazine.com. He is a former communications consultant for corporations and Democratic campaigns.

headline: Contributor: Bill Emmott
text: Bill Emmott, the editor-in-chief of The Economist from 1993 until 2006, is the author of the forthcoming “Rivals: How the Power Struggle Between China, India and Japan Will Shape Our Next Decade.”

headline: The High Low | L.L. Bean’s Kingfield Sweater
text: You don’t need a degree from Central St. Martins to know that good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant affordable gets. In this column, T’s fashion team roll up their Balenciaga sleeves to rummage for the cheap and the chic.

headline: Microsoft Shows Off Interactive TV Features
text: Microsoft is demonstrating its vision of interactive television at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week, displaying next-generation scenarios that include interactive boxing matches on Showtime and straw polls during election coverage on CNN.

headline: Electronics Makers Look for the Next Display
text: For the last several years, the biggest story in the biggest market in consumer electronics—televisions—has been the war between plasma and liquid-crystal displays. In the market now, L.C.D.s have clearly won. Even Matsushita,, the biggest backer of plasma technology, is investing in a big new L.C.D. plant.

headline: Contributor: Douglas MacKinnon
text: Douglas MacKinnon was a press secretary to former Senator Bob Dole. He was also a writer for Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush and a special assistant for policy and communications in the Defense Department. He has worked on three presidential campaigns and is the author, most recently, of “The Apocalypse Directive,” a novel.

headline: World Club Top 10: Championship Week Edition
text: With the Red Wings and Senators gearing up for their only meeting of the regular season, to take place Saturday at 7 p.m. in Ottawa, we take a glance at the World Top 10. Also, No. 8 Slavia Prague will play No. 9 Ceske Budejovice in the Czech Extraliga, and in the European Champions Cup in St. Petersburg, No. 3 Slovan Bratislava and No. 6 Karpat Oulu will vie in their respective groups toward a potential meeting in the tournament final on Sunday.

headline: Team USA to Team Bridgeport
text: Kyle Okposo, the future power forward for the Islanders, will start his professional career as a Bridgeport Sound Tiger in the American Hockey League. He could suit up Friday in Binghamton against the farm team of the Ottawa Senators.

headline: Contributor: Steven Heller
text: Steven Heller is the co-chairman of the MFA Design program at the School of Visual Arts. He writes the “Visuals” column in the New York Times Book Review. He is the author of the forthcoming “Iron Fists: Branding the Totalitarian State.”

headline: Contributor: Bruce Fuller
text: Bruce Fuller, a professor of education and public policy at the University of California at Berkeley, is the author most recently of “Standardized Childhood: The Political and Cultural Struggle Over Early Education.”

headline: Contributor: Lance T. Izumi
text: Lance T. Izumi, a senior fellow in California studies and the senior director of education studies at the Pacific Research Institute for Public Policy, is the co-author of the book “Not as Good as You Think: Why the Middle Class Needs School Choice.” He was appointed to the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges in 2004 by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, and he is the board’s president. Prior to going into the think-tank world, Mr. Izumi served as chief speechwriter and director of writing and research for Gov. George Deukmejian of California and was a speechwriter for United States Attorney General Edwin Meese III during the Reagan administration.

headline: Bumpy Ride on McCain Press Bus
text: WARNER, N.H. — If there is a word that could define the McCain campaign operation as the candidate clawed his way back into contention in the Republican primary contest, scrappy would not be a bad one.

headline: Final Thoughts From Les Miles
text: NEW ORLEANS — There’s no more talking, at least to the news media. In less than eight hours, No. 1 Ohio State (11-1) and No. 2 Louisiana State (11-2) will take the field of the Superdome for the Bowl Championship Series title game.

headline: Best of C.E.S.
text: David Pogue spotlights his favorite tech gadgets from the Consumer Electronics Show.

headline: Final Thoughts From Jim Tressel
text: NEW ORLEANS — Here are five things that Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel said in his final pregame news conference Sunday:

headline: ‘Basically, It’s a Landslide’
text: Almost two months after The Lede noted major political promises made in three countries wracked with instability in a single day, we have a resolution to report.

headline: Gadgets, Germs and the Juice
text: Everyone at the Consumer Electronics Show is on the juice.

headline: A Buckeyes Bash
text: NEW ORLEANS – A strong showing of Ohio State fans gathered Saturday when around 16,000 alumni and fans attended the Buckeye Bash at the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center.

headline: CBS Surrounds the Britney Spears Saga
text: Three CBS brands — “Dr. Phil,” “Entertainment Tonight” and “The Early Show” — ­collaborated to promote Dr. Phil McGraw’s hospital visit with Britney Spears.

headline: Bloomberg Drops No Hints in Oklahoma
text: More than a dozen former and current elected officials met in Norman, Okla., today for what organizers called a “bipartisan forum,” convened by David L. Boren, the president of the University of Oklahoma and a former Democratic senator, and Sam Nunn, with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as the guest of honor. The goal? Spark national discussion on issues like global warming, the federal deficit and the decline in America’s prestige abroad.

headline: A Rapidly Changing Race
text: The simplicity and careful planning of Iowa and New Hampshire are about to give way to a complex, high-velocity game of "Survivor."

headline: Don’t Be Cruel, Justice Scalia
text: The Supreme Court is getting a well-earned reputation for cruelty.

headline: Paulson Discusses Housing Woes
text: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson says there is no single or simple solution to the housing crisis. CNBC's Mary Thompson has the latest on Paulson's speech.

headline: Obama’s Thinking About Tomorrow
text: NEW LONDON, N.H. – As Senator Barack Obama stopped by Jack’s, a village coffee shop here, he ordered hot tea with lemon to nurse his ailing throat. It was the only moment of the day, so far, that reporters were close enough to ask him any questions.

headline: The iPod Economy and C.E.S.
text: Matt Richtel compared being at the Consumer Electronics Show to a return to the tripped out days of the 1960s. My experience, the several times I ventured onto the convention floor in Las Vegas, was somewhat less pleasant: It felt like I was a ball trapped inside a pachinko machine in Tokyo’s Ginza district.

headline: Contributor: Gary David Goldberg
text: Gary David Goldberg is the founder of UBU Productions, which produced nine television series, including “Family Ties” and “Brooklyn Bridge.” He is the author of “Sit, Ubu, Sit: How I Went From Brooklyn to Hollywood With the Same Woman, the Same Dog and a Lot Less Hair.”

headline: ‘I Guess She’s Not Crazy After All’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (use the comment link below):

headline: Q&A: Manchester United’s Mikael Silvestre
text: In a posting late last week, Manchester United defender Mikael Silvestre spoke about his decision to decline a transfer to Newcastle United because of Joey Barton, and also about the prospects of Silvestre one day playing in the United States.

headline: Jones Accepts S.M.U. Job
text: Hawaii Coach June Jones accepted the head coaching job at Southern Methodist University today. He signed a five-year deal that will pay him about $2 million per season. The job makes him the highest-paid college football coach outside the six major conferences and also shows how serious S.M.U. is about reviving a football program decimated by receiving the so-called death penalty from the N.C.A.A. in 1987.

headline: Sony’s Chief Says It Won’t Be Late Again
text: There aren’t many who can admit a mistake like Howard Stringer. He’s charming and easygoing; his relatively close-cropped hair manages to look a little floppy. He’s the big friendly dog who protects you and sometimes tears up newspaper all over the house and then he nestles up to you and you can’t help but feel that you didn’t want to read the sports section after all.

headline: Finding a Faucet
text: Next time I build a custom house (right after hell freezes over), here’s one thing I will do differently: Make sure the builder has provided a reasonable allowance for plumbing fixtures.

headline: In Pursuit of the Pomegranate
text: Waiting for freshly squeezed pomegranate juice at Meyvemix, a new juice bar between the Galatasaray High School and the British Consulate in Beyoglu. A generous serving costs 3 YTL.

headline: Intel C.E.O. on '08 Challenges
text: Paul Otellini, Intel CEO, discusses the challenges his company will face in 2008, with CNBC's Jim Goldman.

headline: Missed Connections, Lost Dogs and More
text: What we’re reading elsewhere…

headline: Contributor: Jacob S. Hacker
text: Jacob S. Hacker, professor of political science at Yale and a fellow at the New America Foundation, is the author of “The Great Risk Shift: The New Economic Insecurity and the Decline of the American Dream.” He is also the author of “Health Care for America,” a proposal for universal health care released by the Economic Policy Institute.

headline: Steep City Deficits Predicted in 2009 and Beyond
text: In what is probably its most alarming forecast in recent memory, the city’s Independent Budget Office today projected a $3.1 billion budget deficit in the 2009 fiscal year, rising to $4.6 billion in 2010 and $6.3 billion in 2011 — largely as as result of the weakening in the housing market and higher labor costs. The office warned that the “the city’s fiscal picture could become even darker” if Wall Street’s economic woes worsen or if the housing market, which in Manhattan has remained strong, further declines. The conclusions in the five-page report suggest that whoever succeeds Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be saddled with fiscal problems as serious as the ones Mr. Bloomberg inherited when he took office in 2002 as the city was still reeling from 9/11.

headline: Outside Groups Spend in N.H.
text: The last-minute blitz of campaigning by the candidates in New Hampshire is also being matched by a last-minute blitz of independent expenditures – outside groups putting up their own money to advocate for, or against, different Presidential hopefuls.Filings over the last few days at the Federal Election Commission show that Hillary Rodham Clinton is a big recipient of support from two of her strongest outside backers – the American Federation of Teachers and the Emily’s List political action committee.

headline: Taser Toting, Without Missing a Beat
text: If the world were divided into neat groups — say, between users of Tasers and MP3 players — perhaps TASER International would have no reason to unveil their latest invention. But it’s not, and they do.

headline: Strong Ratings for ‘American Gladiators’
text: NBC’s remake of “American Gladiators” muscled its way to a strong start in the ratings on Sunday. The amateur athletic tournament based on the early 1990s series with a cult following delivered the highest ratings among adults aged 18 to 49 of any new show this season on any network, matching NBC’s debut of “Heroes” in September 2006, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Ask About the Immigrant Experience on the Lower East Side
text: From Jan. 7 to 14, Steve Long, the vice president of collections and education at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, took questions from City Room readers on the history of immigration and tenement life on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Mixed Emotions
text: She aches, just like a woman … and you can watch it here.

headline: For a Moment, They Stopped to Look
text: New Yorkers rarely stop.

headline: Yahoo’s Quest to Open Up
text: For months, Yahoo chief executive Jerry Yang has been talking about swinging open the doors to the Yahoo portal. A key goal, he has said again and again, is to turn Yahoo into a set of platforms for third-party publishers and developers.

headline: Comfort Food To Count on, in London
text: Restaurants are abundant here in London, ranging from reasonably priced chains to eclectic ethnic treats to Michelin starred establishments. But when looking for a place guaranteed to offer a good all round experience, the choice becomes more limited. One eaterie that can be said to fulfill most requirements is The Wolseley, in Picadilly, which is modeled on the grand European tradition of café-restaurant. Located in a building that originally housed a showroom for Wolseley Motors, it is open from 7 am – midnight serving breakfast, lunch, tea and dinner as well as offering an all day menu.The Wolseley

headline: Who Are More Human: PC Users or Couch Potatoes?
text: Matters turned philosophical here at the Consumer Electronics Show in a discussion with Toshihiro Sakamoto, president and senior managing director of Panasonic AVC Networks. Mr. Sakamoto is charming, twinkle-eyed and at least a grade classier than the sell-at-all-costs, run-of-the mill American chief executive. (And, as my friend Alex Pham of The Los Angeles Times put it, he sure is handsome.)

headline: Contributor: Rachel Kleinfeld
text: Rachel Kleinfeld is the executive director of the Truman National Security Project, a national security leadership institute. She has consulted on homeland security, bioterrorism, defense and rule of law issues for several private and nonprofit organizations.

headline: Pennington? Or Clemens?
text: Reporters met with Jets General Manager Mike Tannenbaum on Monday, and he said he expected quarterback Chad Pennington to be back next season, even with a cap number of $7.8 million. Tannenbaum also said he expected Pennington to compete with Kellen Clemens for the starting quarterback job.

headline: Contributor: Thomas M. Donnelly
text: Thomas M. Donnelly is the resident fellow in foreign and defense policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute. A former journalist who has worked at Army Times and Defense News, he was a professional staff member at the United States House of Representatives Committee on National Security (now the Committee on Armed Services) from 1995 to 1999.

headline: Cable May Open Up Just a Bit
text: One tantalizing tidbit from C.E.S. was the revival of a technology from the cable industry that is meant to let any television or other device hook into cable systems without a set-top box. CableLabs, the industry technology consortium, has been talking about this technology, called OpenCable, for years. Today, it was renamed Tru2Way. Several manufacturers, including Panasonic, said they would deploy sets using the technology.

headline: The Animated Life: Trigger Happy
text: Jeff Scher's latest animation is a ballet in black and white. Part of Sightlines, an Op-Ed visual series.

headline: Contributor: Bill Barich
text: Bill Barich’s books include “Laughing in the Hills,” “Carson Valley,” “A Fine Place to Daydream” and “A Pint of Plain about the traditional Irish pub,” to be published next March.

headline: Bloggingheads: Sex 'Slaves'
text:
Will Wilkinson, left, of the Cato Institute and Kerry Howley of Reason Magazine on whether the international sex trade is enslavement or liberation.

headline: Plenty of Seats Available
text: NEW ORLEANS — Less than four hours before Monday’s national championship game upper-level tickets were selling for $650 apiece and lower-level seats were fetching $1,000 to $1,500 each, the ticket broker Curry Hayes said.

headline: On the Road With John McCain
text: Senator John McCain, Republican candidate for president, campaigned from Nashua to Hanover a day before the New Hampshire primary.

headline: Blogtalk: Emotion and the Campaign Trail
text: At a routine campaign stop in Portsmouth, N.H., Hillary Rodham Clinton got a bit teary after she was asked by a voter how she deals with the pressures of campaigning. There was no all-out crying, just a little misting of the eyes and a noticeable crack in Mrs. Clinton’s voice. But just the little bit of unexpected emotion from the New York senator was enough to spark debate between bloggers on both sides of the political divide.

headline: We’re Looking Live
text: NEW ORLEANS — Both Louisiana State and Ohio State are warming up right now and the fans here are getting worked into a fever pitch with a bevy of chants. Here’s my pregame analysis, which is always dangerous 47 minutes before the game because the prospect of looking foolish is in real time.

headline: ‘Iron My Shirt’
text: SALEM, N.H. — Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was about to deliver a line that has become a centerpiece of her campaign since her loss in Iowa.

headline: Boosting New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — The Sugar Bowl and Monday’s Bowl Championship Series title game had an estimated combined economic impact of more than $500 million for New Orleans, according to Lea Sinclair, the director of communications for the New Orleans Tourism Marketing Corporation.

headline: Morning Briefing on the B.C.S.
text: NEW ORLEANS — When measuring developments in terms of changes in the B.C.S., its difficult to get a handle on what qualifies as significant progress. At the Football Writer’s Association of America Breakfast on Monday morning, both the outgoing B.C.S. coordinator Mike Slive and the new B.C.S. coordinator John Swofford spoke openly about discussing a Plus One model for the future of college football.

headline: Home Field for L.S.U.?
text: NEW ORLEANS — We’re minutes before kickoff, and one of the much-discussed issues heading into this game was whether or not L.S.U. would have a home-field advantage because Baton Rouge is located just 80 miles down I-10. I boldly predicted that that advantage would be negligible, as U.S.C. didn’t appear to have much of a home-field advantage in terms of crowd when they played in the Rose Bowl two years ago.

headline: Dorsey’s Knee Could Affect Draft Status
text: NEW ORLEANS — While the senior Louisiana State defensive tackle Glenn Dorsey is seemingly the front-runner to be the first overall pick in April’s N.F.L. draft, his stock could be impacted by a right knee injury that he sustained earlier this season.

headline: Rock Star Treatment
text: BEDFORD, N.H. — Did it just begin here?

headline: Clinton’s Civil Rights Lesson
text: DOVER, N.H. — As they barnstorm through New Hampshire, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband are often introduced by supporters who once backed another candidate but converted to her cause.

headline: Champions, Again and Again
text: Most championships, clubs in major hockey-playing nations.

headline: A Blizzard of Ads in New Hampshire
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — If you live in the Boston/Manchester media market and you think you’ve been bombarded with political ads this year, you’re right.

headline: Rangers Say Straka Has a Concussion: What a Concept
text: The Rangers are more than a bit woozy from an 0-2-1 trip to Western Canada, but they have enough sense about them to fess up that forward Martin Straka suffered a concussion in Saturday night’s shootout loss to Edmonton.

headline: ‘Trigger Happy’
text: “Trigger Happy” was made with hundreds of objects found on the streets and sidewalks of New York.

headline: And here it comes …
text: When the economy was (sorta, kinda) strong, it showed that tax cuts work, and so we needed to make the Bush tax cuts permanent. Now the economy is falling off a cliff — although according to the White House, nobody is predicting a recession (I seem to know an awful lot of nobodies) — and you know what that means: we’d better make the Bush tax cuts permanent.

headline: Hollywood Hideaway
text: The Costa Brava retreat built by ’30s film star Madeleine Carroll is for sale, priced at €10 million.

text: What would you give up to live pain free?
