headline: Writer-Less Colbert: ‘Where Are My Words?’
text: In Tuesday’s New York Times, Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg summarize Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert’s returns to television:

headline: The Strike Scene at ‘Colbert’ and ‘Daily Show’
text: Fifteen strikers picketed outside “The Daily Show” studio in the Clinton neighborhood of Manhattan amid unseasonably warm weather Monday. Twenty strikers circled two blocks north outside the studios of “The Colbert Report” as both Comedy Central shows resumed taping for the first time in two months.

headline: After Iowa, Campaigns Cast Even Wider Net Online
text: In her Web column, Katharine Q. Seelye notes that since Barack Obama proved that young people do vote after all, most of the candidates have been cranking up their presence online, especially through YouTube.Go to Column

headline: On The Road With Hillary
text: Hillary Clinton swings through New Hampshire on the eve of the nation's first primary.

headline: New Hampshire Voices
text: The price of oil is critically important in New Hampshire, and many residents are disappointed in how the presidential candidates are approaching it.

headline: Nascar Changes, and Johnson Remains
text: On the first day of the first test session of the 2008 Nascar preseason, Jimmie Johnson was confronted with the question that will follow him every day for the next 11 months.

headline: Bridgeport: Ex-Police Detective Sentenced
text: A former New Haven police detective convicted in a Police Department drug scandal was sentenced on Monday in Federal District Court to 90 days in jail. The former detective, Jose Silva, 36, pleaded guilty to depriving an individual of his constitutional rights in October. Federal prosecutors said Mr. Silva knew that another detective, Justen Kasperzyk, had moved suspected narcotics from the basement to the back bedroom of a first-floor apartment in New Haven, resulting in an unlawful arrest in November 2006. Mr. Kasperzyk pleaded guilty to one count of civil rights conspiracy, a felony, and one count of theft of government property, a misdemeanor. He is scheduled to be sentenced March 27.

headline: Let the Season of B.C.S. Discussion Begin
text: NEW ORLEANS  Mike Slive officially ended his two-year tenure as Bowl Championship Series coordinator Monday, but not before passing along another catchphrase, something he is famous for.

headline: No Strangers to the Cold, Voters Now Feel the Heat
text: HILLSBOROUGH, N.H.  People here treasure their rugged surroundings and relative isolation in the hills of southwestern New Hampshire. They welcome winter, and consider their distance from urban sprawl a clear advantage.

headline: Fever May Ease Effects of Autism Disorders
text: Parents of young people with autistic disorders often say they notice that symptoms calm down when the children have a fever. A new study confirms that this may be the case.

headline: An Author Sues the Seinfelds, for a Cookbook and for Barbs
text: Missy Chase Lapine, the author of “The Sneaky Chef,” a cookbook whose recipes camouflage puréed vegetables and fruits in comfort food for children, sued Jessica and Jerry Seinfeld on Monday, charging copyright infringement and defamation.

headline: New DVDs
text: CARY GRANT

headline: Four Wheels for the Masses: The $2,500 Car
text: MUMBAI, India  What does it take to build the world’s cheapest car?

headline: U.S. Describes Confrontation With Iranian Boats
text: WASHINGTON  Five armed Iranian speedboats approached three United States Navy warships in international waters in the strategic Strait of Hormuz on Sunday, then maneuvered aggressively as radio threats were issued that the American ships would be blown up, military officials said Monday.

headline: Founder of a Nonprofit Is Punished by Its Board for Engaging in an Internet Ruse
text: A founder of GiveWell, a new nonprofit research organization that seeks to assess the effectiveness of charities, has been demoted after admitting that he promoted the organization on a Web site by posing as a prospective charitable donor seeking information.

headline: Lender Tells Judge It ‘Recreated’ Letters
text: The Countrywide Financial Corporation fabricated documents related to the bankruptcy case of a Pennsylvania homeowner, court records show, raising new questions about the business practices of the giant mortgage lender at the center of the subprime mess.

headline: F.B.I. Data Show Drop in Crime
text: Crime dipped slightly for the first half of 2007, the F.B.I. reported, signaling a stop to a two-year increase in violence nationwide. Violent crime, including murders, rapes and robberies, dropped by 1.8 percent from January to June last year, according to the preliminary data from the bureau. Property crimes also decreased, including a 7.4 percent drop in car thefts and a 10 percent drop in arsons. But in small cities and rural areas, violent crime appears to be rising, if only slightly, the data show.

headline: Despite Weak Economy, Business Travel Demand Was Up in 2008
text: BUSINESS TRAVEL DEMAND UP IN 2008 Any weakening in the economy apparently has not yet affected most business travelers’ plans this year. According to Access America, an insurance and travelers’ assistance company, 26 percent of business travelers surveyed said they expected to be on the road more this year than last, and 61 percent said they expected to travel about the same amount. Among other findings in the survey of 1,000 travelers: Nearly 78 percent cited high gasoline prices as one frustration of travel, 55 percent named poor airline service, and 41 percent cited airport security and passport and border procedures. By far the least frustrating part of travel was booking the trip. Only 16 percent said they found making travel arrangements frustrating.

headline: Bush Admits Economy Faces Challenges
text: CHICAGO  President Bush, in a marked shift from his usual upbeat economic assessments, conceded here on Monday that the nation faces “economic challenges” due to rising oil prices, the home mortgage crisis and a weakening job market.

headline: Brunswick: Bruno’s Wife Dies
text: Barbara Bruno, the wife of the State Senate Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, has died after a long battle with Alzheimer’s disease. She was 77. The senator’s office announced the death Monday evening. Barbara and Joseph Bruno were married for 57 years, and had four children and seven grandchildren.

headline: Preserving a Fundamental Sense: Balance
text: From the Well archives

headline: Yale Plans to Increase Spending From Its Endowment
text: Facing pressure from Congress and some donors to use more of its multibillion-dollar investment gains, Yale University announced Monday that it would increase the amount of money it spent from its endowment next year by nearly 40 percent.

headline: Two Hopefuls Share Little but Youth Appeal
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  It has the feel and look of a transformative moment, this tidal wave of young voters buoying the disparate campaigns of Senators Barack Obama and John McCain.

headline: Anne Frank Musical to Open in Madrid
text: A musical based on “The Diary of a Young Girl” by Anne Frank is to open next month at the Calderon Theater in Madrid. Its star will be Isabella Castillo, 13, whose mother fled with her from Cuba to Belize, where they lived in hiding before immigrating to Miami, The Guardian of London reported. The newspaper said the production, developed by Rafael Alvero, has been given the support of the Anne Frank Foundation, which holds the rights to the diary. It is adapted from the account written while Anne and her family hid from the Nazis in Amsterdam during World War II. Jan Erik Dubbelman, who heads the international department of the foundation, said: “This production respects the message of tolerance, within the tragedy, that we want to keep alive. Being in Spanish, it can also help to take the message of Anne Frank to Latin America.”

headline: Canada: Appeal in Serial Killer Case
text: Prosecutors in British Columbia asked an appeals court to set aside six second-degree murder convictions against Robert Pickton, and order a new trial on 26 charges of first-degree murder. Relatives and friends of many of the victims were disappointed that Mr. Pickton, a pig farmer arrested in 2002, was found guilty by a jury last month only of second-degree murder, which does not require proof of premeditation. The prosecutors said the judge made errors, including his decision to split the case and put Mr. Pickton on trial on 6 counts of first-degree murder last year, with a trial on the remaining 20 counts to be held this year. Even if the government appeal is successful and Mr. Pickton is convicted on all 26 counts of first-degree murder, it will not change his sentence of life in prison without the chance of parole for 25 years. The remains of the victims, mostly prostitutes, were found buried on his farm in a Vancouver suburb.

headline: 2 Canadian Bank Executives Ousted After Subprime Losses
text: OTTAWA  The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce fired two executives Monday at its CIBC World Markets unit as it grapples with a $9.8 billion exposure to subprime debt, the largest among banks in Canada.

headline: Detectives in Bell Case Want Trial Out of City
text: Lawyers for three police detectives charged in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man in Queens in 2006 filed a motion yesterday requesting that the trial, scheduled to begin next month, be moved out of New York City, saying publicity has “incurably poisoned” the pool of prospective jurors.

headline: Older Men (and Women) Trying Not to Be Angry
text: Norman, Okla.

headline: A Long Wait to Win a Title Ends for Senior
text: NEW ORLEANS  As a redshirt freshman four years ago, Louisiana State quarterback Matt Flynn stood on the sideline here in the Superdome and watched his team win a national championship.

headline: Justices Chilly to Bid to Alter Death Penalty
text: WASHINGTON  With conservative justices questioning their motives and liberal justices questioning their evidence, opponents of the American manner of capital punishment made little headway Monday in their effort to persuade the Supreme Court that the Constitution requires states to change the way they carry out executions by lethal injection.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills Key Sunni Leader
text: BAGHDAD  Militants assassinated two key leaders of American-backed neighborhood militias in northern Baghdad over the past two days, highlighting the militants’ strategy of eliminating militia commanders who have embraced partnerships with American forces but who themselves remain vulnerable to attack.

headline: Madison Square Garden’s ‘Godfather,’ Without the Respect
text: The “Godfather” movies were not merely yarns about mobsters and blood baths. At heart, they were about dynasty, wealth and power. They were about big business in America.

headline: Texas: Environmental Advocates Sue Shell Oil
text: Environmental groups sued the Shell Oil Company and several of its affiliates, claiming that the oil giant has for years released pollutants from its suburban Houston refinery that are well above state and federal limits. In the federal lawsuit, the Sierra Club and Environment Texas claim that the excess air pollutants, including the toxic chemicals benzene and 1,3-butadiene, are a violation of the federal Clean Air Act.

headline: Good Boss, Bad Boss. Which Are You?
text: Maybe it is not them.

headline: Parents and Visiting Hours (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Focus on the Strike, Stewart Returns
text: The glimmer of emotion that Hillary Rodham Clinton displayed in New Hampshire was startling because it was so out-of-character  almost as disconcerting as Jon Stewart returning to “The Daily Show” on Monday and not making fun of it.

headline: A Good Example for Fighting Tobacco
text: The vast majority of all smokers had their first cigarette before the age of 18. That’s why the key to reducing overall tobacco use is to prevent it in the young. The task is daunting. Almost a quarter of high school students nationwide currently smoke. There’s ample reason for hope when one looks at New York City. Smoking among public high school students there dropped from 17.6 percent in 2001 to 8.5 percent in 2007  a rate that is far below the national average.

headline: Even in Exile, a Mobster Never Forsook His Code
text: TUCSON  When the time came to remember the man inside the bronze and gold coffin at the foot of the altar, the Brooklyn-born man’s three sons did not try to hide what had made their father famous.

headline: Strikebound, the Globes Scale Back Awards
text: LOS ANGELES  Are the Golden Globes, the annual movie and television awards given out by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, really news?

headline: Stocks Tumble on New Signs of Economic Woes
text: Stocks tumbled Tuesday afternoon after the chief executive of the nation’s largest phone company, AT&T, suggested a weaker economy was forcing consumers to scale back spending.

headline: Political Rivals Take Field Trip; One Takes Shot
text: CHICAGO  What happens when President Bush and Representative Rahm Emanuel of Illinois, the fast-talking, hard-charging leader of the House Democratic Caucus, take a field trip to the Windy City?

headline: Comedy Central Hosts Return to TV
text: The late-night stars of the Comedy Central cable network, Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert, returned to their programs for the first time in nine weeks Monday night, ready to sling their satirical stones at a new target: the continuing strike by the Writers Guild of America, which is forcing the stars to find creative ways to perform without their writers.

headline: Knicks Need Richardson to Recover From Slump
text: CHICAGO  When all else has failed the Knicks in recent years (which is often), they have at least been able to depend on Quentin Richardson’s jump shot, his defense and his conscience. In this season of across-the-board misery, it would seem that only his conscience has survived.

headline: Clemens’s Lawyer Plays Tape of McNamee Call
text: HOUSTON  Roger Clemens unleashed a furious attack Monday on his former trainer Brian McNamee with a news conference featuring a tape of a recorded phone call and a lawsuit accusing McNamee of lying about injecting him with performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Microsoft Forges Ties to Studios
text: Microsoft announced partnerships on Monday with Walt Disney, NBC Universal and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to bolster online video sales and step up competition with the iTunes operation of Apple Inc.

headline: The Claim: Antibiotics Will Beat a Sinus Infection
text: THE FACTS

headline: Israeli Troops Kill 3 Armed Palestinians
text: Israeli soldiers shot dead three armed Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank, including a woman, an army spokeswoman said. The armed woman, 23, identified by Islamic Jihad as one of its members, and a man approached the border fence near the Erez Crossing in northern Gaza at noon, the spokeswoman said, and opened fire on soldiers nearby before being shot. In a village near the West Bank city of Jenin, soldiers fired at armed men who approached a checkpoint, the army spokeswoman said, killing one. Palestinian officials identified the dead man as a member of Islamic Jihad.

headline: Newly Found Planet Orbits Young Star Amid Dust and Gas
text: By itself, the discovery of another extrasolar planet, this time by astronomers in Germany, is no big deal. It’s just another in what is now a long line of planets found orbiting stars other than the Sun.

headline: Back to Folsom
text: On Sunday, 40 years to the day after Johnny Cash performed at Folsom Prison in Northern California, his longtime drummer Fluke Holland will lead a celebratory concert there. The Columbia recording “Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison,” released in the summer of 1968, appeared on the country music charts for 90 weeks and on Billboard’s Top 200 for 122 weeks. Sunday’s performance will feature several members of Cash’s original band, and, according to an announcement, “A special guest vocalist will be introduced at the show.” Although no inmates present at the 1968 concert will attend the new one, one former guard, now 80, will be there, as well as several guests who were present at the time, said the show’s producer, Jonathan Holiff, son of Saul Holiff, the Canadian entrepreneur who managed Cash from 1960 to 1973. The “40th Anniversary of ‘Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison’ ” concert will be filmed and streamed worldwide over the Internet at iClips.net.

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on the Iowa caucuses on Saturday gave an incorrect history of the caucuses. One winner of contested caucuses did win the White House: George W. Bush in 2000.

headline: McCain and Obama
text: Salem, N.H.

headline: Tornadoes Kill 3; More Storms Expected
text: A tornado roared through parts of central Arkansas on Tuesday, killing one person, injuring others, and damaging homes and vehicles and knocking down trees. The latest death brings to three the number of people killed in the last two days in storms set off by unseasonably warm winter air.

headline: A Politically Dangerous Liaison for France’s President
text: PARIS  It is called the “Carla effect,” and it helps explain President Nicolas Sarkozy’s sudden decline in popularity.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Dec. 31 about the elevation of Benazir Bhutto’s 19-year-old son, Bilawal, to succeed her as chairman of the Pakistan Peoples Party three days after her assassination misstated the name of the college he attends at Oxford University, Ms. Bhutto’s alma mater. It is Christ Church, not Christ Church College. (Go to Article)

headline: High-Level Shake-Up at Condé Nast
text: Condé Nast Publications announced a management shake-up on Monday, including the departure of Mitchell B. Fox, one of the company’s highest-ranking executives and a former publisher of Details and Vanity Fair.

headline: Krispy Kreme’s Chief Executive Quits Amid Turnaround
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP)  The chief executive of Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, Daryl G. Brewster, has resigned amid a sputtering turnaround.

headline: One by One, Narratives Reflecting Life’s Mosaic
text: All the stories in this lively collection are portraits, mainly of human beings, though a monster with an identity crisis, a giant in search of love and a puppy in need of a home put in appearances as well. While the stories vary widely in quality  a few are dazzling, many are simply well crafted, a handful are embarrassingly slight or contrived  they come together to provide a kind of lesson in fiction writing.

headline: Manhattan: Holocaust Case Settled
text: A federal judge on Monday approved a settlement among Holocaust victims, their heirs and an Italian insurer. Saying the settlement was “fair, reasonable and adequate,” Judge George B. Daniels of Federal District Court ended more than a decade of litigation over the claim that the insurer, Assicurazioni Generali, refused to honor the victims’ policies. The lawsuit was among nearly two dozen that were thrown out in 2004. The cases were eventually settled, with Generali agreeing to pay $175 million to survivors and their relatives through the International Commission on Holocaust Era Insurance Claims and other channels.

headline: Settlement on Use of Central Park’s Great Lawn
text: After three years of contentious litigation, the New York City Parks Department agreed Tuesday to back away from a controversial regulation to limit public events on the Great Lawn, in the heart of Central Park, to 50,000 people. The decision to rescind the rule  put in place, the city said, to protect the lawn and used in an early form to deny permits to antiwar demonstrators  was hailed by its critics as a victory for the First Amendment and for the public use of public land.

headline: When Superconductivity Became Clear (to Some)
text: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.  Superconductivity, the flow of electricity without resistance, was once as confounding to physicists as it is to everyone else.

headline: A Chairman Is Appointed to Rebuild Sallie Mae
text: Sallie Mae, the beleaguered student lending giant, on Monday appointed a longtime banking executive as chairman as the company struggles with tighter credit markets and fallout from a failed buyout.

headline: In Greenland, Ice and Instability
text: The ancient frozen dome cloaking Greenland is so vast that pilots have crashed into what they thought was a cloud bank spanning the horizon. Flying over it, you can scarcely imagine that this ice could erode fast enough to dangerously raise sea levels any time soon.

headline: Pennington Is Expected to Stay and Compete
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.,  When General Manager Mike Tannenbaum met with Chad Pennington to discuss the Jets’ most pressing issue of the off-season, their conversation centered, oddly enough, on bull riding at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Florida: Boy, 12, Accused in Cousin’s Death
text: Prosecutors are reviewing whether a 12-year-old boy should be charged as an adult after the police accused him of fatally beating his toddler cousin Friday afternoon with a baseball bat for interrupting a cartoon show. The boy, whose name was not released, was being held in juvenile custody in the death of his cousin, 17-month-old Shaloh Joseph, who the police said enraged the suspect by crying.

headline: Mastic Beach: Body Found in Missing Man’s Cesspool
text: Nineteen months after a Mastic Beach man was reported missing by his relatives, Suffolk County police detectives have found a body in a cesspool behind his house, the police said on Monday. The man, Nicolo Caietta, 59, was reported missing on May 30, 2006, and several months later, the investigation of his disappearance was transferred to the homicide squad, the police said, without elaborating why. On Saturday, the police excavated the cesspool behind Mr. Caietta’s home at 275 Forest Road West, and found the body. The body had not been identified Monday evening, and an autopsy has been scheduled, the police said.

headline: Excerpts From Sarkozy’s News Conference
text: Following is an excerpt from a news conference by President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, as translated by The New York Times, who responded to questions from Roselyne Febvre, a French television reporter, about his relationship with the pop singer Carla Bruni:

headline: What to Ask About Exercise
text: A new diagnosis can be a frightening experience, and ever-changing research can complicate already difficult treatment decisions. Here are some questions you might ask your doctor if exercise has been recommended as part of your treatment plan.

headline: An Art Donor Opts to Hold On to His Collection
text: LOS ANGELES  Eli Broad, the billionaire financier and philanthropist whose private collection of some 2,000 works of Modern and contemporary art is one of the most sought-after by museums nationwide, has decided to retain permanent control of his works in an independent foundation that makes loans to museums rather than give any of the art away.

headline: Canadian Emissions Market Recommended
text: A Canadian government panel recommended Monday that prices be set for greenhouse gas emissions and that taxes, caps and emissions trading plans be quickly established.

headline: Frenchman Isn’t Ready Yet to Play in U.S.
text: Mikael Silvestre said he liked the United States because everything is big. But apparently the soccer is not yet big enough to entice him to consider relocating across the Atlantic for anything more than a vacation.

headline: South Korea: Warehouse Fire Kills 40
text: Fire tore through a refrigeration warehouse under construction in Ichon, south of Seoul, killing 40 workers. A local fire official said all the dead were found in the basement. More than 500 firefighters fought the blaze. The cause was undetermined, although the workers were injecting urethane foam into basement walls at the time. Among the dead were 13 ethnic Koreans from China, the Yonhap news agency reported. China has a sizable ethnic Korean minority and in recent years some have migrated to South Korea to seek employment. Like other foreign migrants, they often end up doing difficult and low-paying work.

headline: Musings as We Await New Hampshire
text: To the Editor:

headline: Aging: Mental Health Overlooked in Care of Elderly Patients
text: Depression and other mental illnesses are common among the elderly, and when they get treatment, it usually comes from their primary care doctors. But a new study suggests that those doctors may devote too little time to talking about those ailments.

headline: Kenyan Leader and Opponent to Meet
text: ELDORET, Kenya  For the first time since Kenya exploded into election-related violence that has killed more than 400 people, the president and the top opposition leader have agreed to meet, both sides said Monday.

headline: Now on the Governor’s Desk
text: Among the measures approved by the Senate and Assembly:

headline: Arkansas Proves Its Worth as a Political Testing Ground
text: BEARDEN, Ark.  Long before his diet began, Mike Huckabee would campaign in this hamlet, population 1,000, eyeing the succulent pies at the snug Bear City Diner. Patrons there have also chuckled firsthand at Bill Clinton’s glibness.

headline: Obama’s Surge Deflates Forum and Talk of a Bloomberg Run
text: NORMAN, Okla.  He arrived here for what seemed like it could be a big moment. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, eyeing a third-party presidential bid, joined Republican and Democratic elders at a forum to denounce the extreme partisanship of Washington and plot how to influence the campaign.

headline: Illinois: Agency to Investigate Control Tower Conditions
text: The United States Transportation Department will investigate the work conditions of Chicago-area air traffic controllers amid an increasing frequency of errors, the agency said. The department’s Office of the Inspector General announced the audit in response to a request last month by Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois. That request came after the General Accountability Office released a study showing that O’Hare International Airport had the second-highest number of near-collisions on runways from 2001 to 2006.

headline: Setting May Be More Significant Than the Actual Game
text: New Orleans

headline: Sony BMG Will Sell Music Without Copyright Protection
text: Sony BMG Music Entertainment, the record company, said on Monday that it would begin selling digital albums without copyright protection, making it the last record company to do so.

headline: Bronx Family Receives Help, From Early Education to Furniture
text: Sonia Gayle and her husband, Kubblla Waliyaya, want their teenage sons and their granddaughter to have one thing on their minds: getting an education.

headline: Rome Enjoys Two Gatherings of Masterworks, by Canova and Bernini
text: ROME  Nearly four years in the making, “Venus Victorious,” Canova’s seminude, life-size statue of Napoleon’s sister Paolina Borghese Bonaparte, was ready to be unveiled in that sculptor’s studio in Rome in July 1808.

headline: Jones Leaves Hawaii to Be Coach at S.M.U.
text: NEW ORLEANS  Less than a week after Hawaii’s appearance in the Sugar Bowl, which was a high point in the state’s sporting history, Coach June Jones accepted the coaching job at Southern Methodist.

headline: Ending One Airport Runaround
text: When travelers think about air travel these days, many conjure up images of overcrowded skies. And while that may not be easily fixed, there is another problem plaguing many airports  traffic on the ground. And for that, there is hope.

headline: No Golden Globes Show, Just a News Conference
text: LOS ANGELES  Are the Golden Globes, the annual movie and television awards given out by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, really news?

headline: Homeless, With a New Loss: Identity
text: There is always plenty to worry about when you are homeless. The most pressing concerns have to do with health and finances, of course. But occasionally there are other worries  deeper, odder, more unexpected. Some are even existential. A while ago, I met a man in a shelter clinic who described the worry that preoccupied him.

headline: Selected Studies: Exercise
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, please visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: New Jersey Revamps State Aid to Schools
text: TRENTON  After a tense three-hour stalemate, legislators handed Gov. Jon S. Corzine a dramatic political victory on Monday night when they approved his $7.8 billion plan to revamp New Jersey’s formula of financing the state’s public schools.

headline: Bush Assails Iran for Naval Confrontation
text: WASHINGTON  Just hours before President Bush began his trip to the Middle East, he sharply criticized Iran on Tuesday for fomenting “a dangerous situation” in an incident over the weekend in the Strait of Hormuz in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Xerox Hopes Its New Logo Doesn’t Say ‘Copier’
text: STILL think copier when you hear the name Xerox?

headline: Parasitic Butterflies Keep Options Open With Different Hosts
text: The larvae of the Alcon blue butterfly, Maculinea alcon, are sly little parasites, tricking ants into raising them. They smell just like the ants’ own brood  their surface chemicals are very similar. So the ants take the butterfly larvae to their nest, where they feed them, neglecting their own.

headline: Microsoft Bids for Norwegian Search Engine Firm
text: Microsoft bid $1.2 billion on Tuesday for a Norwegian search software company in an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products. But it is also making the move with an eye toward Google, according to industry analysts.

headline: Garden City: Long Island Rail Road Hails Performance
text: The Long Island Rail Road said Monday that 2007 was its best year for on-time performance since it began keeping records. The railroad president, Helena Williams, said 94.07 percent of its trains were on time last year, the best since record-keeping began in 1979. The previous record came in 2002, when it hit 94.04 percent.

headline: Ancient Yucatán Soils Point to Maya Market, and Market Economy
text: Scientists using improved methods of analyzing the chemistry of ancient soils have detected where a large marketplace stood 1,500 years ago in a Maya city on the Yucatán Peninsula of Mexico.

headline: A Safety-Net Hospital Falls Into Financial Crisis
text: ATLANTA  Pamela Vaughn is a Grady baby.

headline: Handling of Interrogation Recordings Leads to a Defense Request in Padilla Case
text: MIAMI  Citing disclosures that the federal government had concealed, and in some cases destroyed, videotaped interrogations of Al Qaeda operatives, a defense lawyer in the case of Jose Padilla, the Brooklyn-born convert to Islam who was convicted as a terrorism conspirator, asked a federal judge on Monday to disclose any recordings that might bear on Mr. Padilla’s recruitment into the terrorist organization.

headline: Genzyme Wins Cholesterol Drug Deal
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Genzyme has agreed to pay at least $325 million to win the hotly contested rights to a potentially powerful cholesterol-lowering drug being developed by Isis Pharmaceuticals.

headline: Striding Past the Cynics
text: Derry, N.H.

headline: Does Exercise Really Keep Us Healthy?
text: Exercise has long been touted as the panacea for everything that ails you. For better health, simply walk for 20 or 30 minutes a day, boosters say — and you don’t even have to do it all at once. Count a few minutes here and a few there, and just add them up. Or wear a pedometer and keep track of your steps. However you manage it, you will lose weight, get your blood pressure under control and reduce your risk of osteoporosis.

headline: Clinton Goes Face to Face With the Public as Obama Plays Not to Lose
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has become the open and accessible candidate  sharing beers with reporters, taking endless questions from voters at campaign events and showing rare glimpses of emotion.

headline: Snow Falling on Voters
text: Wilmot, N.H.

headline: Navigating Life With Humor and Bewilderment
text: “I think the wind created me,” says Nicky Gottlieb, the subject of “Today’s Man,” a documentary that has its television premiere on Tuesday night on most PBS stations. Mr. Gottlieb, who in the film offers his theory of how the world was formed, has Asperger’s syndrome, a form of autism, and his sister, Lizzie Gottlieb, spent six years committing his life to film. She depicts a highly intelligent man addicted to television, socially inappropriate, self-aware about his condition and negotiating the world with both humor and bewilderment.

headline: New Bond Girl
text: The name is Arterton, Gemma Arterton, and before the next James Bond film reaches its conclusion she’ll probably be shaken and stirred. Ms. Arterton, 21, has been cast as the “Bond girl” opposite Daniel Craig in the production with the working title “Bond 22” now being filmed in London, Reuters reported. Ms. Arterton, above, will play a character named Fields, a representative for the film’s producer said, adding “It’s a nice-sized role.” No further details were disclosed. Citing reports, the BBC said the film picks up where “Casino Royale” left off and is loosely based on “Risico,” a short story by Ian Fleming that pits Bond against a drug ring flooding Britain with heroin.

headline: Acting on Mitchell Report
text: Major League Baseball eliminated a 24-hour notice of drug testing and imposed background checks on clubhouse personnel, adopting recommendations in the Mitchell report on drugs in the sport. A statement from Commissioner Bud Selig also said clubhouse personnel would be subject to random drug tests and teams would be required to log all packages sent to major league clubhouses. Personal trainers were banned from locker rooms.

headline: Clinton Stuns Obama; McCain Wins
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York rode a wave of female support to victory over Senator Barack Obama in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday night. In the Republican primary, meanwhile, Senator John McCain of Arizona revived his presidential bid with a Lazarus-like win.

headline: Nature Overrun
text: Nearly 40 years ago, President Richard Nixon issued an executive order calling for a national strategy to protect wildlife by restricting off-road vehicles to carefully designated trails. President Jimmy Carter later gave the interior secretary the authority to ban such vehicles from sensitive lands. Unfortunately, except for a brief and encouraging crackdown during the Clinton administration, nobody has paid much attention to these directives since.

headline: Florida: Delay in Retrial of Six in Terror Plot
text: A judge in Miami delayed the start of jury selection in the retrial of six men accused of plotting to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago, citing an emergency involving the family of a defense lawyer. Ana M. Jhones, the lawyer for the defendant accused of being the ringleader, requested the delay, and Judge Joan Lenard of Federal District Court scheduled a hearing Wednesday to decide whether jury selection would begin this week or next. The first trial ended last month in a hung jury for the six men and in an acquittal for another.

headline: Caution, Not Panic, Seen After Drug Warnings
text: A new study may help quiet fears that the suicide warning labels on antidepressants are scaring countless patients away from medications that could help relieve their suffering.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A film review in Weekend on Dec. 21 about “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street” referred imprecisely to the story on which the film is based. It was originally serialized in Britain in the 1840s, and was the basis of a play written by Christopher Bond and of Hugh Wheeler’s book for the stage musical. While Stephen Sondheim wrote the music and lyrics for the musical, from which the film was adapted, the story is not his.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Starbucks Replaces Chief With Chairman
text: With the stock plummeting and competitors on the attack, Starbucks Coffee said Monday that it was bringing back its top barista to help turn the company around.

headline: Lottery Numbers
To Gephyrophobiacs, Bridges Are a Terror
text: The Verrazano-Narrows bridge has been called a study in grace.

headline: Rolling? We’re More Like the Flying Stones
text: TWO years is a long time to be on tour. We started the Rolling Stones’ “A Bigger Bang” tour in August 2005 at Fenway Park in Boston, and ended in August 2007 in London at the 02 arena. We traveled the globe, playing North America, South America, Europe, Japan, New Zealand, China and Australia. We even did full-stage rehearsals at a hangar at Pearson International Airport in Toronto.

headline: Holocaust Insurance Case Inches Closer to Settlement
text: A federal judge on Monday cleared the way for a long-running dispute over unpaid life insurance claims for Holocaust victims to move a step closer to a settlement. But opponents said they would keep trying to block the settlement, which, they argued, would benefit only a small number of those with potential claims.

headline: Scrutiny for Imports
text: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  The Consumer Product Safety Commission is expanding inspections of imports after the recalls of toys, toothpaste and pet-food ingredients from China, Nancy A. Nord, acting chairwoman of the agency, said Monday.

headline: Nonverbal Actions Add to Clemens’s Story
text: From his parched, pursed lips to the jut of his shoulders, Roger Clemens was holding something back, three body-language analysts who watched him over the past two days said Monday.

headline: Ballet Star to Retire
text: Damian Woetzel, a principal dancer at the New York City Ballet, said Monday he would retire at season’s end, making official what he had predicted a year ago. Mr. Woetzel’s final performance will be on June 18 after 23 years with the company. He earned a master’s degree in public administration from Harvard University last year and is artistic director of the summer Vail International Dance Festival. Mr. Woetzel said it was fitting to leave as the company commemorates the 10th anniversary of the death of Jerome Robbins by featuring his choreography. “His presence was the reason I joined” the company, Mr. Woetzel said. He said he will focus his energy “beyond the limited space of performing” in “areas where I hope to make an impact in the second part of my life.”

headline: Jump-Start on Slow Trek to Treatment for a Disease
text: Last month, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation donated $19 million to the Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative to further one of its goals: finding a new drug for African sleeping sickness.

headline: Expectations for Giants Aren’t Bigger in Texas
text: In the days before the Giants’ final regular-season game against the undefeated New England Patriots, Coach Tom Coughlin kept his team loose by constantly reminding his players that they had nothing to lose and everything to gain.

headline: More Acidic Ocean Hurts Reef Algae as Well as Corals
text: The gradual acidification of the oceans, a result of rising levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, is thought to be bad for coral reefs. The absorption of CO2 by seawater leads to lower saturation levels of carbonate ions, which reduces calcification, the process by which corals make their hard skeletons.

headline: Italy: Army Called in to Clear Naples Trash
text: The government sent troops to Naples to start clearing festering piles of rubbish from the streets, many blocking entry to the city’s schools, which reopened Monday after the Christmas break. Mountains of trash, too much for garbage collectors to cope with, built up after municipal dumps overflowed Dec. 21. Residents of Naples have taken to burning their own refuse, creating blazes that in some cases have had to be put out by firefighters. The city’s effort to move the garbage to a previously closed dump brought a revolt by residents, who blocked garbage trucks’ access to the area. Naples has faced periodic trash emergencies for the past 14 years.

headline: Women Are Never Front-Runners
text: THE woman in question became a lawyer after some years as a community organizer, married a corporate lawyer and is the mother of two little girls, ages 9 and 6. Herself the daughter of a white American mother and a black African father  in this race-conscious country, she is considered black  she served as a state legislator for eight years, and became an inspirational voice for national unity.

headline: To Raise Armyworms and Corn Borers, Study Insect Husbandry
text: STARKVILLE, Miss.  The fall armyworm, scourge of young pretassel corn, grows up to be a nondescript brown moth about the length of a long finger’s knuckle. Frank M. Davis’s trainees are growing about 30,000 of them in the moth house at the United States Department of Agriculture’s laboratory at Mississippi State University.

headline: Hong Kong Power Regulations Based in Part on Emissions
text: HONG KONG  The two electric power companies here have agreed to a new regulatory system that sets their annual rate of return, based in part on how much pollution they emit, a carrot-and-stick approach that could some day be a model for mainland China’s giant power industries.

headline: E.P.A. Seeks New Life for Old Cellphones
text: The way the Environmental Protection Agency sees it, one discarded cellphone is like one vote: on its own, it cannot do much harm or good, but the cumulative effect can pack a wallop.

headline: Comcast Plans to Offer a Huge Menu of Films
text: Comcast, the nation’s largest cable television company, will outline an ambitious plan Tuesday to set up two new paradigms for how people will watch movies and television shows in their homes or on the road.

headline: Is Prefab Fab? MoMA Plans a Show
text: To many people the term “prefab housing” calls to mind trailer parks. Yet lately prefabricated houses  built off site and then delivered largely complete  have become fashionable at architecture schools and among an upscale segment of the housing market. They pose a considerable design challenge.

headline: Questioning an Adviser’s Advice
text: “Come on, you can say it. I’m a professional entrencher of management.”

headline: Raw and Edited: The Two Versions of Clemens
text: The moment Roger Clemens cut off his news conference Monday by walking off (still, in high dudgeon, remembering to take his bottle of water), I said to myself, “Now that’s television!”

headline: Pros and Cons of Giving Adult Drugs to Children
text: The attention-deficit generation has been supplanted by the bipolar generation, we learn in Tuesday night’s “Frontline” on PBS. And overmedication of children is not the only concern these days. Parents may now be turning their youngsters into guinea pigs.

headline: Strong Debut for Gladiators
text: NBC’s remake of “American Gladiators” muscled to a strong start on Sunday. The amateur athletic tournament, based on the early 1990s series, delivered the highest ratings among adults 18 to 49 of any new show this season on any network, matching the debut of “Heroes” in September 2006, Nielsen estimated. In total viewers, however, “American Gladiators” was less impressive, drawing an average of 12 million from 9 to 11 p.m. ABC’s “Cashmere Mafia,” by comparison, which made its debut on Sunday at 10 p.m., attracted 10.7 million viewers but markedly lower ratings in the 18-to-49 set. “Cashmere Mafia” also benefited from a plum time slot following ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” (19.8 million), the only show to outpace “American Gladiators” on the night among adults 18 to 49. ABC, NBC and CBS finished in a virtual tie for first in that demographic over all on Sunday. CBS, buoyed by an overrun of its afternoon football coverage during the 7 p.m. hour that was followed by one of the highest rated editions of “60 Minutes” in recent years (19 million), won the race in total viewers.

headline: Little Support for McGwire Among Hall Voters
text: Mark McGwire, the player who did not want to talk about the past, will learn how his achievements are viewed in the present when the voting for the Hall of Fame is announced Tuesday. Unless hundreds of writers experienced stunning reversals in the past year regarding their feelings about McGwire, he is not expected to be voted into the Hall.

headline: Respects Paid to Dying Suharto
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  It was the place to be seen over the weekend, the hospital bedside of Indonesia’s former strongman, Suharto, who was driven from office 10 years ago and is now hovering near death as his heart and kidneys weaken.

headline: Fraud Trial Focuses on Insurance Giants
text: HARTFORD  The reputations of two business titans  Warren E. Buffett and Maurice R. Greenberg  came under attack on Monday as the latest corporate corruption trial got under way in federal district court here.

headline: Court Revives Lawsuit Against No Child Left Behind Law
text: A federal appeals court on Monday revived a legal challenge to the federal No Child Left Behind education law, saying that school districts have been justified in complaining that the law required them to pay for testing and other programs without providing sufficient federal money.

headline: Recording Reveals Frayed Remains of a Friendship
text: In a bizarre news conference in which reporters in Houston and fans on television listened in suspense to a crackling 17-minute telephone call between Roger Clemens and his accusatory former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, no eureka moment emerged from the dissonance.

headline: Niacin to the Rescue
text: Q. I am taking niacin for high cholesterol. How does it work?

headline: Progress on Guns
text: It took too many years and too many deaths to persuade Congress to act, but President Bush is expected to sign into law today a measure that will make it harder for people with a history of dangerous mental illness to purchase firearms. That is good news, but there is more work to be done.

headline: P. K. Sethi, Inventor of the Low-Tech Limb, Is Dead at 80
text: Dr. P. K. Sethi, who invented the affordable prosthesis called the Jaipur foot, which has helped millions of amputees in developing countries to lead normal lives, died Sunday in Jaipur, India. He was 80.

headline: Tiny Specks of Misery, Both Vile and Useful
text: I spent New Year’s Eve with friends and family. A couple of days later, my pathologically healthy mother called to say she’d gotten very sick after the party, like nothing she’d experienced before. She thought it had been a stomach bug. Hey, it’s just like in “The Devil Wears Prada,” I said lightly, the perfect way to jump-start your new diet!

headline: A President’s Defender Keeps His Distance
text: TEHRAN  A rift is emerging between President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and Iran’s supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, suggesting that the president no longer enjoys the ayatollah’s full backing, as he did in the years after his election in 2005.

headline: Health Spending Exceeded Record $2 Trillion in 2006
text: WASHINGTON  National health spending soared above $2 trillion for the first time in 2006 and has nearly doubled in the last decade, amounting to an average of $7,000 a person, the government reported on Monday.

headline: Morocco: Western Sahara Talks Resuming
text: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, appealed for “substantive” results from deadlocked talks brokered by the United Nations between Morocco and the pro-independence Polisario Front over the future of the resource-rich Western Sahara annexed by Morocco in 1975 after the colonial power Spain withdrew. A closed-door round of negotiations, the third in seven months, begin on Tuesday in Manhasset, N.Y., amid fear that failure to settle the dispute in the region, already victimized by violence linked to Al Qaeda, could lead to the resumption of a guerrilla war that lasted until 1991, when the United Nations sent peacekeepers.

headline: Alabama: Two Men Charged in Church Fires
text: Two men who the authorities said dabbled in satanism have been arrested in connection with a rash of arson and vandalism at rural churches in east Alabama. Satanic graffiti was scrawled at or near some of the churches. The two men, Geoffrey Parquette and James Clark, both 21, pleaded not guilty. Fires were set at three churches over four days beginning last Tuesday, and one of the buildings was destroyed.

headline: Gilbert Harrison, 92, Ex-Editor, Dies
text: Gilbert A. Harrison, a former publisher of The New Republic, the political and cultural opinion journal that for nearly a century has adhered for the most part to a liberal bent, died Thursday in Phoenix. He was 92 and lived in Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Record Price Seen for Francis Bacon Painting
text: A triptych by Francis Bacon, appearing at auction for the first time, is expected to set a record for a British or Irish work when it leads Christie’s Post War & Contemporary Art Evening Sale in London on Feb. 6. Held by a private collection, “Triptych 1974-77,” above, is the last in a series painted by Bacon (1909-1992) in response to the suicide of his lover, George Dyer, in their room in Paris. Bacon’s “Study From Innocent X” (1962) sold in May for a record $52.6 million.

headline: Sharpton in Escape Case, but Prosecutor Is ‘Upset’
text: ELIZABETH, N.J.  A three-week odyssey appeared to be reaching an end on Monday for one of two men who escaped from a New Jersey county jail here last month, a day after the Rev. Al Sharpton said he had received a request to broker a surrender.

headline: The Debate Over How and How Long
text: WASHINGTON  If President Bush becomes convinced the economy is indeed headed toward a recession, he is likely to respond much as he did on entering office in 2001 with the economy on the verge of a downturn: lower tax rates for people at all income levels and provide tax breaks for businesses.

headline: No. 3 Train From Times Square to New Lots Ave.
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Spitzer May Ask to Cap Property Tax Increases in Annual Speech to Legislature
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer may propose a ceiling on annual property tax increases, an idea he has rejected before and one that has often met resistance among fellow Democrats.

headline: More Caveats Than Clarity in Batteries-in-Baggage Rule
text: LAST week, I spent most of an afternoon trying to get a cogent explanation of a confusing news release issued late on the Friday before New Year’s by a mouthful of an agency called the United States Department of Transportation Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

headline: Bear Stearns Announces New Leadership
text: Bear Stearns announced Tuesday that James E. Cayne, its embattled chief executive, would step down after the deepest losses in the firm’s history.

headline: Detectives’ Lawyers in Sean Bell Trial Push for Change of Venue
text: Lawyers for the three police detectives charged in the shooting that killed Sean Bell argued in a motion filed on Monday that publicity surrounding the case has “incurably poisoned” the pool of prospective jurors for the trial next month and asked that the proceedings be moved out of New York City.

headline: Albany: First Grants From Stem Cell Program
text: The state has awarded the first grants from its $600 million stem cell research program, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced on Monday. The $14.5 million in grants were awarded to 25 medical institutions to support stem cell research and training, the governor said. The one-year grants will provide $6.1 million for research, $7.4 million for equipment purchases and $1 million for training, state officials said.

headline: Mozilla Names New Chief, but Reaffirms Open-Source Commitment
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Mozilla, the developer of the open-source browser Firefox, will announce on Tuesday that John Lilly, the company’s chief operating officer, will succeed Mitchell Baker as chief executive.

headline: For Cancer Patients, Empathy Goes a Long Way
text: Four years ago, my sister found out she had two types of cancer at the same time. It was like being hit by lightning  twice.

headline: Manhattan: Police Officer Faces Federal Charges
text: A city police officer who was arrested last month on charges of raping a 14-year-old girl was charged in federal court on Monday with bringing her and a second teenage girl across state lines to engage in illegal sex, officials said. The officer, Trent Young, 39, had been a martial arts instructor to both victims and, on separate occasions in 2006 and 2007, took them from his hometown, Middletown, N.Y., to his martial arts school in New Jersey, according to a statement by the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan. Officer Young was arrested on Dec. 27 by the Middletown police. The second girl came forward on Jan. 3, according to a federal compliant. Officer Young was held without bail on Monday, officials said. Officer Young’s lawyer, Gary Greenwald, said, “His defense is it never happened.”

headline: Charter Bus Crash Kills 9 in Utah as Rain, Snow and Avalanches Batter Region
text: DENVER  A powerful Pacific storm system that slammed into the western half of the country last week wreaked havoc throughout the weekend and Monday, causing fatal traffic accidents, power failures and deep avalanches across the region.

headline: Turner Goes From a Tight Spot to Letting Loose
text: SAN DIEGO  The clock was winding down, signaling the end to 12 seasons of futility. As the final seconds of the Chargers’ 17-6 victory against the Tennessee Titans ticked off Sunday, Chargers Coach Norv Turner stopped strategizing how to replace Antonio Gates or thwart Vince Young and succumbed to the moment.

headline: Regimens: Whites More Often Given Opioid Drugs, Study Finds
text: Opioid medications, the powerful painkillers that experts say have been underused by doctors because of their stigma, are increasingly being given in emergency rooms  but white patients are more likely to get them than minorities, a new study finds.

headline: Skipping the Grand Canyon for a Town Hall Meeting
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Jim McCloskey has seen the Grand Canyon, Niagara Falls and Yellowstone National Park. He’s been to Ireland, London and Spain. But on Saturday, instead of Londonderry, Northern Ireland, Mr. McCloskey, an accountant in Philadelphia, found himself in Londonderry, N.H., holding his iPhone above the crowd and trying to snap a picture of former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas at a campaign event with the actor Chuck Norris.

headline: The Power of Everyday Activity
text: Steven Blair, an exercise scientist, has been researching the health benefits of physical activity for more than 25 years, first at the Cooper Institute in Dallas and currently at the University of South Carolina’s Arnold School of Public Health. He is a former president of the American College of Sports Medicine.

headline: In Professor’s Model, Diversity = Productivity
text: In the long-running debate on affirmative action, Scott E. Page, a professor of complex systems, political science and economics at the University of Michigan, is a fresh voice.

headline: Baltimore Is Suing Bank Over Foreclosure Crisis
text: Baltimore’s mayor and City Council are suing Wells Fargo Bank, contending that its lending practices discriminated against black borrowers and led to a wave of foreclosures that has reduced city tax revenues and increased its costs.

headline: Bear’s Cayne to Quit as Chief Executive
text: James E. Cayne, the embattled chief executive of Bear Stearns, will step down after the deepest losses in the firm’s history, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.

headline: McNamee Opens Up in an Interview
text: As he watched Roger Clemens’s interview on “60 Minutes” on Sunday with a reporter from SI.com, Brian McNamee guessed that Clemens could beat a lie-detector test.

headline: Woman Dies After Car Plunges Into Suffolk Waters
text: One woman died and another was in critical condition after their car went over the edge of a parking lot and landed upside down in the waters of an inlet on the Great South Bay in Bay Shore, N.Y., on Monday afternoon, the Suffolk County police said.

headline: Deal for Maker of College Texts
text: Macmillan Publishers has agreed to buy Hayden-McNeil Publishing, a publisher of custom textbooks, for an undisclosed sum. The deal is expected to be announced on Tuesday.

headline: The Netherlands: Not Reaching New Heights
text: The Dutch, thought to be the world’s tallest people, appear to have stopped growing, the Central Bureau for Statistics reported. It said growth rates for men and women had increased scarcely or not at all since 2001. The average Dutch man is 5 feet 11 inches tall. The average woman is 5-foot-6.

headline: A ‘Daring’ Bandit Steals Valuables, and Peace of Mind
text: By all appearances, the burglary could not have happened on a more sedate and established corner of Staten Island than this one on Melhorn Road.

headline: Ford to Expand in India, Planning a Small Car and an Engine Plant
text: Ford Motor plans to more than double its investment in India to produce a small car for the fast-growing local market and to build an engine manufacturing plant there.

headline: Corzine Proposes Huge Financial Move for N.J.
text: TRENTON  Gov. Jon S. Corzine on Tuesday proposed the biggest financial gambit in New Jersey’s history, arguing that almost quadrupling highway tolls over the next 15 years could help generate about $38 billion to help the state pay off half of its debt and pay for transportation improvements.

headline: In Final Push for Votes, Pledges From Both Sides to Change Washington
text: LEBANON, N.H.  Republican and Democratic presidential candidates alike called Monday for a sharp break with the way the Bush administration and Congress have been running the country, as the final hours of campaigning before the New Hampshire primary became a rush to capture the excitement surrounding Senator Barack Obama.

headline: A Doctor’s Apology (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: On Eve of Primary, Clinton Campaign Shows Stress
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Key campaign officials may be replaced. She may start calling herself the underdog. Donors would receive pleas that it is do-or-die time. And her political strategy could begin mirroring that of Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican rival, by focusing on populous states like California and New York whose primaries are Feb. 5.

headline: Pain Relief for Some, With an Odd Tradeoff
text: For people with chronic pain, relief comes with a tradeoff. Bed rest means missing out on life. Drugs take the edge off, but they also dull the senses and the mind.

headline: Still a Sideshow, Giuliani Bets on Survival Strategy
text: DERRY, N.H.  As Rudolph W. Giuliani trudged along the slushy sidewalks of Nashua on a gray Monday morning, he kept getting the kinds of questions that no candidate wanted to hear on the eve of an important election.

headline: Suzy Welch Sells Book
text: Suzy Welch, a former editor of the Harvard Business Review and the wife of John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric, has agreed to sell the rights to her book “10-10-10” to Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster. A person involved in the negotiations said that Scribner paid Ms. Welch a price in the seven figures for world and audio rights to the book. Based on an article Ms. Welch wrote for O, the Oprah Magazine, in 2006, the book offers strategies for making decisions in which people think about what the consequences of a decision will be in 10 minutes, 10 months and 10 years. Robert Barnett, a Washington lawyer, negotiated the deal on behalf of Ms. Welch. Nan Graham, editor in chief of Scribner, will edit the book with Samantha Martin. Ms. Welch, who wrote the best-selling “Winning” with Mr. Welch, said she originally thought there wasn’t a book beyond the article. But, she said, “I began to encounter this hunger for people who were using it to play out its nuances.” She said the book would include examples from her own life as well as others she has observed using the “10-10-10” process. Susan Moldow, publisher of Scribner, said that although Ms. Welch’s article might seem sufficient for those who wanted to know about the strategy, Ms. Moldow believed the book would sell well. “The Scarsdale Diet fit on a Xerox-ed sheet that you could fit on the front of a refrigerator,” Ms. Moldow said. “And it sold millions and millions of copies. It’s often true that when something strikes an immediate ‘Aha!,’ you really want to have time to meditate on it and try to get to know more about it.”

headline: Concertgoers, Please Clap, Talk or Shout at Any Time
text: Concertgoers like you and me have become part police officer, part public offender. We prosecute the shuffled foot or rattled program, the errant whisper or misplaced cough. We tense at the end of a movement, fearful that one of the unwashed will begin to clap, bringing shame on us all. How serious we look, and how absurd we are.

headline: The Climate Klaxon (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Risks: Lax Catheter Policies Seen at Many Hospitals
text: One of the best ways to get an infection in the hospital is to have a urinary catheter installed (don’t everyone rush out at once). Almost half of all infections acquired at hospitals are in the urinary tract, and most are linked to catheters.

headline: White Plains: Federal Oversight for Polls
text: A panel of three federal judges has approved the extension of a consent agreement through which Westchester County provided bilingual assistance at the polls for Spanish-speaking voters, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, announced on Monday. The agreement, between federal prosecutors and the county, was signed in 2005 and set to expire last summer, but federal prosecutors asked to extend the agreement to December of this year. In a Jan. 3 opinion, the judges found that the county had made progress in complying with the agreement, but that the extension was still justified, the prosecutors said.

headline: Consumer Electronics Show | Chic Squad?
text: As the official blog of T: The New York Times Style Magazine, The Moment works hard to come off like one of the cool kids. Yesterday we blew our cover when we arrived in Las Vegas for the Consumer Electronics Show (C.E.S.), arguably the preeminent geek convention of the year. Our mission over the next few days will be to indulge our obsession with sexy electronics, browsing millions of doodads in search of good design. More on that later — you see, we aren’t kidding about millions. The show sprawls for miles inside the mother of all convention centers. The crush of business men, cheesecake spokesmodels and high-tech signage has us thinking we’re in Tokyo, not Nevada. It’s an infamously brutal ordeal, and yesterday we saw people passed out on the floor by day’s end. According to our buddies at Bits, the Times’s technology blog, there’s a big microbe scare at C.E.S. this year: Everybody’s wiping down with Purell, and one company is even handing out sanitary gloves for germ-free handshakes. Lest we’d forget our surroundings, upon registration all journalists were issued blue and silver backpacks complete with external mesh pockets for water bottles, a waist belt, reflective coating (safety first) and a handy internal organizer that looks awfully pocket-protector like. Rather than wearing it, The Moment opted for the ghetto-chic boom-box shopping bag (above) we snagged at the Lasonic booth. But when the paper started to give, we saw the error of our ways, donned the backpack and accepted the inevitable. Today, we’re jumping in again, but this time we’re bring the new leopard-print Taser to clear the way.

headline: Escape From Camelot

Unlike in Iowa, where you can actually go see the caucus process play out somewhere, primary day in New Hampshire means that we are mostly reduced to hanging around and awaiting the voters’ verdicts. Four years ago, I passed the afternoon playing pool with a couple of other journalists. This time, I might just stop by the mall.

headline: Now Booking | Guadeloupe
text: (Daniel Barillot/Masterfile)When I learned that an outpost of Barbuto — a stylish restaurant around the corner from my West Village apartment — had opened on the French Caribbean island of Guadeloupe, I scratched my head. What was the chef Jonathan Waxman, known for his seasonal take on traditional Italian dishes, doing on an island that not only has no Italian connection but is also pretty well overlooked by Americans? Turns out the explanation is a fairly simple: when one of Barbuto’s partners, Phil Scotti, was visiting Guadeloupe, he happened to meet Valerie Robein, a well respected local restaurateur who was looking to open a new place, and hatched the idea to back her in a Caribbean-inflected version of Barbuto, with Robein helming the stove and Waxman developing the menu. While Barbuto Guadeloupe’s lasagna with conch or roast chicken with curry aren’t reason enough to make a trip, the restaurant’s opening got me thinking again about an island that is said to combine the typical Caribbean assets of sun and sand with what is, let’s face it, a real rarity in the region: a vibrant food scene, and one that intriguingly blends both Creole and European influences. Guadeloupe is one of the few major islands I haven’t been to, but friends who have tell me the food’s unusually good, from excellent morning pastries in the cafés to fresh grilled fish on the beach to more ambitious fare in the restaurants of Deshaies, the cute town where Barbuto is based. What’s more, although French tourists in high season do pack the coastal resorts of Grand-Terre, Guadeloupe’s eastern half, over on Basse-Terre you can supposedly still get some peace and quiet on the beach in January and February. Even in deepest darkest winter I’m always discouraging my better half from planning Caribbean getaways, in large part because a week without great eating is not my idea of a vacation, but in 2008 I think I’m voting for Guadeloupe. (For an overview of the island, and some hotel and restaurant advice, go here. Been to Guadeloupe? Let me know how you liked it here

headline: Wallace Should Hang
text: This week, I want to look at a figure in the history of biology: Alfred Russel Wallace. January 8th was his birthday. And 2008 is the 150th anniversary of one of the most important events in the history of biology. In 1858, Wallace wrote to Charles Darwin from the Moluccan Islands, in what is now Indonesia, where he was collecting birds, beetles, butterflies and anything else he could catch. The letter contained a manuscript in which Wallace outlined the idea of evolution by natural selection.

headline: Britain: Bhutto’s Son Critical of U.S.
text: Bilawal Bhutto Zardari, the 19-year-old son of Benazir Bhutto, Pakistan’s assassinated opposition leader, said at a news conference in London that the United States would have to stop “supporting dictators” in Pakistan for Islamic extremism to be defeated there. Returning to Britain from Pakistan two weeks after his mother’s death to resume his first-year studies at Oxford, he gave a battery of feisty answers to reporters who questioned the Pakistan Peoples Party’s decision to pick him as his mother’s successor as party chairman. To a reporter who suggested he had been appointed to the post “like a piece of family furniture,” he said he had not sought it, but added, “It was recognized at this moment in crisis the party needed a close association with my mother through the bloodline.” Asked if he feared for his life, he replied: “How many Bhuttos can you kill? From every house a Bhutto will come.” Noting that the party had selected his father, Asif Ali Zardari, as the party’s co-chairman until he finishes his university degree, he said he would step “gradually and carefully” into politics. He renewed the family’s demands for a United Nations inquiry into his mother’s death and spoke out against American support for the generals who have ruled Pakistan for more than half its 60-year existence. “The problem is that dictatorships breed extremism, and once the U.S. stops supporting dictators, we can successfully tackle extremists,” he said.

headline: Appeal Dropped in New Forest Rules
text: The Bush administration has dropped its appeal of a 2007 court decision that overturned new management rules for 191 million acres of national forests. Opponents to the rules had argued that they weakened protection for wildlife and the environment to the benefit of the timber industry. The Justice Department notified the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit this week that it was withdrawing its appeal, saying the other parties, including the timber industry, would do likewise. Last March, a federal district court in California found that the United States Forest Service had bypassed required environmental reviews and provisions under the Endangered Species Act in its overhaul of the management rules, including changes in logging limits, for its national forests.

headline: An Affiliate Sues Habitat for Humanity Over a Pact
text: In an extraordinary act of rebellion, the oldest affiliate of Habitat for Humanity International has filed suit to protest a new agreement that the nonprofit housing organization is imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.

headline: Young and Broke in the City, but Staying Afloat
text: As hosts of a small gathering the other night to watch a college football game, Brian Markey and his roommate, Owen Cahillane, hustled to get their place ready, which took a startling amount of time, considering that it has only 250 square feet of space. They live on a houseboat in the Bronx, on a finger of water that is formally known as Westchester Creek. It is close to the elbow of the Hutchinson River Parkway and the Cross Bronx Expressway, in a pocket of the city that is in no immediate danger of becoming the new Williamsburg.

headline: McCain’s Victory Scrambles Field
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. After Senator John McCain’s victory here on Tuesday, the Republican field is more scrambled than ever, with the battleground now shifting to a series of states where each of the leading candidates believes he holds certain advantages.

headline: Demolition to Resume at Deutsche Bank Site

headline: Germany: Manufacturing Orders Surge Again
text: Manufacturing orders in Germany unexpectedly surged for a second month in November as domestic companies increased spending on goods such as factory machinery. Orders, adjusted for seasonal swings and inflation, gained 3.4 percent from October, when they rose 4 percent, the Economics and Technology Ministry said. Domestic orders rose 4.2 percent from October and export sales increased 2.8 percent. Orders from the euro area gained 6.8 percent, the report showed. Capital goods orders rose 3.6 percent and sales of intermediate goods advanced 4.3 percent, while demand for consumer goods slid 1.1 percent.

headline: Suharto Suffers More Setbacks
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Doctors struggled Tuesday to stabilize the condition of former President Suharto after a setback that they said included new signs of internal bleeding, heart problems and a buildup of fluid in his lungs.

headline: From an Iranian Cook, the Taste of Memory
text: FAROKH MEHDIAN, a maker of custom home furnishings, like draperies and tablecloths, has a divided life. In 1999, she moved from Brooklyn first to Alexandria, and then to McLean, Va., to live near her sister, niece and nephew.

headline: Microsoft Bids for Search Software Firm
text: Microsoft bid $1.2 billion on Tuesday for a Norwegian search software company, in what analysts said was mainly an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products, but was also being done with an eye toward fending off Google.

headline: Nevada: A Shift at Yucca Mountain
text: The Energy Department is cutting operations at the desert site where the government plans to build a national nuclear waste repository and the chief contractor is laying off many of its staff members, officials said, as planners shift from exploring and evaluating the site to preparing a license application. Officials with the main contractor, Bechtel SAIC Company, said all but about 15 “caretaking” employees would be laid off at the Yucca Mountain repository, about 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas. Edward F. Sproat, the Energy Department official in charge of the project, has vowed to submit a license application to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission by June 30. Mr. Sproat has projected 2017 as the earliest the site could open, with a price tag now topping $77 billion.

headline: Storms Strike Midwest, Killing at Least 6
text: Record-breaking temperatures in the midsection of the country gave way to rare January tornadoes and flooding on Monday and Tuesday. The storms killed at least six people, including two young children, and shattered houses and submerged roads.

headline: U.S. Attack in Iraq Is No Surprise to Many Insurgents
text: ESAIWID, Iraq  With extraordinary secrecy, and even an information blackout aimed at most of their Iraqi Army comrades, American troops began a major offensive on Tuesday to drive Sunni insurgents from strongholds in Diyala Province. But many insurgents still managed to flee the first villages the Americans went into, showing just how difficult it is to trap the elusive militants.

headline: Taxpayer Advocate Urges ‘Apology Payments’
text: Taxpayers who endure excessive expense or drain on their time when the Internal Revenue Service mishandles a case should receive “apology payments” of up to $1,000 each, the National Taxpayer Advocate told Congress on Wednesday.

headline: China: Free Plastic Shopping Bags to Be Banned
text: China will ban retailers from giving free plastic shopping bags to consumers starting in June to curb waste and reduce pollution. China’s cabinet, the State Council, calling the excessive use of plastic bags a “serious” waste of resources, also said it would ban production of ultra-thin plastic bags measuring less than 0.025 millimeter thick. Retailers will be able to sell plastic bags, but will have to clearly display the price and may not include the cost in the price of merchandise, the State Council said.

headline: Idol Winner Goes Solo
text: Taylor Hicks, below, the 2006 winner of “American Idol,” has followed Ruben Studdard, the 2003 winner, out the door of J Records, The Associated Press reported. “Taylor is going to record on his own for the next album,” said Liz Morentin, a public relations representative for J, a label within Sony-BMG. Mr. Studdard left his contract with the label late last year but remains under contract with 19 Entertainment, a company managed by Simon Fuller, creator of “Idol.” Mr. Studdard’s last album, “The Return,” sold only 236,000 copies. Mr. Hicks’s self-titled album, released in December 2006, reached No. 2 on the Billboard chart and sold 699,000 copies, failing to reach the million mark achieved by the debuts of previous “Idol” winners, Nielsen SounScan reported.

headline: Citing Persecution, Spanish Abortion Clinics Go on Strike
text: MADRID  Private clinics in Spain, which perform most of the country’s abortions, began a five-day strike on Tuesday to protest what they said was persecution by anti-abortion campaigners and government inspectors, who have swept clinics in recent weeks to crack down on illegal terminations.

text: To the Editor:

headline: A Lentil Soup to Make You Stop, Taste and Savor
text: FOR years it seemed that everyone I knew had a special lentil soup recipe, one that sustained them and kept them warm all winter long. I had flirted with countless incarnations, and most tasted reasonably good. They were brawny, solid and predictable. I liked them in varying degrees, but never quite enough to take home to my soup pot. Until recently, when I fell head over heels. Could this be the one?

headline: Retail Sales Fell in November, to Lowest in 10 Years
text: European retail sales fell the most in at least 10 years in November as rising food and energy costs sapped consumer confidence. Retail sales declined 1.4 percent in November from a year ago, the biggest drop since at least 1997, the European Union’s statistics office in Luxembourg said. From the previous month, sales fell 0.5 percent, the third decline in four months. Higher gasoline and food costs are eroding purchasing power in the euro area and restraining spending even as unemployment falls to a record low.
