headline: Denmark: Cargo Carrier to Lay Off Up to 12%
text: A. P. Moeller-Maersk, the world’s largest ocean cargo carrier, will cut as many as 3,000 jobs in the container division after the unit posted a loss in 2006 for the first time in at least three years. The division, Maersk Line, will reduce its 25,000-member work force by 2,000 to 3,000 people, or as much as 12 percent, the company said. Maersk Line, which owns more than 500 vessels that carry 1.7 million containers, posted a $568 million loss in 2006, its first since Maersk began breaking out division figures in 2003. Moeller-Maersk is based in Copenhagen.

headline: Clinton Escapes to Fight Another Day
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Hillary Rodham Clinton is back.

headline: Maazel at the Met, Brünnhilde in a Bind
text: As soon as Lorin Maazel appeared in the pit at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night to conduct the season’s first performance of Wagner’s “Walküre,” he received a sustained ovation from the audience. At 77, after an inexplicable 45-year absence, Mr. Maazel has finally returned to the Met. Facing high expectations, he delivered, conducting a lucidly textured, rhythmically incisive and strongly conceived account of this touchstone opera and winning what looked to be very respectful applause from the orchestra musicians when he took a solo curtain call at the end of the five-hour evening.

headline: Debate Was Key to Win, Clinton Says
text: A day after the New Hampshire primary recast the presidential race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said on Wednesday that the candidates’ debate on Saturday was a turning point in her surprising victory over Senator Barack Obama, while Mr. Obama sought to remain upbeat and traveled to New York on a fund-raising mission.

headline: Habitat for Humanity Sued by Affiliate
text: In an extraordinary act of rebellion, the oldest affiliate of Habitat for Humanity International has filed suit to protest a new agreement that the nonprofit housing organization is imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.

headline: Redskins’ Gibbs Retires After a Trying Season
text: Hours after the Washington Redskins arrived home Sunday morning following their playoff loss to the Seattle Seahawks, Coach Joe Gibbs was back on a plane, this time for a crucial visit with his family in North Carolina.

headline: Food Allergies Stir a Mother to Action
text: Lafayette, Colo.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about a musical based on Anne Frank’s diary, scheduled to open in Madrid next month, misstated the history of such musicals. There is at least one other, “Yours, Anne,” which was produced Off Broadway in 1985. The one in Madrid will not be the first.

headline: Making Way in America: Jewish Identities and Personal Allegiances
text: Jewish journeys into American society receive an earnest, lively PBS treatment that often seems as all-encompassing as the six million citizens who share this heritage. Their ancestors may have come from different homelands, but their ethnic commonality is considered essential to the dozens who testify in this six-hour sprawl of history. Still, in these testimonials, many assert there are competing elements in their self-definitions.

headline: Corpse Wheeled to Check-Cashing Store Leads to 2 Arrests
text: Even for the once-notorious Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood, it may have been a first: Two men were arrested on Tuesday after pushing a corpse, seated in an office chair, along the sidewalk to a check-cashing store to cash the dead man’s Social Security check, the police said.

headline: Thailand: Ex-Premier’s Wife Arrested
text: Pojaman Shinawatra, the wife of the ousted prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, returned to Thailand to fight corruption charges. She was met by the police after her flight arrived from Hong Kong, arrested, quickly released on bail, and ordered not to leave the country. Analysts said her return  the couple have been living mostly in London and Hong Kong since a military coup in 2006  signaled confidence that the political situation, still unsettled after a victory by Mr. Thaksin’s allies in elections last month, would turn in their favor once a new government has been formed. Noppadol Pattama, a lawyer for the family, said Monday that Mr. Thaksin planned to return by mid-April. He is charged in the same cases as his wife, charges brought by the generals who carried out the coup.

headline: Gossage Elected to Hall in His Ninth Attempt
text: With an explosive fastball that unnerved hitters, a motion that was an intertwining of long arms and long legs and a Fu Manchu mustache that was his perpetual Halloween mask, Rich Gossage was an intimidator. Gossage, a dependable bouncer on the mound who was known as Goose, pushed his way to baseball’s highest honor Tuesday when he was elected into the Hall of Fame.

headline: Ernestine Stodelle, 95, Modern Dancer, Dies
text: Ernestine Stodelle, a pioneering modern dancer who performed with Doris Humphrey and José Limón and also wrote about dance, died on Saturday in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 95.

headline: Oneida: Broken Track Is Blamed in Explosion
text: An undetected break in a section of rail jarred a CSX train from its tracks last year just outside Oneida, triggering an explosion of four liquid propane tankers, a federal report said on Tuesday. The explosion on March 12 forced the evacuation of 200 residents and temporarily shut down the New York State Thruway, according to the Federal Railroad Administration’s report. There were no injuries. The administration said that the crew had been operating the 80-car train in compliance with federal standards and that the track had been inspected and tested regularly. Inspectors determined that the rail was broken before the train passed over it.

headline: Amazon Consolidates in Growing Area of Seattle
text: Amazon.com, the world’s largest online retailer, will soon finally have one place to call home.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Jan. 1 about a federal judge’s rulings on prosecution evidence in the wiretapping case against the Hollywood private eye Anthony Pellicano was published in error. The rulings were issued on Dec. 21 and were reported in The Times on Dec. 25; they were not issued on Dec. 29. (Go to Article)

headline: Rise Seen in Trafficking of Enhanced Ecstasy
text: Methamphetamine-laced Ecstasy is flowing across the Canadian border into the United States, according to a warning last week from the federal government to public health and local law enforcement officials.

headline: Demolition Crews Go to Work on a Winter Wonderland
text: The candy canes were the first to go.

headline: Antiwar Groups Claim Victory in Settlement Over Great Lawn
text: After three years of litigation, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation agreed on Tuesday to back away from the main part of a controversial regulation limiting public events on the Great Lawn, in the heart of Central Park, to 50,000 people.

headline: Job Cuts at McGraw-Hill Will Eliminate 3% of Staff
text: The McGraw-Hill Companies said Tuesday that it was cutting 611 jobs, or 3 percent of its staff, and taking an after-tax charge of $27.3 million, or 8 cents a share, in the fourth quarter.

headline: There Amid the Madness, Dark Humor Lies in Wait
text: Depending on how you look at it, “Three Lost Chords” is a single work in three loosely related acts, or three short, single-character operas yoked together. The source material is far-flung, with Kafka and Poe as the outer acts, and a slighter story by Muriel Spark between them. But these monodramas have something in common, apart from music by Lance Horne and librettos by Mark Campbell. Each of their protagonists is dead, insane or (somehow) both. And ghoulish though the stories are, Mr. Horne, Mr. Campbell and David Schweizer, who directs the production at the Zipper Factory Theater, have found a current of dark humor within each.

headline: Fordham Seniors Honored
text: Fordham punter Benjamin Dato and linebacker Earl Hudnell, both seniors, were named Football Championship Subdivision All-Americans by the Sports Network. Dato was named to the first team and Hudnell was an honorable mention.

headline: Tributes and Grief at a Funeral for a Firefighter
text: By the time thousands of mourners gathered on Tuesday to say farewell to Lt. John H. Martinson, his fellow firefighters had already spent five days telling the world about his bravery, his willingness to run first into the flames and stay there until everyone had escaped, which is part of what led to his death last week at a smoky Brooklyn blaze.

headline: SEC Is Confirmed as King of Conferences
text: NEW ORLEANS  Louisiana State Coach Les Miles interrupted his postgame news conference late Monday night for an impromptu celebration.

headline: Doctors Try to Stabilize Suharto
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Doctors struggled Tuesday to stabilize the condition of former President Suharto after a setback that they said included new signs of internal bleeding, heart problems and a buildup of fluid in his lungs.

headline: Despite Early Results, News Outlets Let Caution Rule on Calling Winner
text: WASHINGTON  Shortly after 10:30 Tuesday night, John King, the chief national correspondent for CNN, was telling viewers how the network would have already declared Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton the winner of the New Hampshire primary under normal circumstances, and how these were anything but.

headline: Wireless Start-Up Fails to Get Financing
text: Frontline Wireless, which wanted to build an innovative cellular network for both private use and local public safety agencies, has collapsed because it could not raise enough money to bid in the government auctions of wireless spectrum that start later this month.

headline: As the Ice Melts, Can the Polar Bears Survive?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A One-Night Shift in the Late-Night Wars
text: For the first time since television’s late-night shows returned to the air last week, David Letterman was able to nose out Jay Leno in the ratings. It was just for one show, Monday night, and Mr. Letterman’s lead was not sizable, but Mr. Leno had won the first three nights. Their competition resumed last Wednesday, when most of the late-night hosts came back after supporting the writers’ strike for two months. Mr. Leno is working without his writing staff, which is still on strike against his “Tonight Show” on NBC, while Mr. Letterman, above, was able to return with writers to his CBS show because of a separate deal his production company made with the Writers Guild of America. Mr. Letterman has also been able to book the normal roster of movie-star guests; on Monday night he had Tom Hanks, while Mr. Leno had the upstart Republican presidential candidate Ron Paul. In the overnight ratings, measuring the country’s 65 largest cities, Mr. Letterman had a 4 rating on Monday to Mr. Leno’s 3.8. (Each point is worth 787,659 households.) But in their shows’ first half-hour, when Mr. Leno is performing a monologue over the opposition of the writers’ guild, he still beat Mr. Letterman, with a 4.5 rating to a 4.3. CBS’s thin victory margin continued on the 12:35 a.m. shows, where Craig Ferguson enjoyed a rare ratings victory over NBC’s Conan O’Brien, with a 1.9 rating to a 1.8 for Mr. O’Brien.

headline: The Legacy of a Pragmatic Custodian of Human Civilization
text: “Either you become more autocratic or you relax,” Philippe de Montebello said some years ago, drumming his fingers on his desk. He had been asked to reflect on what was then a quarter-century as director of the Metropolitan Museum. “I’m much less imperious now. I know pretty much what I’m doing.”

headline: Can Hillary Cry Her Way Back to the White House?
text: DERRY, N.H.

headline: Him, Her and Him by the Seashore, Balancing Levity and Suffering
text: About 10 minutes into “Woman on the Beach,” a bittersweet accounting of the geography of desire from the South Korean director Hong Sang-soo, two men and a woman stand staring into the sea. This seemingly casual triangle is a classic formal and sexual configuration for Mr. Hong, whose elegant, restrained films chart the mysteries of the heart and the follies of the head with intelligence and shock waves of feeling. Yet true to form, Mr. Hong draws this triangle with hard, sharp lines, which you grasp when one man tells the other that he admires him because “it’s hard for a married man to openly bring along his girlfriend,” as he has.

headline: Group of Women to Buy Storm
text: A group of Seattle women, led by the former deputy mayor Anne Levinson, will buy the Seattle Storm of the W.N.B.A. from the SuperSonics’ owner, Clay Bennett, for $10 million. The purchase option for the franchise was completed in the last few days, ensuring the Storm would remain in Seattle, while Bennett continues his push to move the SuperSonics to his hometown of Oklahoma City. The group, calling itself Force 10 Hoops, has until the end of February to close the sale and would need approval from the W.N.B.A. Board of Governors.

headline: Riding Horses Helps in Hurdling Obstacles for Rookie Jockey
text: CICERO, Ill.  For the first time in a long time, Sylvia Harris has a roof over her head, money in her pocket and relative peace of mind. She has found this place, this good place, by riding horses.

headline: Stocks Dive on Reports of New Ills
text: Shares tumbled late Tuesday after the head of AT&T suggested that consumers might be cutting back and Countrywide Financial denied that it was tumbling into bankruptcy.

headline: TV Station Fires Anchor
text: Alycia Lane has been dismissed by KYW-TV, the CBS-owned station in Philadelphia, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lane, 35, was arrested in Manhattan on Dec. 16 and arraigned on a felony charge of assaulting a police officer. The police said she punched an officer in the face, and a police complaint said she used a sexual slur. Ms. Lane has denied the charges. She had been off the air since the incident and had been scheduled to return on Monday. But in a statement that day, the station said she “has been released from her contract effective immediately.” Ms. Lane was previously the subject of reports that she had e-mailed images of herself in a bikini to a married ESPN sports anchor. Michael Colleran, the president and general manager of KYW-TV, said, “After assessing the overall impact of a series of incidents resulting from judgments she has made, we have concluded that it would be impossible for Alycia to continue to report the news as she herself has become the focus of so many news stories.” In a statement, Paul Rosen, Ms. Lane’s lawyer, declared the termination to be contrary to the terms of her contract.

headline: South Florida Officer Killed, Becoming 4th in Six Months
text: MIAMI  An off-duty Miami police detective was shot and killed early Tuesday morning, and the authorities speculated that he may have stumbled on a drug transaction in progress.

headline: Maldives: Quick, a Merit Badge
text: A 15-year-old Boy Scout foiled an assassination attempt on President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, grabbing a man’s knife as he leapt from a crowd and lunged at the leader, a government spokesman said. The president was unhurt, although the knife ripped his shirt. No motive was given. The boy, in his scout uniform for the event on the northern island of Hoarafushi, suffered a hand injury.

headline: He’s Staying in Campaign, Edwards Tells Supporters
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Reminding voters that less than one week ago he took second in the Iowa caucuses, John Edwards said Tuesday night that he would continue his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, despite his distant third-place showing in the New Hampshire primary.

headline: Recipe: Wok-Seared Spicy Calamari Salad
text: Adapted from TenPenh, Washington

headline: A Regulator Not Stymied by Red Tape
text: Shortly before Thanksgiving, Eric R. Dinallo, the insurance regulator for New York State, did something unusual. He called Warren E. Buffett’s right-hand man on insurance, Ajit Jain, and suggested that he start a new company to insure municipal bonds in New York.

headline: U.N. Official Warns of Darfur Failure
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations’ top peacekeeping official told the Security Council on Wednesday that obstructionism by the Sudanese government, the unwillingness of other countries to supply needed transportation equipment and continuing outbreaks of violence threatened to doom the mission of the freshly deployed peacekeeping force in Darfur.

headline: Texas: Child Abandonment Charges Filed
text: A woman accused of leaving her children with little food and no money while she traveled to Nigeria to marry a man she met on the Internet has been charged with child endangerment and child abandonment. The authorities have issued an arrest warrant for the woman, Shanell Monique Mosley, 33, but her relatives have not heard from her, a Child Protective Services spokeswoman said. Harris County sheriff’s deputies conducting a welfare check last week at the home in Cypress, outside Houston, found six children ages 1 to 9 being cared for by their 15-year-old sister. A neighbor’s 3-year-old boy and 4-year-old girl were also in the house. Ms. Mosley’s six children and the neighbor’s two children have been placed in foster homes, and a custody hearing is scheduled for Jan. 16.

headline: A Dangerous Game in the Strait
text: Iran played a reckless and foolish game in the Strait of Hormuz this week that  except for American restraint  could have spun lethally out of control.

headline: Calendar
text: Distilled Apples

headline: Recipe: Clementine Clafoutis
text: Time: About 1 hour

headline: Universities Need to Retake Control
text: NEW ORLEANS

headline: Lackluster Dance
text: “Dance War,” a spinoff of ABC’s popular series “Dancing With the Stars,” attracted only modest interest in the ratings on Monday, drawing 11 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Among adults 18 to 49, the reality competition between the choreographers Bruno Tonioli and Carrie Ann Inaba earned about half the ratings of the most recent premiere of “Dancing With the Stars” in September. The dancers also fell well short of NBC’s “American Gladiators” during the 8 p.m. hour. That new reality show, despite drawing just 10.9 million total viewers, would have led the night among the 18-to-49 set but for Fox’s football coverage, the Bowl Championship Series, which averaged more than 20 million viewers total. NBC ranked second for the night behind Fox, earning solid numbers from “Deal or No Deal” at 9 (10.7 million) and the premiere of the fourth season of “Medium” at 10 (9.6 million). ABC’s “October Road” drew a disappointing five million viewers at 10.

headline: A Taste for Brews That Go to Extremes
text: AS a life philosophy, it may not lead to wealth, happiness or old age, but for many American brewers today the motto printed on the bottle of Moylander Double I.P.A., from Moylan’s, a West Coast brewer, is a guiding principle:

headline: Rutgers’ Rice Will Enter N.F.L. Draft
text: Ray Rice’s most productive game in a Rutgers uniform will apparently also be his last.

headline: Global Ad Agency Moving to Far West of Manhattan
text: Ogilvy & Mather, the international advertising and public relations agency, said Tuesday that it would move its headquarters to 636 11th Avenue, at 47th Street, becoming one of the first corporate tenants to embrace that stretch of the Far West Side of Manhattan.

headline: F.T.C. Asks if Carbon-Offset Money Is Well Spent
text: Corporations and shoppers in the United States spent more than $54 million last year on carbon offset credits toward tree planting, wind farms, solar plants and other projects to balance the emissions created by, say, using a laptop computer or flying on a jet.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bond’s New Woman
text: Oh, that James Bond. Sometimes it’s just about impossible to keep up with him and his women. A day after announcing that the British actress Gemma Arterton will be the new “Bond girl,” Reuters revised its call, reporting that 007’s sidekick will be the Ukrainian actress Olga Kurylenko. The news agency, citing “a source close to the film,” said that although Ms. Arterton has a role in the forthcoming film, it is not as extensive as that of Ms. Kurylenko, above, a former model seen recently in “Hitman.”

headline: Dissent Inside Habitat for Humanity
text: In an extraordinary act of rebellion, the oldest affiliate of Habitat for Humanity International has filed suit to protest a new agreement that the nonprofit housing organization is imposing on its 1,600 local chapters.

headline: Pairings
text: EXTREME beer? Extreme food!

headline: Color Her Protest Pink (and Floral)
text: It all started with the pink shoes. As a girl in Iran in the 1980s, Zarah Ghahramani gravitated toward bright colors and lots of jewelry. She particularly loved a pair of pink slip-ons with flowers on the toes. Unfortunately, with the war against Iraq in full swing, and black the prescribed color for clothing, pink constituted a political affront. At 6, Ms. Ghahramani was already headed for trouble.

headline: Trying to Be Heard Above the Din, and Be Trusted
text: IN bank advertising, what matters is getting noticed at a time when the airwaves are cluttered, customers are nervous and marketing budgets are being slashed. JPMorgan Chase has that in mind with a sleek new brand campaign aimed at unifying its consumer advertising, streamlining its message and stretching the dollars it spends.

headline: A Losing Streak Had to End, but It Isn’t the Rangers’ One
text: The Rangers hit a point in Tuesday night’s game against Tampa Bay when they finally became disgusted with themselves. They had lost three straight games and several players to injuries, and they were trying to rally from a three-goal deficit against the worst team in the Eastern Conference.

headline: Retooled Campaign and Loyal Voters Add Up
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  The Clintons rarely make the same mistake twice.

headline: Two Drifting Life Rafts on a Sea of Circumstance
text: There’s not a single wrong note in “Liberty Kid,” Ilya Chaiken’s poignant drama about marginal lives strained to breaking by the aftermath of Sept. 11.

headline: Knicks Win With Marbury Back in Body and Spirit
text: CHICAGO  Stephon Marbury has been back on the Knicks’ active roster for a week, and back in the lineup for several days. It was not until late Tuesday night, however, that he truly seemed back in his realm  physically, emotionally and competitively.

headline: Italy: Prodi Intervenes in Naples Trash Crisis
text: Prime Minister Romano Prodi announced emergency measures to deal with Naples’ mounting garbage crisis, including three new incinerators, a special garbage czar, and an attempt to get other regions to volunteer to take the trash. The northern Valle d’Aosta offered to help, reports said.

headline: Clinton Is Victor, Turning Back Obama; McCain Also Triumphs
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York rode a wave of female support to a surprise victory over Senator Barack Obama in the New Hampshire Democratic primary on Tuesday night. In the Republican primary, Senator John McCain of Arizona revived his presidential bid with a Lazarus-like victory.

headline: Fed Panel Was Divided Over Outlook for Economy
text: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones/AP)  Reflecting a highly uncertain and divided outlook on monetary policy, regional Federal Reserve banks supported three options for the discount rate last month, according to minutes of the December meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, released Tuesday.

headline: What You Get for ... $5 Million
text: Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: Recipe: Halibut With Nori Jam
text: Adapted from David Myers

headline: University of Georgia President Calls for Playoffs
text: In a move that drew laughter for its feasibility and scorn for its timing, Michael F. Adams, the president of the University of Georgia, said he would use his position as the chair of the N.C.A.A.’s executive committee to push for an eight-team playoff.

headline: Metro-North Hudson Line From Grand Central to Croton-Harmon
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Looking Ahead

headline: If This Happens in Vegas, It Can Sure Stay in Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS  Parking was plentiful right by the door, there was no one to wrestle with for use of the slot machines, and Paris Hilton would not have been caught dead anywhere near this joint.

headline: Spitzer Strikes a Conciliatory Tone
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer kicked off his second year with warm words for his friends and foes alike, offering a strikingly less combative tone in his State of the State address Wednesday.

headline: Clementines in a Blanket
text: IT was one of those “why didn’t I think of that?” moments. I took one glance at a menu in a Paris bistro, and presto! Suddenly I wanted to make a clafoutis with clementines, too.

headline: A Serbian Director’s Eye Remains Fixed on Uncomfortable Truths
text: He has been a Yugoslav and a Serb and worked under dictators as philosophically opposed as Tito and Milosevic. He has made films about old people (“These Earthly Days Go Rolling By”), young love (“Beach Guard in Wintertime”) and a Serbia racked by frustrations and irrational violence (“Cabaret Balkan”). So it makes perfect sense that the place where Goran Paskaljevic really likes to work right now is Ireland.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Directors Guild of America has announced its nominees for directorial achievement in feature film: Paul Thomas Anderson for “There Will Be Blood,” Joel and Ethan Coen for “No Country for Old Men,” Tony Gilroy for “Michael Clayton,” Sean Penn for “Into the Wild” and Julian Schnabel for “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” The winner will be announced on Jan. 26. ... The Oscar-winning actress Nicole Kidman and her husband, the country singer Keith Urban, are expecting a baby, Reuters reported. The birth is expected in mid-2008.

headline: Easing a Grandmother’s Burden
text: It has been seven years since Brenda Hopkins started the treatments that do what her kidneys no longer can. She goes to the Brooklyn Kidney Center for dialysis treatment every Monday, Tuesday and Thursday, and sometimes on Saturday if she has excessive swelling in her ankles.

headline: Recipe: Pork Chops With Apple Nori Purée, Yams and Edamame
text: Adapted from Evan Rich

headline: 7 Feet 7 and 360 Pounds, With Bigger Feet Than Shaq’s
text: ASHEVILLE, N.C.  The University of North Carolina-Asheville men’s basketball team has perhaps the most effective inbounds play in the country: the Bulldogs’ point guard lofts the ball high toward the basket, and center Kenny George either tips it in or dunks it, without leaving his feet, as his opponents leap in vain.

headline: How the Polls Were Off
text: Pre-primary tracking polls conducted by some of the nation’s most reputable polling organizations like Gallup and CNN, raised expectations in the Obama campaign, lowered them in the Clinton campaign and had the media reporting that Barack Obama was such a strong candidate after his victory in Iowa that he was virtually unstoppable. But last night Hillary Rodham Clinton proved wrong what had by then become the conventional wisdom and won the New Hampshire Democratic primary, shifting the klieg lights onto those pre-primary tracking polls.

headline: Kenya Crisis Worsens as Opposition Cools to Talks
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The political mood darkened again in Kenya on Tuesday, with opposition leaders cooling to the idea of negotiations with the government after the president unilaterally made major cabinet appointments, a move that set off riots across the country almost immediately.

headline: Georgia: Inmates Sue Corrections Officers
text: A group of prisoners filed a class-action lawsuit contending that corrections officers have systematically beaten restrained inmates in prisons throughout the state, leaving two dead and dozens of others injured. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Valdosta, names 25 guards and other corrections officials as culprits in routine beatings and torture of inmates. It also claims that they subsequently covered up the abuses by inflicting even more beatings on prisoners who filed complaints. Most of the incidents reportedly took place from 2003 to 2005.

headline: Realtors’ Index Shows Dip for Existing-Home Sales
text: WASHINGTON (AP)  Pending home sales dipped in November, a trade group for real estate agents said on Tuesday, but the association expects sales to pick up in the second half of 2008.

headline: Director Speaks Out on Broad Collection
text: Michael Govan, the director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, said late Monday that he believed Eli Broad’s decision to keep his art collection in a private foundation that makes loans to museums is a positive development because it means none of the artworks will be sold, an act that would limit access to them by the Los Angeles museum and others. The museum will open the $56 million Broad Contemporary Art Museum next month, and it has long been speculated that Mr. Broad would donate his collection at least in part to the museum. But Mr. Broad said he had recently decided to keep his collection in his foundation because no museum, the Los Angeles one included, could commit to exhibiting a significant portion of it permanently. Asked if he viewed Mr. Broad’s decision as demonstrating a lack of confidence in him or the museum, Mr. Govan said: “Quite the reverse. Since Day 1 he’s privately and publicly given me a lot of support.” Mr. Govan said that “from the public perspective, I don’t think most people care when they walk in the door whether the museum owns the works or not, as long as they don’t lose them” to private sales. And, he added, “he’s got 2,000 works, so there is plenty to go around.”

headline: Olson’s Wife Files Challenge
text: The wife of Arizona Coach Lute Olson filed a court challenge to his attempt to divorce her. The petition said Christine Olson “denies the marriage is irretrievably broken” and “remains committed to preserving the marital relationship.” The petition was filed in Pima County Superior Court in Arizona last Friday and seeks marital counseling. Olson, a 73-year-old Hall of Fame coach, filed for divorce Dec. 6, the same day he announced his leave of absence would be extended for the rest of this season. He began his leave for unspecified personal reasons Nov. 4, shortly before he was to have opened his 25th season at Arizona.Christine Jack Olson, 50, is a prominent business executive and a member of the Republican National Committee from Pennsylvania. She married Olson in 2003 and is Olson’s second wife. His wife of 47 years, Bobbie, died of ovarian cancer in 2001.

headline: Hearing Right Waived
text: The New Mexico State freshman Herb Pope waived his right to a preliminary hearing on a drunken driving charge filed by police officers who said they found Pope passed out in a running car on a western Pennsylvania highway. The decision to waive Tuesday’s hearing means Pope will be scheduled to stand trial in Allegheny County Common Pleas Court. Officers found Pope, 19, unresponsive in the driver’s seat with the engine running in the Pittsburgh suburb of Moon Township on Dec. 28. Pope, a heralded recruit, had been academically ineligible at New Mexico State until a New Mexico judge ordered an end to the N.C.A.A. ban based on an alternative-education program he took in high school.

headline: Nori Steps Away From the Sushi
text: IT’S hard to imagine that nori was once the ugly duckling of the sushi bar. About 30 years ago, sushi chefs devised the inside-out roll (whose outer layer is rice rather than nori) to placate diners willing to try raw seafood but not dried seaweed.

headline: The Food’s Ready, but the Décor Is Evolving
text: I FIRST caught word about Seymour Burton in the days after the tryptophan-induced haze of Thanksgiving had worn off, through an e-mail message from a friend that included that dangerous verbal pairing “best” and “burger.”

headline: California Pension Fund Expected to Take Big Stake in Silver Lake, at $275 Million
text: Silver Lake, the largest technology-focused private equity firm, has reached a deal to sell a 9.9 percent stake to the California Public Employees’ Retirement System for about $275 million, according to people briefed on the deal.

headline: A Place So Crowded, Nobody Goes There Anymore
text: When Robert L. Sammons walks home from work each day through Times Square, he frequently encounters a crush of tourists shuffling to Broadway shows like “The Lion King” or restaurants like Planet Hollywood.

headline: When Talk Show Hosts Worked Without a Net
text: Wednesday night’s episode of the PBS mini-series “Pioneers of Television,” devoted to the roots of the late-night talk show, has one sequence that could be particularly helpful, or perhaps just frustrating, for current hosts who are without the services of their writing staffs.

headline: New Investigation in Texas E-Mail Case
text: HOUSTON  Already forced to drop his re-election bid over e-mail love notes sent from work to his executive secretary, District Attorney Charles A. Rosenthal Jr. of Harris County faced new questions Tuesday with the disclosure of hundreds of other office e-mail messages containing racy jokes, racial slurs and political campaign materials.

headline: Fighting Inflation, China Freezes Energy Prices
text: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao responded Wednesday to growing public anxiety about inflation by announcing that China would freeze energy prices in the near term, even as international crude oil futures have continued to surge.

headline: A Cathedral Resists the Label ‘Property of Russia’
text: NICE, France  On a February morning in 2006, a group of experts in Russian art approached the onion-domed Russian church here and demanded to be admitted to take an inventory of the building and its contents  icons, liturgical vestments, incense burners, everything.

headline: Unite, Not Divide, Really This Time
text: The New Hampshire primary has done Americans a service by leaving both parties’ nominating contests open and giving a truly broad range of voters a chance to participate in these vitally important choices. The coming contests will be colored in large part by how the contenders and their backers answer a basic question: Just how far are they willing to go to win?

headline: California Pension Fund Takes Big Stake in Silver Lake, at $275 Million
text: Silver Lake, the largest technology-focused private equity firm, announced a deal on Wednesday to sell a 9.9 percent stake to the California Public Employees’ Retirement System.

headline: Stewart (Angsty) and Colbert (Not) Return, Gazing at Navels and News
text: The glimmer of emotion that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton displayed in New Hampshire was startling because it was so out of character  almost as disconcerting as Jon Stewart returning to “The Daily Show” on Monday and not making fun of her.

headline: Bush Signs Gun Measure
text: President Bush signed legislation intended to prevent the severely mentally ill from buying guns, in a rare bipartisan agreement with the Democratic-led Congress after the shooting massacre last April at Virginia Tech. The bill authorizes up to $1.3 billion in grant money for states to improve their ability to track and report individuals who should not qualify to buy a gun legally, including those involuntarily confined by a mental institution. Much of the money, to be spent over five years, would be used to increase state feeds to a national system used to run background checks on gun purchases. The Virginia Tech gunman, Seung-Hui Cho, was able to pass a background check and buy two guns even though a Virginia court had deemed him a “mental defective.”

headline: Bid for China Eastern Airline Stake Rebuffed
text: HONG KONG  Singapore Airlines was rebuffed Tuesday in an effort to take a stake in China Eastern Airlines in a move that could remake the shape of China’s aviation industry with the possible emergence of one dominant Chinese carrier.

headline: The Secret of the Humble Chickens
text: I’VE had the roasted chicken at Barbuto when snow was blowing against the restaurant’s glass walls, and I’ve had it when summer sun streamed through. I’ve had it before 6:30 p.m., when the restaurant was just stirring, and after 10:30, when it was at full tilt.

headline: Apple Agrees to Cut iTunes Prices in Britain
text: LONDON  Apple said Wednesday that it had agreed to cut the prices on its iTunes digital music store in Britain to align them with those in Continental Europe, settling an antitrust case brought by European regulators.

headline: Queens: Man Admits Fatally Stabbing Friend
text: A homeless man who had been taken in by a Queens family pleaded guilty on Tuesday to charges that he fatally stabbed a family member during a botched burglary attempt, the prosecutors said. The man, Emmanuel Polanco, 22, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to manslaughter in the stabbing of David Higgins, 19, on Oct. 30, 2006, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Polanco previously stayed at Mr. Higgins’s home in Hillcrest, and later attacked Mr. Higgins when he came home and found Mr. Polanco burglarizing the residence, the prosecutors said. Mr. Polanco was also charged with beating Mr. Higgins’s mother with a bat when she arrived a short time later. He faces 30 years in prison when he is sentenced next month, the prosecutors said.

headline: Surfers Defy Giant Waves Awakened by Storm
text: DANA POINT, Calif.  One of the strongest storms recorded in the northern Pacific Ocean pummeled the West Coast last weekend, leading to widespread flooding and state and federal disaster declarations. The storm also left behind some of the most remarkable waves ever surfed.

headline: Rell Urges Strengthening Connecticut Justice System
text: HARTFORD  In the aftermath of last summer’s grisly home invasion in which a mother and her daughters were killed, Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Tuesday proposed a package of measures intended to bolster Connecticut’s criminal justice system.

headline: Bush Castigates Iran, Calling Naval Confrontation ‘Provocative Act’
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush chastised Iran on Tuesday for committing a “provocative act” by confronting United States Navy warships in the Persian Gulf over the weekend. The Pentagon released video showing Iranian speedboats maneuvering around the American convoy.

headline: McCain’s Victory Muddles G.O.P. Field as It Looks to Michigan
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  After Senator John McCain’s victory here on Tuesday, the Republican field is more scrambled than ever, with the battleground now shifting to a series of states where each of the leading candidates believes he holds certain advantages.

headline: Corzine Proposes Steep Rise in Tolls
text: TRENTON  Gov. Jon S. Corzine proposed the biggest financial maneuver in New Jersey’s history on Tuesday, arguing that drastically increasing highway tolls over the next 15 years could generate as much as $38 billion to help the state pay off half its debt and finance transportation improvements.

headline: City Names New Principal for English-Arabic School
text: On Tuesday, the New York City Education Department named an educator who has a “working knowledge” of Arabic as principal of the Khalil Gibran International Academy, the embattled Brooklyn school whose founding principal resigned under pressure after being quoted as defending the word “intifada” as a T-shirt slogan.

headline: Central Islip: Man Charged With Killing Landlord
text: A body found in a backyard cesspool in Mastic Beach has been identified as that of a man who has been missing for nearly 19 months, and a former tenant was charged on Tuesday with murder in the death, a Suffolk County police detective said. The tenant, Jaime Rosario, 38, a nursery worker from Center Moriches, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree murder and was ordered held without bail at his arraignment in Suffolk County’s First District Court. Mr. Rosario had been renting a room for $100 a week from the victim, Nicolo Caietta, 59, in his Mastic Beach home, Detective Sgt. Edward Fandrey said. He said Mr. Rosario was accused of beating Mr. Caietta to death with a baseball bat in May 2006, dumping his body in the cesspool and stealing $800 that Mr. Caietta had withdrawn from the bank to buy a counterfeit driver’s license. The body was found on Saturday when officers excavated the cesspool behind Mr. Caietta’s house, at 275 Forest Road West.

headline: Afghan Civilians Were Killed Needlessly, Ex-Marine Testifies
text: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C.  A former member of an elite Marine combat unit that operated last year in eastern Afghanistan testified Tuesday that his comrades appeared to have needlessly killed civilians after their convoy was attacked by a suicide car bomb.

headline: Executive Leaving Barclays Capital
text: LONDON  Barclays Capital, which reported a write-down of £1.3 billion ($2.6 billion) in credit securities two months ago, said on Tuesday that its co-president, Grant Kvalheim, had resigned and would leave at the end of the first quarter.

headline: India Debates Protocol for French Pair
text: NEW DELHI  Should a motorcade be allocated to Carla Bruni, the girlfriend and possible fiancée of the French president? That is one of the protocol issues perplexing Indian officials as they prepare to welcome Nicolas Sarkozy for the nation’s Republic Day celebrations this month.

headline: 3 Americans Arrested in Gang Battle With Mexican Police
text: MEXICO CITY  Three Americans were part of a well-armed gang that waged a gun battle with soldiers and police officers in Rio Bravo on Monday, the Mexican authorities said.

headline: Ways to Improve the Way We Vote
text: To the Editor:

headline: Some Golden Globes Sponsors Withdraw
text: Some prominent advertisers have pulled their sponsorships for NBC’s strike-subdued Golden Globes coverage and others were weighing their options, media buyers said Tuesday. The decisions came a day after the traditional format for the awards program was scrapped in the face of anticipated picket lines.

headline: Trenton: Ex-Boxing Commissioner Sues the State
text: New Jersey’s former boxing commissioner is suing the state’s attorney general, Anne Milgram, claiming that she ousted him for exposing errors by a subordinate. The former commissioner, Larry Hazzard Sr., filed a whistle-blower protection lawsuit against Ms. Milgram and others in Federal District Court on Friday. Mr. Hazzard, a former boxer and referee, was commissioner of the State Athletic Control Board from 1986 until he was fired in November. The board oversees boxing in Atlantic City, one of a handful of cities where big prizefights are often fought. A spokesman for the attorney general declined to comment on Tuesday.

headline: From a Big Boost for Obama to a Sharp Blow
text: NASHUA, N.H.  On the eve of the New Hampshire primary, Senator Barack Obama delivered a message to supporters: “Do not take this race for granted. I know we had a nice boost over the last couple of days, but elections are a funny business.”

headline: Lawyers Learn How to Be Businesslike
text: When Gabriel R. Munson graduated from law school in 2003, his goal was to have his own practice someday, modeling himself after Atticus Finch, the small-town lawyer in Harper Lee’s classic “To Kill a Mockingbird.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday about Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno, a member of the Bonanno crime family, and an article on Tuesday about his funeral in Tucson, referred incorrectly to his role in the publication of “Honor Thy Father,” a 1971 account of the Bonanno family by Gay Talese. Although Mr. Bonanno was extensively interviewed by Mr. Talese, he did not collaborate with him on the writing.

headline: Deal Reached to Buy Some Verizon Lines
text: FairPoint Communications reached an agreement on Tuesday with the Vermont Public Service Department that would allow it to buy Verizon Communications’ phone lines in the state.

headline: Bronx: Man Shot by Police Officer
text: A city police officer shot and wounded a man during an attempt to stop the man’s car on Tuesday morning, the police said. The officer fired three times as he and his partner struggled with the driver, who continued driving, the police said. Both officers, who were working as part of a plainclothes unit, saw the car being driven erratically, stopped it and approached on foot, the police said. The driver sped away and the officers followed in their car, the police said. At West Kingsbridge Road and Aqueduct Avenue about 11:33 a.m., the officers again approached the suspect’s car on foot, and the struggle ensued, the police said. Both officers, who were not identified, were slightly injured, the police said. The suspect, who was not identified, suffered a gunshot wound to his leg and was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, the officials said.

headline: Attack-Agent Detectors May Require City Permit
text: Individuals and companies have increasingly expressed interest in buying detectors to warn them of a biological, chemical or radioactive attack. But at a public hearing on Tuesday, a City Council committee considered a proposal that would require New Yorkers to get a permit from the Police Department to buy or use such detectors.

headline: Correction
text: An Op-Ed article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s position on the presidential race. He has not endorsed Mrs. Clinton or any candidate.

headline: Newark: Computer Administrator Sentenced
text: A former computer administrator at Medco Health Solutions was sentenced on Tuesday in Federal District Court to 30 months in prison for tampering with the company’s computer systems. The administrator, Yung-Hsun Lin of Montville, pleaded guilty in September to one count of transmitting computer code with the intent of causing damage in excess of $5,000. The prosecutors said Mr. Lin was angry at the possibility of losing his job. The tampering, aimed at a database used by pharmacists to track potential drug interactions, failed to work because of a programming error.

headline: A New Agency for Roads, or Version 2 of the Turnpike Authority?
text: TRENTON  For all the complex leaps of financial logic needed to grasp Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s plan to leverage New Jersey’s toll roads, several crucial components remain unchanged.

headline: Sarkozy Says Press Is Free to Ignore His Personal Life
text: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy refused to use the M word.

headline: We Still Need the Big Guns
text: Washington

headline: Escapee Caught Just Six Blocks From the Jail
text: Law enforcement officers arrested an escaped prisoner Tuesday night, finding him in an apartment just six blocks from the Elizabeth, N.J., jail from which he and another inmate broke out more than three weeks ago, the police said.

headline: The Court and Voter ID’s
text: From the early indications, Americans are feeling enthusiastic about their constitutionally guaranteed right to vote. The Supreme Court should encourage, not frustrate, that enthusiasm when it hears a challenge today to a harsh voter identification law adopted by Indiana. The law aims to be an anti-fraud measure, but its main impact will be to disenfranchise large numbers of registered voters. The court should not let it stand.

headline: A Parade! A Circus! A Carnival! Or, the New Hampshire Primary
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.  To fully appreciate the pure political carnival that is New Hampshire on Primary Day, there is no better place to absorb it than on Elm Street, the main thoroughfare that runs through the heart of downtown Manchester, the state’s biggest city.

headline: Naked and Free
text: The pay-what-you-choose initiative begun by the British art-rock band Radiohead has crossed over to the realm of classical music. The British violinist Tasmin Little plans to offer her next recording, “The Naked Violin,” free as a digital download in an effort to popularize such music, Reuters reported. “Just the fact that people can listen to it on a computer means that hopefully they won’t feel a need to have an education or be from a particular background or a certain sector of society,” she said. The album, featuring three pieces for unaccompanied violin and a commentary from Ms. Little, will be available on Monday from tasminlittle.net.

headline: Schwarzenegger Acts on California’s Big Deficits
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Facing chronic budget problems as well as a short-term deficit bigger than many states’ annual revenues, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger on Tuesday proposed amending the California Constitution to give governors new budgetary powers, including the ability to cut spending in the middle of a fiscal year.

headline: Humbler Spitzer Likely to Focus on Economic Growth and Higher Education
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to strike a more conciliatory note with the Legislature in his annual address to lawmakers on Wednesday  the first political step of the embattled governor’s second year in office.

headline: 3 Killed in Florida Highway Pileup
text: Three people were killed and dozens injured early Wednesday in a major pileup on Interstate 4 in north central Florida, as fog and smoke from brush fires combined to make it almost impossible for motorists to see.

headline: American Motherhood and the Question of Home Birth
text: “The Business of Being Born” is a passionate ground-level examination of home childbirth, anchored in a scene in which its executive producer, Ricki Lake, the actress and former talk-show host, gives birth to her second child in a bathtub. That graphic scene, and several other unblinking sequences of home birth attended by a midwife, are intended to erase any stigma from the situation. Practiced widely in Europe and Japan, home birth has largely disappeared in the United States, the documentary states, because of an image as a primitive, unsanitary ritual.

headline: From Same Dugout to the Same Row Before Congress
text: Roger Clemens’s plan to testify before a Congressional committee next week portends a scene made for the rolling television cameras: a longtime friend and former teammate, Andy Pettitte, being asked questions regarding Clemens’s possible use of steroids with Clemens sitting beside him.

headline: Director (and Voice) of Metropolitan Museum to Retire
text: Philippe de Montebello, who has led the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 30 years and has virtually become synonymous with its monumental profile, announced Tuesday that he planned to retire at the end of the year.

headline: Britain: Prison for Would-Be Jihad Fighter
text: Sohail Qureshi, a London dental technician who was arrested at Heathrow Airport in 2006 boarding a flight to Pakistan, was sentenced to four and a half years in prison in the first conviction under a new law against planning terrorism. The prosecutor said Mr. Qureshi, originally from Pakistan, planned a “two- to three-week operation” either in Pakistan or Afghanistan, possibly against Western troops. He was carrying nearly $18,000, a telescopic night sight and a computer hard drive loaded with militant Islamic tracts, the court was told. Prosecutors said that he had trained with jihadist groups in Pakistan linked to Al Qaeda and that his skills included encrypting e-mail messages. The court was also told of e-mail exchanges he had with Samina Malik, known as the “lyrical terrorist,” who received a suspended sentence in November for keeping a library of terrorist material. Ms. Malik, a clerk at a Heathrow newsstand who wrote poetry limning her passion for Islamic militancy, received an e-mail message from Mr. Qureshi asking about security arrangements at Heathrow. According to the prosecution, she replied, “The airport security is as tight as ever.”

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $5,553,470

headline: Former Premier’s Wife Arrested on Return to Thailand
text: BANGKOK  The wife of the ousted Thai prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, returned from exile Tuesday to face charges of corruption and an uncertain future for her family and its political allies.

headline: Pettitte Plays a Pivotal Role for Clemens
text: On the day that Rich Gossage deservedly gained entry to the Hall of Fame, I thought it would be appropriate to create the Hall of Infamy. Charter members: Pete Rose, Barry Bonds, Roger Clemens and Mark McGwire.

headline: Canada: Rocket Builder Makes Acquisition
text: Alliant Techsystems, a maker of weapons and space systems, said it had agreed to buy a unit of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates for 1.33 billion Canadian dollars ($1.34 billion) to build complete satellite systems. Alliant agreed to buy MacDonald’s information systems and geospatial information services group in its biggest acquisition ever and its first outside the United States, said Alliant’s chief executive, Daniel Murphy. The purchase will be complete by the end of March and will add to Alliant’s profit starting in the 2010 fiscal year. Alliant, based in Edina, Minn., will be able to build and operate full satellite systems as sales slow in its main business, supplying bullets to the United States Army. MacDonald is based in Richmond, British Columbia.

headline: Primaries: Brokaw’s ‘Novel Idea’ For The Media
text: Just after 11 p.m., the MSNBC anchor Keith Olbermann drew comparisons between the media’s pre-primary predictions and the infamously wrong 1948 headline “Dewey Defeats Truman” in the Chicago Daily Tribune.

headline: Primaries: Startled By Clinton’s Surge, TV Pundits Recast The Democratic Race
text: The television networks were quick to declare John McCain the winner of the Republican primary in New Hampshire Tuesday night, but hesitant to project a first place winner in the Democratic race. Hillary Rodham Clinton’s surge of support was deemed a surprise by media commentators who largely expected another win by Barack Obama.

headline: Travel Basics: Frankfurt
text: AIRPORTS: If you are like most of the people coming to Frankfurt, you are well on your way to going as well, which is to say you are changing flights at the mammoth Frankfurt International Airport. Most people at Frankfurt airport are transit passengers, but if you are not, then fear not: transportation into town is as good as anywhere in the world.

headline: Travel Basics: Madrid
text: AIRPORTS: Barajas International Airport has won deserved renown for its vast, wavy-roofed Terminal 4, designed by award-winning architects Richard Rodgers and Antonio Lamela. Inaugurated in February 2006, the airy, luminous terminal is an impressive introduction to Madrid — though confusing signs, long walks from gates and problems with the luggage sorting system have become familiar gripes among Madrileños. If you fly to Spain on Iberia airlines, you will probably have the good fortune to come to T4. Far less prepossessing are Terminals 1 to 3, which share many of the inadequacies that have become emblems of international air travel: dim lighting, grim cafés and endless construction. But they are functional, check-in and security lines are manageable and access to taxi ranks and the subway system is simple.

headline: John McCain's New Hampshire Speech
text: John McCain comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

headline: John Edwards's New Hampshire Speech
text: John Edwards comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

headline: Victories and Defeats
text: At the end of the night, the candidates savored their wins or licked their wounds.

headline: Hillary Rodham Clinton's N.H. Speech
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

headline: Mike Huckabee's New Hampshire Speech
text: Mike Huckabee comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

headline: Barack Obama's New Hampshire Speech
text: Barack Obama comments on the results from the New Hampshire primary. (NBC Video)

headline: The Unpredictability Factor
text: The Times's John Harwood analyzes how Hillary Rodham Clinton's victory in New Hampshire has changed the presidential race.

headline: Flameout on Figueroa
text: NASHVILLE PREDATORS 7LOS ANGELES KINGS 0

headline: Locking up a Star
text: The Dallas Stars wisely got Mike Ribeiro‘s signature on a five year, $25 million deal lest he get to unrestricted free agency in July. Ribeiro, who turns 28 next month, has become the heart of the Dallas offense since he was obtained from Montreal at the start of last season for a song (Janne Niinimaa, who is now playing in Switzerland).

headline: Sights and Sounds From Primary Day
text: The day in New Hampshire began with candidates making their final push and ended with victories by Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain.

headline: Welcome to the New Nuclear Era
text: The nuclear industry went through decades of stagnation after devastating accidents in the 1970s and ’80s. But nowadays the industry has a handy sales pitch: It can claim to be a technology that emits nearly nothing in terms of greenhouse gases.

headline: Making the Switch (or Not)
text: Readers share their experiences with compact fluorescent bulbs.

headline: Sawing Wood
text: An ad for the home improvement catalog that gets things done:

headline: Body Check
text: From the metro report in Tuesday’s Times:

headline: Co-President of Barclays Capital Resigns
text: Barclays Capital, which reported a write-down of 1.3 billion pounds ($2.6 billion) in credit securities two months ago, said on Tuesday that its co-president, Grant Kvalheim, had resigned and would leave at the end of the first quarter.

headline: FairPoint Closer to Winning Approval for Verizon Deal
text: FairPoint Communications reached an agreement on Tuesday with the Vermont Public Service Department that would allow it to buy Verizon Communications‘ phone lines in the state.

headline: Countrywide Denies Rumors of Bankruptcy
text: Shares of Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, plunged 28.4 percent Tuesday after it denied rumors that it was planning to file for bankruptcy protection.

headline: With Fast Search Deal, Microsoft Aims at Google
text: Microsoft‘s $1.2 billion bid on Tuesday for a Norwegian search software company, was seen mainly as an effort to add more tools to its lucrative Office products, but was also being done, analysts said, with an eye toward fending off Google.

headline: In New Ads, JPMorgan Tries to Be Heard Above the Din
text: In bank advertising, what matters is getting noticed at a time when the airwaves are cluttered, customers are nervous and marketing budgets are being slashed. JPMorgan Chase has that in mind with a sleek new brand campaign aimed at unifying its consumer advertising, streamlining its message and stretching the dollars it spends.

headline: Wireless Start-Up Fails to Get Financing
text: Frontline Wireless, which wanted to build an innovative cellular network for both private use and local public safety agencies, has collapsed because it reportedly could not raise enough money to bid in the government auctions of wireless spectrum that start later this month.

headline: PubMatic Nabs $7 Million
text: PubMatic, an advertising optimization software company, said Tuesday it had received $7 million in venture financing.

headline: CalPERS to Take Stake in Silver Lake
text: Silver Lake, the largest technology-focused private equity firm, has reached a deal to sell a 9.9 percent stake to the California Public Employees’ Retirement System for about $275 million, The New York Times reported. The transaction, which values Silver Lake at about $2.75 billion, is expected to be announced Wednesday.

headline: Cisco Systems Connects With SoonR
text: The networking giant Cisco Systems led a $9.5 funding round of a two-year-old application hosting firm, SoonR.

headline: Diller to Keep His Hand In After IAC Split
text: Barry Diller, the media mogul who runs the Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp, told investors Tuesday that after the company spins off four divisions, he will stay involved in the management of the restructured IAC, Expedia and Ticketmaster.

headline: Credit Suisse’s DLJ Takes a Bite of Den-Mat
text: DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, the private equity arm of the Credit Suisse Group, said Tuesday that it has purchased a majority stake in Den-Mat Holdings, a maker of cosmetic dental products such as Lumineers, from Den-Mat’s founder.

headline: Analysts Eye Murdoch’s Next German Move
text: By acquiring a stake in the German pay-television broadcaster Premiere, Rupert Murdoch has cemented the company’s status as a takeover candidate in a saga that hinges on the next auction of Bundesliga soccer rights.

headline: Alliant Makes $1.3 Billon Acquisition in Canada
text: Alliant Techsystems, a maker of weapons and space systems, said it had agreed to buy a unit of MacDonald, Dettwiler & Associates for 1.33 billion Canadian dollars ($1.34 billion) to build complete satellite systems.

headline: Wave of Grim News Expected to Crash on Wall Street
text: Sometimes when it rains, it pours on Wall Street. And next week, forecasters are calling for a flood.

headline: Hedge Fund Loses Suit Against Telos
text: You win some and you lose some. That’s the case with a series of lawsuits filed by an activist hedge fund manager, Costa Brava Partnerships, against a defense networking and information technology contractor, Telos, and Goodman & Company, the company’s independent auditor.

headline: Pioneer Aims to Tap $136 Million in Blank-Check I.P.O.
text: Pioneer Southwest Energy Partners, a limited partnership formed to acquire oil and gas properties, said Tuesday it plans to raise $136 million in an initial public offering of 7.5 million common units, according to an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Liz Claiborne to Sell 2 Brands to Perry Ellis
text: Liz Claiborne said Tuesday it had decided to sell two of its brands to Perry Ellis International and close another as part of a strategic review.

headline: Hong Kong May Limit ‘Cornerstone’ Investors
text: In Hong Kong, preferential access to initial public offerings is a lucrative privilege. But as Forbes.com reports, “that cash machine may get shut off” now that Hong Kong regulators are considering a ban on the practice of doling out pre-I.P.O. shares to so-called cornerstone investors.

headline: Moelis Hires Partner for Buyout Unit
text: The advisory firm founded by the former UBS banker Ken Moelis last July has added a partner to its private equity division taking its headcount to 45 in six months.

headline: A Regulator Who Cut Through Red Tape for Buffett
text: In the last days of December, as the financial strength ratings of the old bond insurance companies were under pressure and the insurers were being forced to put up additional capital, Warren E. Buffett announced the start of his new municipal bond insurer, the Berkshire Hathaway Assurance Corporation.

headline: More Hedge Funds Means More Activists, Report Finds
text: Thanks mainly to a rise in the number of hedge funds players in the field, activist investors in the United States increasingly bared their teeth last year.

headline: Will Lewis Regret Hunting Bear?
text: Is Joseph C. Lewis beginning to regret his big bet on Bear Stearns?

headline: Number-Crunching the 2008 Election
text: Well, I guess I picked the wrong day to tout the Intrade futures market.

headline: Extrication Time at Bear Stearns
text: When he was a top investment banker at Bear Stearns, Alan D. Schwartz deftly outmaneuvered the likes of Carl C. Icahn and won plaudits for his pragmatic ways.

headline: Lichtenstein Launches Proxy Battle With Rowan
text: In a surprise move, Warren G. Lichtenstein’s Steel Partners said it would nominate three candidates to the board of the Rowan Companies, an oilfield services company, to unlock more value.

headline: Merrill Likely to Stay in Lower Manhattan, Report Says
text: Merrill Lynch has put off plans to build a headquarters in Midtown Manhattan and is likely to renew its lease in Lower Manhattan’s World Financial Center, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing undisclosed sources. But a lease renewal hasn’t been signed, and the deal could still fall through, the Journal added.

headline: Nobody knows anything
text: But to be more specific, the prediction markets — which you see, again and again, touted as having some mystical power to aggregate information, know no more than the conventional wisdom. Here’s the Intrade price for “Clinton wins the Democratic nomination” over the past month:

headline: High School With Money 2.0
text: Defamer tracks Ben Silverman, the co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, nominating himself as the Prom King in an interview with Ryan Seacrest. “Sadly, it feels like the nerdiest, ugliest, meanest kids in the high school are trying to cancel the prom,” said Mr. Silverman, whose network holds the rights to broadcast the Golden Globes. “But NBC wants to try to keep that prom alive.”

headline: Almasi Wins Reggio Emilia
Oxygen Shortage
text: The Risky Biz blog noted that dressmakers won’t be the only ones who take a hit from the deflation of the Globes. “American Gangster,” “The Great Debaters” and “Sweeney Todd” all could use a Globe-induced boost, but it will be hard to make an impression amid the tick-tock of an hour-long press conference.

headline: Everyone Knows It’s Indy
text: One strategy to make the Oscars more palatable to the Writers Guild would be to minimize the presence of the major studios. Sort of silly really, but then the Bagger noticed that indies and specialty divisions dominated the Directors Guild awards. Paramount Vantage has a lot of irons blazing away, with a piece of three of the five: “There Will Be Blood,” “No Country” (with Miramax) and “Into the Wild.”

headline: A Wave of Information
text: The technology featured in the blockbuster movie “Minority Report” is coming to a Hilton hotel near you.

headline: God and Mammon
text: “It’s like contemplating my own mortality. I know it’s something I have to face, but not today.” — An industry executive contemplating the ankling of the Oscars in Variety.

headline: Too Much TV for Cisco
text: Televisions have gotten big. Very, very big. Perhaps too big to be practical. Over a lunch of veggie wraps and chicken sandwiches, Michael Kisch, director of consumer marketing for Cisco, told the tale of “The TV That Was Too Big.”

headline: What to Expect in the State of the State
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to strike a more conciliatory note with the Legislature in his annual address to lawmakers today — the first political step of the embattled governor’s second year in office. But lawmakers on both sides of the aisle remain wary and in many cases openly critical of the governor, and some fellow Democrats are troubled by reports he may propose imposing a ceiling on property-tax increases.

headline: The Early Word: It’s a Wide-Open Race
text: “Change” is out, and “comeback” has taken its place as the hot political buzzword, at least as far as New Hampshire voters would have you know.

headline: MBIA Cuts Dividend to Preserve Rating
text: MBIA, the world’s largest bond insurer, slashed its common stock dividend 62 percent on Wednesday as part of a plan to strengthen capital and preserve the “triple-A” credit ratings it depends on to operate normally.

headline: Food Stuff
text: A Creamy Tuscan Ricotta, Made Fresh in Brooklyn

headline: They Were Misinformed
text: Well, it was a shocking defeat for this group, and today they’re going to have to take a long hard look at what went wrong. No, I don’t mean Team Obama — that crowd can move ahead — I mean the pollsters who were so certain that the Clinton campaign was D.O.A.

headline: Pirate Watcher Adds Up Attacks for 2007
text: In the previous three years, the struggle against piracy on the high seas seemed to be turning a corner — from 445 attacks in 2003 to 239 in 2006, according to statistics from the International Maritime Bureau, an agency founded in 1981 to combat sea crime.

headline: A magical French clinic for ailing dolls and bears
text: Henri Launay is the doctor to the dolls, a self-taught surgeon of French porcelain poupèes. For the last 43 years, Launay has presided over a refuge of sorts in northeast Paris for battered celluloid babies with cracked heads and ancient teddy bears in desperate need of snout transplants.

headline: Here a Cluck, There a Cluck
text: Just as I was finishing this week’s review of Barbuto, which throws a spotlight on its roasted chicken, a news release came my way.

headline: E*Trade Rises on Modest Sales Loss
text: In announcing a modest sales loss, E*Trade Financial managed to reap about a 10 percent gain in its battered stock in trading Wednesday morning.

headline: For McCain, Quiet Before the Big Stage
text: NASHUA, N.H. — Senator John McCain stood silently, hands in his pockets, staring at the television as the first television station called the election last night. The only indication of what he thought about this latest chapter in his adventurous life was a wide grin.

headline: School Popularity Affects Girls’ Weights
text: Girls who think they aren’t popular are at higher risk for weight gain, according to a new study.

headline: John McCain, Wall Street Underdog
text: If Mac is truly back — as many supporters of John McCain were chanting Tuesday night — will more of Wall Street open its wallet to this Republican presidential contender? A few big names in high finance have supported his campaign, including John Thain, the new chief executive of Merrill Lynch, but they are a relatively lonely crowd.

headline: A Landmarks Fight on Madison Avenue
text: Not as swiftly as Paul Revere, but with no less determination, Francine Ravitz made her way along Madison Avenue on Tuesday, sounding the alarm from East 65th Street, where she and her husband live, all the way to 64th Street.At one stop, Mrs. Ravitz pulled an envelope from a bag hanging on her walker. She presented it to Karen McAdoo, the manager of the Morgane Le Fay women’s clothing store in the two-story building at Nos. 746-48. Inside was a “Dear Neighbor” letter from her husband, Robert J. Ravitz, a principal in the David J. Greene and Company investment company.

headline: Clinton’s Strategy Echoes Bush in 2000
text: Hillary Clinton stands behind no Democratic presidential candidate in her scorn for George W. Bush – but that isn’t stopping her from implementing Mr. Bush’s 2000 primary strategy. In one notable consequence of the front-loaded 2008 political calendar, she implemented it before the New Hampshire primary, not after.

headline:
Living With Music:
A Playlist by Nicholas Christopher
text: On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for “Living With Music,” a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

headline: A One-Night Shift in the Late-Night Wars
text: “For the first time since television’s late-night shows returned to the air last week, David Letterman was able to nose out Jay Leno in the ratings,” Bill Carter reports in Wednesday’s New York Times. “It was just for one show, Monday night, and Mr. Letterman’s lead was not sizable, but Mr. Leno had won the first three nights.”

headline: An Advance Look at Spitzer’s Speech
text: Updated, 2:41 p.m. | Judging from excerpts released this morning, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s second State of the State address this afternoon will strike a conciliatory tone and focus heavily on meat-and-potato issues like schools, property taxes and health insurance as he seeks to regain his political footing, turn attention away from the multiple and potentially crippling ethics investigations he still faces, and build the foundation for his second year in office.Such a speech would not be so different from Mr. Spitzer’s first such address a year ago, despite the decline in the governor’s fortunes since then. Mr. Spitzer’s first state of the state address mixed broad reform proposals unpopular with Albany lawmakers (campaign finance reform and non-partisan redistricting) with a large platter of proposals that offered something for everyone, whether more education spending for Democrats or worker’s compensation reform for Republicans.

headline: Congress to Investigate Denials by Clemens
text: The House committee looking into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball has postponed a hearing next week that was to feature Roger Clemens and his accuser so that the panel can begin its own investigation into Clemens’s adamant denial that he used such drugs.

headline: Editor’s Note | “The High Low”
text: Only readers of The Moment could have a heated discussion about a cotton sweater. While we love action in our comments section, the editors have some comments of their own regarding Monday’s post, “The High Low | L.L. Bean’s Kingfield Sweater,” which was the initial installment of a feature on chic, affordable goods. First of all, we goofed and published an incorrect image — the author, our fashion associate Melissa Ventosa Martin, liked the sweater in ivory, not the deep red color we showed. The correct color is shown here. [UPDATE: The sweater has sliver buttons, not a zippered neck; photo corrected.] Secondly, a couple of readers commented that they saw the L.L. Bean sweater and immediately thought: “blatant product placement advertising.” We don’t do that. The Times has a policy that keeps advertising separate from editorial content. There is not, however, a Times policy on stylishness — though there should be — so readers should feel free to blow the whistle when they’ve spotted a fashion violation. Those, however, will be hard to come by.

headline: Terrelle Pryor Still Open to Buckeyes
text: Despite Ohio State’s loss to Louisiana State in the Bowl Championship Series title game, the highly regarded quarterback Terrelle Pryor said it did not affect his interest in the Buckeyes.

He says that university administrators need to focus on investing in college athletes, rather than concentrating on “an insignificant sports issue.”

headline: Poll: Some Would Draft Bloomberg, for Governor
text: How’s this for uncertainty? A majority of New York City voters — 52 percent — think Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would make a good president, and a nearly equal proportion believe it is likely that he will run, but only 16 percent would actually like him to do so, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released today.But perhaps because of dissatisfaction with Gov. Eliot Spitzer, whose poll numbers have plummeted, New York City voters would be far more enthusiastic if Mr. Bloomberg were to run for governor in 2010.

headline: 2008: The Year of the Big Airline Merger?
text: It is one of the oldest stories on Wall Street: the idea that big mergers will sweep across the United States airline industry, reshaping a business that is notoriously prone to sharp downturns. And so far, it has largely been a piece of fiction.

headline: Update: Talk Off | Skinny Jeans
text: Earlier this week, in The Moment’s Talk Off column, fashion associates Bifen Xu and Melissa Ventosa Martin debated the virtues of skinny jeans. A record number of readers voted by leaving comments — first Iowa, then New Hampshire, and now Talk Off! Here’s the skinny: Bifen, who argued the affirmative position, won the Talk Off with approximately 62 percent of the votes. Note: Political analysts will question the fairness of a fashion contest that had Kate Moss squaring off against MC Hammer.

headline: Leaders Ride Quick Draws to Victory at Hastings. Is This a Problem?
text: The 83rd edition of the Hastings International Chess Congress in England, which may well be the oldest annual tournament (with a break for World War II for obvious reasons), ended Sunday, Jan. 6, in a three-way tie for first. The winners were Valeriy Neverov of the Ukraine, Vadim Malakhatko of Belgium and Nidjat Mamedov of Azerbaijan. The results, as well as a history of the tournament, are on its Web site.

headline: How Bad Does He Want It?
text: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: John McCain is leading in New Hampshire. McCain really, really wants to be president. As a matter of fact, it’s No. 2 on his bucket list.

headline: ‘He Just Has No Plans’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: I love how the government keeps telling us how the weather affects gasoline prices. For example, when the weather was rainy and cold, well, it takes more fuel to heat our homes. So of course the price of oil goes up. Then when it’s sunny out, well, we take more vacations. We drive around. The price of oil goes up. In fact, the only time weather makes the price go down, I believe, is when it snows in hell.

headline: Council Votes to Require Stores to Recycle Plastic Bags
text: Putting New York City within the forefront of a growing movement to curb plastic bag use, the City Council overwhelmingly passed a sweeping measure today that would require stores to collect, transport and recycle the plastic bags they issue to customers.

Somerville, a climatologist at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography near San Diego, is one of a growing array of scientists who have chosen to move beyond studying heat transfer and cloud physics and take on the role of activist: prodding society to move aggressively to cut greenhouse gases.

headline: Consumer Electronics Show | A Case for Funky-Fresh Wires
text: In a previous post from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, we mentioned the aesthetic advantages of wireless technology. Now we’re wondering if seeing wires might be a good thing. It’s an idea that runs completely against the trends of technology and home design – and that’s exactly why we were intrigued by the tiny booth of Shenzhen Kechenda Technology. This obscure Chinese company was showing a collection of HDMI cables (commonly used with high-fidelity TVs and DVDs) that have the same graphic impact as a pair of sneakers from A Bathing Ape. Our favorites were a glittery emerald and yellow HDMI, a glossy purple one that looks like a jump rope from the Eighties and a wonderfully baroque silver cord with flashy gold plugs. Hook these babies into your home theater and it’ll be business in the front, party in the back.

headline: Bear Stearns Said to Close Third Hedge Fund
text: Months after closing two hedge funds that helped precipitate the credit crunch, Bear Stearns is closing a third fund, Bloomberg News reported Wednesday.
