headline: Dawn of the Pundits
text: I watched Saturday night’s Democratic debate in the filing center on site, along with two of my editors, Gerry and Megan. When Hillary Rodham Clinton’s temper flared, Gerry and I practically recoiled in our seats. Another male journalist sent me an e-mail saying, “She just lost.” But Megan saw something completely different, and even before the candidates could ask another question, she admonished us for being sexist. Why can a man flash some anger, she wanted to know, but not a woman? What was so distasteful about a woman showing a little fight?

headline: A 60,000-Vote Differential
text: Some observers, including David Brooks , have looked at the New Hampshire primary results and concluded that “roughly equal” numbers of votes were recorded in the Republican and Democratic primaries. But I see a huge difference in the numbers — differences of historical significance, in fact.

headline: The Man Who Turned Against the C.I.A.
text: What kind of C.I.A. agent was Philip Agee? With the news today of his death, there have been variations on a theme. Reuters headlined him as a “whistle-blower” while The Associated Press preferred “renegade,” and Redstate, a right-wing blog, was the most unsparing: “A Traitor Dies In Exile.”

headline: Employing the Masses
text: I’ve been reading a lot about an impending recession, but it’s hard to imagine its reality when I hear about the number of people working on our dream home. It seems like half the population of Anna Maria is working on it right now.

headline: For The Moment | Florence Night Owl
text: This week’s guest blogger is the New York-based men’s wear designer Adam Kimmel. Known for his heady brand of cerebral machismo — Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock are recurring inspirations — Kimmel, 28, will be filing from Florence, Italy, where he is the featured designer at the men’s-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo. In today’s post, Kimmel writes about the final preparations for his dinner at the Istituto d’arte on Thursday.

headline: CNBC Video: Bear’s New C.E.O. Speaks

text: SPARTANBURG, S.C. – Every candidate has a crop of funny stories, but with all due respect, as they love to say in election campaigns, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee’s are probably funnier. He does voices. He makes noises with a microphone that any Comedy Central stand-up act might respect.

headline: The People’s Choice: Tune Out the Awards
text: The two-month-old writers strike took a significant toll on the “People’s Choice Awards” on Tuesday, as the taped, scaled-down version on CBS lost nearly half its audience compared with a year ago. The show attracted 6 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, down from the 11.3 million people who watched the show’s live broadcast on the same night last year.

headline: A Call to Action From Newark’s Mayor
text: His intensity matched the soaring oratory and suddenly found voices of the presidential campaign season, but the Democratic mayor of Newark, Cory A. Booker, was thundering about local crime earlier today, and trying to convince 72 police department recruits — some looking dazed, and all the men with their heads shaved — that they were most important people in the world. The stage was small, and there was no blinding glare of television lights. A photographer got too close to Mr. Booker, who told him to “back off.”

headline: Bomb Scare Derails Giuliani Event
text: MELBOURNE, Fl. — Rudolph W. Giuliani bypassed Michigan on Wednesday to return to his must-win state, Florida. There, his effort to shift the focus of his campaign from security to tax policy was dealt a slight setback when a bomb threat forced him to relocate a speech on tax cuts from a corporate headquarters to a secure airplane hangar.

headline: Columbia Says It Knows of No Visit to Iran
text: Officials at Columbia University were taken aback on Tuesday when the Mehr News Agency, a government-sponsored news outlet in Iran, reported online that a delegation of professors and deans planned to travel to Tehran to apologize for the behavior of Columbia’s president, Lee C. Bollinger, during the visit to New York by Iran’s president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, last September.

headline: Gossage on Steroids: ‘I Probably Would Have Done It’
text: Timing is everything, not that Rich Gossage needs a lesson in that. The pitcher nicknamed the Goose made a living unleashing unusually fast pitches with unusual accuracy, which happens only by letting go at just the right moment.

text: If you’re going to troll for poll data at Real Clear Politics any time soon, take time to check out a piece by John Ellis making a plausible case that the “real” winner in New Hampshire was Mike Huckabee.

headline: Museum on Wall Street Celebrates Dollar Signs
text: Updated, 8 p.m. | Robert Vinci pointed at a spindly tree chart that laid out an evolutionary ancestry. It was not dissimilar, he said, to the hierarchical diagrams, known as cladograms, of dinosaur families that he used to work with at the American Museum of Natural History.Only this one laid out the elaborate ancestry of the Bank of America, stretching back to names now relegated to history, including Massachusetts Bank (founded 1784), the Providence Bank (founded in 1791), and, more recently, Fleet, and BayBank.

headline: In Harlem, a Tough Choice Between Clinton and Obama
text: The race for the Democratic presidential nomination, as it moves to Nevada and South Carolina, remains as unsettled as ever. Senator Barack Obama visited New Jersey and New York on Wednesday for a rally and a fund-raising event, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton gave interviews from her home in Chappaqua, N.Y., in Westchester County. We took the occasion of their visits here to ask several self-identified Democrats in Harlem which candidate they supported and whether the results on Tuesday in New Hampshire had affected their decisions.

text: WASHINGTON  The woman found in her home on Wednesday with the decomposing bodies of four children, believed to be her daughters, will face murder charges, authorities said Thursday.

headline: The Approval of Seals
text: A BODY can take only so much modernism. Crisp head-to-toe newness is all well and good, but it needs some kind of counterweight  preferably, of course, in precious metal. Perhaps this is why signet rings, traditionally worn as a paterfamilias hand-me-down, are enjoying a revival. Cleverly referencing and romancing the past without becoming overwrought about it (see: goths), the new crop of restrained signet rings manages to whiff of the Knights Templar while conveying the continental élan of, say, Simon Templar. Having one subtly flashing on your finger is the perfect way to broadcast your affirmation of a bright modern future while reminding everyone of your ancestral ties to the past.

headline: Portland, Ore., Acts to Protect Cyclists
text: “Ghost bikes,” riderless and painted white, were placed at two busy intersections in Portland, Ore., last October, makeshift memorials to two bicyclists killed when they were hit by trucks in accidents that month.

headline: Shipmates Under the Influence of Gilbert and Sullivan
text: Since the company was founded in 1974, the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players have made a point of building their seasons around an alternation of the three most frequently heard Savoyard operettas  “The Pirates of Penzance,” “The Mikado” and “H.M.S. Pinafore”  and the lesser-known works that make up the rest of the canon.

headline: In Corpse Episode, Echoes of a Grittier Time
text: You would see them around Hell’s Kitchen, the men neighbors knew as Jimmy and Fox. They were relics of the past in the once-notorious neighborhood, and now they lived on its edges.

headline: Energizing Moves That Slice and Dice
text: “Revelations” is modern dance’s unquestionable greatest hit, anchoring countless performances by Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and inspiring applause before it even starts. But many troupes have their enduring crowd pleasers, signature works that reveal core artistic values. There is “Esplanade,” Paul Taylor’s joyously unforced celebration of everyday virtuosity, or “Batty Moves,” Jawole Willa Jo Zollar’s ode to the female derrière. These days the much diminished Martha Graham Dance Company settles, tellingly, for a remnant: “Sketches,” from the 1936 antiwar rallying cry “Chronicle.”

headline: Opening Government

headline: Art Stolen From São Paulo Museum Is Retrieved
text: State police in Brazil have recovered two paintings, above, including a Picasso valued at $50 million, that were stolen last month in a predawn break-in at the São Paulo Museum of Art, Reuters reported. The museum’s president, Julio Neves, said Picasso’s “Portrait of Suzanne Bloch” and the Brazilian artist Candido Portinari’s “Coffee Worker,” valued at $5 million, were in perfect condition when found at a house on the city’s outskirts. The police arrested one suspect, Francisco Laerton Lopes de Lima, on Dec. 27, and his capture led them to Robson de Jesus Jordao, who was arrested on Tuesday. Police Chief Mauricio Freire said the two men had long criminal records, including participation in previous robbery attempts at the museum. Mr. Neves said both paintings would be on view in their previous locations when the museum opens on Friday.

headline: Consultant Questions Beijing’s Claim of Cleaner Air
text: BEIJING  A new study has cast doubts about whether air quality has truly improved in Beijing and has concluded that “irregularities” in the city’s system of measuring air pollution have enabled the city to meet environmental targets linked to the coming Olympic Games.

headline: They’re Playing My Song. Time to Work Out.
text: FITNESS magazines and Web sites love to ask readers about their favorite workout music while presenting their playlists or suggestions from celebrities. Self.com features the “ ’80s cardio playlist,” which includes the short-shorts video classic “Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go” by Wham! On Fitnessmagazine.com, the singer Rihanna reveals her favorite workout songs  immodestly recommending four of her own for “when you have to pick up the pace on the treadmill.”

headline: Further Adventures in America’s Favorite Pastime, ‘Addictionology’
text: Addicts come in many guises, but the most pernicious are substance-abuse abusers  those reckless, incorrigible souls who cannot stop bingeing on the weaknesses of the rich and semi-famous.

headline: Executive to Leave Warner Bros.
text: LOS ANGELES  Dawn Taubin, the head of domestic marketing at Warner Brothers for six years, has been ousted in a management shake-up that the movie studio did little to conceal.

headline: Are We Ready for a Woman President? More Debate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Swipes at Clinton, but Takes Aim at Bush
text: JERSEY CITY  Senator Barack Obama, showing strain in the wake of his surprise defeat in New Hampshire, hewed closely to his standard script of hope and change before a largely enthusiastic audience here on Wednesday, keeping his aim squarely on the administration of President Bush.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Antiques Benefit

headline: Two Drives Team Up to Save a Network’s Data. (If They Run Into Trouble, They’ll Let You Know.)
text: A new storage device guards against the day when your PC drive takes a dive. The ReadyNAS Duo, announced this week at the Consumer Electronics Show, is made by Netgear and will go on sale in March. Unlike simple single-drive storage connected to one computer with a cable, it is part of the home or office network, so it can be reached by all of the network’s PCs or media players.

headline: Weak December Sales for Retailers
text: The nation’s big retail chains, a closely watched barometer of economic health, reported dreary December sales on Thursday, which may stoke fears of a recessionary downtown.

headline: Clinton’s Message, and Moment, Won the Day
text: At first, the moment seemed like a disaster: The televised images of the teary-eyed exchange Hillary Rodham Clinton had with a New Hampshire voter about the rigors of the campaign caused her advisers to express fears that it would badly undercut her message of strength and experience.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about President Bush’s criticism of Iran for confronting American warships over the weekend misstated the conclusion of a recent National Intelligence Estimate on Iran, which Mr. Bush also discussed. The intelligence estimate, issued in December, concluded that in 2003 Iran halted its program to develop a nuclear weapon; it did not say that Iran had abandoned its efforts to enrich uranium.

headline: Footnotes
text: The playwriting debut of the filmmaker Ethan Coen sold out before its first preview on Wednesday night Off Broadway at the Atlantic Theater Company’s Stage 2. Featuring F. Murray Abraham, Jonathan Cake, Mark Linn-Baker and Mary McCann, the three short plays, under the title “Almost an Evening,” open officially on Jan. 22 for a run through Feb. 10. ... Kate Winslet will replace Nicole Kidman opposite Ralph Fiennes in “The Reader,” Variety reported. Ms. Kidman, citing her pregnancy, dropped out on Monday. The film, directed by Stephen Daldry  (“The Hours,” “Billy Elliot”), is based on a Bernhard Schlink novel about a German teenager who falls in love with a woman who once worked in Auschwitz.

headline: Colombia: Plan for New Hostage Mission
text: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela said Colombian guerrillas had provided him with the location of two captives, Clara Rojas, a former aspirant to Colombia’s vice presidency, and Consuelo González, a former Colombian lawmaker. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, had agreed last month to release the hostages, but an operation led by Mr. Chávez fell apart after the rebels were found not to have the 3-year-old son of Ms. Rojas, who was instead living in foster care in Bogotá. Colombia’s government gave its approval to the new operation. Mr. Chávez said rescue helicopters could depart as soon as early Thursday.

headline: Best Beats
text: "Studies have shown that listening to music during exercise can improve results, both in terms of being a motivator (people exercise longer and more vigorously to music) and as a distraction from negatives like fatigue," Steven Kurutz writes in The Times today. "But are certain songs more effective than others?"

headline: Planning a Life With Room for Debate
text: NEAR the start of the film “The Great Debaters,” the young man who would grow up to be the civil rights leader James Farmer Jr. comes home with the news that he has been chosen for his school’s debate team. His father sternly warns him that something as frivolous as debate must not get in the way of homework and grades. “Never take your eye off the ball,” he said. But one suspects that it was those debates, more than those grades, that led Mr. Farmer to found the Congress of Racial Equality and help change the world.

headline: A Better Life Here, Yes, but Not Without Worries
text: Raymond Acevedo and his sister, Katiria, share a bedroom in their family’s apartment near Yankee Stadium, in the Bronx. It is tight quarters for two teenagers with different interests. Katiria’s side is decorated in pink and with Hello Kitty paraphernalia. Raymond’s features sports equipment and posters of girls in bikinis.

headline: Democrats Rush to Build Up Campaigns in Nevada
text: LAS VEGAS  Scores of college students fanned out in neighborhoods across this city Wednesday, phone banks buzzed with newly minted volunteers and endorsements were proffered as the Democratic presidential candidates ratcheted up the volume in this once-quiet caucus state.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. My kitchen tile is scuffed and worn in high-traffic areas. Can I fix it without replacing the whole floor?

headline: A Pocket Cam Zooms in for the Game’s Highlights
text: Canon’s latest entry-level video camera, the ZR950, does not skimp on specs. But it also does not carry a lot of doodads or protrusions like a TV-station rig. Instead it is smooth-edged for popping out of a pocket to capture the moment when Junior suddenly comes in goal range  even from the high school version of nosebleed seats.

headline: Folsom Prison Officials Pull Plug on Concert
text: Officials have canceled a concert scheduled for Folsom Prison on Sunday, 40 years to the day after the famous Johnny Cash performance there, The Associated Press reported. Late Monday, citing problems with filming rights and media access, as well as concerns about security, officials at the prison in Northern California called off the “40th Anniversary of ‘Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison’ ” performance that was to have featured some members of Cash’s original band and been streamed worldwide on the Internet. Jonathan Holiff, the producer of the planned show, said the cancellation was a broken promise by the officials. “I was in tears when I found out,” he said.

headline: Ex-Senator Wants to Pay Lawyers With Election Funds
text: Former State Senator Wayne R. Bryant of New Jersey, who is facing criminal corruption charges, is hoping to tap a new source to help pay mounting legal bills: his campaign account.

headline: Tony Blair Expected to Join JPMorgan
text: The former prime minister of Britain, Tony Blair, will join the banking giant JPMorgan Chase & Company as a part-time adviser, a person with knowledge of the decision said Wednesday night.

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Aide Won’t Testify on Tapes Without Immunity
text: WASHINGTON  A lawyer for Jose A. Rodriguez Jr., the former Central Intelligence Agency official who in 2005 ordered the destruction of videotapes of harsh interrogations of prisoners at a secret site overseas, has told Congress that Mr. Rodriguez will not testify about the tapes without a grant of immunity, a person familiar with the discussions said Wednesday.

headline: Richardson Drops Out of Democratic Race
text: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico is pulling out of the presidential race, after coming in fourth in both the New Hampshire primary and the Iowa caucuses.

headline: The Smile Boutique in the Dentist’s Office
text: DR. PIA LIEB, a cosmetic dentist, held an unusual food tasting last month in a Chelsea loft. Plenty of red wine and gobs of delectable nibbles were on hand, including beet and goat cheese salad and raspberry mini-tarts. Dr. Lieb’s aim wasn’t to delight guests but to discolor their teeth.

headline: The Kaufman Center: Something New for Both Ear and Eye
text: On schedule and on budget, the Kaufman Center, home to the popular Merkin Concert Hall, opened its doors on Tuesday night with a gala reception and concert after an eight-month, $17 million renovation. On Monday night anyone passing the center, on 67th Street just west of Broadway, might have wondered how on earth the place was going to be ready to go in 24 hours.

headline: Paul MacLean, 94, Neuroscientist Who Devised ‘Triune Brain’ Theory, Dies
text: Dr. Paul D. MacLean, a neuroscientist and psychiatrist who developed the intriguing theory of the “triune brain” to explain its evolution and to try to reconcile rational human behavior with its more primal and violent side, died on Dec. 26 in Potomac, Md. He was 94.

headline: Deleted but Not Erased: Photos Reborn
text: THANKS to digital cameras, memories are easier than ever to gather. But as Amy Sevigny learned, they can be more fragile as well.

headline: Candy Magnate Loses Bid to Bar Drilling on Ranch
text: HELENA, Mont.  A state judge has ruled that an energy company has the right to explore and drill for natural gas on a sprawling cattle ranch owned by the billionaire candy magnate Forrest E. Mars Jr., despite his opposition.

headline: An Upstart in Films With Many Fast Moves
text: LOS ANGELES  At the Cannes Film Festival last May, the movie producer Avi Lerner knew he had an alluring property on his hands: Robert De Niro and Al Pacino, who have shared the screen only once before, in 1995’s “Heat,” were starring in a gritty New York police drama called “Righteous Kill.”

headline: Queens: Teenagers Admit Fatal Beating
text: Two Queens teenagers pleaded guilty to manslaughter on Wednesday, admitting that they choked and fatally beat John Canora, 55, in his Howard Beach home in October 2006, prosecutors said. At the time of their arrest, the teenagers, Billyray Staton, 18, of Beach 27th Street in Far Rockaway, and Alex Brown, 18, of Liberty Avenue in Jamaica, told the police that Mr. Canora had hired them to do maintenance work on his home and had offended them by making sexual advances. They said they choked him, beat him with an aluminum baseball bat and a fire extinguisher, and hid his body in the basement.

headline: Governor Doesn’t Seek Tuition Rise for Colleges
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s State of the State message was filled with benefits for New York’s public universities, including 2,000 new full-time faculty members and the creation of an endowment of at least $4 billion.

headline: Any Other Bright Ideas?
text: WHEN Lloyd Levine, a California assemblyman, proposed last year that his state become the first in the country to ban energy-wasting incandescent light bulbs, his position was met with outrage.

headline: Air Travelers’ Woes Likely to Worsen This Year
text: The miserably full flights of 2007 might seem like a good reason for airlines to roll out a few more planes and ease the crowding.

headline: Florida: Arrest in Killing of Detective
text: The Miami police have a man in custody who they believe inadvertently killed an off-duty police officer while firing an assault rifle at a couple in an apparent jealous rampage, a police spokesman said. The man, Ricardo Ajuste, 21, was charged with two counts of attempted murder for allegedly opening fire on a car parked near the vehicle of the officer, Detective James Walker. Detective Walker was found dead Tuesday in his unmarked police cruiser in an alley in North Miami Beach. Mr. Ajuste has not been charged with the killing but is a “prime suspect,” the police said.

headline: A Breezy Exchange Between Old Friends (Jazz and Poetry)
text: “This is not an exercise in nostalgia, or giggling at the ’50s,” the poet Robert Pinsky said on taking the stage at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night. Along with his colleague Charles Simic, the current poet laureate of the United States, Mr. Pinsky was taking part in a program billed as “Words and Music.” And his disclaimer doubled as a pledge. “We hope the evening will not be about goatees and berets,” Mr. Pinsky said, “but about art.”

headline: Fixated on TVs, and What’s on Them
text: The Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week was an unabashed display of high-technology gadgetry. Televisions, enormously wide and remarkably thin, were front and center, and overhead, and in the faces of all the visitors to the expansive show, which ends Thursday. Some advertised other new products, but most were there just to display images that were slightly crisper than those seen years before.

headline: Michigan Next, G.O.P. Rivals Turn to the Economy
text: PONTIAC, Mich.  Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney sped to Michigan on Wednesday and turned their focus to the slowing economy as they headed toward the next showdown in the race for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Edmund Hillary, First on Everest, Dies at 88
text: Sir Edmund Hillary, the lanky New Zealand mountaineer and explorer who with Tenzing Norgay, his Sherpa guide, won worldwide acclaim in 1953 by becoming the first to scale the 29,035-foot summit of Mount Everest, the world’s tallest peak, has died, New Zealand Prime Minister Helen Clark announced Friday in Wellington.

headline: The Bride Made Me Buy This
text: IN the new romantic comedy “27 Dresses,” Jane, a perennial bridesmaid, smiles a shade too brightly in response to a remark repeated in scene after scene. Eyeing her invariably frothy bridesmaid’s dress, a well-meaning friend chirps, “Well, you can always wear it again.”

headline: Britain Moves to Build New Nuclear Plants
text: PARIS  The British government on Thursday approved plans to refresh the country’s fleet of nuclear reactors, signaling new enthusiasm for the technology and giving a lift to the industry.

headline: Edwards’s 3 Little Words: The Long Haul
text: CLEMSON, S.C.  Diving into the South Carolina primary, John Edwards has a plan to keep himself positioned to capture the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Met Forms Search Committee for Director
text: Wasting no time, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has formed a committee to begin an international search for a replacement for Philippe de Montebello, who announced on Tuesday that he would retire after 30 years as the museum’s director.

headline: Blog Takes Failed Marriage Into Fight Over Free Speech
text: BOSTON  Normally, Garrido v. Krasnansky, a divorce case playing out in Vermont family court, would be of little interest to anyone but the couple involved. But the court has ordered the husband to stop posting blog items about his wife and their crumbled marriage, possibly turning an ordinary divorce into a much broader battle over free speech on the Internet.

headline: Ken Nelson, Record Producer Behind Bakersfield Sound, Dies at 96
text: Ken Nelson, the record producer behind the twangy Bakersfield Sound made popular by Buck Owens and Merle Haggard, died on Sunday at his home in Somis, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Bank of America in Talks to Buy Countrywide
text: The Countrywide Financial Corporation, the troubled lender that came to symbolize many of the excesses of the subprime mortgage crisis, is reportedly negotiating a sale to Bank of America, a move that would rescue Countrywide from an uncertain future.

headline: Suspects Arraigned in Dead-Man’s-Check Case
text: A sister of Virgilio Cintron, the 66-year old man whose corpse was wheeled up to a check-cashing store by two of his friends on Tuesday, was working at the store when the two men tried to redeem her brother’s check, according to the criminal complaint.

headline: Philip Agee, 72, Is Dead; Exposed Other C.I.A. Officers
text: Philip Agee, the former Central Intelligence Agency officer who turned against the agency and spent years exposing undercover American spies overseas, died Monday in Havana. He was 72.

headline: Blame for 1993 Attack at Center Is Still at Issue
text: One of the most painful parts has been the wait, a lawyer for victims of the 1993 bombing at the World Trade Center told an appeals court on Wednesday.

headline: Kerry Endorses Obama as Campaign Goes Nationwide
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John Kerry embraced the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama here on Thursday, saying Mr. Obama had “the greatest potential to lead a transformation, not just a transition.”

headline: The First Primary: It’s Clinton’s Day
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: 	Anarchy Rules: The Dishes Stay Dirty
text: An article last Thursday about communal or “punk” houses misstated the university affiliation of Joel Olson, a former resident of one such house. Mr. Olson is an assistant professor of political science at Northern Arizona University, not Arizona State University.

headline: Fighting in Congo Rekindles Ethnic Hatreds
text: MUSHAKE, Congo  Andre Simwerayi looked on with satisfaction as the army blasted rockets over a verdant hillside, pummeling what officers said were the positions of forces loyal to a renegade Congolese Tutsi general.

headline: Besting the Tiger Slam
text: Tiger Woods said on his Web site last week that winning all four professional majors in a single year, a feat never accomplished, is "easily within reason." Do you expect him to win the Grand Slam this year? If not, who or what will stop him?

headline: Remaking the Condo With Light and Air
text: WHEN Bob Harper began his search for a new home in West Hollywood, Calif., last summer, what he thought he wanted was a house. But he quickly changed his mind after his real estate agent took him to see a two-story condominium in Habitat 825, a 19-unit building at 825 North Kings Road that was nearing completion.

headline: The G Train From Smith-9th Streets to Long Island City
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Tunes for Every Tribe
text: Though most gym-goers turn on their iPods and tune out everyone else, many health clubs still pump music throughout the gym, tailoring the playlist to their clientele.

headline: Giants Using Power to Start, and Finesse to Finish
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Dressing side by side in the Giants’ locker room, Brandon Jacobs and Ahmad Bradshaw make an unlikely pair: Jacobs at 6 feet 4 inches and 264 pounds, and Bradshaw at 5-9 and 198.

headline: Study Says DNA Flaw May Raise Autism Risk
text: A rare genetic flaw that occurs spontaneously near or during conception may sharply increase the risk that a child will develop autism, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: Congress to Investigate Denials by Clemens
text: The House committee looking into the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball has postponed a hearing next week that was to feature Roger Clemens and his accuser so that the panel can begin its own investigation into Clemens’s adamant denial that he used such drugs.

headline: Alicia Keys Climbs Chart
text: In a slow week for the Billboard chart, Alicia Keys reached No. 2 with 112,000 sales of “As I Am” (J); Mary J. Blige moved 89,000 of “Growing Pains” (Geffen) to reach No. 3; “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 26 is at No. 4 with 54,000; and the 18-year-old country singer Taylor Swift rose three spots to No. 5, though sales of her self-titled album, on the Big Machine label, dropped 39 percent last week to 47,000, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Radiohead reached No. 1 with the conventional release of “In Rainbows,” through the ATO label, on CD and other formats. The indie-rock “Juno” soundtrack (Rhino), popular online, opened at No. 8 with 38,000.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about President Bush’s criticism of Iran for confronting American warships over the weekend misstated the conclusion of a recent National Intelligence Estimate on Iran, which Mr. Bush also discussed. The intelligence estimate, issued in December, concluded that in 2003 Iran halted its program to develop a nuclear weapon; it did not say that Iran had abandoned its efforts to enrich uranium. (Go to Article)

headline: In Address, Spitzer Sets New Tone, for Unity
text: ALBANY  The man who swept into the Statehouse a year ago, determined to overhaul Albany, instead tried to embrace it on Wednesday, as Gov. Eliot Spitzer called lawmakers his friends, asked for prayers for the family of his political nemesis, and shelved, for the time being, talk of dramatic reform.

headline: More Than a Steak Dinner
text: A Texas judge was so delighted last week to free a wrongly convicted inmate  after 27 years in prison  that the judge bought him a steak dinner and taught him how to use a cellphone to spread the news. The fact that this happened in Texas, famous for its draconian criminal punishments, was heartening. Most heartening of all was that Dallas County, where it occurred, is turning into a model for the rest of the nation in preserving potentially exonerating evidence in capital cases.

headline: China to Freeze Energy Prices in an Effort to Quell Worries About Inflation
text: BEIJING  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao responded Wednesday to growing public anxiety about inflation by announcing that China would freeze energy prices in the near term, even as international crude oil futures have continued to surge.

headline: W.H.O. Says Iraq Civilian Death Toll Higher Than Cited
text: The World Health Organization on Wednesday waded into the controversial subject of Iraqi civilian deaths, publishing a study that estimated that the number of deaths from the start of the war through June 2006 was at least twice as high as the oft-cited Iraq Body Count.

headline: Hollywood Investigator to Be His Own Lawyer
text: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that Anthony Pellicano, the Hollywood private investigator facing trial on wiretapping and conspiracy charges, can represent himself at trial next month. Judge Dale S. Fischer of United States District Court said she was bound by Supreme Court case law to let Mr. Pellicano do so, but urged him to reconsider. The ruling raises the prospect that Mr. Pellicano, who often grabbed the limelight in his career as an investigator to the stars, would again take center stage at his trial, set to begin Feb. 27. By acting as his own lawyer he will cross-examine prosecution witnesses like Anita Busch, the former journalist who the authorities say was wiretapped by Mr. Pellicano and was threatened in a scheme he orchestrated, as well as other cooperating witnesses who prosecutors say hired Mr. Pellicano to wiretap their adversaries.

headline: 2nd Finish in Fifth Fails to Dim Paul’s Hopes
text: CONCORD, N.H.  In a state that many people considered his best opportunity to match his strong fund-raising with enough votes to shake up the Republican race, Representative Ron Paul came up short on Tuesday.

headline: Fed Chief Signals Further Rate Cut
text: Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, sent a strong signal on Thursday that the central bank will lower interest rates again this month as it tries to stave off a recession.

headline: Cash, Check, or Euro?
text: The plummeting United States dollar is not something most sports fans think about -- that stuff is for economists and politicians. But next week in New York, American sports executives will have to deal with a consequence of the greenback's weakness, as National Hockey League executives meet with European hockey officials to hammer out a new agreement governing international player transfers.

headline: Hillary’s Free Pass
text: MANCHESTER, N.H.

headline: Study Finds Possible Targets for AIDS Drugs
text: Using a new type of genetic screen, researchers at Harvard Medical School have identified 273 proteins that the AIDS virus needs to survive in human cells, opening up new potential targets for drugs.

headline: In the Catskills, Wondering if Casinos’ Time Has Passed
text: MONTICELLO, N.Y.

headline: Niceness Campaign in Albany Gets Nowhere as G.O.P. Pouts
text: ALBANY  Few second dates have been so awkward.

headline: Steppingstone Squeeze on the Path to a Victory
text: In a Flight A/X Swiss Teams, your team is either A (you have players with lots of master points) or X (your team is not weighed down with points). But although a team is X rated, if you will excuse the expression, it does not mean that its members cannot play.

headline: Tom Cruise and His Bully Pulpit
text: If Andrew Morton’s “Tom Cruise: An Unauthorized Biography” is published peacefully next Tuesday, one of its basic assertions will be undermined. That is because if Mr. Morton is right about the litigious fervor of either Mr. Cruise, who is the book’s ostensible subject, or the Church of Scientology, which is its real one, the publication will be met with dirty tricks, messianic anger and relentless harassment. If Mr. Morton is wrong about that, there will be fewer fireworks. After all, among this biography’s revelations is the fact that Tom Cruise was a cute kid.

headline: Must Flatter, Work Nights and Last Forever
text: Here is a brief guide to the types of light bulbs discussed in the accompanying article.

headline: Second Escapee From N.J. Jail Arrested in Mexico
text: ELIZABETH, N.J.  The second of two inmates who escaped from the Union County jail here last month was captured in Mexico City on Wednesday, ending a nearly four-week search that began with a nighttime jail break and ended with two arrests in two countries within 24 hours.

headline: MySpace Is Said to Draw Subpoena in Hoax Case
text: LOS ANGELES  A federal grand jury here issued subpoenas to MySpace and others last week in connection with the suicide of a 13-year-old Missouri girl after she received cruel messages from people posing as a teenage boy on the site, The Los Angeles Times reported Wednesday.

headline: At 0-17, N.J.I.T. Has Hit Bottom, and Things Aren’t Looking Up
text: NEWARK  When the New Jersey Institute of Technology men’s basketball team lost its season opener to Manhattan, 70-28, the players and coaching staff might have figured that at least things could not become worse. Some two months later, they are finding out that they were wrong.

headline: Nevada Savors Its Place as Maker of Momentum
text: LAS VEGAS  Scores of college students fanned out in neighborhoods across this city Wednesday, phone banks buzzed with newly minted volunteers and endorsements were proffered as the Democratic presidential candidates ratcheted up the volume in this once-quiet caucus state.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: Europe’s Next Rate Move May Be an Increase
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank suggested Thursday that its next interest rate move was most likely to be an increase, despite signs that European economies are slowing.

headline: At Jewish Cemetery, Vandals Strike on Large Scale
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Celia Tracy lay on the ground beside the toppled tombstone, stretching her arm underneath the large slab of marble. As if reading Braille, she rubbed her fingers along the engraved surface, now hidden, searching in vain for any indication that here was the grave of her in-laws.

headline: Where Skis Meet Skates
text: THE cross-country ski has come a long way from the days of wooden slats and bamboo poles. In the last 10 to 15 years, the equipment has undergone drastic changes, resulting in skis that are lighter, faster and stronger.

headline: 9 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Sunni Strongholds
text: ARAB HAMADAH, Iraq  In one of the deadliest stretches for American troops in months, militants killed nine soldiers in the volatile Sunni Arab heartlands north of Baghdad on Tuesday and Wednesday as the military began its third offensive in a year to dislodge Sunni guerrillas from sanctuaries deep within the lush farmlands and palm groves of Diyala Province.

headline: A Microscope for the Lab, Minus the Squinting
text: Mad scientists of an earlier era were content with using a microtome and glass slides to examine odd cell structures through a dusty lens. Modern mad scientists know that there’s something a bit clearer available: the Celestron LCD Digital Microscope.

headline: Cowboys Won’t Say If Owens Will Play
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  While the off-field adventures of Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo have attracted attention, Terrell Owens’s health is a far more critical component of Sunday’s game.

headline: Digital Tools Help Users Save Energy, Study Finds
text: Giving people the means to closely monitor and adjust their electricity use lowers their monthly bills and could significantly reduce the need to build new power plants, according to a yearlong government study.

headline: Albany: Lawsuit Over Ski Resort
text: Residents and community groups in the Catskills filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in State Supreme Court charging the state with a conflict of interest in the way it is handling its review of a proposed resort near the state-owned Belleayre Ski Center in Ulster County. The Catskill Heritage Alliance, the Pine Hill Water District Coalition and individuals who live near the planned development assert that the State Department of Environmental Conservation is a partner in the project at the same time that it is deciding whether to grant final approval. In September, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced an agreement to move forward with the long-delayed project to build hotels, housing units and a golf course alongside the Belleayre center in Highmount, near two reservoirs that supply water to New York City. The developer, Dean Gitter, agreed to scale back the project and sell 1,200 acres to the state, which in turn agreed to expand the number of ski runs and lifts at Belleayre.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: The Elusive Perennial

headline: Fans in a Video Playoff for Super Bowl Tickets
text: DON’T tell the children who watched “Miracle on 34th Street” on TV last month, but there is no Santa Claus  at least, not in a contest being sponsored by Coors.

headline: Ashcroft Deal Brings Scrutiny in Justice Dept.
text: WASHINGTON  When the top federal prosecutor in New Jersey needed to find an outside lawyer to monitor a large corporation willing to settle criminal charges out of court last fall, he turned to former Attorney General John Ashcroft, his onetime boss. With no public notice and no bidding, the company awarded Mr. Ashcroft an 18-month contract worth $28 million to $52 million.

headline: Conditions in Cascades Raise Avalanche Danger
text: SEATTLE  The big snows that pummeled the Cascade Range recently have transformed the mountains into an alluring fresh-powder playground for winter sports. But they have also helped make this one of the deadliest avalanche seasons on record in Washington.

headline: Study Sees Complex Ties Between Plants and Animals
text: A few years ago, Todd Palmer, an ecologist at the University of Florida, was walking past a fenced-off research site in Kenya when he noticed something curious: instead of thriving, acacia trees protected from leaf-eating elephants and giraffes were withering and dying.

headline: Ditching the Suit, the Vest Struts Its Stuff
text: WOMEN may have plenty to smirk about these days as men turn into the very clotheshorses they once sneered at. Even so, men still have a healthy distrust for an impractical trend.

headline: Women’s Support for Clinton Rises in Wake of Perceived Sexism
text: If the race wasn’t about gender already, it certainly is now.

headline: Panama: Noriega Loses Another Round
text: Judge Paul C. Huck of United States District Court in Miami denied a request by lawyers for the former Panamanian strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega to block his extradition to France to face money laundering charges. The lawyers said France had offered insufficient guarantees that Mr. Noriega would be repatriated to Panama after his legal process was completed in Europe. But the judge said France had made assurances that he would be accorded all the rights of a prisoner of war, including repatriation to Panama, even though it did not intend to designate him as one. The judge also rejected an argument that Mr. Noriega’s status as a prisoner of war in the United States prohibited his extradition. The lawyers said they would appeal. Mr. Noriega, who in September completed a 15-year prison term in Miami, will remain in American custody until he exhausts all his appeals.

headline: Philippe de Montebello
text: For 30 years, Philippe de Montebello has been the edifice within the edifice of the Metropolitan Museum of Art  as iconic, in his own way, as the museum’s Fifth Avenue facade. He has announced that he will retire at the end of the year, but it is almost easier to think of him as an antiquity  and I mean this only sculpturally  being restored to the country of his origin. He must have come to us from private life, and to private life he will return, though it is hard to imagine him or the Met without each other as a backdrop.

headline: Not Just the Fed
text: The American economy is weakening fast, and some prominent economists are saying a recession is already here. The Federal Reserve, with its prodigious lending capacity and power to cut interest rates, could yet save the day. But with prices, and fears of inflation, also rising, the Fed has less room to maneuver.

headline: Lawmaker Tied to Abramoff to Retire
text: WASHINGTON  Representative John Doolittle of California, once a rising star in the Republican Party but more recently under investigation in a scandal involving the disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff, announced his retirement from Congress on Thursday, declaring that it was time for a new chapter in his life.

headline: Retailers Limit Purchases of Designer Handbags
text: FOR products that are truly in demand, like Wii game consoles, tickets to the Super Bowl or cans of corn Niblets on double-coupon day, it may seem reasonable to limit the number a customer can buy at one time.

headline: Ice Maker in Talks With Hedge Fund on New Buyout Terms
text: PHILADELPHIA (Reuters)  Reddy Ice Holdings, a producer of packaged ice, said Wednesday that it was in talks to revise a $1.1 billion deal to be bought by a hedge fund, GSO Capital Partners.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A film review in Weekend on Dec. 21 about “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” referred imprecisely to a scene in the film “North by Northwest” that takes place at Mount Rushmore, as does a scene in “National Treasure: Book of Secrets.” While Eva Marie Saint dangles near George Washington’s face in “North by Northwest,” she is not shown dangling from his nose.

headline: Down and Out and Running Numbers in the Rougher Precincts of Manila
text: Much like man’s best friend, the rough-hewn Filipino movie “The Bet Collector” chases its protagonist from step to step, misery to misery, all but nipping at her heels. Though you never see her sell anything, Amy (Gina Pareño) operates a tiny store out of the front of her ramshackle Manila house with her husband and tries to make ends meet by illegally running numbers. It’s a living (if barely), though there are moments in this aggressive, predictably sympathetic excursion into miserablism when it seems a lot more like dying.

headline: Genetic Flaw May Explain Some Cases of Autism
text: A rare genetic flaw that occurs spontaneously during development may sharply increase the risk that a child will develop autism, researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: Iran Accuses U.S. of Faking Persian Gulf Video
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s Revolutionary Guard accused the United States on Wednesday of fabricating a video showing Iranian speedboats confronting United States Navy warships in the Persian Gulf over the weekend, according to a report carried by the semiofficial Fars news agency and state-run television.

headline: Tip of the Week: Managing Your Passwords
text: Tired of having to click that “Forgot Password?” link when trying to log into a secure Web site? Consider using a password-management program to organize and store all the passwords you pick up on your Internet travels. With most programs, you need to remember only one password to unlock the software’s encrypted database and reveal all your others. Free options include Password Safe (passwordsafe.sourceforge.net) and Password Corral (www.cygnusproductions.com). SplashID has $20 password software for PCs and smartphones at www.splashdata.com, and several other programs are rated at password-management-software-review.toptenreviews.com.

headline: Korean Fire Ends Migrants’ Hard Journey Home
text: ICHEON, South Korea  When 31-year-old Sohn Dong-hak and six relatives, all ethnic Koreans from China, began migrating to South Korea several years ago, they were retracing the route of their forebears, who had left their native land a century ago for China to escape poverty and Japanese colonial rule.

headline: A Fierce Corzine Opponent Turns Ally
text: TEANECK, N.J.  Gov. Jon S. Corzine on Wednesday turned to the Republican he defeated in a bitter race for the United States Senate in 2000 to help with what may be his toughest campaign yet: persuading taxpayers and legislators to accept costly increases on New Jersey’s toll roads to pay off billions in debt and maintain its bridges and highways.

headline: Admirable Spirit, but Rules Are Rules
text: In August 1945, a former Army pilot with an artificial leg pitched five and a third innings for Washington against Boston. This would turn out to be Bert Shepard’s only major league game, and it remains one of the heartwarming moments in baseball history.

headline: For Bernanke, a Question of Toughness
text: Is the Federal Reserve’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, too nice for the job?

headline: Artemis and Stag at Met Museum
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is the new (if temporary) home of “Artemis and the Stag,” below, the 2,000-year-old classical bronze sculpture that sold last year for a record $28.6 million at a Sotheby’s auction in New York. The sculpture, sold by the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo to an unidentified private collector for the highest price ever paid for a sculpture or antiquity at auction, will be on view for six months in the Leon Levy and Shelby White Court (the central atrium in the new Greek and Roman Galleries).

headline: Manhattan: Republican Ex-Official Sentenced
text: A former chairman of the Manhattan Republican Committee was sentenced on Wednesday in State Supreme Court to five years’ probation for violations of tax and state ethics laws, prosecutors said. The former chairman, James A. Ortenzio, pleaded guilty in November to tax evasion and violating disclosure laws for public officials. Mr. Ortenzio, who also served as chairman of the Hudson River Park Trust, failed to disclose about $180,000 in income in 2004 and 2005, prosecutors said. As part of the plea deal, Mr. Ortenzio agreed to pay back taxes and penalties.

headline: 3 Groups Lend Names to Suit Asking Release of Database
text: Three groups, including The New York Times, have filed papers in support of a lawsuit seeking to have the police make public a database of officers’ recordings on more than 850,000 stops of civilians between January 2006 and September of last year.

headline: London Art Show to Proceed
text: The Royal Academy of Arts in London announced on Wednesday that it had received official approval from Russia for the loan of its art for the exhibition “French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925 From Moscow and St. Petersburg.” The show is scheduled to run from Jan. 26 through April 18. Russia had cast the show in doubt while seeking assurances that none of the 120 paintings would be seized to satisfy possible claims that they had been confiscated by the state after the 1917 revolution.

headline: Bank of England Resists Calls for a Rate Cut
text: LONDON  The Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged Thursday, resisting calls this week from politicians and businesses that it cut borrowing costs among fears of slowing economic growth in Britain.

headline: Keeping the Housing Slump at Bay
text: THE housing slump has exacted its toll on everyone from banks and Wall Street firms to builders and mortgage brokers. But there are the exceptions, the entrepreneurs who either have long experience in real estate or have carved out a special niche. So far, they have been able to ride out the worst.

headline: Same Old Electronics Show, With Some Intriguing New Ideas
text: One million exhibitors. Sixty million attendees. Four trillion booths spread across an area the size of Rhode Island.

headline: Study Suggests That Amputee Holds an Unfair Advantage
text: The Olympic aspirations of Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, may end soon. Track and field’s world governing body is expected to announce that he is ineligible to race against able-bodied athletes because his state-of-the-art prosthetics give him an unfair advantage.

headline: City Council Passes Bill for Recycling of Plastic Bags
text: The stash under the sink grows inexorably: bags from Duane Reade and D’Agostino, bags from Home Depot and the health food store. Wadded up, stuffed one inside the other, they explode out of the cabinet as you wonder how you’ll ever get around to using all of them.

headline: On Gossage’s Plaque, a Yankee Cap
text: Rich Gossage will wear a Yankees cap when he enters the Baseball Hall of Fame. The announcement was made at a news conference in New York on Wednesday, one day after Gossage was the only player elected by the Baseball Writers’ Association of America in the 2008 class.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,901 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday and Tuesday:

headline: Gov. Spitzer Tries Nice
text: After six rocky months feuding with Republicans, Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York on Wednesday laid out ambitious goals for his second year in office  all in a new and welcome diplomatic style. The centerpiece is a plan to upgrade the state’s uneven public university system with a $4 billion state endowment and a $3 billion “innovation” fund to encourage academic work that also helps the economy statewide. A public university system truly worthy of New York is certainly long overdue.

headline: A Simpler Digital S.L.R. Camera That Borrows Features From Its High-End Big Brother
text: When Sony entered the digital single-lens reflex camera business in 2006, it did not reinvent the category. Its first offering, the A100, was essentially a well-received refinement of the technology it acquired after Konica-Minolta abandoned the photography business. The A200, which will be available next month, takes things a step further.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Weekend Explorer column on Dec. 14, about the Upper East Side, misstated the history of the name of the Yorkville area. Historians believe it was named for the Duke of York (later King James II), as were New York City and State. It was not named for Sgt. Alvin C. York, the World War I hero. (York Avenue was named for him.) The column also misidentified the borough in which Woody Allen, a longtime Upper East Side resident, was born. It was the Bronx  not Brooklyn, the borough in which he grew up.

headline: Justices Question Validity of Voter I.D. Case
text: WASHINGTON  There are many ways to lose a Supreme Court case, and by the end of an argument before the court on Wednesday, the Democrats who are challenging Indiana’s voter-identification law appeared poised to lose theirs in a potentially sweeping way, with implications for many future election cases.

headline: Snow Day
text: Burning calories in the snow doesn't always have to burn a hole in your wallet. This Saturday, Jan. 12, is Winter Trails Day, when rookies can try out cross-country skiing and snowshoeing for free at nearly 100 cross-country centers, parks and recreation areas in 24 states.

headline: 4 Say Marines Took Fire in Attack by Afghans
text: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C.  Marines from an elite combat unit who American military commanders said killed 19 Afghan civilians last year after a suicide bomb attack withstood hostile gunfire immediately after the explosion, witnesses testified on Wednesday.

headline: Target’s Chief Plans to Retire
text: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)  In a long-expected move, the Target Corporation, the discount retailer, said on Wednesday that its chief executive, Robert J. Ulrich, will retire May 1 and will be succeeded by the company’s president, Gregg W. Steinhafel.

headline: Getting It Wrong
text: Washington

headline: Great Lawn Just Got Better, Park Visitors Agree
text: One day after the city rescinded a regulation that had limited the size of the crowds allowed on the Great Lawn in Central Park, there were no blankets, no tents, no fans with picnic baskets  and no picnic baskets, either. And no Paul Simon, no giant stages and no giant video monitors, as there were when Mr. Simon appeared there in 1991.

headline: Spain Says 2 Confessed to 2006 Airport Bombing
text: MADRID  Two men accused of being members of a militant Basque separatist group who were arrested last weekend have confessed to carrying out the December 2006 bomb attack on Madrid’s airport that killed two people and shattered peace talks with the militant group, the government said Wednesday.

headline: Finding Missing Gmail Messages
text: Q. I use Gmail and have turned on the POP3 function to download messages to my computer. I sometimes check mail on the Web version of Gmail, but I notice that messages I download don’t show up in my online in-box. Is there a way to keep all the mail on the Web, too?

headline: Taxpayer Advocate Urges ‘Apology Payments’
text: Taxpayers who endure excessive expense or drain on their time when the Internal Revenue Service mishandles a case should receive “apology payments” of up to $1,000 each, the national taxpayer advocate told Congress on Wednesday.

headline: 2005 Use of Gas by Blackwater Leaves Questions
text: WASHINGTON  The helicopter was hovering over a Baghdad checkpoint into the Green Zone, one typically crowded with cars, Iraqi civilians and United States military personnel.

headline: Radiohead Finds Sales, Even After Downloads
text: LOS ANGELES  In a twist for the music industry’s digital revolution, “In Rainbows,” the new Radiohead album that attracted wide attention when it was made available three months ago as a digital download for whatever price fans chose to pay, ranked as the top-selling album in the country this week after the CD version hit record shops and other retailers.

headline: From Palestinians, Harsh View of Bush
text: JERICHO, West Bank  President Bush will not be coming to this oasis city of beige hills, lush green plantations and ancient ruins on his visit to the Palestinian Authority on Thursday. Given the apparent antipathy of the local population, it is probably just as well.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Is Ethanol for Everybody?
text: CAMPOS, Brazil

headline: In Patriots’ Season to Remember, a Teammate Is Not Forgotten
text: In one of their last telephone conversations, Marquise Hill confided in his mother, Sherry. Back in his native Louisiana for a weeklong visit before the New England Patriots’ June minicamp, Hill, a 24-year-old reserve defensive lineman, said: “Momma, guess what. I feel like we’re going to be unstoppable.”

headline: New Penalties Set as Bush Calls Iran a Threat to Peace
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush charged Wednesday that Iran remained “a threat to world peace” as the Treasury Department imposed strict economic penalties on a top Iranian military commander, a Syrian-based television station and three militants in the region accused of helping the insurgency in Iraq.

headline: Durant Plays, but Seattle Is No Match for the Nets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets’ funk did not last long. One night after a 115-99 loss at Charlotte threatened to halt their momentum, the Nets rebounded with a 99-88 victory against the Seattle SuperSonics at the Izod Center. It was their sixth victory in their last seven games.

headline: You Can Go Home Again, but Why?
text: TOKYO

headline: Judges Tell San Francisco It Can Begin Health Plan
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal panel of judges granted San Francisco the right on Wednesday to put in place a key part of its universal health care program as legal arguments about the first-in-the-nation plan continue.

headline: Justices Indicate They May Uphold Voter ID Rules
text: WASHINGTON  There are many ways to lose a Supreme Court case, and by the end of an argument that was before the court on Wednesday, the Democrats who were challenging Indiana’s voter-identification law appeared poised to lose theirs in a potentially sweeping way, with implications for many future election cases.

headline: Strike Nips Awards Show
text: The two-month-old writers strike took a significant toll on the “People’s Choice Awards” on Tuesday as the taped, scaled-down version of the awards show on CBS lost nearly half its audience compared with a year ago, attracting just 6 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., Nielsen reported. A year ago, the show’s live broadcast averaged 11.3 million. For the night, CBS ranked third overall, trailing second-place Fox with its all-repeat lineup. NBC finished first, leading every hour of the night among adults 18 to 49 with a two-hour episode of “The Biggest Loser” (10.2 million), followed by “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 10 (15.2 million). CW delivered its best Tuesday ratings since March thanks to “One Tree Hill,” which averaged 3.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 in its fifth-season debut. ABC trailed CW in last place among adults 18 to 49.

headline: U.N. Official Warns of Darfur Failure
text: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations top peacekeeping official told the Security Council on Wednesday that obstructionism by the Sudanese government, the failure of other countries to supply needed transportation equipment, and continued violence threatened to doom the mission of the freshly deployed peacekeeping force in Darfur.

headline: Delta Chief to Seek Merger Talks
text: The chief executive of Delta Air Lines plans to ask the company’s board for permission to enter into formal merger talks with both Northwest Airlines and United Airlines, a person close to Delta said on Thursday.

headline: Now That Romo Has Rested, Critics Ask if He’s Ready
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants Coach Tom Coughlin was asked to describe the blooming and well-documented relationship involving one of the quarterbacks in Sunday’s playoff game with the Cowboys.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Intel Gets New York Subpoena in Antitrust Inquiry
text: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York issued a wide-ranging subpoena to the Intel Corporation on Thursday as part of an investigation into whether the company violated federal or state antitrust laws in the way it priced and sold microprocessors.

headline: 4 Children Flung From Bridge, Police Say
text: Search and rescue crews scanned coastal waters off Alabama on Wednesday for the bodies of four young children believed to have been tossed off a bridge by their father after a domestic dispute.

headline: Military Leaders Seek 3,000 More Troops for Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON  Senior military officers will soon propose deploying about 3,000 additional American troops to Afghanistan, where the NATO-led security and stabilization effort is short of combat forces and trainers, Pentagon officials said Wednesday.

headline: VoIP Backups for Power Failures
text: Q. Is it true that you lose VoIP phone service if there’s a power failure? What can you do if it happens and you don’t have a mobile phone to fall back on?

headline: Analyzing the New Hampshire Surprise
text: The morning after Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton claimed victory in the New Hampshire Democratic primary, many pollsters and news organizations plunged themselves into a post-mortem centered on a single question: How could they have not seen it coming?

headline: Richardson Said to Be Dropping Out
text: Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico is pulling out of the presidential race, after coming in fourth in both the New Hampshire primary and the Iowa caucuses, according to people with knowledge of his decision.

headline: Oo-rah! A Squad of Actors Takes Lanford Wilson to the Marines
text: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif.  Adam Driver, former Marine lance corporal, First Battalion, First Marine Regiment, Weapons Company, 81st Platoon, remembers two shows he saw while stationed here on this sprawling base north of San Diego. There was a skateboarder who performed tricks. And a performance by the San Diego Chargers cheerleaders.

headline: Manhattan: Rather’s CBS Suit Proceeds
text: A state judge ordered on Wednesday that parties to a lawsuit filed by Dan Rather against CBS, Viacom and executives of the companies prepare to share evidence. Mr. Rather filed the suit in September, saying that CBS violated his contract by giving him insufficient air time as a correspondent after forcing him to step down as anchor of “CBS Evening News.” The suit also asserted that CBS conducted a flawed inquiry into a controversial report by Mr. Rather about President Bush’s National Guard service that the network concluded was based on documents that could not be authenticated. CBS said Mr. Rather’s accusations were without merit and asked in November that the lawsuit be dismissed. Justice Ira Gammerman of State Supreme Court said on Wednesday that the parties should share evidence while he considered parts of the motion, and ordered lawyers to reconvene in two weeks.

headline: Apple to Cut the Prices of iTunes in Britain
text: LONDON  Apple said on Wednesday that it had agreed to cut the prices on its iTunes digital music store in Britain to align them with those on the Continent, settling an antitrust case brought by European regulators.

headline: Toy Makers Mount Drive to Salvage China’s Safety Reputation
text: HONG KONG  Jay Horowitz, owner of American Classic Toy, started putting a prominent notice last October on all his products, most of them made in China, stating that they contained no lead-based paint.

headline: Bush Begins Peace Effort Bonded With Olmert
text: JERUSALEM  They share an enthusiasm for sports, fitness and the occasional cigar. They are both unpopular leaders, scarred by terrorism and zealous in their warnings about the threat of Islamic extremism. And yet they profess grand ambitions to accomplish what other leaders have failed to do for decades: make peace between the Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: No New Trial for Former Chief of Brocade
text: SAN FRANCISCO (Bloomberg News)  The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Gregory L. Reyes, who was convicted in August of stock-options manipulation, is not entitled to a new trial, a federal judge ruled Wednesday, rejecting arguments that new evidence had emerged.

headline: A ’70s-Style Brawl in Russia
text: We’re filing this under “Championship Week” because Ak Bars Kazan are techinically a championship team, having won the Continental Cup last weekend in Riga. But look what happened upon their return to the Russian Superliga on Tuesday night — they started a full-fledged ’70s-vintage, bench-clearing brawl with Traktor Chelyabinsk, which you can see in its entirety on the Telekanal web site here, or, if you prefer, below:

headline: College Matchup of the Week
text: Wisconsin’s Kyle Turris (Phoenix Coyotes) and Denver’s Rhett Rakhshani (Islanders) and Tyler Ruegsegger (Maple Leafs) are going to get sick of seeing one another. Last week they faced off wearing the jerseys of Canada and the United States, when Turris’s Canadian squad drubbed Rakhshani, Ruegsegger and their fellow Americans in a 4-1, semifinal win at the World Junior Championship in the Czech Republic.

headline: Fight in the Stands!
text: While the players were brawling in Kazan, in St. Petersburg the fans were doing the brawling. This was the scene Tuesday at the SKA St. Petersburg-Spartak Moscow match at the Ice Palace:

headline: The World According to Bob Clarke
text: Bob Clarke, the Flyers senior VP, went on TSN’s “Off the Record,” where he told the host Michael Landsberg that Steve Downie’s hit on Dean McAmmond wasn’t so bad and that Jason Blake deserved to be sucker punched for saying Downie deserved a lifetime ban for the McAmmond hit.

headline: Dress Codes | Ditching the Suit, The Vest Struts Its Stuff
text: The vest has divorced itself from the three-piece suit.

headline: Masks at James Cohan Gallery
text: Images from the group show.

headline: The Green Reaper
text: From Reuters:

headline: Physical Culture | Gear Test, Cross-Country Skis
text: Drew Gelinas, nordic skier, tests cross-country skis.

headline: Your Daily Commute?
text: Image found here.

headline: Tom Cruise, the Early Years
text: The new Tom Cruise bio by Andrew Morton may face legal action, but not for spreading gay rumors about his schoolboy years. From our review of the book:

headline: Who’s Next for the Deal Dead Pool?
text: Reddy Ice on Wednesday announced that it was in price renegotiations with respect to its pending $1.1 billion purchase by GSO Capital Partners. The announcement comes as the February 3, 2008, termination date for the transaction fast approaches. GSO must decide prior to that date whether to commit to the transaction if it can obtain financing, or terminate on that date and pay a $21 million termination fee. In the latter event, GSO may claim a material adverse change to Reddy Ice under the terms of the merger agreement in order to escape even paying the $21 million reverse termination fee.

headline: Launching cars on the Internet – and beyond
text: A couple of hours ago the Toyota Formula One team launched its presentation of the 2008 racing car live on the Internet. At 7 PM Indian Standard Time this evening the Force India team will launch its car live on the net, presenting its new car and drivers (with the surprise announcement of Giancarlo Fisichella signing on as the second driver already being scooped by Vijay Mallya in today’s Gazzetta dello Sport newspaper in Italy). BMW Sauber also just announced today that its car launch will be done with live streaming on the BMW Sauber team’s Internet site next Monday at noon. They will also put up a film of the launch later on, at 2:30 in the afternoon on Monday.

headline: Tony Blair to Join JPMorgan as Adviser
text: The former prime minister of Britain, Tony Blair, will join the banking giant JPMorgan Chase as a part-time adviser, the bank said.

headline: F.C.C. Backs $2.7 Billion Verizon Sale in 3 States
text: Federal communications regulators on Wednesday cleared the way for Verizon Communications to sell its phone lines in three New England states for $2.7 billion to FairPoint Communications.

headline: No New Trial for Former Chief of Brocade
text: The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Gregory L. Reyes, who was convicted in August of stock-options manipulation, is not entitled to a new trial, a federal judge ruled Wednesday, rejecting arguments that new evidence had emerged.

headline: Greenberg Shifts Tone About A.I.G. Moves
text: Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, said on Wednesday that a group he represents did not intend to solicit proxies from A.I.G. shareholders, buy more A.I.G. shares or start a tender offer for the company.

headline: Bayhill Therapeutics Aims to Raise $86.3 Million in I.P.O.
text: Bayhill Therapeutics said Wednesday it plans an initial public offering of its common stock, but the biopharmaceutical company did not disclose any terms in its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Merrill Fires 8 London Bankers, Report Says
text: In what may be John Thain’s latest housekeeping effort since taking the helm at Merrill Lynch, the world’s biggest brokerage reportedly fired at least eight bankers in London from a group that sold asset-backed debt and invested the firm’s money.

headline: Among V.C.’s, Talk of a Green Bubble Arises
text: Egged on by $100-a-barrel oil and consumers going green, venture capitalists plan to pour ever more cash into environmentally friendly technology this year, prompting talk of a bubble reminiscent of the dot-com era.

headline: Affiliated Computer Signs Deal for Britain’s Syan
text: Affiliated Computer Services said Wednesday that it had purchased Syan Holdings Limited, an information technology outsourcing firm based in England, for about $60 million.

headline: Aruba Picks Up AirWave
text: Aruba Networks, the wireless-networking company, announced on Wednesday that it would buy a multi-vendor network management company, AirWave Wireless, for $37 million in cash and stock.

headline: NYSE Said to Be in Deal Talks With Amex
text: The parent of the New York Stock Exchange is reportedly in talks to acquire a longtime rival, the smaller American Stock Exchange, in a deal that may fetch as much as $350 million.

headline: Time Warner Goes Virtual with Gaia Bet
text: Time Warner is joining media heavyweights like Walt Disney, Viacom and Sony in making financial bets on online virtual worlds, The New York Post reported.

headline: Target’s Chief Plans to Retire
text: In a long-expected move, Target, the discount retailer, said on Wednesday that its chief executive, Robert J. Ulrich, will retire May 1 and will be succeeded by the company’s president, Gregg W. Steinhafel.

headline: Ackman Raises Stake in Struggling Borders
text: The hedge fund manager William Ackman has raised his stake in the Borders Group, the bookstore chain, to 22 percent, even as the company’s shares languish near 52-week lows.

headline: Microsoft M&A Guru to Leave
text: A day after signing a $1.2 billion deal to buy a Norwegian search company, Fast Search and Transfer, Microsoft confirmed that Bruce Jaffe, the firm’s mergers and acquisitions architect, will be leaving the company at the end of February.

headline: Colony Said to Bid For Tropicana Casino
text: Colony Capital, the private equity owner of the Resorts casino in Atlantic City, N.J., and a Resorts executive, Nick Ribis, have offered to buy the troubled Tropicana Casino and Resort for $850 million in cash, according to The New Jersey Star-Ledger.

headline: BofA’s Tough Countrywide Choice
text: As it watches its $2 billion investment in Countrywide Financial erode, the Bank of America faces a tough choice, says Fortune: It can buy Countrywide outright, pour even more money into the once high-flying mortgage lender, or simply bide its time and hope for the best.

headline: Judge May Let Rather’s Lawsuit Proceed
text: Colin Moynihan reports:

headline: Classic Game Shows Have Viewers Playing ‘What’s My Vintage?’
text: A popular block of programs, in glorious black and white, has returned to the GSN cable network.

headline: Investment Group Raises Stake in CNet
text: An investment group led by Jana Partners that wants to shake up CNet Networks has increased its holdings in the online technology news and entertainment provider in an effort to overcome the company’s resistance to a proposed overhaul of its board.

headline: Reddy Ice in Talks With Hedge Fund on New Buyout Terms
text: Reddy Ice Holdings, a producer of packaged ice, said Wednesday that it was in talks to revise a $1.1 billion deal to be bought by a hedge fund, GSO Capital Partners.

headline: Analysts and Union Fuel Delta Deal Speculation
text: Two separate analysts reports released Wednesday suggesting that a merger is in the cards for Delta Air Lines may have convinced at least one Delta employee.

headline: Give Us Your Romo Headlines
text: For the reader participation part of our program, we’re asking readers to predict the Cowboys-Giants game by sending in a Tony Romo headline.

headline: RiskMetrics Eyes $306 Million I.P.O.
text: RiskMetrics Group, the parent of the proxy advisory service Institutional Shareholder Services, has set a price range for its initial public offering, which could raise up to $306 million.

headline: Remembering the Old, Gritty Hell’s Kitchen
text: After his roommate, Virgilio Cintron, died, James O’Hare, 65, and another friend, David Daloia, 65, dressed Mr. Cintron’s corpse, carried him down a flight of stairs and heaved his body into a computer chair with wheels. Outside, they rolled him over the uneven sidewalk, pulling the chair toward Pay-O-Matic, a check-cashing shop on Ninth Avenue, seeking to cash Mr. Cintron’s Social Security check. A crowd gathered, a police detective eating his lunch called the authorities and soon the men were arrested.

headline: Logitech Shares Jump on Microsoft Bid Rumors
text: Shares in the Swiss-based computer peripherals maker Logitech International rose more than 12 percent on Thursday amid speculation Microsoft would make a takeover bid, traders told Reuters. Spokesmen for Logitech, the world’s largest maker of computer mice, and Microsoft were not immediately reachable for comment.

headline: An Upstart in Films With Many Fast Moves
text: With a mix of commercial comedies and dramas, indies and genre films, Overture Films, an upstart studio backed by John C. Malone, is fast entering a movie marketplace that is bursting at the seams with new players, releasing an ever-growing number of films vying for limited audiences.

headline: Blackstone to Buy GSO Capital

headline: Living With Fluorescent Light (or No Light)
text: Julie Scelfo, a reporter for our Home section, recently sent me a note saying she was eager to hear about people’s experiences with compact fluorescent bulbs and other low-energy lighting. I put up a post and Dot Earth readers responded in droves with comments about their good, bad, and ugly experiences. There is a strong sense that these bulbs are a transitional technology, but that lighting will be less and less of a drain on the grid after a century of incandescent convenience.

headline: News Corp. Says It Isn’t Bidding for Monster

headline: Scent Notes | Mandorlo di Sicilia by Acqua di Parma
text: There are perfumes built in the classic French fashion, with shiny exteriors of gold and titanium. Wearing them is like wearing a brilliant Cartier ring inlaid with diamonds. You wear these fragrances to show them off. (The French value: the brilliance and ego of the artist.) There are American perfumes that smell like a handsome, showered baseball player, sporty, young and relaxed, and you wear these to assume that identity, as you might wear a polo shirt with a country club logo. (The American genius: self-invention.) Then there are perfumes in the Italian style — often lemon/bergamot citrus scents — that serve as luxury ID badges, and one wears these as one would a beautifully-made Italian dress shirt, to say, “Admire my level of comfort and elegance.” (The Italian obsession: status and the identification of one’s social group.)

headline: ECC, Day 1: Sparta 5-3 Karpat; Magnitka 3-0 MoDo
