headline: Tata Motors Unveils $2,500 Car
text: Ratan Tata, chairman of Tata Motors, displaying the Nano in New Delhi on Thursday. (Photo by Money Sharma/European Pressphoto Association)  Video  Tata Motors today took the covers off the world's cheapest car -- the Nano.  Over the past year, Tata has been building hype for a car that would cost a mere 100,000 rupees (roughly $2,500) and bring automotive transportation to the mainstream Indian population. It has been nicknamed the "People's Car." Over the course of the New Delhi Auto Expo, which began this week, anticipation had grown to fever pitch.  With the theme from "2001: A Space Odyssey" playing, Ratan Tata, chairman of Tata Motors drove the small white bubble car onto Tata's show stage, where it joined two others.  The Tata Nano could sell for around $2,500. (Photo by Raveendran/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images)  "They are not concept cars, they are not prototypes," Mr. Tata announced when he got out of the car. "They are the production cars that will roll out of the Singur plant later this year."  The four-door Nano is a little over 10 feet long and nearly 5 feet wide. It is powered by a 623cc two-cylinder engine at the back of the car. With 33 horsepower, the Nano is capable of 65 miles an hour. Its four small wheels are at the absolute corners of the car to improve handling. There is a small trunk, big enough for a duffel bag.   "Today, we indeed have a People’s Car, which is affordable and yet built to meet safety requirements and emission norms, to be fuel efficient and low on emissions," Mr. Tata added. "We are happy to present the People’s Car to India and we hope it brings the joy, pride and utility of owning a car to many families who need personal mobility.”  The base price for the Nano will be 120,000 rupees, including road tax and delivery. Higher level models will cost more and come with air-conditioning. Sun visors and radios are extra.  The nearest priced competitor is the Maruti 800, which costs roughly twice as much as the Nano. In comparing the Nano to the Maruti 800, Mr. Tata said, "It is 8 percent smaller -- bumper to bumper -- and has 21 percent larger seating capacity than Maruti 800."  The Hindustan Times reports reactions from a couple of Tata's competitors, Maruti and Hyundai:   Jagdish Khattar, a former head of Maruti 800 manufacturer Maruti Udyog Ltd., says it's too early to say whether the Nano will overtake the original.  "It's a good product but it's still too early to say whether it will overtake the 800 because it caters to a totally new market segment," he said while watching a live telecast of Tata's press conference after unveiling of the Nano.  But clearly, at least one other manufacturer was worried.  An official of Hyundai Motors, which unveiled an LPG version of its Santro Thursday, was more circumspect.  "We definitely see it as impacting our sales," he said in halting English, preferring to maintain anonymity.    Anand Mahindra, managing director for Mahindra & Mahindra, Tata Motors' primary competitor, said before the unveiling, "I think it's a moment of history and I'm delighted an Indian company is leading the way."  The Nano will go on sale in India later this year with an initial production run of 250,000 a year. Tata says it will offer the Nano in other emerging markets in Latin America, Southeast Asia and Africa within four years.  Related:    Slide Show: Highlights From the New Delhi Auto Expo  With Cars in Reach, Indians Must Learn to Drive (January 11, 2008)  Four Wheels for the Masses: The $2,500 Car (January 8, 2008)  In India, More Cars, Going Faster (December 7, 2007)  In India, a $2,500 Pace Car (October 12, 2007)  India’s $2,500 Car (June 22, 2007)

headline: If Nice Guys Finish Last…
text: “Belichick’s career is a tricky thing to weigh, especially to those of us who admire the old econ major’s application of reason to football, but who despair at his fetish for brutal efficiency in a game that has no shortage of brutality,” Tommy Craggs writes in this week’s Play newsletter. “It is a dehumanizing way to run a team in our most dehumanizing sport. Alas, in the modern N.F.L., it is also the most effective.”

headline: HD DVDs Fall Like Dominoes
text: Nothing has been announced, but Variety is reporting that the last two major studios backing HD DVD — NBC Universal and Paramount — are opening the door for a switch to Blu-ray. These studios have commitments to release some discs this year in HD DVD, but both have ended their exclusive commitment to that format, which is backed by a group led by Toshiba.

headline: See Rudy Run — Or Not
text: The story in New Hampshire this week was, of course, all about the stunning revivals of Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain. Buried a little further down the scoreboard, though, was another sign of just how fluid and unpredictable presidential politics can be. After winning just 5 percent of the vote in Iowa, Rudolph W. Giuliani managed a fourth place finish in New Hampshire, barely edging out Ron Paul (who had edged him out in the caucuses). To put this another way, the hero of September 11, the man they call “America’s Mayor,” is now battling to put some distance between himself and the former standard-bearer of the Libertarian Party, who would abolish most of the federal government.

headline: Same Time, Next Year
text: The world won’t come to an end because the Golden Globes are kaput. In any case, Steven Spielberg needn’t worry, the Baguette says. He had been voted this year’s Cecil B. DeMille Award for lifetime achievement, but the Hollywood Foreign Press Association has postponed conferring the honor till next year’s show. By then, presumably, labor and management will have settled their differences, so Mr. Spielberg will be able to receive his award with all the usual hoopla.

headline: Cash, Credit or Euro?

headline: New Yorkers, You May Be Excused: A Pay Toilet Opens
text: Few toilets — if any — have ever received the level of government and media fanfare that greeted the new public pay potty that opened today in Madison Square Park. First, the full force of New York City’s newspapers, television and radio were there to tape, record and take notes on the first flushes. Second, the toilet is the product of an on-and-off decades efforts (detailed below) by city officials to, uh, serve the needs of New Yorkers.So it was understandable that the city officials reveled in the toilet paper roll-cutting ceremony (which, fittingly, they did with their hands) on Madison Avenue, between 23rd and 24th Streets. But they couldn’t resist the temptation of scatological humor: “No. 1!” (Janette Sadik-Khan, transportation commissioner), “in loo of” (Adrian Benepe, parks commissioner), “doesn’t block pedestrian movement” (Daniel L. Doctoroff, outgoing deputy mayor for economic development).

headline: Cadwalader to Lay Off 35 Lawyers

The white-shoe law firm, which does a big business advising on asset securitizations, said Thursday that it would lay off 35 lawyers in the United States. That is nearly 5 percent of the roughly 720 attorneys at the New York-based firm.

He will instead focus on Michigan and hopes that his absence means Senator John McCain and Mike Huckabee will finally have to engage each other in a street fight to win the Palmetto State.

headline: Cuomo’s Choice Words
text: Andrew Cuomo, New York’s attorney general and a Hillary Clinton supporter, had this to say about the early, small-state primaries in a radio interview: “It’s not a TV crazed race. Frankly you can’t buy your way into it … You can’t shuck and jive at a press conference. You can’t just put off reporters, because you have real people looking at you saying answer the question, you know, and all those moves you can make with the press don’t work when you’re in someone’s living room.”

headline: A New Take on the Old Math
text: For those of you who read yesteday’s non-explainer explainer on the Academy voting system and wondered if the Bagger was using some trendy new designer drugs, Variety has a much more comprehensive take that should satisfy your innermost wonk. And just in case it doesn’t, spend a little time with EW’s explication. Pay special attention to the section on “magic numbers” because there will be a quiz later. Thanks to AwardsDaily for both of the points.

headline: Huckabee’s Michigan Ad
text: There may be no better place than Michigan (uh, other than the entire Rust Belt), where the line former Gov. Mike Huckabee has perfected about knowing the guy you work with, rather than the guy who laid you off, will resonate. It’s all part of his portrayal as the candidate who represents the common man, the worker-bee (pardon yet another variation on his name), and so not reflective of the corporate executive like his rival, Mitt Romney.

headline: For The Moment | NY Artists Alight in Florence
text: This week’s guest blogger is the New York-based men’s wear designer Adam Kimmel. Known for his heady brand of cerebral machismo — Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock are recurring inspirations — Kimmel, 28, is filing from Florence, Italy, where he is the featured designer at the men’s-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo. In this post, Kimmel writes about the arrival in Florence of a group of downtown artists he’s invited to be the models for his dinner at the Istituto d’arte on Thursday evening.

headline: On the Road Toward One Billion Cars
text: Hold on to your steering wheel. India – where roads are already in near-constant gridlock — took a big step toward mainstreaming car culture, and sending the world on a path to surpass 1 billion cars by 2020, with the unveiling of the $2,500 Nano. The vest-pocket four-seater has an engine barely bigger than those powering some American lawn mowers.

headline: The Noise from Brazil | Fashion Rio
text: If you think the mania surrounding a Marc Jacbos show is the ultimate in fashion insanity, then try getting into Colcci, Brazil’s popular high street label and the hottest ticket in town at Fashion Rio, which is underway this week in Rio de Janeiro. On Tuesday night the scene outside the Centro Cultural da Açäo was sheer chaos, as a conga line of gawkers, guests and gorgeous girls and boys tried to gain access. The show started more than an hour late and when Brazil’s perpetual top model, Gisele Bundchen, took to the rotating circular catwalk, the crowd went as wild as any soccer mob at Maracanã stadium. As an outsider, it was confusing why such banal clothes (imagine a Dsquared and Cavalli collaborative capsule collection for H&M) could inspire such a frenzied reaction.

headline: Lo-Fi
text: The Bagger, oh the shame of it, is a big fan of twee-core, that musically challenged warbling and strumming whose only value is its ability to produce ersatz emotion between the ears of the listener. headline: Team USA: There Goes the Love
text: When U.S. Coach John Hynes first faced his team for the World Junior Championship at camp in Ann Arbor, Mich., last month he stressed togetherness. He told the team to stretch as a group, eat as a group and dress as a group.

headline: Update: $124 Million for Ovechkin
text: The Washington Capitals’ majority owner and chief blogger, Ted Leonsis, put his money where his keyboard is, signing his electrifying young star, Alex Ovechkin, to a 13-year contract extension. The Associated Press reported that the deal is worth $124 million, the richest in NHL history.

headline: Ranking Banks for a Different Kind of Green
text: Has the green movement finally begun to take hold of the bottom-line-driven banking industry?

headline: Bill Richardson, Seeing Good in Everyone
text: In his years as a diplomatic negotiator, Bill Richardson learned to never offend anyone and to look for something positive in each individual. So as Mr. Richardson, New Mexico’s governor, ended his presidential bid Thursday, before about 300 well-wishers at the Statehouse in Santa Fe, he had a nice word for the candidates in the Democratic field. Yes, even for former Senator Mike Gravel of Alaska, who is still in the race.

headline: NPR Cancels Republican Debate
text: Last week, candidates were complaining about their not being included in some debates. This week, low attendance is forcing National Public Radio to cancel its forum with the Republican candidates in Columbia, S.C.

headline: The Carpetbagger
text: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) attends the New York Film Critics Circle Awards with Sarah Polley, director of the lauded "Away From Her."

headline: Live Blogging the G.O.P. Debate
text: 10:58 | Wrapping It Up This debate was a bit of a hard slog, mostly a repetition of talking points with a few sharp elbows thrown in.

headline: McCain on Iraq
text: John McCain answers a question from an anti-war voter at the Opera House in Derry, N.H.

headline: Video: The New York Film Critics Circle Awards
Remembering Sir Edmund Hillary
text: Sir Edmund Hillary, who won worldwide acclaim in 1953 by becoming the first to scale the summit of Mount Everest, has died.

headline: Emotion Without Thought in New Hampshire
text: On the morning after the New Hampshire primary, CNN’s John Roberts interviewed Marianne Pernold Young, the woman whose coffee shop question — “How do you do it? How do you keep upbeat and so wonderful?” — is largely credited with setting into motion Hillary Clinton’s surprise victory on Tuesday.

headline: Experiencing New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS — It would be easy for fans to visit this city for a big game and completely miss the bigger picture.

headline: Have $2.7 Million? Buy The Last Super Bowl Ad
text: Fox Broadcasting “has sold all but one of the 63 30-second commercials that it plans to run” during the Super Bowl on Feb. 3, Stuart Elliott reports in Friday’s New York Times. “The average cost of each 30 seconds of commercial time is estimated at $2.7 million, compared with $2.6 million for spots in Super Bowl XLI in February 2007.”

headline: Spain Buyers Heading Inland
text: Buyers in Spain are looking inland for genuine Spanish settings and better deals, according to the latest trends report from Kyero.com, the property site. Country homes accounted for 27 percent of the searches on the site, compared to only seven percent for apartments.

headline: A Ploy for ‘Uncommitted’ in Michigan
text: Rarely do people work so hard to drum up votes for no one in particular.

headline: Best of the Romo Headlines (So Far)
text: Announcing the first round of eliminations. We received more than 100 submissions, but some had to be deleted for taste.

headline: Jessica Isn’t the Only Distraction: Futures of Favre and Dungy Make News
text: The second-round playoff games are set to begin Saturday, but a few big-name participants in this weekend’s games spent a lot of time Thursday talking about next season instead. In an article in The Sun Herald of Biloxi, Miss., Brett Favre sure sounded as if he planned to play another season. “For the first time in three years, I haven’t thought this could be my last game,” he said. “I would like to continue longer.” And he has the endorsement of his daughters: “Breleigh then spoke up and said, ‘Dad, don’t retire.’ And Brittany said, ‘Dad, I think you need to play one more year.”‘

headline: Q & A With John Branch
text: New York Times reporter John Branch makes his living asking the tough questions. That’s how he is able to write about the big issues in the National Football League such as Tony Romo’s playoff preparation regimen and the Giants’ re-inherited, always-welcome underdog status heading in to Sunday’s N.F.C. playoff game in Dallas.

headline: Manhattan: Labor Leader’s Trial Delayed
text: The federal trial of Brian M. McLaughlin, the former president of the New York City Central Labor Council, was pushed back on Thursday and is now scheduled to begin on March 10. Mr. McLaughlin, left, who is accused of illegally obtaining $2.2 million through embezzlement, fraud and bribes, was to have gone on trial in Federal District Court at the end of the month, but in court on Thursday, Judge Richard J. Sullivan said scheduling conflicts required a delay. Mr. McLaughlin, who is free on $250,000 bail, has been charged with stealing from his own organization, the State Assembly and a Little League team in Queens.

headline: Newark: Gang Sweep Nets 23 Arrests
text: About two dozen people suspected of being gang members were removed from Newark streets in a two-day sweep by F.B.I. agents and local law officers, the authorities said Thursday. Those arrested are believed to be members of a violent Bloods subset called 793 Bloods, and face weapons and drug-trafficking charges, the F.B.I. said. The gang controlled the sale of heroin and cocaine in part of the South Ward, officials said. The 23 people arrested this week are in addition to 16 arrested in the past two years as part of the same investigation, the F.B.I. said. Three others remain at large.

headline: Many Palestinians Offer a Bleak Opinion of Bush
text: JERICHO, West Bank  President Bush did not come to this oasis city of beige hills, lush green plantations and ancient ruins on his visit to the Palestinian Authority on Thursday. Given the apparent antipathy of the local population, it is probably just as well.

headline: Vincent Gruppuso, 67, Seller of Pudding Snacks, Dies
text: Vincent Gruppuso, the founder of Kozy Shack Enterprises, a company in Hicksville, Long Island, that sells millions of four-ounce cups of pudding, particularly rice pudding, at supermarkets in the United States, Canada, Mexico and Europe, died Dec. 29 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 67.

headline: Out West, Where the Ladies Are Consumptive and the Men Confused
text: “Comanche Moon,” a six-hour mini-series beginning Sunday on CBS, is based on Larry McMurtry’s novel of the same title, and begins as it ends, with the camera retreating from the image of a distraught child. Both the first boy and the second have lost their mothers to the ravages of the 19th-century Texas frontier.

headline: Leader of Microsoft’s Office Business Is Retiring
text: Jeffrey S. Raikes, a 26-year veteran of Microsoft and leader of the company’s lucrative Office business, plans to retire later this year. The company announced on Thursday that it was reaching outside its ranks for his successor, Stephen Elop, 44, the former chief operating officer of Juniper Networks.

headline: Iran Shows Its Own Video of Vessels’ Encounter in Gulf
text: WASHINGTON  Iran released its own video Thursday of the encounter on Sunday between Iranian patrol boats and American naval vessels in the Strait of Hormuz in an effort to show that no confrontation occurred.

headline: Ciao to a Met Prize Returning to Italy
text: In the coda to a long tug of war, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is bidding goodbye to the Euphronios krater, a 2,500-year-old vessel that has been a showpiece of its collection for more than three decades. Sunday is the last viewing day.

headline: If Nice Guys Finish Last...
text: Put me squarely in the minority, among the people who do not view Bill Belichick as the walking manifestation of evil or the Nixon White House or whatever those barking dogs are telling ESPN.com's Gregg Easterbrook to write these days. I care little about the New England coach's cinematography, less about his habit of running up points until the scoreboards say "tilt," and least of all about his churlishness with the same media scolds who reckon a postgame handshake a glimpse into a man's soul. He may not be the National Football League's warmest presence, but he is a very good coach of what may be the very best football team ever concocted, and once upon a time that would have been enough.

headline: 7 Indicted After Agent Gets Inside Cocaine Ring and the Ships It Used
text: To infiltrate the cocaine ring, the man had to make his way into the bowels of a cargo ship docked off Staten Island and retrieve a newspaper and a hat that had been hidden there at a stopover in Panama.

headline: North Korea: U.S. Suggests a New Nuclear Deadline
text: Christopher R. Hill, the State Department’s point man on North Korea, urged it to give a full accounting of its nuclear weapons programs before Lee Myung-bak, the new president of South Korea, who is inclined to offer the North more sticks and fewer carrots, takes office on Feb. 25. North Korea missed a year-end deadline for declaring its nuclear activities. After meeting with Mr. Lee in Seoul, Mr. Hill said while there had been “bumps in the road,” it would be “very desirable” if the process were finished by Mr. Lee’s swearing-in. Unlike the departing president, Roh Moo-hyun, Mr. Lee intends to make aid and economic exchanges conditional on nuclear compliance.

headline: The Game for Santana Is Stretching On
text: The most popular baseball game of the winter seems to be endless. If it were being played in July, it would be in extra innings, and the innings would be whizzing by with no end in sight.

headline: Top Prospect Suspended for Fighting
text: Lance Stephenson, a point guard from Coney Island who is considered a top national prospect in the class of 2009, was suspended from school for five days and will miss three games for his role in a fight with a teammate earlier this week.

headline: A Physician Caught Trying to Heal Himself
text: “Corpses had always made me queasy,” Sandeep Jauhar writes in “Intern,” the brutally frank chronicle of his medical apprenticeship. Dead bodies lead a long list of aversions. When giving a rectal examination to one patient, he turns aside and vomits. Unpleasant odors and icky tactile sensations disturb him.

headline: Annan to Help in Kenya, Group Says
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  With no sign of a breakthrough in the Kenyan political crisis, it appears that a high-profile mediator may be flying in to help: Kofi Annan.

headline: Buddy LeRoux, 77, Boston Sports Fixture, Is Dead
text: Edward LeRoux, a former trainer for the Boston Red Sox who rose to become a controversial part owner of the team while amassing a fortune in real estate, died Monday in Wolfeboro, N.H. He was 77 and lived nearby in Tuftonboro.

headline: Jones’s Soaring Career Now a Cautionary Tale
text: Once, Marion Jones ran through the streets for a commercial, her girl-next-door smile and spectacular talent sprinting across television screens throughout America. She would become the most glamorous Olympian in 2000, winning five medals, including three golds, and a rare track and field star who was a household name.

headline: A Hard Look at the Life of Benazir Bhutto
text: To the Editor:

headline: Want to Buy Some Tap? They’re Happy to Sell It
text: All good performers reveal themselves, but there is something about tap, which lacks the strict exoskeleton of, say, ballet, that demands that more aggressively. Like another of America’s great democratic art forms, jazz, tap celebrates the individual, and it is through the ineffable qualities let slip during solos  and not, usually, through technique  that tap dancers win or lose viewers’ hearts.

headline: Administration Is Rebuffed in a Ruling on Deportation
text: A federal judge in Pennsylvania on Thursday blocked the government’s efforts to deport a Coptic Christian who said he would be tortured if he were returned to Egypt. The ruling was a rebuff to the Bush administration’s practice of relying on confidential assurances to send people to countries that have been known to practice torture.

headline: Energy’s Forms: Snazzy, Sly and Sexy
text: Reviewers tend to shrug off the work of David Parsons. Yet the rest of the audience does not seem to have qualms about settling for undemanding entertainment, to judge by the response when Parsons Dance presented a new program on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. It doesn’t hurt that the entertainment is delivered by a company of individualistic performers who don’t all look like dancers but move with the same slyly sizzling energy. Tommy Scrivens appeared to be having the time of his life in the jazzy closing piece, “Shining Star,” after carrying out demanding lead roles in the two preceding dances.

headline: A Step Toward a Free Great Lawn
text: In the decade since it spruced up Central Park’s Great Lawn with private money, New York City has put in place fussy and undemocratic rules barring the lawn’s use for political demonstrations. These free speech restrictions were especially offensive in 2004 when the Republican National Convention came to town and major antiwar rallies were blocked, supposedly to protect the lawn. Now, to avoid a court battle, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has agreed to take another look at his selective keep-off-the-grass policy.

headline: Schwarzenegger’s Budget Includes 10% Cuts
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Faced with billions of dollars in deficits, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger announced a stark state budget on Thursday, including 10 percent cuts in most departments, early release for thousands of inmates and the closing of dozens of state parks.

headline: Bosnia: Police Take Passports of Karadzic Family
text: At the request of the international war crimes court in The Hague, the Bosnian Serb police seized the passports of the wife, son, daughter and son-in-law of Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader during the country’s 1992-95 war and one of the most wanted men in the world. His family is suspected of helping him evade capture, along with a network of supporters.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: New Rushdie Novel Due
text: A new novel by Salman Rushdie, will be published on June 3 by Random House. Titled “The Enchantress of Florence,” it is set in Renaissance Florence and the court of the Mughal Empire as it tells “of a woman attempting to command her own destiny in a man’s world,” a Random House announcement said. In March, Random House Trade Paperbacks will repackage and republish Mr. Rushdie’s works “The Satanic Verses,” “Shame” and “The Jaguar Smile.”

headline: Fishing Boats, Surfboards and Not a High-Rise in Sight
text: PUERTO ESCONDIDO, a tiny fishing village turned surfer’s hub on the Pacific coast of Mexico, certainly has the hallmarks of a tropical paradise: wide beaches, hidden coves and rocky cliffs that soar above crystalline waters.

headline: Whiteface Mountain
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Infection Control
text: To the Editor:

headline: United Antidoping Program Is Formed
text: COLORADO SPRINGS  Several of the biggest, most powerful sports organizations in the United States announced Thursday the formation of a joint antidoping research program, financed with at least $10 million, to find more effective, but less expensive methods to detect and deter the use of performance-enhancing drugs in sports.

headline: Chinese Director Arrested
text: The maverick Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yuan was arrested after he was found taking drugs in his Beijing home, Reuters reported, citing accounts on Thursday in official news media. Mr. Zhang, with four friends, was taking a variety of drugs when the police burst into his apartment, the Xinhua news agency reported, crediting a Beijing television account. A urine sample tested positive for ketamine and crystal meth, the report said. Mr. Zhang, named by Time magazine in 1994 as one of 100 young world leaders for the 21st century, is one of China’s Sixth Generation filmmakers, whose works have addressed alienation, nihilism and homosexuality. Although he has won acclaim and awards, some of his films have been banned in China.

headline: 4 Youths Arrested in Vandalism at Jewish Cemetery in New Jersey
text: The police have arrested four teenagers who they said toppled nearly 500 tombstones at a Jewish cemetery in New Brunswick, N.J., on two separate nights of mischief.

headline: In Writers Strike, Signs of Internal Discontent Over Tactics
text: LOS ANGELES  When Hollywood’s studios walked away from the bargaining table last month, striking screenwriters came out swinging. They filed a legal complaint, boycotted an awards show and picketed late-night television programs.

headline: Weinstein in Deal With Writers
text: LOS ANGELES  The Weinstein Company, one of Hollywood’s biggest independent film companies, is expected to formally announce an agreement with striking writers as early as Thursday, according to Harvey Weinstein, the company’s co-founder.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the filmmaker Goran Paskaljevic, who is the subject of a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, misstated the effect of the 9/11 terror attacks on the scheduled showing of his film “How Harry Became a Tree” at the Toronto International Film Festival in September 2001. Although Mr. Paskaljevic remained in Paris after the attacks and did not travel to Toronto, the film was in fact shown at the festival.

headline: U.S. and Germany Plan to Recognize Kosovo
text: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia  The United States and Germany have agreed to recognize Kosovo after it declares independence and to urge the rest of Europe to follow suit, say senior European Union diplomats close to negotiations over Kosovo’s future.

headline: Good Deal for NBC
text: NBC won a slim victory over second-place CBS in the ratings on Wednesday, largely because of its game-show programming at 8. Nielsen estimated that NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” attracted more than double the audience for CBS’s “Power of 10,” with 13.3 million viewers compared with 6.1 million. CBS led the 9 and 10 o’clock time slots, however, with “Criminal Minds” (14.6 million) and “CSI: NY” (11.6 million), which outperformed NBC’s “Law & Order: Criminal Intent” (9.6 million) and “Law & Order” (11 million), respectively. ABC ranked third for the night in total viewers, delivering decent results from “Wife Swap” at 8 (7.8 million) and “Supernanny” at 9 (8.9 million) but struggling at 10 with “Cashmere Mafia” (6.2 million). Among adults 18 to 49, ABC tied CBS for second place, just behind NBC. Fox, with repeats, was fourth over all.

headline: Exit Another Idol Star
text: Add the name Katharine McPhee, to the growing list of “American Idol” contestants cast adrift from Sony-BMG labels. Ms. McPhee, the runner-up to Taylor Hicks in 2006 on the fifth season of “Idol,” has left RCA after a single album, Billboard reported. Last year her self-titled debut sold only 366,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Mr. Hicks and Ruben Studdard, the 2003 “American Idol” winner, recently parted ways with J Records, another Sony-BMG label.

headline: Personal History, Captured in Plastic
text: Flip through your “Janson’s History of Art” and there they are: sex, death and religion, art’s old standbys, its holy trinity, on almost every page. Visit “Keith Edmier 1991-2007,” and you’ll find them still: alive, and weird, and living  or something like it  two hours north of New York City, at Bard College.

headline: Herbert Keppler, 82, Dies; Covered Photo Gadgetry With Folksy Style
text: Herbert Keppler, a publisher and columnist at leading photographic magazines who advised amateur photographers on everything from lenses and shutter speeds to camera bags and tripods and who helped pioneer independent testing of camera equipment, died last Friday in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Mr. Keppler, who lived in that village, was 82.

headline: Carefully Sorting Legal Chaos Out, With Duke Case as Unlikely Guide
text: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  After a night of heavy drinking just before Christmas break, three linemen on the North Carolina football team called 911 from an off-campus apartment. They were drunk, half-naked and bound at the wrists and ankles.

headline: Credit Suisse Pursuing a Partnership in the Chinese Market
text: SHANGHAI  Amid signs that China may be opening its securities market to more foreign investment banks, Credit Suisse announced Thursday that it was seeking to form a joint venture with a Chinese brokerage firm, Founder Securities.

headline: Delta Executives Consider Merger Talks
text: Executives of Delta Air Lines, facing increasingly grim economic conditions, plan to ask the carrier’s directors on Friday for permission to engage in merger discussions with United Airlines and Northwest Airlines, a step that could push the industry’s much-talked-about need to consolidate closer to reality.

headline: Teachers’ Union Is Leery of Effort to Limit Taxes
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to contain the rising property taxes that support New York’s schools could mean a confrontation with the state’s largest teachers’ union, whose president said on Thursday he was wary of a new commission leading the effort.

headline: Stern Looks on Bright Side of the League
text: Fans who are not worried about the Knicks are scarce in Manhattan, but N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern is one of those rare birds.

headline: California Seeks Thermostat Control
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The conceit in the 1960s show “The Outer Limits” was that outside forces had taken control of your television set.

headline: Defensive Leaks Lead to 5th Loss in a Row
text: When the Rangers’ latest dispiriting performance was over, littered with mistakes by some of their most accomplished players, the players sat quietly at their lockers absorbing the reality of a 6-2 loss to the Flyers on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

headline: First-Year Giants Are Hazed but Helping
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The feet of the Giants rookie Steve Smith have been green for days, discolored by a dye discreetly placed in his socks. A dress shirt in his locker hung stripped of its sleeves. Across the locker room, Plaxico Burress explained.

headline: Clinton to Seek Package to Lift Confidence in Economy
text: WASHINGTON  Adjusting her campaign to address increased fears of a recession, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Thursday that she would call for quick enactment of a $70 billion emergency spending package and for a possible $40 billion tax rebate later if economic conditions worsen.

headline: Sony Joins Other Labels on Amazon MP3 Store
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Sony BMG, the music company, announced Thursday that it would become the fourth and final major label to begin selling digital music on Amazon.com, offering its entire catalog in the MP3 format by the end of the month.

headline: Archdiocese Is Target of Sickout at 10 Schools
text: This is an anxious time for the students of Cathedral High School. Midterms are next week; the SATs are the week after that.

headline: Tide to Make Its Super Bowl Debut
text: THEY say time and tide wait for no man, but Tide has waited a long time to be advertised on the Super Bowl. Soon, Tide, the biggest detergent brand in America  sold by the biggest advertiser in America  will appear for the first time on the biggest day for advertising in America.

headline: Metro-North Harlem Line From Fordham to Chappaqua
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate, Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: For Values-Based Produce, a Heroic Seafaring Quest
text: You don’t have to go far into the press material for “The Pirates Who Don’t Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie” before you hit the phrase “faith-and-values-based property.” It is used to describe this and earlier offerings from the VeggieTales franchise, but the “faith” component of this rather ordinary film for children doesn’t make itself readily apparent.

headline: Waking Up an Idle Hearth
text: NOTHING makes a winter getaway more inviting than that warm glow crackling in the fireplace. “Since cave man times, we like to build a fire and poke around in it,” said Ashley Eldridge, director of education for the Chimney Safety Institute of America.

headline: Tiffany’s Downturn Jolts Luxury Retailing
text: Not even luxury products are immune.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about the controversy over a plan by a Roman Catholic archbishop in Italy to exhume and place on display the body of Padre Pio, the popular Italian saint, misstated the number of years that elapsed between his death in 1968 and his canonization in 2002. It was almost 34 years, not four.

headline: When an Apology Is Not Enough
text: It is one thing for network audio to capture Tiger Woods curse a bad shot, but another for a network announcer to say, as the Golf Channel’s Kelly Tilghman did last Friday, that one way for young golfers to stop Woods is to “lynch him in a back alley.”

headline: In Life’s Web, Aiding Trees Can Kill Them
text: A few years ago, Todd Palmer, an ecologist at the University of Florida, was walking past a fenced-off research site in Kenya when he noticed something curious: instead of thriving, acacia trees that were protected from leaf-eating elephants and giraffes were withering and dying.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: One Dead After Attack on Transit Worker
text: A New York City Transit worker walking home after a late shift, three muggers armed with a curved knife and a bystander who somehow got caught in the middle: they all converged on a dark and rainy street in Upper Manhattan late Thursday in a blood-soaked frenzy that left the bystander stabbed to death and two others  including the transit worker  hospitalized.

headline: New York’s Overlooked Ski Resorts
text: DO you know which state has the most ski areas?

headline: A Season for Big Works (and Two Grand Finales) at the Philharmonic
text: Eras, short and long, will end at the New York Philharmonic next season.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Thomas Sentenced to a Seat on the Bench
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The N.B.A. has decided not to fine or suspend Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas after he was ejected in the fourth quarter of the Knicks’ loss to the Houston Rockets on Wednesday night.

headline: Patriots Get Back to the Basics: Stopping the Run
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The old Giants film is brought out sometimes, providing a turn-back-the-clock tutorial for the New England Patriots linebackers. Who better than Lawrence Taylor and Harry Carson  Hall of Fame players from Coach Bill Belichick’s past  to emphasize a technique or provide a snapshot of a play. Or even to refresh Belichick’s memory of how he coached them.

headline: Indians Hit the Road Amid Elephants
text: NEW DELHI  A few weeks ago, the traditional Indian joint family household of Vineet Sharma, a fertilizer industry consultant, achieved a long deferred dream. Having ferried themselves on scooters all these years, the Sharmas bought a brand-new, silver-gray hatchback known as the Tata Indica.

headline: Giant Write-Down Is Seen for Merrill
text: Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate, prompting the firm to raise additional capital from an outside investor.

headline: Manhattan: Sentence in Tour Manager’s Slaying
text: The companion of a man who was a former tour manager for the musicians Billy Joel and Paul Simon was sentenced Thursday in State Supreme Court to 23 years in prison for stabbing the man to death 26 months ago during a fight in their apartment. The companion, Kathleen Connors, 39, was sentenced on her guilty plea to a reduced charge of first-degree manslaughter in the slaying of the former manager, Daniel L. Harrison, 57, on Nov. 20, 2005. The police said when Ms. Connors was arrested that she and Mr. Harrison had argued violently in their Manhattan apartment, near Gracie Mansion, before the stabbing.

headline: Two Old Friends Arraigned in Dead-Man’s-Check Case
text: Two men who the police say wheeled the corpse of their friend up to a cash-checking shop in Hell’s Kitchen on Tuesday to try to cash his Social Security check face charges that include failing to bury the body soon enough, according to a criminal complaint.

headline: Hot Prospect for Oil’s Big League
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  While some of the world’s largest oil producers, including Mexico and Iran, are struggling to remain exporters, Brazil is moving in the opposite direction. A huge underwater oil field discovered late last year has the potential to transform South America’s largest country into a sizable exporter and win it a seat at the table of the world’s oil cartel.

headline: Pockets to Grandfathers: Time’s Lovely Face
text: Here’s an apt attraction for the start of the new year: “The Art of Time” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a wonderful presentation of about 90 European timepieces from the museum’s permanent collection. They range from pocket watches to grandfather clocks and date from the 16th to the 18th century. They include traditional mantel clocks in wooden, peaked-roofed houses and extravagantly fanciful forms like a revolving globe engraved with star charts and figures of the zodiac held up on the wingtips of a flying horse, all beautifully fashioned in silver, from 1579.

headline: Rival to Georgia’s President Is Charged With Terrorism
text: MOSCOW  Prosecutors in Georgia on Thursday charged Badri Patarkatsishvili, a bitter rival of President Mikheil Saakashvili and a losing presidential candidate in the election last Saturday, with terrorism and conspiring to overthrow the government.

headline: Europe and U.S. Diverge on Rate Prospects
text: FRANKFURT  Can Europe’s economy stay on track even if the United States goes off the rails?

headline: Judge Queries Plan to Give Private Schools Priority on Randalls Island
text: A Manhattan judge on Thursday sharply questioned the city’s decision to turn over primary use of the athletic fields on Randalls Island to a group of 20 private schools in Manhattan. The judge asked whether the city had failed to submit its plans to environmental reviews and to hold enough public hearings.

headline: Newly Elected South Korean Leader Faces Inquiry
text: SEOUL  South Korea’s Constitutional Court on Thursday authorized an independent prosecutor to investigate whether President-elect Lee Myung-bak engaged in financial misdeeds years before his landslide victory in elections on Dec. 19.

headline: Democrats See Enthusiasm Gap in Their Favor
text: It used to be the credibility gap that afflicted politicians. Now Republicans and Democrats are peering over the edge of the enthusiasm gap.

headline: Forget Pundits, Giuliani Says
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani began running the following television commercial on Thursday in Florida, where he is competing most heavily, urging voters not to discount him based on news media coverage of his losses in Iowa and New Hampshire:

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Middle-Class Capitalists
text: In 1974, a group of economists and journalists got together in a bar and launched supply-side economics. It was a superb political and economic package. It addressed a big problem: stagflation. It had a clear policy focus: marginal tax rates. It celebrated a certain sort of personality: the risk-taking entrepreneur. It made it clear that the new, growth-oriented Republican Party would be different from the old, green-eyeshade one.

headline: Bush Outlines Mideast Peace Plan
text: JERUSALEM  President Bush outlined Thursday in the clearest terms so far the shape of a two-state peace treaty he is hoping to broker between Israel and the Palestinians by the end of his term.

headline: Edmund Hillary, First on Everest, Dies at 88
text: Sir Edmund Hillary, the lanky New Zealand mountaineer and explorer who with Tenzing Norgay, his Sherpa guide, won worldwide acclaim in 1953 by becoming the first to scale the 29,035-foot summit of Mount Everest, the world’s tallest peak, died Friday in Auckland, New Zealand. He was 88.

headline: Calls Grow for Bloomberg to Make Up His Mind
text: Nearly every day a tiny new development trickles out from the stealth presidential campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire mayor of New York.

headline: Incident at Sea
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Federal Trade Commission’s hearings on green marketing misspelled the surname of the general manager of Gaiam, a yoga equipment company that offers carbon offsets to its customers. He is Chris Fisher, not Fischer. The article also misidentified the organization that U-Haul works with to provide carbon offsets. It is the Conservation Fund, not Carbonfund.org.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the coming Republican Party caucus in Michigan misstated the title of Craig DeRoche, shown speaking with Mitt Romney on board a plane. He is the minority leader of the Michigan House of Representatives; he is not the speaker.

headline: Chrysler and Nissan in Production Deal
text: DETROIT  Chrysler and Nissan of Japan took the first step toward a possible broader alliance on Friday, reaching agreement for Nissan to supply Chrysler with a small car to be sold in South America.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Well column in Science Times on Jan. 1, about excessive clutter and compulsive hoarders, omitted the names of two authors of a book on the subject. Besides David F. Tolin, the book “Buried in Treasures” was written by Randy O. Frost and Gail Steketee.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review on Wednesday about “Three Lost Chords,” at the Zipper Factory Theater, misstated the surname of the composer at one point. As noted elsewhere in the review, he is Lance Horne, not Holmes. The review also referred incorrectly to the song in the section “The Girl I Left Behind Me.” It was written by Mr. Horne; it was not the British song of the same name. And schedule information gave an incorrect telephone number for the Zipper Factory Theater. It is (212) 352-3101.

headline: Democracy by Other Means
text: Laikipia, Kenya

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Nice Journal article on Wednesday, about a struggle between the Russian government and local Russian Orthodox leaders over the Cathedral of St. Nicholas in Nice, France, described incorrectly the visit of Patriarch Aleksei II of Moscow to Notre Dame, the Roman Catholic cathedral of Paris. The Russian prelate went to Notre Dame to venerate the cathedral’s celebrated relic, the Crown of Thorns. He did not celebrate Mass there. (Go to Article)

headline: Bank Agrees to Buy Troubled Loan Giant for $4 Billion
text: Bank of America announced Friday that it had agreed to pay about $4 billion in stock to acquire Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Poland and Czech Republic Team Up in Missile Defense Talks With U.S.
text: BERLIN  The governments of Poland and the Czech Republic agreed Thursday to coordinate their negotiations with the United States over its request to place elements of an antiballistic missile shield in those countries.

headline: Inmates Are Recaptured, but Skirmish Over the Case Goes On
text: ELIZABETH, N.J.  The manhunt ended, the shouting match did not and the questions kept coming.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Bombs Iraqi Insurgent Hideouts
text: BAGHDAD  American bombers and fighter aircraft dropped 40,000 pounds of bombs on suspected militant hide-outs, storehouses and defensive positions in the southern outskirts of Baghdad on Thursday, the United States military said.

headline: Wal-Mart’s Holiday Strategy Proved a Timely One
text: Twelve months ago, long before fears of a recession loomed, senior executives at Wal-Mart Stores hatched a plan to “disrupt the marketplace” during the 2007 holiday season, said Eduardo Castro-Wright, the chief executive of the company’s United States division.

headline: Literary Laurels
text: Five winners of Costa Book Awards, formerly the Whitbread Book Awards, have been chosen from 553 entries to compete for the 2007 Costa Book of the Year Award. They are the Costa Novel Award winner, “Day,” by A. L. Kennedy; the Costa First Novel Award winner, “What Was Lost,” by Catherine O’Flynn; the Costa Biography Award winner, “Young Stalin,” by Simon Sebag Montefiore; the Costa Poetry Award winner, “Tilt,” by Jean Sprackland; and the Costa Children’s Book Award winner, “The Bower Bird,” by Ann Kelley. The winner, who receives about $49,000, will be announced in London on Jan. 22. ... Three books will compete for the $20,000 Story Prize, given for the year’s best short fiction, The Associated Press reported. They are Jim Shepard’s “Like You’d Understand, Anyway,” Vincent Lam’s “Bloodletting & Miraculous Cures” and Tessa Hadley’s “Sunstroke and Other Stories.” The winner will be announced on Feb. 27.

headline: Cuomo Subpoenas Intel Over Antitrust Accusations
text: ALBANY  The New York State attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, issued a wide-ranging subpoena to the Intel Corporation on Thursday as part of an investigation into whether the company violated federal or state antitrust laws in the way that it priced and sold microprocessors.

headline: Fish Out of Water in the Deep Blue Sea
text: Loved the shoes. Loathed the show.

headline: Where TV Once Turned for Its Tables
text: “ ‘Cheeseburger, cheeseburger’  that was our diner stuff,” Lloyd Kabram said. He was referring, as you may have guessed, to the John Belushi routine on “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Britain: Lethal Bird Flu at Famed Swan Reserve
text: The deadly H5N1 strain of avian flu has reached one of England’s most famous swan breeding grounds, the Abbotsbury Swannery on the Dorset coast. Tests on three dead mute swans confirmed the virus, spread by wild birds. The manager said he was working to determine how many swans might be affected.

headline: Help With One Month’s Rent Mends a Family’s Safety Net
text: Lilia and Rolando Solis, both 39, immigrated to New York City from Mexico 11 years ago, searching for a better way to provide for their family. “It’s hard, but we think that we have to do it, so we have a better life, a better future, for the kids,” Mr. Solis said.

headline: Stocks Drop Sharply Amid Subprime Woes
text: In many ways, the markets seem to be stuck in a loop.

headline: As Military Seeks Site, a Move to Protect Rolling Acres
text: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  A few months ago, when Wesleyan University announced that it would create 10 scholarships to encourage military veterans to study here, school officials and students talked of welcoming them with open arms.

headline: NYSE Urges China to Be Flexible on Where Companies Raise Capital
text: PARIS  NYSE Euronext, the merged trans-Atlantic stock exchange, is lobbying the Chinese government to raise standards of corporate governance and loosen rules on where companies can raise capital as part of an effort to win business from rival markets in cities like London and Hong Kong.

headline: Mend Your Foolish Ways, Would-Be Church Bandits
text: Ice Cube’s recent movie roles, in the “Barbershop” and “Are We There Yet?” franchises, have emphasized his cuddly, family-man side. In “First Sunday,” which is not a new installment in the earlier “Friday” series, he departs a bit from the upright-citizen persona, playing a man driven to crime by desperate circumstances.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Wholesale Inventories Rise, Suggesting Output May Fall
text: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  Inventories at wholesalers rose more than forecast in November and sales increased, reflecting rising prices for oil and farm products, the government reported on Thursday.

headline: When the Family Ski Trip Is What Brings You All Together
text: “KATE can’t ski tomorrow.”

headline: Colombian Rebels Free 2 Hostages
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombian guerrillas freed two politically prominent hostages on Thursday, handing them over to emissaries of President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela in a breakthrough in mediation efforts with Latin America’s largest rebel group.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Dec. 11 about the effort to develop a malaria vaccine using live, weakened parasites grown in mosquitoes referred imprecisely to the financing of a rival vaccine invented by Dr. Pierre Druilhe, a malaria expert at the Pasteur Institute in France. Dr. Druilhe and the Gates Foundation broke off discussions over a grant for vaccine development; his project was not “rejected” by the foundation.

headline: South Korea: Court Rules for Inquiry of President-Elect
text: The Constitutional Court cleared the way for a special prosecutor to start an investigation into allegations of links by President-elect Lee Myung-bak to a 2001 stock manipulation scheme. The inquiry is to be finished before his swearing-in on Feb. 25.

headline: Cuomo Remark in an Interview Takes Clarifying
text: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo’s staff spent much of Thursday explaining Mr. Cuomo’s use of “shuck and jive,” a term with racial overtones, during a radio interview on Wednesday about the presidential race.

headline: Viceroy Anguilla and the Orchard at the Carneros Inn
text: Viceroy Anguilla

headline: British Arts Cuts Inspire Protests
text: The outcry from London theater professionals has been growing in response to proposals by Arts Council England, the government arts-development agency, to cut or eliminate financing for nearly 200 arts organizations. At a meeting on Wednesday at the Young Vic theater in London that was attended by hundreds of actors, including Kevin Spacey and Ian McKellen, members of the British actors’ union lashed out at the Arts Council, passing a no confidence motion against the agency, the BBC reported. Tom Stoppard, Salman Rushdie and Harold Pinter were among dozens signing a letter of protest on behalf of the Bush Theater, which is facing a proposed cut of about $353,000, nearly 40 percent of its government funds. Josie Rourke, the artistic director of the Bush, said that the proposed cuts appeared to be based on inaccurate data. At the meeting on Wednesday the arts council’s chief executive, Peter Hewitt, responded by saying that 80 new organizations would get money and three-quarters of the groups now receiving funds would receive an increase under the proposals.

headline: Blackstone to Buy Hedge Fund to Strengthen Credit Operations
text: The Blackstone Group said Thursday that it had agreed to buy GSO Capital Partners, a $10 billion hedge fund, for as much as $930 million in cash and stock as it seeks to build its credit operations amid tough market conditions.

headline: Of a Birthday and a Baby, on the Very Edge of Mime
text: On Wednesday Performance Space 122 opened its Coil festival. This is promoted as “featuring some of the best up-and-coming artists in New York’s underground performance scene,” but it also includes “C’est Duckie,” an annual sensation in London for several consecutive Christmas seasons.

headline: Art in Review
text: THE HAND-DRAWN

headline: Americana Dealer Cleans House
text: If it’s January, it’s Americana time in New York. The viewings of American antiques, folk art, ceramics and paintings begin on Saturday at Sotheby’s and Christie’s before next week’s auctions. And this season the most talked-about sale is probably the personal collection of the veteran dealer Marguerite Riordan of Stonington, Conn.

headline: American Express Warns About Earnings
text: American Express forecast first-quarter earnings below analysts’ estimates on Thursday and adopted a “cautious view” for 2008 because of a slowing economy.

headline: Cast in Stone
text: Fiona Shaw is indisputably the queen of the mountain in Deborah Warner’s blazing production of Samuel Beckett’s “Happy Days,” an import from the National Theater in London that opened this week at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Notice that I say mountain, not molehill.

headline: Face Time: Masks, Animal to Video
text: The mask is one of the most basic and recognizable of all forms, and for good reason. One way early humans made sense of the universe was to personify its forces, and the most visible form of personification was the face. Masks have long been central to religious rituals, serving as tools of transformation and bridges to the spirit world. They have figured in ceremonies intended to ensure fertility and raise the dead, make crops grow and rain fall, kill enemies, ward off evil and cure sickness. They have been used by soldiers and celebrators of Lent, astronauts and action heroes, hockey players and fencers, firefighters and welders.

headline: A New Clinton, Going Door to Door in Nevada, Asks for Help
text: LAS VEGAS  The all-new, listening and accessible Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton took her message door to door on Thursday night in a heavily Hispanic working-class neighborhood near downtown Las Vegas. She knocked on doors with campaign workers, urging voters to caucus for her in the coming Democratic contest.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the men’s college basketball East roundup on Dec. 16 about Niagara’s upset victory at St. John’s misstated the year that Niagara last beat St. John’s. It was 2004  not 1963, which was the last time Niagara won at Carnesecca Arena (formerly Alumni Hall).

headline: California: Supervisor Resigns
text: Ed Jew resigned from the San Francisco Board of Supervisors as part of a legal settlement with the city for lying about living in the district he represents. Mr. Jew, 47, was accused of living in the city of Burlingame when elected in 2006 to represent the outlying Sunset District in San Francisco, a violation of election rules. He still faces two criminal cases for state election code violations and a federal bribery and extortion case in connection with what the authorities say was a scam to obtain city permits for several business owners, in exchange for $84,000. Already on suspension from the Board of Supervisors, Mr. Jew’s resignation ends two local battles over misconduct with San Francisco authorities.

headline: Symphony President in Cincinnati to Retire
text: Steven Monder, the president of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, will retire in June after 37 years, the orchestra announced. Mr. Monder, 62, joined as a production manager in 1971 and has held the orchestra’s top executive position  with varying titles  since 1976. During his tenure the Cincinnati Pops was created, the Riverbend Music Center was opened on the banks of the Ohio River, and since 1979 the orchestra has released more than 100 recordings on the Telarc label, with worldwide sales of nearly 10 million.

headline: Manhattan: Former Immigration Official Sentenced
text: A former supervisor with the federal Citizenship and Immigration Services office in New York was sentenced in Federal District Court on Thursday to 42 months in prison for taking bribes in exchange for granting citizenship to ineligible applicants, prosecutors said. The defendant, Jimmie Ortega, 59, of Lindenhurst, N.Y., admitted that from 2004 to 2006, he used his position as an adjudications officer to obtain citizenship for at least 20 immigrants in exchange for payments of $1,500 to $4,000, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Ortega, who retired in April 2006, pleaded guilty last July to conspiracy and soliciting bribes, prosecutors said.

headline: Take the Kids, and Don’t Feel Guilty
text: Over the last few years, in the course of many parent conferences and elementary-school curriculum nights, I’ve become familiar with the concept of the “just-right book.” This, my children’s teachers patiently explain, is a book that is perfectly suited to a child’s reading ability: neither too easy, in which case he or she will grow bored, nor too difficult, which risks frustration and confusion.

headline: Charles M. Taylor, 78, Atlanta Real Estate Developer, Is Dead
text: Charles M. Taylor, one of the major real estate developers of Buckhead, an affluent northern section of Atlanta, where high-rise office towers, condominium buildings and boutique malls dot a landscape of mansions tucked into forests, died Saturday at his home in Buckhead. He was 78.

headline: Alabama: Father Now Denies Tossing Children
text: A man accused of tossing his four young children off a coastal bridge denies killing them and says the police harassed him into making a false confession, his lawyer said. The authorities say the man, Lam Luong, 37, of Irvington, confessed to killing the children, ranging in age from a few months to 3 years, a day after reporting them missing and claiming a woman had taken them. But Mr. Luong’s appointed lawyer, Joe Kulakowski, said his client told him he had falsely confessed under pressure after being questioned Monday night and the entire day Tuesday. Search crews have found no sign of the children.

headline: Knoblauch Ends Silence About Report From Mitchell
text: HOUSTON  In his first public comments since the Mitchell report was released last month, the former Yankee Chuck Knoblauch said on Thursday that he was not angry about being named in the report, although he did not explicitly admit that he had used human growth hormone, as the report asserts.

headline: The Will (if Not Triumph) of the Frau
text: The life of Leni Riefenstahl, the filmmaker who made movies for Hitler, has been examined and critiqued aplenty, but rarely so entertainingly as in “Amazons and Their Men,” a brash play by Jordan Harrison receiving a lively production by Clubbed Thumb at the Ohio Theater.

headline: Vermont: Proposal to Lease Lottery
text: Gov. Jim Douglas proposed leasing the state lottery to a private company to raise more than $50 million for schools and for property tax reduction. The governor, a Republican who took office in 2003, unveiled the plan in his State of the State address after broaching the idea last month with the lottery commission. Other states including California and Florida are considering selling or leasing such public assets amid a slowdown in tax revenue. A private company would pay the state $23 million a year to operate the lottery under a 40-year lease, on top of a $56 million upfront payment, according to Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., which Mr. Douglas hired to analyze the plan.

headline: Poor December at Retailers; Most Report Drops in Sales
text: The weakest holiday shopping season in five years ended dismally for most retailers, whose sales tumbled despite deep discounts and extended store hours, stoking fears that the economy is tipping into a recession.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: A Gruesome Find, and a Mother Is Accused of Murders
text: WASHINGTON  United States marshals made a gruesome discovery on Wednesday when they went to evict Banita M. Jacks from her home  the decomposed bodies of Ms. Jacks’s four daughters.

headline: Jurors in a Cape Cod Murder Case Testify About Racial Remarks
text: BARNSTABLE, Mass.  More than a year after it convicted a black trash hauler of a shocking murder on Cape Cod, a jury returned to court here Thursday for an extraordinary hearing on whether racism influenced its verdict.

headline: Civil Rights Tone Prompts Talk of an Endorsement
text: WASHINGTON  Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina, the highest-ranking African-American in Congress, said he was rethinking his neutral stance in his state’s presidential primary out of disappointment at comments by Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton that he saw as diminishing the historic role of civil rights activists.

headline: Study Finds Possible Targets for H.I.V. Drugs
text: Using a new type of genetic screen, researchers at Harvard Medical School have identified 273 proteins that the AIDS virus needs to survive in human cells, opening up new potential targets for drugs.

headline: Theater Listings
text: UNDER THE RADAR If you wander into Veselka restaurant anytime between noon and midnight these days, you may not realize that the folks sitting at one table are both actors and audience members for an unusual two-person production, courtesy of Rotozaza, a London theater company. The show, “Etiquette,” which opened in London almost a year ago, has visited several countries since and was presented at the Theater Communications Group conference at the Guthrie Theater last June (with Sunder Ganglani and Anne Erbe, below).

headline: Horses Spared in U.S. Face Death Across the Border
text: SHIPSHEWANA, Ind.  At the weekly horse auction here, No. 274, a handsome chestnut-colored draft horse, looked at the surrounding men while being led into a small ring. Two of the men looked back, calculating how much meat the animal’s carcass would yield, and started bidding accordingly.

headline: Baseball and Union Discuss the Mitchell Report’s Recommendations
text: Representatives for Major League Baseball and the players union met this week to discuss the recommendations in the Mitchell report that require the consent of both sides.

headline: Bank Agrees to Buy Troubled Loan Giant for $4 Billion
text: Bank of America announced Friday that it has agreed to pay about $4 billion in stock to acquire Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Weinstein Company Makes a Deal With Guild Writers
text: LOS ANGELES  The Weinstein Company, one of Hollywood’s biggest independent film companies, has completed a separate agreement with striking writers, according to Harvey Weinstein, the company’s co-founder.

headline: Marine’s Body Reportedly Found
text: The mystery of a missing pregnant marine may turn out to be a homicide. Lance Cpl. Maria Lauterbach, who disappeared from Camp Lejeune on December 14, is believed to be dead, said Sheriff Ed Brown, of the North Carolina county where the military facility is located.

headline: Manhattan: Man Is Fatally Shot Outside Club
text: A 32-year-old Queens man was fatally shot early Thursday outside a West Side nightclub, the police said. The man, Brione Schneider, was shot once in the back about 3:45 a.m. after a dispute with another man that began inside the club, Stereo, and spilled into the street, the police said. He was taken to St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan and pronounced dead about 4:40 a.m., the police said. Detectives are investigating reports that the dispute was over a woman and say they believe that the assailant, who was still being sought Thursday, left the club first and may have retrieved a 9-millimeter gun from a car, the police said. Brad Zeifman, a spokesman for the club, on West 29th Street, said in a statement that the club was not aware of any prior altercation inside. The police said they brought nuisance abatement proceedings against the club last year because of drug activity, assaults and under-age drinking.

headline: Gift for Miami Arts
text: The $461 million performing arts center in Miami, entering its second year and struggling financially, has received a $30 million infusion. As a result of the gift, announced on Thursday, the complex will be renamed in honor of the donor, Adrienne Arsht, a lawyer, business executive and philanthropist. Previously known as the Carnival Center for the Performing Arts, it will be named the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts of Miami-Dade County. The center is to receive the money over the next three years. Of the total, $13 million will be received immediately. Of that amount, $4 million will be allocated to programming; $7 million will be applied to a bank loan; and $2 million will be refunded to the Carnival Corporation, which relinquished its naming rights. It had a 10-year, $10 million agreement with the center.

headline: New Yorkers Pay More to Keep Their Homes Warm
text: New York residents are being hit with an unusual combination this week: unseasonably warm weather and maddeningly large heating bills.

headline: U.S. Nuclear Envoy Puts Gentle Pressure on North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States urged North Korea on Thursday to rethink its position and give a “complete and correct” accounting of its nuclear weapons programs before a new conservative South Korean president takes office in late February, perhaps with more sticks than carrots for the North.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the Metro Briefing column in some copies on Tuesday about the discovery of a body in a cesspool behind the home of a Long Island man missing for 19 months misspelled the given name of the man. He was Nicolo Caietta, not Nicholas.

headline: Homeland Security on the Hustings
text: Voters in the 2008 elections need to hear in detail how the presidential candidates intend to wrestle the sprawling homeland security apparatus into sync with the true state of the terrorist threat. That critical connection has become befogged in years of hyperbolic alarms, official ineptitude, enormous spending and political sleight of hand.

headline: Endorsing Obama, Kerry Calls Him Leader of ‘Wisdom, Instinct and Vision’
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John Kerry embraced the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama on Thursday, praising him as the only Democrat in the race who can inspire a movement to dislodge Washington partisanship and create a new image around the world.

headline: Europe’s Next Rate Move May Be an Increase
text: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged on Thursday but signaled that it could raise it pre-emptively if generous wage deals threatened to ignite inflation.

headline: The Primary, Upon Further Dissection
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Youthful Awakening to Mother Nature’s Laws in a Turkish Village
text: Livestock far outnumber humans in “Times and Winds,” Reha Erdem’s transporting vision of life in a mountain village in northwest Turkey as seen through the eyes of three children on the verge of adolescence. Make no mistake: The movie, for all its majestic shots of the rocky landscape and of the moon skittering behind clouds, is not a lump-in-your-throat portrait of the noble poor living in harmony with the elements.

headline: Congressman in Inquiry on Lobbying Will Retire
text: WASHINGTON  Representative John T. Doolittle, a California Republican who has suggested he is almost certain to face criminal charges in a Congressional lobbying scandal, announced Thursday that he would retire from the House next year.

headline: Pushing Back as Columbia Moves to Spread Out
text: NICHOLAS SPRAYREGEN, the Upper Manhattan property owner who has dueled to a standoff with an acquisition-minded Columbia University in the real estate version of a “whoever has the most toys, wins” competition, knows better than to ask for a sympathy vote.

headline: Northern Rock Sells Some Assets
text: LONDON  Northern Rock, one of Britain’s biggest casualties of the credit crisis, sold part of its mortgage portfolio on Friday to JPMorgan Chase as it seeks to repay about £25 billion, or $49 billion, in emergency financing.

headline: Tina Brown to Write Book on the Clintons
text: Tina Brown, the former editor of Vanity Fair, The New Yorker and Talk magazine, has signed with Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group to write a portrait of the Clinton era, to be titled “The Clinton Chronicles,” in an echo of “The Diana Chronicles,” her best-selling book about Diana, Princess of Wales. The new book, scheduled for publication in 2010, will cover the lives of Bill and Hillary Clinton and also reflect on the social and political contexts of their rises to power. “I really felt that the Clinton story is such a sort of thrilling roller coaster of a story that also enabled me to write about the media and social culture of the era in which they’ve dominated the stage,” Ms. Brown said in an interview. “The media has played a large part in that, with the rise of the Drudge moment and the blogosphere, and that’s the sort of material that speaks to me.”

headline: Bank May Buy Troubled Giant in Home Loans
text: Countrywide Financial, the troubled lender that became a symbol of the excesses that led to the subprime mortgage crisis, is close to being acquired by Bank of America for slightly more than $4 billion in stock, people briefed on the transaction said Thursday.

headline: Spate of Executions and Amputations in Iran
text: TEHRAN  Using strict enforcement of Islamic law, the judicial authorities in a restive region of southern Iran amputated the right hands and left feet of five convicted robbers this week, part of what the government said was an effort to deter other troublemakers.

headline: Banks Plead They Can’t Follow Rules
text: When you are shoveling money, keeping track of the paperwork is an awful burden.

headline: Bomb Kills at Least 23 in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber approached a crowd of police officers outside a courthouse in Lahore on Thursday and set off a powerful explosion, killing at least 23 people and wounding 58, police officials said.

headline: For Many a Follower, Sacred Ground in Colorado
text: “TRUST an unknown future with a known God,” urges the sign in front of the Sangre de Cristo Christian Church on the outskirts of Crestone, Colo., which is close to a four-hour drive south of Denver off Highway 17. The town might seem to be in the middle of nowhere, but if you’re seeking a taste of the divine, you’ve probably come to the right place.

headline: Britain Shows New Enthusiasm for Nuclear Power Plants
text: PARIS  The British government on Thursday approved plans to refresh the country’s fleet of nuclear reactors, signaling new enthusiasm for the technology and giving a lift to the industry.

headline: Apple’s Customer Service
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trenton: New Jersey Chemical Rules Stand
text: The federal government will not override New Jersey’s chemical security laws, which are tougher than the national standard, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg announced Thursday. A measure, promoted by Senator Lautenberg and recently signed by President Bush, insulates all states from federal pre-emption, and allows them to pass laws protecting their residents from an attack on chemical facilities within their borders. The co-chairmen of the Sept. 11 Commission, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean and former Representative Lee H. Hamilton, joined the National Governors’ Association and the National Conference of State Legislatures in supporting the measure.

headline: An Arizona Road Trip on the Edge of America
text: AS you enter the Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument in southern Arizona, it’s not the park’s namesake plant, thick with a cluster of many branches, that inspires gasps of awe, but thousands of saguaro, the iconic tall cactus of countless Western films. Upright and lanky, with whimsically outstretched arms, one after another the saguaros wave you in.

headline: Off-Road Vehicles
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on Tuesday, about research on ocean acidification, referred incorrectly to the experiments. They were intended to determine whether lower ocean pH, not higher pH, affected a certain type of algae. (On the pH scale, which runs from 0 to 14, the lower the number the greater the acidity.)

headline: Campaign Turns to Economic Concerns
text: WASHINGTON  With the economy trumping all other issues, at least for the moment, Democrats and Republicans were trying on Friday to generate momentum for a variety of moves that they said were designed to keep the country from sinking into recession.

headline: What’s on the Art Box? Spins, Satire and Camp
text: “You are the product of TV,” declares “Television Delivers People,” Richard Serra’s six-minute 1973 video screed of scrolling text set to elevator music. If Mr. Serra were to recreate the piece today, he might call it “People Deliver Television.”

headline: No Immunity Deal
text: We suppose we shouldn’t be surprised. Yet another player in the Bush administration’s break-all-the-rules war against terrorism is trying to evade accountability.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: The Comeback Continent
text: Today I’d like to talk about a much-derided contender making a surprising comeback, a comeback that calls into question much of the conventional wisdom of American politics. No, I’m not talking about a politician. I’m talking about an economy  specifically, the European economy, which many Americans assume is tired and spent but has lately been showing surprising vitality.

headline: Owens Practices but Is a Game-Time Decision
text: IRVING, Tex.  The secrecy surrounding the status of Dallas Cowboys receiver Terrell Owens diminished slightly Thursday, enough to reveal indications that he will play Sunday in the team’s playoff game against the Giants.

headline: Burned by Investing in Troubled Times
text: Bank of America had hoped for a tidy profit when it bought a $2 billion stake in Countrywide Financial and tried to stanch the mortgage lender’s bleeding.

headline: Lawmakers Ask Justice Dept. for Information on Monitors
text: WASHINGTON  The chairmen of the House and Senate Judiciary Committees joined in asking the Justice Department on Thursday for details of contracts that the department directed to former Attorney General John Ashcroft and other outside lawyers who are monitoring companies in out-of-court settlements of criminal allegations.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Nice Journal article on Wednesday, about a struggle between the Russian government and local Russian Orthodox leaders over the Cathedral of St. Nicholas in Nice, France, described incorrectly the visit of Patriarch Aleksei II of Moscow to Notre Dame, the Roman Catholic cathedral of Paris. The Russian prelate went to Notre Dame to venerate the cathedral’s celebrated relic, the Crown of Thorns. He did not celebrate Mass there.

headline: Rikers Island: Jail Death Investigated
text: City health officials are investigating the death of a 17-year-old arrested on sexual misconduct charges who apparently committed suicide while jailed at Rikers Island. Jessica Scaperotti, a Health Department spokeswoman, told El Diario/La Prensa on Wednesday that the city would undertake a thorough investigation of the death of the teenager, David Mercado of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Mr. Mercado, who was arrested on Dec. 17, was placed in a dormitory with 50 other prisoners even though a state judge in Queens flagged the youth as a “suicide risk,” the newspaper reported. Correction officials said Rikers Island medical staff did not deem it necessary to place Mr. Mercado under observation. Mr. Mercado’s lawyers said he hanged himself with a sheet less than 24 hours after arriving.
