headline: A Trail to Your Door
text: I’ve been Nordic skiing seriously since 1974, and I’ve been coaching for five years. Right now I’m the head coach for the Minnetonka Nordic Ski Team at Minnetonka High School. I’ve been coaching the senior class since they were freshmen, and it’s fantastic. It’s definitely cool to follow through with one group over four years like this.

headline: Fed Chief Signals Further Rate Cut
text: Presenting a bleak picture of a deteriorating national economy, Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, strongly suggested on Thursday that the Fed would cut interest rates soon, perhaps by a large amount.

headline: Exchanges in Latest Debate Highlight a New Dynamic in the Republican Field
text: Fred D. Thompson tried to salvage his faltering presidential campaign at a debate Thursday night with a barrage of sharp attacks on the “liberal” policies of Mike Huckabee, the fellow Southerner whom he clearly sees as a rival in the South Carolina primary.

headline: Celebrating Barristers in Temple!?
text: London is full of hidden secrets, one of which is Temple, an area steeped in history. Here, you can find the hall where Shakespeare premiered “Twelfth Night” in 1602 (Middle Temple Hall), as well as Temple Church (built by the Knights Templar in 1185) which is featured in Dan Brown’s “The Da Vinci Code.” It was used as the location in the film.Hall From Garden – credit ” reproduced by kind permission of the Masters of the Bench of the Honourable Society of the Middle Temple

headline: Williams team deal with Baugur Group
text: According to a very good source, the Williams team last night sold one third interest of the team to the Baugur Group, an Icelandic investment company that specializes in retail, media and finances. Among other properties, Baugur owns a supermarket chain in Iceland, a retail chain in Denmark, and in the UK the Hamleys toy store and the House of Fraser department store.

headline: N.H.L. Halfway Standings
text: On Thursday night the last two N.H.L. teams reached the regular season’s halfway point (for the record, Philadelphia and St. Louis, and they both won), enabling us to bring you the league’s halfway standings.

headline: 'Intern'
text: I had been an intern less than an hour, and already I was running late. The sloping footpath leading up to the hospital was paved with gray cobblestones. My feet ached as my oversize leather sandals slipped on the rounded irregular rocks. The hospital was an old building browned by the passage of two centuries, with spidery cracks in its façade. Founded in 1771, New York Hospital is the second-oldest hospital in the United States, a mecca for doctors and patients from all over the world. I had been in the building once before, six months ago, for a residency interview. I spun through a revolving brass door, nearly running into the burly security guard reading the New York Post. He looked up from the tabloid just long enough to point me in the direction of the elevator.

headline: Afghanistan's Police Force
text: Afghanistan's police force, lightly equipped, marginally trained and undermined by corruption, struggles to police a country that lacks the rule of law.

headline: Credit Suisse Pursues a Partnership in China
text: Amid signs that China may be opening its securities market to more foreign investment banks, Credit Suisse announced Thursday that it was seeking to form a joint venture with a Chinese brokerage firm, Founder Securities.

headline: NYSE Urges China for More Listing Flexibility
text: NYSE Euronext, the merged trans-Atlantic stock exchange, is lobbying the Chinese government to raise standards of corporate governance and loosen rules on where companies can raise capital as part of an effort to win business from rival markets in cities like London and Hong Kong.

headline: Would a Monster Move Make Sense for Murdoch?
text: Despite News Corporation‘s denial of rumors that it was in talks to buy online recruiting giant Monster Worldwide for $4.8 billion, Breakingviews thinks such a deal could make sense for Rupert Murdoch’s media company.

headline: Brazil’s Telemar Talks Up a Deal for Brasil Telecom

text: This Comedy Central regular has noticed some overlooked problems of going to the emergency room, like the lack of valet parking …

headline: F.C.C. Said to Approve Clear Channel Deal
text: Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital Partners appear to have jumped one significant regulatory hurdle for their deal to buy Clear Channel Communications, but investors still seem jittery about whether or not the deal will actually close.

headline: After 16 Years, Southeast Bank May Rise from the Dead
text: A New York investment bank plans to inject $1.5 billion into Southeast Banking, a company that’s been in bankruptcy for more than 16 years but still has $800 million worth of unused net operating “loss carry-forwards,” which apply past losses to future profits.

headline: Young Broadcasting to Shop San Francisco Station
text: Young Broadcasting of New York said Thursday that it had retained Moelis & Company, the advisory firm founded by the former UBS banker Ken Moelis, to shop San Francisco’s KRON-TV, which it acquired in 2000 for $823 million.

headline: Fund to Oppose Macrovision-Gemstar Deal

headline: China’s Tencent Leads $11 Million Round for Outspark

headline: In Macau, a $1 Billion Casino I.P.O. With More Expected
text: A $1 billion initial public offering planned by the tycoon Stanley Ho’s Macau flagship company is giving investors a rare chance to bet on a casino boom that has been financed mostly by loans, but more raising of capital on public markets is in the cards.

headline: Bears Said to Eye Stake in China Asset Management
text: Bear Stearns is in talks to buy around 10 percent of China’s biggest fund house, China Asset Management, to tap the country’s red-hot mutual fund market, Reuters reported.

headline: Buffett Raises Burlington Stake
text: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway bought 29,600 more shares of Burlington Northern Santa Fe stock, giving Berkshire ownership of 17.4 percent of the nation’s second-largest railroad.

headline: Synergy Closes $143 Million Debut Fund
text: Synergy Life Science Partners on Thursday announced that it had wrapped up its debut fund with $143 million in committed capital, making it one of a dwindling number of firms to raise a first-time investment vehicle.

headline: 2 CBOT Traders Charged With Fraud
text: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission on Thursday charged two traders with defrauding investors by as much as $2.1 million in a carefully timed deal at the Chicago Board of Trade.

headline: Hedge Funds Said to Put Pressure on Canada’s Nexen

text: Bank of America had hoped for a tidy profit when it bought a $2 billion stake in Countrywide Financial and tried to stanch the mortgage lender’s bleeding.

text: Merrill Lynch is expected to suffer $15 billion in losses stemming from soured mortgage investments, almost double its original estimate, prompting the firm to raise additional capital from an outside investor.

headline: BofA to Buy Countrywide for $4 Billion

headline: Buyout Bust Cuts Into Fees to Banks, Report Finds
text: The decline in leveraged buyouts is slashing fees for investment banks, including Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan Chase, by about 50 percent, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Northern Rock to Sell Portfolio to JPMorgan
text: Britain’s troubled Northern Rock has sold a 2.2 billion pound ($4.3 billion) portfolio of mortgages to JPMorgan Chase, a first step to help the troubled lender repay loans from the Bank of England, Reuters reported.

headline: Tata’s Nano and Global Warming

Millions of consumers each year could leap virtually overnight from the indignity of two-wheeled motor scooters to the relative luxury of four wheels and a roof.

headline: Hype-notized

Mr. Denby not only suggested that Paul Thomas Anderson fumbled the end of a “There Will be Blood” on purpose, he took the froth on the latte by declaring that “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly” “feels like nothing less than the rebirth of cinema.” Vulture called that “the blurbiest blurb ever blurbed.”

text: The Writers Guild of America, showing good manners and an ear for the moment, announced that they will not hold their awards show on Feb. 9. The thought of holding their own fete while shutting down others seemed a little too, too, the Bagger guesses. It puts all the more attention on the Screen Actors Guild awards, which will be held on Jan. 27. So far, only SAG’s awards show is expected to go off as planned, and with the consent and participation of the A-List.

headline: Time for the Mayor to Make Up His Mind?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s flirtation with the idea of running for president has stretched on and on, with his enthusiastic approval despite his public denials. But even before actually entering the contest, Mr. Bloomberg may have already risked losing people’s patience, Diane Cardwell and Ray Rivera write in a front-page article, noting signs of an emerging backlash. Editorial pages from The Wall Street Journal to The New York Post, The Village Voice and The New Yorker have taken him to task. Members of the administration have been rolling their eyes and referring to Kevin Sheekey, Mr. Bloomberg’s political architect, as the deputy mayor for presidential politics.

headline: Now It Gets Really Ugly
text: How petty can it get in the throw-down between Big Media and the writers? Really, really petty. A rep from one of the publicity firms told the Bagger that ABC sent out an email to all publicists for ABC-affiliated stars who were nominated for the SAG awards on Jan. 27. The rep said the email suggested the stars would have to foot the bill for hairstyling and makeup because the ABC didn’t want to pay for what it expects will be a studio-bashing event.

headline: Moving Billions of People on a Still-Green Planet?
text: Jesse Ausubel, who studies, well, everything at Rockefeller University’s Program for the Human Environment, has long been exploring patterns of development and their broader consequences. He’s a quirky, sometimes prickly, thinker who, for example, sees a fossil fuel, methane, as a keystone — and greatly neglected — resource serving as a bridge to a climate-friendly energy future.

headline: Milan Looks to Teen to Save Its Season
text: One of the great Serie A rivalries will be renewed on Sunday when Napoli visits the San Siro to take on the struggling AC Milan. It was 18 years ago that Napoli, led by the irrepressible Diego Maradona and aided by Daniel Fonseca and a young Gianfranco Zola, edged Milan for the scudetto. It was the azzuri’s last title before Maradona’s tragi-comic, drug-fueled downfall and before Napoli suffered financial disaster.

headline: ‘The Craig Ferguson of the Presidential Race’

headline: Mayor Deflects Talk of Higher Property Taxes

Bloomberg deflected speculation this morning that the city could be headed for higher property taxes in the face of a weakening economy. “I don’t know that they’re going to go up,” the mayor said on his weekly call-in radio program on WABC-AM (770). “The first thing we’re going to do for the city is try to reduce spending.”

headline: Surprise! Instant Jury Duty for Shoppers
text: Finding enough qualified jurors to keep the justice system running has been a nagging problem in American courthouses for decades. Legislatures and court administrators have tried all kinds of angles to attack the problem, from eliminating exemptions (so more people are called) to making jury duty more convenient (so fewer people skip out) to streamlining voire dire and lopping years off the time before a juror can be called again (to make the most use of the people who do show up).

headline: God and Small Things
text: There may not be a lot of agreement among the world’s religions on exactly what constitutes humans “playing God,” but you never hear a preacher or rabbi suggesting such behavior is wise or laudable. So you would think they might have a lot to say about nanotechnology. After all, nanotech involves rearranging not just DNA and the other building blocks of life — already a source of controversy in biotechnology — but the very atoms and molecules that make up all matter. If that is not messing around in God’s closet, what is?

headline: Pick a Color, Any Color
text: Several readers have asked whether we know what color we will be painting the exterior of the house. I’ve been spending most of my spare time this week contemplating the answer.

headline: Will Stock Payments Add to Merrill’s Woes?
text: Merrill Lynch‘s move to accelerate vesting on previously awarded stock-based pay to employees could add to the huge fourth-quarter loss already expected by analysts, Reuters reported Friday.

headline: The Next Sir Edmund Hillarys: Riders on the Storm
text: Yes, Sir Edmund Hillary is dead. But before you start muttering into your Darjeeling about how they don’t make chaps like him anymore, men with pluck and courage and the daft compulsion to test the limits of human achievement at the extreme edges of the Earth, consider these odd words: Cortes Bank and Billabong.

headline: Kids, Get Your Jessica Simpson Mask Here
text: Now, we’re not sure just what use this will be for most Giants fans, presumably watching the Cowboys-Giants game thousands of miles from Texas, but that is not the point. An enterprising man contacted us to tell us that he has created Jessica Simpson masks for fans of recent Cowboys opponents, and has devised a New York-themed one for this week.

headline: How Mozilo Should Spend His Exit Package
text: Speculation is already buzzing that Countrywide Financial‘s chief executive, Angelo R. Mozilo, won’t stick around Bank of America after it completes its purchase of the mortgage lender later this spring..

headline: Maybe exports won’t save us
text: I’ve pointed out that rising exports, thanks to the weak dollar, were what allowed the US to avoid slipping into recession up through 3rd quarter 2007. But Brad Setser points out that real exports have stalled over the last few months (this is monthly non-petroleum exports in 2000 dollars, seasonally adjusted):

headline: Clinton Found Her Voice, Now Seeks Youth
text: No doubt women came out strong for Hillary Rodham Clinton in New Hampshire, but the youth demographic still rallied behind Barack Obama. A new video segment on her Web site reaches out to those younger voters.

headline: Strike News: Throwing the Globes Wide Open
text: The Golden Globes press conference will not be a NBC News exclusive, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association announced Friday.

headline: Too Big or Just Right?
text: Interesting article by Corie Brown in The Los Angeles Times this week on Adam Tolmach of the Ojai Vineyard. According to the article Tolmach has had a conversion experience and has decided to dial back the strength and ripeness of his pinot noirs, chardonnays and syrahs. The article quotes Tolmach as saying that while his wines received high scores from critics, they were not, after all, the style of wines he likes best.

headline: Candidates Push for a N.H. Recount
text: Corrected

headline: Old Trees of New York, Reborn
text: It takes certain qualities — patience, resilience, even stoicism, perhaps — to survive in New York City. That explains the selection criteria that were used to select specimens for an unusual program that will produce genetic reproductions of some of the oldest and sturdiest trees in the five boroughs.Some of the trees go as far back as the creation of Central Park in the 19th century; others are believed be even older. That’s particularly remarkable given that urban trees typically don’t survive longer than 50 years in parks and less than decade on city streets.

headline: UrbanEye: Julian Schnabel
text: "Navigation Drawings," a new exhibition by artist and filmmaker Julian Schnabel opens at the Sperone Westwater gallery.  Melena Ryzik reports.

headline: NBC No Longer Taking Hostages at the Globes
text: NBC has returned custody of the Golden Globes to the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and that means there will be lots of coverage, no pickets and maybe even a few stars. The Bagger is grateful that his betters barked him onto an airplane and he is now in position to cover the unfolding story. See you over the weekend.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 11
text: Here is a slide show of 11 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the funeral of a firefighter on Staten Island, the dismantling of this season’s Christmas decorations in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, and the world’s largest spectator squash tournament.

headline: Group Singalongs Flourish
text: Ben Ratliff finds a band of energetic singers in East  Lansing, Michigan.

headline: The Readers Speak
text: I’m afraid I’ve been a little remiss in answering readers lately, but I did want to address just a few comments before we all break for the weekend.

headline: Bloggingheads: The Politics of Juno
text:
Film critics Chris Orr of The New Republic Online, left, and Ross Douthat of National Review discuss whether recent movies are sending pro-life messages.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Vows | Scenes From a Love Marriage
text: The wedding of Sabeen Ali and Hashim Mian in Coral Gables, Fla., offered a colorful mix of ancient Pakistani and Muslim religious traditions and contemporary customs.

headline: Bill Clinton Tries to Tamp Down ‘Fairy-Tale’ Remark About Obama
text: The Clinton campaign moved Friday to try to quell a potentially damaging backlash over recent comments by Bill and Hillary Clinton that have drawn criticism from African-Americans just as the presidential primary campaign reached Southern states with significant blocs of black voters.

headline: Taco Day on the Trail
text: EAST LOS ANGELES — Sometimes it’s not easy being a candidate for president – particularly if you want to do something like have lunch. Hillary Rodham Clinton found that out Friday afternoon at a lunch (O.K., a photo opportunity) at King Taco, a well-known if tiny taco spot in East Los Angeles, a Mexican-American enclave here.

headline: Vows: Lindsay & Lee
text: After Lindsay Stieber and Lee Milstein attended the same bar review course, they didn't let distance keep them apart.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III catches air (and snow) on Whiteface Mountain in his first foray in snowboarding.

headline: Obama Plays Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS – What happens in Vegas should not stay in Vegas.

headline: A Paradise for Surfers
text: Sandy Huffaker for The New York Times

headline: On the Trail
text: Friday was another busy day on the campaign trail for the Democratic and Republican candidates.

headline: What’s With the East All-Star Goalies?
text: We’ll be the first to agree that the NHL All-Star Game is completely meaningless and a good excuse to take a short holiday from hockey. But it’s still astonishing just how wrongheaded some of the selections can be.

headline: Irene Reid, Singer, Bandleader and Actress, Dies at 77
text: Irene Reid, a singer who toured and recorded with Count Basie’s band and appeared on Broadway in “The Wiz,” died last Saturday in the Bronx. She was 77.

headline: China: Horse Racing to Return
text: The government has approved regular horse racing at the Orient Lucky City racecourse in Wuhan, the main city in Hubei Province, starting in September, and is considering allowing legal gambling on the races next year on a trial basis, the official Xinhua news agency reported. Gambling, popular in pre-Communist China, has been illegal since the Communists came to power in 1949 and deemed it a major vice, along with opium.

headline: After Finding the Right Fit, Moss Is Proving Critics Wrong
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Dennis Green spent a lot of time last spring with a telephone jammed against his ear, defending a player he thought he understood. Caller after caller wondered how the player, who had once flippantly said he played when he wanted to, could possibly fit in with the most businesslike of football franchises.

headline: Bush, Leaving Israel, Keeps Up Push for Peace Treaty
text: JERUSALEM  As he left for Kuwait, President Bush promised on Friday to return in May for Israel’s 60th anniversary, a visit that could serve as additional pressure on both Israelis and Palestinians to negotiate a peace treaty by the end of his term.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about the American detention center at the Bagram military base in Afghanistan omitted a reporting credit. Kirk Semple, Carlotta Gall and Abdul Waheed Wafa contributed from Kabul.

headline: 3 Convicted Who Led Charity Tied to Militants
text: Three leaders of a defunct Islamic charity were convicted Friday of defrauding the federal government by winning tax-exempt status for their organization while concealing the fact that it supported militant fighters in Afghanistan and elsewhere.

headline: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Seeking to Block Atlantic Yards
text: A state judge on Friday dismissed a lawsuit filed by a coalition of community groups against the Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn, dealing a major setback to opponents of the $4 billion development plan.

headline: Many Mulligans Later, City Is to Start Anew, and Alone, on Bronx Golf Course
text: It was supposed to be a world-class golf course, designed by Jack Nicklaus, and best of all, it would cost the city next to nothing. Developers would pay for it all and recoup the cost of the city-owned course from greens fees.

headline: U.S. and Europe Ponder Divergent Rate Policies
text: FRANKFURT  Can Europe’s economy stay on track even if the United States goes off the rails?

headline: A Romance Novelist Is Accused of Copying
text: Who says romance novel fans care only about ripped bodices and manly men?

headline: A Political Forum’s Message: We’re One Nation
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Clergyman of the Streets Leaves His Historic Pulpit
text: LEIPZIG, Germany

headline: Not So Itsy Bitsy
text: A giant sculpture of a spider by Louise Bourgeois, similar to one, below,  that has been luring the crowds to Tate Modern on London’s South Bank, has been donated to the gallery, the BBC reported. Vicente Todoli, the museum’s director, called the gift of the almost 30-foot-tall work, titled “Maman,” a “historic moment.” The steel and bronze sculpture was given to the Tate by Ms. Bourgeois and an anonymous benefactor. It is the largest of a series of spiders made by Ms. Bourgeois, now 96. The artist, who lives in New York, has described the piece as “an ode to my mother, my best friend.” She added: “Like spiders, my mother was very clever. Spiders are friendly presences that eat mosquitoes.”

headline: Top Giuliani Aides Forgo Salaries to Help Big Push
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s senior campaign aides have given up their paychecks for the month to help save dwindling campaign funds as Mr. Giuliani heads into the crucial primary races where he has staked his candidacy.

headline: U.N. Nuclear Official Urges Iran to Clarify ‘Outstanding Issues’
text: TEHRAN  Mohamed ElBaradei, the chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency, on Friday urged Iran to move more quickly to clarify questions about its nuclear activities, the Iranian news agency ISNA reported.

headline: Cardiac Arrests in the Hospital
text: To the Editor:

headline: Big Waves Mean No Small Preparation for Surfers
text: HALF MOON BAY, Calif.  The image of the quintessential American surfer  a bronzed slacker in board shorts  may be firmly entrenched. But that surfer dude bears little resemblance to the athletes known as big-wave surfers, a small community composed of men and women who often become amateur oceanographers and experts in wave dynamics in order to ride waves that can be more than 50 feet high.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about the Knicks’ 101-92 loss to the Houston Rockets misidentified the referee who ejected Coach Isiah Thomas after there was incidental contact between them. It was Eric Lewis  not Dan Crawford, another official working the game. Because of an editing error, an article on Friday repeated the error. And a picture caption in some editions with the article on Friday, using information from the European Pressphoto Agency, misidentified the referee shown with Mr. Thomas. It was Mr. Lewis, not Mr. Crawford. (Go to Article)

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $6,363,022

headline: Citing Drop in Inmate Population, Spitzer Plans to Close Four Prisons Upstate
text: The Spitzer administration announced on Friday a plan to close a medium-security prison and three minimum-security camps upstate, citing the declining crime and prison population across the state. Officials said the move would save taxpayers upward of $70 million in the next few years.

headline: Getting Help to Enable Herself to Help Others
text: “The littlest things you do in people’s lives that, you don’t know, it changes their whole life,” Iman Thomas said.

headline: A Day of Confusion at Golden Globes
text: The fight over the Golden Globes on Sunday night has left the once glamorous awards show in a confusing state: a news conference announcing the winners will still be broadcast on NBC, but not exclusively; the striking writers will not picket the event as threatened but it is unclear how many nominees or other celebrities will show up.

headline: Running and Fighting, All to Save Her Son
text: The writers’ strike brings with it, of course, the significant potential to lower our viewing standards now that television’s midseason is under way. How amenable will most people be to rendering honest judgments on anything new and being shown and not the 923rd season of a reality venture in which people trade wives, or nannies, or plastic surgeries, or wallpaper or ferrets?

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about the Knicks’ 101-92 loss to the Houston Rockets misidentified the referee who ejected Coach Isiah Thomas after there was incidental contact between them. It was Eric Lewis  not Dan Crawford, another official working the game. Because of an editing error, an article on Friday repeated the error. And a picture caption in some editions with the article on Friday, using information from the European Pressphoto Agency, misidentified the referee shown with Mr. Thomas. It was Mr. Lewis, not Mr. Crawford.

headline: Of Hope and Politics
text: We’re about to find out how resilient Barack Obama is.

headline: Ringo Returns
text: Ringo Starr, above, returned to his hometown of Liverpool, England, on Friday to help kick off the city’s year as a European Capital of Culture, The Associated Press reported. The ex-Beatle joined Dave Stewart of Eurythmics in headlining an outdoor concert that included about 600 local musicians. On Saturday Mr. Starr is to appear in “Liverpool, the Musical,” a tribute to the city’s musical heritage, which features the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra and local rock groups. Each year two cities in the European Union are designated culture capitals.

headline: Food From Cloned Animals Seems Safe, a Panel Finds
text: Meat and milk from cloned animals seem to pose no special health risks, said a draft report released Friday by the European Food Safety Agency. It was a first step toward the eventual sale of such products within the European Union.

headline: Christopher Bowman, Skating Champion, Is Dead at 40
text: Christopher Bowman, a two-time United States figure skating champion acclaimed as a stylish, crowd-pleasing performer despite a long struggle with drug abuse, was found dead Thursday in North Hills, Calif., near Los Angeles. He was 40.

headline: A Resilient Indonesia Moves Beyond Suharto
text: JAKARTA  As Indonesia’s former strongman, Suharto, lay on his sickbed this week, the country that rejected him 10 years ago was in the early stages of a democratic election campaign.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Friday about Thursday’s Republican presidential debate in Myrtle Beach, S.C., referred incompletely to the sponsors of the debate. In addition to the South Carolina Republican Party, Fox News Channel sponsored the debate.

headline: Teach to the Test
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cleopatra’s Demise Told in Dramatic Harmonies
text: Berlioz described his cantata “La Mort de Cléopâtre” as “somber, broad, sinister and lugubrious: a great voice breathing a menacing lament in the mysterious stillness of the night.” The Prix de Rome jury, however, to which he submitted it in 1829, thought the bold harmonies and adventurous orchestral sonorities weird.

headline: A Quartet Crosses Its Boundaries
text: These days young musicians are devoting a lot of thought and energy to redefining themselves, not only in terms of what and where they perform but in purely structural matters as well. The Lark Quartet offered a glimpse of its own ambitious reconfiguration plan on Thursday evening when it presented itself, and friends, as the Lark Chamber Artists in an expansive concert at the newly renovated (and acoustically brightened) Merkin Concert Hall.

headline: Giants-Cowboys Game Is on the Lines
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants face the favored Cowboys on Sunday in the National Football Conference divisional playoffs, the outcome may depend on how the Giants’ aggressive defensive line performs against the Cowboys’ big and gifted offensive line.

headline: Oil Is Blamed for Widening Trade Deficit
text: Record oil prices widened the United States trade deficit in November as the cost of imported petroleum outpaced a modest rise in exports.

headline: Jurors’ Testimony in Cape Cod Murder Ends
text: BARNSTABLE, Mass.  Rare juror testimony on whether racial bias tainted a high-profile murder conviction ended here on Friday, leaving the judge alone with the thorny task of deciding whether a new trial is warranted.

headline: Blinded and Broken by Ambition
text: White Plains

headline: Old or New? Once Each With Feeling
text: It wasn’t supposed to be a competition, but everyone knew it was. At the Morgan Library & Museum on Thursday, two inanimate objects battled for first place. In one corner stood a Conrad Graff fortepiano from the first part of the 19th century, in the other a seven-foot Steinway grand.

headline: 3 Buddies Home From Iraq Are Charged With Murdering a 4th
text: COLORADO SPRINGS  After surviving intense combat in Iraq, Specialist Kevin Shields was killed on what he had thought was friendly soil. His bloody, bullet-riddled body was found by a newspaper deliverer, sprawled on a downtown sidewalk here on Dec. 1.

headline: That Daunting Commute
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Islanders, an Early Look at a Top Prospect
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  On the first day of his professional hockey career, Kyle Okposo got a ride to the Bridgeport Sound Tigers’ practice with Jeff Tambellini, his new housemate and linemate. Tambellini steered clear of hockey talk.

headline: Directors and Producers to Begin Talks
text: LOS ANGELES  The Directors Guild of America and Hollywood’s production companies said Friday afternoon that they plan to start formal contract negotiations on Saturday, promising a significant break in the entertainment industry’s troubled labor situations.

headline: Packers’ Harris Is at the Front of a Defensive Turnaround
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Four years after making one of the most memorable plays in Green Bay Packers playoff history, cornerback Al Harris stepped to the lectern at a news conference this week and flatly announced he would not entertain questions about it.

headline: Curing What Ails Starbucks
text: To: Howard Schultz

headline: Fighting to Lose
text: Nyack, N.Y.

headline: Lottery Numbers
CSI Gives CBS a Lift
text: With new episodes of ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” and CBS’s “CSI” at 9 p.m. on Thursday, both networks surged to the top of the night’s ratings. “CSI” attracted the largest audience, 18.1 million, Nielsen estimated. But “Grey’s Anatomy” (17.6 million) led among viewers ages 18 to 49, putting ABC on top in that demographic. CBS’s "Without a Trace" won at 10 p.m. in total viewers (13.8 million), while “ER” on NBC (9.1 million) ranked first in the hour among the 18-to-49 group. For the night, NBC ranked third in that age group, with “The Celebrity Apprentice” at 9 (8.1 million), “My Name is Earl” (7.7 million) and “30 Rock” (6 million).

headline: Variation on a Partner Signal Becomes Lost in Transmission
text: The basic suit-preference signal was invented by Hy Lavinthal in 1934. Suppose the contract is four spades. You lead a singleton club. Partner, bless his or her boots, wins with the club ace and gives you a club ruff. If only you could get partner back on lead, you could get a second ruff and defeat the contract. But do you shift to a spade, heart or diamond?

headline: South Africa: Police Chief to Be Charged
text: Prosecutors said they would charge Jackie Selebi, the national police commissioner and president of Interpol who has been accused of having links to organized crime syndicates, with corruption. A date for the court hearing has yet to be determined, they said.

headline: Taiwan Prepares for First of 2 Major 2008 Elections
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan  Voters went to the polls here on Saturday in the first of two closely spaced elections that will shape this self-governing island’s strategy for dealing with mainland China, its rival.

headline: W. F. Ganong, 83, Expert in Brain’s Control of Body, Dies
text: William F. Ganong, a former chairman of one of the leading physiology departments at an American university and one of the first scientists to trace how the brain controls important internal functions of the body, died Dec. 23 at his home in Albany, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Court Allows Scientists to Work at NASA Until Trial Over Background Checks
text: A group of scientists working at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory won a round in federal court on Friday in their challenge to a Bush administration requirement that they submit to extensive background checks or face losing their jobs.

headline: Syria Rebuilds on Site Destroyed by Israeli Bombs
text: The puzzling site in Syria that Israeli jets bombed in September grew more curious on Friday with the release of a satellite photograph showing new construction there that resembles the site’s former main building.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary by The Associated Press on Tuesday about Rabbi Shmuel Berenbaum, leader of the Mir Yeshiva in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to its policy on music, song and dance, and referred imprecisely to the Torah, the sole subject of the yeshiva’s curriculum. As defined by Orthodox Jews, the Torah can include the Old Testament, commentaries upon it and the oral tradition known as the Talmud  not just the first five books of the Bible. And the yeshiva does in fact permit music, song and dance; they are not shunned.

headline: Knicks’ Starters Play Poorly, Then Not at All
text: Fifteen seconds into the Knicks’ game against the Toronto Raptors on Friday, Chris Bosh sank a smooth 15-foot jumper from the baseline. The deficit felt narrow at the time, only 2-0, but it turned out to be wider than an ocean. For the rest of the evening, the Knicks played from behind.

headline: Judge Sentences Jones to 6 Months in Prison
text: WHITE PLAINS  The former track star Marion Jones’s tearful courtroom plea to avoid jail was denied Friday by a federal judge who said her sentence should serve as a deterrent for others who may lie to federal agents, and Jones was sentenced to six months in prison for pleading guilty to two counts of perjury.

headline: Some Debt Trends Are Good. This Isn’t One of Them.
text: AMERICAN credit card debt is growing at the fastest rate in years, a fact that may signal coming trouble for the banks that issue them.

headline: Suitcase of Cash Tangles U.S. and 2 Latin Nations in Intrigue
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  One day last August, an airport policewoman in Buenos Aires noticed something peculiar as she was monitoring a baggage scanner: the appearance of six perfect, dense rectangles inside a suitcase.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary Friday about Sir Edmund Hillary, who with Tenzing Norgay became the first to scale Mount Everest, misidentified the route they took to the summit. It is the South Col, not the South Tor. In comparing the feat to one by Charles A. Lindbergh, the obituary misstated Lindbergh’s accomplishment. Though he was the first to make a solo nonstop trans-Atlantic flight, in 1927, he was not the first aviator to make the nonstop crossing; John W. Alcock and Arthur W. Brown did so together in 1919, from Newfoundland to Ireland. In addition, the precedents for Sir Edmund’s reaching the South Pole in 1957-58 were referred to incorrectly. Robert Falcon Scott reached the pole in 1912, and the United States built a base there in 1956; Sir Edmund was not the first to reach the pole since Roald Amundsen in 1911.

headline: North Korea: Russia Regrets ‘Slow’ Talks
text: Russia regrets the slowed state of progress in talks on North Korea’s nuclear program but will fulfill its commitment under the six-nation agreement to provide North Korea with fuel oil this month so as not to slow diplomatic efforts further, a senior Russian diplomat said, according to Russian news reports. The announcement came as Christopher R. Hill, the chief United States envoy for North Korea, visited Moscow to discuss diplomatic approaches to North Korea’s nuclear program. North Korea did not meet a year-end deadline to disclose its nuclear activities. Mr. Hill again urged North Korea to make a complete declaration and said another meeting of the two Koreas, the United States, China, Japan and Russia could be held soon.

headline: In an Ancient Culture, a Team Takes Root
text: ACOMA PUEBLO, N.M.  To the north, the Sky City casino draws truckers off Interstate 40 with its billboard advertisements promising loose slots and low limits.

headline: Directors and Producers to Hold Talks
Robbery of Transit Worker Turns Into Knife Fight, Killing One
text: A New York City Transit worker walking home after a late shift, three suspected muggers armed with a curved knife and a bystander whose role was unclear converged on a rainy street in Upper Manhattan late Thursday in a blood-soaked encounter that left the bystander stabbed to death and two others  including the transit worker  hospitalized.

headline: France: Sarkozy’s Ex Loses Bid to Bar Book
text: A Paris court rejected an attempt by President Nicolas Sarkozy’s ex-wife Cécilia, left, to block publication of a book that quotes her making critical comments about him. It ruled that a ban “would be totally disproportionate, all the more so because the book is already on sale.” The book, “Cécilia,” by Anna Bitton, appeared in bookstores Thursday and was ranked as the top seller on Amazon’s French site on Friday. The judge also noted that Ms. Sarkozy had discussed her relationship with her ex-husband in two interviews after her divorce, suggesting she was not seeking to keep her private life secret.

headline: The Change We Want
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about reaction from people in Central Park to a settlement in which New York City agreed to temporarily ease crowd-size rules for the Great Lawn misidentified the area of the park where Garth Brooks, the country singer, held a concert in 1997. It was the North Meadow, not the Great Lawn.

headline: Escalating Losses Force Citigroup to Seek More Foreign Investment
text: Citigroup is turning to cash-rich foreign investors for a second time as it confronts mounting losses on mortgage-related investments.

headline: Chase Buys Some of Lender’s Assets
text: LONDON  Northern Rock, one of Europe’s biggest casualties of the credit crisis, sold some of its mortgage portfolio to JPMorgan Chase on Friday as part of its plan to repay about £25 billion ($49 billion) in emergency funding.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Jan. 2 about construction of a park on the site of the High Line elevated tracks in Lower Manhattan misidentified the employer of Gerard Zimmermann, a chief inspector, who said the elevation of the project was not a problem for workers. He works for the LiRo Group, a construction consulting firm, not Kiska Construction, the general contractor.

headline: U.S. Issues National ID Standards, Setting Stage for a Showdown
text: WASHINGTON  The federal government issued national standards on Friday that states would have to meet in order for driver’s licenses they issue to qualify as identification at airports and federal buildings, setting the stage for a confrontation with states that have voted not to cooperate.

headline: Toll Increases in New Jersey Would Be Steep, and the Debate Will Be Fierce
text: Driving the family car on the New Jersey Turnpike from the Lincoln Tunnel to the Delaware Memorial Bridge  just about the length of the highway  could rise to $48 from $5.85. For truck drivers, navigating that same stretch of highway would soar to $186 from the current $23.

headline: Mother Accused of Endangerment Is Now Charged With Killing Baby
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. (AP)  A Piscataway woman recently accused of child endangerment for leaving her 9-month-old daughter alone in a car was charged with murder on Friday after she drowned the girl at the family home, law enforcement officials said.

headline: A Mountaineer Who Defined the Notion of Heroic Explorer
text: “I was just an enthusiastic mountaineer of modest abilities,” Sir Edmund Hillary said on the 50th anniversary of his pioneering climb of Mount Everest, “an average bloke.” Even at the moment of his greatest triumph, he claimed no more. After his descent in 1953, he wrote to his mother, “Well, I may not have produced much joy or happiness in the world but at least I’ve helped make the Hillary name a bit more famous.”

headline: Yonkers and the Leaf Blowers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sir Edmund Hillary
text: I am one of those people who can close their eyes and see Hillary and Norgay on the summit of Everest. I was born the year before that climb, and while I was growing up, Sir Edmund Hillary was the last word in simple, bold heroism. I quietly set him apart in my mind, knowing that I would probably never test my own limits of physical and mental endurance, as he did. What makes the news of his death Friday at age 88 so moving, was his modesty, the sense of a civilian heroism held in reserve apart from that one great moment. He made the word “beekeeper”  his and his father’s vocation  sound like an honorific.

headline: Boris Lurie, Leader of a Confrontational Art Movement, Dies at 83
text: Boris Lurie, a Russian-born artist who survived the Holocaust and then depicted its horrors while leading a confrontational movement called No! Art, died Monday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Florida: Safety Board Faults Cruise Line
text: A boiler explosion that killed eight crew members on a passenger ship was probably caused by Norwegian Cruise Line’s improper operation, maintenance and inspection of the steam chamber, federal investigators have said. Part of the boiler on the S.S. Norway had “extensive fatigue cracking” and deteriorated materials that caused it to rupture under steam pressure in May 2003, the National Transportation Safety Board said in a report adopted last October. The Norway, the line’s only steam-powered ship, was docked in Miami when the boiler exploded. Seventeen workers were injured, but none of the 2,135 passengers were hurt.

headline: True and Untrue Confessions
text: What did Martin Tankleff look and sound like when he confessed in 1988 to bludgeoning and slashing his parents to death? Did he seem like a killer or a confused 17-year-old being pressured into admitting something that he did not do? We’ll never know. There is no video or audio recording, just an incomplete narrative, handwritten by detectives, which Mr. Tankleff signed, quickly repudiated, and spent nearly two decades trying to undo.

headline: The Battle of the Mitts
text: Ever since Barack Obama won big in Iowa, Mitt Romney has been running as a “change” candidate. It is a little strange to see a guy whose party has been in power for years standing in front of a big blue “Washington is Broken” sign, but I think we have already determined that Romney is nothing if not really, really adaptable.

headline: On a Board, Shredding and Stomping, but Mostly Falling
text: I COMMITTED to my executive pursuit of snowboarding by deliberately falling down on my butt. It was minus 17 degrees on the slopes of Whiteface Mountain outside Lake Placid, N.Y. My 56-year-old body was wrapped in long johns, a fur-lined jacket and wind pants. With my black rental helmet, amber goggles and black felt face mask, I fancied myself a winterized Power Ranger. I was determined to drop in, air it out and stomp a ride  just as soon as I learned what all of that meant.

headline: Picking Pockets? Nah, Surfing Shoulders
text: The stop at Grand Central barely amounted to a pause. On the evening of Nov. 29, at the end of a long, wearing day, a man on his way home to Connecticut decided to get a beer for the trip. Almost without breaking stride, he dashed up to a wall of cash machines, took out $40, bought his beer and caught his train.

headline: Alongside the History of the Nation, the Story of Jewish Immigrants
text: PHILADELPHIA  Alongside some of the most historic landmarks in the United States, a building is rising that will tell the story of the national immigration experience through the life of the Jewish people.

headline: Awards Season, and the Swag Goes to ... Few
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  The Hollywood writers’ strike has claimed many casualties in the past few weeks, including this Sunday’s Golden Globes award ceremony, an important precursor to the Oscars. And now it threatens another beloved Tinseltown institution: the swag bag.

headline: What Is Lurking in a Laptop?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Colorado: Woman Missing After Avalanche
text: Rescue crews were searching for a woman reportedly swept away by an avalanche in southern Colorado, and searchers continued to hunt for two New Mexico snowboarders who have been missing in southwestern Colorado since last weekend. The authorities said a man reported his sister missing after they were hit by an avalanche Thursday near the 14,345-foot Blanca Peak. Ground crews were searching, but a helicopter was forced back because of high wind, said Carol Orton, a spokeswoman for the Alamosa County sheriff.

headline: With Economy Slowing, All Speeches Are Turning to It
text: WARREN, Mich.  Presidential hopefuls of both parties pivoted sharply to the economy on Friday, proposing new federal spending plans, help for homeowners facing foreclosures and tax cuts and making promises to preserve and create new jobs.

headline: Searching for Happiness? Beware of Commercials
text: The surface of a production by the French-Austrian performance group Superamas is so shiny and so deeply comical that its pretty wrapping almost  but not quite  masks the seriousness of its core. As part of the Under the Radar Festival, the collective returned to the Kitchen on Thursday with the final installment of a trilogy, “BIG, 3rd episode (happy/end),” a purposeful exploration of the most lauded of Oprah-approved emotions: happiness.

headline: Teachers Sue to Block Hotel Workers’ Union Vote in Nevada Caucus
text: LAS VEGAS  Nevada’s state teachers union and six Las Vegas area residents filed a lawsuit late Friday that could make it harder for many members of the state’s huge hotel workers union to vote in the hotly contested Jan. 19 Democratic caucus in Nevada.

headline: The Burger and Latte Combo
text: McDONALD’S assault on Starbucks’s coffee hegemony is not a bet-the-franchise move, but it is a wrongheaded strategy that is bound to lose, according to Chris Dannen, writing on Fast Company’s blog this week (blog.fastcompany.com).

headline: Disney Reports Chief’s Compensation
text: LOS ANGELES (AP)  Robert A. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, received a compensation package in the 2007 fiscal year valued by the company at $27.7 million, according to an analysis of documents filed Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Debt Relief Made Harder for Homeowners
text: Bankruptcy filings began climbing last year, as the housing crisis and rising consumer debt began to take their toll.

headline: Iraq Passes Bill Easing Limits on Former Baathists
text: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi Parliament passed a bill Saturday to allow some former officials from Saddam Hussein’s party to apply for government positions, in the first of the political benchmark measures to pass after months of American pressure for progress.

headline: A Long-Dry California River Gets, and Gives, New Life
text: INDEPENDENCE, Calif.  What Los Angeles took a century ago  a 62-mile stretch of river here in the parched Owens Valley  it is now giving back.

headline: Bush and Congress Seen Pushing for Stimulus Plan
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration and Congressional leaders, increasingly concerned about a possible recession, are moving closer to agreeing that an economic stimulus package is needed soon, Washington officials said Friday.

headline: Old Worries Bring Big Decline
text: In many ways, the markets seem to be stuck in a loop.

headline: Dismay at Plan to Shut 2 Newark Hospitals
text: NEWARK  The demise of a community hospital is always painful, but residents here awoke Friday to the depressing news that two of the city’s most beloved hospitals will close in the spring.

headline: Real Estate, Cheap and Scary
text: HERE’S one way of dealing with home prices that remain stubbornly high despite the recent downturn: Buy your second home first.

headline: Demand More From Libya
text: To the Editor:

headline: Probation in Case of Stolen Cruise Photos
text: A man who tried to extort $1.3 million from Tom Cruise in exchange for stolen photographs of his wedding to Katie Holmes was sentenced to two years probation, The Associated Press reported. Marc Lewis Gittleman was also fined $3,000 after pleading guilty on Sept. 21 to interstate transportation of stolen property. Mr. Gittleman, a computer technician, obtained thousands of photos from a damaged hard drive that was brought to his workplace by a photographer. He then contacted David Hans Schmidt, 47, who was known for peddling nude pictures and sex tapes of celebrities, and sent Mr. Cruise an e-mail message demanding $1.3 million to keep the pictures private. The authorities set up a sting operation to catch the two men. Mr. Schmidt pleaded guilty to transmitting threatening communications with intent to extort and hanged himself in September.

headline: Bush Promises to Return to Israel
text: JERUSALEM  As he left on Friday for Kuwait, President Bush promised to return in May for Israel’s 60th anniversary, a visit that could serve as additional pressure on both Israelis and Palestinians to negotiate a peace treaty by the end of his term.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Picture captions with an article on Tuesday about the aftermath of a disputed presidential election in Kenya misspelled the name of the president’s ethnic group, whose members were targets of much of the violence by opposition supporters. They are the Kikuyus, not the Kiyukus.

headline: A 16-Year-Old, Two Families and One Hard Decision
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Role in Pakistan: Lessons for Washington
text: To the Editor:

headline: Breaking the Habit of Disposable Diapers
text: TERESON DUPUY thinks reusable diapers are having their back-to-the-future moment.

headline: Bush Prepared to Slow Reduction of Forces in Iraq
text: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait  President Bush said Saturday that he was prepared to slow or even halt further reductions of forces in Iraq, emphasizing that any decision depended on security and the stability of the Iraqi government.

headline: Policies on Juvenile Detention
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Nature of Reasons: Two Philosophers Feud Over a Book Review
text: Over the ages, philosophy has offered valuable guidance on profound questions of truth, beauty and existence, yet still unresolved is the conundrum of how to respond to a bad book review.

headline: Museum Attendance Drops in Sweden
text: Visits to Sweden’s national museums dropped nearly 20 percent last year after they ended their free admissions policy, Agence France-Presse reported. The culture ministry said that Sweden’s 19 national museums, 16 of them in Stockholm, recorded some 6.5 million visits in 2007, down from around 8.0 million a year earlier. The decline came after Sweden’s government pushed through new admission fees to the museums starting on Jan. 1, 2007, two years after the previous government had removed the fees.

headline: A Combative Thompson Sways Voters
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.  John and Ann Berenberk dutifully watched the umpteenth Republican presidential debate on television on Thursday night and had an epiphany. It was about the candidate they had previously referred to as the tall, silent one. Fred D. Thompson.

headline: Magic and Mayhem From a Video Game
text: Like actors in an amateur stage play, the large, mostly all-star  or has-been star  cast of “In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale” look, rather dazedly, to be playing dress-up.

headline: Bank of America’s Chief Makes Big Bet
text: Kenneth D. Lewis has gambled on bold acquisitions to build Bank of America into the nation’s largest bank.

headline: Louisiana: Supremacists to Rally in Jena
text: A white supremacist group will be allowed to hold a rally in Jena on Martin Luther King’s Birthday without posting a $10,000 bond after a federal judge questioned the constitutionality of the requirement in pretrial conferences, officials said. The Nationalist Movement, based in Learned, Miss., wants to protest a march held last September to support the Jena Six, a group of black teenagers charged in the beating of a white schoolmate on Dec. 4, 2006. Towns are permitted to have ordinances for groups wanting to protest or march, said Walter E. Dorroh Jr., the town counsel. But if the law requires a bond, he said, it must have a provision to set that aside for indigent groups or have an appeals process. Jena’s ordinance did not, he said.

headline: Footnote
text: Aidan Quinn completes the cast of the new history play by Richard Nelson, “Conversations in Tusculum,” at the Public Theater. Mr. Quinn is to play Brutus alongside Brian Dennehy as Cicero, Joe Grifasi as Syrus, Gloria Reuben as Porcia, David Strathairn as Cassius and Maria Tucci as Servilia. Previews begin Feb. 19.

headline: British Peer Cites Twins Who Married Unwittingly
text: LONDON  A brother and sister who were parted at birth and adopted by different families married without knowing of their biological relationship, and then won an annulment, a leading anti-abortion campaigner, David Alton, said in the House of Lords on Friday.

headline: Director of Music at Trinity Steps Down
text: Owen Burdick, the organist and music director at Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan, who significantly improved its musical offerings and became a major fixture on the early-music scene, abruptly left his job on Monday after 17 years.

headline: Ailing District to Get Grant for Schools
text: Legislative leaders announced on Friday that they had reached an agreement for an $8 million bailout of the financially troubled, 2,800-student Roosevelt school system in Nassau County after earlier efforts stalled last fall.

headline: Clintons Move to Tamp Down Criticism From Blacks About Recent Comments
text: WASHINGTON  The Clinton campaign moved Friday to try to quell a potentially damaging reaction to recent comments by Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton that have drawn criticism from African-Americans just as the presidential primary campaign reached Southern states with significant numbers of black voters.

headline: Nevada: O.J. Simpson Jailed
text: O. J. Simpson was taken into custody in Florida and will be brought before a judge in Las Vegas on accusations that he violated terms of his bail in an armed robbery case. District Attorney David Roger of Clark County, Nev., said that in a voice-mail message, Mr. Simpson told his bail bondsman to contact a co-defendant, Clarence Stewart, and express frustration about testimony given at the hearing where Mr. Simpson, Mr. Stewart and Charles Ehrlich were ordered to stand trial. Mr. Simpson had been instructed by a justice of the peace not to have contact with anyone involved in the case  not even by “carrier pigeon.”

headline: For McNamee and Clemens, a New Dispute
text: Brian McNamee told federal authorities last summer that Roger Clemens developed an abscess on his buttocks about the same time that McNamee said he was giving him steroid injections during the 1998 season, according to a lawyer with knowledge of details of the case.

headline: Lack of Supervision Noted in Deaths of Home-Schooled
text: Ten states and the District of Columbia, where Banita M. Jacks was charged on Thursday with four counts of first-degree murder in the deaths of her four daughters, have no regulations regarding home schooling, not even the requirement that families notify the authorities that they are educating their children at home.

headline: Resurrecting an Urban Earth Mother
text: Synesthesia, the sensory phenomenon in which musical sounds can be perceived as specific colors and objects, was a condition experienced by the phenomenally gifted singer-songwriter Laura Nyro, who died 10 years ago. So states the sometime Broadway singer Judy Kuhn in “Serious Playground: The Songs of Laura Nyro” (a nightclub spinoff from her 2001 Off Broadway show, “Eli’s Comin’ ”), playing Thursday evenings at Iridium through Jan. 31. (Ms. Kuhn also has an album with the same title.)

headline: Munch Thieves Draw Longer Sentences
text: The Norwegian Supreme Court on Friday increased the sentences of two men convicted of stealing two masterworks by Edvard Munch, “The Scream” and “Madonna,” right, and ordered a new trial for a third convicted man, The Associated Press reported. The paintings were stolen in August 2004 in a daylight raid on the Munch Museum in Oslo. They were recovered by police nearly two years later, and are undergoing repairs for scrapes, punctures, loose paint and moisture damage. Last month the three men appealed their 2006 sentences. In answer, Norway’s highest court unanimously ruled that the prison terms for two of the men, Petter Tharaldsen and Stian Skjold, were not long enough, considering the “irreplaceable national cultural value” of the paintings. The court increased Mr. Tharaldsen’s sentence by one year, to 10 ½ years, and Mr. Skjold’s sentence by six months, to six years. The court did reject the conviction of a third man, Bjoern Hoen, saying that testimony in his trial may have been tainted, and sent his case back for a new trial.

headline: Keep Up the Fight on AIDS
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rituals and Symptoms in a Triple Bill of Movement
text: Is this true? Do we believe this? These questions  constantly asked by actors about their own performances and those of their colleagues  should apply across the board in the arts. During the new triple bill presented by Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet on Thursday night, they came to mind again, but because I could not believe in, or find truth in, more than two-thirds of what was before me.

headline: On Texting, a Question of Access or Invasion
text: NASHVILLE  Like many 17-year-olds, Jrue Holiday does not answer his cellphone.

headline: Should Voter ID Be Required?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cleveland Sues 21 Lenders Over Subprime Mortgages
text: CLEVELAND  Cleveland is suing 21 of the nation’s largest banks and financial institutions, accusing them of knowingly plunging the city into a financial crisis by flooding the local housing market with subprime mortgage loans to people who could never repay.

headline: Indian Point Nuclear Waste Moved to New, Dry Home
text: Nuclear waste may not have found a permanent resting place, but 32 bundles of spent fuel rods from the Indian Point 2 plant in Westchester County have found a home suitable for at least the next few decades  a steel and concrete cask surrounded by razor wire, floodlights and surveillance cameras about 300 feet from the reactor building.

headline: Nets Fade in Fourth as Celtics Take Over
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Suddenly, and for no apparent reason, the Nets began handling the basketball Friday as if it weighed 22 pounds instead of 22 ounces. Open shots hit the rim, and passes skipped off their hands and to the Boston Celtics.

headline: A Tale of Teaching in China
text: To the Editor:

headline: Report Stirs Concern Kazakh Oil Deal May Be Scuttled
text: MOSCOW  Shares in the Italian oil company Eni dipped on Friday after a Russian news agency reported that the government of Kazakhstan was preparing to cancel a contract with a consortium led by Eni that is developing the Kashagan field, one of the world’s largest oil projects.

headline: Anxiety for Luxury Brands as Tiffany Reports Slowdown
text: Not even luxury retailers are immune.

headline: Inquiry Focuses on Withholding of Data on Loans
text: An investigation into the mortgage crisis by New York State prosecutors is now focusing on whether Wall Street banks withheld crucial information about the risks posed by investments linked to subprime loans.

headline: Nepal: Crucial Election Set for April
text: An election to choose an assembly that will rewrite the Constitution and guide Nepal to a new political system after the downfall of the monarchy will be held April 10, the government said. The election has been postponed three times since June.

headline: Obama Giving Clinton a Race in Her Backyard
text: With Senator Barack Obama vowing to challenge Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on her home turf, the Democratic presidential primary in New York on Feb. 5 is shaping up as the state’s most competitive since 1992, when Bill Clinton took up a rival’s mantra of change to all but cinch the nomination.

headline: Justices to Hear Case Testing Rule on Witness
text: WASHINGTON  A defendant’s right to cross-examine the prosecution’s witnesses is among the most valuable of constitutional rights in the courtroom, one to which the Supreme Court has paid increasing attention in the last few years. A landmark decision in 2004 held that unless the witness is available for cross-examination, the state cannot ordinarily introduce any incriminating statements the witness made before disappearing.

headline: United We Fall
text: Austin, Tex.

headline: At a Child-Murder Trial, Raising Questions All Parents Face
text: The prosecutor posed a series of questions about the challenges of raising children, the necessity of discipline, the ubiquity of corporal punishment, and the matter of how hard is too hard.

headline: Still Waiting to Seize the Moment
text: Visiting the Middle East this week, President Bush sounded an unaccustomed note of diplomatic urgency. He insisted that Israel and the Palestinians will conclude a peace agreement before he leaves office in early 2009, and he tried to rhetorically prod the process along.

headline: Gas Terminal Gets Nearer to Approval
text: HARTFORD (AP)  A liquefied natural gas terminal proposed for Long Island Sound moved a step closer to approval on Friday with a finding by the staff of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that it would have no major environmental impact on the region.

headline: Publicly Financed Elections
text: To the Editor:

headline: Putting Price on Flights of Fantasy
text: MY husband and I struggle to stay in sync financially  which is being polite about it.

headline: Body Double Onstage
text: Miley Cyrus uses a body double. A YouTube video shows the 15-year-old entertainer as Hannah Montana dancing onstage during the popular “Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus Best of Both Worlds” tour. She goes offstage through a trapdoor, but another girl, identically dressed and with blond hair, appears and briefly stands in as Hannah. Ms. Cyrus’s public relations firm denied that anything underhanded was at work. The switch, it said, is used in only one song to “help speed the star’s transition from Hannah to Miley.”

headline: Iran Encounter Grimly Echoes ’02 War Game
text: WASHINGTON  There is a reason American military officers express grim concern over the tactics used by Iranian sailors last weekend: a classified, $250 million war game in which small, agile speedboats swarmed a naval convoy to inflict devastating damage on more powerful warships.

headline: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens
text: Record oil prices widened the United States trade deficit in November as the cost of imported petroleum outpaced a modest rise in exports.

headline: Baseball Adds Department to Investigate Drug Use
text: Major League Baseball has set up a department of investigations to look into allegations of illegal drug use by players “and other threats to the integrity of the game,” Commissioner Bud Selig announced Friday.

headline: State to Audit No-Bid Award of City’s School Contracts
text: The state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, is opening an audit of the City Education Department’s increasing practice of awarding contracts without competitive bidding. In the past five years such contracts have totaled $315 million.

headline: An Actor Whose Approach to Singing Lets the Words Take Center Stage
text: As a devotee of Stephen Sondheim’s musicals and a big Johnny Depp fan, I was surprised, intrigued and very dubious when I first heard that Mr. Depp would play the title role in Tim Burton’s film of “Sweeney Todd.”

headline: Kenyan Opposition Calls for New Rallies and Sanctions
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenya’s opposition leaders on Friday called for three days of nationwide protests next week and urged foreign governments to impose sanctions over the country’s flawed elections last month.

headline: Pass Coverage: The Long and the Short of It
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It seemed a complicated question, but R. W. McQuarters had a one-word answer. If so many N.F.L. wide receivers are tall, he was asked, why are so many cornerbacks not even six feet?

headline: Comics and Other Reading Matter
text: To the Editor:

headline: Blackhawks’ Potential Gives the Fans a Reason to Cheer
text: CHICAGO  As fans stood for the national anthem before a game last weekend, clapping and cheering while the singer belted out the last words, they filled the United Center with noise, something that had been sorely missing during years of dismal Blackhawks games. It was excited, hopeful, vibrant, this-game-is-going-to-be-fun noise.

headline: Hadrians Head to Visit Hadrians Wall
text: Two hundred years after it was pulled from the silt of the River Thames, a bronze head of the Emperor Hadrian, below, ruler of the Roman Empire from 117 to 138, will leave the British Museum for the first time, bound for sites along the 73-mile wall he ordered constructed in Northern England to mark the Roman frontier, the BBC reported. The head, once part of a statue thought to have been displayed in London in 122 to commemorate Hadrian’s visit, is to be exhibited at Tullie House in Carlisle next month and at the Segedunum Roman Fort, Baths and Museum in Wallsend in April, before returning for the exhibition “Hadrian: Empire and Conflict” on July 24.

headline: The Gawker Job Interview
text: The following is an instant-message exchange between Nick Denton, the owner of Gawker Media, and Richard Morgan, who was eventually hired as a reporter at Mr. Denton’s flagship Gawker.com, but who quit earlier this month, after his first full day on the job. This exchange, in which Mr. Denton discusses much of his philosophy behind Gawker, occurred on Dec. 19, 2007. Mr. Morgan provided the transcript.

headline: Hong Kong-Macao Hydrofoils Collide in Fog
text: Two high-speed hydrofoils ferrying passengers between the Chinese territories of Hong Kong and Macao collided in heavy fog off Macao, seriously injuring 19 people, the Macao government said. Hours earlier, another high-speed ferry traveling from Hong Kong to Macao with more than 370 passengers hit a small fishing boat. No one was injured.

headline: Shifting Through the Company Catalog
text: Four choreographers were represented in the program presented by New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Still, the folks in the company’s marketing office seem to have run out of steam when they named it “Four by Four,” unless a new subscription series for off-road enthusiasts has crept into the roster. The selection of ballets was odd and rather pallid, though each of the four choreographers has played a major role in the development and maintenance of City Ballet. But standout performing saved the day.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Sports of The Times column on Thursday about Oscar Pistorius, who runs world-class times on artificial lower legs, referred imprecisely to Lou Brissie, a World War II veteran who nearly lost a lower leg in combat and went on to pitch in baseball’s 1949 All-Star Game. He was a left-hander, not a righty.

headline: Pakistan Warns U.S. on Attacking Al Qaeda on Its Own
text: WASHINGTON  President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan warned in an interview published Friday that any unilateral attacks by the United States against Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters in his country’s tribal areas would be treated as an invasion.

headline: Japan Approves Bill on Afghan War
text: TOKYO  The Japanese government on Friday pushed through a special law authorizing its navy to resume a refueling mission in the Indian Ocean as part of the American-led military effort in Afghanistan.

headline: Stake Is Bought in IAC/InterActiveCorp
text: The Liberty Media Corporation, the entertainment and Internet retailing company controlled by the billionaire John C. Malone, purchased 14 million shares of IAC/InterActiveCorp, the company controlled by Barry Diller, for $339.5 million.

headline: Marion Jones Sentenced to Six Months in Prison
text: WHITE PLAINS  Marion Jones, the track and field star who pleaded guilty in October to lying to federal agents about her use of performance-enhancing drugs and her connection to a check-fraud case, was sentenced to six months in prison at the United States District Court here on Friday.

headline: Chrysler and Nissan in Production Deal
text: DETROIT  Chrysler and Nissan of Japan took the first step toward a possible broader alliance on Friday, reaching agreement for Nissan to supply Chrysler with a small car to be sold in South America.

headline: Hailed, From Everest to Park Avenue
text: In March 1954, 10 months after his triumphant ascent of Mount Everest, the newly knighted Sir Edmund Hillary embarked upon a victory tour of the United States.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report from The Associated Press in the N.B.A. roundup in some editions on Friday about Detroit’s victory against San Antonio misidentified the Pistons’ player who had 23 points and 15 rebounds. He is Rasheed Wallace  not Ben Wallace, a former Detroit player who is now with Chicago.

headline: Agency Acts to Cut Delay in Gaining Citizenship
text: Federal officials said Friday that they had agreed on an emergency plan to hire back about 700 retired government employees in an effort to pare an immense backlog in applications for citizenship by legal immigrants.

headline: Refugees in the Cold
text: Thousands of elderly and disabled refugees who have found safety in the United States in recent years may soon find out just how cold and equivocal America’s welcome can be. These vulnerable newcomers are subject to a federal law that cuts off their disability benefits if they do not become citizens within seven years.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: The Battle of the Mitts
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Jan. 12 column.

headline: Executive Pursuits
text: Harry Hurt III catches air (and snow) on Whiteface Mountain in his first foray in snowboarding.

headline: You Stink. I Love You.
text: From The Economist, on a dating site inspired by research into men’s smelly T-shirts:

headline: Tonight on the Blog: Detroit at Ottawa, LIVE
text: Tonight at 7 p.m. Eastern time on the Times hockey blog, we’ll be bringing you our live play-by-play commentary of the Senators-Red Wings game, right as it unfolds at Scotiabank Place in Kanata, Ont. It’s the first and only regular-season meeting of the two best teams in the National Hockey League — the Sens, who are running away with the Eastern Conference, and the Wings, who have already run away with the West. It’s the big game of the season, and we’ll have it for you, LIVE, with Lew Serviss describing the action.

headline: Whale Hunters Hunted
text: Anti-whaling campaigners caught up with Japan’s whaling fleet on Friday in what has become an annual cat and mouse game across the vast stretch of Pacific waters off Antarctica. The crew of Greenpeace’s whaler-hunting Esperanza, a 237-foot ship, has been blogging and posting fresh photos. The Web site also has three webcams through which visitors can monitor the hunt for the hunters.

headline: Citing Impact of Strike, Studios Begin Canceling Deals With Writers, Producers
text: “ABC Studios on Friday became the first TV studio to terminate production deals as a result of the Hollywood writers strike,” The Hollywood Reporter (via Reuters) reports. “Close to 30 writing and nonwriting producers who don’t have active projects have been axed.”

headline: Directors Will Begin Talks With Studios
text: “The Directors Guild of America and Hollywood’s production companies said Friday that they planned to start formal contract negotiations on Saturday, promising a major break in the entertainment industry’s labor troubles,” Michael Cieply reports.

headline: The Early Word: Countrywide
text: Now that the focal points of Iowa and New Hampshire are behind us, the race is becoming increasingly disparate geographically. Of course, while that’s standard for presidential elections, the early states’ failure to knock out any of the major candidates adds a whole new dimension of blurriness to the race.

headline: Saturday Kickoff: Goodbye to McFadden?
text: In a move that can hardly be qualified as surprising, Darren McFadden looks like he’s headed to the N.F.L. ESPN.com is reporting that McFadden’s father sent the appropriate paperwork to the N.F.L. this week, clearing the way for McFadden to skip his senior season at Arkansas and enter the draft.

headline: Rewind | The Pitti Men’s Shows
text: T Magazine’s men’s fashion director Bruce Pask filed this report on the men’s-wear trade show Pitti Immagine Uomo, just concluded in Florence, Italy.

headline: Romney Highlights Michigan Roots
text: Mitt Romney, a Michigan native who emigrated to Massachusetts after high school, played up his local roots in several appearances here on Saturday.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Jan. 12:

headline: A Vegan Cannibal?
text: From NBC Channel 5 in Texas:

headline: Endorsements Can Look Good or Bad
text: Quite a lot of endorsements have been in the news lately, most notably for Senator Barack Obama, who has been racking up big names since his win in Iowa. With endorsements often come credibility, access to donors and e-mail lists and, in the case of unions, boots on the ground. But sometimes, endorsements can be more trouble than they’re worth.

headline: Manglish as a Second Language
text: As the packages found here attest, globalization continues to take its toll on English. We can probably guess what the producer meant by “janitavy towel” (below), but can anyone explain the square of milk (above)?

headline: ECC: Magnitka — by Shootout — Make It to the Final!
text: Metallurg Magnitogorsk earned a place in the European Club Championship final by beating a stubborn Slovan Bratislava in a penalty shootout today in St. Petersburg. The game ended in a 1-1 draw, so it went to penalties, where Magnitka defenceman Aleksei Kaigodorov scored twice to win the game for the Siberians.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Jan. 13
text: The primary battles are playing out on the Sunday news shows.

headline: And the Rangers’ Answer Is … Malik?
text: Trying to jar his team out of its current doldrums, Rangers Coach Tom Renney decided to juggle his defensive pairings for tonight’s game against Montreal at Madison Square Garden.

headline: FINAL: Senators 3, Red Wings 2
text: Tonight we bring you live commentary of the match between the league-leading Detroit Red Wings and the East’s best team, the Ottawa Senators. Lew Serviss is at the keyboard.

headline: Forget Silver; Huckabee Gets the Gold
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. – Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee often jokes about how desperately his campaign needs money, but a story he told supporters at a rally here Saturday night may illustrate just how desperate that need really is.

headline: As Snow Falls, Packers Advance
text: The Green Bay Packers won their first postseason victory in four years.

headline: On the Trail
text: Presidential candidates campaigned in Michigan, Florida, Nevada and South Carolina on Saturday.

headline: Giving In to Pressure, Washington State Is Perfect No More
text: LOS ANGELES  The Washington State men’s basketball team should have felt at ease Saturday in Pauley Pavilion, where it has won one game in its history. In fact, Washington State ought to have felt as if it were playing its identical twin, going up against a U.C.L.A. team that relies, as the Cougars do, on a physical and aggressive defense, a selfless offense and a general stout-heartedness.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: AMERICAN CRESCENT: A Muslim Cleric on the Power of His Faith, the Struggle Against Prejudice, and the Future of Islam and America, by Hassan Qazwini. (Random House, $26.95.) Qazwini wants Muslim Americans to immerse themselves in the life of this country.

headline: Almost Famous, but Still Working a Grocery Shift
text: THESE are strange times for Chad L. Coleman, an actor and a resident of Brooklyn, whose name you probably do not recognize. But if you are one of the fervent few who have watched the HBO series “The Wire” over its past two seasons, his face will be familiar. Mr. Coleman, who plays a parolee trying to leave crime behind and start a boxing gym, knows that very well by now, from people jumping out of cars to greet him, stopping him on the subway or just grinning across a crowded coffee shop.

headline: A Terror Threat in the Courts
text: Newark

headline: Coaches Wanted in the Game of Life
text: NOTHING quite fit Shawn Driscoll’s schedule, or her passion, until she became a life coach. Her job is to help people set and achieve goals in their careers and their personal lives.

headline: Lindsay Stieber, Lee Milstein
text: Lindsay Rebecca Stieber, the daughter of Denise R. Stieber and Michael H. Stieber of North Caldwell, N.J., was married on Saturday evening to Lee Charles Milstein, the son of Marjorie D.
