Milstein and Eddy L. Milstein of Chappaqua, N.Y. Rabbi Howard Goldsmith officiated at Capitale, an event space in New York; his wife, Rabbi Jennifer Goldsmith, also participated in the ceremony.

headline: Emerging Markets, in Emerging Currencies
text: AS emerging-market bonds have racked up strong gains and become more expensive in recent years, fund managers seeking new opportunities have often turned to such debt that is denominated in local currencies.

headline: Over Rome and Above New Zealand
text: With Valentine’s Day drawing near, there are two offers that will sweep lovers off their feet  or at least off the ground. The Hassler Roma (www.hotelhasslerroma.com), atop the Spanish Steps, has a skyline package that includes a helicopter tour of the city and three nights in a suite. Valid through Feb. 28, it starts at 6,570 euros, or $9,855 at $1.50 to the euro. For those looking for a more remote outing, the Otahuna Lodge (www.otahuna.co.nz), near Christchurch in New Zealand, is offering a Romance Among the Vines package that includes a helicopter trip across the Banks Peninsula and the Canterbury High Country to the Waipara Valley wine district for a wine tour and lunch. The package, which starts at 4,700 New Zealand dollars, or $3,560 at 1.32 New Zealand dollars to the U.S. dollar, also includes two nights in a suite and two tasting dinners with wine pairings.

headline: Remaking Paramount by the Seat of His Pants
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Never Grow Up
text: For 21st-century kids growing up surrounded by video games, iPods and YouTube, the idea of playing cat’s cradle with a piece of string or snatching quarters off one’s elbow may seem as quaint as the corncob dolls in “Little House in the Big Woods.” In fact, one worries that all these old skills will be swatted aside by the Nintendo Wii’s wireless controller. But now “The Encyclopedia of Immaturity” is here to preserve that knowledge  and to document a few hundred more goofy tips, tricks and gross-out moves of its own.

headline: Ellis Wins Comeback Award
text: Greg Ellis made a major impact for the Dallas Cowboys at outside linebacker and Saturday was named as The Associated Press’s N.F.L. Comeback Player of the Year. Ellis went from a nonfactor in Dallas to a Pro Bowl player in his new position after spending most of his career as a defensive end. He had 12 ½ sacks, forming a dynamic pass-rushing force with the All-Pro linebacker DeMarcus Ware.

headline: For Magnet School, Protests and Hurdles
text: GREENWICH

headline: ‘The Wire’: What About the Women?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Contemporary Twist on Traditional French
text: FACED with today’s dining trends toward grazing, fusion cuisine (particularly Asian), and the use of local and organic foods in a lighter style of cooking, most traditional French restaurants have been forced to beat ’em, join ’em or simply close up shop. Jacques Loupiac, owner of La Panetière in Rye, has decided to join ’em, gingerly, and his new direction is clear.

headline: Bush Urges Arab Allies to Confront Iran
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  President Bush urged wary Persian Gulf allies on Sunday to rally against Iran “before it is too late,” even as the International Atomic Energy Agency announced that the country had agreed to answer outstanding questions about its nuclear programs within four weeks.

headline: Boxing Day
text: He had a thing for blue. Also clay pipes and Victorian postcards, ticket stubs, bits of tulle, starfish and old clock parts. He was drawn to automats and secondhand-book stalls, corresponded with ballerinas, filmed pigeons, liked pie.

headline: Under My Skin
text: How do you write a book about someone about whom next to nothing is known? For most writers, the answer would be move on to the next subject. But Bill Hayes has an unusual set of skills. The author of previous books on insomnia and blood, he is part science writer, part memoirist, part culture explainer. “The Anatomist,” his appealing new book about the man behind Gray’s Anatomy, combines his search for the remaining traces of Henry Gray with a memoir of his own experience as a dissection student and a scalpel’s-eye tour of the body.

headline: Ancestral Allure
text: The dewy and innocent milkmaid at the center of Thomas Hardy’s tragic novel “Tess of the d’Urbervilles” is destroyed not by rape or heartbreak; what does her in is genealogy. The problems start on the book’s first page, when a troublemaking parson calls Tess’s bumpkin father “Sir John.”

headline: Animal Spirits
text: In his 2005 film, “Grizzly Man,” Werner Herzog reconstructed the final years of Timothy Treadwell, an animal advocate who went into the Alaskan backcountry to live among the bears he loved, and  in an unanticipated form of bonding  was eventually devoured by one of his subjects. Herzog was fundamentally dismissive of Treadwell’s project, finding “no kinship, no understanding, no mercy ... only the overwhelming indifference of nature.” He believed Treadwell’s death was pointless. Those of us who have ever loved a pet may feel otherwise. Animals  wild or domestic  are sentient creatures and have much to teach us about our own emotional lives.

headline: The Afterlife of Cellphones
text: 1. Cellphones in Hell

headline: McCain and Romney Tangle Over Job Losses in Michigan
text: WARREN, Mich.  Senator John McCain and former Governor Mitt Romney battled Saturday over how to rejuvenate Michigan’s rusting economy as the two remained in a tight race in the final 72 hours heading into the state’s Republican primary.

headline: Unfinished Debate on Iraq
text: Iraq will be a central challenge  perhaps the central challenge  for whoever succeeds President Bush and has to repair the profound damage he has wrought with a war that should never have been fought and has been managed so ineptly. The candidates must talk more to the American people about when troops will be withdrawn and how it will be done, as well as how they will manage relations with Iraq and the region.

headline: Correction: Traveling the Globe on a Single Ticket
text: The Practical Traveler column on Dec. 30, about booking around-the-world airline tickets, rendered incorrectly the name of a city in New Zealand. It is Christchurch, not Christ Church. In addition, it included a quotation that contained a statement that is factually incorrect. A travel agent is quoted as stating that it is preferable to travel westward, with the “rotation of the earth.” In fact, the earth rotates west to east.

headline: North Island Coast of Small Wineries and Big Pleasures
text: VISITORS to New Zealand usually plot a trip to the South Island to taste notable wines or glimpse iconic scenery. Yet an hour north of Auckland, on the North Island, you can find an alternative wine destination, on the Matakana Wine Coast, where boutique vineyards and cafes offer specialty wines and sophisticated sustenance at the end of a drive alongside dramatic bays and through sheep-dappled hills.

headline: Closely Watched Trains
text: SOMEWHERE under the corner of Avenue of the Americas and 14th Street, at 2:42 p.m. on a Tuesday, the subway platform was quiet. The L train to Brooklyn had pulled away at 2:40  four minutes later than it was supposed to, according to one of the light-up signs that for more than a year have been hanging above the platform to inform riders of approaching trains  and another was due in one minute.

headline: Coaches in Texas Welcome Clemens
text: WACO, Tex.  In the fight of his life, Roger Clemens has been called a cheat and has been summoned to defend himself under oath before a Congressional committee. But some people in Texas still love him.

headline: Real Director of Fake Fights
text: RICK SORDELET causes an awful lot of fights to break out. But for the most part no one gets hurt.

headline: A Law Office That’s Young at Heart
text: THE former offices of Kriss & Feuerstein, a real estate law firm, were a safe mix of traditional furniture in a modern shell.

headline: A Defenseman Brings Offense to the Capitals
text: After starting the season poorly enough to get their coach fired, the Washington Capitals have found their legs.

headline: Infinite Jest
text: Right from its perplexing title and mysterious 16th-century epigraph  “These demanders for glimmer be for the most part women; for glimmer, in their language, is fire”  Nicola Barker’s latest novel, “Darkmans,” is difficult to grasp. The narrative has barely begun before you’re plunged into a detailed (and somewhat bewildering) exploration of the history of Ashford, in Kent, and the impact of the Channel Tunnel on the region. Yet once you’re in the grip of this broad, funny, deeply strange book  once you and “Darkmans” are grappling with each other  neither you nor the novel is likely to let go.

headline: Clinton Accuses Obama Camp of Distorting Her Words
text: RENO, Nev.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Saturday accused Senator Barack Obama’s campaign of distorting her remarks to suggest that she had cast aspersions on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: D.M.V.: No GETOSAMA Vanity Plate
text: Smithtown

headline: Researchers Create New Rat Heart in Lab
text: Medicine’s dream of growing new human hearts and other organs to repair or replace damaged ones received a significant boost on Sunday when University of Minnesota researchers reported success in creating a beating rat heart in a laboratory.

headline: Evaluating, by the Book
text: Two annually updated portable wine books by influential British critics help focus consumers’ attention on Long Island wines. Both in hardcover, popular and easy to find, they are “Hugh Johnson’s Pocket Wine Book 2008” and “Oz Clarke’s Pocket Wine Guide 2008.”

headline: Consumer Man
text: I’m one of those people who yell at store clerks. Not just any store clerks, but the ones who are rude, incompetent or indifferent. In other words, all store clerks. I’m the guy who always has to speak to the manager. In my head, I’m “Consumer Man”: a superhero fighting on behalf of oppressed consumers the world over. In my wife’s head, I’m crazy.

headline: Loathe Thy Neighbor
text: For all the acts of cruelty committed between its covers, Sara Paretsky’s BLEEDING KANSAS (Putnam, $25.95) might as well have been a crime novel requiring the services of her series sleuth, V. I. Warshawski. Set in the rural Kaw River Valley, where the author grew up, and sparked by a feud between two families that pioneered this farm region during the 1850s, the multigenerational narrative bristles with the kind of prickly social issues that give substance to Paretsky’s detective stories. But the pointed absence of her Chicago private eye may indicate that some of the social conflicts currently polarizing the American heartland can’t be resolved in the fair-and-square manner of genre tradition.

headline: Why Reading Matters
text: To the Editor:

headline: Amy Abbazia and Gregory Rowland
text: Amy Elizabeth Abbazia, a daughter of Catherine Schmitt of Huntington, N.Y., and Patrick Abbazia of Brooklyn was married on Saturday to Gregory Samuel Rowland, the son of Joncie Rowland and Hugh Rowland Jr., both of Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. Stuart Hoke, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Manhattan.

headline: In Texas, Weighing Life With a Border Fence
text: GRANJENO, Tex.  Rafael Garza, a former mayor of this small border city, stood steps from the back door of his simple brick house and chopped the air with a hand. “This is where the actual fence would be,” he said.

headline: Rebirth Along the River
text: THE Fishtown district of Philadelphia was known as a tight-knit Irish Catholic enclave — and a place to score drugs. Set along the Delaware River in the northeastern part of the city, the area was the former home of a Stetson hat factory and a Schmidts beer plant, before its brick warehouses and shad markets were abandoned.

headline: Where to Eat? A New Restaurant Genre Offers Manhattan More Choices
Who Helps Whom in the Peace Corps?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Recovered Addict Struggles to Keep His Home
text: Around Gabriel Crumity’s neck, a few inches to the left of the scar from chemotherapy treatments, hangs a gold medallion the size of a quarter with a triangle punched out of the middle.

headline: Cuomo Set to Look Into 1988 Long Island Murders
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer appointed Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo on Saturday as a special prosecutor to investigate the 1988 murders of a Long Island couple whose son, Martin H. Tankleff, was recently released from prison after doubts arose over his conviction in their deaths.

headline: The Rebel Director, Sincere and Hopeful
text: SOME would say Carl Forsman is too well adjusted to be cutting edge. He’s polite and soft-spoken, and he had a happy childhood in Chatham, N.J., where his mother was a high school teacher and his father was a Methodist minister. Recently, over a healthy breakfast, Mr. Forsman even described his worldview as humanistic, saying he believes “compassion and generosity are a normal, natural part of existence.”

headline: Who Needs Country Radio? Not Tom T. Hall
text: Franklin, Tenn.

headline: A Million Miles vs. a Few More Smiles
text: JAMES T. KANE, a corporate consultant on customer loyalty, has a news flash for his airline.

headline: A Main Street With Real Staying Power
text: WHILE new neighborhoods strive to produce a sense of community, usually by creating a Main Street-like district in a dense residential center, real old-fashioned Main Streets are dying off across New Jersey, particularly in areas not supported by good transportation networks or well-heeled shoppers.

headline: The Crying Game, and the Political Herd
text: ONE of the CNN regulars working the New Hampshire primary last Tuesday, Jeffrey Toobin, turned up his palms during the broadcast and vented his and many viewers’ impatience with his co-hosts’ analysis of Hillary Clinton’s surprising lead.

headline: French Cabinet Position Not Enough? Then Try Mayor.
text: PARIS  The justice minister wants to be a mayor. So does the finance minister. And the culture minister. And the government spokesman.

headline: Easy Slogans, Twinkly Funk and One Busy String
text: Jeffrey Lewis

headline: The Bone Diaries
text: Near the beginning of Frances Itani’s latest novel, “Remembering the Bones,” Georgie Danforth Whitley, a Canadian widow, is bound for London to meet Queen Elizabeth. The two share a birthday, and Georgie is one of 99 commoners invited to a celebratory luncheon. But despite careful planning, she will not make it to the palace. En route to the local airport, her car slips through a pair of guard posts and flips down a hillside, throwing her into the brush and leaving no trace of her accident visible from the road above. Helpless and alone, she staves off thirst by sucking on the silver buttons of her cardigan. Panic is staved off by revisiting 80 years’ worth of memories in which she has been daughter and granddaughter, sister and niece, mother, wife and widow.

headline: Emily Haverstick, Tyler Umbdenstock
text: Emily Whalen Haverstick, a daughter of Jessica W. Haverstick and Samuel A. Haverstick II of Short Hills, N.J., was married on Saturday to Tyler Johnson Umbdenstock, the son of Linda J. Umbdenstock and Robert P. Umbdenstock of Lebanon, N.J. The Rev. Ronald W. Johnson, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Caneel Bay, a resort in St. John, V.I.

headline: Baby-Sitter Confidential
text: WHEN I was 17, I moved from the North Shore of Staten Island, where I had grown up, to Morningside Heights, where I was a student at Barnard College. To earn spending money, I worked on and off for the college baby-sitting service. I preferred working weekend nights, because the hours were longer. There were plenty of clients, and I never ended up going to the same house twice. This was 1968, and the pay was $1.50 an hour.

headline: The Chicken Soup Chronicles
text: THE other day I felt a cold coming on. So I decided to have chicken soup to ward off the cold. Nonetheless I got the cold. This happens all the time: you think you’re getting a cold; you have chicken soup; you get the cold anyway. So: is it possible that chicken soup gives you a cold?

headline: Still Perfect, and Passing Game Almost Is
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Throughout their season of superlatives, the New England Patriots have rarely met an opponent that could keep pace with their offense, which made a mockery of the N.F.L. record book. The Jacksonville Jaguars, whose grind-it-out running game belies the geographic rules of football, seemed an unlikely candidate to match Tom Brady and the pinball numbers he and the Patriots put up.

headline: Man Who Fought Attackers Was Rejected 3 Times by Police Dept.
text: A transit worker who stabbed a man to death while fending off a group of attackers on a Harlem street Thursday night killed a man in self-defense in 1994, and was rejected three times in the 1990s for a job on the police force, the police said Saturday.

headline: Fire Erupts at Hideout of Escapee
text: ELIZABETH, N.J. (AP)  The authorities are investigating a fire that broke out early Saturday at the house where an escaped inmate from the Union County Jail was found on Tuesday.

headline: The Soul of Suburbia, Captured on Film
text: Gazing out the 10th-floor window of the Joan and Donald E. Axinn Library at Hofstra University in Hempstead is quite something. On a clear day, you can see the Jones Beach Water Tower to the south, the skyscrapers of Manhattan to the west. Closer at hand, there is a striking, if more prosaic, panorama of houses  a bird’s-eye view of suburbia.

headline: Interpreting a Blueprint for Birds
text: JAMES PROSEK is a visual artist, an author and a filmmaker. He is a musician and an environmental advocate. He is a lifelong resident of Easton and a fly fisherman who has traveled the world in search of trout.

headline: Proof
text: A physicist, a biologist and a mathematician walk into a bar. Bartender says, “Any of you believe in God?” Which of the three is most likely to say yes? Answer: the mathematician. Mathematicians believe in God at a rate two and a half times that of biologists, a survey of members of the National Academy of Sciences a decade ago revealed. Admittedly, this rate is not very high in absolute terms. Only 14.6 percent of the mathematicians embraced the God hypothesis (versus 5.5 percent of the biologists).

headline: Two Views of Innovation, Colliding in Washington
text: AS the Senate prepares to tinker with the nation’s patent laws this spring, it’s worth recalling the law of unintended consequences.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Film

headline: A Co-op Board Member No Longer Lives There
text: Q A shareholder who was a board member in my co-op sold her apartment. After she moved out, she ran for the board again and was re-elected. Is it legal for a nonshareholder to be voted in as a co-op board member in New York?

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Film

headline: Protecting Our Lands
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Says He Could Halt Withdrawal, if Security Dictates
text: CAMP ARIFJAN, Kuwait  A year after he ordered a large increase in American troops in Iraq, President Bush said Saturday that he was prepared to slow or even halt further reductions of forces there, emphasizing that any decision depended on security and the stability of the Iraqi government.

headline: Between Rock and the River, the Going Is Slow, and Costly
text: At the eastern portion of ground zero, hundreds of workers contend with a nasty subterranean nest: steel and concrete, a defunct railroad, forgotten foundations, landfill, quartz deposits and glacial remnants in a vast pit that the Hudson River ceaselessly tries to inundate with icy, brackish water.

headline: Last Year’s Role Model
text: Madison, Wis.

headline: Footprints of Holocaust in a Battle for Lost Art
text: ARMONK, N.Y.

headline: Uncertainties in the Shadow of Unrest
text: THE violence that erupted in Kenya after a disputed presidential election on Dec. 27 raised questions for those planning a trip to one of Africa’s most popular safari destinations. Is it safe? Can I postpone? If I cancel can I get my money back? Am I covered under travel insurance?

headline: Oppo Man
text: What led you to write your new book, “Confessions of a Political Hitman,” which chronicles your rather unsavory career as a Republican Party operative who was hired in hundreds of political campaigns to dig for dirt on Democratic candidates? I wouldn’t use the word unsavory. The voter has the right to know the history of any candidate in order to make the most educated vote.

headline: The House of Myth
text: Americans have long delighted in movies like “It’s a Wonderful Life,” “Heaven Can Wait” (both the 1943 and 1978 versions) and “Bruce Almighty”  “divine comedies,” to borrow the marketing shtick of the day, in which a benevolent male Judeo-Christian God and sometimes his demonic counterpart are represented by stock imagery like billowing clouds, bolts of lightning, bumbling plainclothes angels and horned creatures thumping pitchforks. The humor may be irreverent, but it’s always delivered with a basic attitude of respect.

headline: In Swirling Snow, Packers Leave Mark
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Not quite three minutes into his first N.F.L. playoff game, Green Bay Packers tailback Ryan Grant looked up into the snowflakes as if searching for an explanation. Grant had lost his second fumble of the game, on only the third time he touched the ball. The Seattle Seahawks had converted the first turnover into a touchdown, and would soon score off the second to grab a 14-point lead.

headline: Aptitude for Destruction
text: The most heartbreaking place I’ve ever visited is the vast, spare, tree-lined cemetery where half a million people who died in the Nazi siege of Leningrad from 1941 to 1944, most of them civilians, are buried in gently rising, grass-covered mass graves  long, rectangular and symmetrically arrayed, each plot holding thousands of dead. From loudspeakers, tragic music swells over the grounds, where a statue of the Motherland watches over all. In pavilions near the entrance, by an eternal flame, notes and photographs of the victims are collected in glass cases.

headline: Letters: Buffon and Jefferson
text: To the Editor: Richard Conniff’s article "Forgotten, Yes. But Happy Birthday Anyway" (Dec. 30) on the Comte de Buffon failed to mention Buffon’s comical quarrel with Thomas Jefferson.

headline: Take Me as I Am, Whoever I Am
text: AS a bipolar woman, I have lived much of my life in a constant state of becoming someone else. The precise term for my disorder is “ultraradian rapid cycler,” which means that without medication I am at the mercy of my own spectacular mood swings: “up” for days (charming, talkative, effusive, funny and productive, but never sleeping and ultimately hard to be around), then “down,” and essentially immobile, for weeks at a time.

headline: Austrian Wins Giant Slalom
text: Elisabeth Görgl of Austria won a World Cup giant slalom in Maribor, Slovenia, for the first victory of her career. Görgl, who led after the first leg, finished in a two-run combined time of 2:38.49. Manuela Moelgg of Italy took second, 0.49 behind, and Denise Karbon of Italy finished third.

headline: Colts’ Record of Success Is Failing to Stir a Buzz
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Are the Colts really sneaking up on the N.F.L. consciousness as they begin their postseason quest to repeat as Super Bowl champions? Perhaps this is partly true as they play host to the San Diego Chargers on Sunday in an American Football Conference divisional playoff game.

headline: News Boxes: All for One, or One for All?
text: TOURISTS seeking the tidiest spot to grab a newspaper might consider the large box on the northeast corner of 34th Street and Fifth Avenue. The box, a “multirack” version that holds several publications, is well tended by the 34th Street Partnership; one recent afternoon, a maintenance worker was busily removing stickers and scrubbing away at the graffiti on the little windows.

headline: Afghan Police Struggle to Work a Beat in a War
text: NAWA, Afghanistan  Many of the problems frustrating Afghanistan’s efforts to secure its dangerous eastern and southern provinces were evident in the bizarre tour of duty of Shair Mohammad, a police officer who spent 18 months in an isolated swath of steppe.

headline: Lawsuit Over Precincts in Nevada
text: LAS VEGAS  In what has become a proxy battle between the presidential campaigns of Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton, the large hotel workers union in Nevada on Saturday attacked a lawsuit by another major union that would make it more difficult for hotel workers to vote in this state’s hotly contested Democratic caucuses.

headline: Unions Pouring Resources Into Nevada Caucus Fight
text: With Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama eager to win the Democratic caucuses in Nevada next Saturday, labor unions backing Mr. Obama are in a surprisingly intense, expensive fight with those supporting Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Paperback Row
text: RALPH ELLISON: A Biography, by Arnold Rampersad. (Vintage, $17.95.) With “Invisible Man,” published in 1952, and the essays collected in “Shadow and Act” (1964), Ralph Ellison established himself as a gifted novelist and analyst of black American culture. But as he struggled with a second novel he withdrew from the black community, growing “ever more protective of his position as the ranking black novelist of the day and as the only black person in whatever room he happened to be standing in,” Brent Staples wrote in the Book Review. Rampersad, a professor of English at Stanford, Staples continued, “is uniquely qualified to examine the Ellison case.” The first biography of Ellison, originally published in 2002, is also newly available in paperback. Lawrence Jackson’s RALPH ELLISON: Emergence of Genius (University of Georgia, $22.95) focuses on Ellison’s early years and ends as he wins the National Book Award in 1953.

headline: Creating the Right Vibe in Harlem
text: “WE tell people we’re a rock ’n’ roll band from Harlem, and they look at us like that’s an oxymoron,” said Mark Hermann of his group, Citizens of Contrary Knowledge. “But the people around here will tell you, it’s all been going on for so long  blues and jazz and rock ’n’ roll.”

headline: Opposition Wins Taiwan Parliamentary Election
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The opposition Kuomintang party won a landslide victory in parliamentary elections in Taiwan on Saturday. President Chen Shui-bian, who has antagonized China with his efforts to forge a national identity for the self-governing island, resigned as chairman of the governing Democratic Progressive Party to take responsibility for the loss.

headline: Larry, Curly, Moe and the Economy
text: NOW for a few short notes on the economy  and you can digest them along with your FiberCon and your English muffins.

headline: Under His Hat
text: Nicolaus Copernicus stands in sharp contrast to the later giants of the scientific revolution. For Kepler, Galileo or Newton, biographers can draw on copious correspondence. Kepler complains to his former teacher that his son never writes home from college. Galileo protests that he can’t have his house arrest suspended to visit his doctor in Florence. Newton accuses John Locke of trying to entangle him with women.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $6,363,022

headline: First Wives World Is Their Oyster, Pearls Included
text: THEIR ring fingers were empty.

headline: Correction: Ghosts That Haunt Pakistan
text: An article last Sunday about Pakistan’s history of difficulty in sustaining democracy misstated the crime for which the former prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was hanged in 1979. Mr. Bhutto was found guilty of conspiring to murder a minor political opponent, not of murdering him. (The opponent survived an assassination attempt, in which his father died.) The article also misstated the opponent’s home region. It was the Punjab, not Baluchistan.

headline: Tara Walpert and Michael Levy
text: Tara Ellen Walpert and Michael Alexander Levy were married Saturday evening at the State Room, an events space in Boston. Rabbi Elaine Zecher officiated.

headline: Man Accused in Killing of Wife and Children
text: MASON, Ohio (AP)  The police charged a man Saturday with murdering his wife and their four children, who were pulled from their burning home the night before.

headline: Drunken Driving Charge for Clinton Aide
text: Sidney Blumenthal, an unpaid senior adviser to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign, was arrested the day before the New Hampshire primary in Nashua, N.H., on a charge of drunken driving, according to the police.

headline: Letters: The Good Old Days
text: To the Editor: In response to the Practical Traveler column on Dec. 30, "Traveling the Globe on a Single Ticket," about airline alliances for round-the-world travel, I heave a sigh of nostalgia for the good old days of far simpler international air travel decades ago, before the advent of computerized reservations and e-mail.

headline: Latvians Say Foe Got Signals From Her Tube of Lip Balm
text: Has it come to this, that a player who has a remarkably good result in a tournament is immediately suspected of cheating?

headline: The Train in Spain Keeps Moving Faster
text: Trains are getting faster in Spain. AVE (Alta Velocidad Española, or Spanish High Speed) is working to decrease the travel time between Madrid and Barcelona from four hours to three by spring (and ultimately to two and a half hours, once the latest version of the European Train Control System has been installed). In December, travel times were shortened between Madrid and Segovia (from two hours to 30 minutes) and Madrid and Málaga (from four hours to two and a half). It is the goal of the Spanish government to upgrade 4,350 miles of track to high-speed quality by 2010, making all major cities reachable by train from Madrid within four hours, and from Barcelona within six and a half hours (www.renfe.es; for English, click inside the box found at the lower left on the site).

headline: Racing to Capture Vanishing Languages
text: JEREMY NEWBERGER, a documentary filmmaker, was camped on the banks of Lake Titicaca in Bolivia with two scientists studying the world’s vanishing languages. They were trying to meet a medicine man who is one of about 100 people who still speak Kallawaya, when one of the scientists, Gregory D. S. Anderson, became ill.

headline: For Duck Farms, Dealing With New Limits
text: MORICHES

headline: A War of the States Over Dredging Rules
text: IN October, Connecticut officials told the Post Road Boat Yard in Westchester that the marina had until Nov. 1 to produce the necessary New York permits before they would sign off on plans to place material from dredging in Long Island Sound.

headline: Standoff at Nassau’s Last Trailer Park
text: SYOSSET

headline: Has Gawker Jumped the Snark?
text: “THE ideal Gawker item,” Nick Denton, the owner of Gawker Media, wrote in an instant message last month to a prospective hire, “is something triggered by a quote at a party, or an incident, or a story somewhere else and serves to expose hypocrisy, or turn conventional wisdom on its head.

headline: Congestion and Other Terminal Illnesses
text: AS I sat on the tarmac for an hour waiting to deplane at Leonardo da Vinci Airport outside Rome after a short-haul flight earlier this year, the pilot got on the public address system to apologize to me and my fellow passengers. “Sorry,” he said, “everybody knows this is one of Europe’s worst airports.”

headline: Obsessed With Her Novels
text: To the Editor:

headline: Is the Apartment Rent Stabilized, or Not?
text: Q When I signed the lease on my West Village rental three years ago, I was told it was not stabilized, and the rent-stabilization language was crossed out of the lease. The rent at that time was $1,695.

headline: Family Recipes for German Favorites
text: GERMAN restaurants are a dying breed on Long Island. It was therefore a cause for celebration when the Village Lanterne opened in Lindenhurst in late October. The Village Lanterne has the same ownership as the Black Forest Bakery, just a few doors away. Tom Lorch, who took over the bakery five years ago from his father, Herb, uses the recipes of his mother, Ursula, at his restaurant.

headline: Notable Thai, on the Outskirts of Town
text: WITH Thai Tida, the jumping new restaurant in Lambertville, there’s good news and bad news. The good news is the solid food, the service, the crowd  the whole experience.

headline: A Building Boom to Welcome the Winter Games
text: AS the sawdust flies in anticipation of the 2010 Winter Olympics, new hotels  and many other things as well  are rising around Vancouver.

headline: Dancing Permitted
text: MY father was a strong influence in my life in terms of my values and performance, but he didn’t believe that a woman should go to college.

headline: Scotch Purists Beware
text: THE first time I visited the restaurant Shorty’s.32, acting on a tip about a new single-malt Scotch cocktail, the bartender turned me down. No such drink on the menu, he claimed.

headline: ‘There Is a God’

headline: Big Swells, Tall Waves, Wipeouts and a Perfect Ride
text: HALF MOON BAY, Calif.  Big blue waves heaved under a bright blue sky for the sixth Mavericks Surf Contest at Pillar Point in Half Moon Bay on Saturday. After all the tall wave faces were carved and wipeouts endured, Greg Long, 24, gripped the coveted first-place check for one of the world’s premier big-wave surfing competitions.

headline: Eating in Cuban
text: On Oct. 30, 1961, an 8-year-old boy named Eduardo Machado and his 5-year-old brother boarded a Pan Am plane in Havana and flew to Miami. They were part of Operation Peter Pan, a program run by the United States government, Cuban exiles and elements of the Catholic Church that transported about 14,000 children from Cuba to the United States. The flight was brief, but it took Machado’s home away from him, embittered him toward his parents and changed his life forever.

headline: A Murderous Talent
text: Serial killers are localists. They murder within their chosen patch  a red-light district, a city quarter  and tend not to travel beyond it. Changing location means recoding the method; learning a new vernacular of murder. It also increases the risk of detection: an out-of-towner is more likely to be remembered from a crime scene.

headline: Another Win for Grange
text: Jean-Baptiste Grange of France won a World Cup slalom Saturday in Wengen, Switzerland, capturing his second victory in two days. He easily held off Jens Byggmark of Sweden, finishing with a combined time of 1 minute 34.81 seconds. Grange won Friday’s super-combi for the second World Cup victory of his career.

headline: When a Mountaintop Might as Well Have Been the Moon
text: EDMUND HILLARY, short of breath in the freezing wind, took “a few more whacks of the ice ax” and surmounted the top of the world, Mount Everest, as high as anyone can aspire and still be rooted on terra firma. At the time, May 29, 1953, it was a magnificent achievement of human daring and endurance culminating an era of crossing oceans, penetrating continental interiors and reaching the ends of the earth.

headline: Shira Tydings and Lee Bressler
text: Shira Elizabeth Tydings, a daughter of Dorothy A. Tydings and Dr. Lawrence H. Tydings of Laurel Hollow, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Lee Alexander Bressler, a son of Jane C. Bressler of New York and the late Martin J. Bressler. Rabbi Neil Kurshan officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street in New York.

headline: Correction: That Campaign Button Can Sting You at Work
text: The Career Couch column last Sunday, about presidential politics in the office, referred incorrectly to comments by Daniel I. Prywes, a partner in the Washington offices of the law firm Bryan Cave. When Mr. Prywes said that soliciting participation in political events might be permissible, he was referring to both employers and employees, not just employees. In addition, he said that employers who coerce employees to make political contributions would be violating federal election laws; he was not referring to employees who solicit contributions.

headline: Dr. Jonathan Shay on Returning Veterans and Combat Trauma
text: Dr. Jonathan Shay is a psychiatrist who specializes in treating the psychic wounds of war. He is also the author of two books, "Achilles in Vietnam: Combat Trauma and the Undoing of Character" and "Odysseus in America: Combat Trauma and the Trials of Homecoming," which examine the experiences of combat veterans through the lens of classical texts.

headline: Michigan Voters Wary of Revitalization Talk
text: STANDISH, Mich.  This quiet town, tucked between the thumb and the rest of the fingers in Michigan’s mitten, feels worlds away from the struggling automobile factories of Flint and Detroit. But economic gloom has made its way here just as it has seeped through so much of this state.

headline: What Awaits the Met
text: THOUGH expected, the news last week that Philippe de Montebello would retire as director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art elicited a range of emotions among museumgoers: pride and sadness at the end of a stellar era, and anxiety about the future.

headline: Closing the Power Gap Between a Hybrid’s Supply and Demand
text: A HYBRID that drives the first miles of each trip on batteries charged from the electricity grid  and burns no gasoline at all until the batteries have been drawn down  is a widely sought antidote to $3 gasoline. But no automaker has yet shown a battery pack for such a vehicle, known as a plug-in hybrid, that would be durable enough for mass production.

headline: Say What You Will
text: Throughout his long career as an author and a reporter and columnist for The New York Times, Anthony Lewis has been one of the most inspiring advocates of a heroic view of the American judiciary. Each year I read aloud to my criminal procedure students the final paragraphs of “Gideon’s Trumpet,” Lewis’s definitive account of the 1963 Supreme Court case that recognized a constitutional right to court-appointed counsel. They never fail to bring a lump to the throat  at least to mine. In his new book, “Freedom for the Thought That We Hate,” Lewis offers a similarly heroic account of how courageous judges in the 20th century created the modern First Amendment by prohibiting the government from banning offensive speech, except to prevent a threat of serious and imminent harm. “Many of the great advances in the quality  the decency  of American society were initiated by judges,” he writes. “The truth is that bold judicial decisions have made the country what it is.”

headline: Far From Home, but Almost There
text: At 6 feet 9 inches and 260 pounds, with a soft touch around the basket and from the perimeter, Samardo Samuels stands out on a basketball court.

headline: 36 Hours in Hollywood
text: HOLLYWOOD is one of those rare places that live up to their stereotypes, right down to the sign. But with minimal effort, it can offer a whole lot more. The pedestrian-friendly district represents both Los Angeles’ past, with icons like the Capitol Records building, and the city’s future — multi-ethnic, vertical, dense. A recent renaissance means there are now million-dollar condos, trendy restaurants, celebrity watering holes and a world-class movie theater. But there are still tattoo parlors, sex shops and homelessness. Tying it all together is the Hollywood Walk of Fame, where it is hard not to be at least momentarily tickled (hello, Mister Rogers) or merely confused (who the heck was he?). It remains a place that only Los Angeles could produce.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Great Adaptations
text: Mass-market adaptations make Great Books go bad. Or so conventional wisdom would have it. But every so often, plundering and pillaging a canonical text for the sake of entertainment gives it the kiss of life. Take “Beowulf” and “Paradise Lost.” The unpalatable truth is that both originals are now virtually unreadable. “Beowulf” is written in Old English, an inflected Germanic tongue that looks a lot less like our language than one would hope. As for Milton’s epic, it’s in “normal” English, but its blank verse is so densely learned, so syntactically complicated and philosophically obscure, that it’s almost never read outside college courses. Even Samuel Johnson, writing 100 years after Milton, said: “‘Paradise Lost’ is one of the books which the reader admires and lays down, and forgets to take up again. None ever wished it longer than it is.”

headline: Voices From Past Are Echoing Today
text: They were two of the distinctive American voices, born 97 miles apart as the catbird flies. Red Barber and Mel Allen spoke the language of baseball in Southern cadences to Northern ears. In this year of debates and primaries and elections, their regional accents may still be relevant as Americans sort out exactly who we are.

headline: Paris: Afaria
text: In Paris, gastronauts are accustomed to trekking to the untouristed fringes of the city in search of good, affordable cooking. For over a decade, La Régalade has lured diners to a bland stretch of the 14th Arrondissement for its enriching 32-euro dinner menu. In the hills of the 20th lies Le Baratin, an organic wine bar where three courses and a glass of unfiltered red will set you back about 20 euros, while the 14-euro lunch menu at Le Châteaubriand draws modern-cooking cultists to the edge of the Bastille.

headline: Iraq Eases Curb for Former Officials of Hussein’s Party

The legislation is the first of the major so-called political benchmark measures to pass after months of American pressure for progress.

headline: A Renter’s Right to a Pet in a Condo Building

Upon moving in, I was informed that renters are prohibited from having dogs, while owners are not. Upon further inquiry, I discovered that the building’s condo board was considering instituting a monthly $250 fee for renters who want to have dogs.

headline: For Him, the Devil Is in the Rhymes
text: THE Irish playwright Mark O’Rowe cuts to the chase. Best known for writing “Howie the Rookie,” a darkly comic blood-and-guts crime story told with racing momentum that made its debut at the Bush Theater in London in 1999 and came to New York two years later, he writes brutal plays that are so packed with energy and verve that they can leave an audience dizzy.

headline: Letters: The Lives They Lived
text: Of all the great tributes in your annual Lives issue (Dec. 30), I was most touched by “The Guardians,” by Dexter Filkins. Perhaps because I, like Omar Mora, am a native of Ecuador and because, as a young immigrant with “only a green card,” I, too, decided to serve my adopted country by enlisting in the United States military in 1958, a service that continued through the war in Vietnam. But here is where the similarities end. Although a volunteer for duty, I did not see combat, and I now enjoy the fruits of my service and of being a naturalized U.S. citizen. Omar not only heroically served in combat but also made the ultimate sacrifice for his new country. As a result, tragically, he never got to enjoy the benefits I did. Gracias compatriota!

headline: Inside the List
text: THE CELLAR MASTER: Sometimes a book can sell tens of thousands of copies, year after year, and not make a dent in one of The Times’s best-seller lists. Such a book is the annual issuing of Kevin Zraly’s “Windows on the World Complete Wine Course.” According to Zraly, these volumes have sold some 2.5 million copies since the first edition appeared in 1985. Zraly became the cellar master at Windows on the World the year the restaurant opened in 1976. He was 25 at the time. The books grew out of the wine courses he’s taught ever since. “Windows on the World is a hard place for me to talk about,” Zraly said recently. “I was there for 25 years, from the day it opened until Sept. 11, 2001.” He would have been in 1 World Trade Center on the day it fell, he said, had he not stayed home because of his oldest son’s birthday. “After 9/11, I had no desire to do anything, or to teach anymore,” he said. “But many people wanted me to carry on the legacy. Really, the only things now left of Windows on the World are the wine courses and my books.”

headline: Fill in Your Dance Card on the Queen Mary 2
text: If you’re single and find yourself inspired by “Dancing With the Stars” to pick up some new moves on vacation, you might want to check out the new dance cruise for solo travelers aboard the Queen Mary 2. Organized by Singles Travel International (www.singlestravelintl.com), the trans-Atlantic cruise to Paris, departing from Brooklyn on July 8, includes daily dance lessons (salsa, cha-cha, merengue) and nightly dance soirees set to a full orchestra in the ballroom. The seven-day cruise, which starts at $1,699, double occupancy, and includes all meals, will also give participants the chance to explore the ship’s amenities, like the Canyon Ranch spa, the Veuve Clicquot Champagne Bar and the planetarium. For those wanting to dance in warmer climes, there will be a Nov. 21 dance cruise departing from Brooklyn and ending in Fort Lauderdale with stops in St. Kitts, Grenada and Bonaire.

headline: Stand by Your Man
text: What might it feel like to be married to a charming and handsome man, highly accomplished, in many ways admirable, who propelled himself from modest beginnings to the highest reaches of our government, who professes undying love for you and appears to feel it, but who can’t stop himself from repeatedly cheating on you in the most public and humiliating ways? What might it be like to stay married to this man, to spend years of your life campaigning for him, covering for him, while at the same time living apart, leading a separate life and discovering new and personally gratifying pleasures and ambitions? What would it be like to reunite with him, on your own terms, with your own power base, to love him more fully, perhaps even to trust him  only to have your faith finally, fatally shattered?

text: MAN trap, serial heart-wrecker, rocker arm candy, photogenic cipher, arrogant heiress, polling gimmick  the woman who appears likely to become the first lady of France has been called a lot of things lately. The last thing anyone would have thought of is that she’s a catch.

headline: Admissions Anxiety, With a Twist
text: IF you are friend or kin to one of Connecticut’s 47,018 public and private high school seniors, pause a moment to take this humane little quiz. If, over the next two and a half months, you encounter this young person, how might you greet him or her?

headline: Correction: The Deluge Before the Dollar
text: The Off the Shelf column last Sunday, a review of “A Nation of Counterfeiters,” a book about the history of American counterfeiting, referred incorrectly to a practice in Britain, where counterfeiting was once considered a treasonable act. It was punishable by death without “benefit of clergy,” meaning the special protections once granted to clergy members and certain others to be tried in separate church courts and to avoid some types of punishment; it did not have to do with “access to clergy” for absolution rites.

headline: Clinton and Obama Spar Over Remark About Dr. King
text: Escalating their fight for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama engaged in a war of words on Sunday over Mrs. Clinton’s recent remark about the role that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. played in securing civil rights laws in the 1960s.

headline: What’s a Ski Area to Do as It Warms? Adapt
text: PLANTSVILLE

headline: Heroin’s Hold on the Young
text: POMPTON PLAINS

headline: In the Farm Bill, a Creature From the Black Lagoon?
text: IT may not surprise you to learn that much of the pork and chicken and beef and milk that you buy at the grocery store comes from huge, industrial-size operations that bear little resemblance to the quaint family farms that adorn many food packages.

headline: A Collector’s New Plan
text: This is an exciting time for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. It has nearly completed a major new addition called the Broad Contemporary Art Museum. But times are not quite as exciting as the museum had hoped. Eli Broad, the financier and collector for whom that new addition is named, has announced that he will not be giving away his art after all. Instead, his foundation will keep permanent control of his collection, making loans to museums in much the way museums lend works to one another.

headline: Datebook
text: Events in Philadelphia, Miami and London worth getting on a plane for.

headline: All the Foods of the Mideast at Its Stable Center
text: ON a warm evening last fall, a handful of old men shuffled into Al Quds, a big, overly lit restaurant on a bustling stretch of King Hussein Street in downtown Amman. Platters of syrupy pastries, crispy phyllo shells and fried dough were artfully stacked in the windows. But the men were there for the house specialty: mansaf.

headline: A Not-So-Simple Plan
text: I am, let’s face it, not the best eater. I don’t like foods touching, I insist that meat, fish and even fowl be perilously rare, and I know how to say “sauce on the side” in five languages. When I was a kid, my diet consisted of American cheese slices that I would not eat unless they had been cut into pretty shapes. On my birthday, I was allowed to skip dinner.

headline: Calm as Ever, Brady Wins With Postseason Poise
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  From the league’s most valuable player to a litany of both personal and team records, Tom Brady has not been shortchanged on awards during this transcendent Patriots season.

headline: N.C.A.A. Ban on Text-Messaging as Recruiting Tool Will Remain
text: NASHVILLE  Members of N.C.A.A. Division I upheld a ban on text-messaging to high school students Saturday at their annual convention, defeating a movement by college coaches who had argued that the new technology was vital to connecting with teenage prospects.

headline: The Howl That Haunts West 66th Street
text: IT was a Tuesday afternoon on far West 66th Street and the subject, as usual, was noise. Lloyd Lederkramer, a beatific-looking 56-year-old with hip black eyeglasses, stood on the balcony of his building at 303 West 66th Street, on West End Avenue, and gazed at the building across the street.

headline: Daunted by Data? See Prospectus Lite
text: BUYERS of mutual funds may soon get an easy-to-understand description of potential investments without having to confront that formidable outpouring of legal verbiage known as the prospectus.

headline: McFadden’s Father Denies Report
text: The father of the Arkansas star running back Darren McFadden denied a report that he has sent paperwork to the N.F.L. so his son can enter the upcoming draft. ESPN.com, citing unidentified sources, reported that the father, Graylon McFadden, provided the relevant paperwork early this week.“I hate to be saying anything because all these false stories and everything are floating around,” Graylon McFadden told The Associated Press on Saturday. “But no, I didn’t  and that’s all I’ve got to say.”

headline: The Right Hires
text: To afford to start a new business, I must use low-cost foreign manufacturers, some of whom likely maintain unsafe working conditions. It is difficult to be certain from here. In the relevant country, many workers doing the tasks I’ll require receive low wages and face serious health problems including chronic colds , fever , stomach disorders, chest pains and tuberculosis. Is it wrong to start my business in this way?  NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

headline: Ameristar to Open Hotel in Missouri
text: St. Charles, Mo., has come a long way since the Lewis and Clark expedition. For one thing, it’s no longer necessary to rough it along the banks of the Missouri River. Ameristar (www.ameristar.com), a Las Vegas-based gambling and entertainment company, is set to open the hotel at its complex in St. Charles soon. The 400-room luxury hotel, with a 7,000-square-foot spa, will be the first all-suite property for the company, whose casino, conference rooms, nightclub and restaurants have already opened in St. Charles. Highlights of the Ameristar Casino Resort Spa include an indoor/outdoor pool and sunken living rooms in each suite and floor-to-ceiling window views of the river or the city. Nightly rates start at $169.

headline: Two Giants Try to Learn to Share Asia
text: BEIJING  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India will arrive in Beijing on Sunday for a three-day visit to China, with each country eager to increase bilateral trade, promote mutual friendship and offer reassurances that Asia is big enough to accommodate the ambitions of both rising powers.

headline: Glad to Dance and Eager to Talk About It
text: WHOEVER first said, “The road to hell is paved with good intentions” might have been inspired by the purgatory of a panel discussion on the creative process. Laborious, awkward and vapid, such talks rarely offer even a glimpse into what makes artists tick. Discussions of dance, a nonverbal form, can be distinctively painful.

headline: Tough Guys for Tough Times
text: YOU don’t need to follow Mike Huckabee, or even politics, to appreciate that Chuck Norris is everywhere these days.

headline: U.S. Presses Kenyan President and Opposition Leaders to Meet
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The American government on Saturday took its toughest position yet on Kenya’s disputed elections, calling on Kenya’s president and opposition leaders to meet immediately and saying that the election had been so flawed that it was impossible to know who had won.

headline: Fathers and Sons
text: To be neoconservative is to bear almost daily witness to the resurrection of Adolf Hitler. “Truly Hitlerian,” the Washington Post columnist Charles Krauthammer pronounced Saddam Hussein’s saber-rattling before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Three days after the 9/11 attacks, Paul Wolfowitz, then deputy defense secretary, opined that Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda followers “misread our system as one that’s weak, that can’t take casualties. ... Hitler made that mistake.” Norman Podhoretz, the former editor of Commentary, said of the Iranian president Mahmoud Ahmadinejad last spring, “Like Hitler, he is a revolutionary whose objective is to overturn the going international system.” In the same month, the defense analyst Richard Perle mused on whether it had been “a correct reading” of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat “to believe that business could be done with him that would produce a result? I don’t think so. These are the difficult decisions. Diplomacy with Hitler. Chamberlain went to Munich, presumably on the theory that you talk to your enemies and not to your friends, and what did it produce?”

headline: Lost Children, Lost Truths
text: BUENOS AIRES

headline: A Passage to India
text: STANDING at the beginning of the buffet line at Jackson Diner in Queens, Krishnendu Ray took a plate from the heated stack of dishes, plopped on spoonfuls of several offerings and headed to table No. 22. There, a waiter tucked the bill into a wire stand and set down a pink plastic jug of water.

headline: Defensive Line Gives Thanks for Praise, Then Takes Aim
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants face the favored Dallas Cowboys on Sunday in a National Football Conference divisional playoff game, the outcome may depend on how the Giants’ aggressive defensive line performs against the Cowboys’ big and gifted offensive line.

headline: From 10 Hours a Week, $10 Million a Year
text: MARKUS FRIND, a 29-year-old Web entrepreneur, has not read the best seller “The 4-Hour Workweek”  in fact, he had not heard of it when asked last week  but his face could go on the book’s cover. He developed software for his online dating site, Plenty of Fish, that operates almost completely on autopilot, leaving Mr. Frind plenty of free time. On average, he puts in about a 10-hour workweek.

headline: Colts vs. Chargers
text: Is there any team more overlooked in these N.F.L. playoffs than the Colts? All they did was win the Super Bowl last season and repeat as American Football Conference South champions with a 13-3 record. It is worth noting that the A.F.C. South produced three playoff teams, each of which won at least 10 games. That has to be good training for the playoffs.

headline: Christine Julian and Garrett Moritz
text: Christine Camille Julian, a daughter of Mary and Francis Julian of Wilmington, Del., was married there on Saturday to Garrett Barak Moritz, a son of Patricia and Elan Moritz of Lynn Haven, Fla. The Very Rev. Daniel W. Gerres performed the ceremony at St. Ann’s Roman Catholic Church.

headline: From Israel, 2,188 Varieties
text: Rising interest in Israel’s wines, both kosher and nonkosher, makes the 2008 “Rogov’s Guide to Israeli Wines” ($19.95, Toby Press) invaluable.

headline: A Militia of One (Well Regulated)
text: THE Supreme Court is poised to decide whether the Second Amendment guarantees an individual right to keep and bear arms or only a collective right tied to service in a state militia. While the arguments in the case will draw on history, policy and empirical data, the discussion must at least start with the text of the amendment.

headline: Haven’t We Heard This Voice Before?
text: SHE had me at “Well, that hurts my feelings.”

headline: A Fed Signal Can’t Dispel the Gloom
text: It was another dismal week for the stock market, despite a short-lived rally on Thursday after Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, signaled that the Fed is ready to cut interest rates further.

headline: The Family Ski Challenge
text: ON our first morning at Copper Mountain Resort, I watched as my 8-year-old son cut his first tracks through the powder on Vein Glory, a beginner slope below the High Point chair. “I live for this!” he shouted back to me as he bombed down the hill in a “pizza” stance, rarely bothering to turn.

headline: The Corn Pudding Mob
text: “Let’s talk about how a washed-up rocker from New Jersey can get play on country radio but we can’t,” said Shooter Jennings as he stood in the buffet line at Hill Country, a barbecue restaurant in Chelsea, on a recent Thursday night. Jon Bon Jovi’s crossover single “Who Says You Can’t Go Home?” was playing as Mr. Jennings, 28, the country-rock musician, waited expectantly for what he calls his favorite shoepeg corn pudding and string bean casserole this side of Texas.

headline: Track Work Disrupts Service on No. 7 Train in Queens
text: The No. 7 train is to Roosevelt Avenue in Queens what the A train is to Harlem: the rhythm of the place. On Saturday, the beat was off as thousands of subway riders in some of the most diverse neighborhoods in the city endured life on Roosevelt Avenue, at least temporarily, without the train that some call the “Immigrant Express.”

headline: Cowboys vs. Giants
text: Cowboys’ pass offense

headline: In Spain, a Monumental Silence
text: MADRID

headline: Condos With Deco in the Details
text: JERSEY CITY

headline: Will Foreign Stocks Start to Disappoint?
text: FOREIGN stock markets have been an ideal refuge from troubles at home: decelerating economic and earnings growth, subprime mortgages, a subpar housing market and a tumbling dollar. But after years of strong outperformance abroad, some fund managers are bringing their investors’ money home.

headline: ‘Marienbad’ Returns, Unsettling as Ever
text: WHEN Alain Resnais’s gorgeous puzzle box of a movie, “Last Year at Marienbad,” reopens at Film Forum for two weeks on Friday, New York cinephiles may find themselves as mystified and delighted as their counterparts were when the film first reached Manhattan in 1962. “Marienbad” either does or does not tell the story of what may or may not be a love triangle that does or does not end violently, though the movie could also be presenting shards of a dream, a memory or a fantasy. What transpires among the three nameless principal characters is, the filmmakers have always maintained, up to you to figure out.

headline: Correction: Caren Raine, Joel Camche
text: Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Caren Raine and Joel Camche misstated the date of their ceremony. It was Saturday, Jan. 5, not Jan. 4.

headline: Thrown by Housing’s Shaky Foundation
text: THE fourth quarter of 2007 ended much as the third quarter did, with investors having reason to be hopeful and maybe more reason to be nervous. Both periods featured steep and sudden declines in the prices of stocks and all but the highest-quality bonds as it became clear that the broader economy and financial system were not immune to worsening conditions in the housing market.

headline: Prosecutor Who Unraveled Corruption in Boston Turns to C.I.A. Tape Case
text: WASHINGTON  In 1999, John H. Durham, a federal prosecutor based in Connecticut, was assigned to wade into a seemingly impenetrable and corrupt network in Boston involving police officers, federal agents and organized crime figures.

headline: Up Front
text: In the early 1990s, Jeffrey Rosen served as a law clerk to Abner Mikva, then the chief judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Rosen described Mikva in an e-mail message as “a great champion of the First Amendment.” Anthony Lewis’s first book in 17 years, “Freedom for the Thought That We Hate,” which Rosen reviews on the cover, also champions the First Amendment. In his own book “The Most Democratic Branch,” Rosen argues that the Supreme Court is most successful when it reflects a national consensus on constitutional values. “I share Lewis’s admiration for the First Amendment cases,” he said, “but disagree that most of them were ‘bold judicial decisions.’ By the time the court got serious about protecting free speech in the 1960s, a majority of the country was willing to go along.”

headline: Vanishing Act
text: What if the United States were at war during a presidential election  and none of the candidates wanted to talk about it? Iraq has become the great disappearing issue of the early primary season, and if nothing fundamental changes on the ground there  a probable result of current policy  the war may disappear even more completely in the new year.

headline: The Two Paths to Wealth: Earn More, Spend Less
text: REDUCED to the absolute essence, there are only two ways to become richer than you are: you need more money coming in, or you must reduce the amount going out.

headline: A Pig and a Priss in Their Prime (Time)
text: SELDOM, if ever, has a single comedic property gone through so many incarnations as “The Odd Couple.” It began life in 1965 as Neil Simon’s Broadway hit about the domestic discord between two divorced yet utterly dissimilar roommates, the finicky neat freak Felix Unger and the sloppy, beer-swilling Oscar Madison. It became a film (1968) and a television series (1970-75). It then morphed into a Saturday morning cartoon (1975-77), followed by a short-lived black television version (1982-83) and a more successful, virtually all-female Broadway rendering (1985-86) before reverting to basics with the 2005 revival on Broadway.

headline: Will Nardelli Be Chrysler’s Mr. Fix-It?
text: DETROIT

headline: A Power Trip With Green Detours
text: HEAR the noise, feel the thunder, experience the lightning! Detroit is firing up the pyrotechnics as it prepares to play host to the 2008 North American International Auto Show. Perhaps all the hoopla will make it easier for the industry to forget, just for a while, the stark new realities of the showroom, where car buyers seem to be falling out of love with the kinds of vehicles that made Detroit the capital of the automobile world.

headline: Is Eloquence Overrated?
text: IN the end, said Theodore C. Sorensen, the celebrated speechwriter for President John F. Kennedy, what made a great speech in 1940 or 1961 is not much different from what makes a great speech in 2008.

headline: Connecting to Roots With Dances From India
text: PARSIPPANY

headline: Jack Brod, Early Tenant of Skyscraper, Dies at 98
text: Jack Brod, a businessman who over nearly eight decades gradually worked his way from the 7th floor of the Empire State Building to the 76th, where he reigned as the skyscraper’s last original tenant, died last Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

headline: The Lemur
text: Chapter 1: Glass Houses

headline: Parent Trap
text: With all the ambitious novels for young adults and fat fantasy trilogies, it’s easy to forget the abiding category of children’s domestic fiction  stories for 9-to-12-year-olds about school, friends and family. Beverly Cleary provided the postwar model with her books about Beezus, Ramona and Henry Huggins; Judy Blume and Norma Klein brought a little edge to the genre in the 1970s; and Ann M. Martin sold millions of books with the Baby-Sitters Club series in the 1980s.

headline: Clemens Faces Dangers of Spin in Steroid Case
text: Roger Clemens has not stumped in New Hampshire, has not yukked with Stephen Colbert, and most certainly has not welled up in a coffee shop. Yet he is running perhaps America’s most provocative campaign.

headline: Rushing and Posturing in Danbury
text: Congress’s failure to pass meaningful immigration reform last year dispersed the debate to dozens of municipalities nationwide. On Monday night, the City Council in Danbury, Conn., will consider a question being asked in too many cities and towns: whether local police should become enforcers of federal immigration law.

headline: Duel of the Titans
text: Duel of the Titans

headline: In Paris, Selling a Duplex
text: PARIS

headline: Teacher Talks Turn Contentious Over Letter
text: THE tone of negotiations between teachers in Mamaroneck, who have been working without a contract since the old one expired June 30, and the school district went from cooperative to contentious last week after the district sent a letter to the community suggesting that the union was to blame for the slow pace of negotiations. Teachers said the letter was misleading.

headline: Lilah Schechner and Marcus Nicolaidis
text: Lilah Schechner, the daughter of Danice Bordett and Bill Schechner of Berkeley, Calif., was married on Saturday to Marcus J. Nicolaidis, a son of Lynn L. Licata of Sylvania, Ohio, and Nick Nicolaidis of Dallas. Matthew J. D’Emic, an acting justice of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, officiated at the Bowery Hotel in Manhattan.

headline: Facing Rumors About Future, Thomas Remains Defiant
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Defensiveness and denials filled the air Saturday afternoon, which made it pretty much like any other day recently at the Knicks’ trouble-filled training center. Nothing changes here except the Knicks’ winning percentage and their mood, which are plummeting in tandem.

headline: Their Satanic Majesties
text: With its motifs of homosexuality, Satan worship, drug addiction, promiscuity, nihilism and general decadence, Zachary Lazar’s superb second novel, “Sway,” reads like your parents’ nightmare idea of what would happen to you if you fell under the spell of rock ’n’ roll.

headline: Forecast in Arizona: Cooling Prices at Some Elevations
text: TO the casual collector, the giant car auctions around Phoenix in January have the confused and frenzied air of a commodities exchange as participants bid on Mustangs, Cobras and Ferraris, with the occasional bus and amphibious car thrown in.

headline: Huckabee Splits Young Evangelicals and Old Guard
text: WASHINGTON  Much of the national leadership of the Christian conservative movement has turned a cold shoulder to the Republican presidential campaign of Mike Huckabee, wary of his populist approach to economic issues and his criticism of the Bush administration’s foreign policy. But that has only fired up Brett and Alex Harris.

headline: Turn Down the Burner, Fire Up the Sound
text: WHAT is it about men and stereo equipment? This fabled connection may be a cliché on par with men’s reluctance to ask for directions. But clichés do not exist in a vacuum  and sound cannot travel through one anyway.

headline: A Remodeling Gift to Remind Tarrytown of a Church’s History
text: Tarrytown

headline: No Lack of Curiosity, or Civility, at Corzine’s First Forum on Toll Proposal
text: LIVINGSTON, N.J.  One person blurted out that Gov. Jon S. Corzine should raise the gas tax. Another yelled that New Jersey’s biggest yoke was its overabundance of elected officials.

headline: A Surreal Moment in the Age of Digital
text: UNABLE to sleep the other night, I got up and wandered around the house. Everywhere I looked I saw little green lights  on the TV, the smoke detectors, the downstairs computer  and digital display screens.

headline: The Moral Instinct
text: Which of the following people would you say is the most admirable:  Mother Teresa, Bill Gates or Norman Borlaug? And which do you think is the least admirable? For most people, it’s an easy question. Mother Teresa, famous for ministering to the poor in Calcutta, has been beatified by the Vatican, awarded the Nobel Peace Prize and ranked in an American poll as the most admired person of the 20th century. Bill Gates, infamous for giving us the Microsoft dancing paper clip and the blue screen of death, has been decapitated in effigy in “I Hate Gates” Web sites and hit with a pie in the face. As for Norman Borlaug . . . who the heck is Norman Borlaug?

headline: Quiet on the Home Front
text: A TOP-FLOOR apartment was what Michelle Panzer and Paul Campbell wanted most. They craved the quiet that came with having no inconsiderate neighbors tromping above them.

headline: Lives of Poverty, Untouched by China’s Boom
text: YANGMIAO, China  When she gets sick, Li Enlan, 78, picks herbs from the woods that grow nearby instead of buying modern medicines. That is not a result of some philosophical choice, though. She has never seen a doctor and, like many residents of this area, lives in a meager barter economy, seldom coming into contact with cash.

headline: New Listings With Your Decaf?
text: SOUTH NORWALK

headline: A Bookworm’s Holiday
text: EVERYONE knows libraries are not just about books anymore, but no one knows it better that the women at the main information booth of the New York Public Library at 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue.

headline: Refusing to Let the Mob Hijack What It Means to Be Italian
text: DON’T get her wrong: Rosanne De Luca Braun loves “The Godfather.” Ditto, “The Sopranos.” But she has devoted much of the last seven years to exploring why certain Italian-American stereotypes  especially the gun-toting, cannoli-loving mobster  loom so large on screen, and in the national psyche.

headline: Correction: The Girl Beneath the Gilding
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 9 about Audrey Munson, who was the model or inspiration for more than 15 statues in New York City, misidentified a city near her final home, in the town of Mexico, N.Y., and her grave, in New Haven, N.Y. Both Mexico and New Haven are near the city of Oswego, on Lake Ontario  not near Lake Oswego, which is a city on Oswego Lake in Oregon. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Jan. 5.

headline: Man Is Charged in Baby’s Death
text: The father of a 3-week-old baby was charged with murder on Saturday, nearly two weeks after the child died at a Staten Island hospital.

headline: Correction: The Huckabee Factor
text: An article on Dec. 16 about Mike Huckabee misstated his academic credentials. He majored in religion at Ouachita Baptist University in Arkadelphia, Ark., not speech and communications. Speech was his minor.

headline: Clinton Campaign Builds Post-Feb. 5 War Chest
text: The Clinton presidential campaign is moving this weekend to create an organizational hierarchy for its donors to accelerate fund-raising to pay for increasingly expensive advertising, travel, and voter-outreach efforts, with an ambitious goal of raising more than $10 million by the end of January, according to several of the donors and a campaign official.

headline: An Interview With Jacqueline Wilson
text: Jacqueline Wilson, 62, has sold more than 20 million books in the United Kingdom, and earlier this month was made a Dame of the British Empire. Yet while she’s a household name in England, her books for children and young adults have never caught on in the same way with American readers. Her new publisher, Roaring Brook Press, is trying to change that with “Candyfloss,” a novel with a classic Jacqueline Wilson heroine: Floss is loyal and resourceful, and determined to stand by her hard-luck Dad when her mother takes off for a more glamorous life in Australia. Wilson answered a few questions about her work by email. —The Editors

headline: ‘Entering Hades’
text: On July 11, 1991, a solar eclipse occurred in the sky over Los Angeles. At 10:12 a.m., the moon began to move in front of the sun, and by 11:28 it covered 69 percent of it. That morning, a couple of men and their children drove up to Corral Canyon Road in Malibu, northwest of the city, to watch the event.

headline: ‘Irreligion’
text: Are there any logical reasons to believe in God? Billions of people over thousands of years have entertained this question, and the issue is certainly not without relevance in our world today. The chasms separating literal believers, temperate believers, and outright nonbelievers are deep. There are many who seem to be impressed with the argument that God exists simply because He says He does in a much extolled tome that He allegedly inspired. Many others subscribe with varying degrees of conviction to more sophisticated arguments for God, while atheists and agnostics find none of the arguments persuasive.
