headline: Under the G.M. Big Top
text: DETROIT — We live in a hypersophisticated marketing world. Just last week I saw -– glimpsed might be the better word -– an episode of “The Hills” on MTV, that reality show about those kids who live in the Hollywood Hills. This special episode was called “Living the Life of the Hills” and there were layers of graphics calling out each product and its price. Arnette sunglasses: $105. Polo shirt $75. BMW: $47,000.

headline: ‘I’m Telling You, It’s Like the Hollywood Writers’ Strike’
text: Aired Friday night on CBS: President George W. Bush is in the Middle East. He’s over there right now because his approval rating is higher.

headline: The Early Word: The Evangelical Vote
text: It’s Sunday, and we’re returning to a theme that’s permeated the 2008 presidential race: religion and politics. The focus this morning is on Republican presidential candidate and former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee.

headline: Odysseus in America: Combat Trauma and the Trials of Homecoming
text: CHAPTER 3Pirate Raid: Staying in Combat ModeJust as some thieves are not bad soldiers, some soldiers turn out to be pretty good robbers, so nearly are these two ways of life related.—Sir Thomas More, Utopia, published in 1516But will warriors lay down, together with the iron in which they are covered, their spirit nourished . . . by familiarity with danger? Will they don, together with civilian dress, that veneration for the laws and respect for protective forms . . . ? To them the unarmed class appears vulgar and ignoble, laws are superfluous subtleties, the forms of social life just so many insupportable delays.—Benjamin Constant, Swiss, 1767–1830But all was not right with the spirit of the men who came back. Something was wrong. They put on civilian clothes again, looked to their mothers and wives very much like the young men who had gone. . . . But they had not come back the same men. Something had altered in them. They were subject to queer moods, queer tempers, fits of profound depression alternating with a restless desire for pleasure. Many of them were easily moved to passion when they lost control of themselves. Many were bitter in their speech, violent in opinion, frightening. For some time while they drew their unemployment pensions, they did not make any effort to get work for the future. . . . Young soldiers who had been very skilled with machine-guns, trench-mortars, hand-grenades, found that they were classed with the ranks of unskilled labor in civil life.—Philip Gibbs, British, 1920

headline: Headlines: An Heiress in Paris; Top Country Homes; Depp in L.A.
text: Recent stories from the world of real estate:

headline: There Will be Financial Bloodletting
text: The Hollywood Reporter reminds that it won’t just be caterers and florists taking a hit because of the not-so-golden Globes:

headline: Five Easy Pieces
text: The Red Carpet blog at the Variety says that figuring out what the Big Five will be come Oscar time may not be as tough as it looks:

headline: The Ultimate Passat, or the Phaeton Revisited?
text: Introduced on Sunday: Volkswagen Passat CC

headline: Worst Airports in Europe? Cast your vote!
text: As a frequent (and frequently frustrated) flyer in Europe, over the past two months I undertook a completely unscientific survey of my fellow air travelers, asking them to nominate the worst airports and to explain their choices. I wrote about it in the International Herald Tribune and the New York Times. You can read about it here.

headline: ‘What Does That Do for Your Self-Esteem?’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: You know, I was reading a story in the paper today about a man who actually trains the suicide bombers in the Middle East. And he says he does not accept every person who volunteers. Well, what does that do for your self-esteem?

headline: Shades of Grey
text: Paramount, through is specialty division, Paramount Vantage, is in the thick of this year’s Oscar hunt with “There Will Be Blood” and “No Country for Old Men,” among others. The Bagger’s colleague Michael Cieply spends some space and time talking with Brad Grey, the head of the studio, about how planning is a bit overrated and why his gut told him making “Cloverfield,” the new J.J. Abrams movie that is the biggest hand-held pic ever, would be a great way to start the new year. The Hot Blog, incidentally, takes a decidedly less sunny view of “Cloverfield.”

headline: In the Beginning, Hyundai Did Not Make Luxury Cars
text: Introduced on Sunday: 2009 Hyundai Genesis sedan

headline: Chevy and Mazda Win North American Awards
text: DETROIT — On Sunday morning, the Chevrolet Malibu and Mazda CX-9 were named 2008 Car and Truck of the Year in a brief ceremony at the Detroit auto show. Tony Swan, senior editor of Car and Driver, made the announcement in front of a large crowd that spilled into the nearby Changfeng Motors display.

headline: Kitchen Magician
text: The Four Seasons is serving as a de-facto watering hole for Globe orphans, including the Bagger, who sat down with Brad Bird, the writer-director of “Ratatouille.” The rat caper/cuisine movie picked up an AFI citation last Friday, as one of the best films of the year, never mind the animation asterisk.

headline: Missouri Senator Endorses Obama
text: LAS VEGAS – Since losing the New Hampshire primary last week, Senator Barack Obama has won a string of endorsements. The latest one came Sunday, with Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri announcing her support for Mr. Obama’s presidential candidacy.

headline: Turns Out We Do Need Your Stinking Badges
text: The show, or at least a simulacrum of it, will go on, and so of course there must be badges and security to match.The Bagger stopped at the Beverly Hilton for his credential photo where he met Jerry Mark, the head of EventCredentials LLC.

headline: Sunday Kickoff: Neuheisel’s Long Road
text: Just how far has Rick Neuheisel traveled to become U.C.L.A.’s new head coach? Well, as Kurt Streeter of the Los Angeles Times writes, Neuheisel began resurrecting his coaching career by volunteering as an assistant for a high school team.

headline: Swag Soldiers On
text: A lot of things have been missing this weekend because of the stripped-down Globes, with its decimated roster of festivities. The Bagger wonders where those 300 vacant-eyed party girls, who were everywhere in L.A. last year at this time, are right now. Are they parking cars somewhere, getting their nails done, or thinking about going back to school and getting their MBAs?

headline: Predix Later Today
text: Taking a stab at what the Hollywood Foreign Press Association will celebrate — show or no show -– is a little like predicting who your batty rich aunt is going to leave all the loot to. Dreams are crushed and heartbreak ensues. It is a small, idiosyncratic bunch which has been known to be susceptible to the blandishments of stardom.

headline: Milan Élan: Group Hug
text: Ferre’s new look.

headline: Clawing Our Way to the Top, With Scion’s Help
text: DETROIT — It wasn’t MTV that pimped the Scion xD into a Coney Island claw machine, it was Scion’s favorite customizer Troy Sumitomo, president of the Five Axis design company. Part of the back hatch rises to become television screens watching us journalists guide the claw over a plush toy Scion (model anonymous) and push the plunger to drop it and squeeze.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, Jan. 13:

headline: Dead Batteries Only, Please!
text: DETROIT — This may be the year of the hybrid at the Detroit auto show, but all the display cars with any lights and displays are purely plug-in: No high-voltage batteries are allowed to carry a charge on the show floor or in displays, said Majid Taghikhani, a hybrid expert at Johnson Controls.

headline: CSI Gives CBS a Lift
text: With new episodes of ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy” and CBS’s “CSI” at 9 p.m. on Thursday, both networks surged to the top of the night’s ratings heap. CBS averaged more total viewers as “CSI” attracted the larger audience of the two hit shows: 18.1 million viewers compared to 17.6 million, according to Nielsen’s estimates. “Grey’s Anatomy,” however, trounced all competition for the night among adults 18 to 49, making ABC No. 1 in that demographic despite a weak showing at 10 p.m. for “Big Shots” (6.8 million).

headline: Let It Snow, Let It Snow
text: DETROIT — General Motor’s announcement that its Saab brand would introduce a crossover four-cylinder capable of running on E85 ethanol was made with a pair of skiers dressed in white hopping out of the vehicle under a gentle fall of shaved-ice snow. The melting flakes made the stage sticky, but G.M. Chief Executive Rick Wagoner found to his delight that his speech, which he had left on the podium moments before, was protected when he resumed the stage. “There’s snow on the podium now; somebody thought of this plastic shield to cover the rest of the script. Good thinking, guys!” he said, smiling.

headline: From Acoma Pueblo to Texas Stadium
text: Tourists heading to the Acoma Pueblo reservation in New Mexico come over a hill that overlooks a valley that surrounds a 367-foot sandstone mesa rising to the sky. The village rests on top, with its breathtaking views and ancient traditions and houses made from adobe clay.

headline: Regarding Tim Thomas
text: Many Islanders fans have written in to object to our assertion that Boston’s Tim Thomas is far more deserving of a spot on the East All-Star team than the Isles’ Rick DiPietro. They say they’ve watched DiPietro save the Long Island team all season long, but they don’t seem to have seen much of Thomas, who doesn’t get a lot of ink as it is. Here’s a video resume of Thomas’s performance last year, featuring some truly amazing stops.

headline: Predicting the “Globs”
text: With not much in the way of events to attend and very little intelligence to go on, the Bagger was reduced to asking random people who they thought the HFPA would pick this year. That included the guy muttering to himself down the breakfast counter at Norm’s on La Cienega, who turned to the Bagger and asked, “Do you think it’s bad if you are the Archangel?” When a question like that comes from someone talking to their waffles, the answer is always tricky.

headline: Bulls on Parade
text: Chrysler showcased its new Ram pickup on Sunday with a herd of cattle strolling down Washington Blvd. in Detroit.

headline: Chrysler: We Won’t Resort to Fleet Sales to Prop Up Sales
text: DETROIT – Chrysler expects to report sales declines every month this year because its dealerships will not be able to sell enough vehicles to compensate for a planned cutback in deliveries to rental companies, a top executive said Sunday at the Detroit Auto Show.

headline: BET Founder Slams Obama in South Carolina
text: UpdatedCOLUMBIA, S.C. — Robert L. Johnson, the founder of Black Entertainment Television, who is campaigning today in South Carolina with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, just made a suggestion that raised the specter of Barack Obama’s past drug use. He also compared Mr. Obama to Sidney Poitier, the black actor, in “Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner.”

headline: Clinton: Pledge to the Flag Every Day
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Senator Hillary Clinton said today that children should recite the pledge of allegiance in school every day.

headline: Giuliani Pushes Hard in Florida
text: MIAMI – “Florida is Rudy Country,’’ the new signs and stickers say hopefully.

headline: Cattle Call Outside Cobo Center
text: Video

headline: A World Without Stars
text: Don’t look for George Clooney or any of his A-list siblings during the Globes press conference tonight even as the Writers Guild of America has removed the threat of pickets. By the time the word came down on Friday that it was okay for actors to participate, most had made plans that did not include hair and make-up. Said one publicist, “We’d all like the Globes to save a little face, but with so little time, there really wasn’t much we could do about it.”

headline: A Twist in the A.F.C. Script
text: Well, well, well. All those anticipating an epic Colts-Patriots rematch in a Super Bowl-esque A.F.C. championship game next week will have to find some film of last year’s game. The San Diego Chargers, left with Billy Volek and Michael Turner to lead the offense, defeated the Colts, 28-24, a few moments ago.

headline: Long Night’s Journey Into Night
text: Between the tributes – Sidney Lumet is God! – and the extended spoken word performances of many of the critics – all the was missing was the bongos – the Los Angeles Film Critics Association event on Saturday was a night when movies and the people who make them received big ups … and a little bit of an endurance test. According to David Poland of Movie City News, when Paul Thomas Anderson, the director who was honored for “There Will Be Blood,” finally got to the podium three hours into the night, he checked his watch and said, “If another [charming, but nonetheless redacted profane adjective] film critic criticizes one of my movies for being too long, I’m going to remind them of this ceremony.”

headline: Clinton-Obama War of Words
text: The Times’s Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny have just written an article published on our home page about the latest developments in the escalating dispute between Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama about remarks made just before the New Hampshire primary. (Update: Adam Nagourney has more in an article on the front page of Monday’s paper.)

headline: Milan Élan: Prada
text: Prada (Don Ashby)

headline: Another War Election
text: It’s tempting to claim, based on recent polling data, that the central issue in the 2008 presidential election will be the U.S. economy. In the Iowa Republican Caucus entrance poll, more voters chose the economy as the most important issue (26 percent) than the Iraq war (17 percent). And in the Iowa Democratic Caucus entrance poll, the economy and the Iraq war were tied for most-important-issue status, with each drawing 35 percent support.

headline: Poetic Injustice
text: Awards Daily is holding their annual Globes Haiku throwdown. (We Oscar ninnies are an odd, obsessive species.) Take a crack at a poetic summation here.The Bagger is sequestered awaiting his curtain call for the press conference that is now the Globes, but nothing says moody quite like a pre-event haiku:

headline: Notable Models From Day One in Detroit
text: A selection of vehicles that were displayed on the first preview day of the North American International Auto Show.

headline: McCain ‘Too Busy’ to Answer Romney’s Jabs
text: Senator John McCain drew large crowds in three appearances in Michigan on Sunday, when he rebuffed attempts to be drawn into a tit-for-tat political war of words with Mitt Romney.

headline: Banks to Try Chrysler Loan Sale Again
text: From Micheline Maynard, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Below-the-Line Protesters
text: Although the Writers Guild of America has said that its members will not be picketing the Golden Globes, a dozen or so below-the-line employees were at the entrance to the Beverly Hilton on Sunday afternoon. A mix of medical personnel, stylists and craft services workers shouted at passing cars and held up signs. “Take care of us, we take care of you!” yelled Tammy Yazgulian, a set nurse.

headline: Obama Questions Nevada Caucus Lawsuit
text: LAS VEGAS – At a rally this afternoon, Senator Barack Obama questioned the timing and legitimacy of a lawsuit that had been filed here seeking to prevent caucuses from being held Saturday in nine casinos on the Las Vegas Strip.

headline: GAME OVER: Giants 21, Cowboys 17
text: Postgame: Anyone expect that to happen? Cowboys looked pretty solid in the first half, but they got bit by penalties in the second. …Manning finishes 12 of 18 for 163 yards and 2 touchdowns. Brandon Jacobs rushed for 54 yards, Bradshaw for 34. The totals are a little anemic for the Giants’ offense, but, as I was telling a friend of mine, yards are overrated. …Romo does not come through in the end; he was 18 of 35 for 201 yards with a touchdown pass and a pick. Let the debate begin: How well would he have played if he’d spent last weekend in Dallas, eating chicken wings at a Hooters? …Keep those comments coming. I am turning this thread over to you. How will the Giants fare in Green Bay? Anybody for the Cowboys going to lose his job over this? And are you ready to accept Eli Manning as the Giants’ quarterback?

headline: Press Function
text: The Bagger is in position, up close, stage right, at a table George Clooney probably would have been sitting at if he were coming. The Bagger is always stuck in dreary press rooms at these events, so he is used to it, and the golden motif of the stage for the announcement is actually quite lovely. Carpenters are still hammering stuff together on stage, which gives the room an air of expectation, but its not like there is going to be a sudden starburst of wattage when the programming begins. It will be a nice, dry press conference, which brings the Bagger back to his salad days as a government reporter. Nothing like a couple of crisp announcements to report on deadline to get the old journalistic juices flowing. And speaking of getting juiced, don’t forget to make your predictions. There’s still time.

headline: In Many Venues, Economy Will Take Center Stage
text: Political wisdom this week runs smack into economic reality. It is not yet clear which force will prove more powerful.

headline: The Uses of the Humanities, Part Two
text: In a poem titled “Matins,” the 17th century Anglican poet George Herbert says to God, If you will “teach me thy love to know . . . Then by a sunbeam I will climb to thee.” But the dynamics of the proffered bargain – if you do X, I’ll do Y – are undercut by the line that proposes it, and especially by the double pun in “sunbeam.”

headline: Remote Reactions
text: Jeremy Piven was on a movie set shooting a film for Paramount Vantage, “The Goods: The Don Ready Story,” and happened to step into his trailer just about the time that it was announced he won best television actor in a supporting role.

headline: The Verdict
text: The results are in. The evening was a downright weird one and contained its share of competitive surprises. “Atonement,” which had been considered to be losing luster in the awards race, stormed back to life with a win as best motion picture drama. The audience of journalists and press agents gasped a bit when it was announced. “Sweeney Todd” bested “Juno” in the best motion picture musical or comedy, also a surprise to some. Cate Blanchett won a best supporting actress for her role, with the HFPA choosing her over Amy Ryan from “Gone Baby Gone,” who has been the much chattered about favorite. And the directors win for Julian Schnabel for “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly” came completely out of left field when the only directors being talked about have been Paul Thomas Anderson and the Coen brothers so far this year. A full recap of the evening is already available as well. In case you were wondering, the Bagger got slaughtered in his picks. More details on the debacle later.

headline: A Starting Point for Productive Climate Discourse
text: The views expressed here on human-caused climate change run the gamut. It’s a hoax. It’s a catastrophe. It’s a crisis. It’s a manageable trend. It can be fixed with a rising tax on carbon. It can be fixed by making people rich. It can be controlled by dumping something in the air or oceans.

headline: A Longer Spot Check of Global Warming
text: Roger A. Pielke Jr. has done some further checking of the IPCC’s predictions, the subject of the last post. You can see the graphs here. Now he’s gone back to 1990 and checked out four different predictions by the U.N.’s climate panel. He concludes, among other things:

headline: Allison Eckardt Ledes, 53, Editor of Magazine Antiques, Is Dead
text: Allison Eckardt Ledes, who, as editor of The Magazine Antiques, brought a new focus on European, Asian and 20th-century decorative arts to a publication traditionally devoted to Americana, died at her home in Manhattan on Tuesday. She was 53, and was also a resident of Bedford, N.Y.

headline: Afghans, Report for Duty
text: Washington

headline: Downsized: The Eerie Tale of a Man and His Monster
text: “Frankenstein (Mortal Toys),” a puppet version of Mary Shelley’s novel, turns out to be that happy thing: an inspired melding of material and medium. The creators of “Mortal Toys,” a production of Here Arts Center and Automata, justifiably call it a “miniature spectacle.” Contained in a small puppet theater, it evokes the Romantic sublime with unflagging inventiveness: Arctic floes with icy blue light, lands of “mist and snow,” the delicate flight of a bird over mountains.

headline: When West Cannot Wait, Squeeze Goes Unbroken
text: Those who can, do; those who can’t, officiate. Then there are those who do both. Andrew Rosenthal is the new president of the Greater New York Bridge Association, but he showed that he can also play well by winning the first two open pair events at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in New York City last month. He captured the Jim Becker Stratified Open Pairs with Bjorn Fallenius, and the Babs Cohen Stratified Open Pairs with Michael Rosenberg.

headline: The Democrats’ Fairy Tale
text: “Give me a break. This whole thing is the biggest fairy tale I’ve ever seen.” Thus spoke Bill Clinton last Monday night, exasperated by Barack Obama’s claim that he  unlike Hillary Clinton  had been consistently right (or wrong, depending on your point of view) on the Iraq war.

headline: Sears Expects 60% Drop in Profit for Quarter
text: Sears used to beckon shoppers to come see its softer side. Now, they are starting to see its struggling side.

headline: The Early Bird Gets the Bad Grade
text: IT’S Monday morning, and you’re having trouble waking your teenagers. You’re not alone. Indeed, each morning, few of the country’s 17 million high school students are awake enough to get much out of their first class, particularly if it starts before 8 a.m. Sure, many of them stayed up too late the night before, but not because they wanted to.

headline: Drug Has No Benefit in Trial, Makers Say
text: A clinical trial of Zetia, a cholesterol-lowering drug prescribed to about 1 million people a week, failed to show that the drug has any medical benefits, Merck and Schering-Plough said on Monday.

headline: Taiwan Election May Ease Tensions With China
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The landslide victory for the opposition Kuomintang in Taiwan’s parliamentary elections could sharply reduce the political influence of President Chen Shui-bian, who has antagonized China and frustrated the United States with his efforts to forge a strong national identity for Taiwan.

headline: When Crime Was Always on Our Minds
text: In the bad old days of street crime, an era most New Yorkers would think of as before 1990, it was a personal quandary and a public obsession: If assaulted, do I run, hand over the money or stand and fight? And should I carry a weapon?

headline: Ford and Chrysler Unveil Their Redesigned Pickups
text: DETROIT  Cowboys and live cattle took over downtown on Sunday as Ford Motor and Chrysler heralded new versions of their all-important pickup trucks at the 2008 North American International Auto Show.

headline: Ex-Baathists Get a Break. Or Do They?
text: BAGHDAD  A day after the Iraqi Parliament passed legislation billed as the first significant political step forward in Iraq after months of deadlock, there were troubling questions  and troubling silences  about the measure’s actual effects.

headline: PGA Will Move Barclays From Westchester Club
text: The PGA Tour has notified Westchester Country Club that it intends to pull the plug on the remaining five years of a six-year agreement to play host to the Barclays, the opening event of its four-tournament playoffs for the FedEx Cup, the club’s president said Sunday.

headline: Fanfare for the Common Kid: Fidgeting but Still Curious
text: Even before the New York Philharmonic played a note of its Young People’s Concert on Saturday afternoon, Avery Fisher Hall rang with sound. Children plucked strings, banged percussion instruments and stomped blasts of air through organ pipes on the first tier; up on the third level others played notes  or at least made sounds  on a French horn. The lobby was filled with skits, demonstrations and interactive installations.

headline: Even a Blowout Victory Ends With Questions
text: Isiah Thomas  still the Knicks’ coach to the chagrin of many, though for how long, no one knows  was back on the bench Sunday night at Madison Square Garden, presiding over a rare victory and issuing another round of quizzical statements.

headline: G.O.P. Voters, in Big Shift, Favor McCain Over His Rivals
text: WASHINGTON  Republican voters have sharply altered their views of the party’s presidential candidates following the early contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, with Senator John McCain, once widely written off, now viewed more favorably than any of his major competitors, according to the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Toyota Will Offer a Plug-In Hybrid by 2010
text: DETROIT  The Toyota Motor Corporation, which leads the world’s automakers in sales of hybrid-electric vehicles, announced Sunday night that it would build its first plug-in hybrid by 2010.

headline: Disney Among Firms to Buy Stake in N.B.A.’s China Subsidiary
text: The Walt Disney Company and four Chinese investment firms will invest in an 11 percent stake in the National Basketball Association’s subsidiary in China, people briefed on the matter said Sunday.

headline: Barber Starts and Proves Tough to Stop
text: IRVING, Tex.  When Marion Barber III runs, dreadlocks flap past his shoulders from behind his helmet. His legs churn at a frightening speed, twin jackhammers working in tandem to punish and propel.

headline: An Iraqi House Was Rigged to Kill American Soldiers
text: SINSIL, Iraq  The courtyard was a scene of devastation, strewn with medieval mud brick and modern cinder block, shattered alike by the explosion that killed six American soldiers and their Iraqi interpreter.

headline: Killing of a Young Hiker Puts North Georgia on Edge
text: ATLANTA  In the days after a young woman was killed after being abducted on a popular North Georgia hiking trail, instructors offering a crash course in personal safety found classes filling up as fast as they were scheduled, and that they had to turn some women away.

headline: The Return of ‘Idol,’ Confident in Season 7
text: LOS ANGELES  Empty seats were common last summer at the American Idols Live concert tour. Two “American Idol” winners  Taylor Hicks, who took the top prize in the program’s fifth season, and Ruben Studdard, who won the second season  recently lost their record contracts. And last season, the sixth, marked the first time that overall viewership of “American Idol” declined from the previous year.

headline: Births
text: Nicole Richie, above left, who starred with Paris Hilton on “The Simple Life,” gave birth on Friday to Harlow Winter Kate Madden at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. The father is Joel Madden of the rock group Good Charlotte.... The singer Christina Aguilera, above right, gave birth on Saturday to Max Lion Bratman, the RCA Music Group announced. The child is the first for Ms. Aguilera and her husband, Jordan Bratman, a music business executive.

headline: Spacecraft Zipping Past Mercury
text: WASHINGTON  The Messenger spacecraft dashed past Mercury today, getting a quick glance at the solar system’s innermost planet, which it eventually will orbit for detailed studies.

headline: Zagat Family Is Putting Guide Empire on Market
text: A “clever and sharp” restaurant guide company with “telling” rankings and “a penchant for quote marks” from its thousands of “in-the-know” reviewers is “on the block.”

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: William J. McGuire, 82, Art of Persuasion Pioneer, Dies
text: William J. McGuire, a social psychologist at Yale whose work on the art of persuasion and how to resist it has been applied in political science, advertising and mass communications, died on Dec. 21 at his home in New Haven, Conn. He was 82.

headline: Prominent Entertainers Cited in Steroids Inquiry
text: Entertainers including the singer Mary J. Blige and the rapper 50 Cent are among thousands of people whose names are turning up in an investigation into obtaining steroids or human growth hormones, an Albany newspaper reported on Sunday.

headline: Clemens’s Lawyers Negotiating Deposition
text: When Mark McGwire and four other baseball players testified in front of Congress three years ago, they did so under oath but were not forced to give depositions in advance of their testimony.

headline: Woman Released by Guerrillas Returns to Colombia to See Son
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Freed by Colombian guerrillas last week after six years of captivity in jungle camps, Clara Rojas, a former aspirant to the vice presidency of Colombia, boarded a military plane here on Sunday bound for Bogotá, where she was reunited with her 3-year-old son.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: The Adidas Group named NYCA, Encinitas, Calif., as the worldwide agency of record for its Adidas Golf division, a new assignment. NYCA is also the creative agency for the TaylorMade brand of golf equipment, owned by Adidas. Spending was estimated at $5 million.

headline: Cartoon Creatures Leave Home and Find ... Home
text: In the halcyon days of our remembered childhoods we played fabulous games of imagination in our neighborhood backyards. Nowadays children don’t get out in the yard as much; they watch those games being played on television.

headline: West Coast Flair Bounds Into East Coast Sensibilities
text: Benjamin Levy came to New York, where he opened on Friday at the Joyce SoHo trailing awards and admiring reviews, as well as a designation as one of Dance magazine’s “Top 25 Choreographers to Watch in 2004.” A great divide may still remain between the dance sensibilities of New York and San Francisco, where LEVYdance is based. The four pieces Mr. Levy presented were certainly professional, as were the dancers, but watching them was dispiriting.

headline: Republican Indecision in South Carolina
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  To borrow a phrase, Bobbie Brock was for Rudolph W. Giuliani before she was against him.

headline: In Defending War Vote, Clintons Contradict Record
text: WASHINGTON  Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton have repeatedly invoked the name of Senator Chuck Hagel, a longtime critic of the Iraq war, as they defend Mrs. Clinton’s 2002 vote to authorize the war.

headline: Romney Embraces His Michigan Roots
text: SOUTHFIELD, Mich.  Wherever Mitt Romney goes in Michigan, he tells the story of the gift his sons gave him for his 60th birthday last year: a 1962 Rambler.

headline: ‘Cry-Baby’ Finds a Broadway Home
text: Now that “The Drowsy Chaperone” has finally gone to sleep, “Cry-Baby,” the musical based on the 1990 movie by John Waters, below, about greasers and squares in 1954 Baltimore, has announced its move into the Marquis Theater on Broadway. The musical, with songs by David Javerbaum (former head writer of “The Daily Show”) and Adam Schlesinger (from the band Fountains of Wayne) and a book by Mark O’Donnell and Thomas Meehan (who wrote the book for “Hairspray”) is scheduled to begin previews on March 15, with an opening set for April 24. Mark Brokaw is directing, and Rob Ashford is the choreographer. The production also announced that preview tickets would be priced at $54. Get it? 1954? $54? Yeah.

headline: With Shows Like These, Forget Reruns
text: I’ve got some bad news for striking Hollywood writers: Election 2008 is a breakaway hit.

headline: MySpace Agrees to Youth Protections
text: The social networking Web site MySpace and the attorneys general for 49 states announced Monday that they had reached an agreement under which MySpace would make a number of changes aimed at protecting teenagers and children using its site from sexual predators.

headline: So, Young Mr. Spinoza, Just What Is Your Thinking About God?
text: In recent years the playwright David Ives has become better known as a theatrical plastic surgeon. He’s the man primarily responsible for nipping and tucking the wayward books of the wheezier Broadway musicals for the City Center Encores! series. And this season he did his level best to spray away the smell of mothballs from a previously unproduced play by Mark Twain, “Is He Dead?”

headline: New Jersey Teams Prove They Can Play the City Game
text: Samardo Samuels, the center for St. Benedict’s Prep of Newark, started Sunday’s Super Six Invitational at Madison Square Garden on the bench, a maroon pullover draped over his immense shoulders.

headline: Error by Allies and 2 Clashes Kill 15 in South of Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two NATO soldiers, two Afghan soldiers and 11 Afghan police officers were killed in separate clashes in the volatile southern region of Afghanistan, officials said Sunday.

headline: Boone Gives Nets a Lift, Except at the Free-Throw Line
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The adventure begins when the Nets’ Josh Boone strolls to the free-throw line. With a white headband pulled over his braided hair and the tops of his ears, Boone gazes up at the rim, sadly, as if it were Mount Everest.

headline: Blood Drive at Shea Stadium
text: The Mets and the New York City Blood Center are holding a blood drive at Shea Stadium on Monday. All donors will receive a voucher for two tickets for a select game in April. The drive will be held between Gates C and D from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Donors must be at least 17 years old and 110 pounds.

headline: Lot of Good 12 Pro Bowl Picks Did for Cowboys
text: Irving, Tex.

headline: Music Industry, Souring on Apple, Embraces Amazon Service
text: LOS ANGELES  At the Super Bowl next month, the music industry will be switching teams  from Apple to Amazon.com.

headline: Better Transit for City’s Disabled Is Urged
text: The City Council assailed the state of transportation for the disabled in the city, and recommended a system of improvements, in a new report released on Sunday.

headline: G.M. Buys Stake in Ethanol Made From Waste
text: General Motors, eager to ensure a supply of fuel for the big fleet of flex-fuel ethanol-capable vehicles it is building, has joined the rush into alternative energy and invested in a company that intends to produce ethanol from crop wastes, wood chips, scrap plastic, rubber and even municipal garbage.

headline: Queens: Truck Possibly Hauling Asbestos Overturns
text: A tractor-trailer believed to have been carrying asbestos-contaminated material hit a median divider and overturned on the Clearview Expressway near the Long Island Expressway about 3 p.m. on Sunday, the police said. Cleanup efforts lasted late into the night, and traffic was snarled for hours on both highways. The driver, identified as Artur Gaska, 39, initially fled but returned and was arrested on a charge of leaving the scene of an accident, the police said.

headline: Youth and Age Blend Well for Packers in Playoffs
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  So who were the kids here, exactly?

headline: Patriots Get a Big Break. Or Do They?
text: New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick was watching just like everyone else Sunday when the game of the year went up in smoke, when the team regarded as the Patriots’ biggest roadblock to another Super Bowl title was eliminated.

headline: Dame Edna Ails
text: Barry Humphries, the Australian comic best known as the flamboyant Dame Edna, below, has been ordered by doctors to rest for six months because of complications from appendix surgery, Reuters reported, citing a spokesman for the Magners Glasgow International Comedy Festival. As a result Mr. Humphries, 73, has canceled a North American tour that was to have started this month. Mr. Humphries underwent surgery late last month for the removal of his appendix and is scheduled for further surgery this week, the spokesman said.

headline: Gulf Air Signs $6 Billion Deal for Boeing Jets
text: Gulf Air, Bahrain’s loss-making national carrier, signed a $6 billion agreement with Boeing for the delivery of 24 Dreamliner aircraft to begin in 2016, a spokesman for the airline, Adnan Malik, said on Sunday.

headline: One Big Win, Two Huge Losses for Chargers
text: INDIANAPOLIS To the surprise of many people who follow the N.F.L., the San Diego Chargers, not the Indianapolis Colts, will meet the New England Patriots next Sunday for the American Football Conference championship and the right to play in Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Trenton: New State Treasurer Named
text: After five months of searching for a new state treasurer, Gov. Jon S. Corzine has tapped the deputy treasurer, David Rousseau, for the position. Mr. Rousseau, 47, was named on Friday to succeed Bradley I. Abelow, who became the governor’s chief of staff on Sept. 1. Michellene Davis, who has been serving as the acting treasurer, was named a special senior counsel to the governor.

headline: Reward Posted in Hunt for Marine
text: A “massive fugitive manhunt” was underway on Monday for the Marine corporal who is the principal suspect in the death of a fellow marine who was eight months pregnant when she died.

headline: Jazz Showcase Fever Propels a Mini Marathon
text: The Winter Jazzfest, now in its fourth year at the Knitting Factory, is one of the necessary gigs to attend on the New York jazz scene. With nine hours of music and 24 bands from all over the place gathered into one building, it’s pure cosmopolitan overload.

headline: On a Fixed Income, and Facing a Financial Disaster
text: Retirement can mean ending one chapter in life and starting another. Edison Epeck decided after 35 years in banking to put his expertise to use by becoming a volunteer financial adviser after he retired.

headline: Lottery Numbers
After Ratings Slip, Animal Planet Turns to Its Wilder Side
text: Animal Planet, long regarded as a gentle wildlife channel, is shedding its cute and cuddly image.

headline: Three Seafaring Queens Spend a Day in New York
text: Deborah D’Ambrosi can recite with ease the weight of each of the Queens  Elizabeth 2, Mary 2 and Victoria, which are among the world’s most luxurious ocean liners. And she came all the way from her landlocked hometown, Olney, Ill., on Sunday just to see “the three girls,” as she called them.

headline: ‘Bucket List’ Lives On
text: In its fourth week in release “The Bucket List,” starring Jack Nicholson, far right, and Morgan Freeman, right, as terminally ill cancer patients determined to live life to the fullest, ascended to the top of the list of the weekend’s biggest-grossing films. Ranked No. 23 last week at North American box offices, “The Bucket List” (Warner Brothers) took in an estimated $19.5 million, according to the tracking company Media by Numbers. At the same time “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” (Disney), the No. 1 film for three consecutive weekends, dropped to fourth, grossing $11.4 million to push its total to $187.2 million after four weeks. Second place for the weekend went to a new release, “First Sunday” (Sony/Screen Gems), starring Ice Cube as a man driven to crime by desperate circumstances. It earned $19 million and was followed by the small film “Juno” (Fox Searchlight), with $14 million, bringing its six-week total to $71.2 million. In fifth place “Alvin and the Chipmunks” (Fox) took in $9.1 million, for a five-week total of $187.7 million. “There Will Be Blood” (Paramount Vantage), playing on only 129 screens in its third week, averaged $15,039 per screen, compared with $6,712 for “The Bucket List” on more than 2,900 screens.

headline: ‘Mountains’ and Messiaen in a Music Project’s Gift
text: Ensemble ACJW’s latest appearance on Friday offered music by Alan Hovhaness and Messiaen at the Paul Recital Hall of the Juilliard School. Carnegie Hall, Juilliard, the Weill Music Institute and the City of New York make up the pool for this teaching and performing project. It is such a handsome gift to the listening public one can only hope that these first-rate young players are learning as much as we are.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Americans Cut Back Sharply on Spending
text: Strong evidence is emerging that consumer spending, a bulwark against recession over the last year even as energy prices surged and the housing market sputtered, has begun to slow sharply at every level of the American economy, from the working class to the wealthy.

headline: Romney Battles McCain for Michigan Lead
text: DETROIT  With economic issues at the top of the agenda, the leading Republican presidential candidates set off Monday on a final flurry of campaigning in Michigan ahead of the state’s primary that could again shake up a remarkably fluid Republican field.

headline: Herbert J.C. Kouts, Nuclear Power Safety Expert, Is Dead at 88
text: Herbert J. C. Kouts, a pioneer in nuclear power safety research and an expert in weapons proliferation, died on Jan. 7 at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in East Patchogue, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Bush Urges Unity Against Iran
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  President Bush on Sunday urged wary Persian Gulf allies to rally against Iran “before it is too late,” even as the International Atomic Energy Agency announced that the country had agreed, yet again, to answer outstanding questions about its nuclear programs within four weeks.

headline: Johnny Podres, Series Star, Dies at 75
text: Johnny Podres, who became a celebrated figure in the storied history of the Brooklyn Dodgers in October 1955, when he pitched them to their only World Series championship, died Sunday at a hospital in Glens Falls, N.Y. Podres, who lived nearby in Queensbury, N.Y., was 75.

headline: In Many Venues, Economy Will Take Center Stage
text: Political wisdom this week runs smack into economic reality. It is not yet clear which force will prove more powerful.

headline: From a Shelter to a Home, but for How Long?
text: This is the year that Jose Guzman’s luck is supposed to change. After spending a year and a half in a homeless shelter with his wife and two young daughters, Mr. Guzman is living in a railroad flat at the edge of Bushwick, just across the subway tracks from a cemetery. The city is paying most of the family’s $1,170 monthly rent this year, and they are expected to save up a few thousand dollars, which will be matched by the city.

headline: A Mother and Son Well Coordinated in Theatrical Flair and Acerbic Humor
text: Robert Leleux is the son of another of those drama-queen mothers: the sort who swoops through life to the accompaniment of jangling charm bracelets, dishing out self-dramatizing wisecracks and using what Mr. Leleux calls “the M&M (Moonlight and Magnolia) Act” to bag her men. Despite many obstacles, not least of them the danger of sounding like a would-be Augusten Burroughs, he has made her the centerpiece of a frantically giddy coming-of-age story.

headline: The Economic Week
text: SIGNALS ON THE ECONOMY The economy and bank results will dominate the week.

headline: Google Sees Surge in iPhone Traffic
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Of all the iPhone’s features, none had reviewers gushing more than its Internet browser. It was the first cellphone browser that promised something resembling the experience of surfing the Internet on a PC. Santa helped deliver on that promise.

headline: A.P. Says It Wants to Know Everything About Britney Spears
text: The Associated Press is bolstering its entertainment news coverage  and for many readers and viewers, Britney Spears is nothing if not entertaining.

headline: When the Hospital Is the Ailing One
text: To the Editor:

headline: Drug Approved. Is Disease Real?
text: Fibromyalgia is a real disease. Or so says Pfizer in a new television advertising campaign for Lyrica, the first medicine approved to treat the pain condition, whose very existence is questioned by some doctors.

headline: Throw in Irreplaceable, Too: Swinging Through Sammy Cahn’s Songbook
text: When the lyricist Sammy Cahn was asked which came first in his collaborations with this or that composer, the music or the words, he famously snapped, “The phone call.”

headline: Strike Was Unseen Star of the Night
text: Day for night is what filmmakers call the technique for shooting night scenes in daylight. “Today” for night was the technique NBC used to get through a Golden Globes ceremony that was canceled by the writers’ strike.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Foreign Sales Help I.B.M. to a Strong Quarter
text: The fallout from the banking industry’s woes and a slowing American economy are certainly not hurting I.B.M. yet.

headline: Teary-Eyed Owens Backs Quarterback
text: IRVING, Tex.  The softer side of Terrell Owens surfaced Sunday. After the Cowboys’ season ended in another playoff loss, after his quarterback turned in another playoff disappointment, Owens became downright sentimental.

headline: Barreling Through Rossini With a ‘Noises Off’ Rhythm
text: Every opera company needs its “Barber of Seville,” and the Metropolitan Opera has one that does quite nicely. The heavy, often murderous gloom that sits over so much of the repertory requires comic fiber in its diet. Unlike Mozart’s operas, Rossini’s are what they are  no undertones of social upheaval or “Parsifal”-like mysticism. Face value is full value. Patrons and performers alike are allowed to be silly and glorious at the same time.

headline: Trenton: State Backs Electoral College Change
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed legislation on Sunday that approved delivering the state’s 15 electoral votes to the winner of the national popular vote in the presidential election. Maryland  with 10 electoral votes  is the only state that has enacted the legislation, in the form of a compact. The compact would take effect only if enough states  those with a majority of votes in the Electoral College  agreed to it. Republicans criticized the bill as undermining federal elections.

headline: A Political Wish
text: To the Editor:

headline: Book Critics Nominate
text: The prolific author Joyce Carol Oates, below, came away with nominations in fiction and nonfiction when the finalists for the annual National Book Critics Circle awards were announced in San Francisco on Saturday. Ms. Oates was nominated in fiction for “The Gravedigger’s Daughter” and in the relatively new autobiographical category for “The Journal of Joyce Carol Oates.” Other nominees in fiction were “The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao” by Junot Díaz, “The Shadow Catcher” by Marianne Wiggins, “In the Country of Men” by Hisham Matar and “Sacred Games” by Vikram Chandra. Ms. Oates’s competitors in autobiography are Joshua Clark for “Heart Like Water: Surviving Katrina and Life in Its Disaster Zone,” Edwidge Danticat for “Brother, I’m Dying,” Sara Paretsky for “Writing in an Age of Silence” and Anna Politkovskaya for “A Russian Diary: A Journalist’s Final Account of Life, Corruption and Death in Putin’s Russia.” In nonfiction the finalists were “Legacy of Ashes: The History of the C.I.A.,” by Tim Weiner, a reporter for The New York Times; Philip Gura’s “American Transcendentalism”; Daniel Walker Howe’s “What Hath God Wrought: The Transformation of America 1815-1848”; Harriet Washington’s “Medical Apartheid: The Dark History of Medical Experimentation on Black Americans from Colonial Times to the Present”; and “The World Without Us” by Alan Weisman. Winners in these and other categories will be announced on March 6 in New York City.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Saturday about the effect of the cancellation of the Golden Globes award ceremony on the practice of giving lavish gifts to Hollywood celebrities misinterpreted a comment by the actor Isaiah Washington. When Mr. Washington said, “When I commit to something, I stick with it like a bulldog,” he was referring to his foundation to help people in Sierra Leone, one of several charities supported by fees paid by companies who want to give away their products. Mr. Washington was not referring to participating in the gift giveaway himself. (Go to Article)

headline: ‘Atonement’ Wins Best Drama at Globes
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Amid the barest hint of star power at a Golden Globes ceremony derailed by striking screenwriters, “Atonement” captured the award for best drama and “Sweeney Todd” won for best musical or comedy on Sunday.

headline: No. 7 Train From Flushing-Main Street to Times Square
text: 8.25 a.m., Jan. 14, Monday.

headline: Footnotes
text: Judy Collins, who received rave reviews leading to a sold-out engagement last winter at the Café Carlyle in her first New York nightclub appearance in more than 40 years, will return on Jan. 22 for a six-week engagement. She will be followed from March 4 to April 12 by Barbara Cook and from April 15 through May 10 by the Grammy Award-winner Christopher Cross.... On her Mondays off from starring on Broadway in “Xanadu,” the caustic comedian Jackie Hoffman will bring her retrospective act, “Scraping the Bottom: The Most Offensive Songs of Jackie Hoffman,” to Joe’s Pub on Feb. 4, 11 and 25.

headline: Family Finds Man Killed in His Home in Brooklyn
text: A 49-year-old man who had helped raise his granddaughter while his daughter served in Iraq was found beaten to death and bound in his apartment in Brooklyn on Sunday, the police said.

headline: Fluidity in  G.O.P. Race; Democrats Eye Electability
text: WASHINGTON  Republican voters have sharply altered their views of the party’s presidential candidates following the early contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, with Senator John McCain, once widely written off, now viewed more favorably than any of his major competitors, according to the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: The Candidates Discover the Economy
text: The presidential candidates are only beginning to recognize what many voters have already figured out through painful, personal experience: the economy is in trouble and unlikely to improve without some sensible government response.

headline: Responding to Recession
text: Suddenly, the economic consensus seems to be that the implosion of the housing market will indeed push the U.S. economy into a recession, and that it’s quite possible that we’re already in one. As a result, over the next few weeks we’ll be hearing a lot about plans for economic stimulus.

headline: More Google Queries Get Google Maps
text: The share of Google searches that result in visits to Google Maps has skyrocketed since last year, according to the online traffic-measurement firm Hitwise. Over the week ending Jan. 6, 2007, 0.22 percent of Google searchers went on to Google Maps. During the same week this year, 0.67 percent did. Hitwise calculated the figures by analyzing the behavior of 10 million Internet users.

headline: Fitness Center Chain Goes Provocative in New Campaign
text: Editor’s Note: Look for In Advertising next week on Tues., Jan. 22, rather than Mon., Jan. 21, in honor of the Dr. King holiday.

headline: Are Awards Really Awards Without a Red Carpet?
text: It seems somehow fitting that NBC lined up “American Gladiators,” the overstimulated warfare show that has contestants in tight clothes flogging one another, to follow its telecast of the Golden Globes news conference. If you can’t give ’em sequins, give ’em spandex.

headline: Trenton: School Finance Law Signed
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a law on Sunday that revamps the formula the state uses to subsidize public schools. Under the law, which changes the way the state allocates money to public schools, aid is partly tied to the number of low-income students in each district. Suburban districts with enrollment increases and a large number of low-income students could see annual aid increases as big as 20 percent, while most of the state’s 31 poor urban districts would receive a 2 percent increase this year and flat state support after that.

headline: With Son Nearby, Davenport Seeks Grand Slam Title
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Margaret Court Arena is not center stage at the Australian Open. It is only the third-biggest show court at the tournament and has no retractable roof to keep it safe from the threat of summer sizzle or drizzle.

headline: Less Hype, but at Least These Restrooms Are Free
text: Reinventing the chamber pot for the 21st century was no small matter.

headline: Europe May Ban Imports of Some Biofuel Crops
text: PARIS  In a sign of shifting attitudes toward biofuels, officials of the European Union are proposing to ban imports of certain fuel crops whose production could do more harm than good in fighting climate change, according to a draft law seen Monday.

headline: The Pork King Keeps His Crown
text: The new earmark disclosure rules put into effect by Congress confirm the pre-eminence of Representative John Murtha at procuring eye-popping chunks of pork for contractors he helped put in business in Johnstown, Pa. The Pennsylvania Democrat, a power player on defense appropriations, exudes pride, not embarrassment, for delivering hundreds of millions of dollars in largesse to district beneficiaries. They, in turn, requite with hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign donations.

headline: New CDs
text: RINGO STARR

headline: Way Up Yonder in Manhattan, Dreaming of Home
text: No one could ever accuse Jazz at Lincoln Center of giving short shrift to the jazz legacy of New Orleans, especially as it pertains to Louis Armstrong. So on a fundamental level “Kings of the Crescent City,” Friday and Saturday at the Rose Theater, upheld standard practice for the organization. The nearly full house on Friday night confirmed the soundness of this approach.

headline: Manhattan: City Reports Record Number of Visitors
text: With a falling dollar encouraging foreign visitors, a record number of travelers came to the city in 2007, spending $28 billion, tourism officials said. With a final count still pending, the city’s tourism office said on Sunday that there were an estimated 46 million visitors to the city last year, up 5 percent from 2006. The gain was attributed largely to an increase in foreign visitors, who numbered an estimated 8.5 million, a jump of 17 percent, officials said. The proportion of the city’s tourists who were from other countries had dwindled since the Sept. 11 attacks, but last year’s growth returned the ratio to pre-2001 levels.

headline: Just What I Need?
text: The Consumer Electronics Show, held in Las Vegas last week, pitched a sleek and shiny Star Trek future where myriad clever devices would satisfy our every need. Microsoft’s chairman, Bill Gates, opened the show with a keynote speech touting a “second digital decade.” More than 2,000 hi-tech exhibitors introduced their brand new wares to about 140,000 attendees.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 9-12 with 1,178 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,061 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Addenda: Accounts, People and Miscellany
text: Accounts

headline: Reality TV Is No Lightweight in the Battle to Outlast Strikers
text: The striking members of the Writers Guild of America may have hoped that television viewers, upset that their favorite dramas and comedies had gone dark, would disdain the chief alternative the broadcast networks had to offer: reality shows.

headline: Race and Gender Are Issues in Tense Day for Democrats
text: LAS VEGAS  After staying on the sidelines in the first year of the campaign, race and to a lesser extent gender have burst into the forefront of the Democratic presidential contest, thrusting Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton into the middle of a sharp-edged social and political debate that transcends their candidacies.

headline: U.S. Cities Put on the Charm for Foreign Tourists
text: THE weak dollar has made shopping sprees in America a bargain for many international visitors. Still, outside favored destinations like New York, many places in the United States are having a hard time attracting foreign tourists and their euros, pounds and yen.

headline: Walter Bowart, Alternative Journalist, Dies at 68
text: Walter Bowart, a founder and the first publisher of The East Village Other, a New York newspaper so countercultural that it made The Village Voice look like a church circular, died on Dec. 18 in Inchelium, Wash. He was 68 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Wesley Snipes to Go on Trial in Tax Case
text: From 1999 to 2004, the actor Wesley Snipes earned $38 million appearing in more than half a dozen movies, including two sequels to his popular vampire thriller “Blade.”

headline: Fire Department Alters Its Inspection Schedule
text: In an effort to focus on larger and more complex construction and demolition projects, the Fire Department has decreased the frequency of inspections for some smaller projects. The move is part of a series of changes made in response to lapses exposed by the death of two firefighters at the former Deutsche Bank building.

headline: Big Weddings Bring Afghans Joy, and Debt
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  On the afternoon before his wedding day this fall, Hamid was sitting in an empty teahouse worrying a glass of green tea between his fingers, his brow furrowed in concern.

headline: A Depleted Secondary Still Delivers for Giants
text: IRVING, Tex.  Facing down Tony Romo and the high-octane Dallas Cowboys offense with a threadbare secondary is usually not a formula for success. But as the Giants reserve defensive back R. W. McQuarters cradled his end-zone interception, which effectively ended Sunday’s National Football Conference playoff game, success was all he could feel.

headline: Japan and Its Neighbors Scrutinized in Mirrors
text: Why do people attend dance samplers? Presenters want work to present, choreographers want to scout the competition, and critics want to find some trends, or at least some good one-liners. But what does the average dance fan  that mythical beast  hope to gain from such a chancy endeavor? Probably a program in which more than one of five dances succeeds, but that is this critic’s assessment of the Japan Society’s 11th annual Contemporary Dance Showcase.

headline: Mail-In Voters Become the Latest Prize
text: LOS ANGELES  The first Tuesday in February, when 22 states hold primaries, may turn out to be the biggest day of the presidential campaign. But for many voters, half or more in some states, the polling place will be the kitchen table, the ballot box will be the mailbox and the choice in many cases will be made weeks before a voting machine lever is pulled.

headline: Trying to Fine-Tune Yahoo
text: Jerry Yang began his biggest public presentation since becoming chief executive of Yahoo with something of an apology.

headline: Expand the Peace Corps
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Broadway Play, Mamet Is a Blogger
text: Before premieres, playwrights sometimes tweak dialogue that actors stumble over in rehearsals, but once the curtain rises they rarely write another word for their characters. But in a promotion for his play “November,” which will open on Broadway on Thursday, David Mamet will continue to write a blog from the perspective of his leading character, Charles H. P. Smith (played by Nathan Lane), a sitting president about to lose a re-election bid.

headline: Oscar Peterson Tribute
text: The pianist Herbie Hancock, the singer Nancy Wilson and the impresario and producer Quincy Jones, as well as Governor General Michaëlle Jean, Canada’s titular head of state, appeared before more than 2,000 fans to pay tribute to the jazz piano virtuoso Oscar Peterson at “Simply the Best,” a free concert on Saturday at Roy Thomson Hall in Toronto, The Associated Press reported. “I don’t call many people geniuses, but Oscar Peterson is definitely one,” Mr. Jones said. Mr. Peterson died of kidney failure at his home in Mississauga, a Toronto suburb, on Dec. 23. He was 82.

headline: H.I.V. Rises Among Young Gay Men
text: AIDS appears to be making an alarming comeback. The Journal of the American Medical Association reports that the incidence of H.I.V. infection among gay men is shooting up, following an encouraging period of decline. The rise of infections among younger gay men, especially black and Hispanic men, is troubling, and the study carries the clear implication that people at high risk of contracting the disease are becoming less cautious.

headline: Volek Fills in Exactly the Way a Backup Quarterback Should
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Billy Volek tossed and turned in his hotel bed as Saturday night melted into Sunday morning amid the rain and snow and church bells of central Indiana.

headline: Getaways to Coddle New Mothers (or Just Inspire Some)
text: CHATHAM, N.J.  The second-floor suite in the Parrot Mill Inn has all the accouterments of a classic bed-and-breakfast, including stenciled flowers beneath the ceiling, candies wrapped in gold foil, and the scent of spices in the hallway.

headline: Giants Make the Leap to Lambeau
text: IRVING, Tex.  In the days before their divisional playoff game with the Cowboys, the Giants were leery of raising the ire of their highly favored opponent and undermining their own quiet, underdog status. But they could not help but point out the perceived discrepancy in talent between the teams. The Cowboys had 12 players named to next month’s Pro Bowl. The Giants had one.

headline: Team Creates Rat Heart Using Cells of Baby Rats
text: Medicine’s dream of growing new human hearts and other organs to repair or replace damaged ones received a significant boost Sunday when University of Minnesota researchers reported success in creating a beating rat heart in a laboratory.

headline: Europe Takes Africa’s Fish, and Boatloads of Migrants Follow
text: KAYAR, Senegal  Ale Nodye, the son and grandson of fishermen in this northern Senegalese village, said that for the past six years he netted barely enough fish to buy fuel for his boat. So he jumped at the chance for a new beginning. He volunteered to captain a wooden canoe full of 87 Africans to the Canary Islands in the hopes of making their way illegally to Europe.

headline: Alternate Worlds Moving on Two Stages, Performing for One Audience
text: BEACON, N.Y.  Because dance occurs in both time and space, it operates upon us as a demonstration of physics. This aspect becomes arresting in the work of two choreographers alone: George Balanchine and Merce Cunningham. Mr. Cunningham has often quoted Einstein’s dictum “There are no fixed points in space,” and since the 1980s some of the ensembles in his work have struck observers as riveting enactments of chaos theory.

headline: When Gadget Parts Break or Get Lost
text: THE proliferation of iPods, cellphones and other devices in the hands of smaller children is sure to have profound social significance in the long term, but in the short term it means something else: broken gadgets and lost parts.

headline: ‘Pagliacci’ Becomes Dreamy
text: Canio, the heartbroken clown in “I Pagliacci,” doesn’t just suffer. In the Seattle Opera’s new version of Ruggero Leoncavallo’s opera, running through Jan. 26, he also dreams. In an 11-minute sequence inserted after the aria “Vesti la giubba,” music taken from Leoncavallo’s “Zazà,” a Metropolitan Opera hit in the 1920s, is heard as Canio relives his life with his beloved Nedda: He discovers her as an orphaned waif, teaches her to be an acrobat and actress and, finally, is rejected by her. Acrobats play Canio, as well as Nedda at different ages. Speight Jenkins, the general director of the Seattle Opera, found the music he said he felt had the proper sound for the dream; Philip Kelsey, the assistant conductor, orchestrated it for seven winds and strings, as well as piano, to give it a different sound from the usual “Pagliacci” orchestra, and the director Bernard Uzan, working with Mr. Jenkins, integrated the sequence into the opera, which, in another break with tradition, is not being paired with another work.

headline: Amputee Ineligible for Olympic Events
text: LONDON  Track and field’s world governing body ruled on Monday that Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, is not be eligible to compete in Olympic qualifying events. The International Association of Athletics Federations explained in a statement that, after an independent scientific study, it deemed Pistorius’s state-of-the-art carbon fiber prosthetics “should be considered as technical aids which give him an advantage over other athletes not using them.”

headline: Attack Jolts Germany Into Fray on Immigrant Crime
text: WETZLAR, Germany  A brutal war of words has broken out between the two major parties here over violence committed by youths with immigrant backgrounds, and neither side is backing down.

headline: Brooklyn: Man Charged in Hit and Run
text: A Brooklyn man was arrested in connection with an Oct. 6 crash that killed one man and injured another near the Belt Parkway, the police said on Sunday. The suspect, Justin Bonilla, 19, of East 34th Street, was charged with manslaughter, the police said. The police said Mr. Bonilla was driving east on the parkway about 4 a.m. when his car veered off the road onto a grassy area and struck two pedestrians. Mr. Bonilla told detectives that his car had been stolen but was charged after a detective identified him in an image from a nearby surveillance camera around the time of the crash, the police said.

headline: Whoa! Russian Folk Troupe Stomps In
text: The weather may shift. The voices that enunciate the eternal political pieties may change. But one thing remains certain: The Moiseyev Dance Company will perform a hoedown to “Turkey in the Straw” on its American tours, as it did on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College. That closing encore was followed by a brief sortie into “Hail, Hail, the Gang’s All Here,” with the audience humming and clapping along.

headline: Toyota Will Offer a Plug-In Hybrid Vehicle by 2010
text: The chief executive of the Toyota Motor Corporation said Monday that he is pushing his company’s engineers to develop a plug-in hybrid-electric vehicle with a lithium-ion battery before 2010, raising the stakes in a race with General Motors.

headline: Golden Globes: Strange and Out Of Sync
text: The 65th annual Golden Globes awards are “sure to go down as one of the strangest awards shows in the annals of Hollywood,” the Associated Press reports. “Instead of the usual three hours of star-studded back-slapping that drags on forever, this one flew by in half an hour, with no winners on hand and prizes announced by TV entertainment show hosts.”

headline: Like, Duh: Coughlin Will Be Back
text: Giants co-owner John Mara, beaming with pride in the visitors’ locker room at Texas Stadium, would not discuss the possibility of a long-term contract for Coach Tom Coughlin. Pestered, he finally relented by offering a laugh and a somewhat off-color confirmation:

headline: Don’t Blame Me — I Voted on ‘Hot or Not’
text: Dear Old Liberals,Hi, it’s me, your collective child. It’s an election year and once again you’re going to make me feel bad for not “doing enough.” You’re going to tell me about how you protested in the 1960’s and how the movement meant something to young people back then. And the thing is we do care, our generation, we really do. It’s just that we got a Wii for Christmas and we absolutely have to beat “Super Mario Galaxy” before we do anything else.
