headline: Saunas with style against the Berlin winter
text: By most accounts, Berlin has so far experienced a mild winter. But the vicious wind whipping through the capital streets has a way of canceling out the warmer temperatures, and pushes everyone indoors again.

headline: Milan Élan: Pssst!
text: This week, the fashion circus pitches its tent in Milan, where the men’s Fall 2008 shows are taking place. If you’re like us, there’s probably only so much talk about “cashmere 8-yarn tweed in ecru” you can take. Thankfully, a lot of the action during fashion week happens off the catwalk. The big scandale of the week has been over Tommy Fazio, the men’s fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, being unceremoniously asked to vacate his front-row seat at Saturday night’s Versace show. We spoke to Fazio afterwards who said that he was asked by a clipboard Nazi to make room for one of Beyonce’s posse. Not surprisingly, Fazio put away the check book and instantly canceled his Versace showroom appointment. Oops….Speaking of Beyonce, the singer and her boo, Jay-Z, walked in and straight out of the GQ party on Saturday when they realized there was no VIP room for them…Lots of “aw-shucks, he so deserves it” talk about John Bartlett‘s being given a lifeline by Liz Claiborne, which has signed Bartlett to oversee its men’s line…The buzz late Sunday night had the Spice Girls showing up en masse to today’s Roberto Cavalli show. (It would make sense as their concert in London last week may as well have been a Cavalli advertorial, given the number of shout-outs Victoria Beckham gave the designer.) We’ll let you know later if the rumor pans out to be true. Till then, baci.Read all of The Moment’s coverage of the Milan men’s fashion shows and after-hours shenanigans.

headline: Japanese Shipbuilders in Merger Talks
text: Two Japanese shipbuilders, IHI and JFE Holdings are holding merger talks that might result in the emergence of the biggest shipbuilder in Japan and spearhead a realignment of the industry as it looks to compete with powerful South Korean and Chinese rivals.

headline: Vodafone Forced to Play Waiting Game in Vodacom Deal
text: Vodafone Group is looking to grow in Africa and other emerging areas, a strategy that has been embraced by the market as revenue declines in Europe.

headline: Tesla Fires Executives Amid Shake-Up
text: Tesla Motors has yet to bring a product to market, but the electric-car maker certainly knows how to give off sparks. The closely watched Silicon Valley start-up, which recently became estranged from one of its co-founders, has apparently just sent a large number of its employees packing.

headline: Packers Fan vs. Giants Fan
text: Highlights from the reader comments on yesterday’s live-blog:A substantive, civil exchange between a Packers fan and a Giants fan sets the stage for Sunday’s game:

headline: Belo Board Approves Spin-Off
text: Belo‘s board of directors on Friday approved details of its spin-off of the company’s newspaper group into a separate, publicly traded company, the company said.

headline: What Advice Would Dr. Phil Have for Ask.Com?
text: IAC/InterActiveCorp is in the middle of a rather tumultuous reorganization as the company prepares to split into five units later this year. The core company, which keeps Barry Diller as chief executive and the fancy Frank Gehry headquarters next to Chelsea Piers (and Mr. Diller’s yacht) , will include Ask.com, Citysearch, Match.com, and a bunch of other advertising driven sites.

headline: Terra Firm’s Reported EMI Moves Rile Artists
text: Following rumors that British financier Guy Hands is looking to sell part of stake in the EMI Group to outside investors, reports surfaced over the weekend that the British music giant is preparing to cut up to 2,000 jobs, or about one-third of its work force, as part of a contentious restructuring plan being prepared by Mr. Hands’s Terra Firma Capital Partners.

headline: It’s Week 2 All Over Again. Or Not.
text: No matter what happened Sunday, the championship games in both conferences were going to be rematches of games earlier this season, but the victories by the Chargers and the Giants created a nice bit of symmetry.

headline: Goldman to Get New Partner in Alliance Deal
text: The Canadian partner who stepped in last summer to help Goldman Sachs meet foreign ownership requirements in its purchase of Canada’s largest film distributor, Alliance Films, has pulled out of the investment, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Israel Chemicals to Buy Henkel Unit
text: Israel Chemicals said on Sunday that a subsidiary agreed to pay 60 million euros, about $89 million, for the industrial-water-treatment business of Henkel.

headline: Pat Robertson Mulls Bid for Landmark Newspaper
text: The religious broadcaster Pat Robertson is considering taking a different kind of pulpit. The founder and chairman of the Christian Broadcasting Network is mulling making an offer for The Virginian Pilot, a daily newspaper he has criticized for its coverage of him and his activities.

headline: Disney, Chinese Investors to Buy Stake in N.B.A. China
text: The Walt Disney Company and four Chinese investment firms will invest in an 11 percent stake in the National Basketball Association’s subsidiary in China, according to The New York Times.

headline: Quebecor to Get Rescue Package
text: Quebecor and Brookfield Asset Management have thrown a controversial lifeline to the struggling printing giant Quebecor World in the form of a proposed 400 million Canadian dollar ($393.6 million) financing package, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: TCW Group Slashes Stake in Circuit City
text: A major shareholder of Circuit City Stores, the nation’s No. 2 electronics retailer, has sold nearly its entire stake in the company, which reported last week that sales in December had fallen.

headline: Endwave Buys Out Wood River Stake
text: On Christmas Eve, Wood River Capital Management finally liquidated its 4.1 million shares of Endwave, a San Jose maker of radio frequency modules used in telelcommunication networks, bringing to a close one of the more bizarre episodes of hedge fund investment in Silicon Valley history.

headline: Omeros Files for $115 Milion I.P.O.
text: A Biopharmaceutical company, Omeros, has filed to go public in a maximum $115 million offering.

headline: Quad-C Said to Buy Sportswear Firm
text: Quad-C Management is buying the Augusta Sportswear Group from Linsalata Capital Partners in a secondary buyout valued at $405 million to $450 million, The Deal reported.

headline: Liberty Takes Bigger Stake in IAC
text: Liberty Media, the entertainment and Internet retailing company controlled by the billionaire John C. Malone, purchased 14 million shares of IAC/InterActiveCorp, the company controlled by Barry Diller, for $339.5 million.

headline: Alder Gets $40 Million Injection from V.C.s
text: Alder Biopharmaceuticals raised $40 million in a third round of venture capital to fund clinical trials of its first novel antibody product for treating rheumatoid arthritis and cancer.

headline: Cenkos in Deal Talks for Close Brothers
text: Cenkos Securities, a British stock adviser for small and midsize companies, said it is in talks to buy Close Brothers as it seeks to head off competing bidders that may include the Blackstone Group.

headline: G.M. Joins Alternative Energy Investment Rush
text: General Motors, eager to ensure a supply of fuel for the big fleet of flex-fuel ethanol-capable vehicles it is building, has joined the rush into alternative energy and invested in a company that intends to produce ethanol from crop wastes, wood chips, scrap plastic, rubber and even municipal garbage.

headline: Credit Agricole Sells Suez Stake to Raise Cash
text: Credit Agricole, the French bank, said Monday it is selling its direct 2.1 percent stake in the Franco-Belgian utility Suez, worth an estimated 1.2 billion euros ($1.8 billion).

headline: Europe's Smart Car in America
text: Ten years after it appeared in Europe, the Mercedes-designed Smart car will soon go on sale in the United States.

headline: Northwest Talks of Merger; Delta Keeps Quiet
text: The chief executive of Northwest Airlines says his carrier could benefit from a merger – if it’s the right deal.

headline: Law Firm Goes Own Way on Compensation
text: In a world of follow-the-leader associate salary scales, a mid-size California law firm is carving its own path, The Recorder reports.

headline: Thomson and Reuters Confident on Regulatory Approval
text: Thomson and the Reuters Group said Monday they are confident the Department of Justice and European Commission will approve Thomson’s proposed $17.6 billion acquisition of Reuters soon.

headline: Peering Inside GlassHouse Technologies
text: GlassHouse Technologies is one of several data-storage companies to seek an initial public offering of late. But GlassHouse is different, according to The 451 Group, because it provides consulting and information technology services rather than storage products. Will the markets buy into the services model?

headline: Williams Pipeline to Kick Off I.P.O.’s
text: The 2008 initial public offering market kicks off this week with a handful of deals, the strongest of which, analysts say, is that of the natural gas transportation and storage company Williams Pipeline Partners.

headline: Kenneth Lewis’s Big Countrywide Bet
text: Kenneth D. Lewis has gambled on bold acquisitions to build Bank of America into the nation’s largest bank.

headline: Writers’ Strike Makes Happy Hunting for Some Start-Ups
text: Few online entertainment ventures today make money. Yet, says The Los Angeles Times, that has not deterred striking Hollywood writers, eager to bypass the studio system, from forming start-ups to distribute their work on the Web.

headline: Third Act Surprise
text: Mary Hart, wearing a fire-engine-red dress, brought the press conference to the final award of the evening: “Please welcome, the man who has gone through fire for weeks, your own Hollywood Foreign Press Association, Jose Camara.”

headline: Citigroup May Face $24 Billion Write-Down, Report Says
text: Even as it seeks foreign investment, Citigroup could write down as much as $24 billion as a result of subprime and credit-related losses, CNBC reported Sunday evening. In addition, an estimated 20 thousand layoffs will be part of a comprehensive plan to slash costs and raise capital, the news channel said.

headline: Inquiry Focuses on Banks’ Data on Loans
text: An investigation into the mortgage crisis by New York State prosecutors is focusing on whether Wall Street banks withheld crucial information about the risks posed by investments linked to subprime loans.

headline: No Victory Lap
text: “It’s great of course,” Richard Zanuck, who produced “Sweeney Todd,” the winner of best musical or comedy, said by phone. “I don’t care about the party, but I do miss the event. Having won for ‘Driving Miss Daisy’, I know what its like to be sitting there and have the name of a picture you produced announced from the dais and then take that walk. We all miss that.”

headline: Sexual Consequences of Female Initiation Rites in Africa
text: Here’s another expert with answers for the Lab readers who have been debating female initiation rites in Africa. Lucrezia Catania is a gynecologist and sexologist in Florence, Italy, at the Research Center for Preventing and Curing Complications of FGM/C (Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting). For more than two decades, the center has been treating women who have undergone these procedures, especially those with complications from the type called infibulation.

headline: Inside the Bubbles
text: Champagne was uncorked and laughter was heard in the ballroom last night following the event, but it was coming from journalists, not from winners. The reporters may have been sad about trading Keira Knightley for Mary Hart, but they were happy to celebrate an early end to a busy night with free booze.

headline: Congress Returns to Face Economic Worries
text: Congress returns this week – at least half of it does – for the start of 2008 and a session that should have distinct differences from 2007.

headline: Citi’s Investment From China May Hit Snag
text: Citigroup‘s attempt to get a $2 billion investment from the China Development Bank may have hit an obstacle in the form of new opposition from within the Chinese government.

headline: La Vie en L.A.
text: Marion Cotillard was in L.A. when, plopped down in front of the tube, she find out that the Globes voters had judged her performance in “La Vie en Rose” irresistible. “Definitely there was champagne involved.” she said. “ Definitely. It was a big surprise.”

headline: Study Sparks Regulator Scrutiny of Merger Arbitrage
text: With the rise of proprietary trading desks, investment banks sometimes find themselves taking positions in the stocks of companies they are advising in merger talks. At least a few of those instances are probably coincidental, and the firms will certainly argue that they are.

headline: Zagat Publisher Seeks Buyer
text: A “clever and sharp” restaurant guide company with “telling” rankings and “a penchant for quote marks” from its thousands of “in-the-know” reviewers is apparently “on the block.”

headline: Failing Global Geography
text: The Bagger went 8-for-14 last night. The technical term for his performance is, um, butt ugly, but the Bagger has been preoccupied by other matters and didn’t make all the calls he should have to his trusted Globe sources.

headline: The Early Word: Michigan
text: All of the Republican candidates, save for Fred D. Thompson, will campaign heavily today in Michigan, which holds its primary tomorrow. Mitt Romney is still hinging his campaign on a win there, although John McCain and Mike Huckabee have made it a very tight race.

headline: When Crime Was on Everyone’s Mind
text: A bloody melee on a Harlem street is flashing New Yorkers back to the era of personal anticrime tactics, like “mugger’s money,” self-defense classes and concealed pepper spray. Just before midnight on Thursday, the police said, Maurice Parks, 39, a subway motorman who had just ended his shift, was preyed upon by a group of muggers armed with at least one knife.

headline: The Right Way to Swaddle
text: Swaddling, the practice of tightly wrapping a baby in a light blanket, is an age-old technique that not only calms babies but makes them portable. The technique is growing in popularity in the United States as a result of a best-selling parenting book that teaches frazzled parents how to soothe crying babies.

headline: Answers About Immigration on the Lower East Side, Part 2

A first set of questions and answers was posted on Jan. 9.

headline: Citi and the Kitchen Sink Theory
text: At first blush, CNBC’s report that Citigroup could announce up to $24 billion in write-downs Tuesday because of credit-related losses sounds like disastrous news. That figure is much higher than what sell-side analysts were expecting, and more than twice the high end of Citi’s previous estimate in early November, which put the losses at $8 billion to $11 billion.

headline: Stunners on Waterboarding and Guantánamo: Less Than Meets the Eye
text: Close Guantánamo, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff says. Waterboarding is torture, the director of national intelligence admits.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Managing Editor John Geddes
text: John M. Geddes, managing editor of The Times, answered reader questions Jan. 14-18, 2008. Questions may be e-mailed to askthetimes@nytimes.com. To skip to the most recent answer, click here.

headline: Who Is G.M.’s New Ethanol Partner?
text: DETROIT — On Sunday, Rick Wagoner, chief executive of General Motors, pushed ethanol to the gathered press like it was going out of business.

headline: They’re Still Talking About It
text: Even after posts scroll off the blog front, readers keep talking. Some recent highlights.

headline: Eyes on the Prizes
text: The winner of the Randolph Caldecott Medal for most distinguished picture book for children was announced this morning at the American Library Association’s annual midwinter meeting: it was “The Invention of Hugo Cabret,” by Brian Selznick (Scholastic). The equally prestigious Newbery Medal went to “Good Masters! Sweet Ladies! Voices From a Medieval Village,” by Laura Amy Schlitz (Candlewick).

headline: Bain’s Big Premium for Bright Horizons
text: Leveraged buyout activity may be lean these days, but that isn’t stopping Bain Capital from paying a fat premium for its chosen takeover target.

headline: Open a New Window: A Tower With a View
text: The only thing standing between the occupants of 375 Pearl Street and some of the most commanding views in Lower Manhattan is three inches of limestone.Though the 32-story telephone company tower is not truly windowless, it might as well be. There are three-foot-wide slits running up and down the structure, some with glass in them. But, like the windows of the World Trade Center, these do little more than offer a tantalizingly small slice of what could have been an extraordinary panorama.

headline: Monday Kickoff: Slaton Headed to the N.F.L.
text: Steve Slaton is passing on his senior season at West Virginia to enter the N.F.L. draft. It wasn’t an easy decision, but Slaton’s father told The Philadelphia Daoily News that — surprise — it had a lot to do with Roch Rodriguez’s leaving to go to Michigan and taking most of his staff with him.

headline: The Mysteries of Surgeons, Revealed
text: What kind of music is played in the operating room? Why don’t you ever see surgeons wearing their stethoscopes? These and other pressing questions are answered in an interesting blog post from University of Virginia medical student Mark Hoofnagle, written after his first week on a surgical rotation.

headline: Bits Debate: Is Copy Protection Needed or Futile?
text: UPDATED 4:18 PM

headline: Equinox "Happily Ever" TV Spot
text: Equinox TV advertisement for the "Happily Ever" campaign.

headline: Saab Boasts BioPower for a New Crossover
text: DETROIT — Saab showed its first crossover vehicle on Sunday at the Detroit Auto Show, the 9-4X BioPower. It is still very much a concept vehicle, but there’s nothing superfuturistic about it, so it’s quite likely we’ll be seeing it on the street sometime soon.

headline: Felicitations, Cover Girl
text: (Raymond Meier)

headline: MySpace to Let Parents Block Their Children From Joining
text: Representatives from MySpace and the attorneys general of 49 states are announcing a new partnership to fight sexual predators and clean up social networks.

headline: Giuliani’s Lead Shrinks in Florida, Poll Shows
text: NAPLES, Fla. — The campaign’s signs say “Florida is Rudy Country.’’ But despite Rudolph W. Giuliani’s heavy advertising effort here, and the fact that he has the state almost to himself while his rivals duke it out in colder climes, a poll released Monday shows that his lead in Florida has slipped, and the state is now very much up for grabs.

headline: Deconstructing Time Warner’s Fix-It Guy
text: At a conference in November, Richard Parsons, the outgoing chief executive of Time Warner, was asked what he would do if he were in the shoes of his successor, Jeffrey Bewkes. “If I were Jeff,” Mr. Parsons replied jokingly, “I would shoot myself.”

headline: For the Moment |  Francesco Vezzoli
text: This week’s guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like “Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal’s Caligula,” starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandello’s “Right You Are (If You Think You Are),” starring — among others — Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his first post of the week, Vezzoli explains his affection for Magnani.

headline: Steve Jobs Keynote: Fun and Games
text: On Tuesday, Apple CEO Steve Jobs takes the stage in San Francisco at the 2008 Macworld Expo. He’ll show charts of iPod and iPhone success! He’ll unveil beautiful new products! He’ll wear black turtleneck and jeans!

headline: The Skim
text: Times of London

headline: A New You: Dr. Richard A. Friedman on Mental Health
text: What are the first steps to take when confronted with a serious mental illness? How do you cope with grief, or everyday stress? Is there a recipe for happiness? This week Dr. Richard A. Friedman, professor of clinical psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical College and a frequent contributor to Science Times, is answering questions and hosting a discussion on mental health and emotional well-being. You may post your comments and questions below. Please remember that Dr. Friedman cannot answer all questions, and he cannot respond to solicitations for medical advice. [Eds. note: We are no longer accepting comments and questions.]

headline: A Bear’s Questions
text: David A. Rosenberg, a Merrill Lynch economist, is out with a report today that concludes that home prices need to fall another 20 percent or more to get into reasonable territory relative to rental prices.

headline: ‘Filipino Monkey’ and the Naval Confrontation With Iran
text: If that wasn’t an Iranian military officer who was threatening American ships in the Strait of Hormuz last week — a claim that the Pentagon is backing away from, conceding that the threat could have come from anyone on shore with a radio — then who was it?

headline: Staying Current on Currency: Another Day, Another Euro?
text: With travel to New York City at record levels, and with the the dollar at near-record lows against the pound and the euro, does it make sense for New York City businesses to start accepting foreign currency?A recent article in The Villager, a neighborhood newspaper, caught our eye. It noted that East Village Wines, a liquor store at 138 First Avenue, accepts payments in euros as well as dollars. During a recent visit to the store, City Room noticed a sign that stated the current exchange rate and noted that euros were welcome.

headline: The Rise, Fall and Rise of Bruce Wasserstein
text: In 1991, GQ magazine pronounced his high-flying career in finance finished: “It’s over for Bruce Wasserstein,” the magazine declared. Just a few years ago, that might have seemed prescient. But today, that conclusion seems more than a bit premature, as Karl Taro Greenfeld reports in a generally flattering article about the Lazard chief executive that appears in the February issue of Portfolio magazine.

headline: Q and A: Lachlan Mackinnon-Patterson
text: To this point the chefs whom Diner’s Journal has asked to participate in its Q and A have all had their principal restaurants in New York. But with today’s post we widen the focus to include chefs rooted in other parts of the country.

headline: Edwards Campaign Calls Nevada Race a Dead Heat
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. – The Edwards campaign characterized the Nevada race as a three-way dead heat in a conference call with reporters today, pointing to poll numbers and a robust field operation in the state.

headline: Ford Rides the Election Coattails
text: DETROIT — With a giant wink of the eye, Ford printed up campaign buttons for its Escape Hybrid, claiming that it is “The Candidate’s Choice.”

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Jan. 14:

headline: Princely Sums for New Sallie Mae Leaders
text: Sallie Mae is paying a pretty penny to get itself out of its latest troubles.

headline: How Now, Green Cow?
text: DETROIT — Journalists at this week’s auto show here cannot stop talking about two topics: green vehicles and cows. Cows, of course, referring to the 120 Texas Longhorns that Chrysler paraded through downtown to spice up the introduction of its 2009 Dodge Ram pickup.

headline: Bad buzz
text: So far, there are very few hard numbers showing a recession underway. What there is, instead, is buzz — an accumulation of small items like the Baltic Dry Shipping Index, plus the way people are talking.

headline: Don’t Feed the Pigeons Here. But Over There, O.K.
text: “Safe pigeon-feeding zones” may be designated around the city as part of the negotiations between animal rights groups and the Brooklyn city councilman who has proposed fining pigeon feeders as much as $1,000 as strategy to control New York’s pigeon population.Fines, which had been used successfully in Basel, Switzerland, to limit pigeon proliferation, were the most concrete proposal in a pigeon report issued by Councilman Simcha Felder’s office in November. Other ideas in the report included pigeon birth control and a pigeon czar.

headline: The Clintons and History
text: WASHINGTON — There’s an old joke people here in the capital like to tell about Charles E. Schumer, the New York senator, and over the years I’m sure it’s been used to describe other politicians, as well: The most dangerous place to stand in Washington is between Chuck Schumer and a bank of television cameras.

headline: Looking Lucky at Harrah’s
text: Harrah’s Entertainment on Monday announced a scheduled closing date for its long-pending $27.8 billion acquisition by funds affiliated with the Texas Pacific Group and Apollo Management. The date is Jan. 28, more than a year after the initial agreement was announced.

headline: Worker Is Killed in Accident at Trump SoHo Tower
text: Updated, 8:46 p.m. | A construction worker plunged to his death, and two others were injured, after a wooden structure on the 42nd floor of the Trump SoHo hotel and condominium tower under construction in Manhattan collapsed, city officials said. The building, which is to rise 46 stories, has been a persistent source of debate, with community groups complaining about its size and proposed use, even before construction began last May.

headline: Bush tax cut mythology
text: As the debate turns to economic stimulus, we’re starting to hear this: “Bush realized that the economy needed help, so he asked Congress to enact tax cuts to provide stimulus. And this turned the economy around.”

headline: Globes Show Delivers Low Ratings For NBC
text: “The Hollywood writers strike took the glitz, the glamour and roughly two-thirds of the audience from this year’s Golden Globe Awards,” the Associated Press notes.

headline: Über-Brunch Buffet on a Sunday in Frankfurt
text: I have never specifically had a German tell me that The Sunday Brunch Buffet is an institution in Frankfurt. But that may be because it is so obvious, no native of the city would feel the need to comment. Having lived in four German towns now, from very small to the largest one (Berlin was my previous billet) I would say that Frankfurt surpasses them all, measured by the quality of Sunday brunch.

headline: Crash Test Outside Cobo
text: DETROIT — I was standing in front of the Cobo Center just before 4 p.m. on Sunday when I heard a huge crash. I turned and saw a police car go sailing across the street and smash into the wall in front of the new Sheraton hotel, formerly the Pontchartrain. A pedestrian jumped out of the way of the police car and barely escaped being sandwiched between bumper and wall. I was impressed by the huge pile of debris in the middle of the street — and the black Vibe that it appeared had smashed into the back of the police car and sent it flying. The area was soon swarming with policemen; both drivers turned out to be all right.

headline: Politics and Soccer: Strange Bedfellows?
text: If money makes the world go-round (certainly, it makes the soccer world go-round), then certainly money also qualifies as the mother’s milk of American political campaigns.

headline: The Butterfly Effect
text: “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” which had a big night at the Globes, woke up to the equivalent of Denny’s Grand Slam breakfast by being one of the the Producers Guild of America’s five nominees for best picture. “Juno,” “No Country,” “There Will Be Blood” and “Clayton” were the other four, while “Atonement,” which wore the slipper last night, went unshod, as did “Sweeney Todd.” Variety has the story.

headline: Question: Steroid Cloud Over Entertainment, Too?
text: In his report released in December, former Senator George Mitchell said that steroids “posed a serious threat to the integrity of the game” of baseball. But can the same be said about entertainment?

headline: Soft Serve | A News Feed of Light Reading
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.

headline: Gov. Spitzer’s New Project: Lowering Property Taxes
text: After a rocky first year that saw his approval ratings nosedive, New York Governor Eliot Spitzer is beginning his second year with a campaign that can be expected to have broad appeal among voters: lowering property taxes.

headline: Where the Smart Car Sells
text: DETROIT — Californians are trendy, so it is no surprise that they are expected to buy more two-seat Smart cars this year than any other state. The tiny car, manufactured in France by Daimler AG, is being delivered this week to its first customers in the United States.

headline: ‘Terminator’ Kills the ‘Golden Globes’
text: NBC’s bare-bones version of the “65th Annual Golden Globes” attracted just 5.8 million viewers on Sunday, a small fraction of the 20 million who tuned in to the awards show a year ago, according to Nielsen’s estimates. A two-hour “Dateline” that preceded the 9 p.m. announcement show and featured interviews with the nominees did not fare any better, attracting just 4.4 million viewers. Combined, the three-hour broadcast delivered a dismal 1.3 rating in the critical demographic of adults 18 to 49, a far cry from the 6.5 rating the show earned in prime time on a Monday last January.

headline: ‘Animal Planet’ Bares Its Feral Side
text: Last month the film “Grizzly Man” debuted on Animal Planet, the cable channel owned by Discovery Communications. The 2005 documentary explored the life of a man who spent years with bears in the Alaskan wilderness before being mauled to death.

headline: Deep-Fried Controversy
text: No one has wielded the power of humor more effectively on the campaign trail than Mike Huckabee, whose one-liners have softened the edge on his Republican populism and enhanced his image as a likable alternative to his better financed opponents. But a joke at Mr. Huckabee’s expense has caused a major headache for a young satire show on public radio as it faced the wrath of a religious advocacy group.

headline: Spain Nightmare
text: The British press is having a field day with the story of a retired couple in Spain who watched their house bulldozed by the government last week.

headline: Notable Models From Day Two in Detroit
text: A selection of vehicles that were displayed on the second preview day of the North American International Auto Show.

headline: Karma Commuting, She Comes and Goes, Week 3
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commuting trip for NYTimes.com/realestate, with additional details and reader comments here on City Room [Week 1 | Week 2]. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Lowes Provides a Venza Grabber
text: DETROIT — It may seem like a stretch to say that Lowes, the home improvement store, has anything to do with Toyota’s new Venza crossover vehicle.

headline: Corvette ZR1
text: General Motors officially revealed its newest high-performance Corvette, with a supercharged 6.2-liter V-8.

headline: The Gingerbread Man
text: I hate to sound like one of those Vaudeville comedians who’d begin their routine with “a funny thing happened to me on the way to the theater — a man walked up to me and said, ‘I haven’t had a bite to eat for days. So I bit him.’” — but I have no choice. Bear with me.

headline: The “Save XP” Petition
text: An eyebrow-raising initiative from an old editor friend of mine:

headline: Romney Addresses a Car Industry That Has Changed
text: DETROIT — In the days leading up to Tuesday’s Republican primary, Mitt Romney has made much of his Michigan upbringing, stressing his experiences as a child of the auto industry. But much has changed since Mr. Romney’s father, George Romney, who later became governor, was running the American Motors Corporation in the 1950s.

headline: That Was Then, This Is Now
text: Today is Jan. 14. And once upon a time – that would be many, many Democratic fights over the nominating calendar ago – this would have been the day of the Iowa caucuses. Back in Des Moines, our friend and colleague Kay Henderson of Iowa Radio shares a post on her blog of what might have been had it happened today. (Veterans of the John Edwards campaign who had been hoping for bad weather, and instead got flooded by new Obama voters who pushed Mr. Edwards back eight-points behind Mr. Obama, might want to skip Ms. Henderson’s post.)

headline: More on Giuliani and Florida
text: PUNTA GORDA, Fla. — Brent Seaborn, the chief strategist for the Giuliani campaign, just offered a few observations Monday afternoon on the race in Florida, given the Quinnipiac poll showing Mr. Giuliani’s lead here evaporating.

headline: Clinton Receives Tepid Reception at MLK Event
text: Speaking to black and Hispanic New Yorkers this afternoon, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tried to quell the controversy over race and the Democratic presidential nomination fight by crediting the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King for his “march for freedom and justice” that had benefited both herself and her rival, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: How Much Is That Rat in the Window?
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Airbus Chief Announces U.S. Plant
text: CNBC interviews Thomas Enders, Airbus chief executive, about the company's plans to build an aircraft assembly plant in Alabama.

headline: Magellan Opens to New Investors
text: Harry Lange, portfolio manager for Fidelity's Magellan Fund, discusses opening up the fund to new investors for the first time in a decade.

headline: More ‘Gladiators’ On the Way
text: NBC has announced a second season order of “American Gladiators,” one week after the series was introduced and drew strong ratings.

headline: Senator Bruno’s Wife Is Eulogized
text: Several hundred people — including Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the archbishop of New York, and a who’s who of state politicians — turned out today for a memorial service for Barbara Bruno, the wife of the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. Mrs. Bruno died on Jan. 8 after a long battle with Alzheimer’s disease.Lining the first row: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, Gov. Eliot Spitzer, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his companion, Diana L. Taylor; the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, and Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson. Others in attendance includes former United States Senator Alfonse M. D’Amato, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and State Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli.

headline: Of Suzy Menkes, Poetry and Hedge-Fund Hotties
text: The Moment is pleased to welcome the International Herald Tribune to its blogroll. Specifically, we’d like to draw your attention to the work of Ms. Suzy Menkes, who is covering the men’s shows in Milan for the I.H.T. (She’s a T Magazine columnist too, by the way.) In this video interview with Burberry’s Christopher Bailey she begins by saying that Burberry’s last collection was “all about hedge-fund hotties,” whereas the new season’s clothes are “autumnal and poetic.” As the video brings to light, Bailey sprinkled the runway with leaves and dressed the boys in turkey feathers. Suzy’s editors, meanwhile, are quite enamored of Posh Spice’s comments about a billboard showing Becks in his B.V.D.’s, in this Suzy video. Whatever works…

headline: This Papal Visit Will Be Smaller Than the Last One
text: Pope Benedict XVI’s visit to New York City will be significantly more modest than the much-celebrated visit his predecessor, Pope John Paul II, made in 1995, as judged by a preliminary itinerary released by the Archdiocese of New York.

headline: Blogtalk: An Uncommitted Vote?
text: What do you do if you’re a Democrat in Michigan?

headline: Facebook Is No Kingmaker
text: Sunday’s “60 Minutes” feature on Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook, hit all the logical bases: privacy, business model, the Beacon miscues and his youth. Only one section struck me as oddly off: the brief section on politics.

headline: First-Timers in Vegas
text: Don’t wager on the latest Nevada numbers: Markos Moulitsas doesn’t buy the new Reno Gazette-Journal poll showing a dead heat in Nevada among the three remaining Democratic candidates for president: “How the heck do you poll ‘likely caucus goers’ in a state that has never had a presidential caucus this early?” he writes. He adds:

headline: Anything but the ‘E’ Word
text: Monday’s New York Times poll, invokes the word I dread the most in any discussion of primary campaigns: “electability.”

headline: Finally, New Corvette ZR1 Makes Official Debut
text: DETROIT — What can you build for $100,000?

headline: Jumbo Jet to Fly (Partly) on Biofuel
text: Car makers are racing to put out new vehicles with ever higher fuel efficiency or — in the case of plug-in hybrids planned for 2010 by GM and Toyota — the prospect of traveling without combustion at all. Such vehicles eventually could (if the grid were powered by nuclear plants, dams, windmills, or solar energy) form the basis for the kind of “green mobility” I wrote about a few days ago.

headline: Friends of the Father
text: Mitt Romney, son of the former car company executive and Republican Gov. George Romney of Michigan, is counting on his father’s outsized reputation to help him turn around his losing streak in the state’s Republican primary Tuesday. But several of his father’s former associates have come out against him.

headline: Function Dysfunction
text: (Editor’s note: Allison Arieff wrote on design for NYTimes.com’s Opinion section in September 2006. She returns now with a monthly column.)

headline: Obama Tries to Stop the ‘Silliness’
text: RENO, Nev. – As he campaigned in northern Nevada on Monday, Senator Barack Obama said he was concerned that a heated discussion of racial issues in the presidential campaign could divide the Democratic Party.

headline: I’m Gonna Wash That Brand Right Into My Hair
text: A hair-care brand is hoping to generate some attention through a worldwide campaign that gets under way with a star-filled commercial during Super Bowl XLII on Fox on Feb. 3.

headline: Amazon Beat eBay in Holiday Traffic
text: For years, eBay ruled the e-commerce roost. Each holiday season, more visitors spent more time and looked at more pages on eBay.com than on any of its rivals, including Amazon.com. It made sense; eBay is a wide open forum for every kind of seller and item, while Amazon has traditionally pushed a selection of products through its network of physical warehouses.

headline: Bloggingheads: Why Not Chris Dodd?
text:
Bloggers Ezra Klein, left, of The American Prospect and Peter Suderman of National Review Online debate the media's role in choosing presidential contenders.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Thought Experiment
text: As a monkey walked in North Carolina its brain activity controlled a robot in Japan. The two treadmills were not connected.(Credits: Duke University and JST)

headline: Monday Injury Update: Chargers Edition
text: San Diego quarterback Philip Rivers has a sprained medial collateral ligament in his right knee and is questionable for the A.F.C. championship game Sunday at New England. He injured the knee when he landed awkwardly after throwing a touchdown pass to Darren Sproles late in the third quarter. He was already wearing a brace on his left knee from a Dec. 9 injury. Chargers Coach Norv Turner said Rivers would be limited in practice this week. (You can watch Turner’s news conference here.)

headline: The Fortune Cookie
text: Jennifer 8. Lee of The New York Times tracks down the original fortune cookie.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Terrorists?
text: How worried are you that you or someone in your family will become a victim of terrorism? Very worried, somewhat worried, not too worried, or not worried at all?

headline: Next-Generation Pickups
text: Rising gasoline prices have driven some consumers toward more fuel-efficient vehicles, prompting manufacturers to offer trucks with improved fuel economy.

headline: Candidates Cruise the Auto Show
text: Cars took a back seat at the Detroit Auto Show for a few hours Monday, as the three top Republican candidates in Tuesday’s Michigan primary stopped by to tour the exhibits.

headline: Fiat King Holds Court in Rome
text: Five years after his death, Fiat kingpin Gianni Agnelli is being commemorated in an exhibit here that blurs the boundaries between the myth and the man. The show runs until Jan. 30 at the Vittoriano Museum Complex, an exhibition space underneath the monument dedicated to the Italian king Vittorio Emanuele II that is usually unkindly compared to a wedding cake and/or gigantic white typewriter. History buffs may be interested to know that the monument commemorates Italian unification and includes a museum to the Risorgimento, as the unification movement is known, as well as the Altare della Patria, the altar of the fatherland.

headline: CNN Beginning Nightly Election Wrap
text: “CNN says it is beginning a nightly prime-time wrap-up of election news, further evidence that the 2008 presidential campaign is a television hit,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Sex After Prostate Surgery
text: For men facing prostate cancer, their first worry is about dying. Often, their second worry is whether the treatment will kill their sex life.

headline: Kucinich Should Be Allowed to Debate, Judge Rules
text: A Nevada judge has ordered MSNBC to include Representative Dennis Kucinich, a Democratic presidential candidate, in Tuesday night’s debate in Nevada, the Associated Press reports.

headline: Our Fetid City
text: Naples, Italy

headline: Johnny Podres, Series Star, Dies at 75
text: Johnny Podres, who became a celebrated figure in the storied history of the Brooklyn Dodgers in October 1955, when he pitched them to their only World Series championship, died Sunday in Glens Falls, N.Y. Podres, who lived nearby in Queensbury, N.Y., was 75.

headline: Crackdown on L.I. Landlords Is Criticized as Harassment of Immigrants
text: WESTHAMPTON, N.Y.  The officers showed up at 6 a.m. at the four connected apartments on Old Country Road.

headline: To Sell Higher Tolls, Corzine Talks Bonds
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine wants you to believe that no politician in New Jersey can be trusted to safeguard the state’s finances, except one: himself.

headline: A Loophole Lets a Foot in the Door
text: The bad news reached Neil Ashe, the chief executive of CNet, as he lounged on the beach in Mexico on vacation with his family over the holidays. The company’s lawyer called to say that two hedge funds had secretly acquired the equivalent of a 21 percent stake in CNet and planned to mount a proxy contest to take over the board.

headline: Insights: Possible Link Between Sleep and Risk for Diabetes
text: What happens when you rouse people hundreds of time a night when they go into deep sleep  besides the possibility that they might get seriously grumpy?

headline: Citi to Announce Big Cuts and New Investors
text: Citigroup is expected to announce a series of drastic steps on Tuesday, including the elimination at least 4,000 additional jobs, a steep cut in its stock dividend and another big investment by foreign investors, in a bid to bolster its finances in the face of deepening losses.

headline: U.S. Army Chief in Europe to Run NATO Afghan Unit
text: WASHINGTON  Gen. David D. McKiernan is expected to be appointed as the next commander of NATO forces in Afghanistan, American military officials said Monday.

headline: A Favorite Meal, Now Offering a Side Order of Environmental Awareness
text: LONDON  The restaurateur Tom Aikens is opening a sustainable fish and chips restaurant this month in London’s trendy South Kensington. Diners at Tom’s Place will be able to fulfill their consumer desires and be environmentally correct, too, but at a price.

headline: Pelosi Begins Discussions on Stimulus to Economy
text: WASHINGTON  Speaker Nancy Pelosi met on Monday with the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, to discuss potential action by Congress, the White House and the central bank to jump-start the economy and try to shorten the slowdown that many economists say has already begun to take hold.

headline: Crisis? Maybe He’s a Narcissistic Jerk
text: With the possible exception of “the dog ate my homework,” there is no handier excuse for human misbehavior than the midlife crisis.

headline: The Show Went On, the Fun Went Away
text: WEST HOLLYWOOD  Those of us who have always wondered why award shows have to be so infernally long got our answer on Sunday night at the Golden Globes: they don’t, but all meaning is derived in such matters from the script that goes with such ceremonies. The windy speeches, the tears of joy, the fashion miscues, all arrayed over remarkable superbeings in gossamer frocks are what people turn the television on for. Without pomp, there is no circumstance, at least in Hollywood.

headline: The Road May Be Rough, but It Yields Material
text: It’s a trick well known to television writers in need of a quick script: stitch together some scenes from old shows with just enough new thread to connect them, however loosely.

headline: A Passionate, Yet Light Voice for Icy Songs by Schubert
text: It’s hard to think of a song cycle as gripping as “Winterreise,” Schubert’s setting of 24 poems by Wilhelm Müller that trace the downward spiral  physical, spiritual and psychological  of a rejected lover who leaves his town in the dark of night and wanders through the snow toward a hoped-for death. Müller’s poetry is presented from a man’s perspective, and Schubert’s cycle is mostly sung by men, although women (generally mezzo-sopranos) have taken it up over the years.

headline: Virgin Atlantic Plans a Biofuel Flight
text: PARIS  Virgin Atlantic said Monday that it would conduct a demonstration flight next month of one of its Boeing 747 jets using biofuel  the first airborne test of a renewable fuel by a commercial jet.

headline: Sweet Potatolicious, and Other Healthy Recipes for East Harlem
text: East Harlem, home to a cornucopia of fried foods that cover a range ethnic tastes  tostones, chicken fried steak, pork rinds, egg rolls, refried beans, cuchifritos, French fries and onion rings, among others  has a bad reputation when it comes to good nutrition.

headline: Quality Is Major Concern of Toyota’s Visiting Chief
text: DETROIT  In his first visit to the Detroit auto show since becoming Toyota’s president in 2005, Katsuaki Watanabe used this very public forum to convey a passionate plea to his employees on Monday to take personal responsibility for the quality of Toyota cars and trucks.

headline: Waiting in Style
text: The airport lounge is no longer just a bunch of sofas in a quiet place.

headline: Doctors Where They’re Needed
text: Few things are more frightening than knowing you live too far away from the nearest doctor. Yet in many rural or poor urban areas there are far too few doctors to serve the community, and the problem is getting worse.

headline: Capitalizing on Oil’s Rise, Kazakhstan Expands Stake in Huge Offshore Project
text: MOSCOW  A consortium of foreign companies has resolved a dispute over Kazakhstan’s giant Kashagan oil field by agreeing to pay the government a bonus of up to $4.5 billion and to transfer 8.5 percent of the project to the national oil company of Kazakhstan.

headline: Rice Makes Unannounced Visit to Baghdad
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice flew to Baghdad on Tuesday, peeling off a trip to the region by President Bush to give momentum to legislative and political reconciliation, the White House said.

headline: Olmert Is Cautious as Talks With Palestinians Begin
text: JERUSALEM  Top Israeli and Palestinian negotiators began talks on core issues on Monday, as Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel sought to lower expectations of reaching a final peace agreement within a year.

headline: F.D.A. Says Cloned Animals Safe to Eat
text: After years of debate, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday declared that food from cloned animals and their progeny is safe, removing the last government hurdle before meat and milk derived from copies of prize dairy cows and superior hogs can be sold at grocery stores.

headline: Missouri: Mayor Arrested in Internet Sex Sting
text: A pastor who is the mayor of a small town was in jail on charges of soliciting sex over the Internet from a police detective posing as a 13-year-old girl. The mayor, Allen Kauffman of Collins, was arrested Friday on four counts of felony enticement of a child in the latest sting orchestrated by a police detective in Diamond, another southwest Missouri town. Prosecutors said in court filings that Mr. Kauffman, 63, believed he was communicating with a girl from the Joplin area in a Yahoo chat room last November and December. In online messages, Mr. Kauffman reportedly asked the girl for sex and nude pictures, and encouraged her to have sex with a female friend in front of a Webcam so he could watch, the authorities said. Collins, with a population of about 200, is in St. Clair County.

headline: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Says Landing Fees Could Be Used to Ease Airport Traffic
text: WASHINGTON  Airports could manipulate landing fees to encourage airlines to fly fewer planes or schedule landings for off-peak times or even less-busy airports, the Transportation Department said Monday.

headline: Canadian Bank Hopes Stock Offer Calms Fears
text: OTTAWA  The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said on Monday that it would issue 2.75 billion Canadian dollars in stock at substantially discounted prices as part of an effort to ease investor anxiety about its subprime mortgage exposure.

headline: Europe Delays Changing Rules on Cheap Goods
text: BRUSSELS  The European Commission has shelved plans to change the trade rules that allow it to retaliate against countries that sell goods below their market value. The move illustrates deep divisions in Europe over how to deal with China’s booming exports.

headline: New DVDs
text: PAYDAY

headline: No Immunity, No Testimony
text: WASHINGTON  Jose A. Rodriguez Jr., the former Central Intelligence Agency official who ordered the destruction of interrogation videotapes in 2005, will not be required to appear on Wednesday at a closed Congressional hearing on the matter but may be called to testify later, an official briefed on the inquiry said Monday.

headline: In Obama’s Pursuit of Latinos, Race Plays Role
text: LAS VEGAS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has eaten beef tacos in East Los Angeles and sat on the living room couch of a working-class family in a largely Hispanic neighborhood here for 30 televised minutes. At a rally of the culinary workers’ union in the shadows of the Strip here one night, Senator Barack Obama pumped his fist and chanted with the crowd, “¡Sí, se puede; sí, se puede; sí, se puede!” or, “Yes, we can!”

headline: Magellan Fund, Closed in ’97, Will Reopen
text: BOSTON (AP)  For the first time in a decade, new investors will be able to put money into a mutual fund that helped fuel Fidelity Investments’ rapid growth in the 1980s and 1990s, but has recently lost many retirement-age investors as they withdraw cash.

headline: In Big Ways and Small, the Giants Grew Into a Team
text: All around the Giants are signs and symbols of change and progression, from the once-isolated head coach, who was spotted Sunday night triumphantly bearhugging a player, to the acutely boyish quarterback, who stepped to the podium wearing the flattering look of whiskered grunge.

headline: To See (and Hear) the World in Five Hours: Unique Sounds Ripe for Import
text: The most striking group at Globalfest 2008  the five-hour, 12-band showcase of world music on Sunday night at Webster Hall  was the one that traveled lightest: Lo Còr de la Plana, from Marseilles, France. It was six male singers, four of whom also played hand drums and tambourine. They sang in a disappearing language, Occitan, and in an old style that once was church music. They performed traditional and traditionalist songs that took pride in what the group’s lead singer, Manu Theron, cheerfully called “filthy Marseilles.”

headline: Childrens' Book Awards Break With the Past
text: The John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to children’s literature was awarded on Monday to “Good Masters! Sweet Ladies! Voices From a Medieval Village,” by Laura Amy Schlitz. The American Library Association announced the prize at its midwinter meeting in Philadelphia. The book, a series of monologues and dialogues about characters in the Middle Ages, is illustrated by Robert Byrd and published by Candlewick Press. Its format is different from the more traditional novels that have characterized past Newbery winners. The winner of the Randolph Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished American picture book for children was “The Invention of Hugo Cabret,” by Brian Selznick. That book, published by Scholastic Press, is also different from the more traditional short picture books for young children that win the Caldecott medal. “Hugo Cabret” is a novel told in blocks of text interspersed with 284 pages of black-and-white drawings.

headline: Jeepers, Rappers, Where’d You Get Those Arms and Torsos?
text: When news surfaced over the weekend that 50 Cent, Wyclef Jean, Timbaland and other rap stars had been implicated in a steroids investigation, some hip-hop fans were shocked, but to many in the industry the accusations seemed inevitable.

headline: Clinton and Obama Call for Truce Over Dr. King Dispute
text: Speaking to black and Hispanic New Yorkers, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton tried on Monday to quell a controversy over race in the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination by praising the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and describing him as a trailblazer for both herself and her rival, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: More Than Games, a Net to Snare Social Networkers
text: FRIENDSHIP means being able to sink each other’s battleships.

headline: The Fourth Wall Is Broken, but the Floor Is Still Available for Use
text: K T Niehoff’s new full-length work, “Inhabit,” starts off a bit like a dining experience at the restaurant chain Johnny Rockets. All you really want is to devour a cheeseburger in peace, but the exhaustingly upbeat wait staff is so keen on entertaining that vegetarianism suddenly starts to look good.

headline: MySpace Agrees to Lead Fight to Stop Sex Predators
text: MySpace, the country’s largest social-networking Web site, has agreed with attorneys general of 49 states to take new steps to protect children from sexual predators on its site. It also agreed to lead a nationwide effort to develop technology to verify the ages and identities of Internet users, officials announced Monday.

headline: Ban on Rides for Teenagers Is Attacked
text: CHICAGO  An Illinois lawmaker says he plans to try to save an unintended victim of tougher laws intended to reduce teenage drivers’ accidents.

headline: Motion Ties W. Virginia Justice to Coal Executive
text: A justice of the West Virginia Supreme Court and a powerful coal-company executive met in Monte Carlo in the summer of 2006, sharing several meals even as the executive’s companies were appealing a $50 million jury verdict against them to the court.

headline: Olmert and Omar: Talking Baseball
text: Some people go to Israel and see their grandchildren. Omar Minaya went to Israel last week and met with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert, President Shimon Peres, the former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the famed Russian refusenik Natan Sharansky, a former member of the Israeli cabinet and parliament.

headline: In South Carolina, a Bid for Black Women’s Votes
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Juanita Ramsey, a retired administrative assistant, was standing by her front door in her largely black neighborhood here. As she pointed to the homes of her neighbors, she identified them by political preference:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a film review on Saturday about “In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale” misspelled the given name of one of the actors. As noted in a listing of credits with the review, he is Burt Reynolds, not Bert.

headline: Scaling a Minimalist Wall With Bright, Shiny Colors
text: YONKERS  “Pattern and Decoration: An Ideal Vision in American Art, 1975-1985,” at the Hudson River Museum, documents the last genuine art movement of the 20th century, which was also the first and only art movement of the postmodern era and may well prove to be the last art movement ever.

headline: Coaching the Comeback
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  In the therapy gym for the minimally functional, Jodi Levin props a patient between cushions, kneels behind him and then braces him with her arms. She directs his mother to select photos of his brother and his father. At the coaxing of Ms. Levin, an occupational therapist on the brain injury unit of Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation, the mother holds one photo to the left side of the patient’s head, the other to the right.

headline: Mayoral Candidates Vie for ’09 Fund-Raising Lead
text: William C. Thompson Jr., the New York City comptroller, has raised the most money so far in the quest for the Democratic nomination for mayor in 2009, but United States Representative Anthony D. Weiner raised the most in the past six months, according to numbers their campaigns provided on Monday.

headline: Yale Plans Sharp Increase in Student Aid
text: Yale said Monday that it would sharply increase financial aid for undergraduates, including those from families with annual incomes up to $200,000, in a bid to ease costs for a broad swath of students.

headline: For a Musical Polymath, Only the Wardrobe Color Stays the Same
text: “I have a strange relationship to variety,” the singer-songwriter Stephin Merritt said recently, as he sat at a West Village cafe meticulously tearing a croissant into little bits. He was discussing his wardrobe  absolutely all of his clothing is in a white-to-brown color palette (more on that later)  but also his career. In music, at least, “I like variety,” Mr. Merritt said.

headline: Mentally Ill and Homeless, Worker Fights to Regain Her Life
text: With her understated makeup, pressed pantsuit and soft-spoken manner, it is easy to imagine Allison Brito at her job, behind a jewelry counter at Macy’s.

headline: Video Game Industry Seeks Political Clout
text: Capitalizing on its improved respectability, the video game industry intends to establish a political action committee to donate money to game-friendly politicians and candidates.

headline: Candidate Clinton Scrutinized by Women
text: For the last week reporters, pundits, bloggers and political operatives have turned all their forensic powers on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s so-called crying moment  the moment in a New Hampshire cafe when her eyes welled with tears in response to some innocuous personal questions from an audience member: “How do you do it?,” “How do you keep upbeat and so wonderful?” That moment is credited with helping Mrs. Clinton stage a remarkable comeback in the New Hampshire primary, with galvanizing the sympathy of female voters and with revealing the candidate’s human side.

headline: Nets Are Overwhelmed by the Retooled Blazers
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Portland traded Zach Randolph, Dan Dickau and Fred Jones to the Knicks last June, it seemed the Trail Blazers had given up a lot while getting little in return. Randolph, the centerpiece of the trade, was coming off a season in which he averaged 23.6 points and 10.1 rebounds. From the Knicks, Portland received the role player Channing Frye and the slumping Steve Francis, who was waived a few weeks later.

headline: Campaign Issues May Fade, but Souvenirs Endure
text: Americans routinely used to wear their political hearts on their sleeves  or at least on their lapels. George Washington proudly displayed his own on his chest when he was inaugurated as the nation’s first president, where Federal Hall now stands in Lower Manhattan.

headline: In Europe, Microsoft Again Faces Inquiries
text: BRUSSELS  After the briefest of truces, Europe’s antitrust regulator resumed its battle with Microsoft on Monday, opening two new investigations into claims that the company has abused its dominant position to squeeze competitors out of the market.

headline: 55-Million-Year-Old Trail Yields Identity of Amber Producer
text: A piece of amber can tell a story, of some unfortunate insect trapped by oozing tree resin millions of years ago. But the tale is often incomplete. It might be easy to identify the insect, but determining what kind of tree produced the resin is another matter.

headline: U.S. Plans Sale of 900 Missiles to Saudi Arabia
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The Bush administration said it would sell 900 sophisticated satellite-guided missiles to Saudi Arabia as part of a $20 billion arms sale intended to bolster military relations with Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states and counter the rising influence of Iran.

headline: U.S. to Speed Deportation of Criminals in Jail
text: Federal authorities expect to identify and deport more than 200,000 immigrants who are convicted criminals serving time in prisons and jails across the country, the country’s top federal immigration enforcement official said Monday.

headline: Sightless Parent Fish Don’t Produce Just Sightless Hybrids
text: In a deep cave in northeastern Mexico, there is a population of fish, Astyanax mexicanus, that through the course of evolution has lost its sight. In other caves not far away, there are more populations of the same species, also blind.

headline: Masback Looks Back on Career
text: Craig Masback’s achievements include a degree from Princeton, a fellowship at Oxford, a senior associate position for a law firm, ownership of a sports marketing company and an analyst’s job for televised track and field meets. For the last 10 years, he has been the chief executive officer of USA Track and Field, helping the sport regain some of its luster.

headline: Film School Meets Assisted Living, With Understanding for All
text: Tammy Signorile, a sharp-witted 95-year-old with a klaxon voice that seldom rests, is one of the stars of the documentary “Andrew Jenks, Room 335.” Late in the film, in a rare moment of sentiment, she offers a philosophy of life: “It doesn’t take much to make somebody feel good. Say something nice to them, tell them how nice they are instead of looking for defects, instead of looking for something they’re not doing right.”

headline: Pulp Fiction Writer Arrested After Collision
text: Roger Avary, who won an Academy Award as the co-writer of “Pulp Fiction” with Quentin Tarantino, was arrested on suspicion of manslaughter and driving under the influence after a single-car collision that injured his wife and killed a man on Sunday in Ojai, Calif., The Associated Press reported. The dead man was identified as Andreas Zini, 34, believed to be a visitor from Italy. Mr. Avary’s wife, Gretchen, 40, was ejected from the car and hospitalized in stable condition. Mr. Avary, 42, who was also a co-writer of “Beowulf,” was released on $50,000 bail.

headline: Malawi Cuts Diplomatic Ties With Taiwan
text: JOHANNESBURG  Malawi cut its diplomatic ties with Taiwan, the government announced on Monday, drawing a bitter response from Taiwanese officials who accused the Chinese government of luring the Malawians into its camp with $6 billion in aid and other inducements.

headline: Trenton: Former Commerce Official Sentenced
text: A former top state commerce official was sentenced in State Superior Court on Monday to six and a half years in prison for public corruption. The official, Lesly Devereaux, left, former chief of staff to the Commerce, Economic Growth and Tourism Commission, was convicted in July of official misconduct and pleaded guilty in October to welfare and public records tampering charges. Ms. Devereaux, 49, of Piscataway, admitted creating fake documents to mask her role in steering $11,000 in state contracts to her mother and sister. Her lawyer, Jack Furlong, said she would be eligible for a tightly controlled parole program after six months.

headline: Much Hype in Player’s Treatment, Doctors Say
text: For all the images of athletes running and jumping in 2007, the sight of Kevin Everett merely walking was one of the most newsworthy.

headline: Philippines: Decline in Killings
text: The number of extrajudicial killings of activists and journalists in the Philippines dropped sharply in 2007 compared with the previous year, according to an Interior Department study released Sunday. The study said the Philippine National Police listed only 7 such killings last year, compared with 41 in 2006. Human Rights Watch, a New York-based group, welcomed the drop in killings but challenged the government of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo to prosecute the killers. The group has accused the government of carrying out a “dirty war” against leftists and journalists.

headline: In Search of Answers
text: The Iraqi Parliament has finally done something that the Bush administration, and many others, considered essential to political progress in Iraq: it passed a law intended to open government jobs to former members of Saddam Hussein’s Baath Party. What should have been heralded as an accomplishment, however, may only serve to further reinforce the bumbling nature of President Bush’s ill-conceived adventure in Iraq.

headline: Politics and Misogyny
text: With Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s win in New Hampshire, gender issues are suddenly in the news. Where has everybody been?

headline: Obama’s Wife Evokes Dangers of Campaign
text: ATLANTA  When Michelle Obama addressed an audience of African-American political and entertainment heavyweights here on Sunday, she obliquely addressed fears that her husband’s presidential run might put him in danger.

headline: Aviation Safety Surveys
text: To the Editor:

headline: Englewood: Arrests in Park Killing
text: A security guard and his companion have been arrested in the shooting death of the companion’s estranged husband in a public park, the Bergen County prosecutor’s office said on Monday. Horrified onlookers fled Mackay Park shortly after 4 p.m. Sunday after the husband, Severino Cepeda, 45, was shot several times. The police arrested the security guard, Livio Antonio Morales, 46, as well as Mr. Cepeda’s estranged wife, Patricia Pichardo, 38, who prosecutors say has been living with Mr. Morales in Englewood. Mr. Morales, a security guard for the Supreme Oil Company in Englewood, has been charged with murder and weapons offenses. Ms. Pichardo is charged with hindering apprehension and obstructing an investigation. The two were being held on Monday, with bail set at $2 million for Mr. Morales and $50,000 for Ms. Pichardo.

headline: Russia: Gazprom Skyscraper Denounced
text: St. Petersburg residents spoke out against the planned construction of a 1,050-foot-tall skyscraper for the headquarters of the state energy company Gazprom at a public hearing. About 600 residents and activists confronted officials who defended proposed changes in city zoning laws to allow for the building to go up. “St. Petersburg is no village and its skyline is an object of world admiration,” said Tatyana Krasavina, head of a group fighting the project. Present regulations limit the height of buildings to 157 feet.

headline: A Stable Life, Despite Persistent Dizziness
text: On the subway, children twirl themselves around the poles in the cars until they are so dizzy I’m ready to catch them. The young seem to delight in making the world spin out of control for a few moments, causing them to flop about like drunks.

headline: Intel’s Big Quarter Fails to Meet Wall St. Forecast
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel reported record fourth-quarter revenue on Tuesday, but the chip maker’s shares dropped sharply after hours as its earnings and its first-quarter projections disappointed analysts.

headline: St. Ann's Warehouse Thinks Very Big
text: St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn has announced its 2008 season, and one of the shows is so big that St. Ann’s has to set up another theater. In June, TR Warszawa, a Polish theater company under the direction of Grzegorz Jarzyna, will stage a huge, multimedia production of “Macbeth,” for which St. Ann’s is creating an outdoor performance space out of the pre-Civil War era tobacco warehouse across the street. St. Ann’s will also be host to the Druid Theatre Company of Galway, Ireland, known in New York for its productions of “DruidSynge” and “The Beauty Queen of Leenane,” which will present a new play, “The Walworth Farce,” by the Irish writer Enda Walsh. It won the Fringe First Award at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in 2007.

headline: Europe May Ban Imports of Some Biofuel Crops
text: PARIS  In a sign of growing concern about the impact of supposedly “green” policies, European Union officials will propose a ban on imports of certain biofuels, according to a draft law to be unveiled next week.

headline: So It Looks Cold on Camera? Try Operating One
text: On Jan. 10, 1982, Cris Collinsworth, then a rookie wide receiver, awakened to a report on his hotel clock radio that the temperature outside was 13 degrees below zero and that the howling 35-mile-an-hour wind made it feel like 59 below.

headline: Supreme Court Restricts Securities Lawsuits
text: WASHINGTON  Ruling in its most important securities fraud case in years, the Supreme Court on Tuesday placed a towering obstacle in the path of shareholders looking for someone to sue when a stock purchase turns sour.

headline: The Identity Trap
text: Correction appended.

headline: Treating Sinus Infections (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Study Reveals Doubt on Drug for Cholesterol
text: A clinical trial of a widely used cholesterol drug has raised questions both about the medicine’s effectiveness and about the behavior of the pharmaceutical companies that conducted the study, cardiologists said Monday.

headline: A Hereditary Perk the Founding Fathers Failed to Anticipate
text: Legacy preferences in college admissions  the nepotistic advantages given to the children of alumni  are indefensible, of course.

headline: Standing on Two Feet (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Foreign Sales Help I.B.M. to a Strong Quarter
text: A slowing American economy is not hurting I.B.M. yet.

headline: Peer Is Expanding Boundaries Outside the Court
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Shahar Peer is in Melbourne competing in the Australian Open but she will soon be in a much more unusual place for an Israeli tennis player: Doha, Qatar.

headline: Trenton: Law Extends Voting Machine Deadline
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a law on Sunday that extends until June 3 the state’s deadline to create a paper trail for its 10,000 electronic voting machines, the governor’s office said on Monday. The original Jan. 1 deadline, set by the Legislature in 2005 as part of a law requiring all electronic voting machines to produce paper records, was established so the machines could be retrofitted with printers in time for the state’s Feb. 5 presidential primary. After it became apparent that the deadline could not be met, state officials pushed back the timetable for the printers to June 3, the date of the Congressional primary. Researchers at the New Jersey Institute of Technology are now testing the printers, said David Wald, a spokesman for the state attorney general.

headline: Terminator Tops Globes
text: NBC’s bare-bones version of the “65th Annual Golden Globes” attracted just 5.8 million viewers on Sunday night, a small fraction of the 20 million who tuned in to the awards show a year ago, according to Nielsen’s estimates. A two-hour “Dateline” special, featuring interviews with the nominees and preceding the 9 p.m. announcement show fared no better, drawing only 4.4 million. Combined, the three-hour broadcast delivered a dismal 1.3 rating in the critical demographic of adults 18 to 49, a far cry from the 6.5 rating the show earned over prime time on a Monday last January. The big hit on Sunday was Fox’s premiere of “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles,” which attracted 18.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. and the highest ratings by far of any new series this season. Although “Terminator” benefited from following a football game on Fox that attracted more than 35 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour, no other scripted series debut on any broadcast network has done better in the 18-to-49 set in three years. The last scripted series debut on a broadcast network to earn higher ratings among adults 18 to 49 was CBS’s “Numb3rs” on Jan. 23, 2005. Fox easily led the night’s ratings, followed by CBS and ABC. NBC ranked fourth. Part one of CBS’s “Comanche Moon” drew 15.8 million viewers.

headline: Reflections on Influence While Being Serenaded by Works Past and Present
text: All so-called original art is based on what someone else has done already. An apt subtitle for a lot of 20th-century painting is “Picasso Looking at Ingres,” and how much late-18th-century music could be called “Mozart Listening to Bach”?

headline: Case on Police Searches Pits State Laws Against Federal
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court’s long-running debate over the meaning of federalism took a new turn in a case the justices heard on Monday.

headline: Sears Warns of Another Steep Drop in Profit
text: Evidence of an abrupt slowdown in consumer spending mounted Monday as Sears Holdings, the owner of Sears and Kmart, warned that its profit would most likely plunge as much as 57 percent for the three months ending in early February.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $6,563,171

headline: Disparities: Rural Residents Less Likely to Get Organ Transplants
text: Add patients living in small towns and rural areas to the list of people who stand a lower chance of getting an organ transplant if they need one.

headline: Florida: Charges Dropped, and a New Suspect Is Arrested
text: A man accused of killing a Miami police detective was arrested after prosecutors dropped attempted murder charges against another man. Andrew J. Rolle, 20, was taken into custody at the Miami police station and later taken to the North Miami Beach Police Department, a police spokesman said. Mr. Rolle, left, was named by North Miami Beach officials as the new suspect in the Jan. 8 slaying of James Walker of the Miami Police Department, who was shot with an assault weapon. Mr. Rolle had been arrested Jan. 5 on misdemeanor loitering and prowling charges but was released on $500 bail, jail officials said. Chief Rafael Hernandez of the North Miami police would not divulge details about how Mr. Rolle was identified as the gunman other than to say technology helped.

headline: Monkey’s Thoughts Propel Robot, a Step That May Help Humans
text: If Idoya could talk, she would have plenty to boast about.

headline: Turning Our Attention Back to Iraq ...
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chinese and U.S. Demand Drives Commodities Surge
text: The price of copper has tripled in five years. Zinc has doubled. Wheat and soybeans rose 70 percent in 2007. Futures prices of crude oil, gold, silver, lead, uranium, cattle, cocoa and corn are all at or near records.

headline: British-Russian Tension Escalates
text: MOSCOW  A British cultural organization on Monday defied a Russian government order to close offices in two cities, creating a fresh strain in the already tense relations between Russia and Britain.

headline: Marbury’s Injury an Opportunity for a Timeout
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Stephon Marbury did not practice Monday because of what the team initially described as a sore left ankle. Marbury said he thought the problem was related to bone spurs, which have plagued him throughout his career. He even raised the possibility of having surgery in the near future.

headline: It’s Drivers vs. Meter Readers, and Guess Who Wins
text: Once you discount crime, poverty, ailing school systems and public corruption, parking is the real scourge of urban life. Or at least that is what the producers of A&E’s new reality series, “Parking Wars” (broadcast on Tuesday nights), seem to believe. This is a show about stationary road rage, the anger that engulfs certain drivers when they are ticketed and towed, circumstances they could easily have avoided if, apparently, they weren’t such arrogant, entitled jerks.

headline: Decision on Football Playoff Is Delayed
text: NASHVILLE  Top university administrators delayed a decision on whether to start a playoff system for major college football at the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s annual convention Monday. They agreed to ask college presidents to weigh in on the topic but did not set a timeline for a decision.

headline: Living in Fear and Paying a High Cost in Heart Risk
text: Which is more of a threat to your health: Al Qaeda or the Department of Homeland Security?

headline: Open a New Window: A Tower With a View
text: The only thing standing between the occupants of 375 Pearl Street and some of the most commanding views in Lower Manhattan is three inches of limestone.

headline: And the Nominees Should Be . . .
text: The ideal slate of Oscar candidates, as chosen by the three critics of The New York Times.

headline: Yankees Expect to Open Camp Without Santana
text: Phil Hughes has been working out at the Yankees’ complex in Tampa, Fla., lately, and Johan Santana has been doing the same at the Minnesota Twins’ facility in Fort Myers. They will most likely be in the same place when spring training starts in four weeks.

headline: Heavy Orders for Airbus and Boeing Raise Backlog Questions
text: PARIS  The chief salesman for Airbus, John Leahy, ended one of the busiest years of his career with a quiet evening at home.

headline: Member of U.S. Chess Federation’s Board Is Asked to Resign in Dispute Over an Election
text: A majority on the executive board of the United States Chess Federation plans to formally ask a member to resign amid allegations that he had posted messages under other people’s names to Internet bulletin boards to get elected to the board.

headline: Judge and U.S.-Linked Sunni Fighters Are Killed in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  Gunmen in two cars assassinated a respected and high-ranking Iraqi appellate court judge and his driver in western Baghdad on Monday morning, Iraqi officials said. Hours later, in Diyala Province, three American-backed Iraqi militiamen died after they entered a building that blew up and collapsed on them, the Iraqi police said.

headline: Bush and the Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Steps to Lift Roadblock to Clemens Deposition
