text: WASHINGTON  The lawyer for Roger Clemens and the staff for the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform had discussions here Monday that made it more likely Clemens would give a sworn deposition and agree to provide a tape of an interview with his accuser without the panel’s having to resort to subpoenas, a key staff member said.

headline: Shake-Up at EMI Clouds Future of Its Artists
text: LONDON  Terra Firma, the private equity firm that recently acquired EMI Group, on Tuesday announced a major restructuring of the music company, saying it would eliminate close to a third of the staff, as it seeks to streamline operations and focus on the discovery of new artists.

headline: Justices Won’t Hear Appeal on Drugs for Terminally Ill
text: WASHINGTON  A legal battle ended at the Supreme Court on Monday over whether terminally ill patients who have run out of medical options have a constitutional right to try experimental drugs that have not yet received federal approval.

headline: Transit Worker Fought Back Before, Wounding a Man
text: The city transit worker at the center of last week’s bloody melee on a Harlem street fought off a gunman who tried to rob him in Queens 14 years ago, a struggle that left the attacker shot and wounded, officials said on Monday.

headline: Quiet Star Now Advocates for Union
text: For 12 seasons in Major League Soccer, Eddie Pope represented himself with quiet distinction and class on the soccer field. Now Pope, a defender who retired after the 2007 season, will further the interests of his former compatriots as the director of player relations for the union that represents M.L.S. players.

headline: As Talk of Recession Grows, Republicans and Democrats Differ on Response
text: WASHINGTON  For Democratic presidential contenders, the growing risk of a recession is an opportunity for action. For Republican contenders, accustomed to calling for less government intervention, it presents a dilemma.

headline: An Island and Its Ice Cap (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Big Fare Increases, Crowded Planes, and More Delays
text: BIG FARE INCREASES After United Airlines raised domestic fares across the board by $50 a round trip on Friday, most major carriers quickly followed with similar increases on many routes, according to FareCompare.com. The reason was sharply higher fuel costs. Delta Air Lines raised its round-trip fares by $50 immediately after United’s move. American Airlines also posted $50 round-trip increases on 55 percent of its route system, though "conspicuously absent" are increases on its routes that overlap with many Southwest Airlines routes, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Then on Monday, Northwest Airlines also joined in the $50 increase on most of its routes. Continental Airlines, which initially raised fares by $50 on some routes on Friday, withdrew the increases Monday morning, but Mr. Seaney said it was unclear whether Continental might reverse course again soon. This was the second broad fare increase in 2008, and the 10th since last Labor Day, Mr. Seaney said, adding: "It seems the legacy airlines, United in particular, are forgoing the nickel-and-dime strategy of increases every few weeks and are going for the whole enchilada at one time."

headline: Europe’s Appetite for Seafood Propels Illegal Trade
text: LONDON  Walking at the Brixton market among the parrotfish, doctorfish and butterfish, Effa Edusie is surrounded by pieces of her childhood in Ghana. Caught the day before far off the coast of West Africa, they have been airfreighted to London for dinner.

headline: Cowboys’ Struggles in December Foretold a Playoff Flop
text: IRVING, Tex.  On the turf at Texas Stadium in late November, the Cowboys dismantled the Green Bay Packers to take control of the National Football Conference.

headline: Producer Signs Deal With Writers
text: Media Rights Capital, an independent production company that helped finance the film “Babel,” signed an agreement that will let striking Hollywood writers work on its projects.

headline: On Sex After Prostate Surgery, Confusing Data
text: For men having prostate cancer surgery, one of the biggest fears is that they will be left impotent. Unfortunately, the research that might help address that question is likely only to confuse.

headline: The Battle Against Smoking
text: To the Editor:

headline: Panel to Study Algeria Blasts
text: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is appointing an independent panel to investigate the car bombing of two United Nations buildings in Algiers last month attributed to a group linked to Al Qaeda that killed 17 staff members and at least 30 other people, the organization announced. The panel is also expected to recommend steps to tighten security at United Nations offices worldwide.

headline: Recent Entries From Our Blogs
text: Dot Earth

headline: Construction Worker Dies in 42-Story Fall in SoHo
text: A construction worker who was pouring concrete at a condominium hotel in SoHo fell 42 floors to his death on Monday when a wooden mold used to set the concrete collapsed, the authorities said.

headline: Woman Released by Guerrillas Returns to Colombia to Greet Son
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Freed by Colombian guerrillas last week after six years of captivity in jungle camps, Clara Rojas returned to Colombia on Sunday, where she embraced and played with her 3-year-old son, Emmanuel, who had been taken from her when he was 8 months old.

headline: Stocks Plunge on Economic News and Bank Woes
text: Stocks fell sharply on Tuesday after Citigroup announced a $9.8 billion quarterly loss and an economic report showed retail sales fell in December.

headline: 1,500 Job Cuts Expected at EMI
text: LONDON  Terra Firma, the private equity firm that recently acquired the music company EMI Group, plans to announce a reorganization Tuesday, including the elimination of close to a third of EMI’s staff, according to people briefed on the plans.

headline: Some Treasures Found Over Harburg’s Rainbow
text: “Words make you think a thought. Music makes you feel a feeling. A song makes you feel a thought.”

headline: Apple Unveils Movie Rentals and Thin Notebook
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple on Tuesday introduced a movie rental service and an ultralight Mac notebook that could set a new industry standard for thinness.

headline: Nonprofit Punishes a 2nd Founder for Ruse
text: The board of GiveWell, a new nonprofit research organization that seeks to assess the effectiveness of charities, has disciplined the second of its two founders for promoting the organization by posing on the Internet as someone else.

headline: Waterfalls for New York City’s Waterfront
text: Four man-made waterfalls, 90 to 120 feet high, will punctuate New York’s waterfront for three months starting in mid-July. The creation of the Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson, the project is a collaboration between the city and the Public Art Fund, the nonprofit organization that presents art around the city. The waterfalls (above, in a rendering) have been designed to be environmentally friendly and will be in New York Harbor at Pier 35 in Lower Manhattan, at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge and between Piers 4 and 5 in Brooklyn and at Governors Island. Money for the project, estimated to cost about $15 million, comes entirely from private funds, and the Economic Development Corporation estimates that the waterfalls will bring more than $50 million to the city’s economy. “Throughout history we have always taken water for granted,” said Mr. Eliasson in a telephone interview from his Berlin studio. “Now people can engage in the physical nature of something as epic as a waterfall.”

headline: Big Brain Theory: Have Cosmologists Lost Theirs?
text: It could be the weirdest and most embarrassing prediction in the history of cosmology, if not science.

headline: Indonesia Watches as an Ailing Suharto Clings to Life
text: SOLO, Indonesia  The tomb is ready, in a mausoleum at the peak of a small mountain here in central Java, surrounded by shimmering green rice terraces, not far from a sacred retreat where former President Suharto had often come to meditate.

headline: Bedside Manner (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Star Power
text: Q. The Sun is a big ball of hydrogen, the lightest element. Why doesn’t it have a core of heavier elements that sank to the center?

headline: Romney Beats McCain in Michigan Vote
text: LANSING, Mich.  Mitt Romney, seizing on his personal ties to a state where his father made his family’s political fortune, captured a must-win victory in the Michigan primary on Tuesday, claiming the first major trophy for his ailing campaign and throwing the wide-open Republican field into further disarray.

headline: Hoboken: No Indictment of Police Officials
text: Edward J. De Fazio, the Hudson County prosecutor, said on Monday that he would not seek indictments of Hoboken’s police chief and a lieutenant accused of forcing subordinates to perform work at their homes on police time. The Jersey Journal reported that Mr. De Fazio said there was not enough evidence to indict the chief, Carmen LaBruno, and the lieutenant, Angelo Andriani, who headed a SWAT unit, but “there were clearly administrative issues that should be addressed.” Lieutenant Andriani was sued in October by five officers who said he coerced four of them to work on his house when they should have been on duty. Lieutenant Andriani has denied the allegations. The SWAT unit was disbanded in November after racy pictures emerged from a trip to the New Orleans area to help Hurricane Katrina victims.

headline: Baltimore Finds Subprime Crisis Snags Women
text: BALTIMORE  At Vixxen Hair Salon, the main topic of conversation has always been money. But since last August, Anjanette Booker, the owner, has noticed a new focus. “Now it’s money and foreclosures,” Miss Booker said.

headline: In California, a Sheriff Quits to Work on Legal Defense
text: LOS ANGELES  Sheriff Michael S. Carona of Orange County resigned Monday to focus on his legal defense against federal charges that he traded his office for hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of cash and lavish gifts.

headline: At Open, an Aggressive Stance on Gambling
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  With this tennis season now in full swing on the new, blue courts at the Australian Open, last season’s troubles are still in plain view.

headline: Praise and Questions for $400 Million Housing Plan
text: In what he called “the biggest housing initiative in a generation,” Gov. Eliot Spitzer said in his State of the State address on Wednesday that he would propose a $400 million affordable housing fund to help working-class New Yorkers, the poor and people with special needs.

headline: Teammates From Long Island to Montreal
text: When Mike Komisarek and Christopher Higgins come home to Long Island, they revel in their anonymity. They play hockey in the hotbed that is Montreal, where they cannot walk a block without someone asking for an autograph or a picture, where they would not dream of going out poorly dressed.

headline: Selling Wine Where the Surf’s Up
text: TUSCANY is best known for its cypress trees, Florence, the Leaning Tower of Pisa, and of course, vino. But few people know that Tuscany has a great surfing scene. Many even consider the western coast of Tuscany to be the “California of the Mediterranean.”

headline: Ruling Halts Amputee Sprinter’s Olympic Bid
text: Oscar Pistorius, a double-amputee sprinter from South Africa, will not be eligible to pursue his dream of qualifying for the Olympics, according to a ruling Monday by track and field’s world governing body.

headline: Six Workers Will Be Fired, Mayor Says
text: At least six child welfare workers will be fired for failing to properly address complaints about a woman’s care for her four daughters, who were later found dead in their home, Mayor Adrian M. Fenty said. The bodies of the girls, ages 5, 6, 11 and 17, were found Wednesday. Their mother, Banita M. Jacks, is charged with murder. A social worker at the oldest girl’s school tried twice in April to get city agencies to investigate. The employees being fired work for the Child and Family Services Agency and include a division director. More workers could lose their jobs as an investigation continues, Mr. Fenty said.

headline: Mississippi: Election Date Is Thrown Out
text: A judge has rejected the date of a special election set by the governor to replace former Senator Trent Lott. Judge Bobby DeLaughter of Hinds County Circuit Court ruled that Gov. Haley Barbour, a Republican, erred when he set the special election for Nov. 4. State law says that after receiving notice of a Senate vacancy, the governor must schedule an election within 90 days if the vacancy announcement does not fall in the same year as a state or Congressional general election. Mr. Lott retired Dec. 18, after November’s general election.

headline: Militants Escape Control of Pakistan, Officials Say
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan’s premier military intelligence agency has lost control of some of the networks of Pakistani militants it has nurtured since the 1980s, and is now suffering the violent blowback of that policy, two former senior intelligence officials and other officials close to the agency say.

headline: A Supreme Court Reversal: Abandoning the Rights of Voters
text: The Supreme Court heard arguments last week in a hugely important case about voter ID laws. Asking for identification at the polls may sound reasonable, but an Indiana law disenfranchises large numbers of people without driver’s licenses, especially poor and minority voters. If the court upholds the law, as appears likely, it will be a sad new chapter in its abandonment of voters, a group whose rights it once defended vigorously.

headline: Genetic Study Bolsters Columbus Link to Syphilis
text: Columbus, it seems, made another discovery of something that he was not looking for.

headline: A Loan to Finish Homes
text: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones/AP)  The home builder Levitt & Sons received approval on Monday to tap a $3.5 million loan to finish building homes across the Southeast.

headline: With ’07 Vetoes to Confront, the House Returns to Work
text: WASHINGTON  Congress opens its 2008 session Tuesday by returning to a crucial bill lingering from 2007, a major Pentagon policy measure that was rejected in a surprise move by President Bush late last year.

headline: Giants Forged Their Identity With Clutch Victories
text: The chance to go to the Super Bowl in the Arizona desert will rest on the outcome of a game that is expected to be played in single-digit temperatures in Green Bay.

headline: Citigroup Loses $9.8 Billion; Will Cut Jobs
text: Citigroup announced a steep cut in its stock dividend and another big investment by foreign investors on Tuesday after taking more write-downs related to subprime securities and posting a $9.83 billion loss for the fourth quarter.

headline: Bomb in Pakistan Market Kills 10 and Wounds 45
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A powerful bomb hidden underneath a fruit cart detonated among shoppers at a market in the southern port city of Karachi on Monday evening at rush hour, and officials and local news reports said it killed at least 10 people and wounded at least 45, four of them critically.

headline: New Bacteria Strain Is Striking Gay Men
text: A new, highly drug-resistant strain of the “flesh-eating” MRSA bacteria is being spread among gay men in San Francisco and Boston, researchers reported on Monday.

headline: Minister Sees Need for U.S. Help in Iraq Until 2018
text: FORT MONROE, Va.  The Iraqi defense minister said Monday that his nation would not be able to take full responsibility for its internal security until 2012, nor be able on its own to defend Iraq’s borders from external threat until at least 2018.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about Maurice Parks, a New York City transit worker who the police believe fatally stabbed a man while fending off a group of attackers in Harlem, and about Flonarza M. Byas, the victim, included incorrect information from a law enforcement official and a state senator about a 1994 attack on Mr. Parks in Queens. Mr. Parks shot his assailant in self-defense but did not kill him. An updated account can be read here. (Go to Article)

headline: Quadrangle to Manage Bloomberg Fund
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg disclosed Tuesday that he has chosen the firm of a longtime friend, Steven Rattner, an investment banker who moves among New York’s power elite, to manage the investments of his billion-dollar fortune.

headline: Barenboim Accepts Palestinian Citizenship
text: The Argentine-born Israeli pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim has accepted Palestinian citizenship and an honorary Palestinian passport, Agence France-Presse reported. “I hope that my new status will be an example of Israeli-Palestinian coexistence,” he said after a concert in the West Bank town of Ramallah on Saturday. Among other posts, including Maestro Scaligero, a sort of principal guest conductor, at La Scala Opera in Milan, Mr. Barenboim is the founding director of the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, based in Seville, Spain, which mingles Israeli (Jewish and Palestinian) and Arab youths.

headline: Collecting the Trash: Its Science and Value
text: The city employees who sweep your streets and collect your garbage? You know them as sanitation workers. But think of them also as “folk sociologists,” Robin Nagle says. She’s serious.

headline: South Korea Proposes Meeting With North
text: SEOUL  In a surprise initiative, the conservative president-elect of South Korea, Lee Myung-bak, said Monday that he would meet with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, anytime if a meeting could help persuade Mr. Kim to abandon his nuclear weapons programs.

headline: Planes Leaving Gates Collide at San Francisco Airport

headline: Spain Dissolves Parliament and Schedules March 9 Elections
text: MADRID  The Spanish government on Monday dissolved Parliament and called general elections for March 9, officially opening what promises to be a close race between the governing Socialists and the opposition Popular Party.

headline: Queens: Body Found at Subway Station
text: A man’s body was found beneath a stairway at a subway station in Edgemere on Monday morning, the police said. The body, which appeared to be that of a Hispanic man in his 30s, was found about 8:30 a.m. at the A train station at Beach 44th Street and Rockaway Freeway, the police said. A police spokeswoman said she did not know the circumstances under which the body was discovered. The police said the city medical examiner would determine the cause of death.

headline: Meditations Conjure Incense, Stained Glass and Devotion
text: The 100th anniversary of the French composer Olivier Messiaen’s birth doesn’t arrive until December, but centenary celebrations have already begun. Numerous prominent performances of this vastly influential avant-gardist’s orchestral, chamber and instrumental works lie ahead. While it may seem rash to make the claim so soon, a survey of Messiaen’s organ music performed by Gail Archer is sure to be among the year’s highlights, to judge by the initial installment on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Bjork Accused of Attack
text: The Icelandic pop singer and songwriter Bjork was accused of attacking a news photographer, ripping his sweatshirt in half after he ignored a request not to take any pictures on her arrival on Sunday at Auckland International Airport in New Zealand, The New Zealand Herald reported. Glenn Jeffrey, above, a photographer for the newspaper, said Bjork was accompanied by a man who asked him not to take pictures. “I took a couple of pictures and I got about three or four frames of her,” Mr. Jeffrey said, “and as I turned and walked away, she came up behind me, grabbed the back of my black skivvy and tore it down the back. As she did this, she fell over. She fell to the ground. At no stage did I touch her or speak with her.”

headline: Blast at Kabul Hotel Kills 6
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomb attack on Monday evening at a Kabul luxury hotel frequented by foreigners killed at least six people, including an American and a Norwegian journalist, and appears to be one of the most brazen assaults by the Taliban in the heavily protected heart of the Afghan capital, officials said.

headline: How The New York Times Counts Delegates
text: Updated | April 9, 2008 State political parties choose different means of selecting their delegates — either a primary or a caucus. A primary is completed in one day and is often binding, while a caucus is the first step and is generally a multitiered process that culminates with the selection of delegates. This year, a number of states have been penalized and docked a portion of their delegates because they scheduled their nominating contests too early.

headline: '30 Ways of Looking at Hillary'
text: In an episode of "The Simpsons" from a few years ago, Bart gets a glimpse thirty years into the future and sees that his sister Lisa has been elected president. The show doesn't make a lot of fuss over the notion of a woman commander in chief (in fact, in an aside we learn that Lisa is "the first straight woman president.") But it's impossible not to notice that President Simpson looks a lot like Hillary Clinton: her spiky hairdo has been smooshed down into a power-helmet; she wears monochrome pants suits and a string of pearls. She is intelligent and earnest, and she has a problem with authenticity. Bart, who has grown into a middle-aged slacker with a ponytail, ends up playing Bill to Lisa's Hillary; he saves the day by smooth-talking a mob of angry world leaders who have converged on the White House. At one point he says, "I coulda been president, but I'm too real."

text: I can’t figure out a cute way to sugarcoat the despondency with which I report this next bit of news, so I’ll give it to you straight: Pies ‘n’ Thighs, home to the finest pulled pork sandwich in New York City and an estimable bastion of down home dessert goodness, is closing. Tomorrow.

headline: Squirrels Ate My Homework
text: A man can only go so far to establish the best possible hockey bunker in his home. He can buy TV sets, laptops, digital cable boxes, WiFi routers and a good, comfortable chair, but the whole thing can go south when squirrels run out of snacks and decide the overhead cable line from the pole to the house looks like a good meal.

headline: Tuesday Kickoff: What Did U.S.C. Know and When Did It Know It?
text: The sports marketer who says he gave almost $300,000 to Reggie Bush is now saying that U.S.C. officials knew about it. Lloyd Lake tells Mark Saxon of the Orange County Register: “They knew Reggie was getting money from somewhere. They had to know.” The book about the payments to Bush, “Tarnished Heisman,” is being released today.

headline: Other Macworld Blogs
text: Somehow there is more coverage of the Macworld Expo keynote by Steve Jobs than the State of the Union Address. Apple won’t allow the speech to be Webcast. But there are lots of sites that are live blogging. In addition to our coverage at Bits here are links to some liveblogs:

headline: Can Cruise Ships and Coral Coexist?
text: [UPDATE, 2/15/09: Our Green Traveler column has provided an update assessing a long list of environmental impacts from cruise ships.] The cruise ship industry, Mexican government, and Conservation International have announced a plan to try to protect coral reefs and other ecosystems in Cozumel, the world’s most-visited cruise destination.[UPDATED 1/15 below]In a joint news release, the industry, environmental group, and government officials said their goals are to boost environmental education of passengers, cruise operators, and local communities, curb traffic and waste-disposal problems, boost protection of the barrier reef, and work to more effectively enforce environmental laws and regulations.

headline: Making Fraud Easier
text: The Supreme Court today made it easier for companies to defraud investors, and impossible for those investors to go after companies that help out in the fraud.

headline: Chinese Auto Chairman Test Drives Hybrid… Inside the Detroit Auto Show
text: DETROIT — It’s no secret that Chinese automakers are adjusting to American customs and auto show etiquette. So far they’ve held press conferences in incomprehensible English, referred to Adolf Hitler as an auto innovator, and press materials list horsepower in kilowatts and torque in Newton-meters. But the stunt of the show goes to the chairman of Build Your Dreams, Wang Chaunfu, who took a reporter from Jalopnik.com on a spontaneous test drive on the show floor:

headline: Live From Macworld Expo
text: We’re reporting from the keynote speech by Steve Jobs at Macworld Expo with reports from Laurie Flynn and Matt Richtel. We’ll keep updating this post for the duration of the speech with the latest news at the top of this post.

headline: Highlights from the Citi Conference Call
text: Citigroup on Tuesday held a two-hour conference call, one that ended with pointed questions from skeptical analysts. But if you missed the discussion, featuring the chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, and the chief financial officer, Gary Crittenden, The New York Times’s Floyd Norris live-blogged the call on Notions on High and Low Finance.

headline: The Skinny at Starbucks
text: My regular coffee order at Starbucks sounds ridiculous. “I’ll have a grande, no-fat, sugar-free Cinnamon Dolce Latte, no whip. Please.” Once, a customer behind me chirped, “Would you like coffee with that?”

headline: Edwards Releases 4 New Ads in S.C.

headline: Perimeter to Acquire E-Mail Service Provider
text: Perimeter eSecurity, a provider of network security services, said Tuesday that it has acquired SECCAS, a provider of e-mail compliance services, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: The EU vs. Friends of the Earth Over ‘Green’ Biofuels

headline: Which Buyout Firms Were Quickest to Cash Out?
text: Most shareholders like dividends — just ask a Citigroup investor — but creditors generally aren’t big fans. This is especially true of the “special” dividends that private equity firms like to pay to themselves, sometimes just a few months after a leveraged buyout is complete. This sudden outflow of cash can be deeply annoying to bondholders worried about the quality of their debt, which is why Moody’s Investors Service decided to examine which private equity firms tend to be quickest on the draw when it comes to dividends.

headline: Alonso fastest in Jerez
text: Was it a taste of things to come, or a little bit of harmless publicity? Was it a real statement that Formula One is as much about the driver as it is about the car, or just a bit of theater?

headline: Can Apple Jump-Start Internet Movie Rentals?
text: The iTunes movie rental announcement at Macworld Expo underscores that this is among the hot categories right now. It’s part of an earnest and chaotic effort by consumer electronics companies to both bring Internet content to the living room and to get themselves into the process and profit it from it.

headline: Stops Short
text: Of all the world’s art forms — color-field painting, millinery, Takurazuka, — the one that most mystifies me may be the common short story.

headline: Police Are Tracking Thefts of Sidekick Phones
text: In September, a study by the Urban Institute, a respected research organization in Washington, suggested that iPods were partly responsible for a nationwide increase in violent crime in 2005 and 2006. Now a different gadget — T-Mobile’s Sidekick line of cellphones and music players — appears to be a rising target in robberies in New York City, especially among younger people.

text: Aired Monday night on NBC: Hey, did you all see the Golden Globes last night? Just “because a movie star wins a Golden Globe, that doesn’t mean they’re going to get an Oscar. The Golden Globes are kind of like the Iowa caucuses for actors.

In a well-timed interview on CNBC’s Power Lunch, held at the Four Seasons, Ambassador Rohatyn of banking discusses the mortgage crisis on Wall Street and the rise of sovereign wealth funds.

headline: ‘Deal’ And ‘Gladiators’ Top ‘Terminator’

According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Deal or No Deal” delivered the largest audience overall, 15 million viewers at 9 p.m., while “American Gladiators” at 8 p.m. drew 10.7 million viewers.

His client list is private, but rumor has it that his handiwork is easy to spot in Fashion Rio’s front row.

headline: Stimulus? Never mind
text: If this Times report is at all right, Republicans will hold any attempt to help the economy now hostage to yet another try at making the Bush tax cuts permanent — thereby, among other things, crippling future possibilities for health care reform. I suspected that’s what would happen, but thought that maybe, just maybe, the GOP would be sufficiently scared by the prospect of a nasty recession in an election year that it would back off. Guess not.

There is a Plan A (no strike) and a Plan B (the strike is still on), but regardless, his crew is building sets, laying out the show and have no plans to cancel or reschedule.

headline: Vendors Want More Permits, Not Just Green Ones
text: In the No Good Deed Goes Unpunished category, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came up with a plan to provide fresh fruits and vegetables to low-income New Yorkers, and he got hit with rotten tomatoes from city street vendors. The mayor’s plan — to provide an extra 1,500 cart permits for vendors willing to sell produce in neighborhoods underserved by grocery stores — has been widely hailed by public health advocates. The city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene says it will make it easier for an estimated 100,000 residents to buy vegetables.

headline: There’s Something About Sarah (A Huge Marketing Push, For Instance)

headline: No Nanoparticles Were Killed Making This Post
text: The Soil Association, Britain’s largest certifier of organic products, issued a press release Tuesday proclaiming itself to be the “first organization in the world to ban nanoparticles.” On closer inspection, that boiled down to the group saying it would not allow its organic label to be used on any product containing synthetic particles with a mean size of less than 200 nanometers or in which the smallest particles were less than 125 nanometers.

headline: A Promising Way of Containing Out-of-Control Medical Spending
text: Conventional wisdom holds that health care costs, especially federal spending for Medicare, are driven by aging. Based on that belief, it’s not illogical to conclude that as the baby boom generation ages, the sheer number of retirees will simply overwhelm the nation’s ability to pay for all of them.

headline: For the Moment | Francesco Vezzoli
text: This week’s guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like “Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal’s Caligula,” starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandello’s “Right You Are (If You Think You Are),” starring — among others — Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his second post of the week he writes about the actress Silvana Mangano. To read all of Francesco Vezzoli’s prior blog posts, click here.

headline: Quadrangle to Manage Bloomberg’s Wealth
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg disclosed Tuesday that he has chosen the firm headed by his long-time friend, Steven Rattner, a financier who moves among New York’s power elite, to manage the investments of his billion dollar fortune.

headline: The Wonders of Sticky Snow
text: This planet’s extraordinary climate — equable and potent, dramatic and sublime — produces a remarkable number of magical moments. I’d like to share one with you, on video at least. I live up on a range of hills paralleling the Hudson River about 50 miles north of Manhattan, at an elevation about 800 feet above sea level. This is just high enough to turn what is a January rain nearby into sticky fluffy snow. As the first potent nor’easter of January rolled up the East Coast Sunday night and Monday, just enough snow fell, of just the perfect light-but-sticky consistency, to cloak a patch of woods near our house with cold cotton.

headline: Congress Takes Second Swing at Steroids in Baseball
text: 2:15 | Wrapping Up The hearing ended rather abruptly but rather predictably — with the chairman, Henry A. Waxman, praising the three witnesses (George Mitchell, Bud Selig and Donald Fehr) for their participation and general candor, while also encouraging them to be vigilant in pursuing a stronger anti-drug program in baseball.

headline: Another Media Exec Leaves Yahoo

I’ve recounted the essentials of this dinner in my column for Wednesday’s newspaper, but mere newsprint cannot contain me.

Right now New Jersey have a pretty good 20-15 record in regulation and a 6-3 record in overtime and shootouts — but here’s the thing: they compiled those marks by playing 26 of their first 44 games on the road.

headline: Video Podcasts: The Sleeping Giant on AppleTV
text: While Steve Jobs talked for a long time Tuesday at Macworld Expo about the movie rental feature of iTunes and Apple TV, he spent only a short time demonstrating its capabilities for podcasts. In fact, the ability of Apple TV to view podcasts may in the long run be its most important feature.

headline: Detente, But Only for Some
text: On the same day that Gil Cates, the producer of the Academy Awards telecast, said in no uncertain terms that the Oscars will go on regardless of what happens with the writers’ strike, Patric Verrone of the Writers Guild America West said in equally certain terms that there will be no such thing if the strike is still in progress on Feb. 24.

headline: Republican Is New City Elections Director
text: Marcus Cederqvist, the executive director for the New York Republican Party in Manhattan, was selected this afternoon as the new executive director of the New York City Board of Elections. Mr. Cederqvist, 38, replaces John A. Ravitz, who stepped down in October to accept a position as chief executive of the American Red Cross in Westchester County. Mr. Ravitz, too, was a Republican, and a former member of the Assembly. The selection of Mr. Cederqvist was done unanimously by the 10-member Board of Elections, which includes two members from each of the five boroughs, a Democrat and a Republican.

headline: McCain Campaign Responds to Attack
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. – The polls had not even closed in Michigan yet when the McCain campaign worked Tuesday evening to repel an attack here in South Carolina, where a brutally negative campaign derailed Senator John McCain’s candidacy in 2000.
