headline: Mona Really Was a Lisa
text: The University of Heidelberg in Germany says it has identified the woman in Leonardo’s “Mona Lisa” (detail below), The Associated Press reported. She is Lisa del Giocondo, wife of Francesco del Giocondo, a Florentine businessman. In a statement on Monday, the college said its library expert, Armin Schlechter, found the answer in a copy of the works of Cicero, where, in 1503, Agostino Vespucci, a Florentine official and friend of Leonardo’s, wrote in the margins that the artist was working on a portrait of Lisa del Giocondo. Surprise? For centuries the Mona Lisa has been known in Italian as La Gioconda. Though anecdotal evidence pointed to Giocondo as early as 1550, vague references in 1517, 1525 and 1540 pointed to others.

headline: Carbon Offsets
text: To the Editor:

headline: Prog-Rock, Punk Fury, Psychedelic Euphoria
text: Tens of thousands of notes hurtled by during the Mars Volta’s nearly nonstop two-and-a-half-hour set at Terminal 5 on Monday night. Compared to virtually any other band that’s equally popular, the Mars Volta is a progressive-rock whirlwind, constructing maniacally complex music and performing it with a mixture of rigorous virtuosity, psychedelic euphoria and punk intensity.

headline: Markets, Greened
text: To the Editor:

headline: Blue-Collar Jobs Disappear, Taking Families’ Way of Life Along
text: JACKSON, Ohio  After 30 years at a factory making truck parts, Jeffrey Evans was earning $14.55 an hour in what he called “one of the better-paying jobs in the area.”

headline: States Advised to Check for a Bridge Design Flaw
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Highway Administration moved quickly Tuesday to tell state authorities to re-examine bridges to make sure they do not have the newly discovered design flaw that doomed the Interstate 35W bridge, which collapsed in Minneapolis last summer.

headline: California: Thermostat Plan
text: After an outcry of objections, the California Energy Commission withdrew its proposal to require new buildings in the state to have radio-controlled thermostats that, in a power emergency, could be used to override customers’ temperature settings. Instead of making the proposal part of new state building requirements, the commissioners will discuss the use of the “programmable communicating thermostats” when considering how to manage electrical loads  with the understanding that customers would have the right to refuse to allow the state to override their wishes.

headline: Mamaroneck: Settlement Over School Building
text: The Village of Mamaroneck has agreed to pay $4.75 million to the Westchester Day School to settle a five-year lawsuit over the school’s attempt to erect a new building on its campus, representatives of the school and the village announced on Monday night. Westchester Day, a 60-year-old Orthodox Jewish school, sued after the village denied its application to add a fifth building to its 25-acre campus. The school will also be able to move forward with the project. In October, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found that the village had shown “an arbitrary blindness to the facts” when it denied permission for the construction.

headline: With Kimchi, a Little Alchemy
text: SOME people collect stamps, others vintage bartender guides or mounted rare butterflies. I’m cultivating a prodigious collection of condiments that is slowly taking over the fridge, much to my husband’s dismay.

headline: Northern Rock Investors Reject Curbs on Asset Sales
text: NEWCASTLE, England  At a special meeting, shareholders in Northern Rock, the ailing British mortgage lender, voted Tuesday against proposals by two hedge funds that would have forced managers to seek shareholder approval for even small asset sales.

headline: As Spitzer’s Popularity Fell, Donors Rallied to His Side
text: ALBANY  Even as Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s popularity plunged last fall, a star-studded group of donors that included Ivanka Trump, Christie Brinkley and Edward Norton, as well as wealthy developers, poured thousands of dollars into his campaign account, helping the governor to amass nearly $3 million.

headline: Decline in New Generic Drugs Draws E.U. Scrutiny
text: BRUSSELS  European Commission antitrust regulators raided some of the continent’s biggest drug makers on Wednesday as part of a far-reaching inquiry into whether settlements of patent disputes and lawsuits are being used to improperly keep generic products off the market.

headline: One Killed and 9 Are Hurt in Blast at Metal Parts Factory
text: CARLSTADT, N.J.  An explosion at a small metal parts factory flung a man 30 feet, killing him and injuring nine others on Tuesday  three critically  according to the authorities here.

headline: Lender to Cut 2,400 Employees, Including Sales Staff in India
text: LOS ANGELES (AP)  The mortgage lender IndyMac Bancorp said Tuesday that it would cut its work force by 24 percent, laying off 2,403 employees to cut costs as it tries to weather the worsening housing slump.

headline: Visiting American Admiral Confers with Chinese Generals
text: BEIJING  China must be more open about its rapid military buildup and should expand military collaboration with the United States to develop greater trust and thereby prevent misunderstandings and confrontation, the United States commander in the Pacific said Tuesday.

headline: With No Time to Waste, Fish Advances Quickly in Australia
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  A spectator no more, Mardy Fish is back in Australia and thriving, even on a new surface.

headline: Bronx: Body Found in Apartment
text: Officers responding to a complaint of a foul odor found the body of a 39-year-old man on Tuesday morning in a bathtub of an apartment at 529 East 138th Street in Mott Haven, the police said. The victim’s identity was withheld pending notification of his relatives. The body was fully clothed, and the bathtub was dry, investigators said. The case remains under investigation, the police said, and the medical examiner’s office would determine the cause of death.

headline: Romney in Crucial Victory Over McCain in Michigan
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor who ran as a son of Michigan though he left the state nearly 40 years ago, won a commanding victory Tuesday in the Republican primary here with a message aimed at voters deeply anxious about the state’s ailing economy.

headline: Settlement in Bias Suit That Stalled for 37 Years
text: A federal judge has approved a $6.2 million settlement for black and Hispanic sheet metal workers in a 37-year-old lawsuit against a union that critics have called one of the city’s most notorious for racial discrimination, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced on Tuesday.

headline: An Effort to Stem Losses at Citigroup Produces a Renewed Focus on Risk
text: Ben Bernanke, meet Gary Crittenden. While you’re easing credit, he is tightening it.

headline: Whole-Grain but Not Heavy
text: WHEN my friend Gary Danko made whole-grain pancakes for me a while ago, I and everyone else in our little brunch party could not get enough of them.

headline: Broadway Web Sites: Now for Fans as Well as Fanatics
text: A poll question on the new Web site BroadwaySpace.com plays to the most stereotypical image of Broadway fans: “Who is your favorite diva?” The choices are (no last names needed) Bernadette, Betty, Idina, Patti.

headline: Spears's Visiting Rights Remain Suspended
text: The right of Britney Spears to visit her two little boys remained suspended under a ruling issued at a closed-door hearing by the Superior Court commissioner, Scott Gordon, on Monday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Neither Ms. Spears, 26, nor her former husband Kevin Federline, 29, was required to attend. He did; she came late to the courthouse but never went inside. He retains custody of the boys, Sean Preston, 2, and Jayden James, 1. Another hearing is scheduled for Feb. 19.

headline: From One Prairie Home to Another, a Suit
text: ST. PAUL  Perhaps they will be able to share some tuna hotdish and work things out, but right now the spat between Garrison Keillor and a next-door neighbor is proving a good deal harder-edged than “The News From Lake Wobegon.”

headline: Guild Allows Writers to Work on N.A.A.C.P. Awards
text: LOS ANGELES  Patric M. Verrone, president of the Writers Guild of America West, said the union’s board voted to approve an interim agreement to let next month’s N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards proceed with guild writers and without the threat of pickets.

headline: ‘The Kite Runner’ Film Outlawed in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Culture Ministry has quietly banned the importing of “The Kite Runner,” a film based on the best-selling novel about childhood betrayal, ethnic tension and sexual predation in Afghanistan.

headline: Check-Cashing Chain Is Takeover Target
text: Last week, a store in the Pay-O-Matic check-cashing chain was the scene of a macabre event when two men were charged with trying to cash a dead friend’s check  with his body in tow.

headline: Carlyle Said to Be in Talks to Buy Booz Allen Unit
text: Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm, is in talks to sell its government contracting business to the Carlyle Group and several other private equity firms for about $2 billion, people briefed on the discussions said Tuesday.

headline: Second Leg of Apple’s Plans Includes Jumping Back Into Movie Rentals
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs is rebooting Apple’s digital movie effort and putting the company squarely in the middle of an intensifying industry battle to download movies and Internet content to high-definition televisions.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Saturday about an investigation by the New York attorney general related to subprime loans referred incorrectly to a sign in a photograph of a residential street in Queens. The sign was an advertisement for a company offering refinancing or credit services to those in danger of foreclosure. It was not a foreclosure sign.

headline: Norman Morrice, Director of Royal Ballet, Dies at 76
text: Norman Morrice, a former artistic director of the Royal Ballet and Ballet Rambert who shook up traditional British dance sensibilities by championing modern-dance choreographers and mentoring young talent, died last week, the Royal Ballet said in a statement. He was 76.

headline: Global Advances Challenge U.S. Dominance in Science
text: The United States remains the world leader in scientific and technological innovation, but its dominance is threatened by economic development elsewhere, particularly in Asia, the National Science Board said Tuesday in its biennial report on science and engineering.

headline: Spate of Police Commander Murders in Mexico
text: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico  The Interior Minister stepped down Tuesday in the latest sign that President Felipe Calderón is shaking up his cabinet after a little more than a year in office, officials said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday about the country record producer Ken Nelson erroneously included a band among his recording credits. While he produced Rose Maddox’s solo recordings for Capitol Records, the Maddox Brothers & Rose had disbanded by the time Mr. Nelson was handling the Capitol label.

headline: As Diseases Sneaked Up on Woman, the Piles of Clutter Grew
text: She simply shut the door. Maybe that would keep everything inside. The debris. The anxieties. The worn furniture. The sadness. The stacks of yellowing papers. The tangle of once-fine clothes. The jumble of interwoven memories of a life past. If she shut the door, it would all be hidden away, and she wouldn’t have to confront It  whatever It was.

headline: What to Expect When You’re Free Trading
text: Rochester

headline: Manhattan: Parachutist Sues Empire State Building Company
text: A professional parachutist who tried to jump off the Empire State Building in 2006 filed a $30 million lawsuit on Tuesday against the Empire State Building Company. The parachutist, Jeb Corliss, 31, accused the building’s agents of defaming his character, unlawfully imprisoning him on the observation deck by shackling him to a fence when he tried to jump and causing him emotional distress and lost income. His lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, was a counterclaim to a $12 million suit filed against him last year by the company. That suit accuses Mr. Corliss of disrupting business, endangering bystanders and being motivated by money. A spokeswoman for the Empire State Building Company declined to comment on Tuesday.

headline: A Strong Intel Disappoints on Outlook
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel reported record fourth-quarter revenue on Tuesday, but the chip maker’s shares dropped sharply after hours as its earnings and its first-quarter projections disappointed an already jittery Wall Street.

headline: Pope Cancels Speech After Protest at University
text: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI, in a rare papal acquiescence to protest, has canceled a speech at the prestigious Sapienza University here amid opposition by professors and students who say he is hostile to science.

headline: Isaac Mizrahi Leaves Target to Revamp Liz Claiborne
text: Isaac Mizrahi, the cheap-chic designer who helped create the image of Target as a style destination, defected from the retailer on Tuesday to a more ambitious, and lucrative, role of making over the struggling Liz Claiborne label.

headline: Knicks Rarity: Two Victories in a Row
text: All this winning at Madison Square Garden is beginning to feel a little monotonous. The Knicks followed their victory two nights earlier by beating the Washington Wizards on Tuesday night, 105-93. For those keeping count, that is two wins in two games.

headline: Solving a Riddle Wrapped in a Mystery Inside a Cookie
text: Some 3 billion fortune cookies are made each year, almost all in the United States. But the crisp cookies wrapped around enigmatic sayings have spread around the world. They are served in Chinese restaurants in Britain, Mexico, Italy, France and elsewhere. In India, they taste more like butter cookies. A surprisingly high number of winning tickets in Brazil's national lottery in 2004 were traced to lucky numbers from fortune cookies distributed by a Chinese restaurant chain called Chinatown.

headline: Returning to Tour After Long Detour
text: PALM DESERT, Calif.  To reach this sun-soaked valley in the desert for the first Bob Hope Chrysler Classic of his career, Todd Demsey, 35, flew six and a half hours on a red-eye from Honolulu to Phoenix on Sunday night, drove his R.V. 287 miles across I-10 from Phoenix to an R.V. park on Monday, then drove his courtesy car the remaining few miles to the Classic Club on Tuesday.

headline: Spies, Blonde and a Guy Go North by Northwest
text: It’s all too easy to identify with Richard Hannay as he first appears in “The 39 Steps,” the absurdly enjoyable, gleefully theatrical riff on Alfred Hitchcock’s 1935 film. True, the odds are that you’re not as deeply, fatuously handsome as Richard (Charles Edwards), or as square of jaw, clipped of diction or cocked of eyebrow.

headline: Belgium: Copyright Violation Is Claimed
text: Belgian newspapers, emboldened by a court victory against Google last year, have started a preliminary copyright action against the European Commission over links on agency Web sites. Two Web sites owned by the commission, the Brussels-based executive for the 27 European Union nations, infringe copyright laws by linking to Belgian newspaper articles free, according to Copiepresse, a copyright group for French- and German-language newspapers. A Brussels court, asked by the group to look at its claim, appointed an expert to study how information is gathered for the E.U. sites. “Once the expert has submitted his report, we may decide to file a lawsuit,” said Margaret Boribon, the group’s secretary general. A Brussels court in February ruled Google had violated Belgian copyright laws by publishing links to the newspapers without permission and ordered the company to remove the links or pay a daily fine of 25,000 euros ($37,000).

headline: In New Jersey, School Chief Appointed to Flagging District Quits
text: Michael E. Glascoe, the state-appointed superintendent of the Paterson Public Schools, said on Tuesday that he would step down in July because he did not have the “complete trust and support” of New Jersey’s education commissioner, Lucille E. Davy.

headline: Blue-Ribbon Beer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Footnotes
text: The pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim has won the Royal Philharmonic Society Gold Medal for outstanding musicianship. Mr. Barenboim will receive the medal at Royal Festival Hall in London on Jan. 28. ... Zaha Hadid Architects of London has been named the winner of the design competition for the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University in East Lansing. ... From the estate of the hotelier Leona Helmsley, Impressionist and modern art, Old Master Paintings, Russian art, Chinese art and furniture and silver will be auctioned in 15 sales beginning on Thursday at Christie’s New York in Rockefeller Center. Net proceeds are to benefit the Leona M. and Harry B. Helmsley Charitable Trust. ... The Lebanese singer Mika, the boy band Take That and the reality television star Leona Lewis led the way with four nominations each when the shortlist for the Brit Awards, Britain’s version of the Grammys, was announced on Monday.

headline: More House Salads, Whether the House Likes It or Not
text: Washington

headline: The Other Nano
text: What do a ’73 Volkswagen Bug, a navigation system on a new Jaguar and a brand new Nano sedan have in common? Two things: they cost about $2,500 and involve the Indian entrepreneur Ratan Tata.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Judge Scolds Simpson but Allows Bail
text: Las Vegas  Five days after being returned to custody for attempting contact with a co-defendant in his armed-robbery case, O.J. Simpson received a tongue-lashing from a judge Wednesday and then a higher bail with stricter rules for his release.

headline: Citigroup Loss Raises Anxiety Over Economy
text: Citigroup, the nation’s largest bank, reported a staggering fourth-quarter loss of $9.83 billion on Tuesday and issued a sobering forecast that the housing market and the broader economy still had not bottomed out.

headline: Correction: Calendar
text: Because of an editing error, a calendar listing last Wednesday about a class on American whiskey followed by a dinner with whiskey cocktails at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y., misstated the date. It will be held Thursday; it did not take place last Thursday.

headline: Short on Fund-Raising, Red Cross Will Cut Jobs
text: Facing a $200 million operating deficit, the American Red Cross is preparing to cut as much as one-third of its headquarters staff, up to 1,000 employees, and pare regional management.

headline: Bernanke Is Said to Support Stimulus Measures
text: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has told members of Congress that he can support tax cuts or spending measures to stimulate the economy, even if they temporarily increase the budget deficit, as long as the measures are quick and temporary.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Tuesday about the challenge facing Barack Obama as he pursues Latino voters in his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination misidentified, in some editions, the former mayor of Los Angeles who defeated Antonio R. Villaraigosa for the post in 2001 and lost to him in a 2005 rematch. He is James Hahn  not Kenneth Hahn, who was his father.

headline: In an Eclectic Concert Series, a Meeting of Rock and Classical Composers
text: With all the fuss over Radiohead’s new “In Rainbows” album, with its pay-what-you-want downloading policy in the fall, and its CD version topping the charts last week, fans of the band might miss another significant milestone for the group, or at least for one of its players. On Wednesday and Thursday the innovative, genre-mixing Wordless Music series will present the first American performance of “Popcorn Superhet Receiver,” a 2005 string orchestra work by Jonny Greenwood, Radiohead’s lead guitarist, on a program with music by John Adams and Gavin Bryars.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of a transcription error, an article on Monday about concern over personal safety in the Atlanta area following the killing of a hiker misspelled, in some editions, the name of the town in Georgia where the hiker’s dog and some of her clothing were found. It was Cumming, not Cummings. The article also misidentified the place where a suspect in the killing was apprehended. It was DeKalb County, not Cumming.

headline: Analyst's Role With YES Shifts away From the Studio
text: David Justice, who was cited in the Mitchell report as having purchased human growth hormone, will no longer be a studio analyst for the YES Network but will contribute columns and participate in chats on the channel’s Web site.

headline: 18 Palestinians Killed in Gaza Clashes
text: JERUSALEM  At least 18 Palestinians, including 13 members of the military wing of Hamas, were killed in Gaza early Tuesday by Israeli Army fire, the highest death toll there in half a year.

headline: Recipe: Whole-Grain Pancakes
text: Adapted from Gary Danko

headline: The Supreme Court Club
text: Every year, the Supreme Court hears arguments in cases that can change the nation and reshape American rights. Just last week, it heard arguments on a challenge to a harsh Indiana voter ID law, a partisan scheme to disenfranchise poor and minority voters. It was, like many legal showdowns in the court, something Americans would have been interested in observing firsthand. Yet beyond a few hundred visitors, the public was denied that opportunity because members of the court, stubbornly clinging to their clubby ways, refuse to allow their proceedings to be televised.

headline: Faith, Freedom and Bling in the Middle East
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia

headline: Friendlier Tone, but Plenty of Tough Talk
text: WASHINGTON  There were no baseball players in the Congressional committee room Tuesday, but the greatest slugger and pitcher of the era were not far from anyone’s mind during a four-hour hearing on the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: A Wine Spree Worth Savoring
text: I WAS sitting at my desk in Paris one day in 1988 when the phone rang. It was Jean-Claude Vrinat, the owner and director of Taillevent, the famed Paris restaurant, who died of cancer last week at the age of 71.

headline: Don Cardwell, 72, Pitcher for 1969 Mets, Is Dead
text: Don Cardwell, a right-handed pitcher who helped propel the Mets to their stunning 1969 World Series championship as he neared the end of a long major league career, died Monday in Winston-Salem, N.C. Cardwell, who lived in Clemmons, N.C., was 72.

headline: Boeing Delays Dreamliner Again
text: CHICAGO  Boeing announced on Wednesday that it was delaying the first flight and deliveries of the 787 Dreamliner because of continued supply-chain problems.

headline: Justice Dept. Cites Obstacles in Blackwater Case
text: WASHINGTON  Justice Department officials have told Congress that they face serious legal difficulties in pursuing criminal prosecutions of Blackwater security guards involved in a September shooting that left at least 17 Iraqis dead.

headline: A Campaign With Echoes From 1968
text: Jesse Epps will be in New York on Thursday afternoon to speak about the future, carrying a credential from history.

headline: In the Czech Republic, a Green Castle
text: MCELY, Czech Republic

headline: War on Allergies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Belichick Sells Patriots on Opponent’s Strengths
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Out in San Diego, at least one player, swimming in the giddiness of the Chargers’ upset of the Indianapolis Colts, thinks the New England Patriots are more worried about having to play the Chargers in Sunday’s A.F.C. championship game than the Chargers are concerned about the undefeated Patriots.

headline: Pennsylvania: Egyptian Released
text: The government released Sameh Khouzam, an Egyptian citizen, from a Pennsylvania prison after a federal judge ruled last week that the United States could not deport him to Egypt. The Egyptian government said Mr. Khouzam was convicted of murder in absentia. But Mr. Khouzam, a Coptic Christian, has maintained his innocence and has said he was tortured in Egypt because he refused to convert to Islam. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials said the United States had received confidential assurances from Egypt that Mr. Khouzam would not be tortured upon his return. But a federal judge ruled that the government could not rely on secret assurances that could not be independently reviewed to deport Mr. Khouzam. The government was granted a short stay on Mr. Khouzam’s release, which elapsed Tuesday, and it then sought an emergency stay of his release from the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, which was denied on Monday.

headline: Justice Department Asked to Investigate Tejada
text: The House committee holding hearings into baseball and steroids promised an early news nugget, and it delivered: The committee formally asked the Department of Justice to investigate the star shortstop Miguel Tejada on the suspicion that he made false statements to the committee nearly three years ago.

headline: Wrangling Over Stimulus Is One-Sided So Far
text: WASHINGTON  The economy needs stimulating  on that much, at least, Congressional Democrats agree. But from there, things get complicated.

headline: A Pair of Rebels Are at It Again
text: THERE are rules by which a vigilant diner lives. There are dictums of common sense.

headline: Bloomberg Chooses a Friend to Manage His Fortune
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has chosen the firm of a longtime friend, Steven Rattner, a financier who moves among New York’s power elite, to manage the investments of his multibillion-dollar fortune.

headline: That Masked Man Is Always in Goal
text: Buffalo Sabres goaltender Ryan Miller girded for a heavier workload this season, and Lindy Ruff, his coach, has had no choice but to take advantage. Miller played 20 games in a row before Ruff sat him down for a game Thursday in Ottawa.

headline: Bill Proposes Database of Offenders to Aid Dating
text: LOS ANGELES  Web sites that promise to give the dirt on prospective dates abound. A guy has a roving eye? Look him up on DontDateHimGirl.com.

headline: At Auto Show, Chinese Are Sidelined but Not Ignored
text: DETROIT  The basement of Cobo Center, where newcomers to the Detroit auto show are relegated, is drawing bigger crowds than usual this year.

headline: Rice, in Baghdad, Praises New Law
text: BAGHDAD  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made a surprise visit to Iraq on Tuesday to brief Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and other top politicians about President Bush’s recent talks with Arab leaders and to praise recent legislative progress.

headline: The Truth About Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Suspect Charged in Death of a Woman Who Vanished in Florida
text: A 32-year-old man who the police believe had been living in his car was arrested on Tuesday on charges that he murdered a young Brooklyn woman who disappeared last spring while on vacation in Florida, the authorities said.

headline: A Classic Series, Retooled and Swingin’
text: IN 1967, when the cartoon series “George of the Jungle” was introduced, cigarette commercials still ran on TV, DVD meant Dick Van Dyke and video was a word in the titles of series like “Captain Video” and “Video Village.”

headline: A Quick Fix for Electronic Voting
text: When Americans go to the polls in November, many will likely have to cast their ballots on unreliable paperless electronic voting machines. If the election is close, the country could end up with a rerun of 2000’s bitterly contentious and mistrusted count. In an effort to avoid another such disaster, Representative Rush Holt, Democrat of New Jersey, plans to introduce a bill this week that would help address the weaknesses in electronic voting. Congress should pass it without delay.

headline: Rice Makes Unannounced Visit to Baghdad
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice flew to Baghdad on Tuesday, peeling off during a trip to the region by President Bush to give momentum to legislative and political reconciliation in Iraq, the White House said.

headline: High-Tech Guns
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Immigrant With a Tough Job and an Easy Smile
text: From the stylish streets of SoHo, where he labored on the rising frame of the newest condo hotel to bear the Trump name, to the modest three-story brick walk-up in Greenpoint where the sounds of his early departure for work served as a virtual alarm clock for his landlady, Yuriy Vanchytskyy was remembered on Tuesday as a reliable, hard-working and cheerful presence.

headline: The Meat of the Matter in a Pasta Debate
text: FOR a simple dish, pasta all’amatriciana is freighted with controversy.

headline: A Tool to Stimulate the Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Enhancing Its Hits, Apple Adds Movie Rentals, Ultralight Laptop
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, took several big gambles Tuesday, betting that he could repeat his success in selling digital music by persuading Hollywood to allow Apple to rent digital movies, while at the same time returning to his original Macintosh roots with an elegant  but limited  ultralight computer called the MacBook Air.

headline: Deal on Dams on Klamath Advances
text: Bitter opponents over the future of the Klamath River unveiled a formal agreement on Tuesday to pave the way for removal of four aging hydroelectric dams that re-engineered the watershed and sharply decreased fish stocks.

headline: A Broadway Producer Is Bringing Back Drama
text: Jeffrey Richards’s office, a space crowded with show posters, old marquee signs and two dogs walking around wearing souvenir T-shirts, is downstairs from his apartment and 18 blocks from where he grew up. With the exception of four years away at college, Mr. Richards, a press agent turned Broadway producer, has lived and worked his whole life within shouting distance of the theater district.

headline: JPMorgan Joins Banks in Write-Downs
text: JPMorgan Chase said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter net income dropped 34 percent as problems stemming from the housing market downturn widened in both its investment banking and consumer businesses.

headline: Interest Fades in the Once-Mighty V-8
text: DETROIT  The V-8 engine, long a symbol of power for American car companies, is sputtering.

headline: Chefs’ New Goal: Looking Dinner in the Eye
text: LAST Friday, in front of 4 million television viewers and a studio audience, the chef Jamie Oliver killed a chicken. Having recently obtained a United Kingdom slaughterman’s license, Mr. Oliver staged a “gala dinner,” in fact a kind of avian snuff film, to awaken British consumers to the high costs of cheap chicken.

headline: Female Business Owners Fault New Rules on U.S. Contracts
text: Women who own small businesses  about a third of all small businesses in the United States, in fact  have been pushing for years for a bigger piece of government contracts, which now total $400 billion a year.

headline: NBC's Deal Delivers
text: Facing some strong competition in prime time on Monday, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” and “American Gladiators” managed to rank No. 1 and No. 2 in the night’s ratings. Nielsen estimated that “Deal or No Deal” delivered the largest audience overall, 15 million viewers at 9 p.m., while “American Gladiators” at 8 drew a less impressive 10.7 million viewers. Among adults 18 to 49, however, the two shows outpaced all other programming on the night, including Fox’s “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” at 9 p.m. That show, which made its premiere on Sunday to 18.4 million viewers, declined in the ratings substantially with its second showing, attracting just 10.1 million while matching the 10 p.m. leader, CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (14.7 million), for the third highest ratings on the night among the 18-to-49 set. Fox ranked second for the night in that demographic but third in total viewers behind both NBC and CBS, which broadcast repeats of its comedy lineup from 8 to 10. ABC was fourth over all, faring better earlier in the night with “Dance War” from 8 to 9:30 (10.5 million) but struggling later on with “Notes From the Underbelly” at 9:30 (4.8 million) and “October Road” at 10 (4.9 million).

headline: Many Violations for Employer of Worker Who Died in a Fall
text: A contractor involved in Monday’s fatal construction accident in SoHo has a history of safety violations at projects in Manhattan and has been fined tens of thousands of dollars in penalties, according to federal records.

headline: Inflation Continues to Edge Up
text: Investors clamoring for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates had two reasons to smile on Wednesday: inflation rose only slightly in December and business activity slowed, according to separate government reports.

headline: New Genetic Risks for Prostate Cancer Identified
text: A combination of common and minor variations in five regions of DNA can help predict a man’s risk of getting prostate cancer, researchers are reporting today.

headline: Investors Show a Deepening Pessimism
text: The stock market fell sharply to its lowest level in nearly a year Tuesday after Citigroup announced a large quarterly loss and an economic report offered more evidence that consumers were cutting back.

headline: Britain: Inflation Exceeds Bank’s Target
text: Inflation in Britain was above the Bank of England’s 2 percent target for a third month in December, adding to the case for fewer interest rate cuts this year. Consumer prices rose 2.1 percent from a year earlier, the same as in November, the Office for National Statistics said.

headline: What You Get for... $600,000
text: Newport, R.I.

headline: Atlantic City: Embattled Casino to Rehire 150 Employees
text: Acknowledging that it had made major mistakes that drastically hurt its business, the Tropicana Casino and Resort said on Tuesday that it planned to rehire 150 workers and begin a major advertising campaign to improve its reputation. The casino is struggling to recover from a year in which the former owners, the Kentucky-based Columbia Sussex Corporation, eliminated 900 jobs and alienated customers with poor service and housekeeping. Those problems led the state’s Casino Control Commission to strip Columbia Sussex of its casino license in December, and the state is seeking a buyer for the property, which includes New Jersey’s largest hotel, with 2,129 rooms.

headline: A Pianist Plays Middleman for Two Composers Who Spoke in Different Voices
text: Listeners could forget about thematic unity at Radu Lupu’s Carnegie Hall recital on Monday night. A sold-out house heard Schubert’s Piano Sonata in D (D. 850) before intermission and Debussy’s first book of “Préludes” after it. The Schubert represents the composer’s strenuous efforts to be big-time in the manner of Beethoven. The Debussy is a series of scenes painted by a master.

headline: Baseball Is Challenged on Rise in Stimulant Use
text: WASHINGTON  When George J. Mitchell was appointed to investigate the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball nearly two years ago, amphetamines were not part of his mandate. The substances had been around baseball for decades, were sometimes winked at and were not even banned until the 2006 season, several years after the sport began to address what seemed to be the far larger controversy of steroid use.

headline: Clues Offered in Search for Student
text: HOUSTON  A month after a Rice University student vanished with his car after withdrawing $500 from a bank machine, school officials on Tuesday disclosed information suggesting the disappearance might have been planned.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about the filing of murder charges against a Staten Island man in the death of his 3-week-old daughter misidentified the current Staten Island district attorney. He is Daniel M. Donovan Jr.  not William L. Murphy, who was the previous district attorney.

headline: Buddy, Can You Spare a Billion?
text: First hard-pressed Wall Street banks turned to rich foreign governments for help. Now, they are seeking aid from the likes of New Jersey and big mutual funds to bolster their weakened finances.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about the filing of murder charges against a Staten Island man in the death of his 3-week-old daughter misidentified the current Staten Island district attorney. He is Daniel M. Donovan Jr.  not William L. Murphy, who was the previous district attorney. (Go to Article)

headline: U.N. Chief Calls for Constructive Dialogue Among Cultures
text: MADRID  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon appealed Tuesday for global dialogue to fight terrorism, though he conceded that there was no quick way to eliminate the Islamist terror threat.

headline: At African Tournament, Goalkeeper Is One of a Kind
text: His teammates on Senegal’s national team call him the American.

headline: New Jersey Transit from Penn Station to Metropark, N.J.
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: 9 Jewish Leaders Say E-Mail Spread Lies About Obama
text: The leaders of nine Jewish groups released an open letter on Tuesday condemning what they called “hateful e-mails” that they said spread lies about Senator Barack Obama’s religious beliefs and his intentions.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the status of reality television shows affected by the writers’ strike referred incorrectly to the competition faced by the NBC show “Celebrity Apprentice” in its debut on Jan. 3. While its ratings that night were the strongest for the series since 2005, it was not until the next week, on Jan. 10, that the show faced “stiff competition” from original episodes of “C.S.I.” on CBS and “Grey’s Anatomy” on ABC. On Jan. 3, both of those shows were repeats.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $6,607,383

headline: Long Robust, Gains in New York City Property Values Start to Flatten Out
text: The robust growth in real estate values in New York, a trend that helped fuel years of record budget surpluses and city spending, has nearly skidded to a halt, city officials said Tuesday, and that shift could bring new pressure on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to raise taxes.

headline: Nearly 12 Years Old, ‘Rent’ Is to Close
text: Nine hundred thirty thousand, one hundred eighty minutes.

headline: Unrest, a Love Triangle and Swinging Hips
text: A colorful and confounding head trip, “Opera Jawa” is guaranteed to test the fortitude of all but the most adventurous viewer.

headline: Michigan, Hearing Promise of Revival, Returns the Favor
text: SOUTHFIELD, Mich.  At the end of Mitt Romney’s victory speech here on Tuesday night, he donned the mantle he had worn for the last week while campaigning to salvage his presidential candidacy  that of native son.

headline: A Fine Day for Giants and Barolos
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

headline: Out of the Icebox, the N.F.L. Caught Fire
text: It was the day before New Year’s Eve, and New Yorkers were leaving the city in droves. Not to escape Times Square celebrations, but to watch the N.F.L. championship game.

headline: Hyperion Editor Leaving for Internet
text: Will Schwalbe is stepping down as editor in chief of Hyperion Books on Jan. 25 to pursue an unspecified Internet-related project. Mr. Schwalbe, who was at Hyperion for 11 years  seven of them as editor in chief  is also the author, with David Shipley, deputy editorial page editor at The New York Times, of “Send: The Essential Guide to Email for Office and Home.” “I’m really just incredibly excited by what is out there in new media,” Mr. Schwalbe said. “I’ve had some thoughts that I want to test and see if I can put them into practice.” Mr. Schwalbe’s shepherded authors included David Halberstam; Chris Anderson, the editor of Wired magazine; and the chef Jamie Oliver.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: Queens: One Dead in House Fire
text: One person was killed in a fire at 89-03 91st Avenue in Woodhaven on Tuesday, the police said. The fire, on the second floor of a single-family house, was reported just after 4 p.m., the Fire Department said. Sixty firefighters responded and had the fire under control by 4:36 p.m., the department said. The victim was identified as Stephen Korovich, 51. The police said there was no indication of foul play, and the cause of the fire was under investigation on Tuesday.

headline: In Baseball, Fear Bats at the Top of the Order
text: Chicago

headline: Recipe: Seared Pork Chops With Kimchi
text: Time: 30 minutes plus 30 minutes to 24 hours’ refrigeration

headline: Worry in Michigan as Forests Change Hands
text: MARQUETTE, Mich.  Last summer, as land and housing values crumbled in much of Michigan, Northern Michigan Land Brokers and a group of investors completed a $7.3 million deal to buy 7,300 acres of forest and undeveloped land  80 parcels in all  along several rivers in the Upper Peninsula.

headline: South Korea: L.C.D. Sales Help Samsung’s Profit
text: Samsung Electronics, the semiconductor and flat-screen maker, posted a smaller drop in fourth-quarter profit than analysts estimated as liquid-crystal display earnings countered a decline in chip prices. Net income fell 6.6 percent, to 2.21 trillion won ($2.4 billion), from 2.37 trillion won in the period a year earlier, the company said. Profit exceeded analysts’ estimate of 1.95 trillion won.

headline: Driver Abandons Child After Chase
text: When a car chase on Long Island ended in an accident on Tuesday night, the driver tried to flee on foot, leaving a toddler strapped in the back seat, the police said.

headline: A Queens High School With 3,600 Students, and Room for Just 1,800
text: From its brass entry doors to its rooftop observatory to the intricate oak paneling of the principal’s office, Richmond Hill High School in Queens was built to inspire something like awe for public education. The only discordant response during the structure’s dedication in 1923 was whether, with a capacity for 1,800 students, it was too large.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The TV Sports column on Tuesday, about the impact of frigid weather on the N.F.L. playoffs, misidentified the position that Forrest Gregg played in the so-called Ice Bowl of 1967 in Green Bay. It was offensive tackle  not guard, a position he occasionally played.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Nov. 2 about Col. Aleksandr Feklisov, a Soviet spy, misspelled the surname of the Soviet prime minister for whom Mr. Feklisov handled security for a 1959 visit to the United States. He was Nikita Khrushchev, not Krushchev. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message last week.

headline: Indian Leader in China Urges Closer Ties
text: BEIJING  Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India on Tuesday described an ascendant Asia in which India and China had a special opportunity to overcome historic hostilities, promote regional development and collaborate on concerns about energy, water supplies and food.

headline: Cholesterol Drug Bombs
text: There have long been suspicions, but it was still very disturbing to learn this week that a heavily promoted cholesterol-lowering drug had flunked a clinical trial of its effectiveness in reducing fatty deposits in arteries. The two companies that reap billions from the drug had been cynically sitting on the results for more than a year.

headline: A Library Exhibition Not for the Children’s Room
text: PARIS  The lighting is bordello red, but the librarians insist that their X-rated exhibition is serious.

headline: Spring Training and the Syringe Generation
text: Washington

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on May 19 about Karen Hess, a food historian, gave an incorrect account of the career of her husband, John, and misidentified the city in which they met. He was a merchant marine and a journalist, but never a longshoreman. They met in Salt Lake City, where he was working as a reporter, not in San Francisco. The errors were pointed out in an e-mail message from the family last month.

headline: Obama and Clinton Seek a Softer Tone
text: LAS VEGAS  A Democratic presidential debate unfolded with an exchange of pleasantries and acts of contrition among rivals on Tuesday as Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama promised to dispel a rancorous feud over race and gender that had threatened to divide the party and alienate voters.

headline: F.D.A. Says Food From Cloned Animals Is Safe
text: After years of debate, the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday declared that food from cloned animals and their progeny is safe to eat, clearing the way for milk and meat derived from genetic copies of prized dairy cows, steers and hogs to be sold at the grocery store.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 3 about an announcement by the Suffolk County, N.Y., district attorney that he would not retry Martin Tankleff in the 1988 murders of his parents after his conviction was overturned by a state appellate court misquoted, in some copies, Judge Stephen Braslow of Suffolk County Court, who had refused Mr. Tankleff’s appeal, in which he cited new evidence and new witnesses. Judge Braslow called the new witnesses “a cavalcade of nefarious scoundrels”  not “characters.” (The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 22 about the voiding of the conviction and on Dec. 28 about Mr. Tankleff’s release.) The Jan. 3 article also misstated, in some copies, the length of time Mr. Tankleff was interrogated by the police and the timing of hearings before Judge Braslow. Mr. Tankleff was interrogated for about seven hours, not 18, and the hearings took place in 2004 and 2005, not last year.

headline: Albany: Bailout for Long Island School District
text: The State Assembly and Senate passed legislation on Tuesday authorizing an $8 million bailout of the 2,800-student Roosevelt school system in Nassau County. The legislation provides a one-time state grant of $8 million to the district, the only school system ever placed under state control, to settle a debt that had threatened to create a fiscal crisis. The legislation also doubles the amount of an annual state grant to the district for academic improvement, to $12 million from $6 million. The money will allow the district to raise its per-pupil spending. The legislation will now go to Gov. Eliot Spitzer for approval.

headline: High School Musical Role Reprisals
text: All the stars will be back again when “High School Musical” makes the jump from the Disney Channel to the big screen, Reuters reported. Zac Efron, Vanessa Hudgens, Ashley Tisdale, Lucas Grabeel, Corbin Bleu and Monique Coleman, seen in the hit “High School Musical” (2006) and its sequel, are confirmed to reprise their roles in the movie, “High School Musical 3: Senior Year,” when Troy (Mr. Efron) and Gabriella (Ms. Hudgens) face separation as they go off to college. Once again, Kenny Ortega will direct. The film is to be released in October.

headline: Scorsese's Stones Film to Open Berlin Festival
text: “Shine a Light,” the Rolling Stones concert documentary by Martin Scorsese, right, will open the 58th Berlin International Film Festival on Feb. 7. Mr. Scorsese and the Stones will be in attendance, Paramount Pictures announced. The film, derived from more than half a million feet of concert footage, captures the band in two concerts at the Beacon Theater in New York, on Oct. 29 and Nov. 1, 2006, when guest performances were delivered by Christina Aguilera, Buddy Guy and Jack White of the White Stripes. The film will be released in North America by Paramount Classics on April 4.

headline: Judah Folkman, Researcher, Dies at 74
text: Dr. Judah Folkman, a path-breaking cancer researcher who faced years of skepticism before his ideas led to successful treatments, died Monday in Denver. He was 74.

headline: Volkswagen Corruption Trial Includes Seamy Testimony
text: BRAUNSCHWEIG, Germany  Rarely have so many top auto executives been summoned to talk about something other than cars.

headline: U.S. Dominance in Science at Risk, Report Says
text: The United States remains the world leader in scientific and technological innovation, but its dominance is threatened by economic development elsewhere, particularly in Asia, the National Science Board said on Tuesday in its biennial report on science and engineering.

headline: Justices Back N.Y. Trial Judge System
text: WASHINGTON  Sweeping aside complaints that New York State chooses its trial judges through an antiquated, patronage-tainted system that favors party cronies and gives voters no real say, the United States Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld the state’s unique system.

headline: Bank of America Curbs Investment Banking
text: Bank of America, the banking giant, said on Tuesday that it was scaling back its investment banking operations, shedding an additional 650 jobs after suffering heavy trading losses from bad mortgage investments.

headline: New Troubles for Apartment Mogul in South
text: Michael B. Smuck was one of the leading real estate syndicators in New Orleans in the 1980s until his limited partnerships began unraveling, causing large losses and unleashing years of legal battles with unhappy investors.

headline: Bomb Targets U.S. Car in Beirut
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A bomb exploded next to an American Embassy vehicle on Tuesday, killing at least three civilians and wounding many other people, including an American bystander and an embassy employee, Lebanese and American officials said.

headline: Bush Prods Saudi Arabia on Oil Prices
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  President Bush on Tuesday urged Saudi Arabia and other members of OPEC to consider the strain the high cost of oil was having on the American economy, addressing an issue that has begun to color the last year of his presidency and dominate the presidential election campaign.

headline: In His Own Words
text: Excerpts from remarks to supporters on Tuesday night after winning the Republican primary in Michigan:

headline: Novelist Sells Archive
text: The archives of Cormac McCarthy, below, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, have been bought for $2 million by the Southwestern Writers Collection of Texas State University-San Marcos, The Associated Press reported. The university said the archives included correspondence, notes, drafts and proofs of 11 novels by Mr. McCarthy, 74, who won the Pulitzer for his 2006 novel, “The Road,” and a 1992 National Book Award for “All the Pretty Horses.”

headline: Brad Renfro, Former Child Movie Actor, Dies at 25
text: Brad Renfro, the former child star who played a witness to a mob lawyer’s suicide in the 1994 legal thriller “The Client” and a suburban youth tutored in evil by an elderly Nazi war criminal in the 1998 film “Apt Pupil,” was found dead Tuesday morning in his Los Angeles home. He was 25.

headline: More Delays Expected for Boeing’s Dreamliner
text: CHICAGO  Boeing’s great success in selling its 787 Dreamliner  it has 817 of the fuel-efficient planes on order, valued at more than $100 billion  is turning to a period of frustration.

headline: Romney Seeks New Edge in South Carolina
text: BLUFFTON, S.C.  Fresh from his victory in Michigan, Mitt Romney rolled into South Carolina on Wednesday as he continued to his focus on the economy but also tried to play down expectations of how he would fare in the state’s Republican primary on Saturday. (The Democratic primary here is a week later.)

headline: Airbus Orders Trailed Boeing in 2007
text: TOULOUSE, France  Airbus said on Wednesday that it had secured a record 1,341 orders for new aircraft last year, closely trailing Boeing but surpassing it in terms of deliveries as a surge in demand for air travel drove demand for new planes.

headline: Supreme Court Limits Lawsuits by Shareholders
text: WASHINGTON  Ruling in its most important securities fraud case in years, the Supreme Court on Tuesday placed a towering obstacle in the path of shareholders looking for someone to sue when a stock purchase turns sour.

headline: Music Festival Coming to Liberty State Park
text: In the latest shift in the competition for music fans this summer, the concert promoters behind the popular Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in California will stage a three-day event in Liberty State Park, according to people briefed on the plans. The new festival, tentatively scheduled for Aug. 8 through Aug. 10, is to be presented by the promoter AEG and its Goldenvoice subsidiary. A competing event, the Vineland Music Festival, held by C3 Presents and Festival Republic, a unit of the concert giant Live Nation, is scheduled from Aug. 8 to Aug. 10 in Vineland, N.J. The band Radiohead and the singer-songwriter Jack Johnson have been mentioned as headliners at the Liberty State Park event, though a lineup has not been announced. Representatives for AEG declined to comment.

headline: Coca-Cola Urged to Close an Indian Plant to Save Water
text: NEW DELHI  A leading environmental research group based here has asked Coca-Cola to consider shutting down a bottling plant in the drought-stricken state of Rajasthan, saying that the plant is depleting scarce water supplies.

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Saturday about videotaping police interrogations referred incorrectly to a written confession attributed to Martin Tankleff in the murders of his parents in 1988. He never signed it.

headline: Scoldings, Regrets and Forced Geniality, but Little Fun
text: The Democrats debate in Las Vegas didn’t turn out to be a testy showdown between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama. It was a school intervention for the leaders of the eighth-grade “Mean Girls” clique.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: NEW PLACES

headline: Board Tells States to Look for Bridge Design Flaws
text: WASHINGTON  Acting swiftly on the recommendation of accident investigators, the Federal Highway Administration told state authorities to take a new look at bridges to make sure they do not have the kind of design flaw that doomed the I-35W bridge, which collapsed in Minneapolis last summer.

headline: Library of Congress Settles Scottish Spat
text: Card-catalog classifications hardly seem the subject of trans-Atlantic imbroglios, but the Library of Congress recently settled one when it agreed to reinstate a past policy of classifying works by Scottish authors under the heading “Scottish literature.” Early last year the library started classifying about 600 titles by Scottish writers as “English literature,” with subheadings like “Scottish authors” or “Scottish poets.” That offended the National Library of Scotland, which complained, enlisting the support of an American congressman, Mike McIntyre, Democrat of North Carolina. Early this month, the librarian of Congress, James H. Billington, wrote to the National Library of Scotland and the British Library, informing them that the Scots would get their own catalog distinction. As of now the Library of Congress is still classifying the works of Irish and Welsh writers under subcategories of English literature, but a spokesman, Matt Raymond, said the library has yet to receive any complaints.

headline: Trenton: Corzine Vetoes Change to Wrongful-Death Law
text: Gov. Jon S. Corzine pocket-vetoed a controversial bill on Tuesday that would have expanded the state’s wrongful-death law and allowed families to sue for pain and suffering. The bill had been supported by trial lawyers and victims’ advocates, who argued that under current law, families cannot recover damages when the death of a child, disabled person or retiree could have been prevented. The bill had been opposed by business interests, including the pharmaceutical industry, which argued that liability insurance and property taxes would escalate as a result. In a statement, Mr. Corzine said that he had allowed the bill to expire without signing it because of his concern about “a significant impact on state and local budgets.”

headline: Sun Buying Swedish Software Firm for $1 Billion
text: Sun Microsystems, one of the biggest sellers of open-source software in the United States, said Wednesday that it would spend $1 billion to buy MySQL, a Swedish company that is the world leader in open-source database software used by Internet powers like Google, Yahoo, MySpace and YouTube.

headline: In Complex Times, Turkey Seeks a Reassuring Face
text: ANKARA, Turkey  Looking dapper in a bow tie and a crisp suit, the founder of the Turkish republic, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, stared fiercely into a dark room. He was made of wax and standing in a museum, but for some visitors last week, he might as well have been alive and breathing.

headline: Dusty Cohl, a Toronto Film Festival Founder, Dies at 79
text: Dusty Cohl, a founder of the Toronto International Film Festival, a bellwether for the annual movie awards cycle, died on Friday in Toronto. He was 79 and lived in Toronto.

headline: A Revival of 1992’s Glum Mood
As Jobs Leave Ohio, Many Are Driven to the Edge
text: JACKSON, Ohio  After 30 years at a factory making truck parts, Jeffrey Evans was earning $14.55 an hour in what he called “one of the better-paying jobs in the area.”

headline: Oracle, Sweetening Terms, Buys BEA
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The Oracle Corporation said Wednesday that it would acquire BEA Systems for $8.5 billion, just three months after BEA handily rejected its original unsolicited bid..

headline: Bankrupt Art Dealer Asks to Sell House for Millions
text: An art dealer who filed for bankruptcy last year after his gallery was ordered padlocked by a judge is seeking permission to sell his Upper East Side town house, for up to $25 million. The dealer, Lawrence B. Salander, ran the Salander-O’Reilly Galleries. By the time he filed for bankruptcy in November, complaints were mounting from people who said they had consigned artworks to the gallery but were never paid for them. Some former clients maintained that the gallery had sold their paintings without their permission.

headline: 4 Arrests Made in Kabul Hotel Attack
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Police authorities in Afghanistan have arrested four people in the aftermath of the suicide bomb attack on Monday evening at a Kabul luxury hotel and said Tuesday that three Americans and one Frenchwoman might have been among the six dead.

headline: Kenyan Opposition Wins a Skirmish
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Judging from the opening session of Parliament on Tuesday, it looks like it is going to be a long political year in Kenya.

headline: Iraqi Spending to Rebuild Has Slowed, Report Says
text: Highly promising figures that the administration cited to demonstrate economic progress in Iraq last fall, when Congress was considering whether to continue financing the war, cannot be substantiated by official Iraqi budget records, the Government Accountability Office reported Tuesday.

headline: Calendar
text: The Thirsty Farm

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Dec. 25 about the choreographer Michael Kidd misstated his given name at birth and his birthplace. He was Milton (not Michael) Greenwald, and he was born in Manhattan, not Brooklyn.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,912 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: Oprah Winfrey and Discovery to Create New Cable Network
text: Oprah Winfrey, the daytime talk show host whose media empire also includes a television production company, radio show, magazine, popular Web site and other ventures, will soon be getting her own television network.

headline: If You Want to Observe ’Em, Join ’Em
text: On a hot summer day in 1989, Sudhir Venkatesh, a callow sociology student with a ponytail and tie-dyed T-shirt, walked into one of Chicago’s toughest housing projects, clipboard in hand, ready to ask residents about their lives. Sample question: “How does it feel to be black and poor?” Suggested answers: “very bad, somewhat bad, neither bad nor good, somewhat good, very good.” Actual answers: unprintable.

headline: When Veterans Fight the War Within
text: To the Editor:

headline: Everybody’s a Winner
text: Romney wins: If things keep going this way, John Edwards will win Nevada, Fred Thompson will win South Carolina, Rudy Giuliani will win Florida, and the two parties will have to dig up scores of new candidates to win the remaining states. But despite the murky state of the race on both sides, Portfolio’s Matt Cooper (whose wife, Mandy Grunwald, works for Hillary Clinton) says the economy is becoming the defining issue of the 2008 campaign. At his Portfolio blog, Cooper notes that Romney “dominated the economic vote in Michigan, according to the exit polls.” He writes:

headline: Good Seats Still Available
text: The Patriots announced Tuesday that, believe it or not, they still have some tickets available for Sunday’s A.F.C. championship game. They go on sale this morning, so don’t dawdle. Here’s the release:

headline: Democrats Debate in Nevada
text: The political tone was purposefully gentle on stage at the Cashman Center in Las Vegas.

headline: The Hillary-Tyra Show
text: She already made an appearance this week on “Meet the Press.” And she can’t very well do “Oprah.”

headline: A Holiday Affair in Myrtle Beach
text: The Democrats will again face one another on Monday in a debate sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus Institute in Myrtle Beach, S.C. That happens to be the day celebrated as Martin Luther King’s Birthday. And this happens to be the first time that the South Carolina city will officially recognize the holiday.

headline: Kenya Opposition Plans More Protests
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya was in partial lockdown mode on Wednesday as opposition supporters pressed ahead with plans to hold protests across the country.

headline: Archive Fever
text: Photography, with its extensions in film, video and the digital realm, is the main vehicle for the images in the exhibit "Archive Fever."

headline: That’s the Way the Fortune Cookie Myth Crumbles
text: We hate to burst your bubble, but even though fortune cookies are served in Chinese restaurants around the world, a Japanese researcher says they’re almost certainly originally from Japan (which explains why they’re not found in China):

headline: Latest Flyby Gives New Views of Mercury
text: NASA's Messenger spacecraft has captured a new view of the planet Mercury. During a flyby on Monday, cameras onboard snapped images of the cratered surface that had not been previously observed.

headline: Imitating the Imitators
text: A lot of people try to do impersonations on YouTube. Here’s a guy who goes them one better (found at Digg.com):

headline: Wrong About Risk? Blame Your Brain
text: These days, it’s tough to know what to worry about. Resistant bacteria? Cancer? Global warming?

headline: U.S. Bancorp Earnings Dropped 21% in 4th Quarter
text: U.S. Bancorp said Tuesday that fourth-quarter earnings fell 21 percent, but the Minneapolis-based bank largely avoided the subprime woes that have hurt other major financial institutions.

headline: New Troubles for Apartment Mogul in South
text: Michael B. Smuck was one of the leading real estate syndicators in New Orleans in the 1980s until his limited partnerships began to unravel, causing large losses and unleashing years of legal battles with unhappy investors.

headline: Volkswagen Corruption Trial Includes Seamy Testimony
text: Rarely have so many top auto executives been summoned to talk about something other than cars.

headline: IAC’s Ticketmaster Pays $265 Million for TicketsNow
text: Ticketmaster, the largest seller of sports and concert tickets in the United States, agreed to buy an online reseller, TicketsNow, for $265 million to compete with eBay‘s StubHub.

headline: Facebook Scores New European Investment
text: Facebook has attracted yet another strategic investor, raising millions of euros to fuel its European expansion, from three German brothers who made their fortune building Internet companies.

headline: Northern Rock Investors Reject Hedge Fund Proposals
text: Shareholders in Northern Rock, the ailing British mortgage lender, voted at a special meeting Tuesday against proposals by two hedge funds that would have forced managers to seek shareholder approval for even small asset sales.

headline: Northwest, Continental and the Golden Share
text: As airline merger talks heat up and speculation runs rampant on who will end up with whom, one oft-overlooked detail in the game of musical chairs could add further complications to the expected round of industry consolidation.

headline: Mixed Messages From the BBC
text: By Simon Marks

headline: Founders Equity to Acquire Pay-O-Matic
text: Pay-O-Matic, the check-cashing chain, said Tuesday it had agreed to be acquired by Founders Equity, a private equity firm in New York.

headline: Sun Capital Gets Hostile With Kellwood
text: The Sun Capital Securities Group has gone hostile on Kellwood, owner of the clothing brand Baby Phat.

headline: Centric Rounds Up $14 Million from V.C.’s
text: Centric Software has wrapped up a $14.3 million Series B venture capital financing that will allow it to ramp up its growth and increase market awareness of its technology offerings.

headline: Warburg Takes Lifecore Private in $239 Million Deal
text: Warburg Pincus has signed a deal to take Lifecore Biomedical, a medical device maker, private in a $239 million buyout.

headline: Consortium Launches $588 Million Bid for Ocwen Financial
text: A mortgage servicing firm Ocwen Financial has received an unsolicited $588 million offer to be taken private from an investor group led by its chairman and chief executive, William Erbey, and two private equity firms, it said Tuesday.

headline: Dominion and Equitable Hang Up on Merger Plan
text: The wheels of justice apparently grind too slowly for rival natural gas distributors Dominion Resources and Equitable Resources, which announced Tuesday that they’ve abandoned a merger they announced in 2006.

headline: A Bad Quarter but a Good Year
text: The amount of money flowing into hedge funds slowed during the fourth quarter after some managers suffered big losses from the broadening credit crisis, Hedge Fund Research reported on Tuesday.

headline: Transoma Medical Announces I.P.O. Terms
text: A medical technology company, Transoma Medical, disclosed the expected terms of its proposed initial public offering in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Tuesday.

headline: Swiss Venture Capital Firm Eyes I.P.O.
text: HBM BioVentures, the Swiss biotech and medical-device investor with about $1 billion in net assets, soon expects to go public in a rare move for a venture capital firm.

headline: Citi’s New Mantra: Risk Management
text: Ben Bernanke, meet Gary Crittenden. While you’re easing credit, he is tightening it.

headline: Buddy, Can You Spare a Billion?
text: First hard-pressed Wall Street banks turned to rich foreign governments for help. Now, they are seeking aid from the likes of New Jersey and big mutual funds to bolster their weakened finances.

headline: Exit Strategy
text: Image found here. Location and details not given. Anyone know?

headline: Laura Ashley Raises Stake in British Suit Maker
text: The British fashion and furnishings retailer Laura Ashley raised its stake in a potential takeover target, Moss Brothers, the British men’s fashion retailer, to 5.05 percent, it said on Wednesday.

headline: J.P. Morgan Says Profit Fell in 4th Quarter
text: Though it has held up better than many of its Wall Street peers in recent months,  J.P. Morgan Chase is feeling the subprime pinch. The bank on Wednesday posted a 21 percent decline in net income from continuing operations for the fourth quarter, driven in part by a $1.3 billion write-down on assets tied to mortgage loans.

headline: 'Gang Leader for a Day'
text: Chapter Four

headline: New Owners for Au Bon Pain
text: Au Bon Pain, which runs a chain of bakery cafes, said Wednesday it would sell itself to a private equity firm, LNK Partners, and the restaurant chain’s management as part of a recapitalization that includes a $100 million equity investment from LNK.

headline: BEA Accepts $8.5 Billion Bid From Oracle
text: Oracle said Wednesday that it would finally acquire BEA Systems, an enterprise software maker, for about $8.5 billion in cash.

headline: Carlyle Said to Be in Talks for Booz Allen Unit
text: Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm, is in discussions to sell its government contracting business to the Carlyle Group and several other private equity firms for about $2 billion, people briefed on the discussions told DealBook.

headline: Citigroup Loss Raises Economic Anxiety
text: Citigroup‘s staggering fourth-quarter loss of $9.83 billion and its sobering economic forecast about the housing market are likely to amplify the anxiety of consumers and workers — who are already concerned that the mortgage crisis could plunge the economy into a recession. Adding to worries, the government reported Tuesday that retail sales in December declined for the first time since 2002.

headline: ‘Makes Flipping the Bird Twice as Fun’
text: More of your “late night’ jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Tips on Post Vacation Re-entry
text: I returned from a two-week vacation yesterday, and before I left I promised myself I was going to try to carry my holiday mood with me as I eased back into work. So I did something I thought would help. I wrote my post-vacation entry before I went on vacation. I did it for two reasons: I wanted to make sure I didn’t have a deadline my first day back at work. But I also wanted to come home and read a good post on getting organized again.

headline: Personal Demo
text: Scott Foundas of the LA Weekly hits the mom button on his way to expressing outrage — it’s going around — about the absence of “4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days” in this year’s Oscar race for foreign film.

headline: Ambac to Cut Dividend and Replace C.E.O.
text: As bond insurers continue to suffer from subprime-related mistakes, one of the largest, Ambac Financial Group, said it would raise at least $1 billion in capital and replace its chief executive.

headline: The Early Word: G.O.P. Shuffle
text: Three contests down, three G.O.P. winners.

headline: Gimme Some Sugar
text: The Reeler is already on the case at Sundance, talking with the director Ryan Fleck, who knows his way around both Sundance and the Oscars, the two poles of the Bagger’s current universe. Stu VanAirsdale talks with the director of “Half Nelson” about “Sugar,” his latest film. It tells the tale of a minor league baseball player from the Dominican Republic whose field of dreams ends up being a corn field in Iowa.

headline: Food Stuff

headline: Waiving Common Sense?

headline: AWYM

He saw “The Savages,” but missed “Once.” He showed up late for overcommitted movies and spent too many hours at parties full of the same vacant eyed twits that L.A. and N.Y.C. are lousy with.

headline: Taxes and revenues — another history lesson

headline: Snow Blind

Having just checked the forecast, the Bagger thought it would be good to head up a day early and lay down some tracks in the fantastic powder at Alta pursuit of great stories for the Little Shop of Horrors.

headline: Yanks Struggling Abroad
text: At the start of the English Premier League Season, there were a total of 11 American players on the first-team rosters of six different clubs. That’s an impressive figure — enough for a full starting side, if you could start three goalkeepers — in arguably the best (or at least the most exciting) league in the world.

headline: Flat Housing Market Adds to Tax Pressure
text: The robust growth in real estate values in New York, a trend that helped fuel years of record budget surpluses and city spending, has nearly skidded to a halt, and that shift could bring new pressure on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to raise taxes, Diane Cardwell and Ray Rivera report. The city estimates that when it conducts its annual valuation of all property in the city in May, it will be just 1.44 percent more than the last assessment, the smallest gain since the beginning of the Bloomberg administration. In recent years, the city seemed insulated from dips in the national real estate market, posting several double-digit gains, including an 18 percent increase in values last year. But now, according to data from the tentative annual assessment roll, which will largely determine taxes for the fiscal year beginning in July, declining values of small homes outside Manhattan are pulling down the overall market as the effects of the country’s mortgage trouble take hold.

headline: The Background on Blue Ribbon
text: In my telephone conversations with the Bromberg brothers over recent days, as I fact-checked this week’s review on the newest Blue Ribbon restaurant, I was reminded of the background of the Blue Ribbon brood, a background that’s pretty interesting. There wasn’t enough space in the review to share much of it.

headline: The Endless Fear of Terrorism
text: I’ve written about weather alarmism and terrorphobia as examples of availability cascades, but there’s an important distinction between these cascades. The environmentalists promoting fear of climate change sometimes use dubious tactics in exploiting images like Hurricane Katrina, but they can legitimately point to longer trends showing that the planet has warmed and is projected to warm further, affecting everyone on Earth.

headline: Study Finds Changes in Who Uses Food Stamps

headline: In Istanbul, an Electrifying Exhibit
text: Not too long ago, the shores of the Golden Horn, a waterway linked to the mighty Bosporus and the Marmara Sea, seemed downright derelict in parts. Few visitors included it on their itineraries and those who did made a beeline to the Pierre Loti Cafe high in the hills. Those on longer stays might eventually have added the Rami Koç Museum of Industry or the kitschy wonder known as Miniaturk.

headline: Hospitals See Rise in Flu-Related Visits
text: “Something’s going around.” The statement — a staple of water-cooler conversation and cubicle chitchat — appears to be grounded in truth, for the moment. The average daily number of flu-related emergency room visits increased by 19 percent from November to last week, the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced today. This is separate from the novovirus, or stomach flu, that the department warned about last month.

headline: The White House and the Whales

headline: Meet Lala Guimarães
text: Name: Lala GuimarãesHome base: Rio de JaneiroAge: 57Occupation: Public relationsRetail standbys: Osklen for everything, especially long dresses and accessories; Lenny for pre-, post- and during the beach. It’s not that difficult to make a bikini, but she takes it to another level of sophistication.Provisions: My health is really important to me, so Zona Sul for the freshest organic vegetables and fruits.Escape route: Buzios. It has all different kinds of beaches: rocky, sandy, surfy, big, small. It’s very close to Rio, so it’s easy to get to, and once you’re there it’s magical.Party central: Londra at the Fasano. The décor is very dark and British, like an old club or library. The walls are decorated with old album covers, from bands like the Who and the Rolling Stones.Cocktail: Water.Restaurant: Fasano Al Mare . The food and service are excellent, but more importantly it’s in front of the sea, which is rare for restaurants in Rio.Bookshop: Livraria Travessa. They have a huge variety and you can find most anything you need or want in one location.Flip-flops: Havaianas. I collect them. They’re very democratic shoes. Whether it’s the working class, or those who live in the favelas or those with money, everybody has them. I love them because you can wear them to a party and no one bats an eye.

headline: Forced Rectal Exam Stirs Ethics Questions
text: Under what circumstances can a patient in an emergency room be forced to submit to a procedure that doctors deem to be medically necessary? That question — and the notion of informed consent — is at the heart of a civil case that is about to go to trial in March in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.Brian Persaud, a 38-year-old construction worker who lives in Brooklyn, asserts that he was forced to undergo a rectal examination after sustaining a head injury in an on-the-job accident at a Midtown construction site on May 20, 2003. Mr. Persaud was taken to the emergency room at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, where he received eight stitches to his head.

headline: For The Moment | Francesco Vezzoli
text: This week’s guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like “Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal’s Caligula,” starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandello’s “Right You Are (If You Think You Are),” starring — among others — Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his third post of the week he writes about the actress Monica Vitti. To read all of Francesco Vezzoli’s prior blog posts, click here.

headline: A Home for the 9/11 ‘Survivors’ Stairway’
text: With the new World Trade Center rising clamorously around it, the last standing vestige of the old World Trade Center is about to be uprooted. In the last week, workers have cut openings into a concrete superstructure supporting 38 steps that once led from Vesey Street up to the north end of the sprawling Austin J. Tobin Plaza. Because hundreds of evacuees made their way down this route on Sept. 11, 2001, it is called the “survivors’ stairway.”

headline: A Brigade of Grannies on Fifth Avenue
text: An activist group, Grandmothers Against the War, held a mock funeral procession this afternoon from the Times Square Armed Forces Recruiting Center to Rockefeller Center to protest the war in Iraq. The group has been holding weekly antiwar vigils for four years. Its founder, Joan Wile, is one of 18 women — all grandmothers — who were arrested in 2005 for trying to enter the recruiting station. They were acquitted of disorderly-conduct charges after a six-day trial. The protest today occurred without incident.
