text: A. O. Scott reviews "Summer Palace," a film directed by Ye Lou about life before and after the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.

headline: Congressmen Push for Paper Ballots
text: Both New Hampshire primary elections are going to be recounted, since Dennis J. Kucinich has put up $27,000 to get the Democratic recount started, and Albert Howard (who was on the New Hampshire Republican ballot) has donated $56,000 to re-tally the Republican vote.

headline: Too Much Apple for New York?
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: BET Founder Apologizes to Obama
text: It would be completely accurate to begin this way:

headline: More From Snowy Green Bay
text: Packers receiver Shaun Bodiford spent part of his adolescence homeless. Sometimes, he lived with friends. Other times, he slept on the ground on the streets of Seattle’s rough-and-tumble Central District, or closer to the home he left in Federal Way.

headline: Directors Guild Reaches Deal With Studios
text: “After months of informal discussions, Hollywood’s movie and television directors tentatively agreed Thursday afternoon to a new contract with production companies, while sending a none-too-subtle message to striking screenwriters: This is not the time to get hung up on new media,” Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Moral Minority
text: Does Mike Huckabee’s post-Iowa flameout (so far) demonstrate that the religious right does not dominate the Republican Party?

headline: Court Strikes Down Pedicab Licensing Plan
text: In a case that has exposed the division between owners and drivers in the pedicab industry, a state judge in Manhattan has struck down the system the city planned to use to distribute 325 licenses to operate the human-powered vehicles. The city said that it planned to appeal the decision. The legal dispute is another wrinkle in the city’s long-standing effort to regulate the pedicab industry for the first time.

headline: Phil Hughes Starts a Blog
text: When I covered the Yankees in 2003, a grim daily task was to check David Wells’ old Web site to see if he ripped anybody. Wells could be hostile to the news media (he’s the only athlete who has ever answered my question with a burp), and he used his site to air his unfiltered thoughts.

headline: Soft Serve | A News Feed of Light Reading
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.

headline: Strike: Writers Looking At the Fine Print
text: Updated, 6:59 p.m. | As the industry rushed to interpret the Directors Guild of America’s deal with the studios, the Writers Guild of America said it would carefully evaluate the terms of the agreement:

headline: Striking Similarity
text: Joke told Wednesday night by David Letterman, who has settled with striking writers:

headline: Week of Family Follies, From bin Laden to Bhutto
text: This week, the descendants of several world figures turned up in the headlines facing challenges of varying levels of seriousness. Here’s a quick round-up.

headline: For the Moment |  Francesco Vezzoli
text: This week’s guest blogger is the Milan-based artist and satirist Francesco Vezzoli. Over the past decade, the diva-and-Prada-obsessed Vezzoli, 36, has at once defiled and genuflected at the altar of celebrity. His campy oeuvre includes everything from needlework portraits of Maria Callas and Anna Magnani to films like “Trailer for a Remake of Gore Vidal’s Caligula,” starring Helen Mirren and Courtney Love, and live performances like Pirandello’s “Right You Are (If You Think You Are),” starring — among others — Cate Blanchett, Natalie Portman and Abigail Breslin, which he produced at the Guggenheim last October as part of the Performa 07 series. In his fourth post of the week he writes about the actress Anita Ekberg. To read all of Francesco Vezzoli’s prior blog posts, click here.

headline: Hollywood and the Young Smoker
text: How do we stop young people from taking up smoking?

headline: Clinton Kicks Off California TV Campaign
text: Already thinking ahead to Super Tuesday, Hillary Rodham Clinton began showing her first TV ad in California today.

headline: Strike: Studios Offer Writers ‘Informal’ Talks (White Flag Optional)
text: Seven weeks after negotiations stalled, the chief executives of Hollywood’s studios are inviting the Writers Guild of America to engage in “informal discussions” that could lead to a strike-ending deal.

headline: For Clinton and Obama, the Burden of Identity
text: The “biggest fairy tale” in this year’s Democratic contest may be the hope, expressed with renewed vigor by both Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton at Tuesday night’s Democratic debate, that, as the campaign moves forward, they will be viewed as “individuals” and not as representatives of their gender or race.

headline: Laughs and Lyrics With Belichick
text: Occasionally — very, very occasionally — Bill Belichick flashes the sense of humor we are convinced he has buried deep in his hoodie. Today, at the most unlikely moment, we had one of those occasions.

headline: Reagan and revenue
text: Ah – commenter Tom says, in response to my post on taxes and revenues:

headline: Republicans in Democrats’ Clothing
text: Nothing is more self-defeating in presidential politics than a candidate trying to be something he or she is not. Sometimes the incongruity is visual — Mike Dukakis photographed riding atop a tank — but more often it concerns a policy stand or a position that seems opportunistic and inauthentic. In such instances, the departure from form may produce some short-term political gain, but in the long run, it leaves voters confused and alienated.

headline: IBM: A Separate Reality?
text: We knew the bottom-line numbers, after I.B.M. jumped the gun by three days and announced its surprisingly strong profits and sales figures on Monday. But what was striking in the company’s conference call on Thursday afternoon was the unhedged optimism in its outlook for 2008, given the strong whiff of recession fear elsewhere.

headline: YouTube’s Traffic Continues to Snowball
text: More content begets more viewers, which, in turn, beget more content. That’s the virtuous cycle — the network effect — that has propelled Google-owned YouTube to the No. 1 spot in online video.

headline: CBS Outernet Deal: You Can Run From Mary Hart, But You Can’t Hide
text: For the second time in 24 hours, a major TV-centric media company is announcing deals to help advertisers reach consumers outside the home.

headline: Should Banks Take Back Their Bonuses?
text: With the release of Merrill Lynch‘s long-awaited fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday, the tallying began. Watchers of Wall Street were quick to count up the bonuses at the five biggest financial firms in the United States, given the disastrous financial results that four of the five reported in the second half of 2007. (The exception was Goldman Sachs.)

headline: Lightning Strikes the Avalanche
text: The Colorado Avalanche has been hanging onto the last playoff spot in the West desite the loss of its leading scorer and spiritual leader, Joe Sakic, and its gritty man in the crease, Ryan Smyth.

headline: Peshawar Under Siege
text: Situated near the eastern end of the Khyber Pass, Peshawar has long been a gateway to Afghanistan. But in the past year, Pakistan's war with the Taliban and Al Qaeda has spilled right into the Pakistani frontier city, killing policemen and soldiers and scaring its famously tough citizens.

headline: A Few Late Words: Where’s Edwards? Flags. Calls.
text: We were going to try to keep this a bit on the short side, but we’ve got a lot we’d like to catch up on from the trail and beyond so … here goes.

headline: How’s This for Nastiness? BC vs. BU
text: A couple of great match-ups mark the college hockey landscape this weekend, both with a long history of bad blood. Last weekend’s preview was of Denver University vs. Wisconsin, but we’re moving away from the WCHA to avoid situations like this.

headline: Tomlinson Practices; Rivers Sits Out Again
text: Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers did not practice Thursday, unless you count throwing a pass along the sideline.

headline: Inside the Giants: Will Eli Watch ‘Seinfeld’ While Wearing Gloves?
text: Phew. If Eli Manning wants to watch “Seinfeld” on Saturday night, as he usually does before a game, he can. It does not matter that a Green Bay television station is pulling the show out of its usual time slot to show its support of the Packers.

headline: Romo Headline Winner
text: Thanks to all who sent their Romo headlines. To review the submissions, click here and here. As it happens, all the top headlines were written before the game.Three Times sports copy editors served as judges, and each was asked to select a top three. Here’s how they scored it:

headline: Searching for a Packers Refuge in New York
text: If you’re a Packers fan in the New York area, you will find few bars Sunday that won’t be overrun by Giants fans. There’s the Kettle of Fish in the Village, long a Packer bar, but there must be other places. Any advice for Packer backers?

headline: Obama Skewers Critics in Nevada
text: LAS VEGAS – At a rally here tonight, Senator Barack Obama mocked his rivals about how they answered a question during the debate on Tuesday evening. (Yes, this is the same debate where the candidates bathed one another in pleasantries and compliments.)

headline: 11 Die in Attack on a Shiite Mosque in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  For the second time in two days, a suicide bomber struck outside a Shiite mosque in Diyala Province north of Baghdad on Thursday, as worshipers prepared for one of the most important days in the Shiite calendar. The police and witnesses said at least 11 people were killed.

headline: We’re All Gonna Die! Grab Your Video Camera!
text: It was only last month that Will Smith started up boogeyman patrol in Manhattan in “I Am Legend,” and yet here we go again with the end of the world, or at least some of the city’s most exclusive ZIP codes. This time, the annihilation comes courtesy of a reptilian creature with a slithering, smashing tail, multiple grabby appendages and an apparently insatiable appetite for destruction. At one point in “Cloverfield” you get a close, very personal look at that hungry mouth, which agape recalls that of the adult monster designed by H. R. Giger for the first “Alien,” though without any of the older beastie’s freakily sexualized menace or resonance.

headline: Close to History, Art and Lots of Adobe
text: ONE way to assess condominium real estate values in Santa Fe, N.M., is to strap on a pedometer. Walk outward from the city’s geographic, historic and cultural hub, the Plaza, and all else being equal, values decline in direct relation to distance from its center.

headline: Americans in the Action as Macao Casinos Soar
text: HONG KONG  A battle for supremacy in Macao’s gambling market is shaping up between the casino tycoon Stanley Ho and an American newcomer as the Chinese enclave emerges as the biggest gambling territory in the world.

headline: Some New Old Masters at the National Gallery
text: When the National Gallery of Art in Washington opened in 1941, its collection reflected the tastes of its founding benefactors, like Andrew Mellon and P. A. B. Widener. Both men collected Dutch old master paintings but mostly from the latter half of the 17th century. Neither owned work by Salomon van Ruysdael, an earlier landscape painter who now is considered a founding Dutch naturalist.

headline: 12 Killed in Suicide Bombing at Shiite Mosque in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Twelve people were killed and 25 others were wounded, three of them seriously, when a suicide bomber detonated explosives on Thursday in a Shiite Muslim mosque in Peshawar in northwestern Pakistan, police and hospital officials said.

headline: Legal Immigrants Facing a Longer Wait
text: Because of an unprecedented surge in immigration applications last summer, legal immigrants will have to wait much longer during the next two years to receive visas or naturalization papers, the top official of the federal agency that issues those documents said Thursday.

headline: Rock & Pop Listings
text: POP

headline: Suddenly Called to Serve: A Dove, a Hawk and a Loon
text: If the abysmal reception so far for films about the war in Iraq is any indication, “Day Zero,” which imagines a time in the near future when the war has widened, is the last thing movie audiences will want to consume. In this fantasy of the day after tomorrow, coordinated suicide bombings stretch from Ankara to Cairo. An unspecified act of terrorism has wreaked havoc in Los Angeles, and the draft has just been reinstated.

headline: One Argument, 12 Million Holes
text: The big fat immigration bill that died last year in Congress was, for all its flaws, an anchor that kept debate tethered firmly to reality. Like it or not, it contained specific remedies for the border and the workplace. It had a plan for clearing backlogs in legal immigration and managing its future flow. Perhaps most critical, it dealt with the 12 million illegal immigrants already here, through a tough path to earned citizenship.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $6,676,015

headline: Stones Change Label for New Album
text: Long associated with EMI, the Rolling Stones have signed an exclusive recording agreement to release their next album  the soundtrack for Martin Scorsese’s documentary concert film “Shine a Light”  through Universal Music Group, The Associated Press reported. The album is scheduled for March. The announcement prompted speculation that after 16 years the band could part ways with EMI, which has changed ownership and plans to cut as many as 2,000 jobs. Radiohead and Paul McCartney have already left the label. EMI, pointing out that Universal Music is affiliated with Universal Pictures, producers of the film, said its relationship with the Stones would be unaffected.

headline: New Jersey Investigating Amgen’s Marketing of a Psoriasis Drug
text: New Jersey’s attorney general has begun investigating whether the biotechnology giant Amgen violated patient confidentiality laws in its effort to sell its drug Enbrel.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about the casino mogul Sheldon G. Adelson misidentified, in some copies, the company controlled by Lawrence J. Ellison, whose wealth was compared with Mr. Adelson’s. It is Oracle, not Sun Microsystems.

headline: Rockets Hit Israel, Whose Strikes Kill 5 Palestinians
text: SDEROT, Israel  Rockets fired from Gaza slammed into this small Israeli border town in quick succession Thursday evening, and Israeli airstrikes killed at least five Palestinians in Gaza, three of them civilians, on a third day of heightened tension and hostilities between Israel and Palestinian militant groups in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Classical & Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Charlie Rose Joins 60 Minutes
text: Charlie Rose, the PBS interviewer, will moonlight as a contributor to the CBS newsmagazine “60 Minutes” beginning this season, the network announced Thursday. Mr. Rose is expected to provide several reports each season for the program. He served as a correspondent for the spinoff series “60 Minutes II” for six years until it was canceled in 2005. “It will be great to have Charlie working with us again,” Jeff Fager, the executive producer of “60 Minutes,” said in a statement. “His considerable talents will make our all-star team even better.” Mr. Rose will continue to produce and be the host of his long-running public television series.

headline: State Revises Hormone Label for Milk
text: After an outcry from consumers, Pennsylvania’s Agriculture Department has backed off its plan to ban milk-container labels stating that the milk comes from cows not treated with bovine growth hormone.

headline: Clyde Otis, 83, Executive and Songwriter, Dies
text: Clyde Otis, a songwriter and record producer who was one of the first black executives at a major record company, died on Jan. 8 in Englewood, N.J. He was 83.

headline: Europe’s Social Safety Net, and America’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hamm Silhouette on League Logo
text: Mia Hamm retired in 2004 as one of the greatest players in women’s soccer. Now she is the image of a new league. Hamm’s silhouette is featured in the logo unveiled Thursday by Women’s Professional Soccer, a league that plans to begin play in the spring of 2009 in seven American cities. Hamm is about to strike a ball with her right foot in the navy, red and gold W.P.S. logo. The formation of the league was announced in September, with teams expected in Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles, New Jersey/New York, St. Louis and Washington. The league offices are in San Francisco.

headline: Richard Knerr, 82, Craze Creator, Dies
text: Richard Knerr, who gave the company he and a friend started in a garage the altogether appropriate name Wham-O, then marketed products that for two decades virtually defined frivolity in postwar America, from the Hula Hoop to the Frisbee to the SuperBall, died on Monday at his home in Arcadia, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Texas Supreme Court Justice Is Embroiled in an Arson Case
text: HOUSTON  A Texas Supreme Court justice and his wife were charged on Thursday in an arson fire that destroyed their suburban Houston home last June, the judge’s lawyer said.

headline: A Brutal Cossack Hero Strides Into Brooklyn
text: Introducing himself to the audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night, George Isaakyan, the artistic director of the Tchaikovsky Opera and Ballet Theater of Perm, said the members of his company were “happy and proud” to be appearing in New York. “And nervous,” he added.

headline: Queens: Suspect Denies Killing Dentist
text: A man arrested in connection with the killing of a 34-year-old orthodontist in Queens was arraigned on murder charges in State Supreme Court on Thursday, prosecutors said. The man, Mikhail Mallayev, 50, an immigrant from Uzbekistan who has a family tie to the victim’s widow, has been charged with killing the orthodontist, Dr. Daniel Malakov, on Oct. 28 at a Queens playground. Michael Siff, Mr. Mallayev’s lawyer, said his client pleaded not guilty. The killing occurred as Dr. Malakov’s estranged wife, Dr. Mazoltuv Borukhova, and their daughter, Michelle, 4, looked on, the police said. In a statement on Thursday, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said Mr. Mallayev was “acting in concert with another person” when he shot Dr. Malakov twice in the chest. But he did not identify the second suspect and did not elaborate.

headline: Children’s Events
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Those Days of Doom on the Yangtze
text: A modern master of postmodern discontent, Jia Zhang-ke is among the most strikingly gifted filmmakers working today whom you have probably never heard of. During the past decade he has made some half-dozen documentary-inflected fictions and several documentaries that weigh the human cost of China’s often brutal, dehumanizing shift from state-controlled communism to state-sanctioned capitalism, a price paid in the blood and sweat of people who have, paradoxically, inspired him to create works of sublime, soulful art.

headline: Theater Listings
text: THEATER

headline: Manhattan: Lawsuit Over Energy Standards
text: In a sign that local governments are growing impatient with Washington’s approach to solving environmental problems, New York City and three states on Thursday joined environmental advocacy groups in suing the Bush administration over new standards for gas furnaces and other home heating appliances. In a lawsuit filed in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, the City Law Department, along with the States of New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts, argued that the efficiency standards set in November by the federal Energy Department were far too weak to significantly cut carbon dioxide emissions or to help lower home heating costs, which have hit people in the Northeast especially hard.

headline: In Pitches to Doctors, Promise of Big Payday
text: Using e-mail solicitations that promise high pay, US HIFU (pronounced you es HIGH-foo) is trying to build and train a network of American urologists for its offshore prostate cancer treatments. “The opportunity before F.D.A. approval is very lucrative,” said one message sent by the company.

headline: Conservative Approach Pays Off for BlackRock as Profit Grows 90%
text: Dodging the rocky investments that have damaged many Wall Street banks, BlackRock, the giant asset management firm, said on Thursday that fourth-quarter profit jumped 90 percent.

headline: Snowmass
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: A Leader Looking Out for Future Leaders
text: PRESIDENTIAL material  who’s hot, who’s not, and who’s ready to succeed as a black candidate for president of the United States  is not just a running theme but also a ground-level enterprise in the garment district office of Sandra E. Timmons, the president of A Better Chance. Her mission, which she took on in 2003, is to identify, cultivate, and help educate future Barack Obamas when they are adolescents. On her end, clairvoyance helps. On theirs, brains, talent, and any racial identity except white.

headline: Surgery Could Bring an End to Marbury’s Knicks Career
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Stephon Marbury has decided to have surgery for bone spurs in his left ankle, the Knicks said in a statement Thursday. The operation was expected to take place Tuesday, and Marbury will be out indefinitely, the team said.

headline: Gates Seeks Troop Estimates
text: WASHINGTON  When they decided last September to begin a slow withdrawal of troops from Iraq, the White House, Pentagon and senior military officers put off a harder decision about how long those withdrawals should continue.

headline: In Tentative Deal, Directors Send Message
text: LOS ANGELES  After months of informal talks, Hollywood’s movie and television directors agreed Thursday afternoon to a new contract with production companies. The accord would appear to send a none-too-subtle message to striking screenwriters: This is not the time to get hung up on new media.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Dec. 18 about the escape of two inmates from the Union County Jail in Elizabeth, N.J., included an erroneous age from law enforcement authorities for one of the escapees, Jose Espinosa. He was 19 at the time, not 20; he has since turned 20.

headline: Prosecutors Argue Against Moving Bell Case From City
text: Prosecutors in Queens argued Thursday against moving the trial of three detectives charged in the 2006 killing of a man out of New York City.

headline: G.E. Profit Rises, Aided by Overseas Sales
text: The General Electric Company said Friday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 4 percent as surging overseas sales more than offset the fallout from domestic woes. The company also reaffirmed its forecast that earnings per share would rise at least 10 percent this year.

headline: Everything Old ...
text: Here is a listing of antiques shows taking place in New York this weekend, including those reviewed on this page:

headline: Coming Attractions
text: Julie White, who won a Tony Award for her performance in “The Little Dog Laughed,”  is coming back to New York theater for Manhattan Theater Club’s production of “From Up Here,” a new play by Liz Flahive to be directed by Leigh Silverman. Previews begin on March 27 for an April 16 opening at New York City Center. ... “Shrek the Musical,” based on Shrek the Book as well as Shrek the Movie, has announced Shrek the Pre-Broadway Engagement at the 5th Avenue Theater in Seattle. The musical, by David Lindsay-Abaire and Jeanine Tesori, will play there from Aug. 14 to Sept. 21 and is scheduled for Broadway in early November. No theater has been announced, but a musical the size of "Shrek" needs a big theater, sort of like those now occupied by “The Color Purple” and “Legally Blonde.” Hmmm.

headline: State of the City Could Be a Campaign Speech, Too
text: As the setting for his latest State of the City speech, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg chose a new swimming pool and ice-skating rink complex in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Bloggers Push China to Prosecute Beating Death
text: SHANGHAI  More than 100 people are under investigation and several government officials have been detained or removed from office in central China after a dispute in early January in which a group of city officials beat a bystander to death.

headline: Mallett Transfers From Michigan
text: Bobby Petrino landed his first major recruit for Arkansas  Ryan Mallett, the former Michigan quarterback. Mallett has transferred to Arkansas and will have three years of eligibility after sitting out the 2008 season. Mallett, a 6-foot-7 freshman who played in 11 games for the Wolverines, left Michigan after Rich Rodriguez replaced the retiring Lloyd Carr as the coach.

headline: Baby Sitter Charged With Murder in Death of Hartford Toddler
text: HARTFORD  A 25-year-old baby sitter who told the police that she tied a toddler in a sleeping bag last week and ran through her apartment with him slung over her shoulder as part of a game was charged with murder on Thursday in Superior Court here.

headline: South Pole Building Is Dedicated
text: The National Science Foundation dedicated its third Amundsen-Scott research building at the South Pole on Saturday, the agency said Wednesday. The new building replaces the iconic but increasingly snow-covered geodesic dome that since 1975 covered a kitchen building, sleeping quarters, laboratories and other facilities. The new station, built on pilings, can be raised if necessary to escape drifts. The dome will be dismantled, but will probably be reconstructed somewhere in the United States, Peter West, a spokesman for the agency, said. The base, established in 1957, is named for Roald Amundsen of Norway and Robert F. Scott of Britain, who led the first expeditions to the pole almost a century ago.

headline: Renewed Warning on Cold Medicines
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Concerned that many parents continue to give infants over-the-counter cold remedies, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it “strongly recommends” that these medicines not be used in children under 2.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Public Lives column in some editions last Friday, about Nicholas Sprayregen, a businessman and Bruce Springsteen fan who is fighting efforts by Columbia University to seize property he owns in Upper Manhattan, referred incorrectly to the shows Mr. Sprayregen attended during Mr. Springsteen’s 2002-3 “Rising” tour. He saw six of the multiple-night shows at Giants and Shea Stadiums in 2003; Mr. Springsteen did not give a “10-night stand” at Madison Square Garden during that tour.

headline: Pennsylvania Acts to Bolster High School Requirements
text: HARRISBURG, Pa.  A requirement that students pass a series of state exams before being allowed to graduate from Pennsylvania’s public high schools was unanimously approved Thursday by the State Board of Education.

headline: Federal Judge Criticizes C.I.A. Handling of Interrogation Tapes
text: A federal judge in New York said Thursday that he was “disappointed” in how investigators from the Central Intelligence Agency had handled videotapes documenting the harsh interrogation of detainees from Al Qaeda, adding that he was considering questioning agency officials who had watched the tapes about why they had made no record of them in their files.

headline: Crash Landing Temporarily Paralyzes Heathrow
text: LONDON  A British Airways passenger jet crash-landed just short of a runway at London’s Heathrow airport on Thursday, plowing on its belly across open grassland before slowing to a halt when it hit the tarmac with parts of its landing gear torn off.

headline: Obama and Clinton Trade Attacks in Nevada
text: RENO, Nev.  Senator Barack Obama sharply criticized Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on the eve of the Nevada caucuses, declaring: “The American people don’t want a president whose plans change with the politics of the moment.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Monday about the simultaneous departure of three luxury ocean liners  the Queen Mary 2, the Queen Elizabeth 2 and the Queen Victoria  from New York Harbor misstated the context of a quotation from Peter Knego, co-editor of a Web site devoted to the history of passenger ships. When Mr. Knego said, “They would only meet in the Atlantic and were never in port together,” he was referring to the Queen Mary and the Queen Elizabeth  not their successors. (The Queen Mary 2 and the Queen Elizabeth 2 were both in port in New York in 2004.)

headline: Filling In as a Parent for 2 Younger Brothers
text: Thomas Leach, 20, does not speak. But his sister, Shedina Leach, says he communicates using expressions that are as clear as words. A bat of his eyelashes means he is trying to persuade her. When he looks down, he is upset. When he smirks, he is happy.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Jan. 7 about Big Think, the Web site that has interviews with public intellectuals from a variety of fields misspelled the surname of a politician cited in an example. He is Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, not Spector.

headline: McCain Hunts a Second Chance, Wary of the Blade in the Back
text: Aiken, S.C.

headline: In Over Their Heads, With Destiny Looming
text: “Cassandra’s Dream,” Woody Allen’s latest excursion to the dark side of human nature, is good enough that you may wonder why he doesn’t just stop making comedies once and for all. Perhaps that’s heretical, but it’s the view of someone who has accompanied Mr. Allen on all his recent follies, “The Curse of the Jade Scorpion” included, and has too often heard her own laughter die gurgling in her throat from a lack of inspiration. There’s nothing remotely funny about “Cassandra’s Dream,” save perhaps that immodest title.

headline: Hogwarts Founder to Address Harvard
text: J. K. Rowling, who gave the world Harry Potter, will be the principal speaker at the afternoon exercises of Harvard University’s 357th commencement on June 5. “Perhaps no one in our time has done more than J. K. Rowling to inspire young people to experience the excitement and sheer joy of reading,” said Drew Gilpin Faust, the university’s president.

headline: Corrections: Fishing Boats, Surfboards and Not a High-Rise in Sight
text: Because of an editing error, the Havens column last Friday about Puerto Escondido, Mexico, misspelled the name of a real estate agency there. It is Zicatela Properties, not Zicateca.

headline: When Going Gets Tough, a Not-So-Tough Turns to Meth
text: Crime does pay in the movies, at least for a while  the outlaws in “Bonnie and Clyde” and “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid” have delightful rides until the authorities intervene.

headline: Cloning Said to Yield Human Embryos
text: Scientists at a small biotechnology company say they have used cloning to create human embryos from the skin cells of two men.

headline: For Collectibles, All Roads Lead to New York
text: If art fairs were cameras, their views might range from panoramic wide-angle to sharp-focus close-up. Most land somewhere between, but for the next several days New York will be host to two that define the extremes.

headline: Google Offers a Map for Its Philanthropy
text: Google announced a plan on Thursday that begins to fulfill the pledge it made to investors when it went public nearly four years ago to reserve 1 percent of its profit and equity to “make the world a better place.” The beneficiaries of Google’s money range from groups that are fighting disease to those developing a commercial plug-in car.

headline: A Little Midday Music and Where to Find It
text: Here is a selection of afternoon concerts in the coming weeks.

headline: Corrections
text: A sports article on Thursday about the surprising emergence of running back Ryan Grant of the Green Bay Packers referred incorrectly to his classroom performance at the University of Notre Dame. The university said he was never ineligible to play for academic or other reasons; he did not miss one season because of academic trouble. (Go to Article)

headline: Protesters Clash With Police in Kenya and Loot Train
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Law and order seem to be steadily deteriorating in some parts of Kenya, like the Kibera slum here in Nairobi, where on Thursday protesters hijacked and looted a freight train bound for Uganda.

headline: Rookie’s Debut Delights Family and Scares Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Elaine Pope is not a big fan of her son’s tattoos.

headline: Well, It Looks Like Truth
text: After an autumn of large, expert, risk-free museum retrospectives, the time is right for a brain-pincher of a theme show, which is what “Archive Fever: Uses of the Document in Contemporary Art” at the International Center of Photography is.

headline: Why There Will Never Be a Last Tango
text: The cheering audience seemed eager to linger all night on Wednesday at City Center. But finally the house lights came up. The last encore by Compania Tango X2 was over.

headline: Mexican Forces Clash With Drug Cartel Gunmen in Tijuana
text: REYNOSA, Mexico  Drug cartel gunmen and government forces fought a three-hour battle Thursday in Tijuana, the latest in a series of violent clashes in border towns where President Felipe Calderón has deployed the Mexican Army and federal agents to dismantle drug cartels.

headline: Ridgeway: Four Killed in House Fire
text: A late-night fire tore through a two-story home in western New York on Wednesday, killing two children, their mother and grandmother, officials said on Thursday. The fire was in the town of Ridgeway, about 35 miles northeast of Buffalo. The victims were April Hausler, 31; her daughter, Dawn, 7; her son, James, 10; and her mother, Anna Monagan, 56, Orleans County sheriff’s officials said. The fire did not appear to be suspicious, fire officials said. Ms. Hausler’s husband, David, is a truck driver and was on the road when the fire occurred.

headline: Defense Secretary, Facing Criticism, Hails NATO’s Forces in Afghanistan
text: BERLIN  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that NATO countries were playing a “significant and powerful role in Afghanistan,” after some of Washington’s closest European allies assailed him for comments cited in a news report about their counterinsurgency operations in the volatile south.

headline: Europe’s Ethics Panel Says Cloning Harms Animals
text: Just days after being told that milk and meat from cloned livestock were safe for human consumption, Europeans were warned Thursday that cloning causes suffering to the animals.

headline: On Deathbed, Suharto Avoids Answering for Crimes
text: SOLO, Indonesia -- Gilang was one of the last victims of former President Suharto’s harsh 32-year rule, a young activist who disappeared here on the day the former president was forced from power 10 years ago and whose body was found six days later, shot, stabbed and disemboweled.

headline: Mamet, Cornered in the Oval Office
text: You may have been wondering just how all those gagmeisters who make their livings contributing jokes to television talk show monologues and sketch reviews have been occupying their time during the long-lived writers’ strike. Well, one possibility would be that they have been funneling their one-liners  and not always their best ones  directly to David Mamet.

headline: Messenger From Late ’50s, Scatting and Swooning Away
text: You have to admire the jazz singer Mark Murphy for his fearless vocal deconstructions of songs in which crooning, scatting, note bending, muttering and bleating create musical equivalents of Abstract Expressionist paintings. But there is a point at which that kind of invention sacrifices a coherent sense of form, when adventurous exploration verges on doodling, and the work never comes together. During Wednesday’s opening set of a four-night engagement at Birdland, Mr. Murphy trod perilously back and forth over the line separating expressive invention and foolish self-caricature.

headline: Paula Vogel Goes to Yale
text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Paula Vogel, director of the playwriting programs at Brown University for 24 years, has been appointed an adjunct professor and the chairwoman of the playwriting department at Yale School of Drama. She’ll be part of a much bigger drama department, but that’s what appeals to her, she said. “I’m really proud of the students that I’ve had and really proud of the program,” Ms. Vogel said of her time at Brown, “but I feel like I’ve just about done everything I can do.” The appointment, which begins July 1, is for five years.

headline: A Sad Story, Told by Nixzmary’s Things
text: A child’s wooden school chair with a length of nylon twine tied to it.

headline: Australia: Job Growth Stirs Inflation Concern
text: Australian employment rose for a 14th month in December, adding to the longest hiring boom in almost three decades, which is fanning inflation and may force the central bank to raise borrowing costs next month. The number of people employed climbed by 20,100, after a revised 47,600 gain in November, the Bureau of Statistics said. The jobless rate fell to 4.3 percent from 4.5 percent. “It’s one more tick in the box for our view that the Reserve Bank will probably have to lift rates as early as February,” said John Peters, senior economist at Commonwealth Bank of Australia in Sydney. “An ever-tighter labor market runs the risk of wage inflation.”

headline: Queens: Man Charged With Hate Crime
text: A Queens man has been charged with shouting racial slurs before severely beating a Sikh man in New Hyde Park, prosecutors said on Thursday. The man, David C. Wood, 36, of 263rd Street, was arraigned in Criminal Court on Wednesday evening on charges of second-degree assault as a hate crime and aggravated harassment, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Prosecutors charged that the Sikh man, Chadha Bajeet, 63, had just parked his car on 95th Avenue on Monday when Mr. Wood shouted, “Arab, go back to your country!” and punched him in the face, breaking his nose and jaw.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Man a Fortress of Futility
text: “Beaufort” may be, strictly speaking, a war movie, but for long stretches it feels more like science fiction. The small band of Israeli soldiers who are its main  virtually its only  characters inhabit a mountain outpost in southern Lebanon that might as well be a space station marooned in a hostile galaxy.

headline: Texas Man Held in Pakistani Jail Said to Be Gravely Ill
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani-American doctor who campaigned for the rights of a minority group is gravely ill in a remote Pakistani jail, held without charges under severe conditions for nearly two years, his lawyers and human rights advocates said.

headline: Bloomberg Warns of Spending Cuts
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, looking at once to close a multibillion-dollar deficit and burnish his national profile as a fearless innovator, unveiled a mix of tough education and anticrime measures while warmly embracing the virtues of immigration on Thursday at his annual State of the City address.

headline: Queens: Eight Injured in Fire Truck Crash
text: Eight people were injured on Thursday in a crash in Laurelton involving a United States Postal Service tractor-trailer, a taxicab and a fire engine responding to an emergency, the Fire Department said. The injured, five firefighters and three civilians, were taken to area hospitals. The Fire Department said the accident, which occurred about 3:15 p.m. at 225th Street and Conduit Avenue, was under investigation. The truck driver, who was not identified, was in critical condition Thursday evening, the police said. The injuries to the firefighters and the other civilians were said not to be life-threatening.

headline: Bush Calls for $145 Billion Economic Aid Package
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush called on Friday for about $145 billion worth of tax rebates for American families and incentives for businesses to provide “a shot in the arm to keep a fundamentally strong economy healthy” and avert a slide into recession.

headline: Easy Glider: This Isn’t Your Flexible Flyer
text: THE snow was so deep one morning in Vermont last month that Lincoln Gap was barely recognizable as a road. The mountain pass, the gateway to sun-dappled Long Trail hikes in warmer months, was buried beneath white powder.

headline: Don’t Cry for Me, America
text: Mexico. Brazil. Argentina. Mexico, again. Thailand. Indonesia. Argentina, again.

headline: Lowell Wants Flawless H.G.H. Test
text: Mike Lowell, the most valuable player of the World Series, said he was willing to give blood if that is what it takes to be tested for human growth hormone  but only if the test is 100 percent accurate. “If it’s 99 percent accurate, that’s going to be seven false positives,” Lowell said Thursday before the annual dinner of the Boston chapter of the Baseball Writers’ Association of America. “Ninety-three percent is 70 guys. That’s almost three whole rosters. You’re destroying someone’s reputation. What if one of the false positives is Cal Ripken? Doesn’t it put a black mark on his career?”

headline: A January to Remember as a Dismal Start
text: While the chairman of the Federal Reserve told Congress on Thursday that a recession can be averted, Wall Street sent Washington a different message: it’s already here.

headline: In Offense of Riches, Maroney Is Hidden Gem
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Laurence Maroney sat for most of this week playing dominoes quietly in the middle of a locker room maelstrom, barely watching as the clot of dozens of members of the news media followed his teammates around. Maroney, the N.F.L.’s most anonymous starting running back, was overlooked again.

headline: Bank’s Trash Is Treasure for Grabbing
text: In the breezy, amoral heist comedy “Mad Money,” “Fun With Dick and Jane” meets “9 to 5” on the way to recession. If this uncomfortably timely movie lacks the political bite of the first and the cozy star chemistry of the second, it sputters to fitful life in the crooked grin of Diane Keaton, whose character, Bridget Cardigan, an upper-middle-class homemaker in suburban Kansas City, Mo., develops an insatiable lust for larceny.

headline: Rodriguez and Wright, Together
text: Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees and David Wright of the Mets play the same position, third base, and play in the same city. At the 28th Thurman Munson Awards dinner Feb. 5, they will also take the same stage and receive the same award.

headline: Rhode Island: Budget Cuts Proposed
text: Gov. Donald L. Carcieri proposed deep budget cuts to close a $151 million deficit, including forcing state workers to take unpaid days off, removing children of illegal immigrants from state health care rolls and cutting back on welfare spending. The plan by Mr. Carcieri, a Republican, seeks to close a budget gap in the current fiscal year. It now goes to the General Assembly, which Democrats control.

headline: Bridesmaid Revisited, Again and Again
text: At the beginning of “27 Dresses,” Jane (Katherine Heigl), a serial bridesmaid with an almost pathological devotion to other people’s nuptials, spends a long night shuttling between two weddings. One is in Midtown Manhattan, the other in Brooklyn; one has an upper-crusty, white-bread look, while the other appears to be a Jewish-Hindu intermarriage. But as the director, Anne Fletcher, methodically cuts back and forth between them, she makes the reasonably insightful, moderately funny point that modern American weddings, however they may strain for individuality and specialness, are all pretty much alike.

headline: Ex-Hospital Patients File Lawsuit Over the Status of Health Care Services in New Orleans
text: A group of former patients of New Orleans’s shuttered public hospital filed a lawsuit on Thursday in a Louisiana state court, saying that medical care for the poor is still woefully inadequate in the city and asking for a return to the level of services the hospital provided before Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Bush to Offer Stimulus Plan; Tax Rebates Expected
text: WASHINGTON  The stock market plunged again on Thursday on bad economic news, taking little comfort from reassuring words by the chairman of the Federal Reserve or an emerging consensus about a stimulus plan that many worry could be too late.

headline: Collector Returns Art Italy Says Was Looted
text: After 18 months of intense negotiations, the New York philanthropist Shelby White has ceded 10 classical antiquities from her private collection that Italy contends were looted from its soil, the Italian culture minister confirmed this week.

headline: Winter Day Out in Atlanta
text: IT is in Midtown that Atlanta feels most like a real city. That is where the sprawl finally ends, where Costco and Outback give way to condos and Outwrite (the gay bookshop). There is a vertical grace to the streetscape, a fundamental yet all too rare appreciation for proportion and design. Home to the arts center, a great urban park and some of Atlanta’s best restaurants, the district has a vitality that is at once hip and sophisticated.

headline: Merrill Posts Huge Loss; Chief Says Firm’s Capital Is Adequate
text: The outlook darkened for Merrill Lynch on Thursday as news of a huge quarterly loss sent the company’s stock plummeting.

headline: How Voters Think
text: People in my line of work try to answer certain questions. Why did Hillary surge after misting up in New Hampshire? Why have primary victories produced no momentum for the victors? Why did John McCain win among Republicans who oppose the Iraq war in both New Hampshire and Michigan, but lose among voters who support it?

headline: Art Listings
text: A A BRONSON’S SCHOOL FOR YOUNG SHAMANS Some group shows, like this one organized by A A Bronson, feel atmospherically of a piece. Mr. Bronson is the surviving member of General Idea, a group of three artists and lovers who were together from 1969 to 1994. Since his partners, Jorge Zontal and Felix Partz, died of AIDS in the 1990s, Mr. Bronson has worked alone, but not really alone. As an artist, mentor of artists, healer and gay role model, he remains, in one way or another, a collaborator. That’s what this rich show is about.

headline: California: Smoke-Free Apartments
text: The Calabasas City Council adopted an ordinance regulating smoking in apartments, following the leads of the cities of Temecula and Belmont last year. The Calabasas ordinance requires at least 80 percent of apartment buildings to be permanently designated nonsmoking. It goes into effect Feb. 16, and landlords have until Jan. 1, 2012, to complete the transition. The ordinance allows current tenants who smoke to continue smoking in their units if they request to be grandfathered in.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg’s State of the City
text: National economic indicators may be headed downward, but the annual State of the City speech that New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg delivered Thursday was so upbeat that he proposed another round of tax breaks. The effect was perhaps a little too happy, but the mayor has earned the right to preach at least a little optimism.

headline: Southern Blacks Are Split on Clinton vs. Obama
text: ATLANTA  The People’s Voice African-American Weekly News in tiny Roanoke, Ala., has not endorsed a candidate in the state’s Democratic presidential primary on Feb. 5  much to the frustration of its publisher, Charlotte A. Clark-Frieson, a Barack Obama supporter.

headline: Canadian Manual Has U.S. on Torture List
text: OTTAWA  A training manual for Canadian diplomats lists the United States among countries that potentially torture or abuse prisoners.

headline: A Long Way From Radiohead (or Maybe Not So Long)
text: Wordless Music, a series now in its second season, is an experiment in genre mixing that has shown what can be done when you value imagination more than formats and rules. Usually matching rock bands with classical chamber groups, the program has built a following among young listeners on both sides of the street.

headline: Effect of Prosthetics Ruling Is Unclear
text: In ruling Monday that the double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius, who runs on two carbon-fiber blades, was ineligible to qualify for the Olympics, track and field’s world governing body was hoping to establish a precedent. Instead, the question of whether prosthetic limbs confer an advantage over able-bodied runners remains shrouded in confusion.

headline: Bill Clinton, Stumping and Simmering
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton may be the spouse running for office, but it is more Bill Clinton who appears to be feeling the heat.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Armstrong to Run in Boston
text: The seven-time Tour de France winner Lance Armstrong plans to run the Boston Marathon in April to raise money for his foundation. Armstrong, 36, qualified for Boston by completing the 2007 New York City Marathon in 2 hours 46 minutes 43 seconds, finishing in 214th place. The Boston qualifying time is 3:15 for men ages 35 to 39.In 1996, Armstrong had a diagnosis of testicular cancer that had spread to his lungs and brain. But he recovered to win the Tour from 1999 to 2005.The Lance Armstrong Foundation supports cancer research, prevention and better care for cancer survivors. Armstrong and others running for the foundation raised about $500,000 at last year’s New York City Marathon.

headline: Corrections
text: A picture caption last Friday with an article about Crestone, Colo., as a spiritual center misstated the name of a Catholic monastery there. It is the Nada Hermitage, not Napa Hermitage.

headline: Creative Force of VH-1’s Reality Shows Leaves, but Not in Reality
text: VH-1, the cable channel which has soared in the ratings because of reality shows like “Flavor of Love” and “I Love New York,” is losing its top creative executive but not his creativity.

headline: Ohio: Suit Over Voting Plan
text: The American Civil Liberties Union sued the state and its most populous county to block the county from switching to a paper voting system in time for the March 4 presidential primary. The A.C.L.U. claims the system to be put in place in the county, Cuyahoga, violates voters’ constitutional rights because it does not allow them to correct ballot errors. With more than one million registered voters, Cuyahoga County, which includes Cleveland, plans to send paper ballots filled out by voters to a central location to be scanned and counted. That system does not give voters notice of ballot errors and an opportunity to correct mistakes, the A.C.L.U. says.

headline: Frontier Insurgency Spills Into Peshawar
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  For centuries, fighting and lawlessness have been part of the fabric of this frontier city. But in the past year, Pakistan’s war with Islamic militants has spilled right into its alleys and bazaars, its forts and armories, killing policemen and soldiers and scaring its famously tough citizens.

headline: A Mining Town With a Bleak Past Starts to Blossom
text: DOUG GREENWELL and his wife, April, took a ski holiday to Jackson Hole, Wyo., five years ago with the idea of looking for a vacation home. She found it too cold. He found it too expensive.

headline: Things They Don’t Teach in Any Dental School
text: Teenage horror-movie spoof, John Waters parody, No Nukes protest movie, twisted sex-education film, quasi-feminist fable, outrageous stunt: Mitchell Lichtenstein’s clever, crude comedy, “Teeth,” is all these and more.

headline: U.S. Fines Mine Owner $20 Million for Pollution
text: WASHINGTON  The nation’s fourth-largest coal producer, the Massey Energy Company, was hit Thursday with a $20 million fine, the largest civil penalty ever levied by the federal government for a pollution violation of this type under the Clean Water Act.

headline: Staten Island Ferry and Staten Island Railway
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Louisiana: FEMA Trailer Refunds
text: Responding to concerns about high levels of formaldehyde in its disaster trailers, the Federal Emergency Management Agency said it would offer refunds to people who bought the units. In the summer of 2006, the government began selling travel and park model trailers through online auctions and to victims of the 2005 hurricanes. Sales were suspended in July 2007 because of formaldehyde fears. FEMA said 10,839 travel trailers and park models were sold at an average price of $6,936, and 864 trailers were sold directly to hurricane victims.

headline: No Murphy Marriage
text: Eddie Murphy’s recent marriage was over before it began. The ceremony he and the film producer Tracey Edmonds took part in on New Year’s Day on a private island off Bora Bora in French Polynesia was merely symbolic and not legally binding, the couple said in a statement, The Associated Press reported. The statement said that “we have decided to remain friends.”

headline: Planning for Newark’s Next Big Step: An Apartment Tower Near the Arts Center
text: NEWARK  An impressive cultural complex in the heart of this down-and-out city? They said it could not be done, but Lawrence P. Goldman, the man behind the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, proved them wrong.

headline: Back in His Arms Again: The Home Campaign
text: Sue Miller’s novels, beginning with her assured debut, “The Good Mother” (1986), tend to feature soap-opera plots fleshed out with remarkable psychological detail and emotional precision. This is certainly true of her unsatisfying, if professionally executed, new book, “The Senator’s Wife,” which revolves around a brilliant, self-made, philandering politician (who seems inspired in part by Bill Clinton, who is frequently mentioned in passing in these pages) and his stoical wife, who like the Hillary Clinton described in Gail Sheehy’s 1999 tendentious book, “Hillary’s Choice,” is “addicted” to her husband.

headline: Bring on the Lift but Hold the Groomers in Washington
text: THE smothering storm, some 50 inches of snow in four days, wasn’t so unusual  not for Washington State. What was rare was the cloudless, not-a-breath-of-wind dawn that arrived on the fifth day, the last of 2007. It was a perfect morning to check out what is possibly this winter’s most intriguing addition to the ski slopes of the Pacific Northwest.

headline: Romney Leaves South Carolina to Focus on Nevada Caucus
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The next big Republican presidential contest is Saturday in South Carolina. So what did Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, the winner of the Michigan primary this week, do on Thursday morning?

headline: Secret Service: Detailed Look at ’06 Turmoil
text: DENVER  The arrest of a man named Steven Howards in June 2006 after he approached Vice President Dick Cheney at a Colorado ski resort and denounced the war in Iraq might have seemed, at the time, no more than a blip on the vice president’s schedule.

headline: Virus Is Linked to a Powerful Skin Cancer
text: Scientists have discovered a previously unknown virus and strongly linked it with the most aggressive form of skin cancer, they reported in a scientific journal on Thursday.

headline: Extending Requirement to Advance in School
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday unveiled strict new criteria for promotion to high school that could, if current testing patterns hold, put nearly a quarter of New York City’s eighth graders in danger of spending an extra year in middle school.

headline: Tennessee: Ex-Lawmaker Is Sentenced
text: One of five former lawmakers convicted of bribery or extortion in an F.B.I. sting was sentenced to two years’ probation by a judge who indicated that the defendant’s heart ailment had kept him out of prison. The former state senator, Ward Crutchfield, 79, pleaded guilty in July to bribery for taking $3,000 from a company called E-Cycle Management, which turned out to be a creation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. His probation includes six months of home detention.

headline: A Movement That Brightened Victorian Lives
text: A MOVEMENT

headline: Corrections: For Many a Follower, Sacred Ground in Colorado
text: A picture caption last Friday with an article about Crestone, Colo., as a spiritual center misstated the name of a Catholic monastery there. It is the Nada Hermitage, not Napa Hermitage.

headline: Sorting Out the New Housing Market
text: The shape of the new American housing market  the post-bubble market  is starting to emerge. It is one that favors the young who never owned a house and the banks that have access to cheap deposits. It may be harshest on the two coasts, where both distress and a newfound lack of mobility may be on the increase.

headline: ‘The Senator’s Wife’
text: Meri, June 1993

headline: Pacific Islanders’ Ancestry Emerges in Genetic Study
text: The ancestral relationships of people living in the widely scattered islands of the Pacific Ocean, long a puzzle to anthropologists, may have been solved by a new genetic study, researchers reported Thursday.

headline: The Resort as Residence
text: “WE’RE always getting massages,” Troy Coughlin said, “or my wife is getting her nails done. We’re totally pampered by the people at the spa.”

headline: Art in Review
text: BERTIEN VAN MANEN

headline: Bronx: Carwashes to Pay Back Wages
text: The United States Labor Department announced on Thursday that two Bronx carwashes, Tremont Car Wash and Webster Car Wash, and their corporate president had agreed to pay $707,298 in back wages and damages to 237 employees. The department’s investigators found that many carwash employees were required to work more than 70 hours a week without being paid the federal minimum wage or time and a half for overtime. The department said the carwashes had also failed to maintain adequate and accurate records. Judge Barbara Jones of Federal District Court in Manhattan said that if the carwashes failed to make the payments, she would appoint a receiver to seize and liquidate their assets to satisfy the order.

headline: Resignation Weakens Italy’s Government
text: ROME  A new element of instability shook Italy’s government Thursday as the justice minister, resigning over a corruption investigation, withdrew his small party from the already fragile center-left ruling coalition.

headline: Winter Day Out in Washington, D.C.
text: FOR a quintessentially D.C. start to a winter day, grab a power breakfast (the fruit platter with salmon is a good morning choice) among the wheelers and dealers at the Old Ebbitt Grill, just steps from the White House. A favorite hangout for Presidents Grant, Cleveland, Harding and Theodore Roosevelt, and now senators and lobbyists, the Grill, built in 1856, makes you feel like a true political insider and gives you a chance to test your C-Span skills by trying to identify fellow patrons.

headline: Mayor Hails City’s Immigrants and Innovation
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, looking at once to close a multibillion-dollar deficit and burnish his national profile as an innovator, unveiled a mix of tough education and anticrime measures while embracing the virtues of immigration on Thursday at his annual State of the City address.

headline: State Makes Bid to End Costly Tax-Refund Loans
text: New York officials filed civil complaints on Thursday against two tax preparation firms that offer high-interest loans against income-tax refunds, saying the companies had aimed the loans at low-income black and Hispanic families and military families in violation of state antidiscrimination laws.

headline: McDonald’s Ending Promotion on Jackets of Children’s Report Cards
text: McDonald’s has decided to stop sponsoring Happy Meals as rewards for children with good grades and attendance records in elementary schools in Seminole County, Fla.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Monday with an article about inns and hotels in the New York region that cater to new mothers, pregnant women or couples who want to become parents misstated, in some editions, the given name of a man who recently stayed with his wife and their new son at the Parrot Mill Inn in Chatham, N.J. He is Mark Sodano, not Dan.

headline: Corrections
text: A sports article on Thursday about the surprising emergence of running back Ryan Grant of the Green Bay Packers referred incorrectly to his classroom performance at the University of Notre Dame. The university said he was never ineligible to play for academic or other reasons; he did not miss one season because of academic trouble.

headline: Councilman Is Penalized for Violating Finance Law
text: Five hundred seventy dollars for Spanish food delivery. An additional $770 for campaign jingles. Some $2,000 for a Dominican Day parade float and $1,500 to buy a bus.

headline: Footnotes
text: A portrait of Stephen Colbert, below, of “The Colbert Report” has been hung between the bathrooms in the “American Presidents” exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution’s National Portrait Gallery in Washington, The Associated Press reported. Bethany Bentley, a museum spokeswoman, said the display, scheduled for six weeks, is a joke.

headline: Rivers Sits at Practice, but Could Play Sunday
text: SAN DIEGO  Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers did not practice Thursday, unless you count throwing a pass along the sideline.

headline: Spare Times Listings
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Giuliani Had Ties to Company Trying to Sell Border Technology
text: On the presidential campaign trail, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani often promotes the installation of electronic monitoring devices at the border to stem illegal immigration, without mentioning that until a few months ago, he was partner in a company trying to market such technology.

headline: Prison Makes Way for Future, but Preserves Past
text: SAN QUENTIN, Calif.  The dank crypt for the living still wields emotional power, its peeling ocher walls and low vaulted ceilings suffused with chill and darkness.

headline: Clemens Hires Top Washington Lawyer
text: Roger Clemens has bolstered his legal team, hiring a powerhouse Washington lawyer, Lanny A. Breuer, who represented former President Bill Clinton during his impeachment hearings as well as numerous corporations that were the subject of Congressional investigations.

headline: Winter Day Out in Seattle
text: DRINK coffee. Put on another layer of dry clothes. Repeat. This is the formula to warm inside and out. Then attack a Seattle winter day undaunted, ignoring downpours like the locals, who act as if the epidermis were made of Gore-Tex.

headline: Jennings Joins Rangers
text: Jason Jennings, a Dallas native who grew up watching Nolan Ryan pitch for Texas, was introduced as the newest addition to the Rangers’ rotation. Jennings, a free-agent right-hander, agreed to a one-year deal worth $4 million. Jennings, 29, is coming off an injury-plagued season in Houston, where he was 2-9 with a career-worst 6.45 earned run average. He missed three months with elbow problems.

headline: C.I.A. Says Tribal Leader Behind Bhutto’s Death
text: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the assassins who last month killed former Pakistani prime minister Benazir Bhutto were directed by Baitullah Mehsud, a Pakistani militant leader, and that some of them had ties to Al Qaeda.

headline: Herald Tribune Publisher Departs
text: PARIS  Michael Golden, the publisher of The International Herald Tribune, said Friday that he was leaving the newspaper and returning to New York to focus on his position as vice chairman of The New York Times Company.

headline: South Korea: Bid Is Made for Shipping Service
text: The Kumho-Asiana Group, owner of South Korea’s largest builder and second-biggest airline, bid more than 4 trillion won ($4.3 billion) for control of the Korea Express Company to add cargo delivery and warehousing services. The bidding group comprises about 10 companies, not all of which are controlled by Kumho-Asiana, and is the leading bidder, according to a spokesman for the Seoul Central District Court, where Korea Express has been in receivership since 2001. Korea Express, based in Seoul, fell under court control after failing to pay debts inherited from its parent, the Dongah Construction Industrial Company. It runs warehouses and container ports, as well as handling international door-to-door deliveries.

headline: Politics Wrapped in a Clothing Ad
text: IT is not often that a clothing advertisement includes the words “apartheid” and “purgatory” along with a quote from President Bush, but American Apparel has always been different from other consumer brand companies.

headline: Owners Give Selig Ultimate Endorsement
text: Bud Selig’s legacy as the commissioner of Major League Baseball will always be complicated. In more than 15 years on the job, he has steered the sport through periods of unprecedented growth and unrelenting controversy.

headline: Brazil: Sale of Iron Ore Projects Is Weighed
text: The British mining company Anglo American is in exclusive negotiations to pay $5.5 billion for control of iron ore projects owned by the Brazilian mining concern MMX Mineração e Metálicos, the companies said. Under terms of a complex deal, Anglo American would buy the MMX shares owned by a Brazilian businessman, Eike F. Batista, and secure control of the company’s Minas-Rio and Amapa ore mines in Brazil, the companies said. Anglo American said the talks focused on the acquisition of Mr. Batista’s 63.6 percent share in what would be a new company broken off from MMX. That company would own MMX’s current 51 percent interest in Minas-Rio and 70 percent interest in Amapa. Anglo American would also pay royalties to MMX for the Minas-Rio project beginning in 2025 and beginning in 2023 for Amapa.

headline: A Renewed Candidacy for Thompson
text: LAURENS, S.C.  The presidential candidate known as Fred moseys into Whiteford’s Giant Burger, possessing that La-Z-Boy manner and a fistful of conservative principles.

headline: Hamas Police Force Recruits Women in Gaza
text: GAZA CITY  The policemen of Hamas now have company: since the Islamic group took over here last June it has been recruiting policewomen as well.

headline: With Big Backlog of Homes, Builders and Buyers Wait
text: New-home construction fell again in December as builders scrambled to cut back in the face of rising inventories and fewer orders. The drop-off is likely to hurt businesses that serve the housing industry, which economists do not expect to bottom out until the middle of the year.

headline: Defensive Coordinator Has the Giants’ Respect
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants started the season losing by 45-35 to the Dallas Cowboys and by 35-13 to the Green Bay Packers, there was dismay in sports bars and on talk radio, but not in the locker room.

headline: One Plus One Plus One Equals Infinite Options
text: Wednesday night at the Jazz Gallery, three musicians who have played as a trio only a few times before  the drummer Jeff Ballard, the guitarist Lionel Loueke and the alto saxophonist Miguel Zenón  played as if they were meant to be together, and also demonstrated how wide the knowledge of the well-prepared jazz musician can be today.

headline: Directors Reach Accord With Hollywood Studios
text: LOS ANGELES  After months of informal talks, Hollywood’s movie and television directors agreed Thursday afternoon to a new contract with production companies. The accord would appear to send a none-too-subtle message to striking screenwriters: This is not the time to get hung up on new media.

headline: Snapshots of a Campaign in Flux
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Magazine Adds to a Controversy
text: The Golfweek cover, with a noose set against a purplish sky, showed that the comment from the Golf Channel’s Kelly Tilghman on Jan. 4 that one way for young golfers to stop Tiger Woods is to “lynch him in a back alley” is not abating.

headline: For Leonard, It’s All About Fairways, Greens and Rock ’n’ Roll
text: LA QUINTA, Calif.  A fair wind blew across Justin Leonard’s left shoulder in the second round of the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic on Thursday, and like any great Texas golfer he knew just what to do with it. Standing on the 15th tee at La Quinta Country Club, a 3-iron in one hand and a share of the tournament lead in the other, Leonard gauged the breezes gusting through the tall palms and pierced them with a textbook shot that stopped 4 feet from the hole, 209 yards away.

headline: A Joyful Noise: Midday Music
text: I HAD never seen anyone walk through a church so fast.

headline: Acrimony Leads Closure in West Virginia Conflict
text: In the acrimonious aftermath of the Rich Rodriguez era at West Virginia, Bill Stewart, the head coach for about two weeks, is looking for closure, which does not seem to be in reach.

headline: Knocked Out
text: Los Angeles

headline: Researchers Challenge Water-Flow Model
text: Decades ago, when geologists were developing ideas about how water typically flows across land, many of them studied the streams of the Mid-Atlantic States, concluding that they naturally move in ribbonlike channels cut through silty banks. In the years since, ecologists and conservationists have used this model in efforts to restore streams damaged by urbanization.

headline: A Weekend Home That’s Straight Out of a Dream
text: JAMES WOODYARD has no problem starting small.

headline: A Car-Fraud Sting With a Long Arm
text: The cars came from all over  upstate New York and Maryland, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The owners brought them to middlemen who would deliver them for a fee to a nondescript garage in Queens. The cars, the owners thought, would be stripped down for parts, and they could then claim the vehicles as stolen and recoup tens of thousands of dollars from insurance companies.

headline: Facing Deportation but Clinging to Life in U.S.
text: WAUKEGAN, Ill.  She is a homeowner, a taxpayer, a friendly neighbor and an American citizen. Yet because she is married to an illegal immigrant, these days she feels like a fugitive.

headline: West Virginia Chief Justice Steps Away From Case
text: Chief Justice Elliott E. Maynard of the West Virginia Supreme Court disqualified himself on Friday from further participation in a case involving a powerful coal executive after photographs of two men meeting in Monte Carlo in 2006 were filed in court this week.

headline: A Season of Achievement, a Week of Distraction
text: Last spring the New England Patriots took a gamble. On draft day, the franchise noted for employing players with character sent a 2007 fourth-round draft choice to Oakland for Randy Moss, a player known for having his share of character issues.

headline: Newark: 2 Planes ‘Dangerously’ Close
text: Federal aviation officials are investigating what they described as an error by an air traffic controller that put two planes landing at Newark Liberty International Airport within 600 feet of each other on Wednesday. The minimum vertical separation allowed for flights landing at the airport is 1,000 feet, according to Federal Aviation Administration officials and air traffic controllers. “This was a very difficult and dangerous situation,” said Ray Adams, vice president of the air traffic controllers’ union at the airport. According to Jim Peters, an F.A.A. spokesman, the error occurred when an air traffic controller mistakenly gave one of the planes the frequency for the tower at nearby Teterboro Airport. As a result, the Newark tower was temporarily unable to contact the crew as both planes approached Newark. Compiled by John Sullivan

headline: Growth of Genetic Tests Concerns Federal Panel
text: WASHINGTON  The science of genetic tests is marching ahead and so are efforts to sell them directly to consumers who are willing to send in a check and a bit of saliva to learn whether they are at risk for a disease.

headline: Confederate Flag Takes Center Stage Once Again
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The Republican presidential candidates on Thursday moved to appeal to different types of conservative voters before the South Carolina primary, with Mike Huckabee using colorful language to declare the Confederate flag a states’ rights issue and Senator John McCain embracing a supply-side tax cut proposal.

headline: Britain Suspends Operations of Two Offices in Russia
text: LONDON  A government-financed British cultural organization said Thursday that it had suspended operations in two Russian cities, accusing the Russian security police and tax authorities of harassing members of its local staff by summoning them for interrogation, sometimes late at night in their homes.

headline: Edwards Attacks Obama for View of Reagan
text: HENDERSON, Nev.  The legacy of Ronald Reagan was invoked in the Democratic nominating race on Thursday when John Edwards attacked Senator Barack Obama for remarks he made to a Nevada newspaper suggesting praise for Reagan.

headline: Taking a Long, Bumpy Ride to Systematic Brutality
text: A year from now, the presidency of George W. Bush will end, but the consequences of Mr. Bush’s policies and the arguments about them are likely to be with us for a long time. As next Jan. 20 draws near, there is an evident temptation, among many journalists as well as politicians seeking to replace Mr. Bush, to close the book and move ahead, an impulse that makes the existence of documentaries like Alex Gibney’s “Taxi to the Dark Side” all the more vital. If recent American history is ever going to be discussed with the necessary clarity and ethical rigor, this film will be essential.

headline: It’s Easier This Year: Serena Williams Cruises to Victory
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  It has been a much more tranquil first week at the Australian Open for Serena Williams. A year ago, she was having to slug her way out of early danger as an unseeded outsider who would end up winning the most surprising title of her career.

headline: Fewer ‘Idol’ Viewers
text: One day after the premiere audience for Fox’s "American Idol" fell 4 million viewers shy of the series’ 2007 debut, the talent competition slipped further in the ratings on Wednesday. Still, television’s most popular series continued to crush its competition on the night by tens of millions of viewers, drawing 30.3 million from 8 to 10 p.m., Nielsen estimated. That tally, however, represented a decline of 3 million from Tuesday’s premiere and 6.7 million from the series’ first Wednesday installment a year ago. In second place, NBC trailed far behind Fox but got a boost from both “Deal or No Deal” at 8 (11.8 million) and “Law & Order” at 10 (11.6 million). CBS finished third, struggling at 8 with “Power of 10” (4.9 million) but faring better at 9 with the two-hour conclusion of the mini-series “Comanche Moon” (12.1 million). ABC ranked fourth over all but edged past CBS for third place among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A headline in Business Day on Thursday with an article about research involving two widely used cholesterol-lowering drugs misstated the issue raised by the results. It is whether using drugs to lower cholesterol at all costs is always medically effective, or even safe; there is no question that cholesterol itself can pose dangers.

headline: Locating Love Between Silly and Serious
text: When Paul McCartney sang “Some people want to fill the world with silly love songs” in 1976, he was merely stating the obvious. Nor does the world lack for serious love songs. But writers have also portrayed amorous subjects in countless shades of gray, and it was to some of those works that the New York Festival of Song turned for a concert on Wednesday night in the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at the Juilliard School.

headline: Coming From Different Places, Two Americans Advance
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  They are unseeded Americans in the third round of the Australian Open.

headline: Despite Doubts, Cancer Therapy Draws Patients
text: PUERTO VALLARTA, Mexico  Some weekends, more than a dozen American men wait at beachfront hotels, anxious for their turns in the treatment room at a small private hospital here.

headline: Winter Day Out in Boston
text: BOSTON is a city of ghosts, but on the coldest of days, don’t expect them to come to you. Instead, visit Forest Hills Cemetery, a rambling Victorian-era burial ground about four miles from downtown and a splendidly quiet place to roam. Winding paths crisscross its 275 acres, and if you pick up a map by the entrance, you can find the graves of Anne Sexton, E. E. Cummings and Eugene O’Neill. Drive slowly along the narrow roads until you find a good place to park and wander. On a recent morning, snow crunched underfoot and fell in soft chunks from the treetops. Bliss.

headline: Those Chaotic College Years in Beijing
text: Toward the end of Lou Ye’s “Summer Palace,” Yu Hong (Lei Hao) reflects that her college years were the “most confused” time in her life. A lot of us might feel similarly, but Yu Hong, the beautiful and passionate heroine of this beautiful and passionate film, is something of a special case.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Wednesday about Coach Bill Belichick’s efforts to motivate the New England Patriots for their playoff game against San Diego misstated the Chargers’ record through the first five games this season. It was 2-3, not 1-4.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Dec. 30 about Nyiga Tenzin Nordon, a Tibetan refugee whose son was badly injured by a hit-and-run driver in Queens and who received help through The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misidentified the hotel where Ms. Nordon works as a maid. It is the Hilton Garden Inn in Times Square, on Eighth Avenue at 48th Street  not the Hilton Times Square, on 42nd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

headline: Winter Day Out in Chicago
text: WINTER comes and Chicago trudges proudly on as if nothing has changed. On a recent Saturday morning, as the city sat beneath a foot of fresh snow, people strolled in Millennium Park, the city’s front yard along Lake Michigan, even as three snowplows scraped circles around them. Still, without violating the city’s code of stoicism, one can find the ideal winter day here by alternating all that outdoor grit with a smattering of permitted hideaways.

headline: China Says Its Seafood Is Now Safer and Better
text: BEIJING  The Chinese agriculture ministry said a recent crackdown on the use of illegal veterinary drugs had significantly improved the quality and safety of the country’s seafood production.

headline: Their House to Yours, via the Trash
text: By 9:15 most mornings, Thomas Germain, a ruddy-faced man in a yellow slicker, is pushing his oversize black wheeled suitcase down 12th Street in the direction of the Strand Bookstore on Broadway.
