headline: Stray Voltage Still a Problem 4 Years Later
text: On Jan. 16, 2004, Jodie S. Lane, a 30-year-old graduate student walking her dogs, was electrocuted after she stepped on an electrified metal plate in the East Village. Improperly insulated wire beneath the plate had sent 57 volts of electricity running up the side of an underground service box to the plate above.

headline: Blogtalk: Details From Nevada and South Carolina
text: With that messy at-large caucus lawsuit behind them, the Nevada blogs have quieted down a little bit ahead of the state caucuses and are turning their attention to who’ll be the winners and losers come Saturday night.

headline: Merriman Must Battle the Flu Before the Patriots
text: Chargers linebacker Shawne Merriman hopes his defense against Patriots quarterback Tom Brady is better than his body’s defense against the flu. Merriman got sick upon returning from Indianapolis and missed practice earlier in the week.

headline: Breaking Bad
text: A scene from AMC's new series, where Bryan Cranston plays a chemistry teacher turned drug dealer.

headline: Paris: Not on Easy Street
text: I have several thoughts about recent posts here, notably on Prada and Jil Sander, and some observations about the men’s shows we saw today. There is no trace of self-conscious in Junya Watanabe’s clothes, as there is with so many designers, no gender manipulation that blows up in his face and only makes the rest of us laugh sadly with disappointment. He showed the shrunken blazer, a style he has done before (before Mr. Browne), as if to express the general distaste and contempt that young men have for this formal look. They scorn it, and so does Junya, now showing the coat with ties and shirts that are so glossy and colorful as to perhaps tempt the militant boys into an establishment uniform. A number of the jackets combined classic tweeds with bits of other fabrics, seemingly from a rag bin. OK, he made his point, and didn’t sit on it proudly or for too long.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Jan. 18:

headline: Perella Weinberg’s Big New Assignment
text: Business got off to a slow start for Perella Weinberg Partners, the boutique investment bank founded by Joseph R. Perella, formerly chairman of mergers at Morgan Stanley, and Peter A. Weinberg, a former partner at Goldman Sachs.

headline: Councilman Suspects Politics in a Burglary
text: Updated, 6:15 p.m. | Maybe Councilman Hiram Monserrate, Democrat of Queens, has good reason to be sensitive about crime. A former marine and city police officer, Mr. Monserrate became the first Latino elected official from Queens in 2001.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 18
text: Here is a slide show of 12 photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the sentencing of the track star Marion Jones, Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s State of the City address and a Grandmothers Against the War procession on Fifth Avenue.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Art in the Age of Franchising
text: Why is “Friday Night Lights” such a bust?

headline:
Fischer’s Epochal Match,
Shelby Lyman’s Star Turn
text: When people say they remember watching the epic 1972 Fischer-Spassky world championship tournament on public television, what they really mean is they remember watching Shelby Lyman.

headline: Spitzer Speaks on Finance Regulation
text: CNBC interviews New York Governor Elliot Spitzer on new financial regulations in the state.

headline: Bloggingheads: How Black Is Barack?
text:
Scholars John McWhorter of the Manhattan Institute, left, and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate Obama's ethnic identity and what it means.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: You’re Not Buying Gadgets, You Are Subscribing to Them
text: When I wrote last week, about the apparent victory of Blu-ray discs over HD DVD, there was a deluge of comments from readers. Those that agreed with my take on things, let’s say, were a rather small — if well-informed — minority.

headline: Rivers Is Doubtful for Sunday, but He Isn’t Packing Light
text: After practice Friday afternoon, Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers finished packing for the biggest business trip of his four-year career. Into his black roller bag he tossed a pair of jeans, an extra tie, and a couple of shirts.

headline: A Potpourri of Pols
text: I can’t figure out what it is that keeps me watching the current star search for our next president.

headline: Optimistic Analysts, Part 1
text: Arnie Berman, the chief technology analyst at Cowen, surveyed the consensus expectations on profits at 388 tech companies.

headline: Black Support Shifts Toward Obama
text: A new national poll released Friday by CNN suggests Senator Barack Obama’s victory in Iowa and other events in recent months have encouraged more black voters to support him.

headline: Optimistic Analysts, Part 2
text: Heather Hunt, a Citigroup analyst and longtime fan of MBIA and Ambac, is out with a report today dowgrading the shares to hold, after they have lost most of their value. She says she is “throwing in the towel.”

headline: Off to Davos
text: I’ll be in Davos next week, at the World Economic Forum, and will be blogging (and fililng columns) from there.

headline: Mind the Gender Gap
text: A lot of attention has been paid to the women’s vote in the first two Democratic nominating contests. In the Iowa caucuses, Barack Obama won a narrow victory over Hillary Clinton among female voters. But in New Hampshire women rallied to the former first lady giving her a huge 46 percent to 34 percent margin, which was the deciding factor in her comeback win.

headline: Fred Thompson in South Carolina
text: The South Carolina primary may be the make or break moment for Fred Thompson's 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: Vows: Emily & Preston
text: Emily and Preston recount their courtship, from a blind date in Newark to an engagement ring in San Francisco.

headline: In Green Bay, Even the Footballs Are Frozen
text: No, really. Dead serious. The footballs for Green Bay’s practices this week were frozen like pizzas in the grocery store.

headline: Will Baseball Look to Players to Speak Out Against Steroids?
text: When I was growing up in the 1980s, baseball was embroiled in a cocaine scandal. I was vaguely aware of it; I read the names of the players who were caught, and I perceived drugs to be very bad.

headline: Inside the Giants: The End for Strahan?
text: Michael Strahan has been in a great mood recently, having played two strong postseason games (a career playoff-high eight tackles against Tampa Bay, trumped by 10 tackles against Dallas) and sitting within one victory of the Super Bowl.

headline: Write Your Own Brett Favre Story
text: Packers quarterback Brett Favre has been compared to everyone from Paul Bunyan to Everyman. The broadcaster John Madden likens Favre to “Superman with an S on his chest.” ESPN’s Chris Berman says that “rooting for Favre is like rooting for America.” Now you can lionize him, too. Should you need assistance, we offer suggestions below to fill in the blanks.

headline: Bits Debate: On the Rights of Readers and Viewers
text: Throughout the debate this week on copyright issues, the question of fair use has come up repeatedly. On Wednesday, the topic for Rick Cotton, the general Counsel of NBC Universal, and Tim Wu, the Columbia law professor, was the legal concept of fair use: how much of a copyrighted work can be included in a review or other sort of work. But in many of the comments we received all week, readers have asked about their own broader sense that when they buy a CD or movie, they purchase rights that include making copies for their personal use.

headline: Edwards Leaves Nevada for Oklahoma
text: OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla. – On the eve of the Nevada caucuses, John Edwards has already skipped out of the state on a fly-around tour, looking ahead to states that are holding primary contests on Feb. 5.

headline: Gaps in Medical Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ancient Vase Comes Home to a Hero’s Welcome
text: ROME  As the restless crowd applauded, and flashbulbs popped, the Euphronios krater, at the heart of a three-decade tug of war between the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the Italian government, received a hero’s welcome here on Friday.

headline: From Hospital Into Rehab, Six Weeks After 47-Story Fall
text: Continuing a recovery that has left medical professionals searching for superlatives, the window washer who fell 47 stories six weeks ago was discharged from the hospital Friday.

headline: Chargers’ Rivers Says He’s Ready to Return
text: SAN DIEGO  After practice Friday afternoon, Chargers quarterback Philip Rivers finished packing for the biggest business trip of his four-year career. Into his black roller bag he tossed a pair of jeans, an extra tie and a couple of shirts. “In case you have to spend the night Sunday,” he explained to one of his teammates, adding, “There may be a blizzard.”

headline: Could Congress Be Waking Up?
text: AMID the clamor of the presidential campaign, it’s sometimes easy to forget that all 435 House seats and 35 of the Senate’s seats are up for election this year, too. So how should Congress under its new Democratic leadership be judged?

headline: Roddick Loses After Five Sets; Blake Rallies
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Andy Roddick had been here before: deep into a fifth set well past midnight at the Australian Open with the legs getting weary and the mood getting edgy. But this marathon in Rod Laver Arena did not end nearly so happily for Roddick as his coming-of-age epic against Younes el-Aynaoui did in 2003.

headline: Director of Antigang Group Sold Illegal Assault Weapons
text: LOS ANGELES  The director of an antigang organization here that sought to reduce gun violence and received $1.5 million from the City of Los Angeles pleaded guilty on Thursday to charges that he sold illegal assault weapons to a federal undercover agent.

headline: C.I.A. Sees Qaeda Link in the Death of Bhutto
text: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that the assassins of Benazir Bhutto, the former Pakistani prime minister, were directed by Baitullah Mehsud, a Pakistani militant leader in hiding, and that some of them had ties to Al Qaeda.

headline: Four Distinct Dream Worlds, Sharing the Same Language of Classical Ballet
text: “Are you a ‘Tombeau’ freak too?” a leading New York dance critic asked me at our first meeting in 1979 at the New York State Theater. We had just been watching Balanchine’s ballet “Le Tombeau de Couperin,” which was then less than four years old.

headline: Internet Puts a Sugarcoat on Scalping
text: Big games tomorrow. Green Bay against the Giants at Lambeau Field. New England versus San Diego in Foxborough. Winners go to the Super Bowl. Big, big games.

headline: Clinton Defeats Obama in Nevada
text: LAS VEGAS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won the Nevada caucuses on Saturday, capturing strong support from women voters and adding a fresh boost of momentum to her campaign as the Democratic presidential race heads to South Carolina, where she is engaged in a fierce battle with her rival, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: When an Innocent Turns Aggressor
text: Janacek based his “Diary of One Who Disappeared,” a dramatic song cycle, on the familiar scenario of an upstanding young man lured away by a Gypsy temptress. But in the Gotham Chamber Opera’s provocative production there was nothing innocent about Janicku, the plowman protagonist, who raged around the small stage of the Morgan Library & Museum’s intimate Gilder Lehrman Hall in a bloodstained shirt, manhandling the Gypsies and chaining them to a wall.

headline: 2 Belgian Tourists Killed in Yemen Ambush
text: SANA, Yemen  Gunmen opened fire on a tourist convoy on Friday afternoon in the Hadramawt region in eastern Yemen, killing two Belgian women and two Yemeni drivers, Yemeni officials said.

headline: Writers’ Strike Tests the Mettle of 2 Outsiders
text: LOS ANGELES  Patric M. Verrone, president of the Writers Guild of America West, is a sporadically busy comedy writer with a law degree that has seen him through the rough spots between jobs at shows like “The Simpsons” and “Futurama.” David J. Young, his chief lieutenant, is a plumber turned hard-bitten labor organizer, with roots in the rough-and-tumble world of Los Angeles sweatshops.

headline: Mr. Blair Sits
text: Prime Minister Tony Blair refused to sit for a formal portrait while in office, but he has now done so for Jonathan Yeo, a well-known portrait painter. His first official portrait was commissioned by the Honourable Society of Lincoln’s Inn, one of four so-called Inns of Court in London to which barristers of England and Wales belong. The painting will go on exhibition at Lincoln’s Inn in March, when it will be installed in the Great Hall. Mr. Blair is the 16th prime minister to have been a member of Lincoln’s Inn, in a line that started with Robert Walpole, generally considered the first prime minister, in 1721. Previous portraits of prime ministers in the Inn include those of William Pitt, Spencer Perceval, Herbert Asquith and Margaret Thatcher.

headline: Germany: Another Cub With Fans
text: A female polar bear cub born this month at Nuremberg Zoo and being hand-raised has officially been named Flocke, or Snowflake, by a jury of city and zoo officials, spurring on the baby-bear craze in Germany that began last year in Berlin with the cuddly Knut. The jury received more than 50,000 e-mail messages, letters and postcards from around the world suggesting names, but in the end decided to keep the name zookeepers had given her.

headline: Head Scarf Debate Intensifies in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL  An angry debate over a ban on the Islamic head scarf, which is strictly forbidden in public buildings in Turkey, spilled into view this week, with the country’s secular elite vehemently opposing any loosening of the restriction.

headline: Horses Sent to Slaughter
text: To the Editor:

headline: Emergency Room Delays
text: The nation’s failure to provide health insurance for all Americans seems to be harming even many of those who do have good health coverage. That is one very plausible interpretation of a disturbing increase in waiting times at emergency rooms that are often clogged with uninsured patients seeking routine charity care.

headline: Leader of Insider Trading Scheme Free After 2 Years
text: A former Goldman Sachs trader who helped lead a $6.7 million insider-trading conspiracy was sentenced to time served by a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan on Friday.

headline: Georgia Frontiere, 80, First Female N.F.L. Owner, Is Dead
text: Georgia Frontiere, the owner of the National Football League’s Rams for nearly three decades and the first woman to take control of a league franchise, died Friday. She was 80.

headline: U.S. Sees Stalling by North Korea on Nuclear Pact
text: WASHINGTON  A debate is under way within the Bush administration over how long it can exercise patience with North Korea without jeopardizing the fulfillment of a nuclear agreement that President Bush has claimed as a foreign policy victory.

headline: Russia-Britain Impasse Appears to Reach Pause
text: MOSCOW  Russia’s Foreign Ministry on Friday expressed satisfaction over the decision of the British government to suspend operations at two cultural centers in Russia, even as the British ambassador said that he hoped the centers would reopen after further negotiations.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Wednesday about N.F.L. championship games between the Giants and the Green Bay Packers in 1961 and 1962 misidentified the position played by Willie Davis, an All-Pro for the Packers in the 1960s. He was a defensive end, not a defensive tackle.

headline: Rockies Settle With Holliday
text: The Colorado Rockies, hoping to lock up Matt Holliday for the long term, settled for a two-year deal with him. Holliday agreed to a two-year, $23 million contract to avoid arbitration. He hit .340 with 137 runs batted in last season, the third player since 1967 to lead the National League in both categories.

headline: Ex-N.F.L. Player Pleads Guilty in Balco Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Dana Stubblefield, a former defensive lineman in the N.F.L., pleaded guilty in federal court here Friday to charges that he made false statements to a federal agent about his use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Bush Proposing $145 Billion Plan to Spur Economy
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush called Friday for roughly $145 billion in tax relief for individuals and businesses that he said would “provide a shot in the arm” for the economy, while Congressional Democrats, in a rare show of Washington bipartisanship, pledged to work with him to enact a plan quickly.

headline: Court Rejects Challenge to New Thai Government
text: BANGKOK  Thailand’s Supreme Court appeared to clear the way for a new government on Friday, dismissing a challenge to the party backed by Thaksin Shinawatra, the ousted prime minister whose return to the country now seems more likely.

headline: Footnotes
text: Primary Stages has announced its 2008-9 season, which includes a new play by Tina Howe, “Chasing Manet,” starring Jane Alexander, and the New York premieres of plays by A. R. Gurney (“Buffalo Gal,” under the direction of Mark Lamos) and Lee Blessing (“A Body of Water,” under the direction of Maria Mileaf). Mr. Gurney’s play is to kick off the season on July 22. ... Steven Holl Architects of New York and Beijing has been chosen to design an arts complex for Princeton University’s theater and dance programs, parts of its department of music, its Lewis Center for the Arts and its Society of Fellows in the Creative and Performing Arts. ... Aaron Betsky, an American who directed the Netherlands Architecture Institute of Rotterdam for six years, has been appointed director of the 11th International Architecture Exhibition at the Venice Biennale, to run from Sept. 14 to Nov. 23.

headline: Gold’s Rise: It’s Not Just Armageddon
text: THE price of gold has always been a way to keep score of economic, financial and political instability, but the game may be changing. The dollar is weak, inflation is troublesome and the world isn’t getting any safer, but it is hard to see how those factors alone drove gold from just over $250 an ounce in 2001 to more than $900.

headline: Valentín Agrees to Deal
text: José Valentín, a vital member of the Mets’ 2006 division champion team who missed the majority of last season because of leg injuries, agreed to a minor league deal. Valentín, 38, sustained a season-ending broken leg July 20 in Los Angeles, less than two weeks after he returned from a two-and-a-half-month absence because of a partial tear of the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee.The Mets and Aaron Heilman avoided salary arbitration by agreeing on a one-year deal worth $1.2 million. The team exchanged contract figures with the five remaining arbitration-eligible players  Endy Chávez, Ryan Church, Pedro Feliciano, Oliver Pérez and Jorge Sosa  and are still negotiating. Sosa and Pérez have requested a 2008 salary that is more than $1 million higher than what the Mets offered. Sosa asked for $2.75 million, and the Mets submitted $1.7 million; Perez asked for $6.5 million, and the Mets offered $4.725 million.

headline: In Killing of 7-Year-Old, Defense Cites Fetus in Jar
text: A lawyer for a Brooklyn man charged with killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter drew gasps from jurors on Friday after he submitted photographs of a fetus in a jar in his bid to show that the girl’s mother was responsible for her death. The mother was driven mad by the miscarriage, the lawyer has said, and held the unruly girl, Nixzmary Brown, responsible, beating her viciously because of it.

headline: Clemens to Testify Under Oath
text: Roger Clemens will go to Capitol Hill on Jan. 26 to answer questions from staff members for the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, Clemens’s lawyer said Friday, setting the stage for a possible perjury showdown against the personal trainer who says he injected Clemens with performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about plans by the federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency to deport immigrants convicted of crimes misstated how soon the agency would complete some deportations. Although the agency expects to start deportation proceedings this year against more than 200,000 immigrants serving criminal sentences in prisons and jails, the individuals will be removed when they complete their terms  not necessarily in 2008.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about some New Yorkers’ recollections of the city’s more violent past, prompted by a knife fight during a mugging in Harlem, referred imprecisely in some editions to state statutes concerning the possession of knives. Although the state classifies possession of any “dangerous” knife as a crime provided there is intent to use it, it does not address the length of the blade. (Under city law, it is legal to carry knives with blades shorter than four inches, except for some that are specifically outlawed, including switchblades.)

headline: Holiday on Monday: Martin Luther King’s Birthday, Actually Jan. 15, Will Be Observed
text: NEW YORK

headline: Scandal Steals Spotlight in Greek Culture Ministry
text: ATHENS  Even as Greece lauds its success in reclaiming ancient classical treasures from museums abroad, a scandal has arisen over its oversight of its archaeological past.

headline: Gamez Leads the Hope Classic After Answering the Call
text: PALM DESERT, Calif.  Robert Gamez was packing for Hawaii a few weeks ago when the telephone rang. It was Mike Milthorpe, the tournament director from the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic, calling to offer him a sponsor’s exemption.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Voices Against the Abuse of Women
text: To the Editor:

headline: What’s Behind Those Offers to Raise Credit Scores
text: A HOST of companies have cropped up in the last year that offer struggling subprime mortgage holders quick-fix programs aimed at raising their credit scores.

headline: For Champions of Haggling, No Price Tag Is Sacred
text: MY husband and I hate haggling. In markets in Istanbul or Jerusalem or Florence, where arguing over price is a high art  and after we have given it our best shot  we always feel we have walked away paying twice as much as the seller expected.

headline: Familiar Songs, the Way You’ve Never Heard Them
text: You’ve probably never heard “Heartbreak Hotel” performed with the stark, no-frills approach that the British singer Barb Jungr brings to it in her show “No Regrets: The Remarkable Barb Jungr” at the Metropolitan Room. Stripping it of its hubba-hubba and bump-and-grind beat, with nary a “baby” to be heard, she forces the song to stand on its own as a surreal, minimalist, blues-flavored lament, whose last word “die” is hissed.

headline: Bodies Yield Evidence of Homicide
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. (AP)  Eight men whose skeletal remains were discovered last year in Fort Myers were the victims of homicide, the police said Friday.

headline: Revisiting the Works of a Former Firebrand to See if They’re Still Warm to the Touch
text: In 1952 Pierre Boulez wrote that “any musician who has not felt ... the necessity of the dodecaphonic language is of no use.” A year after this youthful, narrow-minded declaration, Mr. Boulez indulged his open-minded interest in the music of foreign cultures by evoking non-European sounds in a chamber work featuring a groundbreaking combination of instruments.

headline: Yankees Begin Arbitration
text: The Yankees exchanged salary arbitration figures with three players on Friday and signed another, infielder Wilson Betemit, to a one-year, $1.165 million deal.The biggest difference in figures was with second baseman Robinson Canó, who asked for $4.55 million while the Yankees offered $3.2 million. Starter Chien-Ming Wang asked for $4.6 million, $600,000 more than the Yankees’ offer; and reliever Brian Bruney asked for $845,000 while the Yankees offered $640,000. The Yankees are likely to settle with Bruney before a hearing. They believe their offer to Wang is fair, but a settlement seems possible because the figures are not far apart. Canó’s case is trickier, since the salary he is seeking would be higher than the $4.5 million earned by Justin Morneau of the Twins last season, after Morneau had won the Most Valuable Player award. The Yankees are unlikely to sign any of the players to long-term contracts, because their general policy is to make one-year deals until players reach free agency.

headline: Algeria Angered by U.N. Plans for Bombing Inquiry
text: UNITED NATIONS  Algeria said Friday that it would not cooperate with an independent panel that Secretary General Ban Ki-moon was setting up to investigate the car bombing of United Nations offices in Algiers last month. The Algerians also denied accusations that they had ignored requests to tighten security around the building before the attack.

headline: Crawford and Knicks Fail to Keep Streak Alive
text: WASHINGTON  In the post-Marbury era, however long it may last, the Knicks’ fate will ride most games on Jamal Crawford’s stutter-step, his crossover dribble and his streaky jumper. That repertory helped fuel the Knicks’ longest winning streak of the season this week, but it was not enough to extend that streak to a fourth game Friday.

headline: Smarts Are Tops
text: Fox’s “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” delivered its highest ratings in 10 months on Thursday, helping to lift the network to a rare No. 1 finish over all among adults 18 to 49. The quiz show earned 11.5 million viewers, Nielsen estimated, leading the 8 p.m. hour ahead of ABC’s “Ugly Betty” (9.5 million) and repeats on CBS and NBC. In the next hour, Fox’s “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” (8.8 million) trailed NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice,” (9 million) which was the night’s top-rated show among the 18-to-49 set. NBC ranked second in that demographic, winning the 10 p.m. time slot with “ER,” which edged past CBS’s “Without a Trace” despite drawing a much smaller total viewership. Although CBS finished third among adults 18 to 49, the network averaged the most viewers for the night, thanks largely to a rerun of “CSI” at 9 (14.1 million).

headline: Two Charged in Mascot Death
text: A father and son from Paramus, N.J., have been charged with lying to the police about a motor vehicle accident that killed a University of North Carolina student who was the mascot for the university’s basketball team. Authorities said Friday that Gagik Hovsepyan, 52, was covering for his son, Armen, 25, when he told the police last March that he was driving the car that struck the student, Jason Kendall Ray, as he was walking along Route 4 in Fort Lee. Armen Hovsepyan, whose driver’s license was suspended at the time of the accident, was actually behind the wheel, authorities say.

headline: New York Settles on Far More Modest Expansion of Javits Convention Center
text: Thirteen months and $30 million after the Spitzer administration said it would conduct a 90-day review of longstanding expansion plans for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the state has come up with a new, far less ambitious proposal that major users of the center say is disappointing.

headline: Economists Debate the Quickest Cure
text: WASHINGTON  In trying to assemble a bipartisan package to jolt the slumping economy, the White House and Congress have turned to familiar tools that experts say have worked in the past. But there is also a lively debate among economists about which measures will best accomplish the goal.

headline: Seeing the Dead
text: Lindsay Lohan, right, will soon be working at a morgue as part of her punishment for misdemeanor drunken driving, The Associated Press reported. Her two four-hour days at the morgue are part of a court-ordered program to show drivers the real-life consequences of drinking and driving. She must also spend two days working in a hospital emergency room. Ms. Lohan was arrested twice last year on drunken driving charges and pleaded guilty in August to misdemeanor drunken driving and cocaine charges. She was sentenced to one day and served 84 minutes as part of a plea deal.

headline: Ex-Union Chief Pleads Guilty
text: The former president of the union representing 15,000 New York City school bus drivers pleaded guilty on Friday to extortion and receiving bribes as part of a racketeering conspiracy.

headline: Michigan: 911 Operator Convicted
text: A Detroit jury convicted a 911 operator of willful neglect of duty after the authorities said she did not take seriously a boy’s calls to report that his mother had collapsed. The misdemeanor charge against the operator, Sharon Nichols, is punishable by up to a year in jail. She will be sentenced March 11. Ms. Nichols, 45, testified that she could not hear the boy on the other end of the line. The authorities said the boy, Robert Turner, now 7, called 911 twice on Feb. 20, 2006, to report that his mother had passed out. Robert testified that Ms. Nichols accused him of playing games and hung up on him. The police found Robert’s mother, Sherrill Turner, 46, dead three hours after the first call. Charges were dismissed against another operator, Terri Sutton, who took the boy’s second call.

headline: With Reminders of Past, Duquesne Moves Ahead
text: PITTSBURGH  Beneath the bed in his Duquesne University dorm room, Shawn James keeps a red and white, left-foot, size 13 Nike Air Force sneaker. It is not an unusual possession for a college basketball player  except for the bullet hole.

headline: Brazilian Museum Declared a Menace
text: More bad news for the São Paulo Museum of Art. The museum, site of the theft last month of paintings valued at more than $50 million, has been threatened by São Paulo state authorities with temporary closing, Agence France-Presse reported. In court proceedings, the authorities contend that the museum has been operating for 40 years without formal permission from the city, the police and the fire service. Mariza Schiavo Tucunduva, a state official in charge of health and safety, said a recent inspection had shown that the fire system was not operating, extinguishers were missing, and exits were not clearly marked. “There is an imminent risk to the life and health of museum visitors as well as to the priceless historic and cultural heritage that the institution’s collection represents,” Ms. Tucunduva said. The museum asserted in a statement that it was the safest in the country.

headline: Herald Tribune Publisher Departs
text: PARIS  Michael Golden, the publisher of The International Herald Tribune, said Friday that he was leaving the newspaper and returning to New York to focus on his position as vice chairman of The New York Times Company.

headline: Romney Alters His Message, but Questions Remain
text: RENO, Nev.  Mitt Romney’s advisers contend he has found his voice with his retooled message focused on changing Washington and confronting the economic jitters gripping the country.

headline: New York Panel Rethinks Securities Oversight
text: A commission assembled to revise New York State’s financial regulations recommended on Friday that the state have one regulator to oversee the securities industry, instead of the current four overseers.

headline: Romney Offers an Economic Stimulus Plan
text: Mitt Romney offered an ambitious plan Friday to try to forestall a recession, proposing a $250 billion economic stimulus package with sweeteners for supply-side conservatives, older Americans and corporations.

headline: Pipeline Cements Russia’s Hold on Europe’s Gas Supply
text: SOFIA, Bulgaria  Russia strengthened its grip on Europe’s energy supplies on Friday as it signed a major gas deal with Bulgaria that analysts said would further undermine the European Union’s attempts to diversify its energy sources.

headline: India: Bird Flu Spread ‘Alarming’
text: India’s third outbreak of avian flu among poultry is the worst it has faced, the World Health Organization said. The chief minister of West Bengal State, which is trying to cull 400,000 birds, called the virus’s spread “alarming.” Uncooperative villagers, angry at being offered only 75 cents a chicken by the government, have been selling off their flocks and throwing dead birds into waterways, increasing the risk. New outbreaks were also reported this week in Iran and Ukraine.

headline: What the Surge Doesn’t Do
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rushdie Visit Leads to Boycott Threat
text: A visit by Salman Rushdie to India has prompted an organization of Islamic clerics to call for a boycott of products from the major conglomerate owned by the family that was his host, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Rushdie, right, a lightning rod for Muslim protests since he was accused of insulting Islam in his 1988 novel “The Satanic Verses,” arrived in Mumbai last week and left on Tuesday, curtailing his visit by two days when Muslim groups began protesting outside the beachfront house of the Godrej family, whose company, Godrej Industries Ltd., has interests in furniture, machine tools, food processing and chemicals. Maulana Sayyed Atarali, the president of the All India Ulema Association, a national organization of Islamic clerics, said, “Until there is an apology, we will boycott all their products.”

headline: Praying for Christian Unity, When Diversity Has Been the Answer
text: Has the movement for unity among Christians gone into a coma?

headline: Equity Firms Acquiring Food Supplier
text: Two equity buyout firms, the Blackstone Group and Wellspring Capital Management, agreed Friday to acquire the Performance Food Group, the food distributor, for $1.2 billion to combine it with a competitor they purchased in September.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A theater review on Thursday about “Small Metal Objects,” part of the Under the Radar Festival, reversed the identities of two actors and their characters. Gary was played by Sonia Teuben, and Steve was played by Simon Laherty. The review also misidentified the character who had second thoughts. It was Steve, not Gary.

headline: Bottom Line on Doing Good
text: “IT’S alluring and very much in vogue to connect social responsibility with profitability,” an article in The Harvard Business Review begins. “If you can make a business case for positive social action, everybody wins  employees, shareholders and society at large.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A film review in Weekend on Friday about “Still Life” misstated the given name of the director of photography. As a listing of credits with the review noted, he is Yu Likwai  not Yu Jianmin.

headline: Save the Polar Bear
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lawyer Reveals Secret, Toppling Death Sentence
text: For 10 years, Leslie P. Smith, a Virginia lawyer, reluctantly kept a secret because the authorities on legal ethics told him he had no choice, even though his information could save the life of a man on death row, one whose case had led to a landmark Supreme Court decision.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,915 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Thursday:

headline: Not Funny but Sad
text: To the Editor:

headline: Man Freed After 17 Years in Prison Faces New Investigation in Murder
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  A state prosecutor was given 30 days by a Suffolk County judge on Friday to decide how to proceed with a case involving the 1988 murders of a Long Island couple now that the conviction of their son, Martin H. Tankleff, has been overturned.

headline: Fighting Before It’s Too Late, Jones Jr. Will Face Trinidad
text: As the ever-excitable boxing promoter Don King tells it, he did not arrange the fight between Roy Jones Jr. and Felix Trinidad. Fate, chance and the appetite of the two boxers did.

headline: Inquiry Finds Power Failure in London Jumbo Jet Crash
text: LONDON  Both engines on the British Airways jumbo jet that crash-landed just short of a runway at London’s Heathrow Airport on Thursday failed to respond to a demand for more power during the final few moments of the flight, British investigators said Friday.

headline: Good Jobs Are Where the Money Is
text: I think of the people running this country as the mad-dashers, a largely confused and inconsistent group lurching ineffectively from one enormous problem to another.

headline: UBS, After a Write-Down, Closes Finance Unit in U.S.
text: UBS, Europe’s biggest bank, said on Friday that it would close an American unit that invested in fixed-income securities as it scales back risk-taking after writing down the value of subprime mortgage investments by $14.7 billion last year.

headline: Rodriguez Is Paid Incentives
text: Michigan Coach Rich Rodriguez, who is being sued by West Virginia in an attempt to collect on a $4 million buyout clause in his old contract, received a $287,000 incentive payment from W.V.U. on Friday for goals reached during the 2007 season. Among the incentives was a one-time $150,000 payment for winning the Big East championship and receiving a Bowl Championship Series berth, and $25,000 for finishing in the top 10.

headline: G.E. Profit Rises, Aided by Overseas Sales
text: The General Electric Company said Friday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 4 percent as surging overseas sales more than offset the fallout from domestic woes. The company also reaffirmed its forecast that earnings per share would rise at least 10 percent this year.

headline: Border Patrol Agent Sentenced for Role in Smuggling Ring
text: SAN DIEGO  A former Border Patrol agent who helped smuggle more than 100 people into the United States and shared internal documents with leaders of the smuggling ring was sentenced Friday to three years in federal prison.

headline: Glossary of Terms for ‘Could Congress Be Waking Up?’
McCain and Huckabee Avoid Sparring in Final South Carolina Push
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John McCain capped his final full day of campaigning in South Carolina with a big rally in an aircraft carrier museum here on Friday evening, as Mike Huckabee delivered his populist economic message on the trail while highlighting his religious beliefs to draw out the evangelical vote in Saturday’s primary here.

headline: Giants Recall a Stinging Defeat and See How They’ve Changed
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When the Giants faced the Green Bay Packers on Sept. 16 the weather at Giants Stadium was idyllic: sunny and 64 degrees with a refreshing breeze from the northeast. The field conditions were tempestuous: the Giants’ defense sprung leaks in the fourth quarter and the offense sputtered all day. It amounted to a forgettable 35-13 defeat.

headline: A Scout at Heart Leads a Revival in Green Bay
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The rookie scout in the Green Bay personnel department did not attend college all-star games or scouting combines. He parked himself in a chair in an empty office for his first assignment in January 1992.

headline: Kenya’s Opposition Switches Its Tactics From Street Protests to Business Boycotts
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Protests cooled in Kenya on Friday as opposition leaders, still furious about last month’s presidential election, announced that they were switching tactics from street demonstrations to boycotts.

headline: Behind on the Rent, and Then a Baby Needs Surgery
text: It was Memorial Day 2007. Cheryl Brooks and her family were enjoying a cookout with her youngest children’s father in Upper Manhattan when her 2-month-old, Arianna Williams, started to cry. Then Arianna’s heart began to race.

headline: From Texas to Iraq, and Center of Blackwater Case
text: DICKENS, Tex.

headline: Seeking Tools to Calm a Market
text: Dow 6,000 or Dow 14,000?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 3 about the death, apparently by suicide, of Rudolph Zurick, a corrections officer at the Union County Jail in Elizabeth, N.J., who had been mocked in a note left by two escaping inmates, Jose Espinosa and Otis Blunt, misstated Mr. Blunt’s age. He is 33, not 32; he was 32 at the time of his escape. (The error was repeated in related articles on Jan. 8 and Jan. 9.)

headline: Study Says Drivers Will Use New Jersey Toll Roads Despite Increases
text: Most New Jersey drivers would continue using the state’s toll roads even if Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s proposal to raise fees sharply is adopted, according to a traffic study made public on Friday.

headline: A Common Foe in Nevada: Confusion
text: LAS VEGAS  As Nevada Democrats began their caucuses on Saturday, the emphasis centered on one question: What, exactly is a caucus?

headline: Pakistan, Terrorism and Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fixing a Budget at the Toll Booth
text: As states and cities look to their roadways to generate badly needed money, the state of New Jersey is offering an approach worth studying. Gov. Jon Corzine wants to shore up his state’s troubled finances by sharply raising tolls. If he gets his way, the cost of driving most of the turnpike could eventually rise from $5.85 to $48, providing money for both debt reduction and public transportation. The plan has potential pitfalls, but it may well be the best solution to a difficult problem.

headline: Phillips in Line at Kentucky
text: Joker Phillips, the Kentucky offensive coordinator, will eventually become the Wildcats’ coach after Rich Brooks’s retirement. Brooks, 66, has not set a timetable for his retirement, the university said. He signed a contract extension through 2011 on Friday that will pay him $1.6 million a season. Phillips would become the university’s first black head football coach.

headline: Fischer vs. the World: A Chess Giant’s Endgame
text: There may be only three human activities in which miraculous accomplishment is possible before adulthood: mathematics, music and chess. These are abstract, almost invented realms, closed systems bounded by rules of custom or principle. Here, the child learns, is how elements combine and transform; here are the laws that govern their interactions; and here are the possibilities that emerge as you play with signs, symbols, sounds or pieces. Nothing else need be known or understood  at least at first. A child’s gifts in such realms can seem otherworldly, the achievements effortlessly magical. But as Bobby Fischer’s death on Thursday might remind us, even abstract gifts can exact a terrible price.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Thursday about cultural groups in England that face funding cuts from the government-financed Arts Council England included a quotation from Louise Wylie, the council’s director of media relations, that misstated the plans of the Bush Theater in West London, which faces a cut. The theater, in fact, does not plan to scale back productions in the next three years.

headline: Players Recall Fischer as Inspiring and Difficult
text: Chess players and chess journalists from around the world reacted on Friday to the death of Bobby Fischer with a mixture of sadness, praise and lingering anger about his behavior in his later years.

headline: Sprint’s Customer Erosion Prompts Cutbacks
text: Sprint Nextel’s announcement on Friday that it is losing customers more rapidly than expected is making investors nervous about a weak economy’s effect on other wireless companies.

headline: Maryland Pulls Away to Win
text: Marah Strickland and Kristi Toliver made consecutive 3-pointers in the second half Friday night to help No. 4 Maryland defeat host Virginia, 74-62, for its 11th consecutive victory.

headline: More Kremlin Harassment
text: The British Council is a cultural organization, partially financed by the British government, operating in more than 100 countries around the world. It exhibits films, educates English teachers and, in some countries, sets up student exchange programs  hardly a hotbed of sedition. Nonetheless, the Kremlin has ordered the council to close two of its three offices in Russia.

headline: Bond Insurers’ Distress Rattles Wall Street
text: If it was a terrible week for Wall Street, it was a devastating one for companies that promise to protect investors against bond losses.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A Week in Review article on Jan. 6 about Pakistan’s history of difficulty in sustaining democracy misidentified the military leader under whom Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who would later become prime minister, served as foreign minister in the 1960s. The leader was Gen. Ayub Khan, not Gen. Yahya Khan. The article also misstated the timing of the disputed parliamentary election that left Mr. Bhutto in a position to emerge from a civil war in 1971 as the first civilian head of government of a truncated Pakistan. The election was held before the war in 1970, not after the war.

headline: ‘NYPD’ Producer Revisits the Police
text: David Milch, the writer and producer best known for his work on “NYPD Blue,” “Hill Street Blues” and “Deadwood,” is working on a new HBO police show, “Last of the Ninth,” which focuses on the rampant corruption in the New York Police Department in the 1970s, Reuters reported. Mr. Milch wrote the pilot with his fellow “NYPD Blue” executive producer Bill Clark, a former New York homicide detective. “Last of the Ninth” stems from Mr. Milch’s development deal with HBO, which was extended in August after the network canceled his most recent show, “John From Cincinnati,” at the end of its first season.

headline: No. 3 U.S. Diplomat, Lead Negotiator on Iran, Retires
text: WASHINGTON  R. Nicholas Burns, the country’s third-ranking diplomat and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice’s right-hand man, is retiring for personal reasons, the State Department said Friday.

headline: When to Start the School Day, So Kids Learn
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: Editor's Note

headline: Barred Driver Returns to Track, Raising Doubts About Discipline
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. Eric Ledford made his return to the Meadowlands on Thursday night, about 21 months after being arrested and charged with race fixing, about 21 months after the New Jersey State Police said it had “dealt a crushing blow to illegal activity in the sport of harness racing.”

headline: Brutality in Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: License, Registration and DNA, Please
text: A brake light on Howard Blum’s car had burned out, a bit of news he learned when a police officer pulled him over one evening last year as he drove up Park Avenue in Manhattan. Mr. Blum, on his way home to Connecticut, produced his license and registration for the police officer, who returned to his patrol car to check on the documents.

headline: SAG Show Is New Star of Awards Telecasts
text: LOS ANGELES  For most of their first 13 years, the Screen Actors Guild Awards played little more than the role of a seat-filler, taking up space between the real shows of the Golden Globes, the Oscars and the Emmys.

headline: The Just-So Story of a Justified Ruff-and-Sluff
text: There are a lot of bridge proverbs that we learn, proverbially, at our grandmother’s knee. Bridge has survived because we can rarely use the words always and never in those maxims. Take, for example, the axiom “Never give declarer a ruff-and-sluff.” Most of the time that is good advice, but not always.

headline: Armored Vehicle Supply Better After Early Delays
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The Defense Department has now delivered more than 1,500 heavily armored ground transport vehicles to Iraq and Afghanistan in an accelerated program to protect American troops from improvised explosives, senior Pentagon officials said Friday.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $6,881,972

headline: Capturing Dream States and Unraveling Knots
text: Nearly 30 years ago, when he was about to celebrate his 70th birthday, I did an interview with Elliott Carter in which we touched on the freighted question of whether a composer can write memorable themes in a difficult modern style. After musing for a moment that certain kinds of art are easier for some listeners than for others, Mr. Carter mentioned that the pianist Ursula Oppens had spoken with him that morning about one of his works she was about to perform.

headline: Precision in a Pub-Like Setting
text: FRIMLEY GREEN, England  Evoking an oversized English pub with a cover charge disguised as admission to a sporting event, the lights were dim, the beer flowed freely and the audience was getting rowdy.

headline: Can You Hear Me Now?
text: A judge wants more information before she decides whether to let the rapper Foxy Brown, below, get out of jail and go to California for repair of an electronic ear implant, The Associated Press reported. Judge Melissa C. Jackson of Manhattan Criminal Court said she wants proof that deafness looms unless Ms. Brown, 29, goes to a Los Angeles clinic for treatment and repair of a cochlear implant. Ms. Brown revealed her hearing problems during a court appearance in late 2004. Her petition says that her condition is worsening in jail and her hearing faces serious harm unless she has the implant reprogrammed and repaired. Ms. Brown, whose real name is Inga Marchand, was sentenced in September to a year in jail for violating probation. She was put on probation after pleading guilty to misdemeanor assault of two manicurists at a Manhattan nail salon in August 2004.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article on Tuesday about Barack Obama’s pursuit of Latino voters in his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination gave an incorrect date for a speech he gave to supporters in Reno, Nev. It was on Monday, not last weekend.

headline: Israel Closes All Gaza Border Crossings, Citing Palestinian Rocket Attacks
text: JERUSALEM  Israel closed all border crossings with the Gaza Strip on Friday, cutting off at least one aid shipment, and bombed the empty Interior Ministry building of the Palestinian Authority, which was already a ruin after a previous Israeli bombing.

headline: Inspired by Old Masters, and Each Other’s Artistry
text: That the musicians of the New York Philharmonic play so well for Riccardo Muti cannot be explained simply by their well-established respect for this eminent conductor’s skills. Their relationship has that inexplicable chemistry that sometimes just happens, as was clear from the ecstatic performance of Scriabin’s weirdly fascinating “Poem of Ecstasy” that ended the orchestra’s program on Thursday night.

headline: Fear and Voting in Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the thriving illegal trade in fish to Europe included an incorrect conversion from euros to dollars for the value of the European market for fish. It is worth more than 14 billion euros a year, or about $20.6 billion  not $22 billion.

headline: Former N.F.L. Player Pleads Guilty in Steroids Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Dana Stubblefield, a three-time Pro Bowl selection as a defensive lineman in the National Football League, pleaded guilty in federal court Friday afternoon with making false statements to a federal agent about performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Two Escapees Are Remanded to Prison in New Jersey
text: ELIZABETH, N.J.  More than four weeks after making a remarkable escape from their county jail cells in New Jersey, two inmates finally returned to the building they had fled.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Thursday about a new DNA test that can help predict the risk of prostate cancer misstated the name of a company formed by researchers at Wake Forest University that plans to market the test this year. It is Proactive Genomics, not ProActive Genetics.

headline: Prosecutor Quashes Charges Against Judge
text: HOUSTON  A grand jury’s bitter backroom struggle to charge a Texas Supreme Court justice and his wife in the burning of their house burst into the open on Friday after a prosecutor who had opposed the indictments went to court and had them quashed.

headline: Belgian Tourists Killed in Yemen Ambush
text: SANAA, Yemen  Gunmen opened fire on a tourist convoy Friday afternoon in the eastern Hadramawt region, killing two Belgian women and two Yemeni drivers, Yemeni officials said.

headline: A New, Global Oil Quandary: Costly Fuel Means Costly Calories
text: KUANTAN, Malaysia  Rising prices for cooking oil are forcing residents of Asia’s largest slum, in Mumbai, India, to ration every drop. Bakeries in the United States are fretting over higher shortening costs. And here in Malaysia, brand-new factories built to convert vegetable oil into diesel sit idle, their owners unable to afford the raw material.

headline: Editors’ Note: Bridgeport’s New Mayor and His Senate Seat
text: An article in the Connecticut section this weekend describes the decision by Mayor Bill Finch of Bridgeport to retain his seat in the State Senate pending a State Supreme Court ruling on the mayoral election. After the article went to press on Friday, Mr. Finch announced that he would resign the Senate seat.

headline: Genetic Bank Raises Issues of Practicality and Privacy
text: Simple cotton swabs would be rubbed inside the mouths of suspects. The collected human cheek cells would then be mined for DNA strands. And those samples would be put together as potential evidence in prosecutions.

headline: Canadian Gets Life in Qaeda Bomb Plot
text: A Canadian man who once met personally with top leaders of Al Qaeda in devising a plot to blow up United States embassies in Singapore and the Philippines was sentenced on Friday to life in prison at a court hearing in Manhattan.

headline: Russian Boxer's Bout Honors 2 Whose Lives Were Cut Short
text: Roman Karmazin, a world-class professional boxer, has never met the families of Russel Timoshenko, a New York City police officer, and Yevgeniy Marshalik, an auxiliary officer, who died in the line of duty last year.

headline: He Violated Probation, but Gets to Keep the Prize
text: A man who was convicted of robbing banks so he could buy scratch-off lottery tickets does not have to worry about keeping the $1 million he won in the Massachusetts lottery.

headline: The Immigrant Vote
text: The Nevada caucuses today will be the first test of the mood of immigrant voters since comprehensive immigration reform was killed.

headline: Thompson, Lingering in Midpack, Sticks to a Slow and Steady Strategy
text: LAURENS, S.C.  The presidential candidate known as Fred moseys into Whiteford’s Giant Burger, possessing that La-Z-Boy manner and a fistful of conservative principles.

headline: Damaged Landscape Can Still Be Helpful, Researchers Say
text: Researchers who study coastal mangroves, sea-grass beds, coral reefs and sand dunes are reporting that, contrary to widely held views, environmental preservation on the coast does not have to be an all-or-nothing proposition and that landscapes can perform “services” like storm protection even if they have been somewhat disturbed by development.

headline: Spain Arrests 14 in Plotting Attack
text: MADRID  Spain was on high alert for terrorist attacks on Saturday after the police arrested 14 suspects of Pakistani and Indian origin who authorities contend were plotting an attack on Barcelona, officials said.

headline: S-q-u-a-b-b-l-e
text: THIRD-PARTY applications are supposedly the secret to Facebook’s success.

headline: Job Data Passes Threshold Where Recessions Dwell
text: When the number of Americans out of work starts to rise sharply, a recession occurs.

headline: Justices Add More Cases on Job Discrimination
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday added two new employment discrimination cases to a docket on which such cases are already well represented.

headline: Which Movies Are Right for Kids?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Baseball Already Knew of Rise in Exemptions
text: As major leaguers ponder their goals for the 2008 season, some hitters wonder how many runs they will drive in, some pitchers wonder how many earned runs they will permit. And some players wonder about securing their therapeutic-use exemption.

headline: Former Secretary on Waterboarding
text: The first secretary of homeland security says waterboarding is torture. “There’s just no doubt in my mind  under any set of rules, waterboarding is torture,” the former secretary, Tom Ridge, said in an interview. Mr. Ridge offered the same opinion earlier in the day to members of the American Bar Association at a conference on national security. Mr. Ridge served as secretary from 2003 to 2005. He said: “I believe, unlike others in the administration, that waterboarding was, is and will always be torture. That’s a simple statement.” The Central Intelligence Agency has not used waterboarding as an interrogation technique since 2003, and the director of the agency, Michael V. Hayden, prohibited it in 2006, officials said.

headline: Sergeant Is Accused of Aiding Drug Ring
text: A New York City police sergeant faces charges that he used a police computer to aid a man federal prosecutors call the leader of a crack-cocaine distribution ring.

headline: Courts and Terror Cases
text: To the Editor:

headline: McCain Wins South Carolina Primary
text: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Senator John McCain staved off a spirited challenge by former Gov. Mike Huckabee to win the South Carolina primary on Saturday, exorcising the ghosts of the attack-filled primary here that derailed his presidential hopes eight years ago.

headline: Anthony Solomon,  Finance Policy Maker, Is Dead at 88
text: Anthony M. Solomon, a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and an influential behind-the-scenes financial policy maker in three presidential administrations and at the World Bank, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Despite Deadly Clashes in Iraq, Shiite Pilgrims Spared
text: BAGHDAD  Government troops in southern Iraq fought with a millennial religious militia group on Friday in clashes that left more than 40 people dead, but the troops successfully protected millions of pilgrims on the first day of Ashura, the largest religious holiday for Iraq’s Shiite majority and one frequently marred by violence.

headline: A Leaf Spinning, Darting and Falling in an Electronic Tempest of Light and Video
text: Richard Siegal plunges into a dark and tumultuous world in his new “As if Stranger,” which opened on Thursday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church. The most acute of dancers, he moves like a leaf in a powerful and contrary wind. Smart and imaginative, he is lost in the roiling void that he has created with pieces of electronic equipment and huge cables and plugs.

headline: Between Pulpit and Podium, Huckabee Straddles Fine Line
text: SPARTANBURG, S.C.  Mike Huckabee mentioned his faith only glancingly in his stump speech this week at North Greenville University in Tigerville, S.C. Discussing presidential decisions that will matter after he is long gone, he added: “By the way, I have made arrangements for what happens after that, and it’s all good. It’s all good.”

headline: In Pursuing Terror Cases, Respect Our Freedoms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bobby Fischer, Troubled Genius of Chess, Dies at 64
text: Bobby Fischer, the Chicago-born, Brooklyn-bred genius who became one of the greatest chess players the world has ever seen, died on Thursday in Reykjavik, Iceland. He was 64.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Friday about the Australian Open misstated, in some editions, the score in the fifth set of a match when Vince Spadea saved three match points during his eventual victory against Denis Gremelmayr. It was 5-6, not 4-5.

headline: Golfweek Fires Editor Over Noose Cover
text: The parent company of Golfweek magazine on Friday fired the editor who approved this week’s cover image of a noose for an article about the Golf Channel host Kelly Tilghman’s use of the word “lynch” to describe how young players could challenge Tiger Woods.

headline: Oil Demand, the Climate and the Energy Ladder
text: Energy demand is expected to grow in coming decades. Jeroen van der Veer, 60, Royal Dutch Shell’s chief executive, recently offered his views on the energy challenge facing the world and the challenge posed by global warming. He spoke of the need for governments to set limits on carbon emissions. He also lifted the veil on Shell’s latest long-term energy scenarios, titled Scramble and Blueprints, which he will make public next week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Following are excerpts from the interview:

headline: Work Is Afoot to Take the Free Out of Freeway
text: DELAWARE WATER GAP, Pa.  Hundreds of cars and trucks scream past Chris Howsare and Laren Myers in the half-hour they spend examining the hodgepodge of wetlands, historic landmarks and utility lines on the stretch of Interstate 80 that bisects this town on the New Jersey border.

headline: Researchers Go Unchecked, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON  The National Institutes of Health do almost nothing to monitor the financial conflicts of university professors to whom it provides grants, a government report found, and the huge federal research agency does not want to start now.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article last Saturday about jury selection in the murder trial of Cesar Rodriguez, the stepfather of Nixzmary Brown, a 7-year-old Brooklyn girl who was beaten to death two years ago, misidentified her home address in Bedford-Stuyvesant. It was Greene Avenue, not Green Street.

headline: Bracing for the Cold, Giants’ Punter Puts Emphasis on Receiving
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jeff Feagles is too old to try to play cool. He will wear gloves during the National Football Conference championship game Sunday at Green Bay’s Lambeau Field because he does not want to let this opportunity slip through his hands.

headline: In Nevada, Campaigns Face a Common Foe
text: ELKO, Nev.  On the eve of the Nevada caucuses, the third stop in the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination, the campaigns were doing more Friday than feverishly rallying their supporters. They were also fielding a question: What, exactly, is a caucus?

headline: Detainee’s Lawyers Rebut C.I.A. on Tapes
text: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for Majid Khan, a detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, have challenged the Central Intelligence Agency’s assertion that videotaping of interrogations stopped in 2002, saying that Mr. Khan’s interrogations after that time were recorded on videotape.

headline: Back to Roots, G.M. and Toyota Trade Places Again
text: DETROIT  At last year’s auto show here, General Motors and Toyota Motor seemed to be trying to steal each other’s core customers. G.M. unveiled the Chevrolet Volt, a hybrid-electric concept car, to bolster its green credentials. And Toyota took the wraps off its huge new Tundra, which has a big V-8.

headline: A Most Proper Marriage: Jane Austen and PBS
text: Like the current fad for Chinoiserie or fatty meats or big-patterned wallpaper, Masterpiece Theater’s presentation of “The Complete Jane Austen,” a seven-part series in full swing on PBS, feels like something that has already happened. How can it be that television’s great purveyor of baronial imagery  the sweeping shots of mist-covered dells and manor houses, the close-ups of blushed cheeks at the ball  had failed to commit itself fully to the novelist as attached to her property fetish as she was to her moral vision of love? Let it be said that “Masterpiece Theater” has been remiss. Let it also be said that it has compensated for its lax ways.

headline: Justices to Hear Cases on Product Liability
text: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The Supreme Court’s already substantial investment in defining the boundary between federal regulation and state tort law grew even bigger on Friday. The justices added two new cases to their docket on drug and cigarette labeling requirements.

headline: Help for Afghanistan
text: To the Editor:

headline: West Virginia Judge Steps Out of Case Involving a Travel Companion
text: Chief Justice Elliott E. Maynard of the West Virginia Supreme Court disqualified himself on Friday from further participation in a case involving a powerful coal executive after photographs of the two men meeting in Monte Carlo in 2006 were filed in court this week.

headline: TV Networks’ Schedule Competition Is Starting to Resemble a Quilting Bee
text: With favorite scripted shows like “Desperate Housewives,” “The Office” and “CSI” now out of fresh episodes, the strike-torn network television season is starting to look like the National Football League around 1987, when “replacement players” took over the league for three weeks during a walkout by the real players.

text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Jan. 19 column.

text: Presidential candidates campaigned Friday in South Carolina and Nevada.

headline: Ouch! Sid’s on the Shelf
text: The NHL will have to get along without Sidney Crosby perhaps for a month after the league’s brightest light slid heavily into the endboards Friday night against Tampa Bay and sustained what was called a high ankle sprain.

headline: The Carpetbagger at Sundance
text: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) hoofs it to Park City, Utah, for the 2008 Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Dressing for Lambeau
text: What Ryan Verrier will wear, head to frozen toes, on Sunday at Lambeau Field.

text: A hockey team on Long Island is one of many in the region and the country that specialize in coaching children who have disabilities.

headline: Video: The Carpetbagger at Sundance

text: ORLANDO, Fla. – Today is about tie-breaking. headline: My Space, My Ketchup
text: Branding is a constant at Sundance. Everything is brought to you by someone. In the MySpace Celebrity Lounge at the bottom of the chair in Park City, there was a nice place to check e-mail messages and get some vittles. Even though the Bagger is a few rungs belong a celebrity – he doesn’t even write about them that much – Lisette, who runs the joint, let him and his camera crew in for a latte and a warm-up. The Bagger was enjoying the high life for the moment, sipping the froth of another galaxy, and then he noticed that both the ketchup and the mustard were branded. My Space Ketchup and My Space Mustard. Rupert Murdoch, chieftain of MySpace owner News Corporation, is clearly at the top of his game, grabbing every opportunity to remind the rest of us that there is not much that he won’t eventually own, including the condiments of life. Now, you want fries with that?

headline: Cleaning Up
text: “Sunshine Cleaning” was a tidy, crowd-pleasing hit, with much of main street bubbling about its charms. IndieWire liked it a bunch, calling it “an affecting, well-acted drama that casts an even brighter spotlight on rising starlet Amy Adams.” At the party afterwards, Harvey Weinstein was out front, chatting about the film — the Bagger did not lean in, so shame on him — and inside Marc Turtletaub was not gloating, but you could tell he knew he had a winner on his hands. Look for the film, which also stars Emily Blunt, to be part of the story of movies that got a nice start at Sundance.

headline: The Best Movie Ever
text: Emily Mortimer, the winsome, friendly star of “Transsiberian,” told the audience at the premiere that the film, the result of an arduous, vodka-infused shoot with Sir Ben Kingsley and Woody Harrelson, was the best set she had ever been on. The Bagger reminded her that she had said the same thing about “Lars and the Real Girl,” another movie that benefited from her talents. “But I really was being sincere this time,” she said, managing not to bat her eyes. “I love these guys.”

headline: At the White Hot Center of Things
text: Last night, the Bagger went to Reaction Lounge on Main St. for the after-party for “Transsiberian,” the Brad Anderson directed psycho-thriller. There was a bit of a flow problem in the middle of the room at a narrow hallway near the stars – Emily Mortimer and Woody Harrelson. The Bagger wanted to pay his respects, but a large man on a cell phone was using his backside to push the him away, and a seated woman, who was now being stepped on by the Bagger, began pummeling his lower back with fists. He could not move. Just then, a young woman who was also pinned in front of him, managed to get out a business card and slime the Bagger, saying she had a client that she’d like him to speak to. If the Bagger had a grenade on him at that instant, he would have pulled the pin.

If Malik has a lower point, the Rangers surely do not want to see it. He seems certain to be a healthy scratch in today’s rematch with Boston and team management has to be mulling a way out.

headline: Your Comments on “Hillary, Barack, Experience.”

I argue that the value of traditional Washington experience is overrated as a prerequisite for the presidency: Experience itself is useful, but that includes unorthodox kinds such as growing up in Indonesia. And history suggests that governors often make better presidents than senators, because they gain executive experience. Please post your comments here.

headline: A Festival to Celebrate a Fabled Wine
text: EVERY year, in the depths of winter, the newest vintage of a little-known wine is unveiled in a weekend of festivities in the Jura mountains of eastern France. The Percée du Vin Jaune  literally, the piercing of the yellow wine  marks the opening of the latest batch of this cult wine, whose minerally taste some compare to sherry. Busloads of wine lovers arrive from all over Europe, with some 50,000 expected at this year’s event, which will take place Feb. 2 and 3. The atmosphere varies from party-hearty (visitors receive a glass to use for wine-tasting, and a cord from which to conveniently dangle it from their necks) to serious oenophilia.

headline: 36 Hours in Breckenridge, Colo.
text: WHEN carving down Breckenridge, which was one of the first major resorts to embrace snowboarders, it still helps to pack a phrase book for common sayings like, “Sick pow, bro!” This former mining town, unlike its upscale Colorado neighbors, Vail and Aspen, still exudes a crunchy, laid-back vibe. But Breckenridge also has a new shine. Multimillion-dollar condos now loom over old miners’ cabins. The year-old BreckConnect Gondola soars over pine forests cleared for luxury homes. And in the historic downtown, wine bars serving marinated olives are taking the place of honky-tonks with beer and Buffalo wings. Still, it’s your gnarly moves, not your designer outfit, that gets locals stoked.

headline: South Poll
text: The campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination has thus far been marked by a heightened sense of history and optimism  the former because its two leading candidates are pushing up against societal barriers that were once thought unmovable; the latter because Democrats feel as assured of recapturing the presidency as they have at any time since the post-Watergate election of 1976. Now it’s reality-check time. After early contests in friendlier territories, the nomination fight moves this week into the heart of the Old South, where the inspiring story line of a woman dueling with an African-American will collide, at last, with another side of history. While much of the primary electorate in South Carolina comprises traditional Democrats (black voters, college-town liberals, etc.), the candidates will nonetheless encounter, in a broader way, a less-welcoming political culture in a state that hasn’t voted for a Democratic nominee since Jimmy Carter.

headline: Inside the List
text: BEST AND BRIGHTEST I: Thirty-five years ago this week, in January of 1973, the No. 1 nonfiction title was “The Best and the Brightest,” by David Halberstam, a wide-screen, gossip-packed account of the snaky path to war in Vietnam. The book’s reviews were essentially positive, with one notable exception: Mary McCarthy’s scorched-earth put-down in The New York Review of Books. (While reading Halberstam’s book, McCarthy wrote, she was “unable to stay awake for more than a few paragraphs at a go without ferocious application of will power, tea, coffee, drinks of water, propping open of eyelids, pinches, strolls about the room.” And that’s a friendly passage.) McCarthy’s 7,000-word review didn’t stop the book from selling; it remained on the hardcover list for 36 weeks, and Halberstam sold the paperback rights for $700,000. As John Leonard, then the Book Review’s editor, wrote at the time, the paperback money “presumably makes a nice poultice to apply to the wounds of pride.”

Meals will be taken in the dining hall, and nights will be spent in Worcester College, which has an 18th-century chapel and hall and extensive gardens.

headline: The Education of Ben Bernanke
text: Ben Bernanke’s first exposure to monetary policy was reading the works of Milton Friedman, the Nobel laureate. That was 30 years ago, when Bernanke was a graduate student at M.I.T., and he has been studying central banking ever since. By the time President Bush nominated him to run the Federal Reserve, at the end of 2005, Bernanke knew more about central banking than any economist alive. On virtually every topic of significance  how to prevent deflationary panics, for instance, or to gauge the effect of Fed moves on stock-market prices  Bernanke wrote one of the seminal papers. He championed ideas for improving communications between the Fed  whose previous chairman, Alan Greenspan, spoke in riddles  and the public, believing that clearer guidance about the Fed’s aims would help the economy run more smoothly. And having devoted much of his career to studying the causes of the Great Depression, Bernanke was the academic expert on how to prevent financial crises from spinning out of control and threatening the general economy. One line from his “Essays on the Great Depression” sounds especially prescient today: “To the extent that bank panics interfere with normal flows of credit, they may affect the performance of the real economy.”
