headline: The Campaign Goes Big Time
text: O.K. The presidential race is beginning to move out of the retail politics mode. No more Q. and A. sessions in picturesque community centers. The Republicans are off to Florida, a very large place you just can’t woo one town hall after another — although Rudy Giuliani is certainly giving it the old college try.

headline: The Campaign Goes Big Time
text: Okay. The presidential race is beginning to move out of the retail politics mode. No more Q. and A. sessions in picturesque community centers. The Republicans are off to Florida, a very large place you just can’t woo one town hall after another — although Rudy Giuliani is certainly giving it the old college try.

headline: Lower Aid Increase Planned for Schools in New York City
text: ALBANY  New York City schools are likely to receive $100 million less in operating aid than the city expected in the budget that Gov. Eliot Spitzer will unveil on Tuesday.

headline: Power Ballads for Suburbanites
text: Wholesomeness reigned when Rascal Flatts headlined Madison Square Garden on Friday night. The top band in 21st-century country music, with four multimillion-selling albums and a fifth that has sold a million copies since September, Rascal Flatts is fearlessly contented and relentlessly inoffensive.

headline: Letter From Penn Berates Paper That Used Him as a Contributor
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A letter to the editor in The San Francisco Chronicle last Monday attacked the “increasingly lame-brain paper” and said parts of it resembled Mad Magazine. It was signed: SEAN PENN, Former SF Chronicle contributing reporter.

headline: Gaza Power Plant Shuts Down Over Dispute
text: JERUSALEM  Israel’s closing of its border crossings with Gaza remained in effect Sunday, and Gaza’s only electricity plant shut down because of a shortage of imported fuel needed to run it.

headline: Israel Is Set to Promote the Use of Electric Cars
text: JERUSALEM  Israel, tiny and bereft of oil, has decided to embrace the electric car.

headline: New York City Braces as Fear on Economy Creeps In
text: By most official measures, the New York metropolitan area appears to be shrugging off the economic troubles that have beset much of the country. With fears of an imminent recession spreading from California to Michigan to Washington, the latest data still show New York recording job gains and rising tax revenue.

headline: Tough but Smart on Drugs
text: A dozen troubled men and women from Hempstead, N.Y., got an unusual break this month. They had been caught on tape selling drugs, and as repeat offenders faced serious prison time. But after attending a community meeting, at which they endured the scoldings of neighbors and promised a prosecutor that they would stay out of trouble and take advantage of social services like drug treatment, they walked free.

headline: The Women Who Protest Deaths of Man After Man
text: Ariel Dorfman’s “Widows,” having its New York premiere at 59E59 Theaters, is the kind of play that makes you feel bad for being bored.

headline: Turkmenistan Lifts Ban on Opera and Circuses
text: Happy days are here again for lovers of opera and circus in Turkmenistan. Reversing a ban imposed in 2001, President Gurbanguli Berdymukhamedov said that the Central Asian nation deserved to have the artistic performances, The Associated Press reported on Sunday. “Our flourishing nation should not stand separate from the world,” he said at a meeting, the state-run television reported. “It absolutely should have a worthy operatic theater and a worthy state circus.” The ban was imposed by President-for-Life Saparmurat Niyazov, who declared opera and ballet to be foreign to Turkmen culture and allowed financing for state-sponsored circuses to dry up. He died in 2006 after more than two decades in power. President Berdymukhamedov estimated that the first opera would be performed in six or seven months. It was unclear if his order covered the return of ballet.

headline: Frontline Blogger Covers War in Iraq With a Soldier’s Eyes
text: Michael Yon was not a journalist, and he wasn’t sure what a blogger was. He had been in uniform but not in combat, and he wanted to keep it that way. He went to Iraq thinking he would stay for a month, and maybe find a way to write about the war after he got home.

headline: Evolving and Mutating, Dubstep Splits Cells and Gives Life to Dance Floors
text: You could tell this wasn’t a normal dance party because the music kept doing something strange: stopping. The record would spin backward, the dancers would cheer, the D.J. would pause, and then the song would start again, from the top. This crowd-teasing technique  the rewind  has long been a major element of reggae concerts and parties. And as a few hundred dancers were reminded on Friday night, it also lives on in the reggae-influenced electronic genre known as dubstep, which has sprouted around London over the last few years.

headline: New York Measuring Teachers by Test Scores
text: New York City has embarked on an ambitious experiment, yet to be announced, in which some 2,500 teachers are being measured on how much their students improve on annual standardized tests.

headline: Bomber Kills Sunni Allies of the U.S.
text: BAGHDAD  A teenager holding a box of candy strode into a gathering of Sunni Arab tribal members near Falluja and detonated an explosive belt, killing four people and wounding nine, members of the Issawi tribe said Sunday. It was the second major bomb attack to strike American allies in Anbar Province in two days.

headline: Doctors Say Suharto Shows Signs of Recovery
text: SOLO, Indonesia  In what they called an amazing recovery, doctors in Jakarta said Sunday that former President Suharto was beginning to move his hands and speak and that they were preparing to begin physical therapy.

headline: Betting on a Bright Future for Rear-Projection TVs
text: PLANO, Tex.  Back in the early years of this decade, when plasma high-definition televisions cost $10,000, consumers found that buying a rear-projection TV was a more affordable way to jump into the digital era.

headline: What Was Added, and What Was Taken Away
text: There was a lot going on in “ ... Not the Same Solo,” an intriguing program presented by the Whitney Live program and Jonah Bokaer’s Chez Bushwick on Friday night at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Three dancers performed solos, which each had adapted from a piece by Deborah Hay called “News.” All were participating in Ms. Hay’s Solo Performance Commissioning Project, in which dance artists from around the world work with her on an assigned dance and then spend at least three months adapting it, adding elements like costumes, sound, text, sets and extra performers, with the option of subtracting choreography.

headline: The Video Game May Be Free, but to Be a Winner Can Cost Money
text: Ever since John Riccitiello took over last year as chief executive of Electronic Arts, the video game industry bellwether, he has promised to revitalize the company with new games and new ways of reaching consumers. Now, that may be happening.

headline: Indie Riffs Wrapped in Reverb
text: Saturday could have been billed as Reverb Night at Terminal 5. All three bands on the bill  Blonde Redhead, the Raveonettes and School of Seven Bells  enveloped their songs in the overtone haze of reverb, the better to conjure grand, mysterious, incantatory recesses in simple structures.

headline: Born of ‘Juno’: A Hit Soundtrack With an Uneasy Singer at Its Heart
text: Her songs are all over a hit indie soundtrack, and new fans are mobbing her concerts. Most musicians would see this as good news. But for Kimya Dawson, the 35-year-old den mother of the tiny anti-folk scene, all the attention for her music in the film “Juno” is a little troubling.

headline: Court Backs Borat
text: Sacha Baron Cohen, below, creator of the boorish Kazakh journalist Borat Sagdiyev, has emerged victorious from a lawsuit brought by Kathie Martin, an etiquette teacher who unwittingly appeared in the hit movie “Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan.” Overruling a lower court, the Alabama Supreme Court decided that Alabama could not be the forum for Ms. Martin’s lawsuit against Mr. Cohen and the companies that produced the film because she had signed an agreement stating that only courts in New York could hear disputes arising from her appearance, The Associated Press reported. South Carolina fraternity members, a Maryland driving instructor, Romanian villagers and a businessman seen fleeing from a hug from Mr. Cohen are among those who have filed suit over the movie, which has grossed more than $200 million.

headline: It’s Good, and Giants Head to Super Bowl
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Under a full moon, a black sky and a crisp and cruel blanket of cold, the Giants stood on the frozen sideline of Lambeau Field, waiting for a rush of warmth.

headline: A Hair-Trigger Double Helps Determine a Contract
text: You are playing in a team-of-four match. Your table finishes much quicker than the one where your teammates are playing. You could get up and move around, or you could chat with your opponents. For a journalist talking is the much better plan, especially if you are playing against someone with a good eye for a deal.

headline: Farewell Remarks by Los Angeles Editor
text: Following is the text of an e-mail message sent on Monday by James E. O’Shea after he was ousted as editor of The Los Angeles Times:

headline: In Brooklyn, a Psychic for the Famous, or Rather, for Their Pets
text: Christine Agro’s career as a pet psychic to the stars started, as so many auspicious events do, with a particularly open chakra. The chakra in question did not belong to her, but to a young woman who happened to pop into one of Ms. Agro’s yoga classes in upstate New York five years ago, and thanked her at the end of class for freeing up that center of spiritual energy.

headline: Can’t Tell a Book by Its Cover, or Even Its Title, It Turns Out
text: When Missy Chase Lapine, author of the cookbook “The Sneaky Chef” that suggests ways to hide fruit and vegetables in dishes for finicky children, was angered by the publication of “Deceptively Delicious,” a similar book by Jessica Seinfeld (a k a Mrs. Jerry Seinfeld), she had recourse. This month, she sued for copyright infringement and defamation.

headline: Los Angeles Editor Ousted After Resisting Job Cuts
text: The top editor of The Los Angeles Times has been forced out for resisting newsroom budget cuts, executives at the paper said Sunday, marking the fourth time in less than three years that the highest-ranking editor or the publisher has left for that reason.

headline: Campaign Reporting in Under 140 Taps
text: “NASHUA: Just saw Bill O’reily misbehaving at Obama rallly. Shoving Obama staffer.”

headline: Baryshnikov Arts Center Gets New Director
text: Stanford Makishi has been appointed executive director of the Baryshnikov Arts Center. Mr. Makishi, formerly the director of creative services at Carnegie Hall, succeeds Christina Sterner, who stepped down at the end of 2007 after 20 years. The arts organization built by Mikhail Baryshnikov and Ms. Sterner has brought contemporary works, notably through the White Oak Dance Project, to stages around the world. In 2005 they opened the Baryshnikov Arts Center on West 37th Street.

headline: Britain to Aid Northern Rock Sale
text: LONDON  The British Treasury said Monday that it would facilitate a sale of the troubled mortgage lender Northern Rock by converting a pool of the company’s assets to bonds for sale to investors.

headline: Favre’s Pass to Driver Provides Early Spark
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Early in the second quarter, after three unsuccessful drives, the Packers’ offense had matched the temperatures at Lambeau Field. Both were well below freezing.

headline: Los Angeles Times Editor Forced Out
text: The top editor of The Los Angeles Times has been forced out for resisting newsroom budget cuts, executives at the paper said Sunday, marking the fourth time in less than three years that the highest-ranking editor or the publisher has left for that reason.

headline: None but Soulful Hearts for Schubert and Goethe
text: Schubert’s attraction to Goethe approached obsession. He set “None but the Lonely Heart” six times and returned again and again to the poetry of “Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship” and “Faust.” Goethe took up much of Saturday night’s Schubert recital at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Pregnancy Problems Tied to Caffeine
text: Too much caffeine during pregnancy may increase the risk of miscarriage, a new study says, and the authors suggest that pregnant women may want to reduce their intake or cut it out entirely.

headline: After Nevada Loss, Edwards Hangs On
text: ATLANTA  It looked like sweet relief for John Edwards that more than 1,700 miles separated him from the Nevada caucuses on Saturday.

headline: Radical Love Gets a Holiday
text: IN 1983, Ronald Reagan signed a bill honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a federal holiday. Reagan opposed it, but back then, in the olden times of checks and balances, the vote by 338 representatives and 78 senators establishing the holiday threatened certain veto override.

headline: To Drive or Not to Drive: That Was Never the Question
text: Every now and then I meet someone in Manhattan who has never driven a car. Some confess it sheepishly, and some announce it proudly. For some it is just a practical matter of fact, the equivalent of not keeping a horse on West 87th Street or Avenue A. Still, I used to wonder at such people, but more and more I wonder at myself.

headline: Undaunted Director at Indian Museum
text: WASHINGTON  It was not exactly a welcome mat that greeted the new museum director. When Kevin Gover left his quiet life teaching American Indian law among the cactuses of Arizona to lead the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian here, he arrived during a storm of publicity about spending by his predecessor, W. Richard West Jr.

headline: Favre Energizes Packers’ Offense With One Throw
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Early in the second quarter, after three unsuccessful drives, the Packers’ offense had matched the temperatures at Lambeau Field. Both were well below freezing.

headline: Suharto, From Verge of Death, Is Making a Recovery
text: SOLO, Indonesia  In what they called an amazing recovery, doctors in Jakarta said Sunday that former President Suharto had begun to move his hands and speak and that they were preparing to begin physical therapy.

headline: In Harlem, 2 Record Stores Go the Way of the Vinyl
text: On Saturday morning, Bobby’s Happy House, a music store in Harlem that opened in 1946, was in a state of chaos.

headline: Fischer’s Roots in City Tangle With His Legacy
text: Before he became notorious for his anti-American and anti-Semitic ravings, and before he became an icon for dominating, and then dismissing, the cloistered world of chess, Robert James Fischer was just Bobby, another young New Yorker on the make.

headline: Ailing UConn Women’s Team Faces Biggest Test in Tar Heels
text: HARTFORD  Before his team’s victory over Cincinnati here Saturday, the University of Connecticut women’s basketball coach, Geno Auriemma, entered to what he thought was a standing ovation. He seemed to deserve it. His Huskies were undefeated, ranked first in the country and winning with ease.

headline: Thoroughly Unmodern McCain
text: In his victory speech after winning the South Carolina primary Saturday night, John McCain acknowledged the economic challenges we face, and then said: “But nothing is inevitable in our country. We are the captains of our fate.”

headline: Taxi Drivers in London Take a Turn as Pitchmen
text: LONDON  Taxi drivers here have never been shy about sharing their views. George W. Bush? The royals? Cabbies are sure to have an opinion. But what if they start talking about Texas Hold ’em or a royal flush?

headline: On Field and in Stands, Proper Attire Is a Must
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Checklist time. Dante Pasqualucci and his teenage daughter Mia would soon be headed to Lambeau Field for the Packers-Giants National Football Conference championship game, and as they sat in a downtown hotel lobby awaiting their cab, a snugly dressed Pasqualucci made sure he was not the only one prepared for single-digit temperatures and numbing wind chill.

headline: Footnotes
text: Nearly 20 Off Broadway shows will offer two tickets for the price of one from Tuesday through Sunday in observance of Live Theater Week, proclaimed by the City Council to celebrate the contribution of live theater to culture in New York. Participants in the promotion, sponsored by the League of Off-Broadway Theaters and Producers, are listed at OffBroadway.org. ... Mariah Carey has set April 1 as the date for the release of her new album, “That Chick,” Billboard reported. Her last album, “The Emancipation of Mimi,” was the biggest-selling album of 2005. ... The Peruvian author Mario Vargas Llosa, 71, was rushed to a hospital in Lima on Friday with heart problems, Agence France-Presse reported. He was released on Saturday after undergoing tests and was out of danger, local news media reported. Mr. Vargas Llosa’s books include “Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter,” “The War of the End of the World” and “The Feast of the Goat.” ... The eighth annual New York Flamenco Festival, running through Feb. 24, will begin on Feb. 8 at Town Hall, with a performance by two of flamenco’s leading singers, Carmen Linares and Miguel Poveda. The festival’s all-star gala, dedicated to the women of flamenco, will be presented on Feb. 15 at New York City Center, where the featured performers will be Merche Esmeralda, Rocio Molina and Belén Maya, with a special appearance by the singer Diana Navarro.

headline: The Truth About Ethics Reform
text: We’ve long grown used to candidates’ cherry-picking each other’s records to score points in a campaign. But the new Congressional ethics law, and the role Senator Barack Obama played in passing it, have been belittled in troubling ways that are worth noting.

headline: Republican Field Rides Full Force Into Florida Test
text: POLK CITY, Fla.  The Republican presidential contest entered a new phase on Sunday as the campaigns descended on Florida for the first primary in which all the candidates are participating full force, using as their stage a state famous for divisive election battles.

headline: Clean Energy as Stimulus
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ex-Newsman Laments a Dying Craft
text: “Something’s burning,” said one reporter to another, absently staring out the window at angry, thick black smoke rising over the city of Baltimore.

headline: 16 and Pregnant: No Fairy Tale Ending
text: To the Editor:

headline: Volcanoes Tied to Thinning of Antarctica’s Glaciers
text: Here is another factor that might be contributing to the thinning of some of the Antarctica’s glaciers: volcanoes.

headline: Where 3 Died in Fire, a Changing Neighborhood
text: The men huddle on street corners in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, like apparitions: No one seems to know their names or anything about them. They speak Spanish in a neighborhood where Italian is still common, even if its presence has waned over the years. They will paint homes, fix roofs, tend to yards or lay bricks if someone is willing to hire them for the day.

headline: Place-Kicker Takes Charge and Makes Up for 2 Misses
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Lawrence Tynes did not wait for Giants Coach Tom Coughlin to call for the field-goal team in overtime. He knew roughly where the ball was, inside the 50. He had already missed two critical fourth-quarter attempts, one with four seconds left that would have sent the Giants to the Super Bowl. He wanted another try as badly as anything he ever wanted in his life.

headline: Darkness in the Land of Steady Sunshine
text: Stephen King’s “Duma Key” ventures to an all-but-uninhabited Florida island where the shells groan at high tide, tennis balls appear unexpectedly, foliage grows ominously quickly, and at least one heron flies upside-down. Given this combination of author and setting, it’s inevitable that something terribly undead will show up before the book is over.

headline: Worried About Rivers, Chargers Lose Tomlinson Instead
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  In the days leading up to Sunday’s American Football Conference title game, the balms and potions that accumulated like junk mail at the San Diego Chargers’ practice facility were intended mainly for quarterback Philip Rivers, who hardly practiced all week because of a sprained right knee.

headline: The Week’s Economic Reports
text: A QUIET WEEK It is a slow week for economic data. The highlight will be the government’s report on existing-home sales for December (Thursday).

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about Bill Clinton’s scolding of a television reporter on Wednesday misstated the location of the reporter’s station, KGO-TV. It is based in San Francisco, not Oakland.

headline: A Finnish Turf Battle Pits Wolf Against Reindeer Herder
text: SUOMUSSALMI, Finland  Close to the tiny Finnish village of Saaravaara, bloody tracks lead through the snow to the frozen carcass of an 8-month-old male reindeer lying on its side, its neck torn, its underbelly ripped open.

headline: Gun Wound Leads to Weapons Trove
text: A 37-year old man who was storing weapons, including pipe bombs, crossbows, guns and silencers, in his Brooklyn Heights apartment was also responsible for writing a rash of hateful messages aimed at Jews in his neighborhood last year, the police said.

headline: Fuel Shortage Shuts Gaza Power Plant, Leaving City Dark
text: JERUSALEM  Israel’s closing of its border crossings with Gaza remained in effect Sunday, and Gaza’s only electricity plant shut down because of a shortage of imported fuel needed to run it.

headline: Obama, Reagan and the Internet
text: While the mainstream media has been obsessed with the presidential horse race (guilty!), the Internet has been obsessed with recent comments by Senator Barack Obama about Ronald Reagan and the Republicans.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Public Lives column in some editions on Friday, about Sandra E. Timmons, president of A Better Chance, a national organization that prepares underprivileged students to attend elite preparatory schools, misidentified the preparatory school that President Bush attended. It is Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.  not Phillips Exeter Academy, which is in Exeter, N.H.

headline: As Sight Dims, a Battle to Keep His Apartment, and His Place in the Sun
text: The floor is uneven and the stove does not work. Nor does the electricity in the kitchen. Until it was fixed eight months ago, there had been a gaping hole in the ceiling for three years. Julio Angarita, 59, is aware of the flaws in his apartment in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn, but he is still happy to call it home.

headline: From MySpace to YourSpace
text: Two years ago, Chris DeWolfe, the co-founder and chief executive of MySpace, was talking about international expansion with Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation bought the social networking site in 2005. According to Mr. DeWolfe, an entrepreneur used to moving at Internet velocity, he suggested that MySpace could expand to “four or five” countries in the next year.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Bruins Make the Most of Their Chances in Beating Rangers
text: By the time forward Brendan Shanahan stepped into the Rangers’ locker room after Sunday’s 3-1 loss to Boston at Madison Square Garden, the place was empty and silent. He spoke softly, otherwise his words would have echoed off the empty lockers, equipment hanging forlornly in the wake of another game the Rangers say they gave away.

headline: G.O.P. Rivals Open Final Assault in Florida
text: MIAMI  Senator John McCain of Arizona arrived to Latin salsa music on Monday at the Versailles restaurant in Little Havana, downed a cortadito  a shot of espresso with steamed milk  and with the other Republican presidential candidates opened a final assault in Florida before the state’s presidential primary on Jan. 29.

headline: Then, With a Touch of Now, and a Fully Charged Prodigal Son
text: The three ballets in New York City Ballet’s new “Traditions” program, which received its first performance on Friday night at the New York State Theater, were created over 50 years: from “The Prodigal Son” in 1929 through “Square Dance” (1957, revised in 1976) to “The Four Seasons” in 1979. But their music, all brightly conducted on Friday by Fayçal Karoui, covers a far wider chronological distance.

headline: Resurgent Knicks Confront Old Ghosts
text: Doc Rivers had a front-row seat when the Knicks hit rock bottom two months ago. He has recently seen them only on tape, but the contrast is striking.

headline: With Brady in Trouble, the Supporting Cast Takes Over
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  All season, the New England Patriots mocked their opponents, the league’s record book and football convention with a blistering passing game.

headline: U.S. Worries Deliver a New Jolt Overseas
text: FRANKFURT  The United States economy has demonstrated an enduring power to surprise since late summer. And not for the better.

headline: Fires, Falling Buildings and No One to Clean Up
text: The first question you may ask about “Life After People,” a two-hour documentary being shown on Monday night on the History Channel, is what connection, if any, it has to Alan Weisman’s popular book “The World Without Us,” which reached No. 6 on the New York Times nonfiction best-seller list last year.

headline: New CDs
text: PATTY LARKIN “Watch the Sky”  (Vanguard)

headline: Celebrating the Circles That Signify Our Lives
text: Concert-stage performances of American Indian dance and music are rare in New York City. But “The Drum Is the Thunder, the Flute Is the Wind,” presented by the Kevin Locke Native Dance Ensemble at Symphony Space on Saturday night, was often disappointing.

headline: A Man’s Gunshot Wound Leads to a Weapons Trove
text: Police officers investigating a report of a gunshot wound discovered a cache of weapons that included pipe bombs, numerous types of guns and a crossbow in an apartment in a stately building in Brooklyn Heights on Sunday morning, the police said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about paradoxes that cosmologists face in trying to explain the origin of the universe misspelled the surname of a physicist at the University of California, Berkeley, who commented on the limitations of probability measures. He is Raphael Bousso, not Buosso.

headline: Ousted Los Angeles Editor Assails Tribune Co.
text: The top editor of The Los Angeles Times, saying he had been forced out for resisting budget cuts, accused the Tribune Company’s management on Monday of using “voodoo economics” in allocating newsroom resources and forcing him to choose between maintaining foreign bureaus and fully covering the Olympics and the presidential race.

headline: For Moss, One Catch and Plenty of Scrutiny
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The New England Patriots’ march toward N.F.L. immortality continued Sunday, but once again they advanced despite a second consecutive unimpressive performance by the star receiver Randy Moss.

headline: HBO Putting Shows Online, at No Additional Charge
text: HBO, cable’s most popular premium channel, is carefully entering the arena of Internet video.

headline: Andy Palacio, Who Saved Garifuna Music, Dies at 47
text: Andy Palacio, a bandleader and songwriter who spearheaded a revival of the Garifuna music of Central America, died Saturday in his native Belize City, Belize. He was 47 and lived in San Ignacio, Belize.

headline: A Missing Son, ‘Confused & Unable to Call Home’
text: KENNESAW, Ga.

text: An article on Friday about Bill Clinton’s scolding of a television reporter on Wednesday misstated the location of the reporter’s station, KGO-TV. It is based in San Francisco, not Oakland. (Go to Article)

headline: Democratic Rivals Remember Dr. King
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  The three rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination stood together on the steps of the state capitol here on Monday in a brief display of political unity as they remembered the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: For Clinton, Government as Economic Prod
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that if she became president, the federal government would take a more active role in the economy to address what she called the excesses of the market and of the Bush administration.

headline: Ads Use Logos of Washington Post to Skewer It
text: WASHINGTON  Since the beginning of the month, the names of The Washington Post’s signature sections have been used in a negative advertising blitz against the paper.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Thursday and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Pentagon Weighs Top Iraq General as NATO Chief
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is considering Gen. David H. Petraeus for the top NATO command later this year, a move that would give the general, the top American commander in Iraq, a high-level post during the next administration but that has raised concerns about the practice of rotating war commanders.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about the death of a construction worker in a 42-story fall from the Trump SoHo condominium hotel in Manhattan misstated its location and the location of a gash on the building created by the collapse of wooden molds used to set concrete, the cause of the fatal accident. The building is on the southeast, not northwest, corner of Spring and Varick Streets; the gash is on the southwest  not northwest  corner of the building.

headline: Scientists Find Active Volcano in Antarctica
text: Here is another factor that might be contributing to the thinning of some of the Antarctica’s glaciers: volcanoes.

headline: Superman Stunt Undoes Malaysian Rocker
text: A Malaysian rock singer who stripped off his shirt and bared his chest to reveal a bright red Superman logo has been barred from television concerts for three months by the country’s media authority. The singer, Faizal Tahir, apologized last week for his behavior during the performance on station 8TV. The station declared his stunt “shocking” and said his actions were unacceptable in the country, which has a Muslim majority. “The commission found the artist’s act was intended without taking into account the sentiments and sensitivities of the viewers and public values,” said Muhammad Tahir Muhammad Noor, director of corporate communications for the Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission. Officials said going topless, even for males, is a violation of local broadcasting standards. The commission also banned 8TV from broadcasting any delayed concerts for the period of the ban on Mr. Tahir.

headline: Keeping His Mouth Shut, Rivers Lets His Play Do All of the Talking
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Sometimes, Philip Rivers’s passion looks misplaced, as it did last week when he exchanged barbs with Indianapolis Colts fans on his way to the locker room to have a brace put on his sprained right knee. On Sunday, the New England Patriots and a national television audience saw Rivers’s passion in all its radiance.

headline: See Cookies? Go Watch a Movie
text: It is well known that people often crave certain things after they see them. For example, a nearby dessert cart can prompt a diner to start hungering for a slice of pie.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: On Eve of King Holiday, Race Dominates Campaign
text: ATLANTA  As he stood at the pulpit of Ebenezer Baptist Church here, addressing worshipers at the former congregation of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Senator Barack Obama was doing something Sunday that he has rarely done in his months of campaigning for the presidency.

headline: Soap-Operas Are the Hidden Drama of Strike
text: As the writers’ strike approaches the three-month mark, it has conveyed new cachet, such as it is, on soap operas. Shows like “General Hospital” and “As the World Turns” have become virtually the only reliable option for viewers interested in watching rerun-free, serialized drama on broadcast television.

headline: Echoes of Dr. King in Finance, Politics and the Daily Grind
text: The leader of one of America’s most venerable civil rights groups kicked off his annual celebration of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in what might have once seemed an unlikely fashion: by ringing the opening bell Friday morning at the Nasdaq stock exchange.

headline: Britain Says Northern Rock Is Not Sold Yet
text: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain denied reports on Sunday that he had made a deal with Richard Branson over the sale of Northern Rock during a trip to China and India.

headline: Investigation of Study Programs Widens
text: An investigation of college study abroad programs by the New York attorney general’s office has expanded to include 15 colleges and universities, among them Harvard, Brown and Columbia, a senior lawyer in the office says.

headline: Little Data on Stent’s Most Common Use
text: From 2003 through 2006, more than one million patients suffering from clogged arteries and veins in their torsos and legs received stents that had undergone scant testing for such uses, said Dr. William H. Maisel, a device safety specialist at Harvard Medical School.

headline: Slovenia Chief Is Accused of Censorship
text: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia  As a young journalist in the late 1980s, Janez Jansa, now prime minister, played a critical role in spurring Slovenia’s pro-democracy movement after he was sentenced to 18 months in prison for opposing the Communist government and writing articles attacking the former Yugoslav Army.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about a scheduled appearance by Paris Hilton at Harvard on Feb. 6 misstated the reason for her visit. She will be accepting the Hastiest Pudding of the Lampoon Award from Harvard Lampoon. She is not going for the Hasty Pudding Theatricals’ Woman of the Year Roast, which is on Feb. 7.

headline: Poe Toaster Pays Homage
text: In the dead of night, someone came again to the Baltimore cemetery, as happens every Jan. 19. When the figure melted into the darkness, three red roses and a half-filled bottle of cognac were found at the grave site. Once more, tribute had been paid to Edgar Allan Poe, poet and master of horror; born Jan. 19, 1809, in Boston; died Oct. 7, 1849, in Baltimore and buried in the cemetery of Westminster Presbyterian Church. For years  exactly how many is a matter of dispute  a person who has come to be known as the Poe Toaster has made an annual pilgrimage to the site. This year, nearly 150 people gathered outside the cemetery, but Jeff Jerome, above, the curator of the Poe House and Museum, said the toaster was able to avoid being spotted, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Suzanne Pleshette, Actress, Dies at 70
text: Suzanne Pleshette, the husky-voiced actress who redefined the television sitcom wife in the 1970s by playing the smart, sardonic Emily Hartley on “The Bob Newhart Show,” died on Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 70.

headline: Stocks Plunge  Worldwide on Fears of a U.S. Recession
text: FRANKFURT  Fears that the United States is in a recession reverberated around the world on Monday, sending stock markets from Bombay to Frankfurt into a tailspin and puncturing the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia will be able to sidestep an American downturn.

headline: Manning and the Giants Can Be Doubted No More
text: Green Bay, Wis.

headline: Until All the Fish Are Gone
text: Scientists have been warning for years that overfishing is degrading the health of the oceans and destroying the fish species on which much of humanity depends for jobs and food. Even so, it would be hard to frame the problem more dramatically than two recent articles in The Times detailing the disastrous environmental, economic and human consequences of often illegal industrial fishing.

headline: Debunking the Reagan Myth
text: Historical narratives matter. That’s why conservatives are still writing books denouncing F.D.R. and the New Deal; they understand that the way Americans perceive bygone eras, even eras from the seemingly distant past, affects politics today.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about penalties imposed by the New York City Campaign Finance Board on Councilman Miguel Martinez for violating campaign finance laws in the 2001 election gave incorrect figures for the board’s earlier determination of violations and penalties. In June, the board listed 17 violations totaling $100,780 in fines, not 11 violations totaling $84,000. (In its final determination, the board fined Mr. Martinez $44,780 for 12 violations.)

headline: With Win, Jones Evokes Past and Revives Future
text: Roy Jones Jr. has been in the boxing spotlight for nearly 20 years. But on Saturday night, he might have turned himself into one of the sport’s most intriguing figures.

headline: A Site Follows the Money So Users Can Slice and Dice
text: The more people Shelby W. Bonnie can get arguing over politics, the better.

headline: Shares Tumble in Asia and Europe
text: NEW DELHI  Asian and European markets nose-dived on Monday as hope that healthy local economies might escape the force of a United States recession evaporated and fear gripped investors instead.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart in some editions on Dec. 16 with an article about the struggles of New York’s state university system misstated the relationship between the $1 billion spent on the Tuition Assistance Program and the $3.9 billion that New York spends on higher education each year. The tuition program is part of the total, not separate. This correction was delayed for research.

headline: With Power and Putting, Trahan Defeats Leonard
text: PALM DESERT, Calif.  D. J. Trahan overpowered the Classic Club and stunned the overnight leader, Justin Leonard, shooting a final-round 65 that turned a four-stroke deficit into a three-stroke victory Sunday in the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

headline: Getty Images Up for Sale, Could Fetch $1.5 Billion
text: Getty Images, the world’s biggest supplier of pictures and video to media and advertising companies, has put itself on the auction block and could fetch more than $1.5 billion, people briefed on the situation said Sunday.

headline: Everest’s Conqueror, Remembered for His Heart as Well as His Courage
text: The lights were shut off, and suddenly the lanky man with rosy cheeks, the most beloved Western friend of the Sherpas, seemed to come back to life on Sunday.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $6,881,972

headline: Low-Key Elections May Affect Castro’s Role
text: HAVANA  As Cubans went to the polls on Sunday, the ballot boxes, campaign posters and other trappings of democracy that are hauled out every election day were all in place. But there was something else that had not been present for many years  some degree of suspense.

headline: At Least 7 Killed in Violence Across Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  At least seven people were killed in Kenya over the weekend in reverberations from last week’s nationwide protests, and police officials have begun investigating the officer seen on television shooting an unarmed demonstrator, police officials said Sunday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about “AA Bronson’s School for Young Shamans” at John Connelly Presents, in Chelsea, omitted part of the surname of Mr. Bronson’s current partner. He is Mark Jan Krayenhoff van de Leur, not de Leur.

text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.

headline: Web Cartoon Bolsters Visits to Newsday
text: The audience for newspapers may be getting older but if the success of Newsday’s Web site is any indication, there may be a silver lining in the graying cloud.

headline: In Previous Title Game, Giants No Match for Lombardi’s Packers
text: The Giants and the Packers, two of the N.F.L.’s oldest franchises, have played each other 54 times since 1928, but Sunday’s National Football Conference championship game was only the second of the matchups in Green Bay, Wis., with a title at stake.

headline: After Raids, 14 Held in Spain on Suspicion of a Terror Plot
text: MADRID  Intelligence agents on Sunday were sifting through evidence collected during a weekend crackdown on a group of suspected Islamic militants who the police say were plotting an attack on Barcelona.

headline: A Venerable Magazine Energizes Its Web Site
text: A year ago, The Atlantic’s Web site was, to put it gently, weak  in content, staff, traffic and advertising.

headline: City Evacuates 11-Story Building in Brooklyn, Citing Safety
text: An estimated 150 people had to relocate when city officials evacuated an 11-story factory building in Brooklyn on Sunday night, citing illegal loft conversions and fire safety violations involving a matzo bakery in the basement.

headline: Against Giants, Breaks Don’t Go Favre’s Way
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The ending felt all wrong. In this season, when almost everything went right for the Green Bay Packers and their quarterback, Brett Favre expected victory right up until the very moment that he lost.

headline: Caution’s in the Air as Sundance Opens
text: PARK CITY, Utah  So much for the sellers’ market. The Sundance Film Festival’s opening weekend, often the setting for rapturous audience reactions and frenzied all-night bidding wars, drew to a close looking more and more like a disappointment, if not an outright dud.

headline: Even in Singles, Williams Sisters Are Double Trouble
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  With her doubles partner, Serena Williams, watching from the stands, Venus Williams kept her family undefeated so far at the Australian Open, reaching the quarterfinals with a 6-4, 6-4 victory Monday against Marta Domachowska, a qualifier from Poland.

headline: With a Contest in Chaos, Predictions Are Futile
text: People paying close attention to the 2008 presidential race have no idea what will happen next. The contest keeps defying precedents.

headline: Monster Gross for Monster Movie
text: “Cloverfield,” starring Michael Stahl-David and Odette Yustman, both at left, and the monster that mashed Manhattan, obliterated the competition at movie box offices over the weekend, taking in an estimated $41 million to wrest the No. 1 spot from last week’s favorite, “The Bucket List.” In its debut, “Cloverfield,” distributed by Paramount, set a record for a January opening and had nearly double the gross of the No. 2 film, another newcomer, “27 Dresses” (Fox). That romantic comedy, starring Katherine Heigl, took in $22.4 million, according to the tracking company Media by Numbers. After “The Bucket List” (Warner Brothers), which attracted $15.1 million in its fifth week, “Juno” (Fox Searchlight), the little film that became a big hit, accumulated $10.2 million more to bring its seven-week gross to $85.3 million. Fifth place went to “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” (Disney), which pulled in $8.1 million, bringing its total to $198 million in its fifth week.

headline: Suzanne Pleshette, 70, ‘Newhart’ Actress, Dies
text: Suzanne Pleshette, the husky-voiced actress who redefined the television sitcom wife in the 1970s, playing the smart, sardonic Emily Hartley on “The Bob Newhart Show,” died Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 70.

headline: Brady Is Far From Perfect, but the Patriots Still Are
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The dazzling offense was absent, struggling through misfires and mistakes that threatened to upend the New England Patriots’ relentless march through the N.F.L. The Patriots had endured suspensions, scandal and the mounting pressure of their own magnificence, but even in their closest calls during an undefeated season, they had never looked quite so lifeless with the ball, and Tom Brady had never seemed quite so befuddled.

headline: Songs Bouncy to Melancholy, and Back
text: Many a mezzo-soprano initially draws public attention by donning a man’s trousers on the operatic stage. For Kelley O’Connor, portraying the Spanish poet and playwright Federico García Lorca in Osvaldo Golijov’s bracing “Ainadamar” kick-started what promises to be a major career. Ms. O’Connor, a striking young mezzo from California, has sung the role widely, including an engagement at Lincoln Center in 2006. Her smoky sound and riveting stage presence made an indelible impact.

headline: In Europe, Apple Faces Hurdles to iTunes Movie Rentals
text: LONDON  After introducing an online film rental business for American consumers last week, the chief executive of Apple, Steven P. Jobs, said he expected that the service would be expanded into international markets later this year.

headline: Signs in Kenya That Killings Were Planned
text: KERINGET, Kenya  At first the violence seemed as spontaneous as it was shocking, with machete-wielding mobs hacking people to death and burning women and children alive in a country that was celebrated as one of Africa’s most stable.

headline: Paris: Losing Our Heads
text: On my way to Dior this afternoon to see John Galliano, my driver Bernard Alloux paused in the Place de la Concorde to point out a group of royalists gathered at the site where Louis XVI lost his head. Mr. Alloux said there were quite a few people in France who are royalists and then hastened to add, “Pas moi.” He gunned the Mercedes toward chez Dior.

headline: Short Fusion?
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: A Forfeit Over Refusing to Shake Hands?
text: A game Sunday between Nigel Short of England and Ivan Cheparinov of Bulgaria in the B section of the Corus tournament in the Netherlands ended in a forfeit win for Short after Cheparinov refused to shake Short’s hand at the start of the game. According to a report on Chessbase.com, Short immediately complained to the tournament’s referee who consulted the World Chess Federation’s rules and decided that Cheparinov’s conduct merited that he forfeit the game. It was an unprecedented decision, which was appealed and later reversed, although Cheparinov was required to apologize and shake Short’s hand before playing the game on Monday, which Short won.

headline: Why Career Change Would Be Bad Reality TV
text: Imagine if career change were the subject of a reality television show. Match up three candidates with a coach. Give them weekly assignments. Tune in every week. And voilà. After a season, the contestants would transform before our eyes, and the winner would be the one whose metamorphosis was most complete. There is only one catch. Watching a career transformation could be downright dull. And it would never conclude in the length of a television season.

headline: The Giants' Road to the Super Bowl
text: The Giants have won an N.F.L.-record 10 games in a row on the road during their journey to Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Third Time for Tynes (the Transcript)
text: I looked for a transcript of Tom Coughlin’s news conference at Giants.com, and stumbled upon Lawrence Tynes’s instead. (An excerpt is below.) It describes how Tynes, despite his two earlier misses, influenced Coughlin’s decision to go for the field goal in overtime. Last year, Coughlin loosed hell and damnation (and Devin Hester) on the Giants’ season by electing to go for a long field goal in the Bears game.

headline: The Early Word: Honoring King’s Birthday
text: The presidential primary race will be in full gear this week in two states, with the Democrats focused on South Carolina and the Republicans in Florida for a long week before that state’s contest next Tuesday.

headline: Elsewise
text: The Bagger has been a little too scattered blogging, reporting stories for the newspaper and making videos to keep up with firehouse of movies at Sundance. If you want to see what people are seeing — and what they are saying about it — you might want to log on to FilmThreat. And USA Today’s Anthony Breznican has the advantage of youth on the Bagger, so his blog is always coming up with tangy bits, including getting a actual quotation from Robert DeNiro, a very difficult nut to crack, that one.

headline: Blood in the Snow
text: The Bagger and quite a few others speculated that the writer’s market would create a buying frenzy at Sundance. Good logic, nice thesis, but one, as David M. Halbfinger points out, that lacks the prime virtue of being correct.

headline: Comparing $100 million fines
text: It will no doubt continue to take a long time to digest the magnitude of the $100 million fine that the FIA asked McLaren Mercedes to pay in last summer’s Formula One spy scandal. But my wife, Nathalie, last night pointed out an interesting measuring stick: We were talking about the $285 million fine that Total SA, the oil company, along with three other defendants, were asked to pay by a Paris court for the ecological disaster that occurred after the sinking of the Erika tanker in 1999 spread oil along the French coast of Brittany.

headline: Stimulus issues
text: The big problem with attempts to provide temporary economic stimulus is how to ensure that the money gets spent. As Milton Friedman pointed out 50 years ago, consumers tend to base their spending on “permanent income” — the income they expect to have over the long run — rather than their income in any given year. So an $800 check from the Treasury tends, other things equal, to be mostly saved rather than spent.

headline: G-Man
text: Paul Giamatti is a low-key guy who just happens to be an adept at the craft of acting. He has played in big movies and small, and he is here at Sundance starring in “Pretty Bird,” a movie directed by actor Paul Schneider. Mr. Giamatti formed a production company with his wife, Elizabeth and his pal Dan Carey to get the film made.

headline: Dropping the Puck
text: Yesterday afternoon, there was a celebrity hockey tournament that featured Luc Robitaille, some other NHL greats, and then some movie folks, including Taylor Kitsch, from “Friday Night Lights,” who was a demon on ice, and a fairly talented winger named Jason Reitman, better known as the director of “Juno.” Mr. Reitman said before the came that he was going to make sure the didn’t get smushed by Marty McSorley, the legendary NHL enforcer.

headline: Fan’s Journal: Goin’ Goin’ Ghana
text: I was greeted in Ghana by the dusty smell of the Harmattan Winds, the punch of tropical humidity and a functional airport decorated lavishly in red, yellow, and green banners with signs greeting soccer fans to their mecca of the moment.

headline: Tears of Joy
text: The paradox of choice is manifest at Sundance. Just as the exits from Disneyland are filled with children crying because they missed certain rides, the feeling here is that, no matter where you are, you should be somewhere else.

headline: U.S. Soldiers and Shoppers Hit the Wall
text: Wars in Afghanistan and Iraq have pushed the U.S. armed forces to the limit. Many soldiers have scarcely seen their families in recent years. But a much larger American army, the one that's spent this century shopping, is even more overextended and its pain is now coming home to roost.

headline: Out and About: Il Nido

headline: Employment and confidence wonkery
text: For wonkish types only: I’ve been using the employment-population ratio rather than the unemployment rate as an indicator of labor market conditions; the unemployment rate has been fairly low, roughly late-90s levels, but employment-population has never regained its late-90s peak.

headline: For the Moment |  Jeff Klein
text: This week’s guest blogger is Jeff Klein, the hotelier behind The City Club in New York and the Sunset Tower in Los Angeles. In his first post, Klein recalls his early fascination with the hospitality industry. To read all of Jeff Klein’s prior blog posts, click here.

headline: Making Sense of Arthritis Supplements
text: Arthritis sufferers are routinely targeted by the $20 billion supplement industry, which has introduced more than 800 purported remedies for arthritis in recent years.

headline: Binx Bolling’s Voice
text: Rereading “The Moviegoer” was a revelation to me, as rereading usually is. Some book has left an imprint, often an indelible one, but it naturally gets fainter and fainter as time goes by, till it’s more an impression, a shadow on one’s consciousness. One of my heroes once wrote that “true culture is what remains in a man when he’s forgotten everything he’s learned.” In that sense, “The Moviegoer” was part of my “culture,” but in such a generalized way as to be virtually indescribable. I found I really remembered very little of it. And so the reread book is, in fact, a new book, only better than new, because there are neural pathways somewhere that can somehow be reopened…

headline: Reborn, In Film and In Life
text: Kimberly Rivers, the amazing woman at the heart of “Trouble the Waters,” a documentary about Katrina that has been a huge hit, took a bit of time out from Sundance to head down to Salt Lake City and give birth gave birth to Skyy Kaylen Rivers Roberts, 7 lb, 1 oz. at 6:15 this morning. New snow on the mountain and new life in our midst. It’s a lovely day in Park city.

headline: Paris: Investments
text: In the mood for tradition, a number of designers showed vests at the Paris men’s shows. Paul Smith added them to his English checks-and-plaids mix. At Lanvin, they looked slightly more formal, while Ann Demeulemeester evoked country folk heroes with hers.

headline: McCain Courts Cuban-Americans in Miami
text: MIAMI — John McCain arrived to Latin salsa music this morning at the Versailles restaurant in Little Havana, downed a cortadito – a shot of espresso with steamed milk – and opened his final push in Florida with an appeal to the powerful Cuban-American community before the state’s presidential primary next Tuesday.

headline: Panic Hits
text: While the United States celebrates one of its non-birthday-birthdays — Martin Luther King Day, although the real birthday was last week — the rest of the world is concluding that the American recession is going to be very bad indeed.

headline: Poll Suggests Giuliani’s Woes at Home
text: The strong advantage that former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani enjoyed in his home state appears to be slipping away, according to the latest WNBC/Marist Poll, while Senator Hillary Clinton is still leading among the Democrats of New York.

headline: Global Stock Markets Plunge
text: Markets from Frankfurt to Mumbai went into a tailspin, puncturing the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia will be able to sidestep an American downturn.

headline: Giuliani Shrugs Off Polls
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Rudolph Giuliani paused next to the car bay at the Daytona International Speedway and briefly considered his political prospects, which seem to grow more complicated by the hour. Not only have recent polls showed him in a tight race with John McCain and Mitt Romney in Florida, but now a poll shows him trailing Mr. McCain in his home state of New York.

headline: In Dr. King’s Church: ‘It’s Time, It’s Time’
text: ATLANTA — The annual ceremony to honor the late Martin Luther King Jr. here at the Ebenezer Baptist Church, Dr. King’s old congregation, is often a rich blend of prayer and politics. But politics nearly eclipsed prayer this year.

headline: Clinton, Edwards and Obama Remember King
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — The three rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination stood together on the steps of the state capitol on Monday in a brief display of political unity as they remembered the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Obama’s National Ad
text: Barack Obama has begun showing a one-minute national ad on CNN and MSNBC.

headline: Reader Responses to “Hillary, Barack, Experience.”
text: I’ve pulled out a number of comments from the hundreds that have been submitted in response to Nick’s column on Sunday.

headline: The View from the Mountaintop
text: The trip to the mountains of Park City offers writers and directors to gain perspective on a lot of things, including the tentative deal struck by the DGA.

headline: The Top Ten Presidents
text: A number of readers chided me for my implicit rankings in Sunday’s column of which presidents were the greatest. Some argued that I shouldn’t have included Woodrow Wilson as a great, while Steve Clemons at The Washington Note believes that I overrate FDR and don’t adequately appreciate Nixon or the first President Bush.

headline: Greetings from Davos, Switzerland
text: A team of us from The New York Times and The International Herald Tribune will be here at the annual conference of the World Economic Forum, a high-wattage powwow for bigshots of all stripes — think Tony Blair, Bill Gates and Bono — to rub elbows and talk big ideas.

headline: How the Other Half Lives
text: When I first read “The Moviegoer,” I was as intrigued as anyone by Binx’s search. But as a New Orleanian who grew up among the working poor of Treme, far from the Cutrer home, what struck me, and what remains after three reads, is the portrait it offers of a certain part of New Orleans that I wanted to understand. For me, reading about the world of the Garden District, the setting for much of the book, was like reading about an exotic country.

headline: Professional Driver on a Closed Course: Do Not Attempt
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla — Teetering precariously in local polls, Rudolph W. Giuliani took a lap at a most severe angle on the Daytona International Speedway today.

headline: Who Let Mitt Romney Out?
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. – Mitt Romney has more often been compared to a 1950s television dad than a hip pop-culture savant. This clip, care of Fox News Channel’s Shushannah Walshe, illustrates why.

headline: Who Is Here (And Who Is Not)
text: For some, scoring an invitation to the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum is like getting asked to the prom. For others, it is just another invitation to blow off. (Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. just bailed out at the 11th hour.) This year, the guest list is a heady mix of egos, personalities and leaders. Some have been here before, while others are making their first pilgrimage.

headline: Listen Close, Then Go the Other Way
text: The Bagger has been in Park City shoveling copy snow, so he is so far out of the Oscar ninny loop he can’t even remember what all the fuss was about in the first place. But you can’t win if you don’t play, right? Your comments and amendations would be highly regarded.

headline: Davos Loses Two of Its Stars to the Campaign Trail
text: With John McCain and Bill Clinton otherwise engaged this year, Davos will be without two of its most reliable draws. While both thrived in this talk shop, there was no mistaking the status gap between a former president and a potential future president.

headline: Morning Papers: Weekend Round-up
text: — Soap opera drama | Jacques Steinberg reports in Monday’s Times: “None of the eight daytime soap operas on network television “have gone into reruns, and none have plans to do so. But in a genre that thrives on drawn-out cliffhangers, the most sensational mystery in daytime may be how these shows are being written at all, considering that nearly all of their writers are guild members on strike.” More…

headline: Why The Strike May Hurt ABC The Most
text: As previously noted, Fox appears best positioned to weather the writers’ strike. ABC, on the other hand, may be hurt by it the most. Why? “Because it has the biggest scripted hits — and because its audience, heavily female, is most susceptible to being stolen away by ‘American Idol,'” Bill Carter reported in Saturday’s Times.

headline: With Informal Talks Set To Begin, Guild Plans Mass Picket at Paramount
text: Debate roiled within the striking writers guilds over the weekend about whether or not to go with the kind of deal companies just made with the Directors Guild of America, and get back to work. Tuesday looks like a big day.

headline: Obama, Reagan and the Web
text: Video

headline: Meet Lucas Ossendrijver
text: Lucas Ossendrijver, the 37-year-old Dutch-born Lanvin men’s wear designer, has an international resume to rival most diplomats. After graduating from the Fashion Institute Arnhem (ex alumni include Ossendrijver’s compatriots Viktor & Rolf), he skipped from Kenzo, to the German-Greek Kostas Murkudis, and then to Dior Homme in the Hedi Slimane years, before being charged in 2006 with translating Alber Elbaz’s success at Lanvin to the men’s market. He hasn’t missed a step, as yesterday’s Lanvin’s Fall 2008 show, one of the week’s hottest tickets, proved once again.

headline: Bill Clinton’s Strategic Emotion
text: Remember September 2006? It was a little over a month before Election Day when Bill Clinton gave an interview to Fox News Channel’s Chris Wallace. The peg for the interview was a summit held by the Clinton Global Initiative, one of the former president’s many philanthropic activities. Wallace asked several questions about the initiative, but four minutes into the interview also brought up criticisms of the Clinton administration’s counterterrorism policies that had been aired in Pulitzer-prize winning journalist Lawrence Wright’s history of Al Qaeda, “The Looming Tower.” Whereupon Clinton went … ballistic. His face turned red. His voice rose. He tore into Wallace, accusing the veteran journalist, who over the decades has worked for several “mainstream” networks and whose credibility seldom has been questioned, of being a right-wing shill. He claimed the “neocons” who now say he did too little to capture or kill Osama bin Laden had in fact during the 1990s been highly critical of his administration’s emphasis on counterterrorism, that they “thought I was too obsessed with bin Laden” and “had no meetings on bin Laden for nine months after I left office.”

headline: A Return Engagement in a Different Role
text: Almost exactly one year ago, in this space, we observed that Tony Blair, then British prime minister, had celebrated a “valedictory moment” at Davos – “his final appearance at the World Economic Forum as Britain’s prime minister after almost 10 years in office.” In parentheses we added: “but probably not his last time at the conference.”

headline: Live From South Carolina, the Democratic Debate
text: 10:59 p.m. | Wrapup With all this broken china on the floor, it’s hard to know where to start picking up the pieces. Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Obama showed themselves pretty adept at hurling plates, then reaching into the cabinet and pulling out cups and saucers too.

headline: Doomsayers in Fashion This Year
text: The opening panel of the World Economic Forum traditionally gives a macroeconomic weather forecast for the coming 12 months. This year, expect black clouds to gather over Davos when the panel kicks off on Wednesday morning.

headline: The Mouse That Roared in Bali
text: Andrew C. Revkin talks with Papua New Guinea's Kevin Conrad about taking a stand at the climate talks in Bali, Indonesia.

headline: Bloggingheads: Is McCain on Top?
text:
Spencer Ackerman, left, of The Washington Independent and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic debate whether John McCain deserves the front-runner status the media has given him.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Cholesterol Study Leads to Confusion
text: This weekend, New York City cardiologist Dr. Nieca Goldberg and her nurse spent their Saturday fielding phone calls from patients. The issue was a recent study of the cholesterol drug Vytorin.

headline: Equal Opportunity Insults, in Five Acts
text: This just in from David M. Halbfinger:

headline: Zambia: Nationwide Blackouts
text: Zambia was plunged into darkness in what appeared to be the second nationwide power failure in three days. The country relies on hydroelectricity, and national blackouts are rare. The electricity network went down around 7:30 p.m. and was restored about four hours later. There was no immediate explanation. On Saturday, the country lost electricity for eight hours. Neighboring Zimbabwe was also hit by a nationwide blackout over the weekend, and worsening power cuts have caused economic losses and chaos across South Africa.

headline: Feeling Misled on Home Price, Buyers Sue Agent
text: CARLSBAD, Calif.  Marty Ummel feels she paid too much for her house. So do millions of other people who bought at the peak of the housing boom.

headline: Heath Ledger, Actor, Is Found Dead at 28
text: The actor Heath Ledger was found dead in a Manhattan apartment on Tuesday afternoon, the New York City police said.

headline: Mexico Hits Drug Gangs With Full Fury of War
text: RÍO BRAVO, Mexico  These days, it is easy to form the impression that a war is going on in Mexico. Thousands of elite troops in battle gear stream toward border towns and snake through the streets in jeeps with .50-caliber machine guns mounted on top while fighter jets from the Mexican Navy fly reconnaissance missions overhead.

headline: An Opera for a Crowd Unfamiliar With Opera
text: Before a performance at the Dicapo Opera Theater on Saturday afternoon, Michael Capasso, the company’s general director, asked how many of the chattering audience members had seen an opera before. About a dozen waved in response. When he polled those who had not, perhaps three times as many hands went up. Among both groups, few appeared to have reached their 10th birthdays. Brightly dressed and mostly attentive, they sat with parents or grandparents.

headline: A Pandemic That Wasn’t but Might Be
text: Last year, for the first time since avian flu emerged as a global threat, the number of human cases was down from the year before. As the illness receded, the scary headlines  with their warnings of a pandemic that could kill 150 million people  all but vanished.

headline: Send-Off for Comic Book
text: MySpace Comic Books, the comics corner of this online social network, and Meltdown Comics, a store in Los Angeles, have teamed up to commemorate the end of “Y: The Last Man,” the comic book series created by Brian K. Vaughan, above, and Pia Guerra. The event, “Y: The Last Party,” will be held on Friday, Feb. 8, and will benefit the Comic Book Legal Defense Fund. The organization, founded in 1986, is dedicated to the preservation of First Amendment rights for members of the comic book business. Of late the defense fund has been involved in the case of Gordon Lee, a comic book retailer in Rome, Ga., who has found himself in court over the distribution of obscene material to a minor. The material in question depicted Picasso in the nude. Mr. Vaughan, who is also a writer on ABC’s “Lost,” is a firm believer in the defense fund. “It’s obviously a completely different situation from the writers’ strike, but, similarly, it’s creators taking care of their community, which I always support,” he said in a telephone interview. The $100 V.I.P. tickets have sold out, but a limited number of $25 tickets will be available the day of the event. More information:www.myspace.com/cbldf.

headline: Failure Isn’t Always a Bad Thing
text: Successful entrepreneurs invariably say that they have learned as much from their failures as their successes.

headline: For Giants, Redemption Is as Good as It Gets
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  A year ago, when the Giants retained Coach Tom Coughlin despite the season’s disappointing finish, John Mara, the team president and co-owner, heard about it from disgruntled fans. Outside the Giants Stadium offices, it was not a popular decision.

headline: Fractured Family Warmed by Its Bright Teenage Star
text: “Life of Ryan” is a reality television milestone for one good reason: after years of commoners’ showboating, here comes a showboat who wants to be common. As the MTV series’s second season continues on Tuesday night, the camera crews are tracking the pro skateboarder Ryan Sheckler, someone with real talent rather than yet another manufactured, disposable celebrity.

headline: As Alps Warm, a Snow-Deprived Ski Resort Sells for $1
text: ERNEN, Switzerland  Bruno Prior, a British entrepreneur, saw the ad from the Ernen ski-lift company one day as he was sipping coffee and looking through the newspaper in London.

headline: University Investigates Whether Governor’s Daughter Earned Degree
text: MORGANTOWN, W.Va.  It started with a phone call from a newspaper reporter in October seeking to verify the academic credentials of Gov. Joe Manchin III’s daughter Heather Bresch. But in less than three months, the inquiry has mushroomed into a controversy that risks casting a shadow of cronyism over this state’s flagship university.

headline: A Chinese Makeover for Mickey and Minnie
text: What would Walt Disney say? Mickey and Minnie Mouse, left, have gotten a makeover that put him in a bright red Mao suit and her in a cherry-blossom red dress  all in an effort to appeal to Chinese tourists at Hong Kong Disneyland, The Associated Press reported. Mickey and Minnie strutted along a red carpet on Monday to display their new outfits, designed by Vivienne Tam, while nine other models showed off red and black dresses featuring Mickey Mouse patterns. “I’ve liked Mickey Mouse since I was very little,” said Ms. Tam, who was reared in Hong Kong and works in New York. Amid disappointing attendance at Hong Kong Disneyland, which opened in 2005, Ms. Tam was brought in to help attract more tourists from the mainland, which has become the park’s biggest market. Bill Ernest, the park’s managing director, said, “Our mission is to be very connected with the local culture  with mainland China, Hong Kong.”

headline: Managers Foresee Fewer Airlines and Higher Fares
text: Three-quarters of corporate travel managers said in a recent survey that they expect airline mergers to result in higher fares and more than half expect the quality of service to suffer.

headline: Study Says Implants Double Risk of Infection in Breast Reconstruction
text: Breast cancer patients who had reconstructive surgery using implants immediately after mastectomies were twice as likely to acquire infections as women who immediately had breast reconstruction using their own tissue, according to a study published yesterday.

headline: Skin as a Battlefield
text: Q. I was recently told I had Stevens-Johnson syndrome. What is happening to cause these burnlike skin lesions?

headline: Scrub Soap Opera, Flight Attendants Ask
text: Hot and bothered by a steamy new soap opera about airborne love and lust, Thai Airways flight attendants urged Thailand’s culture ministry on Monday to nip the show in the bud, The Associated Press reported. After broadcasts of three episodes of the series, “The Air Hostess War,” the Thai Airways International union protested the story about an affair between a married pilot and a tall, slim flight attendant, featuring sex at stopover cities and love triangles that lead to fighting in the aisles. Viewers were captivated, but Noppadol Thaungthong, a Thai Airways flight attendant leading the union’s action, said: “This soap opera is insulting and damaging to the reputation of flight attendants. It’s all about sex and air hostesses beating each other up in the cabin because of love and jealousy. This kind of thing never happens. We are demanding that the station and the producers immediately stop airing this ugly soap opera.” A culture ministry spokesman withheld comment until officials saw the letter of complaint, and the broadcaster, Channel 5, said it had no plans to pull the soap opera but would consider asking the producer to edit scenes found to be offensive.

headline: Top Horse of 2007 Is Likely to Return
text: After being named the 2007 Horse of the Year on Monday, Curlin appears on track to take another run at the title. Jess Jackson, Curlin’s principal owner, said Monday afternoon that he would announce plans to race Curlin in 2008 when he spoke at the Horse of the Year and Eclipse Award ceremonies in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Upside of a Slow Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Israel Allows Some Supplies Into Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli defense minister, Ehud Barak, announced Monday night that he was lifting some of the restrictions imposed on Gaza and that on Tuesday morning he would allow delivery of a week’s supply of industrial diesel fuel for the local power station, as well as 50 trucks of food and medical supplies.

headline: Iran Leader Backs Parliament in a Dispute With Ahmadinejad
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s supreme religious leader, in what appeared to be his first public dispute with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, sided with Parliament on Monday in a conflict over energy policy.

headline: Rangel Remains in Clinton’s Camp in Her Battle With Obama
text: Last summer, a Brooklyn lawmaker ran into Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem and they began discussing the presidential race. Mr. Rangel, 77, bluntly told the younger politician that he should get on board with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Deaths of Rare Crocodile in India Stir Alarm
text: NEW DELHI  Three decades after it was brought back from the brink of extinction, the rare Indian crocodile known as the gharial is turning up dead by the dozens on the banks of a river called the Chambal. Forest officials are at a loss to explain why.

headline: 4 Officers Arrested in Corruption Inquiry
text: Four New York City police officers are facing criminal charges as part of an ongoing criminal investigation into corruption among officers assigned to a unit of narcotics investigators in Brooklyn, officials said on Monday.

headline: Footnote
text: Gary Glitter, the 1970’s glam rocker jailed in Vietnam in 2006 for sexually molesting two young girls, has been treated at a prison hospital for intestinal problems and an irregular heartbeat, the BBC reported. Mr. Glitter, 63, whose real name is Paul Francis Gadd, is scheduled to complete his sentence in August.

headline: The Psychology of Voters
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Scramble Across Florida as Republicans Square Off
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The Republican presidential candidates began grappling with the complicated electoral landscape of Florida on Monday as they made appeals in Spanish and English and sped from Little Havana in Miami to the racetrack in Daytona Beach.

headline: The Body of Her Work: Hearing Questions of Life and Death
text: NEW HAVEN  Anna Deavere Smith covers a big patch of territory in “Let Me Down Easy,” her populous new solo show at the Long Wharf Theater here. A checklist of topics covered would include the steroid scandal in sports, cancer therapies, African folk healing, the genocide in Rwanda, the tragedy of Katrina and the ailing American health-care system.

headline: Ivy-League Letdown
text: LAST month, Harvard reached into its deep pockets  its endowment is $35 billion  and changed the way it calculates student financial aid. The aim, its press release says, is “to make Harvard College more affordable for families across the income spectrum.” Last week, Yale, whose $22.5 billion endowment is growing even faster than Harvard’s, followed suit. Yale’s president, Richard Levin, said he didn’t want students to have to choose “between Yale and Harvard based on cost.”

headline: Brazil’s Vale Confirms Talks to Merge With Xstrata
text: LONDON  Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the world’s largest producer of iron ore, said on Monday that it was in talks with a rival, Xstrata, about a merger.

headline: Aviation Industry Offers Ideas to Help Passengers
text: WASHINGTON  Aviation executives are sharing a list of steps they can take to make passengers’ lives a little easier the next time a blizzard, a hurricane or another event strands planes on the ground.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the men’s college basketball roundup in some editions on Friday misstated the home team in Long Island University’s 85-65 victory over Wagner. It was Long Island.

headline: The Battle Against H.I.V.: No Letup
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spitzer Proposes New Taxes and Fees
text: ALBANYGov. Eliot Spitzer proposed an array of new taxes and fees, $1 billion in health care cuts and scaled back plans for new education aid and property tax relief in his second executive budget.

headline: Reprising a Career
text: This 60-second advertisement for the Democratic presidential campaign of Senator Barack Obama of Illinois began running nationally on cable television on Monday. It is titled, “Inspiring.”

headline: Fed Makes Emergency 0.75% Rate Cut
text: The Federal Reserve, responding to an international stock sell-off and the likelihood of a sharp drop in America on Tuesday morning, cut its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point.

headline: Canseco Finds a Publisher for Sequel
text: Less than a week after Jose Canseco lost a publisher for “Vindicated,” his follow-up book to the controversial 2005 best-seller “Juiced: Wild Times, Rampant ’Roids, Smash Hits and How Baseball Got Big,” a new publisher, Simon Spotlight Entertainment, has picked up the book and will publish it in time for opening day.

headline: Brazil: Gas Field Discovered
text: The Brazilian state oil company said it had discovered a natural gas reserve off the coast of Rio de Janeiro that could be as big as the recently discovered giant Tupi oil field. The company, Petróleo Brasileiro, said the potential reserves were about three miles below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean, 23 miles west of the Tupi field. The release did not provide figures as to the size of the reserve but said its structure could have dimensions that are similar to Tupi’s. Late last year, Petrobras announced the discovery of as much as eight billion barrels of light crude oil in the ultra-deep Tupi field.

headline: Coachella Picks Headliners
text: Jack Johnson, My Morning Jacket, Kraftwerk and Portishead will be among the headline acts at the Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival in California, when the event’s ninth edition takes place in California. Tickets for the festival, from April 25 to 27, will cost $269 as well as fees for all three days; a single day’s ticket will cost $90, according to the details released by Coachella’s organizers, Goldenvoice and AEG. The organizers also said they were planning another three-day event, All Points West, at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, from Aug. 8 to 10. That lineup, not yet announced, is expected to include Radiohead and Mr. Johnson. Paul Tollett, promoter of Goldenvoice, said that unlike Coachella, which takes place on a polo field in the desert about two hours east of Los Angeles, the All Points West will “have its own personality,” incorporating the area’s urban setting and local art scene. Several of this year’s Coachella headliners will be touring in connection with new releases.
