Portishead, for example, is expected to release its first album in about a decade internationally in April. “They’ve been one of the most requested bands to play Coachella” among fans, Mr. Tollett said. “Talent is still king.”

headline: In Vioxx Settlement, Testing a Legal Ideal: A Lawyer’s Loyalty
text: If you listen to brainy law professors who have been studying big injury cases, you will learn that lawyers no longer owe their clients a duty of loyalty. They say this approvingly, even enthusiastically.

headline: L Train From Rockaway Parkway to Eighth Avenue
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 17 at Ceremony Near Capital
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber killed 17 people in Salahuddin Province north of Baghdad on Monday in the latest suicide attack outside the capital.

headline: Romney Waxes Lyrical at a Holiday Parade in Florida
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  Mitt Romney, whose 1950s manner and celebratory drink of choice call to mind a milkshake man more than a rap singer, gave a shout out Monday that left no doubt that he had spent little time listening to hip-hop.

headline: Craig Romney Promotes His Father, en Español
text: Mitt Romney on Monday began running the following television commercial, his first in Spanish, in Miami, where Spanish-speaking voters make up a large proportion of the electorate.

headline: Patriots Trust in Defense in a String of Close Calls
text: Now for some sobering news to interrupt the Giants’ revelry: the New England Patriots are ahead of their normal preparation schedule for Super Bowl XLII because the Patriots and the Giants played three weeks ago in a mesmerizing regular-season finale.

headline: Cancer Data? Sorry, Can’t Have It
text: Not long ago, I asked a respected cancer researcher if he could send me raw data from a trial he had recently published. He refused. Sharing data would make the study team members “uncomfortable,” he said, as I might use this to “cast doubt” on their results.

headline: Major Printer in Canada Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: OTTAWA  Quebecor World, the second-largest commercial printer in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada and the United States on Monday.

headline: Serena Williams Isn’t Able to Defend Her Title
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Serena Williams, a surprise winner at the Australian Open last year as an unseeded outsider, was a surprise loser Tuesday against Jelena Jankovic in the quarterfinals. Williams’s fine, early form in this tournament dissolved in a sea of unforced errors, halting steps and oddly unconvincing serves.

headline: In Matters Big and Small, Crossing Giuliani Had Price
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani likens himself to a boxer who never takes a punch without swinging back. As mayor, he made the vengeful roundhouse an instrument of government, clipping anyone who crossed him.

headline: Packers Are Poised to Contend Next Year
text: GREEN BAY, Wis.  When their season ended, the Packers shuffled from the field toward a shocked and almost silent locker room.

headline: What Money Can Buy: Influence
text: “Why isn’t Warren Buffett making an investment in Citigroup when Kuwait is?” asked Felix G. Rohatyn, the banker who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s.

headline: Here Come the Brides, Really Simply
text: Editor’s Note: This newsletter is coming to you today because of the Dr. King holiday yesterday. Next week, look for In Advertising on its usual day, Monday.

headline: The Subprime Crisis
text: To the Editor:

headline: Issuing a Bold Challenge to the U.S. Over Climate
text: For 15 years, United Nations talks aimed at fixing a faltering 1992 climate treaty have provided little drama. But at the latest session last month on the Indonesian island of Bali, Kevin Conrad, a young man representing one of the world’s least influential nations, Papua New Guinea, gained a worldwide spotlight as he faced down the sole superpower, the United States.

headline: Political Animals (Yes, Animals)
text: As the candidates have shown us in the succulent telenovela that is the 2008 presidential race, there are many ways to parry for political power. You can go tough and steely in an orange hunter’s jacket, or touchy-feely with a Kleenex packet. You can ally yourself with an alpha male like Chuck Norris, befriend an alpha female like Oprah Winfrey or split the difference and campaign with your mother. You can seek the measured endorsement of the town elders or the restless energy of the young, showily handle strange infants or furtively slam your opponents.

headline: Musharraf Trip Shadowed by Troubles at Home
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  President Pervez Musharraf is touring European capitals and plans to attend the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday in a bid to show that he remains in charge of his troubled country, where his popular support has never been at such a low ebb.

headline: Italy’s Government Tottering as Prime Minister Loses Support
text: ROME  Italy’s staggering government appeared near collapse on Monday after the former justice minister said he would no longer support Prime Minister Romano Prodi, who holds a one-vote majority in Parliament’s upper house.

headline: The Consequences of Surviving Throat Cancer at 37
text: Cancer of the throat took away Peter Broomfield’s natural voice. “I sound like a robot,” he said, pressing the tiny microphone-like instrument, called a Servox, against his neck above the trachea. A listener can slightly imagine how his Caribbean accent sounded before the cancer operation in 1990 that removed his larynx.

headline: Cuba: No Surprises, No Losers
text: Officials said that more than 95 percent of registered voters turned out at the polls on Sunday to endorse a slate of parliamentary candidates, including Fidel Castro and his brother Raúl. Of the 8.2 million voters, 3.7 percent submitted blank ballots and 1 percent voided their ballots in some way. Election officials called the results a success; critics called it a farce. As in past elections in the one-party state, nobody lost. There were 614 candidates and the same number of seats being chosen in the National Assembly.

headline: Venice Opens a Water Bus for Residents, Minus Tourists
text: VENICE  City officials on Monday opened a new water-bus line here with one special feature: no day-trip tourists allowed.

headline: Before He Made Kick, Tynes Made a Decision
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants punter Jeff Feagles, who is also the team’s holder on field-goal and extra-point attempts, has been around a lot of kickers in his 20 N.F.L. seasons. He knows that in the uncompromising world of pro football, they are ultimately judged by their failures. And, how they respond to them.

headline: In Crisis, or Just an Egoist? (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lottery Numbers
Shopping for Films but Settling for Some Fun
text: PARK CITY, Utah  A half foot of perfect, powdery snow fell here on Monday, carrying a message to the frantic crowd in temporary residence at the Sundance Film Festival: Slow down. Forget the branded parties on Main Street and the accompanying marketplace of film, and just enjoy the crunch of snow underfoot as you make your way to the next screening.

headline: Rewards, With Risks, Go Into the Sale of the G.M. Building
text: Harry B. Macklowe is in a hurry to sell all or part of the General Motors Building to raise cash to pay billions of dollars in debts due in less than three weeks.

headline: A Fatal Stabbing in Times Square
text: A 20-year-old Newark man was stabbed to death early Monday after a shoving match at a Times Square restaurant spilled out onto the sidewalk and turned into a brawl, the police said.

headline: Britain to Aid Northern Rock Sale
text: LONDON  The British Treasury said on Monday that it would facilitate a sale of the troubled mortgage lender Northern Rock by converting a pool of the company’s assets into bonds for sale to investors.

headline: For Evacuated Building’s Tenants, an Uncertain Future
text: To artists, photographers and writers, it is known as the “kibbutz”  a pock-marked pasta factory converted into a commune of creative types.

headline: In Pakistan, TV Network Loses Bite in Its Return
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  With the notable absence of two hard-hitting political talk shows, Pakistan’s most popular private television news channel was allowed to resume cable broadcasts within the country on Monday, ending a blackout that had lasted more than two months.

headline: A Name Awaiting a Bridge
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is understood to be mulling ways to honor some famous people.

headline: In a Sheep Population, Researchers Find a Fitness Gene
text: The Soay sheep of St. Kilda, a group of small Scottish islands, have been living free and unfettered for millennia. While these primitive sheep are still unmanaged, detailed records have been kept on them for the past 20 years. That makes St. Kilda a kind of natural evolutionary experiment, an island-scale Petri dish where sheep, not fruit flies, are the subjects.

headline: Dungy to Stay for 2008 at Least, as Caldwell Waits for His Turn
text: Indianapolis Colts Coach Tony Dungy, who last year became the first black head coach to win a Super Bowl, will coach at least one more season before retiring, he announced Monday.

headline: Anheuser-Busch Pushes the Big Beers for the Super Bowl
text: THE biggest advertiser on the Super Bowl  the most important day on the calendar for advertising as well as football  intends a back-to-basics approach, concentrating on its two top brands in humorous commercials that take a cheery, feel-good tack.

headline: Online Reviews of Hotels and Restaurants Flourish
text: Many of the reader-generated reviews of hotels, restaurants, destinations and other travel services on the Web may have started their lives as independent blogs by travel buffs. But they have consolidated into major online businesses, taking an ever-growing piece of the market from print guides.

headline: It Never Hurts to Quote the Classics
text: PARIS  Is traditional the new modern? Several innovative designers at the French fall men’s shows made that case over the weekend, none more plausibly than Raf Simons, whose tailored suits and graphically patterned coats used textures and materials from handicrafts and at the same time looked 21st century.

headline: Serbia: East-or-West Presidential Runoff Set
text: The runoff election between Serbia’s pro-Western president, Boris Tadic, and the ultranationalist challenger Tomislav Nikolic, who wants closer ties with Russia, will take place on Feb. 3, the state electoral commission said. First-round results of voting on Sunday gave Mr. Nikolic 39 percent and Mr. Tadic 35 percent. Other hard-line and liberal candidates shared the remainder, and the runoff next month, said Marko Blagojevic of the Center for Free Elections and Democracy, a vote monitoring group, “will be the tightest election ever in Serbia.”

headline: China Wonders if Its Stock Boom Is Over
text: SHANGHAI  A dramatic sell-off that has sent share prices here plummeting more than 10 percent over the past two days is raising fears that China’s spectacular stock market boom may be coming to an end.

headline: Profit Off 95% at Bank of America
text: Bank of America said Tuesday that its fourth-quarter profit tumbled 95 percent because of huge write-downs of mortgage-related securities and higher provisions for future losses in credit card and home equity loans.

headline: A Basic Hospital To-Do List Saves Lives
text: This is a call to arms for everyone who may someday be hospitalized, or who has a relative who may someday be hospitalized  which is to say everyone.

headline: Charity Begins in Washington
text: The munificence of American corporate titans warms the heart, sort of. The Chronicle of Philanthropy reports that the top 50 donors gave $7.3 billion to charity last year  about $150 million per head. Excluding Warren Buffett’s $43.5 billion burst of generosity in 2006, last year’s giving easily beat the record set the year before.

headline: Europe, Cutting Biofuel Subsidies, Redirects Aid to Stress Greenest Options
text: Governments in Europe and elsewhere have begun rolling back generous, across-the-board subsidies for biofuels, acknowledging that the environmental benefits of these fuels have often been overstated.

headline: The Prostate and Surgery (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Outcomes: Heeding Familiar Advice May Add Years to Your Life
text: The advice is as sound as it is familiar: avoid smoking, exercise, eat lots of fruits and vegetables, drink alcohol if you want (but not too much). Now researchers have figured out exactly how many years these habits will add to your life.

headline: City Intends to Renovate Landmark Pier as a Hub
text: City officials have decided to try again to have a 122-year-old pier near Battery Park restored so that it can serve as a hub that links parks and attractions around the harbor to the rest of the city.

headline: In Asia, Global Market Decline Accelerates
text: Amid fears that the United States may be in a recession, the decline in stock markets accelerated Tuesday across Asia.

headline: Japan’s Bank, as Expected, Leaves Key Rate Unchanged
text: TOKYO (Bloomberg News)  As expected, the Bank of Japan on Tuesday left its interest rates unchanged at 0.5 percent in a unanimous vote, the bank said in a statement. The key rate was doubled last February.

headline: World Markets Plunge on Fears of U.S. Slowdown
text: FRANKFURT  Fears that the United States may be in a recession reverberated around the world on Monday, sending stock markets from Mumbai to Frankfurt into a tailspin and puncturing the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia would be able to sidestep an American downturn.

headline: Obesity Surgery Found Effective in Treating Diabetes
text: Weight-loss surgery works much better than standard medical therapy as a treatment for type 2 diabetes in obese people, the first study to compare the two approaches has found.

headline: In the Fatosphere, Big Is In, or at Least Accepted
text: For years, health experts have been warning that Americans are too fat, that we exercise too little and eat too much, that our health is in jeopardy.

headline: For Ex-Trader, Sinking Feeling Is Reassuring
text: After four years of trading subprime mortgages, Jason Rew jettisoned his job at the investment bank Goldman Sachs and founded an off-shore business.

headline: Thailand: Democracy Returns, and Politics Comes Full Circle
text: Parliament convened for the first time since last month’s election and since Thaksin Shinawatra was ousted as prime minister in a military coup in 2006. Lawmakers were to select a speaker of the House of Representatives on Tuesday and a prime minister on Friday, with the pro-Thaksin People Power Party, which will lead a coalition government, expected to nominate its deputy leader, Yongyuth Tiyapairat, a longtime Thaksin confidant, as speaker, and its leader, Samak Sundaravej, left, who calls himself a stand-in for Mr. Thaksin, as prime minister.

headline: Lois Nettleton, 80, Dies; Acted on Stage and TV
text: Lois Nettleton, an actress whose dramatic and comic dexterity in theater, film and television earned her wide public recognition and deep professional respect for more than a half century, died on Friday in Woodland Hills, Calif. She was 80.

headline: The Voters Revolt
text: The Reagan administration had its pragmatists and its so-called ideologues. It had James Baker as well as Ed Meese. Reagan carried moderate states like Connecticut, Wisconsin and Washington, as well as conservative ones like Wyoming and South Carolina.

headline: In S. Carolina, It’s Obama vs. Clinton. That’s Bill Clinton.
text: Facing formidable support for Senator Barack Obama in South Carolina, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is deploying former President Bill Clinton there while she shifts her attention to campaigning in states with nominating contests next month and to raising money.

headline: The Claim: Too Much Cola Can Cause Kidney Problems
text: THE FACTS

headline: Memo Pad
text: FARE INCREASES ON AGAIN Major airlines have raised fares again, a week after a round of $50 round-trip fare increases collapsed when Continental Airlines rescinded its increases, causing all the others to back off as well. But on Thursday, American Airlines instituted a new increase of $40 round trip, citing fuel costs. Delta matched, and the others fell in line over the weekend, according to Tom Parsons, chief executive officer of Bestfares.com. Mr. Parsons said that business travelers booking flights at the last minute have been hard hit by incremental fare increases in recent years. "Since January 2005, business travelers who purchase tickets with little or no advance purchase have taken the brunt of increases in airfares,” he said.

headline: Earmarks Likely to Continue, but With Details
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush is unlikely to defy Congress on spending billions of dollars earmarked for pet projects, but he will probably insist that lawmakers provide more justification for such earmarks in the future, administration officials said Monday.

headline: Red Bulls Coach Heads South to Find Players
text: His bags are packed, he is ready to go. Red Bulls Coach Juan Carlos Osorio is headed to South America this week on a scouting trip with scheduled stops in Colombia, Argentina and Brazil.

headline: Oliver Stone's Presidential Ambition
text: Oliver Stone isn’t a fan of the decision to invade Iraq, but in his next film he wants to render “a fair, true portrait” of President Bush, Variety reported. “How did Bush go from an alcoholic bum to the most powerful figure in the world?” Mr. Stone asked. “It’s like Frank Capra territory on one hand, but I’ll also cover the demons in his private life, his bouts with his dad and his conversion to Christianity, which explains a lot of where he is coming from. It includes his belief that God personally chose him to be president of the United States, and his coming into his own, with the stunning, pre-emptive attack on Iraq. It will contain surprises for Bush supporters and his detractors.” If financing materializes, “Bush,” starring Josh Brolin, above, as the president in a screenplay written by Stanley Weiser, who wrote “Wall Street” with Mr. Stone, will go before the cameras in April and could be in theaters by Election Day or by the inauguration of the next president. “I’m a dramatist who is interested in people,” Mr. Stone said, “and I have empathy for Bush as a human being, much as I did for Castro, Nixon, Jim Morrison, Jim Garrison and Alexander the Great.”

headline: The Blight That Is Still With Us
text: Columbia, S.C.

headline: Stove for the Developing World’s Health
text: When Kurt Hoffman visited Tanzania in the 1970s as a young product-development researcher, he could hardly bear to enter village huts to ask questions.

headline: Remarks on Reagan Live On
text: In one of their starkest differences in Monday’s debate, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that Senator Barack Obama had talked about “admiring Ronald Reagan” and that Mr. Obama “said in the last week that he really liked the ideas of the Republicans over the last 10 to 15 years, and we can give you the exact quote.”

headline: Electric Cars Are Better
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fears, Risks and Allergies (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Joe Burk, 93, Won Honors on Thames and in Pacific, Is Dead
text: Joe Burk, a single sculls champion of the 1930s who became a leading figure in American rowing and a highly decorated PT boat skipper in World War II, died Jan. 13 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 93.

headline: California: Trade Mission to Cuba
text: California, the nation’s largest agricultural producer, is trying to increase its share of the hundreds of millions of dollars in food products that Cuba buys every year from the United States under a loophole in Washington’s trade embargo against the island. A. G. Kawamura, California’s secretary of food and agriculture, is leading a delegation of 18 business officials to Havana this week to promote products like nuts, citrus fruits and wine. California sold about $700,000 in products to Cuba in 2007, but the state predicted that the figure could be increased to $180 million. Pedro Alvarez Borrego, chairman of the Cuban government company that imports food products, said the biggest thing Cuba wanted from California was help in lifting what Havana calls an economic blockade.

headline: Newlyweds Seething After a Photo Studio Fails to Deliver
text: Michael Ruiz de Somocurcio, a health insurance executive from Clifton, N.J., paid $5,500 to Celebration Studios, a regional photography service, before his wedding in September. The price included albums, personalized thank-you notes and a DVD starring his wife, Erika, and himself.

headline: Teenagers, Scalpels and Real Cadavers
text: Around Oak Ridge, Tenn., Harry Hitchcock, a 61-year-old science teacher with owlish wire-rimmed glasses, a few wisps of white-blond hair and a gentle drawl, is known by his old military nickname, Whitey.

headline: The Boomerang Effect
text: For more than a decade, Pakistan’s powerful and secretive intelligence service has fueled a treacherous dynamic in South Asia by supporting Islamic militants in Afghanistan and Kashmir. Now comes the distressing, but not surprising, news that the ISI, or Inter-Services Intelligence, has lost control of some of these Taliban and Al Qaeda-linked networks. The militants have turned on their former patrons and helped carry out a record number of suicide attacks inside Pakistan in 2007, including possibly the one that killed Benazir Bhutto.

headline: Lew Spence, a Songwriter for Sinatra, Dies at 87
text: Lew Spence, a composer and lyricist whose songs were recorded by Frank Sinatra and many others, died on Jan. 9 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: A New Palm Species Is Discovered Through Its Swan Song
text: Even by the standards of species-rich Madagascar, the palm discovered along the northwestern coast of the island is unusual. It’s a massive tree, close to 60 feet tall with fronds up to 15 feet in diameter.

headline: Japan: Fujitsu Spins Off Unit
text: Fujitsu said that it would spin off its semiconductor division in a move that could make it easier for the new company to establish alliances with other chip makers and to share the significant development costs expected as the industry gears up for bigger silicon wafers. The company wants to spin off the semiconductor division by March, a company spokesman, Toshiyuki Fukuoka, said. The spinoff will begin as a 100 percent Fujitsu-owned subsidiary.

headline: A Nazi Past Casts a Pall on Name of a Disease
text: What’s in a disease’s name? Long-hidden shame, perhaps.

headline: Investors Abroad No Longer Immune From U.S.
text: FRANKFURT  Since late summer, the United States economy has demonstrated an enduring power to surprise. And not for the better.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about last-minute Republican campaigning before the South Carolina primary referred imprecisely to the schedule for Feb. 5. There will be more than 20 nominating contests for Republicans, including primaries and caucuses  not more than 20 primaries.

headline: Obama and Clinton Tangle at Debate
text: In the most intense and personal exchange of the presidential campaign, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama assailed each other’s integrity and voting records during a televised debate on Monday in South Carolina, the site of a critical primary in five days.

headline: Stricter System to Trim Carbon Emissions Is Considered in Europe
text: BRUSSELS  European Union officials this week will propose an overhaul of the bloc’s sometimes dysfunctional carbon emissions trading system, aiming to reduce corporate influence and make polluting more expensive.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about last-minute Republican campaigning before the South Carolina primary referred imprecisely to the schedule for Feb. 5. There will be more than 20 nominating contests for Republicans, including primaries and caucuses  not more than 20 primaries. (Go to Article)

headline: Sudan’s President Defends Accused Militia Leader
text: ISTANBUL  President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan on Monday defended a government appointment for an Arab sheik accused of leading a militia that helped the government suppress a rebel movement in the Darfur region, leading to 200,000 deaths.

headline: Coughlin Tones It Down, but Still Puts on a Show
text: Through last season, networks could rely on Giants Coach Tom Coughlin’s unhappy, transparent body language and assortment of dyspeptic facial expressions to tell a running story of exasperation, anger, frustration and, often, extreme sorrow.

headline: A Dream Is Achieved, a Legacy Is Established
text: East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: Editing of Frost Notebooks in Dispute
text: Robert Frost wrote some of this country’s most quoted  and in the minds of some, most misunderstood  poetic lines.

headline: Hundreds of Layoffs Expected at Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo is planning to lay off hundreds of employees in an effort to increase its profitability, prop up its deflated stock price and narrow the focus of its sprawling Internet portal to a smaller number of crucial areas, people close to the company said Monday.

headline: Regulators Look Closer at I.B.M. Deal
text: Antitrust regulators in the European Union have stepped up a review of International Business Machines’ proposed $4.9 billion bid for Cognos, a maker of business-analysis software. The European Commission said in a statement that the transaction’s combined market share was above certain thresholds for a simplified review. The commission did not change its Jan. 29 deadline to rule on the deal. The transaction “no longer fulfills the criteria for simplified procedure,” said Jonathan Todd, a commission spokesman.

headline: Prime Roller, Prepare to Meet a Wiseacre
text: Sam Harris’s 2004 book, “The End of Faith: Religion, Terror and the Future of Reason,” set off a noisy boomlet of antireligion books, including Richard Dawkins’s provocative if preachy tome, “The God Delusion” (2006), and Christopher Hitchens’s furious (and often very funny) jeremiad, “God Is Not Great: How Religion Poisons Everything” (2007). These books provided a vehement response to the growing influence of evangelicals in American politics and the raging fires of fundamentalism around the world, and they even led to talk about the stirrings of a “new atheist” movement.

headline: Brazil: Airline Buys 22 Airbus Jets
text: The Brazilian airline TAM said it had signed a contract to buy 46 Airbus jets, including 22 extra-wide-body A350s. The European-made A350 is a rival to the Boeing 787 Dreamliner. TAM said that the order is worth $6.9 billion at list prices, although most airlines obtain deep discounts. The addition of the A350s to TAM’s fleet represents the first time that the plane will be used in South America, TAM said.

headline: Congo Agrees to Peace Deal With Rebels
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Congo’s government reached an agreement on Monday with a renegade general to end an insurgency that has forced more than 400,000 people from their homes in the country’s volatile east in the past year and threatened to undermine the new democratically elected government, according to Congolese officials and Western diplomats involved in the negotiations.

headline: Germany: More Cracks at Holocaust Memorial
text: More than half of the 2,711 pillars that make up the Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe in Berlin have cracked, the magazine Cicero reported. It said damage was found in 1,361 of the pillars, or stelae; last year the number was put at about 400. The study said the cracks might be a result of the expansion and contraction that come with temperature change. The Holocaust memorial, designed by the American architect Peter Eisenman, was officially opened in May 2005. Its gray concrete stelae are of varying heights and are arranged in a tight, waving grid that extends over more than five acres. Thousands of people visit the site daily, walking through the rows of pillars. City officials said repairs would begin in the spring.

headline: Symptoms: Irritable Bowel Syndrome and Action by the Brain
text: Women who suffer from irritable bowel syndrome may respond to pain signals differently from other women, leaving them more vulnerable to the intestinal discomfort that characterizes the disease.

headline: Tracking the Spread of Contaminants by Testing Blood Cells
text: It’s a familiar scene following a major oil spill: struggling seabirds, doomed from the thick coat of oil on their plumage. They are a very visible indicator of how catastrophic a spill can be.

headline: High in the Air, Artist Attracts a Crowd
text: I ALWAYS take a sketch pad with me when I fly. And I fly quite a bit, sometimes to meet with clients. Other times just for pleasure. There is something wonderful about being 35,000 feet in the air, looking down on the earth, that gives an artist a new perspective.

headline: Unbeaten UConn Handles Injuries and No. 3 Tar Heels
text: STORRS, Conn.  With a little more than four minutes remaining Monday night against third-ranked North Carolina, Connecticut guard Renee Montgomery dribbled downcourt, as she had hundreds of times this season.

headline: To Some, the Widening Crisis Seems Driven by Fear, Not Facts
text: The fear is spreading.

headline: Celtics End Knicks’ Modest Winning Trend
text: Four giants of the New York sports landscape visited Madison Square Garden on Monday afternoon and bathed in roaring adulation from a packed house. Qualifying for the Super Bowl has that kind of effect on people.

headline: In the Lab: Simple Math Errors Can Imperil Patients
text: Doctors make the same arithmetic mistakes the rest of us make, but the consequences can be considerably more serious.

headline: Nostrums: Seawater Seems to Beat Medicine in Fighting Colds
text: There is no cure for the common cold, but researchers might have found a safe and simple way to reduce a child’s symptoms and the chance of recurrence: wash out the nose with seawater.

headline: Manning Enjoys Highlights
text: Eli Manning said he had trouble sleeping Sunday night, so he sat up in bed and watched various cable-sports television shows.

headline: Lacking Flaws at 33-6, Celtics Nitpick and Roll
text: One of the perks of being the best team in the N.B.A. is that you get to invent your own adversity. And so it was on a cold Monday afternoon at Madison Square Garden that the Celtics never trailed, shrugged off the Knicks by 16 points and nevertheless left the building shaking their heads at all manner of seemingly phantom concerns.

headline: Editor Fires Parting Shot at His Chain
text: The ousted editor of The Los Angeles Times on Monday offered a scathing critique of the newspaper industry and specifically his longtime employer, the Tribune Company, arguing that cost cuts, a lack of investment and an aversion to serious news was damaging the business.

headline: The Rough-and-Tumble Online Universe Traversed by Young Cybernauts
text: A baby-faced eighth grader, viciously bullied online, hangs himself. With a click of her mouse, a young woman with anorexia uses cyberspace to find tips on starving. A high school student, with a world of plot outlines available on the Internet, admits that he cannot recall ever actually reading a book.

headline: Icy Day Finds Old Union Outside Modern City Shops
text: The dramatic battles of the American labor movement were often fought in hazardous settings like the coal fields of Kentucky or the textile mills of Massachusetts.

headline: Why the European Bank Is Sitting Back
text: LONDON  Monetary policy usually takes some time to bite. That is one explanation why the American stock market continued to gyrate on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve’s emergency rate cut. It may also explain why the European Central Bank has given no indication that it will follow suit.

headline: What That Cholesterol Trial Didn’t Show
text: The cholesterol drug Vytorin became known for its commercials showing people who look oddly similar to foods like tacos and banana cream pie. But now Vytorin is getting attention that is anything but funny.

headline: Padilla Sentenced to 17 Years in Prison
text: MIAMI  Jose Padilla, the Brooklyn-born convert to Islam who was once accused by the government of plotting to detonate a “dirty bomb” in the United States, was sentenced on Tuesday to 17 years and four months in prison for his role in a conspiracy to help Islamic jihadist fighters abroad.

headline: Strength Renewed, a Grand Old Building Is Back
text: SALT LAKE CITY  When engineers began poking and prodding at the Utah Capitol a few years ago, sounding the structure for how it might fare in the earthquake that seismologists say will surely strike here one day, they grew increasingly scared as they moved higher toward the dome.

headline: Renewed Optimism for a Global Deal
text: Negotiators for the European Union and the United States said that they hoped a meeting of trade ministers in Davos, Switzerland, this week could help restart global trade talks and pave the way for a deal. Begun in 2001 to help increase trade and develop the economies of poorer countries, the talks have already missed a succession of deadlines. The European trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, sought to increase pressure for a breakthrough after a meeting on Monday with Susan C. Schwab, above, the United States trade representative. “We are rapidly moving toward a moment of truth,” Mr. Mandelson said.

headline: Feisty Gods, Bored With Ambrosia, Still Get a Kick Out of the Cancan
text: Mocking the gods has provided irresistible comic material for artists from Jacques Offenbach to Monty Python, although blaspheming is also a surefire way to attract criticism. After the 1858 premiere of Offenbach’s satirical “Orpheus in the Underworld,” one curmudgeonly critic wrote that the operetta, a sort of 19th-century “Saturday Night Live” satire of the myth of Orpheus (and Gluck’s “Orfeo ed Euridice”), was a “profanation of holy and glorious antiquity.”

headline: Siemens’s Prosperity Doesn’t Obscure Bribery Scandal
text: FRANKFURT  Business is booming at Siemens under the new chief executive, Peter Löscher, who took over last summer in the wake of a corporate bribery scandal.

headline: In the End, a Goodbye With Love and Dignity
text: “It’s not a joke,” said the tall man in the F.D.N.Y. hat as he left the funeral home. “I mean, it’s somebody’s life, that just happened to pass away. Same thing’s going to happen to all of us.”

headline: Fed Cuts Rate 0.75% and Stocks Swing
text: The Federal Reserve, responding to an international stock sell-off and fears about a possible United States recession, cut its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point on Tuesday, an aggressive move that came ahead of a regularly scheduled meeting of the central bank.

headline: Mayor Bloomberg Tackles Poverty
text: Politicians have mostly skirted poverty as a political issue since President Lyndon Johnson declared war on it more than four decades ago. Even the federal government’s method of measuring poverty is a relic from the 1960s  all but useless to cities and states seeking an accurate picture of the problem. Enter Michael Bloomberg, New York’s solutions-minded mayor, who recently took on the challenge  and the measurement  of poverty.

headline: An Illusory Existence (6 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Profit Doubled at Royal Philips
text: Royal Philips Electronics, the lighting and health care giant, said that fourth-quarter profit doubled to 1.39 billion euros ($2.03 billion) from 680 million for the same quarter a year ago, while sales rose 3.8 percent to 8.37 billion euros ($12.2 billion). Philips said its profit included gains from the 1.09 billion-euro ($1.60 billion) sale of stakes in several other companies, offset by 404 million euros ($591 million) in one-time charges. The medical equipment unit remained the most profitable, with earnings up 9.9 percent to 322 million euros ($471 million), despite a 2 percent fall in sales. The unit’s operating profit rose 34 percent to 170 million euros ($249 million) on a sales rise of 14 percent.

headline: Nascar Hopes Getting Back to Basics Brings Back Fans
text: CONCORD, N.C.  With the introduction of a new racecar, an expansion of the playoff format and the addition of ESPN as television partner in 2007, Nascar not only looked different, but it was viewed differently as well.

headline: Proving Laughter Is Best Medicine for Air Sickness
text: MESA, Ariz.  When I last saw Rene Foss, a couple of years ago, she was in her underwear. She and about a dozen other flight attendants were wearing red lingerie, in fact, as they posed for a photograph around a shiny World War II trainer parked on an airport ramp.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $6,881,972

headline: Illegal Boarding Houses Pit City’s Laws Against Lack of Alternatives
text: The four-story red-brick building blends in with the apartment houses on a hardscrabble stretch of hair salons and liquor stores in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. But it is here, miles from what was not long ago the most notorious skid row in America, where a new kind of Bowery makes its home.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: John M. Anderson, a longtime counsel to advertising and marketing communications agencies, joined Coblentz, Patch, Duffy & Bass, San Francisco from Heller Ehrman, San Francisco.

headline: Weapons Trove Suspect Is Linked to Hate Crimes
text: It all happened in less than three hours on a cool September night  a prolific spurt of anti-Jewish vandalism at more than a dozen locations in the heart of Brooklyn Heights.

headline: In Different Minor Keys, Three Formidable Pieces
text: You greet a cold, hard, wintry Sunday afternoon with either avoidance or embrace. Stay home and dream about the beach at Waikiki, or go hear the Emerson String Quartet play Brahms chamber music in three different minor keys.

headline: Japan: Sanyo Sells Cellphone Unit
text: Sanyo, the electronics maker, will sell its troubled cellphone operations to a rival, Kyocera. The companies said the value of the business is about 40 billion yen ($374 million). Including debt, the deal  set for completion April 1  is worth about 50 billion yen ($467 million), although the companies have yet to agree on a final price. The long-anticipated sale of the unit comes months after Goldman Sachs and other investors saved Sanyo in a 300 billion yen ($2.8 billion) bailout.

headline: Woods Calls Remarks ‘Unfortunate’
text: After a month out of the public eye, Tiger Woods addressed the controversy that has swirled in the news media about the inappropriate racial remarks made three weeks ago by a Golf Channel anchor.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Jan. 14 about The Associated Press’s reporting on the entertainer Britney Spears misspelled the surname of a managing editor at the news agency who defended a decision to bolster coverage. He is Lou Ferrara, not Ferrera.

headline: For the Record
text: In a Jan. 14 Editorial Notebook on gadgets: The VHS format was developed by Matsushita, not by Toshiba.

headline: Burress Battles Back at Just the Right Time
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  In his first five seasons in the N.F.L., Plaxico Burress made many friends on the Pittsburgh Steelers but never reached the Super Bowl. After he left as a free agent in 2005, the Steelers won the title.

headline: Airwaves, Web Power at Auction
text: WASHINGTON  The auction for rights to a highly valuable swath of the nation’s airwaves will begin Thursday and is expected to include multibillion-dollar bids from the nation’s two biggest wireless phone companies, Verizon and AT&T, as well as Google.

headline: Market’s Wild Ride Ends With Dow at 15-Month Low
text: Tuesday began on Wall Street with ominous warnings that the stock market was set for its biggest plunge since the dark days after the terrorist attacks of 2001. It ended with the markets down scarcely 1 percent, as stocks somersaulted through a volatile day of trading.

headline: Birds in Great Salt Lake Felled by Cholera by the Thousands
text: Some of the birds flew upside down or threw their heads back between their wings. Some fell out of the sky. Others tried to land a foot or more above the water, or swam in circles when they got there. And then they died.

headline: Apocalypse, Described in Visions of Long Ago
text: Benjamin Bagby has put his bardic re-creation of the “Beowulf” epic behind him, but he is clearly still drawn to the dark and terrifying in projects for Sequentia, his early-music group.

headline: Hopes for Vehicle Questioned After Iraq Blast
text: ARAB JABOUR, Iraq  From the blast and the high, thin plume of white smoke above the tree line, it looked and sounded like any other attack. The bare details were, sadly, routine enough: a gunner was killed and three crew members were wounded Saturday when their vehicle rolled over a homemade bomb buried beneath a road southeast of Baghdad.

headline: Wal-Mart Says Most Workers Have Health Plan
text: Wal-Mart Stores, the nation’s largest private employer, said on Tuesday that for the first time in its 45-year history more than half of its workers had enrolled in the company’s health insurance plan, a potent milestone for a retailer long associated with unaffordable benefits.

headline: Whales in the Navy’s Way
text: According to a federal district judge in California, the Navy’s own research predicted that its sonar training exercises off the California coast will cause widespread harm  and possibly permanent injury or death  to nearly 30 species of marine mammals, including five species of endangered whales. That still didn’t stop the Bush administration from rejecting the judge’s carefully crafted plan to protect these animals from avoidable harm.

headline: New DVDs
text: 4 BY AGNèS VARDA

headline: If Everyone’s Finger-Pointing, Who’s to Blame?
text: Everyone wants to know who is to blame for the losses paining Wall Street and homeowners.

headline: Sutherland Out of Jail
text: Time’s up for Kiefer Sutherland. After 48 days Mr. Sutherland, the star of Fox television’s “24,” walked out of jail in Glendale, Calif., at 12:05 a.m. Monday, The Associated Press reported. He was sentenced to 30 days after he pleaded no contest in October to driving with a blood alcohol level above the legal limit, and 18 days were added for violating probation in connection with a drunken driving arrest in 2004. He spent his jail time on laundry duty, cleaning sheets, pillowcases and blankets. John Balian, a police officer, said: “He was very humble, never complained. He didn’t give us any problems at all.”

headline: Blitzer’s Leniency Goes a Long Way
text: As a seemingly endless series of presidential candidate debates have proven this election cycle, the posture of the debate moderator can make the difference between a forgettable evening and a feisty one.

headline: Endowing an Elite Prep School
text: The endowment of Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire last year surpassed $1 billion, making it richer than many universities.

headline: Lighter Than Air Travel
text: Rene Foss, a flight attendant, has a one-woman show called “Around the World in a Bad Mood,” in which she ridicules the airline industry. Here is her explanation to the audience about why her fictional airline does not serve food:

headline: Political Animals
text: From today’s Science report:

headline: Tom Cruise Parody
text: A sendup of the actor’s now-famous Scientology video (if you don’t like constipation or flatulence jokes, don’t watch):

headline: Tom Brady Is Limping; Should the Spread Be Shrinking?
text: Should the Patriots be favored by 14 points if Tom Brady is hobbling around on a walking boot?

headline: The Climate Challenge. Same as it Ever Was?
text: I have a story in Science Times looking at the latest round of climate-treaty talks, one month ago in Bali, from the vantage point of Kevin Conrad, the young man who represented Papua New Guinea and shook things up with a strong rebuke of the United States in the final tumultuous session. (An Associated Press video report is on YouTube.) It turns out things were not quite as they appeared.

headline: Woodpecker Boom and Bust
text: Both the ivory-billed woodpecker and a thriving local economy are hard to find in the bayou of Arkansas.

headline: ACA Capital Receives Extension to Unwind Subprime Exposure
text: ACA Capital Holdings, the troubled bond insurer, has received an additional month to unwind an estimated $69 billion of credit exposure stemming from the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Maker of SuperPoke Takes $50 Million
text: A social network software maker, Slide, said on Friday it had closed a $50 million institutional financing round, marking the rising valuations of start-ups riding fast-growing Facebook‘s wave of popularity.

headline: India’s Emaar Kicks Off $1.8 Billion I.P.O.
text: Emaar MGF Land, a real estate developer, started an initial public offering in India on Monday.

headline: Israel’s Teva Takes CoGenesys for $400 Million
text: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries of Israel said on Tuesday that it plans to acquire CoGenesys, a privately held biopharmaceutical company, for $400 million in cash.

headline: Europe Stabilizes
text: Davos, Switzerland

headline: With Airline Mergers, Managers Foresee Higher Fares
text: Three-quarters of corporate travel managers said in a recent survey that they expect airline mergers to result in higher fares and more than half expect the quality of service to suffer.

headline: Brazil’s Vale Confirms Talks to Merge With Xstrata
text: Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the world’s largest producer of iron ore, said on Monday that it was in talks with a rival, Xstrata, about a merger.

headline: L.A. Times Editor Fires Parting Shot at Tribune
text: It’s been only a month since Samuel Zell took control of Tribune and already he’s facing the fallout from rebellion in the ranks.

headline: Major Printer in Canada Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: Quebecor World, the second-largest commercial printer in the world, filed for bankruptcy protection in Canada and the United States on Monday.

headline: If Everyone’s Finger-Pointing, Who’s to Blame?
text: Everyone wants to know who is to blame for the losses paining Wall Street and homeowners.

headline: Roche Wins Ventana With Sweetened $3.4 Billion Bid
text: Roche Holding has overcome Ventana Medical Systems‘ resistance to its takeover bid by raising the price, acquiring the diagnostics maker for $3.4 billion to expand its cancer testing business.

headline: Sears Reorganization: Prelude to a Break-up?
text: The billionaire hedge fund investor Edward Lampert is playing an old tune for Sears Holdings: break up to make up. Make up for the beating that Mr. Lampert’s portfolio has taken on the retail giant he forged out of the merger of Sears and Kmart, that is.

headline: ‘Where They Didn’t Pool Any Paunches’
text: More of your “late night” humor (send via the comment link below):

headline: Japan’s Kyocera Dials Up Deal for Sanyo Cellphone Unit
text: The Japanese electronics maker Kyocera said it would buy Sanyo Electric‘s money-losing cellphone business for as much as $468 million, creating the world’s sixth-largest cellphone maker.

headline: G.E. Says Its Mulling Deal for Spain’s Colonial
text: General Electric confirmed Monday that it is studying a possible deal with Colonial, in a move that could spark a bidding war for the Spanish real estate firm.

headline: Ambac Faces Shareholder Lawsuits
text: The Ambac Financial Group, the second-largest bond insurer, has been accused in two lawsuits of misleading investors and artificially raising its share price.

headline: Dog Mascot Dance-Off
text: Will the Super Bowl halftime show be this good? Just asking.

headline: Fund Run by Ex-SAC Trader Said to Suffer 12% Loss
text: Sailfish Capital Partners, a credit hedge fund run by a former SAC Capital Management bond trader, Mark Fishman, recorded a loss of more than 12 percent for the first 51 weeks of last year and is understood to be suffering significant client redemptions, Financial News reported.

headline: Consolidation for German Banks Necessary, Minister Says
text: The German economy minister, Michael Glos, said on Tuesday the problems at the state lender WestLB showed that further consolidation in the German banking system was necessary.

headline: British Advisers Reap $10.5 Billion from Buyout Deals
text: Whatever the subsequent fallout from the easy credit extended during the recent private equity boom, bankers nonetheless reaped handsome profits.

headline: Is RiskMetrics’ I.P.O. a Bellwether for 2008?
text: A share sale this week for RiskMetrics Group, the owner of Institutional Shareholder Services, the proxy advisory service, could go a long way toward determining whether the new-issues market will have a smooth or bumpy ride in the early part of the year, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Britain to Use Bond Sale to Aid Northern Rock Sale
text: The British Treasury said on Monday that it would facilitate a sale of the troubled mortgage lender Northern Rock by converting a pool of the company’s assets into bonds for sale to investors.

headline: Getty Images Up for Sale, Could Fetch $1.5 Billion
text: Getty Images, the world’s biggest supplier of pictures and video to media and advertising companies, has put itself on the auction block and could fetch more than $1.5 billion, according to The New York Times.

headline: Flowers May Bid for British Insurer
text: J.C. Flowers, the private equity shop run by J. Christopher Flowers, said Monday that it was floating an informal 4 billion pound ($7.8 billion) offer for Friends Provident, a British insurance company.

headline: 2 Moguls’ Sons, 1 Bid
text: Lachlan Murdoch, a son of the media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, and the gambling magnate James D. Packer have made an offer of 3.3 billion Australian dollars ($2.9 billion) to buy the Packer-backed publishing company Consolidated Media Holdings.

headline: For Ex-Goldman Trader, a Good Sinking Feeling
text: After four years of trading subprime mortgages, Jason Rew jettisoned his job at the investment bank Goldman Sachs and founded an off-shore business.

headline: How Low Will the Market Go Tuesday?
text: Stocks looked ready to plunge in the United States early Tuesday, as the waves of anxious selling in Asian markets threatened to spread to Wall Street. Before the open of regular trading, Dow Jones Industrial Average futures were down more than 500 points, amid fears that the economic troubles in the United States were deeper and more far-reaching than previously thought. That was before the Federal Reserve announced early Tuesday it would cut its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a percentage point.

headline: What’s Really Driving the Sovereign Fund Rush
text: If all these government-controlled funds in Asia and the Middle East that have been falling over one another to buy up stakes in Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley are so smart, where are all the big-name value investors like Warren Buffett? DealBook looked into this question in its latest column in The New York Times — and the answer seems to have a lot to do with politics.

headline: Minnows Clash in African Cup of Nations
text: The first two days of the African Cup of Nations have unfolded according to form: hosts Ghana won the opening match 2-1, perhaps with more difficulty than was expected. Morocco handily dispatched Namibia, 5-1, thanks to a hattrick from Soufiane Alloudi. Mali earned a 1-0 victory over Benin. And in the marquee matchup of the first round, Nigeria fell 1-0 to Ivory Coast in a tight affair, Chelsea’s Salomon Kalou scoring the only goal.

headline: The Early Word: Feisty Democrat Fight
text: As the presidential candidates march toward Super Tuesday (two weeks from today!), they are drawing sharp differences against their opponents. And last night in Myrtle Beach, S.C., the Democrats traded barbs in ways we hadn’t seen before.

headline: The Oscar Gun Goes Off
text: Here are the nominations for the Golden Guy:

headline: Ambac Posts $3.3 Billion Loss
text: The Ambac Financial Groupm the bond insurance company, reported a quarterly loss of $3.3 billion on Tuesday after recording massive credit derivative write-downs and setting aside more money for credit losses.

headline: Panic in Washington
text: DAVOS

headline: Atonement: A Drama in Three Acts
text: Most Oscar ninnies, including the Bagger, had counted out “Atonement,” but there it was, the first picture mentioned in the tick-tock of best picture announcements by the Academy in the week hours of the California morning. The guessing for the No. 5 slot in the category had been spread around between “Into the Wild” or “Diving Bell,” but it’s “Atonement” that will be there for The Dance.

headline: Tracking the Markets After a Global Plunge
text: Following a full day of trading in the U.S. after 2 days of market dives around the world.

headline: Preemptive easing
text: Wow. First the markets, now the Fed’s reaction.

headline: Designs for a Downsized Future
text: DETROIT — One of the more refreshing displays here at the auto show, which runs through Sunday, is one for the Michelin Challenge Design, an annual competition held by the French tire maker.

headline: Giuliani as Mayor: Tough, Ruthless and Vengeful
text: In a front-page article, Michael Powell and Russ Buettner explore Rudolph W. Giuliani’s tendency, during his eight years as mayor, to go after anyone who crossed him. In case after case, the Giuliani administration tried to silence or punish critics, including public interest lawyers, the nonprofit advocacy group Housing Works, top city officials and ordinary citizens.

headline: Long Division
text: O.K., long weekend and the Opinionator is still catching up, but I think this still deserves mention: on Saturday Al Giordano, a former reporter for the alt-weekly Boston Phoenix now covering politics for the advocacy group RuralVotes’ blog, The Field, attended the caucuses held on the strip in Las Vegas. It was not pretty:

headline: Playing Well With Others
text: Paramount Vantage and Miramax are in the midst of a very profitable corporate friendship. They share credits on the biggest winners today: “No Country for Old Men” and “There Will Be Blood” led the field with eight nominations each, including best picture. Paramount Vantage has domestic rights to “TWBB” while Miramax has foreign, and Miramax owns “NCFOM” in the United States while Paramount has the international rights. There will be some smiles across the room, along with quiet competition, between John Lesher of Paramount and Daniel Battsek of Miramax.

headline: Davos in the Papers: Before the Show Starts
text: The World Economic Forum likes to see its annual meetings in Davos as a forum for politicians, business people and regulators to discuss the problems facing the world. For many captains of industry, however, the gathering is largely an opportunity to talk to each other – in private.

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

headline: Getting Around Davos: Our Annotated Map
text: View Larger Map

headline: After Eight Rounds, Carlsen Leads at Corus
The Apparatus of Award
text: With “No Country for Old Men” and “There Will Be Blood” racking up nominations, the Bagger wonders what would happen in a throwdown between Anton Chigurh and Daniel Plainview. Both Javier Bardem (supporting) and Daniel Day-Lewis (lead) received nominations, but in a face-off between their characters, would the bowling pin-wielding Plainview or Chigurh, he of the lethal cattle stunner, come out on top?

headline: The Senate Returns
text: Congress returns in full force today as the Senate ends the abbreviated pro forma sessions it has been conducting to deny President Bush recess appointments and opens its 2008 session in earnest.

headline: Butterfly Flap
text: The Bagger and others had chosen “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly” for the fifth best picture slot, but the Miramax-backed French language film never emerged from its cocoon. Still, “Diving Bell” did get some love. Director Julian Schnabel was nominated for his efforts, which were remarkable, given that he had to come up with a way of visualizing and dramatizing the inner life of a man whose only communication with the outside world involved blinking one eye.

headline: Weather Report: Mirroring the Markets, Gloom Over Davos
text: Today’s stormy market looks as if it will be finding an echo in the weather for participants arriving in Switzerland on Tuesday for the World Economic Forum in Davos.

headline: As Markets Fall, a Time for Panic — or Opportunity?
text: Crisis begets drama. Perhaps one of the more compelling stories of the 1987 market crash was the offering of British Petroleum shares.

headline: From Davos, an Early Take on Rate Cuts
text: As world leaders such as Gordon Brown and business bigshots such as Lloyd Blankfein stream into Davos this week for the World Economic Forum, the stock markets are giving them plenty to talk about. Floyd Norris, the chief financial correspondent for The New York Times, is already in Davos for the event. The latest post on Mr. Norris’s blog offers his initial thoughts on Tuesday morning’s potentially market-moving development: the United States Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cut:

headline: A Night Out in Accra
text: We set out to experience the Accra buzz this past weekend. Dinner at Celsbridge, a local favorite specializing in chicken and chips, fueled us for a long night. If you are in the area, I highly recommend it — especially if you enjoy your chicken crispy and spicy. A Star beer – a hoppy local lager that resembles Heineken, but better — easily washes the food down. A table of travelers decked out in green Nigeria kits was the only other exception in a restaurant glowing with Ghanaian colors.

headline: The Insider | M. Blash
text: (Bryce Kass)

headline: Moment of Truth in Toronto
text: The Toronto Maple Leafs have not won the Stanley Cup since 1967. They won’t win it this season, either.

headline: ‘The Closer at a Cadillac Dealership’
text: Aired Monday night on CBS: Pundits say that Mitt Romney may actually be too good-looking to be president. Well, that’s what keeps me from running.

headline: One Foot, Two Foot, Red Foot, Green Foot
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Countrywide’s Strangely Normal Deal Agreement
text: Last week Countrywide Financial filed its merger agreement with Bank of America. Given market conditions there was the expectation that there would be something particularly juicy in it.

headline: Race Tightens in New York for G.O.P. Candidates
text: Senator John McCain of Arizona and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City are running neck and neck among New York State Republicans likely to vote in their party’s presidential primary on Feb. 5, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released this morning.

headline: Clinton’s Big Spousal Shadow
text: On the heels of last night’s Democratic debate, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton held a news conference this morning in Washington, D.C.. But all the reporters wanted to talk about was her husband.

headline: The Panic Eases
text: DAVOS

headline: Deep? Maybe. Long? Probably.
text: I still keep reading articles asserting that the last two recessions were brief and shallow. Formally, that’s true. But both were followed by prolonged “jobless recoveries” that felt like continuing recessions. Below is the employment-population ratio since 1989, with shading showing the official recessions. In both cases the employment slump went on for a long time after the recession was supposedly over.

headline: Writes Like a Girl
text: One of the more interesting and heartening bits of glittering data to emerge this morning has to in the screenplay categories. In both adapted and original, four great screenwriters who happen to be women were nominated. There’s a lesson down in there somewhere, something which suggest that while the loud clanky male voice has its uses – the Bagger is a proud bellower himself – if you are interested in making the kind of movie that engages audiences and wins lots of awards, maybe you should find someone who has interests beside NFL playoff point spreads.

headline: Suicide Watch
text: Way back in August, Harvey Weinstein of the Weinstein Company looked toward this day and made a vow.

headline: Miramax Plays Blackjack, and Draws 21
text: With 21 nominations across four movies – “No Country For Old Men,” “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” “Gone Baby Gone,” and “There Will Be Blood” (for which Miramax has international distribution rights) — Daniel Battsek, the head of Miramax, best have some champagne with his eggs.

headline: Juno What? A Best Director Nom for Reitman
text: The biggest surprise in the directing category had to the nomination of Jason Reitman, the 30-year-old director of “Juno,” which had three other nominations including original screenplay (Diablo Cody), best actress (Ellen Page) and best picture. No one is more surprised that Mr. Reitman. Both he and the Bagger are in Sundance, and Mr. Reitman was half-asleep when he turned on the TV.

headline: Davos Keeps Tabs on the Dow
text: As I write this, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is down only 130 points. (Now there’s a line I have not often used.) Financial stocks, after opening lower, are now up for the day. And Europe rose nicely. The Fed’s move, contrary to what I feared, has brought in buyers.

headline: Fun Fact to Know and Forget
text: Per the Academy: For the second year in a row, an American director has been nominated for directing a foreign-language film. Last year, Clint Eastwood was nominated for the Japanese-language “Letters from Iwo Jima”; this year, Julian Schnabel is nominated for the French-language “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” (The Bagger’s colleague, Randy Kennedy, checked in with Mr. Schnabel back in November.)

headline: Report Says Whitman to Leave After Conservative Decade at eBay
text: The Wall Street Journal is reporting that Meg Whitman is retiring as chief executive of eBay. In March, Ms. Whitman, 51, will have served in the position for 10 years.

headline: Low Batting Average
text: Those of you ninnies who use the Screen Actors Guild awards as some king of indicator might want to wipe them from your database.

headline: Romney and Keynes
text: Romney:

headline: Hold Contest. Read 1,000 Entries. Name Winners!
text: Last week I challenged readers to dispense wisdom in just seven words. More than 1,000 of you offered ideas, adding up to more than 7,000 words of sage advice.

headline: Huckabee’s Money Woes Curtail Campaign
text: A chronic lack of campaign money may finally be catching up to Mike Huckabee.

headline: Chanel: Icon Power
text: On my way to the Armani couture show, I dropped by Chanel to see Karl Lagerfeld in his studio. The first person I saw was Amanda Harlech, sitting by the windows overlooking the Rue Cambon, and then I seemed to see everybody at once—Odile Gilbert, who always does the hair, Michel, who does the music, Elsa, who deals with VIPs who want to wear Chanel, Madame Jacqueline, who presides over the ateliers, and Sebastian, who drives Lagerfeld. Right away, Lagerfeld got down to business and said the collection had been inspired by shell patterns. He had never really thought about shells before, he said, and, as he opened a picture book of shells—“Coquillages” by Paul Starosta and Jacques Senders—he described it as an unknown world of color and texture.

headline: Juno Over the Moon
text: A jet-lagged Ellen Page checked in with the Baguette from London, where “Juno” is set to open on Feb. 8. She said she was still a little in shock over the Oscar nomination: “I mean, everything is obviously wonderful, and I’m extremely grateful but of course this is very exciting. I’m extremely humbled to be nominated with the women I’m nominated with. It’s crazy! It’s absolutely crazy!”

headline: Academy Award Nominees
text: Images of the nominees for the 80th annual Academy Awards.

headline: ‘He Couldn’t Afford the Grey Poupon’
text: Aired Monday night on NBC: Folks, one year from today, we will swear in a new president of the United States. How about that? And as Hillary Clinton likes to say, “Whoever she may be.”

headline: The Little Sparrow’s Voice
text: There were lots of noisy people speaking in French in the background when Marion Cotillard called the Baguette from her L.A. hotel. “It’s unbelievable!” she said. “It’s unbelievable! It’s huge. A French actress with a French movie to the Oscar is something that you can’t imagine that it’s impossible.”

headline: The Rat Man Speaks
text: Brad Bird had a big morning: his film “Ratatouille” was been nominated for best animated film and he also got a nod for best screenplay. “The Oscars are kind of the grand daddy of them all,” he told the Baguette. “I remember watching it as a little kid.

headline: Should Student Test Scores Measure a Teacher’s Value?
text: What makes a good teacher? The city’s Education Department has come up with one answer: Use standardized reading and math test scores to measure how much a teacher’s students improve from one year to the next. In a new pilot program at 140 city schools, the city has used a complicated statistical analysis to predict how much students should improve, then measure that against how well they actually do. Teachers are measured against other teachers with similar experiences and students. The outcome: Teachers will be rated to measure how well they taught their students in any given year.

headline: BMW Welt
text: BMW Welt, or BMW World, joins an impressive list of high-profile architecture projects by German car companies in recent years.

headline: Cameras Permitted–Maybe
text: Over the weekend, I took my family to see a freestyle motocross show (motorcycle and bicycle stunt-riding) at a local arena. I know that, as a white bread suburban Ivy-League writer, I’m not most people’s idea of a motocross-show goer, but you should see these guys: 19-year-old riders powering up a ramp and flying what must be 150 feet through the air, 50 feet off the ground, doing backflips, letting go of the bike altogether and otherwise channeling the spirit of Evel Kneivel.

headline: Obama Continues Duel With Bill Clinton
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. – As his campaign opened a telephone hotline for voters to report instances of dirty politics in the South Carolina primary fight, Senator Barack Obama did not back down from a defiant tone he struck at the Democratic debate last night.

headline: Stocks Down, Interest In Business News Up
text: Whether markets are falling or rising, viewership of the business news network CNBC swells on volatile trading days. The same will likely be true for the four-month-old Fox Business Network.

headline: 15 and Out
text: It was just 15 months ago that Buffets Inc., a restaurant company controlled by Caxton-Iseman Capital, a private equity firm, expanded by purchasing Ryan’s Restaurant Group, the owners of Ryan’s Family Steakhouses. The $16.25 per share purchase price was a 45 percent premium over the market price before the deal was announce.

headline: Moviegoing
text: The third round of the Book Review’s Reading Room series is up and percolating.

headline: Stocks Down, New Romney Ad Up
text: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla. — In the midst of troubles in the stock market today, Mitt Romney has a new ad out in Florida touting his economic plan.

headline: Race Tightens in New York for G.O.P. Candidates
text: Senator John McCain of Arizona and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City are running neck and neck among New York State Republicans likely to vote in their party’s presidential primary on Feb. 5, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released this morning.

headline: Secret Plans, Private Meetings
text: While Senators Clinton and Obama brawl in South Carolina and John McCain, Mitt Romney and Rudy Giuliani gear up in Florida, the ground seems to be shifting under some of the other remaining headliners.

headline: Now Screening | Suzy Menkes
text: Now that the Paris and Milan men’s shows are over, The Moment would like to call your attention to the fine reporting of our fashion sister, Suzy — Suzy Menkes, that is — at the International Herald Tribune. We’d meant to say this earlier: Check out her interviews with Dior Homme’s creative director Kris Van Assche and Gildo Zegna of Ermenegildo Zegna.

headline: Passion Erupts in a Burst of African Colors
text: The highway from Accra to Sekondi is a two-lane road that follows the Atlantic. It’s lined with palm trees and dotted with towns whose only reason for existing seems to be to sell pineapples and Ghanaian flags to travelers. The route is mostly dominated by overloaded trucks that list like boats and jam-packed tro-tros, the minibuses that are the transportation lifeblood of Ghana. In other words, it’s not the best road to be on if you’re running late.

headline: A Caribbean Restaurant Recommendation in Santo Domingo
text: As a present for a friend I want to give a meal at a very nice restaurant in the old city in Santo Domingo that serves (at least some) Caribbean food. Preferably not too big a place, and not in a hotel. Do you have any suggestions? Including how to contact them? Thanks!

headline: The Man From ‘Sicko’
text: Michael Moore, nominated for the documentary “Sicko,” told the Baguette he clearly remembered his nomination and win for “Bowling for Columbine.”

headline: The Valley Goes to the Mountains, in Full Blogging Mode
text: “Tech is back at Davos this year,” one of the participants exclaimed to me before I left Silicon Valley for the annual conference at this ski resort town.

headline: It’s Just Gravy
text: Javier Bardem is traveling in Europe with pals and swears that he is not carrying that pneumatic thingamajigie that Anton Chigurh used to dispatch people in “No Country for Old Men.” He watched the awards on television.

headline: Bill Clinton Campaigns in S.C.
text: AIKEN, S.C. — As Senator Hillary Clinton flew off to Washington and then California, her husband stayed on the ground — and on message — to continue her campaign here in advance of Saturday’s Democratic primary.

headline: A Tale of Two Worlds
text: DAVOS, Switzerland

headline: Science Explains Wilson the Volleyball
text: I have never understood why Wilson didn’t get an Oscar for his performance in “Castaway.” The volleyball stole the movie! But now at least we have a scientific explanation for his existence.

headline: Edwards Ad: Rivals Take Lobbyists’ Money
text: CONWAY, S.C. – Echoing a line of attack from Monday night’s Democratic debate, John Edwards takes on both of his Democratic rivals for accepting money from drug companies and Washington lobbyists in a new television ad that goes up in South Carolina today.

headline: Anti-Davos Gatherings Go Smaller, but Global
text: The World Social Forum has billed itself as the anti-Davos since 2001, when a collection of leftist activists of all stripes met in Porto Allegre, Brazil to proclaim “Another World Is Possible.” So, it turns out, is another kind of World Social Forum.

headline: Finally, Deal Flow
text: After five days of wandering across the snowscape, the Bagger has finally found news of some deals from his colleague David M. Halbfinger.

headline: Despite Strike, Oscar Organizers Are Optimistic
text: The Oscar nominations are out, “one of the biggest questions about this year’s Oscar race — how a continuing writers strike will affect the ceremony — went unanswered,” Brooks Barnes notes.

headline: Atonement: Obits Were Dead on Arrival
text: James Schamus, poohbah of Focus Features, ribbed the Bagger and others for not picking “Atonement” to get into the final five, but he was in too good of a mood about the film’s seven nominations to dwell on the past.

headline: Soft Serve  | A News Feed of Light Reading
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.The Journal reports that playing Wii and surgical training can be one in the same… Going under the knife? Might as well make sure an “indie” knife from Joel Bukiewicz… A non-invasive solution for men with small swords: the Wonderjock swimsuit from Aussiebum, an Australian-made pushup bra for a man’s thunder down under… Before hitting the beach, surf over to Shoppingblog, which has compiled an exhaustive list of all the new, hair-brained diet books… If your latest regime has you skipping coffee, you might want to cheat with a halitosis-busting mouth spray that’s super-charged with caffeine... Smell you later.

headline: Just Browsing | Ripped From the Fashion Rags
text: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

headline: Open Caucus: Voters View the S.C. Fracas
text: One of our Open Caucus participants, Patricia Barry, characterized last night’s Democratic debate as “a rousing, gloves-off session.” With attacks flying every which way, members of our voters’ roundtable from around the country watched the fracas in Myrtle Beach, S.C. unfold on their television screens. Please feel free to join in the discussion in the comments section.

headline: Can this be true?
text: According to Sam Stein:

headline: Here, There and Everywhere, Week 4
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commuting trip for NYTimes.com/realestate, with additional details and reader comments here on City Room [Week 1 | Week 2 | Week 3]. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Thompson’s Out
text: Everybody’s been asking: “Where’s Fred?”

headline: When Elbows Rub, Can Deals Be Far Behind?
text: “A merger is like two people falling in love,” Klaus Schwab, the founder of the World Economic Forum, was once quoted as saying in Wired magazine. “Sometimes we are the place where the people first meet. Sometimes we are the place where they do the proposing. And sometimes we just provide the beautiful sunset.”

headline: A Brighter Year Ahead? Some C.E.O.’s Think So
text: How this year looks depends on where you sit. If you sit in a developed economy, it doesn’t look so good. But if you are in a developing economy, all is rosy.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Jan. 22:

headline: Prince Charles ‘Appears’ at an Energy Summit
text: Prince Charles gave a keynote lecture at a summit meeting on advanced energy technologies in Abu Dhabi on Monday — not in the flesh, but as a three-dimensional hologram. By not flying there and back, he avoided adding about 20 tons of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere (the carbon cost of flying him and his entourage), according to conference organizers.

headline: Market Troubles Deter Few from Attending
text: Shares plummet, American central bankers meet for an emergency rate cut and George Soros asserts that this could be the worst financial crisis since World War II? Apparently that’s no reason for the world’s top bankers and financial policy makers to cancel the annual schmoozefest that is the World Economic Forum in Davos.

headline: ‘Jeopardy!’ Returns to Air Without Writers
text: From Dateline Hollywood:

headline: The Goddess Speaks
text: “It’s Julie,” Ms. Christie said on the phone. She said it so softly that the name didn’t immediately register with the Baguette — that Julie Christie, the legendary actress who won an Oscar for “Darling” (1965). “I’m sitting down to breakfast,” she said with a laugh.

headline: McCain Jokes About D’Amato’s Endorsement
text: FORT WALTON BEACH, Fla. – After two rallies in Florida’s Panhandle this morning, Senator John McCain was airborne for New York to collect cash for his burgeoning campaign.

headline: Sundance Winner: There Will Be Bagels
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Bagels may have gone coast-to-coast, but New Yorkers still sniff at the frozen supermarket creations and rolls-with-holes that masquerade as the real thing in other parts of the country. Which is why your City Room reporter was surprised to encounter real Brooklyn bagels in the Rocky Mountains last week during the Sundance Film Festival, which continues through Sunday.

headline: Sarah Gets the News
text: Sarah Polley was having her hair done on a film set when she got the news that she had received an Oscar nomination for best adapted screenplay for “Away From Her.” “I had my hair in curlers and was listening to the nominations on the radio,” she told the Baguette.

headline: Girls in Japan
text: On the subject of the mute, wide-eyed seductress who stares and goggles and cryptically gestures, my friend Shizu explains it all from Japan.

headline: Writers Informally Meet With Studios
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Europe: Your I.P. Address Is Personal
text: At a hearing Monday, a top privacy regulator in Europe said something that needs to be said: I.P. addresses need to be treated as personal information.

headline: Federal Reserve Cuts Interest Rates
text: The Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates Tuesday morning.

headline: Beyond ‘Mad Men': AMC’s Second Series Shows Promise
text: Fresh off its Golden Globe win for “Mad Men,” AMC is enjoying another round of positive press for its second original series, “Breaking Bad.”

headline: High on Rebellion
text: After admitting that he passed up a live set by Patti Smith because of work, the Bagger took a little bit of a beat-down in comments and vowed not to make the same mistake twice when he heard there was a second show last night.

headline: The Democrats Head South
text: As they campaigned across South Carolina in preparation for Saturday's primary, the Democratic candidates adopted a sharper tone.

headline: Television for the Captive Commuter
text: Will New Jersey commuters turn into PATH potatoes?

headline: Answers About ‘The Jewish Americans’, Part 2
text: Following is the second and final set of answers from David Grubin, a director, writer and cinematographer working in New York City, who took questions from readers over the past week on his new three-part documentary, “The Jewish Americans” on PBS. The previous set of questions and answers was posted on Jan. 18.

headline: The Bidding Starts at $160,000
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: For The Moment | Jeff Klein’s Anti-Formula
text: This week’s guest blogger is Jeff Klein, the hotelier behind The City Club in New York and the Sunset Tower in Los Angeles. To read all of Jeff Klein’s prior blog posts, click here.

headline: The Death of Heath Ledger
text: Updated, 10:17 p.m. | The actor Heath Ledger was found dead Tuesday afternoon in an apartment in Manhattan, according to the New York City police.
