Some signs pointed to an accidental overdose or a suicide, although no note was found, police sources said. Mr. Ledger was 28. [Now online: Comprehensive coverage prepared for Wednesday editions of The Times.]

headline: NBC Sweeps Monday Night
text: NBC led every hour of prime time in Monday night’s ratings, buoyed by the successful combination of “American Gladiators” (a new reality show/sports competition) followed by “Deal or No Deal” (a game show).

headline: Ron Paul’s MLK Fund-Raiser
text: There are a lot of ways to honor the memory of Martin Luther King Jr. Ron Paul’s supporters turned MLK day into a fund-raising opportunity. With majestic and swelling music on a You Tube clip, supporers of Ron Paul kicked off the “Free at Last 2008″ Web site and his supporters responded by donating $1.85 million on the King anniversary — an amount that more cash-strapped candidates would envy.

headline: The Unhappy Warrior
text: Well, that didn’t take long: “Fred D. Thompson, the former senator of Tennessee, dropped out of the Republican race for president today,” reports The Times.

headline: The Butterfly Effect
text: Julian Schnabel, speaking to the Baguette from Rome, about his Oscar nomination for directing “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” said he had friends waiting for him at a restaurant. “They’re going to buy me a bottle of champagne and we’re going to act like we’re excited.”

headline: Responses to Spitzer’s Budget Proposal
text: Updated, 7:07 p.m. | Reaction has been pouring in to Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s second executive budget, in which he proposed an array of new taxes and fees, $1 billion in health care cuts and scaled back plans for new education aid and property tax relief.

headline: Debate Is a Ratings Hit for CNN
text: Political aficionados will remember Monday’s Democratic presidential debate for the heated and personal exchanges between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama. Television executives will remember it as the most-watched presidential primary debate in cable news history.

headline: Regulators Fault Con Ed on Steam Pipe Blast
text: Consolidated Edison faced a tough crowd this morning at a City Council hearing over the causes of the deadly steam pipe explosion in Midtown last July. On Dec. 28, the utility released an investigation that attributed the rupture to a combination of heavy rainfall, leaks in underground water and sewer pipes and debris that clogged two critical devices intended to let water out of the steam main.

headline: Bobby G Opening Credits
text: Bobby G is a series on the Mojo HD Network that follows a publicity-loving entrepreneur and venture capitalist.

headline: Gone Missing: Heath Ledger
text: Heath Ledger, a nice guy to deal with and a talented actor — he was nominated in 2005 for best actor for his role as a conflicted cowboy in “Brokeback Mountain” — was found dead in a Manhattan apartment. He was 28.

headline: Bobby G Closing Credits
text: Bobby G is a series on the Mojo HD Network that follows a publicity-loving entrepreneur and venture capitalist.

headline: Too Nasty?
text: Since Monday night’s debate among Democrats, much of the talk in political circles has been around just how pointed the exchanges were between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama.

headline: The Top-Rated Primary Debate In Cable History
text: Political aficionados will remember Monday’s Democratic presidential debate for the heated and personal exchanges between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama. Television executives will remember it as the most-watched presidential primary debate in cable news history.

headline: Silver lining to the financial crisis
text: The econoblogs have been great reading — and some of the commenters offer some much needed comic relief.

headline: The Monster Is Back, and It’s Hopeful
text: I often entertain a fantasy in which I’m the editor of a newspaper that could be read by any organism on the planet, be it a bacterium or a hippopotamus. The newspaper is called The Hopeful Monster Daily News, and it has the slogan, “All the news that’s fit to select.”

headline: Dance Off!
text: GREENVILLE — Former President Bill Clinton said today that he would take Senator Barack Obama up on his challenge last night to prove himself as the first black president by entering a dance competition — against Mr. Obama.

headline: Shredded Cabbage
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes a crunchy midwinter salad with a frequently overlooked vegetable.

headline: Blogtalk: Political Life Down South
text: Florida bloggers take their turn in the spotlight as their state is flooded with G.O.P. candidate meet and greets, pancake breakfasts, chicken dinners and the like.

headline: Can the Touch Revive Apple’s iPod Sales?
text: Investors are all in a tizzy that Apple is only promising them a 30 percent growth, year over year, in its first-quarter revenue. But looking at the company’s fourth-quarter 2007 results, it’s clear that the company is doing very, very well.

headline: Writers to Spare Grammys From Picketing
text: Writers Guild of America members may not write for the Grammy Awards — but they will not picket the event either. Reuters reports:

headline: Not Exactly in the Footsteps of the WUSA
text: Gayle Bryan is the publishing director of Fair Game Magazine, a publication dedicated to covering and supporting women’s soccer. She writes a blog on Fair Game’s Web site and occasionally contributes to The Times’s soccer blog, as she did from China during the Women’s World Cup.

headline: Meet the New Boss
text: Cliff Fletcher is not much like the old boss of the Toronto Maple Leafs.

headline: More Random Travel Notes: Heathrow, Zurich and Swiss
text: Back at Heathrow:  I must have angered the travel gods. Right after I criticizedHeathrow, I found myself back there, waiting for another delayed flight.It was an incremental delay, meaning the departure time kept inching back. Ground staff blamed “communications between Heathrow and Zurich” and added, disparagingly, that “Everything’s delayed today anyway.”I am spoiled by Hong Kong International Airport, which has free wifi for those with laptops, and free computer terminals for those who don’t.At least the electricity at Heathrow’s i-Pod and laptop charging stations is free. But an hour on a T-Mobile connection, which was about as quick as the security queue, cost me 5 pounds, or nearly U.S. $10.

headline: Strike: Writers Pull Reality, Animation Off the Table
text: The Writers Guild of America has decided to withdraw its proposals relating to reality show and animation writers, removing a major impediment to a potential settlement between the guild and the alliance of major Hollywood studios.

headline: No Habla Español
text: SALINAS, Calif. – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton does not usually speak in Spanish as she makes overtures to Hispanic voters, and now we have evidence of why.

headline: Can Washington Really Help?
text: John Harwood, of The Times and CNBC, interviews the president of the Urban Institute and former director of the Congressional Budget Office.

headline: Solar City
text: Columnist Jim Dwyer's building is one of  the first private co-ops in the city to use arrays of solar panels.

headline: A Little ‘Eastern Promise’ among the Bardem Lovers
text: “I’m far away. I’m in Javier Bardem’s country,” Viggo Mortensen told the Baguettewhen he called to chat about his best acting Oscar nomination for “Eastern Promises.”Mr. Mortensen was in Madrid to finish editing books for his small press,percevalpress.com, and he told the Baguette that all the talk today was about Mr.Bardem’s nomination. “People are very happy about him here, and they’re sort ofhappy about me being nominated,” he said, as “a wayward adoptive son I supposebecause I’ve done a few movies here and I’ve done a few movies in Spanish.”

headline: The Carpetbagger at Sundance
text: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) says goodbye to the surrogate center of the movie world, but not before taking in a hockey game.

headline: Basketball: Perceptions of St. John’s
text: What do U.C.L.A., Indiana, Louisville and Arizona have in common? Each has fewer victories all-time than St. John’s.

headline: “Teen” Gets Big Allowance
text: According to those always mysterious sources-close-to-the-negotiations, “American Teen,” a kind of cinematic diary of four teens making their way though their senior year of high school in a small town in Indiana, has been sold to Paramount Vantage for a rumored $2.5 million, a very hefty price. Both Fox Searchlight and Sony Pictures Classics apparently expressed interest, but decided to pull out when the asking grew under bidding pressure. Virtually everyone who has seen the documentary has come away thinking it may be the rare documentary that can do significant business in theatrical release.

headline: There’s Pain in College Hockey, Too
text: College players have to wear full facemasks, but that doesn’t make them immune to injury. Last weekend, a pair of season-ending injuries marred a great slate of college hockey games.

headline: Will Falcons Wait for Spagnuolo?
text: The Atlanta Falcons are still interested in interviewing Steve Spagnuolo, the Giants’ defensive coordinator, for their vacant head-coaching position, but it is unclear whether they are willing to wait two weeks to talk to him.

headline: Bloomberg Aide’s Schedule Is Revealed, Up to a Point
text: As Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg continues to dance around a presidential run, news media interest in the maneuverings of his chief political deputy, Kevin Sheekey, has intensified. Yet city officials have been slow to peel back the curtain on just how he spends his time.

headline: Worries That the Good Times Were Mostly a Mirage
text: So, how bad could this get?

headline: Strong Rail Prices Help CSX Beat Expectations
text: CHICAGO (Reuters)  The CSX Corporation reported a better-than-expected quarterly net profit Tuesday as strong pricing for rail freight offset higher fuel costs and weaker volumes, sending its shares up more than 5 percent.

headline: Italy’s Premier Seeks to Bolster Support
text: ROME  Prime Minister Romano Prodi defiantly called Tuesday for a vote of confidence in both houses of Parliament, a move he hopes will keep his wounded coalition government alive. His longtime nemesis, the former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, kept up pressure for new elections he hopes will make him Italy’s leader again.

headline: Recipe: Long Island Heirloom Squash
text: 1 Long Island, Cinderella, butternut or other flavorful winter squash, about 3 pounds

headline: Letters
text: Thinking About Meat

headline: ‘No Country’ and ‘Blood’ Lead Oscar Nominations
text: LOS ANGELES  Roll out the black carpet. A lineup of films bleak in tone and worldview will take center stage at the 80th annual Academy Awards next month, with critical darlings like “There Will Be Blood,” “No Country for Old Men” and “Michael Clayton” dominating the nominations, including the best picture category.

headline: Bank of America Joins Parade of Mortgage-Related Losses
text: The upheaval in the mortgage market, a slowing economy and an increasingly stretched consumer have made the last few quarters among the toughest since Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, took over in 2001.

headline: Candidates Turn Attention to Gyrating Markets and Weakened Economy
text: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.  The weakened economy and the turmoil in financial markets have helped to cement a gradual shift in emphasis in the presidential campaign to domestic issues from national security, giving the candidates an opportunity on Tuesday to spotlight economic proposals and try to convince voters that they could handle a crisis.

headline: Vietnam Agrees to the Return of Deportees From the U.S.
text: American immigration authorities reached an agreement on Tuesday with Vietnam that clears the way for Vietnamese immigrants under deportation orders to be sent back to their country.

headline: Versus Extends Contract With N.H.L.
text: Buoyed by higher ratings this season, Versus has agreed to carry N.H.L. games through the 2010-11 season. The cable network, which is paying $72.5 million for the league’s rights this season, will pay inflationary increases over the next three years.

headline: Mets Sign Chávez
text: The Mets avoided arbitration with their best defensive outfielder Tuesday by signing Endy Chávez to a two-year, $3.85 million contract. Chavez, 29, will make $1.8 million this season and $2.05 million in 2009. Chávez, who was limited to 71 games last season because of a left hamstring strain that knocked him out for nearly three months, batted .287 and scored 20 runs while playing his customary strong defense.

headline: Retreat of the Foreign Investor Is Singularly Painful for Japan
text: TOKYO  From buoyant optimism just two years ago, the mood among foreign investors in Japan has swung to grim pessimism.

headline: Ruses and Daring Escapes by a Jew in Nazi Germany
text: In June 1942 a 20-year-old Jew named Cioma Schönhaus stood in front of a Nazi bureaucrat in Berlin for final processing before being deported to a concentration camp in Poland. Asked if he had any money, he replied, “Yes, my lucky penny.” The penny went into the coffers of the Third Reich, duly noted in an account book.

headline: Dragila and Stuczynski at Millrose
text: Stacy Dragila, who dominated American women’s pole-vaulting for more than a decade, and Jenn Stuczynski, her successor, were matched Tuesday for the 101st Millrose Games on Feb. 1 in Madison Square Garden.Dragila, 36, is competing again after chronic Achilles’ tendon problems. In a two-week period last summer, Stuczynski broke Dragila’s American record of 15 feet 10 inches, then became the second woman in track and field history to clear 16 feet.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the sentencing of a Border Patrol agent who helped smuggle more than 100 people into the United States misstated the reason that more than a dozen fellow agents were on hand. Some were there to condemn his actions; not all were there to support him.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 3 about an announcement by the Suffolk County, N.Y., district attorney that he would not retry Martin Tankleff in the murders of his parents after his conviction was overturned misstated the date of their deaths. It was Sept. 7, 1988, not Sept. 17. (The error was repeated in articles on Jan. 4 about Mr. Tankleff’s plans for the future and on Saturday about the possibility that he would be investigated again by a special state prosecutor handling the case.)

headline: Ambac Looks at ‘Alternatives’ After $3.26 Billion Loss
text: The Ambac Financial Group, one of the largest companies that insures against bond losses, said Tuesday that it was exploring “strategic alternatives” as it announced a $3.26 billion loss for its fourth quarter.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening this Week

headline: PATH Train From Hoboken to 33rd Street and Journal Square to 33rd Street
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Make the Tax Cuts Work
text: Washington

headline: Times Company in Group Investing in Blog Publisher
text: Automattic, the commercial arm of the popular WordPress publishing platform for blogs, has received $29.5 million in financing from four companies, including a small portion from The New York Times Company.

headline: Mattingly Cuts Coaching Role to Spend More Time at Home
text: Don Mattingly, who followed Joe Torre west to work for the Los Angeles Dodgers this season, has told the Dodgers that he cannot be their batting coach after all. Mattingly has decided to spend more time with his wife and his youngest son at home in Evansville, Ind. He will remain with the team as a special assignment coach.

headline: When Fire Takes All but the Memories
text: Alener Baskins was on a lunch break from jury duty last fall when she got the bad news.

headline: Pakistan: U.S. Commander and Army Chief Hold Talks
text: Adm. William J. Fallon, the senior American military commander in the Middle East, arrived for a one-day visit and called on President Pervez Musharraf’s successor as army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, left. Mr. Musharraf is on a tour of European capitals. Little detail of the meeting with Admiral Fallon, held at military headquarters in Rawalpindi, was made available. The commanders discussed “the overall security situation in the region,” a spokesman for the Pakistan Army said. Admiral Fallon was recently quoted as saying that the United States military would play a greater role in training Pakistani forces and would provide technical advice to its troops.

headline: Agreement on Proposal for New Iran Sanctions
text: BERLIN  The foreign ministers of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council agreed Tuesday to a new set of sanctions against Iran to present to the Council as a draft resolution, but they did not announce details of the sanctions, which are intended to induce Tehran to give up its nuclear program.

headline: Booth in One Ear, Benches in Other
text: Pierre McGuire stood on a wobbly, foot-high black box and stretched his neck to watch the Rangers play the Bruins on Sunday at Madison Square Garden. His perch, nearer to Boston’s bench, enabled him to watch the game as an NBC analyst and eavesdrop on what the coaches were telling the players. At stoppages, he strode to a nearby monitor to comment on replays. Between periods, he dashed to a makeshift studio, where he was the host for intermission reports with Mike Milbury.

headline: On Martha’s Vineyard, Using Scallops as Currency
text: Chilmark, Mass.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Theater Hall of Fame has announced its new inductees: the actor and playwright Harvey Fierstein, the actors John Cullum, Lois Smith and Dana Ivey, the director Jack O’Brien, the playwright Peter Shaffer, the librettist Joseph Stein and, posthumously, Mel Gussow, a critic for The New York Times. Tommy Tune will be the M.C. and the directors Hal Prince and Mike Nichols will be among the presenters at the induction on Monday at the Gershwin Theater in Manhattan.

headline: How to Stop the Downturn
text: AMERICA’S economy is headed for a major slowdown. Whether there is a recession (two quarters of negative growth) is less important than the fact that the economy will operate well below its potential, and unemployment will grow. The country needs a stimulus, but anything we do will add to our soaring deficit, so it is important to get as much bang for the buck as possible. The optimal package would contain one fast-acting measure along with others that could lead to increased spending if and only if the economy goes into a steep downturn.

headline: Bush Pushes Justice Dept. Nominee
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Wednesday renominated Steven G. Bradbury to be an assistant attorney general in a move certain to be controversial because of Mr. Bradbury’s link to Justice Department memorandums authorizing the harsh interrogation of terrorism suspects.

headline: Without Proof, an Ivory-Billed Boom Goes Bust
text: BRINKLEY, Ark.  David Baxter, 62, has hunted the Big Woods in eastern Arkansas for most of his life. But these days, his weapon of choice is an old 35-millimeter camera with a zoom lens, which he keeps in his blue pickup truck at all times just in case he comes across an ivory-billed woodpecker.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Friday about fallout from the 2006 arrest of a man who approached Vice President Dick Cheney and denounced the war in Iraq misidentified a former employer of the Secret Service agent who made the arrest, Virgil D. Reichle Jr. He worked for the Colorado State Patrol; there is no Colorado State Police.

headline: Rating the Politicians, Past and Present
text: To the Editor:

headline: Chief of eBay Is Expected to Retire
text: SAN FRANCISCO  An era at eBay is about to end.

headline: (Solar) Power to the People Is Not So Easily Achieved
text: One day nearly four years ago, it suddenly seemed like a good idea to give solar electricity a try at home  home, for me, being an apartment house in Washington Heights, alias upstate Manhattan. The price of electricity was climbing. A war was being fought, if not over oil, then certainly over the ground the oil was in. Solar technology had proven that it could generate real power.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the marketing strategies of automakers misidentified the model of a Toyota sedan/station wagon aimed at baby boomers. It is the Venza  not the Versa, which is a small hatchback made by Nissan.

headline: Rise of Chávez Sends Venezuelans to Florida
text: WESTON, Fla.  In December 2002, Ariel Dunaevschi, then the owner of a furniture business in Caracas, Venezuela, was on vacation in New York with his family when opponents of President Hugo Chávez called a crippling labor strike hoping to bring the government to its knees.

headline: Going Far While Staying Close to Home
text: Life is good for Jessica McEntee. She has an apartment in the West Village, a 3.0 grade-point average at New York University and all-American recognition on the nation’s No. 3-ranked Division III women’s basketball team.

headline: Polishing the Brand in a Cathedral for Cars
text: MUNICH  I admit I had not been thrilled about flying here to see the BMW Welt, this car company’s fancy new delivery center. The enthusiasm many of us once felt for the notion of an increasingly interconnected world has dimmed, a casualty of the canceled flights and lost luggage that is the reality of travel today. And I feared that the building itself  a luxury showroom that could double as a theme park for car fetishists  would be a monument to excess.

headline: Asian Markets Ease Higher After Rate Cut
text: NEW DELHI  The United States Federal Reserve’s surprise rate cut stemmed bloodletting on the Asian stock markets on Wednesday, but heightened fears that a painful recession is imminent for the world’s largest economy.

headline: What You Get for... $2 Million
text: Washington D.C.

headline: Enticing Tough Cabbage to Show a Little Tenderness
text: THE days when late-fall vegetables had to last through the winter are long gone, but eating summer vegetables in midwinter doesn’t make much sense, as most people recognize now. Traditional winter vegetables have a certain freshness that just can’t be found in January asparagus or tomatoes. Enter cabbage salad, a crisp and flavorful alternative to tasteless winter lettuce.

headline: Defense in Beating Death Points to Child’s Gift
text: To bolster his case that a man accused of killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter is not guilty, the defense lawyer showed the jury on Tuesday a photo of a mug with the words “World’s Greatest Dad”  the girl’s gift to the defendant, he said.

headline: A Reminder From Mr. Doolittle
text: Representative John Doolittle, under criminal investigation for his past ties to Jack Abramoff, the imprisoned über-lobbyist, has decided not to seek re-election. The nation may not have noticed his adieu, but surely other members of Congress can draw a timely lesson as they approach an important vote on whether to create an independent Office of Congressional Ethics.

headline: EBay Names Successor to Whitman
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Meg Whitman, the chief executive of eBay for almost 10 years, is stepping down and will be replaced by John Donahoe, president of eBay’s marketplaces division, the company said Wednesday.

headline: At Last, a $20,000 Cup of Coffee
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Justices Broaden Immunity for Officers
text: WASHINGTON  Federal law enforcement officers are immune from lawsuits for mishandling, losing or even stealing personal property that comes under their control in the course of their official duties, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday in a 5-to-4 decision.

headline: Apple Earnings Up, but Stock Falls on Outlook
text: Apple beat Wall Street expectations with its earnings report Tuesday, but its shares fell more than 11 percent in after-hours trading as investors fretted over its prospects.

headline: Gov. Spitzer Threads the Needle
text: Across the country, governors are wrestling with many of the same problems as investors watching the Big Board on Wall Street. California’s governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, announced that “the wolf is back” as his state faces a $14 billion shortfall and 10 percent budget cuts. Jon Corzine, the governor of New Jersey, is hoping that toll increases will fill the potholes in his state’s bottom line.

headline: Turkmens End Holiday for Birthday of Ex-Leader
text: MOSCOW  Turkmenistan’s president has abolished a holiday honoring the birthday of his predecessor a year after his death, further undermining a personality cult that nevertheless clings to Turkmenistan, a hermetic Central Asian country.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about fierce competition in the South for black Democratic primary voters misstated the position of the Alabama Education Association, a teachers union. Although two of its leaders have endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the union has not endorsed a presidential candidate.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about a study linking caffeine and miscarriage misstated the name of the medical journal in which the study was published. It is The American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, not The Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

headline: Bike Lanes in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Fed Weighs In
text: Tuesday’s stock market gyrations were stomach churning. There is no doubt that without the Federal Reserve’s large emergency interest rate cuts, the market slide would have been worse. The main stock gauges in the United States all fell, but not as far or as fast as some of their global counterparts and not as much as feared.

headline: Clinton’s No. 1 Surrogate Clashes With No. 1 Rival
text: GREENVILLE, S.C.  With Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigning more than 2,500 miles away, her fight against Senator Barack Obama in South Carolina’s Democratic presidential primary emerged here Tuesday as a head-to-head match between him and her husband.

headline: Victorious Giants Return Home and It’s Time to Party On
text: Word had it the Giants were coming to the party. The promoter said to set your watch by it. The assistant promoter promised to make introductions. And the D.J. said that’s a fact.

headline: Recipe: Classic Fondue
text: 1 small garlic clove, halved

headline: Product Placement on Reality TV Seems Somehow More Realistic
text: AS the writers’ strike keeps the television networks scrambling to fill their schedules, the producers of reality shows are gladly stepping in to fill the vacuum.

headline: Village’s At-Large Voting Is Found to Be Biased
text: Citing a history of official discrimination against Hispanic voters, a federal judge ruled on Tuesday that the way municipal elections are conducted in the village of Port Chester, N.Y., violates federal election law.

headline: Asian Markets Ease Higher After Losses
text: SHANGHAI  The calm seemed to return to markets across Asian on Wednesday morning.

headline: More Aid for City Schools, but Less Than Promised
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer came into office pledging to solve one of the most vexing issues in Albany  the way the state doled out money to pay for public schools  and to give New York City a greater share of the aid.

headline: Junior League Appoints Black Woman as President
text: The New York Junior League announced on Tuesday the appointment of its first black president, characterizing the move as a groundbreaking one for an organization that has tried for years to cultivate a more socially and racially diverse image.

headline: What New Yorkers Think
text: To the Editor:

headline: Huckabee, Short on Cash, Curtails Effort in Florida
text: WASHINGTON  Before he won the Iowa Republican caucuses, Mike Huckabee told voters that sending him to victory would forever debunk the conventional wisdom that money could decide a presidential race.

headline: Recipe: Cabbage Salad
text: Time: 10 minutes, plus 1 to 2 hours for salting

headline: Borrowers With Good Credit May Benefit
text: The Federal Reserve’s decision on Tuesday to cut interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point should offer some comfort to consumers, with limits.

headline: City Tries Again to Require Restaurants to Post Calories
text: New Yorkers wondering just how many calories they are consuming in each grande-size white hot chocolate at Starbucks (490) or Double Whopper with cheese at Burger King (990) could soon see those numbers printed alongside the price, according to revised regulations approved on Tuesday by the city’s Board of Health.

headline: One Pot
text: IRON pot chicken is a childhood favorite of Michael Huynh, the executive chef and a partner at Bun and Mai House. He learned to cook it by watching his mother in Saigon (now Ho Chi Minh City), Vietnam, as she sautéed chicken with caramelized sugar and fish sauce. The dish, which takes only 12 minutes, is a bright, palate-awakening blend of salty, sweet and spicy. Best of all, it all comes together in a single pot.

headline: Chang Elected to International Tennis Hall of Fame
text: Michael Chang, who at age 17 became the youngest man to win a Grand Slam title, was elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

headline: Fast Start for Egypt
text: Egypt opened the defense of its African Cup of Nations title by defeating Cameroon, 4-2, Tuesday as Mohamed Zidan and Hosni Abd Rabou scored two goals each. In Tuesday’s other game, Zambia beat Sudan, 3-0.

headline: Qualifying Plan in Indy League
text: The Indy Racing League will use a four-lap qualifying procedure similar to the Indianapolis 500 at all its oval-track races this season. The pole winner and lineup at those events will be determined by the overall times for all four laps, rather than the fastest of two qualifying laps as in the past. The format for road and street courses will remain unchanged, with single-lap qualifying for all cars followed by a 10-minute group session with the six fastest qualifiers to determine the pole position.

headline: Clemens Saga Is Upstaging Santana Trade Talks
text: Correction: In this space two weeks ago, I wrote that the most popular baseball game of the winter was the Minnesota Twins’ attempt to trade Johan Santana, and the game, I said, seemed to be endless. The endless part was right, but I’m not so sure I was right about it being the most popular game of the winter.

headline: Urgently, Washington Responds to Fast-Spreading Market Turbulence
text: WASHINGTON  Even though Monday was a holiday, Ben S. Bernanke showed up early at his office at the Federal Reserve. The next day, he was planning a trip to New York.

headline: Sharapova Upsets Henin; Venus Williams Loses
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  A good night’s sleep failed to improve the Williams sisters’ fortunes at the Australian Open on Wednesday when Venus Williams followed her sister Serena out of this Grand Slam tournament at the quarterfinal stage.

headline: Winehouse Is Shown in Apparent Drug Use
text: In a grainy video that circulated online Tuesday Amy Winehouse, 24, left, appears to smoke crack and claims to have taken “about six Valium.” It was posted on the Web site for The Sun, a British tabloid (thesun.co.uk), and an accompanying article, inset, said the video was taken early Friday morning at Ms. Winehouse’s London home, and that the two-minute clip follows “a 19-minute binge in which she snorted powdered ecstasy and cocaine.” Her record label, Universal, said in a statement: “We are deeply disappointed and upset by these latest revelations and are doing everything we can to offer Amy our full support in dealing with her problems.” Contradictory reports circulated online on Tuesday about whether Ms. Winehouse had been taken to a rehab clinic. (She had a hit with “Rehab,” in which she sings about refusing treatment.) A spokeswoman for her label declined to comment on that issue.

headline: Padilla Gets 17 Years in Conspiracy Case
text: MIAMI  Jose Padilla, the Brooklyn-born convert to Islam whom the government once accused of plotting to detonate a “dirty bomb” in the United States, was sentenced on Tuesday to 17 years and 4 months in prison for his role in a conspiracy to help Islamic jihadist fighters abroad.

headline: Drugs-for-Information Scandal Shakes Up New York Police Narcotics Force
text: In the world of urban policing, few relationships are as fraught with peril as those between narcotics officers and confidential informants. These informants  C.I.’s in police parlance  are often small-time criminals who are paid or get criminal charges dropped in return for information about other, theoretically more dangerous criminals.

headline: A Writer and Speaker Specializing in Everything
text: “Doc,” a nonfiction feature about the life of the novelist, inventor and cult figure Harold Louis Humes, known as Doc, starts with an audio snippet in which Mr. Humes insists that the best classroom lectures are those in which the speaker seems to be engaged in a perpetual search for his subject.

headline: Southwestern Sun, Late in the Day
text: FOR one illustration of the chef Bobby Flay’s formidable celebrity, just check out the Food Network. He stars in, or appears on, three shows now in production, meaning you can’t watch for long without spotting his sunny face.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,918 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Monday:

headline: Citigroup’s Financial Hit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jury Blocked From Reindicting a Justice
text: HOUSTON  A Texas judge on Tuesday dismissed the grand jury whose indictment of a State Supreme Court justice and his wife here last week was thwarted by prosecutors.

headline: Dayton Coach Retires
text: Mike Kelly retired Tuesday after 27 years as coach at Dayton. Kelly compiled a 246-54-1 record for an .819 winning percentage, fourth-best among coaches with at least 25 years of experience. Rick Chamberlin, the defensive coordinator, will take over as head coach, Athletic Director Ted Kissell said. Kelly will remain at the university, expanding his duties as an associate athletic director.

headline: Missouri Governor Will Not Seek 2nd Term
text: CHICAGO  Matt Blunt, the governor of Missouri and a Republican, announced late Tuesday that he would not seek re-election this fall, a decision that stunned many in the state’s political circles and threw the anticipated alignment of Missouri’s election into disarray.

headline: Foreign Aid and Chicago Past Disputed in Latest Debate Back-and-Forth
text: WASHINGTON  In the Democratic debate on Monday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said that Senator Barack Obama had not explained how he would pay for his proposal to increase foreign aid by $25 billion a year.

headline: Writers Drop Demand and a Picket Plan
text: LOS ANGELES  In a major step toward ending a 12-week walkout, Hollywood’s striking writers on Tuesday dropped their demand for extended jurisdiction over reality and animation work and agreed to extend informal talks with Hollywood production companies, even as they decided not to picket next month’s Grammy Awards telecast.

headline: G.M. and Toyota in a Close Race in ’07 Sales
text: DETROIT  General Motors and Toyota ended 2007 effectively tied in their fight to be the world’s largest automaker.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $6,914,159

headline: Mystical to Muscular: Many Styles in Play at a Keyboard Marathon
text: Merkin Concert Hall, closed for refurbishing during the first part of the season, had its official opening two weeks ago and quickly got back to the business of presenting chamber and new-music concerts. But on Monday it changed pace with a Grand Piano Marathon: a free concert of piano music, including contemporary works, classical scores and jazz, that began at 2 p.m. and finished at nearly 9. For most of the day the hall was packed, with a line outside that was only partly alleviated by a late-afternoon decision to put seats on the stage. Not until the final hour did the audience begin to thin out.

headline: Man Imprisoned for 9 Years for Murder Is Released in Wake of DNA Evidence
text: FORT COLLINS, Colo.  A judge on Tuesday threw out the murder conviction and life sentence of a Fort Collins man who said for years that he was innocent of one of this city’s most sensational killings, the stabbing and mutilation of a woman whose body was found in February 1987 in a vacant field near the man’s home.

headline: Time-Travel Odyssey Through War and the Cosmos
text: Given the maiming and killing in Iraq and Afghanistan, the time seems nigh to revisit Kurt Vonnegut’s antiwar 1969 masterpiece, “Slaughterhouse-Five.” Few in the theater are better qualified to do so than the director Joe Tantalo and his Off Broadway troupe, Godlight Theater Company, which has made a specialty of exuberant, muscular adaptations of literate science fiction, including a provocative take on “Fahrenheit 451” in 2006.

headline: Surgery Makes Marbury More Irrelevant
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Stephon Marbury had surgery on his left ankle Tuesday, a routine procedure that was described as successful, but with the ultimate outcome yet unknown. Even New York’s finest doctors cannot project where Marbury’s serpentine career is headed.

headline: Google and Ad Conglomerate Teaming Up
text: PARIS  The chief executives of Publicis Groupe, the advertising conglomerate, and Google, the Internet giant, said Tuesday that they would jointly develop an approach to digital advertising that was both creative and technologically savvy, a combination they said is lacking.

headline: Mexico: Army Seizes Guns From Police
text: The federal authorities stepped up their campaign against armed drug gangs and police corruption, sending soldiers to shut down temporarily the local police departments in Nuevo Laredo, Río Bravo, Miguel Alemán, Valle Hermoso and Matamoros, all in Tamaulipas State, and seized the officers’ weapons to investigate whether any guns were linked to crimes.

headline: On Wall Street, a Day of Frayed Nerves
text: Dan MacMillan was fearing the worst on Tuesday morning. Like many Wall Street traders he expected share prices to plummet after two days of severe declines in overseas markets.

headline: Stocks Slide Steeply Again in Europe
text: PARIS  European stock markets fell steeply again on Wednesday after the head of the European Central Bank dampened investors’ hopes that the bank would follow the Federal Reserve in cutting interest rates.

headline: Studies Link Other Ills to Mercury, Too
text: In the past few years, several studies have concluded that elevated mercury levels may be associated not only with neurological problems but with cardiovascular disease among adults as well.

headline: Albert Bowker, 88, Dies; Ex-CUNY Head
text: Albert H. Bowker, the outspoken head of the City University of New York who stunned the campus and ruffled the city’s self-esteem in 1971 by departing to become chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, where he spent nine sometimes turbulent years, died on Sunday in Portola Valley, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Recipe: Beet Curry Soup
text: 2 tablespoons vegetable oil

headline: Mickelson Recovers
text: The Buick Invitational will have the top two players in the world after all. After three days of bed rest and antibiotics for respiratory problems, Phil Mickelson said Tuesday he was feeling better and will play in the pro-am Wednesday at the Buick Invitational, paving the way for him to make his 2008 debut at Torrey Pines. He also has a practice session planned with his swing coach, Butch Harmon.

headline: House Committee Subpoenas Knoblauch
text: The House oversight committee subpoenaed the former Yankee Chuck Knoblauch on Tuesday after he failed to respond to an invitation to give a deposition and testify before Congress about his suspected use of human growth hormone and his insights into Roger Clemens.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a new television advertisement in Spanish for the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney misstated the value of his company, Bain Capital, at the beginning of his tenure there. It was $36 million, not $6 billion. (Go to Article)

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column on Saturday about a new contract for Matt Holliday of the Colorado Rockies misstated the significance of his performance in 2007. He became the third player since 1967  not the first  to lead the National League outright in both batting average and runs batted in. (The others were Joe Torre in 1971 and Todd Helton in 2000.)

headline: The Late Deciders
text: They are elusive. They can upend campaigns. They are the great swath of voters who decide just days before or even moments before they actually vote.

headline: Asian Markets Endure 2 Brutal Days of Plunges
text: SHANGHAI  The stark sell-off that sent share prices plummeting around the world early this week brought renewed concern that the equity markets in China and India might be overvalued. But while Chinese investors and analysts worried this might be the case and fretted over the potential social consequences, in India the market chaos was often greeted as a buying opportunity.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports chart last Wednesday about the Pro Football Hall of Famers who were involved in the 1962 championship game between the Packers and the Giants misstated the titles of Vince Lombardi and Wellington Mara in some editions. Lombardi was Green Bay’s coach, not owner; Mara was the Giants’ owner, not coach.

headline: Gladiators and Deal Deliver One-Two Punch
text: NBC led every hour of prime time in Monday night’s ratings, buoyed by the successful combination of its new hit “American Gladiators” followed by the game show “Deal or No Deal.” Those shows earned the night’s top ratings among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen’s estimates, with “Deal or No Deal” also drawing the largest audience of the night, 14.1 million viewers at 9 p.m. “American Gladiators,” meanwhile, delivered a more modest 10.1 million viewers at 8. NBC’s “Medium,” which also drew 10.1 million viewers, led the 10 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 group. Fox finished second for the night in that demographic, thanks to its new show “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles,” which attracted 8.6 million viewers while tying CBS’s comedy repeats in the 9 p.m. hour among adults 18 to 49. CBS, which broadcast reruns all night long, ranked third in that age group, but second in total viewers behind NBC. ABC was a distant fourth. Its “Dance War” averaged 9.8 million viewers from 8 to 9:30, but its “October Road” continued to struggle during the 10 p.m. time slot with just 5 million viewers.

headline: Recipe: Pasta With Duck Confit
text: Time: 40 minutes

headline: In Orphans’ Twilight, Memories of a Doomed Utopia
text: TEL AVIV  They are in their 80s now, the last living links to Janusz Korczak, the visionary champion of children’s rights who refused to part with his young charges even as they were herded to the gas chambers.

headline: Recipe: Queso Fundido
text: 3 ounces chorizo, sliced 1/4 inch thick

headline: Terrence Elkes, 73, President of Viacom in ’80s, Dies
text: Terrence A. Elkes, a lawyer who rose to become president of Viacom in the 1980s and oversaw some major acquisitions, but left after Sumner M. Redstone bought control of the company, died on Friday in Washington. He was 73.

headline: European Bank Chief Is Cool to a Rate Cut
text: PARIS  A day after the Federal Reserve announced an emergency rate cut in the United States in the face of a stock market meltdown, the president of the European Central Bank on Wednesday dashed hopes of any short-term rate relief on the Continent.

headline: Gatlin Files Appeal
text: The Olympic sprint champion Justin Gatlin has appealed his four-year doping suspension in an attempt to return to the track for the Beijing Games in August. The notice was filed Monday to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, the international body that has the final say in such matters. A United States arbitration panel earlier this month reduced Gatlin’s potential eight-year ban to four, but Gatlin wants a further reduction.

headline: Why the European Bank Is Sitting Back
text: LONDON  Monetary policy usually takes some time to bite. That is one explanation for the American stock market’s continued gyrations on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve’s emergency rate cut. It may also explain why the European Central Bank has given no indication that it will follow suit.

headline: Entrepreneur Unveils New Tourist Spacecraft
text: Burt Rutan took the cloak off of his new spacecraft on Wednesday.

headline: Maybe Too Little, Always Too Late
text: The history of anti-recession efforts is that they are almost always initiated too late to do any good. This chart, based on recession timelines from the National Bureau of Economic Research, shows the enactment of stimulus plans is a fairly accurate indicator that we have hit the bottom of the business cycle, meaning the economy will improve even if the government does nothing.  Bruce Bartlett, author of “Impostor: How George W. Bush Bankrupted America and Betrayed the Reagan Legacy.”

headline: House Leaders and Bush Move Closer to Deal on Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON  Congressional leaders and the Bush administration appeared close to reaching a deal on a $145 billion economic stimulus package, with negotiations expected to continue through Wednesday night as the Treasury Department crunched the numbers on components of the plan, senior House officials said.

headline: Whole Foods Chain to Stop Use of Plastic Bags
text: The Whole Foods Market chain said Tuesday that it would stop offering plastic grocery bags, giving customers instead a choice between recycled paper or reusable bags.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Saturday about Georgia Frontiere, the longtime owner of the St. Louis Rams football team, misstated the timing of her comment to USA Today about encouragement she said she had received from her husband, Carroll Rosenbloom, who died in 1979. It was made before the 2000 Super Bowl, not before the 1980 Super Bowl. (USA Today was founded in 1982.)

headline: Two Against One
text: GREENVILLE, S.C.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Rice Rebukes Bush Envoy Who Criticized Policy on North Korea
text: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, in a rare public rebuke, has upbraided a White House envoy who criticized United States diplomacy toward North Korea that is aimed at coaxing the North Koreans to give up their nuclear weapons.

headline: Living in a Dutch Town House
text: UTRECHT, the Netherlands

headline: Pairings
text: The Napa cabernets were earthy and sometimes bold, with brambly fruit in the ones I liked. Call them rustic yet refined. That also describes the pasta, whole wheat or made with farro, I set out to sauce.

headline: Recipe: Scallops With Preserved Lemons on the Half Shell
text: 4 scallop shells or oven-safe plates

headline: Brown, in an Article, Needles the Knicks
text: Eighteen months after the Knicks fired him  and days before his current team will play them  Larry Brown has broken an apparently self-imposed silence to accuse the Knicks of espionage. The spying, Brown said, was directed at him.

headline: City Parks Officials Seek Safety Review of Synthetic Surfaces
text: For more than a decade, the city’s Parks Department has extolled the environmental and safety benefits of replacing the grass or asphalt at dozens of its play spaces with synthetic material made from recycled tires, despite safety concerns expressed by some scientists and children’s advocates.

headline: Veto of Children’s Health Plan Stands
text: WASHINGTON  Democrats cited the nation’s economic problems as a reason to expand a popular health insurance program for children on Wednesday, but their effort failed as the House sustained President Bush’s veto of a bill to provide coverage to nearly four million more uninsured children.

headline: Toehold in Napa: Some Starter Bottles
text: NO California wine region has the branded power of Napa Valley. Whatever you think of the wines, the name is the vinous equivalent of Mercedes or Louis Vuitton. What that means, practically speaking, is that when you buy a Napa Valley wine you are paying for a lot more than what’s in the bottle.

headline: Hedge Fund Founder Sentenced for Fraud
text: A founder of several Bayou Management hedge funds was sentenced to more than four years in prison Tuesday for a scheme to defraud investors.

headline: Diabetes Study Favors Surgery to Treat Obese
text: Weight-loss surgery works much better than standard medical therapy as a treatment for Type 2 diabetes in obese people, the first study to compare the two approaches has found.

headline: Sierra Leone: Leader in Child Mortality
text: A newborn in Sierra Leone has the lowest chance in the world of surviving until age 5, and the prospects are almost as bad for children in Angola and Afghanistan, Unicef said in its annual report. In 2006, nearly 9.7 million children worldwide died before their fifth birthdays, mostly from preventable causes like diarrhea, malaria or malnutrition, it said, and on average more than 26,000 children under 5 died each day. Sierra Leone had the highest child mortality rate, with 270 deaths per 1,000 births. Angola was second with 260 deaths, followed by Afghanistan with 257. The rate worldwide in 2006, in contrast, was 72 deaths per 1,000 births. The average rate in industrialized countries was six deaths per 1,000 births. Sub-Saharan Africa, where the rate has dropped only 14 percent since 1990, is the region of greatest concern, the report said. It is home to 28 of the 30 countries with the highest child mortality rates. But the report said considerable progress had been made in East Asia and the Pacific, Central and Eastern Europe, and Latin America and the Caribbean. Child mortality in those regions has been cut roughly in half since 1990, to below 30 deaths per 1,000 births.

headline: U.S. Given Poor Marks on the Environment
text: WASHINGTON  A new international ranking of environmental performance puts the United States at the bottom of the Group of 8 industrialized nations and 39th among the 149 countries on the list.

headline: Closing the Barn Door After the Cows Have Gotten Out
text: Last week, the Food and Drug Administration cleared the way for the eventual sale of meat and dairy products from cloned animals, saying, in effect, that consumers face no health risks from them. The next day, the Department of Agriculture asked farmers to keep their cloned animals off the market until consumers have time to get over their anticloning prejudice. That is one prejudice I plan to hold on to. I will not be eating cloned meat.

headline: Iraq Parliament Purges Hussein Vestiges on Flag
text: BAGHDAD  Iraqi lawmakers adopted a modified version of the national flag on Tuesday, removing three stars that symbolized the Baathist ideals of unity, freedom and socialism, and Saddam Hussein’s handwritten calligraphy of the Koranic incantation “Allahu akbar.”

headline: Russian Inquiries Threaten an Opposition Candidacy
text: MOSCOW  Russian prosecutors opened a criminal investigation on Tuesday into an opposition leader’s effort to register as a candidate in the March 2 presidential election, raising doubts about whether he would be able to run against the Kremlin’s favorite choice.

headline: Patriots Are Reluctant to Solve Limp Mystery
text: Officially, the New England Patriots say they know nothing about an injury to Tom Brady’s right foot. Unofficially, something seems wrong.

headline: Done Deals Finally Start to Appear at Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah  And on the fifth night, the wallets opened.

headline: Test of Brain Device Is Setback for Maker
text: Any impact that Tuesday’s plunging stock markets might have had on Northstar Neuroscience was lost in the bad news released before trading began  results from a crucial clinical trial showed that its brain-stimulating device failed to help stroke victims recover the use of their arms and hands.

headline: Heath Ledger, Actor, Is Found Dead at 28
text: Heath Ledger, the Australian-born actor whose breakthrough role as a gay cowboy in the 2005 movie “Brokeback Mountain” earned him a nomination for an Academy Award and comparisons to the likes of Marlon Brando, was found dead Tuesday in an apartment in Manhattan with sleeping pills near his body, the police said.

headline: California: Driver in Ferrari Crash to Be Deported
text: A Swedish businessman who crashed a $1.5 million Ferrari in Malibu in 2006 will be soon released from a detention center near Los Angeles and deported to Sweden, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said. The businessman, Bo Stefan Eriksson, left, pleaded no contest to a drunken-driving charge in connection with the crash on the Pacific Coast Highway, and also pleaded no contest to embezzlement and gun possession charges. He was sentenced to three years. The authorities say Mr. Eriksson and Trevor Michael Karney were traveling 162 miles per hour in a rare Ferrari Enzo, one of only 400 made, when it crashed into a pole.

headline: Heirs Seek Proceeds From Russian Art Show
text: Descendants of two prominent czarist-era art collectors demanded compensation as a major exhibition of Russian art was previewed on Tuesday at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, Bloomberg News reported. The descendants, André-Marc Delocque-Fourcaud, grandson of Sergei Shchukin, and Pierre Konowaloff, great-grandson of Ivan Morosov, did not seek the return of paintings. Instead, they asserted a moral right to a portion of the proceeds from the show, to open on Saturday. A spokeswoman for the Russian Federal Agency of Culture and Cinematography declined to comment. Fears of legal claims to some of the 120 works in the show, “From Russia: French and Russian Master Paintings 1870-1925 From Moscow and St. Petersburg” cast doubt over the exhibition for several weeks until Britain satisfied Russia that the paintings, including art by Gauguin, Kandinsky and van Gogh, would be returned after it ends on April 18.

headline: California Race Increases Drug Testing
text: The Tour of California, a 650-mile, eight-day race that is expected to attract some of cycling’s top international teams next month, announced Tuesday that it would increase testing of riders before and after each day’s event, and contribute its results to an antidoping database sponsored by the sport’s governing body.

headline: Viewership of Debate Sets Record
text: Political aficionados will remember the Democratic presidential debate on Monday night for the heated and personal exchanges among Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Barack Obama and John Edwards. Television executives will remember it as the most-watched presidential primary debate in cable news history.

headline: Panel Questions Canadian Role in Afghanistan
text: OTTAWA  A government panel said Tuesday that the Canadian military should withdraw from a combat role in Afghanistan next year unless it is reinforced with 1,000 additional troops from other NATO countries.

headline: Thai Soap Opera Receives a Cleanup
text: Longer skirts and shorter catfights were promised on Tuesday by the producers of a steamy Thai soap opera about airline crews that drew a protest from the Thai Airways International union, The Associated Press reported. At a news conference, executives from the Exact Company, which produces the show, said they were sorry if they had offended anyone and would tone down some of the raciness.

headline: A Little Nostalgia, a Long Fork and Lots of Cheese
text: ONE chilly afternoon, my mother dropped by with a small shopping bag filled with fondue forks.

headline: New York Is All McCain’s, for a Night
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Senator John McCain of Arizona scooped up $1 million for his presidential campaign on Tuesday night in the center of Rudolph W. Giuliani’s political turf, the St. Regis Hotel in Midtown Manhattan, and announced the support of former Senator Alfonse M. D’Amato and a swath of the New York Republican establishment.

headline: Child Soldiers Book Faces a Challenge
text: A best-selling author who is the world’s leading spokesman for child soldiers strongly defended himself against an Australian newspaper’s accusation that he had distorted the account of his service in Sierra Leone’s civil war during the 1990s. In a statement released on Tuesday, the author, Ishmael Beah, above, said: “I am right about my story. This is not something one gets wrong.” His publisher, Sarah Crichton Books, a Farrar, Straus & Giroux imprint, also defended the accuracy of his book, “A Long Way Gone: Memoirs of a Boy Soldier.” The Weekend Australian reported that his ordeal had lasted one year, not the three that he had stated. Mr. Beah, now 27, said the newspaper may not have understood that rebels first attacked his village in 1993, two years before they closed a village mine.

headline: Israel Resumes Fuel Shipments to Gaza
text: GAZA  After widespread criticism of its decision to cut off supplies of industrial diesel oil required to run a power station that serves Gaza City and its hospitals, Israel resumed fuel shipments on Tuesday on what it said would be a temporary basis.

headline: Wal-Mart Says More Than Half Its Workers Have Its Health Insurance
text: Wal-Mart, the nation’s largest private employer, said on Tuesday that for the first time in its 46-year history more than half its United States workers had enrolled in the company’s health insurance plan, a milestone for a retailer long criticized as offering unaffordable benefits.

headline: Missouri: Group Membership Prompts a Resignation
text: A member of the Kansas City Parks Board resigned after her membership in an anti-illegal-immigration group led two organizations, the National Council of La Raza and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, to hold their annual conventions elsewhere. The board appointee, Frances Semler, 74, a member of the Minuteman Civil Defense Corps, said she resigned because her involvement with the group had become too contentious and because she did not feel that Mayor Mark Funkhouser supported her. Ms. Semler defended her involvement with the group, which advocates vigilante patrolling of the Mexican border and reports illegal immigrants. “I’m a decent, nice person that happens to belong to the Minutemen and thinks our borders should be protected and our laws upheld,” she said.

headline: Bridging Civilizations to Make Sense of Slaughter
text: The women stand in sparkling evening dresses, barefoot, behind a chain-link fence. Their faces are brutalized.

headline: New Cost for Some Smokers and Drinkers
text: On a sunny day in its parks and on its street corners, Hell’s Kitchen in Manhattan can be a parade of connoisseurs of low-end cigars and cheap malt liquor.

headline: The Slow Hands of a Clock
text: To the Editor:

headline: Will Pigs’ Feet Fly?
text: IN this age of rapidly rising restaurant prices, it’s heartening to find a new place that serves a nine-course tasting menu for $40. The portions aren’t Lilliputian, the folks who work there are friendly and attentive and nothing on the à la carte menu costs more than $12.

headline: A Neighbor Joins the Revival of Jamaica Avenue
text: The Dermot Company, a real estate developer in Manhattan, often invests in historic buildings and emerging neighborhoods. Three years ago, it took on both challenges when its development proposal to remake the old Queens Family Court building in downtown Jamaica was accepted by the New York City Economic Development Corporation.

headline: A Restaurateur Bets on the Ribs and a Lucky 13
text: THE mantra of real estate investing has always been that success is dependent on three variables: location, location, location. Steven Levy, a 62-year-old former stockbroker, hopes it’s less vital to the restaurant business.

headline: More Than Rock ’n’ Roll: U2 on Tour in 3-D Images
text: The musical documentary “U2 3D,” which stitches together three performances by this Irish rock band during a recent tour of South America, is not merely a technical landmark  shot entirely in digital 3D  but also an aesthetic one, in that it’s the first Imax movie that deserves to be called a work of art.

headline: Pete Candoli, Trumpeter and Studio Musician, Dies at 84
text: Pete Candoli, a jazz trumpeter who made his mark as a high-note specialist in the big-band era and went on to become one of the busiest studio musicians in Hollywood, died on Jan. 11 at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 84.

headline: France: ‘Not Yet Married’ to Sarkozy
text: The Italian fashion-model-turned-singer Carla Bruni said in an interview that she and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France are not married, quashing rumors that there had been a secret wedding ceremony in the Élysée Palace. The newspaper Libération quoted Ms. Bruni as saying that she was “not yet married.” But she strongly suggested it would happen, adding, “even if this is in our plans.” She also said she would not accompany Mr. Sarkozy on his official visit later this week to India. “I cannot take part in an official visit with the president,” she said, without mentioning the protocol issues the relationship could have posed. She said that she was planning to begin recording her next album next month.

headline: High Mercury Levels Are Found in Tuna Sushi
text: Recent laboratory tests found so much mercury in tuna sushi from 20 Manhattan stores and restaurants that at most of them, a regular diet of six pieces a week would exceed the levels considered acceptable by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Recipe: Iron Pot Chicken
text: 3 tablespoons fish sauce

headline: Night Shift Has Long Ties to Corruption
text: Since the days of Teddy Roosevelt, the New York City Police Department has faced problems with lax supervision in the early morning hours, when officers prone to corruption or laziness face few challenges, and even fewer commanders.

headline: Cuba: Will Castro Return?
text: Ricardo Alarcón, the National Assembly president, said in an interview that he expected Fidel Castro to be nominated for president on Feb. 24 when the new Parliament meets, but expressed uncertainty over whether he would accept the post again. “It’s obvious that he has been very successful in the recovery process, but he has the right to say yes or no,” Mr. Alarcón said.

headline: Seeking Room to Rock Where Cost of Space Just Keeps Rising
text: It is something many musicians hate to do but have to do, and now they hate it even more. Rehearsing can be tedious and time-consuming, and in New York City, musicians say it is more expensive than ever.

headline: Anxiety Crashes the Party at Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland  There was George Soros hunched over a dinner table, deep in conversation with a nodding companion. Howard Stringer of Sony ran into Mickey Schulhof, who once ran Sony’s American arm. And Klaus Schwab, the impresario of the World Economic Forum, welcomed an A-list crowd to a twinkling ballroom at the Hotel Belvedere.

headline: ABC Drama Takes on Science and Parents
text: LOS ANGELES  A new legal drama making its debut this month on ABC is stepping into a subject that is the source of heated debate among some parents  the relationship between autism and childhood vaccines  and seemingly coming down on the side that has been all but dismissed by prominent scientific organizations.

headline: Congo’s Death Rate Unchanged Since War Ended
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Five years after Congo’s catastrophic war officially ended, the rate at which people are dying in the country remains virtually unchanged, according to a new survey, despite the efforts of the world’s largest peacekeeping force, billions of dollars in international aid and a historic election that revived democracy after decades of violence and despotism.

headline: Judge Delays Curlin Auction
text: A judge refused to force an auction of an ownership stake in Curlin, the Horse of the Year, saying the request has been made too soon. Special Judge Roger Crittenden left the door open for 418 people to pursue a 20 percent ownership stake. The judge made his decision during a hearing on Tuesday after concluding that the plaintiffs did not have enough information about the assets of the lawyers William Gallion and Shirley Cunningham Jr. The two men are accused of bilking former clients out of at least $42 million in a $200 million settlement involving the diet drug Fen-phen.

headline: Stocks Surge, Erasing Big Losses, at End of Volatile Day
text: This week, investors were bracing for Black Tuesday. Instead, they got Whiplash Wednesday.

headline: An Adult Soul Amid Cookies, Hugs, Puppets and Song
text: Fittingly, “North” opens with snow, but the static kind: television sets full of blurry patterns dot the small stage of the Club at La MaMa E.T.C. When the storm clears, a lone figure is revealed onscreen, exploring a wintry shoreline.

headline: Legislation on Economy Will Start in House
text: WASHINGTON  Congressional leaders agreed Tuesday that the House would take the lead on legislation intended to stabilize the economy, giving the speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and Representative John A. Boehner, the Republican leader, primary responsibility for reaching an agreement with the White House.

headline: Pittsburgh Perseveres Without Injured Starters
text: The anecdotes are almost too many to tell. Pittsburgh, a program already known for hard-nosed basketball, has overcome so much physical pain and so many obstacles that its season already sounds like folklore.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article in Science Times on Tuesday about politics in some species of animals was published out of order. The top of the second column of type, above the illustration, is continued at the top of the third column, followed by the bottom of the third column, the bottom of the second column and the top of the fourth column.

headline: Calendar
text: Singing, Eating

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Tuesday about a new television advertisement in Spanish for the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney misstated the value of his company, Bain Capital, at the beginning of his tenure there. It was $36 million, not $6 billion.

headline: Web Site Assembles U.S. Prewar Claims
text: WASHINGTON  Students of how the Bush administration led the nation into the Iraq war can now go online to browse a comprehensive database of top officials’ statements before the invasion, connecting the dots between hundreds of claims, mostly discredited since then, linking Saddam Hussein to Al Qaeda or warning that he possessed forbidden weapons.

headline: Russia’s Gazprom Takes Control of Serbian Oil Monopoly
text: BERLIN  Serbia announced Tuesday that Russia has bought Serbia’s oil monopoly, the latest in Russia’s recent string of energy acquisitions. The deal will also allow Moscow to send more natural gas to Europe through its South Stream pipeline.

headline: Rangers Mix Up Lines, Then Put It All Together
text: For the first 17 minutes of Tuesday night’s game at Madison Square Garden, the Atlanta Thrashers hardly seemed to know what hit them. The Rangers were fiercely charging up ice on every possession. They battled for nearly every puck. This did not seem to be the team that had been drawing raised eyebrows around the N.H.L. for its lackluster record and turnover-filled games.

headline: Wachovia’s Big-City Splash Has a Sobering Aftermath
text: In yet another concrete sign of trouble in the commercial real estate market, Wachovia, the nation’s fourth-largest bank, announced on Tuesday that it would be taking write-downs of more than $1 billion for commercial loans for the second half of last year. That sum includes $488 million in previously disclosed write-downs for the third quarter.

headline: Giants Guarantee No Guarantees
text: Up close, Amani Toomer could see and hear the winning coach hyperventilating with joy. That is his most vivid memory of his only Super Bowl, or, as of now, his first Super Bowl.

headline: City Parents Boycotting Added Tests at 2 Schools
text: New York City public school students have taken English tests for years. Math tests, too. This year, 10 “diagnostic” tests have been added to the menu in the hope that they will improve results on the real thing.

headline: China Offers Plan to Clean Up Its Polluted Lakes
text: HONG KONG  The Chinese government unveiled a detailed plan on Tuesday to limit pollution in China’s lakes by 2010 and return them to their original state by 2030.

headline: Lincoln Center Offers a Season of Russians, Romeos, Kafka and Woolf
text: Valery Gergiev is returning to Avery Fisher Hall next season with another Russian survey course.

headline: ‘No Country’ and ‘There Will Be Blood’ Lead Oscars
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Hollywood is in a bleak mood this year, and the Oscar nominees announced Tuesday morning reflected that state of mind.

headline: Star Light, Star Bright, Remake My Home Tonight
text: If you have never seen a certain kind of reality show or read a tabloid or heard about an actress demanding that her trailer be spritzed with Arpege 10 times a day, then “Hollywood Residential” will have something to say to you. It will feel like CNN.

headline: Recipe: Sweet Gorgonzola Fondue
text: 1 garlic clove, halved

headline: A World Right Around the Corner From Hell
text: It’s no disgrace that “Almost an Evening,” the new bill of bite-size plays by Ethan Coen, lives up to the modesty of its title.

headline: In a Reversal, AK Steel Reports Profit
text: CINCINNATI (AP)  AK Steel Holding said Tuesday that it swung to a fourth-quarter profit in contrast to a loss a year ago, when it took a one-time charge for employee health care benefits during a long lockout at its biggest mill.

headline: Thompson Ends Campaign for G.O.P. Nomination
text: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.  Fred D. Thompson, the former senator from Tennessee, dropped out of the Republican race for president on Tuesday after a third-place primary showing on Saturday in South Carolina, a state he had hoped to win when he entered the race riding a wave of optimism among conservatives looking for a strong general election candidate.

headline: Recipe: Italian Fonduta
text: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter

headline: To Cut Costs, NBC Universal Ends Pilots
text: Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, said Tuesday the broadcaster was moving to save as much as $50 million a year by reducing its reliance on expensive pilots of new series on the NBC television channel.

headline: Commercial Fishing
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spitzer Plans Cuts and Fees to Close Deficit of $4.4 Billion
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer on Tuesday proposed an array of taxes and fees and almost $1 billion in health care cuts, and scaled back plans for new education aid and property tax relief, in an effort to close a budget deficit estimated at $4.4 billion.

headline: A Last Goodbye for a Man Whose Body Was Rolled Down a Sidewalk
text: It seemed fitting that the last goodbye for Virgilio Cintron took place at Sacred Heart of Jesus Roman Catholic Church. It was the place where a far different future for Mr. Cintron was undoubtedly envisioned.

headline: Senior Bowl Opens N.F.L. Scouting Season
text: MOBILE, Ala.  Romeo Crennel spoke softly into a digital recorder as he watched some of the top prospects for the coming N.F.L. draft go through drills and workouts Tuesday morning.

headline: Dartmouth Joins Push to Reduce Costs for Middle Class
text: HANOVER, N.H. (AP)  Dartmouth College announced on Tuesday that beginning in the fall undergraduates from families with incomes less than $75,000 would receive free tuition.

headline: Origins of ‘The Great Moderation’
text: James Stock, a Harvard economist, coined the phrase “the great moderation” while writing a research paper with Mark Watson of Princeton earlier in this decade. You can read the paper  “Has the Business Cycle Changed and Why”  here.

headline: Democrats Try to Delay Eavesdropping Vote
text: WASHINGTONSenate Democrats concede that they probably lack the votes needed to stop a White House-backed plan to give immunity to phone utilities that helped the National Security Agency’s eavesdropping, and they are seeking to put off the vote for another month.

headline: Fed’s Action Stems Sell-Off in World Markets
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, confronted by deepening panic in global financial markets about a possible recession in the United States, struck back on Tuesday morning with the biggest one-day reduction of interest rates on record and at least temporarily stopped a vertigo-inducing plunge in stock prices.

headline: Throngs Gather in City as News Spreads at the Speed of Technology
text: Hundreds of fans, curiosity seekers and news crews gathered in front of Heath Ledger’s home in SoHo on Tuesday night, spilling into the street as the police struggled to keep one lane open for traffic and roped off a sidewalk path to the door.

headline: Tuesday on the Trail
text: The remaining Republican candidates campaigned in Florida, and the Democrats were back on the trail after a debate.

headline: Video: Winding Down at Sundance
Gretzky and Brady and Arizona
text: Six degrees of Tom Brady and Wayne Gretzky. Gretzky won four Stanley Cups. Brady is expected to win his fourth Super Bowl ring. Brady broke a record this season by throwing 50 touchdown passes. In 1981, Gretzky broke a record by scoring 50 goals in 39 games.

headline: Dr. Z and Dr. David Banner
text: Tom Brady ditched his walking boot, and his injury doesn’t appear to be serious. (If you click the link, you’ll probably find Gisele Bundchen’s boots more compelling.)

headline: Inside the Giants: Tiki Talks
text: A lot of fans have wondered just how Tiki Barber feels, watching his old team get to the Super Bowl the season after he retired. Thanks to the Sirius N.F.L. radio show that he co-hosts with his brother, Buccaneers cornerback Ronde Barber, now we know. Some excerpts, courtesy of Sirius, from Tuesday night’s, “The Barber Shop.”

text: The pilot's bag goes civilian.

headline: Field Bunches Up at Corus
The (Unlisted) Hot Tickets at Davos
text: Davos may seem like it is all about the big theatrically produced panels and presentations, like Bill Gates’ planned speech this year schedule titled “A New Approach to Capitalism in the 21st Century.” But the hottest tickets — and the hardest to come by — aren’t on the schedule at all.

headline: Lessons in Democracy and Modesty
text: The world must be changing when on a World Economic Forum panel on geopolitics you have three Asians, two Europeans and just one American (even though that American was called Power — the Harvard professor Samantha Power).

headline: ‘Sure, I’ll Take Fries With That’
