headline: Davos in the Papers: Crisis Management, Google’s New Friend
text: The day before the official kick-off of the World Economic Forum in Davos Switzerland, it seemed like just another meeting of the world’s most exclusive talk shop, held each January in this Alpine ski resort.

headline: Wachovia’s Big-City Splash Has a Sobering Aftermath
text: In yet another concrete sign of trouble in the commercial real estate market, Wachovia, the nation’s fourth-largest bank, announced on Tuesday that it would be taking write-downs of more than $1 billion for commercial loans for the second half of last year. That sum includes $488 million in previously disclosed write-downs for the third quarter.

headline: Hedge Fund Founder Sentenced for Fraud
text: A founder of several Bayou Management hedge funds was sentenced to more than four years in prison Tuesday for a scheme to defraud investors.

headline: Bird Flu — Still a Simmering Biological Bomb
text: For many years, Donald G. McNeil has been covering the grim toll wrought by infectious diseases in developing countries, and the global threat some pathogens pose in our increasingly interconnected world. In Science Times this week, he provides a valuable update on the H5N1 virus behind recent outbreaks of avian flu. While out of the headlines, it remains a simmering threat that, experts say, needs far more attention than it is getting. He took some time to explore the issue with me for Dot Earth readers. Please feel free to post any additional questions you may have, or comments, and I’ll forward them to him.Q. That was a fine summary today of the bird flu situation, which seems to be on simmer, not boil, but hardly a non-threat at this point. This is a risk I want to explore on Dot Earth because it’s one of the potential “hard knocks” we face in a world of growing populations and mobility.

headline: Ambac Looks at ‘Alternatives’ After $3.26 Billion Loss
text: The Ambac Financial Group, one of the largest companies that insures against bond losses, said Tuesday that it was exploring “strategic alternatives” as it announced a $3.26 billion loss for its fourth quarter.

headline: Chief of eBay Is Expected to Retire
text: An era at eBay is about to end.

headline: Buffett’s Berkshire Takes 3% Stake in Swiss Re
text: Swiss Reinsurance, the biggest reinsurer in the world, said the billionaire investor Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway took a 3 percent stake and will assume a share of its non-life business, giving Swiss Re’s shares their biggest spike in four years.

headline: Will eBay Ring Up Sales of Its Own?
text: With eBay‘s chief executive, Meg Whitman, reportedly on the verge of retiring, attention will no doubt now turn to how her heir apparent, John Donahoe, will move to recharge the online auctioneer’s business — and its lackluster stock price.

headline: Russia’s Gazprom Takes Control of Serbian Oil Monopoly
text: Serbia announced Tuesday that Russia had bought Serbia’s oil monopoly, the latest in Russia’s recent string of energy acquisitions. The deal will also allow Moscow to send more natural gas to Europe through its South Stream pipeline.

headline: American Capital Flips Exstream to H.P.
text: American Capital Strategies is selling Exstream Software, an enterprise technology maker, to Hewlett-Packard only seven months after acquiring the company.

headline: Index Closes First Late-Stage Venture Fund
text: In a move highlighting the growth of the European venture capital market, Index Ventures has closed its first fund targeting later-stage investments, a 400 million euro ($585 million) vehicle from which the firm may invest as much as 50 million euros in target companies.

headline: 3i Leads $117 Million Investment in Gain Capital
text: The 3i Group has led a $117 million equity investment in an online foreign exchange service, the Gain Capital Group, which will provide growth capital for the company and liquidity for earlier investors.

headline: China Mobile Plans I.P.O.
text: China Mobile Communications hopes to launch a domestic A-share listing “as soon as possible,” its chief executive, Wang Jianzhou, said Wednesday on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Tripwire Considers an I.P.O
text: With 2007 revenue approaching $50 million and a third year of profits in the books, Tripwire is better positioned to go public, according to the company’s chief executive, Jim Johnson.

headline: LBO France Said to Mull Sale of Cegelec
text: A private equity shop, LBO France, is considering selling its electrical contracting and IT group, Cegelec after receiving an approach for the business, according to The Deal.com.

headline: Cenkos Pulls Close Brothers Bid
text: Cenkos, the British small and mid-cap securities broker, has decided to withdraw its offer for the British independent merchant bank Close Brothers.

headline: Fortress Calls in MFS Loan
text: A hedge fund, the Fortress Investment Group has demanded repayment for its loan to the troubled Australian property and funds group MFS, The Australian Financial Review reported.

headline: Fifth Third Reassures on First Charter Deal
text: Fifth Third offered some assurance on its earnings conference call Tuesday that its $1.1 billion merger with First Charter will go forward.

headline: Times Company Joins $29.5 Million Round for WordPress Owner
text: Automattic, the commercial arm of the popular WordPress publishing platform for blogs, has received $29.5 million in financing from four companies, including a small portion from The New York Times Company.

headline: How Does RiskMetrics Measure Up?
text: The RiskMetrics initial public offering is scheduled for this week. According to The Wall Street Journal, it could be a “bellwether” for this year’s I.P.O. market.

headline: After Losses, BofA’s Lewis Welcomes Rate Cut
text: The upheaval in the mortgage market, a slowing economy and an increasingly stretched consumer have made the last few quarters among the toughest since Kenneth D. Lewis, the chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, took over in 2001.

headline: Quantcast Collects $20 Million in Second Round
text: A Web analytics start-up, Quantcast announced a $20 million second round of funding on Tuesday led by the Founders Fund and Polaris Venture Partners.

headline: Insurance for Hedge Fund Investors
text: Amid a spate of allegations of fraud at hedge funds, a London-based firm has created fraud insurance for investors.

headline: London May Lose $9 Billion Rusal I.P.O. to Hong Kong
text: United Company Rusal, the world’s largest aluminum producer, is considering shifting its initial public offering of more than $9 billion from the London Stock Exchange to Hong Kong amid souring relations between Britain and Russia and proposals for tougher British listing rules.

headline: British Hedge Funds Outline Dislcosure Rules
text: Britain’s biggest hedge fund managers have outlined plans to bolster standards on disclosure, valuation and risk management in an attempt to clean up the image of the industry.

headline: Live From Davos 2008
text: The usual crowd of A-list names is here, or soon will be — political heavyweights, business bigwigs and prominent academics who have come together in the Swiss resort town of Davos for the World Economic Forum.

headline: Work/Life Balance — How Do You Do It?
text: I took that two-week, nonworking vacation and now I’m paying for it. Aside from one prewritten blog post, I didn’t plan ahead for the work that was awaiting me. So I came home, in the middle of a week, in need of two doctor visits to deal with trip-related maladies. My desk, clean when I left, quickly became a jumble of work stuff and personal bills, all vying for my attention. In the next three weeks, I have business travel, family responsibilities and a few more deadlines than usual. I worked through my first weekend back, and I’m likely to do the same next weekend (on top of taking a business trip).

text: Lower cholesterol doesn’t have to come from a pill.

headline: U.S. and China Still Sparring, But Smiling

headline: Correction: Winter Day Out in Washington, D.C.
text: An article last Friday about what to do for a perfect winter weekend day in Washington referred imprecisely to the history of the Old Ebbitt Grill. It was founded in 1856 and moved to its current location in 1983; it was not built in 1856.

headline: Museum Clubbing in Berlin
text: Berlin has never had a problem mixing traditional cultural attractions with more offbeat ones. This has birthed events like the Yellow Lounge, where string quartets play for the retro-sneakered and shawled set in clubs around the city; or performances by ballet troupes at the former transformer station that now houses the legendary Panorama bar.

headline: A $200-a-Gram Tax on Cocaine
text: Among the hundreds of proposals contained in Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s second executive budget, which he unveiled on Tuesday in Albany, is a provision that would impose a $3.50-a-gram tax on marijuana and a $200-a-gram tax on other illegal drugs, like cocaine.We took a look at the fine print to better understand the details of this legislative proposal — which, incidentally, is very similar to a proposal that Mayor Edward I. Koch put forward in 1988. (That proposal, to tax illegal drugs in New York City, also at a rate of $200 a gram, did not come to fruition.)

headline: Republicans, Lost in Space
text: Even by election-year standards, the current field of Republican candidates has been doing some truly ambitious pandering. First, Mitt Romney told the autoworkers in Michigan that he could get all their jobs back—no problem, consider it done. Then, Mike Huckabee told South Carolinians that it was nobody‘s business but theirs if they wanted to wallpaper their public buildings with the Confederate flag. And now here comes Rudolph W. Giuliani to show these amateurs how it’s done. Campaigning in his make-or-break state of Florida last week, Mr. Giuliani released a statement promising to “make space a priority.” Apparently, America is facing a crisis far greater than health care or education reform: when the current fleet of space shuttles is retired in 2010, it’s going to take as much as five years—five years, people!—before we can send another guy into orbit. “This is not acceptable,” Mr. Giuliani said. “America should be number one in space. We have been. We shouldn’t lose that position.” In other words, it would be as if a guy had the number one position in all the national polls and then suddenly … well, you get the idea.

Indeed, if you pull an iPhone out of your pocket, it still creates a mild sensation here, because unlike in the United States, most Europeans have yet to touch Apple‘s six-month-old handheld phenomenon.

headline: Kovalainen faster than Hamilton
text: Today’s Formula One testing times in Valencia are enough to get the mouth watering and the heart beating hard in anticipation for the start to the season on 16 March. At the top of the time sheets we find Heikki Kovalainen, followed by the two Ferraris, Felipe Massa and then Kimi Raikkonen…and then Lewis Hamilton in fourth. And the pattern of the teammates who were supposed to be faster but weren’t does not stop there: In fifth in a Williams we find Kazuki Nakajima, with Nico Rosberg in the other Williams finishing behind Fernando Alonso in the Renault.

And Binx indeed has much in common with Holden, who is after all a moviegoer, too.

headline: If I Wrote This on a Typewriter
text: If I wrote this on a type writerNever would I knowThat typewriter is just one word.Computer told me so.If I wrote this on a typewriterIt would not be trueThat words could be many colors.That’s from computer, too.If I wrote this on a typewriterYoud be missing outOn text effects like this and that.Computers work, no doubt.If I wrote this on a typewriterItd be sad for sure.This would still be spelled like tihs;Spellcheck-less spellings poor.Good thing I write on a computerThe payoff is immense.For if I wrote with typewritersThis poem would not make sense.

headline: Finding bin Laden: Musharraf Sniffs, a Filmmaker Whiffs

headline: Tickets by Any Means Necessary
text: Last week, before I left the United States, my friends in Ghana had been trying to explain to me the frenzy over tickets. My friend John Rue, who has been living in Ghana and had been searching for tickets nearly full-time, said last Thursday in an e-mail that the Ghanaian Embassy in Washington was selling tickets and that I needed to get there ASAP. Getting tickets in Ghana, especially for games involving the host team and countries in West Africa such as Ivory Coast, Cameroon and Nigeria, has been extremely difficult, my friend told me.

headline: A History of Good Taste
text: In my column in today’s newspaper I wrote about the wine panel’s recent tasting of some inexpensive Napa cabernets, if you can call wines $50 and under inexpensive. They are by Napa standards, where mediocre cabernets run $50 to $150 as a matter of course. Although we found wines we liked the tasting was disappointing on the whole. Not because so many wines were bad but because so many were boring and innocuous, with a sort of generic plush, smooth fruitiness.

headline: Which Cities Pass Go and Collect Global Acclaim?
text: In recent years, New York and London have been dueling for the title of capital of the 21st century. Now Monopoly — that’s right, the Hasbro board game — is allowing the world to cast a vote in an online contest that will determine which 22 cities will be immortalized in a new global edition of the 75-year-old board game.The contest began at midnight Greenwich Mean Time, or about 7 p.m., on Monday night. As of today, London and New York are in the top two positions, with Paris just a smidgen behind New York. The top winner will be awarded the Boardwalk position, while No. 2 will get Park Place. The new game is scheduled to be unveiled in August.

headline: Kathleen Turner: Hold Susan Collins Accountable for the Supreme Court
text: The Supreme Court has lurched far to the right in recent years, as President Bush has nominated Justices favored by the most conservative elements of the Republican Party. This shift has occurred in large part because moderate Republicans have voted in virtual lockstep with the administration on judicial nominations.

headline: Colonial Update
text: There’s a new twist in the tale of Inmobiliaria Colonial, Spain’s second largest property company. GE Real Estate, the property arm of General Electric, is confirming its interest in a possible takeover of the troubled company. This comes just a month after Colonial acknowledged merger talks with French company Gencia, and two weeks after the company’s value plunged 40 percent and its founders were ousted.

headline: Pa. Governor Backs Clinton

Ed Rendell threw his political weight behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential candidacy on Wednesday afternoon, after months of courting by both Clintons, who hope that Mr. Rendell’s endorsement can give her a boost in the New Jersey and Delaware primaries on Feb. 5.

headline: Skeletal Remains Discovered in Washington Sq. Park
text: Updated, 6:31 p.m. | Mostly intact skeletal remains from at least four people were discovered this morning by city archaeologists doing soil testing as part of a restoration of Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village, city officials said. The discovery could have significance for scholars studying the history of the early United States; the area of the park was used as a common burial ground, or potter’s field, from 1797 to 1826.

headline: Picks and Pans From the Detroit Auto Show
text: With our coverage of the North American International Auto Show winding down, but while the show is still open to the public, here is a roundup of highlights and lowlights, as selected by some of The Times’s writers and editors.

headline: Sony Chief Says Don’t Panic Yet
text: An increasing number of economists are predicting a recession in the United States, but some top executives here in Davos appear to be less dour. One of these executives is Sir Howard Stringer, chief executive of Sony, whom I interviewed as the World Economic Forum got underway on Wednesday.

headline: Soft Serve  | A News Feed of Light Reading
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.As the global economy enters a tailspin, what better time to announce production of the Maybach 62 Landaulet — a convertible sports-car limo — that resembles a “marshmallow” and costs $1.19 million? … Here’s one amenity Maybach engineers graciously omitted: a  La-Z-Boy jacuzzi in the trunk … If you can’t drown your economic sorrows in the hot tub, drink a cup of joe from a  $20,000 coffee-maker… Maybe the economy is okay after all — in Brooklyn a chic independent bookstore, Melville House, has just opened. Take that, Fox Books! … When times are hard, sometimes the only recourse is, well, shopping! White Lighting is crushing on lace-up wedge boots from Chloë Sevigny’s Opening Ceremony collection… Speaking of footwear fetishism, two dudes from New Jersey were (are?) camped out in the freezing cold in front of a Foot Locker in Herald Square awaiting the new Air Jordan XX3 (23 get it?) … If you’d like to remember more prosperous times, Allure’s Jessica Matlin has a notion: go for glitter! Like Mariah Carey, “it’s back”… And so are we, tomorrow.

headline: Party of what?
text: Um, Greg — I thought everyone knew that the “party of ideas” line came from Moynihan. The weirdness of Obama’s use of the phrase came in the fact that he applied it to the Republican Party of the “last 10 or 15 years,” and suggested that the party of Tom DeLay and George W. Bush — a party that had nothing much to say except tax cuts good, terrorists bad — was “challenging conventional wisdom”.

headline: Who’s the Greenest of Them All?
text: We all love lists of winners and losers, and an obliging research team at Yale and Columbia has been trying to refine one that regularly ranks countries on their environmental performance. Switzerland is on top; Niger is dead last at 149th. The United States ranks 39th, below all of the other Group of 8 industrialized nations. By comparison, Albania is 25th, Russia 28th. Felicity Barringer’s story on the list, called an Environmental Performance Index, is online here.

headline: Police Give New Details on Ledger Death
text: Updated, 9:17 p.m. | The masseuse who discovered the body of Heath Ledger in a Manhattan apartment on Tuesday twice called a friend of his, the actress Mary-Kate Olsen, before calling 911, New York City police officials said on Wednesday. The officials, who provided new details about Mr. Ledger’s death, emphasized that no illegal drugs were found in the apartment and that there were no obvious signs of suicide. Tests on a rolled-up $20 bill that was found in the apartment found no evidence that the bill had been used to handle drugs, they said.

headline: Gore’s Gay Marriage Gambit
text: It’s widely agreed that Al Gore, private citizen, has done more to move the global political debate than Al Gore, elected official, ever did. Now Gore, who as vice president supported the Defense of Marriage Act, has put up a video on his Current TV Web site in which he stands up for gay marriage: “Gay men and women ought to have the same rights as heterosexual men and women — to make contracts, to have hospital visiting rights, to join together in marriage, and I don’t understand why it is considered by some people to be a threat to heterosexual marriage…”

headline: Slipping Into a Recession?
text: It’s not yet clear whether the nation as a whole has slipped into recession. But some parts of the country are clearly deep in the hole.

headline: Sushi Eaters Weigh the Health Risks
text: Marian Burros reported in The Times on Wednesday that recent laboratory tests of tuna sushi from a sampling of stores and restaurants in Manhattan found high amounts of mercury. There was so much that a regular diet of six pieces a week would exceed the levels considered acceptable by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: Davos avoidance
text: I’m not at Davos. Partly this is because my wife and I really needed some quiet time together, before the semester starts. Partly it’s because textbook revision deadlines loom. But I also have to say that the scene at Davos, with all the great, good, wise, and, especially, rich gathered together to celebrate their greatness, goodness, wisdom, and, especially, wealth, has always made me uncomfortable. I usually end up skipping a couple of big dinner affairs and sneaking off to feast on the modern Swiss national dish — which is, of course, spaghetti carbonara.

headline: Gore Defends Same-Sex Marriage

headline: Your Comments on my China-Darfur Column
text: I’d welcome your thoughts on my Thursday column, arguing that perhaps the best way to make progress on Darfur is to shame China. If you have other suggestions for how to make progress in Darfur (and also to reduce the risk of a new North-South war in Sudan), please post them as well.

headline: So This Is It: Valentino
text: The ovation was still going as I moved toward the backstage, slowly and then at a brisk walk. I passed Marisa Berenson and Marie-Chantal of Greece, who was with her husband Pavlos and her in-laws, Queen Ann-Marie and King Constantine. I saw Uma ahead of me. I caught up with Uma in the backstage and asked her what she thought of the show, half embarrassed that I bothered. “I have no comment to make at this time,” she said, as if she had said it a million times before. Okay. Wouldn’t “beautiful” have worked just as well? I turned away, toward the mob of photographers and models, all of them in identical red dresses, gathering with intensity around Valentino. Natalia V. had tears welling in her eyes. I saw Carlos Souza, who has done the press for Valentino for years, and I asked him if the girls were going to keep their red dresses. They’d all came out in red for the finale. “For sure!” he said, watching Valentino and the mob. Later, I asked one of the models about it and the look she gave me said, “Are you kidding?”

headline: Prominent Lawyer Is Fined by Ethics Board
text: The New York City Conflicts of Interest Board has fined Stanley K. Schlein, a prominent political lawyer, lobbyist and former chairman of the New York City Civil Service Commission, $15,000 for misusing city resources and personnel to perform work for his private law practice.

headline: Close Quarters
text: The last batch of games before the N.H.L.’s All-Star Break is to be played Thursday, and only 7 points separate the Devils, the first-place team in the Atlantic Division, from the Rangers, the last-place team. All five teams have more points than games played, and the Central Division is the only other division in the league with five teams in similar positions.

headline: Lionsgate Poised to Make Deal With Writers

headline: A Crackdown on Cabbies Who Refuse Credit Cards

That includes a rule that passengers must be able to pay by credit card in certain cabs and a rule barring cabbies from chatting on cellphones while driving.

headline: Goodbye Rudy, Tuesday
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. – Albert Einstein defined insanity as doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results. Flailing around Florida, Rudolph Giuliani is getting different results, just not the ones he wants. Call him a lot a things – weird, imperious, self-aggrandizing – but crazy he is not, at least by Einstein’s notion.

headline: CNBC Video: Silver Lake’s Hutchins at Davos

headline: Pessimistic Bulls, or Optimistic Bears?
text: It was an aptly named dinner debate on this first day of gloom and doom at the World Economic Forum: “Recession,” the title read in the forum’s program folder in bold red letters as if to drive home the point. After a day of debates dedicated to (or inevitably turning to) the United States economy’s sorry outlook, two high-profile chief executives joked that it felt like an act of masochism to end the day like this (rather than at the simultaneous wine-tasting or story-telling dinners).
