headline: Broadcom Founders Cited as Potential Co-Conspirators in Suit
text: Federal prosecutors on Thursday identified the co-founders of Broadcom, Henry T. Nicholas III and Henry Samueli, as “unindicted potential co-conspirators” in an investigation into the illegal backdating of stock options.

headline: Security Capital Gets Downgrade From Fitch
text: Shares of bond insurers opened strongly Thursday on hopes of a bailout for the beleaguered sector, but ended up falling sharply after Fitch Ratings downgraded Security Capital Assurance.

headline: E*Trade Discloses Turnaround Plan
text: E*Trade Financial, the discount brokerage that received a $2.55 billion cash infusion from the Citadel Investment Group in November, on Thursday announced details of a widely anticipated “turnaround plan” that includes disposing of non-core assets, cost-cutting and possibly raising money in capital markets later in the year.

headline: Live Nation Finds a Buyer for Its Theater Business
text: After almost a year of fielding bids, Live Nation has sold most of its North American theater business, including the Broadway Across America touring network, to Key Brand Entertainment, a company owned by a British producer and run by an American entertainment executive.

headline: Billionaires and Ice Stars
text: Russians, like blondes, have more fun. At least that was the impression at a party hosted Thursday night by the Russian investment firm Troika Dialog. Olympic ice skating stars were imported for the night, and guests were invited to try their luck with these supremos of the rink. Then they twirled and spun their way through well-known Russian folk tunes, with at least 200 spectators clapping along, fortified by vodka and gluehwein! In an after-party in a rink-side tent, there were possibly more billionaires per square foot than anywhere else, even in the town of Davos.

headline: Study Says Private Equity Isn’t Big Job Killer
text: Among the world’s private equity kings and policy makers, the issue of whether buyouts create jobs or result in more layoffs has always been the $100 billion question.

headline: Imperial Bids $1.3 Billion for Logista
text: Imperial Tobacco Group plans to bid 910 million euros ($1.3 billion) for full control of Compania de Distribucion Integral Logista, Spain’s largest cigarette distributor, following its 12.6 billion euro ($18.26 billion) takeover of the Spanish competitor Altadis, the maker of Gauloises cigarettes.

headline: Carlsberg and Heineken to Swallow British Brewer
text: Heineken is set to assume the mantle of Britain’s biggest brewer after Scottish & Newcastle on Friday accepted a $15.2 billion (7.8 billion pound) joint takeover offer made by the Dutch brewer and its Nordic counterpart, Carlsberg.

headline: F.C.C. Approves $20 Billion Clear Channel Buyout
text: Federal communications regulators on Thursday said they had approved the $20 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications by Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners.

headline: Deutsche Post May Sell DHL to FedEx, Report Says
text: Deutsche Post, the world’s biggest logistics group, is considering selling its ailing DHL express delivery unit in the United States to FedEx as part of a wider turnround plan that could be announced within months, The Financial Times Deutschland reported.

headline: Allis-Chalmers Drills Down Deal for Bronco
text: An oilfield services company, Allis-Chalmers Energy, said Thursday it would acquire Bronco Drilling for $437.8 million in cash and stock, the third combination in the increasingly competitive industry in as many months.

headline: Crunch Time for a Tech Start-Up
text: LiquidPlanner is one of about 70 tech companies preparing to make their pitch next week at the DEMO Conference in Palm Desert, Calif. John Cook of the Seattle Post-Intelligencer spent some time at the firm’s headquarters to see what life is like inside a pre-launch start-up.

headline: RiskMetrics Raises $245 Million in I.P.O.
text: RiskMetrics Group began its highly touted initial public offering on Thursday, at a time when many others are shying away from a foray into the public markets.

headline: SocGen’s Story Raises More Questions Than Answers
text: Société Générale, one of France’s largest and most respected banks, announced Thursday that it had lost $7.2 billion, not because of complex subprime loans, but the old-fashioned way – because a 31-year-old rogue trader made bad bets on stocks and then, in trying to cover up those losses, dug himself deeper into a hole.

headline: Chinese Retailer Pulls I.P.O.
text: A Chinese department store operator Maoye International Holdings postponed its $905 million Hong Kong initial public offering because of poor market conditions, becoming the latest listing hopeful to pull its deal amid poor risk appetite.

headline: Some Big Names in Hedge Funds Are Hurting
text: Recent stock market drops hurt some of the world’s most famous hedge fund managers, who have long attracted money with promises that they could sidestep even the worst conditions.

headline: Sprint Ousts Three Executives
text: In its latest move to restructure and shore up its stock, Sprint Nextel announced on Thursday the immediate departures of three top executives, including the chief financial officer, Paul Saleh.

headline: Caxton Pulls Back from Private Equity investments
text: While hedge funds and private equity firms have increasingly begun to resemble each other, a move by one prominent hedge fund to pull back from private-equity-style investments indicates that the melding is not always smooth sailing.

headline: A Risk Index for Sovereign Wealth Funds
text: Sovereign wealth funds were hardly talked about 12 months ago. Now they are one of the hottest topics in global financial markets. Over the last year, these state-owned entities have spent more than $75 billion snapping up stakes in some of the world’s biggest banks, taken big positions in stock exchanges on both sides of the Atlantic and even attempting a takeover of one of Britain’s leading supermarkets.

headline: Two Shows to Cure Winter Blues in London
text: London in January can be rather dark and dreary. In fact, on Monday 21 January the BBC reported that it was the most depressing day of the year – according to a scientific study carried out by a Chris Arnall, a psychologist at Cardiff University. Apparently, a combination of failed New Year resolutions, cloudy, dull weather, post Christmas credit card bills – you get the drift – leads people to feel very low on this particular day.

headline: LifeLock Takes $25.5 Millon from Big Name Investors
text: LifeLock said Wednesday that it received $25.5 million in venture capital funding from Goldman Sachs and other investors.

headline: Box.net Takes $6 Million in Fresh Funding
text: Box.net, whose goal is to become the file system for the Web, has scooped up $6 million in B round funding led by U.S. Venture Partners, the company said Thursday.

headline: W.H.O. Responds on F.G.M.
text: Early in our debate over female genital cutting, Richard Shweder of the University of Chicago critiqued a 2006 Lancet study by a group of researchers working with the World Health Organization. I invited those researchers from the W.H.O. study to respond.

headline: Private Placements Rise as Markets Gyrate
text: Global investment banks and small-cap companies rarely have much in common when it comes to raising capital, but they have both been using private placements to meet their financial needs, according to Financial News.

headline: The Best Use of Euphemism So Far This Season!
text: He gives incredibly, enthusiastic blurb, but Pete Hammond will be doing it for somewhere other than Maxim. Hollywood Wiretap reports that Maxim editor James Kaminsky has decided to drop movie coverage.

text: A hopeful sign appeared over the writer’s talks yesterday, and no, it was not Ben Silverman apologizing for calling writers ugly, prom-spoiling nerds. It’s even better.

headline: Why 2008 Is Not 2001
text: Some corporate chiefs see a silver lining amid the economic thunderclouds. A case in point is Henning Kagermann, the chief executive of SAP, Europe’s leading software firm. He argues that SAP will continue to prosper during a downturn because the business software it makes will help companies increase productivity and cut costs.

headline: Ambac Shares Rise Amid Takeover Speculation
text: Shares of the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurer, rose in European trading Friday following a newspaper report, citing unnamed sources, that said Wilbur Ross is in talks to buy the company.

headline: God Was a Metal Fan. So Was Wagner
text: Amongst the movies the Bagger missed at Sundance — there are so many to choose from — he kept hearing about “Anvil: The Story of Anvil,” directed by Sascha Gervasi and produced by Rebecca Yeldham. Cinematical has a pretty nifty podcast that helps explain why two big-deal movie types spent their time telling the story of a washed up metal band.

headline: Sundance: Plenty of Heat Left, Some Light
text: The Bagger pulled out of Sundance because there’s nothing in his drawers left that he was willing to place next to his skin he had been on the road two weeks and had to get back to headquarters, but the festival is far from over, as Living in Cinema points out.

headline: Deadly Tick-Tock
text: If you haven’t seen “No Country” yet, you will want to skip the Film Experience’s loving reconstruction of the mayhem, a series of scenes in which the bodies are stacked like just so much cordwood.

headline: Another Surprise as Federer Falls to Djokovic
text: MELBOURNE -- A surprising Australian Open took its latest unexpected turn Friday when Roger Federer, of all people, failed to reach the final after failing to win a set against Novak Djokovic in the semifinal.

headline: The Early Word: G.O.P. Keep It Civil
text: Viewers tuned in to Thursday night’s debate between the leading Republican candidates may have been expecting a brutal, no-holds-barred attack show like the Democrats put on Monday night. Instead, though, the G.O.P. hopefuls kept their remarks to one another mostly friendly.

text: Julian Schnabel, the director of “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” is setting out on the his anti-Oscar campaign, reminding people that in addition to having made an exquisite film, he is has an ego of Ruthian dimensions. Thanks to Defamer for the point.

headline: The Art of Nanotech
text: By day, Christian Orfescu relies on his training in materials science to run the analytical laboratory at Caleb Technology, a small company in Torrance, Calif., that is using nanotechnology to design improved lithium batteries. When the work day ends, though, Mr. Orfescu’s enthusiasm for the technology bubbles over into his other persona — Cris Orfescu, abstract artist.

headline: Friday’s Links: Career Advice from Marc Andreessen
text: A kind reader tipped me off to a series of postings on career planning posted by Marc Andreessen, a founder of Netscape, on his blog. I’d suggest putting aside a little time to read these as they are jammed with valuable tips. The series is told in the form of advice Mr. Andreessen would give to someone starting out in a career. But much of it is applicable to those of us already in the midst of one. The advice also has a bit of a techie entrepreneurial orientation. The series begins with this post and continues here, and here.

headline: At Sundance, a Second Life Sweatshop Is Art
text: One of the more exotic premieres at this year’s Sundance Film Festival is “Invisible Threads.” It’s not a movie, but a virtual sweat shop that exists only on Second Life, the online virtual world, yet produces real-life, custom-ordered, personalized blue jeans.

headline: How Effective Are Safety Nets at Construction Sites?
text: Required under a 1987 city law, safety nets have festooned construction sites across New York City for more than a decade, and now, amid a record-setting pace of high-rise construction, they are popping up all over, Thomas J. Lueck finds. The netting proved a lifesaver last week, when a construction worker fell from the 42nd floor of the Trump SoHo, a condominium hotel being built at Varick and Spring Streets, and was snared by a net that protruded 10 feet from the side of the building about two floors below where he was working. He was then lowered to the ground safely. But for another worker, who also fell from the 42nd floor, a similar net proved useless. For reasons that remain under investigation, he fell to the ground and died. For developers, contractors and construction workers, the accident in SoHo on Jan. 15 has raised questions about whether the city’s requirement for safety netting, which has generally been applauded, goes far enough.

headline: They Left the Gloves On
text: I doubt anyone tuned into last night’s Republican debate on the economy hoping for the sorts of fireworks we saw among the Democrats on Monday, but still, “the decidedly gentle sparring” (as The Times described it) left nearly everybody unsated.

headline: Business Executive Is Charged in Fatal Hit-Run

headline: Double Standard?
text: Tony Romo’s trip to Mexico with Jessica Simpson before the Cowboys’ game against the Giants caused quite a furor in the media, but Tom Brady gets nearly a free pass for his off-week excursions to New York, where he hangs out with his supermodel girlfriend, Gisele Bundchen. Why is that?

text: John Markoff asks Nicholas Negroponte, the co-founder of the MIT  Media Lab for a progress report on his One Laptop per Child program.

headline: Home from Camp Couture
text: There were a couple of models and a show producer on my flight yesterday from Paris, all of us in jeans and looking a little whacked. Three or four nights of staying up until 2 a.m. will do that to you, and I can only imagine the client demands nowadays on a show producer. It’s ALL about money, one way or the other.

headline: Where Social Responsibility Meets the Bottom Line

headline: Finding Their Voice, Then Losing It
text: Olive oil. No whispering. Extra water. These are some of the remedies the presidential candidates are using to prevent hoarseness on the campaign trail.

headline: Stray Questions for: Karen Olsson

headline: Basketball: The Political Views of Majerus
text: Rick Majerus has taken some heat recently about his pro-choice and pro-stem cell research views. The criticism has mainly come from the Archbishop of St. Louis, Raymond Burke, who has said that Majerus, the first-year coach at St. Louis, should be disciplined for making those views public when he spoke to a television reporter at a Hillary Clinton rally last week.

headline: Ode to Otey Ann
text: Throughout his career, Walker Percy took criticism for his portrayals of women. His usual refuge was to cheerfully claim that, in fact, he knew nothing about them whatsoever. There are few wholly flattering portraits of anyone, male or female, in “The Moviegoer.” Say what you will, the women are varied, strong each in her own way and vividly delineated: Aunt Emily, who is Prince Lorenzo, the New Orleans Marcus Aurelius, Hal to Binx’s Falstaff; Kate (a most improbable Natasha Rostov; in my experience, fiancées don’t come much scarier than this); Binx’s mother, Anna Smith, “old Eve,” the evident head of a clan that Percy somehow casts as a counterweight to the dynamic Bollings; and Sharon Kincaid, Binx’s Alabama Aphrodite, she of the amber Coca-Cola droplet.

headline: Has Bill Gone Bull Moose?

headline: A Railroad Rarity: Train Arrives Five Days Early
text: In these days of overburdened, frustrating transportation systems and drop-of-a-hat delays, it’s a headline to stun and gladden the heart: On the maiden voyage of a new cross-continental direct rail service between China and Germany, the first trainful of freight containers made it to their destination in Hamburg five days ahead of schedule. A journey that still would have been something of a logistical triumph if it had taken the expected 20 days was completed in 15, Bloomberg News and others reported. With some practice, railway officials say they may eventually be able to knock that down to 10.

headline: Fox’s Big ‘Moment': The Truth Hurts

It’s a pseudo-psychological trial by ordeal in which the contestants trade candor for dollars.”

headline: Now Booking | Riviera Maya, Mexico
text: Way back in 1997, Rosewood Hotels & Resorts made a big splash in Mexico with Las Ventanas al Paraíso in Los Cabos, a stunning beachfront resort that in the decade since has become an icon in the world of luxury hotels. In December, following a long gestation and much anticipation, the company finally “soft opened” its second property in the country, Rosewood Mayakobá on the Riviera Maya; the resort’s official, full-scale launch is next week. Rosewood is the second company to open in the big mixed-use residential-hotel-golf community north of Playa del Carmen called Mayakobá. (Fairmont was the first, and a Viceroy and Banyan Tree are slated to open later this year.) Though we haven’t yet booked ourselves in, early reports suggest the new Rosewood is a winner. Of the 128 suites — all done in a stylish, pared-down style using local limestone and woods from renewable sources — the 16 on the beach are obviously prime real estate, though the remainder, arranged along a network of lagoons that wend their way through mangrove forest, provide a novel take on the typical Mexican resort experience: each has its own dock, and guests are transported around the property via silent boats (silent, to avoid disturbing the wildlife). All rooms have a private plunge pool, and there’s a staff of 40 butlers to take care of your needs. The nice thing about the Riviera Maya in general, of course, is that there’s more to do than just loll on the beach — you’ve got Mayan ruins at Tulum; some decent shopping, restaurants and bars in Playa del Carmen and coral reef for diving and snorkeling offshore — but looking at the images from Rosewood, we think it might be hard to tear yourself away.

I wrote a history of eBay a few years ago, The Perfect Store: Inside eBay, and Ms. Whitman was one of its heroes: the brash Harvard M.B.A. who took eBay from a fledgling website of uncertain prospects to the $40 billion company it is today.

headline: A List Worth Thinking About
text: Every once in a while I like to highlight a great wine list. What do I mean by a great list? Well, certain kinds of lists you can take for granted. Restaurants like Veritas or Cru in New York are built around wine — they better have great lists! Similarly, a restaurant in wine country, like Cyrus in Healdsburg, Calif., ought to have a great list, too. What I love about the Cyrus list is that it not only has an excellent selection of locally made wines, but of great wines from around the world. I’m looking forward to eating there someday soon so I can write about that list.

headline: Some Personal Notes
text: I grew up in the Mississippi Delta town where Percy lived with his Uncle Will, said to be the model for Aunt Emily. His brother and his nephew were both my neighbors when I was growing up. When my husband and I decided to buy our house, we discovered that it had belonged to Percy’s other brother, Phinizy, known as Phin, who is still alive and now lives a few blocks away on St. Charles Avenue. Phin, a World War II veteran who was in the PT boat just behind Jack Kennedy’s when it got rammed by the Japanese, taught at Tulane Law School and lived with his wife and their four children, in the house I now live in between 1955 and 1977.

headline: The Path to Super Tuesday
text: For most Americans, the current race for the White House has been the most unpredictable and exciting in many years. On Feb. 5, voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will help to choose the Democratic and Republican presidential nominees. Super Tuesday could result in a clear favorite in both parties — or the race could remain wide-open until the summer conventions. From now through the primaries, City Room will focus on the presidential contest as it is waged in our region. Already, the schedule of campaign events is busier, and a sampling from the New York region this weekend is below.

headline: Once Plentiful, Activists Are a Rare Breed at Davos
text: There was a time in the 1990s that Davos had little time for what was then called – it seems so quaint a label now – the anti-globalization movement. Protests prompted a security lockdown, and at times managed to shut down parts of the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum.

headline: Wonder Returning to New Orleans
text: Stevie Wonder, right, will perform at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival after an absence of 35 years, The Associated Press reported. On May 2 Mr. Wonder is scheduled to headline the second weekend of this year’s event, along with Billy Joel, Sheryl Crow and Tim McGraw. The festival will be held from April 25 to April 27, and from May 1 to May 4. Headlining the festival’s opening day are Ms. Crow, Robert Plant and Alison Krauss. Also scheduled to perform are Dr. John, Al Green, Elvis Costello and Allen Toussaint. Performers on the second weekend include Randy Newman, Widespread Panic, Aaron Neville and  Santana. The event, with more than 1,000 musicians, is held at a racetrack where 11 stages and tents are set up. This year features a particularly strong lineup of female jazz singers, including Patti Austin, Cassandra Wilson, Dianne Reeves, Diana Krall and Ruby Wilson.

headline: Hedge Fund Seeks Board Seats at Times Co.
text: An Alabama-based hedge fund gave notice Friday that it would try to elect directors to The New York Times Company board, a day after the same hedge fund gave similar notice to another newspaper company, Media General.

headline: A Song-and-Dance Salute to the King of French Operetta

headline: Giants Move On, With Two Stars in Their Wake

headline: A Bitter Rivalry Finds a Little Common Ground

headline: Draft of New Iran Sanctions Restricts Cargo and Travel

headline: Wonders and Woes of a Working-Class Life
text: A cornerstone of country music is an age-old celebration of family values: not the politically loaded kind often put in quotation marks as a buzz term for a right-wing social agenda, but the meat-and-potatoes satisfactions and sorrows of everyday life. On Thursday evening Lori McKenna, a twangy-voiced mother of five children from Stoughton, Mass., brought it all back home at the Allen Room, where she was appearing as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.

headline: The FISA Follies, Redux
text: The Senate (reportedly still under Democratic control) seems determined to help President Bush violate Americans’ civil liberties and undermine the constitutional separation of powers. Majority Leader Harry Reid is supporting White House-backed legislation that would expand the administration’s ability to spy on Americans without court supervision and ensure that the country never learns the full extent of Mr. Bush’s illegal wiretapping program.

headline: Hate to Spoil a Weekend, but ....
text: Back in his mid-1980s heyday, when he was America’s most famous investor, managing America’s most famous mutual fund, Peter Lynch used to hate Mondays. Monday, you see, was the day the market was most likely to go down; according to research Mr. Lynch had compiled, from 1955 to 1985, it dropped by a cumulative 1,500 points just on that one day.

headline: Blaze Sends Thousands Fleeing a Las Vegas Resort
text: A fire on Friday swept parts of the top several floors of a hotel-casino on the Las Vegas Strip, but no one was seriously injured, a remarkably fortunate outcome given that thousands of guests and employees were inside when the blaze broke out around midday.

headline: Schools Call on Alumni Networks to Help Fill Coffers
text: Rich prep schools, with wealthy and talented alumni to draw on, are becoming a lot richer. And it’s not just because they have a lot of generous donors.

headline: Swedish Star Finds Motivation in Variety
text: BOSTON  Carolina Kluft of Sweden will not turn 25 until next Saturday, but in the heptathlon, the seven-event test in women’s track and field, she has won the last Olympic gold medal, the last two European championships and the last three world championships. She has won her last 19 heptathlons. Only the legendary Jackie Joyner-Kersee has scored higher.

headline: Coach Filed 2nd Resignation
text: More than two weeks after he was sued over a $4 million buyout clause in his contract at West Virginia, Rich Rodriguez turned in a second resignation letter, which claimed that Mike Garrison, the university president, reneged on a deal to reduce and possibly eliminate the clause. The letter obtained by The Associated Press and bearing Rodriguez’s name indicated the tack his legal defense will take when he files a response to that lawsuit in United States District Court.Rodriguez resigned with a one-sentence letter Dec. 18 to take the coaching job at Michigan. The latest letter is dated Jan. 10. In the letter, sent to Athletic Director Ed Pastilong, Rodriguez restated his displeasure with how slowly West Virginia was responding to additional demands he made in December 2006, when he passed up a $12 million deal at Alabama.

headline: A Light at the End of the Half-Pipe, Through Closed Eyes
text: THE last thing I saw before plunging down the bobsled track at the Olympic Sports Complex outside Lake Placid, N.Y., was an eerie orange light. I shivered in a wind chill of minus 17 degrees that penetrated all the way from my crash helmet to my long johns. I realized that the orange light was the sunset reflecting off the summit of Whiteface Mountain a dozen or so miles to the north. But I had no idea whether it foreboded the thrill of a lifetime or imminent death.

headline: Officer in Scuffle Killed by Police in White Plains
text: An off-duty Mount Vernon, N.Y., police officer was shot and killed in downtown White Plains on Friday evening after he pulled his gun on another man and was fired at by Westchester County police officers, the authorities said.

headline: In Matchup of Futility, Knicks Stand Taller Than Struggling Sixers
text: Just when the Knicks had begun to look sufferable, Larry Brown haunted them this week through a magazine article with a reminder of one of the franchise’s worst seasons.

headline: Congress Moving for Swift Passage of Stimulus
text: WASHINGTON  House Democrats on Friday said they would try to speed passage of a $150 billion economic stimulus package by scheduling it for a vote on Tuesday, eight days earlier than originally planned.

headline: Listen Up and Fly Right
text: Grand Forks, N.D.

headline: Out of Favor for Benefiting From Favors, Rowland Stirs Varied Sentiments
text: STAMFORD, Conn.  The job description may be less impressive than governor or congressman, but John G. Rowland is raring to go.

headline: Author Faults a Game, and Gamers Flame Back
text: The Internet hath no fury like a gamer scorned.

headline: Reads Like a Book, Looks Like a Film
text: Brian Selznick, the author and illustrator of “The Invention of Hugo Cabret,” uses the word “obsessed” a lot. As in: “I was deeply obsessed with ‘Star Wars’ ” (elaborate pencil drawings of Princess Leia and Darth Vader that he did as a 10-year-old hang on a wall of the art studio in his Brooklyn apartment) or “I remember being really obsessed with the ‘Virgin of the Rocks,’ ” by Leonardo da Vinci (a sketch of the angel from that painting hangs in the hallway).

headline: Mr. Bloomberg’s Budget Plan
text: New York has never had a more fiscally fluent mayor than Michael Bloomberg, a self-made billionaire. As he unveiled his preliminary $58.5 billion budget this week, the mayor warned of challenges ahead, but he also predicted that he could successfully steer the city through another downturn. There are a lot of uncertainties, but we take comfort in knowing that Mr. Bloomberg has prepared New York to weather bad times.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the entry of tens of thousands of Palestinians into Egypt after Hamas militants destroyed part of a fence at the border with Gaza described incompletely the events regarding Gaza and Egypt three decades ago. In that era, Egypt accepted the return of Sinai from Israel but declined to take back Gaza, not just the Gazan half of the border city of Rafah. The article also misstated, in some editions, the location of the border. It separates Gaza from northern Egypt, not southern Egypt.

headline: Sentencing in Murder
text: A man who pleaded guilty in Phoenix to murder in the 2003 slaying of a Cincinnati Reds prospect was sentenced to life in prison Friday, but a judge decided that the man, Reginald Riddle, would be eligible for parole after 25 years. Riddle, 23, pleaded guilty in 2006 to the first-degree murder of outfielder Dernell Stenson of LaGrange, Ga., as part of a plea agreement.

headline: And Triplets Make Seven in Rookie Policeman’s Home
text: As Boatema Amoah was having her eighth-week sonogram, the technician asked her three times, “Was this a natural pregnancy?”

headline: Wyeth Says It May Cut 10% of Jobs
text: Wyeth said Friday that it might cut as many as 5,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its worldwide work force, after federal regulators delayed four medicines in the last year.

headline: Colombia: Rice Lobbies for Trade Deal
text: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice wrapped up a two-day visit with a strong show of support for President Álvaro Uribe, a close ally of the Bush administration who is seeking a trade agreement with the United States. Ms. Rice, accompanied by nine Democratic lawmakers, lobbied for the United States Congress to approve the deal, which faces resistance from labor and human rights groups amid concerns over killings of union officials in Colombia and ties to paramilitary death squads among political supporters of Mr. Uribe. Democratic leaders in Congress and the leading Democratic candidates for president have shown little enthusiasm for the trade agreement.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Monday about the effect of the television and film writers’ strike on soap operas referred incorrectly to the “financial core” designation held by some writers who have returned to work. It is a provision of federal law under which individuals pay some union dues and fees and are covered by collective bargaining agreements, but are not union members and not compelled to go on strike. The designation is not based on financial need.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the Sports Briefing column on Wednesday about the African Cup of Nations soccer tournament misstated the outcome of a match involving Zambia. Zambia defeated Sudan, 3-0.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the entry of tens of thousands of Palestinians into Egypt after Hamas militants destroyed part of a fence at the border with Gaza described incompletely the events regarding Gaza and Egypt three decades ago. In that era, Egypt accepted the return of Sinai from Israel but declined to take back Gaza, not just the Gazan half of the border city of Rafah. The article also misstated, in some editions, the location of the border. It separates Gaza from northern Egypt, not southern Egypt. (Go to Article)

headline: Going Live From Pyongyang
text: The New York Philharmonic’s concert in North Korea, to take place on Feb. 26 at the East Pyongyang Grand Theater, will be broadcast live internationally. The broadcast will be produced by the New York Philharmonic and EuroArts Music International, in co-production with the Munhwa Broadcasting Company of South Korea and ARTE France, and in cooperation with the European Broadcasting Union. Details of the broadcast in the United States are to be announced later. The concert, to be conducted by Lorin Maazel, above, the orchestra’s music director, will include the national anthems of North Korea and the United States; the Prelude to Act III of Wagner’s “Lohengrin”; Dvorak’s Symphony No. 9, “From the New World”; and Gershwin’s “American in Paris.” The concert, and the Philharmonic’s visit, have aroused controversy, with some contending that they offer legitimacy to North Korea’s government.

headline: Museum Workers Are Called Complicit
text: LOS ANGELES  Appraisal forms, import applications, reference materials. To that usual array of tools a museum might harness in assessing donated artifacts, some museums in Southern California appear to have added one more, according to investigators’ affidavits: a wink and a nudge.

headline: Scottish & Newcastle Agrees to Be Bought and Split
text: LONDON  Scottish & Newcastle, Britain’s largest brewer, agreed on Friday to a £7.8 billion ($15.4 billion) takeover by the European rivals Carlsberg and Heineken.

headline: Young Singers’ Chance to Fill a Stage All Alone
text: This week the Marilyn Horne Foundation and the Weill Music Institute at Carnegie Hall joined forces to present “The Song Continues,” this year’s installment of Ms. Horne’s annual series of master classes and concerts meant to encourage young singers toward recital singing as an art worth cultivating, even as they prepare for bigger-ticket operatic careers.

headline: Beating Federer, Djokovic Has Look of a Champion
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Novak Djokovic, a master of imitating the quirks and strokes of other tennis stars, did a fine impression of a champion Friday night by refusing to surrender even one set to Roger Federer, of all people, in the semifinals of the Australian Open.

headline: As State Primary Nears, Pataki Is Barely Visible
text: When Gov. George E. Pataki left office last January, he was the dominant Republican politician in New York. Over three terms, he had shattered fund-raising records and had racked up double-digit victory margins in an overwhelmingly Democratic state, becoming a national political figure in the process. Mr. Pataki ruled Albany for so long that even now some swatches of state bureaucracy are still run by his political appointees.

headline: Two Twins Agree to Deals
text: Justin Morneau, the 2006 American League Most Valuable Player, received the most lucrative contract in Minnesota Twins history, a six-year, $80 million deal announced Friday. The Twins also announced a three-year, $24 million agreement for right fielder Michael Cuddyer. General Manager Bill Smith said the deals did not affect other players.

headline: 3 Leading Executives Resign at Insurer Under Inquiry
text: The top managers of WellCare Health Plans, an insurer being investigated by the F.B.I. for possible fraud, resigned Friday.

headline: Bulking Up for Rambo
text: Sylvester Stallone says he used human growth hormone, though not steroids, to get in shape for “Rambo,” which opened on Friday, and defends its use in an article on Time magazine’s Web site (time.com). Mr. Stallone, 61, says he gained 41 pounds to play Rambo by using prescription testosterone. “Everyone over 40 years old would be wise to investigate it because it increases the quality of your life,” he says. “Mark my words. In 10 years it will be over the counter.” HGH and other performance-enhancing substances have become a matter of concern to sports officials, who are fighting their use among athletes.

headline: Ivory Coast Advances
text: Didier Drogba scored one goal and set up another for Aruna Dindane to help Ivory Coast to a 4-1 victory against Benin on Friday in Sekondi, Ghana, making the Elephants the first team to qualify for the quarterfinals of the African Cup of Nations. Nigeria struggled again to create chances in a 0-0 draw against Mali in Group B’s other match.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about the visit to Turkey by Prime Minister Kostas Karamanlis of Greece misidentified, in some copies, the city where he met with his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. It was in Ankara, not Istanbul.

headline: Venezuelan Pleads Guilty in Cover-Up of Suitcase of Cash
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  A Venezuelan lawyer pleaded guilty in Miami on Friday to his role in a plot to cover up the destination of a suitcase stuffed with $800,000 in cash that United States prosecutors say was intended as a campaign contribution from the Venezuelan government to Argentina’s president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner.

headline: Two Presidents Are Worse Than One
text: Evanston, Ill.

headline: Democratic Hopefuls Seek to Widen Appeal Beyond Core Groups
text: GREENVILLE, S.C.  As Democrats headed on Friday toward the finish line of their first presidential primary in the South, the three candidates sought to widen their appeal to voters outside their core support groups.

headline: Dropping Pants, Dispelling Rumors
text: The popular South Korean singer Na Hoon-a, below, went live on national television Thursday and unexpectedly dropped his trousers, saying he was ready to prove he had not been castrated or dismembered in a love quarrel over an unnamed actress, Reuters reported. The singer addressed a packed news conference to deny rumors that he had undergone amputation or injury at the hands of a Japanese gangster.

headline: Union Membership Sees Biggest Rise Since ’83
text: The roll of American workers belonging to labor unions climbed last year by the largest number since 1983, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday.

headline: Doing Battle on the Field of Parody
text: So much has been written about the homoeroticism in the film “300” that any spoof is bound to feel like overkill. Fortunately, overkill is what Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer do best: as the uncontested titans of the parody genre (with fingers in everything from the “Scary Movie” franchise to the more recent “Epic Movie”) they continue to prove that ridiculing other movies is much easier than making your own.

headline: Questions Surround Idea of Privatizing the Lottery
text: ALBANY  Can New York hit the jackpot by selling its lottery?

headline: Lo Duca Will See Doctor
text: Nationals catcher Paul Lo Duca injured his left knee during a workout and will travel to Washington next week to be examined by a team doctor. Lo Duca, who signed a $5 million deal for one season as a free agent this off-season, was hurt this week and had a magnetic resonance imaging exam Friday.

headline: House Republicans Urge Earmark Moratorium
text: WASHINGTON  House Republicans called on Friday for “an immediate moratorium” on earmarking money for pet projects. They urged Democrats to join them in establishing a bipartisan panel to set strict new standards for such spending.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Jan. 5 with a dance review of New York City Ballet misspelled, in some copies, the given name of a dancer. He is Damian Woetzel, not Damien.

headline: Reprising Anonymous Role in Another Super Bowl
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants tight end Jerome Collins will be attending his second consecutive Super Bowl next week in Arizona. A member of the Indianapolis Colts last season, Collins has a Super Bowl ring and has pocketed hundreds of thousands of dollars in winning team playoff shares over the last two postseasons.

headline: At the Tournament Table, Learning by Doing
text: Williams College in Williamstown, Mass., gives an annual gift of sorts to its students. During the winter they are allowed almost a month away from regular classes to pursue a nonacademic subject. Some use the time to enhance their skiing and partygoing skills. But this year seven students  Todd Bustard, Chris Chudzicki, Jon Dahlberg, Jason Griffith, Bill Jannen, Edward Newkirk and Bryant Renaud  chose to pursue tournament bridge under the tutelage of Frank Morgan, the Atwell professor of mathematics.

headline: Italian Leads
text: Carolina Kostner held off a strong challenge from two Finnish teenagers to lead the women’s competition after the short program Friday at the European Figure Skating Championships in Zagreb, Croatia.Kostner, an Italian, opened defense of her title with a triple flip-triple toe loop combination. She made mistakes on her next two jumps, but her spins and triple-triple gave her an overall total of 59.31 points. Kiira Korpi, last year’s bronze medalist, finished with 58.60 points. The Finnish champion Laura Lepisto was third with 56.96.The ice dancing title went to the Russians Oksana Domnina and Maxim Shabalin, who overtook Isabelle Delobel and Olivier Schoenfelder of France.

headline: Seeking a More Flattering Light on, and From, Bulbs
text: SOME 26 years ago, when Robert Pai joined Sylvania’s fluorescent technology laboratories, he and his fellow researchers did not think much about compact fluorescents. They were more interested in solving problems with mercury and ballast, and otherwise making big industrial fluorescent lamps more efficient and safer for the environment. Much has happened since. Sylvania is now part of Osram Sylvania, a unit of the German company Siemens. Dr. Pai  he has a doctorate in physics  is heading compact fluorescent research. And compact fluorescents, usually called C.F.L.’s, are definitely on researchers’ minds.

headline: In South Carolina, Everything Turns on Jobs
text: ORANGEBURG, S.C.  Officially, the state of South Carolina calls the fancy new building the Orangeburg Workforce Center. Around here, people know it as the unemployment office. And everyone in Orangeburg County, it seems, can tell you how to get there.

headline: Jockey Barred
text: The champion jockey Kieren Fallon was barred for 18 months after a second positive test for an unidentified banned substance. Fallon, from Ireland, appealed the ruling by the governing body of thoroughbred and steeplechase racing in France. He can race in France until his appeal is heard. Fallon, 42, tested positive for cocaine Aug. 19 in Deauville after riding Myboycharlie. He served a ban from December 2006 to June 2007 after testing positive for cocaine while riding in France.

headline: Ex-HarperCollins Publisher Settles Defamation Suit
text: Judith Regan, the publisher who was fired from HarperCollins in late 2006 after the company decided to scrap the release of “If I Did It,” O. J. Simpson’s hypothetical murder confession, has settled her $100 million defamation lawsuit against News Corporation, Harper’s parent.

headline: Easing Taut Prog-Metal Into a Majestic Crunch
text: Neurosis started out in the late ’80s as a hard-core punk band, making rickety songs in speedy two-beat rhythms. Its music was a slanted plywood hutch. Now it makes monument music: slow and graceful, determined, balanced, imperious.

headline: Taking the Bears to Task
text: ON Monday, Barry Ritholtz, the chief executive of the research firm Fusion IQ and the author of the popular blog the Big Picture, criticized what he called the “Long and Wrong” crowd  people who insist on remaining positive about the markets and the economy.

headline: Memo Details Objections to Command Center Site
text: The New York Police Department produced a detailed analysis in 1998 opposing plans by the city to locate its emergency command center at the World Trade Center, but the Giuliani administration overrode those objections. The command center later collapsed from damage in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

headline: Getting Ships in Shape
text: The Heritage Lottery Fund awarded grants toward the preservation of two historic British ships, the Mary Rose and the Cutty Sark, Agence France-Presse reported. The fund awarded £10 million ($19.7 million) for extensive restoration to the Cutty Sark, a tea clipper shown above in a computer image, after it was gutted by fire last May. And £21 million ($41.4 million) went to the Mary Rose, King Henry VIII’s flagship, which sank in 1545 and was raised in 1982. The money is to pay for a museum in the dockyards at Portsmouth, England, that will house the Mary Rose and the artifacts found with it.

headline: Woman Who Survived 9/11 Is Killed by a Car in the City
text: It was a beautiful morning on Sept. 11, 2001, so Florence Cioffi made a decision that helped save her life: She left her office in the World Trade Center for a coffee break and was able to flee the devastation of the terrorist attack.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Jan. 15 about an experiment in which a robot was controlled by a monkey’s thoughts misattributed the robot’s design. It was by the Sarcos Research Corporation in Salt Lake City, not Gordon Cheng and colleagues at the ATR Computational Neuroscience Laboratories in Kyoto, Japan. (The Kyoto group helped design the experiment.)

headline: A Stress-Filled Week Shows Obama With a Blend of Humor and Fire
text: CLEMSON, S.C.  On the fifth day, Senator Barack Obama chose humor.

headline: Building Costs Deal Blow to Local Budgets
text: SEATTLE  State and local governments in many parts of the country are struggling to pay for roads, bridges and other building projects because of rising construction costs, adding another burden to budgets already stressed by the troubled housing market.

headline: Only Private Security Will Do, Until It Doesn’t
text: On a Friday evening exactly 29 years ago, a man in a town house on West 54th Street in Manhattan had a heart attack. His name was Nelson A. Rockefeller; he had built a life of power atop the oil fortune that came down to him from his father, serving as governor of New York and vice president of the United States.

headline: Richard G. Darman, 64, Aide for 5 Presidents, Dies
text: Richard G. Darman, who marshaled a deep, prickly intelligence to guide policy and deal making in four Republican administrations, including negotiating the reversal of the first President George Bush’s campaign pledge not to raise taxes, died Friday. He was 64 and lived in McLean, Va.

headline: Conviction in Poisoning of Indonesian Rights Activist
text: SOLO, Indonesia  In a high-profile case that had become a test of the independence of Indonesia’s judiciary, the Supreme Court convicted on Friday a former airline pilot for the 2004 poisoning of a human rights advocate and sentenced him to 20 years in prison.

headline: Russian Police Arrest a Suspected Racketeer
text: MOSCOW  Semyon Y. Mogilevich, a reputed kingpin of the Russian mob, was arrested in Moscow this week on tax evasion charges.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A caption in Science Times on Tuesday about blogs that celebrate fat people omitted the source of an illustration for the blog fatgrrl.com, which said, “Love Your Fat Self.” It was from an article in Utne Reader about obesity that the blog was highlighting on its home page.

headline: Loud Crashes, Dignified Stereotypes and a Touch of Wagner
text: Julian Rosefeldt, a German artist born in 1965 who lives in Berlin, makes visually opulent, earnestly political films and videos. Most of his work is high-minded, excessively middlebrow and seemingly bent on tweaking consciousness seductively and without strain.

headline: With Third Title, Sharapova Shows She’s Back
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  Nothing could stop Maria Sharapova at the Australian Open this year. Not her usual nemesis, Serena Williams, who was beaten by someone else in the quarterfinals. Not her fragile right shoulder, which remained loose and pain free.

headline: Giants Have Fan in Cashman
text: WAYNE, N.J.  When Brian Cashman was an assistant general manager for the Yankees, one of his roommates was Timmy Coughlin, son of Tom Coughlin, the Giants’ coach.

headline: Yanks and Canó Agree on Deal
text: The Yankees and second baseman Robinson Canó reached a preliminary agreement Friday on a contract that could pay him about $55 million over six years.

headline: Judge to Decide 3 Detectives’ Fate
text: The three detectives charged in the 2006 shooting death of Sean Bell will be tried by a judge, not a jury, the judge in the case ruled Friday.

headline: McCain’s Fiscal Mantra Becomes Less Is More
text: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Senator John McCain said that, if elected, he would do what other presidents had tried but failed to do: cut government spending sharply enough to reduce the budget deficit while lowering taxes at the same time.

headline: Death of Troubled Connecticut Surgeon Leads to Charges Against an Employee
text: GREENWICH, Conn.  Ian M. Rubins appeared to have it all. He was a skilled plastic surgeon who treated breast cancer patients in need of reconstructive surgery, and his surgical talents helped him achieve a pampered life, with a $2 million house here, a ski house on 10 acres in Vermont, a 39-foot boat and a plane.

headline: Report by British Military Finds No Systematic Abuse of Iraqi Prisoners by Its Soldiers
text: LONDON  A British Army report on the mistreatment of Iraqi prisoners by British soldiers in southern Iraq in the first year after the allied invasion in 2003 has concluded that there was no systematic abuse but that there were “individual instances where people behaved disgracefully.”

headline: Egypt Tries to Plug Border; Gazans Poke New Hole
text: GAZA  Egypt tried to restore its border with Gaza on Friday, stationing riot police officers in an effort to block Palestinians from entering. But Palestinians used a bulldozer to knock down another portion of the wall separating Egypt and Gaza.

headline: Britain Seeks Its Essence, and Finds Punch Lines
text: LONDON  It was a lofty idea: formulate a British “statement of values” defining what it means to be British, much the way a document like the Declaration of Independence sets out the ideals that help explain what it means to be American.

headline: Who Has the Optimism? The Have-Nots
text: DAVOS, Switzerland

headline: Masters of Zen, Not of Winning
text: A book called “The Complete Pocket Positives” sat at the center of Cathy Andruzzi’s desk after a recent practice. One of her players had bought it for her earlier this season, and Andruzzi, the women’s basketball coach at Fordham, has taken to flipping it open to a random page and having a member of her team read one of the quotes out loud before each practice.

headline: A Lovefest, if Misery Loves Company
text: Pain, alienation and the thousand varieties of loneliness that flesh is heir to: these are the topics that Abi Morgan’s “Tender,” a British play being given its New York premiere by Thirteenth Night Theater, means to address. The action has been moved to New York from London, but misery trumps geography  these characters would be unhappy anywhere.

headline: Arkansas: Not-Guilty Plea Entered for Bus Driver
text: A not-guilty plea was entered on behalf of a bus driver charged with four felonies after he tested positive for amphetamines in a deadly crash in eastern Arkansas. The driver, Felix Badillo Tapia, 28, did not attend the hearing. Mr. Tapia, who faces four counts of negligent homicide, was previously released on $50,000 bond. If convicted, he could be sentenced to up to 10 years in prison. Mr. Tapia was driving a Tornado Bus Company bus Nov. 25 when it crossed the median near Forrest City and collided with a pickup and a tractor-trailer.

headline: The Endorsements: The Readers’ Turn
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Said to Be Weighing Public Pricing of Derivatives
text: DAVOS, Switzerland  United States regulators are considering forcing investment banks to make public markets in some of the more exotic financial instruments that have plunged in value in the last six months, the head of the New York Stock Exchange said Friday.

headline: Tackling a Character Who’s a Real Character
text: Richard Thomas, the composer of “Jerry Springer: The Opera,” says that the libretto contains only 174 objectionable words, including “nipple.” That tally may not account for certain expressions  all of them unprintable in this newspaper  that are repeated over and over, but is nevertheless considerably shy of the 8,000 swear words and obscenities claimed, Mr. Thomas says, by overexcited critics of the show during its run in London. “Jerry Springer: The Opera” was a huge hit in the West End, but when it was shown on BBC television in January 2005, it generated so many complaints that some BBC executives asked for police protection.

headline: All of Nature Is on the Stage, in Sound and Light and Moves
text: Jordan Fuchs’s new “Thicket” is a small, neatly constructed piece that didn’t just fill the stage on Thursday at Danspace Project. Mr. Fuchs created an entire universe of throbbing, sprinting natural life in just 45 minutes, with four dancers and a mysterious score by Andy Russ. Carol Mullins’s stark lighting shifts, from pitch-black night to blazing orange-honey noon, added immeasurably to the dance’s quiet power.

headline: Mosul Bombings Prompt Promise of New Offensive
text: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki announced Friday that he was sending more forces to Mosul for what he vowed would be a “decisive” struggle to rid the city of insurgents.

headline: Being Sport’s New Face, After Homework Is Done
text: ST. PAUL  The little girl in the pink skating dress could not have been more adorable, or more charming.

headline: Museum Seeks Ruling on Claim to Painting
text: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, has turned to the courts to validate its claim to a 1913 Oskar Kokoschka painting sought by Claudia Seger-Thomschitz, an Austrian woman who says it was sold under duress during the Nazi occupation of Austria, The Boston Globe reported. Lawyers for Ms. Seger-Thomschitz contend that there is no doubt that the Kokoschka painting, “Two Nudes (Lovers),” was sold under duress by Oskar Reichel, a physician who ran an art gallery in Vienna. The Museum of Fine Arts, citing months of research, maintained that the sale in 1939 was voluntary and to another Jew, the Viennese art dealer Otto Kallir. “The painting was never confiscated by the Nazis, was never sold by force as a result of Nazi persecution and was not otherwise taken from Dr. Reichel,” the museum’s complaint states. Ms. Seger-Thomschitz’s lawyers said they would respond to the suit.

headline: Moody’s Official Concedes Failures in Some Ratings
text: DAVOS, Switzerland  The chief executive of Moody’s, the credit rating agency, conceded on Friday that his agency had made significant mistakes in the rating of structured finance products, but added that the agency had been deceived by people who put together the products.

headline: U.S. Race Captures World’s Eye, and Holds It
text: DAVOS, Switzerland  To look at the reams of coverage in newspapers outside the United States or to follow the hours of television news broadcasts, you might conclude that foreigners had a vote in selecting an American presidential candidate  or, at least, deserved one, so great is America’s influence on their lives.

headline: Stakeholder Sues IAC Over Breakup Plan
text: The Liberty Media Corporation, the entertainment and Internet retailing company controlled by the billionaire John C. Malone, has sued IAC/InterActiveCorp in a dispute over IAC’s plans to split into five companies.

headline: Woods Isn’t Driving Perfectly, but He’s Cruising
text: SAN DIEGO  In the relative calm before the coming Pacific storm, Tiger Woods churned inexorably across the North Course at Torrey Pines on Friday, making birdies from the rough, a par from the sand, a chip-in par from the green and putts from everywhere else. His bogey-free round of 65 on a striking California day provided yet another Tiger Woods Clinic, this one titled: How to Thrive When You Can’t Drive.

headline: After Break for Debate, Two Rivals Resume Spat
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  A day after a relatively reserved debate in which they appeared to take pains to avoid attacking each other, Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney on Friday engaged in their most vigorous sniping since their back-and-forth before the New Hampshire primary over two weeks ago.

headline: Where Would the 12 Million Go?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giuliani Does It His Way in New York’s Balmier Precincts
text: Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: Mayor’s Amorous Texts Lead to Perjury Inquiry
text: DETROIT  The city’s charismatic but scandal-plagued mayor and his chief of staff will be the subject of an investigation into whether they lied under oath when they denied having an extramarital affair, the Wayne County prosecutor announced here Friday.

headline: Alton G. Marshall, 86, Nelson Rockefeller’s Top Aide, Is Dead
text: Alton G. Marshall, who as executive secretary to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York in the late 1960s was considered a behind-the-scenes manager of the governor’s programs, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Fighting for Justice, Even at His Own Peril
text: BRISBANE, Australia

headline: U.S. Ignores Finding on Student Lender
text: The Education Department has brushed aside a finding by its own inspector general that a student lender improperly received $34 million in federal subsidies, and is instructing the lender to decide for itself how much money it should pay back.

headline: Taking Aim at the Perks of Districts in Nassau
text: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  The man who oversees the Water Authority of Great Neck North drives a Crown Victoria financed by taxpayers, who also pick up the tab for the gas and insurance.

headline: Peyton Sees Success in His Brother’s Future
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The empty space between the conference championship games and the Super Bowl has always been filled with predictions. This year, the New England Patriots are heavily favored to beat the Giants and become the first N.F.L. team to finish with a 19-0 record.

headline: Questions for the Clintons
text: Charleston, S.C.

headline: No Apparent Link Between Two Fatal Cases of Meningitis, Health Officials Say
text: Two people from local high schools  a Queens woman and a Long Island teenager  have died of bacterial meningitis in the past two days.

headline: French Trader Is Remembered as Mr. Average
text: PARIS  Jérôme Kerviel was too middling to be considered a loser. Until he was charged by Société Générale with perpetrating the biggest fraud of its kind in banking history, there was nothing superlative about him.

headline: So Is Waterboarding Torture? Mukasey May Never Say
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey suggested Friday that he might never provide an answer to the question that threatened his Senate confirmation last year: Does the harsh interrogation technique known as waterboarding amount to torture?

headline: Heeere’s Rudy!
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

headline: At Elite Prep Schools, College-Size Endowments
text: EXETER, N.H.  When Curtis Thomas, a 14-year-old from a poor family living in St. Rose, La., arrived here two years ago to attend Phillips Exeter Academy, he brought little more than a pair of jeans and two shirts. That would hardly do at a 227-year-old prep school where ties are still required for boys in class.

headline: Fight Brews in Italy Over New Elections
text: ROME  The day after Prime Minister Romano Prodi resigned, Italy’s leaders began gearing up Friday for a new fight: whether to hold immediate elections, an option considered favorable to former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, or first fix an electoral law blamed for the current instability.

headline: Behind the Abortion Decline
text: Coinciding with this month’s 35th anniversary of the Supreme Court’s ruling that legalized abortion, a new study shows that the United States continues to make progress on reducing the abortion rate. The progress would be greater if more was done to avoid unintended pregnancies.

headline: Knoblauch Wait Continues
text: HOUSTON  The mother of the former Yankees player Chuck Knoblauch said Friday that she believed he would cooperate with a Congressional committee investigating the use of steroids in baseball.

headline: French Film Nominations
text: “La Vie en Rose,” “Persepolis,” “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” “La Graine et le Mulet” and “Un Secret” are the nominees for the Césars, France’s version of the Academy Awards, as best picture. “La Vie,” about the singer Edith Piaf, led with 11 nominations, including one for Marion Cotillard, above, who plays Piaf,  for best actress. The Césars will be awarded in Paris on Feb. 22.

headline: Why Replace Our Drawbridge? It Can Be Repaired
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tensions Grow at Egypt-Gaza Border
text: JERUSALEM  Egyptian riot police used armored vehicles to try to restrict Gazans from taking their cars into Egypt on Saturday, and the Egyptian foreign minister warned of “provocations” at the border. He said that at least 36 Egyptian security officers had been hospitalized, some in critical condition, after confrontations with Palestinians.

headline: Florida: New Head of Hurricane Center
text: A veteran weather forecaster was named the new director of the National Hurricane Center. The forecaster, Bill Read, 58, had been the interim deputy director of the center since August, when X. William Proenza was ousted as director. Mr. Proenza’s staff had urged federal officials to dismiss him because they said he was exaggerating problems with a satellite. Mr. Read ran the Houston-Galveston office of the National Weather Service before joining the center. The interim director of the center, Edward N. Rappaport, chose not to apply for the permanent position and will return to his previous post as deputy director.

headline: Belt-Tightening, but No Collapse, Is Forecast in Technology Spending
text: In the consumer economy, the Main Street shopper leads the way. In the corporate economy, big technology buyers like Monte Ford will determine the arc of business spending in the coming months.

headline: Société Générale’s Sales May Have Incited Market Plunge
text: PARIS  As panic swept European markets on Monday, word spread that a big hedge fund was in trouble and dumping stocks.

headline: Judge Rules for the City in Gun Sting of Dealers
text: A federal judge in Brooklyn ruled on Friday that the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg did not break the law in conducting sting operations meant to catch out-of-state gun dealers making illegal sales.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In South Carolina, Race Seen Through Economic Lens
text: ORANGEBURG, S.C.  Officially, the state of South Carolina calls the fancy new building the Orangeburg Workforce Center. Around here, people know it as the unemployment office. And everyone in Orangeburg County, it seems, can tell you how to get there.

headline: Inspired by Remark, Weir Has Slim Lead
text: ST. PAUL  Similar senses of relief enveloped Johnny Weir and Evan Lysacek after their short programs at the United States Figure Skating Championships. Weir put his hand over his heart and made a sign of the cross, although he admits to not being particularly religious. Lysacek, the defending champion, brought his hands to the sides of his head and later said to reporters, “Jesus was with me today.”

headline: Pakistani Official Dismisses Concerns Over Nuclear Security
text: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan  A top Pakistani official dismissed on Saturday concerns over the safety and security of the country’s nuclear program but said there was increased security alertness around its nuclear weapons and facilities given the recent political turmoil and militant violence in the country.

headline: Too Much Jersey Rock
text: The first Vineland Festival, to have been held southeast of Philadelphia in Vineland, N.J., has been postponed because of competition from the newly announced All Points West at Liberty State Park in Jersey City. “Due to the overall festival traffic in the Northeast and big bands touring through this area at the same time, co-producers Festival Republic and C3 Presents have decided to step back and launch Vineland in 2009,” organizers said in a statement. Vineland had been scheduled for Aug. 8-10, the same dates as All Points West, which is being organized by the promoters behind the Coachella Music Festival in Southern California.

headline: For Police Fix-It Man, a Scandal to Work On
text: Police officers sum up different bosses in different ways.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart with the continuation of a front-page article on Wednesday about high mercury levels found in tuna sushi in New York stores and restaurants referred imprecisely to what the Environmental Protection Agency deems to be an acceptable level of mercury consumption over a period of several months by an adult of average weight. The agency uses the phrase “reference dose” to refer to the daily level of mercury consumption it considers acceptable for a long-term diet; it does not use the phrase “weekly reference dose.” (To find the acceptable weekly level of consumption over the long term, the reference dose is multiplied by seven.)

headline:
Where the Ice Bowl
Meets the Ice
text: OSHKOSH, Wis.  The home of the Otter Street Fishing Club is Jerry’s Bar, family owned since 1911, nestled in a neighborhood a few blocks from frozen Lake Winnebago.

headline: Networks Ponder Poststrike Landscape
text: Scripts have been junked, pilots have been canceled, deals with writers have been wiped off the books, and almost no one in the television industry has been able to make any plans during the past three months.

headline: Actor’s Body Is Leaving New York for Burial in Australia
text: The body of the Australian-born actor Heath Ledger was taken from a Manhattan funeral home on Friday, and police officers who had been assigned to the funeral home said the body would be flown to Australia for burial.

headline: A Battle of Mind Over Mishaps
text: ASPEN, Colo.  In the moments before a snowboardcross race, Peter Foley, the United States snowboard coach, has found that sometimes the best way to help Lindsey Jacobellis is to distract her.

headline: Violence Continues in Kenya a Day After Talks
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The political bickering continued in Kenya on Friday, and so did the violence, with young men in gangs from opposing ethnic groups killing one another in the streets with machetes and bows and arrows.

headline: Texas: Ex-Chief of Norris Charity Pleads Guilty
text: The former chief executive of Chuck Norris’s martial arts program for inner-city children has pleaded guilty to stealing from the Houston charity, the United States attorney’s office said. The executive, James D. Brasher, 47, pleaded guilty on Thursday to one count of uttering a forged security, the office said in a statement. Mr. Brasher confessed to opening bank accounts in names similar to that of Mr. Norris’s Kick Drugs Out of America Foundation, then fraudulently endorsing checks sent to the foundation and depositing them into his own accounts, the office said. Mr. Brasher is scheduled to be sentenced in April.

headline: A Novice Filmmaker Profiles a ‘Lonely Man of Faith’
text: When the mail arrived one day in the late summer of 2004, Rabbi Jacob J. Schacter found a large envelope bearing the return address of one Ethan Isenberg. Rabbi Schacter vaguely remembered a young man by that name from his former synagogue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a young man who was working as a computer programmer.

headline: Obama Wins South Carolina Primary
text: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Senator Barack Obama won a commanding victory over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the South Carolina Democratic primary on Saturday, forging a coalition of support among black and white voters in a contest that sets the stage for a state-by-state fight for the party’s presidential nomination.

headline: Mixed Messages
text: Iran sent an unusually high-profile delegation to the World Economic Forum this year. Among those rubbing shoulders with Western politicians and business leaders this week are Foreign Minister Manouchehr Mottaki, pictured above, and Seyed Samare Hashemi Shajareh, first adviser to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad himself. Another example: Mohammad-Bagher Ghalibaf, the mayor of Tehran and a possible contender for Iran’s next presidential election.

headline: Edwards Aide Clarifies Health Care Stance
text: In an interview with The Times about health policy on Wednesday, former Senator John Edwards said that his proposal to require all legal United States residents to have health insurance did not include a hardship exemption. Such an exemption, which exists in Massachusetts, the only state to mandate insurance coverage so far, would allow the granting of waivers to those who cannot afford premiums, even after they are heavily subsidized by the government.

headline: Brian Cashman and Theo Epstein Talk Baseball
text: It wasn’t Brian Cashman Unplugged, but it was pretty close. When Cashman, the general manager of the Yankees, and Theo Epstein, his counterpart with the Red Sox, combined for a lecture at William Paterson University on Friday night, Cashman was the chattier and more candid of the two.

headline: How Being a Woman Gets You Star Service
text: There has probably never been service like it! About 40 women congregated Friday night in the cozy wooden chalet restaurant of the Davos Golf Club and heard Queen Rania of Jordan, Sarah Brown (as in wife of Gordon, Prime Minister of Britain), Indra K. Nooyi, CEO of PepsiCo, Wendi Murdoch, the rock star Annie Lennox and the ”best dressed woman at Davos,” the former Nigerian finance minister Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, make powerful appeals for concerted action to cut down maternal mortality. Among those listening: Cherie Booth (as in wife of Tony Blair, Gordon’s predecessor), Ann Veneman of UNICEF and leaders of charities like Oxfam and Save the Children.

headline: Deal Professor Archives
text: We’re thrilled to announce that Steven M. Davidoff had joined DealBook as “The Deal Professor.” Davidoff is one of the most insightful and perceptive minds in the world of deal making. With an ability to distill the most complicated legal issues into clear prose, he has become a must read inside the nation’s boardrooms and corner offices.

The Rangers will play the European champions, Metallurg Magnitogorsk of Russia, as well as SC Bern, who are the current runaway leaders of the Swiss Nationalliga A.

headline: Song Getting the “Once” Over
text: The original song category for the Oscars has already hit its share of clanky notes, what with none of Eddie Vedder’s breathtaking songs for “Into the Wild” making the cut. And now comes quiet word that “Falling Slowly,” the achingly pretty song from “Once” written by Glen Hansard and Marketa Irglova, may be ruled ineligible. The Bagger has been making some calls and there are indications that that the song, which is up against three, count ‘em three, songs from “Enchanted” in addition to “Raise It Up” from “August Rush,” may have some problems with eligibility requirements. Post nominations, this tempest could set the teapot to boiling. (There is a lot of seemingly well-informed speculation in the comments, so give a click for more info.)

headline: 11 Connecticut Unions Endorse Clinton
text: BERLIN, Conn. — In a strip mall off Route 71, a few dozen union members gathered in a local lodge on Saturday as 11 labor unions representing more than 80,000 workers endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. This afternoon, Mrs. Clinton’s campaign announced that she would visit Hartford, the state capital, for a campaign event Monday morning.

text: WEEHAWKEN, N.J. — In the windswept parking lot of a supermarket here on Saturday afternoon, most people seemed more eager to head for the grocery aisles or head back to their cars than to talk about Barack Obama‘s presidential campaign.

headline: Keeping Secrets Before Super Bowl
text: Tom Brady, the New England quarterback who may or may not have an ankle sprain, has been M.I.A. the last few days, at least publicly. For the second straight day on Friday he was not present in the locker room when reporters were allowed in, nor did he participate in the first several minutes of practice that reporters were allowed to watch. Coach Bill Belichick was evasive and coy about his quarterback’s status (and enjoying every minute of it), while the Patriots’ publicity department failed to provide any information on Brady’s condition.

headline: News Roundup
text: Headlines from the world of real estate:

headline: In Sickness and in Health, and in Overtime
text: Few Giants fans will forget where they were last Sunday when Lawrence Tynes’s overtime field goal went through the uprights at Lambeau Field. Our colleague Jim Luttrell was watching in a bathroom in Philadelphia during a wedding reception, a story he shares in Sunday’s paper.

headline: Pakistan's Talibanization
text: The man who until recently was Pakistan's most senior law enforcement official has criticized his government's failure to respond to the spreading Taliban insurgency.
