headline: Why has the Bush economy been so lousy? (part I)
text: OK, I’m trying to figure something out. One question we won’t get answered in tomorrow’s State of the Union is why economic performance since 2001 has been a pale shadow of Clinton-era prosperity. In fact, it’s a question nobody in political life wants to answer. The administration and its supporters won’t admit that performance has been lousy; critics are happy simply to point out how bad things have been, and blame Bush.

headline: Romney Goes Casual
text: SWEETWATER, Fla.—A buzz went through the press corps when Mitt Romney showed up at a Cuban-American community center here on the outskirts of Miami this morning.

headline: Local Obama Backers, Eyes Turned South
text: To an even greater extent than Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s, Senator Barack Obama’s campaign effort in New York appears to be relying in large part on a profusion of small gatherings, like dinner parties and meet-ups at local bars. The Obama campaign’s Web site called on Saturday for supporters to gather at Minton’s Playhouse, a well-known restaurant and nightclub at 208 West 118th Street, near Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard in Harlem, to watch as the results from the South Carolina Democratic primary were captured on television. Rob Bennett, a photographer for The Times, captured these images in the moments during and after Mr. Obama’s victory speech.

headline: For Some Harlem Voters, Clinton’s Experience Is Key
text: A day after Barack Obama‘s decisive victory in South Carolina, propelled by overwhelming support among black voters, it remained an open question whether Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton would be able to hold on to her African-American base in New York.

headline: At City Hall, a Rousing Rally for Obama
text: Senator Barack Obama was nowhere in sight, but the more than 300 people who gathered on the steps of City Hall in Lower Manhattan on a chilly Sunday afternoon were clearly as energized as if the Illinois senator had been there in person.

headline: Spreading economic misinformation
text: Mark Thoma and Brad DeLong are right: this is a crime by the Washington Post against its readers.

headline: Of Glamour and Gravitas
text: Tonight, you will likely hear some brave political speeches from the Screen Actors Guild membership, wagging a finger about the writers’ right to participate in the fruits of their labors, but a little historical perspective might have you reaching for the shaker of salt. This is the bunch, after all, that chose Ronald Reagan as its president. And Patty Duke. And Ed Asner. Notice a trend here? The Bagger doesn’t either. The only flag the Screen Actors Guild flies with any consistency is one with a finger to the wind on it. Harsh? Well, in 1953, the Screen Actors Guild decided to take a rigorous stand on blacklisting: Some 96 percent of their members voted in favor of making members sign a “loyalty oath.” They said they were sorry, oh, 50 years later. This glittering assembly of human jewelry, a delight to behold on screen and on the carpet, has all of the subtlety and not much of the homework of Michael Moore, who is fond of dishing out the brussel sprouts when it comes to making acceptance speeches.

headline: Red Carpet Real Estate
text: The Gold Rush blog at the Hollywood Reporter has noted that demand for inane, stand-up Q&As is up. Because of the glitter outage at the Golden Globes, press officials at the Screen Actors Guild have lengthened the red carpet at the Shrine Auditorium by 20 feet to accommodate all of the banal questions that were left over from events that had to without, thanks to threats of picketing by the striking Writers Guild of America.

headline: Senators Lieberman, Martinez Stump With McCain
text: THE VILLAGES, Fla. — The town hall meeting here, at the Savannah Center, was jammed to the rafters. People were standing around every single wall and streaming outside the door.

headline: Free at Last
text: Turns out everybody has used the strike to, yes, ‘spend more time with their family.” Talking with E! on the red carpet, Tina Fey of “30 Rock” said she had spent a lot of quality time with her daughter. But not that she minded going to the SAG awards.

headline: Giuliani Hangs Loose
text: COCOA BEACH – After a low-energy day or two, he seemed amped. Perhaps even stoked. And, despite some gnarly polls, not remotely concerned about a wipe-out.

headline: Bourne Lucky
text: “The Bourne Ultimatum” picked up the chit for best film stunt team in an announcement that preceded the show. “24” won for television stunt dudes and dudettes. This is the first time the SAG Awards has given out award for the people who nearly kill themselves, or at least look like they do, to get movies and television made. The Bagger is one for one on his picks, a nice trend that.

headline: Clinton’s Kennedy Backers
text: News of Kennedy support for Senator Barack Obama has prompted the campaign of Senator Hillary Clinton to issue a reminder that it has support from Kennedys too.

headline: Belly Up
text: Ellen Page, the 20-year-old star of “Juno,” did not know “whose shoes” she was wearing, bringing shame and umbrage from the red carpet crew at E!

headline: GUM: A Piece of Soviet History, Turned Mall
text: My first visit to GUM, the shopping arcade on Red Square just opposite Lenin’s Mausoleum, was hardly auspicious. It was 1988 and I was in the Soviet Union with my mother and sister. It was sweltering and we desperately wanted a drink. Sounds easy enough, especially since we spoke fluent Russian.

headline: Striking. A. Pose.
text: What is the appropriate mien for a potential winner at the SAG awards? A Nikki Blonsky freak-out would not seem to be appropriate given the fact that so many people are out of work, but then to go completely bummer and serious would seem not in keeping with the frothy spirit of the occasion. This being Hollywood, trust that someone will get both the mood and the zeitgeist completely wrong and clank one off the rim. Probably a TV person – the movie folks are much more carefully managed.

headline: What It All Means — and Doesn’t
text: In a year when all five Oscar nominees for best picture would seem to have a shot — and the muted Golden Globes did little to clarify the picture — the Screen Actors Guild awards would seem to have a huge role to play. But there’s just one small unhelpful fact: Only one of this year’s nominees for the best picture Oscars is in the running for the SAG ensemble award, which is how the actors settle on a best picture. “3:10 to Yuma,” “Hairspray,” “American Gangster,” and “Into the Wild” did not make it to the dance for the Big 5. Only “No Country for Old Men” garnered nominations from both the Screen Actors and the Academy.

headline: Whacked, but Still Winning
text: Early on in what Steve Carrell called “the most glamorous and exciting evening in the history of the world,” it was New Jersey proud early on at the SAG Awards. James Gandolfini and Edie Falco won male and female outstanding perfomance for their work in the final season of “The Sopranos,” and the entire cast won for outstanding performance by an ensemble.

headline: Stone Cold Killer
text: Javier Bardem, who won outstanding performance for a male actor in a supporting role, is so stone-cold handsome, he could just stand there mute at the microphone and people would adore him. But he came through with a classy speech on top of it all, making a sincere acknowledgement of his co-nominees – Casey Affleck, Hal Holbrook, Tommy Lee Jones and Tom Wilkinson – “whose performances will stay with us forever.” He also thanked his directors, the Coen brothers, for a very specific favor: ignoring “the takes where I really sucked.”

headline: Panama Controversy
text: One of the pioneer foreign developers in Panama is embroiled in a six-year legal controversy, which is heading to the country’s Supreme Court.

headline: Watching the Party End for Gazans in Egypt
text: Life in the Egyptian towns of Rafah and El Arish has been unusual since Wednesday, when thousands of Gazans streamed through breaks in the border wall. To get a feel for the situation on the ground, The Lede asked Nadim Audi, who has been contributing to The New York Times’s coverage, to write about what he saw over the weekend.

headline: Tasteful Tastemakers
text: The SAG Awards has been known to host its share of rhetorical excess in the past, but the discourse from the podium was remarkably chaste, with both James Gandolfini and Edie Falco, best actor and actress in a dramatic series respectively, giving very short speeches long on thank you’s. Tina Fey, who won for her role as Liz Lemon in “30 Rock,” compared her acting skills to “a hat rack” and was the first speaker of the night to address a strike that was very much on the mind of the audience of the event. She kept it short.

headline: Confessions of a Ninny
text: Would it be untoward for the Bagger to admit that he is happy to see famous people back at the microphone saying that “it’s about the work.” No surprise there, but there is something in the ritual of it, the kabuki of a rotating cast saying the same things over and over. One clanky note though: The SAG’s self-congratulatory infomercials, about the unions fight for racial tolerance, safety and worker dignity. All nice stuff, but as long as they are doing a historical tick-tock, they might want to mention that when the pall of a black-list hug over America, the union capitulated, throwing may of their colleagues under a bus.

headline: Back Office
text: T. L. Stanley is locked back in the press room where the Bagger would be if he were not on the wrong coast. But reading the Gold Rush blog is almost like being there. Better in fact.

headline: Relying On ‘The Gut Of The Programmer’
text: “What will television look like when the strike ends, and how is the next season going to be changed? Beyond the conviction that some scripted television series will be replaced by reality shows, network and production studio executives are expressing hope that one outcome of the strike will be a different, and much cheaper, process for getting scripted shows on the air,” Bill Carter reported in Saturday’s New York Times.

headline: Tone Poem
text: The SAG Awards, historically a B-List event populated by A-List actors, did a good job of filling in the glamour gap without being unseemly. The speeches have been short and tasteful, the strike and the effect it has had on working people in the industry was present, but did not overwhelm. Broadcast on TBS and TNT, the SAG awards will not provide the kind of marketing firepower that the Globes might have, had they not been downsized by the threat of pickets. The industry is in a middle place, with uncertainty abounding and no clear path to settlement at the negotiating table. So far, the SAG Awards have reflected the mood without seeming downright moody.

headline: Rock of Ages
text: Many people, prior to the show, reminded us that the SAG Awards tend to recognize a large body of work over many years, and so they have, giving Ruby Dee her first SAG award for her supporting role in “American Gangster.” The Bagger chose Amy Ryan for this category, and something tells him his Ellen Page pick in best actress ain’t looking so great right now. Right now, he’s 2-3.

headline: Beyond the Fringe
text: The South Carolina primary results were so amazing that it took me a while to notice that while a record-breaking number of voters were racing to the polls to take part in the historic Clinton-Obama-Edwards showdown, 240 Democratic voters had cast their ballots for Mike Gravel.

headline: Aiming Point
text: In the least surprising win of the night, Daniel Day-Lewis was named the best leading actor in a dramatic role. He was halting, smashing and affecting in receiving the award. Instead of merely saying he was humbled, he clearly demonstrated it. “It has always been the work of my fellow actors, including my fellow nominees, who have given me a sense of regeneration.”

headline: March of the Barbies!
text: The red carpet at the SAG Awards tonight looked surprisingly scripted, even by red carpet standards. Did the stylists and publicists get together and decide that (nearly) every actress should go strapless? Maybe my tube was small, maybe there were too many people and pets crowding in my kitchen on this Sunday night, but the view was predominantly of bare shoulders and bobbing bouffant heads. Oh, and a little slash of fabric representing the bodice & cleavage of a dress. The camera angles could be lascivious. In the strapless contingent were Cate Blanchett, Kate Beckinsale, Vanessa Williams, Angelina Jolie, Michelle Pfeiffer, Sandra Oh, and Teri Hatcher. Though I couldn’t see all of her dress, Ellen Paige looked smart, I thought, in a black Zac Posen dress with a v-neck and short kimono sleeves, especially with her smooth hair. Debra Messing’s gold Oscar de la Renta dress at least had some kind of interesting neckline on an evening of what amounted to table-top dressing.

headline: A Knockout
text: Julie Christie took the stage to accept her award for outstanding actress in a leading role, as an Alzheimer’s patient in “Away From Her,” and reminded anybody who was in the room or tuning in that beauty sometimes matches and endures along with talent. She said that her win and the movie were “a reminder of how important unions are.” She went into a long tick-tock of thank yous, most effusively the film’s director, Sarah Polley, but then added, “If I have forgotten anybody, it’s just because I am in character.”

headline: Sticking It to The Man, Whoever That Is
text: Josh Brolin has had a big year, what with his turns in both “No Country for Old Men” and “American Gangster.” On screen, he frequently seems as if he might explode, sending human shrapnel in all direction. On stage? About the same. He was langorously making his way through thank yous when Woody Harrelson came over his shoulder to remind him to thank the Coen brothers; Brolin told him to “back off.”

headline: Beyond the Fringe
text: The South Carolina primary results were so amazing that it took me a while to notice that while a record-breaking number of voters were racing to the polls to take part in the historic Clinton-Obama-Edwards showdown, 240 Democratic voters had cast their ballots for Mike Gravel.

headline: Tall Money
text: Rugrats by the handles of Warrior Ant and Christopher nailed four out of five in the SAG Awards — missing only Ruby Dee, earning them much respect and one dollar a piece. Congrats boys and girls, or animal and vegetable, or whatever you are behind the commenting avatars. Nicely done. The Bagger got four out of six, because he picked stunt too, but take that away and he was three out of five, sort of miserable, actually. He went with the youth brigade — Any Ryan and Ellen Page — while it was experience and guile — Ruby Dee and Julie Christie — that took home The Actor statue. Nice tidy night, good balance of glam and gravitas. And how ’bout that Josh Brolin? We’ll have what he’s having, some kind of substance that makes you see the world as your own little plaything. “This is my fricking moment.” Hope it was fricking swell and thanks for, um, sharing, Josh.

headline: Does Constitutional Theory Matter?
text: While we are still in the primary season, the quarrels candidates have are largely intramural. Republicans argue about who is tougher on immigration and who will cut more taxes. Democrats argue about who will get us out of Iraq quicker and whose health plans covers the most people. But once the nominations are settled, the focus will shift to the differences between the two parties, and issues that have been on the back burner for a while will come front and center.

headline: Stars Come Out at the Annual Writers’ Dinner
text: I just got back from the 85th annual dinner of the New York chapter of the Baseball Writer’s Association of America. There were three-plus hours of baseball talk and not a single mention of steroids or salaries. Hallelujah!

headline: Hedge Fund’s Letter Explains Intentions Regarding The Times
text: One of two hedge funds seeking to name directors at The New York Times Company sought on Sunday to clarify its intentions for the newspaper publisher, saying it wanted the company to sell some assets and focus on digital publishing.

headline: A Little Bit County, a Little Bit Coloratura
text: How is a Broadway golden girl to proceed when the whole world appears to be at her beck and call? That is the treacherous question facing Kelli O’Hara, the luminous star of two successive hit shows (“The Light in the Piazza” and the revival of “The Pajama Game”) and an imminent production of “South Pacific.”

headline: The College Admissions Frenzy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Children of Immigrants
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pathologist Accused of Profiting From Office
text: PITTSBURGH  By his own count, Dr. Cyril H. Wecht, one of the nation’s foremost forensic pathologists, has testified in more than 1,000 civil and criminal trials in his 46-year career, and opined on thousands more on television, on radio and in print.

headline: McCain and Romney Trade Sharp Attacks
text: Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney traded blistering attacks in Florida on Monday morning, a day before the state’s Republican primary.

headline: Directors Acclaim Coen Brothers
text: Joel and Ethan Coen woke up on Sunday as the favorites for the Academy Award for directing after being chosen best directors by the Directors Guild of America on Saturday night in Los Angeles for their latter-day western, “No Country for Old Men,” Reuters reported. Since the guild began honoring directors in 1949, only six of its choices have failed to win the Oscar . “It’s nice to get the acknowledgment of critics and even audiences, but there is something about being acknowledged by people who do the same thing you do,” said Joel Coen, above right, who has joined his brother, in cowboy hat, in making films like “Fargo” and “Blood Simple” in the last 25 years. The last time the guild honored two men as best feature-film directors was 1961, when the winners were Robert Wise and Jerome Robbins for “West Side Story.” “No Country for Old Men” has been nominated for eight Academy Awards.

headline: Despite Housing Slide, Real Estate Sites Sell
text: TALK about an uh-oh moment.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition of works by Richard Diebenkorn at the Grey Art Gallery at New York University misidentified the site of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery, which organized a Diebenkorn retrospective in 1976 in which a work at the Grey Gallery, “Untitled (Albuquerque),” was shown. It is in Buffalo, not Rochester.

headline: Washington Post Starts an Online Magazine for Blacks
text: In attempt to broaden its online audience, The Washington Post Company on Monday is to introduce an online magazine primarily for a black audience, with news and commentary on politics and culture, and tools for readers to research their family histories.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Chief of Sears to Step Down
text: Wanted: a retail chief who can do more with less  and save Sears.

headline: Charges Are Sought Against French Trader
text: PARIS  Jerome Kerviel, the former Société Générale employee at the center of the biggest trading fraud in history, has confessed to police that he hid his activities from superiors, and he gambled in the markets because he wanted to be a star trader, the Paris prosecutor said Monday.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Rob Cristo joined Sawchuk Brown Associates, Albany, as an account executive. He had been a reporter at The Record, Troy, N.Y., part of the Journal Register Company.

headline: Footnote
text: The Whitney Museum of American Art at Altria will close on Tuesday after 25 years of presenting new work by contemporary artists at 120 Park Avenue, at 42nd Street. The closing of the branch, which was expected, comes as Altria, formerly the Philip Morris Companies, prepares to relocate its corporate headquarters from the site.

headline: New CDs
text: VAMPIRE WEEKEND

headline: Clinton’s Camp Seeks Gentler Role for Ex-President
text: Democrats inside and outside the Clinton campaign on Sunday debated and in some cases bemoaned the degree to which former President Bill Clinton’s criticism of Senator Barack Obama last week had inflicted lasting damage on his wife’s presidential candidacy.

headline: Homeowners and the Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Manhattan: Schumer Says F.A.A. Plans to Move Jobs
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer said on Sunday that the Federal Aviation Administration was considering transferring nearly 100 engineering jobs for the region’s three major airports to Atlanta within months. The senator criticized any transfer, saying such jobs are crucial to installing new technology to improve safety and reduce delays. The possible transfer of jobs at the F.A.A.’s eastern regional office in Jamaica, Queens, is part of the agency’s nationwide consolidation plan, Mr. Schumer said. Jim Peters, a spokesman for the F.A.A., said on Sunday, “There’s been no official announcement, or plans, that additional staff will be transferred.”

headline: Another Rolex Win for Ganassi Team
text: Juan Pablo Montoya teamed with Dario Franchitti, Scott Pruett and Memo Rojas to give Chip Ganassi’s team an unprecedented third consecutive victory in the Rolex 24-Hour race in Daytona Beach, Fla.Other than a minor handling problem for Pruett at the start of the race Saturday afternoon, the team’s No. 01 Lexus Riley Daytona Prototype was almost perfect, racing at or near the lead in the race, which until its waning hours was the most competitive in the event’s 46-year history.At dawn on Sunday, with about six hours to go, there were five other prototypes on the lead lap. But as often happens in endurance events, attrition took its toll.The Ganassi car had been swapping leads with the Ford Riley shared by Nascar’s A. J. Allmendinger, Ian James, Burt Frisselle and John Pew. The Ford Riley car, driven by Frisselle, was only seconds behind the leader when a tire blew, damaging the suspension midway through the 21st hour and knocking it out of contention.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about the Canadian military’s secret action to stop transferring prisoners to Afghanistan’s government after Canadian monitors found evidence that they were being abused and tortured misspelled the surname of the leader of the British Columbia Civil Liberties Association, one of the groups seeking an injunction to block more transfers. He is Jason Gratl, not Gretl.

headline: A Shelter Is Built Green, to Heal Inside and Out
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Although he will not be moving from the dilapidated homeless shelter here for another week, Paul McClendon, 55, has his oversized baby-blue garbage bags packed. Sitting on his bed in a winter jacket, he talked Thursday about the new, so-called green shelter with the central heating that he will be moving into.

headline: LeapFrog Hopes for Next Hit With Interactive Reading Toy
text: EMERYVILLE, Calif.-- LeapFrog Enterprises needs a knockout hit.

headline: Martz Trailways Bus from Mount Pocono, Pa., to the Port Authority in Manhattan
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Novel to Screen to Stage: Evolving, Step by Step
text: In London the award-winning theatrical comedy is billed as “John Buchan’s The 39 Steps.” But on Broadway, where the British import opened this month, it is called “Alfred Hitchcock’s The 39 Steps.” Is it possible that Buchan, who published his novel “The 39 Steps” in 1915, is better known in Britain than Hitchcock, the cinematic master of suspense who in 1935 made his film adaptation of that novel into one of the triumphs of his early London period?

headline: Briton Opposed by Afghans Won’t Take U.N. Post
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  The British politician Paddy Ashdown withdrew his name from consideration for the post of United Nations special envoy to Afghanistan on Sunday, after being rejected by President Hamid Karzai in what was widely seen as a move to assert his authority against Western control.

headline: Russia Bars Opposition Candidate From March 2 Ballot
text: MOSCOW  The Russian government on Sunday denied an opposition leader’s application to appear on the March 2 presidential ballot, clearing a path for the Kremlin’s favorite candidate to run all but unchallenged.

headline: Ta-ta! Give ’Em the Old Existential Soft-Shoe
text: PRINCETON, N.J.  As he approaches his 80th birthday, Edward Albee, that most distinguished of American dramatists, is being seriously silly. Or is it sillily serious? Sillily  that can’t be right. Isn’t that one of a group of islands off the coast of England? Or do I mean the ingénue from “The Importance of Being Earnest”? Am I making any sense at all?

headline: Michael Abbott, Producer,  Is Dead at 81
text: Michael Abbott, a television, film and theater producer who was bringing a revival of “Stalag 17” to Broadway 57 years after producing its premiere Off Broadway, died Thursday in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: A Sweet Sundae? No, It’s Primaries
text: Super Duper Tuesday sounds like a special mealtime offering at Friendly’s or Applebee’s. But it is an expression coined last February by Bill Schneider, CNN’s senior political analyst, during a discussion on “The Situation Room” about the crowded calendar for presidential primaries.

headline: McCain, Long a G.O.P. Maverick, Is Gaining Mainstream Support
text: LADY LAKE, Fla.  Is John McCain, the maverick flyboy of the Republican Party, becoming the candidate of the Republican establishment?

headline: 19 Burned to Death in Violence in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ethnically driven violence intensified in Kenya on Sunday, and police officials said at least 19 people, including 11 children, were burned to death in a house by a mob.

headline: No Campaigning but Much Debate Over Florida
text: MIAMI  One of the big disputes taking place between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama these days is over an election that is  or is not  taking place here on Tuesday: the Florida Democratic primary.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded 6,938,431

headline: With a Whisper, Cuba’s Housing Market Booms
text: HAVANA  Virtually every square foot of this capital city is owned by the socialist state, which would seem sure to put a damper on the buying and selling of property.

headline: 13 Arrested in Push to Stifle Turkish Ultranationalists Suspected in Political Killings
text: ISTANBUL  In one of the biggest operations against Turkish ultranationalists in decades, the authorities announced on Saturday night that they had arrested 13 people who were part of a criminal group that was suspected of carrying out political killings and having shadowy ties to the Turkish state.

headline: U.S. Stocks Recover After Sell-Off Abroad
text: An early tumble gave way to a modest rally on Wall Street on Monday, as American investors shrugged off heavy losses in the Asian markets and sent stocks steadily up in the afternoon.

headline: Should Bankers Pay for Their Mismanagement?
text: What is to be done with the bankers? From the savings and loan meltdown in the 1980s to the current housing-led seizure, financial institutions have proved unable to curb their appetite for risky assets  blowing up the bank and spreading economic mayhem.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A television review in Weekend on Friday about the Fox game show “The Moment of Truth” misstated the amount of money a contestant won on the show “Deal or No Deal” on Wednesday night in comparing “The Moment of Truth” with other game shows. The contestant, Britney Lewzader, won $471,000, not $1 million.

headline: For the Record
text: An editorial on Jan. 13 about Eli Broad incorrectly described the arrangements he announced for his private art collection. Mr. Broad will put it into his existing foundation, which will control the art. He did not create a new foundation for that purpose.

headline: Majesty of Bach, With a Wild West Trip
text: There was no dancing at one of the best performances of Jerome Robbins’s “Goldberg Variations” that I have attended. I was late for the matinee. And as the score welled out into the First Ring lobby of the New York State Theater, I sat in the early afternoon sunshine and simply listened to the music in the company of the lobby’s giant Nadelman ladies. It was unexpected magic and perhaps forgivable considering George Balanchine’s famous observation that if you didn’t like the ballet you could just close your eyes and hear the music.

headline: When Neither A Nor B Looks Good
text: A study in The Journal of Consumer Research finds that people have more trouble choosing between bad alternatives than good ones. In one experiment, college students were asked to choose between a car with a poor warranty and one without air-conditioning. They took 26 percent longer to choose than students who were asked to pick between a car with good financing and one with a powerful engine.

headline: A Pan-American Welcome to Warm the Corazón
text: Alejandro Sanz strolled onstage at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, smiling appreciatively, maybe a little sheepishly. One of Spain’s biggest pop stars, he is a first-rate balladeer who has gradually expanded his reach, experimenting with the rich rhythms that have long underpinned even his gentlest love songs.

headline: In Death, Ex-Dictator Elicits Grief and Tributes
text: SOLO, Indonesia  _ Former President Suharto was buried in a family tomb on a sacred hillside here on Monday, one day after his death in Jakarta, embraced by many as a great leader despite his reign as a brutal and corrupt dictator.

headline: Bernstein’s New York: West Side and Beyond
text: In case you’ve forgotten: “New York, New York, it’s a helluva town!” Those words by Betty Comden and Adolph Green, borne aloft on the music of Leonard Bernstein, were wafted high into the stratosphere by the singers Gavin Creel and Kate Baldwin at the Allen Room on Friday evening.

headline: Disney Youth Don’t Bop; They’re Singing in Hindi
text: LOS ANGELES  How do you sing “bop to the top” in Hindi? If you are the Walt Disney Company, very carefully.

headline: Moon and Earth and Sky: A Festival’s Long Reach
text: Young Soon Kim, the founder and director of the White Wave modern dance company, has a thing for festivals. But there are usually several choreographers and performers who stand out in what are essentially showcase series. The Cool New York festival’s program on Friday, at the company’s John Ryan Theater in Brooklyn, opened on a high note with “359 Degrees,” a solo choreographed and performed by Ashley Lecille Suttlar. Set to music by Donny Hathaway, the dance communicated a deeply felt emotional state clearly and evocatively, through a strongly centered body that seemed drawn to the earth and sky from moment to moment.

headline: Bank Outlines How Trader Hid His Activities
text: PARIS  The French bank Société Générale, facing persistent questions over how a lone, junior trader could have instigated more than $7 billion in losses, acknowledged on Sunday that his activities prompted questions from risk managers several times last year, but that the bank never began an investigation because his explanations defused any suspicions.

headline: This Week’s Economic Reports
text: ECONOMIC INDICATORS A big week for economic news will be led off by the Federal Reserve’s announcement on interest rates on Wednesday and capped by the unemployment report for January. Other reports will include new home sales for December (Monday); durable goods for December and the Conference Board consumer confidence index for January (Tuesday); the first estimate of fourth-quarter gross domestic product and the ADP employment forecast (Wednesday); personal income and spending for December and the Chicago purchasing managers index for January (Thursday); and reports on unemployment for January, the Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index for January, construction spending for December and the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).

headline: Old Memories Look Better Through New Glasses
text: Sasha Meza lifted her tiny finger, delicately pointing herself out among her junior high school classmates in the yearbook. Her mother and grandmother shuffled through photographs that were spread across a heavy, dark wood table in the rectory of St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn  pictures of Sasha at the Special Olympics and at her eighth-grade prom, and some from past Easters of Sasha, her brother, Gabriel Samolyuk, now 5, and her sister, Sabrina Samolyuk, now 12.

headline: The Bush Who Got Away
text: AS George W. Bush prepares to deliver his final State of the Union address, it’s worth revisiting the first speech he gave to a joint session of Congress. His valedictory words tonight will provide an opportunity to reflect on the kind of president Mr. Bush was. The speech delivered seven years ago points to the very different sort of president he might have been.

headline: Real Estate Troubles Are Weighing on Florida Voters’ Minds as Primary Nears
text: ST. CLOUD, Fla.  Florida is a cultural patchwork. The Panhandle seems to have more in common with neighboring Alabama and Georgia than with Fort Lauderdale and Miami in the eclectic southern reaches of the state. The condo canyons on the coasts are worlds away from the sugar cane and orange plantations in the interior.

headline: Vetoing History’s Responsibility
text: President Bush’s threat to veto a bill intended to improve health care for the nation’s American Indians is both cruel and grossly unfair. Five years ago, the United States Commission on Civil Rights examined the government’s centuries-old treaty obligations for the welfare of Native Americans and found Washington spending 50 percent less per capita on their health care than is devoted to felons in prison and the poor on Medicaid.

headline: Waiter, Is That Mercury in My Sushi?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lieberthal Retires
text: Catcher Mike Lieberthal, 36, has decided to retire after a 14-year major league career with the Phillies and the Dodgers.The Dodgers declined the option they had on Lieberthal for the coming season. Lieberthal played in 38 games last season, hitting .234 in 77 at-bats.

headline: Tie Breaker Allows Lysacek to Defend Title
text: ST. PAUL  Nobody could have anticipated an ending like this. A tie breaker? In figure skating?

headline: Gordon B. Hinckley, Mormon Leader, Is Dead at 97
text: Gordon B. Hinckley, the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints who led Mormonism through a period of global expansion, died Sunday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 97.

headline: A Violation of Both the Law and the Spirit
text: RIPTON, Vt.

headline: Direct-to-DVD Releases Shed Their Loser Label
text: LOS ANGELES  If you missed the red-carpet premiere for the latest “American Pie” movie, you are not alone. There wasn’t one. “American Pie Presents: Beta House,” the sixth film in the popular comedy series, was sent straight to DVD.

headline: Echo of First Bush: Good Economy Turns Sour
text: WASHINGTON  Will George W. Bush be remembered as the president who lost the economy while trying to win a war?

headline: White Cruises to Win After a Near-Perfect Run
text: ASPEN, Colo.  With the snow and wind flying through the Elk Mountain Range, many of the riders in the halfpipe final at the Winter X Games on Sunday night were somewhat grounded. But not Shaun White.

headline: Kennedy Chooses Obama, Spurning Plea by Clintons
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Senator Edward M. Kennedy, rejecting entreaties from the Clintons and their supporters, is set to endorse Senator Barack Obama’s presidential bid on Monday as part of an effort to lend Kennedy charisma and connections before the 22-state Feb. 5 showdown for the Democratic nomination.

headline: Former Assemblyman Spreads the Largess as a Lobbyist
text: ALBANY  Paul A. Tokasz, a former Assembly majority leader, has put his campaign war chest to work since leaving the Legislature to become a lobbyist.

headline: Brady Says Ankle Was Hurt on Sack
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Tom Brady and his right ankle arrived here for the Super Bowl on Sunday night, and with flashes from more than a dozen cameras going off just feet from him, he handled his first significant challenge of the week. Wearing brown wingtips, Brady, the Patriots quarterback, scaled the two steps to the podium with only the slightest limp and climbed down with apparent ease.

headline: Music in Review
text: ‘THE SONG CONTINUES’

headline: Four Days, a Therapist; Fifth Day, a Patient
text: Some things sound simply awful: a family reunion holiday cruise, an all-you-can-eat haggis buffet, a television series set entirely in a psychotherapist’s office.

headline: Bush Pledges Vetoes to Slow Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush will veto spending bills this year unless they cut in half the total amount of money earmarked for lawmakers’ pet projects, and he will order agencies to ignore future earmarks unless they are explicitly listed in the text of legislation, the White House said Monday.

headline: Eddie Sutton Chases 800th Victory, and a Brighter Legacy
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The story of how Eddie Sutton went from his home in Oklahoma to a hotel at Fisherman’s Wharf involves a bottle and a big round number.

headline: Stars Seize Their Chance to Shine at SAG Awards
text: LOS ANGELES  There is no show business without a show. And so, in a year when a writers’ strike has all but shut down much of Hollywood, the Screen Actors Guild Awards  as anonymous in most years as “Cop No. 3” in a summer blockbuster  took top billing Sunday and drew an inordinate amount of star wattage.

headline: Seeking Raw Beauty in Fluid Movement
text: Eduardo Vilaro was born in Cuba and grew up in the Bronx before he landed on his feet as a principal dancer with Ballet Hispanico in Manhattan. Now he’s conquered another city, but this time it’s not as a dancer. After receiving his master’s degree from Columbia College Chicago, Mr. Vilaro stayed put and formed a company, Luna Negra Dance Theater, which is dedicated to fostering the work of Latino choreographers.

headline: DNA Collection and Marijuana Arrests
text: To the Editor:

headline: Yemen’s Deals With Jihadists Unsettle the U.S.
text: SANA, Yemen  When the Yemeni authorities released a convicted terrorist of Al Qaeda named Jamal al-Badawi from prison last October, American officials were furious. Mr. Badawi helped plan the attack on the American destroyer Cole in 2000, in which 17 American sailors were killed.

headline: In Florida, Rivals Focus on Economy and Security
text: SWEETWATER, Fla.  Mitt Romney and Senator John McCain continued their tug-of-war Sunday over what should be the top concern of voters in the Florida Republican primary on Tuesday  the economy or national security.

headline: Students Click, and a Quiz Becomes a Game
text: GREAT NECK, N.Y.  The games had begun. In a darkened classroom at Great Neck South High School on a recent afternoon, the Advanced Placement physics students sped through a pop quiz, furiously pressing keys on hand-held clickers. A projection screen tracked their responses in real time, showing who knew what through an animated display of spaceships  individually numbered for each student  that blasted off or fell by the wayside with each right or wrong answer.

headline: After Djokovic’s Quick Ascent, It’s a Little More Crowded at the Top
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was early, very early, in the first set of Sunday’s Australian Open final when an Australian voice yelled out from high in Rod Laver Arena, “Let’s go Roger!”

headline: Target Tells a Blogger to Go Away
text: Target to the blogosphere: you’re irrelevant.

headline: Sundance Honors Immigration Drama
text: “Frozen River,” a first feature about a struggling single mother in upstate New York who joins a Mohawk widow in smuggling Chinese migrants from Canada into the United States, won the grand jury prize for best American drama on Saturday at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, The Associated Press reported. Quentin Tarantino, one of the jurors, described the film, starring Melissa Leo, above right, and Misty Upham, above left, as “a wonderful depiction of poverty in America.” Trade papers reported that Sony Pictures Classics had bought the film, adapted by Courtney Hunt from her 2004 short of the same title, for under $1 million. “Trouble in the Water,” a film by Tia Lessin and Carl Deal about a New Orleans couple’s survival through Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath, won the grand jury award in the American documentary category. The audience award for favorite American drama was won by “The Wackness,” starring Ben Kingsley as a psychiatrist who trades therapy for marijuana.

headline: Carrying Ball and Message: N.F.L. Rewards a 10-Year-Old
text: Jared Doutt, a football player from Erie, Pa., will be making his first Super Bowl appearance Sunday.

headline: California Governor’s Plan for Health Care in Trouble
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It has been a January to forget for Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California.

headline: Excerpts From Bush’s Speech
text: Following are excerpts from President Bush’s State of the Union address on Jan. 28, 2009, as prepared for delivery and provided by the White House:

headline: Kanye West’s Unexpected Rap
text: The audience at Flavorpill’s One Step Beyond party at the American Museum of Natural History in New York got a huge surprise on Friday night. During a set by the Chicago indie rapper Kid Sister in the Rose Center for Earth and Space, Kanye West, above, rushed onstage to rap along to her single “Pro Nails.” Afterward, to deafening cheers from the crowd, Mr. West and his D.J., A-Trak, performed a string of songs from his recent album, “Graduation,” including the radio smashes “Stronger” and “Good Life.” Mr. West wore a bulky fur coat, leading Kid Sister to quip, “Y’all look like my grandma.”

headline: Texas Ensemble Plants Flag in New York
text: To judge by the accented conversation and hearty glad-handing among audience members, there were a lot of Texans in attendance on Saturday night for the Carnegie Hall debut of the Fort Worth Symphony Orchestra. Still, that the hall was nearly full was a testimony to the growing reputation of this active regional orchestra, which maintains a year-round season, has built a $27 million endowment and draws loyal audiences to Bass Hall in Fort Worth.

headline: Fox Mashes Up the Supers
text: Fox is going to get an early jump on Super Sunday. At 9 a.m. E.S.T. next Sunday morning  more than nine hours before the coin is tossed  players and tactics will be scrutinized, coaches will get the once-over, and sideline savants will predict the outcome.

headline: Queens: Prison-Release Party Leads to Killing
text: The police said they found a man dead of a gunshot wound to the forehead shortly before 5 a.m. on Sunday in Hunters Point. The man was identified as Joseph Prince, 30, of 35th Avenue in Ravenswood, the police said. At a news conference on Sunday, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said people had been throwing bottles at each other before the shooting. “The party was a celebration of someone getting out of prison,” he said. Mr. Prince was found in front of 44-3 23rd Street, the police said. There were no arrests on Sunday, the police said.

headline: Bush Urges Quick Action on Economy
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush sought to reassure Americans about the economy on Monday night, declaring in his last State of the Union address that the United States would banish the specter of an imminent recession, provided that Congress acts quickly on the economic stimulus package laid out last week.

headline: Senate Panel Unveils Its Own Stimulus Plan
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate Finance Committee, moving to put its own stamp on a rescue plan for the ailing economy, unveiled a $156 billion fiscal stimulus package on Monday that would pay $500 to most individual tax filers and $1,000 to couples, with an additional $300 a child for families, with no income cap to disqualify high earners.

headline: No Survivors After Night Attack at Home of Baghdad Ex-Official
text: BAGHDAD  A band of attackers on Saturday night broke into the home of a man who was a senior Baghdad city official under the government of Saddam Hussein and shot and stabbed him and his family, killing everyone in the home, an Iraqi official said Sunday. The American military also disclosed the deaths of two United States soldiers in Baghdad, one on Saturday and the other on Sunday.

headline: Less Preening, More Fun and a Touch of Dignity at Awards Show
text: Some awards shows are born great, some achieve greatness and some are thrust upon us. Like England watching with trepidation in 1936 as an untried Duke of York replaced the abdicating Edward VIII, viewers enjoyed a happy surprise Sunday night.

headline: Mellencamp Channels Defiance and Dreams
text: Everyone could hear him when John Mellencamp leaned away from the microphone and declaimed a verse of “Minutes to Memories” virtually unamplified on Friday night. That doesn’t happen when he plays his usual theaters and arenas, but on this night he was leading his band at the Housing Works Used Book Cafe, which holds fewer than 200 people. It was the fifth anniversary concert for “Live From Home,” a series of benefits for the nonprofit AIDS service organization Housing Works that has steadily booked first-rate songwriters to play for audiences much smaller than their usual crowds.

headline: Brooklyn: Hate Crime Charges in Graffiti Cases
text: A Brooklyn Heights man arrested on Jan. 20 after a cache of weapons that included guns and pipe bombs was found in his Remsen Street apartment has also been charged with a hate crime in connection with swastika graffiti in the neighborhood, the police and prosecutors said on Sunday. The suspect, Ivaylo Ivanov, 37, left, was charged with criminal weapons possession, as well as with aggravated harassment as a hate crime. A second man, Pavel Andreenko, has also been arrested in connection with an unrelated spate of spray-painted swastikas last month around Flatbush and Sheepshead Bay, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, an auction of two-year notes on Monday and auctions of five-year notes and four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Amity May Give Bush a Lift
text: This week showcases an unusual role reversal: someplace else will look angrier and more dysfunctional than political Washington, at least for a moment.

headline: For Gay Democrats, a Primary Where Rights Are Not an Issue, This Time
text: The impromptu debate, over light beers and dirty martinis, was at once mundane and remarkable. Provoked by a reporter, four middle-aged men at a Greenwich Village gay bar made fiery pitches for the Democratic presidential front-runners. Two backed Senator Barack Obama, one argued for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, and the fourth made an emotional plea for the cause of John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina.

headline: Smitten by Lyon, a Visitor Tries to Recreate the Magic
text: LYON, France  Strolling the streets of Lyon with his wife last October, Buti Saeed al-Ghandi was suddenly overcome by a double wave of love, for the city and for his spouse.

headline: Suharto Dies at 86; Indonesian Dictator Brought Order and Bloodshed
text: Suharto of Indonesia, whose 32-year dictatorship was one of the most brutal and corrupt of the 20th century, died Sunday in Jakarta. He was 86.

headline: Cisco to Sell Faster Switch for Flood of Remote Data
text: Cisco Systems plans on Monday to introduce a network switch for corporations grappling with rapidly growing Internet data transfers and the increased use of applications that draw on remote data storage, known as cloud computing.

headline: Belichick Left the Giants, but They Haven’t Left Him
text: PHOENIX  They nicknamed him Captain Sominex back then, because even when he was first tasting the success that is now the norm for him, Bill Belichick had a monotone that sent Giants linebackers to their slumber in a darkened meeting room.

headline: Angola and Tunisia Win
text: Angola and Tunisia each won, 3-1, in Tamale, Ghana, to improve their chances of qualifying for the quarterfinals of the African Cup of Nations.Angola rallied to top Senegal, and Tunisia easily defeated South Africa.Angola and Tunisia play Thursday in their final first-round games; each will advance with a tie.

headline: In the Woods and Streams of New York State, an Artemis for Modern Times
text: WATERFORD, N.Y.  Patricia Riexinger, the new director of New York State’s Division of Fish, Wildlife and Marine Resources, stood in the falling snow here and peered through her binoculars, looking for bald eagles. Suddenly, a bird leapt from a tree and soared out of sight, and Ms. Riexinger, visibly excited, set off in pursuit, traversing streams and sloshing across muddy slopes.

headline: Too Easy to Refuse
text: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made Iran another offer it could refuse last week. Speaking in Davos, Ms. Rice said that the United States didn’t want Iran as a “permanent enemy” and that better relations were possible if Tehran would give up its nuclear fuel program.

headline: Lessons of 1992
text: It’s starting to feel a bit like 1992 again. A Bush is in the White House, the economy is a mess, and there’s a candidate who, in the view of a number of observers, is running on a message of hope, of moving past partisan differences, that resembles Bill Clinton’s campaign 16 years ago.

headline: SAG Awards: Reading Tea Leaves on Who’s the Latest Cup of Tea
text: What It All Means  and Doesn’t

headline: Once Synagogues, Now Churches, and Ailing Quietly
text: Jewell Cunningham’s year of exodus was 1953.

headline: A French Style of Capitalism Is Now Stained
text: PARIS  In a country where the hurly-burly of market capitalism has long been viewed with suspicion, Société Générale was a rare Gallic success story  the Chanel or Château Margaux of French banking.

headline: Spartans Victorious Over Rambo
text: “Meet the Spartans,” a parody starring Sean Maguire and Carmen Electra in yet another retelling of the historic battle against the Persians, barely outslugged Sylvester Stallone in “Rambo” to seize control of the No. 1 ranking at the weekend box office. In their debuts “Meet the Spartans,” distributed by Fox, pulled in an estimated $18.7 million, while “Rambo” (Lionsgate) came away with $18.1 million, the tracking company Media by Numbers reported. The romantic comedy “27 Dresses” (Fox), with $13.6 million, fell to third place from second last week. The monster movie “Cloverfield” (Paramount), on a gross of $12.7 million, plunged to fourth place from No. 1 a week ago. Fifth place went to the newcomer “Untraceable” (Sony), the horror thriller starring Diane Lane as an F.B.I. cyberwizard. It grossed $11.2 million.

headline: Is It a Recession? Marketers Seem to Think So
text: Let the economists and politicians debate whether the American economy is in a recession. Madison Avenue is already battening down the hatches.

headline: Bronx: D.W.I. Charge in Fatal Crash
text: A driver lost control of his Honda Accord early Sunday morning on the Major Deegan Expressway, crossing the center line and killing a passenger when the car slammed into a tree, the police said. The driver, Marcelo Uribe, 21, of Sleepy Hollow, was charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter, the police said. The accident occurred near Van Cortlandt Park about 4:20 a.m. A second passenger was in stable condition at St. Barnabas Hospital on Sunday. The passenger who was killed was not identified Sunday.

headline: F.E.C. Enforcement
text: To the Editor:

headline: Israel Vows Not to Block Supplies to Gaza
text: JERUSALEM Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel promised the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Sunday that Israel would no longer disrupt the supply of food, medicine and necessary energy into the Gaza Strip and intended to prevent a “humanitarian disaster” there.

headline: Names of Officers in Shooting Released
text: The names of four Westchester County police officers who were involved in the shooting death of an off-duty officer in White Plains on Friday were made public on Monday as the investigation into the shooting continued.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: A Composer Who’s 99 With Plenty to Celebrate
text: Perhaps it’s true that composers of formidably complex music, like Elliott Carter, are tough sells for mainstream audiences. That is why the scene at the Juilliard School on Friday night was so encouraging. Outside the school’s Peter Jay Sharp Theater a long line of people stood in the wintry chill, hoping to get tickets for the first concert of Focus! 2008: All About Elliott, the school’s free, weeklong festival devoted to music by Mr. Carter, interspersed with works by composers who influenced him and by sympathetic colleagues.

headline: A Lengthy Duel in France, Championship Berth at Stake
text: They work their players hard in France. The trial final to decide that country’s team for the 49th European Open Team Championship being played in June was over 200 boards, from Dec. 20 to 23.

headline: Kremlin Denies Ballot Spot to Putin Opponent
text: MOSCOW  The Russian government on Sunday denied an opposition leader’s application to appear on the March 2 presidential ballot, clearing a path for the Kremlin’s favorite candidate to run all but unchallenged.

headline: Shooting Highlights a Growing Gap in White Plains
text: A van pulls up outside the Westchester County Department of Social Services in downtown White Plains every weekday morning, discharging homeless men who live in a shelter five miles to the north. The men are brought there for appointments  with substance-abuse and mental-health counselors, or with social workers who hope to find them jobs  joining dozens of other poor people there in need of public assistance.

headline: Eastern All-Stars Win, and Fun Also Prevails
text: ATLANTA  For a game that does not mean anything in the standings, the N.H.L. All-Star Game generated a weekend-long referendum on the sport that seemed far too serious for an event that is supposed to be about fun.

headline: Diary Revisits American Tragedy
text: On March 30, 1908, Chester Gillette, 25, was executed at Auburn State Prison in New York for the murder of his pregnant lover, Grace Brown, on an Adirondack lake in 1906. His sensational trial inspired the Theodore Dreiser novel “An American Tragedy,” the 1951 film “A Place in the Sun” and an opera staged by the Metropolitan Opera. Now, as the 100th anniversary of Gillette’s electrocution approaches, Hamilton College has published “The Prison Diary and Letters of Chester Gillette,” taken from papers donated to the college last year by Gillette’s grandniece, Marlynn McWade-Murray, The Associated Press reported. The editors, Jack Sherman and Craig Brandon, said Gillette’s writings offer neither an explicit admission of guilt nor any clear assertion of innocence, but they do provide a window into his character and his metamorphosis in prison from a blithe youth into an introspective, compassionate, religious adult. In the penultimate entry in the diary, Gillette wrote: “In all that I have done, I hope I have done as men would have me do. I know that I am right with God, and that is the all important thing.”

headline: Paulson’s Deal-Making Revives Treasury’s Relevance
text: WASHINGTON  In his first two years as Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr. spent much of his time learning what his can-do pragmatism could not do.

headline: Kennedy Calls Obama ‘New Generation of Leadership’
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy implored Americans on Monday to “reject the counsels of doubt and calculation,” as he extended his endorsement and placed the aura of his family’s name around the presidential candidacy of Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Tuna Sales Halt Urged
text: OSLO (Reuters)  A global conservation group urged retailers on Monday to stop selling Mediterranean bluefin tuna as part of a move by several European supermarket chains meant to help the fish’s stocks recover.

headline: Manchester United Rallies
text: Manchester United rallied past visiting Tottenham, 3-1, in the fourth round of the F.A. Cup behind two goals by Cristiano Ronaldo.Carlos Tévez scored the other goal for United, which reached the Round of 16. United joined Chelsea, Arsenal and Liverpool in Monday’s fifth-round draw. Visiting Manchester City lost to the League Championship team Sheffield United, 2-1.

headline: Races Entering Complex Phase Over Delegates
text: MIAMI  The presidential campaign is entering a new phase as Democratic and Republican candidates move beyond state-by-state competition and into a potentially protracted scramble for delegates Congressional district by Congressional district.

headline: A ‘PG-13’ Rating, Despite the Haze
text: Has Hollywood’s get-tough stance on cigarettes gone up in smoke?

headline: Sales of New Homes Fell by 26% in 2007
text: The housing industry, caught in a maelstrom of sinking demand, rising foreclosures, and bulging inventories, is in its worst slump in decades, a growing body of economic evidence shows.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Friday about Evan G. Galbraith Jr., a former United States ambassador to France, gave an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of the former secretary of state who disagreed with Mr. Galbraith’s argument that political appointees made the best ambassadors. He is George P. Shultz, not Schultz.

headline: Lo Duca to Have Surgery
text: Nationals catcher Paul Lo Duca was scheduled to have surgery on his left knee Monday to repair what his agent called a minor meniscus tear. Lo Duca will need “an estimated 3-6 weeks for full recovery,” his agent, Andrew Mongelluzzi, wrote in an e-mail message Sunday.Lo Duca, a former Met who signed a one-year, $5 million deal as a free agent this off-season, hurt himself during a workout last week, the Nationals said Friday.

headline: Sallie Mae Settles Suit Over Buyout That Fizzled
text: Sallie Mae, the embattled student lending giant, reached a settlement on Sunday over its scuttled $25 billion buyout, ending months of legal fighting that had cast a cloud over the company, according to people briefed on the agreement.

headline: The Still-in-Danger Gray Wolf
text: One of the great wildlife management stories of our time is the reintroduction of the gray wolf to the Rocky Mountains. From a few dozen animals released in Yellowstone in 1995, the wolf population has grown to about 1,500 in Idaho, Montana and Wyoming. This remarkable comeback means that later this year the gray wolf will be removed from the list of endangered species, at which point its fate will be entrusted to federally approved state management plans that conservationists warn are unacceptably weak.

headline: Rahlves Earns Victory, but Says He Has Much to Learn
text: ASPEN, Colo.  After a year as an apprentice, Daron Rahlves has begun to figure out skiercross, his new discipline.

headline: Sales of HD DVD Players Plunge After Warner Move
text: LOS ANGELES  One week after Warner Brothers Entertainment announced that it was abandoning its support for the next-generation HD DVD format in favor of the Blu-ray high-definition format, consumers abandoned HD DVD.

headline: China Now Pays Troops Involved in Nuclear Tests
text: BEIJING  China has begun paying military personnel involved in nuclear tests, as part of its effort to improve benefits for veterans, the state news media reported over the weekend.

headline: Palm to Close Most of Its Retail Stores
text: Palm, the smartphone maker that is losing sales to BlackBerrys and iPhones, will close seven of eight of its retail stores next month.

headline: Houston’s G.M. Is a Revolutionary Spirit in a Risk-Averse Mind
text: Daryl Morey has charts and spreadsheets and clever formulas for evaluating basketball players, and a degree from M.I.T. to make sense of it all. He would explain this mathematical wizardry, except that every few minutes his train of logical thought is interrupted by impulsive exclamations.

headline: Back on West Coast, Knicks Are Still Doing Anything but Coasting
text: OAKLAND, Calif.  Eddy Curry left Oracle Arena with many regrets Sunday night, though none of them related specifically to the 26 rebounds that were gathered by his waiflike counterpart on the Golden State Warriors.

headline: If You Can’t Win the Case, Buy an Election and Get Your Own Judge
text: “The Appeal” is John Grisham’s handy primer on a timely subject: how to rig an election. Blow by blow, this not-very-fictitious-sounding novel depicts the tactics by which political candidates either can be propelled or ambushed and their campaigns can be subverted. Since so much of what happens here involves legal maneuvering in Mississippi, as have many of his other books, Mr. Grisham knows just how these games are played. He has sadly little trouble making such dirty tricks sound real.

headline: Knoblauch to Talk With House Panel
text: WASHINGTON  Chuck Knoblauch will come to Washington on Friday to talk to congressional staff members about Roger Clemens’s challenge to the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball, the House Oversight committee announced Monday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about the Canadian military’s secret action to stop transferring prisoners to Afghanistan’s government after Canadian monitors found evidence that they were being abused and tortured misspelled the surname of the leader of the British Columbia Civil Liberties Association, one of the groups seeking an injunction to block more transfers. He is Jason Gratl, not Gretl. (Go to Article)

headline: Rapid Changes Since 2001 Cloud Outlook for Viewers
text: A few months ago, media companies were facing declining readership, flat advertising and the prospect of a damaging writers’ strike.

headline: From Prison, Encouraging Words for Giants’ Tynes
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Of the congratulatory telephone calls that Lawrence Tynes received after his field goal sent the Giants to the Super Bowl, the least unusual was the one from a 30-year-old inmate at the Forrest City Federal Correctional Institution in Arkansas.

headline: North Korean Orchestra to Visit England
text: On the heels of plans by the New York Philharmonic to perform in North Korea comes word that the 120-member North Korea State Symphony Orchestra is to play two concerts in England. The Guardian of London reported that after three years of planning and organizing, that orchestra will perform in September at the Royal Festival Hall in London and in Middlesbrough in northeast England. The visit was described as the “brainchild” of the opera singer Suzannah Clarke, who, in 2003, became the first British singer to perform in Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea. The newspaper said that she had suggested that her hosts invite other foreign musicians to North Korea and send its orchestra abroad. Ms. Clarke comes from Middlesbrough.

headline: New Campaign Tries to Butter Up Shoppers
text: A food brand with a funny name, which is known for funny advertising, is starting a campaign that offers a humorous look back at eating habits when Dwight and Mamie were in the White House, Dick and Dorothy were on the radio and Ozzie and Harriet were on TV.

headline: Stranger in a Strange Land Earns Himself an Encore
text: Derrick Braxton has six fingers on his left hand, but that’s only one of the reasons he had a circle of fascinated students gathered around him one day early in his first semester at college. A freshman at Finger Lakes Community College in Canandaigua, N.Y., Mr. Braxton was eating a salami and cheese sandwich in the school lounge last fall when a curious student stopped to chat and ask where he was from.

headline: Deadly Protests in Beirut Leave 7 Dead
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Deadly clashes erupted in Beirut on Sunday, leaving at least seven people dead and escalating Lebanon’s deepest political crisis since the end of its civil war in 1990.

headline: Desperate Husband
text: In the run-up to Saturday’s South Carolina primary, Bill Clinton repeatedly denounced racial divisions in American politics. Indeed, he said Friday in Spartanburg, Americans are “literally aching to live in a post-racial future.”

headline: Scientology Writes; Gawker Rises
text: “If Tom Cruise jumping on Oprah’s couch was an 8 on the scale of scary, this is a 10,” Nick Denton wrote on his media and gossip Web site Gawker.com on Jan. 15, when he posted an internal Church of Scientology video in which Mr. Cruise rhapsodizes about his religion. The page has been viewed over 2.3 million times, a record for Gawker.

headline: Woods Renews Attack on the Record Book
text: SAN DIEGO  Tiger Woods began his 2008 season by once again opening the golf history books and stepping inside. On a blustery Sunday at Torrey Pines Golf Course, Woods won the Buick Invitational by a tournament-record eight strokes for his 62nd PGA Tour victory, tying Arnold Palmer for fourth on the career list and moving within two wins of Ben Hogan.

headline: Merkel Party’s Edge Is Tiny in Crucial State
text: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative party limped to an anemic victory in the hotly contested election in the state of Hesse on Sunday. Her Christian Democrats could yet lose control of the state, depending on the outcome of coalition negotiations, for the first time in nine years.

headline: Beirut Violence Kills 7 and Wounds Dozens
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Violent clashes erupted Sunday in Beirut, leaving at least seven people dead and escalating Lebanon’s most serious political crisis since its civil war ended in 1990.

headline: Violence Spreads in Kenya, Killing 19 in Fire
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ethnically driven violence intensified in Kenya on Sunday, and police officials said at least 19 people, including 11 children, were burned to death in a house by a mob.

headline: Comptroller Audit Critical of Toll Increase
text: Thomas DiNapoli, the New York State comptroller, released a report on Sunday urging the state’s Thruway Authority to call off a toll increase that the agency had planned for July. The audit of the Thruway Authority says the agency should put off increases until it analyzes its expenses, operations and projects. The audit examined the calculations used in justifying proposed toll increases in July 2008, January 2009, July 2009 and January 2010. Mr. DiNapoli’s report recommended cutting costs, using a collection agency to collect unpaid E-Z Pass tolls, and prioritizing capital projects. “We disagree with the financial impact of the recommendations,” said Michael Fleischer, executive director of the authority. “We believe it would be just a fraction of the revenue necessary to continue making the proper investments in the highway.” Compiled by Denise Fuhs

headline: The Secret to (Synthetic) Life
text: You were expecting poetry perhaps? The secret messages hidden in scientist J. Craig Venter’s synthetic bacterial genome have now been revealed. They are  his name, and that of his research institute and co-workers.

headline: Sony Ericsson Sets Deals With 3 Labels
text: LONDON (Dow Jones)  Sony Ericsson announced content deals on Sunday with three of the world’s four top music labels, ahead of the introduction of its online music store in May.

headline: In Open Nomination, ‘Superdelegates’ May Hold Key to Victory
text: WASHINGTON  Not all Democratic presidential convention delegates are awarded like door prizes in the primaries and caucuses being so fiercely contested around the country.

headline: Inquiry Raises New Questions on French Bank
text: PARIS  New questions emerged Monday about Société Générale’s management after the bank’s former trader, Jérôme Kerviel, told French prosecutors that his fictitious trading started as far back as 2005  a year earlier than the bank has acknowledged  and that other employees also routinely exceeded their authorized trading risk limits.

headline: Former Patriots Coach Dies
text: Mike Holovak, a longtime N.F.L. executive who coached the Patriots to their first championship game, died Sunday, a few hours before the team left for the Super Bowl. He was 88.Holovak died in Ruskin, Fla., of complications from pneumonia, the Boston College spokesman Reid Oslin said after speaking with Holovak’s wife, Pauline Scudder Holovak. Holovak was a former football star and coach at Boston College.Holovak led the Boston Patriots to the American Football League title game after the 1963 season. They lost to San Diego, 51-10. Holovak had a 53-47-9 record as Patriots coach. Only Bill Belichick has more wins, with 105.Holovak later was vice president for player personnel and general manager of the Houston Oilers, a position he kept when the team moved to Tennessee to become the Titans.

headline: Bush’s Final Speech Recalls Presidents Past
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush’s final State of the Union address on Monday night was in some ways reminiscent in some ways of the speech given by his father 16 years ago.

Fortunately there is one, thanks to Egypt midfielder Mohamed Aboutreika, who lifted his jersey on Saturday after scoring against Sudan to reveal a T-shirt that read “Sympathize with Gaza”.

headline: Kellwood Lowers Defenses to Sun Capital Bid
text: Kellwood, the apparel company that makes the Baby Phat line of clothing, will remove all barriers to a cash tender offer of $21 a share made by the private equity firm Sun Capital so that the deal can be concluded if a majority of the shares are tendered, the company said on Sunday.

headline: Brinksmanship in the Kellwood Showdown
text: Last night the Kellwood board of directors did the most unusual thing. Throwing out their ’80s playbook, the board simply folded in the wake of Sun Capital‘s bid. The board announced that it intends to remove all impediments to the $21 per share hostile tender offer being made by the Sun Capital Securities Group. Kellwood said it would permit Sun to freely close its Feb. 12 tender offer if a majority of Kellwood’s shares are tendered into the offer.

headline: Resistant Bacteria, Football Players and Gay Men
text: Recent media reports about a new strain of resistant bacteria among men in San Francisco angered national gay rights groups concerned that the reports would create hysteria and a backlash against gay men. The university researchers who first announced the problem even issued an apology, saying their press release about the original study “contained some information that could be interpreted as misleading.”

headline: In January, Record Number of I.P.O.’s Are Pulled
text: Tumbling equity markets prompted 24 companies this month to halt plans for initial public offerings, the most in at least a decade.

headline: Smaller Banks See Opportunity, but History Is Skeptical
text: Despite the terrible time in leveraged finance some lenders see opportunity in the crisis. In fact, a few foreign banks are pushing to increase market share by capitalizing on the hobbled condition of the largest lenders stuck with billions in loan and bond commitments.

headline: Ranking the Top V.C.’s in the World
text: Putting money into a start-up company can be exciting, but at the end of the day, it’s the money you take out that matters most to a venture fund’s investors.

headline: Analyzing the M&A Boom
text: The M&A boom that defined the most recent business cycle may well prove the largest ever, especially for that rich M&A subset of leveraged buyouts. With about $4.5 trillion of companies bought and sold in 2007 alone, its sheer size is astonishing and unparalleled.

headline: In Palm, Elevation Still Hasn’t Found What It’s Looking For
text: In June, Elevation Partners announced that it was paying $325 million to buy a 25 percent stake in Palm in what the private equity shop termed “the largest investment that Elevation has ever made.”

headline: Nokia Dials Up Deal for Norway’s Trolltech
text: Nokia has offered 843 million Norwegian crowns ($153.3 million) for a software company, Trolltech, to support its new push to services and software operations.

headline: Fortis Shares Surge After Assuaging Investor Concerns
text: Fortis, Belgium’s biggest financial-services company, rose the most in almost 5 years in Brussels trading after the bank eased concerns about possible writedowns on subprime mortgage assets and raising new capital.

headline: Investcorp Technology Raises $500 Million for Third Fund
text: Investcorp Technology Partners, the technology buyout arm of the Bahrain-based investment firm, announced Monday that it had raised $500 million for its third fund, outstripping the $400 million it originally sought to raise.

headline: Swiss V.C. HBM Aims to Raise $137 Million in I.P.O.
text: A Swiss biotech investor HBM Bioventures plans to raise up to 150 million Swiss francs ($137.7 million) from its initial public offering next month, when it will also list all existing shares.

headline: Sallie Mae Settles Suit Over Failed Buyout
text: Sallie Mae, the embattled student lending giant, reached a settlement on Sunday over its scuttled $25 billion buyout, ending months of legal fighting that had cast a cloud over the company, The New York Times reported.

headline: Hedge Fund Urges Times Co. to Sell More Assets
text: One of two hedge funds seeking to name directors at The New York Times Company sought on Sunday to clarify its intentions for the newspaper publisher, saying it wanted the company to sell some assets and focus on digital publishing.

headline: Credit Squeeze Spurs Record Trading at Exchanges
text: While the rising number of delayed or canceled initial public offerings is certainly not good news for the world’s stock exchanges, the current gloomy market conditions seem to have a silver lining for them.

headline: Ex-Dow Jones Director Said to Settle With S.E.C.
text: David K. P. Li, a former board member of Dow Jones & Company, has reached a tentative agreement with federal securities regulators to pay more than $8 million to settle allegations of insider trading during last year’s takeover battle for the media group, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Loan Reviewer Aiding Inquiry Into Big Banks

headline: Saving Sears Doesn’t Look Easy Anymore
text: By all accounts, Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge fund manager whose investment savvy earned him renown as “the next Warren Buffett,” is a man not accustomed to rebukes.

headline: What’s $34 Billion on Wall Street?
text: Under the stewardship of Dow Kim and Thomas G. Maheras, Merrill Lynch and Citigroup built positions in subprime-related securities that led to $34 billion in write-downs last year. The debacle cost chief executives their jobs and brought two of the world’s premier financial institutions to their knees.

headline: Despite Credit Crunch, Vegas Deals Look Lucky

headline: Xstrata Close to Vale Bid, Report Says
text: Xstrata, the world’s fourth-largest copper producer, rose to a three-week high in London trading after newspaper reports that Companhia Vale do Rio Doce may agree to buy the company within the next few days.

headline: Bank Outlines How Trader Hid His Activities
text: The French bank Société Générale, facing persistent questions over how a lone, junior trader could have instigated more than $7 billion in losses, acknowledged on Sunday that his activities prompted questions from risk managers several times last year, but that the bank never began an investigation because his explanations defused any suspicions.

headline: Seeking Day-in-the-Life Bloggers
text: When I was deciding whether to go to law school, I read Scott Turow’s “One L.” Everyone did. You bought it along with your LSAT prep materials. Today, we still have memoirs that give a window into the life in a profession (like the recent “Diary of a Real Estate Rookie,” by Alison Rogers or Atul Gawande’s articles and books about a life in medicine). But if I were considering being a lawyer today, I’d be looking for blogs that offer a regular glimpse of a life in the law, like this one by Evan Schaeffer, offering tips and techniques for trial lawyers.

text: As billionaire Edward S. Lampert struggles to turn around the Sears Holdings Corporation, the company announced Monday that said its chief executive, Aylwin Lewis, will leave the company on Saturday.

headline: What Now for Societe Generale?
text: In a country where the hurly-burly of market capitalism has long been viewed with suspicion, Société Générale was a rare Gallic success story – the Chanel or Château Margaux of French banking.

headline: Will Scandal Force French Bank to Find a Dance Partner?
text: As details of how a rogue trader blew a $7.2 billion hole in Société Générale weigh on investor confidence in the leading French bank, analysts and industry observers wonder if a white knight might be necessary to restore the bank’s image.

headline: G.E. Dives for Tenaris Hydril Unit

headline: Both Neglect and Prosperity Threaten Houses of Worship
text: Churches, synagogues and other houses of worship that have played host to generations of immigrants are under threat throughout the city, either because of neglect in more impoverished areas or development in choice real estate markets, David Gonzalez reports. Preservationists and urban planners say that the concern over separation of church and state has made city officials generally reluctant to designate religious buildings as landmarks or to help them with funds for structural repairs.

headline: Cultural Imperialism at the W.H.O.?

One is a comment from Richard Shweder of the University of Chicago, who calls it “bureaucratic boilerplate” and says it’s further evidence that “identity politics has triumphed over science and critical reason at the W.H.O.”

headline: Binx and Mercer
text: Many relationships in “The Moviegoer” speak to the class divide in New Orleans and the South of the 1960s. Binx’s interchangeable secretaries, his Marcias and Lindas, all strapping country and suburban girls, are nothing like the delicately tuned Kate. His customers are assorted gangsters, bookies and working people, unlike the customers of the bond firm’s Uptown headquarters, who seem to be professional investors. His mother and her family are worlds apart from the Cutrers. (“As a Bolling in Feliciana Parish, I became accustomed to sitting on the porch in the dark and talking of the size of universe and the treachery of men; as a Smith on the Gulf Coast I have become accustomed to eating crabs and drinking beer under a hundred and fifty watt bulb — and one is as pleasant a way as the other of passing a summer night.”)
