headline: Agricultural Practices Found to Contribute to Bicarbonate in River
text: The Mississippi may be known informally as the Big Muddy, but it’s the Big Bicarbonate, too. It contains a huge amount of dissolved inorganic carbon in the form of bicarbonate, or HCO3-, ions, produced by chemical weathering of rock.

headline: They Age So Quickly, at Least in Tree Hill
text: The final moments of “One Tree Hill” last season raised questions, if not about the future of feminism, then certainly about feminism on teenage dramas on CW, the network that once offered a young Rory Gilmore with her Yale education and Martha Gellhorn journalistic dreams.

headline: Bush, Facing Troubles, Focuses on War and Taxes
text: WASHINGTON  Facing an unstable economy and an unfinished war, President Bush used his final State of the Union address Monday night to call for quick passage of his tax rebate package, patience in Iraq and a modest concluding agenda that includes $300 million in scholarship money for low-income children in struggling schools.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Articles on Wednesday about Fred D. Thompson’s withdrawal from the Republican race for president and about the candidates’ renewed focus on the economy carried incorrect datelines. The articles were written from Coral Springs, Fla.; there is no Coral Beach there.

headline: Blogs Becoming Regular Reading for Business Travelers
text: It may be a little late to the game, but business travel is now the subject of a variety of blogs.

headline: 4 Named in Shooting of Fellow Officer
text: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.  The authorities in Westchester County on Monday released the names and photographs of the county police officers involved in the shooting death of an off-duty officer from the nearby city of Mount Vernon.

headline: U.S. Markets Rally After Sell-Off Abroad
text: An early tumble gave way to a rally on Wall Street on Monday, as investors shrugged off heavy losses in the Asian markets and sent stocks steadily up in the afternoon.

headline: Less of a Draw, a Subdued Giuliani Stays Upbeat
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  For weeks, as he was getting shellacked in Iowa, New Hampshire, Michigan and South Carolina, Rudolph W. Giuliani, former front-runner for the Republican nomination, answered his skeptics with a simple refrain: just wait till Florida, his stronghold and his bulwark against the tide of losses in the early states.

headline: M Train From Fulton Street to Metropolitan Avenue-Middle Village
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: California Senate Panel Rejects Health Coverage Proposal
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In a blow to universal health care coverage in California and possibly to its prospects nationwide, a State Senate committee on Monday rejected a sweeping plan by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger that would have offered insurance to millions of uninsured residents.

headline: Knoblauch Will Talk to Committee; Agent Defends Clemens
text: WASHINGTON  The House oversight committee withdrew a subpoena of the former Yankees second baseman Chuck Knoblauch on Monday and said he had voluntarily agreed to speak to committee staff members on Friday about performance-enhancing drugs in baseball.

headline: California’s Unaffiliated Voters Are Sometimes Unreachable
text: LOS ANGELES  The conventional political wisdom in delegate-rich California is that the roughly three million registered voters without a party affiliation are ripe for the picking by the Democratic candidates for president.

headline: See Spot Run, Howl and Move to the Music
text: Mary Seidman has spent a lifetime watching dogs, to judge by her charming new “WeDOGS,” performed on Sunday afternoon at the Ailey Citigroup Theater. Dogs played, fought over chew toys, romanced their owners and taught their progeny good manners in this suite of nine dances, set to singularly well-chosen scores, including works by Edgar Varèse and Murray Weinstock. And Ms. Seidman found the perfect performers in seven company members, two guest artists and seven impressively un-self-conscious children.

headline: Free for Now, L.I. Man Aims for Law Degree
text: MINEOLA, N.Y.  Martin H. Tankleff, the Long Island man whose conviction was dismissed 17 years after he was found guilty of murdering his parents, has begun taking classes toward a bachelor’s degree at Hofstra University in Uniondale, N.Y., a family spokesman said Monday.

headline: Study Gives Key Role to Sleep in Helping Brain Learn Anew
text: Researchers who study the brain know that it’s far from an immutable object. “It’s much more plastic than most people think,” said Giulio Tononi, a psychiatrist at the University of Wisconsin. “It’s changing all the time.”

headline: Countrywide Chief Forgoes $37.5 Million in Exit Pay
text: The chief executive of the Countrywide Financial Corporation, Angelo R. Mozilo, will voluntarily give up $37.5 million in severance and consulting pay in connection with the proposed takeover by the Bank of America Corporation.

headline: Texas: Opponents of Border Fence Lose Round in Court
text: A federal judge ordered 10 Cameron County property owners to open their land to the government for border fence surveying, but not before he denied the government the right to take the land without a hearing. The judge, Andrew Hanen of Federal District Court in Brownsville, ordered 10 of the 12 landowners to comply with the government’s request for access to their land for 180 days. Brownsville residents, including Mayor Pat Ahumada, have been among the most vocal critics of the border fence, which President Bush and Congress have ordered built to stop illegal immigration and smuggling.

headline: Onetime Obama Donor Is Ordered Jailed
text: CHICAGO  A federal judge here revoked bond on Monday and ordered Antoin Rezko, once a major fund-raiser for Senator Barack Obama, held in jail after prosecutors accused him of lying to the court about his finances.

headline: In Tennis, Hardship and a  Hunger to Succeed
text: MELBOURNE, Australia  It was the morning after at Melbourne Park. The players’ lounge was empty of players. Men and machinery made loud noises as Rod Laver Arena began its transformation from the epicenter of tennis into a concert hall that will soon provide a stage for Hilary Duff and Iron Maiden.

headline: Gorbachev, Rebuking Putin, Criticizes Russian Elections
text: MOSCOW  Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the final leader of the Soviet Union, sharply criticized the state of Russia’s electoral system in remarks published Monday and called for extensive reforms to a system that has secured power for President Vladimir V. Putin and the Kremlin’s inner circle.

headline: Higher Costs May Curtail M.T.A. Work
text: Soaring construction costs could force the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to scrap plans for an architecturally ambitious glass-domed subway station in Lower Manhattan and lead to more than $1 billion in cost overruns for the authority’s major expansion projects, officials said Monday.

headline: Dangerous Cases of Cold Medicines and Children
text: Cough and cold medicines send about 7,000 children to hospital emergency rooms each year, the government said in its first national estimate. About two-thirds of the cases were children who took the medicines unsupervised. But about one-quarter involved cases in which parents gave the proper dosage and an allergic reaction or some other problem developed, the study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported. Less than two weeks ago, the Food and Drug Administration warned parents that over-the-counter cough and cold medicines were too dangerous for children younger than 2.

headline: Snowstorms in China Kill at Least 24
text: SHANGHAI  Severe snowstorms over broad swaths of eastern and central China have wreaked havoc on traffic throughout the country, creating gigantic passenger backups, spawning accidents and leaving at least 24 people dead, according to state news reports.

headline: North of Foxborough, Another Team Seeks Perfection in Obscurity
text: WALTHAM, Mass.  From a makeshift turntable in the corner of a gymnasium last week, a D.J. blasted staticky music during timeouts of a basketball game. The stands at the Dana Center, on the campus of Bentley College, were less than half full. Many people in the building, which also houses a student fitness center, did not bother to step away from their treadmills or weight benches to watch the game.

headline: Republican Senator to Retire
text: ALBANY  State Senator Mary Lou Rath, a Republican from Erie County, plans to retire, her staff said on Monday. It is the latest blow to the party’s efforts to hold its two-seat majority.

headline: Text of the Democratic Response
text: Following is a transcript the Democratic response given by Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas to President Bush’s State of the Union address, as recorded by Federal News Service:

headline: Chopin, With Progenitors and Progeny
text: Very little in the recital the pianist Richard Goode presented in the Rose Theater on Sunday evening strayed far from the core repertory for which he is best known. What made the concert compelling was his thoughtful sequencing. In a brief program note Mr. Goode called the concert “a kind of homage to Chopin.” In practice, this meant surrounding Chopin’s works with music by German forebears in the first half, and French successors in the second.

headline: Cellular Unit and Internet Stand Out for Verizon
text: That old phone cord is tying Verizon down.

headline: French Inquiry: Bank’s Inaction Grows as Issue
text: PARIS  The credibility of Société Générale’s management came under fresh scrutiny Monday after Jérôme Kerviel told French prosecutors that his fictitious trading started as far back as 2005  a year earlier than the bank had acknowledged.

headline: Safety: Nonstandard Work Shifts May Hinder Recovery
text: Patching up injured workers and sending them back to work after some time off and physical rehabilitation may be fine if they have ordinary jobs.

headline: French Bank’s Chief Faces Pressure to Resign
text: PARIS  The future of Société Générale’s chief and some of his closest lieutenants appeared increasingly precarious Tuesday as senior French politicians stepped up calls for top managers to resign over the rogue trader’s deals that cost the bank more than $7 billion.

headline: The Nature of Politics (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thousands of Miles From Home, and Possibly Carrying Avian Flu
text: Ornitholologists have long known that waterfowl migrate huge distances. But it is rarely possible to be sure where any flock’s route begins and ends  information useful to tracking the spread of avian flu.

headline: Paul Simon in Brooklyn
text: The music and lyrics of Paul Simon will be celebrated by the Brooklyn Academy of Music with three programs in April. The series, “Love in Hard Times: The Music of Paul Simon,” will begin with “Songs From ‘The Capeman’ ” (April 1-6), a concert staging of the 1998 Broadway show written by Mr. Simon, right, with lyrics by him and Derek Walcott. Among the performers will be Oscar Hernández and the Spanish Harlem Orchestra. The second program, “Under African Skies” (April 9-13), will focus on Mr. Simon’s passion for South African and Brazilian rhythms as reflected in the albums “Graceland” and “The Rhythm of the Saints.” Mr. Simon will be joined by David Byrne, Hugh Masekela, Milton Nascimento and others. The final program, “American Tunes” (April 23-27), will cover a wide range of Simon songs and feature Mr. Simon, the Brooklyn indie band Grizzly Bear, the bluesman Olu Dara, the Roches and others.

headline: Illegal Globally, Bail for Profit Remains in U.S.
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Wayne Spath is a bail bondsman, which means he is an insurance salesman, a social worker, a lightly regulated law enforcement agent, a real estate appraiser  and a for-profit wing of the American justice system.

headline: Margaret Truman Daniel Dies at 83
text: Margaret Truman Daniel, the president’s daughter whose achievements as a concert singer, radio and television host, and author of best-selling biographies and mysteries won her renown in her own right, died on Tuesday in Chicago. Mrs. Daniel, who had long lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was 83.

headline: No Charges for Most of the 32 Arrested on Way to Wake
text: When the police were criticized last spring for arresting 32 young people in Bushwick, Brooklyn, who were on their way to a wake for a friend who had been killed, they said the youths had been threatening public safety  blocking traffic, climbing on cars, wearing T-shirts and flashing signs in homage to their friend’s status as a gang leader.

headline: An American Builder’s Failures in Iraq Are Found to Have Been More Widespread
text: Rebuilding failures by one of the most heavily criticized companies working in Iraq, the American construction giant Parsons, were much more widespread than previously disclosed and touched on nearly every aspect of the company’s operation in the country, according to a report released Monday by a federal oversight agency.

headline: Board’s Theory on Bridge Collapse Facing Tough Sell
text: WASHINGTON  The National Transportation Safety Board’s working theory about last summer’s bridge collapse in Minneapolis, that it was caused by a design error 40 years ago, has run into a peculiar problem, because it contradicts public expectations.

headline: Sears’ Chairman Will Take a Step Back
text: Edward S. Lampert has a new strategy for Sears: less Edward S. Lampert.

headline: Grammys in Deal to Get Writers
text: LOS ANGELES  Striking film and television writers agreed on Monday to an interim arrangement with the producers of next month’s Grammy Awards that would allow the program to be written by members of the writers guild, the union said.

headline: A Call for Sharing (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Selanne Returns to Ducks
text: Teemu Selanne returned to the Stanley Cup champion Anaheim Ducks on Monday after missing the first half of the season while he contemplated retirement.Selanne, an unrestricted free agent, signed a one-year deal, then practiced with the team. The Ducks depart Tuesday for an 8-game, 15-day trip.Selanne followed Scott Niedermayer, the Stanley Cup M.V.P., in returning to the team. Niedermayer came back in December after pondering retirement, and he scored a goal in Sunday’s All-Star Game in Atlanta.Selanne, a 37-year-old right wing, had 48 goals and 46 assists last season. He ranked third in the N.H.L. in goals, led the league in power-play goals with 25 and tied for first in game-winning goals with 10.“I feel the passion again to play hockey,” Selanne said.

headline: Turbulence Is Predicted for New Chief in Thailand
text: BANGKOK  With the selection of Samak Sundaravej as prime minister on Monday, Thailand has completed a transition from military rule back to elected government. But analysts predict that the bumpy ride is not over for Thai politics: Mr. Samak’s tenure is likely to be tempestuous and his administration fragile.

headline: The Tug of War for America’s Heart
text: To the Editor:

headline: Crash in Starz Orbit
text: Several producers of “Crash” have signed on to produce a 13-episode television series based on that Academy Award-winning film. This one-hour series will be the first original drama on Starz, which will produce it with Lionsgate. Production is expected to begin in the spring, with a premiere by the end of the year. “Crash” received the Oscar for best picture in 2006. Among the film’s producers, Paul Haggis, Bobby Moresco, Bob Yari, Don Cheadle, Mark R. Harris and Tom Nunan will take part in the television series. “This series will present an opportunity to delve into many subjects, not just race relations in L.A.,” Mr. Cheadle, right, who co-starred in the film, said in a news release. “I don’t think you can do 13 episodes on that subject and keep people interested. The challenge will be to craft the series characters in such a way as to get beneath the skin that supposedly differentiates them and create entertaining story lines that show the hurdles and obstacles we all struggle to overcome day to day.” Starz is available in 16 million homes. Lionsgate, which also produces “Weeds” for the premium channel Showtime, reached an interim agreement with the Writers Guild of America last week.

headline: Two Grievous Cases Seek Different Paths to Justice
text: Cesar Rodriguez may be the most despised man in New York. He will certainly do until a more likely candidate for the title comes along.

headline: Question of Timing on Bush’s Push on Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush has never shown much distaste for Congressional pork.

headline: Ohio: Lawsuit Over Primary Ballots
text: The American Civil Liberties Union asked a federal judge to block the March 4 presidential primary in Ohio’s most-populous county if it switches to a paper ballot system that does not allow voters to correct errors. In a follow-up to a suit it filed Jan. 17, the A.C.L.U. of Ohio asked for a preliminary injunction against any election in Cuyahoga County, which includes Cleveland, if the switch is made. The lawsuit argued that the proposed paper-ballot system would violate voters’ constitutional rights because it does not allow them to correct errors before the ballots are cast.

headline: Brazil: Bank’s Lending and Profit Rise
text: Banco Bradesco, the Brazilian bank, reported a 29 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income on higher lending and one-time gains. Net income climbed to 2.19 billion reais ($1.23 billion) from 1.7 billion reais a year earlier, Bradesco said. Recurring profit, similar to profit from continuing operations, advanced 14 percent to 1.85 billion reais from a year ago, it said. Bank lending in Brazil has increased every month since February 2004 as interest rates fell to record lows and employment rose. The total loan portfolio, including receivables from credit cards, grew 39 percent to 161.4 billion reais, from 116.2 billion in December 2006. Net income was helped by a one-time 227-million-reais gain from the sale of a stake in Bolsa de Mercadorias & Futuros, Latin America’s largest derivatives market, and 178 million reais of profit from the sale of shares in Bovespa Holding, owner of São Paulo’s stock exchange.

headline: Israel Seeks Harmony With the Beatles
text: Israel wants to kiss and make up with the Beatles, above. Forty-three years after canceling the group’s concert date in Israel, the country plans to deliver letters of apology to the two surviving members and to relatives of the dead Beatles, an official in Israel’s embassy in London told Agence France-Presse. In addition the survivors, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr, were expected to be invited to perform in May at Israel’s 60th anniversary celebrations. The Hebrew-language Israeli newspaper Yediot Aharonot reported that the letter of apology said: “We would like to take this opportunity to rectify a historic missed opportunity which unfortunately took place in 1965 when you were invited to Israel. Unfortunately the state of Israel canceled your performance in the country due to lack of budget and because several politicians in the Knesset had believed at the time that your performance might corrupt the minds of Israeli youth.”

headline: Perception and Irony at Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland  “Behind every great fortune there is a great crime,” David M. Rubenstein said with a sardonic smile.

headline: A Fight for Life Consumes Both Mother and Son
text: “A good death” may be one of the emptiest phrases in the English language. Research has confirmed that no two people use it to mean exactly the same thing. Even the premise is unclear; for whom, exactly, is that death supposed to be good? Many would prefer a swift, sudden and painless exit for themselves  but a little warning when it comes to friends and relatives, with time to prepare and to say goodbye.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the decline in fourth-quarter profit for Motorola referred incompletely to the decline in the stock price of Palm Inc., another struggling cellphone maker. Part of the 77 percent drop from the 52-week high in Palm’s stock price as of Thursday can be attributed to a $9 dividend paid on Oct. 25, which caused the shares to fall to $8.50 from $19.18 a day earlier.

headline: Menstruation as a Source of Stem Cells? Maybe Not
text: In the past, menstruation was often viewed as a sign of uncleanliness or shame. In some cultures, women have been banished to huts or forbidden to cook during their periods.

headline: D.C. United Signs Midfielder
text: The Argentine midfielder Marcelo Gallardo signed with D.C. United on Monday, becoming the biggest of five South American additions to the club in the past week.The team also added the Peruvian goalkeeper Jose Carvallo, 21, and the Argentine defender Gonzalo Peralta, 27, on Monday as it held its first preseason practice.The 32-year-old Gallardo played in the 1998 and 2002 World Cups. He will fill the central playmaker’s role previously held by Christian Gómez, Major League Soccer’s most valuable player in 2006. United is expected to trade Gómez.Last week, United signed the Colombian defender Gonzalo Martinez and obtained the Argentine forward Franco Niell.

headline: With Ankle Taped, Brady Practices
text: PHOENIX  Patriots quarterback Tom Brady practiced Monday for the first time since sustaining a mild ankle sprain in the American Football Conference championship game on Jan. 20.

headline: Looking Anew at Campaign Cash and Elected Judges
text: Vernon Valentine Palmer, a law professor at Tulane University in New Orleans, could not understand how justices of the Louisiana Supreme Court could routinely hear cases involving people who had given them campaign contributions. It seemed to him a raw and simple conflict of interest.

headline: Rove Passes Up Commencement Speech at Choate After the Students Object
text: WALLINGFORD, Conn.  When 17-year-old Alessio Manti heard that Karl Rove, the former chief political adviser to President Bush, would be delivering the commencement address this spring to his class at Choate Rosemary Hall  the elite boarding school that produced such liberal giants as John F. Kennedy and Adlai Stevenson  he was shocked.

headline: A History Buff Uncovers Thefts of American History Treasures
text: Until two weeks ago, Joseph Romito, a history buff, was not a person who trolled the Internet for artifacts related to the statesman John C. Calhoun, a 19th-century vice president.

headline: Maladies: Hormone Levels and Chronic Fatigue
text: Women who suffer from chronic fatigue syndrome may be starting the day at a disadvantage. A new study finds that they wake up with lower levels of a hormone that helps people deal with stress.

headline: Feagles’s Roundabout Route to the Super Bowl
text: At 41, Jeff Feagles will be the oldest player in Super Bowl history, and maybe the last to be older than the Super Bowl itself. But he never expected to be going back to Arizona like this.

headline: Kennedy Backs Obama With ‘Old Politics’ Attack
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy implored Americans on Monday “to turn the page on the old politics of misrepresentation and distortion,” as he placed the aura of the most prominent Democratic family around Senator Barack Obama’s candidacy.

headline: Germany Confronts Holocaust Legacy Anew
text: BERLIN  Most countries celebrate the best in their pasts. Germany unrelentingly promotes its worst.

headline: The Kennedy Mystique
text: Something fundamental has shifted in the Democratic Party.

headline: Aide Linked to Detroit Mayor Will Step Down
text: DETROIT  The chief of staff for Detroit’s mayor resigned on Monday, five days after the release of text messages indicating that she and the mayor had lied under oath when they denied having had an extramarital affair.

headline: The Claim: Never Drink Hot Water From the Tap
text: THE FACTS

headline: Co-Owner of Pharmacy Is Fatally Shot
text: The part-owner of a Brooklyn pharmacy that the authorities have raided twice in recent months, seizing millions of dollars’ worth of steroids in an investigation of illicit drug use, was found shot to death in an office above the pharmacy on Monday evening, the police said. The death was apparently a suicide.

headline: Suharto Is Mourned in Indonesia
text: SOLO, Indonesia  Indonesia’s former strongman, Suharto, was buried Monday in a family mausoleum near here with a military honor guard, Muslim prayers and an overlay of the Javanese mysticism that, for some people, had given him the aura of a king.

headline: An Uncommon Wealth of Success Hits Boston
text: BOSTON  For a city with an inveterate inferiority complex, Boston has been feeling awfully superior lately.

headline: Wall St. Journal Plans a Move and a Sports Page
text: The Wall Street Journal miles away from Wall Street? Covering sports?

headline: For F.D.A., a Major Backlog Overseas
text: WASHINGTON  The Food and Drug Administration is so understaffed that, at its current pace, the agency would need at least 27 years to inspect every foreign medical device plant that exports to the United States, 13 years to check every foreign drug plant and 1,900 years to examine every foreign food plant, according to government investigators.

headline: English Council to Review Arts Cuts
text: Arts Council England, responding to the anger of hundreds of actors, writers and others in the arts, has decided to rethink its decision to slash financing for 194 theaters, art galleries, orchestra, literary groups and the like, The Independent of London reported. The newspaper said the board of the council, a government-financed body that allocates subsidies to the arts, will vote to reconsider its three-year $827.6 million budget at a board meeting on Tuesday. The new budget is to take effect on April 1. The proposed cuts would have forced some of England’s leading regional and fringe arts groups to close, The Independent reported. Sir Christopher Frayling, chairman of the council, said he had been persuaded to reconsider some cuts by sustained and “reasoned argument” from protesters. Among the institutions likely to be spared cuts in whole or part are the Bush Theater in West London; the National Student Drama Festival; the London Mozart Players, a chamber orchestra; Queer Up North, a gay and lesbian arts festival based in Manchester; and Anjali dance, a London troupe for dancers with learning disabilities.

headline: New Insights Into Genital Pain in Women
text: When a woman complains of genital pain so severe that it makes sexual intercourse all but impossible, her partner may jump to the conclusion that she has a phobia about sex. But what if that same woman also experiences excruciating pain when trying to insert a tampon, undergo a pelvic exam, wear a pair of jeans, ride a bicycle or go jogging? Can phobia explain all those problems?

headline: Screening: Co-Pays Seen as a Deterrent to Getting Mammograms
text: When it comes to medical fees, $12 may not seem much, but it is enough to deter many women from getting a mammogram, a new study finds.

headline: Legal Delays Tax More Than the Nets’ Patience
text: Choose the most pressing problem for the Nets:

headline: Can a Sandwich Be Slandered?
text: Some companies have made a sport of using advertising to bash a competing brand: Pepsi and Coke, Colgate and Crest, Miller Lite and Bud Light.

headline: A Treasure Made With Math and Marble
text: “Secrets of the Parthenon,” Tuesday night on PBS, is no mere how-did-they-lift-those-heavy-rocks rumination. It’s a condensed mathematics course, challenging you to keep up as it examines the principles and proportions the ancient Greeks used to erect that majestic building. You may fall by the wayside in the home stretch, which features a detailed analysis of the slight curve in the Parthenon’s columns, but you’ll still feel smarter by the program’s end.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Report Details Smithsonian Business Unit’s Problems
text: In its latest effort to right itself, the Smithsonian Institution has accepted a finding that its business unit is plagued by poor internal communication, diffuse organization and inadequate oversight.

headline: Deal to Buy Credit Card Processor Is in Peril
text: The turbulence on Wall Street threatened to claim another victim on Monday as the Alliance Data Systems Corporation, the big credit card processor, warned that its proposed $6.4 billion buyout might unravel.

headline: Text of the State of the Union Address
text: Following is a transcript of President Bush’s State of the Union address on Monday, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

headline: Belated Support Puts Boston Ahead of Curve
text: The Boston Red Sox were the last major league team to have a black player (Pumpsie Green in 1959), and now, half a century later, it appeared they were using Jackie Robinson for their own self-interest.

headline: In Turkey, a Step to Allow Head Scarves
text: ISTANBUL  Turkey’s governing political party  a class of young, observant Muslim politicians  reached an agreement late Monday to lift a ban on the wearing of head scarves by women attending universities, a move likely to enrage the country’s staunchly secular old guard and clear the way for a more openly religious society.

headline: In His Own Words
text: From remarks Monday at an airport in Fort Myers, Fla.:

headline: 5 G.I.’s Die in Ambush in Mosul
text: BAGHDAD  Sunni Arab guerrillas ambushed an American convoy in the northern city of Mosul with a roadside bomb on Monday, then sprayed survivors with machine-gun fire from perches in a nearby mosque, killing five American soldiers.

headline: Camelot ’08 Overshadows Bush Speech
text: The day began in Camelot and ended in Southfork.

headline: Aging: Growing Older Is Found to Hurt Decision Making
text: For the especially unscrupulous con artist, the elderly are a tempting target. Now researchers have confirmed in the lab what frauds already knew instinctively: as they grow older, even people who seem perfectly on top of things may have trouble making good decisions.

headline: 120 Million Years Old, Fossil Shows Divergence of Platypus and Anteater
text: The platypus tops many people’s oddest mammal list, what with its ducklike bill and beaverlike tail. Its closest relatives, the echidnas, don’t get the press the platypus gets, but they are pretty weird, too, and are the only other monotremes, or egg-laying mammals, around.

headline: Knicks Would Like to Have Laker Woes
text: LOS ANGELES  A steady, seven-day downpour soaked Southern California, sparked fears of mudslides and, to the great alarm of the locals, intruded on the sanctity of the Los Angeles Lakers.

headline: Greek Orthodox Leader Dies at 69
text: ATHENS  Archbishop Christodoulos, the charismatic head of the Greek Orthodox Church who helped heal centuries-old grievances with the Roman Catholic Church but stirred controversy with his politically tinged statements and tireless interventions in state affairs, died on Monday. He was 69.

headline: The City Is the Future of the Suburbs, and Other Heresies
text: The suburbs are dead. People always say that, and if you live in suburbia you expect to hear it, particularly from teenagers who are convinced that growing up there comes at some cost to their souls. Still it is remarkable to hear that dire diagnosis from the leaders of the two counties that make up Long Island, America’s emblematic suburb, and home of the original Levittown.

headline: In Harlem, Backing Up Bill Clinton
text: Omega Nelson had stopped for a cigarette in the heart of Harlem on Monday morning when he found himself in a political debate. As many are these days, this one was prompted by a reporter and focused on Bill Clinton’s role in Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign.

headline: Wall Street Journal’s New Direction Will Take It to Midtown
text: The Wall Street Journal miles away from Wall Street? Covering sports?

headline: Britain: Robbery Gang Convicted
text: Five men were convicted in a court at the Old Bailey for their roles in the largest cash robbery ever in Britain. The five, three Britons and two Albanians, were found guilty after a seven-month trial of taking part in a 2006 robbery of a Securitas company depot in Tunbridge Wells, south of London, in which gang members dressed as policemen kidnapped a depot manager, his wife and 7-year-old son at gunpoint and loaded a truck with several tons of used British banknotes valued at $92 million. The five will be sentenced on Tuesday; two other men were found not guilty. The convicted men were seized by the police within a week of the robbery, and 40 percent of the money was recovered from London and elsewhere. The balance of the stolen money, believed by the police to have been converted into villas and other luxuries in northern Cyprus and Morocco, has not been recovered.

headline: Severe Cold and Snow Hit Midwest
text: The upper Midwest braced for an Arctic blast on Tuesday with temperatures expected to drop as much as 50 degrees during the day, as areas farther west dug out from a snowstorm on Monday that snarled highways, closed schools and interrupted power to thousands of homes and businesses.

headline: Eli Manning Took Cues From Mother
text: By the time Eli Manning was able to throw a tight spiral, his father Archie’s long drives were confined to America’s highways, the elder Manning’s station as the singular quarterback of the subpar New Orleans Saints winning him a long and lucrative second career as a public speaker.

headline: China Allows U.S. Port Call in Hong Kong
text: BEIJING  China on Monday allowed a United States warship to make a port call in Hong Kong, two months after it turned away an American aircraft carrier battle group and set off a diplomatic dispute between the countries.

headline: Operator of Walk-In Clinics Shuts 23 Located in Wal-Mart Stores
text: CheckUps, a start-up operator of walk-in medical clinics, has shut down 23 of the clinics operating in Wal-Mart stores in Florida and three other Southern states.

headline: Rediscovering the Vienna Avant-Garde of a Century Ago
text: For some listeners the music of the Second Viennese School is by now  a century on  so thoroughly entrenched as to be standard repertory; for others it was supplanted by other styles so long ago that it’s irrelevant. But if you’re still trying to figure out what you think about it, the best idea may be to seek out a performance with James Levine at the helm. Mr. Levine is a true believer, but where other true believers approach this music with earnest reverence, he makes it sing.

headline: Greek Orthodox Leader Dies at 69
text: ATHENS  Archbishop Christodoulos, the charismatic leader of the Greek Orthodox Church who worked to heal centuries-old grievances with the Roman Catholic Church but stirred controversy with his politically tinged statements and tireless interventions in state affairs, died on Monday at his home in the Athens suburb Psychiko. He was 69.

headline: New Home Radiates More Energy for Seton Hall
text: NEWARK  The Seton Hall men’s basketball team is better than it was last season, which has something to do with the hot shooting of Brian Laing, the veteran leadership of Jamar Nutter and the energetic play of the freshman Jeremy Hazell. It also has something to do with a building.

headline: Ghana Reaches Quarterfinals
text: Host country Ghana advanced to the quarterfinals of the African Cup of Nations on Monday, beating Morocco, 2-0, on first-half goals by Michael Essien and Sulley Muntari.Essien scored in the 26th minute, and Muntari beat goalkeeper Nadir Lamyaghri in the 44th minute off a pass from Essien.Ghana (3-0) won Group A, and second-place Guinea (1-1-1) advanced with a 1-1 tie against Namibia (0-2-1). Morocco (1-2) finished third. Guinea went ahead on Souleymane Youla’s goal in the 62nd minute, but Brian Brendell tied the score in the 81st.Ivory Coast has also advanced to the quarterfinals.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about film studios’ increasing interest in direct-to-DVD movies used an outdated title for a coming Warner Brothers production to be released directly on DVD. It has been changed to “Get Smart’s Bruce and Lloyd Out of Control” from the original title, which was “Get Smarter: Bruce & Lloyd Out of Control.”

headline: Florida’s Phantom Democrats
text: Perhaps the most telling moment before Tuesday’s Democratic presidential primary in Florida, came last week when Senator Barack Obama’s supporters carried around a cardboard cutout of their candidate to smile, stiffly, at potential supporters.

headline: London Opening for Disney School
text: The Disney hit “High School Musical” is bound for London. The musical, based on the first of the television movies about the talented teenagers Troy and Gabriella, will play a 10-week engagement at the Hammersmith Apollo Theater in June, the BBC reported. A touring version of the show in Britain has already generated $17.8 million in ticket sales.

headline: Louisiana: Police Officer Fatally Shot
text: A man wanted for questioning in a rape overpowered a New Orleans police officer who was trying to handcuff him and then shot her to death with her own weapon, the police said. The man, whose name was not released, stayed on the scene and was arrested, a police spokesman said.

headline: Beijing Confirms Deaths of 6 Workers at Olympic Construction Sites
text: BEIJING  Municipal officials said Monday that six workers had died and four had been injured at the National Stadium and other Olympic sites since construction for the 2008 Games began five years ago.

headline: Synthetic Genome: Signed, Sealed, Decoded
text: You were expecting poetry, perhaps? The secret messages hidden in J. Craig Venter’s synthetic bacterial genome have now been revealed. They are Dr. Venter’s name, and that of his research institute and co-workers.

headline: In His Own Words
text: From a speech on Monday at a campaign rally in Fort Myers, Fla.:

headline: In Report, Kidd Says It’s Time to ‘Move On’
text: The struggling Nets may need a shake-up, and Jason Kidd is offering to start the process.

headline: Spitzer Reneged on Aid to City, Bloomberg Says
text: ALBANY  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Monday that the Spitzer administration was shortchanging New York City by about $500 million, and he urged lawmakers to restore the money, especially in education and health care.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the failure of the French bank Société Générale to investigate the actions of a junior trader that eventually cost the bank more than $7 billion misstated, in some copies, the volume of trades placed by the employee. It was $70 billion, not $750 billion.

headline: Developer Sought for Restaurant in Freedom Tower
text: For the price of a meal, Windows on the World atop 1 World Trade Center offered diners a spot in the stratosphere, a spot that was lost  along with so much else  on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: One Man’s Jigsaw Puzzle, Capturing an Odd World
text: LONDON  The classical facade of the Wellcome Collection here makes it seem as if this museum, which opened last June, were going to treat medical history the way the nearby British Museum treats Greek and Near Eastern civilizations, with an ordered, carefully annotated display of marvels and antiquities. But it doesn’t take long before that notion is thoroughly overturned.

headline: A Nod to Big Ideas of the Past, but Domestic Issues Are Now the Focus
text: WASHINGTON  Making his seventh and final State of the Union address, President Bush proposed a short list of initiatives Monday that more than anything else underscored the White House’s growing realization that his biggest political opponents now are time and an electorate already looking beyond him.

headline: Great Drug, but Does It Prolong Life?
text: Statins are among the most prescribed drugs in the world, and there is no doubt that they work as advertised  that they lower not only cholesterol but also the risk for heart attack.

headline: Renewed Focus on Customer Service at J.F.K. International Airport
text: AIRPORT EFFORT ON CUSTOMER SERVICE A program to improve airport workers’ customer service skills started last week at Kennedy International Airport and is expected to be expanded nationally under the name Aviation Resiliency Project. The initial phase of the project  which is being run by the Reclaiming the Sky Institute, a nonprofit group that aims to support aviation workers, along with Fordham University  has about 300 participants at Kennedy. They will receive extra training in “resiliency skills” to better handle passengers distressed over flight delays and cancellations. Findings of the pilot project will be compiled in March.

headline: A Quest for Glory and a Bonus Ends in Disgrace
text: PARIS  When Daniel Bouton, the chief executive of Société Générale, announced that the venerable bank had lost more than $7 billion in unwinding the positions of a rogue trader, he called the culprit “a terrorist.”

headline: Egypt Presses for Abbas to Control Border
text: JERUSALEM  Egypt said Monday that it preferred that the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, take control of the breached border between Gaza and Egypt, seeming to exclude Hamas, the Islamist group that took control of Gaza from Mr. Abbas in June.

headline: Gunmen Allowed to Flee After Hostage Standoff at Pakistan School
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A mass hostage-taking ended peacefully on Monday when a group of armed men released more than 200 schoolchildren after holding them for several hours in northwestern Pakistan, officials said.

headline: Colombia: Guerrilla Leader Is Sentenced
text: Ricardo Palmera, a top leader of the Marxist-inspired Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, was sentenced by a federal court in Washington to 60 years in prison for taking part in the kidnapping of three American military contractors in 2003. Mr. Palmera, 57, the most senior Colombian guerrilla leader extradited to the United States, had justified the abductions as a tactic of war by the FARC, Latin America’s largest rebel group. At the courtroom where he was sentenced, Mr. Palmera, known by the nom de guerre Simón Trinidad, accused the United States of improperly intervening in Colombia’s affairs and shouted, “Long live the FARC!”

headline: Russia: Gazprom-Ukraine Gas Dispute
text: The prime minister of Ukraine, Yulia Tymoshenko, below, demanded that Gazprom, the Russian natural gas monopoly, deal directly with the Ukrainian state oil and gas company rather than through an intermediary as it does now. The demand could unravel a natural gas trade agreement that settled a dispute between Ukraine and Gazprom two years ago. That agreement set up the intermediary, RosUkrEnergo, to buy gas from Gazprom and sell it at a loss to Ukraine and then recover the loss by selling gas in Europe at a higher price or blending gas with lower-cost gas from central Asia. Europe buys about 25 percent of its gas from Gazprom, and about 25 percent of it is shipped through Ukraine. In another sign that the deal may be unwinding, the Russian police last week arrested Semyon Mogilevich, a reputed organized-crime figure with ties to RosUkrEnergo, though on tax-evasion charges unrelated to the Ukrainian gas business.

headline: Tennessee Women End Duke Home Streak
text: DURHAM, N.C.  The Tennessee men’s basketball coach, Bruce Pearl, showed his school spirit last season, baring his chest and painting it with a white “V” when the Lady Vols faced Duke in Knoxville. There was no such display Monday night from Pearl’s Duke counterpart, Mike Krzyzewski, when Tennessee played at Duke.

headline: She’s Crazy, He’s Macho: Reader, It’s Love
text: Russell Banks’s new novel, “The Reserve,” bears less resemblance to any of his gritty, visionary epics, like his 1985 masterpiece, “Continental Drift,” than it does to a melodramatic B movie from the 1940s. Its two main characters are not his usual blue-collar workers, struggling against horrible odds to hold on to their glimpse of the American Dream, but a wealthy socialite and a famous artist who take their privileges for granted and who lead profligate, self-dramatizing lives.

headline: Zhang Hanzhi, Mao’s English Tutor, Dies at 72
text: SHANGHAI  Zhang Hanzhi, a former Chinese diplomat who once served as Mao’s English tutor and also interpreted for President Nixon during his historic trip to China in 1972, died after a long illness on Saturday. She was 72.

headline: A Kinder, Gentler Bill Clinton Campaigns in New Jersey
text: BLACKWOOD, N.J.  Nice Bill is back.

headline: Liberty Asks for Power to Push Out Diller at IAC
text: Ratcheting up a dispute between two media giants, the Liberty Media Corporation asked a Delaware Court of Chancery on Monday for the right to take control of IAC/InterActiveCorp and oust its chief executive, Barry Diller.

headline: Charles F. Luce, Ex-Chief of Con Ed, Is Dead at 90
text: Charles F. Luce, the chairman and chief executive of Consolidated Edison, the giant New York electric and gas utility during some of its most difficult times, died Saturday in Torrance, Calif. He was 90 and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

headline: In His Own Words
text: At a rally on Monday at an airplane hangar in Orlando, Fla.:

headline: Connections That Go Far Beyond Wins
text: If Bill Belichick can be judged by the company he keeps, then his relationships with Jim Brown, the legendary football player, and Bill Russell, the epitome of winning, provide an intriguing insight into a man few outsiders know.

headline: Hitting It Off, Thanks to Algorithms of Love
text: PASADENA, Calif.  The two students in Southern California had just been introduced during an experiment to test their “interpersonal chemistry.” The man, a graduate student, dutifully asked the undergraduate woman what her major was.

headline: For a Woman Who Is Unable to Hear, More Difficulties Lie Ahead
text: For Ramona Palanco, life is silent. It is now becoming darker, too.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway to Expand Bond Insurer Nationwide
text: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the holding company for the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, agreed to expand its new bond insurer nationwide in exchange for faster licensing, a group of state regulators said Monday.

headline: Cone Nears Deal With Yes
text: David Cone, who pitched a perfect game as a member of the Yankees in 1999, is nearing completion of a deal to work as an analyst for the YES Network. A YES spokesman would not confirm the imminent hiring. Cone, who pitched for the Yankees from 1995 to 2000, told teammates from the 1998 Yankees at an autograph show over the weekend that he was returning to YES, where he was a part-time analyst in 2002.YES needs to replace Joe Girardi, who left the booth to become the Yankees’ manager, and David Justice, who chose not to continue in the studio so that he could oversee the rebuilding of his house in San Diego. His home burned down last year.Cone is expected to make at least 50 appearances for YES in the booth and the studio. Cone, who also pitched for the Mets, was also a candidate to join SNY as a Mets analyst before the 2006 season.

headline: ‘Porgy’ Meets Katrina, and Life’s Not So Easy
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  “Summertime/And the livin’ is easy” takes on a whole new meaning when the time becomes the summer of 2005, and the storm-tossed denizens of Catfish Row find themselves stranded on the Katrina-flooded rooftops of New Orleans.

headline: New DVDs
text: EL CID

headline: High Enthusiasm Propels Democrats
text: WASHINGTON  The race for the Democratic presidential nomination may have its divisive moments, but it is generating intense interest and enthusiasm among the party’s rank and file: significantly greater, by several measures, than the Republican contest, political experts say.

headline: The State of the Union
text: Six years ago, President Bush began his State of the Union address with two powerful sentences: “As we gather tonight, our nation is at war, our economy is in recession, and the civilized world faces unprecedented dangers. Yet the state of our union has never been stronger.”

headline: Giants Tell Story Behind Their Smiles
text: CHANDLER, Ariz.  Giants defensive end Michael Strahan arrived at the first of many Super Bowl news conferences dressed in all black. Five teammates and his coach appropriately followed suit.

headline: Teens and Gross Anatomy (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Student Dispute Threatens Montclair State’s Paper
text: In a rancorous dispute that has pitted student journalists against student government, the editors of Montclair State University’s weekly newspaper were forced to stop publishing last week after the student body president froze the paper’s financing.

headline: Who’s Black and Female and How Do They Vote?
text: In the Democratic presidential primary next Tuesday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton appears to have an advantage in New York City: Among enrolled Democrats, women outnumber men by about half a million, or 50 percent.

headline: Court Backs Law Banning Managers as Agents
text: The California Supreme Court on Monday unanimously upheld a lower court’s ruling that the state’s Talent Agencies Act prohibits managers from procuring jobs for their celebrity clients. But the court weakened the penalty for managers who flout the law.

headline: House Passes $146 Billion Economic Aid Package
text: WASHINGTON  The House voted overwhelmingly Tuesday afternoon to approve a $146 billion fiscal stimulus package, hoping to quickly seal a fast-paced deal with the Bush administration. But Senate Democrats forged ahead with their own, more expensive plan despite a rising chorus of warnings from the White House and Speaker Nancy Pelosi that they risk delaying much-needed help for the economy and could plunge the nation too far in debt.

headline: The Indie Singer-Harpist Who Met the Orchestra
text: Violence may not be the first thing that comes to mind from the pristine sound of a harp, a woman’s elfin voice and the genteel, elaborate backup of a symphony orchestra. But for Joanna Newsom, the songwriter, singer and harpist who will be performing her entire 2006 album “Ys” (pronounced ees) with the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra on Thursday and Friday nights at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, “emotional violence and brutality” are at the core of the songs, from their cataclysmic lyrics to their jumpy harmonies.

headline: In a New Home, Reprising the Old Tunes
text: The Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra, an 18-piece band led by the pianist Arturo O’Farrill, left its perch at Jazz at Lincoln Center last year and moved itself a mile and a half north, to Symphony Space. It’s starting over, and its programs this year are re-introductions to the things the band did best at its old home.

headline: Super Sunday for Former Jet Involves All Types of Football
text: Darrol Ray said he was ready for Sunday’s big game. Make that games.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Thursday about the hopes at Brown for an Ivy League men’s basketball title misstated the status of a player at Cornell, Collin Robinson, a transfer from the University of Southern California who had been playing well. He left the team for personal reasons before the article was published.

headline: Yahoo Will Cut 1,000 Jobs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Yahoo said Tuesday that it would cut 1,000 jobs from its 14,300-member work force by mid-February in an effort to cut costs and focus on its most important businesses.

headline: The Preservation Predicament
text: Conservation organizations that work to preserve biologically rich landscapes are confronting a painful realization: In an era of climate change, many of their efforts may be insufficient or beside the point.

headline: New Homes Set Record: Sales Fell 26% in ’07
text: The housing industry, caught in a maelstrom of sinking demand, rising foreclosures and bulging inventories, is in its worst slump in decades, a growing body of economic evidence shows.

headline: Tristan and Isolde Go to La Scala: The Video
text: The annals of opera will record that Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, was the trailblazer who brought high-definition video broadcasts of performances to movie theaters around the world. Following the enormous success of this venture, companies from the San Francisco Opera to La Scala in Milan have embraced the idea.

headline: Ex-Client Sentenced in Law Firm Case
text: A former client of the securities law firm Milberg Weiss was sentenced to six months’ home detention and a $600,000 fine for lying under oath about secret payments that he received in exchange for serving as lead plaintiff in investor lawsuits.

headline: Commodities Markets in New York and Chicago Discuss Merger
text: The CME Group, which owns the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and Nymex Holdings, the owner of the New York Mercantile Exchange, said Monday that they were in talks about an $11 billion merger.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about the possible effect of a recession on media consumers and advertisers gave an incorrect middle initial for the chief operating officer of News Corporation. He is Peter A. Chernin, not Peter F. (The error has appeared in a number of articles since May 2006.)

headline: Grants Would Finance Private Schooling
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush’s call for a $300 million program called Pell Grants for Kids is the latest effort by his administration to channel tax dollars to low-income parents to help them send their children to private or religious schools.

headline: Questioning the Allure of Putting Cells in the Bank
text: Can a woman’s period save her life years later?

headline: Barnard Names New President
text: Barnard College named as its next president Debora L. Spar, a Harvard Business School professor who has written about the economics of the human fertility industry and the evolution of the Internet but has not previously been affiliated with a women’s college.

headline: Comedy Stop: State of The Union’s Shocking Omission
text: We had been looking forward to President Bush’s State of the Union address for months, knowing that it would once again bring to the fore the most pressing issue of our generation: human-animal hybrids.

headline: ‘The Reserve’
text: When finally no one was watching her anymore, the beautiful young woman extracted herself from her parents and their friends and left the living room. She passed through the screened porch and crossed the deck and barefoot walked softly over the pine needles in front of the sprawling log building downhill toward the sheared ledges along the edge of the lake.

headline: The Neediest Cases | Food Truck Supports a Family
text: Tania Sanchez, a single mother, dishes out home-cooked meals from a food truck parked in Upper Manhattan. She runs the business that supports her three children.

text: Properties on the market in Washington, California and New York.

text: Aired Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: President Bush gave the State of the Union address earlier this evening and wasn’t it great? It was. I found it very moving and inspiring and very — I didn’t watch it either.

headline: ‘Like Regis and Kelly’
text: Aired Monday night on CBS: You know what happened earlier tonight? It was the annual State of the Union address. … By the way, this is President Bush’s last State of the Union address. The next one will be given by co-presidents Bill and Hillary Clinton.

text: Aired Monday night on NBC: As you all know, earlier tonight President Bush gave his big State of Delusion address.

headline: Former Milberg Client Sentenced in Law Firm Case
text: A former client of the securities law firm Milberg Weiss was sentenced to six months’ home detention and fined $600,000 for lying under oath about secret payments that he received in exchange for serving as lead plaintiff in investor lawsuits.

headline: Backdating Case Brings a Prison Term
text: The former chief financial officer of SafeNet, a maker of computer network security products, was sentenced Monday to six months in prison and fined $1 million for securities fraud in connection with an options backdating case.

headline: Legg Mason Picks Chief From Inside
text: The money manager Legg Mason said Monday that it had promoted Mark R. Fetting, a senior vice president, to chief executive, succeeding Raymond A. Mason, who is retiring.

headline: Accountant and S.E.C. Reach Deal in Enron Case
text: A former partner at Arthur Andersen responsible for the Enron account has settled allegations that he violated securities laws when he signed audit reports that were false and misleading, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Monday.

headline: Go Ahead, Ask Us a Question
text: Imagine for a moment that you, dear readers, could have a “media day” and could surround reporters and editors and poke microphones in our faces. What kind of questions would you ask? I mean, with the swear words deleted.

headline: Britain Orders BSkyB to Cut ITV Stake
text: The British government ordered BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster controlled by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, to cut its stake in ITV from 17.9 percent to less than 7.5 percent.

headline: Landry’s C.E.O. Bids to Take Chain Private
text: Tilman Fertitta, who built Landry’s into a nationwide restaurant chain propelled through nearly two decades of acquisitions, wants to make one more purchase – the company he runs. As chairman, president and chief executive of the restaurant, hotel and casino company, he already owns 39 percent of it.

headline: Critiquing the Times’ Digital Deals
text: As two hedge funds that want The New York Times Company to sell some assets and focus on digital publishing prepare to nominate a slate of directors at the publisher’s next shareholder meeting, The Deal’s Corporate Dealmaker blog takes a look at just what the strategy has been at The Times — which owns The New York Times, The Boston Globe a The International Herald Tribune, and more than 30 Web sites.

headline: Inverness to Pick Up Matria Healthcare for $900 Million
text: Inverness Medical Innovations continued a shopping spree with the acquisition of Matria Healthcare, a troubled provider of disease management services.

headline: Gore’s Current Media to Seek Nasdaq Listing
text: Al Gore’s Current Media, the interactive cable TV company that the San Jose Mercury News describes as “better known for its Nobel Prize-winning co-founder than for any of its shows,” said Monday that it plans to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq.

headline: Merrill Lynch Co-President Will Leave
text: Merrill Lynch said on Monday that a president, Ahmass L. Fakahany, would leave as the company builds a new management team after an implosion in the credit market that caused $12 billion in net losses in the second half of 2007.

headline: The Rubicon Project Snags $15 Million
text: The Rubicon Project, which essentially acts as a middleman between Web sites and ad networks, announced Monday that it raised an additional $15 million in funding, bringing its total financing to $21 million.

headline: Visible Measures Counts $13.5 Million in New Funding
text: As it prepares to introduce its first product, an online video audience measurement start-up, Visible Measures, has tapped Mohr Davidow Ventures to lead a $13.5 million second round of funding.

headline: Ebay Picks Up Fraud Sciences for $169 Million
text: The online auctioneer eBay said on Monday its PayPal subsidiary had agreed to acquire Fraud Sciences, an Israel-based online credit card fraud detection company, for $169 million.

headline: Regulatory Fears Said to Drive Countrywide into BofA’s Arms
text: The fear of potential regulatory crackdowns helped drive Countrywide Financial into the arms of acquirer Bank of America, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Investors Pour $31.5 Million into Intrinsity
text: Intrinsity, a semiconductor design start-up, said Monday that it had raised $31.5 million in a fifth round of venture capital, a strong endorsement of the company’s three-year transition into a “chipless” company devoted solely to licensing its intellectual property.

headline: Regulator Chills Alliance Data Deal
text: The turbulence on Wall Street threatened to claim another victim on Monday as the Alliance Data Systems Corporation, the big credit card processor, warned that its proposed $6.4 billion buyout might unravel.

headline: Icahn Steps Up Attack on Biogen
text: Will 2008 be a year of reprisals for Carl C. Icahn?

headline: Will Nymex Be a Hot Commodity?
text: The announcement Monday that the CME Group, which owns the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and Nymex Holdings, the owner of the New York Mercantile Exchange, were in talks about an $11 billion merger may lead to a flurry of rival bids for Nymex, whose longtime lead in energy and metals dealing has been challenged by newer rivals.

headline: Perella to Advise N.Y. Insurance Regulator on Bond Firms
text: January is shaping up to be a banner month for the boutique investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners.

headline: Diller and Malone: When Moguls Collide
text: Ratcheting up a dispute between two media giants, the Liberty Media Corporation asked a Delaware Court of Chancery on Monday for the right to take control of IAC/InterActiveCorp and oust its chief executive, Barry Diller.

headline: Can Lampert Manage Not to Manage Sears?
text: Edward S. Lampert has a new strategy for Sears: less Edward S. Lampert.

headline: A Quest for Glory and a Bonus Ends in Disgrace
text: When Daniel Bouton, the chief executive of Société Générale, announced that the venerable bank had lost more than $7 billion in unwinding the positions of a rogue trader, he called the culprit “a terrorist.”

headline: Mastering the Informational Interview
text: Informational interviews can be a useful tool throughout your career, not just when you’re thinking about a new job or a new line of work. You can do informational interviews when you want to learn more about a certain career move or even what it would feel like to get involved in a new project like writing a book, starting a blog, or running your own company.

headline: When Risk Management Isn’t Just a Department
text: Managing risk within a bank is not just a matter of relying on internal processes but also requires making the right decisions at the top of the company, Citigroup‘s chairman, Winfried Bischoff, said on Tuesday.

headline: For Appearance’ Sake
text: SpoutBlog tracks what they call guerrilla efforts to make it to the podium, suggesting that various players are using media appearances to create YouTube moments. By that standard, Diablo Cody’s recent appearance with Dave Letterman was rated a wash — she was funny and charming, but in one quip gave away the ending to “There Will Be Blood.”

headline: Blanchett Off 8.75 Basis Points, Ruby Dee Up a Whopping 60 Percent
text: The Hollywood Stock Exchange has a real-time exchange based on the perceived changes of the chances of various nominees. Whenever there is a news inflection point like the SAG Awards, check in and see who is making a market.

headline: Late to the Party
text: The DGA is always fun. Two years ago, George Clooney used the effenhemier from the podium, in part because television and video cameras are not allowed at the awards. But the lack of a visual record does have drawbacks. Apparently, actress Sean Young totally flipped her noodle at this year’s awards, a fact that has been noted on all manner of Oscar blogs, save this one. Defamer checks in on her piece of performance art, which included getting 86’ed from the hall during Julian Schnabel’s speech. Kris Tapley of the Red Carpet District blog was in attendance and has details on Ms. Young’s meltdown.

headline: EWWWWW!
text: Dave Karger of Entertainment Weekly is that rare Oscar ninny who has it all. The rest of us spend our days snoozing, taking credit for brilliant predictions we never made, and sniping about the work of others. But there sits Karger, above it all, offering real-time analytics, solid reporting and gracious coverage — both in print and on television.

headline: NCFOM
text: Something about typing the acronym of “No Country For Old Men” makes the Bagger wonder, when he types in NCFOM, what else one could conjure out of those letters? They seem strangely resonant, a kind of all-caps invitation to further annotation of the film’s aesthetic.

headline: Private Equity in the Purgatory Age
text: Many of private equity’s top moguls made an appearance at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland last week — and for once in the last 12 months, they weren’t on the hot seat. But in the real world outside of picturesque Swiss villages, buyout firms remain pressured by both economic and political realities.

headline: The Early Word: Florida Fight Time
text: “Just wait ’til Florida!” has been Rudolph W. Giuliani’s mantra, after suffering big losses in Iowa, New Hampshire and the handful of other states that have already held Republican primaries and caucuses.

headline: McDonald’s Training Adds Up to British Diploma
text: Never mind the Oxford English Dictionary stalwarts who refused McDonald’s entreaties in Britain to redefine “McJob” in a more positive light; the fast food giant has just won the support of the prime minister himself.

headline: Bloomberg’s Albany Assault on Spitzer
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg testified at a state legislative budget hearing on Monday, criticizing the Spitzer administration for reneging on its promises and shortchanging New York City by about $500 million, according to an article by Trymaine Lee. “A deal is a deal,” the mayor argued. “This year, as we do every year, we’ve made budget decisions in the city based on the expectation, and even the expressed assurances, that Albany will honor its commitments to us.”

headline: Drinking Water Do’s and Dont’s
text: Notes on the News: As the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, reminded attendees at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland: There’s water, water everywhere, but, increasingly, not enough to drink.

headline: Many New Yorkers Are Called to Run; Few Are Chosen
text: If former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani or Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton manages to reach the White House, either would be the first New Yorker nominated, much less elected, by a major party for president since Gov. Thomas E. Dewey in 1948 — and the first to actually capture the presidency since Gov. Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.Mr. Dewey tried three times, beginning in 1940, when he was still only the Manhattan district attorney, and two more times as governor, when he won the Republican nomination but lost the election, first to F.D.R. and then to Harry S. Truman. (After the second defeat, the Washington wit Alice Roosevelt Longworth sniffed: “We should have known he couldn’t win. A soufflé never rises twice.”)

headline: Critic’s Choice: Thumbs Down on the Spectacle
text: Will Leitch is the editor of Deadspin.com and a frequent contributor to Play: The New York Times Sports Magazine. His latest book, “God Save the Fan,” was released last week.

headline: The Debate: Broadcast Voices
text: Joe Buck and Troy Aikman will be in the booth on Sunday for Fox Sports’s broadcast of Super Bowl XLII. The announcing crew for any sports event can help enhance the viewing experience, or ruin it. (The Times’s site was inundated with bitter complaints about the ABC announcers during the 2006 World Cup). Who are the best announcers — and why? Does John Madden still rule the roost? And who are the worst?

headline: Toni Morrison’s Early Votes: For Obama, Kindle
Bali to Hawaii: The Climate Caravan Moves On
text: The next step is approaching in President Bush’s effort to round up the world’s biggest emitters of carbon dioxide and extract non-binding pledges to limit growth in emissions and settle on a long-term target for cutting them.

headline: On the Field and Off, Two Africas
text: ACCRA, Ghana — A few minutes before the decisive match between Ghana and Morocco kicked off on Monday night, Mohammed Mallouk, a veteran journalist with the Casablanca daily Le Matin, predicted that Morocco was going to lose.

headline: Mormon Pride and Anxiety Over Romney’s Bid
text: Joseph Doria, 39, and Jeff Magee, 34, are neighbors in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., friends and fellow Mormons. But get them talking about the presidential candidacy of Mitt Romney, and the similarities stop.

headline: Sandra’s Sources | Alejandro Ingelmo
text: T Magazine’s Senior Editor Sandra Ballentine opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know. For previous Sandra’s Sources, click here.

headline: McCain and Crist Hit the Polls
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Senator John McCain met up with Governor Charlie Crist on Tuesday morning at a polling place in St. Petersburg near the governor’s high-rise condominium. There were not many voters in evidence, but there were plenty of cameras and a handful of sign-waving McCain supporters there to provide a backdrop for the photo opportunity.

headline: An Iraq recession?
text: One thing I get asked fairly often is whether the Iraq war is responsible for our economic difficulties. The answer (with slight qualifications) is no.

headline: Answers About Tenant-Landlord Issues, Part 3
text: Following is a third set of answers to readers’ questions selected by Lucas A. Ferrara, a partner at Finkelstein Newman Ferrara who has practiced in the landlord-tenant arena for more than two decades.

text: Hugh Atkin, a 23-year-old Australian online humor whiz, has hit two American nails on their two heads by digitally mashing them up into one nail. Nice.

headline: Memory lane
text: Remember when those of us who argued that the United States was in the midst of a serious housing bubble were ridiculed, and told that we were simply motivated by irrational Bush-hatred? Ah, memories.

headline: For New York Republicans, the Winner Takes All
text: Unlike the intricate and somewhat confusing system used by New York Democrats to allocate delegates, New York Republicans use a simple winner-take-all system.

text: Is a loss ever better than a victory in basketball?

headline: County Leaders Criticize Spitzer’s Budget
text: County leaders in both parties assailed Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s budget shortly after the governor addressed them at their annual conference in Albany this morning. The governor, in his remarks, said he was making the best of a bad economic situation, and said “this year, there is in the budget I just proposed a net benefit of $519 million” for counties.

headline: Clips: Current IPO, ‘Eli Stone,’ FiOS Figures
text: — Current TV, the cable network co-founded by Al Gore, said Monday “that it plans to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering on the Nasdaq,” Dealbook reports. “Nearly $37 million of the offering’s proceeds will pay off debt, including $30.4 million to NBC Universal, the company said in its prospectus. Last year, Current lost $9.9 million on revenue of $63.8 million.”

headline: Deal or No Deal
text: The Risk Biz Blog finds eerie parallels between “What Just Happened” and “The Deal,” two star vehicles at Sundance.

headline: TV Decoder, Live at the NATPE Conference
text: LAS VEGAS – The annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives, being held here this week, is where stations come to buy and producers come to sell.

headline: An Embarrassment of Riches
text: Anne Thompson, poking through the tea leaves of Sundance, talked to Jonathan Dana, a knowledgeable insider, about why there was a glut of unsold films this year, and not just at Sundance.

headline: $5 Million for Moussaoui: Far Too Much?
text: The State Department’s awarding of a $5 million reward to one individual for information leading to the arrest of Zacarias Moussaoui, the “20th hijacker” convicted of conspiring in the Sept. 11 terror plot, has attracted enough criticism to warrant an informal Lede reader poll.

headline: ‘Raymond’ and ‘Family Guy’ Are Rare Bright Spots in Syndication Firmament
text: LAS VEGAS – The last few years have been particularly rough for syndicated television shows. Local stations that are affiliated with the major networks purchase the rights to these shows and sell advertisements against them, but those ads can be a tough sell in the absence of hit shows.

headline: Waving Goodbye From a Distance
text: Director Chris Nolan spent some time in Newsweek talking about Heath Ledger, who knew his way around both a set and skateboard. Mr. Nolan writes about having Ledger very much on his mind as he cuts “The Dark Knight,” the Batman sequel in which the actor played the Joker.

headline: In Giuliani’s Old Brooklyn Neighborhood, Skepticism
text: Along the quiet low-slung Brooklyn street where Rudolph W. Giuliani spent his earliest childhood years, residents express respect for his tenure as mayor, but are not optimistic about his presidential chances in the fiercely competitive primary race.

headline: Morgan Stanley and the $7 Billion Unknowable
text: If you thought the fog surrounding the value of debt securities was starting to lift, think again.

headline: The Envelope, Please
text: The Baguette just checked with this update on the undersung guys who, as much as anyone, make the movies magical. Robert Elswit was awarded this year’s top prize in the film category by the American Society of Cinematographers for his work on “There Will Be Blood.” Mr. Elswit also shot “Michael Clayton.”

headline: Now Playing
text: “This is a character whose one contact with a kind of para-reality is through film. Actually he’s not a movie buff in the conventional sense. He doesn’t really care about movies as entertainment, let alone about films as an artform. He just goes to the movie theater to touch a kind of reality he can depend on.” —Stanley Kauffmann, who edited “The Moviegoer” for Alfred A. Knopf.

headline: Soft Serve | Gucci Lost In Brooklyn, Posh Undressed, Obama In Limited Edition
text: Soft Serve is a news feed of light reading. We scan newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.

headline: Slashdot Founder Questions Crowd’s Wisdom
text: One of the oldest rivals to the community news site Digg is pointing to recent unrest at the site as evidence that the social news model is flawed.

headline: Bill Clinton, in South Jersey, Doesn’t Mention Obama
text: BLACKWOOD, N.J. — Nice Bill is back.

headline: World Club Top 10: Ominous for Rangers Fans
text: With all the January breaks for international play and the NHL All-Star Game out of the way, we look again at the World Club Top 10 and find the topmost clubs pretty much unchanged. But there are some new faces, especially Metallurg Magnitogorsk, who won the European championship a couple of weeks ago. They’ve been on a tear in the Russian Superliga under a new coach, Fedor Kanareikin, and have moved up to second, displacing faltering SKA St. Petersburg.

headline: Alfred Kazin’s Winesburg, Ohio
text: As a literary reporter, I spend most of my waking hours tracking people down and trying to connect the dots. Which is to say, I’m a Google addict. In recent years, tons of ink has been spilled about Google — as a business model, as an intellectual phenomenon and as a way of reflecting on reading habits.

headline: When 50 Percent Growth Isn’t Enough
text: On Wall Street, hype cuts both ways.

headline: For The Moment | Kicking It With Hiroki Nakamura
text: This week’s guest blogger is John Jay, the Executive Creative Director and Partner of the Wieden + Kennedy advertising agency which includes Nike among its clients. Now based in Portland, Ore., Jay works in Asia once a month. In addition to helping to open W+K’s Tokyo, Shanghai, Beijing and New Delhi offices, he also founded W+K Tokyo Lab (an independent DVD music label) and Studio J, a private creative consultancy in Portland’s Chinatown. Jay writes a blog for Honeyee.com in Tokyo and is a contributor to magazines in Tokyo and the U.S. on creativity and pop culture, including Tokion Japan, Giant Robot, Theme and Spread magazine. In today’s post, Jay meets with Hiroki Nakamura, the designer behind the Visvim brand. (For all of John Jay’s posts, click here)

headline: Caroline Kennedy in Campaign Ads for Obama
text: Updated, 5:06 p.m. | David Plouffe, the campaign manager for Senator Barack Obama, told reporters in a conference call this afternoon that the campaign would begin showing television advertisements on Wednesday in New York — an indication that the Illinois senator intends to wage a fight to win delegates in the home state of his chief rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Tuesday, Jan. 29:

headline: Sellers Give Negative Feedback on eBay Changes
text: EBay’s highly touted cut in sellers’ fees announced this morning is not so clearly a boon for sellers as it may appear at first look. AuctionBytes, a newsletter and blog for eBay sellers, calculated that for some scenarios, sellers actually will end up paying more than they did before. In one comparison, the fees increased by 33 percent. What is more, eBay’s changes to its feedback system have many sellers up in arms.

headline: ‘Forest Fire:’ Zucker Sees Strike as an Opportunity for Change
text: LAS VEGAS — Perhaps the ongoing writers’ strike is the “forest fire” the television industry desperately needs, said Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, in a keynote address at the annual conference of the National Association of Television Program Executives Tuesday morning.

headline: Thai Leader Vows to Revive Cooking Show
text: Emeril Lagasse, take note: here’s how to get a cooking show back on the air, courtesy of Thailand’s new prime minister, Samak Sundaravej.

headline: Obama Says It Was a Turn, Not a Snub
text: EL DORADO, Kan. – Was it the great snub beneath the Capitol Dome or a simple turn of the head?

headline: Sudden Impact in Boston
text: Milan Lucic hit the Boston Bruins’ training camp in the fall fresh off unimaginable success in his final moments of junior hockey.

headline: O Canada, Where the Writers Aren’t on Strike
text: As the networks search for work-arounds to find fresh material during the writers’ strike, CBS has hit on a novel strategy: go to countries where the writers are not striking.

headline: Can a Sandwich Be Slandered?
text: Video

headline: Another Skyscraper Is Planned Near Ground Zero
text: Less than a century after it soared heavenward as the world’s tallest building, the Woolworth Building — the icy Gothic pinnacle that generations of New Yorkers knew as the “Cathedral of Commerce” — will soon fall under the shadow of an 80-story next-door neighbor.The new 912-foot tower at 99 Church Street, designed by Robert A. M.
