Stern Architects for Silverstein Properties, will have a 175-room Four Seasons hotel on the first 22 floors and 143 condominium apartments in the floors above, managed by Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts. Larry A. Silverstein, the president and chief executive of Silverstein Properties, unveiled the design this morning.

headline: Fire at Will: Talking to the Automobiles Editor
text: Readers of this blog may want to look at another online feature this week. James G. Cobb, automobiles editor of The Times (including the Sunday Automobiles section, the Web section and the Wheels blog), is responding to reader questions as part of the Talk to the Newsroom feature. So far, he’s answered questions about advertisers and editorial independence, midsize hybrids and the proper focus of automotive journalism.

headline: Rome Underground (the Catacombs!)
text: Recently, over dinner, a neighbor told me that my apartment building in Rome — indeed my entire neighborhood — is built over a series of ancient catacombs that contain the remains of tens of thousands of bodies. My first reaction was a shiver.

headline: Just Browsing
text: Just Browsing sews together the latest fashion news from our global sources of mags, trades, blogs and tipsters.

headline: Chow Down
text: At an all-you-can-eat banquet, 350 men consume 500 pounds of tenderloin in less than an hour.

headline: Florida’s Democratic Delegate Mess
text: MIAMI — What a strange situation we’re facing here in Florida today.

headline: Clipboard: What Happens if the Patriots Lose?
text: William C. Rhoden says that the New England Patriots are “the greatest professional football team in regular-season history.” But we won’t know until Sunday night exactly where they fit in the pantheon of N.F.L. history.

headline: A Nixon Grandson Leads McCain’s New York Effort
text: Christopher Nixon Cox said that he and his grandfather rarely spoke about politics. Instead, he said, his conversations with the 37th president centered more on baseball.

headline: Where Are Those Million iPhones? Everywhere.
text: Our readers think they have found the million unaccounted-for iPhones discussed in an earlier post — phones that were bought but then never activated on the networks of the wireless carriers that are Apple’s partners. They are all around the world, in many countries where Apple has not yet worked out deals with local carriers, indicating that these phones have been “unlocked.” A sample of some of the comments (with a little editing for punctuation):

headline: What You Didn’t Know About Sovereign Wealth Funds
text: Sovereign wealth funds are all the rage. But with all the talk it is hard to separate out the truth from the fiction. Here is a guide to the burning questions surrounding these phenomena.

headline: Ratings: State of the Union Down, ABC News Up
text: Because of last night’s State of the Union address, final ratings data will not be issued by Nielsen until late on Tuesday, but overnight estimates suggest that ratings for the president’s speech may be down considerably from a year ago. Then again, one difference last year was that Fox broadcast “American Idol” in the hour preceding the speech, which could have given President Bush a ratings bump.

headline: Youth Activists Defend Generation
text: Today’s youth are not apathetic, they aren’t dazzled by celebrity politicians and they do care about substantive issues.

headline: Unrest Escalates in Kenya
Slide Show: Florida Primary
text: Republican candidates made last minute appearances to rally supporters in the hotly-contested Florida primary, where the turnout is expected to be high.

headline: The Sex of Your Surgeon May Matter
text: Whether a woman receives radiation treatment after breast cancer surgery may be influenced by the gender of her surgeon, according to a new report from The Journal of the National Cancer Institute.

headline: Excited Volunteers Greet Obama Team in Queens
text: The hook that Mike Griffin uses with would-be volunteers is pretty much fail-safe. “I ask them,” he said Tuesday, “can you give me one hour to help change the world?”

headline: Walnut Tart
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes pecan pie -- with walnuts.

headline: Bush Logic: The State of The Union & Telecom Immunity
text: President Bush’s State of the Union address last night was not only uninspiring, full of bad ideas, and short on prescriptions for the serious problems facing the country. It was also packed with faulty logic — the sort that has made reasoned debate with this administration so difficult.

headline: Pouring Over the Border
text: The old rule about matching foods with wines of the same region is a truism – always useful when you’re dealing with cuisines from winemaking regions but often limiting. For a case in point, I offer up my dinner Sunday night, where I relearned this lesson in a most pleasant way.

headline: ‘The Satisfaction of Saying That They Tried’
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: John Edwards’s New York Strategy (Yes, There Is One)
text: In New York, it is easy to feel a little outnumbered if you’re trying to be a delegate for John Edwards. As Marc A. Landis, a lawyer from Manhattan who is on the ballot to be an Edwards delegate in the 8th Congressional District, put it, “Look, this is the kind of thing you do in politics as a labor of love.”

headline: False Alert: About.Com Is Not for Sale
text: Speculation emerged Tuesday afternoon that The New York Times Company had put About.com up for sale. A report from Silicon Alley Insider said The Times had hired an unnamed bank and was shopping the digital unit, which it estimated was worth as much as $600 million. However, people close to the company — and we’re well placed — flatly denied the report.

headline: Clinton Booked On Letterman
text: “Democrat Hillary Rodham Clinton will yuk it up on CBS’s ‘Late Show with David Letterman’ on Monday, a day before the Feb. 5 Super Tuesday contests,” the Associated Press notes.

headline: Films for Short Attention Spans
text: The Oscar-nominated short films don’t get noticed much, maybe because few moviegoers get the chance to see them. But as the Baguette notes, a good short can launch a career. Take the Irish playwright Martin McDonagh. He won an Oscar in 2006 for a short called “Six Shooter,” and this year “In Bruges,” his first feature, which Mr. McDonagh wrote and directed, had its premiere at Sundance and will open in New York and L.A. on Feb. 8.

headline: Psst.  Wanna Buy a House?
text: Wall Street keeps bidding up the prices of homebuilding stocks, secure in the belief that the bottom is nigh. The S&P 1500 homebuilder index is up 48 percent from its low earlier this month.

headline: A Giants-Patriots Bet: Go Easy on the Cheese
text: With all the spontaneity of a summit conference, the mayors of New York and Boston have announced their friendly wager on the Super Bowl. If the Giants emerge victorious on Sunday night, City Hall is due to receive a veritable grocery aisle from One City Hall Plaza in Boston. Should the New England Patriots win to complete their undefeated season, a similar collection of goodies will head north from Manhattan. Here are the details of the wager:

headline: Romney Entourage Sightings
text: TAMPA — A few items of note from Mitt Romney’s morning event, in which he fought through a hoarse voice to address up about 150 supporters:

headline: Keeping Predators Away From ‘Spacebook’
text: In a bipartisan effort to keep sexual predators from trolling social networking sites like MySpace and Facebook, lawmakers have drafted a bill that would track the e-mail addresses of serious sex offenders and restrict their use of the Internet.The bill was announced this afternoon and promised a bridging of the technological gap between young and old. “We have to admit that life is different than when we were growing up,” said Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol. “We have to have educational programs so that parents know about MySpace and Spacebook and…”

headline: In Fla., McCain Outspends Romney on TV Lately
text: TAMPA — Senator John McCain appears to have slightly outspent Mitt Romney, with Rudolph W. Giuliani lagging significantly behind, in television advertising in Florida in the week leading up to the Republican primary here, according to newly released data from the Campaign Media Advisory Group, which estimates ad spending.

headline: Ex-Bayou C.F.O. Gets 20-Year Prison Sentence
text: The former chief financial officer of the hedge fund Bayou Group was sentenced to 20 years in prison Tuesday for his role in a scheme that defrauded investors of $450 million and led to the fund’s collapse.

headline: Yahoo Will Cut 1,000 Jobs
text: The punch line in Yahoo’s droning conference call came 40 minutes in. After Jerry Yang, the chief executive, and Sue Decker, the No. 2 exec, spoke about the company’s goals in terms worthy of career bureaucrats, Blake Jorgensen, the chief financial officer, got to the meat.

headline: Clinton Aspires to be an Amiga
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton puckers up to kiss a Latina toddler against a soundtrack of salsa music in her latest Spanish-language TV ad, now showing in Super Tuesday states Arizona, California, Connecticut and New York.

headline: In Las Vegas, a Beauty Contest for Game Shows
text: Howie Mandel will host the syndicated version of “Deal or No Deal.” (NBC/2005)

headline: Navy Aims to Break Record With Next Test of Railgun
text: “What is the electromagnetic railgun?,” the Navy asks in a news release today. “In a word, innovation.”

headline: Obama’s New Ads in the Big States
text: In a sign of the overarching importance of paid media in Feb. 5 strategies, Senator Barack Obama’s campaign is out with a flurry of new ads.

headline: New Hampshire is Not Amused
text: The editorial page of New Hampshire’s Union Leader is, shall we say, irked by Hillary Clinton’s decision to attend a rally tonight in Florida, which is holding a “beauty contest” primary for the Democrats (no delegates will be awarded) in addition to a Republican primary.

headline: Near Clinton’s Home, the Latest ‘Major Event’
text: WHITE PLAINS — “Clinton Campaign Launches Major Central New York Effort.” “Clinton Campaign Launches Major Broome County Effort.” “Clinton Campaign Launches Major Effort in Westchester County.”

headline: Bill Clinton Draws Hundreds in Ohio
text: CLEVELAND — Bill Clinton stuck to the script on Tuesday during a rally at a community college near Cleveland, keeping the focus on his wife and steering clear of any fresh remarks about Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Live-Blogging the Sunshine Primary
text: 10:39 p.m. | The Last Word From our reporters in the field, here’s what we know — just at this moment and we’re sure there’ll be more to come: Mr. Giuliani’s campaign and the McCain camp have been in talks about a possible endorsement. It will likely happen later this week. Could we suggest tomorrow?

headline: The Repeater
text: Here’s an evolutionist’s dream: 10,000 planet Earths, starting from the same point at the same time, and left to their own devices for four and a half billion years. What would happen? Could you go on safari from one planet to the next seeing an endless procession of wildly different organisms? Or would many of the planets be home to life forms that are broadly similar?

headline: Many Are Already at Work on Fulfilling Gates’s Vision
text: Bill Gates’s bold Davos challenge to the world’s capitalists last week should have come with equally bold footnotes.

headline: A One-Woman Man With a Zen-like Approach to Life
text: The New England Patriots were very business-like and reserved in their approach to media day.

headline: Undecided in New York
text: Kelle Jacob, a first-time voter, and her friends share their perceptions of the Democratic candidates. And sashimi.

headline: Kenyan Politician Assassinated
text: A popular parliament member was gunned down outside his home in Nairobi, sparking clashes between mourners and police.

headline: Waiting Out the Rain
De Savary Sells Abaco Interest
text: British entrepreneur Peter de Savary has sold his percentage in the Abaco Club on Winding Bay, the seminal resort and residential project he developed in the Bahamas with Ritz Carlton.

headline: Yanks Step Back From the Brink and Watch Santana Go to the Mets
text: Resisting the temptation to trade for Johan Santana may be the surest sign we’ve seen that the Yankees are operating differently now. Even as late as Tuesday afternoon, when the Mets were finishing off their deal with the Twins -– which is contingent on Santana agreeing to a contract extension -– some insiders believed the Yankees could pounce in the final moments.

headline: A Giants-Patriots Bet: Go Easy on the Cheese
text: John Sullivan writes on the City Room blog:

headline: Media Day: Your Virtual News Conference
text: With Super Bowl XLII five days away, the N.Y. Giants and New England Patriots made players and coaches available to the news media Tuesday at University of Phoenix Stadium to answer questions. Questions about the game, their lives and the experience of preparing for the big game. Some of the answers were cliche. Others funny. A few were insightful.

headline: “Once” Again, a Legit Nominee
text: At the 11th hour, members of the executive committee of the music branch of the Academy met and decided that in spite of some questions about the validity of “Falling Slowly,” a nominee for best song from the movie “Once”, the song was eligible and would be on ballots that shipped tomorrow morning. Charles Bernstein, chairman of the music branch executive committee, speaking to the Bagger by phone, read part of the committee’s statement on the matter:

headline: Voter Profile: John Weiss
text: Meet John Weiss, a police officer and Iraq veteran, and an independent voter from Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.

headline: Schieffer To Retire Next January
text: Bob Schieffer, a reporter for CBS News for nearly four decades and the host of “Face the Nation’’ for 17 years, said on Tuesday that he would retire next January, as a new president moves into the White House and he nears his 72nd birthday.

headline: McCain’s Florida Win: What It Means
text: Three instant reactions to John McCain’s victory in Florida:

headline: Forever Young
text: The Associated Press has a report of actress Sean Young checking into rehab , while the Hollywood Reporter has a video of director Julian Schnabel at the Directors Guild Awards, attempting to make his speech over Ms. Young’s heckling.

headline: The Florida Primary
text: Senator John McCain won the biggest delegate prize so far in a closely contested primary.

headline: Eating Meat: Is It Killing Us, and the Planet?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Year Into Job, WNET President Seeks a Heightened Urgency
text: When Neal Shapiro, president of the New York public television station WNET, Channel 13, heard about the Virginia Tech massacre in April, he reacted like the former NBC News president that he is: he wanted the station to produce a documentary about teenage rage and mental illness. Right away.

headline: Fed’s Issue on Rates: How Low?
text: WASHINGTON  Having stunned investors one week ago by unexpectedly slashing short-term interest rates, the Federal Reserve appears poised to announce another rate cut on Wednesday as insurance against a recession.

headline: Dip Once or Dip Twice?
text: OUR annual national snacking binge is almost here. It would take a very large bowl indeed to hold all the guacamole mashed from the more than 100 million avocados that are consumed on Super Bowl Sunday. (My rough calculation gives a hemisphere bowl 20 yards in diameter and 3 times the height of the goal post crossbars.) And guacamole is just one of many dips that will be shared around the TV.

headline: Restoring Civil Rights
text: In recent decades, and to much public acclaim, Congress passed a series of landmark laws designed to ensure equal rights for all Americans. Lately, and without much notice, the Supreme Court has been gutting them.

headline: Two More G.O.P. Congressmen Won’t Run
text: Two Republican representatives, Kenny Hulshof of Missouri and Ron Lewis of Kentucky, have announced plans to leave Congress, adding their names to a list of more than 24 House Republicans who will not be running for re-election. Mr. Hulshof, 49, who is in his sixth term in the House, is leaving Congress to run for governor of Missouri. Mr. Lewis, 61, who is completing his eighth term, said he was resigning to concentrate on his family.

headline: Amazon’s Profit More Than Doubles
text: For Amazon.com, the fourth quarter was even sweeter than usual. But Wall Street reacted negatively because profit margins slid slightly.

headline: Seeing Red Over Hillary
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Where Everyone, and Anything, Goes
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  A rope barred the walkway leading to the field at University of Phoenix Stadium on Tuesday morning. Reporters and camera operators strained behind it, fingers sticky from free pastries offered as they waited for the clock above the field to read 9:45 a.m.

headline: Foreign Retailers Follow Their Shoppers to New York
text: New York’s chic shopping districts seem to be teeming these days with foreign tourists, particularly Europeans, who have flown over to take advantage of the weak dollar. Less noticeable, perhaps, is the spate of new foreign shops. But brokers say that foreign retailers are also spending lavishly in New York.

headline: Special Flavor: The Big Rhubarb
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

headline: Forgery Sentence
text: An 84-year-old man whose family forged statues and paintings that were sold to museums including the Art Institute of Chicago received a two-year suspended sentence in London on Monday, The Associated Press reported. The man, George Greenhalgh, right; his wife, Olive, 83; and their son, Shaun, 46, pleaded guilty in 2002 to laundering money from the sale of forged artworks. In November a sentence of more than four years was imposed on Shaun, described by the authorities as the creator of fakes that supposedly ranged across the millennia, from gold and silver Roman and Anglo-Saxon works to sculptures attributed to Paul Gauguin and Henry Moore. Mrs. Greenhalgh received a one-year sentence. The police said the parents handled most of the sales. Detective Sgt. Vernon Rapley, chief of Scotland Yard’s art and antiques unit, said there was little doubt that some of the family’s forgeries were still circulating in the art world.

headline: Research Groups Boom in Washington
On Senator Kennedy’s Endorsement of Obama
text: To the Editor:

headline: Margaret Truman Daniel, President’s Daughter and Popular Author, Dies at 83
Penguins Try to Stay in the Race Without Crosby
text: NEWARK  Like the waiting room at a train station, a visitors’ dressing room is a place to get in and get out. But the Pittsburgh Penguins made themselves at home on Tuesday at Prudential Center, covering the walls with logos and laying a rug on the floor.

headline: On a Day of Talk, Burress’s Words Anger Giants Coach
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  In training camp six months ago, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin unveiled the season’s theme and had it printed on T-shirts: “Talk is cheap. Play the game.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about a disabled American spy satellite that is likely to plunge to earth by late February or early March referred imprecisely to Jonathan McDowell, an astronomer at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics who said it was fairly common for satellites to drop out of orbit. He is an analyst of various government space programs; he does not work for the government as an analyst of space programs.

headline: Financial Ties Are Cited as Issue in Spine Study
text: Some of the nation’s most prominent spine surgeons hailed it as a medical breakthrough.

headline: Village Wants to Keep Its Fields as They Are
text: Mellora Ansbro plays soccer for the Gotham girls’ team on the huge green fields within Pier 40, where city noises and river winds seem as remote as the Holland America Line ships that once pulled up alongside.

headline: Would-Be Peacemaker Killed in Kenya
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Melitus Mugabe Were, a freshman member of Parliament, could have been one of the keys to unlocking Kenya’s crisis, but he never got the chance.

headline: Rule Change to Help Smaller Companies Raise Funds
text: Federal regulators are about to ease rules that have made it difficult for small and medium-size publicly traded companies to raise money. The changes, experts say, are well timed, given the tightening credit market.

headline: Memorial Planned for Barbaro
text: Barbaro, who won the 2006 Kentucky Derby and broke down two weeks later at the Preakness, will have his ashes interred at Churchill Downs. He was euthanized Jan. 29, 2007. The site will include a bronze statue commissioned by Barbaro’s owners, Roy and Gretchen Jackson. The statue will be loaned to the track.

headline: New Hijuelos Books
text: Oscar Hijuelos plans a companion novel to his 1990 Pulitzer Prize winner, “The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,” as well as a memoir that will recall his encounters with musicians including Rubén Blades and Lou Reed, The Associated Press reported. The new novel, “Beautiful Maria of My Soul,” and the memoir, “Thoughts Without Cigarettes,” were announced jointly on Tuesday by Hyperion Books, which will publish the novel in 2009, and Gotham Books, a Penguin Group (USA) imprint, which will release the memoir in 2010.

headline: Diva Back in Damascus
text: Singing in Damascus for the first time in more than 20 years, the Lebanese diva Fairuz, 73, electrified an audience that included Vice President Farouq al-Shara on Monday night as that Syrian capital celebrated its designation as Arab Capital of Culture 2008, Agence France-Presse reported. Fairuz, above, widely considered the greatest Arab singer after the death of Umm Kalthoum in 1975, is to give eight concerts, all sold out.

headline: More Testing of Seafood to Address Mercury Concerns
text: A NUMBER of restaurants and retailers in different parts of the country have started testing the fish they sell in response to concerns about the amount of mercury in seafood, and the Environmental Protection Agency is beginning to examine the mercury content in fish sold in the New York City region.

headline: At White House, a Second Look at Iraq Troop Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  Four months after announcing troop reductions in Iraq, President Bush is now sending signals that the cuts may not continue past this summer, a development likely to infuriate Democrats and renew concerns among military planners about strains on the force.

headline: 3 More Airlines Cite Fuel Costs for Losses
text: Three airlines  Northwest, JetBlue and AirTran Holdings  posted fourth-quarter losses on Tuesday as rising fuel costs erased gains from fare increases.

headline: Seeking a Change, but Finding Few Choices
text: COLUMBIA, Tenn.  The domed courthouse clock tower tolls the hour, but not much else breaks the stillness in this centuries-old county seat where politics seems to have reached equilibrium, balanced between ancient Democratic traditions and newer Republican ones.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: A letter yesterday about Caroline Kennedy’s Op-Ed article endorsing Barack Obama was published under a false name. The writer was Joan Sommers, not Maggie Atwood.

headline: Bernanke’s Midterm Tests
text: The chairman of the Federal Reserve has come to seem a bit like a Supreme Court justice  an unelected, unaccountable figure who wields power for years, regardless of who’s in the White House.

headline: For Giuliani, Opening Note Stayed True
text: On his way to school one morning, a 13-year-old boy was knocked down by a cab outside his home on East 86th Street in Manhattan. The first ambulance arrived in six minutes. The boy was conscious. He had a small cut on his head. His leg hurt. With a supervisor steadying the boy’s head, the medics moved him onto a backboard, and then into the rear of the ambulance.

headline: Georgia: Troubled Hospital’s Leader Quits
text: The chief executive of Grady Memorial Hospital, Otis L. Story Sr., has resigned, ending a brief stint as the troubled hospital’s fourth C.E.O. since 2000. The public hospital, which handles a million patient visits a year and is one of the nation’s largest safety-net health providers, is millions of dollars in debt, needs more than $350 million in capital improvements and has faced steep drops in state and federal assistance. Mr. Story’s resignation came one day after the hospital board approved an agreement to lease the hospital to a new nonprofit corporation, a move board members hope will streamline costs and attract new government and philanthropic money.

headline: Kidd Shows Nets How Much They Could Soon Be Missing
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets’ nine-game losing streak ended Tuesday night, thanks in part to the play of Jason Kidd over the final two minutes. But how much longer the Nets can count on him to bail them out of tough spots remained uncertain after their 87-80 victory over Milwaukee.

headline: Germany: Lufthansa in Deal With Pilots
text: Deutsche Lufthansa, the German airline, reached an 18-month contract agreement with pilots to avoid further strikes. The airline’s 4,400 pilots will receive a 2.5 percent raise retroactive to Oct. 1 and an additional 3 percent increase retroactive to Jan. 1, Lufthansa said. The agreement runs through March 2009 and includes a one-time payment equal to 25 percent of a month’s wages.

headline: Drag Queen Who Reminisces About Her Drunken Family
text: Early in “Sisters, Such Devoted Sisters,” a crudely effective solo portrait of the seedy gay underworld in Glasgow, Russell Barr, the author and performer who portrays an angry, bruised drag queen, says that when he was young he accidentally cut off half his thumb.

headline: Super Bowl Game Balls: The Pride of Ada, Ohio
text: ADA, Ohio  The calls come in every year, right before the N.F.L.’s conference championship games, and when they do, Peg Price tries not to laugh.

headline: Bush’s Last State of the Union Address
text: To the Editor:

headline: White House Criticizes Envoy Over Iran
text: WASHINGTON  White House officials expressed anger on Tuesday about an appearance in which the United States ambassador to the United Nations, Zalmay Khalilzad, sat beside the Iranian foreign minister at a panel of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Saturday.

headline: A Lovefest, if Misery Loves Company
text: Pain, alienation and the thousand varieties of loneliness that flesh is heir to: these are the topics that Abi Morgan’s “Tender,” a British play being given its New York premiere by Thirteenth Night Theater, means to address. The action has been moved to New York from London, but misery trumps geography  these characters would be unhappy anywhere.

headline: Calendar
text: Simply Chocolate

headline: Imus Closer to a Return to TV in Big Cities
text: Viewers in Washington, D.C., Boston, Chicago and San Francisco, among other big cities, moved a step closer on Wednesday to being able to see a simulcast of Don Imus’s morning radio show on television.

headline: Beirut, On and Off the Radar
text: IN addition to its considerable charms, intermittent disappointments and svelte-letter palindrome of a name, the new restaurant Ilili presents a case study: how do you try to turn a medium-profile cuisine into a big-time event?

headline: Fed Reduces Rate by Half-Point; 2nd Cut in 8 Days
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve reduced short-term interest rates on Wednesday for the second time in eight days, meeting widespread expectations by investors on Wall Street for a big rate cut.

headline: Pressure Mounts for Resignation at French Bank
text: PARIS  Senior politicians here increased calls for the resignation of top executives at Société Générale, ahead of the board’s regular meeting, scheduled for early Wednesday.

headline: In the South Bronx, Robotics and Rebirth
text: At the end of a distinctly pugilistic day of sixth grade, Abdoulie Lemon was escorted by a dean to the industrial-arts classroom that doubled as the detention pen. No sooner had he restlessly settled into his chair than he caught sight of a dozen students gathered in rapt attention around a table at the other end of the room.

headline: Dining Briefs
text: NEW PLACES

headline: For a Change, New Jersey’s Primary Is at the Storm’s Center
text: BLACKWOOD, N.J.  From the spectacle of a visit by a former president to the buzz of informal gatherings in living rooms and coffee shops across New Jersey, Democrats find themselves in a competitive Democratic presidential primary for the first time in a generation.

headline: Knicks Can’t Keep Up With Kobe and the Lakers
text: LOS ANGELES  Isiah Thomas did not need to see Kobe Bryant orchestrate a fourth-quarter comeback and a near triple-double to endorse his candidacy for most valuable player. He got that out of the way on Monday, about 36 hours before the Knicks had to actually cope with Bryant.

headline: Good Times for Some
text: To the Editor:

headline: Big-Selling Drugs Aid Lilly Profit
text: INDIANAPOLIS (AP)  Strong sales from several drugs helped Eli Lilly & Company post a higher-than-expected fourth-quarter profit.

headline: Professor From Harvard to Be Barnard President
text: Barnard College has named as its next president Debora L. Spar, a Harvard Business School professor who has written about the economics of the human fertility industry and the evolution of the Internet but has not previously been affiliated with a women’s college.

headline: Canada: Cold Weather Shuts Down Oil Project
text: Extreme temperatures have frozen equipment and forced a shutdown at Syncrude Canada, the oil sands project. Most of the 350,000 barrels of oil produced daily at the project are sent to the United States. But temperatures in northern Alberta, where Syncrude is located, have dipped below minus 40 degrees at night this week. That has led to “several instrument freeze-ups,” the Canadian Oil Sands Trust, which owns about 37 percent of the project, said on Tuesday. Full production will probably not resume for several days.

headline: Nigeria Tops Benin to Advance
text: John Obi Mikel and Yakubu Aiyegbeni scored to lead Nigeria over Benin, 2-0, on Tuesday in Sekondi, Ghana, and into the quarterfinals of the African Cup of Nations. Ivory Coast (3-0), which already was assured of advancing, defeated Mali, 3-0. Ivory Coast won Group B and will play the Group A runner-up, Guinea, on Sunday. Nigeria (1-1-1) will meet host Ghana.

headline: It All Comes Down to (or Looks Up to) Bach
text: The jingling piano, the humming traffic and the prancing horse tap out separate if connecting songs in the beguiling nonnarrative film “The Silence Before Bach,” from the septuagenarian Spanish auteur Pere Portabella. You could say that these three make beautiful music together, though this observation doesn’t capture the contrapuntal complexity of the film, which unfolds note against note, scene against scene.

headline: North Carolina: Arrest Warrant for Marine
text: An arrest warrant has been issued in Mexico for a marine wanted in North Carolina for killing a fellow marine who had accused him of rape, said an official at the United States Embassy in Mexico City. The marine, Cpl. Cesar Laurean, 21, a naturalized United States citizen, was spotted visiting relatives in Guadalajara earlier this month. The warrant has been issued for the purposes of extradition, officials said. Corporal Laurean is accused of killing Lance Cpl. Maria Lauterbach and burying her remains in a fire pit in his backyard sometime in mid-December. She was eight months pregnant when she died. It remains unclear if Corporal Laurean was the father. Both marines were stationed at Camp Lejeune.

headline: Tropical Teaser: ‘Lost’ Clues Decoded
text: Here is the problem for ABC: In “Lost” it has the show with perhaps the most compelling continuing story line in television history, one whose resumption this week has been hotly anticipated by its devoted fans.

headline: Recipe: Roasted Delicata Squash Purée
text: Adapted from North Pond, ChicagoTime: About 1 hour 15 minutes (depending on size of squash)

headline: Italian Style Is Refracted Through a Chinese Lens
text: In one of the stranger acts of globalism, the Chinese are writing Italian operas. Xiao Bai’s “Farewell My Concubine” from the China National Opera House is touring the United States and came semistaged to Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night.

headline: Profit Drops at Dow Chemical
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. (AP)  The nation’s largest chemical company, Dow Chemical, said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 52 percent because of an overhaul effort and a $1.7 billion jump in spending on materials and energy.

headline: Clinton Wins in Florida, but Without Any Delegates to Sweeten the Victory
text: MIAMI  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won the Florida Democratic primary on Tuesday, a contest that generated extraordinary voter interest even though the result will have no practical impact because no delegates were at stake.

headline: Lilly in Settlement Talks With U.S.
text: Eli Lilly and federal prosecutors are discussing a settlement of a civil and criminal investigation into the company’s marketing of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa that could result in Lilly’s paying more than $1 billion to federal and state governments.

headline: Britain: Guilty Plea in Plot to Behead Soldier
text: A 37-year-old man from Birmingham, in the English midlands, has pleaded guilty to plotting to behead a British soldier. Parviz Khan, who described himself to investigators as a Muslim charity worker, was heard in covert recordings made by Britain’s security services outlining a plan to kidnap a soldier from Birmingham’s nightclub district and have him beheaded, the court in Leicester was told. Nigel Rumfitt, the prosecutor, said Mr. Khan’s plan was to videotape the killing and release the tape “to cause panic and fear within the British armed forces and wider public.” Three other men, all Muslims, have admitted offenses in the case, one of them a Gambian citizen tasked by Mr. Khan to identify a Muslim West African soldier serving in the British Army as the victim for the beheading plot, according to the prosecution. Mr. Khan was said to have shown the other men videos of terrorist beheadings in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $6,987,843

headline: Beyond Bank’s $7 Billion Loss, Fear of More
text: LONDON  Jérôme Kerviel’s 4.8 billion euro trading loss ($7.1 billion) had a positive effect for Société Générale, at least temporarily.

headline: Correction
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about residents of Martha’s Vineyard, Mass., who get most of their food in winter from the island’s farms, omitted a description about a protest that residents mounted regarding a 43-acre farm that had been leased to the island’s Community Sponsored Agriculture program. The protest was an attempt to keep the property from being sold to become a horse farm.

headline: Roddick and Blake in Cup Lineup
text: Andy Roddick and James Blake will lead the defending champion United States against Austria in the first round of the Davis Cup in Vienna on Feb. 8-10.

headline: Costa Rica: Delay in Trade Agreement Sought
text: President Óscar Arias of Costa Rica, below, said he would ask the United States to delay the start of a free-trade agreement to give the country time to pass several local laws. Costa Rica approved the Central American Free Trade Agreement in October, but its Congress has passed only 4 of 13 laws necessary to begin it, Mr. Arias said. The deadline for doing so is Feb. 29 and Mr. Arias acknowledged that his administration would not be ready by that date. The pact has already taken effect in the Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador.

headline: Stimulus Plan Advances
text: The Senate Finance Committee is set to produce an economic stimulus bill that, on balance, improves on the bill passed by the House on Tuesday. Among other things, the Senate version would extend unemployment benefits as needed for laid-off workers.

headline: Coach Follows Dream to Football’s Summit
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  He knew early on what his happiest days would look like, rising before the sun when he was 4 years old to be with his father at football practice at a high school in Canton, Ohio. Thom McDaniels is an Ohio coaching legend; Josh McDaniels wanted to be a coach  a high school coach  just like him.

headline: Some Quirky Drills for Gritty Players
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  No two practices ever seem the same for the Giants’ tight ends, not with their coach thumbing through his file of 430 practice drills, all of them specific to tight ends and some of them downright peculiar.

headline: Sensor Deprivation
text: AT the suggestion of the federal Department of Homeland Security, New York City Council members have drafted legislation requiring anyone who has or uses a detector that measures chemical, biological or radioactive agents to get a license from the Police Department.

headline: Brief Extension for Eavesdropping Law
text: Congress approved a 15-day extension of the government’s authority to eavesdrop on suspected terrorists to give lawmakers more time to consider permanent legislation. President Bush has threatened to veto a 30-day extension of the surveillance law that Democrats favor. The current law expires Friday, and Democrats and Republicans agreed on the 15-day measure. The Senate rejected Mr. Bush’s demand for quick passage of a permanent extension of the law.

headline: Festivals to Lead Carnegie’s Season
text: Phrases from spirituals floated softly from the podium. “Plenty good room, good room, in my Father’s kingdom,” Jessye Norman sang on Tuesday in a reception space at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Pouring of Concrete at High-Rise Sites Is Choreographed Like Ballet in Sky
text: The trucks navigate a cumbersome stop-and-go route on the chaotic streets of New York. The workers  dozens of them simultaneously  move with precision, nailing wood, twisting metal reinforcements, smoothing cement and climbing narrow wooden frames on cue, hundreds of feet in the air, sometimes in the face of swirling winds. Neighboring high rises often sit a crane’s whip away.

headline: Oh, Yugoslavia! How They Long for Your Firm Embrace
text: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia  This spring, Bostjan Troha and 50 of his friends from across the former Yugoslavia plan to celebrate the official 116th birthday of the former dictator Josip Broz Tito with a pilgrimage in boxy Yugoslav-era Fico cars to Tito’s Croatian birthplace and his marble tomb in Belgrade.

headline: Jury to Start Deliberations in Wesley Snipes Tax Case
text: OCALA, Fla.  The most prominent tax prosecution in nearly two decades went to the jury Tuesday after defense lawyers argued that while a defendant, the actor Wesley Snipes, did in fact owe tens of millions of dollars in back taxes, interest and penalties, he had not committed a crime.

headline: Subpoenas Over Fraudulent Drug Data
text: A Congressional subcommittee voted to subpoena former and current Food and Drug Administration investigators to testify about fraudulent clinical data that supported approval of the antibiotic drug Ketek. Ketek was approved in 2004. It is manufactured by Sanofi Aventis. Last February, after getting reports of liver failure in some patients treated with the drug, the F.D.A. issued its sternest warning and restricted use to patients with pneumonia. The four people subpoenaed had conducted their own inquiry in connection with Ketek’s approval.

headline: Learning to Mix Business With Art
text: Hospital administrators usually do not find themselves offering advice or encouragement to art museum curators. But in an elegant Upper East Side town house the other day, Harold E. Varmus, the Nobel laureate and president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, told a group of prestigious curators something that made several gasp audibly.

headline: A Pilgrimage in India Timed by a Taxi Meter
text: The title characters in “Three Travelers,” a comedy by Richard Abrons, aren’t lost, but the actors playing them seem to be. And that costs the production, staged by the New Federal Theater under the direction of Jay Broad, a lot of its punch.

headline: Overhaul, Make It a Venti
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.When a Starbucks moved in next door, the coffee fanatics who run the Broadway Cafe trembled. Sure, they roasted their own beans and served up handmade espresso drinks to a loyal clientele. But would it be enough to fight off a corporate behemoth?

headline: Italy: Sales Rise at Eyeglass Maker
text: The Luxottica Group, the Italian maker of eyeglasses, said fourth-quarter sales rose 7.1 percent after last year’s acquisition of Oakley. Revenue at the company, which operates Sunglass Hut and LensCrafter stores and makes Ray-Ban sunglasses, climbed to 1.19 billion euros ($1.8 billion) from 1.11 billion euros a year earlier. Fourth-quarter wholesale sales rose 16 percent to 479 million euros ($705 million). Sales fell 1.7 percent at retail stores open at least a year, reflecting Luxottica’s exposure in the United States. Luxottica bought Oakley for $2 billion in June.

headline: Starbucks Scales Back U.S. Expansion
text: As it begins a major turnaround effort, Starbucks on Wednesday announced a slight gain in quarterly profits and a significant slowdown in the rate of growth in the United States as it seeks to recapture its former glory.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening this Week

headline: McCain Defeats Romney in Florida Vote
text: MIAMI  Senator John McCain defeated Mitt Romney on Tuesday to win the delegate-rich Florida primary, solidifying his transformation to the Republican front-runner and dealing a devastating blow to the presidential hopes of Rudolph W. Giuliani.

headline: DeCamp Bus Line No. 66 From the Port Authority to Upper Montclair, N.J.
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: Recipe: Braised Kale
text: Adapted from North Pond, Chicago

headline: Dissident’s Arrest Hints at Olympic Crackdown
text: BEIJING  When state security agents burst into his apartment last month, Hu Jia was chatting on Skype, the Internet-based telephone system. Mr. Hu’s computer was his most potent tool. He disseminated information about human rights cases, peasant protests and other politically touchy topics even though he often lived under de facto house arrest.

headline: Kicking Democracy’s Corpse in Russia
text: Look into the eyes of Vladimir Putin, the president of Russia, and what you see is a K.G.B.-trained mind that apparently cannot tolerate leaving any detail of an election to chance.

headline: One Pot
text: A COCIDO, a soulful, slow-cooked stew of tender chickpeas, bacon, spareribs and chorizo, is an ancient Spanish dish.

headline: What You Get for... $12.5 Million
text: Water Mill, N.Y.

headline: Wal-Mart Will Shake Up Apparel Unit; Layoffs Set
text: In a major revamping of its sluggish clothing business, Wal-Mart Stores will shut two divisions at its headquarters in Arkansas, eliminate dozens of positions and move dozens more to New York City.

headline: Doctor Accused of Leak to Drug Maker
text: A key member of the Senate said Wednesday that a prominent diabetes expert leaked an unpublished and confidential medical journal article to GlaxoSmithKline last year, tipping the company to the imminent publication of safety questions involving the company’s diabetes drug Avandia.

headline: Down on the Farm and Up in Washington, Hoyas’ Wallace Excels
text: WASHINGTON  When Georgetown point guard Jonathan Wallace was in elementary school, he worked on his family’s 80-acre cattle farm in Harvest, Ala.

headline: S.& P. Home Price Index Continued to Fall in November
text: Home prices in 20 metropolitan areas fell in November for the 11th consecutive month, as foreclosures and a slump in sales added to the glut of unsold properties.

headline: Thomas Barr, Top Lawyer in I.B.M. Case, Dies at 77
text: Thomas D. Barr, a formidable lawyer whose tenacity and discipline helped transform the way major corporate litigation is conducted, died Thursday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 77.

headline: A Long Surrender: The Guerrilla War After the Civil War
text: In April 1865 Robert E. Lee surrendered to Ulysses S. Grant, putting an end to four years of savage internecine conflict and settling the issue of slavery forever. “The war is over,” Grant said. “The rebels are our countrymen again.”

headline: Pettitte Deposition Postponed
text: WASHINGTON  The House oversight committee has postponed a deposition of Andy Pettitte as part of its investigation into Roger Clemens’s denials that he used performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Pettitte Will Discuss Clemens, Lawyers Say
text: WASHINGTON Andy Pettitte will soon give a sworn deposition to staff members of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, and lawyers for his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, say they believe they know part of what he will say.

headline: Iran Executes Bribery Convict
text: TEHRAN  Iran’s judiciary has executed an airport customs contractor accused of bribe-taking and other corruption and has sentenced three other airport employees to death, the Iranian news agency ISNA reported Tuesday.

headline: Bill Would Bar Sex Offenders From Facebook and MySpace
text: ALBANY  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo and state lawmakers, with the backing of the social networking sites MySpace and Facebook, are pushing a bill that would crack down on sex offenders’ use of the sites.

headline: Bomb Explodes Near U.S. Patrol in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide car bomb exploded near an American patrol in the northern city of Mosul on Tuesday, a day after Sunni Arab guerrillas killed five American soldiers during an ambush on a convoy in Mosul.

headline: Police Shooting of Mother and Infant Exposes a City’s Racial Tension
text: LIMA, Ohio  The air of Southside is foul-smelling and thick, filled with fumes from an oil refinery and diesel smoke from a train yard, with talk of riot and recrimination, and with angry questions: Why is Tarika Wilson dead? Why did the police shoot her baby?

headline: Lawmakers Say Mattel Broke Word on Lead
text: Dozens of members of Congress sent a letter Tuesday to the chief executive of Mattel, accusing the company of not living up to its promise to keep lead-tainted toys out of children’s hands.

headline: Comfort Food in Hong Kong
text: The Eskimos, so they say, have 12 different words for snow. Well, in Hong Kong, we have a dozen or more ways to say: Eat Here!

headline: U.S. Failed to Oversee Corps on Iraq Work, Agency Says
text: A federal report released Tuesday says the Army Corps of Engineers charged the government hundreds of millions of dollars for supervising projects in Iraq that have been identified as having failed or fallen behind schedule specifically because oversight was lax or nonexistent.

headline: Illinois: Energy Dept. Pulling Support for Clean Power Plant
text: Frustrated by ballooning costs for an ambitious plan to build a virtually emissions-free power plant, the Energy Department told federal lawmakers that it planned to pull its support for the $1.8 billion project in Illinois, lawmakers said. The department would not divulge its intentions about the plant, called FutureGen, or discuss what was said in the private meeting with lawmakers, saying only that it planned an announcement. But some lawmakers who attended the briefing later insisted that any departure from building the coal-fired, 275-megawatt prototype power plant anywhere other than the central Illinois town of Mattoon would be unacceptable  and grounds for a possibly nasty Congressional fight. Senator Richard J. Durbin, above, Democrat of Illinois, accused Energy Secretary Samuel W. Bodman of “cruel deception” of Illinoisans by “creating false hope in a FutureGen project which he has no intention of funding or supporting.”

headline: Young Runner Lets a Champion Dictate His Pace
text: At age 21, baby face and all, Galen Rupp is one of the United States’ brightest young distance runners. He is also a realist. He says he will not win the Wanamaker Mile in the Millrose Games on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, but he expects to be in the fight.

headline: Pitching Prize in Mets’ Grasp: Twins’ Santana
text: Until Tuesday, the Mets had conducted a quiet off-season, switching catchers and acquiring a few relievers and an outfielder. None of the moves did much to counteract the disenchantment that took hold after the team’s memorable collapse in the final weeks of last season.

headline: When the Campaign Comes to New York, It’s a Tough Room but a Rich Prize
text: With Florida behind them and more than 20 primaries looming next Tuesday, the presidential candidates are about to grapple with a state where the Democratic governor’s popularity is in the gutter, the most powerful Republican is under federal investigation and the mayor of the largest city bolted not one but both political parties and has been mulling a presidential race himself.

headline: City Centralizes Hiring Process for Principals
text: The Bloomberg administration is overhauling the way that principals at New York City’s 1,500 public schools are evaluated and selected, taking centralized control of the initial screening of candidates and trying to shake up a system where, officials say, a vast majority of principals routinely get satisfactory evaluations.

headline: Hotel Where Dodgers Celebrated a Title Is Up for Sale
text: The historic Hotel Bossert, where the Brooklyn Dodgers celebrated their first and last World Series championship more than a half-century and many bittersweet memories ago, is being put up for sale.

headline: Gluttonous Rite Survives Without Silverware
text: IT was Friday evening at V.F.W. Post 4591 in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and the scene was a vegetarian’s nightmare.

headline: Estonia Bans Travel for Kremlin Youth Group
text: MOSCOW  Like many Russians, Mariana B. Skvortsova planned to spend her winter vacation traveling abroad. Yet, as she tried to cross from Russia into Finland this month, border guards refused her entry.

headline: Brady Stands Up to Blitz: Pass Rushers or Paparazzi
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  It was with much sympathy that Joe Montana watched the footage of New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady facing an all-out blitz in New York last week. And a little surprise. In that situation, Montana wondered, why wouldn’t Brady try a play fake?

headline: Patriots’ Backup Quarterback Happy Playing Himself
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The backup spends his days in the shadow of the famous quarterback. There is Tom Brady, always, with his magazine covers and his model companion and his record-breaking season as the Patriots’ starting quarterback.

headline: Recipe: Crispy Potato Wedges With Mustard
text: Adapted from Waldy Malouf, Beacon Restaurant

headline: Man Killed in Hoboken Blaze
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.  A four-alarm fire swept through an apartment building here early Tuesday, killing one man and leaving more than 60 people homeless.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A dance review on Monday about the Cool New York 2008 Dance Festival, at the John Ryan Theater in Brooklyn, misidentified the dancer who performed a solo by Darcy Naganuma. He is Kambi Gathesha, not Charly Wenzel (who is a woman).

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Verizon’s earnings misstated its revenue for 2007 in some copies. It was $93.4 billion, not million.

headline: Mets Acquiring Santana From Twins
text: Until Tuesday, the Mets had, by their standards, conducted a quiet offseason, having switched catchers and added a few bullpen pieces and an outfielder but done nothing to prevent last season’s historic collapse from being the most-discussed topic when spring training gets under way in two weeks.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Shockey’s Loss Is Not the Giants’ Gain
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Mike Pope, the Giants’ tight ends coach, is aware of the conjecture that their offense has been better off without Jeremy Shockey, who broke his leg in mid-December. In Shockey’s absence, the Giants’ offense, and most especially quarterback Eli Manning, have been startlingly effective.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 23 about Senate debate on a plan to provide immunity for telephone companies that helped the National Security Agency with a wiretapping program misspelled the surname of the director of the Washington legislative office of the American Civil Liberties Union who criticized Senator Harry Reid’s strategy for handling the measure. She is Caroline Fredrickson, not Frederickson.

headline: Outside Groups Aid Obama, Their Vocal Critic
text: After months of denouncing the influence of special-interest money in politics, Senator Barack Obama is nonetheless entering a critical phase of the presidential campaign benefiting from millions of dollars being spent outside campaign finance rules.

headline: Colorado Woman Faces Murder Charge in Fire That Killed One Child and Injured 4
text: DENVER  A woman is suspected of setting her house in Colorado Springs on fire Monday night, killing her 16-month-old daughter and badly injuring her four other children.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Verizon’s earnings misstated its revenue for 2007 in some copies. It was $93.4 billion, not million. (Go to Article)

headline: ‘Jerry Springer,’ the Great American Musical
text: Oh hear America singing, citizens of New York, as you never have heard it before. Hearken to your everyday sisters and brothers  the lost, the lonely, the fetishists, the freaks  as their voices swell and meld into one common chord of longing: to be seen, to be heard, to be (oh yes) famous.

headline: The Suit Maker Who Sounded the Alarm About Nazis
text: If you’ve always found puppets only slightly more appealing than, say, clowns, “Fabrik: The Legend of M. Rabinowitz” may well change your mind. This modest yet powerfully affecting production capitalizes on the range of the art form and takes it to impressive heights.

headline: Mukasey Offers View on Waterboarding
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey said Tuesday that the harsh C.I.A. interrogation technique known as waterboarding was not clearly illegal, and suggested that it could be used against terrorism suspects once again if requested by the White House.

headline: After 40 Years, Schieffer Plans to Quit CBS in Early 2009
text: Bob Schieffer, a reporter for CBS News for nearly four decades and the host of “Face the Nation” for 17 years, said Tuesday night that he would retire next January, as a new president is sworn in and as he nears his 72nd birthday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Media Equation column in Business Day on Monday, about the News Corporation blending its news and sports divisions to cover the Super Bowl and the coming Tuesday primaries, misidentified the location of the Super Bowl this Sunday. The game will be played at the University of Phoenix Stadium in Glendale, Ariz., not in Phoenix itself.

headline: F.B.I. Opens Subprime Inquiry
text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has opened criminal inquiries into 14 companies as part of a wide-ranging investigation of the troubled mortgage industry, F.B.I. officials said Tuesday.

headline: Roasted Beefsteak Sirloin With Blood and Butter Sauce
text: Adapted from Waldy Malouf, Beacon Restaurant

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary in some editions on Monday about Gordon B. Hinckley, the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, attributed an erroneous distinction to him concerning the number of years he spent in the church’s top leadership. Although he spent 46 years in leadership posts, he was not the longest-serving president; Brigham Young was. The obituary also described the church’s office of the First Presidency incorrectly. It encompasses the church president and his two advisers; it is not a two-man team that counsels the president. The obituary also rendered incorrectly the name of a fund Mr. Hinckley established to pay for needy church members to attend college and misstated its source of financing. It is the Perpetual Education Fund, not the Perpetual Loan Fund, and it is financed by contributions, not tithes.

headline: Spellman Arrested After Chase
text: The former N.F.L. player Alonzo Spellman was arrested Tuesday in Tulsa, Okla., after a nearly 20-minute chase in which police fired pepper-spray pellets into his car. His bond was set at $10,700, and Spellman remained jailed early Tuesday evening. Spellman played nine seasons in the N.F.L. for the Chicago Bears, the Detroit Lions and the Dallas Cowboys.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about the management turnover at Interview magazine referred incompletely to the positions held by Sandra Brant at Brant Publications, which owns Interview. Ms. Brant is the chief executive, president and publisher of Brant Publications, and will continue in those roles until Feb. 22; she is not just the publisher.

headline: A Comeback Story Decades in the Making
text: WASHINGTON  Many neglected urban neighborhoods have been renewed across the country in recent years, but few cities have experienced changes as extensive as those in Washington.

headline: NBC Sues Dick Wolf
text: In a spat between partners who have shared a lot of success, NBC Universal has filed suit against Dick Wolf, the prolific producer of the network’s three “Law & Order” series. The suit, filed last week in Los Angeles County Superior Court, centers on complex terms in Mr. Wolf’s contract. NBC argues that Mr. Wolf, right, is misinterpreting them to demand millions of dollars in executive-producer fees for two years after his shows leave the air. NBC’s interpretation is that if the network produces a sufficient number of episodes it can fulfill the contract and not owe Mr. Wolf for work he is no longer doing. Mr. Wolf’s side contends that the contract guarantees the money as a kind of termination payment, or “kill fee.” No matter when NBC decides to end his series, Mr. Wolf argues, he is to be paid for 48 more episodes. NBC asks that if the court finds the contract language ambiguous, it direct that the errors be fixed rather than force NBC to pay the money. A representative of Mr. Wolf, who like other Hollywood writers is on strike, said he was traveling on Tuesday and could not be reached. But Mr. Wolf issued a statement last week saying: “NBC Universal is trying to rewrite an existing contract. Apparently, our partner is willing to commission rewrites during the strike.”

headline: The Fine Print
text: With President Bush, you always have to read the footnotes.

headline: War Concussions Linked to Stress
text: About one in six combat troops returning from Iraq have suffered at least one concussion in the war, injuries that, while fleeting, could heighten their risk of developing post-traumatic stress disorder, researchers are reporting.

headline: Vuitton Is Embracing Medium of the Masses
text: IN an unusual marketing move for a fashion and luxury goods brand, Louis Vuitton said Tuesday that it planned to advertise on television for the first time, with a travel-themed 90-second spot that was shot in France, Spain, India and Japan.

headline: The French Answer to Pecan Pie
text: AMONG the many assets of pecan pie is, oddly enough, an intensity so piercing that you can’t eat much of it. In fact, pecan pie usually feeds twice as many people as you expect it to.

headline: Coughlin Writes His Own Material
text: Glendale, Ariz.

headline: Methodists Against Bush Library Lobby for Vote
text: DALLAS  Methodists opposed to a George W. Bush Presidential Library, museum and policy institute at Southern Methodist University here are mounting a last-ditch effort to block a nearly completed deal by throwing the decision to a regional church conference in July.

headline: Curry and Brown Still Struggling to Fulfill Potential
text: LOS ANGELES  In seven N.B.A seasons, Eddy Curry has been praised, cheered, berated, traded, cheered, booed and benched. No wonder his expression sometimes seems fixed in a state of bemusement. The person who may best understand that look stood across from Curry on Tuesday night, providing a momentary mirror image of teenage dreams gone awry.

headline: Recipe: Roasted Arctic Char With Ancho-Shallot Butter
text: Adapted from North Pond, Chicago

headline: When Truck Is Disabled, the Meals Stop, Too
text: The orders were coming in fast. Rice and pigeon peas, fried plantains, okra, tripe soup, and steak with onions. Inside a truck, nestled under a rocky drop from Highbridge Park in Upper Manhattan, four Dominican women, wearing multiple layers to protect them from the freezing January air, gracefully hustled to fill each order. They filled tins with hefty scoops of rice and ladles of soupy red beans.

headline: In Santana Duel, Mets Are Left Standing
text: All winter, the experts said the Mets didn’t have a chance, and all winter, the Mets’ general manager quietly and confidently said he would be the last one standing when the Minnesota Twins traded Johan Santana. The Twins traded Santana on Tuesday, and look who got him.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the On Baseball column on Sunday about a book to be released this spring that includes interviews with 11 stars of the game from the 1950s and ’60s attributed an incorrect distinction to four of the men. The former players Ralph Branca, Carl Erskine, Bill Rigney and Lew Burdette are not in the Hall of Fame.

headline: Obama Campaigns in His Grandfather’s Hometown
text: EL DORADO, Kan.  When Senator Barack Obama arrived here Tuesday afternoon on the gusty plains of Kansas, the political stage was set for a homecoming, a moment to highlight a branch of his family tree that receives far less attention in a presidential campaign that has been rooted in biography.

headline: For Giuliani, a Dizzying Free-Fall
text: Perhaps he was living an illusion all along.

headline: Stocks Rally Then Fall Back
text: Wall Street watched a Fed rally abruptly fizzle on Wednesday, as excitement over an interest rate cut gave way to concern about a new round of problems related to the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Pellicano Delivers a Surprise
text: In a surprise move in his first appearance since taking over as his own lawyer, Anthony Pellicano, the embattled Hollywood private investigator, withdrew his request for a hearing into allegations that the F.B.I. and federal prosecutors violated his constitutional rights by using his former girlfriend to elicit confidential information, The Los Angeles Times reported. In withdrawing the request, Mr. Pellicano, who is facing trial on wiretapping and conspiracy charges, told Judge Dale S. Fischer of United States District Court, “I don’t believe I had any chance of prevailing.” The accusation of prosecutorial misconduct was a crucial element in the defense of the lawyers who previously represented Mr. Pellicano. Thom Mrozek, a spokesman for the United States Attorney’s Office in Los Angeles, expressed satisfaction with the withdrawal and said, “We have always believed that the motion was unfounded.” The judge plans to begin the trial on Feb. 27.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,924 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: McCain’s Victory in a Party-Only Primary Raises the Hurdles for Romney
text: MIAMI  Senator John McCain’s victory in the Florida primary came in the face of considerable odds and suggests that his chief rival here, Mitt Romney, faces tough going in what has effectively become a two-person Republican field.

headline: Edwards Drops Out of Democratic Race
text: NEW ORLEANS  John Edwards, the progressive Democratic candidate who made a populist, antipoverty message the centerpiece of his campaign, announced his exit from the presidential primary race on Wednesday, saying he was stepping aside “so that history can blaze its path.”

headline: Campo Returns to Cowboys
text: The former Cowboys coach Dave Campo rejoined the staff Tuesday as the secondary coach. Campo was the only coach never to get Dallas into the playoffs  the Cowboys were 5-11 in each of his three seasons. He replaces Todd Bowles, one of several assistants who left to join the staff of the new Dolphins coach Tony Sparano, a former Cowboys assistant.

headline: Papers Show Wider Focus in Inquiry of Artifacts
text: LOS ANGELES  A federal investigation into the smuggling and sale of looted Asian and American Indian antiquities has expanded to include stolen artifacts from Central America; a collector who is on the board of the Art Institute of Chicago; a gallery in Encino, Calif.; and a second alleged smuggler, according to federal court documents made public this week.

headline: Inhabiting the Spirits of Songs, While Letting Them Speak for Themselves
text: Not long ago a countertenor could be expected to specialize in early music: that was the point of becoming one. David Daniels has accepted that limitation in his opera career, and until a vogue erupts for countertenor Alfredos or Tristans, he doesn’t have much choice. But in recitals Mr. Daniels does as he likes, and if that means opening a concert with a Brahms group, as he did on Monday evening at Zankel Hall, who will complain?

headline: Robbins Celebration
text: Jerome Robbins, below, will be celebrated by New York City Ballet in performances of 33 of his dances during its spring season, running from April 29 through June 29. The tribute at the New York State Theater, featuring 10 all-Robbins programs, each showcasing a different aspect of his work, will commemorate the 90th anniversary of his birth. Guest artists participating in the event will include dancers from American Ballet Theater, the Paris Opera Ballet and the Royal Ballet.

headline: Austria: Death Camp Case Reopened
text: Prosecutors reopened the case of Erna Wallisch, 85, who ranks seventh on the Simon Wiesenthal Center’s list of most-wanted Nazi war criminals, after new evidence suggested that the woman might have taken part in the mass murder of inmates in the Majdanek concentration camp near Lublin, Poland. “We are trying to establish whether statements from Polish witnesses are sufficient to identify Mrs. Wallisch,” said Gerhard Jarosch, spokesman for the state prosecutors in Vienna, in a telephone interview. “Obviously this is very difficult more than six decades later.” The woman, who served as a guard in the death camp, is living in a small apartment in Vienna.

headline: Justice in Darfur
text: To the Editor:

headline: N.Y.U. Offers an Accord on Growth
text: Eager to cool its often rancorous relations with its neighbors in Greenwich Village  and to pave the way for its next 25 years of expansion  New York University has agreed to try to push some of its expansion farther from its central core, to consult the community when it designs new space and to develop policies to relocate tenants when they must be moved because of university construction.

headline: 7-Year-Old’s Blood Found on Stepfather, Expert Says
text: Blood found throughout the apartment of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown and under the fingernails of the man accused of killing her belonged to the girl, a representative of the chief medical examiner’s office testified Tuesday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Kidney Thefts Shock India
text: GURGAON, India  As the anesthetic wore off, Naseem Mohammed said, he felt an acute pain in the lower left side of his abdomen. Fighting drowsiness, he fumbled beneath the unfamiliar folds of a green medical gown and traced his fingers over a bandage attached with surgical tape. An armed guard by the door told him that his kidney had been removed.

headline: David Bradley, 92, Author, Antinuclear Advocate, Champion Skier and State Legislator, Is Dead
text: David Bradley, a writer, surgeon and antinuclear advocate whose best-selling first book, “No Place to Hide,” was an eyewitness account of the postwar atomic tests on Bikini Atoll in the South Pacific, died on Jan. 7 in Norway, Me. He was 92. A former resident of Hanover, N.H., Dr. Bradley had lived in Maine in recent years.

headline: For Many Turks, Head Scarf’s Return Aids Religion and Democracy
text: ISTANBUL  The Turkish government’s decision this week to lift a ban on women wearing head scarves in universities raised a troubling question: Is Islam starting to erode Turkey’s secular democracy?

headline: France: Mitterrand Items Auctioned
text: A famous black felt hat and other personal objects worn by the former French president, François Mitterrand, were sold at a Paris auction. The sale fetched about $192,000, money that will be donated to a charity run by Mr. Mitterrand’s widow, Danielle. More than 300 items went under the gavel, including official gifts, like a miniature ceramic house from Barbara Bush and a crocodile-skin briefcase from Fidel Castro. The auction was the third organized by Mrs. Mitterrand since her husband’s death 12 years ago.

headline: Obama Donates Challenged Funds
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  After another review of campaign contributions, an aide to Senator Barack Obama said Tuesday evening that the campaign was giving to charity $72,650 in donations tied to an indicted Chicago businessman, Antoin Rezko, who helped raise money for Mr. Obama’s Senate campaign four years ago.

headline: Rutgers Will Expand Stadium
text: Rutgers University approved spending $102 million to expand its football stadium by 14,000 seats. The plan approved by the university’s governing board will boost the stadium’s capacity to 56,000.The plan calls for borrowing $72 million that will be repaid through increased ticket revenues. Another $30 million is to come from private donations. The project is expected to be completed by 2009.

headline: Yahoo to Cut 1,000 Jobs, and Warns on Growth
text: SAN FRANCISCO  After announcing a sharp drop in fourth-quarter profits Tuesday, Yahoo issued a disappointing outlook for this year, suggesting that investors would have to wait until 2009 for a turnaround.

headline: Where Moss Goes, So Go Brady and the Patriots
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The woman in the wedding dress was gone, and so was the genie who predicted Patriots quarterback Tom Brady would receive two rings in 2008  a Super Bowl championship ring and a wedding band.

headline: Worker in Brooklyn Killed in Fall
text: Two workers apparently fell from a scaffold on Wednesday while working on the roof of a 13-story high-rise under construction in Brooklyn, officials said.

headline: Moss Is More Than Sound Bites
text: Glendale, Ariz.

headline: Snow Buries Many Areas as West Braces for New Storms
text: BOISE, Idaho (AP)  A powerful storm system raced across the nation Tuesday, bringing heavy snow and numbing cold as well as thunderstorms and possible tornadoes, and forecasters warned that more bad weather was on the way.

headline: Recipe: Cocido
text: Adapted from Alexandra Raij, Tía Pol

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Jan. 18 about “A A Bronson’s School for Young Shamans” at John Connelly Presents, in Chelsea, rendered part of Mr. Bronson’s name incorrectly. He uses “A A,” not A.A. The entry also misstated the former relationship between Mr. Bronson and the artist Terence Koh, who collaborated on a work in the show. Mr. Koh was Mr. Bronson’s studio assistant, not his student.

headline: New Literary Program to Make Its Home Online
text: Daniel Menaker, who left his post as executive editor in chief of the Random House Publishing Group in June, is moving online in March to be the host of a new Web-based book show.

headline: Costs of Overfishing
text: To the Editor:

headline: ABC News in Front
text: In the extremely tight ratings race between the two leading evening news broadcasts, ABC’s “World News With Charles Gibson” last week edged past its rival, NBC’s “Nightly News With Brian Williams,” for the first time in eight weeks. Nielsen estimated that the ABC newscast drew 9.8 million viewers, its highest average in nearly a year and slightly more than the 9.6 million who tuned in to NBC. ABC’s slim margin of victory was only modestly higher in the age bracket of adults 25 to 54, a demographic the two networks split evenly during the previous week. The last time ABC finished No. 1 was during the November sweeps period. Last week CBS’s “Evening News With Katie Couric” remained a distant third (7.13 million).

headline: Recipe: Walnut Tart
text: Time: 40 minutes (with premade crust), plus chilling

headline: Instant Nutrition
text: Butte, Mont.

headline: Afghan Women Protest Aid Worker’s Kidnapping
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  About 500 Afghan women gathered Tuesday in this southern city to protest the kidnapping of an American aid worker and her Afghan driver and to call for her release.

headline: Hall of Fame Game to Be Dropped
text: This year’s Hall of Fame Game between the Chicago Cubs and San Diego Padres on June 16 will be the last in the exhibition series. Officials at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum said Tuesday that Major League Baseball decided that keeping the game was too difficult because of the complexities of the major league schedule. The first Hall of Fame Game was played in 1940.

headline: A Befuddlement of Liquor Laws
text: I have a confession to make. I am a lawbreaker.

headline: House Approves Economic Stimulus Plan
text: WASHINGTON  The House voted on Tuesday to approve a $146 billion fiscal stimulus package, hoping to seal a fast-paced deal with President Bush on tax rebates and business incentives intended to jolt the economy with new spending.

headline: Mukasey Demurs on Waterboarding
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey got a harsh reception on Wednesday from senators of both parties, who used his appearance on Capitol Hill to accuse the Bush administration yet again of contempt for the rule of law and American values. But they told Mr. Mukasey he was a big improvement over his predecessor, Alberto R. Gonzalez.

headline: An Appeal That Looks to (and Uses) the Spirit of the 1960s
text: This 30-second advertisement for Senator Barack Obama begins on Wednesday in Boston, Los Angeles, New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco and nationally on cable television. The spot, “Caroline,” is the first with Caroline Kennedy.

headline: A Police Confrontation Comes Slowly Into Focus
text: WHITE PLAINS  The off-duty police officer was sitting in his parked car when he saw two men fighting on a downtown street. He stepped out of the car and tried to break up the confrontation, then rushed inside the county government building nearby to ask for help.

headline: No Go for Foxy Brown
text: The truculent rapper Foxy Brown will stay put  in jail  after Acting Justice Melissa C. Jackson of the New York State Supreme Court rejected her petition for early release to enable her to travel to California for an ear examination and repair of an electronic ear implant, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Brown, 29, right, whose real name is Inga Marchand, complained that her hearing problems were worsening in jail and that she faced serious harm unless her cochlear implant was repaired and reprogrammed. Prosecutors said she could get the treatment she needs in New York. She was sentenced in September to a year in jail for violating probation. She was put on probation after pleading guilty to misdemeanor assault of two manicurists at a Manhattan nail salon in August 2004.

headline: French Bank Chief Stays for Now
text: PARIS  With pressure for his resignation flowing from nearly every major French politician amid a trading scandal that has darkened France’s reputation as well as his bank’s, the chief of Société Générale put his job on the table Wednesday for the second time in a week.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Saturday about optimistic comments by Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning regarding his brother Eli’s prospects for future Super Bowls with the Giants misidentified the location of the 2006 season opener between their teams. It was at Giants Stadium, not in Indianapolis.

headline: TV Showman, Once Exiled, Returns With Video Site
text: LOS ANGELES  One of Big Media’s most controversial executives is back after a period of quasi-forced retirement.

headline: Taking Worry Off the Plate
text: WATCHING the amount of mercury in your diet does not have to mean avoiding seafood.

headline: Wariner Splits With Coach
text: With the Beijing Games only seven months away, the defending Olympic 400 meters champion Jeremy Wariner and his longtime coach have split over a contract dispute. Clyde Hart, who has coached Wariner for five years beginning with their days at Baylor University, said Wariner wanted to pay him less than in his previous contracts. Michael Johnson, the world-record holder in the 200 and Wariner’s agent, did not immediately respond to a telephone message seeking comment left with Wariner’s manager, Deon Minor.

headline: On Iraq, Bush Shows a More Restrained Optimism
text: President Bush left his comments on Iraq until nearly halfway through his final State of the Union address on Monday night, after his discussion of domestic issues like the economy, health care and education, even though the war is one of the two most important factors shaping the American agenda, along with the economy.

headline: 3M’s Profit Falls After a 2006 Gain
text: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)  The 3M Company, which makes Scotch tape, Post-it notes and industrial adhesives, posted lower fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, compared with the quarter a year ago, which included a one-time gain.

headline: Field Narrows as Giuliani and Edwards End Campaigns
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Rudolph W. Giuliani, the combative former Republican mayor of New York City, and John Edwards, the Democrat who ran for the White House as an anti-poverty populist, both dropped out of the presidential race on Wednesday, leaving a narrowed field hurtling toward what amounts to a national primary next week.

headline: Pakistan Movie Ban
text: A Pakistani Senate committee has proposed an end to the four-decade ban on showing movies from India, Agence France-Press reported. In a statement on Tuesday, the committee referred to the films when it said, “The ban has practically become ineffective as these are being viewed uncensored in almost every household on cable TV as well as CDs and DVDs, necessitating a reappraisal to deal with the issue rationally.”

headline: Henry Froehlich, Pioneer in Japanese Camera Imports, Is Dead at 85
