text: Henry Froehlich, one of the first distributors of high-tech Japanese cameras in the United States and one of the developers of an easy process for transferring home movies from film to videotape, died in Manhattan last Thursday. He was 85 and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

headline: Letters
text: Coffee Royale

headline: A Celebration Unto Itself
text: WHEN it happened for the second time in two weeks, I paid attention.

headline: Youth to Be Tried as Adult in Newark Triple Murder
text: NEWARK  A 17-year-old will be tried as an adult for what prosecutors said was his “active role” in the killings of three young people in a Newark schoolyard last summer, a judge ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Controversy Dogs Inquiry on Bridge Collapse
text: WASHINGTON  The National Transportation Safety Board’s working theory about last summer’s bridge collapse in Minneapolis  that it was caused by a design error four decades ago  has run into a peculiar problem: it contradicts much public belief.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Big City column on Monday, about Derrick Braxton, a black student from a Brooklyn housing project now attending a small, mostly white college in upstate New York, referred incorrectly to his Brooklyn high school, Bedford Academy. It is a public school, not a charter school.

headline: Kenyan Politician Assassinated
text: A popular parliament member was gunned down outside his home in Nairobi, sparking clashes between mourners and police.

headline: What Florida Taught Me
text: Here are a few things I learned Tuesday night.

headline: New Journal Blog a Sign of Murdoch’s Green Bent?
text: “No, your computer isn’t misfiring.”

headline: Climate Change
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.— In their first 10 games this season, the undefeated Patriots only played one game in which they didn’t win by at least 17 points. In their eight victories since, five have been by 10 points or fewer, which includes their 38-35 victory against the Giants in both teams’ regular-season finale.

headline: John Edwards in New Orleans
text: Following is the transcript of John Edwards's announcement to suspend his campaign, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

headline: Forever Tom
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.— With a victory in Sunday’s Super Bowl XLII against the Giants, New England quarterback Tom Brady would tie Terry Bradshaw and Joe Montana at four for most Super Bowl wins by a quarterback.

headline: Championship Friends
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.— During media day Tuesday, New England Coach Bill Belichick discussed his relationship with other successful coaches, including his friend Bob Knight, the Texas Tech basketball coach. The two men met through Bill Parcells, Belichick’s former boss when the two won Super Bowl championships with the Giants in 1986 and 1990.

headline: Airbus and the Environment
text: It wasn’t long ago that the aviation sector turned up its nose at the environment. After all airplanes are only responsible for about two or three percent of global emissions, making them far less of a factor than cars or power stations in pumping out the gases linked to global warming.

headline: Correction: Sounds and Flavors of a Land Left Behind in Cuban Miami
text: The American Journeys column last Friday, about Cuban culture in Miami, gave incomplete lyrics for a song performed in Spanish by the Cuban singer Albita at a club in Little Havana. The correct lyrics include the preposition "de" three times: "Que culpa tengo yo de estas caderas? Que culpa tengo yo de este sabor? Que culpa tengo yo de haber nacido en Cuba?"

headline: Food Stuff
text: How Hard Is It to Boil an Egg? (It's Becoming Easier)

headline: UBS Takes a $14 Billion Write-Off
text: PARIS  UBS, the largest Swiss bank, said Wednesday that it would write off $14 billion in losses on the troubled U.S. housing market and post a net loss for 2007.

headline: Even in Death, Fischer Spawns Controversy
text: Nearly two weeks after Bobby Fischer died, strange reports continue to trickle out about his life and death. Among the stories have been the circumstances surrounding

headline: Eating in Hong Kong: the Cha Chaan Teng
text: Twin Ducks in a Teacup: Hong Kong’s yun yeung coffee-tea

headline: A Closer Look at Mercury
text: Images of Mercury taken by the Messenger spacecraft.

headline: No Dip for You!
text: At last, proof that George was being pretty gross when he “double-dipped” that chip at a funeral reception on “Seinfeld.” Prof. Paul L. Dawson, a food microbiologist, did a study and found that the brother of George’s late girlfriend was justifiably outraged (Super Bowl partyers, be advised):

text: AN OPEN LETTER TO:

headline: ‘The Bloody Shirt’
text: PROLOGUE

headline: TV Showman, Once Exiled, Returns With Video Site
text: One of Big Media’s most controversial executives is back after a period of quasi-forced retirement.

headline: Iberdrola Hires Merrill to Sell Stake in Portugese Energy Firm
text: Spanish utility Iberdrola  said Wednesday it has hired investment bank Merrill Lynch to sell its 4 percent stake in in Portuguese energy firm Galp Energia. In a Spanish regulatory filing, Iberdrola said the Galp shares will be sold to qualified institutional investors.

headline: V.C.’s Pump $20 Million into Virtual Iron
text: Virtual Iron, a start-up aiming to commercialize the open-source Xen virtualization software, has raised $20 million.

headline: XAware Takes $7.4 Million in Latest Round
text: XAware, an open-source data integration developer, announced Tuesday that it raised a $7.4 million third round of funding.

headline: F.B.I. Opens Subprime Inquiry
text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation officials said the agency has opened criminal inquiries into 14 companies as part of a wide-ranging investigation of the troubled mortgage industry.

headline: Margaret Truman Daniel
text: Margaret Truman Daniel, a president’s daughter whose achievements as a singer, author and radio and television host won her renown, died at 83.

headline: Is the United States Chess Federation in Trouble?
text: A statement from a meeting about the finances of the United States Chess Federation was posted over the weekend on the federation’s Web forum by Bill Goichberg, the president of the federation. In the statement, Goichberg talked about the federation’s finances, saying they are not in good shape and the federation is projected to run a significant deficit (significant from the federation’s standpoint as it does not have much in the way of financial reserves and its revenues are about $3 million a year). He also suggested some plans of action. Here is an excerpt from the statement, with the first few paragraphs about technology used to conduct the meeting and plans for the next meeting of the federation’s executive board, omitted.

headline: Goldcorp May Sell Silver Wheaton in Offering
text: Hoping to raise capital to fund the rising costs of its development projects, Canada’s Goldcorp is reportedly looking to unload its 49 percent stake in Silver Wheaton, but The Globe and Mail noted that it’s unclear whether there will be enough investor appetite for what would be a massive $1.8 billion stock sale.

headline: Rule Change to Help Smaller Companies Raise Funds
text: Federal regulators are about to ease rules that have made it difficult for small and medium-size publicly traded companies to raise money. The changes, experts say, are well timed, given the tightening credit market.

headline: UnitedHealth Faces Fine Related to PacifiCare Merger
text: California regulators announced Tuesday that they are seeking as much as $1.33 billion in penalties from PacifiCare as a result of widespread problems stemming from its takeover two years ago by healthcare giant UnitedHealth Group.

headline: Sprint, Clearwire Said to Seek Funding for WiMax Venture
text: Wireless Internet provider Clearwire and cellular operator Sprint Nextel have reportedly restarted talks to combine their high-speed wireless WiMax networks.

headline: Kirkland & Ellis Said to Open Silicon Valley Office
text: Kirkland & Ellis, the litigation-focused law firm, plans to open an office in Palo Alto, Calif., later this year as firms rush to the Silicon Valley area to grab talent and clients in the U.S. technology company center, The National Law Journal reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Take Dillard’s Stake
text: Dillard’s shares rose 3.4 percent after two New York-based hedge funds reported a stake in the department store company, saying Dillard’s shares are significantly undervalued.

headline: Hedge Turns Up Heat on Compton Petroleum
text: Canada’s Compton Petroleum is under renewed assault from its largest shareholder, hedge fund Centennial Energy Partners, which is now dismissing the Calgary gas producer’s latest business plan as “ill-conceived” and reiterating an earlier demand that it put itself up for sale in order to maximize value for investors.

headline: UBS Takes a $14 Billion Hit
text: UBS, the largest Swiss bank, said Wednesday that it would write off $14 billion in exposure to the troubled U.S. housing market and post a net loss for 2007.

headline: Countrywide Posts $422 Million Loss, but Deal Is Still a Go
text: Countrywide Financial, the mortgage lender and loan servicer, reported a fourth-quarter loss of $422 million Tuesday, but the results were not expected to hinder its proposed $4.1 billion takeover by the Bank of America.

headline: AirTran Hopes for a Delta-Northwest Merger
text: As industry observers continue to speculate on the airline merger game, one carrier has made its own wish list.

headline: Excel Pays $2.4 Billion to Board Quintana
text: Excel Maritime Carriers said Tuesday it would acquire competitor Quintana Maritime  in a deal it valued at nearly $2.45 billion that will create one of the world’s largest dry bulk companies by fleet and capacity.

headline: GSO Nears Deadline to Close Reddy Buyout
text: At a time when all buyouts have been subject to doubts, the $680 million buyout of Reddy Ice Holdings by GSO Capital Partners is running up against the end of its extended marketing period.

headline: A Statesman Without Borders
text: Can Bernard Kouchner make France a global player again?

headline: Crosslink Closes $400 Million Fund
text: Crosslink Capital said Wednesday it closed its Crossover Fund V with $400 million in capital commitments, bringing its total capital under management to more than $1.4 billion. The new fund will continue Crosslink’s strategy of investing in early-stage ventures, public companies and those at stages in between, the firm said in a press release.

text: More of your “late night’ jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: A.D.S.: The Way Out
text: Is there still a way for Alliance Data Systems to be acquired by Blackstone Group?

headline: Lazard’s 4th-Quarter Profits Rise 27%
text: Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, said Tuesday that it had record fourth-quarter profits of $122.6 million, powered by increased revenues from its deal advisory business — despite the beginning of a slowdown in mergers and acquisitions at the same time.

headline: Giuliani on the Florida Primary
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani speaks to supporters after the Florida primary. (NBC video)

headline: Republican Debate in Simi Valley, Calif.
text: The following is a transcript of the Republican presidential debate in Simi Valley, Calif., as provided by the Federal News Service and CNN.

headline: Hillary Clinton in Florida
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton speaks to supporters after the Florida  primary. (NBC video)

headline: The Online Dating Approach to Mentoring
text: If searching online can produce a life partner, it should be an effective way to find a mentor. At least that’s the thinking behind iMantri, a new Silicon Valley social networking site that opened its online doors this week.

headline: Mitt Romney on the Florida Primary
text: Mitt Romney speaks to supporters after the Florida primary. (NBC video)

headline: Rio Advisers Say BHP Could Pay a Lot More
text: As BHP Billiton mulls its next move for Rio Tinto after having its first overture for the miner rebuffed, the latter’s advisers have apparently been busy checking out BHP’s books.

headline: Pressure Mounts for Resignation at French Bank
text: Senior politicians here increased calls for the resignation of top executives at Société Générale, ahead of the board’s regular meeting, scheduled for early Wednesday.

headline: Carlyle Chairman: There’s No Crisis
text: Cheap credit may have disappeared, the equity markets may be in the dumps, and the deal graveyard may be littered with failed buyouts, but don’t call it crisis. At least not if you’re speaking with Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman of the Carlyle Group, one of the world’s largest private equity firms.

headline: Mike Huckabee on the Florida Primary
text: Mike Huckabee speaks to supporters after the Florida primary. (NBC video)

headline: L’Affaire Kerviel Distracts from SocGen’s Subprime Woes
text: Jérôme Kerviel’s 4.8 billion euro trading loss ($7.1 billion) had a positive effect for Société Générale, at least temporarily.

headline: At French Bank, Director’s Trades Raise Eyebrows
text: Amid all the hoopla surrounding Jérôme Kerviel, whose fraudulent trades saddled Société Générale with a $7.1 billion loss, new questions have emerged about a different set of trades: Those carried out by Robert A. Day, a member of the French bank’s board of directors.

headline: John McCain's Victory Speech
text: John McCain speaks to supporters after winning the Florida primary. (NBC video)

headline: ‘Juno’ Laid Low by Success
text: The Bagger was never much of a critic, but he used to cover music occasionally and he was always struck by what happened when some indie plaything hit it big — the Replacements or Liz Phair back in the day, and the Strokes or Clap Your Hands Say Yeah more recently. He learned that you could almost set your watch by the backlash. Critics work to lift worthy work into public consciousness, but once it is embraced by the tawdry masses, they drop their treasure like a box of rocks.

headline: The Early Word: Florida’s Waves
text: MIAMI — The calendar is spinning forward quickly, and today should be another newsy day as Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to throw his support behind Senator John McCain, the winner here. The G.O.P. field — grower smaller –is headed out to the Ronald Reagan Library in California for another debate tonight.

headline: Patriots, Giants and a Big Bowl of Chips
text: Friday Night Update: The reader submissions were, overwhelmingly, fattening, cheap, tasty concoctions. They prove we are a dip nation, in tune with avocados (right on, Roger, Billy D and Jen) and artichokes (Yea, Helen and Ashley). We like our chips fresh from a boiling vat of oil, not from the bag. We are willing to eat anything (including roadkill) as long as it’s spicy or creamy.

headline: A Former Mayor’s Failed Endgame in Florida
text: For the New York papers, the focus today is on Rudolph W. Giuliani’s precipitous political free fall, after his third-place finish in the Republican presidential primary in Florida on Tuesday night. “Rudy’s Ruin,” says the front of The Post. “The Fat Lady’s Singin’,” declares The Daily News. In The Times, Michael Powell and Michael Cooper dissect what is called a “dizzying free-fall” for the ex-mayor, noting that just a few months ago a senior Giuliani aide had surveyed the Republican field and said: “I don’t believe this can be taken from us. Now that I have that locked up, I can go do battle elsewhere.”Instead, hubris and strategic miscalculations plagued his campaign, political observers say. For one, he allowed a tight coterie of New York aides, none with national political experience, to run much of his campaign. And while he accumulated a fat war chest — he had $16.6 million on hand at the end of September, more than Mitt Romney ($9.5 million) or Senator John McCain ($3.2 million) — he spent vast sums on direct mail instead of building strong organizations on the ground in South Carolina and New Hampshire.

headline: SOTU Attracts 37.5 Million Viewers
text: “An estimated 37.5 million watched President Bush’s address to Congress Monday night, which was broadcast live on ABC, CBS, NBC, Fox, CNN, Fox News Channel, MSNBC, Univision and Telemundo,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Message from UBS: It’s Not Just Subprime
text: You might think that investors and analysts would be used to hearing about 11-digit write-downs by now. Maybe even jaded. So why was Wednesday’s UBS announcement — or, as the bank called it, a pre-announcement — about $14 billion in write-downs such a shock? “I had assumed additional losses, but not of this magnitude,” an analyst told The New York Times. Shares of UBS were down 2.8 percent in early trading Wednesday in New York.

headline: New York Republicans Rally Around McCain
text: Updated, 1:48 p.m. | Eight years after New York Republicans, led by Gov. George E. Pataki, fought unsuccessfully to keep Senator John McCain off the Republican presidential primary ballot, they are moving swiftly to embrace him as the party’s front-runner Wednesday morning, as Rudolph W. Giuliani prepares to exit the race. The Republican leaders in the State Legislature both announced their support for Mr. McCain this morning.

headline: A Fool for Smart
text: When I tell people I’m buying a Smart Car, I generally get one of three reactions. Most people still don’t know what it is — they haven’t seen the half-pint two seater from Daimler. Many of those who do know about them laugh. The Smart is a tiny thing, comical in its styling and proportions: just 8.8 feet long. (It’s about 40 inches shorter than a Mini Cooper, that road hog.) And then there are the very few who get a sort of funny smile on their faces. Not quite envy, but the look you got in high school from people who had realized that you really were going to jump from that 40-foot tower into the lake, and were waiting with pleasure to see if you’d make it.

headline: The Rigors of the Big East

headline: The Fashionable Pejorative
text: Not long ago, a well-known culture critic with strong neoconservative inclinations told me he was reluctant to be forthright about his political views because “once the label ‘neoconservative’ becomes attached to you, people stop listening to what you have to say.” There’s no question that “neoconservative” has become, in many quarters of both the left and right, a fashionable pejorative, to be casually tossed about, and just as casually misapplied.

headline: Q and A:  Fabio Trabocchi

When he did, the restaurant’s name changed slightly — it’s now simply called Fiamma — and its cooking changed more than that. While it still bills itself as an Italian restaurant, its dishes are less traditionally Italian, more fanciful and more reflective of French influences than the dishes under the previous chef, Michael White, were.

headline: The Post-Surge Campaign
text: As recently as last summer, almost no one would have thought the events of the last week very likely — that Barack Obama would have a won a convincing victory in South Carolina, edging ahead of Hillary Rodham Clinton in the delegate count, or that John McCain would beat all comers in Florida last night, emerging at his party’s leading candidate. I was traveling a lot during those months, and I was surprised to find that the vast majority of voters I met then had effectively written off the struggling Senator Obama, while Senator McCain seemed to have disappeared from view.

headline: New York Post Endorses Obama Over Clinton
text: The New York Post has endorsed Barack Obama in Tuesday’s New York Democratic primary, saying that his chief rival for the party’s presidential nomination, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, represented the politics of the past. “Obama represents a fresh start,” The Post stated in an editorial on its Web site. “His opponent, and her husband, stand for déjà vu all over again — a return to the opportunistic, scandal-scarred, morally muddled years of the almost infinitely self-indulgent Clinton co-presidency.”

headline: New York Post Endorses Obama

headline: Clipboard: The Coughlin/Manning Combination

headline: Plotting the Post-Edwards Strategy
