text: Campaigns in both parties have come to the conclusion that working-class voters may be a key to victory on Tuesday.

headline: Report: Half of Spain’s Estate Agents Shut Down
text: This has the ring of urban myth, but the number is so huge it seems worth repeating: API, the trade association for Spanish property agents, is reporting that 40,000 estate agents-half the estate agents in the country-closed down last year, in the wake of the slowdown in the market. As a result, it is believed that as many as 100,000 property agents lost their jobs last year.

headline: The Oscars’ ‘Contingency Plan’
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Big Seller in Syndication: A Talk Show With Bonnie Hunt
text: LAS VEGAS — The Warner Bros. sales staff doesn’t have to work too hard at the National Association of Television Program Executives conference this year. The syndicated show it is distributing next fall, “The Bonnie Hunt Show,” has already been sold to stations representing 95 percent of the country.

headline: One Eye on the Fish, the Other on North Korea
text: BAENGNYEONG ISLAND, South Korea  On a clear day, one can stand on this island and see the coast of North Korea, pale and milky on the horizon, 10 miles away. The channel could be crossed in just half an hour by boat.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the Slap Shot column on Sunday about the growing worth of Canadian N.H.L. franchises referred imprecisely to the interest of Alex Shnaider, a steel magnate, in buying the Toronto Maple Leafs and their properties. Although he is said to have expressed interest, and a price of $1.75 billion has been reported, Mr. Shnaider has not made such an offer.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Tuesday about the Giants’ arrival in Arizona for the Super Bowl misstated Coach Tom Coughlin’s history in the title game. This is his second Super Bowl appearance as a coach, not his first. (He was an assistant coach with the Giants when they won Super Bowl XXV in January 1991.)

headline: Regulators Warn France on Shielding Bank
text: PARIS  As numerous European banks assess whether to make a bid for Société Générale, still reeling from a devastating $7.1 billion trading loss, regulators in Brussels issued a stark warning to the French government Thursday against any effort to thwart open competition to protect one of its corporate jewels.

headline: The Bill Clinton Factor, From Two More Angles
text: To the Editor:

headline: Snap-Together Gadgets for the 21st-Century Tinkerer
text: Is it time to move on from Erector sets and Lego kits? BUG kits from Bug Labs give tech-loving hobbyists something new to tinker with.

headline: The Mets Are Still on Probation
text: Exciting trade, but the Mets are still on probation.

headline: Italian Leader Calls for Temporary Government
text: ROME  Seeking to head off early elections, President Giorgio Napolitano asked the Senate president, Franco Marini, on Wednesday to try to form a temporary government aimed at fixing Italy’s flawed election law.

headline: Starbucks to Close Stores and End Sandwich Sales
text: At the very least, Starbucks will smell like coffee again.

headline: They Kind of Knew It Wouldn’t Work
text: It was the morning after the Florida presidential primary, and in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the Barrioses were disagreeing.

headline: Charities Vie for Prizes in Online Giving Experiment
text: Fledgling charities, like a year-old group that rescues abandoned dogs in Georgia, are among the leading contenders for prizes in an experimental online fund-raising contest sponsored by the Case Foundation. Meanwhile, more established nonprofit groups have struggled to attract support.

headline: Mutant Flu Virus Is Found That Resists Popular Drug
text: A small but significant percentage of the main influenza virus causing illness this winter in Europe, Canada and the United States has a mutation that makes it resistant to the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.

headline: G.O.P. Exodus in House Bodes Ill for Fall Success
text: WASHINGTON  A swelling exodus of senior Republican incumbents from the House, worsened by a persistent disadvantage in campaign money, threatens to cripple Republican efforts to topple the Democratic majority in November.

headline: Canada: Suncor Expands in Oil Sands
text: In a move that will make it the country’s largest oil sands producer, Suncor Energy said it would spend 20.6 billion Canadian dollars (about the same in American dollars) to expand operations near Fort McMurray, Alberta. The operation will be able to produce 550,000 barrels of oil a day when completed in 2012. The chief executive of Suncor, Richard L. George, said that with the new project, the company expects to generate a 15 percent return on investment at an oil price of $60 a barrel. The expansion will also allow Suncor to use an underground steam heating process rather than open-pit mining for about half of its tar sands oil production, which will reduce the effect on the environment.

headline: Scout Listens to His Instincts, Not to His Boss, and Uncovers a Star
text: Andrés Reiner, a scout for the Houston Astros, watched the 15-year-old play in a tournament in Venezuela. Reiner liked the way he scooted smoothly around center field and he really liked his powerful arm. Reiner studied him for three games, enough to realize he had found an exceptional player.

headline: Lasers Make Other Metals Look Like Gold
text: All that glitters golden is not gold. It could be aluminum. Or tungsten. Or another metal of Chunlei Guo’s choosing.

headline: Museum Seeks Prophet Caricatures
text: The Museum of Danish Cartoon Art in Copenhagen, part of the Royal Library of Denmark, is in discussions to buy the 12 caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad that ignited riots leading to 50 deaths around the world after they were published in a Danish newspaper in 2005, The Art Newspaper reported. “The caricatures have become a part of Danish history,” Jytte Kjaergaard, a spokeswoman for the Royal Library, said. Claus Seidel, one of the cartoonists and the chairman of a Danish cartoonists association, said, “We have generally agreed that we want a museum to have the works, but everyone still has to take a final decision for himself.”

headline: Higher Costs Cited as U.S. Shuts Down Coal Project
text: WASHINGTON  The Energy Department on Wednesday canceled its main program for demonstrating how to use coal without adding to global warming, saying the project needed an overhaul to rein in soaring costs.

headline: Germany: E.ON. Fined for a Broken Security Seal
text: E.On-Energie, the electrical unit of the energy giant E.On, was fined $56 million by the European Union for a broken seal that had been placed across an office door during an antitrust investigation. The European Commission said the broken seal meant E.On had the chance to remove documents after a raid in May 2006  although it could not prove that the company had deliberately tampered with the seal or removed anything. E.On said it would appeal the fine. Regulators sealed the door to make sure no documents could be removed. When they returned the next day, signs of tampering showed that someone had removed the tape and tried to put it back, regulators said.

headline: Blue-Collar Giants Revel in Unity and Obscurity
text: CHANDLER, Ariz.  The Giants’ Tom Coughlin, a football coach for nearly 40 years, emerged from a recent meeting of his offensive linemen and wondered what aspect of football he had just witnessed.

headline: Boeing Beats Wall Street’s Forecast
text: CHICAGO (AP)  Boeing reported a 4 percent increase in fourth-quarter profit on Wednesday, topping Wall Street’s expectations despite concerns over delays in the 787 Dreamliner.

headline: Strong Holiday Season Lifts Amazon’s Revenue
text: Amazon.com, the leading online retailer, had a lot of good news in its financial report Wednesday, but it was overshadowed by just a small bit of bad news.

headline: Pirouettes and Extensions From North of the Border
text: The act of artistic creation is often trumpeted as developing in brave opposition to oppressive regimes, and dance has had its share of highlights, from the defection of great Russian ballet stars to “Chronicle,” Martha Graham’s antifascist work from 1936.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Conor McPherson drama “The Seafarer” will end its run at the Booth Theater on March 30 after 19 previews and 133 regular performances. ... “Take Me Along,” the musical based on the Eugene O’Neill comedy “Ah, Wilderness!,” will be presented by the Irish Repertory Theater beginning with previews on Feb. 20. Directed by Charlotte Moore, the show, with a book by Joseph Stein (“Fiddler on the Roof”) and Robert Russell and music and lyrics by Bob Merrill, opens on Feb. 28. ... Oprah Winfrey has made “A New Earth” (Penguin Group), the 2005 self-help guide by Eckhart Tolle, her latest book-club selection, The Associated Press reported. ... The appointment of Martin E. Sullivan as director of the National Portrait Gallery of the Smithsonian Institution, effective April 28, was announced on Wednesday. Mr. Sullivan, since 1999 the chief executive of the Historic St. Mary’s City Commission in Maryland, succeeds Marc Pachter, who retired on Jan. 25.

headline: Lilly Considers $1 Billion Fine to Settle Case
text: Eli Lilly and federal prosecutors are discussing a settlement of a civil and criminal investigation into the company’s marketing of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa that could result in Lilly’s paying more than $1 billion to federal and state governments.

headline: Ailing Fortunoff Attracts a Suitor
text: One of the most storied names in New York retailing plans to bail out another.

headline: China Orders Relief Efforts, but Public Is Still Angry
text: SHANGHAI  As unusually heavy snow and cold weather continued over much of China, the government on Wednesday stepped up emergency efforts to handle a crisis that threatens to become as much a public relations disaster as it has been a logistical one.

headline: The Patriots Are Baffled by Burress’s Crystal Ball
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. New England quarterback Tom Brady seemed perplexed Wednesday by Plaxico Burress’s prediction that the Giants would beat the Patriots, 23-17, in Sunday’s Super Bowl.

headline: Star Soprano Coaxes a Puccini Role From the Vault
text: There was basically one reason the Metropolitan Opera dusted off its drearily realistic, unbecoming old production of Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut” and brought it back to the house for the first time in 18 years on Tuesday night: the soprano Karita Mattila.

headline: Well-Dressed Travels Well
text: IN fashion the swaggering march of progress sometimes offers more questions than answers. Like, why does a minor yet sublime improvement (upgrading to cashmere socks or handmade shoes, say) always take a back seat to some Dutch-designed, laser-cut, steel-paillette tank top that struts up and down a runway, to be worn maybe once more  by a model on the cover of Angst?

headline: Romney and McCain Tangle at Debate, but Also Try to Mold a Two-Man Race
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Mitt Romney tried to slow Senator John McCain’s momentum Wednesday night as their final debate before the Tuesday contests turned into a raucous and occasionally angry clash over their conservative credentials, the war in Iraq, their government records and charges and countercharges of dirty campaigning.

headline: Bush Seeks Surplus via Medicare Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  In his new budget, to be unveiled Monday, President Bush will call for large cuts in the growth of Medicare, far exceeding what he proposed last year, and he will again seek major savings in Medicaid, according to administration officials and budget documents.

headline: Pennsylvania: More Police in Philadelphia
text: Philadelphia’s new police commissioner promised to decrease gun violence in the city sharply by putting 200 more officers on the street, using “stop and frisk” searches in tough neighborhoods and installing 200 more surveillance cameras. The commissioner, Charles Ramsey, who spent eight years as police chief in Washington, set a goal of reducing killings by 25 percent this year, in large part by allocating more officers to the most violent neighborhoods. There were 392 killings in 2007 in Philadelphia, and 406 in 2006.

headline: A Warning on Insurers Frays Nerves
text: While the Federal Reserve tried to soothe Wall Street’s nerves on Wednesday, a hedge fund manager frayed them by warning that two pillars of the financial markets might crumble.

headline: Keeping an Eye on China’s Security
text: HONG KONG  Since Imperial times, Chinese governments have relied on neighbors to inform on each other as a way to preserve social control.

headline: A Face-Off, Not Necessarily Televised
text: The Democrats may be planning a traditional use of television advertising, but their Republican counterparts are approaching the contest differently.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a dance review in Weekend on Friday about New York City Ballet and the world premiere of “Oltremare” referred incorrectly to a dancer at one point. The dancer, Tiler Peck, is a woman.

headline: A Handmade Home
text: CORNVILLE, Ariz.

headline: Australia to Apologize to Aborigines for Past Mistreatment
text: SYDNEY, Australia  The new government of Prime Minister Kevin Rudd says it will apologize for past mistreatment of Australia’s Aboriginal minority when Parliament convenes next month, addressing an issue that has blighted race relations in the country for years.

headline: Jimmy James, P.O.W. Plotter of Escapes, Is Dead at 92
text: Jimmy James, a British flier in World War II obsessed with escape plots during his five years in German captivity, most prominently the breakout portrayed in the movie “The Great Escape,” died Jan. 18 in Shrewsbury, England. Mr. James, who lived in Ludlow, England, was 92.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: New York: Images and Preservation

headline: The Dynastic Question
text: In a presidential campaign that has involved battles over everything from Iraq to driver’s licenses, one sweeping topic has gone curiously unexamined: Does it diminish American democracy if we keep the presidency in the same two families that have held it since 1989?

headline: Abruptly, Edwards Ends His White House Bid
text: NEW ORLEANS  As of Tuesday afternoon, John Edwards’s campaign staff members were still heading to North Dakota and Georgia. A television advertising campaign was about to hit the airwaves. And that evening Mr. Edwards was flying here to deliver what was billed as a major speech on poverty.

headline: Google Earnings Fall Short of Expectations
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said Thursday that its profits jumped 17 percent in the fourth quarter as sales grew at a healthy 51 percent, propelled by continued strength in the company’s core search advertising business. The results fell short of analysts’ expectations, raising concerns that the Internet search giant will not be immune from the economic slowdown.

headline: Documentary to Compete in Berlin
text: A film about the prisoner abuse scandal at the Abu Ghraib jail in Iraq will become the first documentary to enter the competition at the Berlin International Film Festival when it is shown next month, Agence France-Presse reported. Made by the Oscar-winning director Errol Morris (“The Fog of War”), above, the documentary, “Standard Operating Procedure,” uses film, re-enactments and photographs that were published around the world to shed light on the treatment of inmates. Twenty-one films will vie for awards during the 58th Berlin film festival, running Feb. 7-17.

headline: Burress Stirs Up Controversy Without Showing Up
text: CHANDLER, Ariz.  It seems Plaxico Burress can draw a crowd even when he is not present.

headline: Stocks Rally as Concern Over Bond Insurer Eases
text: Inflation on the rise. Consumers cutting back. Investment banks on edge. Thursday had all the ingredients for a bearish day on Wall Street.

headline: U.S. Growth Slowed Drastically in 4th Quarter
text: The United States economy expanded by a disappointingly weak annual rate of 0.6 percent during the last three months of 2007, the government reported Wednesday, offering the latest indication that the United States is already suffering a substantial slowdown, and perhaps a recession.

headline: On Demand, on Time and for a Fee, an Army of Tutors Appears
text: JEN cut her pie into 12 pieces and ate 9, and then Louisa cut her pie into 8 pieces and ate 6, which for some reason prompted me to open a bottle of white wine and drink two glasses.

headline: Rally Sputters in a Late-Day Sell-Off
text: A Fed rally on Wall Street abruptly fizzled Wednesday as excitement over an interest rate cut gave way to concern about a new round of problems related to subprime mortgages.

headline: In This War, How to Ally With Both
text: The electronics industry has spent billions of dollars on a stupid and unnecessary battle between the next-generation DVD formats: Blu-ray and HD DVD. And so far, it’s all been pretty much for nothing; consumers aren’t touching the things. Nobody wants to risk buying a DVD player that can play only half of the world’s movies.

headline: Michigan: Detroit’s Mayor Says He Won’t Quit
text: Detroit’s mayor emerged after nearly a week in seclusion and apologized to the city’s residents for having had an affair with his chief of staff and lying about it under oath. But the mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, said he would not step down. Mr. Kilpatrick was joined by his wife, Carlita. “I truly apologize to each and every one of you individually and to the whole city,” Mr. Kilpatrick said. Mr. Kilpatrick, 37, did not mention his former chief of staff, Christine Beatty, who quit her job Monday, nor did he address his potential exposure to perjury charges. The Wayne County prosecutor is investigating whether Mr. Kilpatrick or Ms. Beatty should be charged criminally.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $6,987,843

headline: Economic Stimulus, Gridiron Style
text: The bulls are rooting for Wall Street's home team, the New York Giants. Or at least they should be if they believe that football results influence the stock market. On average, the market goes up after the Giants win the Super Bowl and down when they lose. The opposite is true for the New England Patriots.

headline: Official Sees Kenyan Ethnic Cleansing
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  The top American diplomat for Africa said Wednesday that some of the violence that has swept across Kenya in the past month has been ethnic cleansing intended to drive people from their homes, but that it should not be considered genocide.

headline: Female Student Sues Hofstra
text: A former athletic manager for Hofstra University’s football team said in a federal discrimination lawsuit that players sexually harassed her repeatedly, including when an assistant played a sexually explicit film on a team bus. Lauren Summa, a 23-year-old graduate student, said that her complaints to coaches and university officials went unheeded, and that she was dropped from the team’s athletic staff after speaking out. Hofstra’s vice president for university relations, Melissa Connolly, said in a statement the college was “confident that all matters relating to these allegations were handled appropriately.”

headline: Cleric Urges a Science and Religion Dialogue
text: Prompted by what he called the increasingly vocal hostility of some religions to science, and some scientists to religion, the president of the United Church of Christ has appealed for both groups to communicate more openly and to recognize, as he put it, that each has something to contribute to the other.

headline: Doctor Accused of Leak to Drug Maker
text: A leading member of the Senate said Wednesday that a prominent diabetes expert had leaked an unpublished and confidential medical journal article to GlaxoSmithKline last year, tipping the company to the imminent publication of safety questions involving the company’s diabetes drug Avandia.

headline: After Mining Deal, Financier Donated to Clinton
text: Late on Sept. 6, 2005, a private plane carrying the Canadian mining financier Frank Giustra touched down in Almaty, a ruggedly picturesque city in southeast Kazakhstan. Several hundred miles to the west a fortune awaited: highly coveted deposits of uranium that could fuel nuclear reactors around the world. And Mr. Giustra was in hot pursuit of an exclusive deal to tap them.

headline: An Investigation Focuses on Antiquities Dealer
text: CERRITOS, Calif.  Robert Olson hardly looks like the head of a smuggling ring specializing in Asian antiquities.

headline: Mukasey Will Not Rule Out Waterboarding
text: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Michael B. Mukasey said Wednesday that while he would consider it torture if he underwent the harsh Central Intelligence Agency interrogation technique known as waterboarding, the practice was not necessarily illegal, and he would not rule out its use in the future.

headline: Pakistani Justice Breaks Silence
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, the former chief justice of Pakistan who was removed last year when President Pervez Musharraf imposed a state of emergency, has finally broken his silence.

headline: Simpler Labels for Food Content Proposed
text: The European Commission proposed simpler food labels highlighting fat, sugar and salt content in an effort to contain the spread of obesity and junk food. Under the proposals, six content elements will have to appear on packages: energy, total fat, saturated fat, carbohydrates, sugar and salts. The labels will indicate what percentage of advisable daily intake they represent. “Consumers have to be able to make the right choice. They need the right information to plan their diet,” the health commissioner Markos Kyprianou, above, said. The proposals exclude beer, wine and spirits. They will now be taken up by the European Parliament and must be approved by member nations.

headline: Garden Q.&A.
text: A Melancholic Baptisia

headline: Congestion Pricing Plan Is Panned in Albany
text: A plan to ease traffic in Manhattan received harsh reviews this week in Albany.

headline: Big-Donor Politics Elude North Dakota
text: BISMARCK, N.D.  Consider the tactic one local Democratic Party leader in this state resorted to last summer to raise money. He chained hot-pink plywood elephants, 2 1/2 feet tall and 2 1/2 feet wide, to trees in the yards of known Democrats, then offered to remove the Republican beasts in exchange for $25 donations.

headline: No. 1 in a Slow Race
text: Last week was another miserable one for music sales, but with one modest highlight: The indie-heavy “Juno” movie soundtrack rose one spot to the top of the Billboard chart, becoming the first album in Rhino Records’ three-decade history to reach No. 1. After the announcement of four Oscar nominations for “Juno,” including best picture, the soundtrack sold 65,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bumping Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J), which moved 60,000, to No. 2. In the fourth straight week of very low sales, Natasha Bedingfield opened at No. 3 with 50,000 copies of “Pocketful of Sunshine” (Epic), Mary J. Blige’s “Growing Pains” (Geffen) sold 45,000 to reach No. 4, and Radiohead dropped one spot to No. 5 with “In Rainbows” (ATO), moving 35,000. Cat Power’s new “Jukebox” (Matador) reached No. 12 with 29,000 copies sold.

headline: The Rookie Eli Manning
text: Back in December 2004, Eli Manning had just taken over as the starting quarterback of the Giants, replacing Kurt Warner, a former most valuable player. Michael Lewis, a regular contributor to PLAY, profiled the elusive, private, and talented young quarterback for The New York Times Magazine, explaining how the team's fortunes were tied to the youngest Manning:

headline: Weak Dollar Has Small Businesses Thinking Globally
text: THE declining dollar spurred Peggy Karr Glass to exhibit its handmade fused glass products at a spring trade show in London.

headline: Thailand: Nose-Holding for the New Leader
text: Sign language interpreters in Thailand have run afoul of supporters among the governing party by holding their noses to refer to the new prime minister, Samak Sundaravej. Thai sign language interpreters often indicate prominent facial features as shorthand for dignitaries, and during a live broadcast of the parliamentary session on Monday that selected Mr. Samak, left, they held their noses between two fingers to refer to him. “It is not meant as a nose joke,” said one interpreter, Kanittha Rattanasin. “We have touched our noses for years to refer to Samak, but people noticed this time because we had to repeat the movement over 300 times.” Another interpreter, Juthamas Suthonwattanacharoen, said supporters of Mr. Samak, who is nicknamed Mr. Rose Apple Nose because many claim his nose resembles the long, Asian fruit, have called the National Association of the Deaf in Thailand to say the sign does not befit the country’s leader. For now, there are no plans to change it, she said.

headline: Delay in Decision on Protecting Polar Bears
text: A decision on whether to protect Alaska’s polar bears under the Endangered Species Act might not be made before the government opens a major bear habitat to oil leases next week, although staff recommendations are complete, the Fish and Wildlife Service chief, Dale Hall, said. Mr. Hall faced criticism at a Senate hearing from lawmakers who accused the Interior Department of stalling to make it easier for oil companies to obtain drilling leases in the Chukchi Sea, where a fifth of the Arctic’s polar bears depend on sea ice in their hunt for food. Another Interior Department agency, the Minerals Management Service, plans to open a large area of the Chukchi Sea to oil and gas leases on Wednesday. Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California and chairwoman of the Environment and Natural Resources Committee, demanded “a commitment to take immediate action” to protect the bears.

headline: H.P. Case to Go Forward in India
text: NEW DELHI  A decision by India’s highest court may force international companies who outsource business here to do more to guard the safety of local workers.

headline: Arthur B. Kramer, Lawyer and Brother of Playwright Larry Kramer, Dies at 81
text: Arthur B. Kramer, who built a small New York law firm into one with international reach and whose fraught relationship with his brother, Larry Kramer, the playwright and gay rights advocate, helped inspire a benchmark play of the 1980s, died on Saturday. He was 81 and lived in Stamford, Conn.

headline: While the Election Watchdog Wanders
text: The presidential campaign’s heated fund-raising sweepstakes finds lobbyists hurriedly “bundling”  amassing additional hundreds of thousands from donors to re-stake surviving contenders for the next primary rounds. (Lobbyists reportedly bundled $300,000 for Senator John McCain in one night in Washington after his stock revived on the campaign trail.)

headline: South Korea Wins Handball Replay
text: South Korea defeated Japan, 28-25, Wednesday in a replay of a qualifying match for the men’s handball tournament at the Beijing Olympics. The Asian qualifiers were initially held in September, when referees from Jordan and Iran were assigned at the last minute by the Asian Handball Federation to replace German referees.Their disputed calls helped Kuwait win the men’s tournament and Kazakhstan the women’s, qualifying them for the Olympics. In December, the International Handball Federation ordered replays of the qualifiers.The Asian federation has denied match fixing and has said it will punish countries taking part in the replays (Japan and South Korea). South Korea’s women’s team defeated Japan on Tuesday to advance to the Beijing Olympics.

headline: In Europe, Questions Over Continuing Write-Downs
text: FRANKFURT  When UBS disclosed in October that it had written down $3.6 billion in mortgage-backed securities, it was praised for biting the bullet.

headline: A Coffee Shop Closes, and There’ll Be Sad Songs Down at Mory’s
text: NEW HAVEN

headline: Sony Profit Increases 25 Percent
text: TOKYO  Sony said Thursday that its profit rose more than 25 percent in the final three months of 2007, helped by robust sales of televisions and computer games. But it said the strong yen and subprime problems would weigh on demand this year.

headline: And Blessed Are the Singing, Pole-Dancing Fetishists
text: Oh hear America singing, citizens of New York, as you never have heard it before. Hearken to your everyday sisters and brothers  the lost, the lonely, the fetishists, the freaks  as their voices swell and meld into one common chord of longing: to be seen, to be heard, to be (oh yes) famous.

headline: The Slow Life Picks Up Speed
text: “I HAVE a little spiel I like to give about thread,” Natalie Chanin said the other day. “The ladies laugh at me and call it my Oprah moment, but here’s how it goes: It’s called loving your thread, and it’s all about talking to the thread, coaxing it to take the path of least resistance. At the crux of it, that’s what Slow Design is all about.”

headline: Stopping iPhoto From Starting
text: Q. Every time I plug in my Sony digital camera to my Mac Powerbook, iPhoto automatically launches, even though I never use iPhoto for anything. I just want to download my images and edit them with Photoshop or view them with Preview. But every time I have to quit iPhoto. How can I fix this?

headline: A Long Ramble Along the Road to the Blues
text: The North Mississippi Allstars don’t believe in squandering words. Within the first five songs at the Highline Ballroom on Tuesday night, the band’s lead singer and guitarist, Luther Dickinson, managed to wring several different connotations out of the verb “shake.” It first appeared as a frisky command. (“Shake what your mama gave you.”) Then it propelled a carnal boast. (“We gonna shake ’em on down.”) Its next usage was more descriptive: “She’s shakin’ like a leaf/Tremblin’ on a tree.”

headline: Ronaldo Leads Manchester United
text: Cristiano Ronaldo scored two goals to lead Manchester United over visiting Portsmouth, 2-0, Wednesday and back into first place in the English Premier League. Manchester United (18-3-3) and Arsenal (17-1-6) each have 57 points; United leads on goal difference.

headline: Officer’s Slaying Leaves New Orleans Asking Why
text: NEW ORLEANS  On Monday morning, in a bleak shopping strip almost under the Pontchartrain Expressway, Bernel P. Johnson wrestled the gun away from a young police officer and shot her dead. When backup officers arrived, he handed them the weapon.

headline: Moynihan Backed Clinton; His Widow Backs Obama
text: Elizabeth B. Moynihan, the widow of Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York senator who, from a hayfield on his upstate farm, helped shepherd Hillary Rodham Clinton into his Senate seat, has endorsed Barack Obama for the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: America’s Riveting Democracy
text: BERLIN

headline: Two Hits Buoy Fox
text: Fox dominated the ratings on Tuesday, thanks to two popular shows, “American Idol” at 8 p.m. and “House” at 9. Those shows delivered 28.1 million and 22.5 million viewers, Nielsen estimated. A repeat of CBS’s “NCIS” at 8 attracted the night’s third-largest audience (11.7 million). CBS’s all-rerun lineup tied NBC for runner-up on the night, but NBC fared better among adults 18 to 49 with “The Biggest Loser” at 8 (8.3 million) followed by “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” at 10 (9.4 million). ABC finished fourth overall. On Monday President Bush’s final State of the Union address attracted the smallest audience of his two terms, 37.5 million viewers. That tally was 8 million fewer than a year ago, but 6 million more than President Clinton’s last State of the Union address in 2000. The speech was broadcast live at 9 p.m. on a total of nine network and cable channels.

headline: Afghanistan: Road Workers Beheaded
text: Four Afghan road construction workers were discovered beheaded in Kamdesh, in northeastern Nuristan Province, the provincial governor said. The Interior Ministry confirmed the beheadings and said the men were kidnapped last week and a ransom had been demanded. It blamed the Taliban. The army recently mounted an operation in the Kamdesh area and killed a number of Taliban fighters, including a commander, the governor said, and he suggested that the beheadings were an act of revenge.

headline: Assassins, Hot Cars and Post-Apocalyptic Struggle, With a Dash of HDTV
text: When I bought a big television 15 years ago, my wife at that time said it was like a billboard announcing that our lives revolved entirely around TV. With the advent of the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, which support high-definition TV, my television had become a billboard announcing that I could not afford a proper display for my video games.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. There are so many kinds of mosaic tile. How do I choose something interesting and tasteful?

headline: Nuclear Scientists
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fleeting or for Real?
text: Even late into the regular season, Eli Manning’s erratic play prompted questions about whether he could take himself  and the Giants  to the next level. His game improved dramatically in the playoffs, which makes us wonder: Is Manning’s recent performance what we should we expect from him on Sunday and in the future, or just sudden and short-lived?

headline: Needing a Hail Mary, Fans Find a Monastery
text: PHOENIX  There is no sauna, no heated pool, no chauffeur or sommelier. In fact, no alcohol is allowed on the premises, and guests share a bathroom with their next-door neighbor.

headline: Digital S.L.R.’s for the Beginner, With Ways to Reduce Shakes While Shaking Off the Dust
text: The Photo Marketing Association convention, which opens Thursday in Las Vegas, is the arena where camera-gear companies battle for market share and mind share. Some combatants have faded in the move from film to digital, but Nikon and Canon continue to duke it out with hardware that sets the tone for the show and the industry.

headline: Ohio: Rebuff for Man Called a Nazi Guard
text: A former autoworker from Cleveland who is accused of being a Nazi death camp guard lost another battle in his 30-year fight to maintain his American citizenship and residence. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit rejected a challenge from the man, John Demjanjuk, 87, above, to a final deportation order by the nation’s chief immigration judge. The order would send Mr. Demjanjuk to Germany, Poland or his native Ukraine. The government initially claimed Mr. Demjanjuk was the notoriously sadistic guard at the Treblinka camp known as Ivan the Terrible. Officials later concluded that he was not, but a judge ruled in 2002 that documents from World War II prove Mr. Demjanjuk was a Nazi guard.

headline: Credit Card Processor Sues Blackstone to Finish Buyout
text: Another broken Wall Street deal headed to court on Wednesday as Alliance Data Systems sued the Blackstone Group, seeking to force the private equity firm to complete its $6.4 billion buyout of the company.

headline: Big Vote Day Looms for Narrowed Field
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Rudolph W. Giuliani, the combative former Republican mayor of New York City, and John Edwards, the Democrat who ran for the White House as an anti-poverty populist, both dropped out of the presidential race on Wednesday, leaving a narrowed field hurtling toward what amounts to a national primary next week.

headline: A Form of Internet Piracy That Involves Actual (Virtual) Pirates
text: What do Henry Morgan and Blackbeard have in common with Luke Skywalker and Merlin? They have all captured the imagination of millions through tales of their daring deeds, and now they have all inspired online role-playing games.

headline: Electronic Arts Posts Loss but Record Revenue
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Electronic Arts swung to a loss Thursday because of restructuring charges and deferred revenue, but posted record revenue during the most brisk holiday season the video game industry has seen.

headline: Jury Shown Store Video in Death of 7-Year-Old
text: The jury in the trial of a Brooklyn man charged with killing his 7-year-old stepdaughter watched a surveillance video on Wednesday that prosecutors are hinting is crucial to their case.

headline: Absent With Leave: Missing the Big Game
text: CHANDLER, Ariz.  Jeremy Shockey left a voice-mail message for Mike Pope, the Giants’ tight ends coach, with about five minutes left in the National Football Conference championship game.

headline: After the Fed
text: Whether or not the Federal Reserve’s recent dramatic interest rate cuts are the right medicine for today’s stalling economy  and the jury is very much out on that  it is clear that the Fed has used up a big chunk of its recession-fighting ammunition in a very short span of time. In just over a week, it has slashed its benchmark interest rate by a total of 1.25 percentage points, to 3 percent. That doesn’t leave a lot of room to cut further without opening the door to a potentially nasty upsurge in prices, which are already rising at a worrisome rate, and a possible disorderly decline in the dollar.

headline: The Official Line vs. the Betting Line
text: They were not only close friends and founding fathers of the N.F.L., but Art Rooney and Tim Mara were also gamblers, proud ones. In 1936, Rooney, whose family still owns the Pittsburgh Steelers, famously turned two prescient days at the racetrack into $300,000. In 1925, Mara, a bookmaker in the days when that profession was not only legal but honorable, paid $500 for the New York Giants.

headline: Mcgahee Replaces Tomlinson
text: San Diego Chargers running back LaDainian Tomlinson withdrew from the Pro Bowl, paving the way for Baltimore Ravens running back Willis McGahee to make his first appearance in the game. McGahee earned a spot on the American Conference team because Tomlinson has a sprained knee.

headline: Tainted Drugs Tied to Maker of Abortion Pill
text: BEIJING  A huge state-owned Chinese pharmaceutical company that exports to dozens of countries, including the United States, is at the center of a nationwide drug scandal after nearly 200 Chinese cancer patients were paralyzed or otherwise harmed last summer by contaminated leukemia drugs.

headline: U.S. Accused of Overlooking Rights Violations
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration is giving lip service to promoting democracy by endorsing suspect elections in Kenya, Nigeria and Pakistan while allowing human rights violations in those countries to go unchecked, the advocacy group Human Rights Watch said Thursday.

headline: Lenovo Sells Phone Unit
text: The Lenovo Group, the personal computer maker, said Thursday that it planned to sell its slumping cellphone unit so that it could focus on its personal computer business.

headline: Rebate Psychology
text: Chicago

headline: A Warning on Insurers Frays Nerves
text: While the Federal Reserve tried to soothe Wall Street’s nerves on Wednesday, a hedge fund manager frayed them by warning that two pillars of the financial markets might crumble.

headline: Recent Moves by Guild Leaders Rattle Writers’ Talks
text: LOS ANGELES  Promising closed-door talks aimed at settling Hollywood’s three-month-old strike by movie and television writers have been jolted in the last few days by the actions of some prominent guild leaders.

headline: Miles to Go Before Martin Finishes Journey
text: Sages have said we must walk a mile in another person’s shoes before we can pass judgment. Unless the shoes belong to George Martin. Then you have to walk 1,600 miles.

headline: Beauty Blogs Come of Age: Swag, Please!
text: TWO years ago, when beauty bloggers called makeup companies to request free samples, many calls went unreturned.

headline: Bringing the Internet and Television a Step Closer Together
text: As the fusion of the Internet and television continues to evolve, new hardware has been popping up in the living room. With its circular design, Sony’s Vaio TP Home Theater PC stands out on a home entertainment shelf full of typical black and silver boxes  and brings a Blu-ray disc player, HDTV recorder and a full Windows Vista Home Premium system into the mix.

headline: Consumer Spending Falls Off
text: Consumer spending slowed in December and inflation continued to rise, the government said Thursday, leaving the Federal Reserve little leeway as it ponders policy decisions in the months ahead.

headline: City Catholic School League Makes National Impact
text: After several years of steady if unspectacular play, New York City’s Catholic High School Athletic Association Class AA boys basketball league has returned to prominence  as much for its talent as for its depth.

headline: Profit Up, Lazard Defies Investment Banking Trend
text: While other financial services companies are bleeding, Lazard, the investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein, stood out Wednesday by reporting a 43 percent jump in its fourth-quarter profits from the period a year ago.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, the On Religion column on Saturday, about “Lonely Man of Faith,” a film on Joseph Soloveitchik, the important 20th-century Orthodox rabbi, referred incorrectly to its success rate at film festivals. Although it was turned down by the New York Jewish Film Festival, it did indeed appear at Jewish film festivals elsewhere; it was not turned down by all major Jewish festivals.

headline: Fleecing the Sheep, Who Keep Coming Back for More
text: In 1917 the charlatan John R. Brinkley experienced what was truly a seminal moment. This so-called doctor, whose diploma had come from a medical school that was “vague, obliging and long defunct” and whose expertise was dubious at best (“if the white coat reassured people, the healing had begun”), was consulting with a 46-year-old Kansas farmer named Bill Stittsworth. “I’m all in,” Stittsworth said. “No pep. I’m a flat tire.”

headline: Corrections
text: A headline on Wednesday with an article about efforts to block Southern Methodist University from housing the George W. Bush Presidential Library misstated an action of the library’s opponents. As the article noted, Methodists opposed to the library are lobbying members of a regional church conference to vote against the library; the opponents did not force the conference to hold that vote.

headline: Power Failures Outrage South Africa
text: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  At first, the power blackouts seemed a mere nuisance, the electricity suddenly dead for two or three hours at a time, two or three times a day. Radio announcers jocularly advised listeners to make their morning toast by vigorously rubbing two pieces of bread together and wisecracked about amorous uses for the extra darkness.

headline: Office Tower to Rise in Harlem for Baseball TV Network
text: Major League Baseball plans to build a home on 125th Street, Harlem’s premier boulevard, for its cable network, which is scheduled to make its debut early next year with some 50 million subscribers, real estate and baseball executives said on Wednesday.

headline: One Town, 2 Campaigns for President
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y.

headline: Correction
text: Editors' Note

headline: Peter Staudhammer, Who Designed NASA Instruments, Dies at 73
text: Peter Staudhammer, a wide-ranging aerospace engineer and executive who helped design instruments and engines used by NASA in landings on Mars and the Moon, died on Jan. 14 at his home in La Quinta, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Desert Attractions
text: PHOENIX -- While you wouldn't exactly label metropolitan Phoenix as culture-drenched, there is at least a healthy handful of intriguing local attractions to fit into your itinerary if you're out for the Super Bowl. Start with the Heard Museum on North Central Avenue, 10 minutes north of downtown Phoenix. Arguably the nation's finest showcase of Native American culture, the Heard dishes out historical information and artistic works by Southwestern tribes such as the Apache, Hopi, Navajo and Zuni. Not to be missed are the lodging exhibits, which include a Navajo Hogan and an Apache wickiup. www.heard.org, 602-252-8848; admission, $10; open daily, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.

headline: High-Energy Cartoons, Drawn in Jazz
text: David King, the drummer of the trio Happy Apple, is a heavy-gauge clown, honest, graceful and intuitive. He looks as if he’s constantly subverting his own nature around the drums. His body language says he’s going to cream them, really boss them around, but at the last instant he hesitates, hitting lightly or leaving a blank.

headline: Lelouch to Open Festival
text: The United States premiere of “Roman de Gare,” directed by Claude Lelouch (“A Man and a Woman”) and starring Dominique Pinon and Fanny Ardant, right, will open the 13th Rendezvous With French Cinema on Feb. 29 at the Walter Reade Theater. The movie, about a best-selling novelist whose plots bear similarities to the acts of a serial killer, will be one of 15 films shown at the Walter Reade and the IFC Center in Manhattan through March 9.

headline: Lawmaker Demands That Ashcroft Testify
text: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee demanded that former Attorney General John Ashcroft testify about his appointment to oversee a Justice Department corporate settlement. The chairman, Representative John Conyers Jr., a Michigan Democrat, said Mr. Ashcroft had not returned calls inviting him to appear on Feb. 26 before a subcommittee that is reviewing the hiring of former government officials as corporate monitors. Mr. Ashcroft, who runs a consulting firm in Washington, is supervising a settlement between the government and Zimmer Holdings Inc., the world’s biggest maker of artificial hips and knees. For 18 months’ work, the company says it will pay him $28 million to $52 million.

headline: Iraqi Troops Mass for Operation in Mosul
text: BAGHDAD  The unsettled situation in northern Iraq continued Wednesday as Iraqi troops massed in Mosul to fight Sunni Arab extremists, and a Turkmen political group in Kirkuk threatened to resort to arms in response to the kidnapping and killing of Turkmens by extremists.

headline: In North Dakota Forget Money. Politics Is Different.
text: BISMARCK, N.D.  Consider the tactic one local Democratic Party leader in this state resorted to last summer to raise money. He chained hot pink plywood elephants, 2-and-a-half feet tall and 2-and-a-half feet wide, to trees in the yards of known Democrats, then offered to remove the Republican beasts in exchange for $25 donations.

headline: Rams Hire Saunders
text: The St. Louis Rams signed Al Saunders to a three-year contract as offensive coordinator, another step in an overhaul of the coaching staff after a three-win season. Saunders was fired by the Washington Redskins last Saturday after two seasons in the same job.

headline: Battle Concussions Tied to Stress Disorder
text: About one in six combat troops returning from Iraq have suffered at least one concussion in the war, injuries that, while temporary, could heighten their risk of developing post-traumatic stress disorder, researchers are reporting.

headline: Judge in Courthouse Shooting Case Steps Down
text: ATLANTA  The judge presiding over the quadruple-murder trial in the case of the 2005 shooting at the Fulton County Courthouse removed himself from the case on Wednesday after an article in The New Yorker quoted him as saying of the defendant, Brian Nichols, that “everyone in the world knows he did it.”

headline: Imus Marches On
text: Viewers in Washington, Boston, Chicago and San Francisco, among other big cities, moved a step closer on Wednesday to watching the simulcast of the Don Imus morning radio show on RFD-TV, a cable channel. Patrick Gottsch, the founder and president of RFD, which primarily chronicles life in rural America, said that he had signed an affiliation agreement with Comcast. With the agreement RFD-TV is authorized to begin negotiations with individual Comcast cable systems. Comcast is available in more than 24 million households. While RFD-TV is available in 30 million homes, many are in towns and small cities outside the Northeast; the exception are those that receive the channel via satellite. Jenni Moyer, a Comcast spokeswoman, confirmed the deal. In signing Mr. Imus last year after his firing by CBS Radio and MSNBC over a racial remark, Mr. Gottsch was hoping that Mr. Imus would become a lure for big-city cable operators. RFD is seeking a similar agreement with Time Warner Cable, which has systems in New York City and Los Angeles.

headline: Bank Defies French Elite and Keeps Chief, for Now
text: PARIS The board of Société Générale gathered Wednesday in a conference room on the 35th floor of the bank’s headquarters outside Paris. The chairman of the nominating committee reminded them that the resignation of the chairman and chief executive, Daniel Bouton, was still on the table.

headline: Suddenly, Seton Hall Looks Like a Surging Team
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Seton Hall was playing a dangerous team, a resurgent Rutgers group that was coming off back-to-back victories against ranked opponents. But the Scarlet Knights ran into a hotter team Wednesday night at the Louis Brown Athletic Center.

headline: A Landscape in Winter, Dying Heroically
text: HUMMELO, The Netherlands

headline: Tip of the Week: Shortcuts for Microsoft Word
text: Microsoft Word includes keyboard shortcuts for quickly inserting the current date and time into your documents and memos. On most Windows versions of Word, press Alt+Shift+D to automatically add the date into the text of your document, or Alt+Shift+T to add the time. (On the Mac edition of Word, press Shift+Control+D or Shift+Control+T to get the same results.)

headline: Undersized Patriots Are Shedding Their Anonymity
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Another game is approaching, so the familiar fear is due to arrive in Dante Scarnecchia’s head any day. For years, he has had it just before every game, especially the 2004 Super Bowl against the Carolina Panthers, when three of his opening-day starters were on injured reserve.

headline: Magic Johnson Sees the Knicks in the Playoffs
text: SALT LAKE CITY  The Knicks went 0 for California, but Coach Isiah Thomas left the state with some nice parting gifts  a warm hug and a big endorsement, both from his longtime friend Magic Johnson.

headline: Scaffold Falls, Killing Worker in Brooklyn
text: A construction worker fell 12 stories to his death in Brooklyn on Wednesday when the scaffold he was standing on collapsed, apparently because of high winds, according to city officials and witnesses.

headline: Managers Proceed With Shuttle Mission Plans
text: WASHINGTON  Pending resolution of a potential radiator hose problem, the space shuttle Atlantis is scheduled for launching on Feb. 7 on a twice-delayed mission to the International Space Station, NASA managers said Wednesday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the difficulties facing the Federal Reserve misstated the federal funds rate after the Fed’s policy-making committee made a quarter-point cut in December. It was 4.25 percent, not 3.5 percent. (The Fed’s three-quarter-point cut last week reduced the rate to 3.5 percent.)

headline: European Election Monitors May Boycott Russia Vote
text: MOSCOW  European election observers warned Wednesday that they might once again refuse to take part in a Russian election, saying the government was still imposing unacceptable restrictions on their work.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: An article in the Itineraries section of Business Day on Tuesday reported on the increasing popularity of blogs written by or aimed at business travelers. The article reported that a directory of travel blogs that is known as BoardingArea.com, started by Randy Petersen, founder of the online forum FlyerTalk, would feature nine such blogs, including one by Joe Sharkey, who also writes the weekly business travel column On the Road for The New York Times. The article referred imprecisely to the terms of Mr. Sharkey’s participation. Mr. Petersen has offered a small payment to reprint Mr. Sharkey’s blog. While some of the blogs will seek advertising, referred to in the article as “sponsorships,” the one Mr. Sharkey writes is not among them, and he should have been asked what its relationship with BoardingArea.com was before the article was published.

headline: For Knicks, New City, Same Desultory Result
text: SALT LAKE CITY  As the final second ticked off the clock late Wednesday night, Mardy Collins fired the ball 60 feet toward the far basket. The buzzer sounded, the ball clanged and the Knicks  drained, ill and foul-tempered  dragged themselves off the court and to the next city.

headline: This Year’s Super Bowl Ads to Be Gentle and Sweet
text: NO matter how rough the action gets on the field on Sunday, when the New England Patriots meet the New York Giants in Super Bowl XLII, the advertisers will be playing nice.

headline: Sprawling, Diverse State Poses Special Challenge for Candidates
text: REDLANDS, Calif.  The most trenchant symbol of the California presidential primary can be found on an isolated stretch of Interstate 15, smack in the middle of the Mojave Desert. There, affixed to an old trailer, is possibly the largest candidate billboard in the entire state, and it is for the Republican fringe candidate, Ron Paul.

headline: Better Pay for Federal Judges
text: The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to vote today on a proposed pay raise for federal judges  an issue of considerable importance to the quality and independence of the judiciary.

headline: Formatting Lost in the Mail
text: Q. When I format my e-mail with italic, underscore or boldface, my recipient can’t see it. I have Microsoft Outlook set to compose in HTML, so why can’t my recipient see the message as I sent it?

headline: 2 Accused of Keeping Girl, 13, as Prostitute
text: A police detective and his female companion kidnapped a 13-year-old runaway girl and forced her into prostitution with 20 men at private parties, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Myanmar: ‘Prepare for the Worst,’ Suu Kyi Advises
text: The pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was allowed a rare respite from house arrest to meet with members of her party, the National League for Democracy. A party spokesman reported that she had criticized the series of meetings she has held since October with Aung Kyi, a senior junta official  they met for the fifth time after her meeting with party colleagues  for failing to set a deadline to achieve any real political change. She also cautioned the nation to “hope for the best but prepare for the worst,” the spokesman said.

headline: No Tomorrow? 95 Years of Yesterdays
text: The singer Tony Martin may be his generation’s Last Man Standing. A belting crooner of the old school whose 1949 hit, “There’s No Tomorrow,” adapted from “O Sole Mio,” predated “It’s Now or Never,” Elvis Presley’s version of the same Italian melody (with different lyrics) by 11 years, he turned 95 last December.

headline: Like Giuliani, New York G.O.P. Rushes to McCain
text: New York’s Republican establishment rushed to embrace Senator John McCain on Wednesday, with party leaders expressing confidence that his appeal to independents could help fend off a Democratic sweep that might cost them the State Senate in November.

headline: Israeli Court Rejects Appeal to Ease Restrictions on Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected an appeal to block Israel from further reducing supplies of fuel and electricity to the Gaza Strip.

headline: Macao: Ex-Minister Gets 27 Years for Bribery
text: Ao Man-long, the former transport and public works minister, became Macao’s highest-level official ever convicted of corruption and was sentenced to 27 years in prison. He was found guilty of takings tens of millions of dollars in kickbacks from developers in the casino resort construction boom that has allowed the former Portuguese colony, now a special administrative region of China, to overtake Las Vegas in gambling revenues.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,925 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

headline: Four’s a Crowd
text: DENVER

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about a fellowship program intended to help art museum curators deal better with the business aspects of their jobs misstated part of the name of the institution where Eleanor Jones Harvey, who took part in the program, is chief curator. It is the Smithsonian American Art Museum, not Gallery.

headline: Stretching the Truth Just Became Easier (and Cheaper)
text: WHEN Carlo Baldassi came home from vacation and looked at a picture he took of his girlfriend on the Charles Bridge in Prague, he was torn. She looked beautiful, but the proportions of the picture were all wrong. It seemed tight and constrained, and it would not fill his widescreen monitor.

headline: Israeli Inquiry Finds ‘Grave Failings’ in ’06 War
text: JERUSALEM  In a widely anticipated judgment, a formal inquiry released Wednesday found “grave failings” among Israel’s political and military leaders in the 2006 Lebanon war, especially in their failure to decide what kind of war to fight.

headline: Bloomberg’s Poverty Challenge
text: To the Editor:

headline: Experiments in Language and Texture
text: Elliott Carter has touched on just about every musical format in his long and prolific career, but chamber music is where he has always seemed the most comfortable, or at least the most inclined to experiment with language and texture. The Juilliard School has taken that point to heart in this year’s weeklong Focus! festival, which celebrates Mr. Carter’s music. The first and last concerts offer orchestral works; the rest cut a wide swath through his chamber music, old and new.

headline: The Chelsea Women’s Team Signs Its First American Player
text: Chelsea has signed its first American soccer player. Not Landon Donovan, not Michael Bradley and not Jozy Altidore, but Lorrie Fair.

headline: Will Democrats Learn From History?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Economists Dissect the ‘Yuck’ Factor
text: WASHINGTON  You can kill a horse to make pet food in California, but not to feed a person. You can hoist a woman over your shoulder while running a 253-meter obstacle course in the Wife-Carrying World Championship in Finland, but you can’t hold a dwarf-tossing contest in France. You can donate a kidney to prevent a death and be hailed as a hero, but if you take any money for your life-saving offer in the United States, you’ll be jailed.

headline: Quarter’s Weak Growth Adds to Signs of Slowdown
text: The United States economy expanded by a weak 0.6 percent annual rate during the last three months of 2007, the government reported Wednesday, offering the latest indication that the economy is already suffering from a substantial slowdown, and perhaps a recession.

headline: The Online Peanut Gallery Weighs in, and South Plays Up
text: Apart from the fun of watching the play during matches broadcast live over the Internet at www.bridgebase.com, it is also interesting to read the remarks by commentators. The diagramed deal occurred on Dec. 22 in the final of the French trial. What would you say about South’s one-spade overcall?

headline: New Look Planned for Hermitage
text: The Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas, a winner of the Pritzker Prize for architecture, has been chosen to redesign the art displays in the State Hermitage Museum, right, in St. Petersburg, Russia, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Koolhaas and the museum will begin the six-year project by establishing a master plan for a new way of displaying about three million treasures in the museum’s roughly 2,000 rooms. He will also alter the displays in the Islamic and Chinese rooms and transform a section of the imperial general staff building into a space for contemporary art.

headline: The Newly Uptight
text: STEPHANIE LaCAVA has glimpsed fashion’s future, and she likes what she sees. “I’ve really been into this kind of sculptured feminine silhouette,” said Ms. LaCava, 24, a features associate at Vogue. To judge by the outfit she wore at the Winter Antiques Show in Manhattan last week  a sedate cream-colored sheath that Letitia Baldrige would have admired  Ms. LaCava has embraced the fashions of the Kennedy years without irony.

headline: A Lawyer Who Hears New Ways to Argue
text: There is really no good reason for “Eli Stone” to be quite as much fun as it is, given that the premise seems spraywashed with earnestness and spun to alienate the atheistic and the greedy. A new comic drama beginning Thursday on ABC, it revolves around a Stanford-trained lawyer who undergoes a moral conversion in the midst of a career spent ensuring that litigious average Joes, bitten by evil corporate carnivores, never walk off with more than the cost of a Happy Meal. The anti-John Edwards, Eli has contentedly sequestered himself in one of the two Americas  specifically, a vast, honey-colored apartment in downturn-resistant San Francisco  until the Armani suits start to feel itchy.

headline: No Extradition for Dog
text: A three-judge panel in Mexico has ruled unanimously that Duane Chapman, known as Dog, right, who starred on the A&E television show “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” cannot be extradited to that country to face criminal charges for seizing Andrew Luster, heir to the Max Factor cosmetics fortune, on a street in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Chapman seized Mr. Luster in order to return him to the United States to serve a 124-year jail sentence for drugging and raping three women.

headline: Ahmadinejad Sees Nuclear Energy in Iran by 2009
text: TEHRAN  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran said Wednesday that his country would produce nuclear energy by next year and condemned Israel as a “filthy entity” that would soon collapse.

headline: Senate Democrats Short of Votes for Stimulus Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Backed solidly by the Bush administration, Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked a $157 billion economic stimulus package championed by Senate Democrats, who said they would have no choice but to quickly adopt a cheaper, more streamlined plan approved earlier this week by the House.

headline: Gestures on Darfur: The World Must Do Better
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britain: Victim Can Sue ‘Lotto Rapist’
text: A 78-year-old woman who was sexually assaulted in 1988 by Iorworth Hoare, a rapist who went on to win $14 million in the national lottery in 2004, is entitled to seek a share of his fortune, Britain’s highest court ruled. Courts had previously held that a claim for compensation in an assault case must be made within six years of the attack. Mr. Hoare, 53, spent 16 years in prison before buying the winning lottery ticket while on a day pass from prison. He was released in 2005 is said to live in a $1.4 million house near Newcastle.

headline: 2 Communication Cables in the Mediterranean Are Cut
text: NEW DELHI  Two undersea telecommunication cables were cut on Tuesday evening, knocking out Internet access to much of Egypt, disrupting the world’s back office in India and slowing down service for some Verizon customers.

headline: Republicans Battle for Votes and Money in California
text: LOS ANGELES  Competition between Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney for California’s vast array of Republican delegates heated up on Thursday, with Mr. McCain receiving a major endorsement and Mr. Romney preparing to broadcast television advertisements in California and several other February 5 states.

headline: New York Leads the Field in a High School Science Competition
text: Stuyvesant High School led the nation’s schools in finalists in the latest round of the Intel Science Talent Search, the country’s most celebrated high school science competition. The 40 finalists were announced on Wednesday by competition officials.

headline: A Disappointing Debut
text: About the best we can say about Attorney General Michael Mukasey’s testimony Wednesday in the Senate is that he was no Alberto Gonzales, with the frequent memory lapses and possibly intentional misstatements. But that is a very low bar. On torture, domestic spying and other important matters, Mr. Mukasey parroted the Bush administration’s deplorable line. He was particularly disappointing in his see-no-evil approach to the misconduct at the Justice Department before he arrived.

headline: What Romney Said About Troop Pullout
text: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Senator John McCain of Arizona, who makes “straight talk” something of a political brand, likes to say he always tells voters the truth.

headline: Santana’s Rocky Finish Raises a Few Concerns
text: The Mets began contract negotiations Wednesday with the agent for the star left-hander Johan Santana, and very soon they expect to shift their focus from one astronomical figure (his salary) to another (his strikeout totals, victories, innings pitched  take your pick).

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about conservation planning in a warming world misstated the position of Healy Hamilton, who voiced concern about the future of protected areas. She is the director of the Center for Biodiversity Research and Information at the California Academy of Sciences; she is not the overall director of the academy.

headline: Home Depot Plans Layoffs at Headquarters
text: Home Depot, battered by a downturn in the housing market, is laying off 500 workers at its headquarters in Atlanta, or about 10 percent of its work force there, the company said.

headline: Long Island Rail Road From Penn Station to Ronkonkoma, N.Y.
text: Every weekday in January, Billie Cohen is documenting a different commute for NYTimes.com/realestate. Here is a listing of all the articles in the Next Stop series.

headline: This Is a Test: Do We Know Anything About Football?
text: Fellow football fans, let us acknowledge a truth: Much of the game is invisible and unknown to us in a way that our other sports passions are not. How did our left offensive guard do? You know, the fat guy from Nebraska? No idea, unless he happened to pancake the middle linebacker a couple of times or draw serial flags for holding. That blown coverage coverage across the middle? Just for fun, let's put that one on the nickel back lined up across from the slot. But really, we don't know and we're not meant to. Even the coach will say he has to check the film.

headline: For a Woman Who Has Trouble Getting Around, Help Getting By
text: Chaya Tolwinski said she knew that Yehuda Tolwinski was the man for her on their second date.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Text of Federal Reserve Statement
text: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve on Wednesday after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to lower interest rates by half a percentage point:

headline: Staying a Step Ahead of Aging
text: YOU know what is supposed to happen when you grow old. You will slow down, you will grow weak, your steps will become short and mincing, and you will lose your sense of balance. That’s what aging researchers consistently find, and it’s no surprise to most of us.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The About New York column in some editions on Jan. 5, about a legal and public relations fight over allegations of short-selling between Institutional Credit Partners, a private investment bank with offices in Manhattan, and Fairfax Financial Holdings, a Canadian insurance company, referred imprecisely to the bank’s charges against Fairfax. It claims that Fairfax operatives have a history of stealing garbage  which prompted bank executives to take “emergency measures” for protection  but it does not accuse Fairfax operatives of stealing garbage in this particular dispute.

headline: A Site to Bring Parents Up to Speed on Video Games
text: It often seems that being clueless about video games goes hand in hand with being a parent. But a new site called WhatTheyPlay.com aims to give parents an inside scoop by going beyond the ratings and offering evaluations written by knowledgeable gamers  many of them parents.

headline: The Final Two in a Multifront Battle
text: Even before Wednesday morning, the candidates had been befuddled by the sheer strategic challenge presented by Feb. 5. As if things were not complicated enough, John Edwards dropped out of the race, forcing the other campaigns to return to the drawing boards.

headline: Audit Raises Concerns About Fraud at Boat Basin
text: An audit released on Wednesday by the city comptroller found widespread financial irregularities with record-keeping at the 79th Street Boat Basin in Manhattan, raising concerns about the possibility of fraud.

headline: The New Race: Four Candidates, 24 States and One Hectic Week
text: MIAMI  For most of the year, the race for president has been a muddle for both parties: An amorphous cast of candidates seeking to distinguish themselves and win attention from voters, donors and the news media.

headline: Vespers Still Startling After All These Years
text: It says something for Monteverdi’s powerful presence that 400 years of shifting musical standards have not softened his voice. How startling, for example, his galloping brass writing must have sounded to contemporary ears: an early 17th-century audience innocent of Mozart’s diminished seventh chords, Wagner’s wandering key changes or Schoenberg’s serialist combinations.

headline: End Tax Deal for Garden, Council Urges
text: Madison Square Garden and its chairman, James L. Dolan, may have run out of friends at City Hall. The City Council voted 40 to 3 on Wednesday in favor of ending the arena’s unusual tax deal with the city, which for 25 years has exempted the Garden from property taxes.

headline: Zhang Hanzhi, Mao’s Tutor, Is Dead at 72
text: SHANGHAI  Zhang Hanzhi, a former Chinese diplomat who once served as Mao’s English tutor and who also interpreted for President Nixon during his historic trip to China in 1972, died on Saturday. She was 72.

headline: N.C.A.A. to Ease Limits on Athletes’ Expenses
text: INDIANAPOLIS (AP)  The N.C.A.A. said it planned to ease restrictions on educational expenses for current student-athletes and set aside $10 million to reimburse former athletes as part of a tentative class-action lawsuit settlement.

headline: Pictures Reveal Mercury’s Tumultuous Past
text: WASHINGTON  The Messenger spacecraft that zipped past Mercury two weeks ago found more evidence of the innermost planet’s turbulent past, including ridges that run hundreds of miles and a unique feature made up of more than 100 troughs radiating in all directions, scientists said Wednesday.

headline: Ryder Cup Format Changed
text: The United States captain Paul Azinger is switching the Ryder Cup format with hopes of giving his team an edge, going back to alternate shot in the opening matches for the first time since 1999. The Ryder Cup will be played Sept. 19-21 at Valhalla Golf Club in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Bengals Sign Another Palmer
text: Jordan Palmer signed a two-year deal with the Cincinnati Bengals on Wednesday that will give him a chance to play behind his brother, quarterback Carson Palmer, who was the No. 1 pick in the 2003 draft. Jordan Palmer, who is five years younger, set school records at Texas-El Paso by throwing for 11,084 yards and 88 touchdowns. Washington drafted him in the sixth round last year, but he was waived Sept. 1.

headline: Hoosiers Are Grateful for a Star Who Stayed
text: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. (AP)  Eric Gordon makes every move look naturally smooth  the slick drives to the basket, the whip passes to teammates, the poke-away steals, even his long 3-pointers.

headline: Fed Cuts Key Rate as Stimulus Plan Advances
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates on Wednesday for the second time in eight days, meeting Wall Street hopes for cheaper money. At the same time, the Senate pushed ahead on a $161 billion plan to prop up Main Street with tax rebates and temporary tax cuts.

headline: Kovalchuk Hurt on Ruutu Hit

The play took place in the second period of a 4-1 Thrashers victory in Atlanta. Here are details from the Atlanta Constitution’s account of the game, which describes the play as a knee-on-knee hit. The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette described the game this way and said that Ruutu “checked Kovalchuk into the boards in front of the Atlanta bench.” We’ll post video as soon as it becomes available. … And here it is:

headline: The Aftermath of Violence in Limuru, Kenya
text: After a second Kenyan opposition lawmaker was shot dead on Thursday, riots exploded in opposition strongholds, putting the country increasingly on edge. In Limuru, 30 miles north of Nairobi, both ethnic Luos and Kikuyus coped with the aftermath of the continuing violence.

headline: Britain’s Friends Provident Announces Asset Disposals
text: British insurer Friends Provident on Thursday said it would dispose of its controlling stake in F&C Asset Management, the U.K.-listed fund manager, and pull out of its other wealth management businesses as part of a restructuring that would see the life assurer cut costs and rebase its dividend.

headline: Britain’s Kesa Agrees to Sell French Chain to Consortium
text: Kesa Electricals, which owns Comet in Britain, is selling its its French furniture and electricals business BUT for 550 million euros ($814.4 million) to Decomeubles Partners, a company backed by a consortium made up of Colony Capital, Goldman Sachs and Merchant Equity Partners.

headline: Marsh Chooses a Semi-Outsider to Be Its Chief

headline: Buyout Shops Said to Consider Deal for Dulles Rail Line

headline: Deutsche Bank Reaps More of China’s Harvest

headline: The Weak Dollar Isn’t All Bad News
text: It is nearly impossible to go a day without hearing about the dismal state of our economy. And small businesses have been particularly hard hit in recent years. According to one economist I spoke to this week, the housing meltdown has trickled into so many crevices of small business that it will take quite a long time for the overall performance of small business to improve even if there are positive signs in areas that have nothing to do with housing.

headline: Polar Bears and Seer Suckers
text: A new contrarian report on polar bears and global warming in the Arctic has been released by the minority members of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works. As you’d expect, it’s a selective hodgepodge of science and politics. There are useful summaries and links of research challenging some of the media hype about the Arctic, but some of the rhetoric gets in the way of the facts.

headline: Spectrum Auction: C Block Hits Reserve Price
text: A bid of $4.7 billion this morning for the most valuable group of wireless licenses in the Federal Communications Commission auction for 700Mhz spectrum pushed the price over the minimum price the government set. That means that the government is likely to receive over $12 billion for the block of spectrum that is being abandoned next year as television broadcasters move permanently to new digital frequencies. The government has said it hoped to earn at least $10 billion from the auction.

headline: Jimmy Carter and the New York Democrats
text: The modern presidential primary system began in 1976, when for the first time delegate candidates in New York were entitled to list on the ballots the presidential candidate they supported under their names. Previously, voters had to discern on their own which delegates favored which candidates, leaving party bosses with considerable control. “This simple reform has altered the New York primary on Tuesday from an Easter egg hunt into a relatively rational political process,” a Times editorial declared on April 4, 1976.

headline: A Small Turnout at ‘Yoga for Hillary’
text: Journalists easily outnumbered the participants in a “Yoga for Hillary” fund-raiser on Wednesday night in Times Square. A German television cameraman, a Canadian radio reporter, a New York Times photographer and this City Room reporter crowded into the Champions Dance Studio, at 257 West 39th Street, to document three students doing downward-facing dog and warrior poses. The yoga instructor, Brian Williams, who collected $10 from each participant, said he had heard that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton‘s campaign “has yoga classes for her staff.” He cautioned that yoga — sometimes a favorite activity in Times Square — is not particularly partisan. “I know a lot of people that do yoga who are conservative Republicans,” he said. Namaste.

headline: Fox’s Reality Squirmfests Continue to Deliver
text: The return of “Lost” — albeit a two-hour repeat of the last season finale — buoyed ABC’s ratings on a night otherwise dominated by Fox’s “American Idol” and “Moment of Truth.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two Fox programs delivered the night’s largest audiences by far, 25.3 million viewers at 8 p.m. for “American Idol” followed by 17.9 million for “The Moment of Truth” at 9 p.m.

headline: Kate the Great
text: Steve correctly points out that all through “The Moviegoer,” Percy makes brief allusions to crazy or eccentric or just plain bad-acting women. But the truth is that especially in Percy’s part of the world, those sorts of women do waft in and out of casual conversation in just such a way. It’s another spot-on detail he gets exactly right. In my youth, women were forever collecting the equivalent of iron deer, or auditioning and being discovered and going off to Biloxi or maybe even New York or Busch Gardens. They certainly did — and do — a fair share of “going off to Natchez,” of checking in and out of nuthouses, and all such activities were usually reported or repeated at the dinner table. Percy and his brothers believed that their own mother’s accident was likely no such thing, that, despite the fact that youngest brother Phin was in the car with her, she drove off the road intentionally. I’m sure that whispered assumption was a brief aside at many a Delta dinner table.

headline: How Not to Beat a Ticket
