headline: Nakamura Wins Gibtelecom Masters
The Day After
text: We’re at that stage of a campaign now where once serious contenders for the nominations of their parties are forced to cancel events and huddle with their families, to make those difficult calls to friends and supporters who already knew it was coming, to direct their own final scenes on the national stage. It is, in a sense, like planning your own funeral, and I’m sure it feels that way, or at least for a while. I can remember sitting with Bill Bradley in his bare campaign office just after his withdrawal speech in 2000. Everyone was already gone except for a few loyal staff members and the last two Secret Service agents guarding the door. All the noise from all the rallies had subsided, and all that remained were a few empty cubicles and the occasional unanswered phone. I will never forget how one of the agents, checking his watch, offered the candidate a ride home before the final shift came to an end. It’s not just the candidate, though, who suffers the trauma. For all the people who work on a campaign, who share cramped apartments with other true believers and keep most of their belongings in a car, the end really does feel like The End. I stood in the Ohio headquarters of America Coming Together, the massive Democratic voter turnout operation, as John Kerry and John Edwards gave their concession speech the day after the 2004 election. A smart young organizer was weeping on her boss’s shoulder. I knew that if she lived to be 90, no matter what else she did or how successfully, the memory of that moment would probably still feel like a kick in the gut.

headline: Is Connecticut Becoming a Battleground?
text: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have both announced that they will campaign in Connecticut on Monday, signaling that the state might be suddenly shaping up as a critical battleground among the 22 states holding their Democratic presidential primaries on Super Tuesday. Connecticut is a relatively small state, offering only 60 delegates out of 4,050 — but its Democrats have proved to be a volatile group.

headline: Schwarzenegger Endorses McCain
text: LOS ANGELES—Senator John McCain picked up the potent endorsement of Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger of California today as Mr. McCain and his Republican rival Mitt Romney battled across the daunting political landscape of the nation’s largest state.

headline: So Exotic, These New York Republicans
text: Republicans in New York City, outnumbered 5 to 1 by Democrats, are used to being a local curiosity. But with the world’s attention focused on the presidential primary, they have now become a global curiosity, fielding media requests from Japan, Germany, Sweden, and even letting humble local City Room observe them.When about a dozen members of the governing board of New York City’s Young Republican Club gathered on Wednesday night to eat dinner and watch the presidential debate on CNN, one member ducked out for an interview with the BBC.

headline: The Darfur Contagion Spreads
text: I just had an email from Chad that the U.N. is today evacuating Guereda, a major town in eastern Chad that has been a base for helping Darfuri refugees. Frankly, this will mean that more Darfuri refugees will die, but the U.N. has to protect its own people as well. It’s an agonizing position for aid organizations to face when their own staff are attacked.

headline: City Room: The Race in the New York Region
text: Today’s Journal Entries: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s national town hall will be televised on The Hallmark Channel. …The battle for Connecticut is on, as Mrs. Clinton and Barack Obama plan visits there the day before Super Tuesday. …Four John Edwards delegates in Manhattan have switched their support to Mr. Obama. …David Dinkins, the former New York mayor, explains his support for Mrs. Clinton: “She came into the Senate with the perspective that she was one of 100 senators and she did everything but fetch coffee for the Republican senators. She did the hard work and learned how to do the job well.” …Bill Bradley speaks to the “Obama generation” at Rutgers …Outnumbered urban Republicans are much in demand from the global news media. …The McCain and Romney campaigns duel for support from New Jersey Republican leaders … A Wall Street titan is now backing McCain. … New York City election officials, bracing for heavy turnout, roll out the old mechanical lever machines. …New York’s diverse ethnic press — hundreds of publications, dozens of nationalities — is covering the race with gusto. …The two Democrats have taken their campaigns upstate to Kemp country. …Back in Manhattan “Yoga for Hillary” hasn’t quite caught on.

headline: City Election Officials Gear Up for Heavy Turnout
text: If all goes as planned, more than 30,000 poll workers will help citizens use 6,293 voting machines at 1,363 polling places across New York City on Tuesday, as voters go to the polls for the Democratic and Republican presidential primaries. The machinery of democracy is in full gear, even though New York State is expected to replace the machines by next year, to comply belatedly with the Help America Vote Act of 2002, which was intended to prevent a recurrence of the Florida recount debacle of 2000.

headline: Panel Passes Congestion Pricing Plan
text: A plan to thin Manhattan’s perpetual throngs of traffic by charging fees to drivers and increasing prices for on-street parking was approved by a 13-2 vote on Thursday afternoon by a state commission appointed to review different proposals. The plan to decrease traffic [pdf] in much of Manhattan, first proposed in a slightly different form by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg last April, would charge drivers $8 to go below 60th Street from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. The commission, the Traffic Congestion Mitigation Commission, also recommended imposing a $1 surcharge for taxi trips starting or ending in the area and increased parking rates below 60th Street.

headline: Now Screening | Band of Outsiders
text: Welcome to fashion week… almost. As we speak, there’s a presentation underway for Band of Outsiders, the small label known for its preppy basics like skinny ties, button downs and a women’s collection called Boy. Our friends at Refinery 29 posted a video today with behind-the-scenes footage of the preparations for tonight’s event. In the episode, we follow Scott Sternberg, the designer, through the casting process. He calls the plaid-infused collection, “a little romantic, a little older.” (He also mentions that he’s really vibing on ecotones right now.) See for yourself.

headline: A Hallmark Moment?
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s “national town hall” on Monday evening will be broadcast live on the Hallmark Channel, the cable television network that is best known for sentimental tearjerkers, didactic after-school specials and adaptations of well-loved serial juvenile fiction. The Clinton campaign disclosed this unusual fact in a conference call with reporters this afternoon.

headline: A Look at the Numbers
text: So far, the 2008 primaries and caucuses have been anything but predictable — comebacks, fallbacks, not to mention surprised pollsters. But a closer look reveals some common themes that have emerged, despite a still-forming consensus about nominees.

headline: Jobs and Monster
text: Identifying turning points — the points at which the economy goes from expansion to recession or vice versa — is hard, because the official data tend to lag well behind. So we look for scraps of evidence from the private sector. One of those scraps, the employment estimate from ADP (which handles payrolls for many companies, so that it can produce its own employment estimates), is actually looking pretty good for January. But via knzn, the Monster employment index, produced by the online job-listing company, looks terrible.

headline: Q & A: Knight Frank’s Research Guru Looks Into the Crystal Ball
text: So where are the next opportunities for a big property run-up? Liam Bailey, head of residential research for Knight Frank, the property firm, believes Asia, Brazil, Romania, inland Bulgaria and parts of western Germany may be poised for growth, in sharp contrast to most markets.

headline: Bill Bradley and the ‘Obama Generation’
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — Though most of the more than 100 students at a Barack Obama rally at Rutgers University on Thursday afternoon were not yet teenagers when the event’s keynote speaker, Bill Bradley, was a presidential candidate, they still gave the former senator two standing ovations.
